title: Ex-Champions Seles and Agassi Looking Back to the Future
description: Been there, done that, won that. And there's no time like the present to do it again.

title: George A. Butler, 69, Former President of Corestates Financial
description: George A. Butler, a retired president of the Corestates Financial Corporation, died Aug. 22 at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. He was 69 and lived in Blue Bell, Pa.

title: For an Avant-Garde Center, An End and a Beginning
description: Martha Wilson was sitting in her sister's kitchen in Olympia, Wash., two summers ago when she experienced an epiphany. That is how Ms. Wilson, the founding director of Franklin Furnace, the performance art and gallery space in TriBeCa, recalls the moment. She was looking out the kitchen window at Mount Rainier, which had the effect of ''centering'' her, she said. Then it hit her: she was about to embark upon renovating the 19th-century Italianate Franklin Furnace loft space, but renovation was not what she wanted the gallery to be remembered for.

title: W.N.B.A. Surpasses Its Goals
description: The Liberty's 65-51 loss in Saturday's Women's National Basketball Association championship game was a devastating end to a season that had begun with such promise. But it was an historic victory for the Houston Comets, the W.N.B.A. and women's basketball everywhere.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Out, Out, Brief Candle
description: Speaking some years ago to a charity for children, Princess Diana said children nowadays are less likely to experience the early death of parents -- but more likely to suffer the trauma of divorce or other family troubles. So, she said, ''We must help them to face life as stable and confident adults.''

title: TCI Prepares for Yet Another Complex Spinoff
description: For John C. Malone, to whom a day without a deal is like a day without sunshine, August certainly had its sunny moments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHELMAN, HERBERT
description: FISHELMAN-Herbert. On August 26, 1997. Businessman, proprietor of Plaza Furniture Company of Jackson Heights and NYC, friend of organized labor, accomplished violinist, selflessly shared his love, kindness, humor, wisdom and optimism with friends and family for 76 years. He is mourned by Harriet, devoted wife of 53 years; children Norman Fishelman, Linda Eiges, Carol Schulman and Robin Burnett; grandchildren Valeria, Denise, Jackie, Katie, Scott, Emmanuel, Monica, Marielle and Daniel; his sister Sylvia Fial, brother Alvin Fallis and extended family. Contributions in his name may be made to Barge Music, c/o Linda Eiges, 629 11th St, Brklyn NY 11215.

title: Haas Shows Potential As the Last German Out
description: Early last week, a German television station, DSF, sent its reporters into the field to conduct an informal poll. Eighty people were interviewed and 40 of them said they believed that Boris Becker had a good chance to win the United States Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ABRAHAM, ESQ.
description: LEVINE-Abraham, Esq. Died peacefully on August 30, 1997, in Tamarac, FL, at the age of 87. Beloved and cared for by his children Sara, Joel and Charles, and especially by daughter-in-law Suarni during his last days. Survived by brother Louie and sister Tillie Lipp, by son-in-law Jeff Goodman and grandchildren Gabriel, Sara Rose, Jonathan and Jaimie Ross. His wit and generosity touched all who knew him throughout his long and fruitful life. He now joins his cherished wife and life-partner Rose, in eternal rest. Family and friends will gather for services at Parkside Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd and 66th Ave, Queens, Tuesday, September 2, at 10 AM.

title: Marijuana Worth $26 Million Seized by Authorities in Idaho
description: In a mountainous area north of here that is far better known for raising cattle than for growing marijuana, the authorities have seized more than 76,000 marijuana plants in a series of raids in rugged terrain.

title: Charles Accompanies Diana Back Home to a Grieving Britain
description: Prince Charles brought the body of Diana, Princess of Wales, home tonight to a nation convulsed with grief over her death in a high-speed car crash in Paris early today.

title: Quarterback and New Coach Take a Promising First Step
description: PRONUNCIATION of the name notwithstanding, what George Young most needs this season is for his rookie head coach to be facile while Dan Reeves, if not Bill Parcells, proves himself the fossil. Yesterday was a pretty good start, as Reeves lost his debut with Atlanta, while Jim Fassel had a bucket of Gatorade dumped on him, a game ball handed to him and ''Happy Birthday'' sung to him.

title: Don't Let the Past Hinder Germany's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana: Shy Girl Who Became 'Queen of People's Hearts'
description: The death at 36 of Diana, Princess of Wales, in a car crash in Paris early today brought to a premature close the life of someone who had gone from being a shy young society girl to one of the world's most glamorous and attention-getting women.

title: Deep in the Heart of Brooklyn, Cowboys and Kosher Food
description: Rene Gross of Flatbush has seen a few county fairs in her day, but never one with a kosher concession stand. Sean Adams of East New York began horseback riding two years ago, but had never seen a rodeo, let alone one where almost all the cowboys were black.

title: The Life of a Princess
description: The cruelly short life of the Princess of Wales bore the markings of fate from the moment she entered the public stage. Her marriage to Prince Charles in 1981 brought pageantry, triumph and renewal to the British monarchy. Soon, however, the fairy tale succumbed to human frailty. After a bitter divorce, Diana, like Charles, carried out a highly publicized quest for privacy, cultivating some of the very images she complained had become her prison.

title: L.A. Isn't a Wannabe
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: It is broadly true that short auctions tend to lead to easy contracts and long auctions to difficult ones. It is also true that the longer the auction, the more likely it is that the defenders will find the winning path.

title: Two Women Are Killed On Tracks Of L.I.R.R.
description: Two women walking along elevated Long Island Rail Road tracks near the Wantagh station about midnight Saturday were struck and killed by a diesel train that rounded a bend behind them at 65 miles per hour.

title: Water Restrictions Ending
description: The New Jersey-American Water Company is to lift restrictions tomorrow on outdoor use of water by 200,000 customers in Essex, Morris, Somerset and Union Counties.

title: Admirers Pay Respects With Tears And Flowers
description: They came to grieve and to gawk, men and women from across New York, expatriate Britons and suburban families, confessed devotees of the tabloids and a few who said they had once met the Princess, all of whom felt touched by her in some way.

title: Workers Wanted: Slackers Needn't Apply
description: In the spirit of Labor Day, with its respite from heavy lifting, ''That's Why They Call It Work'' should not strain many mind muscles.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''She was the people's princess and that's how she will stay, how she will remain, in our hearts and in our memories forever.''

title: Have the Radio Deals Peaked?
description: Does lightning strike twice?

title: Sotiria Bellou, 75, Greek Singer Of Traditional Rebetika Music
description: Sotiria Bellou, a leading singer of traditional rebetika songs, often described as the Greek blues, died on Wednesday, two days before her 76th birthday.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: PARTY WON'T BACK INCUMBENT -- Amid much criticism of his record, Democratic officials are looking the other way as City Councilman Lloyd Henry mounts a bid for a second term. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOE, COLLEEN MOFFETT
description: NOE-Colleen Moffett. Beloved wife of Henry M. Noe, Jr., of CBS Newspath. Mother of Faye Marie. Daughter of Thelma Moffett and the late Peter M. Moffett. Dear sister of the late Michael Moffett. Beloved sister of Kathleen Placilla, Peter J. Moffett, Eileen Hastings. Colleen was a longtime wardrobe supervisor at ''Seasame Street.'' A memorial service wil be held on Wednesday, September 3, at 12 noon, at St. Dominic's in Oyster Bay. For information call Francis DeVine Funeral Home, 516922-6700.

title: MORE ON THE DEATHS
description: THE PAPARAZZI -- The fury of many at the paparazzi, the tabloids and the press in general over the circumstances of Diana's death obscured the fact that the she often seemed to use the news media as readily as it used her. Page A7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, LILLIAN
description: GELLER-Lillian. Died peacefully on August 30, at the age of 90. Loving mother of Sophia, grandmother of Janet and Laurel, and greatgrandmother of Matthew and Douglas. A woman whose generosity knew no bounds, whose inquisitive spirit about people was accompanied by her sharp wit, and whose zest for life will be a role model for all of us who loved her.

title: Richard Skalak, 74, Pioneer In Bioengineering, Is Dead
description: Prof. Richard Skalak, a pioneer in bioengineering and biomechanics who taught at Columbia University in New York for more than 40 years, died on Aug. 17 at his home in San Diego. He was 74.

title: Makeover by Fassel Has Grand Unveiling
description: In a players-only meeting Saturday night, Giants quarterback Dave Brown stood before his teammates to deliver a speech. ''Every team we play this season thinks they know us,'' teammates quoted Brown as saying. ''We're the team that finds ways to lose. They're wrong. We're a new team that makes plays to win.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDLANDER, HENNI
description: FRIEDLANDER - Henni. The wound heals but the scar remains. You live within our hearts always. Your Loving Family and Friends

title: Mexico Main Party Averts a Legislative Crisis
description: Lawmakers from the Government's party made a major concession to the opposition today, acting to avert a crisis that threatened to leave Mexico with two competing legislatures and a constitutional crisis just as it is testing real democracy for the first time.

title: Pay Attention
description: In mid-July a Saudi Arabian aircraft secretly took off from Syria for Saudi Arabia, carrying one passenger and several guards. And therein lies an intriguing tale of shifting geopolitics in the Middle East.

title: Historic Grievances
description: To the Editor:

title: $350 Million at Rutgers
description: Rutgers University officials estimate that the school needs to do about $350 million in building work over the coming years, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported yesterday.

title: California Draws Newspaper Chains Eager to Cluster
description: Stroll down the sunny side of Alvarado Street in this old seaside city until you reach Bonifacio Plaza and you will all but bump into the competitive reality of today's newspaper business: a miniature Stonehenge of sidewalk news boxes selling eight different daily papers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOSLER, CAROLYN ATLAS
description: SOSLER-Carolyn Atlas, April 10, 1940-September 1, 1993. ''The world breaks everyone and afterward many are strong at the broken places. But those that will not break it kills. It kills the very good and the very gentle and the very brave.'' Hemingway. You are always with us. Pop, Neil, Andree

title: Priest Robbed and 2 Hurt In Incidents on Subway
description: In three separate incidents on the city's subways yesterday, a Roman Catholic priest in clerical clothing was robbed, a flight attendant on her way to the airport was pistol-whipped and a 17-year-old boy waiting for a train was slashed across the face, the police said.

title: A Bitter Episode Ends as the Mets Trade Harnisch
description: The trade that Steve Phillips announced after the Mets defeated the Orioles, 4-1, today is virtually meaningless, in terms of what he gave up and what he received. Phillips, the Mets' general manager, sent a pitcher with no victories to Milwaukee for a Class A outfielder batting .223.

title: Peter Serkin Illuminates Bach's Teaching Pieces
description: Virtually every youngster who has taken piano lessons has been taught Bach's Two-Part Invention in C Major. It's the first of 15 inventions that Bach composed as instructional pieces for his first-born son, and if the composer's descendants held the rights to these works they could be living in comfort off the royalties. The C Major Invention, no doubt the world's most played piece, is ideal for beginners: it lasts less than two minutes (even at a practice room tempo), mostly lies on the white keys and involves just two lines of ambling counterpoint, one per hand. Never is either hand asked to play more than one note at a time.

title: Her Death Is Less a Morality Play Than a Modernized Greek Tragedy : The Royal Superstar
description: LONDON  From the single flower laid beside palace walls to the grand tributes from world leaders, the heartfelt reaction to the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, comes from society's emotional gut.

title: Israeli Arab Sentenced In Egypt for Spying
description: Egypt's State Security Court sentenced an Israeli Arab, Azam Azam, to 15 years of hard labor today on charges of spying for Israel. An Egyptian, Emad Ismail, was also sentenced to 25 years in prison for collaborating with Mr. Azam.

title: INSIDE
description: Mexican Crisis Averted

title: Police Investigating Photographers' Actions
description: The French police opened a criminal investigation today to determine whether a chase by seven photographers on motorcycles was responsible for the car crash here that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, and her companion, the Harrods heir Emad Mohammed al-Fayed, shortly after midnight. This evening, Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne and Diana's husband until their marriage ended in divorce a year ago, flew here from Scotland and sadly accepted her body, in a plain wooden coffin, from President Jacques Chirac at Pitie-Salpetriere university hospital, near the Sorbonne.

title: Award to Lighting Inventor Upheld on Appeal
description: An appeals court in California has upheld a $96 million jury award to an inventor and about 200 investors who contended that energy-saving fluorescent lighting technology he had developed was suppressed by the company that acquired the rights to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, MAX
description: HABER-Max. Of Palm Beach, FL, (formerly of Harrison, NY) on August 29, 1997. Beloved and adored husband of Faye, cherished and devoted father of Robert and Kenneth, loving father-in-law of Roslyn and Adrienne, adored and special grandfather of Jonathan, Jennifer, Brett, Jaime and Adam. We will all miss this gentle man with his warm smile, whose heart was generous to all. Services Tuesday, September 2, 1997 at 12 noon at Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contribtutions in his memory may be made to the Brett Adam Haber Fund, c/o Dr. Marvin Schuster Motility Center, Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center, Development Office, 4940 Eastern Ave., Triad Building, Baltimore, MD 21224-2780.

title: Giants' Man of the Hour, At the Moment of Truth
description: THERE comes a point in a rebuilding year when someone, usually someone not intimately connected with the dreary past, steps forward, says ENOUGH! and reverses the flow of fate. Yesterday, that person was Sam Garnes, who jumped in front of Irving Fryar and raced 95 yards into the indeterminable future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOSO, ROBERT FRANKLIN
description: VOSO-Robert Franklin. Died August 30, 1997, at the age of 63. He is survived by his wife Turid (Larsen); a son Robert A. of Phoenixville, PA; his daughter Karen Marie Alboum of Hillsborough, NJ; two brothers Louis of East Greenwich, NY, and Frank of Courtland Manor, NY; a sister Florence Powell of Lancaster, PA, and a grandson Justin Robert. Funeral services Wednesday, Sept 3, 9:30 AM, at Higgins Home for Funerals, Watchung, NJ, followed by a 10 AM Funeral Mass at St. Mary's Stoney Hill Church in Watchung. Interment private. Visitation Tuesday, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM, at the funeral home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENAMY, TAMAR
description: BENAMY-Tamar. With great sorrow, we announce the untimely death of Tami, beloved daughter of Avivah and the late Ehud, and devoted sister of Lonny. Services at Boulevard Riverside, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, Tuesday, September 2, 2 PM.

title: Yankees Rush Rivera In, To Hustle the Expos Out
description: This is how badly Joe Torre wanted yesterday's game: with the Yankees leading Montreal by a run in the eighth inning, he hurried his closer, Mariano Rivera, into the middle of an at-bat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERUTTI, ANITA J. (GIOVANNA)
description: CERUTTI-Anita J. (Giovanna), on August 29, 1997. Co-founder of Cerutti Enterprises, the prominent Madison Avenue children's retailer, devoted and loving mother of Reid Cerutti, Harlan L. Davidson, Jr. & Francesca Davidson Cerutti. Beloved daughter of the late Mr. & Mrs. Frank Cerutti and devoted sister of the late Doris Cerutti Hurdle and Louis A. Cerutti. Cherished aunt of Anita Bindi, Frank L. Cerutti and Donna Storatz. Reposing at ''The Abbey'', 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, September 3, at 11 A.M., at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62nd Street, New York City. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Strict Press Laws Govern Any Invasion of Privacy : France No Paparazzi Market
description: PARIS  The free-lance photographers who pursued Diana, Princess of Wales, and her millionaire companion shortly before their fatal crash would have found no legal market for their pictures in France.

title: The Evolution of the Calculator
description: This year is the 30th anniversary of the first hand-held electronic calculator. Created by three engineers at Texas Instruments, it was a simple machine that could add, subtract, multiply and divide, just like the more sophisticated mechanical calculators at that time.

title: Treasury Bill Auction Scheduled
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, which is usually held on Mondays but will be conducted tomorrow because of the Labor Day holiday.

title: Winter Talk at Labor Day
description: Around Sheridan, Wyo., everyone has been talking about winter all summer. At the Big R, a ranch supply store on the edge of town, the aisles are filled with prognostication. ''They say it's going to be harder than last winter,'' the ranchers and store clerks opine, and if the weight of rumor is any measure of truth, there is a dire season coming.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Some Fear That Fleets of Watchers May Harm Mammals
description: It was nearly three hours before the first, tentative shout rose from the squinting crew. It could be a whale. It looked like a whale. ''We have the animal off the bow at 11 o'clock!''

title: John J. Slocum, 83, Diplomat And Connoisseur of Literature
description: John Jermain Slocum, a retired Foreign Service officer, scholar and bibliophile whose James Joyce collection formed part of Yale University's trove of rare books, died on Aug. 12 at Newport Hospital in Rhode Island. He was 83 and lived in Newport.

description: UNCROWNED KINGThe Life of Prince Albert By Stanley Weintraub Illustrated. 478 pages. The Free Press. $27.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTLINGER, GODFREY A.
description: ETTLINGER-Godfrey A. Of Hastings On Hudson, on August 30. Cherished husband of Dorothy, father and father-in-law of Carla, Robert and Jodi. Grandfather of six. Brother of John, Ruth and Marianne. Loved and admired by many relatives and friends. Funeral service at Temple Beth Shalom, 740 N. Broadway, Hastings, Tuesday, Sept. 2, at 1 PM.

title: Jerseyan Gored in Bull Run
description: A New Jersey man was gored by a bull on Saturday during the final day of a bull run in San Sebastian de Los Reyes, a small town six miles north of Madrid, The Associated Press reported.

title: Worry Voiced Over Direction Of News Media
description: After a summer of deliberation, a group of 28 reporters, editors and journalism teachers has issued a ''statement of concern'' about the state of journalism at a time when entertainment or sensationalism is often favored over more serious news coverage.

description: PORTER-Grace Rapoport. We love you and miss you. Miriam and Martin Ellen and Steve

title: Mattingly's Monument To Effort
description: The most striking aspect of Don Mattingly's career, from one point of view, is the number of years that he produced mediocre statistics.

title: She May Not Get Out Much, but She Does Know a Lot About Art
description: For someone who 27 years ago opted for a life of seclusion, silence and contemplation, Sister Wendy Beckett certainly enjoys talking, which is all to the good. On television, where her programs about painting have turned the 67-year-old nun into something of a cult figure in Britain, her enthusiasm is contagious. In private conversation, her love of life, and God, verge on the gleeful.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks was down 46.80 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,182.62 points. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 222.03 points.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Labor May Be Poised To Reverse Long Decline

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASLOW, FLORENCE
description: MASLOW-Florence. Born July 4, 1910, known as ''Miss Florence,'' an internationally celebrated dancer in the 1920's and 1930's. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry Maslow. Her strong will and ''joie de vie'' will continue to live on in her loving children Toni Gallant and Valerie Outhred, and her adoring grandchildren Mitchell, Chad, Jennifer, Alex and Stephanie. She will be greatly missed by her family whom she loved, and who loved her, so dearly.

title: College Adds First Housing
description: About 40 Felician College students and 5 faculty members moved into a dormitory at the school's new Rutherford campus yesterday, the first time that the private, Roman Catholic liberal arts college has provided housing since it was incorporated in 1942.

title: Bosnian Serb Farmers Bitterly Recall NATO Presence
description: Vlada Stevanic, bare-chested and wearing a faded pair of shorts, walked slowly through his cow pasture until he stood in front of a gaping hole in the ground.

title: Charles Takes Diana's Body Home From Paris : World Mourns the 'People's Princess'
description: LONDON  The body of Diana, Princess of Wales, was brought back to Britain on Sunday by Prince Charles, and Prime Minister Tony Blair expressed a nation's grief over the loss of "the people's princess" after her storybook life ended tragically when a car she was riding in crashed at very high speed in a Paris tunnel.

title: 3 Democrats for Mayor Continue to Campaign on Police Abuse
description: At morning services before black congregations in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday, three Democratic mayoral candidates invoked the name of Abner Louima, faulting Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as they further sought to frame their campaigns around the issue of police brutality.

title: Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: A company says it has built a better magnetic compass, one connected to a microchip.
description: THE magnetic compass has changed little since it came into use some 2,000 years ago. But now a fledgling company says it has discovered a simple improvement that could help blind people navigate through cities, golfers improve their scores and spelunkers find their way out of caves.

title: Kansas City's New Offense Misfires
description: Did somebody forget to tell the Kansas City Chiefs' offense that the preseason is over? That these games count?

title: Quach Tom, 65, C.I.A. Agent Who Became a Prisoner of War
description: Quach Tom, a Vietnamese who parachuted into North Vietnam as a commando for the Central Intelligence Agency, evaded capture for three months and then survived almost 19 years of harsh imprisonment as a spy, died on Wednesday at the Columbia Northlake Regional Medical Center in Chamblee, Ga. He was 65.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, MARY E.
description: KEATING-Mary E. Formerly of Manhattan. On Saturday, August 30, 1997. Sister of Monsignor James V. Keating, Thomas Keating and the late John Keating. Aunt of Thomas and Kevin Keating. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, Saint Joseph's Church, Kingston, New York. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens, New York. Calling hours at The Joseph V. Leahy Funeral Home, 27 Smith Avenue, Kingston, NY, Tuesday, 24 and 7-9 PM.

title: Group Calls for Moderation and Pragmatism
description: When Robert MacCoun, a psychologist at the University of California at Berkeley, set out to analyze American perceptions about illegal drug use, he found himself treading a political minefield.

title: Back to School With Rudy Crew
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, began work in 1995 under laws that allowed corrupt and incompetent school officials to keep their jobs for life, despite decades of scandal and failure. Then came the new school governance law, passed by the State Legislature last winter at Dr. Crew's urging. The law stripped local boards of hiring and firing powers and dramatically extended the Chancellor's authority. Dr. Crew's new powers -- together with his engaging personal manner and his close relationship with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani -- have made him one of the city's most powerful school leaders ever. His task now is to reach out to constituencies worried that he will become an autocrat and shut them out of the process.

title: Library and Dealer Dispute Custody of Medieval Text
description: For more than half a century, no one knew the whereabouts of the rare 12th-century compendium of medical knowledge. But now that it has been found, a West Coast dealer and the august National Library of Medicine here in suburban Washington are locked in a battle to decide who owns it.

title: Some news organizations take umbrage at rating their on-line sites.
description: A GROUP of major news organizations took the digital high road last week. The group members -- which includes Time Inc., the Cable News Network, The New York Times Company, The Wall Street Journal and The Associated Press -- said they would allow their on-line editions to be rendered invisible to some Internet users rather than conform to a rating system that screens material dealing with sex or violence.

title: Equity Schedule For the Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Offensive Line Does a Solid Job
description: The Giants' offensive line, a source of concern before the game, played admirably yesterday. Left tackle Roman Oben occasionally had a tough time pass-blocking Eagles defensive end Mike Mamula, but the Giants often double-teamed Mamula with a running back.

title: Transit Patrols On 7 Line Cut Night Crimes
description: For nearly four months, police officers on overnight patrols on the No. 7 subway line in Queens have focused on deterring two types of crimes: token booth robberies and thefts by pickpockets who prey silently on riders as they sleep.

title: To Messinger, Speed Bump Has Become A Hurdle
description: For much of this year, it appeared that Ruth W. Messinger was sailing toward an easy victory in the Democratic mayoral primary, notwithstanding whatever problems might await her in the fall. She had assembled the traditional ingredients of the successful New York City Democratic primary candidate -- money, a solid political base and a left-of-center ideology -- and seemed poised to overwhelm her two main opponents, Sal F. Albanese and the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: Moderate Drinkers? Not in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking For Union Labels, Or Boycotts
description: Organized-labor sites abound on the World Wide Web -- but don't expect them to shout ''Surfers of the world, unite!'' Rather, these sites reflect the state of unions in today's working world.

title: Williams Is Winning Matches, and Control
description: Sometimes it seems as if the cocky edge on Venus Williams can slice everything from bread to an opponent's self-esteem, a sort of Ginsu arrogance.

title: Rumpipumpy Springs a Surprise
description: Sometimes, a horse just defies the odds, makes a big move and wins a big race. That was what happened today when a filly with the lyrical name of Rumpipumpy made a late dash past fillies with shorter odds and longer credentials and won the 59th running of the Diana Handicap by one length.

title: Nickelodeon, the children's cable network, wins viewers, but loses out on ad rates.
description: MAY you have the best lemonade stand on the block. Almost everyone in the neighborhood buys your lemonade, partly because your stand is open all day every day, and partly because your lemonade is so tasty and refreshing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAIR, STEPHEN WILKENS
description: BLAIR-Stephen Wilkens. Age 53 of Boston, suddenly on August 29, 1997. Husband of Mary (Beldo) Blair of Boston. Father of Clark Blair of Boston and Ann Blair Silvers of Mesa, AZ. Son of George A. Blair of Andover, NH, and the late Madeline (Collins) Blair. Brother of Geoffrey Blair of NH. Memorial services will be held at 11 AM, Wednesday, September 3, at Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston. Burial will be held privately. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be directed in his name to the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Symphony Hall, 301 Mass Ave, Boston, MA 02115 or the Dublin School, PO Box 522, Dublin, NH 03444. Call J.S. Waterman & Sons-Eastman-Waring Funeral Home of Boston for further information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELDON, MAX
description: SHELDON-Max. Beloved husband for 63 years of Bernice. Loving father of Edward and Barbara, and Robert and Barbara. Adored grandfather of Amy, Wendy, Jeffrey and Peter. Graveside services Westchester Hills Cemetery, Saw Mill River Road, Hastings On Hudson, NY, Monday at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRONSTEIN, DR. MELVIN
description: BRONSTEIN-Dr. Melvin. 4/9/249/1/96. In blessed remembrance of a devoted husband, loving father and compassionate physician. Our thoughts remain with you always, as well as the love you bestowed upon us. Our loss will never diminish. Gloria and your loving family

title: A Place for All Eternity In Their Adopted Land
description: As Buddhist priests in long black robes took turns chanting under towering oaks at the Locust Valley Cemetery here, Misako Rudiger bowed and walked slowly toward a small table laden with fruit, flowers, lighted candles and photographs of the dead.

title: A Memorial to Unity
description: To the Editor:

title: Poll Says the Race Is Close
description: A new poll has found that James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, has pulled close to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Broadcast Giants Vie for Control of Regional Sports Markets
description: Two months ago, Fox Sports Detroit did not exist. The only regional sports channel available to 1.6 million cable homes in Michigan and northern Ohio was Pro-Am Sports Systems, or PASS, a subsidiary of the Washington Post Company.

title: In Cambodia, King Sihanouk Once More Moves Deftly Among Powers
description: He is old, he is sick and he is discouraged as he sees his country torn apart by what he called today a new civil war. And once again, King Norodom Sihanouk is ruling by his wits, trying to find the balance between powerful forces that threaten Cambodia.

title: Tabloids Diana Used Now Loom as Villains
description: ''I always believed that the press would kill her in the end,'' the Princess of Wales's brother, Earl Spencer, said bitterly to the reporters clustered outside the front gates of his home in Cape Town, South Africa, early today. ''Not even I could imagine that they would take such a direct hand in her death, as seems to be the case.''

title: Profits From Casino Help an Indian Tribe Reclaim Its History
description: History books may now have to acknowledge what Theresa H. Bell, a member of the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, has always felt in her heart: The Pequots did not disappear in the 17th century when, ravaged by the combination of a war with the colonists and smallpox, measles and other European diseases, the tribe supposedly succumbed to European culture and was assimilated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ALEXANDER
description: SHAPIRO-Alexander. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, beloved father of our member, Barbara Joseph. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHECHTER, HARRY
description: SHECHTER-Harry. On August 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Johanna. Loving father of Sharon and step-father of Benita. Loving grandfather of Monica, David, Shari and Leslie. Great-grandfather of Steven, Amanda, Joshua, Melanie and Shayna. Visitation Monday, 3-5 PM and 7-9:30 PM. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, from Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Rd), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Pleas Leave 2 in Garbage Cartel Trial
description: They are the last significant figures left in a racketeering case that began two years ago with 17 defendants and has now been reduced to a trial of two men accused of being the Mafia controllers of the city's private garbage-hauling industry.

title: Hall Passes Test From 55 Yards
description: When place-kicker John Hall joined the Jets in the spring, Coach Bill Parcells often cast a shadow over the ball. ''I knew he was trying to jinx me,'' Hall said at the time.

title: 7 Big-Name Companies Step Up to Invest In Start-Up Network
description: Seven big Internet and networking companies will invest $40 million in Juniper Networks Inc. to help the start-up company produce equipment that can speed the flow of information over the Internet.

title: A Virtual Cleanup of Chernobyl
description: On the ground floor of Chernobyl's reactor No. 4, robots are already making their way through the maze of pipes and debris that are the remnants of the world's worst nuclear power plant disaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNN, MICHAEL J.
description: GUNN-Michael J. Of Baldwin, on August 30, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Kathleen. Devoted father of Joan Gunn, Kathleen Modick, Richard, Robert and the late Michael Gunn. Dear brother of Catherine Conrad. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Reposing at Weigand Bros Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave, Baldwin. Visiting hours Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Christopher's R.C. Church, Baldwin, Wednesday 9:45 AM. Interment following at Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Only Employment For Many in Europe Is Part-Time Work
description: Tabienne Rogard just started a job as an executive secretary at one of France's biggest food companies. But she is not excited: This will be her 10th job in four years, and she already knows she will be looking for work again in six months.

title: History in a Hazelnut Shell
description: The summer of '97: Dairy Queen and A & W root beer floats are but faint memories, like sock hops and 30-cents gas. It's frappucino now. And macchiato. And Starbucks.

title: At Museum, Films Based on London Plays
description: The Museum of Modern Art will present a program of 31 films adapted from plays first staged in London in a series beginning on Sept. 11 and running through Oct. 19.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDBERG, FLORENCE AND EMANUEL
description: GOLDBERG-Florence and Emanuel. We will always love and remember you. Arthur, Sidney, Ralph, Helen, Lucianne, Audrey, Lynn, Stephen, Kenneth, Judy, David, Joshua and Jonah.

title: Producers Defend Reviled Cable TV Show
description: Tom Loce and Ed Richter will tell you with pride that they produce the most offensive cable television show in Rochester's history -- aptly named ''Life Without Shame.''

title: Western Senators Are Pushing to Break Up Circuit Court
description: For more than a decade, a group of senators from the Northwest has been trying with little success to break up the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, complaining that it was too large and, more important, was dominated by judges from California who issue liberal environmental rulings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRUPPIN, MICHAEL
description: TRUPPIN-Michael. November 26, 1925-September 1, 1983. We love you, we remember you, and we miss you. Your daughters Andrea and Nicola

title: Showcase for Immigrants as Composers
description: When Joel Sachs took over the directorship of the Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden concerts, he changed the focus of the weekly programs from explorations of individual composers and their worlds to more expansive thematic overviews. This summer, noting that immigration has become a hot issue not only in the United States but in other countries as well, he assembled nine programs that looked at the contributions of foreign-born composers to 20th-century American composition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OCUIN, MORTON ''STREAKY''
description: OCUIN-Morton ''Streaky''. You were a wonderful friend. You were the best. We will miss you. Ruth and Seymour Solomon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, EDWARD F.
description: MEYER-Edward F. On August 29, 1997, of Baldwin, LI, formerly of Briarwood, NY. Beloved husband of Claire (nee Moore). Adored father of Colleen Vasicovschi and Kathleen Meyer. Cherished grandfather of six. Friends may call at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 20 Lincoln Avenue, Rockville Centre, LI, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Oilers Win Over Fans In Their Tennessee Debut
description: It is the city that Elvis Presley put on the map. But for much of the afternoon, there were not many ''Love Me Tenders'' for a football franchise that is borrowing this river city for two years while fancier digs are being built to the east in what is perceived as a more upscale city, Nashville.

title: Her Charitable Work Fighting AIDS and Land Mines Is Widely Praised : Homages to a Life of Helping Others
description: PARIS  The death of Diana, Princess of Wales, who once said she preferred to be a "queen of hearts" rather than to be queen of England, touched off an outpouring of grief and shock around the world Sunday.

title: Holding the Marijuana
description: The Edison Police Department has to guard more than three tons of marijuana worth about $20 million during the Labor Day holiday because officers failed to get a court order allowing them to destroy it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Parcells Spurs an Emotional and Aggressive Debut
description: So, this is how it is done.

title: Man Found Dead in Dorm
description: A man from Indian Mills was found dead in a Pennsylvania State University dormitory room on Saturday, the university's police said.

title: Moscow's Scare Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, HOWARD
description: SHEPPS-Howard Another birthday.... Memories never fade, Always in our hearts, Forever loved by us all.

title: Dodi Fayed: A Young, Wealthy Outsider in Britain's Class-Obsessed Society
description: Today, on the day he died, News of the World, Britain's largest-circulation weekly, declared that the Egyptian-born millionaire Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, known as Dodi, was unfit to marry into Britain's royalty.

title: Don't Forget Parcells's Coaching Staff. He Never Does.
description: FOR the Jets, the scoreboard was certainly different 41-3, over the Seahawks. But so were they.

title: Cowboys Shock Steelers, And Themselves, Too
description: Midway through the second quarter, Pittsburgh quarterback Kordell Stewart went deep to wide receiver Charles Johnson, and Deion Sanders got in the way. Going for the interception, the Dallas cornerback smashed into Johnson and cornerback Kevin Smith in one of the scariest collisions you will see this year. Sanders was flipped over, landed on his head and lay on the turf for several seconds after the play before getting up.

title: I.B.M. Sets Enhancements For Deep Blue
description: Deep Blue, the chess-playing computer that defeated the world champion Gary Kasparov, is about to get even more powerful.

title: Hopping Across Time And Space
description: How much do the shim sham and the step-dance have in common? As much as anyone wants them to, to judge by the lively and entertaining ''Afroceltic Connection: Flying Home,'' a program presented by Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Thursday night at Damrosch Park by the Jiving Lindy Hoppers from England, the Sin E band from Ireland and Dianne Walker, an American tap-dancer.

title: Haitians Press Mayor on Issue Of Brutality By the Police
description: Representatives of the city's Haitian residents complained yesterday that the Giuliani administration has been unresponsive to their sentiments and suggestions after police officers were accused of beating a Haitian immigrant.

title: An 'Unknown' Co-Founder Leaves After 20 Years of Glory and Turmoil
description: The steady stream of cyclists who roll by the big steel gate here each weekend may scarcely have time to glance through the bars at the baronial estate inside as they pedal to the hills overlooking Silicon Valley.

title: A Terror to Journalists, He Sniffs Out Terrorists
description: In a sunlit office near the Bosporus shore, Erol Canozkan spends his days reading newspapers in search of terrorist propaganda.

title: Lost Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time, Valentine Wins (but He Is Playing a Dangerous Game)
description: A week after Bobby Valentine finished second in his public confrontation with Todd Hundley, he has surprisingly regained ground in his clubhouse precisely because he had another nasty contretemps with another veteran player.

title: A Sad Clinton Sends Message
description: President Clinton reflected somberly today on the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, after a car accident in Paris.

title: GAINS PUT UNIONS AT TURNING POINT, MANY EXPERTS SAY
description: With the United Parcel Service settlement seen as a major triumph and an omen of future success, union leaders and many experts say the labor movement is in its strongest position in nearly a generation and is poised to increase its membership after a two-decade decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEADOW, VIRGINIA R.
description: MEADOW-Virginia R. On August 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Franklin Meadow. Loving mother of Dorothy Meadow Sobol and Carolyn Meadow Shechtman. Devoted grandmother of Emma, Julia and Edward Sobol and Jonathan Shechtman. Dear sister of Mildred Bellew Leonard. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, 3:30 PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Saybrook College, Yale University, Virginia R. Meadow Fund.

title: Ask East Europeans
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, ALVIN B.
description: GOLDSMITH-Alvin B. Beloved husband of Frances. Loving father of Barbara Goldsmith, Jayne Lewis, Richard and Hank. Dear brother of Wil. Adored grandfather of Evan, Tanya, Michelle, Jocelyn and Melanie. Services were held Sunday at ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, Rego Park.

title: Russian Fear of NATO Aggression Defies Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: MILITARY IS HOPING TO TEST-FIRE LASER AGAINST SATELLITE
description: The developers of the nation's most powerful military laser are seeking permission to fire the laser's beam into space at a $60 million Air Force satellite in what military officials say would be the first test of its kind.

title: I.B.M. Tries to Outmaneuver Microsoft by Supporting Java
description: David Gee has a daunting mission, one that has defeated many older, more experienced executives. His challenge? Making I.B.M. look cool.

title: Where Diana Ruled, the Realm of Celebrity Feels Devastation
description: The death of the Princess of Wales spread shock, grief and a sense of a gaping hole in the international worlds of fashion, charity and celebrity yesterday as people in Diana's circles said they had lost a friend as well as an important energizing force.

title: L.I.R.R. Pilot Program Limits Alcohol Drinking
description: Starting today, riders on the Long Island Rail Road who want to sip a cold beer on their way home from work will be sequestered in two cars under a pilot program on the Port Washington branch aimed at restricting alcohol consumption on the trains.

title: Previous Backers Desert Councilman in Brooklyn
description: Four years ago, when the Rev. Lloyd Henry of Flatbush, Brooklyn, was running for the City Council in his first bid for public office, powerful Democratic officials were lining up to help.

title: Reason for Dread
description: To the Editor:

title: A Popular Couple Charge Into the Future of Art, but in Opposite Directions
description: Elizabeth Peyton, a young artist with a studio near Tompkins Square in the East Village, paints -- and she is hot. That itself is unusual at a time when conceptual, installation, performance or video art is the ticket to art world stardom and cutting-edge exhibition venues. Even more unusual, Ms. Peyton paints people: vividly colorful, true-to-life representations of rock icons like Kurt Cobain and historical figures like Napoleon.

title: Man Charged in Robbery Of Bridge Toll Collector
description: A New York City man was arrested yesterday afternoon after he robbed a toll collector on the New Jersey side of the George Washington Bridge and then fled by motorcycle into Manhattan, bridge officials said.

title: Racial Hurdles
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, MAX
description: HABER-Max. Of Palm Beach, Florida, (formerly of Harrison, NY) on August 29, 1997. Beloved and adored husband of Faye, cherished and devoted father of Robert & Kenneth, loving fatherin-law of Roslyn and Adrienne, adored and special grandfather of Jonathan, Jennifer, Brett, Jaime and Adam. We will all miss this gentle man with his warm smile, whose heart was generous to all. Services Tuesday, September 2, 1997, 12 noon at Riverside Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Brett Adam Haber Fund, c/o Dr. Marvin Schuster Motility Center, Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center, Development Office, 4940 Eastern Ave., Triad Building, Baltimore, MD. 21224-2780.

title: Giants End Drab Days Of Calling Drab Plays
description: In their first possession of the 1997 season, the Giants ran the football twice for 4 yards, then misfired on a third-down pass over the middle. The new-look Giants looked familiar: three plays and out.

title: As Much Mourning as the Market Will Bear
description: There has been no want of accusations amid the television gush occasioned by the death of Diana, Princess of Wales. Broadcast networks and all-news cable stations have taken time out from orgies of eulogy, gossip and old news clips (''Live on the death of Princess Diana,'' one anchor called it) to discuss responsibility. Appearing on all channels was the Princess's brother, Earl Spencer, charging many a publisher and an editor with having ''blood on his hands.''

title: With Vigor, Labor Surges in Politics
description: For years, unions came to expect little more from politicians than the requisite appearances at Labor Day events. But now, labor's visibility in American politics is greater than it has been in years, and it will only intensify this autumn as union-related issues come to the forefront.

title: Blood on Their Hands
description: The brother of the Princess of Wales said it devastatingly and correctly, in a sentence of icy passion from which there is no hiding place:

title: Executive Pay Increases at a Much Faster Rate Than Corporate Revenues and Profits
description: Internal Revenue Service data to be released today will show that from 1980 to 1995, a period when corporate revenues and profits soared, the senior executives of companies did even better, with their pay increasing at a much faster rate.

title: On Saratoga's Final Day, The Outlook Is Optimistic
description: Saratoga ended its 129th season of summertime racing today with a favorite and a 27-1 long shot winning the final two stakes, with Jerry Bailey the leading jockey for the fourth straight year and John Kimmel tying Bill Mott as the leading trainer, and with every indication that next year's meeting would also run 36 days through Labor Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, JAMES WEAR
description: WALKER-James Wear, of Hobe Sound Fla., formerly of Oyster Bay, New York, died on August 30 after suffering a heart attack. Son of the founder of the international Walker Cup competition, he was a lifelong golfer and devoted family man. Husband of the late Sara Mitchell Walker. Survived by brother Louis of Hobe Sound, daughter Hilary Walker Gilmore of Ore., stepdaughter Sheila O'Keefe Todd of Colo., stepson John O'Keefe of MA.; grandchildren: William Walker Todd, James Bridger Todd, Whitney DeForest Todd, James Tucker Gilmore and Eliza Fahy Johnstone Gilmore; one great-granddaughter, many nieces and nephews. Family services will be held September 5 in Kennebunkport, Maine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, LAWRENCE (LARRY)
description: SINGER-Lawrence (Larry). Loving husband of Candy. Father of Marcy Singer, Lisa Cohen, Donna Glabman, grandfather of Nicole, brother of Seymour. Graveside services are at 1 P.M., at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Westchester on Wednesday, September 3. For more information call Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, 718-377-2700.

title: All at Once And All Over, A Cooling Off
description: STARTING in the 15th century, Europe and North America entered a period of climatic cooling that lasted, on and off, for some six centuries. Scientists believe that the average global surface temperature dropped about 1 to 3 degrees Fahrenheit below today's. During the worst of the cold, harvests failed and there was starving in Europe, and people could walk across New York Harbor on the ice.

title: Vietnam Said to Bar Journalist From Taking a U.N. Fellowship
description: The first Vietnamese journalist awarded an international fellowship to report on the United Nations has been barred from traveling to the United States by the Vietnamese Government, the editor of the publication in Hanoi that employs him said last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTICK, RUTH
description: KOTICK-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Samuel Kotick. Devoted mother of Elaine, Charles and Joel, cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. She will be deeply missed by all.

title: MetroStars in Cup Test
description: In the middle of their desperate attempt to qualify for the Major League Soccer playoffs, the MetroStars have a chance to join the likes of the Brooklyn Italians (1991) and Maccabee LA (1973, 1975, 1977, 1978 and 1981) as winners of the U.S. Open Cup championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSMACHER, HARRY A.
description: KOSMACHER-Harry A. Patriach, businessman, and community leader, peacefully at 96, August 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Estelle. Devoted father of Lois and the late Kenneth. He will be dearly missed by daughter-in -law Mildred Richter, grandchildren Karen Lazar, Steven, Richard and Jeffrey Kosmacher, great granddaughters Kassie, Isabella and Sophie, family and friends. Services will be private.

title: Accounts
description: * Vivus Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., to Hoffman/Lewis, San Francisco, to handle the first direct-to-consumer national advertising for MUSE, an impotency treatment. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: Clinton Won't Attend
description: President Clinton will not attend the funeral of Diana in London on Saturday, the White House announced today.

title: Whitman's Daughter Is Hit by a Car
description: Kate Whitman, the daughter of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, was injured yesterday when she was hit by a car while jogging in South Africa, a spokeswoman said.

title: Giant Computer Virtually Conquers Space and Time
description: JANUS, recently christened the world's fastest supercomputer, is not much to look at: 84 tall gray cabinets resembling plastic gym lockers lined up inside a claustrophobic, fluorescent-lighted room.

title: CONGRESS GETS SET FOR A NEW SESSION WITH OLD BATTLES
description: Basking in the accomplishment of its balanced-budget and tax-cutting agreement with the President, Congress returns to the Capitol this week to confront the mechanics of making the historic deal work and to wrangle over several prickly issues, including welfare, education and campaign finance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERUTTI, ANITA J. (GIOVANNA)
description: CERUTTI-Anita J. (Giovanna), on August 29, 1997. Co-founder of Cerutti Enterprises, the prominent Madison Avenue children's retailer, devoted and loving mother of Reid Cerutti, Harlan L. Davidson, Jr. & Francesca Davidson Cerutti. Beloved daughter of the late Mr. & Mrs. Frank Cerutti and devoted sister of the late Doris Cerutti Hurdle and Louis A. Cerutti. Cherished aunt of Anita Bindi, Frank L. Cerutti and Donna Storatz. Reposing at ''The Abbey'', 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, September 3, at 11 A.M., at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62nd Street, New York City. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Knicks Are Low Key About Off-Court Battle
description: The last time the Knicks' future was in the hands of an arbitrator, they lost nearly half of their roster to suspensions. A playoff victory over the Miami Heat is not at stake this time, but obtaining insurance for Patrick Ewing in the post is still crucial.

title: T-Shirts Come Out From Under
description: The perfect underpinnings for a suit are stretch jersey T-shirts like the silk ones Helmut Lang and Calvin Klein showed, layered one color on another. The good news is there are now less expensive versions.

title: An Evolving Isringhausen Leads the Mets
description: An eventful year has passed in Jason Isringhausen's life -- elbow and shoulder surgery, months of recovery from a broken wrist and tuberculosis. He believes he has changed, absorbing maturity from his gamut of experience.

title: Now at a Theater Near You: That Disappointing Season
description: The summer ended on a melancholy note in Hollywood, which was far better than what was predicted.

title: Miller Adds Lucero/Bentz to Roster
description: The Miller Brewing Company has added an agency to its roster by naming Lucero/Bentz, a new shop in Dallas, to create advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers for Miller Lite beer. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Former Stars Seek More Safeguards for Present Ones
description: As children, they reaped success early -- perhaps too early. As adults, they paid a price, watching fame fade and struggling to remake careers. Now, motivated by their experiences, they have joined forces in what is at once an unusual self-help group and an even more unusual political lobby.

title: Summer in Woods Hole: Sea, Science and Synergy
description: As they bid farewell to their squid neurons, their global climate models or their late-night discussions of the microscopic mysteries of life, the summer scientists of Woods Hole do not wax maudlin at season's end. They are not the type.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GALSTON, NINA MOORE
description: GALSTON-Nina Moore. The service will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. on September 5, 1997 at 11 A.M.

title: People
description: * Gail Anne Grosso was named executive vice president and creative director at Evans Group, Seattle, succeeding Mike Mogelgaard, who was promoted to vice chairman and corporate creative director. Ms. Grosso had been senior vice president and creative director at Random House, New York, owned by Advance Publications.

title: Prosecution of Photographers Is Urged
description: A lawyer for Mohammed al-Fayed, the Egyptian-born millionaire whose son was killed in an automobile crash Sunday with Diana, Princess of Wales, called on prosecutors to bring the equivalent of involuntary homicide charges against photographers who he said had hounded the driver.

title: Physicists Find Exotic New Particle
description: PHYSICISTS working at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island believe they have discovered a previously unknown particle, which they call an exotic meson.

title: Days Of the Locust
description: Because of Princess Diana's death, tabloid journalists will be condemned for constantly invading the privacy of the rich and famous. Afterward they will keep right on doing it anyhow.

title: Q&A
description: AIDS and Mosquitoes

title: Driving Increases, as Do Gas Prices
description: With demand surging this summer, the price of gasoline at the pump just took one of its biggest monthly jumps ever. Even running their refineries full tilt, oil companies have barely kept up with the nation's drivers, who increasingly favor hefty, less efficient vehicles.

title: Brokerage Leases Office in Jersey City
description: In a coda to a government-subsidized deal that lured a foreign exchange company, Exco Noonan, to Manhattan from Jersey City, another New York company has taken over the office space that Exco Noonan abandoned in Jersey City.

title: Supporting Mir Is Money Lost in Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Welfare Gets Extra Aid For This Year
description: New York City's child welfare system will receive an additional $22.7 million in combined city, state and Federal aid this year to ease a shortage of beds in foster care that had forced more than 1,000 children to sleep on office floors since January, city officials said yesterday.

title: Piety Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Frontline of Norway Makes Offer for ICB
description: Frontline Ltd. of Norway said yesterday that it had offered about 3.0 billion Norwegian kroner ($400 million) for ICB Shipping A.B. of Sweden. The move would make Frontline one of the world's biggest tanker shipping companies. But ICB's directors rejected the offer, saying it was inadequate in light of ICB's profits and strong cash flow.

title: School by Satellite
description: Twenty-two New York City public schools have signed contracts totaling $1.4 million with Simon & Schuster to receive live, two-way educational programs delivered via satellite, starting this week.

title: In Word and Deed, Londoners Mourn a Family Member
description: Life in Britain's capital went on as usual today, at least in the sense that people went to work, subways and buses ran more or less on time, and stores -- even the redoubtable Harrods, owned by the father of Dodi Fayed, the man who was killed alongside Diana, Princess of Wales, early Sunday morning -- opened for business. But nothing really seemed the same.

title: McCann-Erickson Wins Hotel Account
description: Renaissance Hotels and Resorts in Washington, which was acquired in June by Marriott International, has named McCann-Erickson New York to handle its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million. The account had been handled by Bozell Worldwide in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPP, BARBARA C.
description: EPP-Barbara C. On August 31, 1997, of Bay Shore, N.Y. Loving sister of Carol E. Gibson. Devoted aunt of Cammy, Judie and Denise. Daughter of the late Harold B. and Claire Moran Epp. The family will receive friends at the George C. White Funeral Home, 364 E. Main Street, Bay Shore, N.Y. today 2-5, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 11 AM, at St. Patrick's RC Church, Bay Shore. Interment, St. Patrick's Cemetery, Bay Shore, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Patrick's Hospitality Center, 9 North Clinton Avenue, Bay Shore, New York 11706, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, LOUIS
description: SCHNEIDER-Louis, of Shelter Island, New York (formerly of New Jersey) on August 29, 1997. Retired vice-president of Mortgaging & Trust-Central Bank of New York. Survived by John and Martha Kirchner and Gunnar and Leonore Jensen. Private interment at Fairview Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey by DePriest Funeral Homes, Southold, Long Island.

title: Baptist Board Backs Leader In Face of Ethics Questions
description: In a pair of closed-door sessions, the leaders of the nation's largest predominantly black religious denomination gave their president a vote of confidence today, putting aside allegations of financial improprieties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ALEXANDER
description: SHAPIRO-Alexander. We extend our Kos Tanchumim to Barbara Joseph, member of the National Women's Division Board, on the lose of her beloved father. Together with her husband Manfred, the Josephs are Silver Founders of the Medical Center. Through their longtime support they have shown an extraordinary commitment to helping the mission of the ''Hospital With a Heart'' to heal the sick and ease the pain of the people of Jerusalem and Israel. This outstanding example of tzedekah and chesed, as demonstated by their devotion to Torat Yisrael, Am Yisrael and Eretz Yisrael, emulates the example set by Barbara's father. May the family have loving memories of this wonderful and caring man, and may be they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson Chairperson of the Board Menno Ratzker, President Sidney Adler, Treasurer Lee Weinbach, Secretary

title: As Tourism Rides Rails, New Barons Gain Clout
description: Town officials might have thought they had the final word in June when they refused a request by the Durango and Silverton tourist railroad for the exclusive right to sell photographs of tourists standing in front of the line's antique locomotives.

title: Trade Accords That Spread the Wealth
description: The contest at United Parcel Service may be over, but a much larger labor battle begins in just a few weeks when the Clinton Administration introduces a ''fast track'' bill to make it easier for the President to negotiate trade deals.

title: Fewer Inspectors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, ESTELLE
description: ROBBINS-Estelle. On August 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William, devoted mother of Joyce, Arthur, Leslie and Marvin. Adored grandmother of Eric, Michelle, Marc, Ronna, Warren and David. Cherished great-grandmother of Ariel. Loving sister of Irene, Sally, Lillian and Louis.

title: Korda Handles Pressure and Knocks Sampras Out
description: Mundane items like rainy days and Mondays aren't supposed to get a guy like Pete Sampras down, but there he was skirting the raindrops and locked in another five-set struggle with 15th-seeded Petr Korda yesterday in Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEADOW, VIRGINIA R.
description: MEADOW-Virginia R. On August 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Franklin Meadow. Loving mother of Dorothy Meadow Sobol and Carolyn Meadow Shechtman. Devoted grandmother of Emma, Julia and Edward Sobol and Jonathan Shechtman. Dear sister of Mildred Bellew Leonard. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, 3:30 PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Saybrook College, Yale University, Virginia R. Meadow Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVICO, MICHAEL
description: DAVICO-Michael. September 2, 1996. In loving memory of our father. You are always in our hearts. Sadly missed by Patricia, Daniel, Barbara, and Nicholas.

title: New Studies Reassess Importance of Biodiversity
description: IN recent years biodiversity, the number of different species in an ecosystem, has sometimes been treated like the Holy Grail. Researchers have shown that biodiversity leads to greater productivity and better retention of nutrients, both often interpreted as signs of ecosystem health.

title: 2 Men Assault and Rob Worker In a Subway Station in Brooklyn
description: A token booth worker at the Union Street station in Brooklyn was assaulted by robbers yesterday afternoon after collecting tokens from turnstiles during a shift change, the police said. The attack came as the authorities were seeking to improve security at token booths during shift changes, a time when robberies often occur.

title: Attention Disorder Is Found In Growing Number of Adults
description: For Sally Furbish, life once seemed almost unbearable. By the time she turned 30, she had attended five colleges, nearly set her house on fire and struggled to find her way driving from one town to the next. She had worked as a waitress and a flight attendant but seldom showed up on time.

title: Settlement Smokescreen?
description: To the Editor:

title: Everyone Has a Hand in Jet Success Story
description: Yes, that was Chuck Clements handing off at the end of the Jets' stunning 41-3 victory against the Seahawks at Seattle on Sunday.

title: Shoppers Welcome Week Without Tax on Clothing
description: For the Duncan and Daniels family of the Bronx, yesterday was not a day at the beach. With 3-month-old Samantha in tow, 13-year-old Jasmine preparing for eighth grade and several other children to clothe, it was a single-minded trip up the Avenue of Americas in Manhattan, from Old Navy to Modell's Sporting Goods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNISON, JANE LOWE
description: JENNISON-Jane Lowe. Departed peacefully August 26 at her home in Taftsville, VT., at 79. Formerly of Manhattan and Westport, Conn. She is survived by her husband Peter S. Jennison, a son Andrew & two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 4, 3 P.M., at St. James Episcopal Church, Woodstock, Vermont. Remembrance contributions may be made to the Norman Williams Public Library, Woodstock, Vermont.

title: 3 Centuries of South Carolina Tradition Woven Into Baskets
description: Amid the zips of sports cars, the drones of pickups and roars of tractor-trailers, a stretch of four-lane highway through the lowlands of South Carolina has been turned into a marketplace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOR, RALPH
description: CONNOR-Ralph. Age 87. Died peacefully August 29 in Seattle, WA., surrounded by his family. He made a lasting contribution to the community of Dutchess County, N.Y., as a friend and generous supporter of Oakwood Friends School, Vassar College, Vassar Brothers Hospital, Marist College and the Town of Union Vale. At the time of his death he was an active member and Trustee of the Board of Managers of Oakwood Friends School and Member of Bulls Head Friends Meeting. He is deeply missed and lovingly remembered by Curt and Lily Beck, John and Elizabeth Daniels, Junius and Lisa Ellis, and Justin and Deborah Scheer.

title: The Jets' New Post-Game Tactic: Modesty
description: When people here used to say, ''It's only one game,'' the words represented a bit of hope in the middle of a lot of dreadful football. But this sport has much to do with adjustments, and the Jets tried another one this afternoon at Weeb Ewbank Hall.

title: Whitman and Her Opponent Use Labor Day to Work the Crowds
description: After a weekend of greeting voters at beaches along the Jersey Shore, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and her Democratic challenger, James E. McGreevey, searched for votes in central New Jersey today at the Labor Day parade here.

title: A Good Meal, Plus
description: PITY the poor male firefly. First he is lured by a female of a related genus who flashes her light to signal that she is ready for sex. When the hapless male alights near her, she devours him. And when she does, she takes on his protective chemical armor, lucibufagins, which spiders find disgusting. Now the female is invulnerable to her hated predator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGIN, ANN
description: LAGIN-Ann, on September 1, 1997. Loving wife of the late Nathan. Beloved mother of Ellen and Marvin Ross, Arlene Lagin, Susan and Paul Feiwell, Steven Lagin, and the late Stanley Lagin. Cherished grandmother of Stanley and Karen, Randi and Brad, David, Debbie, Scott, Jill, Nathan, and Max, and greatgrandmother of Jonathan, Jenny, Jake, Nicole, and Alex. Service, today at 12:30 PM at Temple Beth El of Great Neck.

title: Deadly Maelstrom's Secrets Unveiled
description: ''The maelstrom! Could a more dreadful situation have sounded in our ears! We were then upon the dangerous coast of Norway. . . .

title: Let Consumers Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: East Asians Caution Japan on Taiwan's Role in U.S. Pact
description: SINGAPORE  As Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan prepares for a sensitive visit to China this week, other countries in East Asia have told Tokyo that they are deeply concerned by moves to have the strengthened U.S.-Japan alliance cover Taiwan.

title: Manhattan Endorsements
description: Primary elections will be held Tuesday, Sept. 9. This page will not endorse a mayoral candidate until the final vote in November. But many of the other races will be decided for practical purposes in next week's Democratic primaries. These are The Times's endorsements for some of the more competitive races in Manhattan.

title: Accounting Board Proposal On Derivatives Is Getting Heat
description: Ten years after it first began looking into the matter, the group responsible for establishing the nation's accounting standards has finally issued the draft proposal of a new rule that would require companies to report their use of derivatives -- those complex financial instruments like futures, swaps and options intended to protect against unforeseen risks.

title: At 35, Clemens Rises to Top of His Game
description: At the start of spring training last February, Roger Clemens was sitting in a Blue Jays conference room in Dunedin, Fla., in front of montages of 1992 and 1993 World Series memorabilia. Pointing to a ring in one of them, Clemens said it was his desire to play in another World Series that led him to Toronto.

title: Golf War Syndrome
description: The first rule for a successful round of golf, a Purdue University scientist says, is, ''Don't move anything from the turf to your mouth.'' This will not prevent hooks or slices, but then the scientist in question, Dr. Clark Throssell, is a professor of agronomy, not golf. His concern is advising golfers how to limit their exposure to some of the chemicals used to keep greens green.

title: Chess
description: A half-point separation becomes a vast difference in Swiss-system tournament prizes, where clusters of grandmasters can be closely bunched in the last round. Consider the World Open Tournament in Philadelphia over the July Fourth weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHENG, MICHAEL J.
description: CHENG-Michael J. on August 29, 1997, in Stamford, CT. Beloved husband of Theresa H. Cheng; loving father of Jason C. Cheng and Katherine A. Cheng, all of Stamford, CT. Loving son of George and Teresa Cheng of Chatham, NJ. Brother of Dr. David F. Cheng, Freeport, IL., Elizabeth A. CodolaCheng, Pawtucket, R.I. Funeral Wednesday, September 3, 11 AM, in Holy Spirit Church, Stamford, Conn. Burial at Queen of Peace Cemetery. Friends may call at the Gallagher Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT., 4-8 PM, Tuesday, September 2.

title: On Ancient Terraced Hills, Urbanism Sprouted With Crops
description: IN the high country of Yemen, long before the reign of the legendary Queen of Sheba, farmers terraced hillsides and prospered with crops of barley, wheat and sorghum. They produced tools and weapons from obsidian, the glassy rock found in the slopes. They also settled in walled villages, perhaps the earliest experience in urbanism in all the Arabian peninsula.

title: CHRONICLE
description: This is a tale of two Barneys and New York City, where one minute you're cooking up a batch of lox, eggs and onions, and the next, you're a celebrity.

title: A Teen-Ager Earns Attention
description: Yesterday's United States Open girls match between Jackie Trail and Brie Rippner was not just a first-round meeting of promising American teen-agers. It was something of a grudge match.

title: Recall This, Grillers Say: This Holiday Is for Meat
description: The all-American smells of lighter fluid, burning charcoal briquets and sizzling hamburger lofted pleasantly up from a small forest of carnivores, none of them fearful of a new American threat, red meat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, ABNER S.
description: HECHT-Abner S., on August 30, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Ethel. Devoted father of Jonathan. Loving brother of Grace Block and the late Muriel Feller. Services to be held on Tuesday, September 2 at 10 A.M., at Temple Israel Center, White Plains, N.Y. Interment Glenville Cemetery, Glenville, CT.

title: Sam Chase, 80, Retired Broadcasting Executive
description: Sam Chase, a broadcasting and publishing executive who won awards for programming dealing with civil rights, died of natural causes on Aug. 11 in Mexico, his son, Bradley, said. He was 80.

title: Economic Threat Of Aging Populace
description: The year is 2025. The nation has twice as many old people as it has children; its economy is groaning under the weight of heavy taxes; its population is shrinking, and the Government's reserve of social security funds has run dry.

title: Westminster Funeral
description: Diana's funeral will be held Saturday at Westminster Abbey, where sovereigns are crowned. She is to be buried at her ancestral home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LIBBY SHANA
description: MILLER-Libby Shana. On August 29, after receiving bad news about cancer spread this brave and noble woman who put up an extraordinary fight, finally decided she had had enough of ''unfair'' pain & suffering. Formerly of Manhattan, she had moved with her husband of 37 years, Alan, to San Francisco to ''make a new life.'' This did not happen! Loving mother of Elisa & Jennifer, and son-in-law Greg, daughter of Mabel, sister of Manny, she was an inspiration to all, an ardent defender of her family and a rock of support even in her terrible illness. Throughout her life, she had been a gentle but firm teacher, a mentor, a role model for an extraordinary number of young women and evoked tremendous loyalty from all who came in contact with her. She will be missed terribly. Services Tuesday September 2, 10AM at Plaza Memorial, 91 Street and Amsterdam Ave 212-769-4400.

title: Yanks' Talent Search Has Run Out of Time
description: When four of the hits, including a Tony Barron home run, came before an out could be made in the fourth, Yankees Manager Joe Torre had no choice but to extricate the pitcher from yet another disaster.

title: Back to the Showroom
description: For 20 years, Dial-a-Mattress has trumpeted the ease and convenience of buying bedding over the phone. But now the company is trying a more traditional approach: selling Sealy and Serta mattresses in person. In recent months, the company, based in Long Island City, Queens, has opened several stores and showrooms in New York and New Jersey.

title: Space-Jalopy Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Irradiated Food Is Too Pure for Our Own Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Weakened Immunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy, 10, Loses Hand As Firecracker Explodes
description: A 10-year-old boy in East New York, Brooklyn, was seriously injured Sunday night when one of the fireworks he was playing with exploded in his hand.

title: Public Likes Celebrity Photos But Hates the Photographers
description: With the freelance photographers known as paparazzi facing public outrage for their supposed role in the car crash here that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, photographers of all genres closed ranks today, contending that they were scapegoats for a public embarrassed over its insatiable appetite for intimate shots of celebrities.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, JUDITH
description: FURMAN-Judith. Devoted mother of Josh Furman and Julianne Ashkinaze. Dear sister of Miriam Marias. Loving grandmother of Michael, Jordana, Sarah, Alan and Lisa. Great-grandmother of four. Graveside services today 1 PM, at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Commerce Street, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Shell in $2 Billion Deal With Essar in India
description: Shell International Gas Ltd., a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, plans to invest $2 billion in India for the development of an integrated power plant and liquefied natural gas terminal at Hazira in the Indian state of Gujarat, the company said today.

title: Speeding Car Hits 4 Near S.I. Terminal
description: A married couple and two children walking from the Staten Island Ferry Terminal were injured Sunday night when they were hit by a speeding car, which then fled the scene. Two of those injured remained in critical condition yesterday.

title: America's Bureaucracy Keeps Adoptions Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LIBBY
description: MILLER-Libby. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the wife of our member, Dr. Alan Miller. May the entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ABRAHAM
description: LEVINE-Abraham. Formerly of NY. Husband of the late Rose (Ackman). Beloved father, grandfather, brother, uncle and granduncle. A brilliant lawyer and mentor, he was a benefactor to many, while taking pleasure in playing the role of curmudgeon. His memory will be cherished and he will be missed by many. Rest in peace, Uncle Abe. Sandy, Felicia, Marisa and Matt Pomerantz

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Somewhere I feel that the United States has come up very short on respect for the arts,'' LAUREN BACALL said. ''I just think we have to fight to keep the quality.''

title: Israel Eases Ban on Entry of Palestinian Workers
description: The Israeli Government today eased a ban on the entry of Palestinian workers into Israel, taking a first step to loosen a tight border closing imposed on the West Bank and Gaza Strip after a suicide bombing in Jerusalem in July.

title: Microwave Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: High Alcohol Level Is Reported in Diana's Driver
description: The Paris prosecutor's office said today that the body of the driver in the car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, early Sunday had a blood alcohol level well above the legal limit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: French Retailer in Bid To Buy 2 Competitors

title: Mexican President Pledges to Work With Congress
description: Facing a Congress controlled for the first time by opposition parties, President Ernesto Zedillo today pledged to respect the work of Mexico's newly-independent legislature and called on lawmakers to support free-market economic policies he said have fostered growth and modest new spending on schools and hospitals.
