title: Some Biologists Ask 'Are Genes Everything?'
description: FIFTY-THREE years ago, the physicist Erwin Schrodinger wrote a book called ''What is Life?'' in which he posed some of the deepest questions then imaginable about biology: What is the ''substance'' of heredity? When is a piece of matter said to be alive? What kind of process perpetuates genes?

title: Bounty Hunters Kill Couple In Case of Mistaken Identity
description: In a flurry of bullets early Sunday morning, at least five bounty hunters wearing ski masks forced their way into a house here and killed a couple who apparently did not know the bail jumper who was being sought.

title: A Late Bloomer Seeks His First Major Title
description: Petr Korda, the skinny left-hander who yesterday deprived Pete Sampras of the opportunity to win his third straight United States Open, has never won a Grand Slam singles title. But that is not because Korda lacks the ability to win one.

title: Some at Fed See a Test In New Data
description: Once again, the surprisingly robust economy is testing the limits of the Federal Reserve's pragmatic new approach to monetary policy.

title: John Eichorn Jr., 73, Executive Of Utility Company in Boston
description: John F. Eichorn Jr., a retired chairman and chief executive of Eastern Utilities Associates who played a significant role in completing the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire, died of cancer on Aug. 19. He was 73 and lived in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Lucy S. Howorth, 102, Dies; Lawyer, Politician, Suffragist
description: Lucy Somerville Howorth, a lawyer who said her advocacy of women's rights was inspired by the campaign that won women the vote under the 19th Amendment, died on Aug. 23 at her home in Cleveland, Miss. She was 102.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTRAN, CHARLOTTE KUEFER
description: OSTRAN-Charlotte Kuefer. Of Little Silver, NJ. On August 31, 1997. Wife of Howard Ostran. Mother of Howard K. Ostran. Sister of Beatrice Legeret. Grandmother of Christina, Michelle and Michael. Mother-in-law of Annette P. Ostran. Memorial gathering Thursday 7-8 P.M., at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, New Jersey.

title: Top Issue Is Car Insurance
description: Auto insurance is the top concern among New Jersey voters in this year's gubernatorial race, according to a new poll published yesterday.

title: Shamed by Excess, Then Shamed by Too Little
description: HAND TO MOUTH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, SHEPARD J.
description: KANTOR-Shepard J. The Officers and Members of the NY Psychoanalytic Society and Institute wish to express their profound sorrow about the untimely death of their esteemed young colleague, Dr. Shepard J. Kantor. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife, also our colleague, Dr. Arlene Heyman who, we know has gone through this long painful time of his illness. Condolences to Melissa, Jacob and Reuben. Dr. Edward S. Hartmann, President N.Y. Psychoanalytic Institute Dr. Lester Schwartz, President N.Y. Psychoanalytic Society

title: The Packers Wake Up With a Big Second Half
description: It was a slow start for the Green Bay Packers, especially for a team that has talked about a 19-0 season. The finish, however, was predictable.

title: International Petroleum To Get Offer From Sands
description: Sands Petroleum A.B. of Sweden said yesterday that it would offer 1.525 billion kroner ($192.5 million) to acquire the International Petroleum Corporation, bringing together the two main oil companies owned by the Lundin family. Sands said it would offer one new B share in Sands in exchange for 1.15 shares in International Petroleum, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia. Using the Friday closing price of both shares, the offer would be worth 34.6 kroner, or $4.37, a share, a discount of about 3 percent to the market price.

title: Help for College Expenses
description: Governor Whitman was to sign a bill today that would allow college-bound students from New Jersey to establish so-called trust accounts for college expenses without having to pay state tax on the interest.

title: When TV Fantasy Becomes Reality
description: For six years, Greg F. Fossella, a 59-year-old industrial designer in Osterville, Mass., put aside other projects to work on his pet obsession: an adjustable ratchet wrench that does away with the need for sockets. With adjustable jaws that allow the wrench -- called the Drives All -- to do the job of 30 different sockets, it seems like a tool lover's fantasy come true.

title: Putting On The Right Kind of Show
description: LET it be noted that the baptism of Arthur Ashe Stadium as a New York City tennis stage, as opposed to a glitzy corporate showcase, came on Day 8 of the United States Open, in a fourth-round match that began in the midday haze and ended under the misty evening lights. It ended with a raucous New York crowd begging Pete Sampras, by reputation a superstar who moves people to indifference, somehow to stick around for the rest of the week.

title: Arrest in Bridge Robbery
description: A New York City man was arrested yesterday afternoon after he robbed a toll taker on the Fort Lee side of the George Washington Bridge and then fled by motorcycle into Manhattan, bridge officials said.

title: Enhance Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Dispute Settled at Box Energy Corp.
description: The Box Energy Corporation's controlling shareholders settled their legal feud last week, clearing the way for the Idaho billionaire J. R. Simplot to buy their stake in the Dallas oil company for $21.5 million.

title: French Chain Bids $4.6 Billion for 2 Rivals
description: Promodes S.A., a big French retailer, said today that it had offered a total of 28 billion francs, or $4.6 billion, for two rivals. The acquisitions would make it the country's biggest retailer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, JOHN J.
description: O'ROURKE-John J. Suddenly on August 31, 1997. Beloved brother of Margaret, Catherine McCrink, Bernadette McDonough. Beloved long time friend of Margaret Weber. Also survived by 12 McCrink and McDonough nieces and nephews and 19 grandnieces and nephews. Reposing Monday and Tuesday 2-5 PM and 7-10 PM Conway Funeral Home, 83 Street and Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, NY. Funeral Mass at St. Joan of Arc Church, Wednesday 10:15AM, 83 Street and 35 Avenue, Jackson Heights, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTUCCI, AUGUST T.
description: MATTUCCI-August T. On August 9, 1997. Beloved brother of Helen Romano. Loving uncle of Gilda Todisco and Dr. Kenneth Mattuicci. Memorial service will be held at St. Robert Bellarmine Roman Catholic Church is on Saturday, September 6, 1997, at 9:45 A.M., followed by entombment of cremains at Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: 2 Cases Shed Light on Cigarette Smuggling in Italy
description: Smoking is such a part of Italian life that consumption is not measured in cigarettes, packs or cartons, but in tons -- more than 25,000 tons last year.

title: Asian-Americans Emerge As a Political Presence
description: Few would deny that the New York City Council's expansion to 51 members six years ago has achieved one stated goal: increasing representation among the city's ethnic and racial minority groups.

title: With Search for Chancellor, CUNY Is Changing Course
description: If there was any question that the City University of New York would be taken in a new direction with the departure on Sept. 15 of its Chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, the candidates for the job of interim chancellor should dispel the doubt. At least three of the people from within the CUNY system who are being considered have had significant differences with Chancellor Reynolds.

title: Stonewall in Congo
description: For months, the new Congolese Government of Laurent Kabila has been trying to thwart a United Nations investigation of ethnic killings and other human rights abuses during that country's recent civil war. The Security Council must now make clear that it has run out of patience with his obstructions. If that fails to inspire better cooperation, Washington should suspend its plans to provide generous aid to reconstruct the Congolese economy.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There's too much hypocrisy. Those who denounce the paparazzi today will be the first to buy the photos of the young princes crying at Lady Di's funeral.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, JEROME P.
description: FLYNN-Jerome P. On August 31, 1997. Beloved husband of Annabel (nee Midtbo). Beloved father of Thomas, Margaret Kelly, Dennis, Anne, Peter and the late John. Dear brother of the late Brother Dennis Flynn, C.F.X., and Brother Leroy Flynn, C.F.X. Loving grandfather of Alyson & Kathleen Kelly, Sereane Flynn, Flynn Gottselig & Damion Watkins. Mass Thursday, 10 A.M., Holy Name R.C. Church, Brooklyn. Visiting on Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5, 7-9 P.M., at M.J. Smith Sons, 248 Prospect Park West at Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to C.H.I.P.S. at 200-4th Avenue, Brooklyn 11217, in his memory.

title: New Stadium's Prices Not Quite Out of the Park
description: A Coke costs $3.50 at an Atlanta Braves baseball game.

title: Columbia/HCA Discussions on Cost Shifting Were Secretly Taped by U.S. Informants
description: Government informants in the criminal investigation of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation secretly recorded discussions about efforts to increase Federal reimbursements by shifting costs from some company hospitals onto home health care divisions.

title: New Wave of Designers Opening Stores in SoHo
description: Abutting the stern black and red brick walls of Marc Jacobs's new store in SoHo is the soft creamy white exterior of Marie-Anne Oudejans's Tocca boutique, where last month workers were perfecting walls the colors of mint and pistachio.

title: Schilling Shows the Yankees How It's Done
description: It was hot and humid at Veterans Stadium this afternoon. And much of the heat was coming from the pitcher's mound.

title: Weighing Time for New Little Mac
description: MEMBERS of the so-called Macintosh community get extremely touchy when anyone so much as hints that the Macintosh might not be the coolest, most elegant electronic device in the known universe. The Macintosh engenders a sort of fanaticism unknown among the competition; no one ever refers to a ''Windows community.'' But then, Windows users, who constitute the vast majority, tend not to think of themselves as members of some elite group.

title: INSIDE
description: A Resurgence for Labor

title: Hong Kong Stocks Extend Plunge, Falling 6.5% More
description: Local investors joined the panic to exit the Hong Kong stock market on Monday and again this morning, driving China-linked stocks down along with already battered blue-chip shares, and sending the benchmark Hang Seng index below where it was when the year began.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks were trading higher here today, after a decline on Monday. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei average of 225 stocks was up 181.62 points, or about 1 percent, at 18,155.92. On Monday, the Nikkei was down 255.12 points.

title: The Princess of the Common Touch
description: The announcement yesterday that the funeral for Diana, the Princess of Wales, will be a state event but not a full state funeral has a certain symmetry. The funeral is like the Princess herself -- full of paradoxes.

title: Parade Is Stumping Ground for Mayoral Candidates
description: Amid the clamor of steel drums and the aroma of roasting goat, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and three of the Democratic mayoral candidates joined thousands of celebrators in a march down Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn yesterday as this year's mayoral contest lent a political tone to one of New York City's largest and most exuberant ethnic celebrations: the West Indian American Day parade.

title: Door to Tolerance Opens Partway As Gay Life Is Emerging in China
description: On a side street not far from the waterfront, a small restaurant filled up one recent evening with customers, many of them gay. Some came to see a long-haired, cross-dressing singer perform, but more seemed happy just to find a place to relax and laugh.

title: More Food for Needy
description: Despite a slow start, a state program that gives surplus food to the needy will probably match last year's take, an official from the aid organization said late last week.

title: U.S. Bull Nears Age When Japan's Stumbled
description: Countries, like companies, take pride in rising stock prices. So it is no surprise that both corporate and government officials see the prolonged rise in stock prices -- to a level about 10 times where they were just over 15 years ago, when the bull market began -- as proof of the superiority of the nation's economic system. And it is no surprise that they are freely advising other countries that success will come from emulation.

title: The Babies From Yemen: An Enduring Mystery
description: For a few days last week, two ordinary Israeli women became an extraordinary news media sensation.

title: Patterns
description: The Return of Alaia

title: Ernest Schwarcz, 76, Dean at Queens College
description: Dr. Ernest Schwarcz, a dean emeritus at Queens College of City University who raised its continuing-education enrollment from dozens to thousands of older adults seeking degrees or just recharging their minds, died last Tuesday after being struck by a car near his home in Fresh Meadows, Queens. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKIN, DEWITT, JR.
description: PETERKIN-DeWitt, Jr., of Noroton, CT. Died August 29, 1997 of heart failure and complications related to Parkinsons Disease. He was 84. Mr. Peterkin is survived and missed by his wife Katharine Urban, two daughters Clare and Kate, three sons DeWitt III, George, and Patrick and his wife Jennifer and three grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Jane Gurney and his brother John Peterkin. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 5 at 11 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Rd., Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The American Parkinson's Association, 1250 Hyland Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10305-1946 or to Waveny Care Center Employee Fund, 3 Farm Rd., New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: Trying to End Road Rage
description: Hoping to curb accidents in a state with some of the nation's worst traffic, New Jersey traffic and police officials are to meet today in Woodbridge to devise ways to calm aggressive and reckless drivers.

title: Possible New Subspecies of Chimpanzee Identified
description: THE family tree of the common chimpanzee, the closest animal relative of humans, may need revision. Research by a team of New York anthropologists shows that a little-known population of the primate in the West African countries of Nigeria and Cameroon is genetically distinct from other chimpanzees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASHUK, DORIS
description: KASHUK-Doris. Left this world Sunday, August 31, 1997. She was comfortable at home in the loving care of her family. Although Doris rarely spoke of her illness, she corageously battled cancer for more than a year. Beloved mother and best friend of Barbara; devoted mother or Richard and mother-inlaw of Nuna; cherished grandmother of Reesa. She has earned a peacefully rest with her adoring husband Jerry and loving mother Mollie. Services, 1:15 PM, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Memorial contributions to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, Yorktown Hts, NY 10598.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLEN, BERTHA
description: CALLEN-Bertha. On August 31, 1997. Devoted mother of Richard Callen of New York and Judy Rosenberg of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Adoring granny of Pamela and Robin Rosenberg. Dear sister and Aunt. Funeral service on Tuesday 12 PM, at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, EDWARD F.
description: MEYER-Edward F. On August 29, 1997, of Baldwin, LI, formerly of Briarwood, NY. Beloved husband of Claire (nee Moore). Adored father of Colleen Vasicovschi and Kathleen Meyer. Cherished grandfather of six. Friends may call at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 20 Lincoln Avenue, Rockville Centre, LI, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Joint Venture in Auto Lighting Systems
description: Valeo S.A., the world's biggest producer of car lighting systems, and Osram Sylvania, a United States unit of Siemens A.G., have agreed to create a joint venture that would be the biggest North American producer of auto lighting systems.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: TAXES, NO. LINES, YES -- The calendar may have said September but for many retailers it seemed more like December as families flocked to stores to take advantage of a tax-free week. Metro Business, B5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPOSE, HANNAH (HELEN)
description: PEPOSE-Hannah (Helen). Of Kings Point, Tamarac, FL. (Formerly of Jamaica Estates, NY). Much beloved mother, grandmother, sister, sister-in-law and aunt, passed away peacefully on Sept. 1 at age 73, to join her late husband Harry after a brave battle with breast cancer at the home of her daughter and son-inlaw, Drs. Maura & Paul Copeland of Swampscott, MA. Also survived by a son, Prof. Jay S. Repose, MD, Ph.D. and daughter-in-law, Susan Feigenbaum, Ph.D.; brothers: Julius Saltzman & Irving Saltzman, attorney and sister-in law Rae; 7 grandchildren: David, Marnine, Daniel, Morissa, Maxwell, Samuel & Harry; nephews: Alan Saltzman, Robert I. Saltzman, MD and his wife Kathy, niece Arlene Berkman and her husband Milton Berkman, DMD, grandnephew, Seth, grandnieces Lysa and Lauryn Saltzman and their mother, Diane. She will be greatly missed by her loving family and many devoted friends. Most appreciated, donations in her memory to: North Shore Cancer Center Foundation, 81 Highland Avenue, Salem, Mass. 01970. Services Wednesday, September 3, at 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, BLANCHE
description: DIAMOND-Blanche, on September 1, 1997 age 74. Beloved sister of Lewis R. Diamond and the late Philip Diamond. An enthusiastic devotee of Lincoln Center and all of its artistic forms. She will be missed by all the regulars. For information, call Gutterman's, 516764-9400.

title: After a Funeral Befitting a Princess, Diana Will Be Buried at Her Family Home
description: The funeral for Diana, Princess of Wales, will be on Saturday in Westminster Abbey, the crowning and burial place of English sovereigns for nearly 1,000 years, in a ceremony described by the royal household as ''a unique funeral for a unique person.''

title: Why will a pin pierce the Stones logo? And why are those Cover Girls spicing it up this fall?
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.

title: Governor's Daughter Injured
description: Kate Whitman, the daughter of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, was injured yesterday when she was hit by a car while jogging in South Africa, a spokeswoman said.

title: Many Small Events May Add Up to One Mass Extinction
description: DID the mass extinctions that have punctuated the history of life on this planet have a common cause, or were they just statistical fluctuations nudged to extremes by many unrelated causes?

title: One Mother's Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZ, BRONIA REITMAN
description: KURZ-Bronia Reitman. On September 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Fritz. Devoted mother of Rina Pianko & son-in-law Howard. Loving grandmother of Noam, Daniel and Gideon. Services on Tuesday 3 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Project Ezra, 197 East Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10034.

title: Era May Be Ending for Big Local Banks
description: When Barnett Banks said on Friday that it would be acquired by Nationsbank for $15.5 billion, it was a strong signal that even the powerful Florida sun may be setting on the era of regional banking as a handful of national giants emerge.

title: Chinese Bank May Buy Stake in Jardine Unit
description: The Jardine Fleming Group, a brokerage firm closely identified with 156 years of British colonial rule in Hong Kong, is negotiating to sell a stake in its banking unit to a bank controlled by the Chinese government.

title: Libraries Invite Users to Check Out Their New Cafes
description: As a library director, Maxine A. Bleiweis had a special perspective on the success of the mega-bookstores that have been cropping up across America. She saw people using them as if they were libraries.

title: Manhattan Dinners From Great Chefs Around the Country
description: When John A. Halligan, the executive chef of Halcyon, a luxury restaurant in midtown Manhattan, set out to organize a series of dinners featuring some of the top chefs from around the country, he wasn't sure how it would go over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIGNEY, DOROTHY ANNE
description: HAIGNEY-Dorothy Anne. Church, charitable and community leader. Beloved wife of John E. Haigney, yachtsman and attorney, partner at Ide Haigney & Rado, Chairman of the Board and former President of Rheingold Corporation. Cherished mother of Anne Roome, Kathlyn Haigney Krims, Stacy, Mark, Paul, Jennifer and Courtney Haigney. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York, Tuesday and Wednesday, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial, 10 AM, Thursday, at St. Augustine Church, Larchmont, New York.

title: Electronica in the Handy Take-Home Packs
description: Big Top, which had been touted as electronica's version of the Lollapalooza Festival, bypassed the New York City area when its stop on Sunday night at Asbury Park, N.J., was canceled at the last minute. Playing electronica on a home sound system is a distant second choice to experiencing it in its element, on a crowded dance floor, with overwhelming sound and lights. But it does offer a chance to carry the music into daily life, and to distinguish between a momentary thrill and a lasting pleasure. The albums reviewed below are recent releases by some of Big Top's attractions.

title: At 30, Caribbean Festival Is Bursting at Seams
description: Carlos Mateo flew in from Santo Domingo, bringing his good, sharp machete to hack sugar cane at a friend's juice stand. Will Crenshaw, a Trinidadian assistant manager of a rental car agency, drove from Baltimore, as he has for the last three years. And Vallic Weekes, 16, came all the way from Montserrat on his first-ever trip to New York City, where he displayed both his intricate dancing skills and his slack-jawed amazement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASHUK, DORIS
description: KASHUK-Doris. Left this world Sunday, August 31, 1997. She was comfortable at home in the loving care of her family. Although Doris rarely spoke of her illness, she corageously battled cancer for more than a year. Beloved mother and best friend of Barbara; devoted mother of Richard and mother-inlaw of Nuna; cherished grandmother of Reesa. She has earned a peaceful rest with her adoring husband Jerry and loving mother Mollie. Burial was Tuesday. Visiting hours at home, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial contributions to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, Yorktown Heights, New York 10598.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LAWRENCE
description: GROSS-Lawrence. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Lawrence Gross beloved husband of Phyllis. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Abandoned Infants in Care
description: Two newborn babies abandoned over the holiday weekend have been placed in the custody of the State Division of Youth and Family Services, officials said yesterday. As soon as the baby boys are released from the hospital, the agency will place them with foster parents who want to adopt them, said Wendi Patella, a spokeswoman for the Department of Human Services. The babies are healthy but are undergoing routine medical tests, she said.

title: Rand McNally To Sell Control
description: Rand McNally, the world's largest commercial map maker, said today that it had agreed to sell a controlling interest to AEA Investors of New York for an undisclosed amount.

title: Bond Prices Rally After Purchasing Report
description: Bonds rallied yesterday after a weaker-than-expected manufacturing report helped eased concerns that the Federal Reserve would need to raise interest rates soon to rein in the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEEUWKES, LAMBERT BAER
description: BEEUWKES-Lambert Baer, of Atlanta, GA passed away August 31, 1997 in Atlanta. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor B. Beeuwkes; son and daughter-in-law, Foster L. and Adrienne Beeuwkes and grandchildren Foster II & Nicholas Beeuwkes. A memorial service will be held Saturday, Sept. 6 at 1:30 P.M., at The Cathedral of St. Philip in Atlanta, GA. Born in Baltimore, educated at Baltimore Poly. Inst. & Johns Hopkins University, Lambert Beeuwkes was retired from the National Broadcasting Company where he had been Director of Network Radio Sales. Previously, Mr. Beeuwkes worked at Ford-Stout, Fokker and Glen Martin on aeronautical design. Later, he was the personal manager of The Lone Ranger and in the broadcasting industry, station management at KYW, WXYZ and WLAW before joining N.B.C. The family has requested that in lieu of flowers, a contribution be made in Lambert's name to the American Heart Association.

title: Militia Family Life, Before It Goes Undercover
description: To judge by tonight's visit with two families belonging to or constituting the Rocky Mountain Militia, its members love their children and their guns, fear and hate the Federal Government and can do without blacks (one says of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., ''We should celebrate the day he got shot'') and Jews (''Have a white Christmas and a Jew-free New Year'').

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAROSA, DR. WILLIAM
description: DELAROSA-Dr. William, of Voorhees, NJ, Thursday, August 28, 1997. Beloved father of Kate DeLaRosa of Voorhees, N.J., son of Blanche DeLaRosa of Morristown, N.J., brother of Ronald DeLaRosa of Parsippany, NJ. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church of Whippany, New Jersey, Saturday, September 6, 1997, at 1:00 PM. No hours of visitation. Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Avenue, Morristown, NJ. for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLON, MARGARET A.
description: MULLON-Margaret A., of Port Washington, New York and Boca Raton, Florida, on August 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Walter B. Mullon. Dear and loving mother of Mary Pat Schermerhorn, Kevin, Kathleen Gerber, Walter, Jane Ruane and Deborah Sherman. Also survived by 19 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Memorial Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10:30 AM, St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington, NY. Memorial contributions to Hospice Care Network, 128 West Main Street, Bay Shore, NY 11706 or St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31 Street, New York, NY 10001.

title: N.Y. Police Culture Has Changed for Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENAMY, TAMAR
description: BENAMY-Tamar. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Avivah on the untimely death of her beloved daughter Tami. Friends and Alumni of Gymnasia Herzelia

title: Weight Watchers Suspends Campaign
description: Because of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, Weight Watchers International has suspended a multimillion-dollar television campaign that began on Monday featuring Sarah, the Duchess of York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEA, PETER L.
description: SHEA-Peter L. A memorial service will be held at St. Dominic's Church, Oyster Bay, Long Island New York on Friday, September 5 at 10 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about a plan by Teco Energy Inc. to sell a subsidiary, Teco Oil and Gas, misidentified the business that had net income of $65.3 million in the third quarter of 1996. It was Teco Energy, not Oil and Gas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, NAT
description: ZUCKER-Nat. On September 2, 1997. Resident of Manhattan for all his more than 92 years. Survived by his wife of 67 years, two sons, one daughter, five grandchildren and five great grandchildren.

title: Wild-Card Investors Lost-Cause Rebels?
description: So Major League Baseball, in its infinite wisdom, abandoned its position as the keeper of meaningful championships and instead created wild cards. The new system, the rebels-in-charge explained, would maintain interest later into the season among fans in many more cities because their teams would have a chance to reach the playoffs by way of the wild-card route.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN HAMEL, DIEDERIK A.
description: van HAMEL-Diederik A. of Woodstock, NY age 86, former Consul General of the Netherlands in New York from 1966 until 1972 died August 31, 1997. Surviving are his wife Manette Cramer van Hamel, three children, Alfred, Willem, and Martine van Hamel. Funeral services were private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLHAUSEN, MARIE LOUISE
description: OLHAUSEN-Marie Louise of Bedminister, NJ, on Sunday, August 31, 1997. Wife of the late Joseph H. Olhausen. Mother of Sally Mathewson of Basking Ridge and Ethel O. Brady of Summit. Also survived by three grandchildren. Memorial service at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone, NJ, on Friday, September 5, at 11:00 a.m. Private interment. St. Bernard's Cemetery, Bernardsville. Memorial contributions may be made to Morristown Memorial Hospital, 100 Madison Ave., Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the stressful lives of some child actors misstated the medical history of the actress Mary McDonough, who played the middle sister, Erin, on ''The Waltons.'' Ms. McDonough said she developed eating disorders, not alcoholism.

title: Congo Misses Deadline In U.N. Investigation
description: The Foreign Minister of Congo has told Secretary General Kofi Annan in a telephone conversation that obstructions raised last week to the investigation of alleged killings in the eastern part of the country have been lifted, the United Nations spokesman said today.

title: Whitman's Child Released
description: Governor Whitman's daughter, Kate, who was cut and bruised when she was hit by a car on Monday while jogging in South Africa, was released from a hospital yesterday, her mother said. Although she has spoken several times on the phone with her 20-year-old daughter, Mrs. Whitman acknowledged that ''the verbal hug is not as good as the real thing.''

title: Woman Is Rescued From Subway Tracks
description: A 50-year-old woman was pushed onto the subway tracks at Grand Central Station yesterday morning by a man who was apparently angry because he believed that she had blocked his path and caused him to miss a train, the police said.

title: Bankers Trust Adds Trade Center Office
description: In an expansion from its 41-story headquarters, Bankers Trust Company is moving about 1,000 workers across Liberty Street to 4 World Trade Center, where it leased 274,000 square feet from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARDELL, WILLIAM
description: SARDELL-William. Beloved husband of Martha. Devoted father of Alice Catchen and Lucy Sardell. Dear brother of Harry. Loving grandfather of Molly and Rachel. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, N.J., Thursday 11 A.M.

title: Europe Agency Takes On The Fight for Democracy
description: In her political showdown with the former Bosnian Serb President, the current President, Biljana Plavsic, has asked the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to run legislative elections among the Bosnian Serbs in October.

title: Promus and Doubletree Hotel Companies Will Merge
description: The Promus Hotel Corporation and the Doubletree Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to a merger that would create one of the biggest hotel companies in the world, with combined revenue of $5 billion.

title: Lycos Expects Patent on Web Index Method
description: Lycos Inc. said today that it expected to receive a patent for Web-data indexing technology in the next few months and was preparing to demand licensing payments from other Internet-search companies using the technology.

title: Stocks Roar Into September, With the Dow Surging 257.36
description: After suffering through a turbulent August selloff, the stock market roared back to life yesterday, posting some of the biggest gains of the decade.

title: A Resurgent California Finds All That Glitters Is Its Future
description: When demographers at the California Department of Finance finished their annual analysis of drivers' licenses last month, they found a shining nugget of good news for the Golden State: for the first time since 1991, more Americans moved to California than left it to live in other states.

title: Central Europe's Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, JOHN J.
description: O'ROURKE-John J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of John J. O'Rourke a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Victor D. Ziminsky, Jr., President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Outlaw Bounty Hunters
description: To the Editor:

title: Returning To the Scene Of the Heist
description: NEARLY 11 years later, Roger Clemens climbed the hill at Shea Stadium again. This time, Mookie Wilson could do precious little harm to Clemens's team, unless he suddenly discovered new powers for a first-base coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIEGER, LOUIS
description: KRIEGER-Louis, age 92, on August 28, of Brooklyn, New York. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Judith and Martin, father-in-law of Marc. Dear brother of Ida. Loving grandfather of Jennifer, Joseph and David.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLGER, JOHN
description: BOLGER-John, of Littleton, Aug. 30, Colonel USAF Ret. Husband of Mary (Calhoun) Bolger of Littleton, also survived by 7 children. John (and Lorraine) of Cornwell N.Y., Patrick (and Nancy King) of Holliston, MA., Margaret (and Edward) Matthews of Groton, MA. Kathleen (and Richard Duggan) of Manhattan, Michael of Manhattan, Maureen (and Keith) Woods of Littleton and Paul of West Palm Beach, FL. In addition he is survived by his brother Philip (and Gloria) of Annapolis, MD. Five grandchildren, four nieces, eight nephews and countless friends. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Fri. at Sacred Heart Church, Main Rd., Cutchogue, N.Y. at 10 A.M. Burial in Sacred Heart Cemetery, Cutchogue, N.Y. For information contact Badger Funeral Home, Littleton, MA. 508-486-3709.

title: Bronx and Queens Endorsements
description: Next Tuesday's primaries will be more important than the November finale in many parts of New York City with overwhelming Democratic majorities. These are our endorsements for some of the more competitive races in the Bronx and Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRK, (BUCHLER) EVELYN U. (PH.D)
description: SHIRK-(Buchler) Evelyn U. (Ph.D), of Garden City, Long Island, NY, on August 24, 1997. Wife of Justus Buchler, Ph.D., who died in 1991; beloved mother of Katherine Buchler, Ephrata, PA; sister of Marilyn Forman, Atlanta, GA. A professor of Philosophy, Hofstra University for forty years; a published author; a Daughter of the American Revolution. A private memorial service will be held. Memorials to: The Philosophy Dept., Heger Hall, Room 104, 115 Hofstra University, Hempstead, NY 11549, or The National Wildlife Federation, 8925 Leesburg Pike, Vienna, VA. 22184.

title: An Intimate Experience For Players and Audience
description: The towers of lower Manhattan sway gently as you watch from a barge rocking against its moorings close by the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn Bridge. At first, gray outlines against the plum-and-yellow evening sky, those towers turn into brilliant multifaceted lighthouses during the course of a Brahms sonata.

title: In the 32d Council District, a Familiar Name Faces a Fierce Primary Race
description: The name Addabbo is steeped in the political history of New York, particularly in southeastern Queens. And in his current race for the City Council, Joseph P. Addabbo Jr. spares no effort to remind voters of the legacy of his father, a powerful United States Representative who helped shape national defense policy.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL AND PENNCORP END MERGER PACT
description: The Washington National Corporation and Penncorp Financial Group Inc., insurance holding companies, have mutually terminated their merger agreement, Washington National said yesterday. It said they were discussing a possible restructuring of the acquisition. But two extensions of their merger talks proved fruitless, and Washington National said it was in its ''best interests'' to explore other options. In November 1996, the companies announced that Penncorp had agreed to acquire Washington National for about $400 million and planned to merge it into its operations. Washington National is based in Lincolnshire, Ill., and Penncorp Financial is in Raleigh, N.C.

title: Fund Manager Fined $500,000
description: A unit of Paine Webber Group Inc. agreed today to pay a $500,000 fine to regulators for fraudulently misleading investors about the volatility of a Paine Webber mutual fund that incurred significant losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABONACK, C. JOHN
description: LABONACK-C. John, August 31st. Pres., Plaza Tool & Die Co. His skills and knowledge as designer, engineer, master craftsman, were generously shared. Purple Heart veteran W.W. II, devoted to community and country. A.S.I.

title: Food Notes
description: Vinegar Factory Expands

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACSON, PAUL
description: ISAACSON-Paul. Husband of the late Paula, father of Steven, Alan, Gene and Clare. Grandfather and great-grandfather. Brother of Elaine and uncle. Service is on Wednesday, 11:30 A.M., at ''The Boulevard-Riverside Chapels,'' 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, VICTOR B., PH.D.
description: MEYER-Victor B., Ph.D., 76, organic chemist, on August 31st. We have lost a brilliant mind tragically destroyed by Alzheimer's disease. In profound sorrow: his beloved wife of fifty years, Evelyn; cherished sons, Dan and Jonathan; devoted sister and brother-in-law, Gloria and Benjamin Rothberg. His passion for learning lives. Memorial service at a later date. Plant a perennial in his memory.

title: Queen of Soul Food Taking 'Down Home' On the Road
description: THE scene on the broad, cracked sidewalk outside Sylvia's Restaurant in Harlem looked like the opening of a department store sale, as tourists from around the world, in sneakers, shorts and T-shirts, along with other diners in waiting, some in their Sunday best, anticipated the moment when they could surge inside.

title: Stocks Roar Back; Dow Climbs 257.36
description: After suffering through a steep August selloff, the stock market roared back to life yesterday, posting some of the biggest gains of the decade.

title: The Princess and CBS
description: In a weekend consumed by news related to the death of the Princess of Wales, the question most asked inside network newsrooms has been, what happened to CBS?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRASER, ALISTAIR GRAEME
description: FRASER-Alistair Graeme, retired Clerk of the House of Commons, at Ottawa, on September 1, 1997, after a brief illness. Born at Toronto, January 5, 1923, son of the late Jane Graeme (Ross) and the late Hon. Alistair Fraser. Educated at schools in Montreal and Shawnigan Lake, B.C. He served as a Lieutenant in the Royal Canadian Artillery from 1942 to 1945. He graduated with a B.A. from McGill University (1947), an LL.B. from the University of British Columbia (1950) and was called to the Bar of B.C. in 1951. After briefly practising law in Prince Rupert, he embarked on a lengthy and distinguished career in the public service of Canada, serving successively as executive assistant to the Minister of Fisheries (1952) to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (1959) to the Secretary of State (1963) and to the Minister of Transport (1964). In 1966 he was appointed Clerk Assistant and in 1967 Clerk of the House of Commons, retiring in 1979. During his tenure as Clerk, he was actively involved in developing the Parliamentary internship program and the implementation of televised proceedings of the House of Commons. He was a co-author of the 5th and later editions of Beauchesne's Parliamentary Rules and Forms.

title: Hospitals Serving the Poor Struggle to Retain Patients
description: On a cloudy Saturday this summer, two teen-agers gave birth in this West Texas border town.

title: It's Uphill for 2 Trying Not to Be Also-Rans for Mayor
description: A man wearing a double-breasted suit and a broad smile strode amid the canned beans and Pampers at a market in Lefrak City in Queens, handing out smudgy photocopied fliers and telling shoppers, ''I'm Eric Ruano-Melendez, and I'm running for mayor.''

title: Preussag to Buy Hapag-Lloyd in Shift From Metal
description: Preussag A.G. said today that it had agreed to buy Hapag-Lloyd A.G. for 2.78 billion marks, or $1.5 billion, shifting its focus from coal and metals to shipping and the fast-growing tourism business.

title: South Africans Reaching Out for Olympic Gold
description: The Olympics have always been good for graphics at indicating, for example, to the linguistically befuddled that ''the Greco-Roman wrestling is this way.''

title: 'Covenant Marriages' Strengthen Commitments
description: To the Editor:

title: Miso Goes Beyond Japanese Cooking
description: NEW YORKERS have embraced the corner sushi bar -- as well as the loftier Japanese restaurants -- so vigorously that you'd think few big mysteries about Japanese cuisine could remain. But many Westerners seem to know almost nothing about miso, a fermented soybean paste as ubiquitous in Japan as olive oil is in the Mediterranean.

title: Spirlea's Word Is as Good As Gold
description: The promise was made in the spring of 1996 on a Florida freeway.

title: Agassi's Comeback Bid Fades Against Rafter
description: Andre Agassi, that soothing vision in pink, wasn't in the pink last night at the United States Open. Unseeded and, he hoped, underrated, the 66th-ranked Agassi was praying to come down with an incurable case of deja vu and reprise his impossible journey to the Open's 1994 championship, the Grand Slam he won despite being unseeded. But last night Agassi, who had not yet faced a seeded player, much less one sporting a samurai's topknot, ran into trouble in the form of 13th-seeded Patrick Rafter of Australia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MO
description: KATZ-Mo. On August 31, 1997. A man of many parts. Enormously gifted in intellect, artistic in temperament, & forthright in manner, Mo Katz was a loving husband of Mary Jane Koren, a fiercely proud father of Zev and Ivon Katz and devoted grandfather of Nicholas Katz. He was a tenacious friend and mentor to many outside his family. A senior New York City hospital administrator for most of his professional career, Mo earned a national reputation as an industry leader. He was an unmitigated idealist, endowed with a keen sense of what was doable, and the intuitive ability to engage others in achieving it. Mo was most of all a humanist who loved to tell stories as a way of expressing the ironies & triumphs of daily living. He always made his point. His was a fearless spirit-one that animated us all. Memorial services will be held on Tuesday September 23 at 6PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue & 76 St. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name may be made to Amnesty International, 322 8th Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10001.

title: LAIDLAW PLANS TO BUY GREYHOUND CANADA FOR $72 MILLION
description: Laidlaw Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Greyhound Canada Transportation Corporation of Calgary, Alberta, for about $100 million (Canadian), or $72 million (United States). Laidlaw, based in Burlington, Ontario, said it would pay $5.50 (Canadian) a share for Greyhound Canada's 11.2 million shares outstanding in a cash tender offer. The remainder of the purchase price represents stock options and the assumption of debt. Laidlaw, which has interests in transportation, said it would integrate its intraprovincial bus service with Greyhound. The deal is conditional on Greyhound's stopping its air service, which it plans to do on Sept. 21.

title: Rudolf Bing, Titan of the Met, Dies at 95
description: Sir Rudolf Bing, who as the dapper and acerbic general manager of the Metropolitan Opera from 1950 to 1972 ushered the company into the modern era and into Lincoln Center, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. He was 95 and lived at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale in the Bronx.

title: Jet Leaser Places 126-Plane Order
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation has ordered a total of 126 aircraft, valued at $8.5 billion, from Airbus Industrie and the Boeing Company, in the latest sign that the market for jetliners remains robust.

title: Death And the Maiden
description: The New Age Princess did not have to contend with lumpy mattresses, fire-snorting dragons, evil magicians and impudent swineherds wanting to steal kisses.

title: Share Cost, Company Says
description: The artists who were evicted from a mercury-contaminated building in Hoboken last year should pay part of the estimated $14 million cost of cleaning up the site, the General Electric Company said in court papers filed yesterday. General Electric once made mercury-vapor lamps in the building.

title: School Lunches: When They Love Even the Greens
description: MENTION school nutrition, and most people think of ladies in hairnets dishing out dry meatloaf and overcooked spinach or dull lessons on the four food groups.

title: More Downs and Walters
description: Since 1984, Hugh Downs and Barbara Walters have been the anchors of the Friday night news magazine ''20/20'' on ABC. Starting next week, they will be the anchors of the new Thursday edition of the program too, ABC News announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONENFELD, MURRAY
description: DONENFELD-Murray. On 9/1/97. Beloved husband of Evelyn, father of Sharon and Melvin, brother of Harvey and Belle, loving grandfather. Service on Wednesday, 12:30 PM, at the Schwartz Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Queens, N.Y.

title: U.S. Budget Analysis Predicts Shift to Big Surpluses in 2002
description: In the first authoritative analysis of the new tax and spending bills signed by President Clinton, the Congressional Budget Office said today that the measures would not only balance the Federal budget, but also generate substantial surpluses after 2001.

title: High School Shortstop Could Prove a Bargain
description: The Mets have agreed to terms with the third-round draft pick Cesar Crespo, a tremendous coup for the team.

title: BTG TO ACQUIRE MICROS-TO-MAINFRAMES FOR $25 MILLION
description: BTG Inc. of Fairfax, Va., said that it planned to acquire Micros-to-Mainframes Inc. for $25 million in cash and stock -- the equivalent of about $5.58 a share -- to expand its business with private-sector companies. Under the agreement, BTG would pay half in cash and half in BTG stock for Micros-to-Mainframes, a network-integration company based in Valley Cottage, N.Y. BTG reported revenue of $400 million for the year that ended on March 31, while Micros-to-Mainframes reported $58 million for 1997. BTG shares rose 37.5 cents, to $13.50, while Micros-to-Mainframes shares rose 12.5 cents, to $4.9375.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: TWO boys of about 5 are digging a moat on the beach of the Washington Club on Lake Waramaug in Litchfield County, Conn. One boy scurries between the moat and the lake, lugging buckets of water. The other squats beside the moat, overseeing the job. Each time a bucket of water is poured into the moat, creamy froth spreads across the surface of the cinnamon-brown water.

title: Gore's Presence At Fund-Raiser Called Innocent
description: Two days before campaign-finance hearings that are sure to put Vice President Al Gore in a harsh spotlight, the White House mounted a public relations offensive today to show that his appearance last year at a Buddhist temple fund-raiser was an innocent mistake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEARNEY, D. BERNARD
description: KEARNEY-D. Bernard, 88, retired President of the Torsion Balance Company, Clifton, NJ and a national harness racing figure, died after a long illness at Santa Barbara, CA. on August 26th. Born in Sydney, Australia, Bernie was married to Eleanor (Midge) Burkhard of Los Angeles who died in 1981. They are survived by their children: Denis B. Kearney of Hayward, California; Terrence J. Kearney of McLean, Virginia, and Kathleen T. Kearney of San Francisco; and by their 9 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a donation in Bernie's name to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNNISON, WALTER BALFOUR
description: GUNNISON-Walter Balfour. On Aug. 31, at his home in Sacramento, CA. Born Canton, NY, February 21, 1910. He is survived by his son, Robert B. Gunnison; daughter-inlaw, Jan Turner Gunnison; and granddaughters, Katherine Poste Gunnison, Emelie Carpenter Gunnison, and Anne Turner Gunnison. Services are private.

title: Ratings and Death
description: Ratings soared for all aspects of the coverage of the death of Diana. For example, ratings of the network morning news programs on Monday all jumped by 20 to 30 percent over the previous week. The Sunday morning news-maker shows were up by as much as 60 percent.

title: New Year's Day Arrives, in Minds of Many
description: For many people, the real New Year's Day began yesterday at 9 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATTAGLIA, LOUIS
description: BATTAGLIA-Louis. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Louis Battaglia, associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1992.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ALEXANDER
description: SHAPIRO-Alexander. Died Aug. 29, 1997, at his home in his 94th year. Beloved husband to the late Rose for over 65 years, father of Irwin (Ruth) Shapiro and Barbara (Manfred) Joseph, grandfather of Paula and Howard Friedman, Deborah & Warren Hammerschlag, Michael & Faiga Joseph, Samuel & Monica Shapiro, David Joseph, Jonathan Shapiro & bride-to-be Hannah, and fifteen great grandchildren. He was Founder and Chairman of ALRO. Throughout his life he insisted on real values and taught this lesson to his family. He will surely be missed.

title: GRR HOLDINGS TO BUY GROUND ROUND AT $1.65 A SHARE
description: GRR Holdings L.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the shares of Ground Round Restaurants it does not already own for $18.7 million, or $1.65 a share, in cash. GRR Holdings, which was formed by Boston Ventures, a private investment partnership, now owns 4.9 percent of the shares outstanding. In July, U.S. Industries of Iselin, N.J., sold its remaining 27.7 percent stake in Ground Round to a partnership led by two of U.S. Industries executives: Christian Guntner and David DiPasquale. The partnership has agreed to tender its 3.2 million shares. Ground Round, based in Braintree, Mass., operates 121 and franchises 41 restaurants from the Northeast to the Midwest. Its shares closed yesterday at $1.625, up 12.5 cents.

title: Incyte and SmithKline Form Venture in Genetics Field
description: Incyte Pharmaceuticals Inc. and SmithKline Beecham said today that they had formed a joint-venture company, Diadexus, to develop and produce gene-based diagnostic products. The companies have invested $25 million in Diadexus, which will be based in Santa Clara, Calif., near Incyte's headquarters in Palo Alto.

title: Little Bighorn Sealed Fate of American Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, MARGOT
description: FARRELL-Margot on September 1, 1997, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of the late John J. Farrell II. Dear mother of Karen Farrell and the late John J. Farrell III. Sister of Elvira de Iriarte of Bogota, Colombia. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset, 9:45 AM. Interment Private.

title: With Schools Closed, Capital Is in a Bind
description: The playgrounds behind Brookland Elementary School were filled with children today. They kicked soccer balls, shot basketballs and dangled from jungle gyms. Few adults watching them could have imagined a more unfortunate scene.

title: Students' Test Scores Show Slow but Steady Gains at Nation's Schools
description: Despite the pervasive sense that the nation's schools are mired in decline, three major tests of educational achievement released over the last month all indicate that more than a decade of attention to student achievement seems to be paying off in modest, but significant, continuing improvements in student scores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSMACHER, HARRY A.
description: KOSMACHER-Harry A. Patriarch, businessman, and community leader, peacefully at 96, August 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Estelle. Devoted father of Lois and the late Kenneth. He will be dearly missed by daughter-in -law Mildred Richter, grandchildren Karen Lazar, Steven, Richard and Jeffrey Kosmacher, great granddaughters Kassie, Isabella and Sophie, family and friends. Services will be private.

title: Queens Boy Is Stabbed in Chest After Bicycle Strikes a Woman
description: A Queens teen-ager was stabbed in the chest Monday afternoon, apparently after a dispute over a bicycle accident, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PETERMAN, TOMMY DAVID
description: PETERMAN-Tommy David September 3, 1992 In fond loving memory. Douglas

title: Pension Insurer to End Shortfall Listing
description: The annual list of the 50 large pension funds with the biggest shortfalls will be scrapped by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a Government-sponsored company that insures retirement benefits, officials familiar with the plan said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CODY, MARY ELLEN
description: CODY-Mary Ellen. On September 1, 1997. Retired Officer of J.P. Morgan. Beloved daughter of the late Alice and Patrick. Devoted sister of Alice Vain, Johanna Wilkins, Joseph and Thomas Cody and the late John Cody. Reposing at the Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Thursday and Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue at 72nd Street, on Saturday 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Mary Manning Walsh Home.

title: Cigarette Prices Take Big Jump: 7 Cents a Pack
description: The nation's largest cigarette makers raised wholesale prices yesterday an average of 7.6 percent in what is believed to be the industry's largest single such increase, one that would add about 7 cents a pack to the retail price.

title: Principal Guilty in Theft
description: Nearly six months after he was indicted for stealing more than $150,000 of his school's tuition and scholarship money, the former principal of Morris Catholic High School pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of theft, prosecutors said yesterday. In exchange, prosecutors will drop seven other counts against the former principal, the Rev. Dominic A. Scolamiero, said Sgt. Stephen Foley, a spokesman for the Morris County Prosecutor's office.

title: NEW YORK SCHOOLS OPEN WITH NEW AID AND OLD TROUBLES
description: New York City's 1.1 million public-school children begin returning to their classrooms today to find a system that received an election-year infusion of new computers, textbooks, art classes and reading teachers over the summer vacation. But the system remains plagued by severe overcrowding and chronically low performance in one-third of its districts.

title: A Bounty of Freshness and Frugality
description: SHOPPING in New York City for fresh organic fruits and vegetables gets easier and less expensive every year. And for three weeks this summer, belonging to a Community Supported Agriculture program made it even simpler and cheaper.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Postal Worker Shoots 2 and Then Kills Himself
description: A postal worker shot and critically injured his former wife and a female friend today as they were standing in line inside a crowded post office, then went outside and shot and killed himself, the police and witnesses said.

title: Homicide Inquiry Is Begun for 7 in Diana's Death
description: A French judge took the first step today toward holding six photographers and a motorcyclist criminally responsible for the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, and two other victims of a high-speed crash here early Sunday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When CAROLEE FRIEDLANDER began thinking about how best to celebrate the 25th anniversary of her jewelry company, Carolee Designs, she said, ''I thought, wouldn't it be great to put together an album of women who have touched my life and been an inspiration to others?''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cigarette Makers Raise Prices by Average of 7.6%

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CONVICTION OVERTURNED -- A Federal appeals court in Manhattan overturned a conviction for loan-sharking conspiracy, saying that prosecutors introduced evidence they knew was false. B2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEARER, JOSEPH L.
description: FEARER-Joseph L., 87, of West Hartford, CT., and New York City died September 1 in North Branford, CT. He was husband of the late Eunice Holzman Fearer, father of Paul Fearer and Jane Fearer Safer, grandfather of Sarah Safer. Private burial is at Arlington National Cemetery. Funeral service September 7, 1997. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Joseph and Eunice Fearer Fund, Museum of Modern Art, Department of Prints, 11 West 53 Street, New York, NY 10019.

title: Coulter Purchase Planned By Beckman Instruments
description: Beckman Instruments Inc., a medium-sized manufacturer of medical testing equipment for hospitals and laboratories, said yesterday that it would buy the Coulter Corporation, a privately held maker of machines that analyze blood cell counts. Beckman said it would pay $875 million in cash and would assume $175 million of Coulter's debt.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Secretary of State MADELEINE K. ALBRIGHT on Sunday visited Theresienstadt, the former Nazi concentration camp in the Czech Republic, where her grandparents were interned and her grandfather died, C.T.K., the Czech news agency, reported yesterday.

title: Jets and Jones Agree To a 6-Year Extension
description: With both sides spurred by his big game on Sunday, the Jets and Marvin Jones agreed yesterday on a six-year contract extension. The deal, which will go into effect immediately, could bring him as much as $21 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, LAWRENCE (LARRY)
description: SINGER-Lawrence (Larry). Loving husband of Candy. Father of Marcy Singer, Lisa Cohen, Donna Glabman, grandfather of Nicole, brother of Seymour. Graveside services are at 1 P.M. today at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Westchester. For more information call Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, 718377-2700.

title: U.S. CAN SAYS IT WILL SELL A UNIT, NOT THE WHOLE COMPANY
description: The U.S. Can Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its metal-services division and take other measures to raise shareholder value, contrary to speculation that it was looking for a buyer for the entire company. The company, a metal and plastic-container maker, hired Salomon Brothers in July to review its businesses after saying that it would take a third-quarter charge of $30 million to $35 million to shut four plants and discontinue its steel-pail business. Based on the review, U.S. Can said it had concluded that selling the company would not be ''an appropriate alternative at this time.'' Shares of U.S. Can, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., fell $1.1875, to $15.0625.

title: To Have and to Hold? Wheatley Wants to Be Traded
description: It should come as no surprise that, according to people in the Giants organization, representatives of running back Tyrone Wheatley went to General Manager George Young earlier this week and asked for a trade.

title: INSIDE
description: Living With Land Mines

title: Korean-Americans Assist an Ailing Envoy From the North
description: North Korea's representative at the United Nations, who has been hospitalized in New York since Aug. 12 without medical insurance or financial help from his impoverished Government, has received pledges of aid from Korean-Americans, according to Korean-language newspapers. The prospective donors, who are believed to be of varying political views, apparently fear that the envoy, Kim Hyong U, could be recalled by Pyongyang and sent home without treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, (GLAZER) CECELIA
description: NEWMAN-(Glazer) Cecelia. 9/3/96. You are always in our hearts. We miss you. Love, Pat Newman and Dorothy Dollivar

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, TESS
description: WILSON-Tess, beloved wife of the late Bob, loving mother of Susan Pavane (Howard) & Leonard Shoval. Adored grandmother of Avihu, Brian, Jennifer and Ofer. Devoted sister of Edna Stahl, Marion Regen and Irving Rauch. A treasured aunt, great aunt, in-law, friend and co-worker-loved by all. Funeral services Wednesday, Sept 3, Sinai Chapels, 162 St and Horace Harding Expressway, 2 P.M.

title: Peking: Why a Duck?
description: For lovers of Peking duck who don't have time to cook a duck or make Chinese pancakes, here's a version made with chicken and tor tillas that produces a similar flavor with considerably less work.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON TO SELL MILITARY-RELATED DIVISIONS
description: Watkins-Johnson Inc. signed a definitive agreement yesterday to sell its military electronics and microwave components and subsystems business to the TSMD Acquisition Corporation for $103 million. Watkins-Johnson said the sale included its guided-missile subsystems, YIG-tuned devices and military components business, based in Palo Alto, Calif. Watkins-Johnson said the sale would allow it to focus on its two core business areas of semiconductor manufacturing equipment and wireless-infrastructure products. TSMD Acquisition is an affiliate of the Mentmore Holdings Corporation, a privately held investment company. Shares of Watkins-Johnson rose $2.875, to $37.25.

title: Overpowering Williams Reveals Generous Side
description: She barely acknowledged the handshake from her beaten opponent. Venus Williams barely acknowledges that her opponents, particularly worthy ones, exist on this planet.

title: Uniting as Equals
description: To the Editor:

title: Cone Heads North As Yanks Go South
description: If everything were copacetic in Yankeeland, David Cone would have been activated today and would have mimicked Curt Schilling against the Philadelphia Phillies tonight. Or maybe he would have even imitated Mike Grace. The tendinitis in Cone's right shoulder would have dissipated, the agonizing look on his face would have disappeared and the Yankees would not have been so distressed.

title: Little Bighorn Sealed Fate of American Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Held in Forgery To Obtain Computers
description: A Manhattan resident was arrested yesterday on charges that he bought computers over the Internet and paid for them with forged money orders, the police said.

title: Obesity drugs: Weighing the risks to health against the small victories.
description: WITH one-third of Americans seriously overweight and perhaps half of them desperate to achieve a healthier and more socially acceptable size, it was inevitable that the weight-loss drugs known as fen-phen and Redux would take the country by storm. And it was inevitable that once enough people were on these regimens, problems would emerge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, MARTHA K.
description: BRANDT-Martha K. On Sept. 1, 1997. Beloved wife of J. Michael. Devoted mother of Dr. Ellen Brandt and Dr. Laurie Brandt. Dear sister of Dorothy Waxman and Irving Kraus. Cherished grandmother of Benjamin, Nathaniel & Evan. Services Wednesday, 11:30 A.M., at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Teen-Ager Found Dead In Bronx Basement
description: The body of a 17-year-old youth was found in the basement of an apartment building in the South Bronx early yesterday morning, riddled with bullets, the police said.

title: Manufacturing Growth Eased In August, Purchasers Report
description: An important measure of manufacturing activity grew at a slower rate in August as factories contended with bulging inventories and the strike against United Parcel Service.

title: Songwriter Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANE, FRANCIS J.
description: CRANE-Francis J. On August 31, 1997, of Douglaston, NY. Husband of the late Rita Crane, father of Michael A. and Francis J. Crane, brother of Lillian Chesleigh. Also survived by two grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer Inc Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd., Little Neck, NY, on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Mass of Christian burial will be offered in St. Anastasia RC Church on Thursday, at 9:45 P.M. Interment All Saints Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKER, LOIS WETHERELL
description: HACKER-Lois Wetherell, on September 2, at the age of 67, in her home in Manhattan, of a brain tumor and associated complications. At the time of her death, she had been married to Andrew Hacker for 42 years, and is also survived by her daughter, Ann Gower of Harwich, Ma. At her express request, there will be no funeral or memorial service. Friends or relatives wishing to make a tangible tribute in her memory may send a contribution to the Mina Rees Library Matching Fund, c/o Susan Newman, CUNY Graduate School, 33 W. 42 St, New York, NY 10036.

title: A new Belgian carrier is modeling itself after Southwest Airlines, apparently with success.
description: UNDAUNTED by the demise of Sir Freddie Laker's Skytrain and other low-priced trans-Atlantic carriers over the years, City Bird -- a new Belgian airline owned by City Hotels -- began low-fare flights between Miami and Orlando, Fla., and Brussels last March and then added New York (Newark International Airport), Los Angeles and San Francisco (Oakland International Airport) in June. Today, the carrier says it is packing passengers in with a 92 percent load factor.

title: Double by Clemens Actually Helps Mets
description: Pitchers instinctively seek air-conditioning on nights like last night, when sweat was the rule at Shea Stadium, when caps quickly darkened from perspiration. Roger Clemens found himself on second base last night, after hustling out a double, and it was probably the worst place he could have been.

title: D'Amato Bill Would Shutter Lab's Reactor
description: The Brookhaven National Laboratory, already reeling from findings that it did not properly monitor activities that threatened the environment, suffered a new blow today as Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato filed legislation to close the lab's nuclear reactor permanently.

title: BERRY PLASTICS BUYS VENTURE PACKAGING FOR $50 MILLION
description: The Berry Plastics Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Venture Packaging for $50 million in cash or assumption of indebtedness and $5 million of preferred stock. Berry Plastics, which is based in Evansville, Ind., said Venture Packaging had annual sales of about $45 million. Within a few weeks, Berry said Venture Packaging's operation in Chesapeake, Va., would be relocated and combined with Berry's own operation in Suffolk, Va. Venture Packaging, based in Monroeville, Ohio, makes injection-molded containers used in food, dairy, and other markets. Berry makes and markets plastic containers, aerosol overcaps, drink cups and houseware products.

title: G.O.P. Census Tricks
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 6 about the second-quarter results of the Aetna Corporation overstated the potential impact of a new Federal law on the licensing of health maintenance organizations. Health maintenance organizations for Medicare patients, when operated by hospitals and physicians, will be allowed in certain cases to seek a Federal operating license. The new law does not provide all H.M.O.'s with a blanket exemption from state requirements.

title: Mixed News for No. 2's: Seles Loses, Chang Survives
description: Time was when Monica Seles had the hottest hand in the game -- and she used both hands. Time was when Seles couldn't enter a Grand Slam event without winning it; once won, she treated her titles the way a dog treats its bone. They were hard to take away.

title: D'Amato Attacks Messinger on Schools
description: As public school teachers prepared for the opening of school, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato stuck a hand in mayoral politics yesterday afternoon, appearing outside the campaign headquarters of Ruth W. Messinger to attack her on education issues that she has made into a centerpiece of her campaign.

title: Merrill Buys Barclays Unit
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had acquired the Masterworks division of Barclays Global Investors, a unit of the British bank Barclays P.L.C. Terms were not disclosed. Masterworks provides record-keeping, administration and investment services to 401(k) plans. It administers plans for 160 companies with $16 billion in assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURIM, PAULA
description: STURIM-Paula. On September 2, 1997. Beloved daughter of Sarah and the late Samuel Sturim. Niece of Esther Sturim. Cherished by her aunt Esther and uncle Mat Manes, her many cousins and her loving friends. She will forever be in our hearts. Services Thursday, 12 Noon ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice Center, Beth Israel Hospital, NYC.

title: Gasoline Prices Rise Sharply As Refinery Unit Stays Shut
description: Gasoline prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after the Exxon Corporation said a unit at a Texas refinery was still closed, meaning another week of reduced supplies.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Under-17 World Championship

title: Apple Backs Off Cloning
description: Apple Computer has rejected its strategy of cloning Macintoshes, agreeing to buy the Macintosh business of its largest licensee. Page D1.

title: Too Often, Cougars and People Clash
description: The 4-year-old French boy was waving to his parents on a path here in July when a 70-pound cougar pounced from the underbrush and dragged him off by the head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, VICTOR
description: NEWMAN-Victor. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Victor Newman. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, SELMA
description: ROSE-Selma. Beloved wife of the late Myles. Dear mother of Jules and Steven. Adored grandmother of Patti Mandel, Mitchell Rose, and Randi Kaplan. Adored great grandmother of Marissa, Natalie, Molly, Meredith, Melanie, and Max. Missed by all. Graveside service today 2 P.M. For information call Riverside at: 516-487-9600.

title: Black, White or Both: Of Blood Ties Twisted Into Lies
description: When Macky Alston, a white, gay New York filmmaker now in his early 30's, was growing up in Durham, N.C., he paid little attention to the fact that many of his elementary school classmates were black children with the same last name. It was only as a young adult, when he began poring over a book outlining his family lineage, that he was seized with curiosity about the shared name and began digging into the past.

title: Celebrities in the Stands Find No Sure Things
description: IRINA SPIRLEA, Significant Other killer of the United States Open, struck again yesterday. She upset Monica Seles and banished the former Mayor of New York, the spiritual architect of Arthur Ashe Stadium, from its choice location, the players' family box.

title: McGreevey's Insurance Plan
description: The Democratic gubernatorial candidate, James E. McGreevey, presented his auto insurance program yesterday during a late afternoon radio broadcast, promising a 10 percent reduction in rates without cutting coverage.

title: For Some Freshmen, a Course on New Surroundings
description: After unpacking suitcases, studying the campus map and checking out the dining halls, the new first-year students at Middlebury College will also get a crash course in the State of Vermont as part of freshman orientation.

title: South Korea Extols Some of the Benefits of Land Mines
description: Some of the fields and forests scattered around the gash of barbed wire and tank traps that separate the two Koreas are so green and gorgeous that one wants to dash through the fields in sheer exuberance at the beautiful terrain.

title: Intimacy and Autonomy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Aug. 25 about administrative changes at the Lyric Opera of Chicago misstated the retirement date of Bruno Bartoletti, the artistic director and principal conductor. It is April 1999, not 1998.

title: Book-Free Bathrooms
description: ''Take the library out of the bathroom.'' That is the advice of a colorectal surgeon to Americans who spend too much time and effort at what should be a natural process: the elimination of solid wastes. Dr. Bradley Bute of Colon and Rectal Surgical Associates of Long Island and North Shore University Hospitals cautioned in a recent lecture that prolonged straining to have a bowel movement could damage the nerves and muscles of the colon and rectum and result in diverticular disease, painful hemorrhoids and possibly fecal incontinence.

title: Executive Changes
description: SEAGRAM CO., Montreal, named Ellen R. Marram president and chief executive of the Tropicana Beverage Group, effective immediately. The Tropicana Group was formerly called the Seagram Beverage Group.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's hard to name a growth industry in the world that California doesn't have a strong position in. The question should no longer be can California manage the recession, but can California manage the growth?''

title: In Mexico's House, Speaker's Stature Signals a New Day
description: Porfirio Munoz Ledo, Mexico's powerful new Speaker of the House, recalled recently that when he was first elected as an opposition senator in 1988, he pleaded with leaders of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, to allow him to serve on a committee. Any committee.

title: Blunders Fan Fears Over Air Safety in Argentina
description: One morning recently, air-traffic controllers here advised the crew of an Avianca Airlines flight arriving from Bogota, Colombia, that the airport was closed because of low clouds and that the plane should proceed to an airport 400 miles to the northwest, where the skies were clear.

title: Libertarian Nominee Seeks Public Campaign Funds
description: Murray Sabrin, a college finance professor who is the Libertarian Party candidate for New Jersey governor, said today that he has raised enough money to qualify for matching taxpayer dollars under the state program that publicly finances the gubernatorial contest.

title: At U.C.L.A., a Mixed Reaction to Web-Based Courses
description: When students at the University of California at Los Angeles call up the World Wide Web home page for a class on 20th-century American literature this school year, they will have a wealth of choices, including, the professor hopes, clicking on an audio button to hear an aria from an opera mentioned in a Willa Cather novel. But students taking another professor's course on Milton will find a bare-bones Web page, not much more than the course title and a reading list.

title: Allied Signal Agrees to Sell 2 Auto Units
description: Shedding what it regards as a low- margin, cyclical business, Allied Signal Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its automotive seat belt and air bag operations to Breed Technologies Inc. for $710 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISER, JOSHUA
description: KREISER-Joshua. Rabbi Emeritus of the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, N.Y. After over 30 years of devoted service. Beloved father of Dr. Abraham and Hemdah Kreiser, Dr. Sara Feinstein, Rabbi Shabtai and Orah Rubel, Dr. Yehudah and Edna Freidenberg. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be sorely missed. T'hei nafsho tzrura bitzror hachaim. Funeral services today 12PM Shomrei Hadas Chapel, 3803 14th Ave, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS, SOLOMON
description: FIELDS-Solomon. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Solomon Fields beloved father of our devoted member Gary Fields and grandfather of Marjorie and Sara. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Watercraft Accidents Drop
description: For the second summer in a row, fewer people are being hurt in accidents involving Jet Skis and other so-called personal watercraft, the state police said yesterday. Police officials said they did not know whether the decline could be attributed to a new law requiring operators of Jet Skis to pass a safety course. The law did not go into effect until July 1, but many people began taking the course last summer after the requirement was approved by the State Legislature.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Aug. 26 about volcanic hazards misidentified a town in Colombia devastated by an eruption in 1985. It was Armero; Novado del Ruiz was the name of the volcano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERUTTI, ANITA J. (GIOVANNA)
description: CERUTTI-Anita J. (Giovanna), on August 29, 1997. Co-founder of Cerutti Enterprises, the prominent Madison Avenue children's retailer, devoted and loving mother of Reid Cerutti, Harlan L. Davidson, Jr. & Francesca Davidson Cerutti. Beloved daughter of the late Mr. & Mrs. Frank Cerutti and devoted sister of the late Doris Cerutti Hurdle and Louis A. Cerutti. Cherished aunt of Anita Bindi, Frank L. Cerutti and Donna Storatz. Reposing at ''The Abbey'', 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, September 3, at 11 A.M., at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62nd Street, New York City. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Camp Chef Outdoes Marshmallow Roti
description: CAMPING around an open fire often means that dinner is a pretty meager affair: hot dogs speared on freshly snapped twigs, a can of baked beans, a melted marshmallow or two.

title: The Owner Absolves Irabu, but Not Torre
