description: Sounding contrite one moment and cocky the next, George Steinbrenner accepted the blame for Hideki Irabu's floundering with the Yankees and then tweaked his manager, Joe Torre, by predicting that his team can still overtake the first-place Orioles.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORMAN, PATRICK EMMET
description: GORMAN-Patrick Emmet. Pat, after 17 years without you, labor & management have not yet reached the lofty humanitarian goals you always strived for. A Friend

title: The Pop Life
description: Videos on Parade

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLOMENBAUM, HYMAN S.
description: FLOMENBAUM-Hyman S. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its mens club mourn the passing of Hyman S. Flomenbaum, beloved father of their devoted member, Dr. Neal Flomenbaum, and extend heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. Haskel Lookstein, Rabbi Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Apple Decides Cloning Isn't Its Route Back To Profitability
description: Apple Computer Inc. has effectively ended its strategy of attempting to grow through the cloning of its Macintosh computers, agreeing to buy the Macintosh business of its largest licensee.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOME PROPERTIES OF NEW YORK, Rochester, a real estate investment trust, agreed to buy an apartment portfolio in Michigan for $105 million.

title: Dissidents Challenge Baptist Leader in Turbulent Convention
description: Signaling a revolt whose goals include a sweeping overhaul of the nation's largest black religious organization, the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A., Inc., a group of 25 prominent ministers, with a crowd of about 200 supporters standing behind them, demanded today that the Rev. Henry J. Lyons resign as the denomination's president.

title: Dudley Ruling Is Due Today
description: After an all-day arbitration hearing in Manhattan yesterday, Chris Dudley's career is still in limbo. The veteran center, whom the Knicks are trying to obtain in a trade with the Portland Trail Blazers, has become the subject of a leaguewide debate over the issue of signing players for the sole purpose of trading them.

title: The Message in the Mourning
description: The outpouring of popular grief for Diana, Princess of Wales, is on a scale quite unprecedented. It would be safe to say that London has never seen anything like it. Even for the funeral of Winston Churchill, even after the death of Queen Victoria or the Duke of Wellington, there was not such a huge demonstration.

title: Stock Split for Andrea
description: The Andrea Electronics Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, approved a 2-for-1 split yesterday in the company's shares, which have more than tripled this year.

title: S.I. Man Arrested In Hit-and-Run
description: A Staten Island man was arrested yesterday and charged with driving a car that struck a couple and two children outside the Staten Island Ferry Terminal on Sunday, critically injuring the father and his 3-year-old son, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKIN, DEWITT, JR.
description: PETERKIN-DeWitt, Jr., of Noroton, CT. Died August 29, 1997 of heart failure and complications related to Parkinsons Disease. He was 84. Mr. Peterkin is survived and missed by his wife Katharine Urban, two daughters Clare and Kate, three sons DeWitt III, George, and Patrick and his wife Jennifer and three grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Jane Gurney and his brother John Peterkin. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 5 at 11 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Rd., Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The American Parkinson's Association, 1250 Hyland Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10305-1946 or to Waveny Care Center Employee Fund, 3 Farm Rd., New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: With Eye on 2000 Race, The Big Issue Is Money
description: Issues? Personalities? Messages? Forget about it. The early, early handicapping of the Presidential race in 2000 is all about one thing: Who can amass the most (in the parlance of strategists) ''dough.''

title: Nonprofits' Wall St. Home Filling Up
description: The Association Center, opened five years ago at 120 Wall Street to help keep national and international nonprofit organizations from leaving New York City because of high rents, is about to become 100 percent occupied.

title: Dallas Defeats MetroStars In U.S. Open Cup Semifinal
description: The MetroStars could have eased some of the pain caused by the lumps they have received during the Major League Soccer season if they had won last night in the United States Open Cup tournament semifinal round. But the suffering will surely not go away now, not after they lost to the Dallas Burn, 2-1, on a goal in sudden-death overtime at Baker Field.

title: House of Windsor Finds Itself Caught in a Growing Clamor for Change
description: The death of Diana, Princess of Wales, has focused public attention on her criticisms of the royal family and confronted the 160-year-old House of Windsor with a national clamor for change.

title: After Deaths, Delay in Sale Of Windsors' Possessions
description: Sotheby's announced yesterday that it was postponing its auction of more than 40,000 objects belonging to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor from the couple's famous Paris home. The announcement came as Sotheby's experts were putting the finishing touches on the objects' installation in preparation for the nine-day sale that was to begin at the auction house's York Avenue headquarters on Sept. 11. Sotheby's said the decision had been made in accord with the wishes of Mohamed al-Fayed, owner of the Windsors' villa and its contents, after the death on Sunday of Mr. Fayed's son Emad and Diana, Princess of Wales, in a car crash in Paris.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE best place to learn about Italian wines is in an Italian restaurant. Not any Italian restaurant. Most pizza dispensaries and shopping mall pasta places confine themselves to routine wines -- anonymous chiantis, thin valpolicellas, dull varietals -- to go with their routine food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIELLO, DAVID
description: AIELLO-David, age 58, born March 17th, 1939, the son of Helen Aiello, last known to have resided in the Brooklyn area. He died Saturday, August 30th, 1997 in Rome Memorial Hospital. Would any kin or anyone knowing of any next of kin please contact the Rome DDSO collect, 315-336-2300, with any special funeral arrangements.

title: Listening to the Heart: Dying Art?
description: IF any one tool could be declared the symbol of the medical profession, it would surely be the stethoscope. But the ability to use that tool may be a dying art, according to a study of 453 recent medical graduates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIM, SAMUEL ''BILL.''
description: WERTHEIM-Samuel ''Bill.'' Died September 1, 1997, in his 97th year. Beloved husband of Sylvia and the late Grace Tirnauer. Deeply loved by his daughters and sons-in-law, Ruth and Stanley Kaplan, Joan and Jules Levine, loving grandchildren and great grandchildren and Marcy and Joe Sugarman, Maida and Bob Prussian, Richard and Eileen Diamond and their children. Services Thursday 12 noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Buzzwords Won't Help
description: To the Editor:

title: After 12 Steps, One Prayer: To Die Sober
description: TEN years ago, James Roundtree learned how to live a day at a time. He used to mark time bottle by bottle, rising each morning in some dark basement where he tried in vain to shake off the dirt and stupor that clung to him throughout his endless bender. Then, as in the life of any alcoholic lucky enough to be given a second chance, something happened that lifted him off his knees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTZ, CATHERINE B.
description: HARTZ-Catherine B., of Basking Ridge, NJ and East Orleans, MA, age 52, died September 1, 1997 at her home in East Orleans, MA. Wife of John C. Hartz, mother of John C. Jr, Catherine B. Hartz, daughter of Chester C. Burley, Jr and Jane B. Swift, sister of Chester C. Burley III, Susie Schmertz, also survived by several aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday, Sept. 10 at 11 AM at St Bernards Church, Bernardsville, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the ASPCA, 424 East 92nd Street, New York, New York 10128 or The Morristown Memorial Hospital Cancer Center, Morristown, New Jersey 07960.

title: Collector's Family Tries to Illuminate the Past of Manuscripts in France
description: In late October 1940, as Hitler's Germany began picking the fruits of its occupation of France, Nazi troops raided Alphonse Kann's mansion at St.-Germain-en-Laye near Paris and carried away his entire art collection. The works, which included eight rare illuminated manuscripts along with a trove of paintings, drawings and sculptures, were taken to the Jeu de Paume museum in Paris, where they were stored pending shipment to Germany.

title: Blue-Collar Jobs Gain, but the Work Changes in Tone
description: Like so many of the corporate downsizings of the 1980's and 1990's, the 1984 breakup of Ma Bell led to tens of thousands of layoffs while bringing vast efficiencies to the telephone industry. But you do not hear much griping at Local 2101 of the Communications Workers of America these days about the future of blue-collar work.

title: Hillary Clinton Will Go to Diana's Funeral
description: A half-hour telephone conversation between President Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain on Monday, followed by consultations between the two Governments, led the White House to announce today that Hillary Rodham Clinton will attend the funeral of the Princess of Wales in recognition of the ''close personal association'' between the two women.

title: Immigration Disgrace
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Round for Campaign Reform
description: The challenge of cleaning up the nation's corrupt campaign finance system is bearing down again on the Congressional agenda. Many lawmakers who have thrived by the system would like the public to believe that the chances of reforming it are nil. That is not true. The hearings led by Senator Fred Thompson resume tomorrow, with a new cast of experts likely to shed light on current problems. No less important, reform legislation sponsored by Senators John McCain of Arizona and Russell Feingold of Wisconsin is being drafted to reflect the concerns of lawmakers and groups who might well generate new momentum for the cause.

title: Coffee Slushies: Summer's Sweet Blast
description: EVERY summer brings a new invention to mitigate the heat, a man-made moment in the shade, a cool breeze to be bought. This has been the summer of the coffee frappe.

title: N.Y. Police Culture Has Changed for Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALMON, HAMILTON H., III
description: SALMON-Hamilton H., III, 78, of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL., formerly of Garden City, L.I. and Lake Placid, NY., died August 31, 1997. He was born January 10, 1919 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of Ruth and Hamilton H. Salmon, Jr. He attended Choate and graduated from Princeton in 1941. He served in the Army Air corp from 1941 to 1946. He had retired from Marine Offices of America and had been a partner in Estabrook and Company. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Thompson Welch Salmon. He was preceded in death by Francis Sinclair Salmon in 1987. Also surviving are his four daughters, Beverly Hall of West Redding, CT., Susan Wells of Damascus, MD., Ann Peterson of Lancaster, PA., and Shelby Hodgkins of Birmingham, MI; three stepsons, Alexander Welch of Princeton, NJ., Bruce Welch of El Salvador, Christopher Welch of Andover, MA; 11 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 AM, Saturday, September 20, 1997 at St. Eustace Episcopal Church, Lake Placid, NY. For information, contact Hardage-Giddens Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL.

title: ARCO to Develop Gas Field in Indonesia
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, known as ARCO, said today that it would spend as much as $3 billion to develop a natural gas field in Indonesia's easternmost province, as the company makes its entry into the highly competitive business of supplying liquefied natural gas to Asia.

title: Kellogg promotes its family of cereals, even the sugary ones, as components of a healthy diet.
description: THE Kellogg Company, wounded in the cereal wars, is returning fire by dusting off its own time-honored strategy of promoting health claims. An extensive print campaign boasts that all Kellogg cereal brands -- even Froot Loops -- are nutritious staples of a healthy life style, not simply convenient breakfast foods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVE, SHIRLEY
description: LOVE-Shirley. Devoted mother of Michael Gibbs. Loving grandmother of David, Alexandra and Adam. Services Thursday. For info.: ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: Psychologist Is Stabbed
description: A school psychologist was stabbed after getting out of his car in the Forest Hills High School parking lot in Queens yesterday, the police said.

title: Federal Appeals Panel Overturns Loan-Sharking Conspiracy Conviction
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan last week overturned the conviction of a man accused in a loan-sharking conspiracy, saying that prosecutors introduced evidence at trial that they knew was false.

title: Convoluted System of Teacher Hiring Spawns Backdoor Alternative
description: Last Thursday, Melissa Farnesi Dubizh, a teacher with two years of experience, was called by the personnel office of the New York City Board of Education to the hiring hall at Martin Luther King Jr. High School, a hulking Darth Vaderesque building of dark brick and smoked glass that doubles as central headquarters for all public high schools in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUNDLICH, DR. HARRY
description: FREUNDLICH-Dr. Harry. The name of Andrew Seth Kalb, the deceased son of Evelyn Mollet and a favorite grandson of Dr. Harry, was inadvertently not mentioned in his obituary. Andrew will always be remembered in our hearts.

title: Backers of Newark Group Say Brutality Protests Spurred Raid
description: Drug raids last week against a group known as the Zoo Crew were intended to subvert protests against police brutality in which the group played a prominent role, a consortium of community organizations asserted today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, BRUCE CHARLES
description: RIVKIN - Bruce Charles. He sparkled with love and human kindness. Aunt Gracie

title: For British Royal Family, Privacy at What Price?
description: When Diana, Princess of Wales, dispensed with her round-the-clock bodyguards as her marriage to Prince Charles was unraveling, her decision was seen as an effort to liberate herself from the often stultifying confines of the royal family. In hindsight, it appears that Diana's desire for a normal life made her vulnerable in the last years of her life.

title: 2 Targets Reject Bids By French Retail Giant
description: Two French retailers yesterday rejected the takeover bids they received from a rival that is trying to form France's largest retailer. The boards of Casino S.A. and Rallye S.A. rejected the unsolicited offers that were made Monday by Promodes S.A. Casino was offered 19.1 billion French francs, or $3.13 billion, and the bid for Rallye, which owns a third of Casino's shares, was 8.7 billion francs, or $1.43 billion. Both boards were unanimous in rejecting the long- expected offers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Stephen Foster's World Truly Was Sad and Dreary
description: DOO-DAH!

title: Eclecticism Rules: Oysters and Pizza
description: FOR the traditionalists who cling to eating oysters only in months that have the letter ''R'' in them, the Globe, 373 Park Avenue South (26th Street), is right on time. It opened yesterday with a large circular stainless-steel oyster bar that does triple duty: as a breakfast bar, as a takeout counter at lunch and, after 4 P.M., as a place for seafood and drinks. The Globe also has an igloolike tiled pizza oven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELWYN, ALEXANDER
description: SELWYN-Alexander. Age 82, of West Palm Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Ruth. Father of Lee and Philip. Grandfather of Eric, Mark, Jeremy and Amanda. Brother of Irving Zelevansky, Sam Zelevansky, the late Joseph Zelevansky and the late Philip Zelevansky, and friend to many. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURNETT, ALTON R.
description: BURNETT-Alton R. 9/3/05-5/7/90. We miss your love and wisdom. The Family

title: Road Rage in Paris
description: After the shock of the first news of the death of Princess Diana and her escort, the world was swept by an angry reaction: Who was to blame? ''Auto accident'' did not satisfy the sinking sense of loss. What person, group or cultural fault could be held responsible?

title: PEREGRINE SYSTEMS TO BUY APSYLOG FOR UP TO $29 MILLION
description: Peregrine Systems Inc. said yesterday it planned to acquire Apsylog S.A., a provider of asset management software, for $27 million to $29 million in stock. As part of the deal, Peregrine would also acquire Apsylog's parent company, United Software Inc. Apsylog has offices in San Ramon, Calif., London and Paris. Peregrine, based in San Diego, said it expected its earnings in the second quarter ending Sept. 30 to be reduced by an unspecified amount because of the acquisition. Peregrine's shares closed at $16.50, up 87.5 cents.

title: Algeria's Agony
description: The last seven days have been the most violent in Algeria's nearly six-year civil war. The Government reports that nearly 400 civilians were massacred in that week by the Armed Islamic Group. The rest of the world has gone along with the Government's insistence that the violence is the business of Algerians only. But Algeria's President, Liamine Zeroual, has refused to negotiate with even moderate Islamists. It is time for other nations, especially France, to use their influence to press for talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUMMOND, DONALD W.
description: DRUMMOND-Donald W., 93, of Vero Beach, died August 29, 1997 at his residence after a brief illness. He was born December 28, 1903 in Philadelphia, PA, and moved to Vero Beach 30 years ago from Morrisville, PA. He graduated from Wharton University of Pennsylvania. He had a long and distinguished career with Matheson Chemical, Squibb and Olin Industries and retired as an executive officer. He was a member of the First Presbyterian Church of Vero Beach; The Vero Beach Country Club and the Riomar Club. Surviving are his wife, ida, one daughter, Barbara Deibert of Asheville, NC, two grandsons and four great grandchildren. There will be no repose or visitation and no flowers. For information Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach, Florida.

title: Right to Build Over Terminal Is Up for Sale
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, hoping to cash in on the resurgence of the Times Square area, plans to sell the development rights above its Manhattan bus terminal, at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue, for a 35-story commercial building, officials said yesterday.

title: Failing Job Clubs
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Dealer Is Charged With Menacing His Wife
description: A prominent New York City art dealer was arrested early yesterday on charges of menacing his wife with a handgun, the police said.

title: A Day Later, Stocks Climb A Bit More
description: The stock market inched higher yesterday, the session after the Dow Jones industrial average registered its largest point rise ever.

title: For Some, Back to School Means New Environment
description: In a freshly painted hallway yesterday morning, 9-year-old Idalisa Garcia sat on a wooden chair, kneading her hands atop her pleated navy-blue skirt.

title: Courteous Moorer To Face Holyfield
description: If there is one thing that Michael Moorer, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, learned from Mike Tyson, it is not to disrespect Evander Holyfield, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, before a fight.

title: The Mets Have Just Begun To Fight
description: The Mets are hot, again. With last night's come-from-behind 4-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays before an announced crowd of just 14,513 at Shea Stadium, the Mets swept the Blue Jays, won their fifth straight game -- all of them interleague contests -- and kept alive their faint wild-card hopes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITTLE, GLORIA B.
description: WHITTLE-Gloria B. Died Aug. 31, 1997. Beloved daughter of Edward and Mary. Mother of Michelle. Grandmother of Michael and Vanishia. Services on September 5th, 11 AM, Saint Luke's Community Church, 142 Watkins St, Bklyn NY. Interment Evergreen Cemetery.

title: New Type of Bond Sold by City Gets Higher Credit Rating
description: A new type of bond being sold by the New York City government received a favorable reception from Wall Street credit-rating agencies yesterday, which should allow the city to save hundreds of millions of dollars in interest payments over the next few decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEARER, JOSEPH L.
description: FEARER-Joseph L., 87, of West Hartford, CT., and New York City died September 1 in North Branford, CT. He was husband of the late Eunice Holzman Fearer, father of Paul Fearer and Jane Fearer Safer, grandfather of Sarah Safer. Private burial is at Arlington National Cemetery. Funeral service September 7, 1997. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Joseph and Eunice Fearer Fund, Museum of Modern Art, Department of Prints, 11 West 53 Street, New York, NY 10019.

title: National League Wins First Interleague War
description: As baseball's first interleague season within a season concluded last night, the National League had to feel free to borrow a line from Mark Twain. For indeed, the report of its demise has been greatly exaggerated.

title: INSIDE
description: Baptist Group Backs Leader

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUENNE, OLIVIA MICHELLE
description: KUENNE-Olivia Michelle, age 5. Beloved daughter of Christopher and Leslie Kuenne of Princeton, NJ; sister of Peter; granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kuenne of Princeton, Mr. & Mrs. William O. Harbach of Fairfield, CT, Peter Vought of Sante Fe, NM. Extremely bright, funny, and wise, Olivia was beloved of her classmates and friends. She excelled in art, especially perspective and composition. Service at 10:30 A.M. today, Trinity Church, Princeton. Contributions to Olivia's Art Fund at Princeton Junior School, Box 672, Princeton, New Jersey 08542-0672.

title: On the Trail
description: Events yesterday in the Democratic mayoral primary campaign in New York City.

title: Giants to Measure Progress in Rematch Against Jaguars
description: When the Giants and the Jacksonville Jaguars met in a preseason game nearly a month ago, the Jaguars lost a starting quarterback and the Giants lost the game, 38-16. Neither team has been the same since -- the Jaguars for an obvious reason, the Giants for many subtle ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEBER, JULIA W.
description: SCHWEBER-Julia W. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of the late Mark. Interment Beth-El Cemetery, Westwood, NJ on Sept. 4, 1997.

title: SUNY Trustees Approve Budget Of $1.5 Billion
description: The trustees of the State University of New York approved a $1.5 billion budget for the 34-campus system today that calls for no raises in tuition and includes a $34 million increase in state aid.

title: Changes on Posting of Signs
description: The Newark City Council voted yesterday to impose a mandatory fine of $1,000 for posting signs on city property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, EUGENE A.
description: HUGHES-Eugene A. September 3, 1997. Marine and contractor's equipment business. Beloved son of the late John and Mathilda Hughes. Dear brother of John T. Hughes, Sr. Friends may call at The Abbey in the Frank E. Campbell building, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 St, Saturday, 11 AM. Interment to follow at Saint John's Cemetery.

title: F.B.I. Memorandum on Crime Was Mistakenly Sent to Press
description: A confidential F.B.I. memorandum identifying a possible suspect in a fatal train derailment in the Arizona desert was sent by mistake this week to news organizations throughout the state, officials said today.

title: Hoffa's Windfall: 2d Bid to Lead Teamsters
description: Like factory whistles and buttered steaks, the Hoffa name evoked a muscular era, but one that seemed to have lost its relevance.

title: Homeowners' Group Pleads for Help for City
description: In a plea for state and Federal officials to bail out their beach community, members of an Asbury Park homeowners' association have prepared a thick report on the city's financial crisis, rising crime and decaying neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Tuesday about television coverage of the death misspelled the name of the newspaper edited by Steve Coz, who reported that he had turned down a photograph of the Princess taken moments after the crash. It is The National Enquirer, not Inquirer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Panama's Move to Oust Editor Sets Off Storm
description: Gustavo Gorriti does not consider himself a criminal, and neither do the human rights groups that have rushed to his defense. But for a week now, he has been living and sleeping in a small office just off the main newsroom at the daily La Prensa here, waiting for the police to come and take him away.

title: Celebrity, Then and Now
description: Regret over the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, is beginning to mix with more complicated emotions, including wonderment over the celebrity-worship that made her such a public obsession, and some misgivings about the overwhelming news coverage of her passing. The sight of network anchors winging off to the funeral, the coverage on all-news networks that seems to rival that of the gulf war and the competition by interviewers and interviewees to claim Diana's friendship does seem to suggest a world gone out of whack.

title: Amorality of 'Demand'
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices Lower On Treasury Securities
description: Treasury securities turned lower yesterday after the General Motors Corporation reported stronger car sales for August than expected, raising fears among investors that the economy might be expanding fast enough to cause inflation to heat up. G.M. said car sales and light-truck sales rose 7.4 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALLEN, HARRY
description: SMALLEN-Harry. 87. Died on September 2 after a long illness in North Miami Beach, FL. Formerly a resident of New Haven and NY. Veteran of W.W. II. Survived by his wife, Edith of North Miami Beach, FL and his brother, Dr. Edward in Lakewood, New Jersey.

title: Arizona Governor Convicted Of Fraud and Will Step Down
description: A Federal jury today convicted Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona of seven felony counts of defrauding his lenders as a commercial real estate developer, forcing his resignation and leaving him facing the prospect of prison and hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines.

title: Nonprofit Groups to Defy Subpoenas in Senate Inquiry
description: Representatives of more than two dozen nonprofit lobbying groups said today that they would not comply with subpoenas for information about their activities issued by the Senate committee investigating political fund-raising.

title: Venezuela to Sell Post-Brady Bonds
description: Venezuela joined other big Latin American borrowers today, introducing a plan to sell $1 billion worth of 30-year bonds, the longest-term bonds sold in the country's modern history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERUTTI, ANITA J.
description: CERUTTI-Anita J. Children of Bellevue, Inc. is saddened by the passing of Ms. Cerutti, a loyal supporter for many years. We extend sincere condolences to her entire family. Board of Directors Children of Bellevue, Inc. Bellevue Hospital Center

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL CORP., Irving, Tex., a finance company, bought Superior Acceptance Corp., Canada's largest independent consumer-finance company, for undisclosed terms.

title: Rocky Mountain Tunnel Vision
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich was in the northern Rockies last weekend, part of a two-week national tour to buff up his image. Along with two Texans, Dick Armey, the House majority leader, and Tom DeLay, the Republican whip, he came out West to chat with locals and do some fact-finding.

title: Anti-Asian Remarks an Issue in Primary
description: City Councilwoman Julia Harrison has gained more public attention in the last year than at any time in her 11 years as a member of the Council, but not attention she has relished.

title: Chrebet Finds the Stage; Now, a Search for Glory
description: The old Jets posed for a Super Bowl reunion photo Tuesday night and someone said, ''Hey, let's get Wayne Chrebet in the picture.''

title: How Employers See It
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable Venture Formed by 2 Industry Giants
description: Time Warner Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. have agreed to create a new joint venture that will own cable systems and to expand an existing partnership. The moves will also allow both companies to reduce the debt on their balance sheets.

title: 18 People Are Arraigned In Deaf Immigrants Case
description: Eighteen of the 20 people charged with operating a ring that kept deaf Mexican immigrants in virtual slavery and forced them to sell trinkets on the subway pleaded not guilty yesterday to various extortion, alien-smuggling and conspiracy charges.

title: A Mind Full of Frogs, Mice and Snails Grows Riper
description: TO spend a few hours with Leo Lionni is to wade into the warm waters of an Old World where erudition comes with modesty, and where conversation is a calling. ''I would like to have a crusade against mass communication, and promote communication,'' Mr. Lionni said cheerfully the other day in his Upper East Side apartment. ''One with the other, with one person. That's the real art. Now, what were we talking about?''

title: The Last Gladiator Standing
description: MAYBE somebody like him will come along, but Evander Holyfield might be boxing's last gladiator, the last one who seems to enjoy the fight for the fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOTH, ALEXANDER, M.D., D.D.S.
description: TOTH-Alexander, M.D., D.D.S. Alexander Toth, 81, died on September 2, 1997. Dr. Toth was born October 22, 1915 in Koronco, Hungary. He moved to the United States with his family from Gyor, Hungary in 1956. For the better part of his professional career he practiced dentistry in New Brunswick, New Jersey. Dr. Toth retired to Sarasota, Florida in 1989. Loving survivors include his wife Anna; three children: Adrian, Lollia, Zoltan; and five grandchildren. Also, his soul brother Aurel and family and former wife Aranka. Funeral services were private. A memorial mass will be held at a future date which will be announced. The family respectfully requests any donations to be made to: Kossuth Club Scholarship Fund, Hungarian American Cultural Association, Incorporated, P.O. Box 19774, Sarasota, Florida 34276.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESTER, EUGENE
description: CHESTER-Eugene. An extraordinary and honorable man, whose love and devotion to his family are only matched by theirs for him. Funeral services Thursday 10 A.M. at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, opp LIRR.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JOYCE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Joyce. Former Head Nurse at the New York Times newspaper (retired 1980) passed away at the Wood River Retirement Community in Bensalem, PA on August 19, 1997. Mrs. Goldstein was 76. Wife of the late David Goldstein, also retired (1969) from the New York Times newspaper. Mrs. Goldstein was President of the National Association of Industrial Nurses. She was the daughter of John and Edna (nee Nave) Nelson. Joyce is survived by three brothers, Retired Col. Carl A. Nelson of Colorado Springs, CO; John W. Nelson, Jr., of Mountaintop, PA; and Frank L. Nelson of Emporia, KS. Also several nieces and nephews. Tomlinson Funeral Home, Bensalem, PA.

title: Justice on the Go
description: To the Editor:

title: Asians Insist on Japan-China Balance
description: SINGAPORE  When Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan concluded a tour of Southeast Asia in Singapore in January, he called for regular meetings between Japanese and ASEAN heads of government in a speech that appeared to mark a new phase in the competition for regional influence between Japan and China.

title: On the Trail
description: Events yesterday in the Democratic mayoral primary campaign in New York City.

title: Yankees Keep Stumbling as Phillies Finish Sweep on Walk in 9th
description: The plan sounded incredibly simple yet was incredibly revealing. Manager Joe Torre explained that the Yankees hoped to secure tonight's final game against the Phillies so they could roll into the crucial series with the Orioles on Thursday night feeling some semblance of confidence. Huh? That is an interesting admission.

title: Clinton Presses Plan to Test Pupils on Federal Standards
description: Eager to press for political advantage in a legislative fight awaiting him in Washington, President Clinton interrupted his vacation to appear at an elementary school here today, promoting his plan for voluntary tests to measure pupils' performance against new national standards in reading and math.

title: Seat Belt Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Monthly Newspaper In Spanish Is Started
description: A free, Spanish-language monthly newspaper made its debut yesterday, offering arts and entertainment news to Spanish-speaking New Yorkers and tourists.

title: Simon DeBartolo Bids for Mall Developer
description: Simon DeBartolo Group Inc. offered $630 million yesterday for Retail Property Trust, a closely held shopping mall developer. The move is apparently a bid to break up a three-way merger among Retail Property and two other mall developers.

title: For Rivals Ancient and New, Games Have Already Begun
description: A member of the Athens delegation bidding for the 2004 Summer Olympics was speaking to a reporter today when she was suddenly embraced by the official mascot of Stockholm's Olympic bid, who happened to be wearing a moose outfit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLUNKETT, JOHN J.
description: PLUNKETT-John J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John J. Plunkett, associated with The Times from 1947, until retiring in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, HENRY LEROY JR.
description: FINCH-Henry Leroy Jr. The War Resisters League mourns the death August 22 of Roy Finch, pacifist of integrity and courage, W.W. II CO, editor of Liberation and WRL Chair, 1953-59.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULLEN, THOMAS G.
description: BULLEN-Thomas G. Reverend Brother. CFC (Emeritus Professor of Physics) on Sept 3, 1997, of Iona College, New Rochelle, NY. Dear Brother of Frank, Denis, Gerald, Joan, and the late Bernard, Joe, Val, Jack, Madeline and Marie. The family will receive friends Thursday and Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. at The St. Joseph's Residence, 30 Montgomery Circle, New Rochelle, NY. Mass at Christian burial Saturday, 10 A.M. at The Church of the Holy Family, New Rochelle, NY. Interment Christian Brothers Cemetery, West Park,NY. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to The St. Joseph's Care Center, 30 Montgomery Circle, New Rochelle NY 10804 would be appreciated.

title: Impresarios of the World Music World; Extending the Meaning of 'Classical' Beyond the European Tradition
description: There was an atmosphere of mock triumph in the West 27th Street headquarters of the World Music Institute one rainy afternoon recently. A caller was desperately seeking a sitar player who would be willing to sit in a store window for five minutes during a reception for a gallery show opening. The musician had to be good-looking, a credible performer on the large, ancient Indian stringed instrument and someone who would not be insulted by the circumstances. After a few phone calls, the institute's staff made the match.

description: Fashion Statements

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEERBURGER, ETHEL K.
description: LEERBURGER-Ethel K., wife of the late Franklin J. Leerburger, beloved mother of Karen Hartnick and Marna Biederman, beloved mother-in-law of Alan J. Hartnick and Donald E. Biederman, devoted grandmother of Charles and Melissa Biederman, Jonathan (deceased), Katherine, Margaret and Christopher Hartnick and his wife Elizabeth, and great-grandmother of Marina Gracie Hartnick.

title: Bach for a Solitary Cello Accompanied by Nature
description: Associations between the structural logic of Bach's music and notions of the mystical perfection of nature may be fanciful and romantic, but many a writer has made this poetic link. Others have offered a more rationalist view of Bach and nature as polar opposites, the music's supreme artifice and intellectual rigor contrasting starkly with nature's randomness and chaos.

title: For St. John's Rookies, A Special Wake-Up Call
description: Yesterday began at 6:15 A.M. for the five newest St. John's basketball players. It was only hours after they had attended a team meeting the night before, and minutes before they were to report to the first classes of the semester. Still, the freshman recruits were in another meeting with Coach Fran Fraschilla.

title: Honk If You Like Graphic Design
description: LICENSE plate devotees may have noticed Rhode Island's new ''twin wave'' design: a clean graphic in pale blue on white, evoking sun-bleached Block Island, with classic typography straight out of the Rhode Island School of Design.

title: Full Text of a Ransom Note Is Disclosed in Ramsey Case
description: Using the language of a crime thriller, the author of an apparent ransom note threatened to behead JonBenet Ramsey, the 6-year-old beauty princess who was killed last year, if her father did not ''follow our instructions to the letter.''

title: Pulp Fiction
description: MEMO TO: My Literary Agent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRICKLAND, HAROLD ALLISON, JR.
description: STRICKLAND-Harold Allison, Jr., 82, of Vero Beach, FL., formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut, died on September 3, 1997. He was born February 5, 1915 in Detroit, Michigan, the son of Harold A. and Mary (Pugh) Strickland; m. Ruth Voigt, May 29, 1940 (dec. 1982); m. Anne Muir King, May 18, 1985 (dec. 1992); m. Betty Spangler Levenson, January 4, 1994. He was awarded a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering and a B.S. in Electrical Engineering by the University of Michigan in 1937 and an M.B.A. from Harvard in 1938. He was an executive engineer at Budd Wheel Company, 1938-1950, where he helped design the first automotive disc brakes and the first anti-lock brake skid control systems. More than 70 patents were granted in his name. From 1950-1964 he served at General Electric as Vice President and General Manager of Industrial Electronics. At GE, the businesses for which he was responsible created the first solid state electronic computer, the first automated bank check processing system-including magnetic character imprinting and high speed reading and sorting, and the first heart pacemakers. The mass flowmeter was invented for highperformance aircraft, managing fuel consumption on the supersonic Concorde where more than half the fuel is consumed on takeoff. In addition, computer-controlled electric generator stations were produced as well as numerical control systems for machine control and computer-aided design. From 1964-1980 he was President of General Signal Corporation. Under his tenure it grew from an annual volume of $35 million in sales to over $1.6 billion and achieved a position in sales and profitability among the upper half of Fortune 500 companies. He served on the boards of General Signal, Cross & Trecker, Prime Computer, Machinery & Allied Products Institute, and in Vero Beach, the Atlantic Classical Orchestra and the Center for the Arts. Club memberships included the Moorings Club, Vero Beach, and the University Club, New York City. Among his hobbies were music, travel, photography, boating, working in wood, metals, and electronics, and collecting paintings and antiquities. He was also interested in the genealogy of his family, which on his mother's side included Major Moses Van Campen, a Revolutionary War hero, and the Crandall family, who maintained a station on the Underground Railroad. He is survived by his sister, Elizabeth Forrester; his wife, Betty; three children-Stephanie Strickland, Leslie Strickland, Harold Strickland III; four grandchildren-Robin Pfaff, Alexander Pfaff, Douglas Pfaff, Samuel Strickland; and four stepchildren-Suzanne King, Melissa Klingenberg, Ann Roan, and Tom Levenson. The family will receive friends at home, 172 Springline Drive, Vero Beach, Florida, on Friday, September 5, 1997 from 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. Services will be held in the chapel at the Second Congregational Church, 139 East Putnam Avenue, in Greenwich, Connecticut on Sunday, September 7 at 4 P.M. For further information please contact the Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach, Florida.

title: HOME HEALTH INCREASES LINE OF CREDIT FOR AN ACQUISITION
description: The Home Health Corporation of America Inc. said yesterday that it was planning a new acquisition to take advantage of consolidation in the industry. The company, a home health care provider, said it would increase its line of credit to $125 million from $100 million to help finance the acquisition. The company, based in King of Prussia, Pa., made 10 acquisitions in its fiscal year that ended in June. Shares in Home Health fell $1.3125, to $11. In a conference call yesterday, the company's chief executive, Bruce Feldman, declined to identify the acquisition target.

title: NATO General Vows to Curb Bosnian Mobs
description: The new military commander of NATO warned today that American and other Western peacekeeping troops in Bosnia were prepared to use ''lethal means'' to protect themselves against the sort of mob violence that has erupted there in recent days.

title: Dr. Viktor E. Frankl of Vienna, Psychiatrist of the Search for Meaning, Dies at 92
description: Viktor E. Frankl, who used his experiences as a prisoner in German concentration camps in World War II to write ''Man's Search for Meaning,'' an enduring work of survival literature, and to open new avenues for modern psychotherapy, died on Tuesday in Vienna. He was 92 and was considered to be one of the last of the great Viennese psychiatrists.

title: Cheered by Wall Street, Some Asia Stock Markets Revive
description: Share prices jumped 7.1 percent in Hong Kong yesterday, with the benchmark index recording its biggest one-day gain ever in terms of points, as investors drew strength from Wall Street's surge on Tuesday and snapped up shares that had plunged in the last few days, the steepest part of the Hong Kong market's worst slump since 1989.

title: Extending the Meaning of 'Classical' Beyond the European Tradition
description: There was an atmosphere of mock triumph in the West 27th Street headquarters of the World Music Institute one rainy afternoon recently. A caller was desperately seeking a sitar player who would be willing to sit in a store window for five minutes during a reception for a gallery show opening. The musician had to be good-looking, a credible performer on the large, ancient Indian stringed instrument and someone who would not be insulted by the circumstances. After a few phone calls, the institute's staff made the match.

title: Overcoming a Leadership Crisis, Adelphi Sets a New Course
description: A year ago, Adelphi University was in crisis. State officials were contemplating removing its trustees and president, Peter Diamandopoulos, on accusations of mismanagement. As enrollment plunged, faculty leaders and other critics feared Adelphi might collapse.

title: Couples Build Bigger as Their Children Leave Home
description: LYNN KORDA and Jules Kroll raised four children in a 5,900-square-foot home in Rye, N.Y. But now that their children are grown, they have decided to upsize, as builders say, and are planning a new house of at least 8,000 square feet.

title: Photographers Invoke Their Right to Privacy
description: Several photographers assailed for stretching the limits of privacy laws invoked their own right to privacy today, refusing to be photographed or interviewed after six of them and a motorcyclist were declared under suspicion of contributing to the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in a high-speed car crash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISSER, SAM
description: TISSER-Sam. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing in Netanya, Israel, of the father of its esteemed member, Mr. Marvin Tisser. Heartfelt sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres.

title: U.S. to Go Back on Internet With Social Security Benefits
description: Wrestling with one of the largest test cases of how to protect the privacy of electronic information, the Clinton Administration will soon re-establish an Internet site where people can see how much they are entitled to receive in future Social Security benefits, Federal officials said today. But the Government will impose safeguards to enhance personal privacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BING, RUDOLF
description: BING-Rudolf. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of former general manager Rudolf Bing. A consummate man of the theatre and the last of the great impresarios, Sir Rudolf served our company for close to a quarter of a century, guiding the Metropolitan to new heights of artistic achievements. He put his indelible stamp on the company by bringing to the House the world's greatest directors and designers, revolutionizing the look of our productions in which his involvement with the smallest of details is legendary. Of even more profound importance to our company was his fierce commitment to the breaking of all racial barriers. And under his leadership, the company moved successfully to its much needed new home at Lincoln Center in 1966. His unwavering adherence to exacting standards of artistic excellence, discipline and hard work-leavened always by his mordant wit-has served as an inspiration to the Metropolitan to this day. His incalculable contribution to the development of the art form of opera remains unequaled. Everyone who loves opera remains in his debt, and we remember him with deep pride, gratitude, and affection. James W. Kinnear, Chairman of the Board Bruce Crawford, President and Chief Executive Officer Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is my belief that they do share that grief and that sorrow, that they are dealing with it in their own way, which may not be our way.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Music column of the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday about an ''Opera by the Sound'' benefit for the Shubert Performing Arts Center this Sunday misstated the location. The center is in New Haven, not Stamford.

title: On the Trail
description: Events yesterday in the Democratic mayoral primary campaign in New York City.

title: When Money Counts
description: ''IT looks like something you've seen before, but then again, it doesn't,'' David Reid said of the porcelain vases he and his partner, James Klein, design and produce in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARIO M. CUOMO, the three-term Democratic Governor of New York, and WILLIAM J. BENNETT, who was President George Bush's drug czar and Secretary of Education in the Reagan Administration, are not normally allies in public causes. But yesterday it was announced that they will serve as co-chairmen of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America. The two men appeared at a news conference yesterday morning at the J. W. Marriott Hotel in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIESS, PHILIP R.
description: FRIESS-Philip R. On Sept. 1, 1997, age 86, of North Miami Beach, Fla., formerly of Forest Hills, N.Y. Loving husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Renee (Robert) Ehrlich. Loving and cherished grandfather of Michael and David.

title: A Delicate Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney's ESPN Unit Buying Classic Sports Programmer
description: ESPN reached beyond telecasting live sports and news yesterday to acquire Classic Sports Network, which in two years has carved a nostalgic cable television niche by repackaging old sports events.

title: Imitating Billie Holiday, 'Funk' Star Is Still Herself
description: Never mind the fact that when Ann Duquesnay impersonates Billie Holiday in her New York cabaret debut at Rainbow and Stars, her singing is so robust that she makes the legend she is saluting seem a waifish little kitten by comparison. Ms. Duquesnay, who recently starred on Broadway in ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk'' is a commanding performer whose chameleon voice and personality spill out all over the stage.

title: UConn Loses Ralph to Injury
description: Less than six months after undergoing reconstructive knee surgery, Shea Ralph, projected as a key player for the 1997-98 Connecticut women's basketball team, has been lost for the season after reinjuring her right knee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, LUCY
description: GREENE-Lucy, died August 31 at the age of 77 after a brief illness. The family wishes to express their great sorrow at her passing. She is survived by her husband, Thomas LoMonaco, her two children, Joshua Greene and Deborah Bershatsky, her daughter-in-law Judy Greene, her son-in-law Charles Bershatsky, and four grandchildren, Rachel, Sarah, Lydia and Ezra. She will be very much missed by all of us.

title: South Florida Hits Field for First Time
description: Lee Roy Selmon, the Pro Football Hall of Famer, refers to it as the football complex. In reality, Selmon is talking essentially about three trailers and a practice field.

title: 500 Washington Residents Protest Outside Control
description: Several hundred District of Columbia residents today protested the shift of power from the city's elected officials to a financial control board with a rally and march to the Capitol.

title: Joint Venture on Energy
description: The Connecticut Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a joint venture with Delmarva Power and Light Company of Wilmington, Del. to sell natural gas, electricity, fuel oil and other energy products in New York and New England.

title: Soros Closes Foundation In Belarus
description: George Soros, the American financier and philanthropist, closed his foundation in Belarus yesterday, saying that the Government's persistent harassment of the foundation and new criminal investigations of its Belarussian personnel left him with no other choice.

title: Using the Tabloids?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispute in Riverside Park Ends in Fatal Shooting
description: A 20-year-old Manhattan man was shot dead in Riverside Park near 97th Street at dusk yesterday after he and his brother argued with some strangers, the police said.

title: Tobacco Accord Faces Delay in Congress, Leaders Warn
description: Congressional leaders said today that they had no plans to act on the proposed tobacco settlement this year, while advocates for the proposal warned that such a delay could kill the deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUHLSTOCK, FREDA
description: MUHLSTOCK - Freda. Two months short of her 99th birthday. Widow of Rudy. Survived by two sons Robert (Helen) and Arthur (Jacqueline) and five grandsons and seven great-grandchildren. Graveside services were held.

title: U.S. Is Alone in Seeking Loophole in Ban on Mines
description: Negotiators for the United States have found themselves nearly isolated at an international conference here as they try to amend a draft treaty banning antipersonnel land mines. ''I'm sure the American delegation is feeling a bit lonely,'' said Jill E. Sinclair, a Canadian representative.

title: Tabloids In London Scream Softly
description: Three days after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in a car crash in Paris, editors and ombudsmen of Britain's tabloids are uncharacteristically silent. They are keeping a low profile to reduce public outrage over their usual frenzied coverage of the Princess.

title: WPP and Omnicom form specialty units; Bates resigns an account, and Publicis buys a stake.
description: THE lull that settled over Madison Avenue during the Labor Day weekend ended abruptly yesterday with a spate of news that included the formation of specialty units by the world's two biggest agency companies, a resignation of a large account and an acquisition.

title: Teen-Agers' Trial Postponed
description: The New Jersey teen-agers accused of killing their newborn son in November and dumping his body in a trash bin behind a Newark, Del., motel will go on trial in Wilmington on May 4, a Delaware judge ruled yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, NETTIE
description: KATZ-Nettie, on Sept. 3, 1997, at Century Village, Deerfield Beach, Florida. She is survived by her son Jerome, her daughter Marilyn Hirsch, a brother Daniel Oringel, Sister, Cissy Lerner, four grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. A graveside service will be held on Friday, September 5, at 11 AM, Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, Queens, New York. For info: Crabiel Parkwest Funeral Chapel, New Brunswick, NJ.

title: Moynihan and D'Amato Fight Clinton's Veto of Medicaid Help
description: The two Senators from New York, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato, took the first step today to overturn President Clinton's veto of legislation that would have provided millions of dollars to the state for the care of poor people under Medicaid.

title: Coffee Hits a 3-Month High And El Nino Gets the Blame
description: Coffee futures prices jumped to a three-month high yesterday on concern that dry weather in Colombia and Central America would reduce the size and quality of the coming harvests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARCZ, DEAN ERNEST
description: SCHWARCZ-Dean Ernest. The Central Queens YM & YWHA records with profound sorrow the passing of Dean Ernest Schwarcz. An outstanding and distinguished community leader, his vision was responsible for the establishment of the Rabbi Simon Hevesi Jewish Heritage Library, a Jewish public library, located in the Y building. He was an inspiration to all who were fortunate enough to have known him. To his wife, Marta, we extend our deepest sympathy. Craig Goodman, President Judith Friedman Rosen, Chairman of the Board

title: UUNET TECHNOLOGIES ACQUIRES NLNET OF THE NETHERLANDS
description: Worldcom Inc.'s Uunet Technologies unit, an Internet service provider, said yesterday that it had bought Nlnet of the Netherlands for an undisclosed amount of stock. The acquisition of Nlnet, a Dutch Internet service provider, would allow Uunet to provide a wider group of networking services to businesses in Europe, the company said. Uunet connects corporations to the Internet and to their far-flung offices. The closely held Nlnet, which will be renamed Uunet NL, controls 66 percent of the business market in the Netherlands.

title: Prosecutors Join Forces in Torture Case
description: When the top Federal and state prosecutors in Brooklyn, Zachary W. Carter and Charles J. Hynes, recently stood side by side and vowed to cooperate in the case of suspected police torture at the 70th Precinct station house, the amicability contrasted sharply with their rocky encounter in an earlier explosive case -- the murder of a Hasidic scholar in Crown Heights in 1991.

title: Whimsical French Creations
description: NIPPLE-SHAPED, wobbly looking $40 porcelain tea lamps (above), called Igloo de Nuit and meant to be used with votive candles, are among the playful designs by two young Parisian designers, Catherine Levy and Sigolene Prebois.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, DIANA
description: SPENCER-Diana. The patients and staff of The Aids Care Center at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center mourn the tragic death of our beloved benefactor. The Princess touched all of our lives through her efforts on our behalf, as well as her tireless campaign to eliminate stigma and demonstrate a loving, concerned approach to the sick and needy. We will miss the kindness and grace of this remarkable advocate for humanity. Jonathan L. Jacobs, M.D., Medical Director Samuel Merrick, M.D., Associate Medical Director Gerard Ilaria, CSW, Program Director

title: Mahathir's $20 Billion Market Cure
description: KUALA LUMPUR  After weeks of trying to bolster Malaysia's slumping stock market by cajoling investors and threatening speculators, Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad announced Wednesday that the government would inject up to $20 billion into the market to support share prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, BRUCE CHARLES
description: RIVKIN-Bruce Charles, on September 2, at age 43 of brain cancer. Attorney, CPA, executive, community leader and focal point of both his immediate family and his wide ranging extended family. An extraordinary individual who never stopped giving of himself, he was deeply loved and his memory will be cherished. He is survived by his wife Susan Denenholz; his sons Eric fourteen and Jason ten; his parents Charles and Tina Rivkin; and his brother Douglas Rivkin. All are welcome to a service in Bruce's memory at Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, on Sunday, September 7th at 3 P.M.

title: Bill Blass as Furniture Maker
description: BILL BLASS has designed bedsheets and towels, so why not furniture? On Tuesday, at the National Academy Museum, Mr. Blass will preview pieces from his 50-piece furniture collection, to be manufactured by Pennsylvania House and shown at the furniture market in High Point, N.C., on Oct. 21. Perhaps taking a cue from Ralph Lauren, Mr. Blass plays it safe by adapting dressers, tables and chairs from his own homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIA, TED
description: ELIA-Ted. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ted Elia, associated with The Times from 1969, until retiring in 1993.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS-ZYTEC IN $529 MILLION DEAL
description: Computer Products Inc., a maker of power conversion equipment for the computer industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a rival maker of electronic components, the Zytec Corporation, in a $529 million stock swap. Computer Products will exchange 1.33 of its shares, valued at $42.14 based on Tuesday's closing price, for each Zytec share. That gives Zytec shareholders a 45 percent premium. Zytec shares rose $7.4375, to $36.4375, yesterday in Nasdaq trading, while Computer Products fell $3.3125, to $28.375. The acquisition will double Computer Products' 1997 revenue to $530 million and is intended to create a one-stop supplier of power-conversion products.Computer Products, based in Boca Raton, Fla., will issue 16.7 million new shares to buy Zytec, which is based in Eden Prairie, Minn. Computer Products shareholders will own 60 percent of the enlarged company, with Zytec holders owning the rest.

title: Man Is Fatally Shot Near Lincoln Center
description: A 35-year-old man was shot to death in an apartment across the street from Lincoln Center early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Yesterday, because of a production error, a picture in some copies showing flowers left by mourners on a London Street carried an erroneous caption and credit, intended for a different scene. The site shown was Kensington Palace in London, Diana's residence, not Buckingham Palace, and the picture was by Agence France-Presse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFT, ED
description: HAFT-Ed. The Board of Governors, Members and Staff of Middle Bay Country Club mourn the loss of our esteemed member. He was a great fighter, a wonderful friend and terrific person. Our heartfelt sympathies go to his loving family and all those who knew him and will miss him.

title: Good Underdogs, Or Bad Rankings?
description: The exception has become the rule in men's tennis, and the question is whether the rules need to be changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACKER, LOIS WETHERELL
description: HACKER-Lois Wetherell, on September 2, at the age of 67, in her home in Manhattan, of a brain tumor and associated complications. At the time of her death, she had been married to Andrew Hacker for 42 years, and is also survived by her daughter, Ann Gower of Harwich, Ma. At her express request, there will be no funeral or memorial service. Friends or relatives wishing to make a tangible tribute in her memory may send a contribution to the Mina Rees Library Matching Fund, c/o Susan Newman, CUNY Graduate School, 33 W. 42 St, New York, NY 10036.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economic Reports Strong, But Market Effect Is Muted

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CRONIN, KATHRYN
description: CRONIN-Kathryn. Executive Director of the Association of Medical Publications, Inc. was called to eternal glory on July 20, 1997. Her devoted friends will celebrate her life in a memorial service on September 10 at 3:30PM St. Paul the Apostle Church, 415 W. 59 St.

title: HEALTHSOUTH TO ACQUIRE ASC NETWORK FOR $130 MILLION
description: The Healthsouth Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the ASC Network Corporation, an operator of outpatient surgery centers, for about $130 million. Healthsouth, which provides outpatient and rehabilitation services, said it would also assume about $50 million of ASC's debt. The company said it expected the acquisition to immediately add to earnings. Healthsouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., is also in the process of acquiring a nursing home chain, the Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation, for about $900 million in stock. The Privately held ABC is based in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Cablevision Sells Systems
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, Long Island, said it had agreed to sell cable-television systems in 10 states to Mediacom L.L.C. of Middletown, N.Y., for $315 million in cash as part of its plan to focus on a few metropolitan markets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Loss of Diana's Rare Spirit Qualifies as Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: NIGEL MUMFORD is an Episcopal lay minister who believes that the Lord will provide, but that a little human intervention doesn't hurt. And when the help comes from a family member, all the better.

title: Delay Expected For Spacecraft Going to Saturn
description: Launching of the $3.4 billion Cassini spacecraft to explore Saturn will probably be delayed next month as a result of damage caused by a ground cooling-system malfunction, space agency officials said yesterday.

title: Los Angeles Faces a Suit By Writers
description: The Hollywood screenwriters union says it will take the City of Los Angeles to Federal court on Monday to overturn an ordinance requiring writers and artists to get city permits before they can work out of their homes.

title: Dolphins' Stubbs Is Out for Season
description: The Miami Dolphins placed defensive end DANIEL STUBBS on injured reserve after he underwent season-ending knee surgery, the team said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKIN, DEWITT, JR.
description: PETERKIN-DeWitt, Jr., of Noroton, CT. Died August 29, 1997 of heart failure and complications related to Parkinsons Disease. He was 84. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 5 at 11 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Rd., Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The American Parkinson's Association, 1250 Hyland Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10305-1946 or to Waveny Care Center Employee Fund, 3 Farm Rd., New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: Antiques Stars Return to the Scene Of First Loves
description: IT was high noon at the fabled flea market here, and midway down the usually sleepy town's main drag, Route 20 -- where treasure-toting shoppers dodged bumper-to-bumper traffic -- a small but enthusiastic crowd was forming around two identically dressed, identically blond, identically sunglass-shaded men trying to cross the road one Friday in midsummer.

title: Shackling Family Planning Abroad
description: Congress faces another battle on international family planning, which is still mired in domestic abortion politics. The House is scheduled to consider a foreign appropriations bill today that includes an ill-advised amendment to restrict funding for overseas groups that provide abortions or abortion counseling.

title: Sales Results Show Americans Buying Trucks and More Trucks
description: The new Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle has not yet reached showrooms, but most dealerships are sold out for the rest of this year. The Lincoln Navigator, a huge luxury truck, is also in short supply. And August sales results released today show that Americans continue to buy more and more trucks, with the latest, expensive truck models among the most popular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUNDLICH, RALPH B. (AKA RAY FRIENDLY)
description: FREUNDLICH-Ralph B. (aka Ray Friendly). Age 84 of Bisbee, Arizona. Formerly of New York City on September 2, 1997, after a protracted illness. Musician, teacher, composer, artist, writer and advocate. Loving brother of Jules of Minneapolis, Minnesota and the late Irwin. Devoted brother-in-law of Lillian Freundlich and the late Miriam Freundlich. He is also survived by nephews Roger Freundlich of Espoo, Finland and Douglas Freundlich of Arlington, Massachusetts, niece Laura Muessig of Minneapolis, two grand nieces and six grand nephews. A memorial service at Bisbee will be announced at a later date.

title: 70th Precinct Faces Lawsuit In New Arrest And Dispute
description: A 70-year-old Brooklyn man has taken the first step toward filing a lawsuit against the city in connection with an altercation with a police officer from the 70th Precinct that left him with a badly injured hip, the man's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Tunnel Barriers Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Brutality Case Seen Bringing Modified Duty For Officer
description: Police Officer Justin A. Volpe, who was suspended from the police force without pay after he was arrested and charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant on Aug. 9 inside the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn, is expected to return to modified duty next week, two law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Pepsico Wins $94 Million For Defection By Bottler
description: Recouping some of its losses from a defection in Venezuela last year, Pepsico Inc. won a $94 million award that was announced yesterday at the International Court of Arbitration in Paris.

title: Tentative Columbia Accord in Alabama
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has reached a preliminary settlement with the State of Alabama over a Medicaid billing investigation at one of its hospitals, a state official said yesterday.

title: With Golan's Layers of Loyalties, Who's a Spy?
description: At the entrance to this mountain village, charred tires speak of an anger that is welling once again among the Druse in their Israeli-held lands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MO
description: KATZ-Mo. Montefiore Medical Center sadly records the passing of a brilliant visionary, Mo Katz, former deputy director for policy and program development and vice president of planning at Montefiore. A highly respected hospital administrator at the medical center for twenty-eight years, he played a pioneering role in many of Montefiore's most significant social and medical programs. His wisdom, guidance and sense of humor will be missed by all who knew him. Our sincere condolences are extended to his wife, Mary Jane Koren, M.D., his children, and his entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., President Montefiore Medical Center

title: INSIDE METRO
description: WORKING TOGETHER -- Two cases in Brooklyn illustrate the intricate considerations that Federal and state prosecutors face when deciding which of their offices should prosecute a case that either may legally pursue. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, CHARLOTTE
description: ANDERSON-Charlotte. On September 2, 1997. Beloved wife of Robert G. Anderson. Loving sister of Julian and Stephen Paul. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 11, at 10:30 AM, in Stella Maris Hospice Chapel. Please omit flowers. Memorials may be sent to Stella Maris Hospice, 2300 Dulaney Valley Rd., Timonium, MD 21093.

title: Books, Not Decaf
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLON, MARGARET A.
description: MULLON-Margaret A., of Port Washington, New York and Boca Raton, Florida, on August 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Walter B. Mullon. Dear and loving mother of Mary Pat Schermerhorn, Kevin, Kathleen Gerber, Walter, Jane Ruane and Deborah Sherman. Also survived by 19 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Memorial Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10:30 AM, St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington, NY. Memorial contributions to Hospice Care Network, 128 West Main Street, Bay Shore, NY 11706 or St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31 Street, New York, NY 10001.

title: People
description: * Liza Gurall, executive producer at Toth Design and Advertising, New York, was promoted to the new position of general manager.

title: Albanese Is Lent $200,000 To Buy Last-Minute TV Ads
description: Councilman Sal F. Albanese has borrowed $200,000 from a small bank in his district to buy television commercials for his election campaign, trying to mount a last-ditch effort to gain ground on Ruth W. Messinger in the final days before the Democratic mayoral primary on Tuesday.

title: Following Campaign Law At Any Price
description: AS far as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is concerned, there is apparently no price too high to pay to follow the law.

title: Tennis Center Has Its Flaws, but Also Its Possibilities
description: Now that the United States Open has been under way for more than a week, its newly expanded home at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park looks like a very good deal for New York City. The place does have flaws, but it is still a work in progress. And, even in its transitional state, the tennis center already lives up to its name. It looks and feels national. When was the last time you could say that about a major new building project in New York?

title: Catholic Teachers' Contract
description: Contract negotiations are scheduled to resume today between representatives of the 225 lay teachers at eight Catholic high schools in southern New Jersey and the Archdiocese of Camden.

title: Lufthansa May Create A Low-Cost Airline
description: Lufthansa said yesterday that it might create a new low-cost European airline to fly less-traveled routes within Germany and on the Continent to stave off rising competition from lower-cost carriers. Lufthansa is considering a new airline as part of a plan to increase earnings on its smaller routes, said a Lufthansa spokeswoman, Dagmar Rotter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, IRENE
description: MARTIN-Irene. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Barbara and Larry and Barry and Barbara. Dear sister of Blanche Landesman and Mildred Parker. Cherished grandmother of Ari, Romy, Jamie and Kim. Service for family at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W.Broad St., Mt.Vernon, NY

title: No Excuses Accepted
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. to Investigate Gore Fund-Raising
description: As the Senate campaign finance hearings turn toward Vice President Al Gore, his fund-raising activities came under broader scrutiny today when the Justice Department announced that it would begin a preliminary examination into his telephone solicitations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASMANTIER, PAUL E.
description: PASMANTIER-Paul E., of West Orange, on Wednesday, September 3, 1997; Beloved husband of Jeanne, Father of Kathy Oliver and John; Father-in-law of Gordon and Isabelle; Brother of Jean Bueno De Mesquita; Grandfather of Colin and Miranda Oliver and Alexandre Pasmantier. Funeral from Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Ave, Maplewood, Friday, Sept 5 at 2PM. Interment B'Nai Abraham Memorial Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIELLO, DAVID
description: AIELLO-David, age 58, born March 17th, 1939, the son of Helen Aiello, last known to have resided in the Brooklyn area. He died Saturday, August 30th, 1997 in Rome Memorial Hospital. Would any kin or anyone knowing of any next of kin please contact the Rome DDSO collect, 315-336-2300, with any special funeral arrangements.

title: Fancy An Opera Seat?
description: IT may be weighty. It may be slightly shabby, and it's certainly been used. But there may be no better souvenir for a ballet or opera buff than a red plush seat or two from the Royal Opera House in London's Covent Garden.

title: Dell Computer Talking to Agencies
description: The Dell Computer Corporation said that it was talking to agencies about a special project. Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated that they could reach as much as $100 million.

title: Yankees Thinking Ahead About (You Bet!) Orioles
description: The Yankees will not start the injured David Cone against the Baltimore Orioles in their four-game series and may not have him for a good portion of the rest of the regular season.

title: North Korea to Accept Private U.S. Medical Aid
description: The private relief organization Americares has been given permission by North Korea to airlift about $23 million worth of donated medicines to the country for emergency use, officials of the charity said today.

title: IRON MOUNTAIN PLANS TO BUY 2 COMPANIES FOR $60 MILLION
description: The Iron Mountain Company, a business records storage concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two companies for a total of $60 million. The Boston-based company said it would acquire Records Retention/File Safe, an Oakland, Calif., provider of records management services, for $42 million in cash. It will also assume liabilities valued at $3 million. Iron Mountain said it would also buy Data Securities International Inc., a San Francisco provider of software escrow services, for a total of $18 million in stock and the assumption of debt. Records Retention has annualized revenue of about $12 million. Data Securities has annualized revenue of about $5.2 million. Last year, Iron Mountain had $138.7 million in revenue.

title: System Failure Disrupts Portions of AT&T '800' Services
description: Temporarily disrupting businesses across the nation, parts of the AT&T Corporation's toll-free telephone network crashed yesterday, delivering busy signals to callers looking for everything from airline tickets to insurance forms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, PEARL
description: HONIG-Pearl. Loving wife of the late Harry. Beloved mother of Elaine Alper and Alan Honig. Cherished grandmother of Jerome, Alyssa, Susan, Stacey, Barry and Jonathan. Great-grandmother of Benjamin, Andrew and Justin. Services Friday, 10am at Nieberg's Midwood Chapel Inc., 1625 Coney Island Ave (Corner Ave M), Brooklyn. 718-377-2700.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, JOSEPH G.
description: ROSE-Joseph G., passed away Tuesday, Sept. 2, 1997. Beloved father, grandfather, and brother. Survived by daughter Naomi, son Jay, daughter-in-law Carla, grandsons Joshua and Daniel and sisters Annie and Adele. Service Thursday, September 4, 1997 at 1:30PM at Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, family requests donations be made to the Heart Association.

title: Gateway Sees Flat Earnings This Quarter
description: Since its start in a Midwest barn 12 years ago, Gateway 2000 Inc. has grown to become a $6-billion-a-year computer company by combining sophisticated business skills and down-home marketing.

title: Japan without a trade surplus may not be such a great idea.
description: HARDLY anything is going right for the Japanese economy. After a burst of growth in the first quarter, Japan is once again teetering on the brink of recession. Meanwhile, protectionist noises are beginning to emanate from America as Japan's trade surplus grows. And the Japanese economy's near-term prospects for exports of capital goods to Southeast Asia have dimmed with the collapse of the Thai baht and other regional currencies.

title: Trial Date Is Postponed In Killing of Newborn
description: The New Jersey teen-agers accused of killing their newborn son in November and dumping his body in a trash bin outside a motel in Newark, Del., are to go on trial in Wilmington on May 4, a Delaware judge ruled yesterday.

title: The New York Times Company has applied to list its class A shares on the New York Stock Exchange and expects the shares to begin trading on the Big Board on Sept. 25. The company's class A shares currently trade on the American Stock Exchange; the class B shares are not publicly traded.
GOVERNOR VETOES BILL FOR TEACHERS TO RETIRE EARLY
description: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed legislation yesterday that would have allowed thousands of New York City's most experienced teachers to retire early, saying the bill would have created too much instability in a system that opened its doors yesterday to more than a half-million middle and high school students.

title: New League's Verdict: It Parted the Curtain
description: By using its muscle -- and every marketing and promotional lesson it has learned -- the National Basketball Association guaranteed the success of the Women's National Basketball Association.

title: Brooklyn Council Endorsements
description: Primaries are the real elections in many heavily Democratic parts of Brooklyn, and next Tuesday's ballots will feature an unusual number of competitive races for New York City Council seats. These are our endorsements.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stocks were slightly lower here this morning. At the midday recess in trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 75.90 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,659.27. On Wednesday, the Nikkei surged 502.65 points, or 2.76 percent, to 18,735.17 -- its biggest one-day gain since May 6.

title: Child of Oil and Gas Merger Starts Growing Right Away
description: Pioneer Natural Resources, wasting no time since its creation through the merger of Mesa Inc. and Parker & Parsley Petroleum a month ago, agreed today to buy Chauvco Resources, a Canadian oil and gas company, for $975 million in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELFENBEIN, HARRIET SALTSER
description: ELFENBEIN-Harriet Saltser. On September 3rd at her home in Palm Beach, FL. Wife of the late Irving Elfenbein, mother of Ann and Murray Pincus and Joan and William Button. Grandmother of Beth and Lynn Pincus and Jeffrey, Scot and Douglas DiStefano.

title: Viewing Classical Music as a Victim, Not of Pop Stars but Its Own Greed
description: WHO KILLED CLASSICAL MUSIC?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERARD, FRED N.
