description: GERARD-Fred N., age 67, of Phoenix, Arizona and New York City on September 1, 1997 at his home. Loving father of Daniele and Gregory, father-in-law of Dan, grandfather of Fiona.

title: In Life and in Death, a Front-Cover Favorite Whose Star Quality Hopped the Atlantic
description: It wasn't just her beauty, or that she was a real live princess, or that her life was part fairy tale, part soap opera, part Shakespearean tragedy.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS APPROVES $1 BILLION STOCK BUYBACK
description: Browning-Ferris Industries said yesterday that its board had approved a $1 billion stock buyback plan and raised the quarterly cash dividend by 12 percent. The stock repurchase program will consist of a Dutch auction self-tender offer to buy back as many as 15 million shares and a program to repurchase the company's shares on the open market. Browning-Ferris, a waste collection concern based in Houston, said that under the Dutch auction, which will expire on Oct. 1, it would purchase the shares for no less than $34 each and no more than $39. Shareholders who tender their shares will still be eligible to receive the increased dividend of 19 cents a share, up from 17 cents, payable Oct. 6 to shareholders of record Sept. 19.

title: Former Track Coach At School Is Charged In 4 Bay Area Rapes
description: A former high school track coach was charged at an arraignment today with the rape, robbery and assault of four women in the Oakland area. The police said they were continuing to investigate the man in connection with nine other recent sexual attacks in the East Bay area.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the proposed sale of SFX Broadcasting Inc. to Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst misstated the title of a Hicks, Muse executive, Steve Hicks. He is president of the firm's Capstar Broadcasting Corporation, not a principal of the firm.

title: Driver Was Responsible
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMINSKI, JOHN W.
description: KOMINSKI-John W. On August 30, 1997. Revered environmental and science educator. Founding Executive Director of Alley Pond Environmental Center, former Chair of Environmental Education Advisory Council, Assistant Director Science NYC Board of Education, Coordinator Outdoor and Environmental Studies Gateway Environmental Study Center, Founding Project Director, High School for Environmental Studies, former Director of Education, New York Hall of Science. Former VP, New York State Outdoor Education Association, past Education Chairperson American Nature Study Society. Exceptionally creative, innovative workshop leader; shared his knowledge through staff development efforts at Watson Ecology Workshops and other forums.

title: Royal Family, Stung by Critics, Responds to a Grieving Nation
description: Breaking its silence on the astonishing outpouring of grief over the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, the British royal family said today that it was ''deeply touched and enormously grateful.''

title: 31 Superfund Sites Cleaned
description: Thirty-one of New Jersey's 116 Superfund sites have been completely cleaned, according to a report compiled by the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Effort to Oust a Baptist Leader Is Rejected
description: After a tumultuous morning in which dissident ministers surged toward the stage demanding to be heard, delegates at the annual meeting of the nation's largest predominantly black religious organization voted today to retain the Rev. Henry J. Lyons as their president, despite accusations that he misused his office for personal gain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURDUE, WILLIAM
description: PURDUE-William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Purdue, associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1982.

title: Planned Women's Series Could Aid U.S. Runners
description: In the 1980's and 1990's, American women have enjoyed limited success in distance running.

title: For Welfare Recipients, Employment Is Elusive
description: To the Editor:

title: Rusedski Rolls Along With Remodeled Game
description: There will be a funeral. And Greg Rusedski will pry his eyes open before dawn to watch the procession, to absorb the finality of the death of Diana, the Princess of Wales, just as any resident Briton who will be watching the telly from America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEFEL, PROF. DR. ERNEST C.
description: STIEFEL-Prof. Dr. Ernest C., died at 89 in Baden-Baden Germany on September 3, 1997. Born Mannheim, Germany, October 29, 1907. Member of the bars of New York, Germany, France and England. Distinguished international lawyer, legal scholar and author. Adjunct Professor at New York Law School. Recipient of many honors, including the Great Cross of Merit (Germany) and Honorary Degree from the University of Konstanz. Counsel to Coudert Brothers, New York. Survived by nephew Eli Maor, niece Shulamith Nathanson, four grandnephews, many friends and colleagues. No funeral rites. Memorial gathering at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MINTZER, WILLIAM LAND
description: MINTZER-William Land, 19441997. A Memorial Service will be at 7PM Thursday, September 11, 1997 at the Abbott Kaplan Theatre, Performing Arts Center, Purchase College, SUNY, Purchase, New York For additional information, call 914-251-6850.

title: Gallo Powers Its Way Into the Premium Wine Market
description: Over lunch recently at Bistro Ralph, a wine makers' hangout here in the heart of the California wine country, somebody mentioned that E.& J. Gallo Winery Inc., the mass producer of inexpensive jug brands like Carlo Rossi and Gallo Hearty Burgundy and street fortifiers like Thunderbird, had placed in the top 10 in a rating competition with one of its new Sonoma wines. But the remark only exasperated Gina Gallo, a third-generation marketing executive with the company.

title: Plans of Louis XIV, Disney of His Day
description: AN exhibition of renderings by the architectural historians Bernd Dams and Andrew Zega will be on view from Sept. 11 through Oct. 18 at the Didier Aaron gallery, 32 East 67th Street. The show, ''The Pleasure of Building,'' contains 30 watercolors based on historical research that recreate commissions by perhaps the most flamboyant patron of architecture in European history, Louis XIV.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDWIN, HENRY DEFOREST
description: BALDWIN-Henry deForest, of New York, NY and Roxbury, CT, died Tuesday, September 2, at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital from respiratory failure due to ALS, known as Lou Gehrig's disease. He was a Trusts and Estates partner at the law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. Previously, he was a partner and the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the law firm of Lord, Day & Lord (later known as Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith). He served on several not for profit boards, including the Council of the Yale Club of New York City, the New York Botanical Garden, and the Roxbury Land Trust. He is survived by his beloved wife Martha Denniston Baldwin, his two sons Sherman of Darien, CT and Alexander of Silver Spring, MD, his sister Lois Baldwin Bishop of Minneapolis, MN and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11 A.M., on Saturday, September 6, at The Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91st Street. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Columbia University ALS Gift Fund, c/o Maura del Bene, 710 W. 168 St., New York, NY 10032 or the Roxbury Land Trust, Roxbury, CT 06783.

title: Notes From the Movies: When the Audience Exits Humming
description: The popular success of film scores by John Williams, Ennio Morricone, Elliot Goldenthal, Jerry Goldsmith and other contemporary screen composers has convinced classical record labels that there is a big crossover market for soundtrack albums. But while most labels are falling over one another to sign up soundtracks for current films, some are also looking at scores of the past as a repertory that has been poorly explored. Nonesuch, the latest label to take this view, has just introduced a film series that so far includes four volumes, each devoted to the works of a single composer and together representing a broad sampling of the art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, MOLLIE
description: ISRAEL-Mollie. Dearly loved wife of the late Samuel. Much loved mother of the late Lester. Much loved mother-in-law of Shelley and dearly loved grandmother of Mark and Jennifer Israel. The last of eight siblings. Dear aunt of many wonderful nieces, nephews and great nieces and nephews. A very special lady. We love her and we will miss her. Funeral procession will leave ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 12:00PM, Thursday for a 1:30 P.M., service at Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Top I.R.A. Figure Is Visiting Washington
description: Gerry Adams, the leader of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, Sinn Fein, came to Washington for the first time since the Irish Republican Army restored a cease-fire and today promised ''generosity'' and ''compromise'' in coming peace talks.

title: SAFECO TO PAY $140 MILLION FOR WASHINGTON MUTUAL UNIT
description: The Safeco Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the insurance underwriting subsidiary of Washington Mutual Inc. for $140 million. As part of the deal, Washington Mutual, the nation's largest savings and loan company, will distribute Safeco's annuities through its banking networks. The acquisition of the WM Life Insurance Company subsidiary is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter. Safeco, a Seattle-based financial services and insurance company, had 1996 net income of $438.9 million. Washington Mutual, also based in Seattle, had 1996 net income of $114.2 million, and assets of $44.55 billion at the end of 1996.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Sad Glads

title: In Gusty Conditions, a Gutsy Victory for Davenport
description: One got there after a lengthy voyage in broad daylight, the other after a quick cruise under the spotlights, but they both performed in a simulated wind tunnel inside Arthur Ashe Stadium, where every shot was a test not just of their aim, but also of their patience.

title: Wish for the Princes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDERMAN, IDA
description: RUDERMAN-Ida. Of Floral Park, N.Y. Passed away September 2, 1997 at the age of 96. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Alexander Ruderman. Devoted mother, adored grandmother and great grandmother. Ida will be remembered for her great energy, tenacity and devotion to her family. She will be forever in our hearts. Private graveside service.

title: A Wild West Tragedy
description: Almost overlooked in the crush of news about the death of the Princess of Wales is an important and tragic story out of Arizona.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about the investigation of the car crash that killed the Princess of Wales misstated the role of Trevor Rees-Jones, the sole survivor. He was the bodyguard of Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, Diane's companion, not her bodyguard.

title: APPLIED POWER CONFIRMS IT WILL BUY VERSA TECHNOLOGIES
description: Applied Power Inc. ended days of speculation yesterday by confirming it would buy Versa Technologies Inc. for $24.625 a share, or a total of about $140 million. Versa Technologies, based in Racine, Wis., disclosed last week that it was in talks with the Milwaukee-based Applied Power but said a definitive agreement could not be assured. Both companies make products for hydraulic and fluid power markets. Applied Power said it would begin a tender offer for Versa Technologies shares in five days. Versa Technologies shares rose $2.25, to $24.375, while Applied Power's shares dropped 31.35 cents, to $60.1875.

title: Bridge
description: To test yourself on the defense of the diagramed deal, cover the East and South hands. You are West defending two no-trump after South has opened one no-trump, showing 15-17 points, and subsided following a Stayman response. You lead a spade and dummy's queen is played, won by East with the ace. He returns the three, and you capture South's nine with the ten. Now your six brings your partner's jack and South's king, with dummy throwing a heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL BALSO, SUZANNE WILDING
description: DEL BALSO-Suzanne Wilding, of Aiken, SC and Unionville, PA on September 2 in Aiken after a brief illness. Wife of Anthony M. Del Balso, mother of Wendy Berol Gifford of McLean, VA and J. Robin Bliss of Bedford Hills, NY; sister of Josephine Wilding Freeman of Purchase, NY; stepmother of Michael Del Balso of New York City and Dina Del Balso Rosser of Atlanta, GA; grandmother of eleven. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions may be made to Bayard Taylor Library of Kennett Square, PA or the Aiken County Open Land Trust, Aiken, SC 29801.

title: McGreevey Pledges to Roll Back Auto Rates 10%
description: With auto insurance emerging as the biggest issue in the New Jersey gubernatorial race, State Senator James E. McGreevey promised to lower rates today as he outlined his first detailed plan aimed at voters unhappy with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman for not doing more to lower their auto insurance bills.

title: A Legitimate Question: What's a New Window?
description: LESS than a year after my wife and I moved into an 1880's brownstone in Park Slope, Brooklyn, we had to get new windows. About halfway through the installation, our catch phrase became, ''If only we had known.''

title: Owners Discuss Realignment
description: With the baseball owners' self-imposed deadline less than a month away, their executive council and realignment committee met in Chicago yesterday and discussed a variety of realignment plans. No votes were taken.

title: Man Is Hit and Killed By N Train in Midtown
description: A man jumped onto the tracks of the N and R subway line at the 42d Street station yesterday during the evening rush hour, and officials said they thought he was killed by a Queens-bound N train seconds before transit officials shut off power.

title: Prima Donna Senate
description: As Congress returns to work, the battle over William Weld's nomination as ambassador to Mexico is one of the few stories quickening any pulses in the Capitol. It has all the makings of a political drama: a moderate former Governor fights the longtime nemesis of moderates, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, accompanied by hot rhetoric about the soul of their party.

title: Homeowners Call for Help
description: In a plea to state officials to bail out their beach community, an Asbury Park homeowners association has prepared a thick report on the city's financial crisis, rising crime and decaying neighborhoods.

title: The Limited May Sell Off Subsidiaries
description: Are changes afoot in Columbus, Ohio?

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: The Driving Range Becomes Big Business
description: The shag bag, a golfer's personal collection of practice balls, has become one of the game's dinosaurs. Only golf romantics still actually own the big leather or vinyl pouches. You may see them for sale in golf shops, but they are strictly nostalgia items, reminders of golf's quaint past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORRAY, STANLEY, M.D.
description: FORRAY-Stanley, M.D. Of Bayside. Beloved husband of the late Ann. Devoted father of Alan Forray and Barbara Brown. Dear brother of Leonard. Loving grandfather of Joshua, Matthew, Zachary and Charles. Services Friday 12 noon ''Schwartz Bros'', Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ELINOR JEAN SCHOFIELD
description: YOUNG-Elinor Jean Schofield. Died September 1, 1997. Devoted and loving mother of Jonathan and Elizabeth Young of New York. Beloved sister of Michael Schofield of Washington, DC, niece of Mother Virginia Schofield, T.C.G. of Tucson, AZ. and wife of the late William H. Young of NY. She will be remembered not only as a beautiful and cherished mother, but also as a lady of elegance, intelligence and style. Interment will be at Ancient Cemetery at Yarmouth Port, Mass. 10 A.M., Friday, September 5. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th Street and Lexington Avenue at 10AM on Saturday, September 6. All are welcome to attend. We love you and will miss you.

title: Leading Index Rose at a Fast Clip in July
description: The index of leading economic indicators rose at the fastest rate in five months during July, and construction spending advanced -- evidence that economic growth may accelerate in the year's second half.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANENBAUM, SIDNEY
description: TANENBAUM-Sidney, formerly of Lynbrook, NY. On Tuesday, September 2, 1997, at his home in West Palm Beach, Florida. He is survived by his daughter Amy, son Jay and brother Mel Tanenbaum. His warmth, humor and generosity touched us all and he will be long remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHESLER, IRVING (MURPH)
description: CHESLER-Irving (Murph). Dear brother, I remember your untimely death 7 years ago this date with sadness and sorrow. Seymour

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROTHSCHILD, JUDITH
description: ROTHSCHILD-Judith. Loved and greatly missed on your birthday. H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGUILAR, ALPHONSO
description: AGUILAR-Alphonso. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alphonso Aguilar, associated with The Times since 1968.

title: Torre Does Some Explaining
description: George Steinbrenner met with Joe Torre in the manager's office before last night's game with Baltimore and discussed the remarks Torre made on Saturday that it was ''unrealistic'' for the Yankees to think they could catch the first-place Orioles. Steinbrenner conceded on Tuesday that he was miffed by what sounded like a concession speech.

title: Dangerous Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Malaysia, in Crisis, Will Delay Projects
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said today that Malaysia would have to delay several big projects, including the 13.6 billion ringgit ($4.55 billion) Bakun hydro-electric project, because of its currency problems, the official news agency Bernama reported here.

title: 10 Are Accused of Fraud In Auto-Claim Scheme
description: Ten people have been charged in Brooklyn with being part of a ring that collected nearly $600,000 by submitting false auto-accident claims to insurance companies, New York State insurance officials and Brooklyn prosecutors said yesterday.

title: August Auto Sales Kept Up Strong Pace
description: For the second consecutive month, buyers flocked to car dealerships in August, giving the auto industry stronger-than-expected summer sales.

title: A Reporter Is Sentenced Over Article in Malaysia
description: A judge in Malaysia today sentenced a Canadian reporter for The Far Eastern Economic Review to three months in jail for contempt of the judiciary in an article he wrote about a lawsuit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, BRUCE
description: RIVKIN-Bruce. Lives he touched are enriched forever. Love to Susan, Eric, Jason, Douglas, Charles, Tina, Ann. Janet and Richard

title: Financing Is Ready for 3 Mixed-Income Buildings
description: With the New York State Housing Finance Agency given the green light last month by the State Legislature to sell $350 million more in tax-exempt bonds, financing is in place for three mixed-income rental projects in Manhattan to move forward under New York City's 80-20 program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASH, FLORENCE
description: BASH-Florence. The Jewish Teachers Community Chest mourns her passing. Her 50 years as administrator were the solid rock bearing the problems of changing demographics. To her daughter and family, condolences on the loss of our heroine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINOFF, IDA
description: MINOFF-Ida, passed away on August 23, 1997. Mourned by her son Ivan Feldman, her sister Sylvia Jankow, step-sons Marvin and Bruce Minoff, and 6 grandchildren. She is already missed.

title: Tyson to Pay $681 Million For Hudson
description: After a tainted-beef crisis last month that led to the largest recall of meat in the nation's history, Hudson Foods Inc. said today that it had agreed to be bought by Tyson Foods Inc. in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $681 million.

title: ZALE TO SELL FINE JEWELRY OPERATIONS FOR $65 MILLION
description: The Zale Corporation agreed yesterday to sell most of its Diamond Park Fine Jewelers unit to Finlay Enterprises Inc. for about $65 million. Diamond Park manages 185 leased jewelry shops in department stores. The operations being sold account for about 8 percent of Zale's annual sales and about 2 percent of its profit. The sale includes leased shops in Mercantile, Parisian and Marshall Field's stores, Zale said. For the year ended July 31, the sales for those departments were about $100 million. The New York-based Finlay operates 958 leased jewelry shops. Shares of the Dallas-based Zale rose $1.25, to $24.75. Finlay's shares rose 75 cents, to $19.625.

title: Croatian's Confession Describes Torture and Killing on Vast Scale
description: A former Croatian militiaman who acknowledges that he killed 72 civilians, tortured prisoners with electric shocks and ran a death camp has described in a chilling interview his journey from foot soldier to coldblooded killer during Croatia's war for independence.

title: Ronald Bittner, 55, Telephone Executive
description: Ronald L. Bittner, chairman of the Frontier Corporation, the corporate parent of Rochester Telephone, died Sunday at his home in Pittsford, N.Y., two weeks after he stepped down as chief executive. Mr. Bittner was 55.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLANDER, ISIDORE
description: ENGLANDER-Isidore. On September 4, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Father of Yola Coffeen and David Englander. Grandfather of Myriamne, Jonathan, Daniel, Emily and Freya. Great-grandfather of Mikayla. Brother of Sarah, Herman, Florence, and the late Deborah and Abram. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Center for Constitutional Rights, 666 Broadway, NY, NY 10012. Service Friday, 11AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Ready for Comeback, Armstrong Seeks Team
description: Eleven months after surgery for testicular cancer, LANCE ARMSTRONG said he is ready to return to competitive racing next year. But the 25-year-old American, one of the world's most successful road racers, has no team to ride for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORRELL, BROTHER LEONARD, F.S.C.
description: BORRELL - Brother Leonard, F.S.C., 84, passed away peacefully in his sleep on Sept 4, 1997. Calling hours will be held at De La Salle Hall, 810 Newman Springs Rd., Lincroft, NJ on Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. and Saturday from 2-4 P.M. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at De La Salle Hall Chapel on Saturday at 7:00 P.M. The interment will be held at St. Gabriel's Cemetery, Marlboro, NJ, Monday at 9:30 A.M. Memorial donations to De La Salle Nursing Development, 810 Newman Springs Rd., Lincroft, NJ 07738 would be appreciated.

title: Crew Orders Registration To Resume At 3 Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that some intermediate and high schools had wrongly turned away students trying to register on the first day of school and he ordered them to register all the new students in the next two days.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday showing members of I.B.M.'s Java marketing team misidentified the employee shown at the right. He was Kris Lichter; David Gee, the head of the team, was second from the left.

title: Higher Net Expected
description: Cornerstone Properties, a Manhattan real-estate company, said yesterday that it expected earnings in 1998 to exceed analysts' expectations, spurred by higher rents and its recent $1.06 billion purchase of office buildings from a Dutch pension fund.

title: Deep Within Superfund Bill Are Goodies for Montana
description: As if banished to a legislative limbo, bills to extend the toxic waste law known as the Superfund have languished in three successive Congresses. If Republican leaders have any hope of rescuing the latest version, they can scarcely afford to alienate Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the ranking Democrat on the committee considering the bill.

title: Get Rich in Chechnya: Kidnap Your Neighbors
description: The long ordeal of the Tlupov family began on Feb. 22.

title: Stocks Slip in Tokyo
description: Stocks continued their slide here this afternoon. At the midday recess, the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues was down 112.91 points, at 18,502.15, or six-tenths of 1 percent. On Thursday, the Nikkei closed down 120.11 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,615.06.

title: Time Passes, but the Genes Sing On
description: Aldo Mancusi is a Caruso enthusiast who five years ago turned his memorabilia collection -- everything from recordings, posters and photographs to costumes, letters, caricatures and even a cigarette package -- into the Enrico Caruso Museum of America. At the moment, the museum is in Mr. Mancusi's home in Brooklyn, but he is hoping to move the collection to its own building someday, and it was partly with this in mind that he presented a fund-raising concert on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Giuliani Wins Fight On Police Contract
description: An arbitration panel has upheld Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's wage offer to the powerful police union, all but ending an unusually vitriolic dispute that had been fought from precinct station houses to the Capitol in Albany.

title: Calenergy to Buy Back Big Kiewit Stake
description: The Calenergy Company said today that it would pay $1.15 billion to buy back Peter Kiewit Sons Inc.'s stake in the power generation company and its projects.

title: Radio Station Shut Down
description: Marshals pulled the plug yesterday on WZVU-FM (104.7), an unlicensed 92-watt radio station in Howell Township that favored oldies music.

title: After 8 Months, Pete Hamill Leaves The Daily News
description: Ending weeks of intense speculation, the owner of The Daily News announced yesterday that Pete Hamill's tenure as editor in chief was over, making Mr. Hamill the third editor in less than five years to leave or be removed from the paper's top newsroom position.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, JACK
description: WALKER-Jack, of Manhattan, died September 4, 1997 at age 72. He is survived by his beloved Phyllis Altman; children; Jeffrey, Michael and Samantha; grandchildren; Orion, Joshua, Ethan and Rachel; his two brothers Gerald and Newton. He will be dearly missed. Service will be held Sunday 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street.

title: Dispute Over Ellis Island
description: New Jersey got some help yesterday from the Federal Government in its 200-year-old jurisdictional dispute with New York over Ellis Island. In a brief filed with the United States Supreme Court, the Solicitor General's office supported most of the findings of a court-appointed arbitrator who recommended in April that New Jersey gain control of 22 acres of landfill on the island.

title: Civil Court Choices
description: Four Civil Court judgeships are being contested in New York City's Democratic primary next Tuesday. The winners are virtually certain to prevail in November's general election.

title: BRANDYWINE HEAD SAYS COMPANY MAY BE SOLD
description: The Brandywine Asset Management Company, a money management firm with about $7 billion in assets, is considering a sale of the company. ''It's one of the many options we are considering,'' Anthony Hitschler, Brandywine's founding partner, said yesterday. He said Brandywine, which is known for its ''value'' investing style, had retained the investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company. Brandywine, a closely held firm based in Wilmington, Del., could attract more than $115 million in a sale, according to investment bankers. It has about 60 employees. Among its clients are corporate pension funds, foundations and endowments.

title: Cash Transfers Monitored in Effort to Track Drug Money
description: The Treasury Department said yesterday that it is expanding a crackdown on the laundering of drug money from the New York region to focus on electronic cash transfers to the Dominican Republic.

title: Dead Infant Is Found Outside Bronx School
description: A newborn baby was found dead in a trash can outside Community School 150 on East 167th Street in the South Bronx yesterday morning, school officials said.

title: Mayor and Budget Panel Sparring at a New Level
description: As the ancient mariners in the world of New York City government, the leaders of the Citizens Budget Commission have spent six decades grabbing mayors by the purse strings and forcing them to listen to the business establishment's criticisms of their spending policies. And with equal vehemence, mayors have snapped right back that the commission was utterly nuts.

title: The Horror Has Become Near Routine
description: When the explosions sounded, Erez Zakan knew immediately that they were bombs. From his kiosk near the Ben Yehuda promenade, he had heard the bombs go off in the vegetable market five weeks ago, and the bus bomb on Jaffa Street in March 1995.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Mojo Hand'

title: Investors Get Easier Access To Treasuries
description: The Treasury announced several measures today to make it easier and less expensive for small investors to buy and sell Government securities.

title: New Video Releases
description: Kolya

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: OFFICERS' SILENCE STILL THWARTING TORTURE INQUIRY
description: Three weeks after city officials said they had cracked the so-called blue wall of silence in the investigation of the 70th Precinct torture case, investigators say that only two police officers have provided valuable information and that they have learned virtually nothing from scores of other officers who have been granted limited immunity from prosecution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, BENJI (NEE KATZKA)
description: GREEN-Benji (nee Katzka) on September 2, 1997 in Los Angeles. Cherished wife of James M. Green, M.D. Daughter of late Emil and Eva Plotkin Katzka. Predeceased by sister Elinor Benjamin and brother Gabriel Katzka. Survived by sons Steven and Clifford and five grandsons. Daughter Roberta died in 1974. Memorial service at Riverside Chapel 180 West 76th St. Sunday, September 7 at 10:45 AM.

title: No Peace, No Security
description: Death may be around any corner in Israel today. When the suicide bombs went off in a Jerusalem pedestrian mall yesterday, a friend of mine was a block away. A country that had achieved a degree of repose, of normality, is once again living at the edge.

title: Factory Orders Rose in July; Analysts Had Expected Drop
description: Orders placed with factories unexpectedly increased in July to a record level, a sign that manufacturing could be poised for faster growth.

title: Vote on the Site For 2004 Olympics May Make History
description: The 107 voting members of the International Olympic Committee have two choices Friday when they select the host city for the 2004 Summer Games. They can vote for pragmatism, or they can vote for history.

title: Home Depot to Build Its 3d Store in Queens
description: Home Depot has signed a deal to build its third store in Queens. It will be part of a shopping center that is being developed at Metropolitan Avenue and Woodhaven Boulevard in Glendale.

title: Pittsburgh Grabs an Advantage: Not Giving Penn State Extra Help
description: Pittsburgh's new coach, Walt Harris, did not think he needed to give Penn State's Joe Paterno any additional assistance in preparing the Nittany Lions for their season opener against the Panthers tomorrow at State College (ABC, 3:30 P.M.).

title: In computer chip making as in sports, there are times when it's essentially a matter of execution.
description: TWO Silicon Valley companies face sharply contrasting outlooks. Shares of Advanced Micro Devices fell more than 9 percent yesterday after the company said it expected a third-quarter loss, while shares of National Semiconductor gained a similar amount after it reported first-quarter earnings that exceeded Wall Street estimates.

title: Albright to Go Ahead With Mideast Trip
description: Declaring that the latest suicide bombings in Jerusalem gave even greater urgency to American peace efforts in the Middle East, President Clinton said today that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright would travel to the region next week as scheduled.

title: For Children
description: The Central Park Conservancy-Fleet Bank Fishing Derby

title: The Funeral on TV
description: All television networks plan comprehensive coverage of the funeral services Saturday for Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: MAYOR VS. WATCHDOG GROUP -- In responding to a critical report by the Citizens Budget Commission, Mayor Giuliani accused the commission of working with the campaign of Ruth W. Messinger to defeat him for re-election. B3.

title: Study Says Homeless Are Denied Preschool
description: Despite tougher Federal laws to make education available to homeless young children, more than 180,000 of them around the country have been unable to enroll in public preschool programs, according to a report released today.

title: First-Half Profit Rose at Elf Aquitaine
description: Elf Aquitaine S.A. said yesterday that its profit excluding one-time gains rose a greater-than-expected 38 percent in the first half of the year, helped by improved productivity, a stronger dollar and higher oil prices. Elf, France's largest oil company, earned 4.92 billion francs, or $806 million, up from 3.56 billion francs in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Sanctions Against Japan

title: Yankees Are Taking the Slow Lane to October
description: The Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles were relieved and delighted to see each other last night. At least one of them would win a game.

title: Radio Station Silenced; Another Is Heard Again
description: For three weeks, in a swath of New Jersey suburbia the swinging trumpets of big band music waged a losing battle against the sweet melodies of the 50's to the 70's.

title: Season Begins With a Fanfare
description: In his two previous seasons as music director of the San Francisco Symphony, Michael Tilson Thomas has had notable success invigorating his programs with new and unfamiliar works and attracting younger, more casual concertgoers to Davies Symphony Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MO
description: KATZ-Mo. The DOROT community sadly mourns the passing of Mo Katz. He warmly embraced our mission, guided our vision, and kept us laughing. He was a generous humanitarian, with a twinkle in his eye and an undaunted zest for life. We will always remember him a champion of the elderly and a trailblazer in innovative programming. Our hearts go out to his wife, family, friends, and colleagues at The Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation. The Board and Staff of DOROT Vivian Ehrlich, Executive Director Renee Ascher, Board President

title: Edwin M. McConnell, 76, Last Of World War II Pilot Brothers
description: Lieut. Col. Edwin Maurice McConnell, the last of the three ''Flying McConnell Brothers'' of World War II whose name was given to an air base in Kansas, died on Monday at his home in Englewood, Colo. He was 76.

title: Food Stamps Restored
description: A state legislative committee cleared the way yesterday for welfare agencies to distribute food stamps to 20,000 legal immigrants who became ineligible for the program on Monday.

title: 3 More Held In the Inquiry Into the Crash
description: The French police today detained three more photographers who had snapped pictures of the car wreck that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, after a chase last Sunday. The three turned themselves in after learning that the police were looking for them.

title: In Brooklyn, Boredom Can Be Fatal
description: If there's a sure-fire formula for the aspiring filmmaker hoping to grab Hollywood by the nose, it might well be the one followed by Salvatore Stabile's no-budget movie, ''Gravesend.'' Using hand-held cameras, film a bunch of foul-mouthed teen-age lowlifes on some of Brooklyn's meanest streets, crank up the macho violence to a screaming pitch, then let the profanity rip. Presto, you have that most precious of Hollywood essences, Eau de Street Life, an ether so rare and volatile that once inhaled it can turn a mouse into a Tarantino.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEARER, JOSEPH L.
description: FEARER-Joseph L., 87, of West Hartford, CT., and New York City died September 1 in North Branford, CT. He was husband of the late Eunice Holzman Fearer, father of Paul Fearer and Jane Fearer Safer, grandfather of Sarah Safer. Private burial is at Arlington National Cemetery. Funeral service September 7, 1997. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Joseph and Eunice Fearer Fund, Museum of Modern Art, Department of Prints, 11 West 53 Street, New York, NY 10019.

title: New Season at Belmont
description: For race-track aficionados, the first sure sign of the coming of autumn is officially here: Belmont's fall meeting begins today.

title: Hospitals Are Placing Profits Ahead of Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Eases Against Mark On German Rate Comments
description: The dollar fell against the mark yesterday on mixed signals from the Bundesbank over the direction of German interest rates. In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 1.8153 marks, down from 1.8203 marks on Wednesday.

title: New Video Releases
description: The War at Home

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, JACK
description: FRIEDMAN-Jack, passed away September 3rd. Husband of Rae. Father of Robin and Mark Friedman and Eve Fox. Grandfather of Andrew and Alyson Fox and Hallie and Jon Friedman. Brother of Sylvia Schaefer. Service today at noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Two Friends' Nobility in Stone, Oil and the Eye of the Beholder
description: LIKE so many others, the mathematician and philosopher Marie Jean Antoine Nicolas Caritat, Marquis de Condorcet (1743-1794), was an advocate of the French Revolution and then a victim of it. He is probably known to Americans now, if at all, for his ''Sketch of Human Progress,'' a treatise on human development up to the revolution that predicted mankind's ultimate perfectibility. He wrote it while trying to elude the revolutionary tribunal, something he achieved only by dying in a jail cell -- a suicide, perhaps -- before he could be brought to judgment.

title: Expected Oil Bonanza Fails to Materialize
description: When Boris N. Yeltsin was re-elected President last year, it looked as if Russia was finally about to roll out the red carpet for Western oil companies.

title: 700 Refugees Expelled From Congolese Town
description: Soldiers loyal to the Congo's new leader, Laurent Kabila, forcibly expelled almost 700 Rwandan and Burundi refugees from the Congolese town of Kisangani today in a pre-dawn operation that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees called a ''blatant breach of international refugee treaties.''

title: Chief Judge Urges Filling of Vacancies on Circuit Court
description: The Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and his immediate predecessor warned today that the quality of justice in the Federal courts in New York, Connecticut and Vermont will suffer significantly if the Senate does not soon fill vacancies on the court.

title: Kaaren Erickson, 44, Soprano With the Metropolitan Opera
description: Kaaren Erickson, a soprano who was on the roster of the Metropolitan Opera for the last 12 years and whose repertory ranged from Handel oratorios to Philip Glass's most recent opera, died on Saturday at her home in Maryville, Tenn. She was 44.

title: U.S. Judge Lauds Bank in Lawsuit
description: Glendale Federal Bank has an ''exceedingly strong'' and convincing case in its lawsuit seeking at least $1.8 billion in damages from the Government, the judge presiding in the case said during a closed-door hearing in July.

title: A Social Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS CUTS PROFIT FORECAST
description: The stock of American Management Systems Inc. plummeted 23 percent yesterday after the company lowered its earnings expectations for the year. The consulting company, which is based in Fairfax, Va., said it had reduced its 1997 outlook by $9.5 million because Swiss Telecom declined to extend a contract with the company for billing and customer care systems. American Management said it expected earnings of 72 cents to 81 cents a share this year, compared with analysts' consensus prediction of $1.01 a share. In 1996, the company earned $33.8 million, or 81 cents a share. American Management shares fell $5.9375 yesterday, to $18.6875.

title: H & R Block Shares Up on Report of Compuserve Sale Talks
description: Shares of H & R Block and Compuserve rose yesterday following a report that the New York-based investment firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe was in talks to buy a majority stake in Compuserve, Block's faltering on-line service.

title: Space Laser Test Shows Military Hubris
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ISAAC (BUDDY)
description: LEVINE-Isaac (Buddy). Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Loving father of Joan and Robin. Sweet brother of Helen Bisnovich and Reva Sosman. Cherished grandfather of Leah and Erik. Service today 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NARVESEN, LEIF PAUL
description: NARVESEN-Leif Paul. Sept. 4, 1997. Executive of M. Fabrikant and Sons, Inc. Beloved son of Leif and Pat Narvesen, dear brother of John, Ingrid and her husband Frank Rossetti, Carl and Eric. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St Friday, September 5, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, September 6, at 11 A.M., at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66 Street at Lexington Ave. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Westchester, NY.

title: Fending Off Paparazzi
description: The death of Princess Diana has put a spotlight on the paparazzi, with celebrities like Elizabeth Taylor and John Travolta condemning their aggressive tactics and calling for tough new laws to rein in these photographers. In California, for example, State Senator Tom Hayden has proposed legislation that would keep photographers 50 to 100 feet away from famous people who are not participating in public events.

title: For Venus, Big Chill Is Still Going
description: BRANDY WILLIAMS remembers how unhappy many of the young players seemed when she first visited the tennis circuit. She did not want that for her daughter, Venus. ''I don't want her to think, 'I have to do this,' '' Williams said yesterday. ''It's her that's doing it, not her dad, not me, not her sister. This is her life.''

title: First Teach Them English
description: The Bilingual Education Act of 1968 was intended to help Hispanic children learn English. But nearly 30 years later, it is clear that bilingual education has been a dismal failure.

title: Be It Ever So Urban, It's Green
description: PAUL REISER waved across the shade-dappled lawn to the woman with the baby carriage who had shouted his name. ''I left a pair of socks here 20 years ago and I came back to get them,'' he called out.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Once Again in Arizona, Secretary of State Is Suddenly Thrust Into the Job of Governor
description: She is a fiscally conservative former schoolteacher with a broad streak of social moderation. She is a veteran legislator and the first woman to be Speaker of the Arizona House of Representatives. And for most of the last year, she has been quietly waiting for the day she might suddenly become Arizona's 20th governor.

title: Race for 2004 Olympics Comes Down to the Wire
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland  The outcome of many Olympic races last summer in Atlanta was easier to predict than the election that will take place Friday to name a host city for the 2004 Summer Olympics.

title: Reduce Risk in Crash: Front or Back, Use Belt
description: Whatever the cause of the crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, anyone who rides in a car could learn from the circumstances, American safety experts say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABLER, JULIUS
description: ABLER-Julius. Age 83, of Lake Forest, IL, on September 3. We mourn the loss of our dear brother, uncle and cousin. A brilliant light no longer shines. The Morton Abler Family The Paul R. Abler Family The Yetta Littman Family The Alfred Mackler Family The Charlotte Friedman Family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TONDEL, LYMAN M. JR.
description: TONDEL-Lyman M. Jr. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, September 9, 1997, 11:00 AM, at Grace Episcopal Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Home Video
description: Signposts for DVD

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 2
description: Bills (0-1) vs. Jets (1-0)

title: Tropical Impressions At a Career's Dawning
description: UNCERTAINTY can have its pleasures and challenges, especially when it comes to art. Questions of who created what, or of how a work has found its way from one unlikely place to another, are basic ingredients in the absorbing, often nit-picky investigative game of art history.

title: DeWitt Peterkin Jr., 84, Morgan Executive
description: DeWitt Peterkin Jr., a former vice chairman and director of J. P. Morgan & Company, died last Friday at Waveny Care Center in New Canaan, Conn. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AVRETT, JACK
description: AVRETT-Jack. Memorial Service, Thursday, September 11, Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue, at 4:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Metropolitan Opera of New York City.AVRETT-Jack. Memorial service Thursday, September 11, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison (81st St), 4:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera, New York City.

title: Chief of Hughes Again Emerges as a Top Candidate to Head AT&T
description: Seven weeks after embarking on yet another search for a chief executive, AT&T is once again closely scrutinizing C. Michael Armstrong, chief executive of Hughes Electronics, according to several executives close to the deliberations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, RICHARD D.
description: BANKS-Richard D. Age 45. Died August 30th of AIDS, surrounded by his family. He is survived by his mother Helen Bangs; sister Claudia; brothers David and Gregg; sisters-in-law Cary and Kristy; and six nephews and nieces. Will now join his late companion Joseph Tonti. Richard showed great courage and leadership in his battle against AIDS; growing stronger emotionally and mentally even as he weakened physically. He is an inspiration. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 6 at 3 P.M. at St. Michael's, 225 West 99th St, NY, NY 10025. Donations can be made to either St. Michael's or The Gay Men's Health Crisis, 119 W. 24th St. (Attn: Development), New York, NY 10011.

title: From a Witty Young Playwright Named Sturges
description: What an impression Preston Sturges made on the opening night of his airy Broadway escapade, ''Strictly Dishonorable.'' ''It was certain that a fresh talent for gay, buoyant comedy had come into the theater,'' Brooks Atkinson crowed in his review the next morning. ''No one,'' he added, ''could write such deft, amusing lines and describe characters with so much understanding who did not have genuine talent for the theater.''

title: Don't Blame Victims Of Paparazzi Excess
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIEDMAN, KIRSTEN BENTSEN
description: WIEDMAN-Kirsten Bentsen, of Glen Cove, LI, on September 2, 1997. Professor of Nursing, Nassau Community College. Beloved mother of Jennifer L. and Mark K., sister of Birger, Ernest and Arthur Bentsen. Visitation at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, on Friday, 7-10 PM. Service Saturday, 10 AM. Burial Locust Valley Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Kirsten Foundation, 2110 Northern Blvd., Suite 205, Manhasset, NY 11030.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OLIVER, DORIS
description: OLIVER-Doris. Always in our hearts, always in our thoughts. Love Toni and Seth, Bob and Janusz, Donald and Billy, Frank and John.

title: Newark Officer Is Cleared In Shooting During Arrest
description: A grand jury here has cleared a Newark police officer of criminal charges in connection with the shooting in June of a 31-year-old woman during a drug-related arrest that touched off angry protests and charges of a cover-up by law enforcement agencies.

title: Corrections
description: Two front-page picture credits yesterday misstated photographers' names. The photo of James P. Hoffa was by Andrew Johnston, not Johnson. The photo of the first day of school in New York City was by Mary DiBiase Blaich, not Mary DiBiases.

title: Hello? Is That Ms. Right Who's Breathing Heavily?
description: Although the comic possibilities of phone sex have long since been exhausted, the Spanish farce ''Mouth to Mouth'' still gives this well-worn topic a try. As in Spike Lee's ''Girl 6,'' the main character is an aspiring actor who finds that auditioning for roles is no less humiliating than being paid to talk dirty to strangers, and that the phone job may actually be the more interesting professional challenge.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOIS, HARRY JOSEPH
description: LOIS-Harry Joseph. 9/5/58-9/21/78. Today would have been Harry's 39th Birthday. Rosemary, Luke & George Lois

title: Drug-Resistant Germ Found
description: A staph germ that largely resists the most powerful drug used against it has shown up for the second time in the United States, at a Camden hospital, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Joseph T. O'Keefe, 78, Bishop of Syracuse
description: Joseph Thomas O'Keefe, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Syracuse from 1987 to 1995 and temporary head of the Archdiocese of New York for six months in the early 1980's, died on Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Syracuse. He was 78 and lived in Syracuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAGER, DAVID
description: PRAGER-David. The Board of Directors and Faculty of the Diller Quaile School of Music mourns the recent passing of David Prager, who served as President of the Board during a critical time in Diller Quaile's history. Mr. Prager led the school through a period of substantial growth and in 1972 spearheaded the effort to purchase the school's building at 24 East 95th Street, thereby, assuring the future of the institution. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Annabelle and his family.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Collective Action'

title: Cattle Virus Is Redesigned to Attack H.I.V.
description: Applying the tactic of setting a thief to catch a thief, biologists have redesigned a cattle virus to make it attack H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, at a vulnerable moment in its life cycle.

title: From Just Another Body To Giants' Big Center
description: Giants quarterback Dave Brown answered bluntly when asked what veteran players thought of the rookie center Derek Engler, who arrived at camp two months ago undrafted out of the University of Wisconsin.

title: Federal Overseer Who Invalidated Teamsters Election Resigns
description: The Federal official who overturned Ronald Carey's victory in last year's elections for the teamsters presidency announced yesterday that she was resigning for family reasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL BALSO, SUZANNE WILDING
description: DEL BALSO-Suzanne Wilding, of Aiken, SC and Unionville, PA in Aiken after a brief illness. Wife of Anthony M. Del Balso, mother of Wendy Berol Gifford of McLean, VA., and J. Robin Berol Bliss of Bedford Hills, NY; sister of Josephine Wilding Freeman of Purchase, NY; stepmother of Michael Del Balso of New York City and Dina Del Balso Rosser of Atlanta, GA; grandmother of eleven. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions may be made to Bayard Taylor Library of Kennett Square, PA or the Aiken County Open Land Trust, Aiken, SC 29801.

title: Panel Upholds Giuliani Offer On Police Pay
description: An arbitration panel announced yesterday that it was upholding Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's wage offer to the New York City police union, all but ending an unusually vitriolic dispute that had been fought from precinct station houses to the State Capitol.

title: Joyner-Kersee to Retire
description: JACKIE JOYNER-KERSEE, a three-time Olympic gold medalist in the heptathlon and the long jump, will retire next year, she said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEFEL, ERNST C.
description: STIEFEL-Ernst C. The entire New York Law School community mourns the loss of Dr. Ernst C. Stiefel, a man of great intellect, compassion and wit. We are deeply indebted to him for his many generous gifts to the School, including the restoration of the Ernst Steifel Reading Room and his endowment of a Professorship in Comparative Law. He served as an adjunct professor for twenty years at the School and inspired generations of NYLS students by his example. He will be missed.

title: Chang Struggles And Rafter Breezes To Gain Semifinals
description: Michael Chang was on the ropes. Marcelo Rios was on the prowl. The fans were riveted to their shiny blue plastic seats inside Arthur Ashe Stadium last night as the second-seeded Chang, the sole American man left in contention at the United States Open, and the 10th-seeded Rios, the only Chilean man to reach the top 10, used their forehands to stage a virtual fistfight for possession of their quarterfinal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, DIANA
description: SPENCER-Diana. Profound sorrow at her death and deep gratitude for her friendship and generosity at the time of The Royal Visit in Chicago to benefit our cancer support community are offered in memory of Diana, Princess of Wales, by members, staff, Board and Founding Development Committee of Gilda's Club, the free, non-profit program based in New York, and in development in North America and London, England. The Princess of Wales expressed in the acts of her life her belief that we are here to help one another, to open our hearts, to give and to understand. The effects of her kindheartedness and compassion will live on. We are privileged to have known her and extend condolences to all who loved her as we did.

title: Messinger Says Giuliani Uses Sexist Barbs To Attack Her
description: Ruth W. Messinger yesterday accused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of ''gender bashing,'' asserting that he had sought to undercut her candidacy with sexist put-downs she said were typically used by ''the radical right'' against strong women.

title: Ex-Chef Suing Restaurant
description: When Johannes Sanzin, the executive chef at Sanzin in SoHo, was forced out by his partners in June, he left his name behind on the restaurant. Now Mr. Sanzin is suing his former partners, hoping to reclaim his name from the restaurant Sanzin as well as several million dollars in damages.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Strong Results for Stores, Auto Makers And Factories

title: Woman Jogger Stabbed; East Side Man Is Charged
description: As a Queens woman recovered yesterday from more than 15 stab wounds she received on Wednesday while jogging through a park in College Point, the police arrested a 22-year-old neighbor who lives a block from the scene of the crime and charged him with attempted murder.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Angry? At whom? I don't know whom to blame anymore. Maybe it's Arafat, maybe it's the system, I don't know whom to put the finger on. Maybe to some degree it's just a part of life.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISKIND, ERWIN
description: SISKIND-Erwin. Died September 2, 1997. Loving husband of Rosella; devoted father of Jerry (and Sharon) and Eric, cherished grandfather of Sarah and Jessica. Also survived by his brothers Leonard and Eliott. Services Friday at 12 noon at Bouelvard-Nassau North Chapels, 65 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, LI. Contributions in his name may be made to Great Neck United Community Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, SYLVIA K.
description: ISRAEL-Sylvia K., age 89. Sylvia was a gifted first-grade teacher, a life-long fighter for social justice, a musician and composer of many songs for children's records; with her late husband, Leo, she co-produced the first records to accompany children's books. She gave time and caring insight to all who knew her. She is mourned by her daughters, Deborah and Laura, her son, Jared, her grandchildren, Jonah, Chris, Matt and Jennie, her nieces, Carol, Jan and Vicki, her nephews, David, Ken and Jerry, and cousin Evelyn and many friends. Our loss is great. Sylvia wanted no funeral; a memorial gathering will be held Sunday, September 7 from 2 to 4 at the Warburg Lounge, 92nd St. Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the 60 Plus Program at the 92nd St. Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGEE, REV. THOMAS F.
description: McGEE-Rev. Thomas F. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the retired parochial vicar of St. Francis de Sales Church, Belle Harbor, on Sept. 3. Reposing in Evergreen Funeral Home, 131 Nassau Ave., Friday, Sept. 5, 2-5 P.M. Mass of Transferral Friday, Sept. 5 at 7:30 P.M. in St. Cecilia Church, 84 Herbert St., Brooklyn. Funeral Mass, Saturday, Sept. 6 at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Clash of Cultures at a Senate Hearing
description: For three Buddhist nuns testifying before a Senate hearing on campaign finance, some of the questions simply got lost in the translation from English to Chinese and back again. But other questions became mired in a language foreign to nearly everyone outside Congress: the headspinning idioms of senators preening for the camera.

title: By Wide Margin, Miami Voters Preserve City
description: Voters today overwhelmingly supported a ballot measure to preserve the city as a distinct legal entity, rejecting arguments that it was too poor and mismanaged to thrive alone and should be merged with surrounding Dade County.

title: Fox Group Reaches Deal to Buy Dodgers
description: Peter O'Malley has reached an agreement in principle to sell the Los Angeles Dodgers to Fox Group, bringing one of baseball's most prestigious and successful franchises into Rupert Murdoch's global business empire.

title: The Prison Guard as a Good Friend
description: ''The Keeper,'' opening today at the Quad, casts Giancarlo Esposito as a conscientious prison guard who winds up taking his work home. Literally. In this small, sincere film written and directed by Joe Brewster, Mr. Esposito's Paul Lamont is moved to help a despondent Haitian immigrant who has been wrongly accused of rape.

title: More About Mr. Gore
description: For months, Attorney General Janet Reno has cited a loophole in Federal election laws as the reason she would not seek a special counsel to investigate campaign fund-raising abuses in the 1996 election. That loophole has now disappeared. It turns out that funds raised by Vice President Al Gore at the White House were indeed the kind of money that Federal law says must not be solicited from Federal property. Despite Mr. Gore's famous comment that ''no controlling legal authority'' restricted his actions, he appears to have broken the law. Surely Ms. Reno will now see that only an independent counsel can guarantee a thorough and objective investigation.

title: Government to Keep Control of Air France
description: The French Government has decided to retain a majority stake in Air France, a move that will probably prompt its chairman, Christian Blanc, to resign. An official in the Prime Minister's office said yesterday that the Government agreed with the assertion of Transport Minister Jean-Claude Gayssot that it should not sell a majority stake in the carrier. Mr. Gayssot is one of two Communist ministers in the Socialist-led Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, EUGENE A.
description: HUGHES-Eugene A. September 3, 1997. Marine and contractor's equipment business. Beloved son of the late John and Mathilda Hughes. Dear brother of John T. Hughes, Sr. Friends may call at The Abbey in the Frank E. Campbell building, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 St, Saturday, 11 AM. Interment to follow at Saint John's Cemetery.

title: A Sound Veto in Albany
description: When collective bargaining fails, New York City unions routinely turn to the State Legislature, ramming through bills that hamstring the city. The early-retirement provision pushed through by the United Federation of Teachers fits that description. Gov. George Pataki was right to veto the bill this week, forcing the issue back to the bargaining table.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZOHMAN, SIMON
description: ZOHMAN-Simon. 1988. In memory with love from daughter, Laura and family: David, Janet and Jenny; John, Ruth and Cheryl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELCH, ROBERT ALLAN
description: WELCH-Robert Allan, 55, died suddenly on Saturday, August 23, while swimming in the Merrimac River near the historic Rocks Village section of Haverhill, Massachusetts. He was a passionate sailor, a poet and a loving father. Born in Elgin, Illinois, the son of Mrs. Elizabeth C. McDougall and the late Dr. Allan D. Welch, he graduated from the University of Virginia in 1967 and began his career in New York at Time Incorporated. He worked at Sports Illustrated and Money magazines and went on to start a film production division for Ogilvy & Mather and cofound West Side Films, also in New York. Mr. Welch is survived by his children, Robert Jr. of New York City and Leslie C. Welch of Atlanta; his mother Elizabeth McDougall of Barrington, Illinois; a sister, Barbara Welch Dolphin of Glenview, Illinois; and a brother, Dudley C. Welch of Barrington. Those who loved him consider themselves blessed. Contributions can be made in his name to the Rocks Village Memorial Association, C/O Tina Fuller, 35 River Road, Haverhill, MA. 01830.

title: Broadway to Sing Sunday in Times Square
description: It will be standing room only in Times Square on Sunday at noon for the sixth ''Broadway on Broadway'' celebration. The free outdoor event, on Broadway north of 43d Street, will feature performances by the casts of musicals including ''Chicago,'' ''Annie,'' ''The Life,'' ''Jekyll and Hyde,'' ''Rent,'' ''The King and I,'' ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk'' and ''1776,'' as well as previews of the Broadway-bound shows ''Capeman'' and ''The Scarlet Pimpernel.''

title: North Korean Defector's 'Spy List' Proves a Hot Topic in Seoul
description: Some of the most nervous people in South Korea these days are probably North Korean spies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEFEL, PROF. DR. ERNEST C.
description: STIEFEL-Prof. Dr. Ernest C. The American Federation of Jews from Central Europe mourns the death of one of its founding members, a brilliant and great human being. We shall miss his counsel and friendship. Fritz Weinschenk, President

title: Amid Sandy Splendor, Lawrence Rides Again
description: Thanks, Mom and Dad, for driving me weekend after weekend to see ''Lawrence of Arabia'' when it first appeared. None of us knew why a junior high school girl should be so obsessed with an Englishman leading an Arab desert campaign during World War I, but you were kind not to ask too many questions. All we knew was that David Lean's sweeping, cryptic masterpiece exerted an otherworldly appeal in our household, and that it lasted for many years. Thanks also for the pilgrimage to Clouds Hill, T. E. Lawrence's cottage in Dorset, which happened to have closed for the week just before we got there. That's another story.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BOB DOLE, who lost the use of his right arm in combat in World War II, has been given the American Legion's highest award, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Back-to-School Purchases Lift Retail Sales
description: Consumers stocking up on lunch boxes, blue jeans and other back-to-school goods helped bolster retailers' sales in August.

title: Joseph A. Francis, 73, Auxiliary Bishop of Newark
description: The Most Rev. Joseph A. Francis, an auxiliary bishop of Newark for 19 years who was one of the first black priests in the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church to speak out against racism, died on Monday at the Claridge House, a home for retired priests in Verona, N.J. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAINTER, PATSY
description: PAINTER-Patsy. We are saddened by the untimely death of our dear friend. She was truly an elegant and gracious Southern Belle. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her husband Bill and her daughter Bette. Alan and Millie Fell

title: Opponents of Tobacco Move Against Tax Break
description: Members of Congress moved today to repeal a $50 billion tax break for the tobacco industry, setting up an early test of sentiment on the landmark tobacco settlement.

title: Heating Up The Cool With Feeling
description: The rhetoric of emotion, the way various groupings of notes suggest the inner experience, formed the connective tissue in a disparate set of tunes at the saxophonist Antonio Hart's show at Sweet Basil on Tuesday. Mr. Hart, who will be performing through Sunday, played a standard and a few originals, and they were all based on the idea that deeply felt emotion was the point of musical endeavor.

title: Survey Finds Heart Bypass In New York To Be Safest
description: Coronary bypass surgery continues to be safer in New York State than in any other region of the country that surveys the procedure, state health officials reported yesterday.

title: Justices Allow an Anti-Bias Law to Go Into Effect
description: The Supreme Court today refused an emergency request to block California from enforcing its new anti-affirmative-action law, which took effect a week ago.

title: 12 Israelis Killed
description: A raid by Israeli commandos striking 30 miles inside southern Lebanon early today left 12 Israelis dead, Lebanese officials said. If the toll is confirmed, it would be among Israel's highest for a single battle in southern Lebanon in two years.

title: Feature Movie Stars Native Americans But Focuses on Human Commonalities
description: It's not exactly Hollywood East, but if you've got a screenplay and happen to be American Indian, you might want to do lunch with the Mashantucket Pequots.

title: Farewell, Guitar; Hello, Machinery
description: The 17th annual CMJ Music Marathon sent a deliberate signal when it devoted its opening night concert, on Wednesday at Roseland, to electronica rather than its longtime staple, guitar-driven rock. It endorsed the music business's hope that music from computers, synthesizers and turntables will capture a mass audience the way grunge did in the early 1990's. And for most of the six-band bill, it showed that electronica groups are already starting to bend to rock expectations.

title: TARRANT ENDS BID FOR ASSETS OF B.U.M. INTERNATIONAL
description: Tarrant Apparel Group said yesterday that its bid to acquire the assets of the clothing maker B.U.M. International Inc., which is in bankruptcy, was rejected by a bankruptcy court judge on Wednesday. After declining the bid, the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Central District of California approved a reorganization plan by B.U.M.'s unsecured creditors committee. Tarrant, which is based in Los Angeles, said it would not make a new bid for B.U.M. Tarrant, which makes private-label women's casual clothing, agreed in August to buy B.U.M. for $23.8 million in cash. B.U.M., of Rancho Dominguez, Calif., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in April 1996.

title: Palelei Hopes to Stay a Jet, But Bills Pose a Problem
description: It is Lonnie Palelei's last chance. Again. Each week -- each day, actually -- has been like that since he was plucked out of obscurity while tending a bar in Las Vegas, Nev., and brought to the Jets last March.

title: 'Diana Had It Coming'
description: Almost as sickening as the crash that killed Princess Diana are the excuses used to justify the gang of photographers who chased her to death. They are the same excuses used by rapists, and pimps.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN E. ZUCCOTTI, chairman of the New York City Planning Commission during the administration of John V. Lindsay and first deputy mayor under Abraham D. Beame, is on the move. He plans to join the New York law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges as a senior counsel in real estate.

title: Moves That Hint of a Return of Stolen Art
description: The hunt for missing masterpieces stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston in 1990 appears to be entering a sensitive new phase of discussions between Federal officials, a jailed art thief and a convicted associate, an antiques dealer who says he holds the key to solving the $300 million theft.

title: For Williams, the Debut Run Is Chugging Along
description: The last time a woman reached the semifinals of her first United States Open, Venus Williams had yet to be born.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BING, RUDOLF
description: BING-Rudolf. The Board, Officers and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. mourn the passing of Sir Rudolf Bing, former General Manager of the Metropolitan Opera. It is with great respect and appreciation that we recall his role in guiding the Metropolitan Opera Association to Lincoln Center in 1966 and leading it to even greater international acclaim. We join the entire arts community in remembering Sir Rudolf's great passion, leadership and extraordinary contributions to the world of Grand Opera. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDWIN, HENRY DEFOREST
description: BALDWIN-Henry deForest, of New York, NY and Roxbury, CT, died Tuesday, September 2, at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital from respiratory failure due to ALS, known as Lou Gehrig's disease. He was a Trusts and Estates partner at the law firm of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. Previously, he was a partner and the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the law firm of Lord, Day & Lord (later known as Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith). He served on several not for profit boards, including the Council of the Yale Club of New York City, the New York Botanical Garden, and the Roxbury Land Trust. He is survived by his beloved wife Martha Denniston Baldwin, his two sons Sherman of Darien, CT and Alexander of Silver Spring, MD, his sister Lois Baldwin Bishop of Minneapolis, MN and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday, September 6, at The Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 91st Street. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Columbia University ALS Gift Fund, c/o Maura del Bene, 710 W. 168 St., New York, NY 10032 or the Roxbury Land Trust, Roxbury, CT 06783.

title: Aldo Rossi, Architect of Monumental Simplicity, Dies at 66
description: Aldo Rossi, the Italian architect known for works of monumental simplicity and power, died yesterday in Milan, where he lived. He was 66.

title: Chairman Is Replaced At Groupe Bull
description: Groupe Bull, France's largest manufacturer of computer equipment, said yesterday that its chairman, Jean-Marie Descarpentries, had resigned. Bull's board named Guy de Panafieu, a managing director of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux, a water distribution, construction and telecommunications company, to replace Mr. Descarpentries.

title: '72 Olympic Nightmare Still Haunts McKay
description: On a day when suicide bombers killed seven people in west Jerusalem, Jim McKay of ABC Sports yesterday recalled the deaths of 11 members of the Israeli Olympic team at the Summer Games in Munich, Germany, 25 years ago today.

title: Keep in Mind
description: BONGA'S DANCE, DRUM AND SONG WORKSHOP, a demonstration of Haitian music (and American music with Haitian roots), involving audience participation. Handmade instruments will be provided; families can also take their own. Sunday from 6 to 8 P.M. at the Djoniba Dance and Drum Center, 37 East 18th Street, seventh floor, Manhattan. Adults, $12; 12 and younger, $5. Information: (212) 477-3464 or (212) 242-2275.

title: Put College on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: He Does It His Way, And It's Magnificent
description: The experiments are performed about two hours before each game, Rey Ordonez at shortstop, Edgardo Alfonzo at second base. They field balls hit in batting practice and attempt dress-rehearsal double plays. Ad libs are not merely encouraged; they are required.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Economist wants readers to see it as bold, not bland.
description: THE ECONOMIST magazine is embarking on an ambitious effort to help change a perception -- surprisingly widespread among potential readers -- that a typical issue features articles like ''Monetary Policy Made Murkier,'' ''A Yen for Yen: Favorite Foreign Currencies'' and ''Alan Greenspan: Legend or Icon?''

title: Natural Gas Prices Plummet On Strong Inventory Report
description: Natural gas prices plunged 4.6 percent yesterday, their biggest loss in three months, after an unexpectedly large gain in inventories eased concerns about supplies for this winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKIN, DEWITT, JR.
description: PETERKIN-DeWitt, Jr., of Noroton, CT. Died August 29, 1997 of heart failure and complications related to Parkinsons Disease. He was 84. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 5 at 11 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Rd., Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The American Parkinson's Association, 1250 Hyland Boulevard, Staten Island, New York 10305-1946 or to Waveny Care Center Employee Fund, 3 Farm Rd., New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ALEXANDER
description: SHAPIRO-Alexander. Lido Beach Synagogue mourns the death of the beloved father of our esteemed Board of Trustee member Irwin Shapiro. May he and his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Daniel Mehlman, Rabbi Herman Berger, President

title: Marlowe's Creator, Maybe Known Best by His Cat
description: RAYMOND CHANDLER

title: It's All Music, All the Time
description: BY their laminated badges ye shall know them: the thousands of music business aspirants and gatekeepers who have been clustering around Lincoln Center by day and rock club doorways by night since Wednesday. Idealistic college-radio programmers and cold-eyed talent scouts, one-man recording companies and major label delegations and thousands of hopeful musicians are here for the 17th annual CMJ Music Marathon, New York's biggest annual music business convention. They're already hoarse after buttonholing one another all day and shouting over loud music through the night.

title: This Is a Playoff Push? Yankees Now 1 for Last 8
description: David Wells recognized the faces, recognized the batting stances and recognized the orange, black and gray uniforms. Wells wore one last year when he was the enemy at Yankee Stadium. Last night, Wells had the awesome opportunity to be treated like a hero in the Bronx if he could squelch the familiar team that the Yankees have chased all season. Forget about feeding off familiarity. Instead, the funk continued.

title: Small Stocks Gain, but Dow Loses 27.40
description: Stocks finished mixed yesterday as declines among a handful of larger companies dragged down the Dow Jones industrial average. Smaller- company stocks, meanwhile, continued to post gains.

title: Nuns Say Temple Event With Gore Was Not a Fund-Raiser
description: Three Buddhist nuns in cinnamon-colored robes insisted today that an event Vice President Al Gore attended at their temple in California last year was not a fund-raiser, but Republican Senators treated that interpretation as preposterous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDALL, FLORENCE ENGEL
description: RANDALL-Florence Engel. Beloved wife of the late Murray Charles. Beloved mother of Susan Lipsig, Laurel Kirk and Stewart. Devoted mother-in-law of Stephen Lipsig, M.D. and Robert Kirk. Dear sister of Julie Pantages and the late Harold Sloan. Adored grandmother of Diana Lipsig and David Lipsig, M.D.. Services Sunday, 10:00AM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERATY, MARY S
description: GERATY-Mary S., of Huntington, Long Island and New York City died suddenly on September third at age seventy-eight. Devoted wife of 56 years of Matthew F. Geraty. Beloved Mother of Maureen G. Leness. Cherished Grandmother of Sandra, Pamela and Robert Beuerlein, Jr. We will deeply miss her compassionate heart. A mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Hugh Roman Catholic Church, New York Avenue, Huntington Station, on Monday, September 8, 1997, at 9:30 AM. Friends may call The M.A. Connell Funeral Home at 934 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, Saturday, September 6, from 7 to 9 PM and Sunday, September 7, from 2 to 5 PM and from 7 to 9 PM.

title: Seagram Wine Unit Chooses an Agency
description: The Seagram Chateau and Estate Wines Company, a division of the Joseph E. Seagram and Sons unit of the Seagram Company in Rutherford, Calif., said yesterday that it had named Hyett, Broadbent & Heimbrodt Advertising in San Francisco to handle five of its brands, with billings estimated at $3 million. The account had been handled by Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley in San Francisco, an agency whose assets were acquired in January by Hampel/Stefanides in New York.

title: New Video Releases
description: McHale's Navy

title: Former Cable Executive to Run NBC TV Stations
description: NBC named a cable television executive, Scott Sassa, president of its station division yesterday, giving him control of the stations the network owns.

title: The Spoken Word
description: ''MOJO HAND: RECENT WORK BY RICHARD YARDE,'' Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street. A discussion with the artist about his recent work, created after he suffered a debilitating illness several years ago. Tomorrow at 2 P.M. The exhibition will be up through Sept. 28. (Review on page 24.) Free with museum admission: $5; $3 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. Information: (212) 864-4500.

title: $25 and Under
description: No question, it's been an exhausting week. Back to work, back to school, back to serious business. It's the kind of week when cooking seems tedious and hot. Takeout beckons, but you groan, ''Not Chinese again!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOTH, ALEXANDER, M.D., D.D.S.
description: TOTH-Alexander, M.D., D.D.S. Alexander Toth, 81, died on September 2, 1997. Dr. Toth was born October 22, 1915 in Koronco, Hungary. He moved to the United States with his family from Gyor, Hungary in 1956. For the better part of his professional career he practiced dentistry in New Brunswick, New Jersey. Dr. Toth retired to Sarasota, Florida in 1989. Loving survivors include his wife Anna; three children: Adrienne, Lollia, Zoltan; and five grandchildren.
