Also, his soul brother Aurel and family and former wife Aranka. Funeral services were private. A memorial mass will be held at a future date which will be announced. The family respectfully requests any donations to be made to: Kossuth Club Scholarship Fund, Hungarian American Cultural Association, Incorporated, P.O. Box 19774, Sarasota, Florida 34276.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, WILLIAM
description: ROSENBLUM-William, 81, of Del Ray Beach, FL. passed away Aug. 29, 1997. Retired from Reliable Textiles. William is survived by his wife Anne; daughters Linda and Nancy and six grandchildren.

title: Drawn to Window by Shots, Man Is Fatally Hit by One
description: Nester Medero, a 46-year-old maintenance man at a four-story brick apartment building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, was awakened early yesterday morning by the sound of gunfire outside his window. And, the police said, he did what he usually did when he heard a disturbance: he looked out. But the shots continued, and one struck his neck, killing him.

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions Against Japan
description: In the first major trade flare-up with Japan in more than two years, the Clinton Administration imposed a fine of $100,000 today on every Japanese ship entering an American port, in an effort to force Tokyo to relax restrictions on American ships seeking freer access to Japanese harbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONKVROUWE, HELEN JANS, BICKER
description: JONKVROUWE-Helen Jans-Bicker. My tender and supportive wife of thirty years and our warm and nurturing mother has passed away after a short battle against breast cancer. We loved her very much and she will remain in our hearts forever. She has been buried on Saturday, August 9, at Westduin Cemetery in The Hague. Hans Jans Saint Tropez Hotel du Treizain 83580 Gassin Bournemouth UK-Ester Birgitte London UK-Marcelle

title: Single, With Lots of Nagging Relatives
description: Remember the ''Seinfeld'' episode in which Jerry and Elaine visit his parents in Florida? Send Jerry packing, leave Elaine behind (which he actually threatened to do) and you have ''Alright Already,'' a potentially bright new sitcom created by and starring Carol Leifer as Carol Lerner, a 40-ish woman in South Beach coping with single life and a condo full of nagging relatives.

title: CHRONICLE
description: How about this for a juicy assignment? NINA GRISCOM and ALAN RICHMAN, the co-hosts of the Food Network's daily show ''Dining Around,'' and MICHAEL LOMONACO, the head chef of Windows on the World, will be stomping grapes at 12:30 P.M. Tuesday at the plaza at the World Trade Center, near Church Street.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: New Video Releases
description: Nothing Personal

title: European Part-Timers
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Bounties and Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Saks Fifth Avenue President Joins Burberrys
description: The president of Saks Fifth Avenue, Rose Marie Bravo, resigned yesterday to become the chief executive of Burberrys Worldwide, the British maker of apparel and luxury items and a unit of Great Universal Stores P.L.C.

title: 'Fast Track' Trade Deals Must Protect Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: 'Art and Friendship'

title: A Style That Turned All the Way Into Art
description: Nothing helped the recognition of photography as an art form in this country like the Photo-Secession, a high-minded group formed in 1902 by Alfred Stieglitz. Connoisseur, esthetic entrepreneur and lensman extraordinaire, Stieglitz was cued by the art-for-art's-sake photographic Secessionist movement of the 1890's in Europe, particularly London, which meant to free photography from its reliance on facts and mechanics. Secessionists tried to make their photographs look as much like paintings as possible, exercising total control over the printing process.

title: In Their Words
description: SAL F. ALBANESE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUTKIS, MARTIN I.
description: NUTKIS-Martin I. Of Roslyn Heights, New York. On September 4th, 1997. World War 11 Veteran. Beloved and adored husband of Pearl. Cherished and devoted father of Susan, Elyse and David. Loving father-in-law of Leslie, Rick and Peter. Adored and special grandfather of Samuel, Lucas, Isabella, Eliza and Jeanne, will all miss this gentle man with his warm smile, whose heart was generous to all. Graveside service Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, at 1 P.M. today.

title: Islanders Re-sign Two
description: The Islanders re-signed two veteran defensemen yesterday. The All-Star SCOTT LACHANCE and DOUG HOUDA signed two-year contracts.

title: Don't Blame Victims Of Paparazzi Excess
description: To the Editor:

title: Mahathir Halts Infrastructure Projects : Malaysia Threatens Economic 'Saboteurs'
description: SINGAPORE  Malaysia threatened Thursday to use its tough anti-subversion law to arrest those who "sabotage" its economy and announced that it had been forced to postpone key construction projects because of damage to its currency from financial market turmoil.

title: Ukraine Announces Privatization Plan
description: Ukraine's State Property Fund said yesterday that it would sell 58 companies this month on the nation's over-the-counter stock market. The fund, the Government agency responsible for the sale of state assets, plans to sell shares worth 3.9 million hryvnia, or $2.1 million, initially. In October, the fund will sell shares in 139 companies, worth about 50 million hryvnia.

title: A High School Football Team Plays for the Dead
description: Right before the Jarrell Cougars' first play from scrimmage in a pre-season game against Navarro High, Matt Kitchens, the team's star running back, had a few words to say in the huddle. ''You know who this is for,'' he told his teammates. ''Just open up a little hole for me.''

title: Equal Pay for Equal Work Is No. 1 Goal of Women
description: Equal pay for equal work is the top concern of working women, according to a survey released yesterday by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: 13 Independent Schools Open
description: Ten students had to stay after school yesterday to finish book reports assigned over the summer, but otherwise opening day at the North Star Academy Charter School in Newark ''couldn't have been better,'' said Norman Atkins, the co-director, with all but one of the school's 72 students present.

title: COWLES MEDIA SAYS IT MAY BE MERGED OR SOLD
description: The Cowles Media Company, based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that it was exploring a merger with another United States media company and other strategic alternatives at the request of the family that owns most of the publisher's shares. Cowles, which operates The Star Tribune in Minneapolis, could fetch $850 million to $1 billion in a sale, an analyst, John Morton, said. The 62-year-old company, which also publishes American Demographics and Folio magazines, said the Cowles Family Voting Trust, which holds about 56 percent of its voting shares, had asked the board to look into the company's options. Cowles's shares last changed hands on Wednesday, at $31.50.

title: CONNECTICUT BANKS AGREE TO MERGE IN $164 MILLION DEAL
description: People's Bank said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Norwich Financial Corporation for $164 million in cash and stock. Norwich, based in Norwich, Conn., has 17 branches in eastern Connecticut and assets of about $713 million. People's Bank, of Bridgeport, Conn., has 110 branches and assets of $9.5 billion. Under the deal, which is expected to close early next year, Norwich shareholders may receive cash or People's Bank shares valued at $28.85. Half of the purchase will be made in cash and half in stock, People's Bank said. Norwich shares fell 87.5 cents, to $27.625. People's Bank fell 75 cents, to $28.75.

title: House Votes Plan to Curb International Abortion Aid
description: Renewing what has become a perennial fight, the House approved an amendment today that would prohibit the flow of Federal money to international programs that provide abortions or promote them as a method of family planning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELAHER, GRACE H.
description: KELAHER-Grace H., September 3, 1997 of Douglaston, New York. Beloved wife of the late Richard E. Kelaher. Dear mother of Richard, Mary, Kathryn, and Peter. Grandmother of Jennifer and Richard. Sister of Kathryn O'Callahan in repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset on Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Saturday 9:45 AM, St. Anastasia RC Church, Douglaston. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Hartford Courant Editor Resigns
description: David S. Barrett, the editor of The Hartford Courant, who started at the paper as a college intern 27 years ago, was removed from his job yesterday and resigned rather than be demoted to a position on the editorial page.

title: 3 BOMBERS IN SUICIDE ATTACK KILL 4 ON JERUSALEM STREET IN ANOTHER BLOW TO PEACE
description: Three suicide bombers evidently acting in concert set off bombs on a popular shopping promenade in Jerusalem today, killing four passers-by and themselves and dealing a brutal new blow to the reeling Israeli-Palestinian peace.

title: Israel, Beyond the Bombings
description: Terrorist bombers strike, Israel responds by confining Palestinians to the Gaza Strip and West Bank, recriminations fly from both sides and the Middle East peace effort sinks deeper into paralysis. This now-familiar sequence played out again yesterday, which is why it is so essential that the latest suicide bombings in Jerusalem not deter Secretary of State Madeleine Albright from going to the region next week. President Clinton wisely reaffirmed Ms. Albright's travel plans when he learned of the new attack.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a visit to Washington by the Irish republican leader Gerry Adams referred imprecisely to the history of contacts between the British Government and Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. Mr. Adams, the Sinn Fein leader, took part in secret talks with Britain that led to a brief I.R.A. cease-fire in 1972; the inclusion of Sinn Fein in a formal Northern Ireland peace conference scheduled to begin on Sept. 9 would not be its first participation in peace talks since 1921.

title: 'Fast Track' Trade Deals Must Protect Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MORGAN KEEGAN INC., Memphis, agreed to sell its downtown Memphis office building to Parkway Properties Inc. of Jackson, Miss., a real estate investment trust, for $36 million.

title: Stoning Is Lethal
description: To the Editor:

title: Responding to Britain's Sorrow, Queen Will Address the Nation
description: Stung by charges that the royal family was unmoved by the enormous public response to the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, Buckingham Palace announced today that Queen Elizabeth would come to London from her estate in Scotland on Friday and make a television address to the nation on the eve of Saturday's funeral.

title: Restaurants
description: ''It seems to me that the hardest thing to find in New York City is a restaurant that serves plain, delicious American food.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the World Music Institute, which presents concerts by musicians from other cultures and sells a catalogue of recordings, books and videotapes, misstated its telephone number. It is (212) 545-7536. The article also misstated the given name of the director of the Asian Cultural Council, who is an adviser to the institute. He is Ralph Samuelson, not Robert.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TROUT, JOE
description: TROUT-Joe. Died 1970. You still make me smile. F.

title: Diana Memorial in Central Park
description: The Episcopal diocese of New York and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine will sponsor a memorial service for Diana, Princess of Wales, in the North Meadow of Central Park on Sunday, Sept. 14, church officials announced yesterday.

title: More Highway Aid Proposed
description: New Jersey would receive about $592.4 million in Federal transportation money next year under bipartisan legislation introduced yesterday by leaders of the House Transportation Committee. Since 1991, the state has received $488.7 million a year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the investigation of the car crash that killed the Princess of Wales referred imprecisely to Mohamed al-Fayed, whose son died with her. The elder Mr. Fayed owns Harrods department store in London, but is an Egyptian citizen.

title: Inside Art
description: Focusing on California

title: Space Laser Test Shows Military Hubris
description: To the Editor:

title: To See, and Spend the Night In
description: THESE days, participatory artworks come in all shapes and sizes, and with varying price tags. Sometimes, they are free and ephemeral, a good example being Rirkrit Tiravanija's Thai curries, cooked in gallery and museum spaces and served to all comers. In other instances, they can be quite a bit more exclusive, as in the case of Andrea Zittel's usable sculptures in the form of small trailers whose interiors are custom designed to the purchaser's specifications. These qualify as participatory art for one: the one who can afford them.

title: Raw Recruits Survive Lunchroom Wars as Aides Replace Teachers
description: Like rookie police officers setting off on their new beats, Irene Cuebas and Margarita Delgado rushed into the lunchroom at Public School 306 in Brooklyn at 10:40 yesterday morning.

title: Two DDB Offices Get New Accounts
description: Two offices of the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group received accounts yesterday with combined billings estimated at more than $25 million.

title: A Ruler Who Lives Firmly by the Rules
description: In spite of her exalted position, Queen Elizabeth II leads a rigidly proscribed life, one bound in almost every sense by ancient protocols and hundreds of years of musty tradition.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Yankees Waiting for Girardi to Heal
description: Joe Girardi signaled for a sinker to Harold Baines in the second inning, but David Wells inexplicably uncorked a cut fastball on Thursday night and that mistake will deprive the Yankees of one of their most indispensable players for at least several days and maybe much longer. The unexpected fastball glanced off the tip of Girardi's middle left finger and caused a fracture, leaving the catcher and the Yankees in a difficult position.

title: REXALL AND TWINLAB CALL OFF ACQUISITION TALKS
description: Rexall Sundown Inc. and the Twinlab Corporation have called off Rexall's $707 million acquisition of Twinlab after the Securities and Exchange Commission refused to approve favorable accounting for the purchase. The companies, which are both makers of vitamins and nutritional supplements, said discussions were terminated after the S.E.C. said it would not approve a pooling-of-interests accounting treatment. The companies said on July 1 that they were considering a transaction in which Rexall would issue 0.74 share for each Twinlab share, valuing Twinlab at $26.18 a share at the time. Twinlab shares rose $2.25 yesterday, to $21.75, while Rexall shares rose $1.25, to $38. Both trade on the Nasdaq.

title: No Endorsement From NOW
description: The National Organization for Women will not endorse either candidate for governor, officials said yesterday, because they both support a law that denies additional cash benefits to welfare recipients who have more children.

title: His Voice May Be Soft, But His Fists Are Fatal
description: Something is rotten in the State of Kentucky.

title: Renewed Optimism for Adelphi
description: Elite universities that serve the privileged few are certainly important. But so are the community and commuter colleges that allow a broad range of people to earn degrees and move on to greater accomplishments. For that reason, the resurgence at Adelphi University is good both for Long Island's educational mix and for the surrounding area.

title: Victim's Sister Carries On
description: The sister of Alisa Flatow, the Brandeis University student who was killed in a terrorist bus bombing in the Gaza Strip in 1995, will leave tomorrow for 10 months of study in Israel, her father, Stephen Flatow of West Orange, said yesterday.

title: In Their Own Words
description: SAL F. ALBANESE

title: Family Helps Hundley Fight Through Bad Days
description: Randy Hundley is calling games on radio for the Chicago Cubs these days, filling in for his old friend Ron Santo. Before the Mets came to town he warned his bosses that he would not be able to contain his excitement if his son, Todd, got a hit or made a play. Blood runs mighty thick, he said.

title: Record Chicago Seat Sale
description: A Chicago Board of Trade seat giving the owner the right to trade financial contracts was sold this week for a record $130,000. The previous high price for a seat on the exchange's Index, Debt, Energy Market division was $128,000 on June 5, when it doubled from the previous day after Dow Jones & Company announced it would license its industrial average of 30 stocks to be used in futures and options trading.

title: Former Aide and Republicans Debate What Gore Knew
description: Republican senators investigating campaign finance abuses clashed today with a former top aide to Vice President Al Gore over whether Mr. Gore knew that a luncheon he attended at a Buddhist temple in California last year was a fund-raiser.

title: Hungary Reluctant to Give Up Secrets of Its Past
description: In the cellars of a gracious turn-of-the-century building on the banks of the Danube, shelves of dusty files -- some of them just a few pages, others more comprehensive -- are waiting to be read by Hungarians who were spied on in the Communist era. They became accessible for the first time this week.

title: Investigators Are Examining Company's Ties to Democrats
description: The Ellicott Machine Corporation is a small and proud company, best known for supplying the dredging machines for the Panama Canal, and now headed by a 41-year-old Republican with little experience in politics.

title: Raiding Party In Lebanon Belonged To Elite Unit
description: The naval commando unit that was battered in Lebanon today, known as Flotilla 13, is one of Israel's most acclaimed military forces. Covert and daring, the unit's operations are the stuff of legend, built around the image of indomitable warriors.

title: A Duty to Rescue
description: To the Editor:

title: Worldcom Called Ready to Buy Compuserve in $1.2 Billion Deal
description: Worldcom Inc., the nation's fourth-largest long-distance telephone company, is expected to buy the Compuserve Corporation, H & R Block's faltering on-line service, for nearly $1.2 billion in stock.

title: New York City Zigzags on Clean Drinking Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Harriet Browne, Tap Dancer And Choreographer, 65, Dies
description: Harriet Browne, a tap dancer, choreographer and teacher who performed with the Copasetics, died on Sept. 1 at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. She was 65 and lived in the Bronx.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jets Scramble for Better Grip on New Field
description: Along with their hopes to turn around the National Football League's worst home record of the last 10 years, the Jets are stockpiling 200 pairs of shoes at Giants Stadium on Sunday for their home opener against the Bills.

title: TRW Seeking License for Satellite System
description: TRW Inc. plans to build a $3.4 billion global satellite system capable of transmitting and receiving digital data 100,000 times faster than today's PC modems.

title: Malaysian Market Rises 12.4%, Regaining Losses
description: Malaysia's benchmark stock index jumped 12.4 percent yesterday, snapping a 10-day losing streak, after Malaysia ended share-trading restrictions on Thursday night and delayed some public works projects.

title: New President Is Selected for Barney's
description: Barney's Inc. said yesterday that it had named Thomas C. Shull as its president and chief operating officer to replace John Brincko, who resigned last month.

title: Wiley to Sell Legal Unit to Dutch Publisher
description: John Wiley & Sons Inc. has agreed to sell its Wiley Law Publications division to Wolters Kluwer N.V. of the Netherlands for an undisclosed amount.

title: Archbishop Apologizes To Ex-President de Klerk
description: In an effort to avoid a bruising court battle between the Truth and Reconciliation Commission and South Africa's former white rulers, the head of the commission, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, apologized today for publicly criticizing the former President, F. W. de Klerk, after he testified before the panel last May.

title: Reuters to Build 32-Story Headquarters in Times Sq.
description: The Rudin Organization, one of the oldest real estate families in New York, and Reuters are forming a joint venture to build a 32-story headquarters in Times Square for the British media company.

title: Volkswagen to Raise $4 Billion to Expand
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that it would sell 6 million new shares, raising 7.5 billion Deutsche marks, or $4 billion, to expand operations in Asia or South America. VW's shares plunged as much as 8.8 percent amid concern the new shares would dilute existing shares.

title: NEWCOURT CREDIT TO BUY BRITISH BANK FINANCING UNIT
description: The Canadian lender Newcourt Credit Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy a financing unit of the British bank Lloyds TSB Group P.L.C. for about $:235 million, or $372 million. The purchase of the Business Technology Finance division will be in the form of cash and assumed debt. The acquisition of the business, which originates and manages loans to business customers, will raise Newcourt's assets to more than $9.4 billion (Canadian), or $6.78 billion (United States). The 160 employees at the division's head office in Bristol, England, and a sales office in Glasgow will continue as Newcourt employees.

title: Normal Sales for Retailers
description: New Jersey retailers say they have not lost back-to-school business this week, despite New York's weeklong sales-tax exemption for clothing that costs less than $100.

title: New York City Zigzags on Clean Drinking Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams Sidesteps No One
description: SHE came to New York as a curiosity, as a social statement, as a human tribute on the day a stadium was dedicated to Arthur Ashe. Venus Williams will finish it tomorrow, first and foremost, as a women's finalist in the United States Open.

title: Diana and the Paparazzi: A Morality Tale
description: Throughout the summer, Diana, Princess of Wales, and the photographers who pursued her were bound in a dance of attraction and repulsion that reached the deadly limit of its contradictions on the last day of her life.

title: Bounty Hunter Raid Stirs Outcry and Baffles Police
description: When five men in black ski masks and body armor broke into a tumbledown house on the west side of town early last Sunday and shot a young couple to death in a hail of gunfire, the police said the men were bounty hunters seeking a fugitive -- but they had the wrong house.

title: Company Briefs
description: ASARCO INC., New York, a mining and chemical company, sold its remaining Grupo Mexico S.A. de C.V. series L shares for $191.8 million and will record a third-quarter gain of $32.3 million, or 77 cents a share, on the sale.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT         n    By FRANK LITSKY       TODAY'S KEY GAMES    No. 4 WASHINGTON 0-0  No. 19 at BRIGHAM YOUNG 0-0    Brigham Young's only loss last year was to Washington. This time, Washington has a top quarterback in Brook Huard and a tough defense to stop Paul Shoemaker, Brigham Young's new quarterback.       No. 5 FLORIDA STATE  0-0  No. 23 at SOUTHERN CAL 0-0    Flordia State has too much experience and Southern California too far to come. As Coach John Robinson of the Trojans said, ''Our weapons could be pretty sharp by midseason.'' But not yet.   TV: ABC, 8:00 P.M.    No. 24 COLORADO STATE  1-0  No. 8  at COLORADO  0-0    Their first meeting when both are ranked. Colorado's veteran offense replaces Koy Detmer, a 3,000-yard passer last year, with John Hessler, a 2,000-yard passer in 1995.    No. 3  TENNESSEE  1-0      at U.C.L.A. 0-1    A passing battle between Peyton Manning of Tennessee (310 yards and three touchdowns against Washington State).  TV: ABC, 3:30 P.M.    OTHER GAMES    EAST    East Carolina (0-0)  at West Virginia (1-0)  Two strong running games. Amos Zereoue of West Virginia rushed for 174 yards last week, Scott Harley of East Carolina for 1,745 yards last season.  TV: ESPN, 12:30 P.M.    Marshall (0-1)  at Army (0-0)  Army returns only four starters on offense and one on defense. Marshall has an explosive receiver in 6-5 Randy Moss.    Boston College (0-0)  at Temple (0-1)  While other teams ease into the season against nonconference foes, Boston College starts with three Big East games.  TV: ABC, Noon    SOUTH    Indiana (0-0)  at No. 7 North Carolina (0-0)  North Carolina's sound offense and top defense should breeze over a team picked for last in the Big Ten.   TV: ESPN2, Noon    No. 21 Northwestern (1-0)  at Wake Forest (0-0)  Northwestern should be comfortable despite losing its best receiver, D'Wayne Bates, with a broken leg.    North Carolina State (1-0)  at Duke (0-0)  In upsetting Syracuse in overtime, State's Jamie Barnette passed for 279 yards plus the deciding 2-point conversion.    Southern Methodist (0-0)  at Mississippi (1-0)  Ole Miss fell a yard short of losing to Central Florida last week.    Kentucky (1-0)  at Mississippi State (1-0)  State must stop Tim Couch, who passed for 398 yards and four touchdowns against Louisville.    MIDWEST    Georgia Tech (0-0)  at No. 11 Notre Dame (0-0)  Bob Davie, Notre Dame's new coach, fears that his defensive front seven is too green. Not to worry.  TV: NBC, 2:30 P.M.    No. 21 Kansas State (0-0)  at Northern Illinois (0-1)  Kansas State should roll behind quarterback Michael Bishop, a junior-college transfer.    Wester Michigan (1-0)  at No. 25 Michigan State (0-0)  State has a good running game and a good defensive line, but little depth up front on offense or defense.    Texas Christian (0-0)  at Kansas (1-0)  The Kansas defense had two interceptions for touchdowns against Alabama-Birmingham.    SOUTHWEST    Syracuse (1-1)  at Oklahoma (0-1)  Coach Paul Pasqualoni is unsure how Syracuse will respond after that dreary loss to North Carolina State. As he said, ''Football, like life, is about 10 percent what happens and 90 percent how you react to it.''    Air Force (1-0)  at Rice (0-0)  Air Force beat Idaho on a late stop. Rice will be tougher.    MISMATCHES    Pittsburgh (1-0)  at No. 1 Penn State (1-0)  Pittsburgh won't share tapes of last week's victory against Southwestern Louisiana. It will make no difference.  TV: PPV, 3:30 P.M.    Central Michigan (1-0)  at No. 2 Florida (1-0)  Coach Steve Spurrier calls his Flordia team ''just a common, average, bottom-of-the-league bunch of guys right now.'' Not really.    Texas, El Paso (0-0)  at No. 10 Louisiana St. (0-0)  In last year's opener, Louisana State beat underdog Houston by a point. This time, the Tigers are five-touchdown favorites.    Rutgers (0-1)  at No. 12 Texas (0-0)  After a 59-19 beating by Virginia last week, linebacker Aaron Brady of Rutgers said, ''It's very discouraging. I felt a little bit of shame.''  Rankings are by the Associated Press; all times are Eastern.
Charles Can Strengthen the Monarchy by Renouncing the Throne
description: To the Editor:

title: Job Creation Slowed in August As U.P.S. Strike Curbed Hiring
description: The economy created jobs at a slower pace in August, as the unemployment rate inched up one-tenth of a point, to 4.9 percent, from a 23-year low, the Government reported today.

title: BIG REVAMPING PLANNED BY BRUNSWICK TO CUT COSTS
description: The Brunswick Corporation said yesterday that it was cutting jobs, dropping some products, closing a plant and changing some processes, resulting in a third-quarter charge of about $60 million, or 60 cents a share. The company, based in Lake Forest, Ill., a maker of boats, fishing products, marine engines and bowling equipment, said the restructuring steps could cut costs by as much as $60 million in the next three years. Brunswick will use the savings to develop new products and reduce manufacturing costs.

title: Air France's Head Resigns in Protest
description: PARIS  The man credited with turning around France's flagship airline, Christian Blanc, said Friday that he was stepping down as head of Air France, making good on his threat to resign if the leftist government blocked plans to privatize the company.

title: In a Reversal, Apple Decides It Will Keep Its Newton Unit
description: In a reversal, Apple Computer Inc. has decided not to spin off its Newton division and will instead develop a general purpose version of the company's Emate portable, which is now sold only to schools.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Pettite Bloodied by Line Drive; Irabu and Yankees Get Battered
description: The sound of Cal Ripken Jr.'s line drive smashing off Andy Pettitte's face last night was almost as disturbing as the sight of the baseball drilling the Yankee pitcher. It sounded ugly and it looked ugly, as the ball deflected off Pettitte's left thumb, popping him between his mouth and nose, and he collapsed to the dirt.

title: To Andover, With Heart In the Bronx
description: A CRATE of clothing propped open the door to Sheena Hopkins's apartment building on the Grand Concourse, where she stood in the shaded courtyard. Her little brother Shakari scampered behind her while she watched her family haul bulging duffel bags to their waiting station wagon.

title: Village Primary Race Far From the Textbook
description: It might be hard to find another primary campaign like the one in this suburb, where two Haitians, a Jamaican and an Orthodox Jew are running for mayor.

title: Reno Bending on Opposition To New Special Prosecutor
description: In recent days, Attorney General Janet Reno and her inner circle have sharply changed their attitude and are seriously weighing whether to refer the inquiry into campaign fund-raising abuses to an independent prosecutor, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: COMMERCIAL BANK OF NEW YORK BEGINS AN EXPANSION
description: Commercial Bank of New York moved yesterday to expand its banking business in the New York area by acquiring First Bank of the Americas, the United States unit of Colombia's Banco de Bogota, for $48 million in cash. Commercial Bank, owned by the Safdie family of Israel, paid $48 million, or 5 percent more than First Bank's average deposit balance. First Bank gives Commercial Bank eight branches in New York City and Long Island, $365 million in deposits and about $100 million in loans. BanBogota Inc., First Bank's parent and the United States unit of Banco de Bogota, will retain international and automobile loans and other assets.

title: The Aid of Psychiatry
description: To the Editor:

title: Misys and Medic Computer Set $922.8 Million Merger
description: Misys P.L.C., a large British software company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Medic Computer Systems Inc., a leading maker of software for automating physicians' billing and patient records, for $922.8 million in cash, or $35 a share.

title: America's Unfriendly Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Urges That Pentagon Lose Gulf Inquiry Authority
description: A special White House panel said today that the Pentagon had lost so much credibility in its investigation of the release of Iraqi chemical weapons in the 1991 Persian Gulf war that oversight of the investigation must be taken away from the Defense Department permanently.

title: Given Chance to Debate, Democrats Attack Mayor
description: In one of their final televised appearances together, the three leading Democratic mayoral candidates largely refrained from attacking one another yesterday, using instead a debate just days before the Tuesday primary to criticize Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, especially on his handling of the city's schools.

title: Greenspan Voices Doubt On Statistics
description: With investors worldwide awaiting his every word, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, cast doubt again tonight on the reliability of key economic statistics but drew no firm conclusions on why the economy has remained inflation-free despite strong growth and low unemployment.

title: Woods Misses His First Cut
description: Tiger Woods, the world's No. 1-ranked golfer, missed the first cut of his professional career today at the Bell Canadian Open, shooting a six-over-par 76, his worst round of the year, to finish six over par for the tournament at 146. It snapped a streak of 25 consecutive cuts made by Woods since he became a professional in August 1996.

title: Defiant Israelis Crowd Jerusalem Mall Where Suicide Bomb Attack Killed 4
description: At the Finzi Cafe on Jerusalem's pedestrian mall, David Cohen had his usual coffee with friends this afternoon, but today it was an act of defiance.

title: Rome Shrugs Off Loss of Olympics
description: Just as almost everyone suspected, the competition to be host to the 2004 Olympic Summer Games came down to a race between Rome and Athens, Mediterranean cities and ancient rivals, each of which has claimed at one point to have been the center of the known world.

title: Playing the Education Card
description: CANDIDATE: Sal F. Albanese

title: COLONNADE CAPITAL ADDING NATIONAL PICTURE AND FRAME
description: The National Picture and Frame Company said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Colonnade Capital L.L.C. and some National Picture management members for $12 a share, or about $63 million. Colonnade is an investment firm based in Virginia. National Picture, based in Greenwood, Miss., a maker of picture frames and art, said completion of the deal was subject to at least 90 percent of its shares being tendered to the offer. National Picture's shares closed at $11.8125, up $1.0625 on the Nasdaq Stock Market.

title: A Cheery Art Critic Who's Not Too Critical
description: Sister Wendy, nun, art student and British television star, makes it big this weekend on PBS, where she will remain for a month of Sundays in her latest hit, ''Sister Wendy's Story of Painting.'' Bespectacled, bewimpled and with a decided lisp, the 67-year-old woman makes a highly unlikely but entirely likable television guide as she sweeps through centuries and across countries with pauses at the most famous works of art of the Western world.

title: Two Republicans Defy Helms on Weld, But Panel Chairman Won't Budge, Aide Says
description: Republicans today inched closer to forcing a face-to-face confrontation with Senator Jesse Helms over the nomination of William F. Weld, the former Governor of Massachusetts, to be Ambassador to Mexico.

title: TUPPERWARE STOCK FALLS ON FORECAST OF WEAK EARNINGS
description: The stock of the Tupperware Corporation fell 19 percent yesterday after the company forecast weak third-quarter earnings. After the financial markets closed on Thursday, the company, which makes plastic storage products, said it expected its net income to be ''down significantly'' for the quarter ending Sept. 28 compared with the period a year ago. In last year's third quarter, Tupperware, based in Orlando, Fla., earned $18.1 million, or 29 cents a share, on sales of $290.6 million. Analysts surveyed by First Call Inc. had been predicting third-quarter earnings of 28 cents a share. The company said it also expects ''flat sales and a substantial decline in net income'' for the full year. Shares of Tupperware fell $6.6875, to $28.4325, on the Big Board.

title: DAVCO RESTAURANTS GETS $148 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
description: Davco Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it had received a cash buyout offer worth as much as $148 million from an investor group that includes company managers and a Citicorp unit that is its principal shareholder. Davco, the largest franchisee of Wendy's restaurants, said the group offered to pay $18 to $20 in cash for each of Davco's common shares. Davco has about 7.4 million shares outstanding fully diluted. Shares of Davco rose $4.50, or 33 percent, to $17.875, on the American Stock Exchange. Davco went public in 1993 at $12 a share. Leading the buyout group is Ronald D. Kirstien, Davco's president and chief executive. Davco also operates Friendly's restaurants

title: Windsors Through A Lens, Stiffly
description: When Queen Elizabeth addressed her nation yesterday, she was also speaking directly to a television camera, and through it to an audience around the world. What viewers saw, in the larger picture, was the royal family struggling mightily, with some success, to leap into a new age of media coverage.

title: For MTV, Mortality Stalks Celebrity
description: The specter of death hung over the MTV Video Music Awards on Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall. On and off camera, celebrities made frequent mention of those among their ranks who had died of unnatural causes since last year's awards show, from royalty (the Princess of Wales) to rappers (Tupac Shakur and the Notorious B.I.G.) to those made famous by blood and marriage (Ennis Cosby and Dr. Betty Shabazz). Oddly, there was no mention of Gianni Versace, although musicians close to him, like Elton John and Madonna, spoke of Diana.

title: Reinforce The Walls Of Privacy
description: The death of Diana, Princess of Wales, has left us with difficult questions about the relationship between free speech and privacy: Does the law allow celebrities to protect themselves from harassment? And should the law do more?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What I say to you now, as your Queen and as a grandmother, I say from my heart.''

title: The Royal Ice Cubes
description: It is not easy to reverse the emotional customs of the ages. To share feelings with commoners. To bend to the will of the people you were born to rule.

title: Lawsuit Asserts Ford Knowingly Installed Defective Mechanism in Millions of Vehicles
description: Despite safety concerns about millions of its cars and light trucks, the Ford Motor Company withheld information from Federal regulators about an engineering defect that can cause the vehicles to stall at high speeds, documents filed in a lawsuit here suggest.

title: Mom, I'm Not a Paparazzo
description: I had to defend myself to my mother the other day. The terrible feeling I had when she told me that the Princess of Wales had died was compounded by the realization that my career and my mother's interests had suddenly converged.

title: Bosnia's Polluted Airwaves
description: Inflammatory television broadcasts in Bosnia threaten the peace, but silencing the offending stations is not the way to handle the problem. Rather than ordering NATO forces to knock venomous broadcasts off the air, as NATO is prepared to do, the United States and its peacekeeping partners ought to help give viewers more diverse programming. It ill suits an alliance of democratic nations to impose censorship in the pursuit of peace.

title: Unit of Duke in Deal With Providence Gas
description: Duke Trading and Marketing L.L.C., a unit of the Duke Energy Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., has signed a three-year contract to administer the gas-supply agreements of the Providence Gas Company and to deliver Providence's gas at a fixed price. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Among Mourners in London, Anger Still at the Queen
description: Vernon Lloyd-Jones, a 67-year-old businessman who came from Wales to join a sea of people mourning at Kensington Palace, where Diana, Princess of Wales, had lived, watched the crowds streaming in to pay their respects as he listened to Queen Elizabeth praising her former daughter-in-law.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CRASH HURTS CROSSING GUARD -- A school crossing guard was critically hurt when a police tow truck ran a red light and hit a car, which struck the guard, the police said. Page 26.

title: Off-Duty Police Officer Is Shot in Traffic Dispute
description: An off-duty police officer was shot in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon in an apparent traffic dispute, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Blue-Chip Stocks Slip As Small Companies Soar

title: Tabloids Join The Uninvited
description: The editors of Britain's popular and populist tabloids, accused by the brother of the Princess of Wales of having ''blood on his hands'' after her death in a car accident in Paris on Sunday, have been told that they will not be welcome at her funeral.

title: Small Stocks Up Again, While Dow Drops
description: Investors continued their infatuation with the stocks of smaller companies yesterday, pushing a leading index of those companies to new highs. But concerns about Asian market turmoil and a strengthening dollar weighed on the stocks of larger multinational companies, which could see their earnings reduced by exposure in those countries.

title: Tribal 'Sovereignty' Threatens Gray Whale
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Leaves 3 Candidates in the Shadows
description: At the very moment the news that Mother Teresa had died crossed the Channel 2 newsroom in Manhattan yesterday afternoon, the three Democratic mayoral candidates were receiving the final touches of makeup for a televised debate that, they hoped, might finally draw attention to Tuesday's primary.

title: Cubans Blame Exiles in U.S. for 4 Bombings in a Single Day
description: A bomb exploded in one of Havana's best-known tourist restaurants late Thursday night, following three bombs earlier in the day at three of the city's seafront hotels, in which an Italian businessman was killed.

title: 168th St. Subway Station To Reopen After Repairs
description: The busy 168th Street station on the 1 and 9 subway lines is scheduled to reopen on Monday after being closed since July 5 for a $4 million elevator repair project.

title: Evasive Arafat, Elusive Peace
description: After the suicide bombings here on Thursday, the Palestinian Authority promised to show ''zero tolerance'' for terrorism. But it won't destroy the Islamic terrorist infrastructure in the territories it controls. As in the past, the Palestinian police will likely make a show of arresting some Hamas fundamentalists, who will then be quietly released when world attention is diverted.

title: Rome Shrugs Off Loss of Olympics
description: Just as almost everyone suspected, the competition to be host to the 2004 Olympic Summer Games came down to a race between Rome and Athens, Mediterranean cities and ancient rivals, each of which has claimed at one point to have been the center of the known world.

title: Judge Waives Confidentiality Of Proceedings Against Him
description: Lorin Duckman, the New York City judge who faces possible removal from the bench after an investigation spawned by his handling of domestic violence cases, has decided to allow the public and press to attend final arguments on Thursday in the disciplinary proceedings against him, according to his lawyer.

title: Williams Powers Into Final, Where Hingis Waits
description: She delivered her every shot with a shriek and a crash of the 1,800 beads that make hers the noisiest hairdo on the tennis circuit. But when her grueling 2-hour-42-minute semifinal, her first United States Open semifinal, was over at long last, 17-year-old Venus Williams was not done screaming.

title: Healthy Hero Worship
description: To the Editor:

title: Net Gain: Serve and Volley Back in Style
description: Coincidence or cutting edge? That is the question worth asking about today's men's semifinals at the United States Open.

title: Can 2 Magazine Cultures Find Happiness Together?
description: David Cudaback, the editor of Institutional Investor, returned from a week's vacation on Nantucket on Aug. 25 to discover that he had been dismissed. It was not the greatest 52d birthday present.

title: Relatives File Civil Suits
description: The French criminal investigation into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in a car accident on Sunday gathered momentum today with the disclosure that her mother and sisters had filed a civil suit in the proceedings that would allow them to seek damages if there were a trial. The accident took place after a chase by celebrity photographers.

title: La Guardia as a Role Model
description: CANDIDATE: Rudolph W. Giuliani

title: Maybe Computers Aren't Schools' Salvation
description: President Clinton has a vision of ''the day when computers are as much a part of a classroom as blackboards.'' Some educators, however, are beginning to question the contribution of computers to education, at least at the kindergarten through eighth-grade level. They wonder whether the expensive computers are causing other important school services to be sacrificed.

title: A Big Case With Racial Overtones. Familiar?
description: The political types in the Showtime film ''Color of Justice'' include a show-no-mercy Manhattan district attorney, a bleeding-heart civil rights lawyer and a black minister savvy in the ways of media manipulation. This story of a white woman from suburban New Jersey who dies after an encounter with four young black men in a stolen car hits every hot-button issue from police brutality and racial bigotry to Constitutional rights.

title: Money at the Temple
description: Vice President Al Gore's claim that he never knew the reception he attended at a Buddhist temple in Los Angeles was a fund-raising event is likely to haunt him for years. It could even turn out to rival George Bush's insistence that he was ''out of the loop'' during the Iran-contra scandals of the Reagan years. But dwelling on questions about what Mr. Gore knew may be missing the larger point. As the Senate committee investigating the fund-raising scandals showed this week, the Vice President's entourage and others in the 1996 election campaign were operating in such a lax and desperate atmosphere that abuses became inevitable.

title: Tax-Free Has Its Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: No to Air France, Yes to France Telecom on Privatization
description: To be, or not to be, capitalist?

title: High Cancer Rates Reported
description: The rate of cancer of the brain and central nervous system for women living near hazardous waste sites in Bergen County was nearly double the state average over a 17-year period, according to a joint Federal and state study released yesterday.

title: Athens Wins a Vote for Tradition, and the 2004 Olympics
description: The Olympics returned to the country of their ancient beginnings and the city of their modern revival when Athens was selected today by a surprisingly wide margin over Rome to be the host of the 2004 Summer Games.

title: Tribal 'Sovereignty' Threatens Gray Whale
description: To the Editor:

title: '97 Tax Bills Up About 3% In New Jersey
description: Property tax bills in New Jersey, already among the highest in the nation, went up an average of 3 percent this year, according to preliminary estimates released today by the Whitman administration.

title: Brooklyn Primary Is a Battle of Resumes and Endorsements
description: When it comes to identifying ways to revitalize Sunset Park and Red Hook, the five Democrats who would like to represent Brooklyn's 38th Council District have a lot in common. All five have promised to lobby for another high school in the district. Each one backs plans to replace the perpetually gridlocked Gowanus Expressway with a tunnel closer to the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Official Took Kickbacks
description: The director of West New York's Bureau of Housing Assistance, who was responsible for disbursing checks for federally subsidized construction, pleaded guilty to extortion yesterday in Federal court, admitting that he had taken more than $14,000 in kickbacks from a Brick Township contractor, prosecutors said.

title: Investor Group Wins Bid for Israeli Bank
description: A consortium of investors led by the owner of Carnival Cruise Lines, Ted Arison, submitted the winning bid to buy a controlling stake in Bank Hapoalim, Israel's largest bank. The Government's bank privatization agency said yesterday that the group had offered to buy 43 percent of the bank's shares for nearly $1.4 billion in cash and received an option to buy an additional 21.5 percent of the shares in three phases over four and a half years.

title: Liberal Democrats in Japan Regain Hold on Lower House
description: Four years after Japanese voters ejected the Liberal Democratic Party from its longtime lock on power, the party regained control today with an effective majority in Japan's influential lower house of Parliament.

title: New Republic Editor Dismissed Over Criticism
description: Michael Kelly, the editor of The New Republic, was dismissed yesterday by Martin Peretz, the political magazine's owner and editor in chief. He was replaced by Charles Lane, The New Republic's senior editor.

title: ISRAELIS' EDGINESS SHARPENED BY LOSS OF 12 IN LEBANON
description: As they mourned the victims of Thursday's terrorist bombing in Jerusalem, Israelis suffered a new blow today with the news that 11 naval commandos on a raid into Lebanon were ambushed and killed and a 12th was missing and presumed dead.

title: Crude Oil Prices Rise on Hurricane Threat
description: Crude oil prices rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange on concerns that a hurricane in the Caribbean would disrupt operations at a large refinery in St. Croix and smaller refining plants in Puerto Rico.

title: Rabbis Sue to Block New Holocaust Museum
description: Sixteen Orthodox Jewish rabbis filed a lawsuit in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday seeking to block the opening of the Museum of Jewish Heritage -- A Living Memorial to the Holocaust.

title: Zenith Electronics Chief to Step Down
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said today that Peter S. Willmott was stepping down as chief executive of the loss-ridden company.

title: INSIDE
description: New Central Park Caretaker

title: Land for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front-page article yesterday about a suicide bombing in Jerusalem included an outdated passage at the end of the article in some copies about an Israeli raid into southern Lebanon. The Israeli death toll reported early yesterday by Reuters, quoting Lebanese officials, was 12.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a rally at the United States Capitol protesting a shift in political power from the District of Columbia's elected officials to an appointed financial control board misidentified n organizer of the rally. He is Tim Cooper, not Jim Cooper.

title: Christie's Draws a Line For Modern Art at 1900
description: If contemporary artists don't fade away, they become modern masters. Such thinking, long prevalent among museum curators, is now being adopted by Christie's. Works by Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg and Jackson Pollock, once considered blue-chip contemporary artists, will soon be sold alongside Picassos, Matisses and Mondrians.

title: Not the Media's Magic
description: To the Editor:

title: Grambling's Beginning of Goodbye
description: TEN o'clock in the morning, and the first trickle of Grambling football players walk out onto the hot, sun-baked practice field next to Eddie Robinson Stadium. Boyce Walker, a defensive tackle, is first out, then Frank Livingston, an offensive lineman.

title: Russian and American Astronauts Begin Space Walk
description: Russian and American astronauts clambered out of the star-crossed Mir this morning and began a complex and potentially hazardous space walk to help restore the space station.

title: South Africans Disappointed By Vote
description: After ''holding thumbs'' for weeks the South African way of saying keeping one's fingers crossed -- the nation that had thrown the full weight of its new Government behind its Olympic bid got a thumb in the eye at 7 o'clock tonight.

title: The Model of Mother Teresa
description: In death as in life, Mother Teresa will be fondly remembered as a diminutive figure in a simple white habit with blue trim tirelessly ministering to the world's most afflicted citizens. Even in recent years when she was weakened by heart problems and several times seemed close to death, she found the energy and time to visit orphanages, hospices and rehabilitation centers, invariably lifting the spirits of destitute children and patients.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the search for paintings stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston misattributed remarks about where they might be hidden. It was William P. Youngworth 3d, an antiques dealer, not Tom Mashberg, a Boston Herald reporter, who said he was ''at a loss to explain'' how he came by that information and how he came into possession of a 368-year-old charter seal that had been stolen from another museum.

title: Mother Teresa, Hope of the Despairing, Dies at 87
description: Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun who won the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize for her work among the poorest of the world's poor, died yesterday in Calcutta, India, where she had lived since her work with the destitute began five decades ago. She was 87.

title: Giants' Jones Gives Alma Mater $100,000
description: Cedric Jones was at home trying to relax, but his knee was throbbing from what he called a cheap shot by Philadelphia offensive guard Joe Panos last Sunday. Still, there was a smile on Jones's face because he has done something that practically has his alma mater, the University of Oklahoma, prepared to put up a statue in his name.

title: Elizabeth Returns to London To Bury, and Praise, Diana
description: Speaking in remarkably personal terms for a British monarch, Queen Elizabeth today praised Diana, Princess of Wales, as ''an exceptional and gifted human being,'' and said, ''I for one believe that there are lessons to be drawn from her life and from the extraordinary and moving reaction to her death.''

title: Georg Solti, Master Who Shaped Chicago Symphony, Is Dead at 84
description: Sir Georg Solti, the vigorous and exacting Hungarian-born conductor who shaped the Chicago Symphony Orchestra into a gleaming virtuoso instrument during his 22 years as its music director, and who won more Grammy Awards than any other performer, classical or pop, died yesterday while visiting Antibes, in the south of France, reported Agence France-Presse. He was 84 and lived in London.

title: Bridge
description: The number of bridge players in China is probably over one million, although there is no way to be sure. But there is only one Chinese theorist, as far as is known in the West. His name is Chien-Hwa Wang, and four decades ago he analyzed the clash squeeze, a group of endings previously unknown.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Stalwart Member Wins the MacArthur on Opening Day at Belmont
description: After six stylish weeks of racing upstate in Saratoga Springs, the thoroughbreds returned to Belmont Park yesterday for their 33-day autumn season, which will feature world-class horses in 39 stakes worth more than $8 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER

title: In New York, Memories of a Big Heart
description: When word spread through the South Bronx yesterday afternoon that Mother Teresa was dead, residents stopped what they were doing and headed for the two-story red-brick building that has housed her Missionaries of Charity since 1971, the first such house the order established in the United States.

title: Jail Sentence for Imposter
description: Over a four-year period, Marco Carranza, 26, a father of two who worked in a pizza parlor, repeatedly paid Dawn Stegmaier, an Atlantic City prostitute, for sex and gave her marijuana, officials said.

title: No Headline
Family Finds Home Schooling Fits In With Its Values and Seasonal Rythms
description: The scent of freshly sharpened No. 2 pencils is not a totem of the new school year to the Belcher children, Christopher, 10, Noah, 7, and Zia, 5. Nor are yellow school buses or the slippery feel of new shoes on waxed classroom floors.

title: Theorists See Evolutionary Advantages In Menopause
description: THE Hadza people of northern Tanzania are a small group of hunter-gatherers who share a language, a culture and a distaste for gardening. Time and again, government and church agencies have sought to transmute them into full-time farmers, but the Hazda have always returned to the bush, where they subsist on wild goods like fruits, honey, tubers and game. The terrain is hard and hilly, and so is the life, but on one incomparable resource the foragers can always rely: a pack of old ladies with hearts like young horses.

title: Protecting the Soil
description: To the Editor:

title: Owners of Vicious Dogs Face Stiff New Penalties
description: Dog owners could face fines or jail time if their pet makes unprovoked attacks on people, under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Maternity Leave Ended, Officer Helps Deliver Baby
description: The call came tucked amid the usual fare of burglaries, assaults and other nefarious acts: a woman about to give birth who needed help.

title: In School, Intended to Shock
description: CANDIDATE: Ruth W. Messinger

title: Beliefs
description: The millions of mourners expected to join in the last rites today for Diana, Princess of Wales, have overshadowed, for the moment, the sea of over a million people who gathered in a solemn but also joyous religious ceremony outside Paris two weeks ago.

title: The Aging of Japan May Aid Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: City Offers Private Group Contract to Maintain Central Park
description: Formalizing a relationship that has been growing steadily for 17 years, the Giuliani administration has decided to officially turn over responsibility for maintaining Central Park, the pastoral soul of the city, to a private group.

title: School Crossing Guard Is Hit In Crash Involving City Truck
description: A school crossing guard was critically injured in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn yesterday morning when a police tow truck ran a red light and hit another car, which struck the guard, the police said.

title: Thalidomide, Long Banned, Wins Support
description: Thalidomide, the drug that was banned worldwide in the 1960s after it produced thousands of babies with missing and stunted limbs, took a step toward Government approval today when a committee of scientific advisers recommended that the Food and Drug Administration make it available to leprosy patients, but with tight restrictions.

title: Preserving History, Brick by Brick
description: You knew the discussion was getting serious, that something was about to happen to Notre Dame Stadium, when the alumni demand for football tickets became so great that the university was sending back more checks than it could cash. Notre Dame does a lot of things well, but returning checks is not one of them.

title: Play's the Thing
description: INVENTING KINDERGARTEN By Norman Brosterman. Illustrated. 160 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $39.95.

title: Moscow at 850
description: To the Editor: Marina Lakhman's article ''There'll Be Singing in Red Square'' (Aug. 17) referred to a Pavarotti performance with a ''Russian orchestra.'' That orchestra is the Russian National Orchestra, Russia's leading orchestra, which is considered one of the finest in the world. Leone Magiera will conduct this performance.

title: When Dressing Up Is a Spectator Sport
description: The setting for certain sporting events encourages the audience to dress up, rather than to wear the standard catalogue style of T-shirts and shorts. The National Tennis Center, with the new Arthur Ashe Stadium, spacious plazas and outdoor cafes, has set a mood to dress stylishly both day and evening (photographs right). The Hampton Classic, a horse show in Bridgehampton, N.Y., has evolved from an over-the-top ''Dynasty'' dress-up show to a low-key spectator fashion display (left). And at the recent polo matches in Bridgehampton, the idyllic setting encouraged an abundance of stylish dressing. At all the events, the shade hat was popular, from the straw coolie hat to the fabric sun visor.

title: Those Too Friendly Telemarketers: Lessons to Heed
description: AT first, Anna Hartley didn't realize that the telemarketers who called her were leading her astray. The 83-year-old widow, who lives in housing for elderly people in Wethersfield, said she believed that the men and women who called her cared about her, and were sincere when they told her that she would win a new car and increase her chances of winning big prize money if she sent in more money or bought magazines or books.

title: Big Cats Make a Comeback
description: Faced with a 150-pound cougar, what is a 50-pound child supposed to do?

title: Making the Most of the End-of-Summer Bounty of Plums
description: THE end of summertime, when I was growing up in England, was marked by the harvest of plums. There were many different kinds, among them small golden plums called Mirabelles, greengage (named for Sir Thomas Gage who upon receiving an unlabeled sapling of the Reine Claude plum sent from France, named it for himself) and purple Victoria plums. We ate them ripe and juicy straight from the tree. In their short season, they were also made into pies and crumbles or as sauces for game or pork.

title: Manufacturers Line Up for Plant Sites
description: A tiny economic event is taking place in a corner of New York where the city's robust economy often fails to stir much notice. A new manufacturing plant will soon open in East Harlem, and if all goes as planned, there will be another, then another, then another, until the Park Avenue manufacturing zone will be difficult to ignore.

title: Jones Leading Norman In Canada
description: For much of this year, Steve Jones forgot that golf should be fun. He worried about trying to make the Ryder Cup team. He worried about an inconsistent putting stroke. And when the normally jovial Jones turns sour, so does his game.

title: In England, the Crucible of the Modern Age
description: THE British passion for historic restoration has been displayed most conspicuously in gracious country houses, opulent palaces and romantic castles. But restorers by no means neglect the grittier side of the past -- the factories, foundries and mines that ushered in the machine age.

title: Seeing Africa With a New York Museum
description: Small-group trips to Mali and the Ivory Coast are being offered this winter by the Museum for African Art in New York. The trips last for two weeks and focus on traditional culture, including dances and ceremonies, as well as architecture and crafts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, IRA, MD.
description: DIAMOND-Ira, MD. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff, Administration and employees of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center express with great sorrow the passing of its esteemed member of the Department of Medicine. He was a dedicated internist and hematologist, beloved by his patients. To his wife, Beverly, and his family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman, Board of Trustees David I. Schachne, Chairman, Executive Committee Frank J. Maddalena, President and CEO Alvin I. Kahn, MD, Sr Vice President, Medical Affairs I. Akiva Wulkan, MD, President, Medical Board Eric I. Saltzman, MD, President, Medical Staff

title: He Knows the Schools Well
description: WHO -- Kyle Paul Tinnes of Franklin Township, Hunterdon County, a newly elected member of the Franklin Township Board of Education for the township's elementary school. At 18, he may be the youngest school board member in the state.

title: Home, in Sometimes Odd Poses
description: AN exhibition with home in its title has a head start. Home -- as in ''home cooking,'' say -- signals comfort and viewers are automatically prepared to like it. At the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, ''Visions of Home: American Impressionist Images of Suburban Leisure and Country Comfort,'' running through Sept. 28, has this advantage.

title: Ms. Perkins, Mr. de Cordova
description: Anna Katharine Perkins and Michael de Cordova were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Phillips performed the ceremony.

title: In Newport, the Many-Faceted Legacy of Doris Duke
description: IN her $1.2 billion will, Doris Duke left her 40-room oceanfront mansion here, Rough Point, to a nonprofit foundation with instructions that it become a museum.

title: Honoring the Unsung And the Seldom Seen
description: ACROSS THE COUNTRY, between Robert Rauschenberg this month and Pierre Bonnard in June, the season's major exhibitions tend toward the monographic, retrospective kind. This would be business as usual were it not for the fact that many of the subjects aren't among the usual suspects; indeed, in many cases the shows represent firsts.

title: Making House Safe For Toddler
description: JOEL FEIN and Victoria Levin know about children. Both are pediatricians: Dr. Levin is in private practice in Newark, Del., and Dr. Fein is an attending emergency room physician at Children's Hospital in Philadelphia. So it came as something of a surprise to the couple when they discovered that their infant son had learned to climb stairs.

title: Harold E. Yuker, 73, Authority On Attitudes Toward Disabled
description: Harold Elwood Yuker, a psychologist who defied the cerebral palsy with which he was born to become a leading educator at Hofstra University and an authority on attitudes toward the disabled, died on Aug. 25 at his home in Bellmore, N.Y. He was 73.

title: Grammar Cops
description: Good English wasn't supposed to survive the Internet, remember? Traditional grammar, spelling and usage, the digerati sneered, are hopelessly ''analog: uncool, fossilized, predigital. No, they said, the post-Gutenberg era demands a revolutionary language, one that's dynamic and rule-averse. So don't expect to find standard English in the precincts of cyberspace. Well, here's a word to the wired. The grammar police are cruising the info highway, and they're writing tickets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARKMAN, MARTIN
description: STARKMAN - Martin. Family mourns the loss of husband of Rhea, father of Hope and Dawn. Brother of Esther and husband Bob. Devoted his life to his family.

title: Calcutta's Global Ambassador
description: The people of Calcutta knew and respected Mother Teresa long before she became a global symbol of Christian charity. To them she was a neighbor, warm and richly human, with flashes of flinty will evident even in her characteristically good-humored smile.

title: TELEVISION
description: NEW SERIES

title: Business Best Sellers
description: HARD COVER

title: Fashion's Nobility Bowed to Her
description: SAM McKNIGHT was styling Naomi Campbell's hair for Gianni Versace's fall 1991 couture photographs when the Princess of Wales gave him a call on the set.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LAST DAYS IN CLOUD CUCKOOLAND Dispatches From White Africa. By Graham Boynton. Random House, $24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEITZER, HERBERT
description: SCHNEITZER-Herbert. Died at home September 6, 1997. Family mourns the loss of beloved husband of Mildred, father of Leila, father-in-law of Gregg, grandfather of Jordan, brother of Sylvia and Zelda. Devoted his life to his family. Services Monday, 1 PM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J).

title: Chasing a Goal on a String in the Satellite Tour
description: THE splendor and riches that are big-time professional tennis have been on display in Queens for the last two weeks. In today's finals of the United States Open, the winning man and woman will each receive a check for $650,000. Their opponents will have to be consoled with $350,000 apiece.

title: Man Accused of Killing Wife at Homeless Shelter
description: A Queens man shot and killed his wife yesterday afternoon in front of a Bronx homeless shelter where she was living, as her 4-year-old daughter looked on, the police said.

title: BOOT ME UP TO THE BALLGAME
description: What can be done to take the graceful but poky game of baseball into the future? The San Diego Padres and Vyvx Inc., think they have one answer: 400 snazzy interactive touch screens, recently installed at Qualcomm Stadium, home of the Padres. Dubbed ''Choiceseat,'' the screens allow fans to watch a game from nine camera angles, request instant replays or -- if they're really bored -- ignore the action altogether and play bingo. ''This will bring back charm to the game,'' says Barry Goldberg, project leader of Choiceseat. Purists will retch at that statement, but one Choiceseat feature may prove popular: Eventually it will allow users to order cold beers at a touch.

title: Sally Blane, 87, Veteran Film Actress
description: Sally Blane, an actress who appeared in more than 100 films, died on Aug. 27 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERWIN, IRVING
description: SHERWIN-Irving. Died Sept 2. A renaissance man, he was a believer in the quest for loving, learning and living. Always in pursuit of personal and relational excellence. He found beauty and joy in all of life. He realized a life full of experiences only a few could imagine. A traveler in both time and space, he touched those he met with insight and enlightenment. His accomplishments were many, he was a Mensa, a philanthropist, a Mason and a successful businessman. He owned the world renowned Sheru. His wisdom and love will be greatly missed by those who knew him and those who will never have the opportunity to meet him. He is survived by his children Marny and Joe Nedlin, and Steven and Dana Sherwin; his grandchildren Richard Nedlin, and Brian and Kevin Sherwin; and companion Barthy.

title: Boys to Build a Whitehall Worthy of the Hudson
description: They may be landlubbers now, mere students in the fourth through eighth grades. But the boys at Saint David's School on East 89th Street are about to become old salts and boat builders, too, thanks to a grant for ''innovative science teaching'' awarded this spring by the National Science Teachers Association.

title: B.C./A.D. or B.C.E./C.E.?
description: I admire William Safire for taking on such a controversial subject in ''B.C./A.D. or B.C.E./C.E.?'' (Aug. 17). However, I would like to make one observation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOGGIE, JEAN PHILLIPS HIGGINS
description: LOGGIE-Jean Phillips Higgins, 9/7/17-3/3/89. Bless the day you were born. Love, Robin, Jock, Siga, David, Johnnie and Bobbie

title: Lidie Sapp, M. F. Greenwald
description: Lidie Katherine Sapp, a paralegal, and Matthew Franklin Greenwald, a senatorial aide, were married yesterday in Mobile, Ala. The Rev. Paul Zoghby performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Church.

title: How to Save Affirmative Action
description: The Clinton Administration's reversal of position on a case that could be one of the most important of the Supreme Court's coming term has disappointed supporters of affirmative action. But given the tenor of the Court's recent decisions on racial preferences, the Administration has made a smart strategic move to preserve what can and should be saved of affirmative action.

title: The Peaceful Face-Off in Ulster
description: Three years ago, the Irish Republican Army put into effect the cease-fire that eventually led to the British Government's historic decision last week to invite Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's political wing, to take part in formal peace talks.

title: Of Pop and Propaganda
description: Not Like Us

title: Internet Phobia
description: At Large The Strange Case of the World's Biggest Internet Invasion. By David H. Freedman and Charles C. Mann. 315 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.

title: Law Proposed To Regulate Scrambling Of Data
description: The Clinton Administration is circulating proposed legislation on Capitol Hill that would, for the first time, impose strict controls on the manufacture and use of technology that scrambles electronic data for privacy reasons.

title: When News Is in the Timing
description: THE Supreme Court this summer upheld an expanded definition of insider trading, but the decision also underscored a need for someone to answer a most elementary question: When is financial news public -- truly, legitimately, public?

title: Cameron Poetzscher and Varsha Rao
description: Varsha Rajendra Rao, a daughter of Renuka and Rajendra R. Rao of Marlboro, Mass., was married yesterday to Cameron Paul Poetzscher, the son of Gillian and Bernhard Poetzscher of Mermaid Waters, Australia. Dr. Jayant Sane, a justice of the peace in Framingham, Mass., officiated at the Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston.

title: 'One-Stop' Drive Against Drugs Is Focus
description: Robert H. Silbering likes to describe the Office of Special Narcotics in New York City as society's last stand against illegal drugs and their harvest of dealers and predatory junkies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, PAUL
description: RUDOLPH-Paul. The board, officers and staff of the Architectural League of New York mourn the passing of the eminent architect, Paul Rudolph, a longtime member of the League. Paul Rudolph influenced generations of architects in the United States and abroad through his leadership of the Yale School of Architecture from 1958 to 1965, and through his powerfully sculpted built forms and masterful drawings. He is remembered with respect and admiration. Walter F. Chatham, President Rosalie Genevro, Exec. Director

title: A Fairy-Tale Hamlet With a Diamond Tiara
description: THE notion, so often repeated by grief-stricken mourners, that Diana Spencer, Princess of Wales, was ''one of us,'' was, of course, absurd. The one-time future queen of England was more removed from real life than the most pampered movie star or heiress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED, MORRIS
description: FREED-Morris. 4/12/55-2/12/97. Hendersonville, TN and NYC. Actor, dancer, stage manager. Member of Broadway and National Companies of ''A Chorus Line'' for many years. Survived by father, John Freed, sister, Luci Freed, brother, Oliver Freed, and many friends and colleagues. Donations in Morris' memory can be made to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, Friends In Deed and GMHC. Memorial service 9/20/97 4 PM. For details contact Tom Faucett 212-580-7668.

title: Mali's Slips Reflect Stumbling African Democracy
description: When this country emerged from 31 years of dictatorship and held its first free elections in 1992, comparable examples of democratic change on this continent could be counted on one hand -- with fingers to spare.

title: A '97 Ryan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: This Home's Stuffed With 'Stuff' That's Fun
description: JOAN GELMAN and Don Aronson have a secret. The name of their East End house is a riddle and the clue they divulge is, ''It's not mine, it's not yours, it's ours.'' A red Pegasus on the outside of the old barn is another clue to what is inside their unusual home.

title: How Mother Teresa Left A Legacy of Good Works
description: IT seems a peculiar linkage: Diana, Princess of Wales, and Mother Teresa, caregiver to the poor, united as objects of mourning around the world.

title: Complex Calcutta
description: To the Editor: Kate Wheeler's witty report, ''Dense, Complex Calcutta,'' (Aug. 10), is an accurate view of the maelstrom that is Calcutta. I worked there for five years and liked every minute of that fascinating, horrendous city. During a bout of amoebic dysentery, a British doctor told me I would ''either die or get better.''

title: This Justice Is Blind but He's a Great Listener
description: ''They say that justice is blind,'' said Robert A. Schutzman, a former Queens assistant district attorney. ''And if you look at Pete O'Donoghue, he's definitely blind, and probably a better judge than most.''

title: The Futures Industry Wants You, but Do You Want It?
description: THE futures and options industry's biggest push ever to court stock investors is in full swing, as three exchanges here prepare to trade new contracts aimed at investors with stock portfolios as small as $10,000. But while these products and the marketing push behind them are certain to make such trading more accessible and attractive -- one exchange is even offering practice trading sessions on the Internet for the nervous novice -- many advisers have deep misgivings about their value for the average investor.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MIDTOWN

title: Affirmative Action and Reaction
description: America in Black

title: A Poet Discovers a World of Complexities in His Background
description: NORBERT KRAPF, a German-American poet and a professor of English, said he would never forget the day in January 1989 when he stood in front of a wall at an exhibition, ''The History and Culture of the Jews of Bavaria,'' at the German National Museum in Nuremberg and read the names of Bavarian Jews who had been deported to death and concentration camps.

title: In the Mirror, a Ghostly Replica of Pompeii
description: IN their darkest moments, the 4,000 or so people who still have not fled the Caribbean island of Montserrat wonder out loud whether they will meet the same fate as Pompeii, and banter about what archeologists might find in layers of debris a millennium from now. Barely two years after the Soufriere Hills Volcano awoke from centuries of slumber and began spewing ash, rock and superheated gases, the once-verdant landscape of the tiny British colony has in fact given way to one ghastly tableau after another.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE CHIN KISS KING

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Premium Seats

title: Mamaroneck Spot for Fish and More Fish
description: HAVING gone through many tenants, it is difficult to trace all the occupants of the building now called Down by the Bay. The place does have some early historical credentials, however. In 1811, the novelist James Fenimore Cooper was married in this house, which belonged to his in-laws, the De Lanceys, and it is where he and his bride lived for a short time. (At the time Cooper was an unsuccessful farmer, his literary talent not to emerge for nine years.)

title: On the Road and on the Tube
description: WE haven't had a television set in our house since 1983, when my wife and I took our small, rabbit-eared black-and-white to the local dump and heaved it toward a mound of old paint cans and broken screens. Ever since, I've done all my tubing in motels.
