Arriving exhausted at the motel with its sterile, look-alike rooms after a hard day's drive or too many terminals at too many airports, I passively accept not only the key from the desk clerk, but the remote control, that key to another world, switching it on the second I come into the room, plopping down on the bed, needing the fast, cleansing rush of those electrons more than I need a shower, and for precisely the same reason -- to wash off the miles, the disorientation, the loneliness, even if the soap is one I find too corrosive to use back home.

title: Energy Stocks Rise to the Top, but the Future Looks Murky
description: AFTER a decade in the doldrums, energy stocks have finally caught fire, propelling mutual funds that specialize in natural resources to a 24.7 percent average return over the last 12 months. And lately, these funds have managed to post steady gains even as the broader stock market has gyrated wildly.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: PACKAGE TO MALTA -- Grand Circle Travel has a 15-day All-Inclusive Vacation to Malta for travelers 50 and older, starting at $1,395 a person, based on double occupancy. The packages are available beginning in January. The price includes round-trip air fare from Boston, New York or Newark; hotel; meals; open bar service, and four sightseeing tours. The single supplement, usually $195, is waived on departures Jan. 5, Feb. 2, Nov. 11 and Dec. 7, 1998.

title: A Modest Proposal: 'Truth in Air Fares' Rule
description: SO many air fares. So little time. How are budget-conscious travelers to know whether they have paid the best price, or even an average price, for a discount airline ticket?

title: A Flushing Old-Timer Welcomes Asians No More
description: To the Editor:

title: Hiltons They Aren't: 2 Guys In a Hurry
description: J. WILLARD MARRIOTT built his food and lodging empire from a root beer stand opened with $500 in Washington, D.C. Conrad Hilton turned a $5,000 investment in a fleabag hotel in Cisco, Tex., into one of the world's best-known hotel companies. And two Harvard classmates, Ernest Henderson and Robert Moore, started the Sheraton chain by pooling their World War I veterans' bonuses to invest in real estate.

title: Trail Is Defeated
description: Jackie Trail of Paducah, Ky., lost to top-seeded Cara Black of Zimbabwe in the semifinals of the girls' junior singles yesterday, 7-5, 6-2. Trail, 16, won the 18-and-under nationals last month and had a memorable run here, winning a round in the main draw and upsetting two seeded players in the junior event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROCOLL, EDWIN JOHN, SR.
description: CROCOLL-Edwin John, Sr. September 6, 1997. Beloved husband Helen Sipple Crocoll. Cherished father of Edwin J., Jr. and Louise C. Loving brother of the late John W. Crocoll. Friends may call Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral Wednesday, September 10, at 10:30 AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTSEGEN, IRVING
description: GOTTSEGEN-Irving. Age 81. Died suddenly at his home in Bedford Hills, N.Y., on September 4, 1997. A man who brought the same warmth, humor, patience, and love he showed his family to his forty year career as a hospital administrator. After service in the Second World War, he went to Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases and then to Montefiore's Country Sanitarium, overseeing early drug treatments for tuberculosis. He then returned to Montefiore in the Bronx, serving in a variety of administrative positions. Until his retirement as Sr. Associate Director in 1986, his was the human face of medicine. He will be deeply missed by all his friends and by his wife Katherine, his sons, Mark David and Matthew; their wives, Emilie and Susan; and his granddaughters, Katherine and Sarah. A memorial gathering will be held at a later date, to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the UJAFederation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: Further Expansion For Frequent Flier Plans
description: American Airlines and Alaska Airlines have added new partners to their frequent flier plans, and Reno Air recently began its own program. AAdvantage, the frequent flier program of American, (800) 882-8880, has two new partners, Aero California and Pan Pacific Hotel and Resorts. Aero California, (800) 237-8585, flies within Mexico and between Los Angeles and Tucson, Ariz., and several Mexican cities. AAdvantage members can earn miles on all its flights.

title: Stride Rite Turns to Fashion to Walk Tall Again
description: AS parents and children shop for new shoes this fall, they may take a long second look at the Keds display.

title: Amid a Slump for Stocks, Some Sectors Shine
description: It was just about a month ago that the Dow Jones industrial average hit a record high -- 8,259.31 on Aug. 6 -- and since then it and many other closely watched stock indexes have suffered. The Dow itself is down more than 5 percent, to 7,822.41, in its worst swoon since the spring.

title: Helping Addicts To Resist Temptation
description: ''I WAS tired,'' said a 28-year-old Yonkers resident about his 10-year, off-and-on addiction to heroin, in explaining why he checked himself into Yonkers General Hospital's chemical dependency detoxification unit.

title: Never Angry, Often Disappointed
description: Long Way To Go

title: The Bigger the Pay, the Bigger the Risk
description: When my pocket calculator totaled a staggering $142.54 million, I was shocked. Curiosity had compelled me to add the collective salaries of some 20 National Football League rookies who had signed multiyear contracts. As a former defensive lineman who made an excellent living while playing for the Giants for 14 seasons -- and who is now a sports marketing executive familiar with the league's economic landscape -- even I was knocked out by such a huge sum.

title: Retracing the Steps to Freedom
description: THE heritage of African Americans in Connecticut and the story of their progress toward freedom will be celebrated across the state this month, which has been declared ''Freedom Trail Month'' by the state's Freedom Trail Committee.

title: When One Good Turn Deserves Another
description: It's not exactly 40 acres and a mule, but black Democrats in the state have just received their recompense for the extraordinary work they did last year in gathering votes for President Clinton and Senator Robert G. Torricelli.

title: Landing Soon at Airports: Links to Cyberspace
description: The Port Authority is studying 16 proposals for installing computers with Internet access in the airline terminals at Newark International Airport and the other two New York City area airports.

title: Kendra Lawrence and Davis Smith
description: Kendra Stout Lawrence, the daughter of Mary Stout Lawrence and Robert Cutting Lawrence of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Davis Smith, the son of the Rev. Jean Reinhart Smith and Peter Thomas Smith of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Phoebe Kitson-Davis and the bridegroom's mother performed the Episcopal ceremony at All Saints Memorial Church in Navesink, N.J.

title: Ready for Takeoff
description: In Claudia Dreifus's interview with the Boeing C.E.O., Philip M. Condit, I found it simply incredible that he compares Tiananmen Square and Rodney King (''Ready for Takeoff,'' Aug. 17). American jus-tice left King a vindicated man, while Chinese justice hasn't offered the victims, dead, maimed or jailed, so much as a trial. Condit seems unaware that the problem isn't that human rights get abused in both China and the U.S., but that in the U.S. we can rally and sue and use the news media to stop atrocities. The Chinese have no such freedom.

title: Brooklyn's New Or Tried and True
description: BRAWTA CARIBBEAN CAFE ++

title: A New Mikvah for Moderns
description: Celia Weintrob feels rejuvenated every month after completing the 3000-year-old Orthodox Jewish rite of using a mikvah, or ritual bath.

title: Is That Mick Over There? Just Another Photo by the Bridge
description: For once, Beavis and Butt-head were silent. They stood still, their posture ramrod straight, with Manhattan behind and the Brooklyn Bridge overhead.

title: Severing Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Leaderman, Robert Grubman
description: Susan Lynn Leaderman, a magazine editor, and Robert Jon Grubman, a textile executive, were maried last evening in Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Morris Shapiro performed the ceremony at the South Huntington Jewish Center.

title: Abuse and Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Course Change Toward Seriousness
description: WHEN I ASKED STEVEN Spielberg what kind of books he liked to read, a smile spread across his face. ''History,'' he said. ''I don't read fiction unless it's connected to a movie. I like to read about wartime. Historical figures from the past. Benjamin Franklin. Paul Revere. You know, those guys.'' Then his attention was seized by his first assistant director.

title: B.C./A.D. or B.C.E./C.E.?
description: Though William Safire's column made some good points, I suggest it also included three errors. First, Jesus was probably not born in 4 B.C./B.C.E. Herod was thought to have died early that year, but scholarship now points to the winter of 4-3 B.C./B.C.E. as more likely. According to the Gospel of Matthew, Jesus was born sometime before Herod died, probably about 5 B.C.E. Second, the name ''Christ'' (from the Greek ''christos'') is precisely a claim of Messiah-hood and not like a family name. Third, there is a need to use either A.D. or C.E. because in some contexts, like Persian or Chinese history, the era isn't always obvious. Students and general readers simply need to learn both systems, regardless of which they prefer.

title: Where Children Rule
description: As a former P.T.A. president in the beleaguered California public schools, I read with an odd mix of chagrin and delight Kristof's article on Japanese primary education. Attitude is all. In America, children take a back seat as school administrations slog through the bureaucratic quicksand of teachers' unions, class-size reductions and site-based management. In Japan, children cleaning toilets is a golden opportunity for building community.

title: Mary Anne Mrozinski, James O'Neill
description: Mary Anne Mrozinski, a museum director, is to be married this afternoon to James C. O'Neill, a community development executive. R. Wren Abrams, the town justice of Dover, N.Y. is to officiate at the Old Drover's Inn in Dover Plains.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINER, ANNETTE
description: WEINER-Annette. To all my friends who have remembered my dearest sister, I wish to say Thank You and God Bless you. Millicent

title: A Rugged Slice Of Appenzell
description: AS darkness fell in Appenzell, a farmer standing at an open window raised a sort of wooden megaphone to his lips and called out the Alp Segen, an evening prayer begging protection for beasts and people: Ave Maria, God save and bless the cows and all our friends and our country. The blessing is an old custom still observed in Appenzell, one of the most traditional of Swiss cantons. We had come to explore this surprising region on the eastern edge of Switzerland by walking from inn to inn in August of last year.

title: Stepping Out as Summer Fades
description: A preview for a Holocaust museum, a benefit for an arts center.

title: Sunnyside Doors Open to Festival For Book Lovers
description: WASHINGTON IRVING, one of America's first literary idols, liked to consider his estate here a place where people could gather to enjoy books. But even the man who created Rip Van Winkle and Ichabod Crane could never have imagined 5,000 book lovers swarming over his property.

title: Changes in Parking Plan Could Imperil Health Agency
description: A CONTROVERSIAL -- but approved -- plan to move the county's Department of Health from Mount Pleasant to New Rochelle has hit a snag that could return the matter to the Board of Legislators for further consideration.

title: In Portland, a Homecoming of Sorts
description: A homecoming theme has been reverberating through the preparations here for Sunday's World Cup qualifying game between Costa Rica and the United States, and not just because the Americans know they must win this home game to solidify their chances of going to France for the World Cup next summer.

title: Downs Mexico Way
description: Hugh is a 40-something writer from Phoenix who has a taste for prescription tranquilizers and painkillers -- Xanax, Valium, Tylenol with codeine -- that his American doctor won't let him have. Doc's advice: ''Don't drink Coke before you go to bed.'' Not good enough, says Hugh. So, like hundreds of other presumably jangled fun-seekers and college students, he regularly travels to Nogales, Mexico, to scoop up Mexican versions of these mood enhancers.

title: How Significant Are Medals Awarded in Wine Competitions?
description: SEVEN Long Island wineries took the most prized medals in this year's New York Wine Classic, the principal statewide wine competition. But overall, East End wines did not fare as well as those from the Finger Lakes. Why?

title: Public Servant, Now Private Felon
description: Federal prosecutors in Phoenix needed more than five years, 1,437 pieces of evidence and a 17-week trial. But last week, they finally bagged their man: Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona was convicted on seven felony counts of defrauding his lenders as a private real-estate developer. The jury deadlocked on 11 counts, and acquitted the Governor on 3 others, but under Arizona law, he was forced to resign.

title: Sweden's Wartime Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Folk Art Carved Out of Masts And Stereotypes
description: WHEN CUSTER WAS fighting the Cheyenne, the Arapaho and the Kiowa in the 1860's and 1870's, cigar-store Indians were helping to sell tobacco all over America. They stood on the sidewalk in front of tobacco stores, almost life-size and brightly painted, beloved figures of glamour and exotic allure, signalling the wares for sale within.

title: Among the Proles and the Posh
description: THE BOOKSHOP By Penelope Fitzgerald. 123 pp. Boston: Mariner Books/ Houghton Mifflin Company. Paper, $10.

title: Time to Study Butterflies
description: THE silent beauties, butterflies, are out and about now. Their visits are always fleeting. They may spread their lovely wings to rest for a bit; then they are off.

title: Moscow at 850
description: To the Editor: Alessandra Stanley's article, ''At 850, Moscow Takes a Bow'' (Aug. 17), had nothing to say about personal security. I have heard both from American executives who travel to Moscow and from Russian emigres with friends there that it is simply not safe for a tourist to walk around alone in broad daylight. If they are mugged, they will get no help from the police.

title: Up-to-Date Glass in a Place With a History
description: IN 1904, Carl Sandburg noted in his first book, ''In Reckless Ecstasy'': ''Down in southern New Jersey, they make glass. By day and by night, the fires burn on in Millville and bid the sand let in the light.'' Glass making as a South Jersey tradition goes back to 1739 in nearby Alloway, where Casper Wistar founded the first successful glass factory in colonial America. It is, therefore, most appropriate that the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Village here displays the largest and finest collection of glass made in the United States.

title: St. Louis
description: Like many American cities in recent years, St. Louis has been rediscovering and re-imagining its neighborhoods. And with good reason. By early evening, the grid of streets that makes up the old downtown is all but deserted; and though the city is built on a bluff that affords marvelous views of the Mississippi, St. Louisans long ago gave up this stretch of the river to industry. It is, instead, inland, in the far-flung neighborhoods, that much of the city's vitality, creativity and diversity are most apparent.

title: Tours of Japanese Internment Camp
description: The National Park Service has recently taken control of Manzanar National Historic Site, the internment camp in eastern California halfway between Los Angeles and Reno, where up to 10,000 people of Japanese ancestry were held during World War II. The transfer of management brought with it a number of planned improvements, none of which are yet financed, for the 800-acre site.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Ambulance Ruling

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, TEM S. (NEE FAGELMAN)
description: FINKELSTEIN-Tem S. (nee Fagelman) of Jersey City, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Max. Cherished daughter of the late Ida and Louis Fagelman. Devoted mother of Louise Schwartz, Jane Kendall and Stephen Levine. Dear sister of Samuel Fagelman and late Jay Fagelman and Norma Galuskin. Loving grandmother of nine grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Services Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY, on Monday, September 8, 1997, at 1 PM. For information ''GuttermanMusicant,'' 1-800-522-0588.

title: In Russia, Dreams on Wheels
description: ALTHOUGH the third annual Moscow auto show lasted only a week, Kostya Bagaturov can forever treasure the images of the Mercedes-Benzes, Audis and BMW's on display: While many Russian car lovers spent hours making themselves comfortable behind the wheels of Volgas, Volvos and Volkswagens, Mr. Bagaturov was caressing the streamlined bodies with the lens of his camcorder, insuring that he could view over and over the finest offerings of the world's automobile industry.

title: What Armstrong Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Vestpocket With Locks and Waterfall as Pay-Back for a High-Rise
description: It is a rare day when residents of the far West Village can look forward to a new park, but a new one is planned for the west side of Washington Street between Jane and Horatio Streets in an agreement hammered out with the residential developer Rockrose Development Corporation.

title: What Armstrong Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMANN, PETER DANIEL
description: BERGMANN-Peter Daniel, musician, 44, expired June 30th, 1997 in Miami, FL from injuries as a result of a motorcycle accident. Beloved son of Robert I. Bergmann, New York City, and Ava Waddle Bergmann of Miami, FL. Dear brother of Robert A. Bergmann of Los Angeles, CA. Memorial services will be held in Miami and in Dallas, TX at a future date.

title: Stacy Frigerio, Sharif Mahdavian
description: WHEN it snows, Sharif Mahdavian carries Anastasia Frigerio through the streets of Brooklyn Heights, where they live. Otherwise, they are like any other couple.

title: POP MUSIC
description: September

title: 'Wallflowers in An Uptempo Market'
description: To the Editor:

title: Athens Can Thank Atlanta for 2004 Games
description: WHEN Athens lost out to Atlanta in the International Olympic Committee's vote to select the 1996 site for the centennial Summer Games, Melina Mercouri, the actress who was a member of the Greek delegation and who had once been her country's minister of culture, knew what had happened.

title: As the Polo Coach Put It, 'We're No. 1. It's a Secret.'
description: DESPITE rumbles of thunder and rain on and off, about a dozen people had arrived at the University of Connecticut horse barn in Storrs. ''I even left my experiment,'' said Moshe Gai, a physics professor. Like the others he was eager to saddle a horse, grab a mallet, head outdoors and start tearing around a muddy arena.

title: Self-Defense on Fees
description: A Federal court in New York sent investors a message last month: Read the prospectus!

title: L.I. Vines
description: Pinot Blanc

title: Three Fall Series Get an Early Start
description: NOT too many years ago, the concert season in Westchester did not come back to life until late September and was not in full swing until mid-October. Things happen faster these days, so there are at least three series opening next weekend.

title: Colonial Crossroads in a Garden Once Lost
description: SOULFUL expressions of an era gone by often serve to inspire and sustain those in subsequent centuries who want an anchor for their own lives. Thus the quiet of the Gertrude Jekyll Garden in Woodbury, and the Colonial Glebe House Museum set within it, has very modern applications. The property, on the National Register of Historic Places, links the disparate lives of two people from England and the legacies they left in the United States.

title: A Learning Experience
description: AS a young New Yorker in 1956 I tried teaching as a career. For seven months. I was a long-term substitute for a class of 27 sixth-graders. But things never went well. The learning was fragmentary. Many of the children were continually restless, edgy or noisy. Sometimes their young faces were glazed or strained. At the end of most days, I myself was strained and exhausted. So, that June, I gave up teaching and made my career as a textbook editor here in New Jersey.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JAPANESE FESTIVAL

title: The Cabbies' Court
description: New York's taxi industry is large enough to warrant its own justice system for cabdrivers. More accurately, against them. Hack court is a forum for passengers and cops to extract justice, but cabbies can't file charges against, say, rude riders. The court recently augmented its Manhattan office with expanded digs in Queens, enabling it to keep up with a rising number of complaints. How do you keep 42,000 cabbies in line? Swiftly.

title: Defying Her Sport's Logic, A Tennis Prodigy Emerges
description: She spent her wonder years practicing on shabby public courts in Compton, Calif., where the sound of gang gunfire rang louder than applause, but this afternoon Venus Williams will play Martina Hingis for the women's championship at the United States Open in Queens.

title: Students Censored, But Issue Lives On
description: When student reporters for the Naperville Central Times, a suburban high school newspaper, learned that district administrators spent taxpayers' money on travel at the time of a budget crisis, they did what any responsible journalist might do. They investigated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLGATE, FLORENCE MANUEL
description: COLGATE-Florence Manuel, of Locust Valley, NY, peacefully on August 14, 1997, age 92. Beloved wife of the late John K. Mother of Annette Fayard of Paris, France, John K. Jr. of Mill Neck, NY and Mimi Bullock of Greenwich, CT. Grandmother of twelve, greatgrandmother of 16. Memorial service St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, Thursday, September 11, at 4 PM. A gift in her memory may be made to Locust Valley Library, 170 Buckram Road, Locust Valley, NY 11560 or North Country Garden Club, 3 Chapel Gate Lane, Glen Head, New York 11545.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARGO, MARGARET MORSE
description: FARGO-Margaret Morse. Of Edison, NJ. Died on September 3, 1997 on Nantucket Island. She was the wife of the late Alvin W. Fargo, Jr. and is survived by her sister, Louise M. Tweedy, her three children, Lorine, Jane and Mike Fargo, three grandsons and three nieces. A Memorial Service will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, 600 Cleveland Ave, Plainfield, NJ on Saturday, September 27, 1997 at 3pm. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made in Mrs. Fargo's memory to the WardlawHartridge School, Edison, NJ.

title: Revolution
description: Warren Beatty's REDS (1981) tells the story of John Reed (Beatty), the American writer who turned Communist and finally died for the cause. The surprise is that this long, stunning mosaic tells his story so well, within a chaotic world history evoked with clarity for the screen. Early on, the film charts his involvement and fateful romantic link with Louise Bryant (Diane Keaton), a forceful American woman. The picture weaves a rich tapestry of sight and sound, swarming with characters as the odyssey shifts from Greenwich Village to the Bolshevik Revolution on home turf. Reed may not win your admiration but you won't be bored. WED. at 11 A.M. and 4 P.M. (PART 1); THUR. at 11 A.M. and 4 P.M. (PART 2) on HIST. Howard Thompson

title: Cost-Conscious Expos Will Probably Lose Martinez
description: The American League took enough of a beating from the National League in interleague games without adding humiliation to embarrassment, but it wasn't that long ago that a pitcher who beat three A.L. teams was practicing pitching with a department store mannequin positioned at home plate.

title: Lyme Disease Deserves To Be Taken Seriously
description: Dr. Peter Welch referred to Lyme disease $(''Fighting Politics and Lyme Disease,'' June 29$) as a ''fashionable disease to have these days.'' Lyme disease as a fashion statement is as unwanted as a polyester leisure suit. In the same article, the County Health Commissioner, Dr. Harold N. Adel, was quoted as describing Lyme disease as ''a very serious and potentially debilitating disease'' and further saying, ''This is not our only priority.'' This is a disease that is requiring a vaccine. Everyone is vulnerable. It should be a top priority to deal with a serious disease.

title: Susana MacLean, William Zeller
description: Maria Susana MacLean, a daughter of Carmen MacLean of Granville, Ohio, and the late Alberto MacLean, is to be married today to William David Zeller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Zeller of Franklin Lakes, N.J. Rabbi Ari Fridkis officiated at the Americas Society in New York. Robert Knight, a friend of the bride who is Maine's Special Deputy Secretary of State, took part in the ceremony.

title: Rebuilding of 48th St. Ramp May Repeat Old Errors
description: To the Editor:

title: Fisheries Commission Considers New Limits
description: How big or small, and how many? Those are some of the questions that the members of the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission will answer in setting fishing limits for lobster, striped bass and sea herring that will affect commercial and recreational fishermen along the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Returning Soon To www.ssa.gov
description: After learning some hard lessons, the Social Security Administration has decided to re-establish an Internet site where people can learn how much they are entitled to receive in future benefits.

title: She's Not Anybody's Baby Sister Anymore
description: JANET JACKSON IS SOUNDING more and more like someone with nothing to prove. And with good reason. At 31 she has sold more than 30 million albums, signed a deal with Virgin Records reported to be worth $80 million and commands a worldwide army of dance-music fans. After 10 years of painstakingly building a career of her own, Ms. Jackson finally agreed two years ago to collaborate with her incredibly famous brother Michael Jackson. The duet, ''Scream,'' became a runaway success and put her on something close to an equal footing with him.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: When 2,000 Raptors Soar Overhead, the Sight Is Incredible
description: MIKE BOCHNIK will never forget the sight: 2,000 broad-wing hawks, circling through the sky over Lenoir Preserve here, riding warm-air currents higher and higher in a formation known called a kettle.

title: As Camps Open, a Change of the Guard
description: Some things change. Some stay the same. Gone from Madison Sqaure Garden is Mark Messier, the dominant figure on the metropolitan hockey scene for most of this decade. Across the Hudson, not much has changed with the New Jersey Devils. And in Uniondale, L.I., the Islanders not only have a ''new-old'' owner in John Pickett, they just might have an exciting young team by season's end.

title: Fortitude Strikes Late at Belmont
description: Allen Jerkens supplied another dramatic reminder yesterday of why he is known as the master of the upset: his 4-year-old colt Fortitude, who had not won a race in a year, won the Belmont Breeders' Cup Handicap at odds of 21-1, and broke the 20-year-old Belmont course record for a mile and one-sixteenth while doing it.

title: A Big New Stage and a Wide World
description: THE EMPHASIS WILL BE ON ARRIVALS AND returns in this 1997 dance season, with an extra dose of internationalism to keep things lively.

title: Karyn Gerschel And Kevin Lamb
description: Karyn Florence Gerschel, a daughter of Christine A. Gerschel of Aspen, Colo., and Patrick A. Gerschel of New York, was married last evening to Kevin Thomas Lamb, a son of Kathleen E. Lamb of Hingham, Mass., and the late John P. Lamb. The Rev. Colin L. Leitch, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Leslie Chang, Benjamin Appen
description: Leslie Chih-yen Chang, a daughter of Mary and Yuan Chang of New York and Hong Kong, was married yesterday in West Brooksville, Me., to Benjamin Sheridan Appen, the son of Alice Appen and Dr. Richard Appen of Madison, Wis. The Rev. Harald Smedal, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at West Brooksville Congregational Church.

title: Delaware May Join Scenic River Program
description: The Delaware River could become part of the National Scenic and Wild River program, which provides protection from development and Federal money for historical and preservation projects along its banks.

title: Ms. Wasserstein And Mr. Daniels
description: Jennifer Ann Wasserstein, the daughter of Linda and Marty Wasserstein of New Preston, Conn., is to be married at her parents' home today to Reuben Sky Daniels, the son of Beverly Sky of Boston and Nahum Daniels of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Norman Koch is to officiate with the bridegroom's father.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20

title: Missing Cast Members
description: To the Editor:

title: The Model Who Invented Heroin Chic
description: REID MILES'S STYLISH commercial photography studio off Sunset Boulevard isn't open for business today. It's a movie set, as Angelina Jolie, playing the troubled, heroin-addicted supermodel Gia Carangi in the HBO film ''Gia,'' sits on the floor in front of a roll of seamless paper.

title: Bungling Bounty Hunters
description: It had all the makings of a movie nightmare: Raiders in black masks and body armor sledgehammered their way into a rundown house in Phoenix and shot a young couple to death last Sunday. The five men told the police they were bounty hunters in search of a fugitive bail jumper -- and had made a mistake. No one in the house had ever heard of the man they wanted.

title: We'll Be in Touch. But Not in This Lifetime.
description: Full employment. Politicians promise it. But can it ever be more than a glorious mirage as long as there are job applicants who rearrange the interviewer's office furniture, change soiled diapers on the personnel manager's desk or fall asleep between questions? As the mail indicates, some job seekers are equipped with self-destruct buttons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, MITCHELL
description: RIFKIN-Mitchell. Beloved husband of Rose. Devoted father of Richard and Marsha Rifkin and Janie and Steven Goldberg. Cherished grandfather of Cindy and Michael, Debby and Mark and Michele and Robert Rifkin, and Elizabeth and Jonathan Goldberg. Great-grandfather of seven. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday 1:30 PM.L

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Unable to Prove Homelessness, Families Find Revolving Door
description: The homeless woman blinked her sleepy eyes open and gasped as the eviction notice slid under her door at the city shelter one recent morning. She shook her 15-month-old son awake. ''Pops, we got to move again,'' Antonia Sneed told him.

title: James Follows Jane as Screen Writer of the Day
description: THERE IS A MOMENT, early in Henry James's novel ''Washington Square,'' when Austin Sloper, an eminent, pompous 19th-century New York physician and widower, is instructing his sister Lavinia on the rearing of his daughter, Catherine, for whom he has exceedingly low expectations. Catherine should be brought up to be clever, he tells Lavinia. This puzzles her. Isn't it better, she asks, that the girl be raised to be good?

title: Fie on E-Tickets
description: To the Editor: I'm tired of hearing the airlines' self-serving excuses for trying to jam electronic tickets down our throats (Practical Traveler, ''E-Tickets Begin to Catch On,'' Aug. 10).

title: I Was a Teen-age Suspect
description: The Yamhill County Juvenile Detention Center, an 18-bed, $1.2 million facility in McMinnville, Ore., represents a new, pre-emptive style in juvenile crime control. Here, teen-agers who are awaiting adjudication -- that is, who are still legally innocent -- are tossed in with repeat offenders for four days of tough love. McMinnville, not far from Portland, isn't particularly cursed with youth crime, but county officials believe this get-toughism makes sense, and that it will appeal to many other towns and cities as the number of 12- to 17-year-olds rises over the next five years. Youth advocates call the strategy dubious at best. Glen, a pimply 15-year-old assault suspect, says it was ''hell.'' Here's a look.

title: Jets' Graham Deserves High Marks for Leadership
description: Curtis Conway, the Chicago Bears' mercurial but injured receiver, stood GQ-down in a marble-colored suit in the middle of a locker room full of bruised egos. Da Bears were in Da dumps. They had just lost their Monday night game, 38-24, to the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field.

title: The Lonely Campaign
description: Ruth Messinger could hardly have looked more alone. She had just come out of P.S. 249 in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn and now she was stopping to talk to three or four reporters. It was a fine day for campaigning. The afternoon was sunny and mild and traces of autumn were appearing. With the Democratic mayoral primary just days away, it was a perfect time to rev up the faithful and round up additional recruits.

title: Shape Up
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Show Me the Money
description: ''The Millionaire Next Door'' has created an unsettling mystery for New Yorkers. The book, which has been on the New York Times best-seller list for more than seven months, describes the results of the most comprehensive research ever done on America's wealthy. It reports that the typical millionaire is a self-made man who owns a small business, lives in a $320,000 home and has never spent more than $140 for a pair of shoes, $235 for a watch or $399 for a suit.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 24 about a showing of Georges Seurat's ''Bathers at Asnieres'' at the National Gallery in London omitted the writer's location. A dateline reading ''London'' should have appeared. A picture credit with the article misstated the source of a photograph of the Seurat painting. It was the National Gallery, not the New Haven Yale University Art Gallery.

title: For Key Lime Guy, Lemon Boy and You
description: Of all the harbingers of autumn -- crisp nights, lengthening shadows, children clutching notebooks -- few are as poignant as the day when Key Lime Guy shows up at the Ice Hut with his cooler.

title: Girl Talk
description: A few weeks ago I bought ladybugs. I bought them at the nursery to eat the aphids that have been eating my roses. ''There's a thousand of them in there!'' the woman told me as she handed them to me. A thousand ladybugs: it seemed like something one shouldn't be able to buy.

title: Between Image And Reality In Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES IN THE EARLY 1950's.

title: The Air Force Aims to Test Its Space Destroyer
description: Its blisteringly hot beam has hit missiles on the ground and speeding drones in flight, blowing them up. Now the Army wants to fire the nation's most powerful military laser, Miracl (for Mid-infrared Advanced Chemical Laser), at a $60 million Air Force satellite in a first-of-a-kind test of destructive power.

title: Is Life Better In Bulgaria? It's a Matter Of Perspective
description: The appearance this week of another index ranking countries by their social conditions -- a study in which Bulgaria outranks the United States in quality of life -- raises new questions about how and why these surveys are conducted.

title: Ritalin Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: PLACES
description: ALICE TULLY HALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUST, SAUL
description: BRUST-Saul. Died Sept. 4, 1997. Beloved brother of Mary Ann Frieder and Norman Brust. Brother-in-law of Robert Frieder, uncle of Mark Frieder, Laura Darnell, Gina Frieder and Eric Darnell. Great-uncle of Lisa Frieder, Stephen Frieder, Rex Darnell, & Leah Darnell.''A truly gentle man.''

title: Hayes Jackson and Cooper Campbell
description: L. Cooper Campbell, a daughter of Joan L. Hunter of Falmouth, Me., and Andrews B. Campbell of Waldoboro, Me., was married yesterday to F. Hayes Jackson, a son of June Lang Jackson of Washington and Tommy Hayes Jackson of Senoia, Ga. The Rev. Robert C. Curry performed the ceremony at the York Harbor (Me.) Reading Room.

title: Metal-and-Glass Look for an Old Art Theater
description: The designers of the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Film Center at 36 East Eighth Street wanted to create a facade with some drama for a part of New York University that has a long history as a moviehouse.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SABRIYA Damascus Bitter Sweet. By Ulfat Idilbi. Interlink, cloth, $29.95; paper, $12.95.

title: The Birth of a Notion
description: The Inflationary Universe

title: Toilets and Trouble: How Doth The Political Cauldron Bubble
description: GOVERNMENTS are sometimes clueless when it comes to toilets. Leonardo da Vinci's plans for a flushing water closet were ignored by the pooh-bahs of his time. In the 1300's, it took the Black Death to persuade the King of England that latrines befouling the Fleet River were not a good idea from a public-health standpoint.

title: New Musicals, Fresh Talent
description: THE AMERICAN MUSICAL HAS been declared dead so often, how to explain the new season's bumper crop of original Broadway shows? Six new musical productions are scheduled to open by mid-January: ''Triumph of Love,'' ''Side Show,'' ''The Scarlet Pimpernel,'' ''The Lion King,'' ''The Capeman'' and ''Ragtime.''

title: Sizing Up Trip Insurance
description: IF you miss the boat these days, you really miss it. In an era of fierce competition, cruise lines have instituted more stringent rules about reimbursing passengers who cancel or do not appear on the appointed date. Like theatergoers who forfeit the value of their tickets if they miss the performance, travelers who fall ill or suffer some other misfortune are simply out of luck unless they have purchased insurance.

title: Mosquito Alert At Walt Disney World
description: An encephalitis alert in Florida at the end of August caused Walt Disney World to take precautions, including closing its hotel pools and water parks early each day to avoid bites from a type of mosquito that feeds heavily at dusk. These mosquitoes, which carry the virus for a strain called St. Louis encephalitis, have been detected in nine Florida counties, including Orange County, which covers part of the Orlando area. Orange and Indian River Counties issued the health alert while two suspected cases of the disease were under investigation in an adjoining county.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DIANA JOAN
description: KAPLAN-Diana Joan. Age 56, tragically taken from us in train derailment, Sept 3, 1997. Survived by husband Seymour, who was also injured in the accident. Beloved sister of Ronald and Richard of Florida. Funeral and burial at Cedar Park Cememtery, Westwood, NJ, on September 7, 1997, 2 PM.

title: Sugarplum Visions in 3-D
description: THE THREE-DIMENSIONAL movie has come a long way since the 1950's, when audiences in flimsy paper eyeglasses watched, mesmerized, as overgrown lizards in rubber suits seemed to leap straight from the screen and into their laps. These days, 3-D films are shown on screens as tall as small apartment buildings, with spectacular, hyper-realistic details to go with up-to-the-minute technological innovations. Even the glasses are high-tech: every audience member gets an enormous ''Star Trek''-style, liquid-crystal headset, more goggle than spectacle, with its own ''fixed personal sound environment.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARK, STANLEY SANG HYUN
description: PARK-Stanley Sang Hyun CTI2, U.S. Navy. Died suddenly on Sunday, August 31, 1997 of Columbia, Maryland. Devoted husband of Dabet Marrero Park. Loving son of Soon Young and Ryang Sook Han Park, Forest Hills, N.Y. Beloved brother of Susan Park, Forest Hills, N.Y. Visitation 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Monday at the Hardesty Funeral Home P.A. 12 Ridgley Avenue, Annapolis, MD. Funeral at 3PM on Tuesday in Ft. Myer Chapel, Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA with honours.

title: Cougars and Humans Can Peacefully Coexist
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Jazz Age Survivors 'Swing Like Mad'
description: SOME people may think singing about infidelity at a wedding reception is in questionable taste. But when Laurel Watson rips into a version of ''He Might Be Your Man but He Comes to See Me Sometimes'' none of the guests seem to mind. Most seem to like it, even if they're not too sure who these old (average age: 82) band members are.

title: In Their Own Words
description: SAL F. ALBANESE

title: For Young Female Criminals, a Prison of Their Own
description: When Marisol Morales was 17, she killed a girl.

title: Suzannah McLain And Peter Smith
description: Suzannah Riggs McLain, the daughter of Suzanne and James M. McLain of Locust Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Sherman Smith, a son of Joan FitzSimons Smith of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Marcus Wellington Smith of Locust Valley. The Rev. Phillip K. Eichner officiated at St. Gertrude's Roman Catholic Church in Bayville, N.Y.

title: Beth Brownstein, Matthew Buten
description: Beth Jennifer Brownstein, a daughter of Elaine and Daniel Brownstein of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Matthew Buten, a son of Gloria and Max Buten of Penn Valley, Pa. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: Ever Earnest and Funny, Ever Relevant to Youth
description: AT 81, WITH A CAREER OF more than six decades in the theater, the eminent playwright Arthur Miller is in the midst of a renaissance, especially, it seems, among directors who are almost a half century younger.

title: A Summer in the Swiss Hills
description: THOMAS MANN'S directive in ''The Magic Mountain'' couldn't be clearer: The heady pleasures of the high mountains are all well and good, but sooner or later, you have to descend to the flat lands and begin your real life. I don't know that I'd have chosen the flat lands for my honeymoon if not for that most unreal of things: free digs. By way of a wedding present, a friend of my husband's offered up her Swiss atelier, saying: ''Come. Stay as long as you like.''

title: Florida Bank Merger May Ruffle Customers
description: MERGERS like Nationsbank's planned acquisition of Barnett Banks, the biggest banking company in Florida, are nothing new for Manu Patel. When completed, the $15.5 billion deal, one of the biggest yet on Wall Street, will mark the fifth time since 1979 that his bank account has changed hands through a buyout or a merger.

title: The Case of the Ghostly Answering Machine
description: Like urban ghosts, they have haunted her for two years, ever since she moved to West 16th Street: the voices in the answering machine.

title: It's Blue-Green. It's Algae. It's a Direct-Sales Machine.
description: TO critics, it's pond scum. To true believers, it's the nearly perfect food. To some of its 225,000 distributors, it's a disappointment; to others, it's a vegetarian's cash cow.

title: Correction
description: A credit was omitted last Sunday for a cartoon with an article about editorial cartoonists. The cartoon, by Lute Pease, was provided by the New Jersey Historical Society.

title: Tell Us About It
description: To the Editor:

title: Christopher Flagg and Heidi Snyder
description: Dr. Heidi Linette Snyder, a daughter of Anneliese M. Snyder of Vail, Colo., and Dr. C. John Snyder of Aptos, Calif., was married yesterday to Christopher Stratton Flagg, the son of Terry S. Flagg and Thomas R. Flagg of Redding, Conn.

title: Roommates
description: To the Editor: We would like to respond to the letter from Rhoda M. Lippel (Aug. 17), who was looking for a roommate on an American Jewish Congress tour to Turkey. We do everything possible to work out roommate possibilities. On our singles tour we guarantee a share for those who book within a certain period or we do not charge the supplement.

title: Cheryl Mintz, Harris Richter
description: Cheryl Gay Mintz, the resident stage manager at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., is to be married today to Harris Richter, a senior business analyst at American International Group, the financial service company in New York. Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner is to perform the ceremony at the Yale Club in New York.

title: New Look To the Old Charity Drive
description: SERGEANT SLAUGHTER put his troops through calisthenics under the summer sun, barking orders to those who couldn't stop giggling. Luckily it was only warm-up exercises the professional wrestling star was leading. The 480 people on the field had assembled to toss softballs, run relay races and do tug-of-war style events -- not for the army but for charity.

title: Building Better Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Accuser Unhappy With Her Lawyers' Handling of Suit
description: Paula Corbin Jones, the woman suing President Clinton on grounds that he sexually harassed her, may soon part ways with her lawyers because of disagreements on how to handle her case, several people involved with the lawsuit said today.

title: Developer Woos Artists, Who Do Not Return the Favor
description: In clean, well-lighted studios in a cluster of buildings down by the Brooklyn Bridge, artists are shaping fabric into couture, wood into sculpture, paint into beauty. Such a honeycomb of creativity is exactly what their landlord, the Manhattan developer David Walentas, hoped for when he renovated the formerly decrepit manufacturing buildings, part of the 2.5 million square feet of real estate he owns between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges. ''We're trying to create a SoHo kind of environment,'' said Mr. Walentas's son Jed, who works for his father's Two Trees Management Company.

title: Barn That's a Haven of Dreams and Memories
description: WHERE to go for staged readings, workshop productions, plays in progress, showcases with symposiums to follow? Every theatergoer knows the territory and it is not Broadway.

title: Cecily Van Praagh, A. McC. Treadway
description: Cecily Margaret Van Praagh, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ian Van Praagh of New York, was married yesterday to Alexander McCarroll Treadway, a son of Florence Coyle Treadway of New Orleans and William L. Treadway Jr. of Covington, La. The Rev. Richard A. Burnett performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in St. James, N.Y.

title: No Quarters Given in War Of the Wash
description: There is a dirty little war being fought in Sunnyside, a war of market share and customer loyalty as a wave of new Laundromats has washed over the neighborhood.

title: Angenette Martin, Political Organizer
description: Angenette Martin, who specialized in grass-roots organizing and consulting for political campaigns and others, died last Saturday at her home in Sausalito, Calif. She was 50.

title: Melinda Thaler, David Milberg
description: Melinda Beth Thaler, the daughter of Sheldon Thaler of Princeton, N.J., and the late Beverly Casper Thaler, was married last evening to David Jonathan Milberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Milberg of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Robert I. Summers performed the ceremony in the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: 6The Heat Is Outside The Kitchen
description: Cooking is the French national game, understood and appreciated by a highly sophisticated and demanding public, which knows exactly who the stars are and how a star is expected to perform (''The Heat Is Outside the Kitchen,'' by David Blum, Aug. 17). If David Bouley, with his extraordinary gifts, wanted to give high American cuisine a real boost, the way Bobby Fischer boosted American chess, he would open a restaurant in Paris or Lyon and try to become the first American-born chef to decorate himself and his heritage with two or three Michelin stars.

title: Erin Maroney and Jay Fraser
description: Erin Julia Maroney, a daughter of Margaret Solin of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Thomas W. Maroney of Asheville, N.C., was married yesterday to Walter Javan Fraser 3d, a son of Anna C. Fraser of Oakridge, Tenn., and Mr. Fraser Jr. of Statesboro, Ga. The Rev. Stephen Yagerman performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Susan Scott, R. D. Hettleman
description: Susan Lee Scott, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter D. Scott of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at her parents' house in Vineyard Haven, Mass., to Robert David Hettleman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kalman R. Hettleman of Baltimore. Officiating at the ceremony was M. Cristina Failla, a civil marriage celebrant, who was the host mother when the bride was an exchange student in La Spezia, Italy.

title: The Value of Teaching Values
description: As a new school year started, Chatter readers debated whether public schools should teach values and, if so, what?

title: How Sweet It Is
description: Let us praise the ruby-red beet. its versatility and sweet sturdiness are to be admired and extolled. And yet the beet remains the problem child of the root-vegetable world. Throughout history, talented chefs have sought to boost it up the social scale. Usually to no avail.

title: Right Message, Wrong Place
description: Oops. With the stroke of a computer key, a sensitive memo (about your love life, your finances or your boss) has gone astray. Welcome to the wonderful world of computers, where really embarrassing things can happen in a big hurry. Have you ever sent a message to the wrong destination? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Chang Falls to Set Up Final of Upstarts
description: Michael Chang, granted the rare chance to perform the role of big man on this brand-new campus at the United States Open, could not handle the responsibility yesterday. Despite his senior status as a seasoned Grand Slam champion, it was Chang who was held back like he needed remedial work, and the neophyte Patrick Rafter, a net rusher in the classic mold, who advanced to his first Grand Slam final.

title: James Wackerman, Kristin Ferguson
description: Kristin Alane Ferguson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Ferguson of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to James Craig Wackerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Wackerman of Rochester. The Rev. Kevin Cameron performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Manchester, Vt.

title: Taking Charge
description: Making Miracles Happen

title: Detrimental Description
description: To the Editor:

title: A Program To Rebuild Young Faces
description: TWO years ago, then 14-year-old Ronnie Lugo wanted to kill himself. Today, he wants to go to college.

title: Is It a Sport?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How to Refinish Woodwork, Safely
description: SOMEWHERE you may have some woodwork or furniture that looks shabby and should be refinished. Before you can apply a new finish, you'll have to strip off the old one. This is not difficult, job, nor does it require special skill, but it is messy and time consuming. Most commercial strippers are toxic, so it's essential to wear safety gear and take precautions.

title: Understanding Understanding
description: THE EDUCATED MIND How Cognitive Tools Shape Our Understanding. By Kieran Egan. 299 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Love, Jack

title: Complex Calcutta
description: To the Editor: Kate Wheeler aptly points out that hiring a rickshaw in Calcutta enables the man pulling it to eat. But paying him five times what he asks -- rather than bargaining and paying the going rate -- inflates costs beyond the means, potentially, of many local people, devalues the efforts it normally takes to earn prevailing rates, and sets up Ms. Wheeler and her fellow Westerners to be seen as cash cows. It would be more constructive to give money to reputable local charities and to use services like rickshaws more frequently while paying the going rates.

title: 1997 U.S. OPEN: A Phenomenal Final; Hingus and Williams Show Improvement With Every Match
description: As Venus Williams stood whooping with joy inside Arthur Ashe Stadium on Friday, it was clear to anyone within earshot that she was on her way to her first United States Open final.

title: A Tough-Guy Film by a Former Would-Be Tough Guy
description: IT seems that every new season brings a new Richard Linklater, Harmony Korine or Kevin Smith -- a screenwriter or movie director who unearths yet another previously unknown pocket of America's youth culture. Mr. Linklater did it with go-nowhere Texas teen-agers in ''Slacker'' and potheads in ''Dazed and Confused.'' Mr. Smith did it with dopey New Jersey convenience store workers in ''Clerks.'' Mr. Korine wrote about drug-addled Manhattan teen-agers in ''Kids.''

title: Gay Officials' Debate: Evict Military?
description: For 50 years, the armed forces recruiting station at the epicenter of Times Square has stood as a flashy lure to prospective soldiers and sailors. Captured in countless snapshots, the glass and stainless steel box gives the military the kind of advertising money can't buy. The Federal Government, in fact, pays the city no rent for the building, which is moored to a subway grating at 43d Street.

title: Today's Specials: Apples, Pork Chops, Political Satire
description: For months, Fairway Uptown at 133d Street ran advertisements about the store's bargain basement specials atop its billboard facing the West Side Highway, as just about any self-respecting supermarket would.

title: B.C./A.D. or B.C.E./C.E.?
description: Why not have B.P.C.E. and P.C.E. (Politically Correct Era)?

title: Excellent Albert
description: UNCROWNED KING

title: Brady Takes On The Best At Regatta
description: It isn't often that a 23-year-old finds himself courting global yachting campaigns at their highest levels. But Gavin Brady is no ordinary sailor. His swift rise in match racing attests to a special talent.

title: City Unions Turn Focus on Immigrants
description: The head of New York City's labor movement announced yesterday that the city's unions would increasingly focus on helping and recruiting hundreds of thousands of immigrants who often work for low pay under harsh conditions.

title: An Appealing, Casual 1990's Italian Cafe
description: ORLANDO'S was yesterday; Tello is today. For over a quarter of a century, Huntington residents headed to Orlando's for special occasion dinners. There, they sat in comfortable banquettes in a room defined by fabric-covered walls and plush carpeting and were served classic Italian food by tuxedoed waiters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, VIVIAN E.
description: DOUGLAS-Vivian E., September 4, 1997 of Philadelphia, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Founder of Cultural Crossroads, Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, NY and active in numerous organizations such as The Links, Inc., Brooklyn, NY, and the Lawyers' Wives, Brooklyn, NY. Wife of the late Stanley Moreland Douglas, Assistant Attorney General State of New York. Survived by godchildren Sarah Taylor, Samuel Dilworth-Leslie, Colin Gray and many close friends. Graveside service to be held from Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY on Wednesday, September 10 at 11:30 AM. Memorial contributions made in her name to AMISTDD Research Center, Tulane University, 6823 St. Charles Ave, New Orleans, LA 70118 would be appreciated. Oliver H. Bair Company, Philadelphia PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEARER, JOSEPH L.
description: FEARER-Joseph L., 87, of West Hartford, CT., and New York City died September 1 in North Branford, CT. He was husband of the late Eunice Holzman Fearer, father of Paul Fearer and Jane Fearer Safer, grandfather of Sarah Safer. Private burial is at Arlington National Cemetery. Funeral service September 7, 1997. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Joseph and Eunice Fearer Fund, Museum of Modern Art, Department of Prints, 11 West 53 Street, New York, NY 10019.

title: Learning Disabilities
description: To the Editor:

title: ART
description: September

title: Rebuilding of 48th St. Ramp May Repeat Old Errors
description: To the Editor:

title: A Teller of Tales Tells His Own
description: BURNING THE DAYS Recollection. By James Salter. 365 pp. New York: Random House. $24.

title: Cynthia Matthews, John Brown
description: Cynthia Anne Matthews, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald H. Matthews of New York, was married last evening to John Alexander Brown, a son of Johnnie R. Brown and Dr. Louis Brown, both of Atlanta. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Somewhere, Some Call It Music, but . . .
description: WE were on the Orient Point ferry on Labor Day weekend, returning from Cape Cod with about 28 million other people. The least crowded place on the boat was the bar. Most travellers stayed in the main cabin, terrorized by the thought of a whiff of cigarette smoke. Little did we know that even more toxic experiences were coming our way. The bar was blessedly quiet, until the ferry was about 50 yards from the dock in New London. Suddenly, an awful animal howling filled the air, in which inarticulate words could be half-distinguished.

title: It's Butterfly Time, and Time to Study Up
description: THE silent beauties, butterflies, are out and about now. Their visits are always fleeting. They may spread their lovely wings to rest for a bit, then they are off.

title: For Gays in Team Sports, Still a Deafening Silence
description: Dave Kopay turned 55 this year and began collecting his National Football League pension, another reminder, along with constant sciatica and a knee that needs to be replaced, of nine years as a running back.

title: Let's Hear It for Bureaucrats
description: Greed, Chaos, and Governance Using Public Choice to Improve Public Law. By Jerry L. Mashaw. 231 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $28.

title: In Two Looks at Tibet, No Sign of Shangri-La
description: FROM THE TIME Ronald Colman stumbled into Shangri-La in the 1937 movie ''Lost Horizon,'' Tibet in its various Hollywood manifestations has come to represent a kind of ultimate otherness, a golden-hued sanctuary teeming with a quiescent people too simple, too trusting, too good for this world.

title: Two Lawyers For Louima Protest Return Of an Officer
description: Lawyers for Abner Louima urged Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday to continue the suspension of Justin A. Volpe, one of two officers charged with brutalizing Mr. Louima in the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn last month.

title: A New Coach, a Renovated Stadium, and Nearly a Defeat for Notre Dame
description: He had more than nine months to plan for this day, the first game of his first season as a head coach of a college team. As Bob Davie prepared to lead the reshaped Notre Dame Fighting Irish into their enlarged and renovated home today, he emphasized the importance of responding to the inevitable setbacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STREET, ALFRED M.
description: STREET-Alfred M., of Darien, CT., on August 26, 1997. He was a retired officer for Jenkins Brothers in NYC. Husband of Ruth H. Street. Father of Sally Street Sturner. Grandfather of Paige Sturner Sabine, Pamela Sturner, & Kristin Sturner. Brother-in-law of Virginia Cairns & Bettina Canfield. Memorial service First Congregational Church of Darien, CT, Wednesday, September 10th, 1997 at 1:00 P.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to: Darien Senior Mens Assoc., Care of Darien YMCA, 2420 Post Road, Darien, CT. 06820 or Service Corps of Retired Executives, SCORE Chapter #

title: ARCHITECTURE
description: EXHIBITIONS

title: Family-Centered and Hugging Queens
description: WITH nearly 34,000 residents living along its tightly packed streets of one-family houses on small lots, Valley Stream is the third most populous village in New York State. It is also among the more affordable communities in Nassau County, one of the most expensive housing markets in the country.

title: Behind The Velvet Ropes
description: THEY thronged up and down the stairs of the Art Deco Cloud Room in the Chrysler Building -- rap stars, riffraff, rabid Janet Jackson fans and sundry music-industry sycophants. They were waiting for Ms. Jackson, who, true to the name of her not-yet-released CD, ''The Velvet Rope,'' was holding very private audiences in a very select V.I.P. room.

title: Vacant Seats and Challenges to Incumbents Expected to Provide a Number of New Members
description: While mayoral politics has been at the forefront, this year's primary season has also been particularly spirited on a more local level, with an unusually large number of closely contested City Council races.

title: Domestic but Not Domesticated
description: MEN GIVING MONEY, WOMEN YELLING

title: Apartment Seller Picks a Different Approach
description: WANT to own your own home? Here's how! Send $100 and a statement convincing me that you are the owner of this dream home. The winner gets: a spacious, sunny 1 bedroom garden apartment in Hartsdale, w/private entrance, designer ELK, DR, terrace, pool, free parking, pets welcome, walk to shopping and train, quiet neighborhood, cozy retreat nestled amidst ample cultural and social events, 35 minutes from mid-town NYC.

title: Protecting Children From Guns
description: Once again, Congressional Republicans are blocking sensible gun-control legislation. The measure involves child safety, making the G.O.P.'s doctrinal alliance with the National Rifle Association especially offensive. Seeking to prevent the tragedies that frequently occur when children get their hands on guns, President Clinton included in his juvenile justice bill a provision that would require firearms dealers to sell a safety lock with every gun. But the provision got omitted from a version of the bill approved in May by the Republican-controlled House. Republican leaders, anxious to please the N.R.A., successfully maneuvered to avoid an open vote on the House floor.

title: Miriam Schizer, Steven Landau
description: Dr. Miriam Anne Schizer and Dr. Steven Brian Landau were married on Monday at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Alvin Kass, the president of the New York Board of Rabbis.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 4/

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Driftless Zone

title: DIARY
description: PAYDAY

title: Produce To Be Given To Elderly
description: IT is harvest time again and people 60 and over who meet income criteria will be able to get coupons for free fresh produce at local farmers' markets.

title: Going With What's Newsy, and Safe
description: THIS IS THE YEAR WHEN NEWS MAGAZINES FINALLY TAKE over the world. NBC's ''Dateline'' will appear four nights a week. ABC adds a second night of ''20/20.'' Bryant Gumbel promises that his new magazine, CBS's ''Public Eye'' (beginning on Oct. 1), will be more high-minded than the competition. He could be right.

title: Five Orthodox Jews Spur Moral Debate Over Housing Rules at Yale
description: One of the most popular innovations on college campuses across the country a generation ago was the introduction of coeducational dormitories and the elimination of rules that tried to keep young men and women apart.

title: Diana's Funeral, Britain's Message
description: Of all the images evoked during the past week by the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, the one most likely to survive the passage of time is the startling response of the British people. The queues of mourners at the condolence books, the massed bouquets outside Kensington Palace, the millions who lined the streets and applauded spontaneously during the most evocative moments of the funeral service -- all these reflected a collective surge of national emotion that sent two clear messages.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SPIKE, MIKE, SLACKERS & DYKES: A Guided Tour Across

title: Does Attention Deficit Disorder Really Exist?
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Paparazzi To Picasso
description: YES, THERE ARE THE USUAL retrospectives of giants this season: Mathew Brady, Robert Capa, Imogen Cunningham, Walker Evans, Irving Penn, Edward Weston and Weegee. But there are some oddities too.

title: Found, a Final Resting Place
description: FUNERAL arrangements are something most people don't like to think about. The hope is that there will be sufficient money to take care of the expenses, and something for survivors as well.

title: Where's the Pork? Not Here.
description: WHEN he first arrived in New York from Sierra Leone in 1982, Abdul Kargbo fell in love with Chinese food. He indulged often in chicken with broccoli, his favorite.

title: Sharpton Woos a New Bloc
description: As candidate after candidate took the microphone to pitch for votes at a center for the elderly in Harlem the other day, the audience members, appearing largely unimpressed, sat chatting among themselves.

title: Shannon Klaerich, Mark Friedberg
description: Shannon Marie Klaerich, a daughter of Elizabeth Klaerich of La Grange, Ill., and Ralph Klaerich of Flossmoor, Ill., was married last evening to Mark Evan Friedberg, a son of Lorraine and Alan B. Friedberg of New York. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Cloveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Shannon, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: ARTIFACTS
description: September

title: Nancy Lieberman And Mark Ellman
description: Nancy Ann Lieberman and Mark Ellman were married last evening at the University Club in New York. Rabbi Alvin M. Poplak performed the ceremony.

title: Crime
description: Ruth Rendell draws on a fierce love of the English countryside for her 18th Inspector Wexford mystery, ROAD RAGE (Crown, $25), a novel that must have been written as much in sorrow as in anger. Taking what he vows will be his last walk in the deep woods that border his Sussex village, Chief Inspector Reginald Wexford contemplates with dread the new superhighway that will soon plow it all under. ''When I retire,'' he says bitterly, ''I want to live in London so that I can't see the countryside destroyed.'' But whatever sympathy he feels for the militant conservationists who pitch camp in Framhurst Great Wood to protest the highway is lost when a radical splinter group calling itself Sacred Globe kidnaps five innocent people -- including Wexford's wife -- and threatens to kill them unless the road is stopped.

title: Farewell, the Quaint, Old-Fashioned CD
description: DON'T LOOK NOW, BUT stereophonic sound is plunging into history. The audio market has been swept into a converged world of home entertainment under the banner ''digital.'' The game now is simply data, a perpetual stream of ones and zeros. Stir them together as you will. Create soundscapes once unimaginable. Combine multichannel sound and panoramic images. Two-channel sound without pictures? Quaint idea.

title: In Porn House, Sleeping Through It All
description: The naked couple were writhing together with athletic vigor and no discernible passion. As a cheesy rock score droned on, their eight-foot images sent cascades of light across the darkened theater. But that didn't bother the audience. Most of them were asleep.

title: Q. & A.
description: Halloween by the Bay

title: A World in Every Rug and Chair
description: ART, WHATEVER THE MEDIUM, DOES NOT EXIST IN A VACUUM. As the season's richly textured, fascinatingly detailed exhibitions bear witness, every stroke of an artist's brush, every stitch in a couture dress, illustrates the absorption of contemporary culture, politics and society.

title: With a Fine Eye for Trends in Electronics
description: IT began almost by accident 30 years ago. Problems with a buyer left John J. Shalam, a partner in a tiny Japanese import concern, with 2,000 car radios that he thought he would never sell.

title: White Rose Here, White Rose There
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Aztec Autumn

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Time on My Hands

title: Refinishing Woodwork, Safely and Beautifully
description: SOMEWHERE you may have some woodwork or furniture that looks shabby and should be refinished. Before you can apply a new finish, you'll have to strip off the old one. This is not difficult, nor does it require special skill, but it is messy and time-consuming. Most commercial strippers are toxic, so it's essential to wear safety gear and take precautions.

title: Among Cigarette Makers, Old Habits Die Hard
description: IN the images that make up the iconography of the battle over smoking, it is among the most striking: seven suited tobacco company executives standing before Congress, swearing that nicotine is not addictive and that no one had proven that their products cause cancer.

title: Fun on the Job: Celebrity Interviews
description: WHEN Steve Kmetko was a fledgling television reporter at a little station in Rhinelander, Wis., he was assigned his first celebrity interview.

title: Colorado Rethinks Bet on Historic Preservation
description: With wooden trim dripping from its eaves like lace and windows arching below Gothic gables, the Lace House was built on a hillside here in 1863 by a toll-road manager who wanted to impress his new wife. But now this landmark house may be pushed aside by the very industry brought in to save this town: casino gambling.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: September

title: It's Empty at the Top
description: WHEN WORK DOESN'T WORK ANYMORE

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEXLER, MELISSA ANN
description: WEXLER-Melissa Ann. May 9, 1958-September 12, 1981. Our sweet, dear Missy. The warmth and joys of life are saddened by our loss of you. Love, Mommy Arlene Wexler Joachim Eddie, Sheri and Larry

title: Dvorak's Homecoming, With Music
description: AFTER spending 32 years on the roof of Avery Fisher Hall in what was supposed to be, but never became, a roof garden, Antonin Dvorak is coming home to his old Stuyvesant Square neighborhood, or at least a statue of him is returning.

title: The Lives Behind The Brooms
description: When men in blue uniforms first began plucking garbage from the sidewalks and gutters along Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue from 72d to 96th Street in April, residents were delighted but somewhat puzzled. Who were these men and where did they come from?

title: One Phase of Fund-Raising Hearings Ends, With a Shortage of Evidence
description: On the first day of the Senate hearings on campaign finance practices, Senator Fred Thompson, the chairman of the investigating committee, dropped a bombshell.

title: Finding Opportunity Where Disorder Recently Ruled
description: IT has often been said that those who invest in the so-called emerging markets around the world need a cool head and a steel-lined stomach.

title: 163d St: Barricaded In, but Not Unhappy
description: For years, drug dealing on 163d Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway seemed beyond control. No matter what the police did to stamp out the drug trade there, dealers stood brazenly on the sidewalks and hawked cocaine and marijuana, even playing games of dominoes between sales.

title: Victoria Samuel, Harold Whelden
description: Victoria Samuel, a daughter of Cornelia T. Samuel of Bronxville, N.Y., and R. Scott Samuel of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Harold Reid Whelden, a son of Ernest E. Whelden of Nantucket, Mass., and the late Gertrude S. Whelden. The Rev. Edward B. Anderson, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony on Nantucket.

title: Classic Cars in a Properly Grand Setting
description: IT was last year's family festival, kicking off Hill-Stead's 50th anniversary as a museum in Farmington and attracting 3,000 people that inspired this year's enriched event.

title: Cutting Grass, and Other Growths, on 15th
description: MY new season began right on time.

title: Rough Riders Gain in Playoffs
description: The Long Island Rough Riders advanced into the finals of the A-League's Northeast Division playoffs tonight with a 2-1 shootout victory over the Rochester Rhinos before 4,361 fans at Hofstra University.

title: After Months Without Ethics Committee, House May Resurrect It This Week
description: After seven months in the deep freeze, the House ethics committee may be revived this coming week. The House has been out of the business of policing the ethical conduct of its members since January, when a vituperative and fractious investigation of Speaker Newt Gingrich tore the committee apart and paralyzed the House.

title: Touching Moments with Leifer? Get Real!
description: CAROL LEIFER would like to make a promise to the people of the United States: ''On my show, there will be no touchie-feelie moments and no very special episodes.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 7, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Hardly a Contest: No. 1 Penn State Outclasses Pittsburgh
description: When Walt Harris was the quarterbacks coach at Ohio State, he could look across the field at Penn State Coach Joe Paterno and know he had the weapons to match anything Paterno could throw at him.

title: Lily Changchien, John Middleton Jr.
description: Lily Changchien and John Richard Middleton Jr., associates at New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Joseph P. Parkes, the president of Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx, performed the ceremony.

title: For the DVD, Disney Magic May Be the Key
description: ARMED WITH A SCORECARD, a map of the heavens and perhaps clairvoyance, the bedazzled video enthusiast might boldly go where no shopper has gone before: into the brave new solar system of digital technology. Coming in the months ahead are not just one new world, the digital video disk, but several spheres of video enterprise whose scope and significance are yet to be determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUITON, SOFIA
description: QUITON-Sofia. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Lucien Quiton. Loving mother of the late Barbara Jacoby. Devoted and cherished sister of Jack Gould. Adored grandmother of Lauri Greenberg and Sharon Webber. Loved and admired by her great-grandchildren and a great many friends. Services at The Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC, at 12:30 PM on Sunday, September 7. Contributions to your favorite charity in lieu of flowers would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, ELAINE F.
description: ROBERTS-Elaine F. In loving memory of our wife, mother and grandmother who gave generously with her heart and soul, died September 2, 1997. Her loyalty to family and friends and unbroken spirit for life has been passed on to survivors husband, Lloyd, children, Lisa and Joshua, Lisa and Steven and granddaughters, Sydney, Richelle and Perry. Funeral services were held on Friday, September 5.

title: Messinger Sounds the Alarm
description: On the hot Sunday afternoon before Labor Day, Ruth W. Messinger stood on the deck around a swimming pool at the Skyview Apartments, a co-op complex in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, squinting as the sun glittered off the water, and came face to face with what may be the biggest obstacle in her quest to become mayor of New York.

title: Planting Errors That Can Devour the Garden
description: All gardeners make mistakes, and among my worst was the Oriental bittersweet. What I wanted, and what I thought I had ordered, was the native variety Celastrus scandens. What I got, and foolishly planted anyway, was the Oriental variety Celastrus orbiculatus.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IMBARRATO, AURELIA CALIGIURI
description: IMBARRATO-Aurelia Caligiuri. September 2, 1917-August 28, 1992. You are in our hearts always. Valerie and Julia

title: Through London's Streets, The Sounds of Silence Toll
description: The silence the awestruck, reverent, almost worshipful silence -- was positively deafening.

title: Alexandra Kreisler, Eric Weinberger
description: Alexandra Kreisler, a daughter of Patricia H. Kreisler of New York and Stuart L. Kreisler of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Eric Louis Weinberger, a son of Judi and David A. Weinberger of Old Tappan, N.J. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Yanks' Stress, and Losing Streak, Keeps Building
description: The signs of stress, frustration and exasperation permeated Yankee Stadium yesterday before and after the Orioles throttled the Yankees, 4-1, and continued constructing their own magical season. The Yankees can forget about miracles, and they can forget about winning the American League East. If only they could forget about a dreary losing stretch that has them drained. That, however, would take a victory or two.

title: From Star-Struck to Star, a Trouper Steps Up
description: OH, HOW SHE WEPT THROUGH ''On Your Toes.'' She was almost 13 then, tall and coltish, a budding gymnast who had kept a poster of Nadia Comenici on her bedroom wall for years, and who, on the basis of that one day at a Broadway theater, would shift her allegiance from the balance beam to the show tune.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

description: COSTELLO-Walter. Thank you St. Jude for Walter Costello's health. From his wife

title: A Small Island That Sets Off Big Tremors
description: WITH a skeptical frown, Valentin Goncalez stood by the pastry counter at Mi Bandera supermarket in Union City and evaluated the headline that screamed in a red box spread across the front page of the Spanish-language newspaper Continental. Translated, it said:

title: THEATER
description: September

title: William Van Ornum
description: Van Ornum, a psychology professor at Marist College, is the author of ''A Thousand Frightening Fantasies: Understanding and Healing Scrupulosity and Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.''

title: Scott Adams Keeps the Home Office Humming
description: SCOTT ADAMS clearly knows a thing or two about the wrong way to run a business.

title: The Very Good Soldier
description: Ulysses S. Grant

title: Army Gets Thumped by Moss and His Teammates
description: In a game of 135 plays, Marshall's Randy Moss had his large hands on the football just eight times today. Twice was enough.

title: Far From the Country, the Country-Club Life Lives On
