description: The competitive spirit was rising on the courts last week, in Flushing and Flatbush. Flushing had the U.S. Open; Flatbush was where a considerably smaller, but not necessarily less intense, tennis tournament was about to get under way at the Knickerbocker Field Club.

title: For a Poisoned Bay, a Renewed Call on Behalf of Fishermen
description: Herman Dobler, a retired fire captain from Hackensack, has spent a lot of time sport fishing and crabbing on the Hackensack River, but as he fished in Foschini Park here on a cool morning last week, he said a ban on harvesting blue claw crabs and the stiff fines being imposed for doing so were news to him.

title: Altruism for Fun and Profit
description: On a sun-drenched southern California afternoon, in the penthouse offices of a Beverly Hills P.R. firm, the creative team behind the Tanqueray American AIDS Rides has assembled to review the status of their project--and the news is all good. Last year's five rides mobilized almost 10,000 riders and raised more than $25 million for 26 AIDS charities around the country. The group is expecting the 1997 season, which wraps up Sept. 12 with the third Boston to New York AIDS Ride, to do even better.

title: Robert McNamara And the Ghosts Of Vietnam
description: Not all of the senior Vietnamese at the Hanoi conference refused to acknowledge that their side also made mistakes (''Robert McNamara and the Ghosts of Vietnam,'' by David K. Shipler, Aug. 10). When, in a side conversation with the former Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, I repeated the comment cited by Shipler about our both having made great mistakes and both paying for them dearly, Minister Thach replied, ''I agree with you.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, DOROTHY (PERLO)
description: WEISSMAN-Dorothy (Perlo). Of Brooklyn, NY, and West Palm Beach, Florida, on Wednesday, September 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jack Weissman, devoted mother of Stuart (Roberta) Weissman and Ruth (Edward) Vollins of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. Also survived by grandchildren Elizabeth (Jack), Susan, Steven and James and great grandsons Matthew and Ian. Graveside service, Mount Ararat Cemetery, today at 11:00 A.M.

title: From Communism to Congestion
description: IN the days of the Soviet Union, while Moskovites moved about in patterns determined by public transportation, there were relatively few motor vehicles and they ruled the streets. In today's Moscow, the thoroughfares are a crush of cars, often moving at a snail's pace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIFF, DR. NATHAN A.
description: SHIFF-Dr. Nathan A. On September 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruth K. C. Shiff. Dear father of Leslie Solove of Lancaster, PA; adored grandfather of Daniel Solove of Arlington, VA. Cherished brother of Robert Shiff of Naples, FL. Service Monday, September 8, 1:45 PM, at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, FRANK
description: LESSER-Frank. Commissioner of the Great Neck Water Pollution Control District, Democratic State Committeeman, died on September 4, 1997. He will be greatly missed by his beloved wife Deena, children Steven, Laura and Julie, seven adoring grandchildren, sister Carolyn Frucht, brother Stephen Marlowe. Services Sunday, 11 AM, Reconstructionist Synagogue, Plandome Rd., Manhasset. Memorial donations maybe sent to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Project Ezra, or the Great Neck United Community Fund.

title: Lights! Crepe! Action!
description: LOIE FUlLER

title: The Fall and Rise of Kilmer McCully
description: Michelle Stacey's article about Dr. McCully offered a profound and poignant commentary on a number of critical issues in scientific research (''The Fall and Rise of Kilmer McCully,'' Aug. 10).

title: The Many Unsung
description: To the Editor:

title: Golf vs. Tennis Is Off the Mark
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Easing Parents' Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: Literary Cycle: Bookshelf, Broadcast, Video Store
description: FOR A LITERARY CLASSIC ON video, it's all in the sweep, the heartache, the old come-hither that keeps people popping those cassettes into the VCR, sometimes one right after the other. A Jane Austen story, for instance, can seduce any night of the week, especially ''Pride and Prejudice,'' the A&E mini-series that had viewers vying for quickly depleted supplies of videos after it played on television early last year. More than any television production in recent years, it proves that with enough charisma a five-hour tale can make videophiles stay the course.

title: Ending a Bloody Standoff in Israel
description: FROM the time the Israeli-Palestinian peace was first launched on the White House lawn four years ago, the process has been regularly punctuated by the sound of suicide bombs. The triple attack on the popular Ben Yehuda promenade in Jerusalem last week brought the number of Islamic fanatics who have turned themselves into human bombs since then to 20, with many times that number of victims. And with every explosion, Israeli reaction has gone from a horrified disbelief to angry demands for vengeance, and finally to the question that predominated after carnage on Thursday -- ''What now?''

title: Will Small-Town Shopping Survive
description: SPEEDING cars and road rage. Fast food and indigestion. Twenty-four hour shopping and instant gratification. The norm is the answer machine, pagers, faxes and cellular phones. In the wrong hands these devices invade boundaries in churches, restaurants, little league and the L.I.R.R.

title: Torre Makes The Rounds, Then Writes His Lineup
description: Joe Torre paraded around the bustling trainer's room at Yankee Stadium yesterday, looking at swollen thumbs and bruised fingers, asking about sore arms and nagging shoulders and feeling more like a small-town doctor than a big-town manager.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AVRETT, JACK
description: AVRETT-Jack. Memorial service Thursday, September 11, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison (81st St), 4:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera, New York City.

title: Read. You're Getting Very Unsleepy
description: VIKTOR FRANKL, Nazi concentration camp inmate No. 119,104, died last week in Vienna believing that ''decisions, not conditions'' are what mental health is about and that you do not get better by seeing yourself as a victim. In his seminal 1946 book ''Man's Search for Meaning,'' he offered to the world a psychiatric theory emphasizing self-determination and personal responsibility in dealing with emotional suffering. The book, which spawned ''logotherapy'' and the creation of the ''third school'' of Viennese psychotherapy (after Freud and Adler), is now in its 73d edition and has been translated into 24 languages.

title: Give the Met Relievers an Eighth-Inning Lead, Get Another Lost Ball Game
description: Loud and giddy Cubs fans could be heard through the open door of the Mets' clubhouse today after Chicago overcame two late-inning deficits to win, 7-5. Somebody shut the heavy metal door and suddenly all noise ceased, save for the sound of dropped spikes clacking against the floor. The Mets, a blaring presence in the National League East race for four months, are being silenced.

title: Allison Busch, Jonathan Vogel
description: Allison Jill Busch, a daughter of Linda and Bertram Busch of East Brunswick, N.J., was married last evening to Jonathan Ross Vogel, a son of Madeline and Chester Vogel of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Bennett F. Miller performed the ceremony at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Covered With Fur in the Naked City
description: Canine New Yorkers are a lot like their human counterparts, as can be seen in NEW YORK DOGS (Chronicle, $14.95), a collection of photographs by Andrea Mohin, a staff photographer at The New York Times. For some, city life is all about career: the airport luggage inspectors, professional models, police detectives, arson investigators, guides, guards and trackers. For some, there is time for charity work: making an appearance at the A.S.P.C.A. walkathon in Central Park, for instance, or visiting the elderly at a Bronx nursing home. And of course there are layabouts, like Kiko, the soulful-eyed American Staffordshire terrier who spends his days on a stool at a Greenwich Village bar. The 55 black-and-white photographs reveal a preference for relatively large dogs (Rottweilers, German shepherds, Labrador mixes). This may leave cuteness addicts hungry for just one more Pomeranian in a backpack or the equivalent. They will like Dancer, a Chinese crested powder puff, relaxing on a chaise longue on a penthouse terrace. If Mohin's view has a flaw, it is that she sometimes makes a New York dog's life look a little better than it really is. Never mind what taste treat the English bulldog is desperately trying to reach in that silver chafing dish. How did he get into the buffet line at Tavern on the Green? Anita Gates

title: Mother Juggles 2 Careers
description: ''I LEAD two lives,'' the radio disk jockey J. J. Kennedy of WLTW-FM (106.7), said. ''Or if you want to rephrase it, I guess you could say I have two full-time careers.''

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Choice films on television this week draw on themes ranging from romance to show business in settings as diverse as a British country estate, the American frontier, Broadway and Los Angeles.

title: Dark Victory
description: The Rise and Fall

title: Racial Rift Slows Suit for 'Environmental Justice'
description: For the 1,400 residents of Kennedy Heights and the many people who have taken up their cause, the Federal court case unfolding here should be a national landmark in the drive for ''environmental justice,'' a legal strategy based on claims that racial minorities are disproportionately subjected to pollution hazards.

title: Ms. Beresovski And Mr. Hulme
description: Catherine Marie Beresovski, the daughter of Jacqueline Beresovski of Cannes, France, and Theodore Beresovski of Theoule-sur-Mer, France, was married yesterday in Theoule to Randall Kenyon Hulme, a son of Nancy K. Hulme of Riverton, N.J., and Robert D. Hulme of Princeton, N.J. Mayor Andre-Charles Blanc of Theoule officiated at the town hall. The Rev. Alan Kent Salmon performed an Episcopal ceremony later in the day at Club Port La Galere, also in Theoule.

title: Bach and Albert Schweitzer, a Fest
description: TONIGHT at 7:30 the First Church of Christ in Wethersfield begins its season of monthly concerts with a multimedia program that is also the nationwide opening of the Albert Schweitzer Organ Festival/U.S.A.

title: Vols' Punter Nearly Boots Game Away
description: When all else fails, don't punt.

title: Ursula von Rydingsvard, R. M. Greeve
description: Ursula Anne von Rydingsvard, the daughter of Ursula von Rydingsvard and Dr. Paul Greengard of New York, was married yesterday to Raymond Maria Greeve, the son of Ineke and Theo Greeve of Leende, the Netherlands. The Rev. Paul Benes performed the Dutch Reformed ceremony at the Old Dutch Church in Kingston, N.Y.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Style column on page 75 of The Times Magazine today, about British royalty from a dog's point of view, was written to coincide with the Sept. 11 Sotheby's sale of personal articles of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. The magazine went to press before the accident that killed Diana, Princess of Wales; the sale was subsequently postponed.

title: Style's Royal Flush
description: RESTRICTED by rules of protocol and propriety, royalty has seldom been at the cutting edge of fashion. But kings, queens and the like have on occasion lent their prestige to sartorial developments -- and been criticized for exhibiting too great an interest (not to mention for spending too much of the royal purse). Diana, Princess of Wales, was only the latest royal personage in fashion history.

title: In the War on Kudzu, A Scientific Strategy
description: Now and again, Paul Williams will drive past a tangle of deep green kudzu vines and think how pretty it smells. Down here, whether it is grammatically acceptable or not, a thing can smell pretty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSBACHER, EMIL ''BUS'', JR.
description: MOSBACHER-Emil ''Bus'', Jr., 75, died Wednesday, August 13, 1997 at home in Greenwich, Conn. Devoted husband of Patricia Ryan. Dear father of Emil III, R. Bruce and John. Loving father-in-law of Nancy. Adored grandfather of Jack and Emily. Dear brother of Barbara, brother of Robert. A memorial service will be held at 4PM on September 8th at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West 44 St, NYC.

title: Peter Roberson, Alexandra Stoddard
description: Alexandra Brandon Stoddard, a daughter of Alexandra Stoddard of New York and Brandon Stoddard of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Peter Scott Roberson, a son of Barbara Rust Roberson of Cherry Valley, Calif., and the late Robert J. Roberson. The Rev. Cecily Stoddard Stranahan, an aunt of the bride and an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony at Mineral Spring Farm in Claiborne, Md.

title: As Dark Turned to Dawn, a City Watched History Receive a New Legend
description: Jean and Daniel Segal, real estate brokers on Manhattan's Upper East Side and the parents of three small children, began yesterday morning by paying Diana, Princess of Wales, the highest tribute they could think to offer: not watching her televised funeral.

title: For Media and the Royals, Earl Takes Off His Gloves
description: Amid the soothing pomp and ceremony of the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, the eulogy of her younger brother, Earl Spencer, burst forth yesterday as an undiluted cry of pain and anger.

title: Outside Influences
description: This fall, the short, demure coat will make its presence felt.

title: Source Notes
description: THE NAMES OF THINGS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLENBERG, LEONARD
description: ELLENBERG-Leonard, after a long illness in Wynnewood, PA. formerly of Oceanside, New York. Beloved husband of Thelma, devoted father of Dinah Richman and Carol Kurtz, proud father in law, adoring grandfather.

title: Those Who'd Ban Breeds Should Try Dog's-Eye View
description: To the Editor:

title: A Village So Private After a Life So Public
description: In the end, she came home to rest on a leafy island in a small and sculptured lake, behind the wrought-iron gates and weathered stone walls of her family seat well north of London, a final haven of privacy and exclusion as remote as could be imagined from the laser-glare of publicity that Diana, Princess of Wales, both shunned and courted.

title: Frances Peale And Kevin Mills
description: Frances Alice Peale, a daughter of Jean and James Peale of Bronxville, N.Y., was married at her parent's house yesterday to John Kevin Mills, a son of Anne and William C. Mills of Columbia, S.C. The Rev. George Easton, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony with the bridegroom's father, a Baptist minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUFFINO, ALICE (NEE STACEY)
description: RUFFINO-Alice (nee Stacey). Age 88, dearly loved mother of Sandra P. Manne (Jerry) has died in Illinois. She is also survived by her cousins Alice Rowan McCormick and Florence and Reynold Kornicker. Mrs. Ruffino was born and raised in NY and was educated at Barnard. She was a magazine editor with MacFadden-Bartell. She will be remembered for her love of NYC and Paris, as well as her natural red hair and love of muisic and dancing. Interment will be at Woodlawn, Bronx. Memorials to the British Home, Brookfield, IL 60513 would be appreciated.

title: Where Children Rule
description: The contrast of societal upbringing in Japanese primary schools with authoritarian education of children in the United States raises several questions. Is such communal inculcation of responsibility feasible only in a country of an ethnically homogeneous people? Does the diversity of backgrounds and opinions in American neighborhoods, an outcome of our history as a nation of immigrants, make us wary of allowing our children to be taught by their classmates?

title: By the Book but in the Here and Now
description: JUST WHEN THE SERIOUS NOVEL seems more detached than ever from popular culture, movies are turning for inspiration to contemporary literature. The success last year of ''The English Patient'' may be one reason. Another may be that the vogue for Merchant Ivory-style nostalgia is winding down. Its future depends on two fall movies taken from Henry James novels -- ''Washington Square'' and ''The Wings of the Dove'' -- and one in the winter taken from Virginia Woolf's ''Mrs. Dalloway.''

title: Lorinda Ash, Peter Ezersky
description: Lorinda Sam Ash, an art dealer, was married on Thursday evening to Peter Roy Ezersky, a financial executive. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.

title: Eileen Gillespie and Timothy Fahey
description: Eileen Tracy Gillespie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gillespie 3d of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy William Fahey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fahey of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Richard J. Clifford, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. James Church in Prouts Neck, Me.

title: Nicole David and Garry Schumacher
description: Nicole Martine Jamar David and Garry Kemble Schumacher were married yesterday in New York. Canon Ashton J. Brooks performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: Asians Are Making an Impact on L.I. Life
description: WHEN Indu Jaiswal moved to Nassau County 20 years ago, her traditional Indian clothing often got second looks. During the 1960's Shi Ming Hu, who came to teach at Stony Brook University in the 1960's, had to travel to New York's Chinatown for basic Asian foodstuffs. Ten years ago, in Great Neck, Henry Pak, a Korean physician, could not get brokers to show him houses in the more ''exclusive'' parts of town.

title: Hatchling Of Pet Lover Is the Rage Of Toylands
description: Inspiration came to Akihiro Yokoi one day when he was watching a television commercial. A boy wanted to take his pet turtle with him on a trip, and his mother scolded him and told him to leave it at home.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 7, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Special Today: The New Season
description: ''Ragtime'' on Broadway. Yo-Yo Ma on tour with Bach. Steven Spielberg's new movie on slavery. Robert Rauschenberg at the Guggenheim. Merce Cunningham at BAM. Plus, the big events in television, architecture, pop music and antiques. With detailed listings and tipsheets from Times critics on the new cultural season.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about an impromptu song-and-dance performance staged every Friday night on the sidewalk in front of 124 East Fourth Street in Manhattan misstated the vocalist's given name. He is Nick Drakides, not Mick.

title: Jennifer Kochman, Andrew Marrus
description: Jennifer Laura Kochman, a daughter of Carol Salvage Kochman of New York and the late Dr. Richard Shelley Kochman, was married yesterday to Andrew Seth Marrus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Marrus of Rumson, N.J. Rabbi Robert Levine performed the ceremony at Wheatleigh, an inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: A Story of America, Set to Ragtime
description: IN AMERICA, WHERE EVEN HISTORY is democratic, millions of individual tales accrete into a national saga the way notes form a song.

title: Krista Bryant, Edward Ryan
description: Krista Johanna Bryant and Dr. Edward Thomas Ryan were married yesterday at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in North Easton, Mass. Deacon Michael F. Dolan, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ALISON VERA
description: SMITH-Alison Vera. On September 5, 1997, age 64. Dearly beloved sister of Louise Schneider and her husband Otto Schneider. Niece of Margaret Smith and Josephine Seitel. Adored by her cousins Dr. Carl H. Smith, Chris Smith, Lillian Bowers, Joshua Smith, Sephine and Michael Melrod, George Melrod, Joan Melrod Weiss, Carol and George Leibman, Marc Blagawidow, Leni Sandys, Karen Seitel, Joan Ackerstein and Howard Alexander. A woman who loved her family and was devoted to her friends. She was caring, compassionate and gentle to people and causes to which to gave of herself. In all of her associations with people she showed great kindness and consideration. Contributions may be made in Alison's name to Oxfam of America, 26 West Street, Boston, MA 02111 or Children's Blood Foundation, c/o New York Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, NY, NY 10021. Service Sunday, September 7, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY.

title: We're Not So Rare
description: To the Editor:

title: Is There Life After Schubert and Brahms?
description: CAN THERE BE ANYTHING LEFT TO say about Schubert and Brahms after the feeding frenzy that greeted the year's two big anniversaries last season? Kurt Masur evidently thinks so. He opens the New York Philharmonic season this month with an informal festival of the four Brahms symphonies, leavened by the Schubert Third. But Colin Davis's thoughts are elsewhere. He interrupts the Philharmonic season at Avery Fisher Hall in December for a Sibelius festival with the London Symphony, celebrating no particular anniversary.

title: The Seductions of Lake Lugano
description: FLOATING on the green mirror of Lake Lugano, with the gulls chattering above the deck and the waiter delivering a salad platter spiked with arugula, I become persuaded that places of breathtaking natural beauty do not always require a measure of physical hardship.

title: Alvin Ailey's Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Ill Wind Blows Tall Ships to Wrong Side of the Pier
description: The crowds love them. So do the local merchants, whose sales swell when they come, and the museum, too, whose attendance figures rise. But the tall ships are not visiting South Street Seaport the way they used to, officials of the nonprofit South Street Seaport Museum say. The reason, say museum officials: a decision by the commercial operators of the seaport to let ferryboats dock where the tall ships once berthed.

title: Nina Sonenberg, Yoram Wurmser
description: Nina Elise Sonenberg and Yoram Steven Wurmser were married last evening at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Lee Friedlander performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUNDLICH, RALPH B. (AKA RAY FRIENDLY)
description: FREUNDLICH-Ralph B. (aka Ray Friendly). Age 84 of Bisbee, Arizona. Formerly of New York City on September 2, 1997, after a protracted illness. Musician, teacher, composer, artist, writer and advocate. Loving brother of Jules of Minneapolis, Minnesota and the late Irwin. Devoted brother-in-law of Lillian Freundlich and the late Miriam Freundlich. He is also survived by nephews Roger Freundlich of Espoo, Finland and Douglas Freundlich of Arlington, Massachusetts, niece Laura Muessig of Minneapolis, two grand nieces and six grand nephews. Memorial service at Philadelphia Hotel, 19 0K Street in Bisbee at 7 PM, September 20, 1997.

title: JAZZ
description: September

title: Igniting the Stadium Fires
description: The adventure continues today for the Jets, who have not known a loss in this one fat summer of rising expectations and surprising results. The hope that something special has been happening and will continue to happen could bring one of the largest crowds in team history to Giants Stadium, where the Jets face the Buffalo Bills in their home opener.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing on page 98 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the music hall where Simon Rattle is to conduct the City of Birmingham Orchestra next May. It is Avery Fisher Hall, at Lincoln Center, not Carnegie Hall.

title: Opening-Day Rescue
description: Classes are now in session for the nation's public-school students, including those in the largest system of all, New York City, where opening-day numbers can stagger the mind. Its 1.1 million students (18,000 more than last year) attend 1,100 schools with 66,000 teachers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIMAN, ROBERT
description: FREIMAN-Robert. Artist. Son of the late Augusta Aronowitz and Manny Freiman. Dear nephew and cousin. For information call Gannon Funeral Home 212532-6579.

title: Those Are Players, Buffy, Not Ants in Tennis Whites
description: Tennis fans of the world, unite! You have nothing to lose but your lousy seats at the U.S. Open.

title: Dictionaries of Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RABON, JAY L.
description: RABON-Jay L. A genuine Southern gentleman who had a fascination with the world. Always amusing, kind, charming, loving and compassionate; he lived intensely and left us suddenly and unexpectedly of heart failure on the beaches of Corsica, France, on August 6, 1997. He was one of those truly gracious individuals who made life much more pleasant for everyone around him. Jay taught us to be better friends. We loved him living and we love him still. He will be greatly missed. His extended family and friends in New York, Watermill, Florida, France, Mexico and Argentina, and his life partner, Dr. Joshua Algaze, will gather to honor his memory on the day that would have marked his 51st birthday, next Sunday, September 14, 1997 at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60 Street, New YorK at 5 P.M.

title: Coffee and Eggs, Any Style? Sure. But Truck Stops Don't Stop There.
description: THE menus may run to several pages, but the two most important items at any New Jersey truck stop are coffee, served in infinitely refillable cups, and eggs, every style.

title: Falling Off the Edge
description: What a pretty view this is. A stretch of grass, a fringe of Queen Anne's lace, then sand followed by white, bouncing waves at the turbulent edge of a wide expanse of the restless Atlantic, stretching eastward to the horizon. I am sitting in an idyllic little cottage where I do my writing, on Nantucket Island, a few yards from the sea.

title: Nostalgia: Even 1991 Can Count
description: BEHEMOTHS OF THE PAST, reawakened and reunited, will be trampling the pop landscape this season. The biggest one is the Rolling Stones tour, headed for stadiums beginning on Sept. 23 to promote a new album, ''Bridges to Babylon.'' Bob Dylan's latest album, ''Time out of Mind,'' comes out a week later, and James Brown, James Taylor and Johnny Mathis keep rolling along with tours of their own.

title: Not Necessarily What the Name Implies
description: WHAT'S in a name? Not much that's applicable, it seems, in the case of Fat Cat Cafe in Avon. The name doesn't in any way suggest the dining pleasures found inside. Even more perplexing is the posted slogan: ''Fine Dining * No Whining.''

title: Husbands and Wife
description: WHISTLED

title: Robert McNamara And the Ghosts Of Vietnam
description: Robert McNamara went to Hanoi to find out how a war that should not have been fought, and could not have been won, could have been avoided. It could have been avoided if in 1964, when the fateful decision was made, the Johnson Administration had accepted a simple truth, which also eluded the Eisenhower, Kennedy and Nixon Administrations: the overriding motivation of the Vietnamese was the implacable determination not to be denied the right of self-determination, which they had earned in 1954 when they defeated the French at Dienbienphu.

title: Andrea Stern and Adam Pelzman
description: Andrea Caroline Stern, the daughter of Judith Stern Peck and Leonard N. Stern, both of New York, is to be married today to Adam Judd Pelzman, the son of Diane Karnett of New York and Dr. Henry Pelzman of North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Rolando Matalon is to perform the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun in New York.

title: Building Better Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Ossorio's Assemblages, in a Spiritual Direction
description: Alfonso Ossorio: Congregations

title: Miller Aims to Prove His Critics Wrong
description: Wide receiver Anthony Miller, a new addition to what may be the best offense in football right now, was talking recently about how well the Dallas Cowboys' offense is working. He suddenly switched topics and went into a somewhat startling diatribe about negative comments he says Denver Broncos Coach Mike Shanahan has been making about him.

title: Product Placement?
description: To the Editor:

title: Little House in the Big Woods
description: THE ROAD HOME

title: 'To Avoid Such a Disgrace'
description: If by the first week in October Attorney General Janet Reno does not seek appointment of Independent Counsel, she may well be the first Cabinet member since William Belknap in 1876 to be impeached.

title: Millions Say Farewell to Their Princess
description: Britain bid farewell to Diana, Princess of Wales, on a sparkling morning today with a grand tribute as rich in popular pageantry as it was in regal pomp.

title: Tennis Player, 11, With a Dream in Her Mind
description: AT the Eastern Tennis Association Grand Prix competition in Albany last winter, Jenna Loeb, 11, was supposed to warm up before the match with her coach, Chris Casanova. She asked if they could go to McDonald's instead. ''Yes,'' said Mr. Casanova, trusting her judgment. ''Jenna ate, went into the play area and worked up a sweat on the ladders, slides and ball pit. That's how she got ready physically and mentally for the match.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Molly Sweeten, Spencer Boggess
description: Molly Sweeten and Spencer Norton Boggess were married yesterday on Squirrel Island, Me. The Rev. Richard H. Hall, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Squirrel Island Chapel.

title: Where Now for the Long Wharf Theater?
description: DOUGLAS HUGHES, as charismatic and dramatic as any actor who's taken the stage of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, is the first new artistic director that subscribers there have seen in 30 years.

title: B. J. Topol, Jon Evan Blum
description: B. J. Topol and Jon Evan Blum were married on Friday at the Town Hall in Southampton, N.Y., by Marietta M. Seaman, the town clerk. Rabbi Irnie Nadler is to perform a religious ceremony next Sunday at the Hotel du Cap in Antibes, France.

title: Coming of Age in Consumer Land
description: IF America is a nation of customers, market researchers are our cultural anthropologists -- studying the inhabitants as diligently as Margaret Mead studied the Samoans.

title: Brit K. Dewey, Philippe Tinmouth
description: Brit Katrina Dewey, a college administrator, and Philippe Tinmouth, a management consultant, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Walter D. Wagoner, a United Churches of Christ minister, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Michael R. Moynihan, a Roman Catholic priest, at the First Church of Round Hill.

title: Atrocities in Algeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about reaction to a university's being named the No. 1 party school in the nation in a survey misstated the name of the school. It is West Virginia University, not the University of West Virginia.

title: A Five-Day Jaunt in Juneau
description: WHEN I think of the wild, I think of Alaska -- of peaks like ice cubes, of thick trackless forests, and especially of bears. The last time I went to the Alaskan interior, I took a pair of bells to let them know I was there. Shortly after my return, I read in the news that two veteran hikers from Anchorage had been mauled to death by a bear in a state park near Prince William Sound where I had sauntered, jingling.

title: Just Another Formula
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATZA, DAVID D.
description: MATZA-David D. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Jack and Betty Matza. Cherished grandfather of Emily and Henry. Loving father-in-law of Amy Rood. Brother of Ezra Matza and Anne Uffer. Services ''BoulevardRiverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Sunday, 12:30 PM.

title: Turning to 'Violence' to Kill Time
description: FOR THE GERMAN director Wim Wenders, ''The End of Violence'' -- a meditation about paranoia, computer-controlled gadgetry and government nefariousness in Los Angeles that opens on Friday -- began with an unexpected delay in the long-planned production schedule for ''Billion-Dollar Hotel,'' a high-tech thriller Mr. Wenders had developed with his friend Bono, the lead singer in the rock band U2.

title: The Good Loser
description: To promote the good health of the 1,500 clerks processing payments to Civil War veterans, the architect of Washington's vast Pension Building specified that three bricks be left out from beneath each window for better ventilation. This June night, the briefcases resting against the building's huge indoor Corinthian columns belong to a better-paid generation of bureaucrats, whose name tags specify organizations like the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners and Resources for the Future. They're here -- in what has become the air-conditioned National Building Museum (though Washingtonians still call it the Pension Building) -- for an awards dinner sponsored by the Keystone Center, a not-for-profit peacemaker in the environmental wars that has asked Bob Dole to present its Leadership in Government Award to his old Finance Committee colleague Senator John Chafee, the Republican from Rhode Island.

title: Moose Madness
description: To the Editor: ''Town Mouse Seeks Moose'' (July 13) was a hilarious piece. Last year my husband and I had a similar experience in Denali National Park with an equally enthusiastic group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, HARRY
description: ADLER-Harry. On August 23, at the age of 75. The Board of Trustees, staff, students and parents of The Reece School mourn the death of their beloved Assistant Director. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Play by Play, Drill by Drill, Preparing to Take the Field for a New Season
description: LONG before the first official day of school, students around New Jersey were hitting the books -- the drill books, that is, for football teams, marching bands and cheerleading squads.

title: Robert McNamara And the Ghosts Of Vietnam
description: Wouldn't it be ''loverly'' if Robert McNamara, now crying ''peccavi,'' were to distribute the millions derived from his book to Vietnam veterans and the widows and orphans of those who never came home?

title: When Swamp and Suburb Collide
description: Scott Silver, a biologist fresh from studying howler monkeys in the rain forests of Belize, stalked new quarry in the neatly mowed backyard of a town house complex 70 miles north of New York City.

title: Suzanne Tapson, Gordon Burnes
description: Suzanne Yvette Tapson, a daughter of Judith M. Tapson and Stephen A. Tapson of Placerville, Calif., was married yesterday to Gordon MacGregor Burnes, a son of Justice Nonnie S. Burnes and Richard M. Burnes of Boston. The Rev. Alice Hageman, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents in Osterville, Mass.

title: They Shut Down My E-Mail: Diary of a Virtual Prisoner
description: FIVE years of work -- writing, producing, directing and selling my independent feature film, ''Delinquent'' -- was finally coming to fruition early last month. Just a few weeks remained before the premiere, barely time to complete a distinguished site on the World Wide Web, conduct interviews and begin grass-roots promotions in New York and Los Angeles.

title: The 9 Lives Of Deb Parker
description: IT'S 3 A.M. on a Wednesday and Deb Parker is running late. The crowd at her new bar, Barmacy, an East Village hot spot of the moment, is thinning out, and a pair of tattooed bartenders are looking concerned. There are issues of alcohol and money that they are most anxious to discuss with her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, JERRY C., M.D.
description: JACOBS-Jerry C., M.D. Of Riverdale and Westhampton Beach, NY, on September 6. Professor of clincial pediatrics at Columbia Univeristy College of Physicians and Surgeons. Beloved husband for 43 years of Isabel Fenster Jacobs. Devoted father of Deborah L. Jacobs (Ken Stern), Daniel S. Jacobs, and Paul S. Jacobs (Lisa Rau). Adoring grandfather of Bryan Rau-Jacobs, Kelly Rau-Jacobs and Jack Stern. Services Monday, September 8, at 10 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. Family sitting shiva September 8, 9 and 10, at 4621 Waldo Ave., Riverdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Babies Hospital, for the Jerry C. Jacobs Memorial Lectureship in Pediatric Rheumatology.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: A Magazine Celebrates Art for Art's Sake

title: 6The Heat Is Outside The Kitchen
description: Kudos to David Blum for his article on the restaurateur David Bouley. The strength of the piece was in the balanced view he put forth of Bouley. Love him or hate him, the picture is all there.

title: Vincent Reflects, 5 Years After His Resignation
description: Five years ago today, Fay Vincent sat on the deck of his house overlooking Nantucket Sound on Cape Cod. He is there again today. This time the view is prettier, the air sweeter, the birds chirpier. ''It hasn't been a bad five years for me,'' Vincent said. ''If Bud and the owners are very happy with the way things are, then we're both happy.''

title: A Baptist Leader Is Voted Redemption
description: The Rev. Henry J. Lyons received three votes of confidence at the annual meeting of the nation's largest predominantly black religious group, but still that wasn't enough. A group of dissident ministers who had fought among themselves in the past were united in their determination to oust him as president of the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A., Inc., which claims 8.5 million members.

title: I Scream. You Scream.
description: THIS otherwise harmless-appearing citizen has long harbored a diabolical fantasy. It is first to record that all-too-familiar ice-cream truck jingle permeating this city's streets, then to drive to Gracie Mansion in a souped-up sound truck and treat the Mayor to a few bars of what we lesser New Yorkers must endure interminably from April through October.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WOMEN ARTISTS

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: If you want to look into the heart of american art today, you are going to need a passport. You will have to pack your bags, leave the U.S.A. and find your way to Bilbao, a small, rusty city in the northeast corner of Spain. The trip is not convenient, and you should not expect to have much fun while you're there. This is Basque country. A region proudly, if not officially, independent from the rest of Spain, it is also bleakly free from Spanish sophistication. Oh, and by the way, you might get blown up. Basque country is not Bosnia. But it's not Disney World, either. History here has not been sanitized into a colorful spectacle for your viewing enjoyment. People are actually living history here, punctuated by periodic violence. Those who visit Bilbao, however, may come away thinking that art is not entirely remote from matters of life and death.

title: Weak Police Monitor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, MAXWELL M.
description: POWELL-Maxwell M. Four years ago was the saddest day of my life. Can you see our jewel? Susan

title: Karen Canavan, Howard Lapsley
description: Karen Lynn Canavan, a daughter of MaryBeth Canavan and M. Joseph Canavan of Wallingford, Conn., was married yesterday to Howard Lapsley, a son of Hope Whitney Lapsley and John Lapsley of Oyster Bay, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Beloin performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Battell Chapel at Yale University in New Haven.

title: Jean Shim And Daniel Yun
description: Dr. Jean Shim and Daniel Yun were married yesterday in Summit, N.J. The Rev. Susan A. Miller performed the ceremony at St. John's Lutheran Church.

title: Heroic Spaces and the Perfect Spoon
description: THE PUBLIC IS NOT ABOUT TO LOSE ITS TASTE FOR megaprojects. If architects don't provide them, space scientists, medical researchers or military tacticians certainly will. Two of the most highly touted will open this season: Frank Gehry's design for the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, opening in October, was hailed as a masterpiece even before the roof was on. In Los Angeles, the Getty Center by Richard Meier will open in December. Poles apart esthetically, the two buildings are heroic statements of their architects' convictions. The late Paul Rudolph was known for even more colossal megastructures. He will be remembered by a show opening Sept. 19 at the Urban Center.

title: Questions for: Alan Wilzig
description: As a fellow millionaire the same age as Mr. Wilzig, I read his comments with interest (Sunday: Questions for: Alan Wilzig, Aug. 17). When asked which is more attractive -- beauty or power -- he answered power, because it attracts beauty. I however have never found the beauty that money attracts very attractive.

title: Giants Size Up Barber's Playing Time
description: Maybe it's the name. ''Tiki'' sounds like someone who should be protected from 280-pound men eager for a collision. Maybe it's his height, which is a quarter-inch or so under 5 feet 10 inches. That can make Tiki Barber look elfin in a game of giants.

title: Make the Most of Late-Summer Plums
description: THE end of summertime, when I was growing up in England, was marked by the harvest of plums. There were many different kinds, among them small golden plums called Mirabelles, greengage (named for Sir Thomas Gage, who, upon receiving an unlabeled sapling of the Reine Claude plum sent from France, named it for himself) and purple Victoria plums. We ate them ripe and juicy straight from the tree. In their short season, they were also made into pies and crumbles, or sauces for game or pork.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOGAN, IRVING SMITH
description: KOGAN-Irving Smith, on September 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Arline. Adoring grandfather of Kenneth Scott Harris.

title: It's an Oriole Landslide, And Time to Concede
description: So, boss, is it O.K. to concede now?

title: OLLIE OOPS
description: When Tommy Tuccillo -- owner of Just for You, a stuffed-toy and flower delivery company in New York -- learned that one his main products, Ollie the Turtle, would appear in the movie ''Cop Land,'' he decided to cash in. In the film, an Ollie is pictured briefly in scenes involving Sylvester Stallone and Annabella Sciorra. In real life, Tuccillo ordered up 10,000 Ollies -- in sizes ranging from six inches to four feet, priced from $8 to $150 -- and arranged to sell them in Manhattan movie theaters. In realest life, it didn't work: Ollie's cameo just didn't electrify the masses. ''I guess kids aren't really seeing 'Cop Lan' and saying, 'Daddy, I want that!' '' says Tuccillo. Apparently not. Only one Ollie was sold opening night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERMAN, ALEX
description: BERMAN-Alex. August 14, 1921September 18, 1996. Unveiling at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, September 14 at 11 AM.

title: Film Maker Tied to Ocean, Any Ocean
description: BART FREUNDLICH misses the Atlantic Ocean. Every weekend, year-round from when he was 6 until he left to attend Northwestern University, his family drove from Manhattan to their house in Bridgehampton.

title: Plans to Expand Artist's Historic Farm Face Hurdles
description: 60 acres of rustic tranquillity on the Ridgefield-Wilton borderline and including the restored 19th-century home and studio of J. Alden Weir, the American Impressionist -- is experiencing growing pains.

title: And the Winner Is . . .
description: The Summer Olympics didn't come home to Greece for their centennial in 1996, but the International Olympic Committee decided Friday that they will return to Athens in 2004. The birthplace of the modern Olympics won over Rome, Cape Town, Stockholm and Buenos Aires.

title: Dorm Life 101
description: TWO weeks ago, the rooms looked pretty much the same: bare floors, bare walls, two beds, two chairs, two desks, a few bookshelves. Then the cars started pulling up outside Rutgers University's residence halls, unloading more than 13,000 undergraduates, along with their hopes, fears and boxes full of enough possessions to stock several big malls.

title: Fernandez Retires After Loss In Doubles
description: An upset, an end to one career and another player's unsuccessful bid to win four Grand Slam titles in a year -- all this was rolled into one in the women's doubles final at the United States Open yesterday.

title: A Mixed-Housing Program to Stabilize Urban Areas
description: OVER the last year neat clusters of mixed-income one- and two-family homes have sprouted in cities across New Jersey, thanks to the state's $240 million Urban Homeownership Program.

title: The Power of History
description: 1 Entering the Narrative: It wasn't much at first, a brief diversion rising from the ranked columns of the daily paper. The story concerned the 40th anniversary of a famous ballgame played in New York in 1951. I read the piece, sipping my morning coffee, and even remembered where I'd been, age 14, when the game's sky-high climax occurred. But the minute I finished reading, I forgot it all. There were other stories, other preoccupations, another day to confront beyond the breakfast reverie. The newspaper with its crowded pages and unfolding global reach permits us to be ruthless in our forgetting.

title: A Defense Lawyer Who's a Hit on TV
description: THE television in Michael (Mickey) Sherman's office in Stamford was tuned to Carroll O'Connor, once Archie Bunker, now the defendant in a defamation suit. Mr. Sherman would soon be on the air to discuss the ramifications of the upcoming verdict. (Mr. O'Connor ultimately prevailed.)

title: FILM
description: September

title: Programmed for Disaster
description: TRAPPED IN THE NET The Unanticipated Consequences of Computerization. By Gene I. Rochlin. 293 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $29.95.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Cunningham and the Freedom in Precision
description: AT AGE 78, Merce Cunningham continues to be a master of avant-garde choreography, with a new five-day series starting Oct. 14 at the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. He will present four premieres, including ''Scenario,'' which has costumes by Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garcons and music by Takehisa Kosugi, who has taken over the company's music direction from Mr. Cunningham's longtime collaborator, John Cage, who died in 1992. Mr. Cunningham created some of the new dances on Life Forms, a computer program designed for choreographers. The two dance programs will also recall his famous 90-minute Events with collages of his early works.

title: Guess Who?
description: CRYSTAL SCHIFFER was clad entirely in black except for the words on her T-shirt: Constantly Miserable. Jonathan Miller had shaggy hair, a tie-dyed shirt and shoelaces shockingly pink. Sitting on a curb outside Garden State Plaza last week, the couple enthusiastically explained why their high school classmates referred to them as freaks.

title: Quick Status: A 2-Wheeled Speedster Out of Italy
description: HERE is a riddle for the upwardly mobile: What desirable vehicle is handmade in Italy, is bright red, has a name that ends in ''i,'' has won multiple world championships, and is known for blazing performance and faultless handling?

title: Now, a White Backlash Against Rich Indians
description: FOXWOODS Casino, run by the Mashantucket Pequots of Connecticut, is the envy of Donald Trump and the place where many a paycheck goes to die.

title: Before, I Was a City Mouse. Now, I'm a Country Cousin
description: WHILE reading Bea Tusiani's Opinion essay, ''Suddenly, L. I. Is So Far Away'' (Aug. 31), I discovered that I was already composing an essay of my own, along similar lines. The difference, however, is that my move was west to east, from Manhattan (with a stop in Queens) to Long Island, Many of Ms. Tusiani's discoveries are corroborated by my own experiences. But I hadn't realized just how much my life had changed until I made a trip into Brooklyn last August.

title: Unable, Now, To Watch Out For the Block
description: UNTIL Jay Boland's death, few people on Beacon Street paused to consider that their block was really quite unusual.

title: 6The Heat Is Outside The Kitchen
description: David Bouley needs a return to basics following his protracted absence from the kitchen. Rosemary is an herb, not a spice.

title: Lisa Auerbach, John Schwallie
description: Lisa Auerbach, a daughter of Cynthia and Philip Auerbach of Fair Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to John Alan Schwallie, a son of Barbara and Harvey Schwallie of Wellfleet, Mass.

title: In China, Better Unread Than Read
description: WHEN will the news media stop reporting so much about celebrities, sex and violence, all that silly stuff none of us should want to read? Wouldn't everyone be better off with a more serious view of the world?

title: F.Y.I.
description: Push Here for Nothing

title: Twin Pique: Yin, Yang and You
description: PROCEEDINGS began last month in the criminal trial of 22-year-old Jeen (Gina) Han of El Cajon, Calif. She is charged with conspiring to murder her twin, Sunny Han, last year.

title: Enrollment Rise Adds Teachers And Classes
description: THE school year that opened last week unfolded like so many of its predecessors with a mixture of the familiar and the unfamiliar joined like newly paired kindergarten buddies.

title: Better Cooking Through Chemistry
description: While Harold McGee ponders the correlation between low levels of dairy intake and correspondingly low rates of osteoporosis, I find it dismaying that the Magazine features his recipes for thick cream and fresh cheese (''Better Cooking Through Chemistry,'' by Molly O'Neill, Aug. 17). Why not instead provide us with the nondairy, calcium-rich recipes for collard greens and hazelnut milk that seemed to excite McGee? You would be doing women a service by featuring some of the many alternative sources of calcium.

title: No More Bubble Gum: Jane Grows Up
description: YOU want to hate Jane Pratt. She's pretty. She's perky. She edited a magazine, had her own television talk show and landed a book deal -- all before age 29. Now, she's had the nerve to start a magazine and name it after herself.

title: In Westhampton Beach, Police Department Is Caught in Tempest Provoked by One of Its Own
description: The tiny police department that patrols this village of high-fashion boutiques and beachside tennis clubs used to be known for ticketing speeding limousines.

title: Cameras, Rules, First-Day Jitters (Even for Teachers)
description: ACROSS the state, floors are waxed, bulletin boards freshly decorated and familiar routines resume. Children are returning to school. But for kindergartners it is truly a big day.

title: Albanese Sees a City Divided
description: At a center for the elderly in Harlem the other day, Sal F. Albanese described himself once again as the embodiment of ''the New York experience'' -- a garment worker's son who rose to city councilman and mayoral candidate thanks in part to the city's long tradition of generous social support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VICINI, FELIPE J.
description: VICINI-Felipe J., of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, died September 5th at Memorial SloanKettering Hospital. He was President of the Vicini family sugar production company, CAEI, and its affiliates. He was the Dominican Special Envoy to the International Sugar Organization, as well as Dominican Special Envoy to various GATT negotiations and conferences. In the early 70's he served as Dominican Special Envoy to the Philippines for negotiations with President Marcos on international sugar policy. At that time he also appeared before a Special Committee of the U.S. Congress as his country's delegate to testify on international sugar policy matters, being highly praised by committee members as the most informed and persuasive foreign witness. He was also Founding Director of Banco Popular, the first and today largest private bank of the Dominican Republic, and he was Professor of Mathematics and Engineering at the Catholic University of Santiago, D.R. At his death he was a member of the Board of the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic. Felipe J. Vicini was born in New York City on May 4th, 1936. He was a graduate of Portsmouth Priory School and of M.I.T. Beloved brother of Laura Barletta, Juan B. and Jose M. and devoted uncle to Felipe, Amelia, Juan, Jose Leopoldo and Marco. Special service Saturday, September 6th, at 4 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell and Mass of Christian Burial Sunday, September 7th, in Santo Domingo.

title: Residential Resales
description: MANHATTAN

title: A 3-Way Shootout in the Paper-Clip Corral
description: FOR nearly a year, the office supply industry awaited the proposed merger of its two largest businesses, Office Depot Inc. and Staples Inc. The $4 billion deal would have created a giant with about 1,200 stores and $10 billion in annual revenue -- three times the size of Officemax Inc., the industry's third-largest business.

title: The Devil's Deal
description: THE COST OF LIVING

title: The Birds, the Bees and the Crabs
description: Horseshoe crabs are not endearing, but they are important, according to ''THE CRABS, THE BIRDS, THE BAY,'' an educational film produced by Natural Arts Films in Cape May. Commercial fishermen need the crabs for bait. Scientists use them (or at least a substance from their blood) to test the purity of medicines. And hundreds of thousands of migrating shorebirds rely on them to fuel their flights to the Arctic.

title: Seeking More Than Perceptions
description: To the Editor:

title: Moving Up in the Ranking
description: It has been a year of transition for the men in the Grand Slam singles events, with an unseeded finalist in each of the four main events: Carlos Moya at the Australian Open, Gustavo Kuerten at the French Open, Cedric Pioline at Wimbledon, and now Greg Rusedski.

title: Oedipus Sings, Senora Alba Smolders: A New Season Steps Onstage
description: HOW to handle a classic? Play with it, or keep it pure?

title: No Mere Distraction, but a Disorder
description: People who are habitually inattentive or who suffer odd lapses of concentration may want to see a neurologist or psychiatrist -- especially if these symptoms are bedeviling their lives. A record number of adults are being diagnosed with attention deficit disorder, a genetic illness that was once diagnosed primarily in school-age children.

title: Plans for Waterfront
description: As development grows along New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront, plans are being made to turn part of Weehawken's shoreline into a commercial and residential enclave built around an expanded ferry terminal.

title: Alys Reynders, Peter Creighton
description: Alys Ames Reynders, the daughter of Knowlton and Charlton Reynders Jr. of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Colcomb Creighton, a son of Hilary and Albert Creighton Jr. of Manchester, Mass. The Rev. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Nodding to the Past, Looking to Havana
description: MANY OF THE new season's most promising events in jazz trade on collective memory for their drawing power: Joe Henderson's ''Porgy and Bess'' album in October and concerts honoring past luminaries like Sidney Bechet, Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis and John Coltrane.

title: Tamara Heimarck, Eric Bentley Jr.
description: Tamara Val Heimarck, a visiting lecturer in Asian art at Duke University in Durham, N.C., and Eric Bentley Jr., a trial lawyer in the organized crime and racketeering section of the Justice Department in Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. Laurie J. Ferguson performed the ceremony at the Palisades (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Off-Duty Officer in Accident Is Found Dead Behind Wheel
description: An off-duty police officer was shot and killed by an unknown assailant yesterday morning shortly after his car plowed into the side of a livery cab, the police said.

title: Down by the Riverside
description: The New York Waterfront

title: Wendy Geneen and Marc Cohn
description: Wendy Michele Geneen, a daughter of Sheila and Harold Geneen of the Bronx, was married last evening to Marc Allan Cohn, a son of Marvin I. Cohn of Newington, Conn., and the late Myrna Baller Cohn. Rabbi Kenneth Stern performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: In Race Toward 2004, 2 Women Make Strides
description: It is hard to imagine a stuffier old-boy network than the International Olympic Committee. Its founder, the French baron Pierre de Coubertin, began the modern Olympic movement a century ago with the belief that women should lend their applause, not their athletic skills.

title: DANCE
description: September

title: A Medium at Its Best, When Not at Its Worst
description: Inside Westminster Abbey, television was not allowed to interfere with Diana's funeral yesterday. Only two networks had cameras inside (the BBC and ITV, supplying their feeds around the world), and they were forbidden to shoot close-ups of the mourners. On the American networks, the anchors and analysts stopped their chatter during the service, so that even the explosive eulogy of the Princess's brother, Earl Spencer, had to wait for its dissection. This muted approach was a startling contrast to the full week of jabbering that had preceded it, and it brought the coverage full circle. During the time between Diana's death and her funeral, television quickly moved from the best to the worst of what the medium can do, then back again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLTI, GEORG
description: SOLTI-Georg. Georg Solti, as Princess Di and Mother Teresa traversed all boundaries in bringing their love of their own individual unique mission to better our lives. My Carnegie Hall concert, Tuesday, April 7, 1998, an All Wagner concert will conclude with a section of my compositions in their tribute. Kenneth Lane Wagnerian Romantischer Heldentenor Lake Hiawatha, New Jersey

title: Elizabeth Tassone And Thomas Dale
description: Elizabeth Ann Tassone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald V. Tassone of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Denny Dale, the son of Madeline McWhinney Dale of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Dr. John D. Dale. The Rev. Richard G. Goss performed the ceremony at the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAINSWIT, GEORGE
description: SHAINSWIT-George, age 79, of Forest Hills, NY, died September 5 at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was one of the country's foremost chess masters. He is mourned by his beloved wife, Lisa of 54 years, his daughter, Carol of NYC, son, Joseph, daughter-in-law, Jane, and grandchildren Ashley and Gregory of Briarcliff Manor, NY. Also his brothers, Seymour of NYC and Bernard of Forest Hills, NY. Services today at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 66th Ave., Forest Hills, at 12:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, DONNA
description: GOLDBERGER - Donna. Helen and Larry Doppelt, and their children Pamela and Larry, Margery and Larry, Shelley and Jeff, extend heartfelt condolences to Marc and the children Michael, David and Erica, and to Selma and Seymour Goldberger, and to Mabel and Fred Faehner, and their children and grandchildren. Donna was loved by all and her untimely passing is a tragedy. She fought her illness with great courage. We have lost a beautiful person.

title: Prejudice Shows In Business Report
description: The article on Rolande Hodel $(''Book for Women Who Want to Buy From Other Women,'' Aug. 10$), who has started a listing of businesses in Westchester owned by women, really saddened me. I think the idea is great, but I was troubled by her obvious antagonism toward men.

title: A Matter of Taste
description: To the Editor:

title: Alyson Richman, Stephen Gordon
description: Alyson Michelle Richman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Richman of Nissequogue, N.Y., was married last evening to Stephen Joshua Gordon, a son of Marvin N. Gordon of New York and the late Ellen M. Gordon. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Putting Up Housing With A Built-In Sense of Community
description: STANDING on a small dock in the Esopus Creek watching his children swim in the sun-dappled water, Michael Sklaroff tried to explain why he and his wife, Gail, decided to leave Manhattan and join a cohousing community being built in Ulster County.

title: E.T., Give Up
description: If box-office receipts are any indication, the almond-eyed alien is becoming the smiley face of the 90's. But there may be fewer believers after last night's banquet at the 34th National U.F.O. Conference, held in Springfield, Ohio. The after-dinner speaker was James Moseley, a veteran U.F.O. researcher and skeptic whose tart lectures on the phenomenon have prompted some among the U.F.O. faithful to conclude that he's a Government agent.

title: Many More Seek Help for Panic Disorder
description: WHEN a New Hyde Park woman took her month-old daughter for a stroll in the carriage early in 1985, she felt her knees begin to buckle and the tree-lined street looked undefined and unreal. The dizziness and feeling of disorientation worsened after her second daughter was born in January 1986. Afraid to leave her home, or even take a shower without someone in the house, she consulted a psychologist, who diagnosed her problem as panic disorder.

title: Robert McNamara And the Ghosts Of Vietnam
description: I find it ironic that Robert McNamara goes to Vietnam to seek answers and forgiveness. For these, he should go to his own people, the people of the United States. But there's the rub. He faces a greater condemnation before us than before the former enemy who treats him with uncommon grace.

title: Discreet Charm That's Nestled in an Urban Canyon
description: THE wide crosstown streets abreast of Central Park have mostly been gobbled up by apartment development, so the survival of eight houses in a row on the north side of 79th Street from Park to Lexington Avenue is a peculiarity.

title: Laura Waldorf, Robert Griffen
description: Laura Denise Waldorf, a daughter of Mrs. Royall Victor 3d of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Berthold Howard Waldorf, was married yesterday to Robert Henry Goldsborough Griffen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde C. Griffen of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Jeffrey Walker performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Exploring Bach All Over Again, With the Help Of His Friends
description: ONCE UPON A TIME I thought I was going to be a concert cellist. For inspiration, I drove up to the Tanglewood Festival from Connecticut to hear Yo-Yo Ma play Bach's Fifth Suite, a piece that he has described as being about loss and resignation: ''the process you go through when you know you have to give up what's most precious.'' A better description could not be found for what I felt that evening as the contrast between his talent and my own became apparent. A few weeks later I changed my college major from music to Chinese and put my cello in storage.

title: Out of Obscurity and Unpredictability, a Steady Diet of Hits
description: THE VINEYARD THEATER may be the least well-known successful theater company in New York. And the artistic director, Douglas Aibel, is such a nice guy that he doesn't take offense when that's pointed out to him. In fact, he agrees. ''We ask ourselves why every day,'' he admitted.

title: A Maze Makes Sense From Above
description: LARRY'S PARTY

title: Denials of Racism
description: Three of the four women's doubles finalists took exception to implications from the family and entourage of Venus Williams that the animosity between Williams and other WTA Tour players is racial in nature.

title: Truth Into Fiction
description: WITH the publication of ''Deadly Deception'' this month, the novelist Jack Engelhard's only hope is that ''I'll become more of a J. D. Salinger than a Stephen King.''

title: The Jet-Set Pet
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 24 about smoking in films and on television referred incorrectly to Lucille Ball's character on the CBS series ''I Love Lucy.'' She was not shown smoking during her pregnancy; the photograph was from an earlier episode of the series.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is a temptation to rush to canonize your memory, there is no need to do so. You stand tall enough as a human being of unique qualities not to need to be seen as a saint.''

title: At Soaring Heights, a Lab in Learning
description: At 7:30 on Thursday morning, Jacqueline Quagliana was pacing inside her new fourth-grade classroom, obviously jittery, but unable to suppress a broad smile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LA ROZIERE, SONIA NEE RAOULDUVAL
description: de la ROZIERE-Sonia nee RaoulDuval. Dearly beloved mother of Arnold, Anne, Gael and Nathalie, died 30th August 1997 at home in Cuernavaca, Mexico.

title: Clear Night
description: Not long after the sun burns out, some five billion years from now, the galaxy we live in may collide, or intermingle catastrophically, with the Andromeda Galaxy (M31), 2.2 million light-years away. For now that galaxy remains pretty much where it has always been: a few degrees below and to the right of the conspicuous, W-shaped constellation called Cassiopeia, which lies halfway up the northeastern sky at bedtime this season of the year.

title: Where Are Brewster And Buffy?
description: THE United States Tennis Association is preparing to play Robin Hood, taking $31.4 million of its profits from the corporate shrimp-eaters in the luxury boxes and teaching the masses to play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, BROOKE EMMENS
description: GONZALEZ - Brooke Emmens. Cherished and beloved daughter of Diana and Peter William Gonzalez and adored sister of Peter Jr. died September 4, 1997 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Brooke, a freshman at Brown University, had attended the Spence School and graduated from Deerfield Academy. She was Vice President of her senior class at Deerfield and twice a member of the US International 420 Sailing Team, competing in the last two world championships. Her spirit, zest for life and compassionate heart will be sorely missed by all. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Brooke Emmens Gonzalez Memorial Fund at Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA 01342. Funeral arrangements to be announced.

title: Beyond Retailing: Westbury Mall Aims to Entertain
description: WITH the grand opening two days ago of the Source on a 38-acre site on Old Country Road, shoppers can experience what mall developers say is the newest approach to retailing: The 736,000-square-foot mall, which includes an existing 213,000-square-foot Fortunoff, has been designed to entertain.

title: A Show That Tweaks Ecological Concern
description: NOTWITHSTANDING its ill effects, the Industrial Revolution generated widespread optimism and, to judge from his 1844 masterpiece ''Rain, Steam and Speed,'' Turner was one painter who shared in it.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: INSIDE
description: Mourning for Mother Teresa

title: A Company Headquarters Planned for Flexibility
description: WHEN visitors first step inside the barnlike headquarters of SEI Investments in this Philadelphia suburb, they might conclude that the company has invented some kind of dairy for the information age. It looks as if they herded the cows out one day and rolled the workers and their desks in, attaching them to curling, brightly colored conduits that might have been milking-machine tubes.

title: Someone Is Always Coming to The Rescue
description: Even as they congratulated themselves on engineering the bailout of Mexico after the peso crisis a few years back, officials at the Treasury Department and the International Monetary Fund fretted about one clear shortcoming of the plan.

title: Grief on Demand
description: In 17th-century London, there were etiquette books on sale about how to behave at court, so dire was it to behave inappropriately in front of the monarch.

title: Don't Blame Toscanini
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Anxious Moments At Local Shopping Malls
description: ON A tepid December morning, a 74-year-old retired construction superintendent, his facial muscles taut and a look of intense concentration in his eyes, drove over the Whitestone Bridge.

title: Where Children Rule
description: I wanted to congratulate Nicholas D. Kristof for his article ''Where Children Rule'' (Aug. 17). I started primary school in Japan, came to the United States in the second grade and returned to Japan in the seventh grade. I personally never felt much difference in the level of academic content between the two systems. The emphasis definitely differed, and I learned more in the United States in some subjects and more in Japan in others. What I remember most vividly is the shock I felt when I saw a janitor, a grown man, cleaning up after us second graders for the first time.

title: Bradley Smith, 87, Champion Of the Rights of Photographers
description: Bradley Smith, a photographer for Life magazine and a founder of the American Society of Magazine Photographers, died on Aug. 28 at a nursing home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 87 and lived in La Jolla.

title: Recall Obesity Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MINTZER, WILLIAM LAND
description: MINTZER-William Land, 19441997. A Memorial Service will be at 7PM Thursday, September 11, 1997 at the Abbott Kaplan Theatre, Performing Arts Center, Purchase College, SUNY, Purchase, New York For additional information, call 914-251-6850.

title: LEONARDO, THE STUFF:
description: * This month, the Seattle Art Museum is restocking its store early to cash in on the October exhibition of Leonardo da Vinci's notebook, the Codex Leicester, purchased by Bill Gates for $30.8 million in 1994. * Peripheral merchandising at its most aggressive, the store will hawk ''Leonardo-related wares'' ranging from seashells ($1.50) to velvet shawls ($140). * Shells? Yep. He once asked, ''Why are there seashells on mountaintops?'' * ''Many people won't be struck by Leonardo's manuscript,'' says Christine Titus, the museum's retail-operations manager. ''But they can relate to seashells.'' * Other offerings: the Ooze Tube, a gel-filled cylinder ($7) and a $20 ''How to Fly Kit.'' * How would Leonardo take the hype? ''We have no idea,'' says Dakota Keene, a museum product developer. ''That frame of reference doesn't apply to his time.''

title: Chip Terry, Dellara Farmanfarmaian
description: Dr. Dellara Farmanfarmaian and Dr. Wyllys Terry were married yesterday in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John DeVelder performed the ceremony at the Princeton United Methodist Church.

title: Walls That Echo Of the Unspeakable
description: I AM ONLY ONE AMBIVALENT JEW among many in New York, the American city with the largest number of Jews, almost all of us with an opinion on how best to commemorate the Holocaust. So it is no wonder that only now will the city have its own Holocaust museum and memorial, a half century after the idea was first broached and several attempts were made. It will open on Sept. 15 in Robert Wagner Park, at the southern end of Battery Park City, bearing an appropriately complicated, ambivalent name: the Museum of Jewish Heritage -- a Living Memorial to the Holocaust.

title: A Violent Border Town Says 'Basta Ya' -- Enough
description: BLOODSHED is no stranger to Ciudad Juarez, the border city across the swirling Rio Grande from El Paso. For years, it has had a murder rate twice New York's, but authorities mostly shrugged off the carnage as long as it did not spill out of the shanty towns and victims could be dismissed as drug dealers.

title: Astronauts Fail to Locate A Puncture Crippling Mir
description: A six-hour spacewalk by Russian and American astronauts this morning was unable to locate the hole in the damaged Mir, dealing a major setback to efforts to repair the stricken space station.

title: Is There Room For Privacy On the Canvas?
description: TWENTY YEARS AGO, AT THE time of his first major retrospective, a reporter asked Robert Rauschenberg what it felt like to see so much of his old work brought together. ''The pain and the pleasure,'' he answered, ''come in about equal doses. A retrospective is a real obstacle. A retrospective can kill you.''

title: Rebuilding of 48th St. Ramp May Repeat Old Errors
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayoral Candidates Court Voters In Last Days of Muted Campaign
description: From a labor parade up Fifth Avenue to a campaign caravan across the five boroughs, the Democratic candidates for New York City mayor vigorously tried to court voters yesterday in the final weekend of a primary campaign that has turned into one of the least contentious and most muted Democratic mayoral contests in a generation.

title: Joanne Sternlieb And Michael Cohn
description: Joanne Ruth Sternlieb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Sternlieb of Lake Success, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Davis Cohn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Cohn of New York. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattlebaum performed the ceremony at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, ELIZABETH K. (FORMERLY ELIZABETH K. ATKINSON)
description: GOLDEN-Elizabeth K. (formerly Elizabeth K. Atkinson), 69, died September 2, 1997, and is survived by her husband Herbert L. Golden; her sons Peter, Matthew and Leeds Atkinson; her grandsons Eber and Revel Atkinson and her sisters, Bertha Cavagnaro and Marguerite Maly. She served many years at Friends Seminary as teacher, nurse and member of the schools committee of the 15th Street Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends. There will be a memorial service at the 15th Street Meeting House, between Second and Third Avenues in New York City, on Friday, September 26th at 6 pm. Friends, former associates and students are welcome. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Elizabeth Atkinson/Golden Fund, at Friends Seminary, 222 East 16th Street, New York, New York 10003.

title: Julie Goldstein and David Fine
description: Dr. Julie Goldstein, a daughter of Marilyn Goldstein and Rabbi Sidney Goldstein of Wynnewood, Pa., was married on Monday to David Fine, a son of Dr. Rebecca Fine and Roger Fine of Milltown, N.J. The bride's father officiated at the Brunswick Hilton in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: Hungry for Another Taste Of the Sports Limelight
description: THREE seasons ago, this remote city in the west central part of Mississippi was the object of an intense news media frenzy, caused by the presence of one Steve McNair.

title: Trying to Make a Living, and Make a Point, With a Buffalo Farm
description: It's unlikely the neighborhood diner has it on the menu, but some New Jersey restaurants serve bison, or American buffalo. It is a pretty sure bet, however, that the meat came from somewhere out West.

title: 1997 U.S. OPEN: A Phenomenal Final
description: As Venus Williams stood whooping with joy inside Arthur Ashe Stadium on Friday, it was clear to anyone within earshot that she was on her way to her first United States Open final.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: September

title: Claire Keller, Charles Calcagni
description: Claire Jeanette Frances Keller was married yesterday to Charles Lincoln Calcagni at the Snuff Mill of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Lisel Burns, a leader of the Brooklyn Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony.

title: A Play Was Born
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiny Italian Cafe Near an L.I.R.R. Station
description: SOMETIMES it seems as if Long Island is one big Italian restaurant. They open and close without creating even a ripple. Yet a tiny, modest, new entry, near the railroad station in Glen Head, has been drawing raves and crowds since it opened, and with good reason.

title: At P.S. 71, Reeboks and Baggies Give Way to Uniformity
description: For thousands of Bronx children, the first day of school Thursday was missing one element of chaos: the morning wrangle over what to wear.

title: Q. & A.
description: Evicting Business Tenants

title: Miss McCormack And Mr. Rogers
description: Kathleen Ann McCormack, an owner of AKA Reps, an agency in New York that represents photographers and illustrators, and Chris Rogers, a photographer represented by the agency, were married yesterday. The Rev. Norma Schmidt, a Lutheran minister, officiated at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: In Calcutta: Enduring, One Step at a Time
description: THE bodies stretched out on flimsy cots, close together and two rows deep. The air smelled of alcohol and excrement. The patients weren't patient. They banged their plates and screamed for water. The nuns weren't patient, either. They doled out rice with brusque efficiency, emptied bedpans and hustled off to their afternoon prayers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, MADELINE
description: COHN-Madeline. In her 99th year. Survived by sister-in-law Marion Cohn. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Interment was private on September 5, 1997, at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastingson-Hudson, NY.

title: Ernst C. Stiefel Dies at 89; Lawyer Fled Hitler
description: Ernst C. Stiefel, a German-born Jewish lawyer whose answer to Adolf Hitler was to become one of Germany's pre-eminent lawyers -- while practicing in New York -- died on Wednesday at a hospital in Baden-Baden. He was 89.

title: It's a God's Life
description: He enters through the ear, then picks your brain. Hermes, that is -- the ancient Greek god of thieves and the hero of the German novelist Sten Nadolny's comic fable THE GOD OF IMPERTINENCE (Viking, $23.95). Hermes has spent over 2,000 years chained to a volcano, put there by his half-sibling super-rival Hephaestus, god of the forge. Freed, he must learn the ways of a world in which Zeus has retired to play golf, ''Thou shalt not'' has become the prevailing Western ethic and Hephaestus -- now the daemon of industry and technology -- rules by default. Hermes ''borrows'' a few psyches. He soon detects a dearth of fun in the new regime and tries to loosen things up. But Hephaestus co-opts him. So Hermes challenges him to a poker game, winner take the world. As translated by Breon Mitchell, Nadolny's spoof of modern civilization doesn't take itself too seriously, and we shouldn't either. (Otherwise we might be irked by the disposable characters and a plot that suggests the random movements of protozoa.) Think of it as post-modernist beach reading: Apollo channel surfing, Hermes discovering french fries and the trickster god taming the dogs of war: ''He lifted his staff again, and the stubble-faced androids sank to their knees.'' Bill Christophersen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTINIAN, EDWARD
