He is survived by his loving wife Patricia Strzepek, his father Agisha, sisters Elizabeth Nahabedian and Julia Cox, nieces Paula Gordan, Lenora Cox, Johanna Cox and Elizabeth Bendschneider. Ed was a graduate of Brown University and Columbia Graduate School of Business. He was the founder and owner of Chatham House Publishers, Inc. He was a loving man who delighted in a good meal, savored the taste of fine wines, took pride in the books he produced and will be greatly missed by all who loved him. The funeral will be on Wednesday, 1 PM. For details, call Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 201-635-2428.

In that instant, some 40 local governments were consolidated into the world's second-largest city, a metropolis of 320 square miles and 3.4 million people.

This weekend, for instance, there emerged pictures of the Princess at the Ritz Hotel in Paris before her car crash, taken by a security camera: among the last views of her alive, their reproduction in newspapers and on television was justified as pertinent to the sobriety of the driver shown with her in several of the images.

But yesterday, Hilliard ended up in Jacksonville's Baptist Medical Center for observation and a magnetic resonance imaging test on his neck before flying home with the team.

She had a Chinese visa, but at the Shanghai Airport an official said she was trying to enter the country illegally. Without a hearing, or even being told what the problem was and given a chance to explain, she was strip-searched, handcuffed, held in jail and finally sent home.

The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, which is considering the request, needs to make sure that any such messages are not dangerously deceptive.

Mr. Harris was the Founder and Chairman of the Bernard C. Harris Publishing Company, Inc., a directory publisher with headquarters in White Plains, New York. They are an old team, slowly dying, living on the past, and other teams can't wait until they fall.

title: Taking Minimalism to the Maximum

It had a six-hour showcase at Tramps on Wednesday for the CMJ festival, and the deep-seated intellectual sheen on the musicians and the presentation transcended collegiate rock; it was more like graduate school rock.

description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and the auction of a one-year bill on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, LEWIS
description: STEINMAN-Lewis. On September 6, 1997, peacefully at Hartford Hospital, surrounded by his loving family, adored and adoring wife, Joan of 43 years; beloved sons Jeffrey, Peter and Robert; daughter-in-law Jody; and dear friends Robyn and Todd. Also survived by his much adored grandson Carlo; sister and brother-in-law Natalie and Milton Lewin; nephews, nieces, grandnephews and grandnieces; and very special motherin-law, Gracye Weisbrot. Services today, Monday, 11 AM, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83rd St, NYC. Contributions may be made to Congregation Rodeph Sholom or a charity of choice.

Where else, for example, can writing students learn their craft at the feet of luminaries like SHANA ALEXANDER, JULES FEIFFER, KURT VONNEGUT, BRUCE JAY FRIEDMAN, NORMAN LEAR and PETER MATTHIESSEN?

title: Nynex Is Gone, But Its Name Has Yet to Go
description: As a corporate moniker, Nynex was put out of existence with the simple stroke of a pen on Aug. 15, when lawyers for Bell Atlantic legally closed the $24 billion combination of the two big regional telephone companies. But rubbing away the Nynex brand name is a more complicated matter.

title: The Heights And Depths Of Stardom
description: Progressive rock always demanded that listeners use their imagination to let epic instrumental passages transport them to another place. The English group Catherine Wheel demanded the same thing in performance on Friday night at the Loeb Student Center of New York University, in more ways than one.

description: Throughout history, the renovations of major opera houses have usually been compelled by catastrophes like fires, floods or bombs. But in California, as Lotfi Mansouri, the general director of the San Francisco Opera, said recently, ''we don't have wars, we have earthquakes.''

title: Helms to Defend His Stand Against Hearing Over Weld
description: In the face of a direct challenge to his stewardship of the Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Jesse Helms plans this week to defend his refusal to grant a hearing on the nomination of William F. Weld as Ambassador to Mexico by arguing that other senators prevent hearings all the time.

title: 3 Big Utilities Join to Supply Large Users Nationwide
description: Three big utilities are forming an alliance to sell electricity, natural gas and energy management services to large national chain stores, restaurants and hotels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, BROOKE
description: GONZALEZ-Brooke. Our hearfelt condolences to Diana, Peter and Peter, Jr., on the tragic loss of their beloved Brooke. Her spirit and essence will remain with you forever. Our hearts are full of compassion and understanding. Zena, Michael and Jenny Wiener

title: Faulty Fuel Line Spills Oil
description: A broken fuel line at Schering-Plough, the pharmaceutical company, on Sunday spilled about 8,000 gallons of heating oil into the tank that regulates the company's sewage, The Associated Press reported.

title: Wimps in the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stand-In Plays His Role Superbly
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars' latest quarterback hero walked slowly to the post-game interview podium today, with dozens of reporters looking on. ''Now what do I do?'' Steve Matthews asked, sheepishly.

title: The National Enquirer cuts back on sensationalism, but is still haunted by its past.
description: ONE would think that Steve Coz would be feeling pretty good at this point. The 39-year-old editor of The National Enquirer has brought off a string of hard-news coups, from nailing O. J. Simpson's Bruno Magli shoes to uncovering Dick Morris's after-hours activities to helping bring off the arrest of Ennis Cosby's accused slayer, done with the classic tabloid technique of offering a reward. To cap it all off, Time magazine named the Harvard graduate one of the most influential people of 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, JACK
description: FRIEDMAN-Jack. The family of Sylvia and Harry Schaefer deeply mourn the loss of Sylvia's brother, Jack Friedman. We shall sorely miss him. Sylvia and Harry Schaefer Faith and Howard Drucker Jill and Ken Iscol Beth and Victor Sperber

title: Race for Borough President Grows Bitter As Candidates Trade Attacks in TV Debate
description: The Democratic candidates for Manhattan borough president have turned increasingly acrimonious in the last days before tomorrow's primary, with three of the six contenders in the hotly contested race turning their fire on one another.

title: Dollars for Scholars
description: A matter of unusual interest to the global republic of letters is now before Congress. The House has voted to chop Federal support for the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars from $5.8 million to $1 million, which would all but shut down this innovative Federal academy. The Senate is poised to approve an Interior budget, in which the center is a minuscule item, that would continue existing funding. Hence a conference committee is all but certain to have a final chance to stay the execution. We urge it to do so.

title: Acceptance Still Eludes Rural Gay Chinese
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Clinton Deserves 'Fast Track'
description: President Clinton begins an important battle with Congress this week for renewal of ''fast track'' authority, the right to submit trade agreements to Congress for a speedy vote without amendments. Without fast-track protection, countries will not negotiate trade accords with Washington for fear of endless revision. Not surprisingly, protectionist forces within both parties would be happy to block the no-amendment rule, even though every President over the past 20 years has used the rule to open up foreign markets and also bring down prices for American consumers.

title: Catholic School Teachers Poised to Go on Strike
description: Barring a last minute settlement, lay teachers at eight Roman Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese of Camden are scheduled to go on strike tomorrow.

title: An Idea Not Yet Born, But a Custody Fight
description: Everywhere Evan Brown goes, he brings with him, nestled in the gray matter of his brain, an asset his former employer demands: the record of what may be a multimillion-dollar software system that could update old, outdated computer software, making it usable on modern computer systems.

title: Puncturing The Myth Of the West
description: Wallace Stegner, who died in 1993, was a writer of the American West who scorned the triumphal narrative of the lean hero riding into the wilderness and bringing civilization with him. The characters in Stegner's novels ''The Big Rock Candy Mountain'' and ''Angle of Repose,'' which won a Pulitzer Prize in 1972, were often weak, tragic figures driven by flawed dreams for whom the conquest of the Western lands resulted in disaster.

title: Walking on Eggshells to a Better Earth
description: If anybody wants to bring back the reputation of educational television as a vehicle for delivering things worth knowing in a boring way, ''Planet Neighborhood'' is a start. The righteous subject of tonight's three-hour documentary is how to stop harming the environment, at home, at work and in the community at large. The program is recommended to people whose favorite reading matter is the small print on yogurt cups.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRIN, ANNE
description: GRIN-Anne. Creative sculptor and a woman of uncommon grace and goodness. We gather to celebrate her life at Temple Shalom, Richards Ave, Norwalk, CT, at 5 PM, Monday, September 8.

title: A Revolution in AIDS Drugs Excludes the Tiniest Patients
description: Jediyna Roche is missing the AIDS drug revolution, simply because she is a child.

description: When the Yankees' Paul O'Neill huffs after failed at-bats, the breezes are felt from New York to Nebraska, and sailboats founder in San Diego.

title: Dr. Martin Cherkasky, 85; Led Expansion of Montefiore
description: Dr. Martin Cherkasky, a renowned hospital administrator who in three decades at Montefiore Medical Center built it into a respected teaching institution, and who as a top adviser to Mayor Edward I. Koch oversaw changes to the city's Medical Examiner's office in the late 1980's, died at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan yesterday afternoon after a long illness. He was 85.

Watching their at-bats, Jones looks for weaknesses in their swings, for vulnerabilities to a certain pitch. Butch Huskey, he feels, is running out of flaws.

title: For the Ages: Martina and Venus
description: BACK home in eastern Switzerland, a horse named Tina is munching on hay and oats, probably unaware how much she changed history with one impetuous shrug last April.

title: Hurling Harsh Light Into Familiar Faces
description: From an 1875 Degas painting of a preoccupied aristocrat, to the era of Fellini's ''Dolce Vita,'' to the final images of Diana, Princess of Wales, candid pictures of the privileged and celebrated have remained objects of public fascination. The pleasure they offer comes, at least in part, from the privacy they violate.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KELL, YETTA
description: KELL-Yetta, the ''Great Lady,'' never forgotten, sorely missed by her children and all who knew her.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: At Race's End, Folly at Forum Is a Metaphor
description: IT took a hard heart indeed yesterday not to feel sympathy for the three leading Democrats running for mayor. Just when it looked as if the candidates might finally be able to break through and get a little attention, Eric Ruano-Melendez showed up.

title: A Young Lawyer and Her Fantasies
description: ''Ally McBeal'' has a heroine unlike any other on television. She is a bright, pretty and insecure lawyer, capable of losing a foolproof case one day and winning easily the next. She is all too likely to weep into her wine about an unavailable love, even though she knows better. She is realistically flawed and likable, tailor-made for countless accomplished young women to identify with.

title: Bills Batter O'Donnell And the Jets
description: The new, improved Jets and their new, improved offense were bashed repeatedly today by the Bills, those old pros from Buffalo who showed still one more time how it's done. And yet, in the closing seconds of a game in which quarterback Neil O'Donnell was sacked eight times, the Jets were still there, reeling but close, the 72,988 fans standing and imploring.

title: Arafat Has a Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrity Tennis
description: To the Editor:

title: Worldcom To Acquire Compuserve
description: Worldcom Inc. will acquire the Compuserve Corporation for nearly $1.2 billion in stock, and then sell the struggling on-line company's subscription service to America Online in a complex three-way deal, according to executives close to two of the three companies involved.

title: Abortion and Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKOWITZ, MITCHELL
description: MARKOWITZ-Mitchell. On September 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Ileen. Dear son-in-law of Judy and Ben Liss. Also survived by his sister Randi Glicksman. An inpirational healer to thousands of patinets lives his caring hands touched. Private family services.

title: Neighbors Oppose a Plan For an Auto Race Track
description: A proposal to build a $100 million auto race track around the Atlantic City Race Course is drawing opposition from some neighbors, who say they are concerned about noise and traffic congestion from the planned track.

title: Stocks Up in Japan
description: Stocks were trading higher at the Tokyo Stock Exchange today. At the end of the morning session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 84.20 points, or almost half a percent, at 18,734.37.

title: Pettitte Plans to Take Turn
description: Andy Pettitte sounded ecstatic and David Cone sounded cautious after the two injured Yankee pitchers lobbed a ball yesterday.

title: Wishing Away Bosnia
description: Prodded by the Clinton team, NATO has stepped up efforts to harass, if not arrest, Bosnian Serb thug-in-chief Radovan Karadzic. Bringing Karadzic to trial for war crimes is surely the right thing to do and I hope it happens soon.

title: Agencies to Merge On Long Island
description: Two Long Island agencies, Lowell/ Harrison/Leifer in Rockville Centre and Phillips Miller Speyer & Frost in Amityville, are merging to form Harrison Leifer Miller & Speyer. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Whitman's Re-election Race Faces Pocketbook Backlash
description: Despite a strong economy and a record of cutting taxes, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is battling for re-election against a little-known Democratic challenger who has put her on the defensive on the issue that is most important to New Jersey voters: auto insurance.

title: Heavy Hand of Beijing Dampens a Panama Canal Fest
description: As originally envisioned, the ''Universal Congress on the Panama Canal'' was to be a grand gathering of world leaders here to discuss the future of the vital waterway. But that was before Panama stumbled into the bitter dispute between China and Taiwan, prompting the incensed authorities in Beijing to undertake a two-year campaign to sabotage the event.

title: In Canada, Final Shot Is Sweet For Jones
description: Paired in today's final twosome, Steve Jones and Greg Norman battled to the final hole, and then to the final shot, on the last day of the Bell Canadian Open. For Jones, the ending was sweet. For Norman, it was another day when he was forced to settle for second place.

title: Our Celebrities, Ourselves
description: I just unearthed a yellowed copy of the tabloid Star that I had kept from June 1992, when it was published. From its crumbling cover, Diana, the Princess of Wales, in a diamond tiara, smiles radiantly beside headlines declaring that ''callous Charles'' drove her to ''six suicide tries,'' ''taunted her for being too fat,'' ''refused to give up his mistress'' and ''ridiculed her bulimia attacks.''

title: The Long-Term Low Profile Behind the Buzz at Glamour
description: There is no charity in the magazine business. Editors and publishers who do not make their numbers simply do not last long these days. So the fact that Ruth Whitney has entered her 30th year as editor in chief of Glamour has nothing to do with the kindness of Conde Nast Publications, which owns the magazine. The company has stuck with Ms. Whitney because what she does with Glamour still works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZUR, FRANK
description: MAZUR-Frank. Sculptor. Born 1910 in the Ukraine. Died September 3, 1997, in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Nancy, devoted brother of Yetta Rudin Steingart, deceased; loving uncle of Anita Handel, Jerome Rudin, Arnold and Nancy W. Mazur and Jay Mazur; adored great-uncle of Sharon, Ira and Lloyd Heimowitz, Michelle and Brad Romp and Scott and Sarah Mazur; cherished father to Marilyn and Albert Catasus, treasured grandfather to Elisabeth Catasus. Frank Mazur left a legacy of love and devotion to God, family, friends, and his art. He will be missed by all whose lives were touched by his genuine and generous spirit, but his art remains, a beacon to all those who believe in the struggle for freedom and in the spiritual life. Contributions to Boy's Town Jerusalem Foundation of America, 91 Fifth Ave, NY, NY 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHECKNOFF, RUTH (NEE ROSENBERG)
description: CHECKNOFF-Ruth (nee Rosenberg). On September 6, 1997, in Baltimore, MD. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Carl Checknoff. Loving mother of Barbara and Michael Checknoff. Devoted motherin-law of Rabbi Seth Riemer and Judith Stiefel. Beloved sister of Martin Rosenberg. Devoted daughter of Joseph Rosenberg and the late Esther (nee Riemer) Rosenberg. Loving grandmother of Calmen, Ezra, Haddasah Riemer, Flora Wolpert-Checknoff, and Simon Checknoff. Services were held at Temple Rodef Shalom, Falls Church, VA, on Sunday, September 7, at 4:30 PM. Interment Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY, on Monday, September 8, at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be directed c/o the Ruth Checknoff Memorial Fund, Temple Rodef Shalom, 2100 West Moreland St, Falls Church, VA 22043. For information contact Sol Levinson & Brothers Inc, Baltimore, MD (800) 338-1701.

title: Reversal: Rogers Is Hero While Torre Hears Boos
description: The surprisingly invigorated Yankee fans booed with Kenny Rogers on the mound in the sixth inning, which does not seem shocking. They usually lambaste him as much as any Yankee not named Hideki Irabu. But yesterday they were booing Joe Torre when he went to the mound. They wanted the manager to keep Rogers in against the Orioles.

title: A Fine Day for Royal Indy and Jerkens
description: On the day after his long-shot colt Fortitude won the Belmont Breeders' Cup Handicap, the trainer Allen Jerkens was out there at Belmont Park yesterday doing it again. This time, his filly Royal Indy outran some famous rivals, such as Runup the Colors and Pearl City, to win the Gazelle Handicap and carve a major role for herself in this season's championship circles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, EDITH
description: EPSTEIN-Edith. Age 82, on September 6, 1997. Wife of the late Walter. Devoted mother of Martin (Roberta). Loving grandmother of Wendy and Lauren. Sister of Joseph. Services today, 1 PM, at Forest Park Chapels, 76th Rd and Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Business is up, yet on-line services have image problems.
description: THE consumer marketers of cyberspace, led by America Online, have done an excellent job of attracting new customers, but they have an image problem, according to a new survey.

title: Retail Customers To Get Intel's New Chips First
description: When it introduces its newest generation of microprocessor chips on Monday, the Intel Corporation will be breaking with a long tradition in the computer industry by offering the fruits of its most advanced technology to retail customers shopping at outlets like CompUSA instead of to corporations like General Dynamics or Hewlett-Packard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATKINS, THOMAS T.
description: WATKINS-Thomas T. Music librarian, 79, died September 5, 1997, after a long illness. His ashes will be buried in Nesquahoning, PA, Protestant Cemetery in a private ceremony.

title: Saturn Mission's Use of Plutonium Fuel Provokes Warnings of Danger
description: Alan M. Kohn was the emergency-preparedness operations officer at the Kennedy Space Center when the Galileo spacecraft was launched in 1989 to study Jupiter and when the Ulysses craft was lofted in 1990 to collect information on the Sun.

title: Many Tenants Are Struggling To Pay Rent
description: Caught between rising rents and subsistence wages, more renters in New York State are unable to afford their apartments than in any other state in the country, according to a national study.

title: Leon Edel, 89, Prize-Winning Biographer of Henry James, Dies
description: Leon Edel, the biographer whose writing on Henry James won a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award, died on Friday in Honolulu. He was 89 and lived in Honolulu.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCROFT, HANNAH
description: GLUCROFT-Hannah, on August 31, 1997. Devoted mother of Chester and Phyllis and Lita G. and Morton Schloss. Loving grandmother of Alexander J. Schloss, Douglas S. Glucroft, Barbara Schloss-Weinberg and Leah H. Teitel. Cherished great-grandmother of Stacy, Henry, Benjamin, Emily, Julian, Rona, Meredith, Karene, Michael and David.

title: Accused Officers Barred From Duty, but With Pay
description: Four New York City police officers who were suspended without pay last month after they were arrested and charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in Brooklyn will not be allowed to return to duty, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday.

title: New York's Darkened Courts
description: The New York State Legislature served the public and the cause of justice poorly by letting New York's successful 10-year-old experiment with television cameras in the courtroom lapse on June 30 -- and then adjourning without approving legislation to let cameras back in. Ending the camera blackout should be an early order of business when lawmakers reconvene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROCOLL, EDWIN JOHN, SR.
description: CROCOLL-Edwin John, Sr. September 6, 1997. Beloved husband Helen Sipple Crocoll. Cherished father of Edwin J., Jr. and Louise C. Loving brother of the late John W. Crocoll. Friends may call Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral Wednesday, September 10, at 10:30 AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Long Island.

title: Mobutu Sese Seko, Zairian Ruler, Is Dead in Exile in Morocco at 66
description: Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's longtime dictator and the last of a generation of cold war rulers who grew fabulously rich by providing a bulwark against Communism, died in exile yesterday in Rabat, Morocco, after a long battle with prostate cancer. He was 66 years old.

title: This City Won't Need Another Party for 850 Years
description: An angry, flame-spitting mechanical dragon rumbled across Red Square, as the former seat of Soviet power was transformed into a stage for a glitzy, nationalist extravaganza.

title: Teachers Prepare to Strike
description: Barring a last-minute settlement, lay teachers at eight Roman Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese of Camden are scheduled to go on strike tomorrow over a salary dispute.

title: Battalions of Cleaning Crews Descend on Subway Stations To Fight Battle of the Gunk
description: The field officers gather each dawn in a dingy Brooklyn garage to review the previous night's skirmishes, enumerating every sticky encounter in their timeless underground war.

title: People
description: * Jeanine Moss was named to the new position of vice president for marketing communications and promotion at the Magazine Publishers of America, New York. She had been vice president for communications and leisure marketing at the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. Also, Bill Hogue, vice president for promotion and sales development at the association, was promoted to the new position of vice president for creative marketing, overseeing the expansion of the Kelly Awards.

title: Veteran Links Prison Camp Terror to Slaying
description: For 50 years, Richard Keech tried to forget his ghosts.

title: Flower Power
description: Tempests have their origins some distance from where they come crashing down, and so did the applause in Westminster Abbey on Saturday for Earl Spencer's powerful eulogy to his sister, Diana, Princess of Wales, and its rebuke of the royal family.

title: Good Exercise, Nice People and a Fast Lesson in Architecture
description: Newcomers to New York are often struck by the city's absurdly fast pace, but one pack of young people weaving through crowds on Fifth Avenue yesterday barely noticed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIFKIN, MITCHELL
description: RIFKIN-Mitchell. The Seawane Club records with sorrow the loss of our beloved member Mitchell Rifkin. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Rose and family. Robert Roman, President

title: Some large clients including Mastercard and Aamco settle on agencies for their accounts.
description: SEVERAL big national advertisers made decisions late last week on accounts with total billings estimated at $125 million to $135 million.

title: Hollywood Exotica With Electronic Blips
description: Amid the ceaseless recombinations of pop genres, Sukia has come up with an improbable one: applying the sampling and repetition of electronica to the hipster artifacts of lounge music, with an overlay of self-help motivational tapes. The results -- electro-lounge? -- induced dancing and laughter when Sukia performed on Friday night at the Greatest Bar on Earth, atop the World Trade Center, as part of the CMJ Music Marathon.

title: INSIDE
description: Saturn Mission Warning

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, WALKER S. SGT. NYPD
description: FITZGERALD-Walker S. Sgt. NYPD, of Pelham Manor, NY on September 6, 1997. Son of Lona and Edmund Fitzgerald, Jr. Brother of Edmund III, Patrick and John. Grandson of Richard and Joan Warnimont and the late Edmund Fitzgerald and Katherine McVeigh Fitzgerald. Nephew of Brian. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Monday and Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Mary's Church, S. Broadway, Yonkers on Wednesday, September 10, 10 AM.

title: White House Said to Specify 3 Demands in Tobacco Deal
description: Two cigarette industry representatives say the White House told them last week that three crucial concessions must be made in the proposed $368.5 billion tobacco settlement to win President Clinton's approval.

title: The Learning Curve Effect, Both at Home and on the Road
description: This beautiful, sunny afternoon began with teal and white balloons floating over Alltel Stadium in celebration of Jacksonville's home opener. The day ended with the bursting of the Giants' blue balloon, so high and bright a week ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREMNITZER, ERNEST G.
description: KREMNITZER-Ernest G. On September 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Zita. Cherished father of Sandra C. Mintz. Loving grandfather of Jeremy, Julia and Laura. Dear brother of Ruth Whyte. Services Monday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, WOLFE
description: COHEN-Wolfe. Temple Shaaray Tefila records his death with profound sorrow. His long life was a blessing to his family and we wish them all our heartfelt condolences. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum Dr. Ellen Saxl, President

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: In Their Own Words
description: SAL F. ALBANESE

title: Calls Via the Internet, But in Low Fidelity
description: The great telephone trade-off has arrived.

title: In Primary Debate Slugfest, Democrats Slug Only Giuliani
description: In a mini-marathon of debates that gave them more television exposure in seven hours than they had enjoyed on any other day in this race, the Democratic mayoral candidates repeatedly declined yesterday to draw contrasts between their credentials and ideologies, instead saving their attacks for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Chronicle
description: ROBERT ABRAMS, the former New York attorney general, and Senator JOSEPH I. LIEBERMAN, Democrat of Connecticut, have long had a friendship and mutual admiration society. So the Senator seemed an ideal choice to deliver the inaugural talk in the new Attorney General Robert Abrams Public Service Lecture Series at New York University School of Law. He will speak this evening at the law school's Vanderbilt Hall.

title: Hingis Quickly Defeats Williams for a 3d Title
description: With her teeth bared in the Cheshire cat smile that never seems to leave her face for long, Martina Hingis captured her third Grand Slam title of 1997 with impunity yesterday by routing the event's celebrated ingenue, Venus Williams, for the United States Open championship.

title: Race Track Plan Protested
description: A proposal to build a $100 million auto race track adjacent to the Atlantic City Race Course in Hamilton Township is drawing opposition from residents of a nearby condominium complex who are concerned about possible noise and congestion from the planned track.

title: Driver Is Sought Who May Have Tried to Slow Diana's Car Before Crash, Lawyers Say
description: Investigators are searching for the driver of a car they believe might have been trying to slow down the Mercedes carrying Diana, Princess of Wales, last Sunday morning so photographers pursuing on motorcycles could get a shot of her through the window, lawyers involved with the case said today.

title: Enemies Share a Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Blame Netanyahu
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, HILDA
description: STERN-Hilda. Young israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Hilda Stern. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TONDEL, LYMAN M. JR.
description: TONDEL-Lyman M. Jr. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, September 9, 1997, 11:00 AM, at Grace Episcopal Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Giants Take Step in Wrong Direction
description: On this afternoon, the new-look Giants looked familiar. There were passes to nowhere and passes dropped. There were fumbles at pivotal times and mental lapses. There were penalties and poor blocking. Poor tackling. Poor judgment. Poor conduct.

title: Contemporary Styles for Flamenco's Ancient Passion
description: Nine years after their first album of pop-flamenco hits that conquered the world, the Gipsy Kings are looking for renewed brain-wave dominance: in the streets, in parties, on beaches, in bars and casinos and especially in dining rooms. Not long after their debut album gained a stranglehold over the sound systems of Spanish restaurants, they added ''Volare,'' classic Italian-restaurant fare, to their repertory. And on their new album, ''Compas'' (Nonesuch) they've gingerly branched out in further directions, adding a dash of Brazilian music, salsa and -- one eye still trained on the trattoria market -- ''Funiculi Funicula.''

title: To Palestinians Without Hope, Peace Is a Mirage
description: To the Editor:

title: For Some Football Fans, A Web Link Is a Must
description: Paul Allen, the other Microsoft tycoon, was not content to just watch the National Football League team he owns, the Seattle Seahawks, be trounced by the New York Jets on Aug. 31 at the Seattle Kingdome. He sat in his skybox with one eye on the game and the other on the screen of a laptop computer propped on a shelf before him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, BROOKE EMMENS
description: GONZALEZ - Brooke Emmens. Cherished and beloved daughter of Diana and Peter William Gonzalez and adored sister of Peter Jr. died September 4, 1997 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Brooke, a freshman at Brown University, had attended the Spence School and graduated from Deerfield Academy. She was Vice President of her senior class at Deerfield and twice a member of the US International 420 Sailing Team, competing in the last two world championships. Her spirit, zest for life and compassionate heart will be sorely missed by all. Memorial services Thursday, September 11, at 4 PM, at St. Thomas More Church, NYC, and Saturday, September 13 at 11 AM, American Yacht Club, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Brooke Emmens Gonzalez Memorial Fund at Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA 01342.

title: At 37 Kiosks, City Hall at Your Fingertips
description: A change in the way New Yorkers deal with their city's notorious bureaucracy has been quietly spreading across the five boroughs, in government buildings and libraries, grocery stores and check-cashing outlets.

title: The Toe Squeeze
description: Farewell to comfort. Fashion's flirtation with square-toed, chunky-heeled shoes is over, replaced by an affection for pointy toes and spindly heels. Smart women will choose lower heels for every day, reserving stilettos (if they wear them at all) for special occasions. And try a larger size to ease their toes.

title: Q&A
description: Peanuts, Friend or Foe

title: Millions of Dollars Pouring In To Diana's Favorite Charities
description: Along with the outpouring of grief and affection, the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, has set off a cascade of contributions to charity in her name, totaling tens of millions of dollars. It is on course to become one of the largest charities in Britain.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about problems with monitoring lunchrooms in the New York City public schools misidentified the woman shown on cafeteria duty at Intermediate School 145 in Jackson Heights, Queens. She was Carol Segal, a home economics teacher, not Nancy Dumitriescu, a lunchroom aide.

title: HARCOURT TO BUY 18% OF STECK-VAUGHN FOR $42.8 MILLION
description: Harcourt General Inc. said it would acquire the 18 percent of the Steck-Vaughn Publishing Corporation that it did not already own for $42.8 million in cash. Harcourt said it would pay $14.75 a share for Steck-Vaughn's 3.4 million shares and stock options outstanding. That values the total purchase at $42.8 million because the options of Steck-Vaughn, a publisher of educational books and software based in Austin, Tex., have various exercise prices, a Harcourt spokesman, Peter Farwell, said. Harcourt, based in Chestnut Hill, Mass., a publisher of educational books and operator of Neiman Marcus department stores, originally acquired 82 percent of Steck-Vaughn when it bought the National Education Corporation in June, for $800 million.

title: Jets' Loss Simply Put: They Were Outclassed
description: Sometimes, the better team wins.

title: Just Bidness, Charlie
description: GUIDE TO SPORTS

title: Hong Kong's Leader Heads for U.S. to Correct 'Misconceptions'
description: Tung Chee-hwa, the man chosen by Beijing to run Hong Kong, left today for his first visit to the United States since Britain returned this territory to Chinese control on July 1. He said the visit was intended to correct American ''misconceptions'' about Hong Kong.

title: Derek Taylor, Beatles' Spokesman, Dies at 65
description: Derek Taylor, a publicity spokesman for the Beatles, the Byrds, the Beach Boys and other groups in the 1960's, and the author of several books that captured the spirit of the era, died on Sunday at his home near Sudbury, in Suffolk, England. He was 65.

title: Warming Could Bring Some Cold Surprises
description: THE big wild card in the game of climate change is the possibility of unwelcome surprises that would suddenly occur if some threshold of warming caused the climate system to shift to a new state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, JERRY C., M.D.
description: JACOBS-Jerry C., M.D. ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Jerry Jacobs. Dr. Jacobs was a renowned authority on juvenile rheumatoid arthritis and epitomized commitment to and care for children. A worldwide lecturer, he frequently spoke on diseases of the connective tissue in children and on pediatric rheumatoid arthritis. An author, he wrote the definitive textbook, ''Pediatric Rheumatology for the Practitioner.'' A leader and teacher, he was Professor of Clinical Pediatrics at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons; Attending Physician and Head of Pediatric Rheumatology at Babies & Children's Hospital; Pediatrician-in-Chief at the Edward Daniels Faulkner Arthritis Clinic of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center; and Center Director of the Regional Arthritis Program for Children (RAP for Kids). His commitment to improving the lives of children was unsurpassed, his work as a scholar and clinician was brilliant and his research was invaluable to the world's understanding of pediatric rheumatology. We will treasure his memory and work, and we will deeply miss his presence. William T. Speck, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, The Presbyterian Hospital Herbert Pardes, MD V.P. for Health Sciences and Dean, Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROCOLL, EDWIN JOHN, SR.
description: CROCOLL-Edwin John, Sr. September 6, 1997. Beloved husband Helen Sipple Crocoll. Cherished father of Edwin J., Jr. and Louise C. Loving brother of the late John W. Crocoll. Friends may call Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral Wednesday, September 10, at 10:30 AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, MARY B.
description: MATTHEWS-Mary B. Sept. 7, 1997, in Rochester, NY, age 95, survived by two sons, Paul C. and wife Vera, of Setauket, NY, Richard L. Matthews and wife Marjorie, of Rochester, NY, daughter Nancy M. Warrington, of Port Orange, FL, fourteen grandchildren, thirty great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, those wishing may give to the charity of their choice.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about Ruth W. Messinger, a Democratic mayoral candidate, who was shown outside a Brooklyn school discussing vercrowding, misidentified the school. It was Public School 249 in Flatbush, not Public School 286 in Sheepshead Bay.

title: Guard Is Charged in Fire
description: Two days after a fire at the Bergen Pines Hospital in Paramus forced the evacuation of 150 elderly patients, a security guard at the hospital was charged with setting the blaze, officials said.

title: $2.2 Billion Bailout For South Korean Banks
description: The Bank of Korea said yesterday that it would inject two trillion won ($2.2 billion) into the ailing Korea First Bank and other banks to help increase liquidity. The central bank put one trillion won into Korea First yesterday in a one-year special loan with a below-market rate of 8 percent. It is the fourth such bailout in the history of the central bank.

title: Disputed commercial wins a TV award as quarrel is resolved.
description: A CONTENTIOUS dispute over presenting the Emmy Awards for television commercials has ended with the initial prize being presented to a spot that also came under fire.

title: Fashion's Affair With the Paparazzi
description: Before they begin designing each season, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana go through a book of 1950's paparazzi photos for inspiration. And many advertising campaigns for their company have been based on those sorts of images, like the one called ''La Dolce Vita,'' shot by Steven Meisel in 1992. Yet, when the designers are on vacation in Sardinia, where they are celebrities, they are often pestered by paparazzi.

title: After Mets Lose Duel, The Bottom Falls Out
description: Ten times Jason Isringhausen fired away, needing only a single strike to extricate himself from what had been a bases-loaded, no-out jam in a tied game.

title: CSX and Others Ordered to Pay Billions in '87 Rail Chemical Fire
description: A unit of the CSX Corporation said yesterday that a jury had ordered it to pay $2.5 billion in punitive damages stemming from a railroad-car fire in New Orleans 10 years ago.

title: Pilot Regents Math Test: So Tough That Few Pass It
description: In a strong sign of how difficult it will be to raise academic standards in New York, slightly more than 80 percent of the high school students who took a tougher, experimental version of the math Regents exam failed, according to a report released today by state education officials.

title: New Allegations of Abuse For Officer in Torture Case
description: A Brooklyn man has made new allegations of police abuse against Justin A. Volpe, the police officer charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in the bathroom of the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn last month.

title: Haitians in Brooklyn Turn To the Radio for Comfort
description: It was shortly after 9 yesterday morning when Ricot Dupuy of Radio Soleil d'Haiti in Brooklyn fielded a call that a ferry had capsized off the coast of Haiti and that hundreds may have drowned in deep water.

title: For Many Women, Gazing at Diana Was Gazing Within
description: I WAS surprised by my response to the death of Diana, Princess of Wales. I had not expected to feel such a raw edge of grief for this woman I did not know and whose life I had not particularly followed.

title: It's Push Comes to Penalty For Giants
description: Much has been made of the youth on the Giants' roster, but it was some of the team's most experienced players who let the Jacksonville Jaguars goad them into penalties and petty skirmishes after the whistle Sunday.

title: For Queens, Tennis Center Is an Intrusion
description: To the Editor:

title: The Surplus Gun Invasion
description: Gun dealers, with the enthusiastic support of the National Rifle Association, are once again trying to sneak though Congress a measure that could put 2.5 million more rifles and pistols onto American streets and provide a handsome subsidy for weapons importers and a few foreign governments. This bill, introduced with disgraceful stealth, should be pounced on by the Clinton Administration and all in Congress who are concerned about crime.

title: Senior Republicans Stop Bloc Trying to Soften Budget Deal
description: With senior Republicans leading the way, the House this evening rejected a series of moves by a bloc of junior Republicans who were trying to weaken last month's balanced-budget agreement in protest against concessions by the party's leadership.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's like a New York City worker who works 24 hours a day, and it's more friendly. There's no attitude.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYBERGER, BERNARD
description: MAYBERGER - Bernard. We grieve for our Bernie, dear friend and tennis partner. We extend our sincere condolences to Pauline, Tina and Marty and the family. Al Berger Bob Lee Joel Mesznik Art Rinari

title: Not-So-Dangerous Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Prices Rise a Bit After Last Week's Selloff
description: Treasury securities were higher yesterday, with selling on advances limiting the session's gains. Activity was thin, so movement was exaggerated. Many market participants came into the session believing that last week's selloff was a bit overdone.

title: Yearning for Southern California, 1965
description: Sean O'Hagan sang his artistic manifesto when his band, the High Llamas, performed on Thursday night at the Knitting Factory in a CMJ Music Marathon show. With wistful delicacy, he urged, ''Let's rebuild the past, 'cause the future won't last.'' The past he seeks has a specific time and place: Southern California circa 1965-66, when Brian Wilson was creating the Beach Boys' ground-breaking album ''Pet Sounds.''

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ALLEGATIONS OF ABUSE -- A Brooklyn man has made new allegations of police abuse against one of the officers charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in custody. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBER, ANNE M. (NEE SULLIVAN)
description: WERBER-Anne M. (nee Sullivan), of Great Neck, NY died peacefully at home September 7, 1997 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Frank. Devoted mother of Frank Jr., Robert, John and Andrew. Dear sister of Clare Kavanagh. Loving grandmother of Nicholas, Elizabeth and William. Sisterinlaw of Isabel Sue Werber, Florence M. Werber,and Raymond E. Kavanagh. Visitation at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Monday 79PM; Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:45 A.M., St. Aloysius Church, Great Neck. Burial at All Saints Cemetery, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Pathfinder Village for Down Syndrome Children, R.R. #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, BROOKE EMMENS
description: GONZALEZ - Brooke Emmens. Cherished and beloved daughter of Diana and Peter William Gonzalez and adored sister of Peter Jr. died September 4, 1997 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Brooke, a freshman at Brown University, had attended the Spence School and graduated from Deerfield Academy. She was Vice President of her senior class at Deerfield and twice a member of the US International 420 Sailing Team, competing in the last two world championships. Her spirit, zest for life and compassionate heart will be deeply missed by all. Memorial services Thursday, September 11, at 4 PM, at St. Thomas More Church, NYC, and Saturday, September 13 at 11 AM, American Yacht Club, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Brooke Emmens Gonzalez Memorial Fund at Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA 01342.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLB, LIBBY
description: KOLB-Libby. The Aderet Chapter of EMUNAH of America and its national officers mourn the tragic passing of Libby Kolb, age 37, past Chapter President. With her magnetism, talents and vision, she built EMUNAH in Teaneck on behalf of Israel's children. She will be missed by everyone she touched. Our sincerest condolences to Eli, Miriam, Moshe, Yitzie, Yaacov and her sisters Shelly and Judy. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rhonda Avner, Rochel Feld, Janis Klein Aderet Chapter Presidium Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld, Nat'l Pres.

title: In Salmon War, a New Broadside as British Columbia Sues the U.S.
description: The salmon season may be just about over, but the war of words over fishing rights along the Pacific coast grew louder today when Canadian officials sued the United States for violating a salmon treaty.

title: 2 High News Posts Filled by The Times
description: Appointments to two senior news positions have been announced by The New York Times.

title: Two Lawyers For Paula Jones Want to Withdraw from Case
description: In the latest evidence of discord in the group advising Paula Jones on her sexual harassment suit against President Clinton, her two main lawyers asked a Federal judge today to allow them to withdraw from the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, LAURA
description: MARGOLIS-Laura. The Officers, Board and Staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JdC), deeply mourn the passing of one of the outstanding figures in JDC history, who was involved in the rescue and relief of thousands of Jews fleeing Nazi persecution. A true Woman of Valor, she directed JDC's humanitarian programs in Cuba, Shanghai, Portugal, Spain & Sweden before and during W.W. II. Her courage, daring and resourcefulness made her a legend. Afterwards, she directed JDC Services in France, later settling in Israel and helping forge JDC's Malben Homes For The Aged, into a model of services for the elderly. A giant has passed on. Funeral sevices were private. We express our condolences to her nephews: Donald l. Margolis of Teaneck, NJ and James A. Margolis of Brookline, Massachusetts. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Milton A. Wolf, Chairman Michael Schneider, Executive VP Ralph I. Goldman, Hon. Exec VP

title: More Than 300 Feared Lost on Haiti Ferry
description: An overcrowded ferry overturned yards off Haiti's central coast early today, apparently after a panic among passengers. More than 300 people are estimated to have made their way ashore, but an even larger number are believed to be missing and are feared dead.

title: At 18, the 'Squirt TV' Guy Resumes His Pop-Scene Assault
description: At 14, Jake Fogelnest started his own public-access television show in Manhattan. At 16, he was the host of his own talk show on MTV. At 17, he was unemployed and in a drug rehabilitation clinic. Now, at 18, he is back, rebuilding his career as a radio host, producer, musician, record executive, comedian and more. In just four years, Jake Fogelnest has completed a career cycle that typically spans a lifetime. And he still lives with his mother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHONE, MARTIN
description: PHONE-Martin. Born March 3, 1914-July 11, 1997. Beloved father, brother, Uncle.

title: In Their Own Words
description: SAL F. ALBANESE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUDNER, FAY B. KUHN
description: STUDNER-Fay B. Kuhn. Passed away peacefully on September 8, 1997 at the wonderful age of 99. She was the widow of Peter R. Kuhn and David Studner. Beloved mother of Edwina K. Scharff of Kennebunkport, ME and Nancy K. Piccioni of Eugene, OR. Devoted grandmother of Peter B. Scharff of Ossining, Stuart M. Scharff of Northampton, N.H., Cristina Evonuk and David Piccioni of Eugene, OR. Beloved great grandmother of Rachel K., Christopher, Emily and Jennifer Scharff. Services will be held at Temple Israel, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd, New Rochelle, Wednesday, 11AM. Information George T. Davis Funeral Home, 914-632-0324.

title: CABOT OIL TO SELL RESERVES TO LOMAK FOR $92.5 MILLION
description: The Cabot Oil and Gas Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell oil reserves and land in northwest Pennsylvania for $92.5 million to Lomak Petroleum Inc. Cabot Oil, an independent natural gas producer based in Houston, said the sale included 912 wells producing 15 million cubic feet of oil equivalent a day. It said it would use part of the proceeds to finance its $44 million acquisition of an interest in 65 wells in the Rocky Mountains. Its shares fell $1, to $22.6875.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER

title: Pitfalls of a Triple-Threat Machine
description: THE idea seems intriguing: Build a fax machine around a computer printer and scanner. You get a copier in the bargain, and it all fits into a single unit not much bigger than a typical printer or fax machine. Not only do you save money and precious desktop space, you eliminate extra cables, not to mention the thermal paper that produces the unwieldy scrolls and curly pages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLTI, GEORG
description: SOLTI-Georg. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of our esteemed colleague Georg Solti. One of music's giants, Sir Georg was to conduct the MET Orchestra this Spring, and we profoundly regret that this renewal of his relationship with our company will not come to pass. But, we remember with deep gratitude, his incalculable contributions to music through his numerous associations with the world's great orchestras and opera companies, most notably the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and the Royal Opera at Covent Garden. And, his immense discography will provide a vibrant legacy for future generations. We shall miss him greatly, and extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAFTALIN, RUTH YOFFEY
description: NAFTALIN-Ruth Yoffey, on September 5, 1997. Wife of the late Dr. Moses Naftalin. Mother of Alixandra and Peter Kolbe. Grandmother of Seth and Deena Binus, Ari Binus, and Yoni Binus, and 3 step-grandchildren. Special aunt to Micah and Beth Naftalin and Adelle Lohman, and survived by her extended family. Donations to Maimonides School, Philbrick Rd., Brookline, MA 02146, or to Stony Brook Hebrew Congregation, C/O George Pressman, 5 Whitmore Lane, Coram, New York 11727.

title: Chess
description: The United States Cadet Championship, an invitational competition for the top eight players under 16, was won by Justin Sarkar of Scarsdale, N.Y., on July 13 in Nashville. Sarkar, 15, compiled a 5-2 score.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, FLORENCE
description: SLATER-Florence. Age 83, on September 7, 1997. Beloved wife of the late N.G. Slater. Devoted mother of Alan and Robert and loving grandmother to Justin, Noel and Clark. We will miss you.

title: New York's Highest Court Observes Its 150th Year
description: The Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, observed its 150th anniversary today, dogged by political controversy but renewing its reputation as one of the nation's legal trend-setters.

title: In Sermon And in Silence, Mother Teresa Is Celebrated
description: They came in crisp business suits and rumpled Bermuda shorts. They carried newspapers and teddy bears. Some were tourists who saw something happening and wandered in off the street. Others were people who had been personally blessed by the tiny, clear-eyed woman.

title: Winning Literary Acclaim, A Voice of Central Europe
description: More than a decade after his epic novel appeared in his native Hungary and six years after it dazzled Germany's reviewers, Peter Nadas's ''Book of Memories'' arrived in the United States this summer to the kind of acclaim usually reserved for big names. His work has evoked comparisons to the poetic traditions of Thomas Mann, the sexual explicitness of Jean Genet and the stream-of-consciousness of James Joyce.

title: Experts on Climate Change Pondering: How Urgent Is It?
description: WITH the nations of the world counting down to a Dec. 10 deadline for negotiating cuts in emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases that many scientists say are altering the earth's climate, a fundamental question continues to pervade the debate:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Thinking about keeping up with CHELSEA CLINTON by subscribing to The Stanford Daily?

title: Teams Duel in Nevada Desert Over Land Speed Record
description: THE land speed record is under assault on a desert plain in Nevada and could be bested several times in coming weeks as two supercars push the mark on the ground toward its last major barrier: the speed of sound.

title: Teacher Is Charged With 3 More Assaults
description: A Bergenfield, N.J., man who was arrested last week and charged with the sexual assault of two boys who had lived in his foster care was charged yesterday with similar assaults on three other boys who had lived with him, law enforcement officials said.

title: For Asia, Austerity and Exports
description: Now that nearly all the nations of Southeast Asia are reeling under a wave of currency losses, how will they extract themselves from their economic mess?

title: Talking About the Country Club
description: THE denials were emphatic and swift, maybe too much so. ''There's no racism on the women's tour,'' the veteran Gigi Fernandez said after playing the women's doubles final at the United States Open. ''I adamantly deny that. We've had Zina and Lori.''

title: College Life vs. My Moral Code
description: Many people envy my status as a freshman at Yale College. My classmates and I made it through some fierce competition, and we are excited to have been accepted to one of the best academic and extracurricular programs in American higher education. I have an older brother who attended Yale, and I've heard from him what life at Yale is like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, FLORENCE
description: GROSSMAN-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Meyer I. Grossman, devoted mother of Jerome and Jacqueline Grossman, and Hinda and Ben-Zion Kinzler, cherished grandmother of Scott, Jordan, Roger, Daniel and Morgan. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island today at 2:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, WERNER WILLIAM
description: ROTHENBERG-Werner William. Sept 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Irene. Devoted father of John and Randall, father-in-law of Andrea and Cheryl. Cherished grandfather of Arielle, Amanda and Daniel. We will miss him. His ashes will be laid to rest in Florida. Always in our hearts.

title: Fox in Deal With New Regency Productions
description: Fox Filmed Entertainment said yesterday that it had signed a production and distribution deal with Arnon Milchan's New Regency Productions.

title: Grammys Stay In New York
description: The Grammy Awards will be given out in New York City for a second consecutive year, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced yesterday at City Hall. This year's Grammys presentation, at Madison Square Garden, was one of the largest awards shows ever. A scaled-down version will take place at Radio City Music Hall on Feb. 25, 1998. The nominees will be announced in early January.

title: John Esposito, 69, Ex-Legislator And Koch Challenger in 1981
description: John A. Esposito, a former Republican State Assemblyman who ran for mayor of New York on the Conservative Party ticket in 1981, died on Sunday in Garden City, N.Y., at the home of a daughter. He was 69.

title: Strong-Arming, Profit and Fine Food
description: The plot, as detailed by undercover agents working for the Justice Department, was global in its ambitions. A broker from Las Vegas, boasting of his ties to the mob, tried to hire a ''300-pound guy'' to rough up a rival, freeing the way for one man to dominate a fast-growing Asian market.

title: CANADIAN OIL COMPANIES TO MERGE IN $209 MILLION DEAL
description: Baytex Energy Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy Dorset Exploration Ltd. in a share swap valued at about $290 million (Canadian), or $209 million (United States), creating a company with a large portfolio of oil and gas exploration targets in the province of Alberta. Baytex is offering 0.48 class A share for each Dorset share. The new company would be an intermediate producer of oil and gas by Alberta standards, with combined daily production of 10,400 barrels of oil and 90 million cubic feet of natural gas. Both companies are based in Calgary and have focused on producing oil and gas within Alberta.

title: For Selig, the Interim Is 5 Years and Longer
description: If they continue performing their current jobs, Bud Selig would need only three more years to surpass Cal Ripken Jr. In contributing in their own unique ways to baseball history, Selig and Ripken have performed in a not dissimilar fashion.

title: Ramos Will Remember His Return to U.S. Team
description: As usual, Tab Ramos had to be honest. After thumping a 22-yard shot into the Costa Rican goal late in a crucial World Cup qualifying game Sunday to give the United States a 1-0 victory, he was asked whether it was the most important goal he had ever scored. He had to shake his head.

title: America Online to Maintain 2 Services
description: As America Online proceeds to acquire Compuserve, its closest rival, company executives insist that things will not change much for Compuserve's 2.6 million subscribers -- for now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVRETT, JACK
description: AVRETT-Jack. Died August 29, 1997, from a stroke at age 68. Memorial service Thursday, September 11, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st Street and Madison Avenue at 4:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Thomas Helps Eagles Rediscover Defense
description: In the early 90's, when teams arrived at Veterans Stadium to clash with the Philadelphia Eagles' defense, the question often was not if offenses would score touchdowns but if they would score at all. On the field and in the locker room, the Eagles were led by their defense and the personalities it featured.

title: A Good Deal for Central Park
description: The Giuliani administration has decided to hand over the day-to-day maintenance of Central Park to a private group, the Central Park Conservancy. A few community groups worry that the arrangement will rob New York City of its authority over Central Park and perhaps cheat the city's other parks. These fears are groundless. From almost any perspective, the deal makes sense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTER, ADELE
description: KANTER-Adele. Died Sunday, Septemper 7, after a long life filled with service to the cause of human rights. Her many close friends and loving family will sorely miss her unfailing helpfulness, sharp wit and warm heart.

title: Rail Strike Has San Francisco Commuters Creeping Along Alternative Routes
description: Traffic around the San Francisco Bay Area crept along for hours at times today as a two-day railway strike left thousands of commuters struggling to get to work and back.

title: IN PRIMARY TODAY, DEMOCRATS SELECT GIULIANI OPPONENT
description: With a flurry of rallies, advertisements and street-and-subway stumping, three Democratic candidates for New York City mayor brought their campaigns to a close last night, encountering relatively small crowds and often uninterested voters as they struggled to draw attention to today's primary.

title: With Retirement in Sight Again, a Business Empire Awaits
description: Michael Jordan spent part of his summer vacation in Maui being thrashed by large waves. He did not have a $33 million contract at the time, and even now, he laughs at the wisdom of his decision to body surf for the first time. But the ocean was inviting, his children were urging him on and, always paramount with Jordan, a challenge was calling.

title: Clinton to Rekindle Old Debate on Trade
description: This week President Clinton plans to leap into what promises to be a bruising battle over the expansion of Nafta and of his powers to negotiate other international trade accords.

title: The Health Page
description: The Health page, including Personal Health, which appears in the Living section on Wednesday, will move to Science Times beginning next Tuesday.

title: Politicking on the Links
description: To the Editor:

title: German Buyer Seeking 43% Stake in Grundig
description: The German investment company Bayerische Wagnisbeteiligungsgesellschaft G.m.b.H. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the 43 percent stake in the German consumer electronics maker Grundig A.G. currently held by the London investment bank Botts & Company. The German investment company is 25 percent owned by Bayerische Landesanstalt fuer Aufbaufinanzierung, a construction finance agency owned by the state of Bavaria.

title: Drugs Common in Schools, Survey Shows
description: Many teen-agers find illegal drugs more common at school than in their neighborhood, according to a new national survey that concludes that drugs are a barrier to better education.

title: ZELL PAYS $300 MILLION FOR 38 HOME PARKS
description: Manufactured Home Communities Inc., which is headed by the billionaire financier Sam Zell, agreed yesterday to buy 38 manufactured home communities for $300 million. The move would raise the Chicago-based company's portfolio to about 128 communities and 46,000 sites, making it the largest company in the nation in the business of renting land to owners of mobile and manufactured homes. Chateau Communities of Englewood, Colo., the current leader, has 128 communities and 43,300 sites. The purchase is being made through a tender offer for units of closely held partnerships managed by Gerald Ellenburg. The properties are mainly in Florida, Arizona and California. The company's shares rose $1.3125, to $25.375.

title: New York City Primary Choices
description: This list summarizes our recommendations for some of the most hotly contested Democratic primaries today in New York City. Poll hours in the city are 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: Catholic Bishop Is Ordained
description: Monsignor Vincent de Paul Breen became the third bishop of the Metuchen Diocese yesterday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Breen, 60, was ordained at the Cathedral of Saint Francis of Assisi in Metuchen by Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of the Newark archdiocese. A Brooklyn native, he was named to the position by Pope John Paul II in July, shortly after Bishop Edward T. Hughes retired. The Metuchen diocese represents nearly 500,000 Catholics in 108 parishes in Hunterdon, Middlesex, Somerset and Warren Counties.

title: Art and Friendship Were Discarded; Art Alone Survived
description: Anthony Askin frames and hangs pictures for the 20th century department of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He also paints on the side. But he is really a troller for trash. He and his wife, Sheila Ramsey, a converted scavenger since their wedding, have jammed their East Village apartment with treasures from the streets of New York: a table, a desk, a Thermos, a washer-dryer that actually works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUS, MARJORIE LEWENGOOD
description: STRAUS-Marjorie Lewengood. 98. Died at home September 5, 1997, after a lengthy illness. Beloved wife of the late Charles Bennett Straus, dear mother of Charles, Jr. and John. Affectionate mother-of-law of Gwyned and Mary, fond grandmother of Charles, III and Timothy and great grandmother of Taylor, Spencer and Hunter. She also leaves her friend and nurse of 19 years, Anne Flynn. A private memorial service is planned.

title: A Young Man's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks were higher here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei average of 225 stocks was up 52.11 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,685.97. On Monday, the Nikkei lost 16.31 points.

title: Motorola and I.B.M. Look Beyond Chip Pact With Apple
description: In the latest fallout from the troubles at Apple Computer, the company's chip partners, Motorola and I.B.M., said today that they were refocusing the Power PC microprocessor family into new markets beyond the computer industry, toward applications in consumer electronics and industrial markets.

title: I.B.M. Dropping Plans for a Simplified PC
description: I.B.M. said today that it was abandoning plans to make a simplified personal computer called a NetPC, though it said it would offer the enhanced flexibility of the machines across its personal computer line.

title: Elton John's Revised 'Candle,' For a Princess and Charity
description: The images from the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, watched by an enormous worldwide television audience, will be memorialized in a series of television projects to be released over the next several weeks, including instant videos based on the news coverage of the funeral procession and service.

title: Open Mixed History With the Unexpected
description: The stadium was brand new, and so were the champions, but what the 1997 United States Open -- the one that adopted the Sinatra-esque mantra about being able to make it anywhere if you could make it there -- was all about was history. About making it, breaking it, bucking it, faking it.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Tuesday about the Congressional agenda, including spending bills that are to be approved by the end of September, misstated the deadline date. Thirty days hath September.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MALCOLM ''BUD''
description: KAHN-Malcolm ''Bud''. Died peacefully at home after an heroic battle with cancer. Devoted and beloved husband of Sandra, wonderful father to Andrew, Jeffrey and Tara, Michael and Laura, adored ''Poppy'' to Jacob, Alexander and Malcolm, cherished brother of Shirley and Sid Zeitlin, Ted and Muriel Kahn, and Evelyn Nathan. Dear friend to Yetta, Georgia and Lizzie. A rare and special person of many qualities, he will be loved and sorely missed by his entire family. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Malcolm B. Kahn Fund at the Brandeis School, Frost Lane, Lawrence, New York. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at ''Boulvard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: In Germany, Humble Herb Is a Rival to Prozac
description: IT is a lush green plant with bright yellow flowers and a homely name: St. John's wort in English and Johanniskraut in German.

title: MetroStars in Crucial Game
description: It looks more likely that the battle for the last playoff spot in the Eastern Conference will be contested between the MetroStars and the New England Revolution, who meet tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: For Now, Survivor Is Unable To Speak With Investigators
description: The British bodyguard who was critically injured in the high-speed car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, is recovering from a 10-hour operation for facial reconstruction last Thursday but will be unable to talk to French investigators for some time, his family said today.

title: Another Spacecraft Nears Mars For Orbiting Survey of Planet
description: A little more than two months after the Pathfinder and its robotic sidekick Sojourner landed on Mars, another American spacecraft is approaching the planet, ready to swing into an orbit for a comprehensive two-year mapping survey to guide future missions searching for signs of past or present Martian life.

title: Dormant Fire Hydrants Fading Into City History
description: In its day, the 500-pound cast-iron mushroom in front of 1621 Mermaid Avenue was a modern miracle, a high-pressure fire hydrant capable of delivering 3,000 gallons of water a minute on one of Coney Island's main commercial streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFANDRE, JULIAN E.
description: ALFANDRE-Julian E. On September 7, 1997. Beloved father of Rachel, James and David. Funeral Service at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, N.Y., on Wednesday 11 AM. Memorial contributions to Amnesty International USA, 322 Eighth Avenue, New York, New York 10001 are welcome.

title: California Is Big Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CHRONICLE
description: Question: When is an athlete's nude body like a watch?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMBERG, GEORGINE
description: BLOOMBERG-Georgine. Friend Avrutis. Devoted wife of Dr. Allan Ellia Bloomberg. Beloved sister of Shirley Abrams, Arlene Rieser and June Laufman. Dear aunt of Ginger Strauss and Jill Bach. Adored stepmother of Jon, Paul and Seth Bloomberg. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81st, Wednesday at 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAYTELL, FANNIE
description: FAYTELL-Fannie. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Alan Levine, Ch. of the Bd. Robert P. Antler, President

title: The Fallen Commissars of 1918, Now Fallen Idols
description: A giant circle of stone covered with ceramic tiles towers over one of Baku's prettiest parks, looking as if it might be about to lift off for a journey to another planet.

title: INSIDE
description: CSX Ordered to Pay Billions

title: Wash That Mustache!
description: ALL civilized men with mustaches know to wash them after sipping soup or gnawing buttered corn on the cob. There is nothing worse than letting old butter linger on one's upper lip. Unless, perhaps, you have allergies and your mustache is trapping pollen.

title: Private Investors to Be Offered 20% of Stock : A Slice of France Telecom
description: PARIS  The government said Monday it would sell 20 percent of France Telecom to private investors, making it clear that control of the state-owned company, Europe's largest remaining phone monopoly, would remain firmly in state hands.

title: Super Bowl III Revisited, on ESPN
description: In 1969 Steve Sabol produced a 22-minute review of Super Bowl III for NFL Films. In his pro-National Football League stance, Sabol focused more on the sore-armed Johnny Unitas's valiant effort to rally Baltimore than on how the Jets made good on Joe Namath's victory guarantee and beat the Colts, 16-7.

title: Chess
description: The United States Cadet Championship, an invitational competition for the top eight players under 16, was won by Justin Sarkar of Scarsdale, N.Y., on July 13 in Nashville. Sarkar, 15, compiled a 5-2 score.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, SAMUEL J. JR.
description: PAUL-Samuel J. Jr. Of Alexandria, Virginia. On September 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Eleanor J. Paul, father of Samuel III, Susan and Bruce Paul, and Janette Brenner, brother of Lois de Fazio, grandfather of eight. Services Wednesday, Murphy's Falls Church Funeral Home. Interment Quantico National Cemetery.

title: Police Charge a Queens Man With Killing His Wife, Son and Sister-in-Law
description: A Queens man who neighbors said had recently lost his job opened fire with an automatic pistol in his co-op apartment last night, killing his wife, their 12-year-old son and his sister-in-law, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LI, K.C.
description: LI-K.C. 75, died September 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Linda. Cherished father of Ling Sebastian, Anna and Ariana. Visitation 2-4, 7-9 PM at Williams Funeral Home, 99 Newtown Lane, Easthampton.

title: Celtics Reach Deals With Top Picks
description: The Boston Celtics have signed CHAUNCEY BILLUPS and RON MERCER, their top selections in the 1997 draft.

title: The Half-Century War
description: The ''peace process'' between Arabs and Israelis has been going on not for the four years since Oslo but for the half-century since the founding of Israel. Almost all the while it has been the Israelis who have been offering peace and the Arabs who have been answering with acts of war.

title: Judge Hospitalized With Stroke
description: Judge Harold B. Rothwax, the acerbic State Supreme Court justice who has presided over some of New York City's most sensational trials and who last month sued the radio talk show host Don Imus for libel, remained hospitalized last night after he suffered a stroke over the weekend.

title: A Teacher's Poem
description: I am a New York City public high school teacher

title: Campbell Soup Expected to Announce Spinoff
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it planned to make a major announcement in Manhattan today, causing speculation among analysts that the company planned to spin off several businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENOWITZ, NINA POWELL
description: MENOWITZ-Nina Powell. Of Bal Harbour, Florida. On September 7, 1997; cherished wife of Harold, loving mother of Meris Powell Prescott, Richard Powell and Ann Pack and stepmother of Frederick Menowitz & Carol Penn; beloved mother-in-law of Darrell Prescott, Sheila Fitzpatrick and Bob Pack and stepmother-in-law of Sue Menowitz; dearly loved grandmother of Katherine, Dakota, Jeremiah, and Alex and stepgrandmother of Marc, Todd, Lisa, Larry, Jonathan, Valerie, and Gregory; sister of Helen Berkowitz. A Memorial Service will be held at noon, Wednesday, Sept. 10, at the Ethical Culture Society, Central Park West at 64th Street. Contributions may be made in her name for a piano scholarship to the Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, NY, NY 10027.

title: Bilingual Education Keeps Students in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BING, RUDOLF
description: BING-Rudolf. Columbia Artists Management Inc. is deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and colleague, Sir Rudolf Bing. During his many years as General Manager of the Metropolitan Opera, Sir Rudolf made extraordinary contributions to the field. He instilled a new atmosphere of artistic discipline and introduced American audiences to the world's greatest singers, directors and stage designers. Sir Rudolf's vision and guidance were inspirational to our company and the artists we represent, both during his tenure at the Metropolitan Opera and in the years following, when he served as a member of CAMI's Board of Directors and as a Vice President (1974-1987). We remember him with great affection and esteem. Ronald A. Wilford, President and the Board of Directors Columbia Artists Mgmnt Inc.

title: Reader's Digest Chief Hires Ex-Executives
description: When James P. Schadt abruptly resigned last month as chief executive of the Reader's Digest Association, his predecessor, George V. Grune, was brought back from retirement to fill in.

title: Why Did Mommy Leave? Imagining the Reasons
description: THE BOOK OF FAMOUS IOWANS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YASSER, MAC
description: YASSER-Mac. Age 85, of Lake Worth, FL., died on September 7, 1997 peacefully surrounded by his family at the home of his daughter in Southampton, NY. He is survived by his loving wife, Esther, his children, Sandra and Alan Friedman, Roslyn and the late Jan Meren, and Alan and Nan Yasser, his grandchildren, David and Lisa Friedman, Jonathan and Pamela Friedman, Lisa and Jennifer Friedman, Peter & Andrew Meren and great-grandson, Joshua Friedman. He will be remembered for his wit and the pleasure he gave and received from others. Family services were held on September 8, 1997 at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, National Chapter, 386 Park Avenue South, NYC 10016 and Arthritis National Research Foundation, 200 Ocean Gate, Suite 440, Long Beach, CA. 90802.

title: We Strive to Be Insular
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAFF, SONYA
description: STAFF-Sonya. Peacefully, on September 8, 1997. A remarkable woman. Widow of her beloved Otto; survived by her loving daughter, Eve S. Rosahn; daughter-inlaw, Marion D. Banzhaf; loving relatives, and countless friends. Social activist, feminist, with a passionate interest in Yiddish culture and imbued with a fierce love of life. Contributions may be made to The Sonya Staff Foundation, c/o Rosahn, 467 W. 22 St., Apt. F, New York, NY 10011. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESPOSITO, JOHN A.
description: ESPOSITO-John A. Former six-term Assemblyman John A. Esposito of Queens Village, NY, died Sunday, September 7, after a long bout with cancer. He is survived by his wife, Estelle (Nee Boos), and three children, Anne Anderson, M.D., of Garden City, Patricia Todd, of New Hartford, and Thomas Esposito, of Farmingdale. He was blessed with six grandchildren, five boys and one girl. The family lived in Queens Village since 1955. Mr. Esposito was born and raised in Park Slope, Brooklyn, graduating from Saint Saviour's Parochial School. He achieved his legal degree from Brooklyn Law School in 1950. Additionally to his representing the 23rd District for six terms in the Albany legislature, Mr. Esposito also held executive positions with the NY State Public Service Commission and the NY State Court of Claims. He was active as president of the Parents' Association for SS Joachim & Anne Catholic School in Queens Village.
