Of his many achievements in politics, Mr. Esposito is especially remembered for running on the empty Republican-Conservative ticket in the New York City mayoral election for 1981; he voiced strong objection to cross-over endorsement of a Democratic candidate. He was also progenitor of the bill demanding parental consent to an abortion for minors. He most recently worked pro bono as an Assistant District Attorney in Kings County representing elderly crime victims. Visitation scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at R. Stutzmann & Son Funeral Home, 224-39 Jamaica Ave., Queens Village. Mass of Christian burial at SS Joachim and Anne RCC, Thursday at 9:45 AM. Interment will be at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Report Says Judge in Domestic-Violence Cases Abused Power
description: Judge Lorin Duckman, who was widely criticized last year for releasing a suspect in a domestic-violence case who later killed his girlfriend, has repeatedly abused his judicial authority in making antiprosecution rulings, says a report to a state panel that is considering whether to remove the judge from the bench.

title: A Minimalist Approach With Maximum Results
description: From Elvis Presley to the Sex Pistols, the impulse to scale down pop music has always been a smart one. And it still is. During the CMJ festival concert on Friday night at Westbeth Theater Center -- a showcase evening for two Northwestern independent labels, Up and Kill Rock Stars -- the new acoustic-guitar, singer-songwriter music of the hipster underground came sandwiched between heavier, messier electric rock acts, like jolts of wakeful consciousness during a snoozy lecture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEICHSEL, DORIS (NEE CAAN)
description: WEICHSEL-Doris (nee Caan). On September 7, 1997. Beloved wife of Lothar. Loving mother of Marion and Jerry Sussman. Adoring grandmother of Daniel, Andrew & Wendy and Peter. May she rest in peace. Services Tues. 1:15PM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, LELA HENDRY
description: SLATTERY-Lela Hendry. In Manhattan on September 7th, in her 81st year. A native of Auckland, New Zealand, she served in the U.S. Army nurses corps in the Pacific theater during World War II. At Guadalcanal in October 1944 she wed Louis R. Slattery, a surgeon with the U.S. Army Seventh Evacuation Hospital. Between April and June of 1945, she was a combat nurse in the invasion of Okinawa, one of WWII's bloodiest campaigns. After the war, she returned with her husband to Manhattan, bore and raised their children, and lived in cheerful devotion to her family until her death. Survived by her loving husband Louis, son John, daughter Elizabeth Spahr, grandchildren Kate and James Slattery and Nicholas and Emily Spahr, and daughter-in-law Kathy Slattery-all of Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to NYU Medical Center, Attn: Mr. Colby Collier, 550 First Avenue, NY, NY 10016 or Victoria Home for the Aged, 25 North Malcolm Street, Ossining, NY 10562. Funeral service Saint James' Church, Madison Avenue at 71 St at 11:00 AM on Friday, September 12, 1997.

title: Midtown Tower to Be Sold
description: Boston Properties has agreed to buy a midtown New York office tower from Kenvic Associates for about $206 million in securities and assumed debt.

title: Isles and Rangers Settle With Key Players
description: Less than a month after engaging in a contentious arbitration hearing, the Islanders and goalie Tommy Salo agreed to a one-year contract extension yesterday.

title: PRICE MUTUAL FUND ACQUIRES A 5.6% STAKE IN PENNZOIL
description: Franklin Mutual Advisors, the mutual fund run by Michael Price, has taken a 5.6 percent stake in the Pennzoil Company, making Franklin Mutual the company's second-largest shareholder. Franklin criticized Pennzoil for opposing the hostile takeover bid by Union Pacific Resources Group. Pennzoil has fought the $6.4 billion tender offer, which was announced in June and extended until Oct. 29. Franklin Mutual said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, ''The marketplace clearly does not believe that this company can best serve shareholders by remaining independent'' and called on it to ''commence immediate negotiations'' with Union Pacific Resources.'' Pennzoil's largest shareholder is State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, with an 8 percent stake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCH, MYRNA
description: MARCH-Myrna. On September 8, 1997. Beloved wife of Dr. Arnold Roufa, devoted sister of Wendy Rue, NY, and Maxwell Goldhar, Toronto. Devoted stepmother of Karen Caparelli, Michael Roufa and Rachel Bennett, loving grandmother of Crystal Anne Bennett. Services on Wednesday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial contributions be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAIR, FREDERIC ROBERTS
description: BLAIR-Frederic Roberts, of Cold Spring Harbor, NY, died September 6. Service September 11, 12 Noon, at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, MIRIAM
description: GOLD-Miriam, of Boca Raton, Fla., and White Plains, NY. Beloved wife of the late Harold Gold. Devoted mother of Sanford and Cindy Gold, and Lyn-Norma and Paul Lubliner. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Funeral services on Tuesday, September 9, at Congregation Kol Ami, White Plains, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSAHN, SONYA
description: ROSAHN-Sonya. See ''Staff.''

title: Airport Kickback Sentencing
description: A retired chief maintenance supervisor of Newark International Airport was sentenced to 18 months in prison yesterday for taking more than $26,000 in kickbacks from airport vendors during 1991 and 1992, prosecutors said. The supervisor, David C. Williams, 51, pleaded guilty in May to extorting cash, televisions and other merchandise from vendors whom he threatened with dismissal, said James Nobile, an assistant United States attorney. He also pleaded guilty to filing a false income tax return, Mr. Nobile said.

title: Tribes' New Power Over Welfare May Come at Too High a Price
description: On the wind-scarred grassland stretching past Ghost Hawk Lake, Monica Burning Breast, 25, single and pregnant with her third child, has spent her life in a world on welfare.

title: France to Sell Large Stake In Telecom
description: The French Government said today that it would sell up to 38 percent of France Telecom S.A. for about 76 billion francs ($12.5 billion) in one of the world's biggest initial public offerings.

title: First Gene for Social Behavior Identified in Whiskery Mice
description: IN a stroke of inspired good fortune, biologists have found a gene that turns out to exert profound effects on the social behavior of mice. This is apparently the first gene to be isolated that affects social behavior in mammals, the authors and others say, and it promises to shed light on important disorders of human social behavior like schizophrenia and autism.

title: For Queens, Tennis Center Is an Intrusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRAM, JOHN M.
description: SCHRAM-John M. Beloved Sean who added the many colors of intelligence, warmth and humor to the lives of Lorraine; his sons, Michael, Stephen and Sean; his step-daughters, Rachel and Emily; and his many friends. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 13, at 11 AM, St. John's in the Village, 224 Waverly Place, N.Y.C. 10014. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in his memory to the church.

title: Ms. Albright's Daunting Agenda
description: Madeleine Albright could hardly have found a dicier time to make her first visit to the Middle East as Secretary of State. Not only has the peace effort between Israel and the Palestinians all but collapsed, but regional powers like Saudi Arabia and Iran are asserting themselves in ways that may undermine America's leadership in the area. As Ms. Albright works her way through the region this week, she will need all her vaunted bluntness and determination to keep instability at bay.

title: Staten Island Ferry Delays
description: Passengers who take the the Staten Island Ferry should expect delays and crowded conditions during the morning and evening rush hours until late next week because of maintenance work on the fleet's two largest vessels, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: Team Effort Aimed At P.& G. Duties
description: Two agencies that work for the Procter & Gamble Company have taken the unusual step of teaming up to compete for the company's consolidated television media assignment, with combined billings estimated at as much as $1.2 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNAY, LEONARD
description: CHARNAY-Leonard, 81, of Lake Worth, FL. Formerly of Hewlett, NY, passed away on September 8th, 1997 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Jean. Adoring father of Patricia and Michael Gorman and Richard and Ruth Charnay. Loving grandfather of Matthew and Aaron. Dear brother of Bernard Charnay and Shirley Siegel. He will be missed by his family and friends.

title: Neck Injury Sidelines Giants' Hilliard
description: Ike Hilliard, the rookie wide receiver whose skill, spunk and savvy made him one of the promising early season stars of the Giants, is expected to miss six to seven weeks, and possibly more, because of a neck injury sustained in Sunday's loss to the Jacksonville Jaguars.

title: U.S. Gives Up on Plea Bargaining With Saudi in Bombing Case
description: The Justice Department said today that it would drop criminal charges against a Saudi dissident who has been a central figure in the Government's efforts to investigate the truck bombing that killed 19 American airmen in Saudi Arabia last year.

title: Economics Are a Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERKASKY, MARTIN, MD.
description: CHERKASKY-Martin, MD. Former President of Montefiore Medical Center. Died at his home on September 7. Husband of Carole Pesner. Father of Marny Cherkasky & Michael Cherkasky, brother of Fanny Goldstein, father-in-law of Richard Brodman and Betsey Cherkasky, grandfather of Eli, Susannah, Ethan, Dinah and Alexandria and stepfather of Ben and Jonah Pesner. Services today, Tuesday, September 9 at 9:30AM at Riverside at Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee or the charity of your choice.

title: Driver Checks Are Challenged
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a motion on Friday with the New Jersey Supreme Court asking the court to examine the practice of the State Highway Patrol and local police departments using mobile data terminals to search computer databases randomly for drivers' records. The A.C.L.U. asked the court to review a July ruling by the New Jersey Superior Court that upheld the ticketing of two motorists who had been driving without insurance while under suspension, said David Rocah, an A.C.L.U. staff attorney. In each case, the police randomly pulled the drivers' records without first suspecting them of a crime, he said.

title: Following Up on the Disabilities Law
description: John Hockenberry brings a personal element to the charge on ''No Way In'' tonight that Americans in wheelchairs are being shut out of job opportunities and places to live, shop and find entertainment despite the protections accorded them on paper by the Americans With Disabilities Act. Mr. Hockenberry, who has careered around the world in a wheelchair in his years as a television reporter (an automobile accident when he was 19 left him a paraplegic), takes on the cause of those who haven't been given a chance to show what they can do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINFELD, AL
description: REINFELD-Al. Beloved husband to Pearl, father to Carol and Mark Soltz and David and Debra Reinfeld. Grandfather to Ben and Maggie. Loving brother, uncle and friend. Your life was a true joy to all of us. We will miss you dearly. All who knew and loved you.

title: A Powerful Odor
description: It is said that clothes make the man, but for the status-seeking cockroach male, what really matters is how he smells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, LEWIS
description: STEINMAN-Lewis. A true mentor and a compassionate man who always brought a smile to the faces of those around him. Lew was great to know, great to work with and great to talk to. He will be deeply missed. Our condolences to his loving wife Joan, sons Jeffrey, Peter and Robert, and the entire family. Joel Mitofsky Mitofsky & Shapiro Law firm

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNEBAUM, EDWARD J.
description: GRUNEBAUM-Edward J. Died on September 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of James, the late Andrew, and Robert. Loving grandfather of Jason. Family receiving Wednesday from 7-9 P.M., 5 Riverside Drive. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Jewish Guild for the Blind or to your charity.

title: Accounts
description: * TDK Europe, Luxembourg, to Doner Cardwell Hawkins, London, a unit of W. B. Doner & Co., to handle its pan-European brand image account, previously at Havas Advertising's Euro RSCG unit in Paris. Billings were estimated at $16 million.

title: Student Held 30 Hostage At School, Police Say
description: A Manhattan high school student, apparently distraught at not being allowed to graduate, sealed a classroom door with duct tape yesterday afternoon and took the principal and dozens of students and staff members hostage for about 30 minutes, the police and school officials said.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Syracuse

title: Netanyahu's Hard Line Faces Rising Israeli Dissent
description: Though Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has left no doubt that he will cite last week's suicide bombing as a reason to demand that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright lean hard on Yasir Arafat, and as a reason to reject further obligations under the Oslo agreements, he will not be speaking for a united nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISTEFANO, ROSA
description: DISTEFANO - Rosa. Beloved mother of Mary (Chelly), John, Evelyn, Fr. Simeon and the late Sadie. Loving grandmother of four and great-grandmother of ten. Reposing A. Ribustello & Son, Inc., 811 Morris Park Ave., Bronx. Funeral Mass Our Lady of Pity Church, Thursday, 10 AM.

title: Cone to Test His Shoulder In Drill Today
description: There is something about the normally effervescent David Cone's worried voice, something about his concerned expressions and his rigid body language that suggests a pitcher who is frightened about not making another start this season. Cone will throw off the bullpen mound at Fenway Park today, and the seemingly simple session should determine his immediate future and influence how the Yankees view their chances for dancing through October.

title: Trimming Role of Lawyers in Fairfield Real Estate
description: It has long been a source of frustration to real estate agents in the affluent suburbs of southern Connecticut that more deals fall through here than in just about any other part of the country.

title: Sunbeam Sues the A.M.A. On Voided Marketing Deal
description: Charging that the American Medical Association ''is not above the law,'' the chairman of the Sunbeam Corporation, Albert J. Dunlap, filed suit yesterday on behalf of his company in an effort to force the medical group to honor its endorsement deal with the appliance manufacturer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, MARGARETTE
description: REISS-Margarette. In 1949, Margarette Reiss placed a notice in Newsday appealing to other parents of children with mental retardation to come together to discuss alternatives to sending their children away to institutions. A group of parents responded and met at the Carle Place Firehouse and the Association for the Help of Retarded Children Nassau County Chapter was born. Now 8,000 members strong, Nassau AHRC provides community-based opportunities and choices for over 1500 children and adults with developmental disabilities daily and is a source of guidance and support for families. Nassau AHRC extends its deepest condolences to Margarette's family. She helped lead the way in advocating for equal rights for special children. Thomas F. Moore, President Michael Mascari, Exec Director Assoc. For The Help of Retarded Children, Nassau Chapter

title: Small-Company Stocks Continue to Gain
description: After meandering, major stock market indexes finished higher yesterday in moderate trading as investors looked for underpriced stocks and sectors.

title: Patterns
description: Federated Seeks Young Men

title: New Viral Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAMHI, SONYA
description: CAMHI-Sonya. 9/18/51-9/9/95. Although taken from us too soon, the legacy of your tenacious spirit remains as strong as ever. Your loving family

title: AVANT TO BUY TECHNOLOGY MODELING FOR $150 MILLION
description: The Avant Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Technology Modeling Associates Inc. for $17 a share in stock, or about $150 million, increasing its capabilities in computer-aided chip design and heating up its rivalry with Cadence Design Systems in the electronic design automation business. Technology Modeling shares rose $2.50, to $16; shares of Avant, which is based in Fremont, Calif., rose 37.5 cents, to $34. Both Avant and Cadence sell software used to design, test and make silicon chips. Technology Modeling, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., specializes in computer-aided tools used to design manufacturing processes for microscopic semiconductor components.

title: Daewoo Denies Talk Of Italian Investment
description: The chairman of the Daewoo Corporation of South Korea said yesterday that it was in talks with Ansaldo Trasporti S.p.A. about acquiring power-generation equipment, not about buying a stake in the state-owned Italian company. Kim Woo Choong, Daewoo's chairman, said, ''We have no commitment at the moment with Ansaldo, but we are negotiating to buy equipment from them for our power business.''

title: Steinbrenner Warns Orioles
description: Even though the first-place Orioles just finished mauling the Yankees by winning three of the four games at Yankee Stadium and essentially completing any pennant chase in the American League East, George Steinbrenner still sent them a message yesterday while talking about October.

title: Wachtler Comes Back For the Day
description: For the first time since he resigned in disgrace nearly five years ago, Sol Wachtler, the former chief judge of New York, returned to the courthouse in Albany where he once presided, attending today's observance of the Court of Appeals's 150th anniversary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECHLER, ZYGMUNT
description: STECHLER-Zygmunt. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected member of the community; beloved husband of Helen; father of Joseph (and Gail) Stechler-member, Yeshiva College Board of Directors-and Miriam (and Danny) Ravitz. We extend heartfelt condolences as well to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: 2 British Acts Lower the Ante In Folk Songs of the Lonely
description: Good music doesn't always come to you. Sometimes you have to find it yourself, without radio, MTV, major record chains and magazines. But somehow, in Manhattan, quality in pop and rock usually doesn't go unheralded. Concerts by two new, promising and little-known British acts, Beth Orton (on Saturday night at the Westbeth Theater) and Belle and Sebastian (on Sunday night at the Angel Orensanz Foundation on the Lower East Side), were filled to capacity with admiring fans, most of whom had discovered these artists via word of mouth.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUCHS, RICHARD
description: FUCHS-Richard. 7/10/45-9/9/95. Your birthday came and went without a written word. I thought about you then as now as every day. The years pass and your absence becomes more prevalent. I will never get used to it. Love Always

title: Latest Cyberdeal Seems to Have Room for Two Winners
description: Follow the money in yesterday's big Internet deal -- an intricate transaction involving Worldcom, Compuserve and America Online -- and it seems that the real value lies in the dull plumbing of cyberspace, not the glamour of new media.

title: Accounting Firm Reviews Assignment
description: KPMG Peat Marwick said yesterday that it had placed in review its domestic account, which has been handled for five years by TBWA Chiat/Day in New York. Billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

title: Coca-Cola Chief Is Hospitalized
description: The Coca-Cola Company's chairman and chief executive, Roberto Goizueta, has been hospitalized for treatment of a localized malignant lung tumor, the company said today.

title: Clinton Embarking on a New Nafta Quest
description: President Clinton is about to leap into what promises to be a bruising battle over the expansion of Nafta within Latin America and his powers to negotiate other international trade accords.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: $12.5 Billion Offering Set For France Telecom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, WOLFE
description: COHEN-Wolfe, on Sept. 6, 1997. At age 97. Beloved husband of the late Sybil. Devoted father of the late Henry L. Cohen. Survived by daughter Wilma White. Grandfather of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Cohen and Rose Mary Cohen, and Kathleen A. Cohen. Dear brother of Dorothy Parker, Norma Silver and Percy Cohen. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Services were held held Monday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AGRIBIOTECH INC., Las Vegas, Nev., a farm supplies concern, agreed to acquire Lofts Seed Inc., a closely held provider of grass seeds based in Winston-Salem, N.C. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Immersion Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Chance of Tobacco Deal in '97 Gets Slimmer
description: President Clinton will not offer an opinion on the proposed tobacco accord until next week at the earliest, aides said today, further diminishing chances that Congress will act on the accord this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, CAROLYN A.
description: MARTIN-Carolyn A. Sons of the Revolution in the state of New York and its Color Guard regret the passing of Carolyn Martin, wife of Board Member and former Vice President, Cornwell C. Martin on September 5. H. S. Middendorf, Jr., President Laurence S. Simpson, Secretary

title: New York Previews a Centennial of Often-Bumpy Unity
description: Beneath a sprawling tent that served as an apt symbol of the night's events, more than 1,000 of the city's cultural, financial and political leaders and other guests gathered last night outside Gracie Mansion to announce a yearlong celebration of the centennial of Greater New York.

title: CLINTON PROMOTES EDUCATION TESTING GINGRICH OPPOSES
description: President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich staked out opposing positions today on national educational testing as Congress planned for crucial votes perhaps as early as Tuesday on the program that Mr. Clinton has made a centerpiece of his second-term education agenda.

title: Schwab Set To Underwrite Stock Issues
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the country's largest discount brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had signed a deal with three Wall Street firms to help them underwrite public stock offerings, a move that thrusts Schwab into a part of the financial markets that it had avoided.

title: Of Flowers in the Wind And Days of Destruction
description: A generation ago young composers were finding a home for their music in art galleries; now might be the moment when they connect more with movie theaters. Music, like film, has to do with observing time. And the audience for art-house films will have developed many of the talents needed for listening to contemporary music: attentiveness, openness and patience. So the new series at Anthology Film Archives in the East Village, ''Music at the Anthology,'' has a lot going for it, and the programs announced for the four future events this season look promising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUZE, JOHN
description: RUZE-John. In Concord, MA, on September 6, 1997. Husband of Rose (Perry), father of Elizabeth M. Ruze of Honolulu, HI, Patricia Ruze Chapman, MD, and her husband John of Alexandria, VA., Katherine Ruze Walter and her husband Adam of Golden, CO., and John Ruze and his wife Molly of Beaverdam, VA. Brother of Bertha M. Ruze of Trenton, NJ and grandfather of Nicole Ruze Chapman of Alexandria. Memorial Services in the First Parish in Concord, MA, Lexington Road, Concord Center, Friday, Sept 12 at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers gifts in his memory may be sent to the Loring N Fowler Memorial Library, 1322 Main St, Corcord, MA 01742.

title: Exiles' War on Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex Bias Lawsuit In Auto Industry
description: A former sales representative of an auto parts maker has filed a lawsuit here contending that she was discriminated against because her male co-workers routinely entertained auto executives at strip clubs in the Detroit area as part of their efforts to win business.

title: NASA Mission Poses Risk We Can't Measure
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Faces New Charges
description: A Bergenfield middle school teacher who was arrested last week and charged with sexually assaulting two boys who had lived in his foster care was also charged yesterday with similar assaults on three other boys who had lived with him, officials said. The man, Bart Mazzei, 46, now faces five counts of aggravated sexual assault against boys who lived with him between 1982 and 1995, said Ike Gavzy, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor. The names of victims, now all adults, are being withheld by the police, Mr. Gavzy said.

title: Voting Hours for Today's Primary in New York
description: There are several primary elections today in New York State and New York City. Polling places will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York City and in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Ulster and Erie Counties; 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. in all other counties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLISS, JOHN F.
description: BLISS-John F., 84, of Southbury, CT. Died at Waterbury Hospital on Sept. 5, 1997 after a brief illness. Survived by his wife, Jessie Hardy and daughter, Caroline. Memorial service St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Woodbury, September 19, 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, EDGAR
description: KAPLAN-Edgar. Died September 7, 1997. The President of the World Bridge Federation, Jose Damiani and the Executive Counsel, mourn the loss of their dear friend, Edgar Kaplan. Edgar's contribution to Bridge was not only as a worldclass player but as the author of ''The Laws of Duplicate Bridge'', an expert on Bridge Appeals, a most well-known journalist, a contributor to the organization of World Championships, as well as the captain of the winning team in the 1995 World Championships. Edgar's death is a great loss not only to Bridge but for all the people who play the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, MAURICE
description: LEVINE-Maurice. The 92nd Street YM-YWHA Board of Directors and Staff deeply mourn the passing of Maurice Levine. As the artistic director of ''Lyrics & Lyricists'' for 27 consecutive years, Maurice lovingly guided the Y's popular series since its inception. His commitment to the 92nd Street Y's mission to enrich people's lives was shown through his 50 years of service to the institution, first as the conductor of the Y Symphonic Workshop in the 1940s and 1950s, then as director of the Y Chorale in the 1960s and 1970s and finally through his devotion to the ''L&L'' series. He will be greatly missed by us all. Our profound sympathy to his family. Philip L. Milstein, President Joseph N. Leff, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director

title: U.S. Approves Testing for Oil In a Utah Park
description: The Clinton Administration today approved exploratory oil drilling on Federal land in the red-rock country of Utah where President Clinton last year established a vast national monument to protect the rich wilderness from development.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN & JENRETTE TO ACQUIRE BRITISH FIRM
description: The Wall Street investment firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire London Global Securities, a British stock lender, from Paloma Partners L.L.C. of Greenwich, Conn. Terms were not disclosed, but an article last month in The Wall Street Journal estimated the firm's value at more than $50 million. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said London Global would coordinate its business with the Wall Street firm's Pershing division, which has responsibility for the company's securities financing activities.

title: High Technology Could Add New Life to an Old Product
description: Plastics.

title: Single-Sex Classes Start
description: Eighth-grade students at Secaucus Middle School began a yearlong experiment in single-sex classes yesterday, even as civil rights advocates said it violated Federal law. Under the school's program, more than half of the eighth-grade students are participating in all-male or all-female math and social studies classes, said Patrick Impreveduto, the school's principal. Mr. Impreveduto said the change is intended to improve girls' self-esteem and keep the boys more focused on their work.

title: 2 Japanese Banks Pursue Merger Plan
description: The presidents of Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd. and Hokkaido Bank Ltd. met yesterday to discuss details of the banks' planned merger on April 1 next year, a spokesman for Hokkaido Takushoku said yesterday. ''They exchanged opinions, but there was nothing significant,'' the bank spokesman said.

title: A Noted Medical Examiner Goes to Trial on Evidence-Tampering Charges
description: Early in his career as an assistant state medical examiner in New Jersey, Dr. Claus P. Speth won superiors' praise for his work. In 1984, they extolled him for bringing the techniques of death-scene investigation to a ''state of high art'' and discovering six unsuspected homicides in his autopsies from 1982 to 1984.

title: China Telecom Offering Could Be Delayed
description: China Telecom (H.K.) Ltd. may be forced to delay its $2 billion sale of shares, one of the biggest in Hong Kong history, as regulators try to reassert their authority over a market whipsawed by rumor. China Telecom, a unit of China's Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, is planning to sell its shares in Hong Kong and New York next month.

title: Lawsuit Says Chase Abuses Mentally Ill
description: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit yesterday against Chase Manhattan Bank and the insurer that provides its disability benefits, the Unum Life Insurance Company of America, for limiting benefits to bank workers with mental illnesses.

title: A Wedding, a Funeral, A Stepchild's Problem
description: At the gorgeous outdoor South Carolina wedding that is the first scene of ''Clover,'' the only white face in sight is the bride's. Sara Kate (a glowing Elizabeth McGovern) is marrying Gaten Hill (Ernie Hudson), a long-ago college love, and the very young bridesmaid (Zelda Harris, in the title role), Gaten's daughter, does not look happy.

title: Rude Awakenings in a Dream Kitchen
description: I SAT at the kitchen table looking at the woman who, just moments before, I had assumed was my wife. There were the same soft eyes, the same lovely mouth, the smile that lured me all those years ago.

title: Dow Advances 16.73 in Fidgety Trading
description: Skittish investors moved stock market indexes moderately higher yesterday but continued to temper their buying with concerns about currency fluctuations and third-quarter earnings disappointments.

title: Thanks to some princely money, the New York Palace joins the ranks of the city's luxury hotels.
description: WITH a financial infusion from its owner, Prince Jefri Bolkiah of Brunei, the renovated New York Palace has put history behind it -- as the former Helmsley Palace -- and is now a new luxury hotel with big ambitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGGART, MARY
description: BIGGART-Mary. Died September 7 at Mary Manning Walsh Home. Beloved wife of the late William Biggart. Dear mother of Thomas, William, Patrick, Christopher, Catherine, Emily, Elizabeth, Margaret and Agatha, and also of the late John, Michael and Mary. Sister of John Noone and Catherine deGuzman, grandmother of 10. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday, 9:30AM at Our Lady of Pompeii, 25 Carmine St.

title: Patriots and Fans Not Likely to Let Parcells Up for Air
description: When the Jets play the New England Patriots Sunday night in Foxboro, Mass., Coach Bill Parcells of the Jets would like you to think it will be just another football game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKAS, JEAN A.
description: PAKAS-Jean A., on September 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Frederick. Loving sister of Malcolm and Martin L. Abrams and the late Arthur Abrams, devoted sister-inlaw of Kay and Gloria Abrams. Dear aunt and great aunt. She was greatly loved and she will be held in our dearest memory. Private service.

title: Mother Teresa's Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: Libertarian's Aid Questioned
description: An administrative law judge was asked yesterday to decide whether Murray Sabrin, the Libertarian Party candidate for governor, had spent enough money to qualify for state matching funds. Mr. Sabrin, the only independent candidate to seek such funds, must show that he has spent $210,000, said Frederick M. Herrmann, the executive director of the state Election Law Enforcement Commission.

title: For Griffey, So Little Time With So Much at Stake: Home Run Mark
description: Ken Griffey Jr. need look no farther back than this season and other recent ones to find inspiration for the task that faces him in the next two and a half weeks. He may find it impossible to do what the task requires, but he can draw on the recent experiences of Mark McGwire and Albert Belle, or he can simply summon his own memories.

title: Looks Like a Hit
description: The first faint glint of a possible new hit show was detected on Monday by Fox, when the ratings for its new drama, ''Ally McBeal,'' exceeded most expectations. Mainly it did so by beating the rating for the first new episode of ''Melrose Place,'' which immediately preceded it.

title: National Test Plan Runs Into Minefield
description: Even if it is approved by Congress, President Clinton's proposed national testing program of student achievement is traversing so many political land mines in states, cities and school districts that many experts wonder whether it will ever be widely used.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is a changing of the guard at the Fund for the City of New York: FREDERICK A. O. SCHWARZ JR., a partner at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore and a former New York City Corporation Counsel, has stepped down as the fund's chairman after serving two terms, totaling 13 years. There will be a reception to honor him this evening at the Century Association on West 43d Street.

title: Gun to the Head
description: This generation's battle for Jerusalem has begun. With two attacks on Israeli civilians punctuated by the public ''kiss of death'' bestowed by Yasir Arafat on a terrorist leader, militant Arabs have shown that they intend to make Jerusalem their capital at the point of a gun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFFER, ABRAHAM I.
description: SCHAFFER-Abraham I. The Cardiology Section of the Department of Medicine, Lenox Hill Hospital records with sadness the loss of a respected senior staff member. Even after retiring, ''Abe'' continued to participate in conferences encouraging younger cardiologists to emulate his dedicated approach to patient care. His presence, humor and intellect will be missed. Nicholas DePasquale, M.D. Neil Coplan, M.D. Richard Kutnick, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, SARA
description: GLASS-Sara, of Ft. Lauderdale, passed away 9-8-97. Loving mother of Marcia (Eddy) Kirschner, Phyllis (the late Larry) Silverstein and the late Alan (Beverly) Glass. Cherished Bobbi. Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1-800-274-2566, for further information.

title: Ulster Talks Resume With a Promise of Peace by Sinn Fein
description: Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, formally committed itself today for the first time to exclusively peaceful methods in its effort to reach an agreement on the political future of Northern Ireland.

title: Selling Cigarettes in Asia
description: In Hong Kong, hip clothing stores pass out American cigarettes free to their customers. Salem sponsors a ''virtual reality'' dome, where teen-agers attack each other with laser guns. Empty packs of American cigarettes can be redeemed for tickets to movies, discos and concerts.

title: Theater in Review
description: Butterfly, Poor Butterfly?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, BERNARD, MD.
description: PERLMAN-Bernard, MD. The Medical Staff Society of the New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens grieves the loss of its distinguished colleague and extends heartfelt sympathy to his family. Marvin Leder, MD, President Talat Addasi, MD, Vice Pres. Gabriel Deangelis, MD, Secretary Treasurer

title: Elementary School Student Is Cut In Dispute Over Joining a Gang
description: An 11-year-old Brooklyn youth who wanted to start his own gang slashed a boy who would not join, using a pencil sharpener blade during a break at elementary school yesterday, the police said.

title: U.S. Suspends Deportation In I.R.A. Cases
description: The Clinton Administration suspended deportation proceedings today against five veterans of the Irish Republican Army who have settled in the New York region and one from St. Louis, saying that letting them stay in this country ''could contribute to the peace process.''

title: Personal Health
description: THE highly popular drug Prozac and its synthetic rivals may soon be in for competition in this country from a natural herb for the treatment of mild to moderately severe depression.

title: Because New York State Law Is on Her Side Now
description: For decades, there was a gaping hole in New York State law, a sign of prejudice that politicians inexplicably neglected to remedy. But at long last, they have moved to right that wrong. Beginning next year, the same penalties that traditionally have been imposed upon the hit-and-run injurers of dogs will also apply to motorists who mow down cats.

title: Coffee Prices Decline as Rain Aids Crops in 2 Key Regions
description: Coffee futures prices declined yesterday as rainfall in Colombia and Indonesia, two of the world's top producers, raised prospects for world supplies.

title: Cone Is Apprehensive After Bullpen Workout
description: With the team doctor, the team trainer, Manager Joe Torre and the pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre scrutinizing every pitch and every movement David Cone made, the valuable and vulnerable Yankee worked off a bullpen mound at Fenway Park yesterday and tried to determine whether he can still be a factor this season. All four Yankee employees held their breath.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPPER, ELEANOR
description: PEPPER-Eleanor. On September 7, in her 94th year. Beloved sister of the late Benjamin and Morton. Devoted aunt of Alice P. and Carol H.P. Cooper and D. Stephen and Michael Pepper and Sam Hellinger. Family and friends will gather in her apartment at 9 East 96 Street at 1 PM, on Friday, Sept 12. Interment will follow.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Hong Kong's New Leader Disputes U.S. on Rights
description: In the first of a series of high-level visits over the next two months between American and Chinese leaders, the new Chief Executive of Hong Kong, Tung Chee-hwa, sparred with members of Congress over human rights today and declared that Hong Kong would soon enjoy more democracy ''than we ever had in 156 years of colonial rule.''

title: Cooke's Monument Ready to Open Doors
description: Jack Kent Cooke was accustomed to getting his way, especially when it came to his Washington Redskins. He hired Bobby Beathard and Charley Casserly as his general managers and Joe Gibbs as his coach and gave them enough money and a sufficiently free hand to build championship teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMARK, ALICE
description: NEWMARK-Alice. Devoted mother of Ellen Lewy, the late Eva Gitterman. Loving grandmother of Michael, Bob and Barbara, Amy and Brian, Jane and Steven, and Matthew and Nancy. Loving great-grandmother of six. Services at Wien & Wien Funeral Home, Englewood on Wednesday at 1:45. (1-800-322-0533).

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: High-End New Homes For High-End New Cars
description: On 11th Avenue, Manhattan's Automobile Row, the currency is leg room, not square footage; chrome, not granite. But two big renovation projects are hard to ignore, even from a speeding automobile. And that is just the point.

title: Harvard Chair Will Focus A Spotlight On Gender
description: Although some universities have been skittish about taking money to endow chairs in areas like women's studies, gay and lesbian studies or Holocaust studies, which they think may be passing fads, Harvard is creating a chair in gender studies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMBERG, GEORGINE
description: BLOOMBERG-Georgine. Friend Avrutis. Devoted wife of Dr. Allan Ellia Bloomberg. Beloved sister of Shirley Abrams, Arlene Rieser and June Laufman. Dear aunt of Ginger Strauss and Jill Bach. Adored stepmother of Jon, Paul and Seth Bloomberg. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81st, Wednesday at 11:30 AM. The family will receive friends at the Bloomberg residence on Wednesday, 6-8 PM.

title: Diana's Hunters: How Quarry Was Stalked
description: The paparazzi who made their living from the endless pursuit of Diana, Princess of Wales, called it ''being looned'' -- the moment when Diana would lose her cool and flail wildly at the photographers she often accused of making her life a misery.

title: After the Fires of Passion, Lies and a Grim Outlook
description: With her eyes darkened by shadow and heavy mascara and her hair piled on her head, Caroline Finch looked like a mid-1960's English vamp when her band, Linoleum, performed at Wetlands on Friday night. But that was camouflage. Ms. Finch's songs aren't come-ons; they are about what happens after passion gives way to reality. With a pitiless eye and a gift for the lucid detail, she examines the ways people use each other, from temptation to betrayal to weary indifference. ''Each time, he says he won't do it again,'' she observes about one lover. ''But tonight, he knows that he'll do it again.''

title: $2 Million Diverted by Party To Candidates, Records Say
description: In a practice that placed some of its most cherished donors in violation of Federal election laws, the Democratic National Committee took at least $2 million in contributions restricted to generic use by the party and spent it directly on the re-election campaign of President Clinton and other candidates, Federal election records show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLB, LIBBY
description: KOLB-Libby. For as long as we've known Libby, she has been a keen spark in our lives. Her spice, her spirit, her wit, her creative talents and her colorful and unique character stole into our hearts to remain forever. Mindy Orlinsky, Ronnie Faber Joyce Bendavid, Susan Sklarin Zahava Englard

title: Shots Pierce Upper-Crust Calm of Virginia Polo Country
description: Roberto C. Villegas was a star of the Virginia horse country's polo circuit, a 38-year-old Argentine professional with an open face and a mat of black hair. Susan Cummings, 35, slight and introverted, is one of two daughters of Samuel Cummings, a billionaire arms dealer.

title: Griffin to Buy Two Hotels
description: Merv Griffin Hotels, part of the Griffin Group Inc., said today that it would buy the Lafayette Hotel in Miami and the St. Clerans Manor House in Galway, Ireland, in separate transactions for undisclosed amounts. The group's flagship hotel is the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, which it bought in 1987 from the Hilton Hotels Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THAYER, GORDON N.
description: THAYER-Gordon N. On Monday, September 8, 1997 of Short Hills, New Jersey. Husband of Doris Thayer; father of Gordon David Thayer, Richard Thayer and Linda C. Jordan. Also survived by ten grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. Private funeral from the Brough Funeral Home, Summit, New Jersey.

title: In Mexico's Shifting Politics, Traditions Tumble
description: Mexico, in its first weeks of a newly pluralistic political system, abandoned several authoritarian traditions today as the President removed the leader of his party without appointing a new one and the opposition dressed down the Interior Minister in the halls of Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDER, BERNARD
description: LINDER-Bernard. On Sept. 8, 1997 A truly courageous gentleman in every sense of the word who was dearly loved by all and will be sorely missed. He is survived by his beloved wife Norma, his loving children Cheryl and Richard Davids and Suanne and Peter Chiacchiaro. Cherished grandchildren Jamie, Matthew, Cory, Evan, Emily and Pete. Services Wednesday 12PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: CHRONICLE
description: IAN SCHRAGER, the hotel magnate and a former owner of Studio 54, is more likely these days to be singing ''Rock-a-Bye Baby'' than rock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSBERGER, DR. HENRY.
description: ROSBERGER-Dr. Henry. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to his wife Anne and the family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Alan Levine, Ch. of the Bd. Robert P. Antler, President

title: Sinking of Casino Plan Makes Tribes Cry Foul
description: When a half-dozen Minnesota and Wisconsin Indian tribes set out two years ago to sink a rival Indian casino proposal, they turned to some influential Washington insiders for help.

title: Speech on Repentance By Repentant Ex-Judge
description: For Selichot, the solemn Jewish service that marks the start of the season of repentance, some synagogues show movies about the Holocaust. Some play host to celebrity speakers like Alan M. Dershowitz or Elie Wiesel.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column on Aug. 20 about plans to open a Cattleman restaurant in White Plains referred incorrectly to the partners. Along with Larry Ellman, they are Edward Buyes and William Opper. Frank Valenza is a consultant, not a partner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSBERGER, HENRY, MD.
description: ROSBERGER-Henry, MD. Beloved husband of Anne. Devoted father of Daniel (Sonam) and Richard. Loving brother of Sarah Cederbaum, Mollie Rosenberg and Hilda Marsden. Services 11:30AM, Wed., Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Starwood Lodging Signs $540 Million Westin Hotels Deal
description: Starwood Lodging Trust said yesterday that as expected it would acquire Westin Hotels and Resorts, the latest in a growing list of hotel consolidations as the industry enjoys record profits. Under the deal, Starwood will pay about $540 million in cash and stock and assume more than $1 billion in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEICHSEL, DORIS
description: WEICHSEL-Doris. On September 7, 1997. A lady of style, grace and courage. We will always remember and love Aunt Doris. Ruth and Ira R. Hoffman

title: Mosquito-Borne Virus Shuts Long Island Park
description: For the second straight year, officials on Long Island have closed a state park because of an infestation of mosquitoes carrying the Eastern equine encephalitis virus.

title: As Taboo Fades, Actors See Little Career Jeopardy in Playing Gay Characters
description: Fifteen years ago, 20th Century Fox released ''Making Love,'' a movie about a man who leaves his wife for another man. Virtually every young star, including Harrison Ford and Michael Douglas, turned the film down.

title: Shifting Documentaries
description: Documentaries produced by Turner Original Productions have won a shelf full of awards for their parent network, TBS, the flagship of the Turner cable empire. But low ratings will trump trophies every time, and with the TBS's sister network CNN hungry for more documentary-style programming, Turner Broadcasting has decided to drop most original documentaries from TBS, and steer them to CNN.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGUIRE, THOMAS
description: MAGUIRE-Thomas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas Maguire, associated with The Times from 1961, until retiring in 1977.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, GERTA (WEINIGER)
description: GRUEN-Gerta (Weiniger). Died September 8, 1997. Devoted wife of William, beloved sister of Ron and Jaffa Vered, Tel-Aviv, and Harry and Lore Kirchheimer, Chicago; dear loving aunt of Opal, David, Jim, Guri and Lea, great aunt to 10 nieces and nephews and beloved by all. She was a geriatric researcher, poet, and author. Her devotion and active participation will be missed at the Jewish Community Center of Palisades, Englewood & Washington Heights Institute of Retired Persons. Services at 11 a.m. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Treasuries Dip in Wait-and-See Trading
description: Treasury securities dipped yesterday on weakness in the dollar against the yen and apprehension about a heavy supply of corporate and global debt that will be priced in coming days.

title: New Investment Alliance
description: ETrade Group Inc. said today that it had agreed to form an alliance with the investment bank Robertson Stephens & Company to provide stock offerings and investment research through the Internet. ETrade is an on-line brokerage firm based in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Giants' Weary Defense Tries to Regroup
description: Jim Fassel did not need to watch the game films from the Giants' loss last Sunday at Jacksonville to comprehend his team's problem. All he had to do was to check the labels on the videotapes he was handed and it was easy to understand what was wrong.

title: Hundley's Bad Elbow Takes Turn For Worse
description: Todd Hundley swung and missed in the first inning last night and a searing pain jolted through him, from his right elbow to his finger tips, the worst pain he said he had ever felt. He might not swing a bat again until next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORAH, GOLDIE
description: BORAH-Goldie. Beloved mother, grandmother, friend, musician. Loved by all who knew her. Services Thursday, Sept 11, Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY at 10AM.

title: Mary Sears, 92, Oceanographic Editor and Scientist at Woods Hole
description: Mary Sears, a researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution for more than 60 years and a guiding editorial force behind several top scientific publications devoted to marine studies, died on Sept. 2 at her home in Woods Hole, Mass. She was 92.

title: 550 Duke Energy Jobs Cut
description: The Duke Energy Corporation said today that it would cut 550 jobs at its Duke Power subsidiary in the next several months through voluntary departures and layoffs. Jobs will be cut in the unit's electric system support, nuclear generation and power generation departments, which together employ a total of 7,500.

title: Cone, Yanks Facing Race Against Time
description: UNDER the late afternoon sun in the visitors' bullpen in right field in Fenway Park yesterday, the right arm upon which much of the Yankees' pennant hopes rests prepared to warm up. The arm belonged to their remarkable pitcher, David Cone, who has had enough drama in the last two years to have made Dostoyevsky envious. The arm would be undergoing a significant test.

title: Incumbents in Most Races Fend Off the Challengers
description: Despite stiff challenges in several New York City Council races, only one incumbent fell in the primary yesterday, but a handful of newcomers will still take office next year because of vacant seats in eight districts.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: 'Soft Money' Laws Made Room For Wealthiest Donors Again
description: Election laws enacted after the Watergate scandals were intended to prevent wealthy donors from being able to bankroll candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUDNER, FAY
description: STUDNER-Fay. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed honorary member, Fay Studner, and extend sincere condolences to her family. Roy R. Raizen, President

title: Islanders Name McCabe Captain
description: When the 22-year-old Bryan McCabe was named captain of the Islanders today, it was a symbolic move, even if General Manager Mike Milbury did not intend it to be.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. SHEILA E. WIDNALL is the United States Air Force's most enthusiastic booster, as well she should be. She is Secretary of the Air Force, the first woman in that post, and yesterday she had abundant words of praise for her branch of the military as she spoke at a breakfast of the Women's Forum at the New York Helmsley Hotel on East 42d Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUARASCIO, SANDRA
description: GUARASCIO - Sandra. Beloved daughter of Natalie and Louis, loving sister of Susan, Natalie, Maria, Louis and Laura, devoted aunt of Joseph, Katie, Hayley and Richard. Reposing Victor Quirolo and Sons, 3176 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, New York. Mass at OLA Church on Thursday, 9:30 AM.

title: Thompson Hires BBDO Executive
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company said yesterday that it had hired a top executive from BBDO Worldwide as its third worldwide creative director.

title: Lily-White Town
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Bodies on the Beach

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, SONIA, NEE ''ZOSIA'' GERTLER
description: REED-Sonia, nee ''Zosia'' Gertler, age 73, of Lenox and Boynton Beach, FL, died September 8th in Pittsfield, MA. Beloved wife of Curt and loving mother of David, Deborah and Shelley. Memorial services will be held Thursday at 1:00 PM at Devanny-Condron Funeral Home in Pittsfield, MA.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the plastics industry referred incorrectly to Styrofoam, a product of the Dow Chemical Company. It is used primarily in insulation, not in consumer products like cups.

title: $10 Million In Looted Art Is Recovered
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they had recovered more than $10 million worth of valuable drawings, including works by Rembrandt and Albrecht Durer, which were part of the collection looted from the Bremen museum in Germany at the chaotic end of World War II and later stolen from the National Museum of Baku in Azerbaijan.

title: Mirage Sues Trump On Atlantic City Plan
description: Mirage Resorts Inc. said yesterday that it was suing Donald J. Trump, Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts and the Hilton Hotels Corporation, saying they unfairly tried to block Mirage's plans for a development in Atlantic City.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei average of 225 stocks was down 47.31 points, or one-quarter of 1 percent, at 18,648.66. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 62.11 points.

title: ISLAMIC MILITANTS IN GAZA PICKED UP BY ARAFAT POLICE
description: Under heavy Israeli and American pressure to crack down on Islamic militants after recent suicide bombings in Jerusalem, the Palestinian Authority was reported today to have arrested scores of suspected members of the militant Hamas movement in the Gaza Strip.

title: Ashburn Provided Hits, and Humor
description: Richie Ashburn is in the Hall of Fame for his 2,574 hits, 2 batting titles and .308 lifetime batting average. But the longtime Phillies player and broadcaster, who died yesterday after an apparent heart attack, was remembered by friends for his ability to generate laughter.

title: Sabatino Moscati, Linguist, Is Dead at 74
description: Sabatino Moscati, an expert on Semitic languages whose work as an archeologist led him to champion the influence of Semitic peoples like the Phoenicians on the development of European culture, died at his home here on Monday. He was 74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, BROOKE EMMENS
description: GONZALEZ - Brooke Emmens. Cherished and beloved daughter of Diana and Peter William Gonzalez and adored sister of Peter Jr. died September 4, 1997 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Brooke, a freshman at Brown University, had attended the Spence School and graduated from Deerfield Academy. She was Vice President of her senior class at Deerfield and twice a member of the US International 420 Sailing Team, competing in the last two world championships. Her spirit, zest for life and compassionate heart will be deeply missed by all. Memorial services Thursday, September 11, at 4 PM, at St. Thomas More Church, NYC, and Saturday, September 13 at 11 AM, American Yacht Club, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Brooke Emmens Gonzalez Memorial Fund at Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA 01342.

title: Turnabout in the Affirmative Action Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELDON, HENRY L.
description: WELDON-Henry L. September 8, 1997. Loving grandson of the late Louis M. Colton; son of the late Henry and Elizabeth Weldon; brother of Louise W. Floeckher of Palm Beach, FL; devoted father of Henry L. III and Alexander C. Cherished friend of Virginia Pagetti. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, 11:00 A.M., St. Vincent Ferrer Church, (Lexington Avenue at 66 Street), NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Central Park Conservancy, Attn: S. Collins, 10 Columbus Circle, Suite 2155, New York, New York 10019.

title: Trenton Orders Safety Valves on Gas Mains
description: In the wake of a 1994 explosion that destroyed eight apartment buildings in Edison, N.J., state officials have ordered utilities to start installing remote-controlled shutoff valves that would close gas pipelines quickly in an emergency to stop fires from spreading.

title: A small agency creates a campaign for Black & Decker's new line of Kitchen Tools.
description: A PRODUCER of prosaic household appliances is undertaking an ambitious effort to carve out a succulent slice of the lucrative market for higher-priced kitchen gadgets.

title: Diversity on the Bench
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ARTWORKS FOUND -- Prosecutors said they had recovered valuable drawings, including a Rembrandt, that were looted from Germany at the end of World War II. B3.

title: Sneakiness on Guns Makes for Bad Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton and Helms Resume Weld Fight
description: President Clinton today issued his strongest statement yet in support of William F. Weld to be Ambassador to Mexico, telling an audience that Presidential nominees were ''entitled'' to hearings.

title: Executive Changes
description: KRAFT FOODS, Northfield, Ill., a unit of the Philip Morris Cos., plans to combine its former Maxwell House and Post divisions. The company said the combined coffee and cereals division would be headed by Ann M. Fudge, as executive vice president of Kraft Foods and president of the division. In addition, the company is combining its beverage and dessert divisions. James R. Craigie, 43, general manager of the beverage division, was named executive vice president of Kraft Foods and president of the combined division.

title: New Negotiations Reported on Tobacco Pact
description: White House officials and tobacco industry representatives are negotiating a possible overhaul of the provisions on youth smoking in the proposed $368.5 billion tobacco settlement that could reduce fines against companies and increase cigarette costs, people involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: What's Left for AOL?
description: America Online's acquisition of Compuserve's customer base is a smart strategic move because it allows America Online to expand its reach while eliminating its chief rival. But the deal, which also includes the sale of America Online's transmission network, doesn't address looming hurdles. The most serious of these may be potential competition from bare-bones E-mail and Internet service providers.

title: MESSINGER FACES SHARPTON IN SEPT. 23 MAYORAL RUNOFF; DEMOCRATIC TURNOUT LIGHT
description: Ruth W. Messinger was forced last night into a runoff for the Democratic mayoral nomination with the Rev. Al Sharpton, as a low voter turnout in a three-way race, combined with a strong performance by Mr. Sharpton, dashed her hope for a jubilant primary night sendoff into the fall campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, ESTHER (NEE CHARAP)
description: GOLDFARB-Esther (nee Charap) on September 8, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Naomi Solomon. Adored grandmother of Marjorie, Neil, Daniel and Glenn and greatgrandmother of Jacob, Sam, Jordon and Adam. Services Thurs, 1PM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, L.I.

title: Hypnosis May Cause False Memories
description: HYPNOSIS, even self-hypnosis, can sometimes result in the creation of false memories -- the belief that something happened even though it never did. A psychologist at Ohio State University in Lima and fellow researchers found that even when people were warned about the possibility of acquiring pseudo-memories under hypnosis, more than a quarter of them did anyway.

title: Columbia/HCA Says Its 3d-Quarter Earnings Will Fall
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that stagnant business at its 342 hospitals, as well as costs stemming from Federal fraud inquiries, would drag down profits in its third quarter.

title: City Hospital Lease Exceeds Law, Appeals Panel Rules
description: A state appeals court panel has ruled that New York City's hospitals agency exceeded its authority in trying to lease Coney Island Hospital to a company, the second legal setback that the Giuliani administration has encountered in its attempts to privatize the hospital system.

title: Ford Parts Unit Is Given a Name
description: The Ford Motor Company has renamed its parts-making subsidiary Visteon, establishing a identity intended to help the unit attract outside customers.

title: A Senate of Dictators
description: To the Editor:

title: Hail to Summer's End and Farewell
description: Plump, juicy, bright red tomatoes that hang heavy on the vine; basil that grows profusely, and so many cucumbers that you run out of ideas for using them: these are just the foods to close out the hot days of summer, and to provide a final note for this column, which will cease this week. This installment remains true to the roots of Plain and Simple: an uncomplicated grilled salmon with a cucumber vinaigrette and tomatoes with basil sauce, dishes that are quick to fix, low in fat and calories and good to eat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MIRIAM
description: STERN-Miriam. On September 8, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Herman R., devoted mother of Linda, cherished grandmother of David, loving sister of Milton and Caroline and the late Jeanette and Albert. She was a beloved aunt and great-aunt to many. Services on Wednesday, 12:30 P.M., at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer'' Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN
description: BERNSTEIN-On the occasion of the opening of the Museum of Jewish Heritage in New York, I feel more than ever the loss of my parents, Franz and Gertrud Bernstein, 42, and my brother Benno, 14, who perished in the Holocaust. My twin Marianne Wodrig and husband Gerd. I will miss and love them as long as I live. Lisa Herz

title: My Lesson in School Politics
description: For eight months last year, my family lived in a small village in the south of France. During our stay, my 10-year-old daughter and 4-year-old son attended the local public school, and we became friends with the parents of our children's friends.

title: Trump Plans Indiana Hotel
description: The Trump Organization's Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc. has announced plans to build a 300-room hotel at the Trump Indiana riverboat casino at Buffington Harbor, Ind. The Atlantic City-based hotel and casino operator said the hotel would include conference meeting rooms. Construction is expected to be completed by October 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, ISABEL W.
description: ROSENBERG-Isabel W. Isabel dearest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANCHOFF, CANTOR MOSHE
description: GANCHOFF-Cantor Moshe. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion mark the ''Shloshim'' of the passing of Cantor Moshe Ganchoff. We express our sorrow at the loss of one its most revered teachers, a world renowned Cantor and composer. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, President Burton Lehman, Chair Board of Governors Cantor Israel Goldstein, Director School of Sacred Music

title: Banks Gets The Ball And Yanks Stop Boston
description: Willie Banks was talking about being a Yankee, feeling like a Yankee and winning a game for the Yankees against the Red Sox, 8-6. It was obvious that the kid, who is no longer a kid at 28 years old, could have rambled for hours. So pull up a stool and listen to what it is like to be the Yankee fan who becomes a Yankee.

title: Al Agonistes, Again
description: The Spot is growing. Maybe even galloping. That Rogaine better kick in before the millennium. Tipper says I'm paranoid, but I'm not. Everyone is out to get me. Nothing is going perfectly.

title: Kohl's Pains: Lagging East, Inflation, The Jobless
description: After a summer of indecorous squabbling among his supposed political allies, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany was offered little comfort today from statistics showing unemployment at record levels, inflation increasing and evidence that eastern Germany is falling further behind the west in economic growth.

title: Diary's New Home
description: Starting next Wednesday, the Metropolitan Diary moves to The Metro Section.

title: In the Prisons of Puerto Rico, Gangs Have the Upper Hand
description: Like prison gangs elsewhere, the Netas in Puerto Rico have been involved with drugs, extortion and other illegal activities while they were behind bars. But unlike other gangs, they also formed a nonprofit organization, receiving government money to run prison programs.

title: Connecticut's 'Megan's Law' Is Declared Constitutional
description: A Federal appeals court has declared that Connecticut's ''Megan's Law'' is constitutional, ruling that the state's plan to notify communities of the presence of sex offenders is intended to protect society, not to punish offenders.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: For Food-Stamp Families, a More Uncertain Future
description: HER refrigerator is nearly empty. There are 10 cans of food left in the kitchen cabinet. Ruth Acosta looks over her meager spread -- sweet peas, instant potatoes, cling peaches, kidney beans -- and a grimace crosses her face.

title: FINOVA AGREES TO PAY $90 MILLION FOR MORTGAGE LENDER
description: The Finova Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a commercial mortgage lender, the Belgravia Capital Corporation, for about $90 million in cash and Finova stock plus additional payments of as much as $90 million over the next three years. Finova, based in Phoenix, a lender to midsize companies, will pay Belgravia as much as $30 million a year for the next three years, contingent on Belgravia's reaching an undisclosed net income target. Belgravia, based in Irvine, Calif., has 16 regional offices nationwide and generated $1.2 billion of loans in 1996. The lender's average loan size is between $2 million and $15 million for industrial, office, retail, self-storage, mobile home park and multifamily properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, MIRIAM
description: GOLD-Miriam. Congregation Kolami Jewish Community Center of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and convey sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark Hershey, President

title: Kovalev Has Fistful of Dollars, And Faces Fistful of Questions
description: Now that Aleksei Kovalev has agreed to a new contract with the Rangers, it is appropriate to move to the next items on his long questionnaire:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, BRUCE A.
description: KAUFMAN-Bruce A. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Bruce A. Kaufman, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. David L. Rudnick, Pres. Robert S. Puder, Sec'y

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Coming in '99: Another Way to Pay I.R.S.
description: The Government said today that using its new authority it planned to make paying income taxes so easy that taxpayers need do nothing more than allow the Internal Revenue Service to dip into their bank accounts in early 1999.

title: Amex Goes Live On the Internet
description: For those who want to get a taste of Wall Street without actually having to go there, the American Stock Exchange has this alternative: a live video of the trading floor available via the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAVZOW, HAZEL
description: CRAVZOW-Hazel. Temple Israel Lawrence, New York, mourns the death of its beloved member and extends deepest sympathy to his family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: A Little Late for Dinner, After That Awful Trip
description: Holocaust dramas tend to be so relentlessly grim that ''My Mother's Courage,'' a smart, unsettling comedy edged with horror about a plucky Hungarian woman who narrowly escapes deportation to Auschwitz, requires a sharp adjustment of perspective. The tone of the film, which goes out of its way to avoid the customary solemnity surrounding its subject, veers unpredictably between warmhearted humor and savage irony.

title: On a Beach Lined With Ferry's Dead, Haitians Mourn
description: United Nations divers continued today with the grisly task of removing bodies from the overcrowded ferry that capsized and sank in 100 feet of water here early Monday. Several thousand people looked on anxiously from the beach, just a few yards away, and from the tops of walls and the branches of trees, occasionally breaking into wails.

title: Talks Resume In Walkout In Bay Area
description: Tens of thousands of commuters spent a second day yesterday searching for new ways around the San Francisco Bay Area, which has been tied in knots by a strike by workers on the Bay Area Rapid Transit system.

title: Lawyer Says 3d Test Confirms Diana's Driver Was Drunk
description: A new blood test has confirmed earlier findings that the driver in the crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, had a level of alcohol that would be produced by drinking the equivalent of eight to nine glasses of wine before the accident, more than three times the legal limit in France, lawyers and the police said today.

title: Manhattan Democrats Nominate Fields for the Borough Presidency
description: C. Virginia Fields, a City Councilwoman who touted her roots in the civil rights movement during a bitter campaign involving a diverse field of six candidates, won the Democratic nomination for Manhattan borough president yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, LELA HENDRY
description: SLATTERY-Lela Hendry. In Manhattan on September 7th, in her 81st year. Survived by her loving husband Louis, son John, daughter Elizabeth Spahr, grandchildren Kate and James Slattery and Nicholas and Emily Spahr, and daughter-in-law Kathy Slatteryall of Manhattan. Funeral service at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue at 71st St at 11:00 AM, on Friday, September 12, 1997.

title: Jordan-St. John's Deal
description: To expand his empire, MICHAEL JORDAN has gone back to college.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN
description: KENNEDY-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Kennedy, associated with The Times from 1951, until retiring in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURALT, CHARLES
description: KURALT-Charles. You are remembered and missed every day. Your friend Jan Sheldon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MEYER
description: ROSEN-Meyer. With much love. Cherished husband to Lillian. Dearest father to David, Barbara, Francine and Bill. Adored grandfather to Lana, Peter, Dana, Darin and Allison. Precious great grandfather to Nicole and Ryan. Our icon for support and love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLAM, EUGENE JOSEPH
description: FULLAM-Eugene Joseph, 69, of Lattingtown, died after a long illness on September 9. Beloved husband of Adele and father of Anne, Eugene, Kristin, Peter and Karen Brennan. Also survived by four grandchildren. Licensed professional engineer New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania. Owner of Twin County Steel, St. James. WWII veteran, First Marine Corps Division, Northern China. Served on Manhattan College Board of Trustees. Friends may visit 3-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. on Thursday at McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home, Glen Cove. Funeral mass 11 A.M. Friday, at St. Hyacinth's R.C. Church, Glen Head. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to aid colon cancer research.

title: World Bank Report Sees Era of Emerging Economies
description: The World Bank forecast today that growth in developing countries would accelerate over the next decade, and that the five biggest emerging economies -- China, India, Indonesia, Brazil and Russia -- would become economic powerhouses in the next quarter-century.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 2 about a lawsuit filed by Joseph Garcia, an actor who was dismissed from the Broadway revival of ''Show Boat,'' misstated the role played by an actress who the suit said was involved in a dispute with Mr. Garcia. According to the show's representatives, the actress, Karen Curlee, played the role of Dottie, and was also a member of the ensemble; she did not play Magnolia. (The error was pointed out several weeks later by a caller to The Times.)

title: Follies at the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAXTER, ANTHONY CAMPBELL
description: BAXTER - Anthony Campbell. Born to John and Marion Baxter on April 27, 1939 in Garden City, New York. He was one of six children. He attended the College of The Holy Cross & was graduated from Cathedral College. Married to Margaret Mary Regan, April 29, 1967. After a successful executive career in the home furnishings industry working for companies such as Baxter, Kelly, and Faust, Greeff Fabrics, Katzen Bach and Warren, and Scalamandre. He had begun a career with Coldwell Banker Realties in Bedford Village, New York. Along with his wife of thirty years Margaret, he is survived by his five children and three daughters-in-law, Anthony R. and Dawn of Ryebrook, New York, Kevin C. and Kimberley of Manhattan Beach, California, Richard R. and Gina of Manhattan, New York. Daughters Mary R. of Boston, Massachusetts and Kathleen B. of Bedford Village, New York. Information: OelkerCox Funeral Home, 262 Main Street, Mount Kisco, New York.

title: Real Estate Firm Expands
description: Cushman & Wakefield, the New York-based real estate brokerage and management company, said yesterday that it had completed its purchase of Premisys Real Estate Services, the property management division of Prudential Insurance Company, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GASARCH, RIVIA M.
description: GASARCH-Rivia M. Beloved wife of the late Harry D. Devoted mother of Mark. Dear sister of Ruth Benenfeld and Mildred Chesney. Loving grandmother of Eve and Shira. Cherished aunt of Marian, Eric, Richard and Mark. Service today, at 12 Noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: Food Notes
description: 150 Brews to Taste in Brooklyn

title: The Race Was Uphill, Then Came Sharpton
description: Ruth W. Messinger's tortured quest to become mayor would have been difficult enough without her having to face an opponent in an embarrassing runoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRK, DR. EVELYN URBAN BUCHLER
description: SHIRK-Dr. Evelyn Urban Buchler. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Dr. Evelyn Urban Buchler Shirk, Professor Emerita of Philosophy. Professor Shirk died on August 24, 1997 after a short illness. She graduated cum laude with her A.B. degree from Wilson College, and earned her M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Columbia University. She came to Hofstra in 1949 as an Assistant Professor of Philosophy, became a full professor in 1963, and in 1967 became Department Chair. She was President of Hofstra's AAUP Chapter and of the faculty honor society, Sigma Kappa Alpha, which preceded Hofstra's Phi Beta Kappa Chapter, in which she also served as President. In tribute to the memory of Professor Shirk, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half staff. James M. Shuart, President Helene Fortunoff, Chairperson, Board of Trustees Hofstra University

title: Sneakiness on Guns Makes for Bad Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, JOHN RANDOLPH
description: HARRISON-John Randolph, of Hightstown, NJ. On September 8, 1997, age 93. Father of Josephine H. Evarths of Mt. Kisco, NY, Randolph Harrison of Mill Neck, NY and Robert C. Harrison of New York NY. Grandfather of eight, great-grandfather of 16. Stepfather of Lawrence W. Fox, III, Diane F. Downs and Cary F. Fisher. Private serice Hollywood Cemetery, Richmond, VA. Memorial contributions to St. Paul's School, Concord, NH 03301 appreciated.

title: Studying Airport Pollution
description: Environmentalists and elected officials will seek to drum up support today for legislation to determine whether smog-forming gases emitted at the state's airports have reached dangerous levels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, MAURICE
description: LEVINE-Maurice. Beloved husband of Bobbi Baird. Father of Tedra Schneider, Michael Levine, Whitney Levine and Sigmund Romberg Levine. Passed away Monday, September 8, 1997. The marinara sauce has ended, but the melody lingers on. Funeral service at Riverside Memorial on Wednesday, September 10, 1997 at 11:15 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUCCI, PHYLLIS
description: CUCCI-Phyllis U., of Brooklyn on September 8, 1997. Beloved wife of Vincent E. Cucci, Sr. Loving mother of Vincent E., Jr., John P., and Richard C. Cucci, and Dorothy A. Siclare. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Ave, Staten Island on Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Teresa's R.C. Church 11 AM.
