Entombment Calvary Cemetery. Visitation Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: Storyteller At the Top Of His Form
description: THE COMPLETE STORIES

title: WESTERN RESOURCES PLANS TO BUY SECURITY COMPANY
description: Western Resources Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Network Multi-Family, an electronic security provider, for about $171 million in cash and assumed debt. The closely held Network Multi-Family, based in Dallas, has more than 200,000 subscribers in apartment complexes in 38 states. Western Resources, a gas utility based in Topeka, Kan., also disclosed yesterday that it had sold 5.4 million Tyco International Ltd. shares to Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. for $446 million. The sale reduced the company's stake in Tyco to about 4.6 percent from about 6.5 percent. On Aug. 15, Tyco agreed to discontinue all litigation with Western Resources arising from Tyco's $5.6 billion acquisition of ADT Ltd. in July. Western was a rival suitor for ADT.

title: A Course That's a Feast of Films
description: ''BABETTE'S FEAST'' and ''Tampopo,'' standouts in the pantheon of food films, make you hungry for something other than a tub of popcorn. These films, along with others that deal with eating, will be the subject of an eight-session course to be given this fall by Doris Weisberg, a television producer, at New York University's School of Continuing Education.

title: 1996 Democratic Chief Admits Arranging Access for Big Donors
description: Donald L. Fowler, the national chairman of the Democratic Party in last year's election campaign, acknowledged publicly today that he had intervened with officials of the Clinton Administration on behalf of some of the party's largest donors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARDON, EUNICE POLK NORTON
description: PARDON-Eunice Polk Norton. Age 73, of Ten Springs Drive, Saratoga Springs, New York. Died on Saturday 9-6-97 at home after a long illness. Surviving relatives are son Todd Pardon; grandson Dexter Guy Pardon both of Saratoga Springs; sister Ann Harrington of Newport Beach, California.

title: Accounts
description: * U.S. Air Force Reserve Command, Warner Robins, Ga., to TMP Worldwide , New York, to handle recruitment advertising, which had been handled by HMS Partners, Columbus, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BASSEN, DR. EDWARD J.
description: BASSEN-Dr. Edward J. Always in the hearts of your wife, Lupe, and your family, especially Frank, Numi and Millie.

title: Not Equally Qualified
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Hear Clinton Tell Of Priorities For the Fall
description: Declaring the economic and political drag of budget deficits to be a thing of the past, President Clinton moved on today to a broad agenda for the rest of the year, trying to summon support for a grab bag of causes from expanding trade to tightening pollution controls to passing wide-reaching laws to restrict tobacco.

title: Productivity Up; What It Signals Is Still Debated
description: The productivity of American workers -- measuring how much they produce in an hour on the job -- was much higher in the second quarter than originally estimated, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But both sides in a growing debate over the efficiency of the nation's work force saw support for their viewpoints in the new figures.

title: Schools and Industry Clash Over Site in Brooklyn
description: Hoping to end a long and increasingly bitter dispute involving public school parents and a food company in Brooklyn, the Giuliani administration has announced a plan that would allow construction of a badly needed new school and also allow the company to expand its plant.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP PLANS TO BUY UNITED AMERICAN BANK
description: Colonial Bancgroup agreed yesterday to buy United American Bank of Central Florida for $70 million in stock, expanding Colonial's banking business into central Florida. United American, a unit of the Florida Security Holding Corporation, has nine branch offices in the greater Orlando area. The purchase brings Colonial's assets in central Florida to more than $850 million and 33 branches. Colonial is a multistate holding company, based in Montgomery, Ala., with assets of $6.5 billion and 181 offices in four states. Shares of Colonial were unchanged at $27.9375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Long Apprenticeship Ends for Penn State's McQueary
description: Breaking a couple of records was not exactly what Mike McQueary expected in his debut as Penn State's starting quarterback in the season opener against Pittsburgh last Saturday.

title: Furrowed Brows at Messinger Headquarters
description: As the clock ticked toward 11 P.M. and the reality of the ballot count slowly set in, the Democrats outside Ruth W. Messinger's suite on the 33d floor of the Grand Hyatt Hotel scratched their heads, shrugged their shoulders and furrowed their brows.

title: BARRICK GOLD PLANS TO SET ASIDE $385 MILLION
description: The Barrick Gold Corporation, a Canadian gold producer, said yesterday that it would set aside $385 million to cover third-quarter writedowns of mines in Chile and the United States. The company said the provision would cover the write-down of the El Indio and Tambo mines in Chile, and the Bullfrog, Mercur and Pinson mines in the United States. A write-down is a reduction in asset value on a company's financial statement. The moves are part of a two-year plan to increase cash flow by increasing output at low-cost properties and phasing out higher-cost mines. Barrick said it would concentrate on exploring its own properties in North and South America.

title: Hans J. Eysenck, 81, a Heretic In the Field of Psychotherapy
description: Hans J. Eysenck, one of the most distinguished, prolific and maddeningly perverse psychologists of his generation, died on Sept. 4 at a hospice in London. He was 81.

title: Millions of Mourners
description: More than 30 million people in the United States roused themselves in the middle of the night last weekend to watch the television coverage of the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, on eight networks. The figure was slightly lower than some initial estimates but still beyond any number previously recorded by Nielsen Media Research for an event between 4 and 8 A.M., Eastern time.

title: Xerox Takes Next Step Out Of Insurance
description: The Xerox Corporation, continuing to liquidate its insurance holdings, said yesterday that it was selling one of its three remaining units to a management investment group for $612 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEGUN, BENSON H.
description: BEGUN-Benson H. On September 8, 1997. Beloved husband of Angela, loving son of Ruth and the late Harry. Cherished father of Harold and Ellen, Matthew and Elizabeth, Daniel and devoted brother of Marcia, beloved cousin of Martin Begun. All mourn his passing after an arduous and difficult illness. Fortified with extraordinary determination to survive, blessed with an intellect and winning personality he strove and achieved excellence in his professional life and nurtured a loving family. A graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School where he was awarded the high honor of being an Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar and an Editor of the Law Review. His career in entertainment law was highlighted by his association with olumbia Pictures, Warner-Amex and the Fox Film Corp. Service to be held Wednesday 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Leukemia Society of America, 600 3rd Avenue, NYC. His spirit will remain in our hearts forever.

title: Anti-Gun Group Praises State
description: New Jersey's efforts to keep guns away from children won high marks yesterday from a group that promotes gun control.

title: Confronting Peace, a Warrior Finds His Greatest Challenge
description: Bertrand Tavernier's tough, contemplative wartime epic ''Capitaine Conan'' unfolds in historical limbo, set among French troops who continue fighting in the Balkans even after the Armistice ending World War I has been declared. That atmosphere of strife and confusion ably mirrors the film's moral climate, in which Mr. Tavernier brings his characteristic acuity to bear in weighing the meaning of combat and the ethics of a true warrior. Conan (Philippe Torreton), the film's brave and stubborn hero, is a fighter by nature, for better and for worse.

title: Richie Ashburn, Whiz Kid and Original Met, Dies at 70
description: Richie Ashburn, the Hall of Fame center fielder who starred for the Philadelphia Phillies' pennant-winning Whiz Kids of 1950 and concluded his career as the lone All-Star and designated quipster for the original Mets of 1962, died yesterday. He was 70.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, LEWIS
description: STEINMAN-Lewis. The partners and staff of Goldfarb & Fleece mourn the passing of our longtime friend and colleague, Lewis Steinman. We extend to his family our deep-felt sympathy and condolences.

title: Article 1997091000000022144 -- No Title
description: The Health page, including Personal Health, will move to Science Times beginning on Tuesday.

title: Street Justice: Banks' Gadfly Now a Lawyer
description: THE law offices of Matthew Lee look as if a team of litigators collided with a battalion of handymen, with casebooks and file folders scattered among tool chests covering the worn, tile floor. In one nook, a wooden plank sags under the weight of dozens of law books in Mr. Lee's fledgling law library.

title: 7Up to Change Its Formula
description: The Dr Pepper/Seven-Up beverage unit of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. will change the recipe for its 7Up soft drink in a bid to gain on Sprite, a brand of the Coca-Cola Company, a Cadbury official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESPOSITO, JOHN A.
description: ESPOSITO-John A. District Attorney Charles J. Hynes and all the staff of the Kings County District Attorney's Office mourns the passing of our friend and colleague John A. Esposito. John was a volunteer Assistant District Attorney in the Kings County District Attorney's Office, who passed away on September 7th, 1997. He was a longtime community activist who among other positions, served as a six term member of the New York State Assembly from the 23rd Assembly District. In November 1992, he joined this Office to aid in the prosecution of those who victimize the elderly. My staff and I offer our sincere condolences to his wife Estelle, and his family. His dedication and service to the senior community of Kings County and to this Office will long be remembered. Charles J. Hynes District Attorney Kings County

title: Mr. Fowler's Selective Memory
description: We have now heard from Donald Fowler, who seems barely to remember that he ran the Democratic National Committee during the last election cycle. Mr. Fowler would have the country believe that the party suffered from ''deficient'' vetting of donors and ''mistakes of process, not intent,'' as he told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee yesterday. But D.N.C. and White House documents produced at the hearing made plain that at least in one prominent case of fund-raising abuse, the vetting of a dubious donor was just fine. It was an insatiable appetite for money that drove the campaign to misconduct.

title: Korean Mines Don't Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, JEREMY JON
description: BENDER-Jeremy Jon, 21, 9/1/97. Beloved son of Sharon Elizabeth Bender and Alan Scott Meyer. A senior at NYU/Gallatin. Memorial service 9/13, 11:00 A.M. Graham Chapel, Washington University, St. Louis. ''Je t'aime Jeremy Jon.''

title: INVACARE PLANS TO TAKE A $39 MILLION AFTER-TAX CHARGE
description: The Invacare Corporation said yesterday that it would take a third-quarter pretax charge of about $61 million as it accelerates its plan to lower operating costs. The charge was equal to $39 million, or $1.27 a share, after taxes, said Thomas Miklich, a spokesman for the company, a maker of respiratory and mobility equipment for home health care. Invacare, based in Elyria, Ohio, also said its board had approved the repurchase of as many as 5 million of its shares. Invacare currently has about 28 million shares outstanding. The third-quarter charge consists of $34 million to cover the cost of consolidating facilities. Shares of Invacare rose $2, to $23.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Fight for Second Place
description: The first Thursday-night showdown of the new season comes tomorrow: a showdown for second place, that is, after NBC's popular drama ''E.R.'' Offering something entirely different, ABC has put a second night of ''20/20'' into that 10 P.M. slot, opposite ''48 Hours'' on CBS.

title: Theater in Review
description: Yearning for a Home

title: Venus Williams's Father Stands By His Remarks
description: One day after his daughter returned home from the United States Open tennis championships, Richard Williams reiterated his concerns yesterday about the values and views on the women's tennis tour.

title: Elation for Sharpton and Campaign Workers
description: ''Sharpton!'' ''Sharpton!''

title: To Speed Up Gas Switches
description: Since customers of the New Jersey Natural Gas Company were eager to join a pilot program allowing them to choose their natural gas supplier, the Board of Public Utilities voted yesterday to speed up the process, a spokesman said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It may not be possible to do national testing in America under government sponsorship. There may just be too many fault lines in our politics and our educational systems.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINSON, HOPKINS, MARIAN
description: HOPKINSON - HOPKINS - Marian. Beloved godmother of Helen W. Wallace, & former Vice President of Brown, Harris, Stevens, died peacefully in her sleep early Monday morning. Friends may visit at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday from 4-8 P.M. Funeral is Thursday September 11th, at 1 P.M., Saint Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. A gift in her memory may be made to The Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd Street, New York City 10021-8383.

title: Potboiler Dreams: Chef Hopes To Write His Way Out of the Kitchen
description: HE was a chef with a checkered past, a peripatetic career and no writing experience. Then an old college chum in the marketing business offered him a 10-day vacation in Cozumel, Mexico, if he would write a novel, any kind of novel, when he returned.

title: Union Chief Criticizes Pupil Promotion Policy
description: Seeking to sharpen the debate over national educational testing, Sandra Feldman, the new president of the American Federation of Teachers, assailed today what she called the ''rampant'' policy of promoting unprepared pupils to the next grade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBER, ANNE M. (NEE SULLIVAN)
description: WERBER-Anne M. (nee Sullivan), of Great Neck, NY died peacefully at home September 7, 1997 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Frank. Devoted mother of Frank Jr., Robert, John and Andrew. Dear sister of Clare Kavanagh. Loving grandmother of Nicholas, Elizabeth and William. Sisterinlaw of Isabel Sue Werber, Florence M. Werber,and Raymond E. Kavanagh. Visitation at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Monday 79PM; Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday 9:45 A.M., St. Aloysius Church, Great Neck. Burial at All Saints Cemetery, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Pathfinder Village for Down Syndrome Children, R.R. #

title: Theater in Review
description: A Fast-Moving Melodrama

title: Wed as a Publicity Stunt, Then Finding Ambiguities
description: Ambiguity is one theme of ''The Marital Bliss of Francis and Maxine,'' which the Fay Simpson Dance Theater presented on Saturday night at the Ohio Theater. Ambiguities of plot also account for both the strengths and weaknesses of this musical theater production, conceived and choreographed by Bill Torres and Ms. Simpson.

title: Seeking Status as Blue Chip, Campbell Sets 7-Unit Spinoff
description: The Campbell Soup Company is making a high-profile bet on its core businesses, in an effort to lift its earnings into the realm of blue-chip performers.

title: Wine Talk
description: When Jean-Claude Rouzaud realized that 1997 would be his 30th anniversary as the managing director of Champagne Louis Roederer, he decided to celebrate in a special way. ''At the suggestion of several friends,'' he said recently, ''I decided to host a dinner at Tour d'Argent that would feature the 30 greatest wines in the world.''

title: Youth Study Elevates Family's Role
description: THERE is no shortage of efforts in homes, schools and communities to discourage teen-agers from taking drugs, smoking, drinking or having sex. The question is, What really works? One answer, from a major study of adolescents, is that families are more important than previously thought, perhaps as important as peers.

title: Mother Teresa's Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: Curry Goat, Albanian Lamb? New York Caterers Have It
description: WHEN Dejazmatch Coombs wanted to celebrate the third birthday of his son, Tikim, a year ago by holding a huge party that Jamaicans call a ''bashment,'' he asked Carol Lentini of Along Came Carol Creative Foods and Catering in Fairfield, Conn., to cater it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERKASKY, MARTIN, M.D.
description: CHERKASKY-Martin, M.D. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Dr. Martin Cherkasky, a giant in the field of hospital administration, and a longtime head of Montefiore Medical Center, one of our premier healthcare institutions. His dedication to the art of medicine and the healing of humanity was unsurpassed. During three decades as President of Montefiore, he expanded its social service programs, transforming it into a world-renowned hospital. A relentless innovator, he displayed a passionate commitment to the needy and a deep belief in high quality medical care for everyone. Beloved husband of Carol Pesner, devoted father of daughter, Marny Cherkasky, M.D. and son, Michael, and good friend to all who needed him. Dr. Cherkasky's many philanthropic endeavors included shaping health programs for The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, a UJAFederation beneficiary, and developing the Brookdale Institute of Gerontology in Israel. To his family, we send our deepest sympathies. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAFF, SONYA
description: STAFF-Sonya. Peacefully, on September 8, 1997. A remarkable woman. Widow of her beloved Otto; survived by her loving daughter, Eve S. Rosahn; daughter-inlaw, Marion D. Banzhaf; loving relatives, and countless friends. Social activist, feminist, with a passionate interest in Yiddish culture and imbued with a fierce love of life. Contributions may be made to The Sonya Staff Foundation, c/o Rosahn, 467 W. 22 St., Apt. F, New York, NY 10011. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Plan Would Broaden Access Of Police to Medical Records
description: Bowing to Federal and state law-enforcement authorities, Clinton Administration officials will soon propose legislation that would allow police officers to gain broad access to patients' medical records, with hardly any restrictions on use or redisclosure of the data.

title: MAGNA TO BUY A DIVISION OF GERMAN AUTO PARTS MAKER
description: Magna International Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the plastic-products division of the German auto parts maker Ymos A.G. for $140 million (Canadian), the equivalent of $101 million (United States). The unit supplies exterior and interior parts to large European car makers. The acquisition would allow Magna to expand its presence significantly in Europe. The planned takeover would strengthen Magna's position ''as a major full-service systems supplier to the global automotive industry,'' Magna said in a statement. Magna, based in Markham, Ontario, a leading supplier of parts to auto makers around the world, has more than 36,000 workers in 125 plants and 20 product development and engineering centers in 11 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVRETT, JACK
description: AVRETT-Jack. Died August 29, 1997, from a stroke at age 68. Memorial service Thursday, September 11, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st Street and Madison Avenue at 4:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera.

title: A Senseless Federal Subsidy
description: There is not much good to say about the way the Federal Government has managed the national forests. Over the years, the Forest Service has behaved more like a partner of the timber industry it is supposed to regulate than as a fiduciary for the American people, who on the whole would like to see more of the forests preserved for future generations rather than cut for immediate profit. Changing that will require a new mindset in the Forest Service and a tightening of the outdated National Forest Management Act of 1976. But in the near term, perhaps as early as tomorrow, the Senate can do something positive for the forests by getting rid of a small but pernicious subsidy that fuels deforestation at taxpayer expense.

title: Stares of Lawyerly Disbelief at a Huge Civil Award
description: Big civil-damages awards have become an increasingly common feature of the American legal landscape, but Monday's nearly $3.5 billion punitive-damages assessment in a 1987 Louisiana railway fire is being seen as a case unto itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MALCOLM ''BUD''
description: KAHN-Malcolm ''Bud''. The Association for the Help of Retarded Children (AHRC), Nassau Chapter, mourns the passing of former longtime board member, Bud Kahn. Although he was not a parent of a child with developmental disabilities, he was an active member of his local auxiliary and a tireless worker and advocate for children and adults with developmental disabilities. His dynamic enthusiasm in raising public support and community awareness made a tremendous contribution to the individuals with special needs served by Nassau AHRC. Our deepest condolences to his family. Thomas F. Moore, President Michael Mascari, Exec. Director Assoc. for the Help of Retarded Children, Nassau Chapter

title: Stadium Turf to Stay
description: The $1.3 million Astroturf field installed in Giants Stadium this year will remain throughout the pro football season despite drainage problems, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority announced yesterday.

title: Nominee to Lead Joint Chiefs Faces Tough Bosnia Questions
description: Though his confirmation as the next Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff is all but certain, Gen. Henry H. Shelton was confronted in the Senate today with pointed questions about whether the United States will meet its deadline to pull thousands of American troops out of Bosnia next year.

title: Pouring It On: Extra Virgin Oil as a Staple
description: WHEN the culinary world first embraced olive oil whole-heartedly, the finest grass-green, peppery-tasting extra virgin oils from estates in Tuscany were the ones it sought. And it found them in stores like Dean & DeLuca and Balducci's, not the neighborhood A.&P.

title: Playing Catch-Up to the U.S., Commerce Takes the Field
description: Sports mania is hardly a new phenomenon in Europe, where in many countries soccer is almost a national religion. But sports as a business has long been decidedly minor league compared with the big-money madness across the Atlantic.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Columbia/HCA Warns Earnings Will Be Lower

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSAHN, SONYA
description: ROSAHN-Sonya. See ''Staff.''

title: Peace Talks Resume; Sinn Fein to Join In
description: As peace talks opened in Belfast, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, committed itself to peaceful methods in efforts to reach an agreement on Northern Ireland, and the Clinton Administration suspended deportation proceedings against five I.R.A. veterans who have settled in the United States.

title: New Type of Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss New Jersey Wins
description: Miss New Jersey, Kathy Nejat, of Voorhees, won the swimsuit competition yesterday in the first of three nights of preliminary contests leading up to Saturday's Miss America Pageant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCH, MYRNA
description: MARCH-Myrna. On September 8, 1997. Service on Wednesday, at 4:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: McGreevey Is Endorsed
description: The state's most powerful teacher's union, the New Jersey Education Association, has refrained from endorsing either candidate in the governor's race, but yesterday, State Senator James E. McGreevey got the support of the American Federation of Teachers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VALUE ASSET MANAGEMENT INC., Westport, Conn., a unit of BankBoston Corp., acquired Harris, Brettall, Sullivan & Smith Inc., a money management company based in San Francisco, for undisclosed terms.

title: Graf Plans Return
description: STEFFI GRAF is scheduled to return to competitive tennis in an exhibition match in Baltimore on Nov. 25, five months after undergoing surgery on her left knee. The 28-year-old Graf is scheduled to play CHANDA RUBIN at the First Union Signet Bank Tennis Challenge at the Baltimore Arena on Nov. 25.

title: Social Insecurity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Sign Top Center
description: Devils General Manager Lou Lamoriello announced the signing Tuesday of center Brendan Morrison, last year's top collegiate player, to a multiyear contract.

title: House G.O.P. Sophomores Open New Effort on Taxes
description: Disenchanted with the Republican leadership's pace on pushing for tax cuts, Republican sophomores in the House today started a major new tax-cutting initiative by proposing to eliminate what has long been called the marriage tax penalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUCETTE, ARTHUR
description: DOUCETTE-Arthur. September 8, 1997. Prominent ladies dress designer. Beloved son of Elva and the late Maurice Doucette, devoted brother of Robert. Service Thursday, 1:30 P.M., September 11, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Fund.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: World Cup Qualifying

title: Health Page Moving
description: The Health page, including Personal Health, will move to Science Times beginning on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHENRY, MARTIN
description: McHENRY-Martin. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Martin McHenry, associated with The Times since 1984.

title: MetroStars Are Hustling Right Into Playoff Position
description: The MetroStars were playing their fourth game in eight days tonight against a New England team that was playing its first match in 10 days. Still, the MetroStars had the fresher legs and greater intensity.

title: In the Shadow of Mother Teresa, Many Others Toil
description: While sweepers swept and dignitaries inspected the broad avenues where the Indian Army will escort Mother Teresa to her grave on Saturday, Dr. Sushinet Raichoudhury, poised on a rough stool in a makeshift clinic miles away, was focusing today on the rasping chest and bloated stomach of 3-year-old Salim Pyada.

title: In Texas, A Showdown On Money For the Arts
description: It may not be as big as the Alamo, but another important battle will take place in San Antonio today, when the city council decides whether public money will be used to finance the arts. At stake is the fate of the city's Department of Arts and Cultural Affairs, which annually provides about $2.7 million in grants to 39 cultural organizations, from the San Antonio Symphony to urban mural projects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, ESTELLE
description: MILLS-Estelle, 96 years young. On September 9. Cherished wife of the late Jack Mills, loving and beloved mother and mother in law of Helen, Bill, Martin, Stanley and Judy. Devoted grandmother of Peter, Dale, Patricia, Joshua, Kenneth and Mitchell and great grandmother of Rebecca. Services at Boulevard Park West, Hewlett, New York, on Thursday 11:30 AM. Memorial observance will be at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Mills, Woodmere, New York.

title: Jacor Will Purchase Rights to a Show
description: Jacor Communications Inc. has agreed to buy the rights to ''The Dr. Laura Schlessinger Show'' from Synergy Broadcasting Inc. for $71.5 million.

title: Judge Is Told Defendant Once Plotted to Kill Him
description: A Federal judge who was to sentence a Mafia figure removed himself from the case this week after prosecutors said the defendant had admitted plotting several years ago to kill the judge.

title: Finding It Hard to Say That Enough Is Enough
description: The debauch of recent days has doubtless sent all the television news stars and recruits with English accents to spas to get their metabolisms calmed down. For more than a week, the Anglo-American cohort of big-name personalities, royalty watchers and handkerchief wetters, courtiers and hangers-on and random gossips let loose for all they are worth, and they are worth plenty.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS ; G.M. Links Marketing to a Cause
description: When Mary Cobbs, who is receiving chemotherapy treatments for breast cancer, learned that General Motors was a Women's National Basketball Association sponsor, she told her daughter, the Houston Comets star Cynthia Cooper, ''Did you know they have a breast cancer awareness program?'' Yes, Cooper said.

title: Bridge
description: A man who contributed more to bridge than anyone else in the world died on Sunday in Manhattan and will be mourned by millions. Edgar Kaplan was a world-class player, a teacher, a system creator, an author, a journalist, an editor, a publisher, an administrator, a lawmaker and a witty commentator.

title: Currents; Incredible Expanding Classroom in a Kit
description: CARNIVALS spring out of trailers, so why not schools? In New York City, where school buildings are always in need of repair, finding temporary classrooms is a constant problem. The answer may be inflatable classrooms that can be delivered by truck. In January, Martin Raab, president of the New York City School Construction Authority, asked FTL/Happold, an architectural and engineering firm in Manhattan, to design a prototype of a mobile classroom that would be more efficient and less expensive than the trailers the Board of Education is now using. With the push of a button -- on the drawing board, at least -- walls are extended hydraulically, while the floor unfolds and the roof expands, forming two classrooms for 35 students each (above and right). The prototype, which is expected next summer, will compress 1,500 square feet into 336 square feet inside a container 42 feet long, 8 feet wide and 8 feet high.

title: The Primary Surprise
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton's success in forcing Ruth Messinger into a runoff for the Democratic mayoral nomination has shocked many New York City Democrats -- none more than Ms. Messinger. But the message that was delivered Tuesday could not have been clearer. People need a positive reason to show up to vote in a primary election, and Ms. Messinger did not give them one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIORDAN, BRIAN
description: RIORDAN-Brian, 45, of Manhattan and East Hampton on September 5th, 1997. Beloved companion of Bob Deckert for 18 years. Son of Dorothy Riordan, brother of Dennis, Michael and Patrick Riordan and Maureen Viola. Funeral Mass Sunday, September 14th, 1:30 PM at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 30 W. 16th Street, NYC. Memorial service to be held Monday, October 6th, at 6PM at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette St.

title: Sports of The Times; Knee Hits: Just Football, Or a Hazard?
description: STEVE YOUNG, the 49ers' quarterback, has been cleared to return Sunday, two weeks after sustaining a concussion caused by a knee belonging to Hardy Nickerson, a Buccaneers linebacker.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Police Annexes at McDonald's
description: Starting next week, Jersey City residents will be able to satisfy a craving for hamburgers and file a police complaint at the same place, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, ARNOLD
description: GELLER-Arnold. Age 62, on September 8, 1997, of New City, NY. Survived by daughters, Gail Schafer of New City, Nadine McMahon of Tampa, FL., Stacey of New City, brother, Saul of New Brunswick, NJ, five grandchildren and wife, Jerry. Shiva Sunday through Tuesday at Gail Schafer's.

title: Foreign Affairs; Albright's Kind Gesture
description: On my way to Israel to watch Madeleine Albright's inaugural Middle East tour, I ran into a friend who said to me: ''Boy, she has really put her credibility on the line with this trip.'' I thought about that for a moment and without even knowing why answered: ''I don't think so.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIGSBERG, FANNY
description: KOENIGSBERG-Fanny. On September 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Mother of Carol and Paul Newman and Ruby and Martin Vogelfanger. Loving grandmother of Nina and Arnold Lehman, Naomi & Marshall Jaffe, Dinah Wernick, Judith Theodori, Deborah and Jason DeSalvo. Also survived by 8 great-grandchildren. Sister of Ida Gerzberg and Beatrice Multer. Services on Thursday 12 PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Trifling With Medical Privacy
description: ''If we act now,'' says Health and Human Services Secretary Donna Shalala in written testimony prepared for a Senate hearing today, ''we still have a golden opportunity to safeguard our age-old right to privacy in a brave new world of computers and biology. Nowhere is that more important than with our most personal information, our family secrets: our medical records.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STATE FARM INSURANCE CO., Bloomington, Ill., said it would pay $692.3 million as dividends to auto insurance policyholders in 30 states and the District of Columbia because claims had been lower than expected.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; New Rules on 'Megan's Law'
description: The 21 state judges overseeing implementation of ''Megan's Law'' are to meet today to begin rewriting the ground rules for the hearings to determine whether a paroled sex offender poses a risk of committing new crimes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Tomorrow night, New York City will go pink. That is the color of the lights that will bathe the tops of a dozen Manhattan structures all weekend, including 30 Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler and Empire State Buildings, as well as the Lincoln Center fountain.

title: When Truth Trumps Secrecy
description: It would seem self-evident that executive branch officials should have the right to inform Congress about violations of law, abuses of authority and other misconduct they encounter at work, even if the misdeeds involve classified activities. The Clinton Administration, influenced by the secrecy zealots of the Central Intelligence Agency, disagrees, and is doing its best to block legislation that would affirm and make explicit that right. Congress should insist on the measure, overturning a threatened Presidential veto if necessary.

title: Metro Business; Network for Health Data
description: A computer network that links hospitals, doctors' offices and insurance companies will go on line in New York City during the next three months at the four Manhattan hospitals affiliated with New York University, according to a health industry group that designed the system.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The whole climate in talking about welfare recipients has changed, from

title: There's Gold In This Old Tool Belt
description: IMAGINE a marginally more relaxed Martha Stewart with a beard. Is America ready for that?

title: Why the Excitement? It's Parcells's Patriots Vs. Parcells's Jets
description: If Bill Parcells would say what he feels, he would still not sound like Pete Carroll.

title: M.T.A. Studies Where to Run Subway When Manhattan Bridge Needs Work
description: Subway trains have been rumbling across the Manhattan Bridge since 1915, and the heavy traffic has contributed to the deterioration that ultimately required a $470 million overhaul of the bridge.

title: In America; Racing to Oblivion
description: New York does not need this. Two losers, one meek and essentially devoid of leadership qualities, the other brash, irresponsible and very loud, vying for the right to concede the mayoralty to a man who would like nothing more than to crush his opponents and govern the city with something approaching absolute power.

title: Can You Spell 'Compliance,' Boys and Girls?; Networks Go Along, but Just Barely, With New Federal Rules on Children's Shows
description: A nourishing new world of children's television was supposed to begin this week, with the nation's broadcast stations required by Federal regulations to carry three hours a week of educational shows for viewers under 16.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, ARNOLD
description: SEGAL-Arnold. Of Paramus, N.J. On September 9, 1997. Beloved husband of Celia (nee Saffan); devoted father of Robert, Daniel, Zachary and David; dear brother of Thelma Mergedant and Roslyn Goldberg; loving grandfather of Michael, Ashley and Stella Lisa. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', corner Passaic and Park St, Hackensack, NJ, today at 11:30. The memorial period will be observed at the family residence. Contributions to Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center NY would be appreciated.

title: Planet Hollywood's First Hotel May Enter Times Square's Orbit
description: Las Vegas hotels have their pirates and Egyptian kings. Orlando hotels have their mouse. Now New York may be getting its own version, and on Broadway no less.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSCH, FRANCES MAY WILLIAMS
description: RUSCH-Frances May Williams, September 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Henry A. Rusch, Jr. Loving mother of Cecile RuschQueuil, Henry A. Rusch, III and Dr. Valerie Rusch. Service Monday, September 15, 1997, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Douglass College, New Brunswick, New Jersey or the American Cancer Society.

title: Burning Body Is Found On East Harlem Rooftop
description: A human body was found burning on the roof of a public housing building in East Harlem yesterday afternoon by police and firefighters responding to a report of a fire. The body, found on the roof of 218 East 104th Street just after 5 P.M., was so badly burned that the race and sex could not be immediately determined, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEPPER, ELEANOR
description: PEPPER-Eleanor. On September 7, in her 94th year. Beloved sister of the late Benjamin and Morton. Devoted aunt of Alice P. and Carol H.P. Cooper and D. Stephen and Michael Pepper and Sam Hellinger. Family and friends will gather in her apartment at 9 East 96 Street at 1 PM, on Friday, Sept 12. Interment will follow.

title: Cleaning Out The Medicine Cabinet; Prescription Drug Makers Reconsider Generics
description: When Bill Clinton stopped at Merck & Company's old headquarters in Rahway, N.J., during the 1992 Presidential campaign, it was not for an entirely friendly visit. The campaign was gearing up that September and Mr. Clinton, promising a revolution in health care, had come to one of the citadels of the pharmaceutical industry to call for cost controls on prescription drugs.

title: Exxon Valdez Money to Aid City Wetlands
description: In March of 1989, the Exxon Valdez spilled 11 million gallons of oil into the pristine waters of Alaska's Prince William Sound, causing one of the worst environmental disasters in history.

title: UNITED INTERNATIONAL TO SELL CABLE ASSETS IN ARGENTINA
description: United International Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its assets in Argentina to Supercanal Holding S.A. for $225 million. The sale includes United International's eight cable television systems and its options to acquire other properties. United International said it expected a gain equal to $2.25 a share from the transaction. United International, based in Denver, provides multichannel television services to 25 countries outside the United States. Its shares fell 43.75 cents, to $10.3125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Letter Asks Suharto's Aid in Ending Conflict : Notables Seek Solution To East Timor Rebellion
description: SINGAPORE  In an effort to hasten an end to one of Asia's longest running rebellions, a group of Nobel laureates and other prominent figures recently signed a letter to President Suharto of Indonesia appealing for his "fullest support" for new moves to try to resolve the conflict in East Timor.

title: As Rules on Welfare Tighten, Its Recipients Gain in Stature
description: Welfare recipients, last year's political pariahs, are shedding their outcast status.

title: In Accord, Con Ed To Lower Rates 10%
description: Facing criticism that an early version of a proposed rate reduction favored large businesses, Consolidated Edison and state regulators agreed yesterday to an across-the-board 10 percent cut in electric rates, the largest rollback in half a century.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Strawberry Staying on Shelf
description: Darryl Strawberry was between rounds of a batting practice in which he whacked baseballs into the right-field seats at Fenway Park, but the questions the limping slugger fielded were about sitting, not hitting. Joe Torre had just revealed that Strawberry would probably not be on the post-season roster for the Yankees because of a weak left knee.

title: Television in Review
description: Those Who Help Themselves, And Yes, Those Who Don't

title: Dormitory Life Is Essential to a Yale Education; 'No Religion' Is Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Radisson Hotels is using pictures by a well-known photojournalist to spruce up its image.
description: THIS month, Radisson Hotels Worldwide is rolling out a multimillion-dollar print advertising campaign with pictures by a well-known photojournalist to spruce up its image and increase awareness of its brand.

title: Divisions Deepen Among Algeria's Military Rulers
description: Recent massacres on the outskirts of Algiers have prompted widespread speculation that a power struggle may have erupted within the secretive military-backed oligarchy that governs Algeria.

title: G.O.P., Citing Fund Memos, Steps Up Its Attack on Gore
description: Stepping up their assault on Vice President Al Gore, Senate Republicans sought today to show that Mr. Gore should have known that calls he made to donors from the White House might have violated Federal election law because the money he raised directly benefited his and President Clinton's re-election campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIAZZA, DR. LOUIS R., DDS
description: PIAZZA-Dr. Louis R., DDS beloved Husband, Father and Grandfather, died on Monday, September 8, 1997 at Bridgeport Hospital. He was born in Bronx, NY on November 27, 1916. Louis left a legacy of caring and compassion to all he treated in his dental practice for fifty years. He was a member of the First District Dental Society of NY and served on the staff of Our Lady of Mercy Dental Clinic for most of his career. A POW in W.W. II, he was a member of the 106th Infantry 423 Division of the U.S. Army. An exceptional and respected man, he will be missed by his family and friends. A Mass of Christian Burial at St. Francis of Assisi Church, Norfield Road, Weston, CT at 11:00 AM. Friends may call on Thursday from 3-9 PM at the Shaughnessey Brothers Funeral Home, 50 Reef Road, Fairfield, CT. Interment in Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. Donations may be made in his memory to: Oglethorpe University, 4484 Peach Tree NE, Atlanta, GA. 30319.

title: Truckers Are Driving With Too Little Sleep, Research Shows
description: A weeklong, moment-by-moment study of 80 truck drivers found that they got too little sleep to stay alert, less than five hours a night, and that two drivers had had repeated episodes of a sleep-like state while driving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, VIRGINIA M.
description: McCARTHY-Virginia M., September 9th, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John E. McCarthy. Loving mother of Maureen C. McCarthy and J. Thomas McCarthy. Friends may call Friday, 2-5, 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Sat., September 13th, 10 AM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th St. Interment will follow in Parnell, MI. She was a graduate of the Class of 1931 University of Michigan, Ann Arbor School of Architecture.

title: China Reviews Tax Aimed at Foreign Banks
description: China is reviewing a taxation clause that withholds as much as 20 percent from interest earned by foreign banks on their loans. Foreign bankers are angered by the tax because it is not levied on local banks and threatens to erode their profitability in what is already a highly restrictive market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKSTEIN, GERTRUDE S.
description: LOOKSTEIN-Gertrude S. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the passing of an aishet chayil-a gracious lady, charming and helpful, a source of moral and psychological strength for her husband and children, and, in her own right, a personality of importance in the Jewish community; beloved wife of the late Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein; mother of Rabbi Haskel (and Audrey) Lookstein and Nathalie (and Israel) Friedman. Gertrude Lookstein was the granddaughter of the RaMaZ, Rabbi Moses Z. Margolies, outstanding Jewish scholar and an early leader of RIETS. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is a founding member of the Board of Directors, Bernard Revel Graduate School, and occupies RIETS' Dr. Joseph H. Lookstein Chair in Homiletics-established in memory of the eminent communal leader who was an honorary YU Trustee and Board member of Yeshiva College and RIETS. We extend heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Bosnia Jitters: West Fearful of Having to Use Force
description: Despite setbacks for Serbian hard-liners in Bosnia in recent days, there is rising concern among NATO commanders and senior western diplomats that more force will be needed to make the Dayton peace plan work.

title: Dispute Over Emmy Flares Up Again
description: A dispute over a decision to present the first Emmy Award for television commercials, which seemed to have been settled when the award was given out, has flared up again.

title: New Test Finds an Anti-Depressant in Diana Driver's Blood
description: The driver of Diana, Princess of Wales, had taken the anti-depressant drug commonly marketed as Prozac in addition to drinking large amounts of alcohol before the car accident that killed them, the French prosecutors' office said today.

title: A Face-Off On TV Link To the Internet
description: A powerful team of companies is mounting a direct challenge to a plan by William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, to use cable television to dominate the Internet.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Casino Taxes for Apartments
description: A building with 16 apartments on the top two floors and retail stores on the ground level will be constructed near City Hall with $1.8 million in tax revenues from Atlantic City's casinos under a plan unveiled yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Error May Change Result
description: The outcome of a hotly contested New York City Council primary on the Lower East Side was thrown into doubt last night when election officials said there had been an error in counting ballots.

title: Davis Finding a Way to Contribute
description: Since June 17, the Baltimore Orioles have had an unfair advantage over their rivals in the American League: they have been driven by the indomitable spirit of Eric Davis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, JOHN RANDOLPH
description: HARRISON-John Randolph, of Hightstown, NJ, on September 8, 1997, age 93. Father of Josephine H. Evarts of Mt. Kisco, NY, Randolph Harrison of Mill Neck, NY and Robert C. Harrison of New York NY. Grandfather of eight, great-grandfather of 16. Stepfather of Lawrence W. Fox, III, Diane F. Downs and Cary F. Fisher. Private service Hollywood Cemetery, Richmond, VA. Memorial contributions to St. Paul's School, Concord, NH 03301 appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTKIN, DR. JOAN
description: GUTKIN-Dr. Joan. On September 10, 1997. Beloved wife of Allen. Loving mother of Cari, Lisa and Jeffrey. Loving mother-in-law of Kenneth & Karen. Adoring grandmother of Lauren, Tara, Erin and Jessica for whom she knitted with love. Devoted Principal of P.S. 9 for seven years. She will be deeply missed. Service on Thursday 11:15AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: TRANSACTIONS

To his dear wife Adele and his great sons and daughters, my deepest sympathies. I shall also dearly miss Gene. Jerome Belson

title: Classical Cachet and Taut Technique in an Ascent to a Heavenly Wingding
description: It is no insult to Dance Theater of Harlem to say that the company has never danced better. Under its artistic director, Arthur Mitchell, it always had aspirations and standards of the highest order. Excellence has not been absent.

title: THE GOLF REPORT; Companies Mix Hope And Hype At Show
description: It is fitting that the Professional Golfers' Association of America would bring one of its two annual golf merchandise trade shows here. This is, after all, the city where unrealistic hope is a governing principle, hype is the official language and blind luck is often rewarded more than concentrated effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, FLORENCE (MRS. WILLIAM T.), NEE VALIS
description: McKENNA-Florence (Mrs. William T.), nee Valis, peacefully on Sept. 7, 1997. Born June 20, 1906 in Austria. She was widowed in 1933 and worked as an accountant for Continential Insurance Company for many years. After her retirement, she volunteered at Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, NY. She is survived by her sons, William J. and Richard T. McKenna and their wives. She had ten grandchildren and 15 great grandchildren. She resided in New York for most of her life, then in St. Louis, MO, Boynton Beach, FL, and most recently, in St. Agnes Home, Kirkwood, MO. She lived and died in the Roman Catholic Church. Visitation and Mass on Wednesday, September 10 at St. Agnes Home, Kirkwood, MO. Entombment on Friday, Sept. 12 at St. Raymond's Cemetery, Balcom Road, Bronx, New York. For information Castle Hill Funeral Home, Bronx, NY.

title: Clinton Seeks to Make Trade Deals Congress Can't Amend
description: President Clinton began a tough struggle today with the nation's labor unions and much of his own party in Congress over his authority to negotiate new trade deals that he declared are ''absolutely critical for our world leadership.''

title: BOXING: These Days, He's Not Clowning Around; With a Wife in His Corner, Camacho Gets Serious in Latest Bid for a Title
description: He is the first man to fight in a loincloth, A.D., which is one way to get on pay-per-view. The other way is to defeat a 50-year-old former champion, or however old Ray Leonard is, and that is how Hector (Macho) Camacho found his name up in neon again.

title: Jubilation at Reprieve in I.R.A. Expulsion
description: Colleen Gaynor started crying before dawn, and at 2 P.M. she was crying still, staggered by the news that her husband of seven years, a veteran of the Irish Republican Army, would not be deported.

title: Economic Scene; Some say no to a high-powered drive to revamp patent law.
description: WITH the blessing of a coalition of large, technology-driven corporations, the Clinton Administration and some senior members of Congress are pressing for a makeover of American patent law. ''We're starved for resources and shackled by regulation,'' argued Bruce A. Lehman, Commissioner of the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Up From Southern Poverty, Into a Wider World
description: ALL OVER BUT THE SHOUTIN'By Rick BraggIllustrated. 329 pages. Pantheon Books. $25.

The funeral services were held on Wednesday, September 10, 1997 at 12:30 P.M. at the Belkoff-Goldstein Funeral Chapel, 313 Second Street, Lakewood, N.J. Interment in Riverside Cemetery, Paramus.

description: BATTISTA-Anthony Harry, died September 5, 1997 in Orlando, Florida at the age of 81. A long time resident of New York City and a former member of Musician Local 802. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth and four brothers. Carey Hand Funeral Home, Orlando (407) 898-7881.

title: Despite Taliban Vow, Afghan Opium Production Is Up, U.N. Says
description: The Muslim fundamentalist Taliban movement has pledged to crack down on opium poppy cultivation in Afghanistan, but opium production there has jumped by 25 percent over the last year, with almost all of the increase occurring in Taliban-controlled areas, United Nations International Drug Control Program officials said Wednesday.

title: France Telecom Reports 41% Increase in Profits
description: France Telecom S.A. said yesterday that net income for the first half of the year rose 41 percent, to 8.9 billion francs, or $1.45 billion, largely because of a capital gain of 1.1 billion francs from the sale of its stake in the holding company Cofira.

title: Smolinski and Belanger Sign as Isles Open Camp
description: The Islanders signed forward Bryan Smolinski and the enforcer Ken Belanger today on the opening day of training camp at Nassau Coliseum. The signings leave center Travis Green and defenseman Kenny Jonsson, who are restricted free agents, as the team's only question marks.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Back Bill on Religious Persecution
description: A coalition of religious groups led by evangelical Christians today won critical support from the Republican leadership in its effort to mandate economic sanctions against any country engaged in religious persecution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKMAN, IRVING R.
description: DICKMAN-Irving R. Formerly of New York. Died Sept. 8, 1997, in Rancho Mirage, California. An accomplished man in the apparel industry. His greatest distinction was the love and affection he gave to his family and friends. Services were held at Mt. Sinai Memorial Park in Los Angeles.

title: Dormitory Life Is Essential to a Yale Education; Lawsuit Isn't Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Boots of Britain to Buy Skin-Care Company
description: The British drug retailer the Boots Company P.L.C. said yesterday that it was buying the medical skin-care company Hermal Kurt Herrman from the German drug maker Merck K.G.a.A. for 500 million marks, or $276 million. Boots said the acquisition would help it sell its existing skin-care products in Germany and use its sales channels to increase sales of Hermal products elsewhere in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, MARY C.
description: PEARCE-Mary C. Age 83, of Mahwah, NJ, formerly of Riverdale, New York, died September 10, 1997. She ran the Kingsbridge Answering Service in the Bronx for 45 years, retiring in 1996. Beloved mother of Deborah Pearce, Ph.D. Funeral Mass will be on Saturday 9:30 A.M., at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, with interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Visiting Friday 7-9 PM at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave, Ridgewood, N.J. (201-444-7650).

title: Suit Says Nynex Shortchanged Women on Benefits
description: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit yesterday accusing the Nynex Corporation, which is now a part of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, of discriminating against a group of female employees who took maternity leaves 20 years ago and were denied full retirement benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAITHWAITE, ARNOLD
description: BRAITHWAITE-Arnold. The William F. Ryan Community Health Center is deeply saddened by the death of Arnold Braithwaite. Arnold was a true friend of the Ryan Center, giving generously of his unparalleled wisdom and guidance as a member and officer of the Board of Directors for more than 25 years. With Arnold at the helm, the Ryan Center gained stature as a model community health center recognized by local, state and federal officials. In 1988, under Arnold's leadership, the Ryan Center successfully moved to its new, state of the art facility thus dramatically increasing the center's ability to serve the poor and uninsured. Throughout the struggling years of the community health center movement, Arnold was an inspiration to many by remaining faithful to his principles and never compromising his values. His dedication and lifelong commitment in improving the lives of impoverished minority populations has made an indelible contribution to community health centers across the country, and his warmth, enthusiasm, and kindness will be greatly missed by friends, colleagues, and the community. Our thoughts and love are with his wife, Hope; his son, Ryan; and his grandchildren, Tatiana, Tiye, and Jahi. Viewing services will be held on Friday, September 12 from 2-8 PM at Unity Funeral Chapel, 2352 Eighth Avenue, corner of West 126 Street. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, September 13 at 11 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Convent Avenue and 145 Street. Condolences may be sent to Hope Braithwaite and family, 120 West 97th Street, Apartment 8J, New York, New York 10025. A memorial service for Mr. Braithwaite will be held at Ryan in the coming weeks. Bobbie Maniece-Harrison, Ed.D Julio Bellber Barbra E. Minch John L.S. Holloman, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVRETT, JACK
description: AVRETT-Jack. Died August 29, 1997, from a stroke at age 68. Memorial service Thursday, September 11, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st Street and Madison Avenue at 4:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI performed a new role at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday: he unveiled United States postage stamps honoring four legendary opera stars, Richard Tucker, Lily Pons, Lawrence Tibbett and Rosa Ponselle. The stamps, part of the Postal Service's ''Legends of American Music'' series, go on sale today around the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHTER, MAURICE N.
description: SCHACHTER-Maurice N., passed away on August 30 at the age of 78. Principal of Lafayette Avenue Securities, a Standard & Poor's listed bond brokerage and a W.W. II veteran. Murray is survived by his wife, Arlene Schachter of Middletown, NY; three children, Rebecca Schachter of Elgin, IL., Sharon Shoemaker of Columbia, MD., and Cordell Schachter of the Bronx, NY; two sisters, Harriet Struhl and Roslyn Rubinstein; and four grandchildren, Laura, Phillip, Adrianna, and Megan. He was laid to rest September 2. Memorial contributions may be sent to the World Wildlife Fund or to the Baltimore, Maryland VA Hospital General Fund for Patient's Social and Recreational Needs, Baltimore, VA. Rehabilitation Center, Voluntary Services Office, 3900 Loch Raven Boulevard, Baltimore, MD 21218.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: LINKS TO LANDFILL -- Investigators have found a significant rate of birth problems in women who, in the early 1970's, lived near the Lipari landfill in Gloucester County, N.J. B2.

description: Treasury securities remained depressed for a second day yesterday, as market sentiment remained negative before tomorrow's reports on retail and manufacturing data for last month.

title: U.K. to Hold Inquest for Diana After Paris Inquiry
description: LONDON  Britain will conduct an inquest into the deaths of Diana, Princess of Wales, and Dodi al Fayed, but only after French authorities establish the cause of the automobile crash that killed them and conclude any criminal proceedings in the case, British officials said Wednesday.

title: AT&T Argentine Pullback Is Linked to Wiretapping
description: When the AT&T Corporation announced last week that it would not compete for licenses to provide Argentina with the next generation of wireless communications services, it offered little explanation.

description: HOPKINSON - HOPKINS - Marian. Beloved godmother of Helen W. Wallace, & former Vice President of Brown, Harris, Stevens, died peacefully in her sleep early Monday morning. Friends may visit at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday from 4-8 P.M. Funeral is Thursday September 11th, at 1 P.M., Saint Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. A gift in her memory may be made to The Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd Street, New York City 10021-8383.

title: 'Wide World' Expanding
description: Its ratings aren't great, but its name is. So in January, ''Wide World of Sports'' will become the umbrella brand for all ABC Sports programming except college football and ''Monday Night Football.''

Klein and the late Hilda Levine and Lawrence Klein. Adored uncle. Private services were held on Wednesday, September 10th.

description: WALLDOV-Liz (Elizabeth), at home September 8, 1997. New York native, community activist, naturalist and world traveler. Liz set a shining standard of service. She did it with tough questions, hard work, good humor, and finesse. She enjoyed music, dance, and the company of good friends. Marga Walldov Parent, her sister, and nephews Mark and Steven Koenig suggest donations to The Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Medical Center or The New York Chapter of The Nature Conservancy.

title: AT HOME WITH: Paul Rudnick; You Want Gay Role Models? How About a Joke First
description: AS Paul Rudnick sees it, the moment when a person scrounges together enough money and begins to buy furniture is not merely an economic rite of passage. It is also a fork in the road of self-identity that leads, alternately, to levelheaded reason or loopy fancy.

title: Devils Begin Search for Two More Defensemen
description: The first order of business for the Devils today as they opened their fifth training camp under Coach Jacques Lemaire was to begin the search for replacements for the defensemen Shawn Chambers and Dave Ellett, who left as free agents.

title: Bamako Journal; Here, an Artist's Fame and Fortune Can Be Fatal
description: Pictures can be deceiving, and so, it would seem, can a visit to the home of Mali's greatest photographer, Seydou Keita.

title: Dow Plunges 132.63 Points On Concerns Over Earnings
description: The stock market's major indexes fell more than 1 percent yesterday as skittish investors appeared to shun large, multinational companies that could see their third-quarter earnings cut by this year's rally of the dollar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, MICHAEL
description: RUBENSTEIN-Michael. Our sympathies are extended to our friend and colleague, Ilana Artman. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, Pres. Kenneth J. Bialkin, Chairman Of The Board

title: STOCK OF TINSLEY LABS SOARS ON NEWS OF ACQUISITION
description: The stock of Tinsley Laboratories Inc. almost doubled yesterday, a day after the company said it would be acquired by Silicon Valley Group Inc. for $42 million in stock. Silicon Valley, based in San Jose, Calif., said after financial markets closed on Tuesday that it would exchange 0.6594 of its shares for each of Tinsley's 1.9 million shares. Tinsley, based in Richmond, Calif., makes precision optics. Silicon Valley, which makes chip-making machinery, uses Tinsley lenses in its lithography equipment. Shares of Tinsley rose $10.50, to $21.25, on the Nasdaq stock market, where Silicon Valley gained 18.75 cents, to $33.6875.

title: Protestants Criticize U.S. for Halting Deportation of 6 in I.R.A.
description: Protestant political leaders attacked the Clinton Administration today for its decision to suspend deportation action against six former Irish Republican Army convicts now living in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELDON, HENRY L.
description: WELDON-Henry L., September 8, 1997. Loving grandson of the late Louis M. Colton; son of the late Henry and Elizabeth Weldon; brother of Louise W. Floeckher of Palm Beach, FL; devoted father of Henry L. III and Alexander C., nephew Nicholas C. Cassavetes, Fort Collins, CO. Cherished friend of Virginia Pagetti. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, 11:00 A.M., St. Vincent Ferrer Church, (Lexington Avenue at 66th Street), N.Y.C. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Central Park Conservancy, Attn: S. Collins, 10 Columbus Circle, Suite 2155, New York, New York 10019.

description: MICHAELSON-Stanley, Sept. 10, 1997 in Tampa, FL. Born in NYC, came to Tampa in 1980 from Long Island, NY. Survivors include his wife, Lorna; 3 sons, Richard and Peter of Portland, OR, and Jay of Tampa; 3 daughters, Nancy of Baltimore, MD, Patricia of Atlanta, GA, and Maia of NYC; a brother, Arthur (Arline) of Great Neck, NY; and 3 grandchildren. Graveside services will be held Thursday, September 11, at 3 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery. Info: Beth David Funeral Chapel, Tampa, FL.
