description: KAUFMAN-Bruce A. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff of CLAL-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership extend deepest condolences to Arlene Kaufman, our esteemed Board member, on the passing of her beloved husband, Bruce Kaufman. May she and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Radine Abramson Spier, Chmn. Rabbi Irving Greenberg, Pres. Rabbi Irwin Kula, Pres.-Elect Donna M. Rosenthal, Exec Vice Chairman

title: Banks in Thailand Lift Prime Lending Rates
description: Thai banks raised prime lending rates yesterday to six-year highs, making it harder for cash-pressed companies and consumers to repay loans and dealing another blow to the country's struggling economy. The move, prompted by a rise in the financing costs of banks and a slumping Thai currency, came as Moody's Investors Service said it might cut the country's credit rating. Higher rates may only slow the economy further.

title: Maurice Levine, 79, Founder Of Musical Theater Series, Dies
description: Maurice Levine, the founder and artistic director of the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Where Isolation Pays Off in Achievement; At Fire Island School, the Classes Are Tiny and the Test Scores High
description: Only 40 miles east of the crowded classrooms of New York City, there is a school with just 54 children in seven grades.

title: House Panel Pushes Road Bill, Putting Gingrich in a Tough Spot
description: A House transportation subcommittee today approved a three-year, $103 billion highway bill that outspends the balanced-budget agreement by billions of dollars, setting up a confrontation between some of the most powerful committee chairmen on Capitol Hill, with Speaker Newt Gingrich in the middle.

title: Hundley Surgery Is Certain, but Its Seriousness Is Not
description: Todd Hundley could not straighten his right elbow yesterday, nor could the Mets' catcher bend it enough to touch his right shoulder. For someone who must throw 200 times a day and generate a powerful swing with that elbow, this was not good.

title: Apartheid Inquiry Is Told Details of Biko Killing
description: The South African police officers who killed Steve Biko 20 years ago say they beat him with a hose and rammed his head into the wall of an interrogation room after he fought back and refused to stand during questioning.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM TO HIRE 1,000 IN MONTREAL EXPANSION
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. will hire 1,000 high-technology employees and spend $196 million in Montreal over four years to expand its production of high-speed fiber optic equipment to meet a growing demand from communications companies worldwide. The company, based in Toronto, will build a 400,000-square-foot plant in Montreal and update and expand its existing operations. This is Northern Telecom's second large expansion in Canada in three months. In June, it announced plans to hire 5,000 people in Ottawa. The investments reflect increasing orders for the company's fiber optic products. Shares of Northern Telecom, which employs 68,000 people worldwide, fell $2.8125, to $98.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: In Hilliard's Absence, Lewis Gets Starting Nod
description: Two weeks ago, Thomas Lewis plunged to fourth on the depth chart of Giants wide receivers. Or, as Lewis put it today, ''Maybe even fifth.'' And there are only five receivers on the Giants' roster.

title: Dormitory Life Is Essential to a Yale Education; Folly of Separatism
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Carbon Monoxide Detectors Fail to Perform in Laboratory Tests
description: MANY carbon monoxide detectors sold in hardware stores sound their alarms for no reason, or fail to sound an alarm even when high concentrations of the deadly gas are present, according to recent laboratory tests. Industry officials, prodded by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, are drafting tougher standards that may make obsolete the tens of millions currently in use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, MAX
description: SCHWARZ-Max, Sept. 9th, 1997. Beloved Father of Marna and Fred, and Joseph, brother of Herbert, and husband of late Rose. Funeral at West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West 76th Street, 9:30 AM, September 11th, 1997.

title: Correction
description: The obituary of Sir Rudolf Bing on Sept. 3 misstated the year when Leontyne Price made her official debut at the Metropolitan Opera during his regime as general manager. It was 1961, not 1953. Her earlier appearance was in a fund-raising concert, the Metropolitan Opera Jamboree, at the Ritz Theater. The obituary also misstated the year of Sir Rudolf's dismissal of Maria Callas. It was 1958, not 1968.

title: Shots Fired Out Window On Upper East Side
description: A man fired three to five shots out the window of his Upper East Side home at 10:15 P.M. yesterday, but no one was injured, the police said.

title: New Contest Of Diplomacy
description: After weeks of portraying herself as the inevitable Democratic mayoral nominee, Ruth W. Messinger confronted a new political predicament yesterday: how to conduct a runoff campaign against the Rev. Al Sharpton without undermining what she still hopes will be a fall campaign against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SITLER, MARGARET B.
description: SITLER-Margaret B. September 9, 1997. Of the Bronx. Retired NYC school teacher. Beloved wife of the late Charles R., Jr. Devoted mother of Charles T., loving grandmother of Charles V., Rosemary and Thomas. Family will receive friends Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at John J. Fox & Sons, Inc., East 201 St and Grand Concourse. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Philip Neri Church Friday 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Metro Business; Aerospace Plant Moving
description: Allied Signal Inc. says it is closing an aerospace parts plant that employs 240 people in Eatontown, N.J., and moving the work to a plant in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Make My Prescription Chateau Margaux '61
description: To the Editor;

title: MOLSON SAYS DEAL IS NEAR FOR STAKE IN BREWER
description: The Molson Companies said yesterday that its talks to buy the Miller Brewing Company's 20 percent stake in Molson Breweries, Canada's biggest beer maker, were in an advanced stage. Financial terms were not disclosed. Analysts have estimated the value of Miller's stake at $220 million to $300 million (Canadian), or $160 million to $220 million (United States). The companies disclosed in July that they were negotiating. Molson owns 40 percent of Molson Breweries, with Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. of Australia owning another 40 percent. Molson said it had also offered to buy Foster's stake but had been turned down. Miller is a unit of the Philip Morris Companies.

title: Market Place; A rarity for Wall St.: a takeover target whose share price drops.
description: WHEN two bidders are fighting to take over a company, you can bet that the price will rise before the battle is over.

title: No. 2 Man at F.B.I., Important Manager, Retires This Month
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis J. Freeh, said today that his second in command, William J. Esposito, was retiring from the bureau after playing an important managerial role in some of its most prominent recent cases.

title: Replanting the Renaissance
description: A LILAC walk and a viewing mount, topiary yews and an ivy maze, a rose rondel, a knot garden and quadrant beds of medicinal, culinary, dyeing and ornamental herbs. You'd think you were in the Cotswolds. No way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, MARIE, BONNE DE VIEL CASTEL
description: ROBERTS-Marie-Bonne de Viel Castel, of Glenn Dale, Maryland, on September 9, 1997. Wife of the late Eugene Bowie Roberts of Glenn Dale; sister of PierreEtienne de Viel Castel of St. Georges Motel, France; step-mother of Gladys R. Thomas and Eugene B. Roberts, Jr.; aunt of Louis-James, Pierre and Gilles de Viel Castel and Anne-Marie d'Aillieres and survived also by six step-grandchildren, five grand-nieces, four grand-nephews and their children. Funeral Saturday, September 13, at St. Pius X Church, Bowie, MD, at 11 A.M., followed by interment at Holy Trinity Church, Bowie. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to: Parish of St. Louis de France, 4125 Garrison Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20016.

title: Longer Visits for the Everetts
description: Mets outfielder Carl Everett and his wife, Linda, will have extended visitation this weekend with their children, Shawna and Carl Jr., the player's agent, Larry Reynolds, said yesterday. The agent said that the Everetts' visitation time, which is supervised, would increase from about one hour to six hours as a result of a pretrial conference yesterday. The children have been in foster care since last month because of allegations of child abuse against the Everetts.

title: THE 2 DEMOCRATS IN RUNOFF ASSERT ENEMY IS GIULIANI
description: Suddenly thrust into the first Democratic mayoral runoff in 20 years, the Rev. Al Sharpton and Ruth W. Messinger insisted yesterday that they would go right on attacking Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and they barely acknowledged each other's presence in the surprise contest.

title: Panama's Benefactors
description: To the Editor:

title: General Reprimanded in Scandal at Base
description: The Army has disciplined the two-star general who directed the Maryland training base where one of the Army's worst sexual harassment scandals was centered, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Prices Reach a 2-Month Low For Gasoline and Heating Oil
description: Gasoline and heating oil futures prices tumbled to their lowest prices in more than two months yesterday after a surge in inventories indicated that refineries were producing more than motorists and homeowners could use.

title: $8 Million Is Allocated To Improve Weak Schools
description: Facing threats that the state could close failing New York City schools, Chancellor Rudy Crew announced an $8 million initiative yesterday to develop remedial plans for up to 200 of the city's weakest schools.

title: Accord Ends Con Edison's Monopoly and Cuts Rates by 10%
description: Facing criticism that an early version of a proposed rate reduction favored large businesses, Consolidated Edison and state regulators agreed yesterday to an across-the-board 10 percent cut in electric rates, the largest rollback in half a century.

title: CISCO TO CUT PRICES ON KEY NETWORKING PRODUCT
description: Shares of Cisco Systems Inc. fell yesterday after the company said it planned to cut prices on remote-access concentrators, a key networking product that Cisco is concentrating on, analysts said. Cisco's shares fell $3.50, to $72.50, in Nasdaq trading of 14.3 million shares. Cisco said at the Salomon Brothers Technology Conference in New York that it was planning to cut prices on its remote-access concentrators, analysts said. The devices are used to link hundreds of telephone callers to the Internet. Price cuts will have a small effect on Cisco's profit because remote-access concentrators account for only 3 percent of Cisco's sales, said Vijay Rajamani, a Cowen & Company analyst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBLIN, HOWARD
description: LUBLIN-Howard. On September 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley; loving father to Mary, Douglas and Candace; adored grandfather to Ben and Michael; dear brother to Sheldon and the late Ada and brother-in-law to Dorothy, Sylvia, Walter, Stanley and Diane; devoted uncle, great uncle, great great uncle and friend. Services Friday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Thursday 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKAS, JEAN A.
description: PAKAS-Jean A. On September 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Frederick. Loving sister of Malcolm and Martin L. Abrams, and the late Arthur Abrams. Sister-in-law of Gloria, Kay and Gertrude Abrams. Dear aunt and greataunt. She was greatly loved and will be held in our dearest memory. Services were private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, BROOKE EMMENS
description: GONZALEZ - Brooke Emmens. Cherished and beloved daughter of Diana and Peter William Gonzalez and adored sister of Peter Jr. died September 4, 1997 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Brooke, a freshman at Brown University, had attended the Spence School and graduated from Deerfield Academy. She was Vice President of her senior class at Deerfield and twice a member of the US International 420 Sailing Team, competing in the last two world championships. Her spirit, zest for life and compassionate heart will be deeply missed by all. Memorial services Thursday, September 11, at 4 PM, at St. Thomas More Church, NYC, and Saturday, September 13 at 11 AM, American Yacht Club, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Brooke Emmens Gonzalez Memorial Fund at Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA 01342.

title: Search Widens To Find Source Of Tainted Beef
description: The Agriculture Department has found that hamburgers made at Hudson Foods Inc. were contaminated by E. coli bacteria on more dates than originally known, meaning that more consumers could have been taken ill than the 16 identified last month in Colorado, agency officials said today.

title: Unconventional Logic Guides This Campaign
description: IN politics, as in thermodynamics, it is well known that large spaces swallow up energy. And so for its ''victory'' celebration, Ruth Messinger's campaign was careful to choose a small room.

title: Calendar: Quilt Show, Antiques Sale, Garden Fair
description: Quilts in Focus

title: A New Links Course For Old Nantucket
description: When most people think of Nantucket, they envision a remote, often fog-covered island, best known for its pristine beaches, moors, Quaker-style houses and an old-world quaintness that evokes the island's past as the world's foremost whaling center. Few are inclined to associate the island, 30 miles off the Massachusetts coast, with golf.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Appeal Denied in Sex Assault
description: The State Supreme Court declined on Monday to hear an appeal from three former Glen Ridge high school football players who are in prison for sexually assaulting a mildly retarded classmate in 1989, court officials said yesterday.

title: Drugs' Effect on Driver Discounted
description: The drugs found in the blood of the driver in the accident that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, are unlikely to have added substantially to the profound effects of the large quantity of alcohol he drank, alcoholism researchers said yesterday.

title: Ode to 1930's Architecture
description: To The Home Section:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER

title: Dormitory Life Is Essential to a Yale Education; Piety as a Shield
description: To the Editor:

title: Kudzu With Your Tea?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Chefs Fuming in Bias Suit Against White House
description: With his kitchen in the throes of remodeling and only the sink in place, Walter S. Scheib 3d was doing today what any sensible chef would do under the circumstances: planning to have 1,000 people over for dinner.

title: Albright at Shrine to Victims of Nazis
description: Like many Secretaries of State before her, Madeleine K. Albright paid a solemn and pensive visit today to Yad Vashem, the Israeli memorial to the victims of the Holocaust, on her first official visit to the Jewish state.

title: Ex-Toxic Dump Is Linked To Rise in Birth Problems
description: Medical investigators poring over thousands of birth records from households near a former toxic waste dump in southwestern New Jersey have found unusually clear evidence of a link that is often hard to measure -- between industrial chemicals in the environment and their impact on human health.

title: Detroit Manager Going To Boston Symphony
description: Mark Volpe, executive director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, has been named managing director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, effective on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, LEWIS
description: STEINMAN-Lewis. The Cystic Fibrosis Association of Greater New York marks with profound sorrow the passing of our very good friend and esteemed colleague on September 6, 1997. Lewis, together with his wife Joan, played pivotal roles in the early organizational and fundraising efforts to combat cystic fibrosis. Lew continued his leadership support for over 30 years in dedicated, selfless effort to give the ''breath of life'' to children and young adults with CF. He was a member of the Board of Directors and Corporate Chairman of the Cystic Fibrosis Association of Greater New York. His legacy of caring, love and giving will remain in our hearts. We extend deepfelt condolences to our friend, and Lew's beloved wife Joan, to sons Jeffrey, Peter and Robert and to all of the family. Phyllis L. Kossoff, President Jerome Hershman, Exec. V.P.

title: Slump Continues for Yankees' Wells
description: A perplexed David Wells stood between third base and the plate with both hands on his hips for about 20 seconds in the fifth inning, searching for answers. The Red Sox had just scored the go-ahead run on a close play at first in a game they would eventually win, 5-2, and Wells could not understand it.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Michel Stuart, 54, an Actor and Designer
description: Michel Stuart, a member of the original company of ''A Chorus Line'' and later a costume designer and theatrical producer, died on Sunday in an automobile accident in Malibu, Calif. He was 54, and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Feminist Number Games
description: Feminists have seized on a new study from the Bureau of Justice Statistics as proof that domestic violence against women is even worse than they thought. They note that the figures in this study, based on 1994 data, are four times higher than estimates of domestic abuse reported in another major survey. Such violence ''appears to be on the rise,'' said Kim Gandy, executive vice president of the National Organization for Women.

title: Lionel Chapman, 47, Producer for ABC News
description: Lionel Chapman, an award-winning producer for ABC News, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 47.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNTSEN, CARL A.
description: BERNTSEN-Carl A., of 355 Grace Church Street, Rye, N.Y. Died after a short illness, September 9, 1997. Survived by his widow the former Anne Rice, two sons Carl, III and Thomas S., a daughter Elise B. Stanbury and 4 grandchildren. Predeceased by his son Douglas E., Professor Emeritus in Medicine, Cornell Medical Center, New York Hospital and Physician Emeritus in Medicine at Hospital for Special Surgery. Service 4PM Saturday, September 13th, Christ Church, Rye, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to United Hospital Hospice, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, NY 10573.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Murder Suspect Flees
description: A Newark man awaiting trial for murder and kidnapping escaped from police custody Tuesday, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Racing Dates Sought for 1998
description: A five-day break at Christmas and another 36-day season at Saratoga were featured in the 1998 racing calendar proposed to the state yesterday by the New York Racing Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLSON, MIRIAM (MIMI)
description: NICHOLSON-Miriam (Mimi), of New York City on September 9, 1997. Mother of Leslie and Gail Nicholson. Sister of Fahnya Bean, Mary Jane Bension and Suzanne Westwater. Relatives and friends are invited to memorial services, on Sunday, September 14, 1997, at 12 Noon at Congregation Rodeph Sholom the Berkowitz Chapel, 615 North Broad St. (Mt. Vernon Street entrance), Philadelphia, PA., Joseph Levine & Son. 215-927-2700.

title: Still Offstage, Ickes Has Star Billing at Hearings
description: As in the long wait for Godot, the name of Harold M. Ickes, President Clinton's former White House political operative, is being invoked increasingly, impatiently at the Senate hearings into campaign finance abuses.

title: Gingrich Out West
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Backs Tax Penalty Against Silent Lawyer
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday upheld a decision by the Internal Revenue Service to impose a $25,000 penalty on a prominent New York lawyer, Gerald B. Lefcourt, in a case that he and other lawyers said raised critical issues about the ethical responsibility of lawyers to their clients.

title: At Ellis Island Museum, Dispute on Armenia Show
description: For Armenians, a massacre of their compatriots at the hands of the Ottoman Turks more than 80 years ago is a watershed event in the history of their diaspora.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHONBERG, GEORGE
description: SCHONBERG-George. 9/11/95. Gone two yearsSo absent, so present. Love always, Doris

title: People
description: * Avi Dan was named to the new position of executive vice president and new business development director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. He had been senior vice president and brand equity director at Ryan Drossman & Partners, New York.

title: Currents; Reflections In a Work Of Art
description: IN January, Robert Ming, a fashion designer, went shopping for a mirror that was also a strong sculptural conversation piece -- more than just a place to show his face. Not finding any, he designed some of his own, like Big Wow (above, $800), which looks like an exclamation point, and Self-Portrait ($800, below with the artist), a silhouette against a sand-blasted background. His line also includes Greetings, Earthlings ($400), a circle with antennas that has a certain Martian charm. Information from (212) 396-0912.

title: Burgess Meredith, 89, Who Was at Ease Playing Good Guys and Villains, Dies
description: Burgess Meredith, a virtuosic actor whose career spanned most of the 20th century and a multitude of performing arts, died on Tuesday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, ADELAIDE (NEE PHILLIPS)
description: BULL-Adelaide (nee Phillips). On Tuesday, September 9, 1997 of Chatham Township, NJ and Green Pond, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Calvin T. Bull (1992); loving mother of Robert E. Bull, Louis P. Bull and Kenneth A. Bull; devoted daughter of Edwin Phillips; sister of Kenneth E. Phillips. A Memorial service will be held Friday, September 12, 1997, 11 AM at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to the American Cancer Society, 468 Parish Dr., Suite 6, Wayne, NJ 07470 and/or The Chatham Community Players, 23 N. Passaic Ave, Chatham, NJ 07928, or The Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit, NJ 07901 would be appreciated.

title: The Bosnia Puzzle Needs a New Solution
description: The recent clashes between American forces and Serb nationalists in Bosnia highlight the fatal flaw of the Dayton peace accords that American-led NATO are there to enforce. The Dayton accords, reached in 1995, envision a melting pot of Muslims, Serbs and Croats in a united Bosnia. As desirable as that may be, it ignores the facts on the ground and the sad history of the region.

title: H.M.O.'s Move to Restrict Use of Diet Pills by Members
description: Many large health maintenance organizations are placing new restrictions on doctors' use of the controversial weight-loss drugs fen-phen and Redux and are declining to reimburse patients who obtain prescriptions for the medications through commercial weight-loss centers or by other means.

title: Dormitory Life Is Essential to a Yale Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Selection Is Under Way In Slaying By Policeman
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of an off-duty New York City police officer accused of killing a man in a dispute over a parking space in front of a Dobbs Ferry delicatessen.

title: Plaintiffs Win Right to Sue Lawyers in Malpractice Case
description: Eight years after a chemical plant explosion killed 23 people and injured hundreds in Houston, plaintiffs accusing a wealthy, influential law firm of malpractice in negotiating their multimillion-dollar settlement have finally won the right to take their suit to a jury.

title: Women Are Left Out Of Hunt for AIDS Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei average of 225 stocks was down 346.23 points, or 1.85 percent, at 18,358.54. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 8.80 points, closing at 18,704.77.

title: Aikman And Irvin: Two for The Money
description: They're an odd couple, Troy Aikman and Michael Irvin. The quarterback is a country music lover who has fiercely guarded his private life throughout a career that will certainly end in the Hall of Fame. His primary target, until recently, has lived publicly to a very different and loud beat.

title: Huskey, Batting Cleanup, Batters Phillies
description: In the last hours before the nation came to know Venus Williams on a first-name basis, she showed up at Shea Stadium to take batting practice. Alone among the Mets, Butch Huskey immediately recognized Williams, chatted with her and wished her well in the United States Open. Huskey is a sports nut, the sort who is aware of what is going on with every baseball, football and basketball team in the majors.

title: INSIDE
description: Challenge to Microsoft

title: Senate Repeals Tax Break For the Tobacco Industry
description: In another resounding setback for the tobacco industry, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to repeal a $50 billion tax break for the industry that was slipped into the tax cut legislation just before it was passed in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPMAN, LIONEL
description: CHAPMAN-Lionel. Beloved husband of Mary Hubbard. Memorial service Saturday, September 13th, 3:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, New York City.

title: Lyle M. Nelson, Fellowship Program Leader, 79
description: Lyle M. Nelson, who played a leading role in several graduate fellowship programs, including the John S. Knight Fellowships program at Stanford University, died on Friday at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 79.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Troops to Get New Jersey Flag
description: Seeking to undo a bureaucratic gaffe, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ordered yesterday that a New Jersey flag be sent immediately to American troops stationed in Bosnia-Herzegovina to help them mark the 50th anniversary of the United States Air Force on Sept. 18.

title: Arafat Must Take Greater Steps To Halt Terrorism, Albright Says
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright made a public show of support today for Israel and for Israeli victims of Palestinian terrorism and accused the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, of not doing nearly enough to crack down on the support network for the terrorists.

title: Making Believe in Someone Else's House
description: THERE is a house in western Massachusetts that I know well, or think I do. It's an old barn, with a red front door and a thicket of beams on the inside. For a moment as fleeting and luminous as a firefly, my family and I called it home.

title: Dormitory Life Is Essential to a Yale Education; Laxity by Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERKASKY, MARTIN, M.D.
description: CHERKASKY-Martin, M.D. On behalf of the Department of Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery of Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Enstein College of Medicine, we note the death and acknowledge the extraordinary life of Dr. Martin Cherkasky. His leadership and contributions to Montefiore Medical Center will always be remembered and appreciated. We extend sincere condolences to Dr. Cherkasky's family and friends. Berish Strauch, M.D., Chairman Department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, Montefiore Medical Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Misdiagnoses Are Said to Mask Lethal Abuse
description: Two reports expected to be published in a medical journal suggest that doctors over many years may have been inadvertently listing numerous cases of child abuse and infanticide under the category of sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS.

title: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE VOTERS -- On Their Home Turf, a Wide Gulf in Enthusiasm for Two Candidates; In Messinger Land, Talk of Apathy And Its Aftermath
description: Imagine a diehard Ruth W. Messinger voter, and Fred Kramer may come to mind. A novelist and a longtime resident of the Upper West Side, Ms. Messinger's home turf, he carries books in the pocket of a rumpled blue suit stained with red sauce.

title: Railroad Agrees to Implement Safety Measures
description: After a 17-day investigation of the nation's largest railroad, the chief of the Federal Railroad Administration said today that to reduce safety hazards, the line has agreed to hire more workers, increase training and supervision and reduce chronic worker fatigue.

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES UNIT TO BUY SIEMENS'S LIGHTING DIVISION
description: The Lighting Corporation of America, a unit of U.S. Industries, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the lighting division of Siemens A.G. for $67 million. The deal is expected to close by the end of this month. U.S. Industries, which makes a variety of consumer products, had 1996 sales of $2.23 billion. Siemens Lighting, which had 1996 sales of $185 million, has plants in Germany, Austria and Slovenia. Siemens A.G. is the German electronics company.

title: Entertaining Grandchildren
description: To The Home Section:

title: Television in Review
description: Sitcom Siblings And Their Sitcom Pals

title: Staff Shuffle at Institutional Investor
description: Euromoney Publications P.L.C. announced new management yesterday for Institutional Investor, which it acquired on Aug. 29 when it bought Institutional Investor publications from the Walt Disney Company for $142 million.

title: Nassau Democrats Pick a Novice
description: A political newcomer won the Democratic nomination in Nassau County's First Legislative District, narrowly defeating the party's choice in Tuesday's primary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, LELA HENDRY
description: SLATTERY-Lela Hendry. In Manhattan on September 7th, in her 81st year. Survived by her loving husband Louis, son John, daughter Elizabeth Spahr, grandchildren Kate and James Slattery and Nicholas and Emily Spahr, and daughter-in-law Kathy Slatteryall of Manhattan. Funeral service at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue at 71st St at 11:00 AM, on Friday, September 12, 1997.

title: Williams Faces Eye Surgery
description: Brian Williams, the Giants center sidelined with an eye injury since July 21, will undergo surgery Friday in an attempt to correct the double vision he has been experiencing. The Giants said that doctors will try to release a muscle adhesion in the area of the fracture that Williams sustained when he was inadvertently poked under his right eye during a drill at the team's training camp.

title: 2 Men Plead Guilty in Killing of Club Denizen
description: Michael Alig, whose elaborately planned parties once drew thousands of young people to Manhattan night spots, pleaded guilty yesterday to killing and dismembering a fellow denizen of the downtown night scene.

title: States to Sue F.C.C. Over Bell Jurisdiction
description: Setting up yet another showdown between Federal and state authorities over telephone deregulation, several state regulators plan to sue the Federal Communications Commission for attempting to set the terms by which the local phone companies must open their networks to new rivals, F.C.C. officials and industry executives said yesterday.

title: Rangers Start Camp With a Hole at Center
description: According to Wayne Gretzky, Mark Messier had 21 million good reasons to leave the Rangers as an unrestricted free agent and sign a multiyear contract with the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Ex-Agriculture Chief Pleads Not Guilty to Taking Gifts
description: Former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, the highest-ranking member of the Clinton Administration to be charged with a crime, pleaded not guilty today in Federal District Court to charges that he accepted more than $35,000 worth of sports tickets and other gifts from agriculture businesses he was charged with regulating.

title: Growth in Germany Spurts on Export Surge
description: German economic growth accelerated in the second quarter as the weak mark fueled an export surge, central bank figures released today showed.

title: When Money Counts
description: JUST ask Wonder Dog Fields: some things are meant to be black and white. Dalmatians, for example. Also zebras, wall phones and the checkerboard floor of Westminster Abbey.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: States Plan to Sue F.C.C. On Jurisdiction Over Bells

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEERR, CLINTON JAY
description: SHEERR-Clinton Jay, 50, prominent New Hampshire architect, died Monday, September 8, at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center after a long and heroic struggle with cancer. Loving husband of Deirdre McCrystal Sheerr. Devoted son of Alvin and Vivian Sheerr. Beloved brother of Phyllis Duberstein and Patsy Cardillo. Dearly loved uncle, son-in-law and brother-in-law. The funeral will be held on Friday, September 12 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Concord, New Hampshire. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Clinton's memory may be made to the New Hampshire Charitable Foundation, 37 Pleasant Street, Concord, New Hampshire 03301.

title: Events: Shows on Roman Art, Dixie Furniture, Mayor's Race
description: Artists in Ancient Rome

title: Currents; Off for a Spin on a Child's Fancy
description: TOMORROW, what may be the first carousel designed by children (although made by adults) will be unveiled at 1:30 P.M. at Riverbank State Park, Riverside Drive and 145th Street in Manhattan.

title: Metro Business; $2 Coupons to Settle An Antitrust Case
description: The Procter & Gamble Company and nine other consumer-product companies have agreed to pay $4.2 million to settle state antitrust charges that they conspired to reduce the availability of shopping coupons in western New York State.

title: Tandem Chief Gets A Post at Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that it had named the former chief executive of Tandem Computers Inc., Roel Pieper, to head its global sales and marketing as part of its strategy to become one of the world's top three computer makers by 2000.

title: Holtzbrinck's New Word on U.S. Publishing
description: Hard by a turkey farm and the brittle, blond cornstalks of this somnolent Southern community is a gleaming, new automated distribution center that is the German answer to some of the ills of the American publishing industry -- digital efficiency and laser wands.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Killing Time'

title: Peach Weekly Makes It to 10; Surviving on Readership Of Rich and Slightly Snide
description: From the moment The New York Observer first appeared on Sept. 22, 1987, two questions dogged the weekly newspaper. One concerned the proper term for its unusual hue, which media writers and gossip columnists variously labeled orange, pink, ''salmon colored'' and even ''lox colored.''

title: The Self as a Mix of Personal and Political
description: FOR some reason, the work of the Mexican painter Nahum B. Zenil, 50, has been seen only in dribs and drabs in the United States. But in his low-key way he's a sensational artist, and the arrival of a 20-year retrospective at Grey Art Gallery is cause to sit up and take notice.

title: Tracking Down the Killers of a Poet
description: When movies try to grapple with the lives of famous writers, they tend to be terribly starchy and self-consciously reverential. ''The Disappearance of Garcia Lorca,'' an elaborately contrived thriller focusing on the death of the Spanish poet and playwright Federico Garcia Lorca, who was executed by fascists in 1936, hews solemnly to the mold.

title: Art in Review
description: Michelle Fierro

title: Isidore Englander, 93, a Civil Libertarian
description: Isidore Englander, a civil liberties lawyer who was a founder of the National Lawyers' Guild, died on Sept. 4 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Residential Real Estate; At 100, Skyscraper Becomes Housing
description: Built a century ago as one of the first skyscrapers in downtown Manhattan, the former office building at 71 Broadway began leasing this week as the financial district's newest luxury rental and the latest response to the city's tight housing market.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Schools' Problem Is Teachers, Not Computers; Quick, Easy and Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Coming Up Short On Second-Down Plays
description: Of the 30 National Football League teams, no team was worse on offense last season than the Giants. But you need not remind Coach Jim Fassel's players.

title: New Cliffhanger at Marvel In Battle Over Its Debts
description: In comic books, the superhero faces numerous obstacles, and often seems to be in imminent danger of death or defeat. But somehow, readers know, the hero will prevail.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks were trading sharply lower here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei average of 225 stocks was down 290.53 points, or 1.6 percent, at 17,991.70. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 422.54 points, or 2.3 percent, to 18,282.23.

title: 2 Homeless Men Sue City Over Arrest in a Park
description: Two men who said they were homeless sued New York City yesterday, accusing the police of arresting, strip searching and detaining them and others who were lawfully sitting or sleeping on benches in a city park in lower Manhattan.

title: Women to Play Pro Soccer
description: The Olympic gold medals won by the United States last year in basketball and softball led to the formation of professional leagues for women in the United States. Yesterday, soccer followed when the National Soccer Alliance announced it would begin play next April with eight teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAHM, HERBERT
description: RAHM-Herbert. On September 11. Devoted husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Jason Rahm and Susan Holden. Beloved grandfather of Jillian, Wendy, Danielle, Jonathan and Kevin. Interment at Knollwood Park, Ridgewood, NY, September 12 at 2 P.M.

description: New Scrutiny for Teamsters

title: Of Latino Lovers Inflamed by a Torrid Soap Opera
description: In the romantically overheated world of Ela Troyano's satirical sex comedy, ''Latin Boys Go to Hell,'' all emotion flows from a fiery, nostril-flaring Spanish-language soap opera called ''Dos Vidas.'' When a woman is betrayed by her macho lover on the serial, his cheating is punishable by death and her lethal revenge exacted with a triumphal fury.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, ARNOLD
description: GELLER-Arnold. The Officers and Executive Board of SEIU, Local 2 expresses its sorrow at the passing of its beloved President and extends its heartfelt sympathy to his family. Viewing will be at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th Street, New York City, on Friday, noon to 4 PM, and Saturday at Michael Higgins Funeral Home, 321 Main Street, New City, NY 2-4 PM, and 7-9 PM. Funeral services on Sunday at 10 AM at Michael Higgins Funeral Home.

title: A Big Tax Blunder
description: Two years ago, Republicans in Congress tried to let lobbyists for big polluters rewrite environmental laws behind closed doors. Not surprisingly, many people were appalled. But now Republican leaders are back with a similar notion for the Internal Revenue Service. They want to put corporate special interests in charge of the nation's tax-collecting agency.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Fordham

title: Nassau Official Calls Rail Stations 'Intolerable'
description: Saying poor maintenance of railroad stations has jeopardized the health and safety of commuters, the Nassau County Comptroller threatened today to withhold payments to the Long Island Rail Road's parent agency unless the problems are corrected.

title: New York Plans a Tribute to Diana
description: New York City's farewell to Diana, Princess of Wales, who charmed New Yorkers from Fifth Avenue to the South Bronx, will be a sedate Central Park service on Sunday punctuated by classical music and traditional prayers.

title: Account Changes By 3 Marketers
description: Three large marketers have changed agencies on their accounts, with combined billings estimated at $66 million to $70 million.

title: American Airlines Ruled Guilty Of Misconduct in '95 Cali Crash
description: A Federal judge today found American Airlines guilty of willful misconduct in the crash of its flight from Miami to Cali, Colombia, in December 1995, a decision that eliminates the damage cap specified by international law.

title: Schools' Problem Is Teachers, Not Computers; Machine on Every Desk
description: To the Editor:

title: SEAGULL ENERGY SAYS IT WILL SELL A UNIT TO RIO ALTO
description: The Seagull Energy Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its Canadian exploration and production unit to Rio Alto Exploration Ltd. for $182 million of stock. Both Seagull and Rio Alto are oil and gas companies. Rio Alto, based in Calgary, Alberta, said it planned to keep almost all of the unit's employees. Seagull said it planned to use the proceeds from the deal to repay long-term debt, including all of its Canadian debt. Seagull, which is based in Houston, said it expected its fourth-quarter earnings to increase by about $13 million, or 21 cents a share, from the sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLAM, EUGENE
description: FULLAM-Eugene. A very special friend and a very special partner. Gene was a dedicated, forceful visionary who, unfortunately, was not granted sufficient time to see the fruition of his development dreams for Orange County. To his dear wife Adele and his great sons and daughters, my deepest sympathies. I shall also dearly miss Gene. Jerome Belson

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE FOOTBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPALMA, RALPH JOSEPH
description: DePALMA-Ralph Joseph. On September 10, 1997. Beloved brother of Irene. Uncle of two nieces and one nephew. Very close friend of Henrietta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBBS, JOSELYN REYNOLDS
description: GIBBS-Joselyn Reynolds, of Spring Valley Rd, Ossining, age 83. Died Sept. 10 after a long illness. One of three children of George O. Reynolds & Ruth Sutton Reynolds of New Rochelle, she attended Syracuse University and was a model for the John Robert Powers agency in New York. The beloved wife of the late Donald S. Gibbs, an advertising executive, she was a founder of Twigs and its ''Thrift Tree,'' volunteer units that raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for Northern Westchester Hospital. Active in other local charities, she was also a water colorist honored in regional art shows. She is survived by a brother, George Reynolds, of Longboat Key, FL; a sister, Beverly Lauffer of Clearwater, FL, a son, Donald S. Gibbs, Jr; a daughter, Ruthie Gibbs Becker; and five grandchildren; Kristen A. and Erin J. Becker; and Donald S., Justin T., and Jonathan S. Gibbs. A memorial service will be held Monday, September 15 at 11:00 AM at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Northern Westchester Hospital or Hospice of Northern Westchester and Putnam, Inc.

title: Abroad at Home; The Wrong Signal
description: If there is one person in the world who best symbolizes human resistance to tyranny, it is the Chinese prisoner Wei Jingsheng. Alone, he has challenged the most powerful tyranny on earth -- and been willing to pay the fearful price it exacted. For advocating democracy in China, he was imprisoned for 14 years and is now serving another 14-year sentence under brutal conditions.

title: No Refuge for the Young In a Small Town Upstate
description: ''Delinquent'' is a small, tough, imperfect film about troubled adolescence. The movie also serves as a calling card for its writer, producer and director, Peter Hall, who is making his debut in feature films after a past in journalism, multimedia concert production and the writing of financial and industrial videos.

title: SUN COMMUNITIES IN $93 MILLION DEAL WITH PARK REALTY
description: Sun Communities Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy nine manufactured housing communities from partnerships managed by Park Realty Inc. for about $93 million. The properties are in the Southwest, Indiana and Florida. Sun, which is based in Farmington Hills, Mich., did not provide details about the agreement or about the properties. Sun Communities is among the biggest renters of property to owners of manufactured and mobile homes. It owns and operates 85 communities with about 30,000 developed sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNTSEN, CARL A.
description: BERNTSEN-Carl A., of 355 Grace Church Street, Rye, N.Y. Died after a short illness, September 9, 1997. Survived by his widow the former Anne Rice, two sons Carl, III and Thomas S., a daughter Elise B. Stanbury and 4 grandchildren. Predeceased by his son Douglas E., Professor Emeritus in Medicine, Cornell Medical Center, New York Hospital and Physician Emeritus in Medicine at Hospital for Special Surgery. Service 4PM Saturday, September 13th, Christ Church, Rye, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to United Hospital Hospice, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, NY 10573.

title: .F.L. Matchups: Week 3
description: Ravens-Giants

title: Asian-American Groups File a Complaint of Bias in Inquiries and Coverage
description: The telephone calls to Charles Woo came in mid-December, as the campaign finance scandal was heating up. The caller said she was an accountant working for the Democratic National Committee and was investigating Asian-Americans who had donated more than $5,000 to the Democratic Party. Could she ask a few questions?

title: A Liar and Manipulator, Naturally He's Successful
description: ''A Self-Made Hero'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 30, 1996. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Judge, Under Investigation, Pleads to Keep his Job
description: Sounding like a defendant appealing for mercy, Lorin Duckman, the New York City judge under investigation since a domestic violence case he handled ended in murder, expressed regret to a state commission yesterday for some of his behavior, insisted that other accusations against him were untrue and asked to be allowed to remain on the bench.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMER, BONNIE
description: SOMMER-Bonnie. September 10, 1997. Born March 1, 1948. Bonnie died after a valiant battle with lung cancer. She was the daughter of the late Smitty Sommer and his survived by her mother Esther, her sister Elissa and the joy of her life, her son Michael. Bonnie was a graduate of the Cooper Union. She devoted many years teaching children born with neurological problems, but she never lost her interest in the arts. She was a devoted mother, always trying to do her best for her beloved son Michael. She is survived by many friends and relatives and she will be sadly missed for her smile, her wit and her laughter. She also was the very best of sisters and will be missed more than mere words could possibly express. The funeral will be held Friday at 12:30PM at I.J. Morris, Flatbush and Kings Highway. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory to the Mary McDowell Center for Learning, 110 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, New York, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Schools' Problem Is Teachers, Not Computers; Limits of Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Weld's Foes Increase Pressure on Clinton
description: On the eve of Friday's Senate showdown over the nomination of William F. Weld to be Ambassador to Mexico, Mr. Weld's opponents today increased the pressure on President Clinton to back off the nomination.

title: Coyotes' Owner Nears Deal To Purchase the Islanders
description: The Islanders announced last night that New York Sports Ventures, L.L.C., a newly formed company controlled by Steven M. Gluckstern and the developer Howard P. Milstein, has signed a letter of intent to purchase the team from John O. Pickett Jr., the current majority owner of the team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, ARNOLD M.
description: PRICE-Arnold M. Died September 9, 1997. WWII veteran, copywriter, poet and former National Treasurer for Amnesty International USA. Devoted father of Adam and Donald Price. Loving grandfather of Giovanna Price. Dear brother of Stella Klein and Cynthia Oxenberg. Visiting Saturday, September 13, 10AM-12 Noon, Stevenson Funeral Home, 790 Piermont Ave, Piermont, N.Y. Memorial gathering to be announced 718-745-3048

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELSON, STANLEY
description: MICHAELSON-Stanley, Sept. 10, 1997 in Tampa, FL. Born in NYC, came to Tampa in 1980 from Long Island, NY. Survivors include his wife, Lorna; 3 sons, Richard and Peter of Portland, OR, and Jay of Tampa; 3 daughters, Nancy of Baltimore, MD, Patricia of Atlanta, GA, and Maia of NYC; a brother, Arthur (Arline) of Great Neck, NY; and 3 grandchildren. Graveside services will be held Thursday, September 11, at 3 PM, at Beth Moses Cemetery. Info: Beth David Funeral Chapel, Tampa, FL.

title: Opposition-Led Mexican House Greets Budget Angrily
description: In a blitz of speeches this week, President Ernesto Zedillo and his economic team defended the fiscal discipline they have championed, seeking to set the parameters for a far-reaching debate over the economy.

title: Restaurants
description: Ask for table 12. It's got the best view of the restaurant, and the Park is definitely a place you want to watch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ALICE
description: GREENBERG-Alice. Beloved wife of Aaron, devoted mother of Barry and Susan Greenberg, Gail and Jeff Elkins, and Susan and Scott Schildhaus. Cherished grandmother of Seth, Zachary, Carly, Sam, and Jordan. We love you all there is and then some more. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, today at 11:30 A.M.

title: Substitutes for Strikers
description: The Bishop of the Diocese of Camden yesterday authorized the hiring of substitute teachers as temporary replacements for striking lay teachers in eight Roman Catholic high schools in southern New Jersey. Officials of the teachers' union called the move an effort to break the union.

title: Lullabies and Little Sighs, With Memories, of Course
description: James Taylor fell victim to his own predictability on Wednesday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. Introducing his song ''Frozen Man,'' he announced, ''I got this idea from --''

title: Sitting in the 70's; With Outdated Styles, Furniture Sellers Are Struggling
description: By every visible measure, there is no excuse for not making money in the furniture business these days.

title: Clinton Plans To Nominate C.D.C. Head To Health Job
description: Trying to fill a high-profile position that has been vacant for more than two years, President Clinton plans on Friday to nominate Dr. David Satcher, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, to be Surgeon General, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Veliko Trgovisce Journal; Boyhoods Enshrined: Keeping Up With Tito
description: This village, with its wooden crucifix in the main intersection, is known chiefly for its turkeys.

title: James R. Phelan, 85, Is Dead; Biographer of Howard Hughes
description: James R. Phelan, an author and a dogged investigative reporter who made a crusade out of exposing the reclusive billionaire Howard R. Hughes, died on Monday at his home in Temecula, Calif. He was 85.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Michael Alig, a party promoter on the New York City nightclub scene who pleaded guilty in the killing of a clubgoer, referred incorrectly to the specifics of the plea. While Mr. Alig pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the case, he did not acknowledge details of the slaying, including an assertion that the victim was smothered and his body chopped up and thrown into the Hudson River. Those assertions were included in statements to the police by an accomplice who also pleaded guilty.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What do Paula Jones, Patsy Ramsey, Madeleine K. Albright, Susan Molinari and Chelsea Clinton have in common?

title: Terrifying Tricks That Make a Big Man Little
description: MIGHT ''The Game'' suggest a special gift? It's for the man who has enough of everything except nightmares. This thriller's surprise scheme for Nicholas Van Orton, a joyless investment banker whose first name is effectively Mister, is a string of tricks to disrupt his privileged tranquillity. Those tricks mean an expensive and mostly unrelated string of shocks, illusions and chase scenes, so the audience should have no trouble sharing Van Orton's brush with flashy artificiality. After all, at the movies we've been doing that all summer.

title: Immigration Service Is a Law Unto Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: CORPORATE EXPRESS AGREES TO BUY DATA DOCUMENTS
description: The shares of Data Documents Inc. rose 27 percent yesterday after Corporate Express Inc. said late on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the company for $195 million to expand its office-products line. Shares of Data Documents, which provides business forms, labels and forms-management services to corporate customers, rose $4, to $18.875. Corporate Express, based in Broomfield, Colo., is offering one of its shares for each share of Data Documents, which is based in Omaha. Corporate Express shares fell 6.25 cents, to $19.9375. Corporate Express said the acquisition would enable it to consolidate certain operations and improve purchasing costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MEYER
description: ROSEN-Meyer. With much love. Cherished husband to Lillian. Dearest father to David, Barbara, Francine and Bill. Adored grandfather to Lana, Howie, Peter, Dana, Darin and Allison. Precious great grandfather to Nicole and Ryan. Our icon for support and love.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHONBERG, GEORGE
description: SCHONBERG-George. 9/11/95. Gone two yearsSo absent, so present. Love always, Doris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTKIN, JOAN, DR.
description: GUTKIN-Joan, Dr. We mourn the loss of a most special person-a sister-in-law, aunt and great aunt we will miss always. Janet and Jack Sexer Rhonda Meir and Ethan Levy Beth, Jonathan and Sara Kern Leslie and Rob Reiner

title: Craft Is On Track to Map Terrain of Mars
description: Putting on the brakes with a steady blast of rocket exhaust, an American spacecraft eased into a wide orbit of Mars tonight to spend two years mapping the planet's mountains and canyons, icy polar caps and windswept flood plains.

title: Ann Dunnigan, Actress and Translator, 87
description: Ann Dunnigan, an actress and translator, died on Sept. 5 at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

title: New Video Releases
description: Fathers' Day

title: Schools' Problem Is Teachers, Not Computers; Training Is Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chinese Plot
description: Two months after Senator Fred Thompson boldly declared that China had developed a plan to influence the 1996 American elections with secret and in some cases illegal operations, his serious accusation remains unproved but also unimpeached. That is unnerving, for the charge is not only one of the most explosive elements of the campaign finance scandal but also central to the management of Washington's relations with Beijing. Both the Senate and the White House have an obligation to tell the country what they know and what they make of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, BENJI K.
description: GREEN-Benji K., of Encino, CA. Died September 2, 1997. Rest in peace, dear friend of 50 years. Grace Glueck

title: Officer's Suspension Ends
description: Robert J. Leaks Jr., the Newark police officer suspended for the fatal shooting in June of Danette Daniels, a drug suspect, returned to work yesterday and was assigned to a desk job in the department's property and evidence division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENOWITZ, NINA
description: MENOWITZ-Nina. A loving wife, mother, grandmother and friend, all who knew her will never forget how vividly she touched our lives. Rarely does there come along a woman with so many wonderful qualities as Nina. Intelligence, honesty, and courage were only some of the outstanding virtues possessed by this unique individual. Undaunted and uncomplaining to the very end, Nina remained the eternal optimist throughout her long and trying illness. Her charm and wit, and most of all her compassion and love will remain in our hearts forever. The family of Harold Menowitz, husband of Nina Menowitz, wish to express our sincerest gratitude to all her many friends who have so generously expressed their deepest sympathy and kindness during this lengthly illness. Harold Menowitz Fred and Sue Menowitz Carol Penn and family

title: Gore Aide's Memo on Fund-Raising
description: Following is a memorandum by Vice President Al Gore's chief of staff on talking points for a 1996 White House fund-raising meeting. Mr. Gore did not use them at the meeting, aides said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMMUNITY FIRST BANKSHARES INC., Fargo, N.D., agreed to acquire 37 branches in Arizona, Colorado and Utah from Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, for about $38 million.

title: Giuliani Campaign Agrees To Return Illegal Funds
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election campaign has been suspended from the city program that gives candidates public funds after regulators accused the campaign of accepting a total of more than $300,000 in illegal contributions. In response, the Giuliani campaign acknowledged yesterday that at least $290,000 of the contributions were illegal and said that it would return that money.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Profit Warnings Push Most Market Indexes Down

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKSTEIN, GERTRUDE S.
description: LOOKSTEIN-Gertrude S. Upper East Side Hatzolah, its members and coordinators, mourn the passing of Gertrude Lookstein, an exceptional individual, a true ''eishet chayil'', and leader in our community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her son, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Rabbi of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and principal of The Ramaz School, and to her daughter, Dr. Nathalie Friedman. Mrs. Lookstein's dedicated support for and pride in Hatzolah as well as her decades of leadership in the Upper East Side Jewish Community will be sorely missed. May the bereaved family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David W. Shipper Andrew M. Shipper Coordinators

title: Arlington Vowing To Stick to Plan
description: Richard L. Duchossois, chairman of the Arlington International race track near Chicago, said yesterday that he would not change his decision to cancel all racing next year, and expressed hope that he might be sending a message to an industry in turmoil.

title: Is It Real, or Just a Bout Of Paralyzing Paranoia?
description: Hollywood-style hubris has rarely been portrayed as indelibly as it is in an early scene of Wim Wenders's brilliant puzzle of a film, ''The End of Violence.'' In it a bullying producer of action-adventure films named Mike Max (Bill Pullman), who intermittently narrates the movie, is shown doing tough business while lounging beside the swimming pool on his opulent estate overlooking the Pacific.

title: Bosnian Serb Media Are Threat to Dayton
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Who's Afraid Of Stock Drop? Apparently Not Fund Investors
description: Investors in mutual funds apparently need a lot more than a 6 percent decline in stock prices to scare them off. As the market alternately soared and skidded in August, mutual fund investors remained remarkably steadfast, adding some $13.5 billion to equity funds, a trade group reported yesterday.

title: Inside Photography
description: Large construction sites hold such a fascination for passers-by that the walls surrounding them usually have openings through which the curious can watch the primeval efforts to tear down and build up. But for the French photographer Stephane Couturier, such sites are particularly interesting during moments of little or no activity.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Be-Bop Goes Bold

title: Art in Review
description: Johan Grimonprez

title: UNITED BANKSHARES AGREES TO $215 MILLION DEAL
description: United Bankshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire George Mason Bankshares Inc. for about $215 million in stock, expanding its presence in Virginia. Under the agreement, United, based in Parkersburg, W. Va., is to exchange 0.85 share for each George Mason share. George Mason's stock gained $1.25 yesterday, to $35.75; United fell $1.9375, to $43.5625. George Mason, based in Fairfax, Va., has $963 million in assets. Upon completion of the acquisition, United is to merge George Mason with United Bank, its unit in Arlington, Va. The merged company would have more than $3.5 billion in assets.

title: Pettitte and Solid Offense Make Orioles Look Mortal
description: It is obviously too late for the Yankees to overtake the powerful Orioles, no matter how much they want to dream. It is undoubtedly too late for the Yankees to steal a division title from Baltimore, no matter what George Steinbrenner thinks. But it is not too late for the Yankees to revive themselves and maybe even scare the Orioles for a minute when their thoughts shift to baseball in October.

title: Japan's Auto Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Survivors of Evil Dedicate Reminder for the Future
description: As rain enveloped lower Manhattan yesterday, scores of survivors of the Nazi atrocities made their way, haltingly, to the dedication of the Museum of Jewish Heritage, the first public memorial to the Holocaust in the city that is home to more refugees of that horror than any other place in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZISSON, GERTRUDE (ROSENHIRSCH)
description: ZISSON-Gertrude (Rosenhirsch). Of Narragansett, RI, died Wednesday at home. She was the wife of the late Max Zisson. She leaves two sons, Harry and William and daughter-in-law Nancy. She was the grandmother of Alex, Robin and Daniel. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Miriam Hospital Foundation, Box H, Annex Station, Providence, RI 02901.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, STELLA JOLLES
description: REICHMAN-Stella Jolles. Died September 9 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Henry Reichman. Loving mother of the late Thomas and Steven, grandmother of Jamie. Memorial service Wednesday, October 1, Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 Street at 2PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY.

title: Albright Asks Israel to Take A 'Time Out' on Settlements
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright called on Israel today to refrain from actions the Palestinians find provocative, and urged a ''time out'' on settlement activity.

title: Memo Appears to Reveal Gore In Active Role as a Fund-Raiser
description: Vice President Al Gore's top aide wrote a memorandum of ''talking points'' for Mr. Gore to use at a 1996 White House fund-raising meeting to outline a strategy, which included telephone solicitations, for achieving the lofty financial goals of the Democratic Party.

title: George Schaefer, Director and Producer, 76
description: George Louis Schaefer, an award-winning producer and director who worked in television, theater and film, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 76.

title: A Prying Mother and a Not-So-Deep Secret
description: Mario Fratti doesn't seem to have an ear for character-specific language. You just wouldn't expect a 20-something, American-born, T-shirt-and-jeans kind of guy in present-day New York to say of an old girlfriend, ''She's probably obsessed with some other poor devil.'' This is right before that guy, Carlo (Wayne Maugans), describes someone as ''punctilious.'' Audiences haven't heard anything like this since a 22-year-old Troy Donahue, playing a teen-ager, used the word ''supercilious'' in ''A Summer Place.''

title: Limited Access to Medical Records Is Urged
description: Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, urged Congress today to set comprehensive Federal standards to protect the confidentiality of medical records. But she said lawmakers must not ''interfere with the well-established procedures of the criminal justice system.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have a museum in my mind and in my heart. I live with it every hour of every day. But others need this building to learn.''

title: Schools' Problem Is Teachers, Not Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEREDITH, BURGESS
description: MEREDITH-Burgess. The Cathedral School of St. John the Divine mourns the loss of our loyal alumnus, Burgess Meredith, Class of 1924. Phillip G. Foote, Headmaster The Very Rev. Harry H. Pritchett, Jr. Dean of the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine

title: Mexican Party Balks at Vote, So Zedillo Chooses Its Chief
description: The Government's political party chose a new leader today after two days of stormy wrangling in which President Ernesto Zedillo abruptly abandoned his push for greater democracy within the party.

title: Teen-Ager Is Slain in Clash in Subway
description: A confrontation between two groups of high school students in a busy Harlem subway station yesterday ended with a 14-year-old boy stabbed to death and two other boys wounded, the police said.

title: Accident Puts De La Hoya on Course
description: Somebody up there likes him and a few down here do, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANLON, MARCELLA R.
description: HANLON-Marcella R. Of Dobbs Ferry, formerly of Hastings-onHudson, NY. Beloved wife of the late Francis, devoted mother of Marcella Dietz and Claudia O'Donnell, dear sister of Gregory and William Shearn and fond grandmother of David, Christopher, Michael and Meghan. Mass of the Resurrection 10AM Saturday, St. Matthews Church, Hastings-onHudson. Visiting 7-9PM Friday, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford (Saw Mill Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, New York. Memorials to Hastings-on-Hudson Ambulance appreciated. ''United with Franny and in our hearts forever.''

title: Diner's Journal
description: The entrance is dark. Looking toward the light, you find yourself peering through a curtain of water falling gently into a grass-rimmed pool. Serene is the word that floats into your mind. The impression lingers as you sink into the soft, curved banquette and survey the attractive room; everything about the new Union Pacific is so quiet that it is hard to believe it is the same space that once housed C. T.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOSHIDA, MARY BERNADINE
description: YOSHIDA-Mary Bernadine, on September 1st, 1997. Loving aunt of Nadine Wegner, Margaret Wilhelm and Paul Wilhelm. Dear cousin of Jan Merlin and John R. Barnett. Memorial service on Sunday, September 14, 1997 at 3 PM in First Church of Christian Science, 14 East 48th Street, NYC.

title: U.S. Life Expectancy Hits New High
description: Americans are living longer than ever, the infant death rate has reached an all-time low and the percentage of teenagers giving birth has declined for the fifth straight year, with the drop among black teen-agers nearly double that of the decline among whites, according to an analysis of the nation's vital statistics released today by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Giuliani Endorsed by Municipal Workers Union
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani received a major boost yesterday when New York City's largest union of municipal workers endorsed him -- the first time the 120,000-member union, a longtime ally of local and state Democrats, has ever endorsed a Republican in a mayoral race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEIL, EDWARD P.
description: KEIL-Edward P., Denver, formerly of Mount Kisco, New York; husband of Barbara Keil; father of David Keil, Denver, and Caroline Keil, NY; Memorial Service will be held 3:00PM Sunday, September 14th, Temple Shearith Israel, 46 Peaceable St, Richfield, CT., 06877, Ph#

title: Jessye Norman to Receive A Kennedy Center Award
description: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced the recipients of its annual awards today, and one of them, the soprano Jessye Norman, represented a watershed of sorts: she is the first honoree to have been born after World War II.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about reaction to the mayoral campaign of Ruth W. Messinger misstated the view of one Upper West Side voter, Fred Kramer, on the death penalty. Mr. Kramer says that while he voted for Councilman Sal F. Albanese, who supports the death penalty, Mr. Kramer himself opposes capital punishment.

title: He's Loud and Boorish, She's Shy, for Starters
description: If it weren't so beautifully understated, Steven Mackintosh's portrayal of a shy but determinedly independent transsexual named Kim Foyle in ''Different for Girls'' might qualify as the stunt performance of the year. Kim, who is blond, thin-lipped and cautious, radiates an air of wounded embattlement as she embarks on a new life as a writer of occasional verses for a greeting-card company. And the subtlety with which Mr. Mackintosh conveys her complicated mixture of vulnerability, defensiveness and pride makes her one of the most fully realized characters to be portrayed on the screen in a long time.

title: La Jolla Capital and 5 Executives Are Penalized by N.A.S.D. Panel
description: Regulators ordered the La Jolla Capital Corporation, a San Diego brokerage firm, and five of its current and former executives, today to pay $912,385 in penalties for inducing customers to sign misleading letters in a scheme to evade penny-stock rules.

title: Adventure and Loneliness Riding Freights in the 30's
description: The romantic spirit and visual prettiness of ''Riding the Rails'' are unexpected, since this documentary deals with hard times. But during the Great Depression, as this film by Michael Uys and Lexy Lovell attests, a world of adventure briefly revealed itself to certain daring American teen-agers.

title: G.O.P. Wooed By Democrat For Overhaul On Donations
description: The Democratic minority leader in the Senate said today that he was two Republicans short of enough votes to pass a campaign finance reform bill perhaps this year.

title: Art in Review
description: Itty Neuhaus

title: ABC, PBS and CBS Lead Emmys for News
description: With four trophies apiece, ''Nightline,'' ''Frontline'' and ''60 Minutes'' were the big winners of the 18th annual News and Documentary Emmy Awards, presented Wednesday night in Manhattan. Their respective networks -- ABC, PBS and CBS -- also led the pack.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EPSTEIN, ANNA G.
description: EPSTEIN-Anna G. Unbound by time. Doris George Estelle

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: More Effort Is Promised for the Homeless
description: New York City officials have agreed to heighten efforts to insure that they do not unfairly turn families away from homeless shelters, and to make sure that families who live in unsafe or overcrowded conditions will not be denied help.

title: ARMY'S LEADERSHIP BLAMED IN REPORT ON SEXUAL ABUSES
description: The Army announced today that its largest investigation ever of sexual misconduct in its ranks found that ''sexual harassment exists throughout the Army, crossing gender, rank and racial lines,'' and that the Army's leadership was to blame.

title: A New Trump Tower Could Overshadow Diplomacy
description: The United Nations, sleek and elegant on the East River, may soon have a new neighbor, a tall and silvery condominium tower that Donald J. Trump is planning to build on a site overlooking the complex's permanent gardens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEELER, HELEN ALICE (NEE QUINN)
description: KEELER-Helen Alice (nee Quinn) of Stamford, CT., formerly of Greenwich, CT., and Mineola, LI on September 11, 1997. Retiree of The West Publishing Co., Westbury. Beloved wife of the late Paul J. Devoted mother of Carol K. Colmer of Wyndham, NY, Susan K. McNamara of Ridgewood, NJ, Helen Marie K. Shipp of Alexandria, VA, Paul J. Jr., of Greenwich, CT, John M. of Wyckoff, NJ and Christopher M. of Old Greenwich. Dear sister of Kathleen Q. Hackett of Stony Brook, NY, Mary Q. Lilja of Brooklyn, NY, Margaret A. Quinn of Brooklyn, NY, Patricia Q. Phelan of Rockville Centre, NY, Maureen Q. Murphy of New York City and Edward G. Quinn of Brooklyn, NY. Also survived by 15 grandchildren. Visiting 7-9 P.M. Friday, Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis, Ave., Mineola. Memorial service 8:30 AM Saturday, St. Mary's Church, Greenwich, CT. Funeral Mass 11:30 AM Saturday Corpus Christi Church, Mineola. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to the Campaign for Greenwich Hospital, or the Greenwich Hospital Auxiliary, Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: Motorola Sees Low Earnings; Stock Tumbles
description: Motorola Inc. said yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter would be significantly below expectations, hurt by weak sales of pagers and one-time costs. It also said it would stop producing clones of Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh, resulting in one of those costs, a $95 million charge.

title: Man Is Charged in Slayings
description: A 19-year-old man was charged yesterday in the murders of two people who were shot Monday in a rooming house, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRAUNZ, SYLVIA
description: KRAUNZ-Sylvia. 10/11/05-7/16/97. A memorial service will be Sunday, September 14, 2PM, Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAHR, HENRY
description: BAHR-Henry, Dr. Of 355 Blackstone Blvd., Providence, RI died Wednesday at Rhode Island Hospital, Providence. He was the husband of Lore (Barth) Bahr, and the father of Dr. Robert Bahr of Providence, and the late Doris Bahr. He was the grandfather of Talia Goldfarb and Danielle and Jonathan Bahr. Interment will be held on Friday at 2:30 P.M., at the Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hasting on Hudson, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Henry & Lore Bahr Family Fund For The Promotion of Tolerance, C/O Mrs. Beth Raffeld, Development Office, PO Box 231, Williamstown, MA. 02167.

title: In Their Own Words
description: Outside Public School 33 in the Fordham section of the Bronx, to a rally by the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition's Education Committee to protest school overcrowding:

title: Musicians On the Road To Stardom, Or Oblivion
description: ''Bandwagon'' is the scruffy, tenderly funny story of a fledgling rock band from Raleigh, N.C. And as written and directed by John Schultz, it shows much more finesse than its low budget or raffish atmosphere might suggest. Mr. Schultz brings a fond and knowing perspective to the world of the garage band, but his previous experience in making promotional documentaries about Steven Spielberg movies (''Jurassic Park'' and ''Hook'') also shows. Sweet and rueful, with a fresh, likable cast and solid comic timing, ''Bandwagon'' offers a laid-back good time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUGE, GRACE
description: HOUGE-Grace. The Trustees and Staff of The Hudson Valley Children's Museum offer their condolences to the David Houge family on the loss of Grace Houge. The Hudson Valley Children's Museum

title: Doubt on Carey Spot on Teamster Ballot
description: The Federal official overseeing the teamsters election said yesterday that new evidence and new witnesses were causing her to reconsider her decision not to disqualify the union's president, Ron Carey, from running for re-election against James P. Hoffa.

title: Renault Bounces Back, Reporting a Profit
description: Renault S.A. posted a first-half operating profit compared with a loss a year earlier thanks to cost cuts and successful new models, and the company said yesterday that it would probably earn money for the whole of 1997. Renault, Europe's sixth-largest car maker, had operating income of 364 million French francs ($59.6 million) in the period compared with an operating loss of 255 million francs a year earlier.

title: No Chinese Connection?
description: To the Editor:

title: BTR to Sell Several Divisions
description: The British industrial conglomerate BTR P.L.C. said yesterday that it planned to sell several divisions by the end of next year to focus on its engineering business. BTR said it would sell its packaging, materials, building products and polymers divisions. It would not comment on the likely sale proceeds, but the businesses have combined sales of $:2.8 billion, or $4.4 billion. Proceeds will be used to make acquisitions, increase spending in the engineering divisions and buy back shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, FRED
description: STERNBERG-Fred. Of Palm Coast, FL, formerly of Paramus, NJ, September 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Fanny (nee Ullmann). Devoted father of Sandra Sternberg Barash, Linda S. Theos and Deborah J. Sternberg. Dear brother of Bette Sternberg. Loving grandfather of Michelle and Lauren Theos. Services ''GuttermanMusicant'', corner Passaic and Park Streets, Hackensack, NJ, today at 1:00 PM. The memorial week will be observed at the Theos residence, Paramus, NJ. Contributions to Temple Beth Shalom, Palm Coast, FL or Hospice of Volusia-Flagler, Port Orange, FL would be appreciated.

title: WHG RESORTS AND CASINOS SAYS IT IS IN ACQUISITION TALKS
description: WHG Resorts and Casinos Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to be acquired by an undisclosed party for about $20 a share, or $124 million. WHG, which owns the Condado Plaza Hotel and Casino and interests in other Puerto Rican hotels and casinos, said the negotiations were preliminary. The company was spun off from WMS Industries about five months ago. WHG's stock has doubled since then as the company has added rooms to its hotels and has sought to expand in the Caribbean. WHG's shares fell 75 cents yesterday, to $18.50. Analysts said real estate investment trusts like Patriot American Hospitality Inc. or Starwood Lodging Trust could be possible buyers. WMS, based in Chicago, makes slot machines and Atari games.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; 100 Candles for Olds And Cars That Shine On
description: AS its 1998 models arrive in dealer showrooms, Oldsmobile begins its second hundred years. For those who love vintage autos, Olds is significant for more than being the oldest surviving American nameplate, and the first to celebrate its centennial. The General Motors division has built some merry and memorable cars, a handful of which are highly desirable today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEYMER, JOHN F.
description: HEYMER-John F. June 22, 1933 to September 12, 1991. In loving memory. It is now six years that has passed that we have been without you, but not one day has passed that we haven't thought about what a wonderful and devoted husband and father you were.
