We miss you and love you. Marion and Laura Jean Heymer

title: Civil Tones On a Topic Of Violence
description: IN case anyone was under the misguided impression that charges of systemic police brutality were about to disappear, the issue reverberated again at City Hall yesterday, like an unending drumroll.

title: A Collection of the Sassy New and the Solid Familiar
description: The ambitious Dance Now '97 festival began on Wednesday night with a marathon program at the Joyce SoHo that lived up to most of the festival's four aims. If there wasn't anything particularly unconventional, one of the aims, about the pieces, the evening was intimate, theatrical and in parts even dynamic.

title: Nuclear Plant Shuts Down
description: The Hope Creek nuclear power plant, owned by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, was shut down yesterday after an alarm indicated a problem with one of the plant's three main power transformers.

title: Metro Business; 14 Women's Gyms Are Suddenly Closed
description: The office of the New York Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, is investigating the sudden closing of at least 14 Living Well Lady physical fitness centers this week, which has affected hundreds of customers in the metropolitan area, a spokeswoman for the office said yesterday.

title: Broad Gains Seen In American Health
description: Life expectancy for Americans has reached a record level, while the infant mortality rate has fallen to a new low, the Government reports.

title: For Children
description: 20th Annual New York Renaissance Faire

title: On My Mind; Look, See Us Alive
description: As long as we live, now we will remember the delicious faces of the children and the proud look of the parents who had primped them for the cameras, just so, to show them as good little boys and girls, exceptionally good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWALD, BLANCHE
description: GEWALD - Blanche. Beloved daughter of the late Adolph and Bertha Gewold, loving aunt of Lenore Saltzman of Weeki-Wachee, FL, and Philip Leib of White Plains, N.Y. Longtime member of the First Suczawaer Sick and Benevolent Society. Graveside service today, 10:30 A.M. at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: Bosnian Serb Media Are Threat to Dayton
description: To the Editor:

title: ADOBE SAYS IT EXPECTS EARNINGS TO EXCEED ESTIMATES
description: Shares of Adobe Systems Inc. rose almost 9 percent yesterday after the company said it expected its third-quarter earnings to beat analysts' estimates. Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., cited a rise in product shipments in the last week of the quarter. The company, which makes desktop publishing software, said it expected its earnings, excluding extraordinary expenses, to beat analysts' estimates of 42 cents to 49 cents a share. Adobe shares closed at $44.5625, up $3.5625, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Rowland Proposes Health Plan to Cover 88,000 Uninsured Children
description: Gov. John G. Rowland announced a plan today to provide health insurance to the state's 88,000 uninsured children by setting up a subsidized health care program for working families.

title: When You Wear What You Say
description: SOME fashion statements speak louder than others, and not just in terms of style. These are the days when clothes talk back, incorporating all manner of language -- letters, words and whole sentences -- into their multifarious designs. The amount of wearable verbiage encountered on a crowded street can be overwhelming.

title: Venezuela Sells $4 Billion of 30-Year Bonds
description: Venezuela took advantage of robust demand for high-yielding securities to sell $4 billion of new 30-year bonds, four times more than initially expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, STANLEY M.
description: KAHN-Stanley M. Died September 7, 1997. He is survived by his wife Ethel Gruber Kahn, his daughter Holli Kahn Gersh and husband Edward Gersh, son, Robert Kahn and his wife Susan, daughter Cynthia Kahn Abrams; grandchildren, Heather Greenberg, Harrison and Ashley Kahn, and Maya Abrams. Mr. Kahn built Holly Hills Homes on Long Island. He raised thoroughbred horses in Chatham, New York. He later retired to Boynton Beach, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCHES, ARON
description: BROCHES-Aron. With great sadness we note the death of our father on Tuesday, 9 September. Funeral services to be held at Temple Sinai, Washington, DC, on Monday, 15 September. Alexandra Broches and Paul Broches

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBLIN, HOWARD
description: LUBLIN-Howard. On September 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley; loving father to Mary, Douglas and Candace; adored grandfather to Ben and Michael; dear brother to Sheldon and the late Ada and brother-in-law to Dorothy, Sylvia, Walter, Stanley and Diane; devoted uncle, great uncle, great great uncle and friend. Services Friday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Pillowtex to Acquire Fieldcrest for $400 Million
description: The Pillowtex Corporation, a maker of textiles for the bedroom, said yesterday that it would acquire Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., another maker of household linens, for about $400 million in cash and stock. Including debt assumption, the value of the transaction is more than $700 million.

title: National Testing's Pedigree
description: Though the Senate approved a modified version of President Clinton's plan for national reading and math tests yesterday, the battle isn't over. There is strong opposition in the House of Representatives, which is expected to vote next week on a measure to block Federal money from being used to develop such tests. Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican Representative Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania and other conservative opponents of national testing insist that it would be a Federal intrusion on local control of education.

title: Bulking Up To Join Vets On Rangers
description: Ask Christian Dube about horses and he won't necessarily talk about the race track. He might discuss dinner.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Saint

title: CHRONICLE
description: It will be a madcap night at the theater tomorrow in Ashford, Conn., as PAUL NEWMAN, JOANNE WOODWARD, JULIA ROBERTS, NATHAN LANE, TONY RANDALL and CAROLE KING share a stage. They will perform in a musical by A. E. HOTCHNER that was inspired, somewhat, by ''Cinderella.''

title: Selig Is Said to Be Opposed to Reinstatement of Pete Rose
description: Pete Rose has taken a preliminary step in his desire to return to Major League Baseball's good graces, but two high-ranking baseball officials said yesterday that his effort, if he applies for reinstatement, will fail. One said that Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, would never recommend to the ruling executive council that Rose be reinstated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIPLITZ, GEORGE LEWIS
description: TIPLITZ-George Lewis. On September 9, 1997. Succumbed to death after a heroic battle with pneumonia and Alzheimers at White Plains Medical Center. He leaves his wife of 50 years Doris (nee Wiederschall), one son John Evan, and two grandchildren Lee Evan and Ian David; two cherished sisters Ruth Zelinka and Anita Kirsten, husband Marvin. He also leaves myriad nieces and nephews who adored and were devoted to him. Service Friday, September 12, 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Those who may wish to remember him may send contributions to White Plains Medical Center, White Plains, New York or a charity of your choice.

title: Preparing for Final Round, Democratic Rivals Refuse to Spar
description: Like two boxers preparing for a bout, Ruth W. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton eyed and circled each other yesterday on the steps of a Bronx elementary school with stern looks and grim smiles. But they did not say a word to each other, even as they competed with strong blasts of populist rhetoric before a crowd of parents angry over school overcrowding.

title: Dispute Over Drug Regulation Bill Is Resolved
description: Republicans and Democrats in the Senate agreed today to allow the states to continue to regulate over-the-counter drugs and cosmetics, breaking an impasse that had stalled the final push to complete a three-year effort to modernize the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ENGLER, GEORGE J.
description: ENGLER-George J. Sept. 12, 1910-Jan. 14, 1992. Dearest DreadNaught forever cherished.

title: Retreat From the Indefensible
description: There is nothing like a little sunlight to disinfect a smelly political deal. When forced to act in broad daylight this week, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to rescind a $50 billion tax break that Congress had previously awarded the tobacco industry in stealthy bargaining over tax-cut legislation as part of the balanced-budget deal this summer. The 95-to-3 vote is a measure of the waning clout of the tobacco lobby and a warning that such underhanded deals are apt to backfire once discovered.

title: Art in Review
description: Judy Pfaff

title: I.R.A. Offers Support (of a Sort) for Nonviolence
description: The Irish Republican Army said today that it approved of the pledge by its political wing, Sinn Fein, to adhere to principles of nonviolence when Sinn Fein enters formal peace talks on Ulster next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPI, THOMAS
description: CAMPI-Thomas. On September 11, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife, Christina Walker Campi and loving children Robert, Jeanine, Sally Ann, Thomas, Timothy, Timothy, Theodore and Roberta. Brother of Vincent and Robert Campi. Also survived by six beloved grandchildren. Viewing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St, NYC, Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 AM, St. Bernard's RC Church.

title: Sharpton in Ceremonies Of Unification Church
description: In the last several months, the Rev. Al Sharpton has taken part in at least three religious ceremonies and outreach efforts sponsored by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, renewing his marriage vows based on the tenets of the church and appearing at a holy day ceremony attended by Mr. Moon, according to church officials and publications.

title: Very Laid Back in Texas
description: The three main characters in MTV's engaging new comedy series, ''Austin Stories,'' are in their 20's, scamming their way through life. Laura writes for an alternative weekly newspaper where she tries to hide the fact that she is running up a big phone bill calling a mystery boyfriend in Prague. Chip floats through temporary jobs, and invests in a movie usher's vest so he can try to see ''Speed 2'' for free. In a thrift shop, Howard switches tags so a $5 jacket sells for $1, then tells the clerk: ''This jacket is kind of messed up. You think you could let it go for half price?''

title: Immunex Shares Jump on New Drug Data
description: Shares in the Immunex Corporation rose sharply yesterday after the company, a biotechnology concern based in Seattle, released positive clinical trials data on a new drug for rheumatoid arthritis. Scios Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., which had reported positive data on a drug for congestive heart failure late on Wednesday, also saw its stock gain.

title: Adviser Defends Clinton on Donor Visits
description: Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, told Senate investigators today that a procedural breakdown at the White House, not an uncontrolled hunt for campaign money, enabled a wealthy oil entrepreneur to make four visits to the President despite security warnings of his ''shady and untrustworthy reputation.''

title: World News Briefs; Japan Premier Re-elected As Leader of His Party
description: The governing Liberal Democratic Party re-elected Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to another two-year term as its party leader today, and he immediately installed a new Cabinet intended to help him carry out his plans for a far-reaching restructuring of Japan's economy and society.

title: Irabu Unfazed by Chance He's Not in Playoff Plans
description: Hideki Irabu was in the rarest of moods today, smiling, smoking and waving his arms as he stood in a corner of the visiting clubhouse at Camden Yards and discussed his immediate future with the Yankees. Usually, Irabu is subdued off the field, but he showed a playful side in an interview with a reporter before tonight's game against the Orioles.

title: First National Ad Campaign By Newspaper Association
description: The Newspaper Association of America is using celebrities as disparate as former Presidents and rap singers in its first national advertising campaign, which is centered on literacy and encouraging young people to read newspapers.

title: Rare Triple Wraps Up The Cycle For Olerud
description: John Olerud was asked the first thing to go through his mind last night as he stood on third base after hitting his first triple in three years.

title: Home Video
description: The image is flatter, but, a growing number of videophiles say, distinctly better. Among the 16 films released this week in a new video collection from Universal, three -- ''Psycho,'' ''Out of Africa'' and ''The Deer Hunter'' -- are available for the first time in wide-screen, or letter-box, editions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGENSBURG, NELLIE (NEE CUOMO)
description: REGENSBURG - Nellie (nee Cuomo), on September 10, 1997. Loving wife of the late Charles. Beloved mother of Kenneth and Elizabeth Jacovina. Dear sister of Dominick, Anthony, Giro, Frank, Susie D'Angelo, and Anna Bitalvo. Devoted grandmother of Kenneth Regensburg Jr., Joseph and Sharon Jacovina and proud great grandmother of four. Funeral from Thomas M. Quinn & Son Funeral Home, Inc., 35-20 Broadway, LIC, New York, on Saturday at 8:45 AM. Funeral mass Most Precious Blood RC Church at 9:45 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Ellicott Machine Corporation and its ties to the Democratic Party misidentified the party organization that the company has joined. It is the Democratic Business Council, not the Democratic Leadership Council.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Editorial Notebook; The British Road Not Taken
description: Curiously enough, our century is ending as did the last -- with a great British debate on home rule. Twice, in 1886 and again in 1893, William Ewart Gladstone fought for but failed to establish a separate Irish parliament so that an island with its own Gaelic culture and Roman Catholic faith could manage its own domestic affairs. Few political failures have cast longer and darker shadows on our own time.

title: In Class Wars, the Cheap Seats Win
description: The greatest threat to heavy-metal bands as corporate entities these days is the risk of losing an audience by appealing to fickle, upwardly mobile college students. So class hostility often becomes the binding glue for durability of the bands that are still standing. During Pantera's concert at Roseland on Wednesday night, the class war was being directed from the stage toward the concert hall's V.I.P. section, on the right side of the dance floor.

title: The Spoken Word
description: STUDS TERKEL, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. The author will read from his new collection of interviews, ''My American Century.'' Tomorrow at 5 P.M. Free with museum admission, which is by suggested contribution: $4; $2 for students; $1.50 for the elderly; free for those under 12. Information: (718) 638-5000.

title: MICROSOFT BUYS STAKE IN SPEECH TECHNOLOGY COMPANY
description: The Microsoft Corporation, the software giant, said yesterday that it had acquired a minority stake in Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V. of Belgium for $45 million. Through their alliance, the companies plan to develop products for Microsoft Windows programs that allow computers to recognize spoken words. The shares of Lernout & Hauspie rose $8 a share, or 25 percent, to $39.875. Shares of Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., gained $1.6875, to $136.8125. Lernout & Hauspie, based in Ieper, Belgium, develops speech-recognition technologies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, SYD KRIVIT
description: CHASE-Syd Krivit. Beloved wife of the late Maurice Krivit and the late George Chase. Died with grace and beauty on September 9 at the age of 91. Cherished mother of Dan and Harriet, and loving mother-in-law of Sandy and Charles. Dear sister-in-law of Anne. Treasured grandmother of Irene, Andy, Diane, John, Ken, Esti, Robin, Kara and Bobby. Adored great-grandmother and also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Services ''GuttermanMusicant'' 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ, Friday 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Breast Cancer Coalition, 1707 L Street NW, suite 1060, Washington DC 20036 would be appreciated.

title: Levine of the Met Opera In Talks for Munich Post
description: James Levine, the artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera, said yesterday that he was in discussions with city officials of Munich, Germany, about gradually taking over the podium of the Munich Philharmonic, whose longtime conductor, Sergiu Celibidache, died last year.

title: Heston Asserts Gun Ownership Is Nation's Highest Right
description: Charlton Heston, perhaps the best-known evangelist for the National Rifle Association, delivered a blistering defense of gun ownership today and excoriated news organizations for what he called their gullibility in swallowing anti-gun arguments.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SUBWAY STABBING -- A 14-year-old boy was fatally stabbed in a fight in a Harlem subway station. B3.

title: In the Faces Of the Living, Honor for the Dead
description: AMONG other things, museums provoke questions, and certainly Holocaust museums are more vexing than most. So it seems fair to begin with a few questions about the cumbersomely named, imperfect and finally redeeming Museum of Jewish Heritage -- A Living Memorial to the Holocaust, which was dedicated yesterday at the southern end of Battery Park City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, EVE A.
description: STONE-Eve A. Peacefully on September 10, 1997 at the age of 93. Devoted mother of Barbara Hess and the late Patricia Aks. Loving grandmother of John Newburger, Susan Karchmer, William Straus, Michael Untermeyer and Kathryn Atwood and four great-grandchildren. Services will be private.

title: Cuba Arrests Salvadoran in Hotel Blasts
description: Cuban authorities have arrested a Salvadoran they describe as ''a mercenary agent recruited abroad,'' saying he has confessed to a series of recent bombings of hotels and restaurants in Havana that they called part of a vast ''terrorist plan'' orchestrated by the largest Cuban exile group here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDLER, GLORIA (JINX)
description: BANDLER-Gloria (Jinx). Beloved wife of Alan, devoted mother of Ken, Martha, Joel and Susan. Loving grandmother of Alejandra and Jana. Sister of Jerome Jaffe. Funeral service today, 11:30 AM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Treasuries Extend Losses A Third Day
description: Treasury securities lost ground for the third consecutive day yesterday, with traders and investors concerned that today's reports on producer prices and retail sales would show rapid growth and inflation pressures.

title: Life Among Randy Apes Can Be Tough on a Guy
description: GREAT APES

title: With Gusto, Scots Say 'Yes' to Setting Up Parliament
description: Seven hundred years after the Scottish hero William Wallace routed England's forces at the Battle of Stirling Bridge, Scotland won a modern nationalist fight on Thursday, voting to establish a legislature of its own for the first time since 1707.

title: Sports of The Times; Guy Heroes, Female Heroines
description: MY wife is mourning Diana. I am mourning Richie Ashburn. I am thinking of writing a book about the difference between women and men. The tentative title is, ''Women Are From London; Men Are From Philadelphia.''

title: Current-Account Trade Gap Narrows
description: The nation's deficit on the current account, the broadest measure of international trade, narrowed to $39.03 billion in the second quarter from a revised $39.97 billion in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Safir, Under Council Fire, Defends Police's Conduct
description: Facing three hours of harsh questioning at a City Council hearing yesterday, Police Commissioner Howard Safir was forced to defend his department against accusations of widespread brutality in the wake of charges that a Haitian immigrant had been attacked by officers at a Brooklyn station house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, CHARLES I.
description: HAAS-Charles I., on September 10th, 1997. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Devoted father of Pamela and Jules. Loving father-in-law of Lenore. Cherished grandfather of David and Stephanie. Beloved by all whose lives he touched.

title: Major Shift for Communist China: Big State Industries Will Be Sold
description: China's leaders have agreed to sell off most of the nation's big state-owned industries, and outlined plans today at the opening of a Communist Party congress that is setting the nation's political and economic agenda for the post-Deng era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, LEWIS
description: STEINMAN-Lewis. The Advisory Council to the Housing Part of the Civil Court of the City of New York offers its condolences to the family of Lewis Steinman. As a member of the Council for more than a decade, Lew devoted countless hours to improving the Housing Court as a forum for owners and tenants to resolve their disputes. Lew's energy, intelligence, hard work and sense of humor will be sorely missed. David Rosenberg, Chair

title: Three Schools Picked for Truancy Experiment
description: The Board of Education has chosen three New York City schools for a pilot program that will cut welfare benefits for families whose children skip school repeatedly, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: Informer Admits Lying In Pan Am Crash Case
description: A former drug informer told a Federal court yesterday that he lied when he claimed that a secret drug sting enabled terrorists to evade airport security in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in 1988.

title: Japan's Economy Shrinks by 11.2% Annual Rate
description: Japan's economy saw its sharpest contraction since the oil shock 23 years ago, with economic output in the second quarter falling at a startling annual rate of 11.2 percent, the Government said today.

title: Findings and Recommendations of Army Panel Studying Harassment
description: Following are excerpts of findings, recommendations and conclusions in a report issued today by a panel of senior Army officers and civilian military officials investigating sexual harassment in the United States Army:

title: Crumbling Calcutta Begins to Clean Itself Up
description: Like a lot of Bengalis, Sarmistha Ghose, 23, writes poetry. She also spends a good deal of time with friends at a cavernous coffee house near Calcutta University, the philosophical epicenter of a city that refuses to die.

title: Seven executives at the Deutsch agency find that suddenly they're working for themselves.
description: SEVEN executives at Deutsch Inc. are becoming part owners of that thriving New York agency as part of significant management changes.

title: Man Sentenced In Camby Case
description: The Hartford lawyer accused of extortion in an attempt to become the agent for Marcus Camby received two years of probation today and agreed to perform extensive community service in a plea arrangement.

title: Dainong Group To Be Dissolved
description: The Dainong Group, a textile maker reeling from $1.5 billion in debt, will be dissolved by a court, becoming the latest casualty of South Korea's sagging economy.

title: Stocks Fall for 2d Day on Profit Forecasts
description: Most major stock market indexes fell for a second day yesterday as investors reacted to another round of company announcements of expected earnings shortfalls in the third quarter.

title: Jewel in Franchise's Crown? Its Cable Deal
description: The financial mess wrought by John Spano during his abortive $165 million purchase of the Islanders shone a bright light on an asset more valuable than anything on the team's books, including the fisherman logo: Its cable TV deal.

title: A.C.L.U. to Aid in Bias Case
description: The American Civil Liberties Union agreed on Wednesday to represent a white former Division of Motor Vehicles worker charged with using a racial slur against a black patron.

title: Rohr in Acquisition Talks; The Price Is $847 Million
description: Rohr Inc., a maker of housing compartments for airliner engines, said yesterday that it would be acquired for about $847 million in stock if negotiations with an unidentified company succeeded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, CAROL
description: MOSKOWITZ-Carol. On September 10, 1997. Beloved wife of Herbert. Loving mother of Robert and Marlon. Visiting Saturday 7 to 9PM. Service Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to the American Cancer Society.

title: Schools' Problem Is Teachers, Not Computers; Ostentatious Displays
description: To the Editor:

title: Salmon War in Northwest Spurs Wish for Good Fences
description: It started with a maritime blockade angry Canadian fishermen holding an Alaska ferry at bay for three days. Then came an abrupt move to shut down an American torpedo-testing range in British Columbia, followed by three international lawsuits and a barrage of insults between politicians who usually excel at cross-border backslapping.

title: After 7 Months in Limbo, Ethics Panel Is Back
description: For the first time since Speaker Newt Gingrich was reprimanded and fined, the House ethics committee was once again open for new complaints today. But the panel still lacked most of its members and an agreed-upon set of new operating rules.

title: Japanese Bank Writes Off Debt
description: Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. moved today to shake off its financial problems by writing off 1.3 trillion yen, or $10.9 billion, in bad loans and providing financial assistance to an affiliate, Nippon Trust Bank.

title: Bessie Dance Awards
description: The 13th annual Bessies ceremony will be held on Wednesday at 6 P.M. at the La Guardia Concert Hall at the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts, Amsterdam Avenue at 65th Street in Manhattan. The prizes are given for outstanding achievement in dance and related performance work. Tickets (general seating): $5. Information: (212) 691-6500.

title: Yanks' Underpinning? It's Cone and Girardi
description: You would not expect veteran ballplayers who survive and even thrive in frying pans like Yankee Stadium, Fenway Park and Camden Yards to need security blankets or even crutches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONE, THOMAS E., JR., M.D.
description: CONE-Thomas E., Jr., M.D., of Lincoln, Massachusetts, on September 11. Husband of Barbara (Cross). Father of Thomas E. III of Andover, MA; Dr. Mary C. Barrie of Toronto, Canada and Elizabeth C. Smallridge of Jacksonville, FL. Brother of Daniel G. and George E., both of Somers, NY, and the late Dorothy C. Uhl. Also survived by 6 grandchildren, and six nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass on Monday, September 15, 10:00 AM, in St. Julia Church, 374 Boston Post Road, Weston, Mass. Interment Lincoln Cemetery, Lincoln, MA. Visiting hours Sunday, 7-9 PM, at the Joseph Dee & Son Funeral Home, 27 Bedford Street, Concord, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: About Automobiles
description: Section B is printed today in two parts. Automobile news and advertising begin on page B17.

title: Reaching Out to Grasp the Sacred in the Ordinary
description: They were contemporaries, the two big painters of the Romantic movement in Germany. They tried to make visual the nonvisible, that is, to show the Divine in earthly manifestations. Both viewed the study of Nature -- God's doing -- as a religious observance, and their imagery was deeply spiritual. It isn't too much to say, in fact, that the profound but sometimes twaddlesome Northern mysticism later expressed by Wagner and Nietzsche can be read in the work of Caspar David Friedrich (1774-1840) and Philip Otto Runge (1777-1810).

title: $25 and Under
description: The two partners in Cyclo, a new Vietnamese restaurant in the East Village, both have day jobs at other restaurants. The chef, Hoang Lieng, cooks at Le Refuge, the French country restaurant on the Upper East Side. His partner? Shhhhh. He doesn't want to be identified. It's not that he's a silent partner -- he's an enthusiastic presence in the dining room -- but he's skittish because he's playing hooky from a competitor.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Daytrippers

title: Mining Company Posts 7.8% Profit Increase
description: Rio Tinto P.L.C., the world's largest mining company, reported yesterday that its first-half profit rose 7.8 percent, at the high end of expectations, although it disappointed some investors by leaving its dividend unchanged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ZONA
description: HARRIS-Zona. Wife of the late George Harris. Dearly loved sister of Eva Rosenthal; on August 25th, 1997, in London, England.

title: Art in Review
description: Dana Hoey

title: China to Return Computer It Had Diverted to Military
description: China has agreed to return to the United States a powerful supercomputer that was illegally transferred to a military institute earlier this year, Clinton Administration officials said today. They are trumpeting the case as a rare victory in controlling equipment that can aid in designing nuclear weapons.

title: After 8 Sacks, Jets' Line Looks to Hold Ground Against Patriots
description: The Jets' offensive line was trampled into embarrassment last Sunday against the Buffalo Bills. And now that unit, which averages 305 pounds, is trying to shake the hangover that afflicts players who fail to protect the quarterback.

title: White House Visits Are Called a Mistake
description: President Clinton's national security adviser told Senate investigators it was not an unbridled pursuit of campaign money that opened the door to the White House for a wealthy oil entrepreneur with a ''shady and untrustworthy reputation,'' but rather a procedural breakdown and the absence of a formal vetting process.

title: Robert Pinget, 78, a Master Of the Nouveau Roman, Dies
description: Robert Pinget, a Swiss-born novelist and playwright who first won recognition as a member of the Nouveau Roman literary movement in France in the late 1950's, died in a hospital in Tours on Aug. 25 at the age of 78.

title: Study Finds No Clear Link Of Aid Cap To Birth Rate
description: Researchers looking at the impact of New Jersey's four-year experiment in denying welfare mothers more money when they have another child have found that those mothers had the same birth rate as women who still received the added benefits.

title: Suspect Arrested in Fires At Apartment Complex
description: A resident of the state's largest apartment complex, which has been bedeviled by dozens of suspicious fires, was arrested on arson charges yesterday.

title: Why Must Queen Show Her Grief?; Royal Role Reversal
description: To the Editor:

title: City Opera Opens Season With a Favorite of Verdi's
description: Has the New York City Opera finally found a formula that works? What its new general director, Paul Kellogg, has put on paper is credible. Now to watch its application in the field.

title: Convention Hall Is Planned
description: A 72,000-square-foot convention hall will be built on the beach in Wildwood and will replace a hall that was built in 1971, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday.

title: A BLUNT ALBRIGHT CHALLENGES ISRAEL AND PALESTINIANS
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright acknowledged today that she had made little progress in restarting peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians, and said she had no intention of returning to the Mideast until leaders on both sides make ''the hard decisions'' required to restore mutual confidence.

title: French Concern Bids For Grocery Operator
description: Rallye S.A. made a bid yesterday for Casino Guichard-Perrachon S.A. to shore up its control of France's No. 3 supermarket operator in the face of a hostile $4.6 billion bid from Promodes S.A. The offer from Rallye, which owns 33.2 percent of Casino, involves convertible bonds, cash and other guarantees. If Casino's founding family accepts the offer, it would be impossible for Promodes to gain control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIGAN, ALICE S.
description: MULLIGAN-Alice S. of Massapequa, N.Y. on September 10, 1997. Loving wife of Charles. Devoted mother of Susan and Glen Hudson, Theresa and Donald Gross, Charles H. and Karen Mulligan, William and Susan Mulligan, Vincent, Patricia and Jeremy Langdale, John and Joyce Mulligan, and Timothy. Beloved grandmother of sixteen grandchildren. Reposing at Massapequa Funeral Home Inc., 1050 Park Blvd. (at Clark), Massapequa Park, on Saturday and Sunday 2-4:30 and 79:30 PM. Mass Monday 9:30 AM St., Martin of Tours RC Church, Amityville. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: An Insider Trading Charge at J. P. Morgan
description: Federal authorities arrested a 25-year-old junior analyst at J. P. Morgan & Company yesterday and charged him with insider trading. The Government said he had made illegal profits of more than $350,000 over a two-month period this summer.

title: At I.M.F.'s Urging, Romania Shelves Copter Deal
description: Several years ago, Romania began lining up a $1.4 billion deal intended to please Washington: the purchase of 96 Cobra attack helicopters under an arrangement that would also give the manufacturer, Bell Helicopter Textron, an assembly plant in Eastern Europe.

title: Takeover Deal In Insurance
description: The American General Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy the 55 percent of the Western National Corporation that it did not already own for $1.2 billion.

title: Privatizing City Parks Comes at a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Edgar Kaplan Is Dead at 72; Top Bridge Player and Writer
description: Edgar Kaplan, one of the greatest figures in the world of bridge, died on Sunday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKSTEIN, GERTRUDE S. ARIEL
description: LOOKSTEIN-Gertrude S. Ariel United Israel Institutes deeply mourns the passing of the beloved mother of Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, member of our Board of Governers, devoted friend and supporter. She was a true Woman of Valour, lover of Torah, Israel and Eretz Israel. Heartfelt condolences to Rabbi Haskel and Audrey Lookstein, Dr. Nathalie and Israel Friedman, and to the entire family. Rabbi Shear Yashuv Cohen, Chancellor and Chief Rabbi of Haifa Natalio S. Fridman, President Michael D. Jaspan, Treasurer Ariel American Friends of Midrasha

title: Stolen Sign Was Radioactive
description: When a 16-year-old from Union stole three illuminated exit signs from a demolition site in May, he did not notice labels marked ''radioactive'' until he took one of the signs apart, officials said. A small quantity of tritium gas was released, but the teen-ager was not harmed, officials said.

title: Dizzy Gillespie, the Man and the Music
description: Sometimes concerts break up into small parts of great brilliance, and Jazz at Lincoln Center's ''Dizzy's Big-Band Bop,'' the opening concert of its season and a tribute to the orchestral work of Dizzy Gillespie, did just that. The pianist John Lewis and the vibraphonist Milt Jackson, members of the Modern Jazz Quartet as well as original members of the Dizzy Gillespie big band of the middle 1940's played so quietly and so logically and with so much authority that they threatened to leave everybody behind. Chucho Valdez, the Cuban pianist, constructed extraordinary rhythmic solos that had the audience cheering. And Wynton Marsalis, the artist director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, performed the ballad ''I Remember Clifford''; full of sighs and pearly notes, it was mature.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the growing involvement of evangelical Christians in the human rights movement misstated the opinion of William Schulz, executive director of Amnesty International U.S.A. While Mr. Schulz has written that some human rights advocates are wary about the emergence of evangelical Christians in their movement, he has made it clear that he does not share these doubts and welcomes ''all political and religious stripes.''

title: B-2 Bomber Gets a Bath to Prove That It 'Does Not Melt'
description: In hopes of dispelling the notion that the B-2 bomber cannot fly through a rainstorm, the Air Force decided today to give one a bath before cameras.

title: Black and Cuban-American: Bias in 2 Worlds
description: When black and Hispanic residents in this racially polarized city fought over a vacant City Commission seat, Henry Crespo stepped in and offered himself as the solution.

title: India's Ex-Premier Is To Go to Trial
description: An Indian court cleared the way today for the trial of former Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao and four of his Cabinet colleagues in a four-year-old vote-buying scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABAK, HARRIET N.
description: TABAK-Harriet N., on September 11, 1997, of Malverne, Long Island. Beloved wife of Wallace J. Devoted mother of Jeffrey. Loving mother-in-law of Susan. Dear sister of Kay and dearest sister-inlaw of Frieda. Adored grandmother of Alexis, Elizabeth and Philip. Graveside services on Sunday, 1:30 PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: Johnson Is Expected to Pitch Tonight
description: Randy Johnson is expected to rejoin the Seattle Mariners rotation tonight after missing four starts because of tendinitis in the middle finger on his pitching hand.

title: Lemonade Money Stolen
description: They were selling lemonade to pay for new sneakers, but two young girls were empty-handed after a robber stole $30 from their lemonade stand last Saturday.

title: PRO FOOTBALL ; The Stage Is Set for Keyshawn Johnson
description: Keyshawn Johnson asked the question as if he didn't know the answer.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: NO. 8 COLORADO 1-0

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELSEL, MILTON J., M.D.
description: HELSEL-Milton J., M.D. On September 12, 1997 in Miami, FL. Beloved husband for over fiftyeight years of Selma (Geshwind). Loving father of Eileen Swartz and Meryl (Robert) Meltzer. Adored grandfather of Reesa (Steven) Fischer, Jeffrey (Shayna) Swartz, Neal and Sara Meltzer. Cherished great grandfather of Adam & Brian Fischer and Jessica Swartz. Dear brother of Helen Epstein and the late Irving Helsel. Dr. Helsel practiced medicine in Lynn, MA. for over fifty years. He will be remembered by all who knew him for his great kindness, care and compassion. He was a wonderful man whose inate sense of caring, loyalty, fair play and intellectual curiosity added much to the lives of his family. He wished only the best for those he loved. He leaves us all with a legacy of love and devotion by which he will remain in our hearts and with us for all the days to come. Graveside services Sunday, September 14, at 1:45 PM New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Miami Jewish Home and Hospital at Douglas Gardens, 5200 NE 2nd Ave, Miami, FL 33137.

title: FISHER SCIENTIFIC REACHES REVISED DEAL WITH LEE
description: The Thomas H. Lee Companies yesterday cut its offer for Fisher Scientific International Inc. to $48.25 a share, from $51, because the scientific instruments maker's profit and market share had diminished as a result of the strike at United Parcel Service of America Inc. Fisher Scientific said it would accept the reduced offer, which values its shares at about $980 million. Lee thwarted an offer by the Bass family of Texas, which had forced Fisher to seek a buyer sooner than it would have liked. Fisher, based in Hampton, N.H., would not say how much the U.P.S. affected it. Fisher's shares fell $2.4375, to $47.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've created a rule for myself: I will come back to the region whenever the leaders have made the hard decisions and I can make a difference. But I am not going to come back here just to tread water.''

title: PALFED DISCLOSES MERGER TALKS WITH UNNAMED PARTNER
description: Palfed Inc. said yesterday that it was in merger discussions. Its management said Palfed, a bank holding company based in Aiken, S.C., was ''making this announcement as a result of unusual trading activity in its common stock.'' Palfed's stock rose $1.25, to $21.50, giving the company a market capitalization of almost $114 million. Management at Palfed, which had $664.9 million in assets and $562.2 million in deposits as of June, rejected a resolution made in April by shareholders to sell the company. Palfed is a South Carolina corporation whose principal subsidiary, Palmetto Federal Savings Bank of South Carolina, operates 22 banking and 7 mortgage lending offices in South Carolina and a mortgage lending office in Georgia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDMAN, EDNA KAUFMANN
description: ERDMAN-Edna Kaufmann. Died peacefully on September 11, 1997, Devoted wife of Herbert J. Erdman. Loving mother of John H. and Doris S. Erdman, and the late William H. Erdman. Cherished grandmother of John H. Jr, Robert W, Michael F., Peter N., Andrew H, and H. James. Adored great-grandmother of Anne L., Elizabeth L., and John H. III. Devoted sister-in-law of Evelyn L. Kaufmann and sister of the late Frederick W. Kaufmann Jr. Funeral service Monday, September 15, at 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to: Henry Kaufmann Camp Grounds, P.O. Box 175, Pearl River, N.Y. 10965, or the charity of your choice.

title: Eleanor Pepper, 93, a Consultant And a Professor in Interior Design
description: Eleanor Pepper, a former chairwoman of Pratt Institute's department of interior design who was a longtime design consultant and decorated an early version of the United Nations Security Council meeting room, died on Sunday at her apartment in the Carnegie Hill section of Manhattan. She was 93.

title: Gore Is Facing Toughest Point Of His Career
description: The storm over his campaign finance practices has thrust Al Gore into what his advisers concede is by far the most perilous moment of his political career, leaving his aides scrambling to contain the damage.

title: 3 Lawyers Win Races to Lead The Democrats
description: Three lawyers -- two of whom spent their careers providing legal services to the poor -- and a housing court judge won Democratic primary races on Tuesday for civil court judgeships in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. All four of the Democratic primary winners face challengers in the November election.

title: Sale of Thermo King Is Said to Be Close
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is close to selling its Thermo King refrigeration unit for about $2.5 billion, people associated with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: 2-Year-Old Shot in Robbery at Bronx Store
description: A 2-year old Bronx boy sleeping in the back of his uncle's store was shot in the shoulder by robbers yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Westinghouse Said to Be Close To Sale of Thermo King Unit
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is close to selling its Thermo King refrigeration unit for about $2.5 billion, people associated with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Camille Henry, 64, Small but Skillful Ranger
description: Camille Henry, whose frail physical stature and artistry with a stick made him one of New York's most beloved hockey players in the 1950's and 60's, died in Quebec on Thursday. He was 64.

title: Opening the Doors on Family Court's Secrets
description: At 9:30 on Monday morning Judge Philip C. Segal, suddenly a public figure, sat in his courtroom in Family Court in Brooklyn, a converted office roughly the size of a bedroom.

title: Retail Sales and Producer Prices Up, but Modestly
description: Retail sales rose in August, and producer prices increased for the first time this year. But the reports were generally in line with expectations and did little to alter perceptions that the economy continued to advance with prices in check.

title: Police Say Union Leader At Lab Made Death Threat
description: A union leader at the Brookhaven National Laboratory has been charged with threatening to kill the leader of a conservation group that has pressed for the closing of the lab's nuclear reactor.

title: About New York; Simple Dress In Spotlight, Triumphantly
description: THE sole creation from the House of Frania Blum is strikingly simple. In 1945, Mrs. Blum sewed a blue and white peasant dress with puffed sleeves, a cinched waist and the slightly rough look of something stitched by halting hands. It has no price tag, because it is priceless.

title: On China Intelligence Data, Senators See Yin and Yang
description: Why do Republican and Democratic senators who have received the same classified intelligence briefings about whether the Chinese Government influenced American elections last year disagree so sharply about the same information they all have heard?

title: Russian-Chechen Agreement on Rebuilding a Major Oil Pipeline Is Beginning to Unravel
description: When Russian leaders and the government of the secessionist republic of Chechnya announced an agreement on Tuesday to rebuild a key oil pipeline that runs through the territory of both sides, it looked as if they had begun to subordinate their old hatred to the common pursuit of cash.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: FIELDS'S POLITICAL REACH

title: A Long, Winding Road To Loss
description: Bobby Valentine stared straight ahead in his office shortly after the Mets' 15-inning, 3-2 loss to Montreal last night, rapidly tapping a blue felt pen on his desk. In his mind's eye, he might have been replaying the 10th inning, or the 11th, or any of the many chances the Mets had to win the game and creep ever closer to Florida in the wild card standing.

title: China's Leader Announces Sell-Off of State Enterprises
description: President Jiang Zemin opened China's 15th Communist Party Congress today by embracing a program of bold economic reform for the nation's ailing state-owned industries while deferring any significant change in the nation's political system.

title: Gun Control Makes Economic Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARES OF WATERS RISE ON NEWS IT WILL BUY MICROMASS
description: Shares of the Waters Corporation soared nearly 19 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of analytical instruments, agreed late Thursday to buy Micromass Ltd. for $160 million in cash and $10 million in stock plus the assumption of $10 million in Micromass debt. Shares of Waters, which is based in Milford, Mass., rose $6.4375, to $40.4375. The sellers are Schroder Ventures, the venture capital arm of the London investment bank Schroders P.L.C., and the Micromass management. Waters makes liquid chromatography instruments, while Micromass, of Manchester, England, makes mass spectrometers, another type of instrument.

title: Ronald Rosenfeld, 65, Part of Advertising's 1960's-70's Revolution
description: Ronald M. Rosenfeld, an important figure in the ''creative revolution'' that swept the advertising industry in the 1960's and 1970's, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital from complications of a stroke he suffered in 1991. He was 65.

title: Beijing's Possessive Leadership Team
description: JIANG ZEMIN, 71, President and General Secretary of the Communist Party

title: Carl Franz Hinshaw Jr., 75, Florida Restaurateur
description: Carl Franz Hinshaw Jr., a self-taught chef who transformed Chalet Suzanne of Lake Wales, Fla., from a small but well-known family-run bistro into a critically acclaimed restaurant, died on Sept. 4 at his home near the restaurant just north of here. He was 75.

title: Times Mirror's Chief Replaces Top Publisher
description: Mark H. Willes, chairman, chief executive and president of the Times Mirror Company, nailed another title to his office door yesterday with the announcement that he would replace Richard T. Schlosberg 3d as publisher of the company's flagship newspaper, The Los Angeles Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISH, ELI
description: FISH-Eli. We note with sorrow the passing of a highly respected professsional. As Director of the Hospital's Pharmacy for more than thirty years, he presided over a department that evolved to serve the needs of North Shore as it grew in size and complexity. He was a good friend to many and will be truly missed. Our sincere condolences are extended to his family. John S.T. Gallagher President and CEO and the Physicians and Employees of North Shore University Hospital

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASINDORF, BLANCHE
description: KASINDORF-Blanche. Long time principal of P.S. 8. Beloved Aunt of Steven and Larry. Great-Aunt of Dana and Allison. Services held at Riverside Chapel, Coney Island Avenue and Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, NY. Sunday at 11:30AM.

title: Religion Journal ; Why a Church's Leader Survived
description: With the Rev. Henry J. Lyons facing state and Federal investigations into whether he financially misused his office, as well as accusations of adultery, it might have seemed unlikely that he would survive a vote of confidence as president of the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A., Inc.

title: After 2 Years of Secrecy, Library Donor Is Named
description: For two years it has been among the best-kept secrets in New York philanthropy. Speculation abounded, but only two people at the New York Public Library knew the identity of the donor who in 1995 pledged $15 million -- the largest single gift in the institution's history -- to renovate the magnificent but dilapidated Main Reading Room, the heart of the library.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW ; Seeing Money as the Ruler, More Despotic Than Kind
description: The United States has a new social disease, or maybe it's just an old one with a new name. As introduced on Monday, ''Affluenza'' is ''an unhappy condition of overload, debt, anxiety and waste resulting from the dogged pursuit of more.'' Among the symptoms collected by doctors, psychologists, environmentalists, poll experts, therapists and authors of books with titles like ''Marketing Madness'' and ''Your Money or Your Life'' are swollen expectations, shopping fever, chronic stress and fractured families.

title: Xochimilco Journal; Zapatista Caravan: Road Test for Peaceful Politics
description: A dancer naked to the waist with a towering headdress of indigo peacock feathers blew a call on a conch shell and intoned an ancient Aztec blessing over the stage erected in a pine-shaded park.

title: Marriage Tax and G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNER, JOSEPH
description: ARNER-Joseph on September 10, 1997 of Great Neck, NY. Beloved friend of Marta Bilek. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset on Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday 9:45 AM, at St. Aloysius RC Church, Great Neck with interment to follow in All Saints Cemetery, Great Neck, NY.

title: Liberties; Nothing From Nothing
description: Poor Jesse Helms was feeling misunderstood.

title: Life Insurer, In Comeback, Is Set for Sale
description: Six years after the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company became the largest American insurance company ever to collapse, the company has been revived and is expected to announce on Monday that it is for sale.

title: Tennessee Judge, Convicted of Sexual Assault, Becomes a Fugitive
description: A Tennessee judge accused of sexual assault, who was freed from prison while appealing his conviction, is now a fugitive, pleading by mail to be spared what he called a virtual death sentence.

title: Yankees Tearing Up Orioles' House
description: Nothing irritates the Orioles and their executives more than when gorgeous Camden Yards turns into Yankee Stadium South. It confounds and confuses them. It befuddles and baffles them. Basically, it ticks them off when their home turns into a home away from home for the dreaded Yankees. They were ticked tonight.

title: HARNISCHFEGER TO BUY BACK 10 MILLION SHARES
description: Harnischfeger Industries, which three months ago failed in a hostile bid for Giddings & Lewis Inc., said yesterday that it would buy back as much as 21 percent of its shares and might sell a heavy machinery unit. The machinery maker plans to repurchase 10 million shares, valued at $416 million based on the average share price over the last three months. Harnischfeger, which is based in Brookfield, Wis., also said it might sell its P & H Material Handling unit, which makes cranes and hoists, to help finance the buyback. The Giddings & Lewis purchase was aimed at lifting earnings at its P & H Material Handling unit. Harnischfeger shares rose $3.3125 each, to $42.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUEHLER, SEYMOUR J.
description: BUEHLER-Seymour J. On September 11, 1997. Devoted and beloved husband of Joan. Adoring and proud father of Robert and Susan Buehler. Cherished brother of Joan and Howard Eisenstein. Dear uncle of Susan and Jon Kerz, and Beth and Jim Eisenstein. Service Sunday, 11:30 AM. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Sy fought a heroic battle. A special man of utmost integrity, he will be missed by his family and many friends. Contributions in his memory may be made to Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, 1440 York Ave, P4, NY NY 10021.

title: There She Is, Just In Time
description: The melancholy of fame is much in the news these days, and the heavens darken wherever pundits gather to talk about the dire business of celebrity.

title: Balanchine Purity in a Harlem Mode
description: George Balanchine was the artistic godfather to Dance Theater of Harlem, and on Thursday night the company paid energetic tribute to him with three of his landmark ballets, ''Serenade,'' ''The Prodigal Son'' and ''The Four Temperaments.''

title: A Rivalry Good to Last Drop (Or Catch)
description: A rivalry was created in an instant. All it took was one pass toward the twilight above Michigan Stadium three years ago this month, one last gasp that would surely fall to the grass and complete a Michigan victory over Colorado. One pass from Kordell Stewart that traveled a different path -- redirected by Blake Anderson into the hands of Michael Westbrook for a game-winning 64-yard touchdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, BERNARD
description: GOULD-Bernard. On September 11, 1997, of White Plains, New York. Husband of the late Sonya Gould, father of Steven Gould, Linda Abtalion, Karen Ziaman, and Barbara Boyley. Brother of Victor and Edward Gould, grandfather of six grandchildren. The family will receive friends Saturday 7-9 P.M. at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye. Interment service Sun., 3PM, the Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Red Cross, Westchester County Chapter, 106 N. Broadway, White Plains, New York 10503, appreciated.

title: Rangers' Tatis Meets Father
description: Years of searching for his father ended happily yesterday for Fernando Tatis, the Texas Rangers' rookie third baseman. His father, Fernando Sr., flew to Texas and saw his 22-year-old son for the first time since he was 3 or 4 years old.

title: In Mexico, Gephardt Faults Trade Pact
description: Stepping over drainage ditches ripe with sewage, past ramshackle homes patched together with cardboard and pallets, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader north of the border, saw little more today than missed opportunities all around him.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EYER, JAMES A.
description: EYER-James A. Age 64 years, on Friday, September 12, 1997. Husband of Patricia. He was reporter for NBC and ABC news in NYC retiring from NBC in 1988.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBLES, IDA T.
description: ROBLES-Ida T., on Sept 11, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Daniel Robles. Cherished sister of Riva T. Holtz, adored aunt. Services were held on Friday, September 12.

title: The Harassment of Female Troops
description: The nation and the Army have known for some time that the service has a severe problem with sexual threats against women in the ranks. But its new investigation found sexual harassment to be much more pervasive than previously acknowledged, ''crossing gender, rank and racial lines.'' An even more important finding was that the problem existed because senior commanders were not following the Army's doctrinal commitment to the integration of women. The report's condemnation of ''passive leadership'' as a core problem is its most noteworthy feature and one that offers some hope for reform.

title: Resume Aside, Morrison Is Long Shot With Devils
description: Brendan Shanahan was the last rookie to join the Devils with the same gaudy offensive credentials as Brendan Morrison. That was a decade ago. Shanahan became a regular almost immediately and became an All-Star, but these days the Devils are a tough team to crack for a rookie, especially a center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ALICE
description: WEISS-Alice, on September 11, 1997, Beloved wife of the late Rudolph. Loving aunt of Carol and Charles, great aunt of Jason, John, Jim, Kim and Allison. Service on Sunday, 1:30PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Police Say Slain Teen-Ager Was Trying to Aid a Friend
description: A high school student who was fatally stabbed in a Manhattan subway station Thursday afternoon was killed while trying to defend a friend from a group of rival teen-agers, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, DAVID
description: LEVITT-David. After a courageous stuggle for health, beloved husband for 60 years of Norma Uttal Levitt and loving father of Sally Steinberg, Nancy Hoffman and Andrew Levitt. Devoted grandfather to Noah M. and Jonah A. Steinberg, Rebecca HoffmanGreenwald, Mia and Elizabeth Levitt. Also mourned by son-in-law Peter Greenwald, daughter-in-law Peggy Whalen-Levitt and sister Dorothy Beskind and her family. Services at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck, NY at 1:00 PM Sunday. Contributions to be made to Temple Beth-El or The American Cancer Society.

title: Vicious Reminder of 70's Atrocities in Argentina
description: A former Argentine Navy captain who broke a military code of silence two years ago when he admitted publicly to atrocities said today that four attackers slashed his face on Thursday night and warned him to stop speaking with journalists about crimes by the repressive military Government of the 1970's.

title: 2 Arrested in Shooting Of Officer in Traffic Jam
description: Brooklyn detectives have arrested two men believed to be responsible for last week's shooting of an off-duty police officer during a traffic dispute in Crown Heights.

title: 81.99 Rebound in Blue Chips Recoups Part of Week's Loss
description: The stock market regained some of the ground it lost in the previous two trading sessions, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 1 percent yesterday. Economic reports indicating that growth remained moderate and inflation tame in August tempered some investor concerns about possible third-quarter earnings disappointments.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Craft's Orbit Around Mars Is Near-Perfect
description: In navigating space, flight controllers always strive for perfection, of course, but when they achieve it -- or come too close to quibble -- they seem as astonished as anyone else. And they are basking in their astonishment over the Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, MORRIS
description: ZUCKERMAN-Morris. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute mourns the passing of Morris Zuckerman, beloved father of Joseph D. Zuckerman, Chairman of the Departments of Orthopaedic Surgery of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute and NYU Medical Center. Morris Zuckerman will always be remembered as a committed friend of HJD and generous benefactor of our major initiatives. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Lee, sons Nathan, Howard and Joseph, grandchildren and to the entire family. William A. Perlmuth, Chairman of the Board Victor H. Frankel, M.D., President John N. Kastanis, FACHE, Chief Executive Officer

title: Bonds Break Out of Slump After Tame Data
description: Bond prices rallied strongly yesterday, the first gain in four days, after tame reports on producer prices and retail sales for August suggested that the Federal Reserve might not need to raise interest rates this month to slow the economy.

title: San Antonio Cuts Subsidies For the Arts by 15 Percent
description: In a unanimous vote, San Antonio's city council decided Thursday night to reduce the amount it spends on the arts by about 15 percent and cut off all city grants to the Esperanza Peace and Justice Center, a gay and lesbian arts organization whose programs provoked criticism.

title: Testaverde's Long Trip: Hero to Failure to Hero
description: He will be 34 years old before the season ends, but an elder status among National Football League quarterbacks only begins to attest to the things Vinny Testaverde has seen and experienced in his 11 years in the league.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, STELLA JOLLES
description: REICHMAN-Stella Jolles. Died September 9 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Henry Reichman. Loving mother of the late Thomas and Steven, grandmother of Jamie. Memorial service Wednesday, October 1, Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 Street at 2PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JITNEY-JUNGLE STORES OF AMERICA INC., Jackson, Miss., a supermarket chain company, has received United States antitrust approval to buy its rival Delchamps Inc. by promising to sell 10 grocery stores in Mississippi and Florida. Jitney-Jungle has agreed to sell the 10 stores to Supervalu Holdings Inc., Prairie, Minn., for an undisclosed sum.

title: New Site for Stadium Planned
description: Newark and Essex County officials announced yesterday that they would recommend that a $22 million minor-league baseball stadium proposed for Riverbank Park be built instead on the east side of Broad Street, along the northern end of the business district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALL, PHYLLIS S.
description: THALL-Phyllis S. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend, after a long illness. Pre-deceased by her dear husband Arnold. She will be missed by friends and family alike. Funeral service to be held Sunday, September 14 at 11:30 AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Hospice Care Network or Gay Men's Health Crisis.

title: Mercy for Disabled Children
description: Under the old law, children could qualify for disability payments if they suffered from a single extreme disability, like an I.Q. below 60, or from a combination of less extreme problems, like an I.Q. in the 60's along with cerebral palsy, rendering the child incapable of functioning like other children of the same age. Congress concluded that these functional standards were lax and, despite Government studies to the contrary, many critics also believed the standards were subject to fraud and abuse.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the effects of drugs found in the blood of the driver in the accident that killed the Princess of Wales misspelled the name of a tranquilizer similar to one drug. It is risperidone, not resperidone.

title: Price of a Free Ride? Some on S.I. Wonder; As Ferry Troubles Multiply, Cries of 'I Told You So' Resound
description: The incident last month in which a ferry lost power mid-crossing and had to limp back to Staten Island was a fluke.

title: Why Must Queen Show Her Grief?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNTSEN, CARL A., JR., M.D.
description: BERNTSEN-Carl A., Jr., M.D. The Society of Alumni of Bellevue Hospital records with profound sorrow the death of its Honored Member and Past President. David S. Weiss, M.D., President Ariel Distenfeld, M.D., Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, ARTHUR CAMPSEN
description: MORGAN-Arthur Campsen, on September 12th, 1997. Husband of Ruby Anderson Morgan. Father of Rebecca Cedwyn and Bruce Morgan and Meredith Rossborough. title: Child Pornography Charge
description: An executive of the Avon Products Corporation was charged yesterday with receiving and distributing child pornography over the Internet, officials said.

title: Nazi Victims Also Suffer Delayed Stress Disorder
description: To the Editor:

title: In Great Pomp, Calcutta Buries A Modest Nun
description: Mother Teresa made her last journey this morning through the streets of the city to which she gave her life for more than six decades.

title: Living on the Water, Looking Out for Fire
description: Waterfront is the most prized real estate on Long Island, and coastal home sites don't get much better than Edward and Marjorie Sheehan's.

title: GREENMARINE ACQUIRES 91% OF OUTBOARD MARINE
description: Greenmarine Holdings L.L.C. said yesterday that it had closed its tender offer for the Outboard Marine Corporation after acquiring 91 percent of the company. Greenmarine is an investor group led by Greenway Partners, a New York investment firm, that includes affiliates of Soros Management Fund L.L.C. Greenmarine said 16.5 million Outboard Marine shares had been tendered at $18 a share, for a total of about $327 million. Greenmarine's success sank a rival bid of $16 a share for Outboard Marine from the Detroit Diesel Corporation. Outboard Marine, based in Waukegan, Ill., makes two leading outboard engine brands, Evinrude and Johnson.

title: Young Arabs Pour Out Complaints, But Only After Albright Leaves
description: After Madeleine K. Albright concluded her brief visit to the Friends School here today and left in a blaze of sirens and guards, the Palestinian high school students pounced on reporters and teachers to pour out the frustrations they had hoped to share with the American Secretary of State.

title: Who Should Define HDTV?
description: Congress ordered the Federal Communications Commission to give broadcasters space on the nation's airwaves that is worth billions of dollars. This is the spectrum that could be used for digital television, a new medium for broadcasting video, data or even radio.

title: Don't Fear Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana's Death Resonates With Women in Therapy
description: It is a truism of psychotherapy that there are never just two people in the treatment room. The patient, in a manner of speaking, is joined in that snug chamber by a cast of significant others: an overbearing mother, a distant father, a faithless husband, a needy child, a difficult boss, to name a few.

title: Gun Control Makes Economic Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Fields Poised to Extend Political Reach
description: Inside a glossy brochure promoting C. Virginia Fields's candidacy for Manhattan borough president is a black-and-white photograph of her clasping the raised hands of two frequent political antagonists, Edward I. Koch (on her right) and David N. Dinkins (on her left). The caption under the photo delivers the punch line: ''Who else could bring them together?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, CAROL
description: MOSKOWITZ-Carol. On September 10, 1997. Beloved wife of Herbert. Loving mother of Robert and Marlon. Visiting Saturday 7 to 9PM. Service Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to the American Cancer Society.

title: Down but Not Out, Clearly Down Under; Lean Times at an Australian Mainstay
description: Write-offs of more than $1 billion over the last two years. Sagging earnings and stockholder equity. Huge cost overruns at a much heralded iron ore processing plant here in mineral-rich Western Australia and a troubled copper investment in the United States. Three resignations of senior executives. And a chairman who acknowledges he is ''ashamed'' and ''a bit flabbergasted'' by it all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDBERG, MINDEL RUTH, M.D.
description: ERDBERG-Mindel Ruth, M.D. Born Sept. 20, 1916, died Sept. 11, 1997. Adored mother of Beverly (Stephen) Vosko, cherished grandmother of Jennifer and Michelle. Distinguished psychiatrist. Services Sunday 10:30AM, Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Shiva following, Sheraton Manhattan, 55th and 7th.

title: Chicago Seat Record Price
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that a seat giving the owner the right to trade financial contracts sold for a record $140,000. The previous high price for a seat on the exchange's Index, Debt and Energy Market division was $135,000 on Wednesday. Prices have more than doubled since Dow Jones announced in June that it would license its industrial average to be used in futures and options trading.

title: Shell to Acquire Rest Of Chemical Venture
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies agreed yesterday to acquire the remaining 50 percent of its Montell B.V. petrochemical venture from Montedison S.p.A. of Italy for 3.59 trillion lire, or $2 billion. Montell is the largest producer of polypropylene in North America, with capacity of 2.7 billion pounds a year, or 19 percent of the market. Polypropylene is used in consumer products.

title: De La Hoya Intends to Cut Camacho Short
description: Only a sedative can shut up Hector (Macho) Camacho, but give Oscar De La Hoya time, or perhaps three rounds, Saturday night.

title: Keeping a Stageful of Stars to a Single Beat
description: The drummer Elvin Jones, who was the implacable rumble suffusing the John Coltrane Quartet, has been celebrating his 70th birthday at the Blue Note this week. In the opening set on Tuesday, with a front line full of guests, the musicians reveled in simple, profound minor-key dirges taken from the post-1960 Coltrane school of hypnotism.

title: A Cat Tips His Hat
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the front page of front-page article in The Metro Section yesterday about the New York City mayoral race misstated the total of illegal campaign contributions that the re-election campaign of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been accused of accepting. As noted in a related article in the section, it was more than $300,000, not more than $400,000.

title: After a Trip, Woman Finds Home in Ruins
description: Like many people on vacation, Marilyn Charleston worried about burglars. But she was dumbstruck when she returned on Wednesday to Old Bridge, N.J., to find her house had been looted and gutted by a fire.

title: Islander Sale, Part 2: Coyotes Co-owner Sets Deal for Team
description: Two months after the sale of the Islanders to John Spano fell apart, embarrassing the Islanders and the National Hockey League, the team announced today that John O. Pickett had agreed in principle to sell his majority interest to Steven M. Gluckstern, the co-owner of the Phoenix Coyotes, and three partners.

title: The Benefits of Being Flexible
description: The recent decision by the Clinton Administration not to deport nine veterans of the Irish Republican Army reveals the difference between decrying terrorism and dealing with terrorism.

title: Still Waiting for the Football Thunderbolt
description: Stop the presses; it seems that the National Football League has discovered women. Hoping to increase its audience, the league has come up with a ''Women's Initiative'' to try to figure out how to make football more appealing to those of us with XX chromosomes.

title: With Iron Gavel, Helms Rejects Vote on Weld
description: Gaveling his colleagues to silence, Senator Jesse Helms asserted his power as a committee chairman today and, with an iron hand and a snarl, ran roughshod over the nomination of William F. Weld to be Ambassador to Mexico.

title: Corrections
description: The mutual fund tables in Business Day yesterday included erroneous data supplied by Morningstar Inc. showing the net asset values of 170 funds for Wednesday, rather than Thursday. Today's tables reflect changes from the actual net asset values for Thursday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rebound Strongly On Economic Reports

title: N.J. Wetland Flourishes Alongside Development
description: To the Editor:

title: Bus Fares May Increase
description: Bus fares could rise by up to 4 percent starting Jan. 1 for about 235,000 daily passengers on 4,000 private buses that handle routes for New Jersey Transit, an agency spokesman announced this week.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Bridge
description: All bridge players must from time to time explain to their partners the rationale for an action that turned out disastrously. One of the most difficult, requiring a maximum level of groveling, concerns the penalty double of a contract that was due to fail but causes an opponent to retreat to a contract that succeeds. It is even worse when information given away by the double was crucial.

title: Whodunit and Who Wunit: The Plot Quickens
description: Whodunit? William Evermore, Franklin Boyce or Uncle James Polk? Or Miss Tasso Polk herself? Or Colonel Mustard? Or was it John Updike?

title: Credit Suisse to Acquire 25% Stake in Insurer
description: The Swiss financier Martin Ebner said yesterday that he would accept Credit Suisse's stock offer for his 25 percent stake in the Winterthur Insurance Company, giving Mr. Ebner a large stake in a third big Swiss bank. Mr. Ebner, Winterthur's biggest shareholder and the man who initiated the bid from Credit Suisse, will own 7 percent of Credit Suisse after selling his Winterthur stake.

title: Hevesi Rejects Any Support For Sharpton
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, one of New York City's most influential Democrats, said yesterday that he would not support the Rev. Al Sharpton if he won the mayoral nomination. Mr. Hevesi cited what he described as Mr. Sharpton's ''willingness to tolerate the bigotry'' of Louis Farrakhan and a City University professor who made racist and anti-Semitic remarks.

title: Edward Scripps, 88, Who Built A Chain of Mostly Small Papers
description: Edward Wyllis Scripps, a newspaper executive and philanthropist who built a publishing company independent of his family's newspaper empire, died on Sept. 4 at his farm in Charlottesville, Va. He was 88.

title: Coffee Prices Drop as Supplies Seem Ample
description: Coffee prices plunged more than 8 percent yesterday as supplies have flooded into exchange warehouses, a sign that roasters are well stocked at the start of the season of peak demand.

title: Man in the News; 'America's Doctor' David Satcher
description: The defining moment in Dr. David Satcher's life occurred when he was 2. It was then, as a toddler near death with whooping cough, that he first encountered the powerful lessons of race, community, and disease prevention that have shaped his scientific career.

title: Mayor Says Campaign Got $290,000 Illegally
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani conceded yesterday that his re-election campaign had made a mistake in accepting $290,000 in illegal contributions that it has now promised to return. He said the error occurred because officials of his campaign had misunderstood an obscure campaign finance regulation.

title: SIMON DEBARTOLO RAISES RETAIL PROPERTY TRUST BID
description: Simon DeBartolo Group Inc. of Indianapolis, the largest real estate company in the United States, raised its tender offer for the closely held shopping mall owner Retail Property Trust to $19.375 a share, or about $698 million, about $72 million more than its previous offer of $17.50 a share. Retail Property's independent trustees recommended that the company's shareholders, made up of pension funds, accept the revised offer. The bid, if successful, would thwart a plan by Retail Property's manager, O'Connor Group, to merge it with two other shopping mall developers: the developer Richard Jacobs and another owned by New England Development of Boston.

title: Deadlock in the Middle East
description: The Israeli-Palestinian peace effort has fallen into a coma, and the prospects for recovery anytime soon are bleak. That is the depressing reality left by Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's failure this week to move Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat toward renewed dialogue. Ms. Albright did what she could on her brief trip, speaking bluntly of the steps each side must take to restore confidence in the peace effort. Neither leader was in the mood to listen, much less agree. She departed Israel yesterday with the terse announcement that she had no intention of returning until the two sides were prepared to recommit themselves to settling their differences.

title: Boarding School Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Cutbacks Being Planned At Health Unit Of Prudential
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America plans to squeeze $250 million to $500 million in annual savings from the company's big, money-losing health insurance unit, Prudential executives said yesterday. They said the savings would be made by cutting layers of managers and tightening controls on medical services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, DR. STANLEY (STEVE) J.
description: BRODY-Dr. Stanley (Steve) J., on Sept. 11, 1997 in La Jolla, CA. He was 79. Dr. Brody was Prof. Emeritus of Rehabilitation Medicine in Psychiatry, Univ. of Pennsylvania and of the Wharton School of Business. He authored first texts on rehabilitation and the aged. Among his awards, Dr. Brody was recipient of the Key and Donald P. Kent Awards for Excellence in Gerontology. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Elaine, daughter Laurel Karpman of Phoenix, son Peter of San Diego and four granddaughters. Donations: The Stanley J. Brody Memorial Fund The Gerontological Society of America, 1275 K St NW Suite 350, Washington, DC 20005-4006.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
