title: Mambo Kings and Queens
description: Near the end of ''Yo Soy del Son a la Salsa,'' a sweeping history of popular Caribbean dance music, the great Afro-Cuban singer Celia Cruz is asked to define ''salsa,'' the term under which this music is generally lumped. Ms. Cruz replies that to her, salsa is ''a marketing word, a myth I don't think exists.'' But she adds that whatever it is, it is mostly based on Cuban rhythms.

title: Sports of The Times; In Boston, A Mixed Bag Of Emotions
description: THE question seemed simple enough: ''Is this the way to Foxboro?'' But the toll-booth attendant at the Callahan Tunnel seemed puzzled.

title: Cone Workout Prompts Growing Concern
description: With each day of uncertainty about David Cone's future, the possibility that Cone will not pitch for the Yankees again this season seems to grow.

description: A Bomber Under Attack

title: The Return of the Master Builder
description: It was only four and a half years ago, at one of those huge Bill Parcells-related news conferences at some turning point in his career. He was the newly anointed commander in chief of the perpetually troubled New England Patriots' franchise.

title: Donna Lowton, Thomas Ecton
description: Donna Faye Lowton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry D. Lowton of Virginia Beach, Va., was married there yesterday to Thomas Lucian Ecton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Ecton of Cabin John, Md. The Rev. W. Jerry Holcomb performed the ceremony at King's Grant Baptist Church.

title: A Return to Earth, and the Chase Begins
description: ALIENS, angels and fugitives from justice wouldn't seem to have much in common, but for television viewers, these three constituencies share something important: they're on the run, or at least on the road, in a number of classic and current series.

title: Morocco, the Bitter and the Sweet
description: In Rabat there was dust on the tarmac, dust on the leaves, dust on the burned grass, but the dry heat was pleasurable. The sky was overcast. There was to be rain later in the evening. As soon as the luggage came off the plane it was surrounded by poor, hungry-looking porters. When I went to pick up my bags, an old, gaunt porter protested. I showed him that I hadn't as yet acquired any Moroccan money. He responded with a gesture more eloquent than words. Thin, delicate fingers plucked an offering to his mouth. He needed to eat.

title: A Chance to Discover
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Labyrinth For Phone Customers
description: YOU may think you're seeing things when your phone bill shows that calls to a friend in a neighboring town are more expensive than calls to your sister on the other coast.

title: Reveille In New York
description: The language of New York early in the morning is Spanish. Chinese runs a close second. That is not to say you can't get by nicely in other languages, even English. But at the ungodly hour of 5:30 A.M., the people who keep the city moving tend to be its most recent arrivals, hard-working immigrants without many alternatives.

title: Lucinda Williams Is in Pain
description: Lucinda Williams slides her black sweater off her shoulder blades. Closing her eyes, she wraps it like a feather boa across her back, grips herself in a gentle embrace and, as her backup band kicks off, fills the room with her extraordinary voice -- a raw, plaintive soprano that in this song expresses a woman's longing for her vanished lover. ''You've left your mark on me -- it's permanent, a tattoo,'' she sings, sliding from note to note in a mournful, Dylan-esque way. ''Pierce the skin and the blood runs through.'' Sparely narrated, charged like a dream, the song moves from the kitchen, where Williams's protagonist stands trancelike and alone, to the bedroom, where she begins to undress. Toward the end, Williams's evocation of sexual loneliness is almost too much to bear as the woman, naked, lies on her back, snaps off the light and --.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKSTEIN, GERTRUDE S.
description: LOOKSTEIN-Gertrude S. We mourn the passing of Gertrude Lookstein, Aishat Chavil, whose devotion to her family, faith and community have been an inspiration to us all. Her legacy continues in the leadership of our dear friend, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein. May he and his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jersusalem. Diana and Morad Roshanzamir Debra and Asher Roshanzamir Esther and Menashe Dror Roset and Elliott Eshaghian

In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to: Henry Kaufmann Camp Grounds, P.O. Box 175, Pearl River, NY 10965, or the charity of your choice.

title: A Gift of Life to Fiji From Valhalla
description: WITH her husband by her side, Ashwini Sharan carried her 11-month-old daughter, Shania, out of the Westchester County Medical Center and into a misty rain here on Aug. 21, exactly 57 days after saving Shania's life by donating 20 percent of her liver to the child.

title: De La Hoya Beats Camacho To Keep Welterweight Title
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho wore what appeared to be a motorcycle helmet into the ring tonight, although it was pure leather. He could have used the real thing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLEDELL, JOSEPH
description: FLEDELL-Joseph. You can't stop the rain from raining. You can't quarrel with fate. For everything there's a season. A time to be born, a time to live, and a time to die. There is nothing unusual about a funeral or an unveiling, except that this time it's yours, Sweetheart. I console myself by trying to believe that God needed you to be on the welcoming committee for lovely Princess Diana and the blessed angel Mother Teresa. He knew your love for entertainment, mainly singing. Allan Correli, Ed Sullivan's talent scout, said he never heard our national anthem sung with such perfection and feeling, and he arranged to have you sing at the Salute to the Wounded in Madison Square Garden (the old one). I was your Jewish American Princess. You will forever and ever be my Prince Charming. From the day I saw you, Memorial Day weekend 1927, at the Idyl Hour Hotel in Pleasantdale, NJ, I was born again. My life really began. I couldn't take my eyes off you. Would I do it again? You bet I would! Hasta La Vista, Baby. I wuve you until eternity. Betty

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. Vivid, sweet memories and deepest gratitude to my beloved unforgettable mother on her birthday.

title: Karen Cantor, Dannel Arnold
description: Karen Cantor, a daughter of Maria Cantor and Dr. Eugene Cantor of Fair Haven, N.J., is to be married today to Dannel Arnold, a son of Donna Arnold of Los Angeles and the late Danny Arnold. Rabbi Robert Kirschner is to officiate at the Catalina Room in Palos Verdes, Calif.

title: At a Farm Market, an Absence Is Noted
description: There was an empty spot in the sun-drenched Union Square farmers' market yesterday.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; The Answer, My Friend, Is Snapping In the Wind
description: IN the last few months, I have saved myself hundreds of dollars by invoking a little-known secret of the technological universe. Amazingly, the secret does not rely on digital expertise, arcane wisdom or high-level data access. In a moment, I'll tell you exactly what it is so you, too, can benefit.

title: The Nation; Wide Open Spaces, but Hardly Untouched
description: IN the heart of the nation's newest and largest national monument, a simple roadside sign atop a spine of red sandstone says something rather remarkable for a nation of 260 million people. From that point in southern Utah, the view is one of earthly infinity, until the horizon itself slips out of focus in the arid sky. In all the land below, the sign notes, there is no hint of humanity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUBER, FLORIAN
description: STUBER-Florian, died September 11, 1997, of complications due to AIDS. Columbia B.A. and Ph.D. Professor at F.I.T., scholar, playwright, devoted teacher. Mourned by many friends in NYC. Survived by parents, Mr. and Mrs. Florian Stuber, of Buffalo, two brothers and a sister, nieces and nephews. Predeceased by his partner of many years, Irving Clark Piper. For information on the memorial service, call 212-662-4929. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to God's Love We Deliver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, JOHN M.
description: WILCOX-John M., former banker, died on September 6th, 1997, in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, New Jersey, at age ninety-six. He was born in New York City in 1901 and lived in Tenafly, New Jersey. Forty years of his business career were spent with the Marine Midland Banking Group. In 1928, he joined the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo. He represented that bank in New York City. At the time of his retirement in 1968, he was a Vice President of Marine Midland Corporation, the holding company. Also, at the same time, he was a Vice President of Marine Midland Bank, New York, and Marine Trust of Buffalo. Mr. Wilcox never married. He is survived by a nephew, Brian Wilcox, of Vancouver, Canada; a niece, Norah Irwin of Toronto, Canada, and grandnieces and grandnephews. He is also survived by a cousin, James A. Hyslop, of Bethesda, MD. Services were private.

title: Gov. Bush Denies Pardon In Rape Case, Despite DNA
description: Rejecting the unanimous recommendation of the state board of pardons and of the judge and prosecutors in the case, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has declined to grant a pardon to a Houston man who spent 12 years in prison for a rape that DNA testing later indicated he did not commit.

title: The Bargains and the Blowouts
description: Given the steep rise of the dollar in the last several months, much of Europe is now a better deal for American travelers than it has been in years. A fine bottle of French merlot, a pair of Ferragamo shoes in Milan or a night at the new Adlon Hotel in Berlin are all about 20 percent cheaper in dollar terms than they would have been a year ago.

description: There will be no shuttle diplomacy for Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. Ocko of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Avery Manchester of the United Church of Christ officiated at the First Church of Round Hill.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Conditions of Immortality
description: Taking his lead from the historian Fernand Braudel, the scholar George Holmes portrays the Renaissance as an expression of urban life and the opportunities created by commercial imperialism: ''Brutality and exploitation make possible wealth and the prosperity of the city, where refinement encourages an original creativity.'' Holmes shows how the veneration of classical architecture and sculpture led to a new realism in painting and literature; how even an attempt to copy classical handwriting could contribute to the individualism we associate with the Renaissance; and how separate innovations in Florence, Venice, Bruges and Ghent touched and eventually joined to change the perceptions of the European mind, ''like a dye coming from one source being diffused through a lake.'' Holmes's fine selection of color reproductions in Renaissance (St. Martin's, $35) makes plain why so many of the period's finest works of art -- bold and often startling even today -- could not have been possible except ''where thinkers and artists were protected from the tyranny of ecclesiastical intolerance and princely despotism.'' He is especially good at conveying what is mysterious and cannot be explained in many Renaissance paintings and sculptures, and he makes somehow coherent, if not fully definable, the greatness of painters like Leonardo, Michelangelo and Raphael. His story concludes with Cervantes, Shakespeare and Rembrandt, who marked the fulfillment of Renaissance achievement just as the influence of the cities that fostered it was being lost to the growing power of monarchies that resulted from population growth and shifts in the trade routes. ''Through a long struggle of historical recovery and artistic inspiration,'' Holmes writes, ''the European mind has been reborn.'' David Walton

title: Book Notes; Butler's Revelations on a Life of Service
description: AFTER almost 10 years of ''dining out'' on tales Christopher Allen told about his life as an English butler in Europe and the United States, he and his wife, Kimberly Burton Allen, decided to take the stories beyond the dinner table.

title: Skipping Class Not Advised
description: ''This was uncalled for, says Ed Wilson, 46, a former police chief from Sardis, Ga., who runs two private academies for bounty hunters, one in Central Islip on Long Island, the other in Belvedere, S.C. We're trying to standardize this profession, so incidents like this don't happen.

title: Jellyfish Plague Island's Waters
description: LIKE finicky people who only patronize the shore when the mercury zooms into the stratosphere, jellyfish have been materializing in hordes in waters off Long Island and all along its coast since the beginning of August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALL, PHYLLIS S.
description: THALL-Phyllis S. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend, after a long illness. Pre-deceased by her dear husband Arnold. She will be missed by friends and family alike. Funeral service to be held Sunday, September 14 at 11:30 AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Hospice Care Network or Gay Men's Health Crisis.

title: Rebounding Orioles Land Fast Haymaker
description: The Orioles punched back against the Yankees today, and Kenny Rogers served as their speed bag. Consider how a speed bag gets bashed back and forth by some fast fists in any gymnasium, and that provides a snapshot for how Rogers was bashed by some fast bats in a forgettable first inning at Camden Yards.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; A Massachusetts Museum Weaves a Spy Story
description: Thanks to nature's abundance and an early act of industrial espionage, textile production in America grew swiftly from a necessary domestic craft into one of the country's primary industries. To trace this technological revolution and its stamp on the lives of the American people, the American Textile History Museum has expanded and recently reopened in a cleverly redesigned mill in Lowell, Mass.

title: Connie Clausen, Literary Agent And Actress, 74
description: Connie Clausen, an actress and literary agent who began her career by riding circus elephants, died on Sept. 7 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Teen-ager Stabs Officer, Then Himself, in Queens
description: A distraught 17-year-old stabbed a police officer in the chest and then stabbed himself in the abdomen three times at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday evening, the police said.

title: Dandy in Gray Flannel (With an English-Style Shirt)
description: HAMISH BOWLES is known for daring sartorial combinations that make him a perennial on the International Best-Dressed List -- like ''an intense pink'' Richard James shirt, he says, or a ''quite racy one'' from Brooks Brothers with ''Matisse blue and flamingo pink stripes, worn with a pink-and-fuchsia-spotted Gene Meyer tie.'' He quite deliberately does not own a single dress shirt in plain white.

title: Hingis Goes Back To Her Czech Roots
description: Three days after winning the United States Open in Queens to claim her third Grand Slam singles title of 1997, Martina Hingis took the court in far different surroundings.

title: Overnight Sensation
description: I was very surprised to see that all of the recipes in Molly O'Neill's column instructed the cook to baste chicken on the grill with leftover marinade (''Overnight Sensation,'' Aug. 24). Everything I have read lately says that marinade is full of bacteria from raw poultry and should be either boiled before basting or discarded. I myself will reserve some of the marinade before chicken is added and use this uncontaminated portion for basting.

title: Three Rare Invitations to the Inner Sanctum
description: ARTISTS don't have to hang ''do not disturb'' signs on the doors of their studios. It is widely understood that a studio is an inner sanctum, a private space where work can be made, free of intrusion. But this solitude has also fostered the idea that artists are remote figures and that making art is a mysterious ritual.

title: The Nation; Selling the Government Like Soap; It Seems to Work
description: RONALD REAGAN was fond of observing that possibly the biggest lie in the English language was: ''Hi, I'm from the Federal Government and I'm here to help you.''

title: St. Louis, The City Under The Arch
description: Here's a picture I like: Me, standing at the window of my St. Louis hotel room, looking out. Nothing particularly happening. Just me, standing there looking. The glass is fixed, of course. The room's oddly arranged, shaped something like a telephone receiver, as if it had been carved out of a storage space. No hair dryer, though I called for one hours ago, and housekeeping has once again forgotten to leave a packet of supplies for the coffee maker. The fact is, the hotel I've chosen is under construction, but I don't care. Out there's the Mississippi. And it's enough.

title: Getting Opal Caples to Work
description: What if Opal Caples doesn't get her job back? What happens to her children? Where's the safety net for her kids? It used to be Aid to Families with Dependent Children. How little we value our children, especially those who are poor.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEFFEN, CAROLE KARP
description: GEFFEN-Carole Karp. September 14, 1941-September 11, 1990. Carole-you have two beautiful granddaughters, Caroline and Cayley. I miss you. Love, Joan

title: Westchester Q&A: Ethel Beville ; Giving a Home to Children Without One
description: FOR 49 years, Ethel and William Beville of White Plains have answered the call from child welfare authorities, and in doing so have helped about 80 infants, young children and adolescents in need of a temporary home and some tender loving care.

title: Teaming Up to Help Another Underdog Fight Free
description: AT THE CENTER OF A GLITTERING London ballroom, two middleweight fighters are slugging it out in the ring before an audience of 300 well-fed patrons, resplendent in evening dress, their tables littered with the remains of dinner, half-empty bottles of wine and overflowing ashtrays. As the blase audience followed the boxers' moves, the bout inspires parallels with gladiatorial combat in the arenas of ancient Rome.

title: President Presses Senate to Pass Campaign-Finance Changes
description: Presient Clinton today challenged the Senate to bring a long-delayed campaign-finance reform bill to a formal vote this month and told senators threatening to block consideration of the legislation that ''a vote to filibuster campaign reform is a vote to keep special interest money and kill reform.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: THE KINGDOM OF SHIVAS IRONS

title: As Taste for Comfort Rises, So Do Corporations' Profits
description: Ellen Elias has not yet seen the latest General Electric refrigerator, featuring a filter that purifies the chipped ice and chilled drinking water that at the touch of a button flows from a spigot on the door. But she already knows the sales pitch she will use to get shoppers who visit her Manhattan appliance store to buy the $1,800 refrigerator -- about twice the price of a standard one.

title: Kindra Predmore, Sean Thompson
description: Kindra Louise Predmore, a daughter of Dr. Roamer E. Predmore of Fort Washington, Md., and the late Renetta M. Lynch, was married in Newport, R.I., yesterday to Sean Roger Thompson, a son of Shirley and Roger Thompson of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Terry Baker of the Newport Church of Christ officiated at Beechwood, the Astor house.

title: Irene Draesel, Christopher Todd
description: Irene Renton Draesel, a daughter of Ada M. Draesel and the Rev. Herbert G. Draesel of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Russell Todd, a son of Anna L. Todd and Michael P. Todd of Newark, Ohio. The bride's father performed the ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Bay Head, N.J.

title: Good Music and Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL FUNDS; Investing With: Ronald E. Elijah
description: AT the age of 21, Ronald E. Elijah won the Dipsea, a grueling seven-mile run up Mount Tamalpais north of San Francisco. His record time, 44.49 minutes, stands to this day. Now 44 and a managing director at Robertson, Stephens & Company, Mr. Elijah is running an even tougher race to keep his place among the top managers in the mutual fund industry.

title: Jeanne McLean, Alfred Schmitt Jr.
description: Jeanne Beyea McLean and Alfred Joseph Schmitt Jr. were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson officiated.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Excess Baggage

title: Hearing From the Seven Who Are Seldom Heard
description: If you are unimpressed with the plans that Governor Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey have offered to lower auto insurance rates in New Jersey, there are seven other gubernatorial candidates with something to say about the issue.

title: A Mother on Trial
description: THE DEATH OF INNOCENTS

title: STYLE NOIR
description: TROUBLE is big business this fall. If urban crime is down, urbane fear is on a roll -- in fashion, movies, books and home design. Hollywood and Seventh Avenue have introduced a sinister new lining to the American dream, and they are escorting it to the bank like a dry-eyed widow with a fat will in her purse.

title: Ellen Ostrick, Richard Knight
description: Ellen Faith Ostrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester M. Ostrick of Woodsburgh, N.Y., was married last evening to Richard Peter Knight, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger P. Knight of Hong Kong. Justice Gabriel S. Kohn of State Supreme Court in Mineola, N.Y., officiated at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, N.Y.

title: Two 13-Year-Olds With Top S.A.T. Scores
description: THIRTEEN-YEAR-OLD Bobby Nampiaparampil has black wavy hair, braces and two older sisters who sometimes say annoying things that make him roll his eyes and groan.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: HAND TO MOUTH A Chronicle of Early Failure. By Paul Auster. Holt, $25.

title: Do You Know Where Your Luggage Is?
description: Even at the best regulated check-in counters, a slip of the pen can send your goods and chattels off to parts unknown. No prizes if you can identify the dozen airports coded above, but you might get your parrot back. Answers on Page 52

title: Taking The Office To the Highway
description: FIVE years ago, John Fickewirth decided he was wasting too much time driving from his office in Ventura, Calif., to visit clients and attend meetings all over the state. So he bought an empty van and had it fashioned into a rolling work station, then hired a driver.

title: Indian Rebels Draw Tens of Thousands to a Rally in Mexico City
description: The Zapatista rebels in Mexico have shown that their political appeal remains strong by drawing tens of thousands of people to a rally in the capital's central square late on Friday.

title: In I.R.A.'s, Remember the Beneficiary
description: THE new tax law will vastly expand Americans' opportunities to use individual retirement accounts. So it may be a good time, financial advisers say, to pay close attention to a task that I.R.A. investors often give short shrift: naming a beneficiary.

title: Capturing What Is
description: DOING DOCUMENTARY WORK By Robert Coles. Illustrated. 278 pp. New York: The New York Public Library/ Oxford University Press. $25.

title: Talking Entertainingly About Science
description: EACH Thursday evening, a man leans toward a microphone in a spare studio at WSHU-FM in Fairfield and enthusiastically says, ''Hi, I'm Ira Flatow, and this is 'Sounds Like Science.' '' Actually, he says it several times, piped from Connecticut to a National Public Radio recording studio in Washington, D.C., where his producer and her engineers patch the program together from bits and pieces.

title: Vanya Tulenko, Nunzi Sapuppo
description: Vanya Derkhiem Tulenko, a daughter of Karelei D. Tulenko and Dr. John F. Tulenko of New York, was married yesterday to Nunzi Michael Sapuppo, a son of Helen and Michele S. Sapuppo of Andover, Mass. The Rev. Michael Corrigan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Saviour in Brookline, Mass.

title: Adrift From Pop, Billy Joel Takes A Classical Turn
description: WHEN BILLY JOEL released his third volume of greatest hits last month, many of his fans were surprised that the album's three new cuts were written by other people.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Subdivision Sales Raise Concerns on Shelter Island.
description: THICK woods still line large sections of the quiet roads that meander through the Wards Point peninsula on Shelter Island's southern shore.

title: Elmsford Animal Shelter Draws Fire for Conditions
description: ARMED with a bulging file of complaints, some dating back a quarter of a century, the county's Department of Health is finally hoping to crack down on violations at an animal shelter here. Concerned about overcrowding, rat infestation and dogs choking on tethers, officials say that the Central Westchester Humane Society's no-kill policy may inadvertently be resulting in a living death for many of the 1,100 or more animals that reside at the Elmsford Animal Shelter.

title: Fashion's Creative Playtime
description: IT was not the usual fashion-crowd setting; for one thing, it was on the wrong side of the river. On Thursday night, Creative Time, the not-for-profit art foundation, lured a number of fashion mavens -- and their wildest couture visions -- across the Brooklyn Bridge and deep into its vaulted entrails for a benefit party.

title: Amanda Beesley, Nicholas Weinstock
description: ON Sept. 6, Amanda Beesley and Nicholas Weinstock were married outside the bridegroom's family home on Martha's Vineyard, in a yard full of gnarly, weather-beaten scrub oaks with branches growing sideways like flags in a strong wind.

title: To Pick Up Buyers, Some New Lines
description: IN designing its 1998 Accord coupe, Honda's philosophy was to the point: A coupe should be more than a sedan that's missing two doors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLON, CLARA HALL
description: MILLON-Clara Hall, on Tuesday, September 9, 1997, in Rochester, New York. Survived by her husband, Rene Millon; son, Peter (Debra Janes) Hall of MO.; three grandchildren, Rachel Hall of Rochester, NY, Daniel Hall of MO, Carrie Greeson of MO. One greatgranddaughter, Maude Hall Skillern of Rochester, New York; one brother, Sidney Stern of Mass. Clara was a graduate of Wadleigh High School and Hunter College. She received her Ph.D. in Anthropology at the University of California, Berkeley. Memorial services will be private. Friends wishing may contribute to the American Lung Association. Further information may be obtained from the Corbett Funeral Home, 2771 Chili Avenue, Rochester, New York.

title: Residential Resales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, STELLA JOLLES
description: REICHMAN-Stella Jolles. Died September 9 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Henry Reichman. Loving mother of the late Thomas and Steven, grandmother of Jamie. Memorial service Wednesday, October 1, Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 Street at 2PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY.

title: On a Course of Adventure, Moving From Fear to Trust
description: MOST weekdays, the executives and managers at J. P. Maguire Associates, a property damage restoration company with four offices in Connecticut and one in New York, can be found behind their desks or at job sites making estimates or supervising repairs. Recently, 13 of them tried a different approach to problem solving; they spent a day at Hopkins School in New Haven on what is called a challenge course. On the wooded campus, the men pooled their resources to complete difficult activities. They pondered loading everyone onto a giant wooden teeter-totter, without touching down, and coaxing frightened co-workers through daredevil stunts on ropes and cables 20 feet or more above the ground. Faced with the ''horizontal playpen,'' a 40-foot-long rope contraption laced with planks, rubber tires and toeholds anchored to tall trees, Mike Gutterman, a production manager, voiced what others were thinking.

title: New Rochelle Celebrates With a Street Festival
description: NEW ROCHELLE celebrates New Rochelle on the last day of summer next Sunday, with a street festival that will focus on the city's many attributes.

title: Any Way You Look at It, It's Up
description: IT has been a good year in just about every segment of the real estate industry in the New York metropolitan area. Office vacancy rates are down and effective rents are moving upward. Building sales have been brisk and some eye-popping prices are being paid.

title: Bath: Georgian Pluperfect
description: For more than 2,000 years people have journeyed to Bath, in southwest England, because the place makes them feel good. A vibrant city of about 84,000, Bath draws well over two million visitors a year and offers them a beguiling combination of geography, architecture, atmosphere, street life, shopping and the pleasures of just walking around.

title: JERSEYANA ; Finding Out if Those Hidden Treasures Really Are
description: The twins were ecstatic. Leigh and Leslie Keno, maestro appraisers of American antiques, were scrutinizing a Federal mahogany card table with most of its original label -- John Seymour & Son -- intact on its underside.

description: Special Today: The Sophisticated Traveler

title: The World; In Death, Too, Demand for Diana Exceeds the Supply
description: IN an emotional news conference at a celebrity tennis tournament in Florida last week, the pop star Elton John urged people still mourning the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, to begin putting aside their grief and get on with their lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNTSEN, CARL A., JR., M.D.
description: BERNTSEN-Carl A., Jr., M.D. The Society of Alumni of Bellevue Hospital records with profound sorrow the death of its Honored Member and Past President. David S. Weiss, M.D., President Ariel Distenfeld, M.D., Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIEBOFF, JANET
description: LIEBOFF-Janet. Though you're gone for many years, you are forever in my heart. Harry

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 4 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the actress Julie Harris misstates an honor she received this year. It was her 10th Tony nomination -- for ''The Gin Game'' -- not her 10th Tony Award.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Halfway Heaven

title: From John Harvard To Ramses II; Paris
description: She is tucked away, in a small square in Paris, behind the Church of St.-Germain-des-Pres, ignored by the old women chatting on benches, sullied by the pigeons passing overhead, apparently as abandoned as the stone vestiges of a former cloister that litter the grass. Her wide eyes are fixed on the middle distance and, ever since the vener-able bookstore Le Divan was closed last year to make way for a Christian Dior boutique, I have sensed a new defiance to her gaze.

title: Take a Lesson From Paris In the Fight Against Fliers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Richardson And Mr. Lyons
description: Rachel Jacqueline Richardson, the daughter of Lee Richardson of New York and the late Elane Rower, was married yesterday to David McKenna Lyons, the son of Margaret M. Lyons of Chicago and Richard D. Lyons of New York. Judge Barbara Ackerman of State Probate Court in Sherman, Conn., officiated at a private home in Easton, Conn.

description: GOT a craving for cow pizzel, burnt goat head, batata or coco yam? How about isinglass, Scotch bonnet or ylica? Or maybe just a bottle of sea moss and peanut punch?

description: To the Editor:

title: Official Vows to Review Aid Cuts For Disabled
description: President Clinton's nominee to head the Social Security Administration promises a ''top-to-bottom review'' to find out whether the Government has improperly cut off disability benefits for tens of thousands of children in low-income families.

title: The Birding Business
description: ABOUT 500 people and 200 species of birds are expected to visit Cape May beginning Friday for the annual New Jersey Audubon Society Weekend. Millions of migratory hawks, songbirds and waterfowl will be heading south for the winter, pausing on the beaches, marshes and back bays of Cape May County to rest and feed.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/ Milltown, N.J.; A Factory Town's Blue Collar Is Fading
description: MILLTOWN'S Mayor Raymond (Duke) Graulich has his nickname tattooed on his right forearm and ''Mother'' on his left, and he says that's ''typical Milltown.''

description: CHRISTOS

title: Plugging Cigarettes
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Ex-Rich Lived
description: IN the early 1950's, when young Pete Pilla was learning to fix the oil-burning boiler, the Andrew Freedman Home was a palace. It covered two square blocks, an Italian Renaissance building of soft gray and yellow limestone on the Grand Concourse, the Bronx's most fashionable avenue. Women in white gloves walked past on the way to furriers or dress shops.

title: Augusta Reese, Jason Eiswerth
description: Augusta Bliss Reese, a daughter of Hope Wells Reese and John Rathbone Reese of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday in Hughsonville, N.Y., to Jason Andreas Eiswerth, a son of Anne and Barry Eiswerth of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. Wendell W. Meyer, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Obercreek, the farm of the bride's grandmother Frances Stevens Reese.

title: Battle of Service Agencies Reveals Unfortunate Trend
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/New Jersey; At Fair Lawn Business Park, the Prospect Is Housing
description: IN the last 25 years the owners of the 150-acre Fair Lawn Business and Technical Center along Route 208 in this Bergen County community have proposed five projects -- including a million-square-foot commercial complex -- for the remaining 20 acres of their campus.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about a Jewish ritual bath, or mikvah, misstated one condition for its use. Under Jewish law, it is not forbidden for women who have had premarital sex. Married women are welcome to use it, regardless of their past sexual activity.

title: For Fassel & Company, Crucial Point Hits Early
description: A head coach's journey through a 16-game National Football League regular season has been likened to many things, but an apt comparison would be a ride on a roller coaster. Not just for the ups and downs, but for the parts where those around you, or maybe even you, are screaming. For the parts when your stomach squirms. For the parts when you are being jerked around. For the parts when the anticipation is exhilarating.

title: Party Designees Win Most Primary Spots
description: LAST week's primary in Westchester showed the power of party structure, for in most cases officially designated candidates defeated their challengers in intra-party battles.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: HOCKEY

title: Drug Tests on School Athletes
description: Should high schools be permitted to do drug testing on members of sports teams? Some say such testing is an unreasonable search.

title: Pressure Is On, and She Knows It
description: Call it local knowledge, or call it unapproachable talent, but Betsy Alison has a lock on one of the world's most important women's sailing events.

title: Holocaust Revulsionism
description: Your Sunday item on the planned Holocaust Memorial for the Civic Plaza in Albuquerque, N.M., lacked a great deal of information (''Holocaust Revulsionism,'' Aug. 17). I informed the reporter that discussions were still taking place and that the final outcome was yet to be determined. The reporter also failed to point out that a number of the members of Cafe Europa (the survivors group) are in fact supportive of the project.

title: Getting Ready For Winter
description: HEATING experts say that homeowners who have not prepared their heating systems for the winter should do so right now. Test runs and precautionary measures, they say, can help avoid surprises when the thermostat sends its first call for heat and the furnace grunts and rumbles in response.

title: In East Africa, Panel Tackles War Crimes, and Its Own Misdemeanors
description: The wheels of justice move at their own pace in this remote, dusty place, home to the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda though better known as a tourist layover for safaris to the Serengeti and treks up Kilimanjaro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, BERNARD
description: GOULD-Bernard. On September 11, 1997, of White Plains, New York. Husband of the late Sonya Gould, father of Steven Gould, Linda Abtalion, Karen Ziaman, and Barbara Boyley. Brother of Victor and Edward Gould, grandfather of six grandchildren. The family will receive friends Saturday 7-9 P.M. at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye. Interment service Sun., 3PM, the Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Red Cross, Westchester County Chapter, 106 N. Broadway, White Plains, New York 10503, appreciated.

title: Fraud Case Focuses On Internet
description: BE careful what you say about stocks over the Internet -- you could inadvertently be furthering a securities fraud. And if there is nothing inadvertent about your comments, you could end up spending a year in jail.

title: Morris County Lawyers Can Pay for Replacements
description: Your family doctor wouldn't refer you to a podiatrist for heart surgery, even if the operation were free. But that kind of pairing of client and professional is just what happens when corporate and other non-criminal lawyers are assigned to defend indigent defendants in municipal court, legal scholars agree.

title: The Museum's the Thing
description: DRESDEN in the 18th century was no ordinary German city. It was more beautiful than most, and more prosperous: the lead and silver mines nearby, together with its position as a great trading center, insured its wealth. Most important, though, was the character of its princes. Saxony -- the state of which Dresden was, and is, the capital -- was among the largest and most powerful in the Holy Roman Empire, and its rulers, the Electors, took full advantage of that. Augustus II, the Strong, who reigned from 1694 to 1733, made the right alliances, fought at the right times in the right places and was elected King of Poland with Russian backing. His son, Augustus III, managed to retain that slippery throne; and both monarchs put on the kind of display that was meant to impress the rest of Europe.

title: A Chief Banker for Nations At the Bottom of the Heap
description: A FEW months ago, James D. Wolfensohn, the wealthy former investment banker who heads the World Bank, stood in a teeming hillside ghetto in Rio de Janeiro, watching people who had never had running water experience the simple pleasure of opening a tap.

title: Real Life in Bulgaria
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: MR. PUTTER AND TABBY ROW THE BOAT. By Cynthia Rylant. Illustrated by Arthur Howard. Harcourt Brace. Cloth, $11; paper, $5. (Ages 6 to 10) The sixth in a series of books for newly independent readers is a peaceful, gently amusing story of a hot summer afternoon. Mr. Putter, an elderly gent, and his neighbor, Mrs. Teaberry, and their pets, Tabby the cat and Zeke the dog, cool off at a pond. The illustrations enhance the text nicely.

title: A Rugged Stalwart For the End Of Summer
description: SOME plant hybridists are never willing to leave well enough alone. They often work with native plants to tuck in an earlier flowering component here or a brighter color there. The result is usually dazzling.

title: No Shyness About A Landmark Birthday
description: ALIDA AUGEN not only admits her age but also celebrates it. This afternoon at 4 the soprano who lives in Redding is giving herself a 50th birthday party at the Pequot Library in Southport, surrounded by friends and family as she sings arias and songs of Mozart, Berlioz, Debussy, Massenet and more.

title: Progress on Plastics?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ball Game In Bridgeport's Near Future
description: NOT far from a failed dog track, which previously had been a failed jai alai fronton, and on a site where the real estate developer Donald Trump had hoped to build a gambling casino, a baseball stadium will begin to rise next month near the Bridgeport waterfront.

title: Q. & A.
description: Mush!

title: The Boy Who Gave Away The Bomb
description: On a late winter morning, we were settling once again around the kitchen table at Theodore and Joan Hall's pleasant brick row house near Cambridge University. Outside the sliding glass doors to their back garden, a feeble sun was making no headway against the gray English day. But it was light and warm enough inside, and the wall of snapshots overlooking the table -- children and grandchildren, siblings and friends -- generated a cheery warmth of family love.

title: Seat Belts Ignored, Despite Diana
description: East Side, West Side, uptown and down: everywhere, the story is the same. Despite celebrity admonishments blaring from back-seat speakers, New York taxi passengers are simply not buckling up. Even the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, has had little apparent effect upon cab riders, notwithstanding news reports indicating that she might have survived the crash in Paris had she only been wearing her seat belt.

title: Style; Tip of the Iceberg
description: Economists assure us that the inflation rate is now near zero and holding steady, and we might be inclined to believe them, if we ate iceberg lettuce. For those who do, it's true that the price of a salad has indeed remained constant over the course of the past 10 years. But here is where hidden inflation comes into play: For those of us who have left iceberg behind, the price of a salad has increased exponentially. There was a time when we subscribed to lettuces like Boston and bibb, but before long they were supplanted by other breeds of greens, each more exotic than the one before, and more expensive. First there was arugula, then radicchio, followed by mache and, more recently, mesclun -- each of which made its debut as a delicacy at the top of the charts and has since sunk to the level of ubiquity. It was frisee that ousted mesclun, precipitating its decline, and now mizuna, an upstart salad green from Asia, with darling pointy leaves and a bitter peppery taste, has gone frisee one better. Anyone whose appetite has followed this trajectory from iceberg (stable at an average of $1.19 a pound at D'Agostino) to mizuna (currently $9 a pound at Balducci's) has in effect experienced a 656 percent increase in the cost of a salad.

title: ART: Arriving in New York After Taking Off in London; 2 Brothers And Their Macabre Creations
description: THE WORK OF THE ENGLISH sculptors Jake and Dinos Chapman is not for the prudish. The brothers fabricate child-size mannequins -- not unlike those seen in department store windows -- out of fiberglass, paint them with vapid expressions and give them only wigs and sneakers to wear. They are also mutants, with extra limbs, multiple heads and both male and female genitalia -- always in the wrong place and in a permanent state of arousal.

description: To the Editor:

title: Essay ; New Kind Of 'Dirty Tricks'

title: September 7-13; Too Poor to Afford Safety
description: In another country, the 200 or so people who drowned when a ferry capsized and sank a few yards off the Haitian coast probably would be alive today. But Haiti's deep poverty makes it fertile ground for easily preventable disasters.

title: Lisa Kassenaar, Edward Hampton
description: Lisa Maria Kassenaar and Edward Willoughby Middleton Hampton, reporters in New York for Bloomberg News, were married yesterday in Toronto. Canon Sydney Woodd-Cahusac performed the Anglican ceremony at the Church of St. Clement, Eglinton.

title: When the Artist Is Also Actor: A Show Caught Up in a Caprice

He specializes in finding art that people have never seen but know about through rumor: art made by famous people who inhabit worlds other than that of art.

title: Kenney's Beach And Erosion
description: Hearing that Kenney's Beach residents have filed a suit against Southold County is a disappointment in the sense that it indicates that they are not interested in finding the real facts as to why beach erosion is affecting Kenney's Beach and other beaches. We are all interested in protecting our property at the Sound, but we cannot do this at the detriment of other people. Kenney's Beach residents know that Goldsmith jetty has been very protective for those houses west of it and of the ecology of that area. Removal of the jetty will create an ecological disaster, which may result in the condemnation of many houses up to SoundView Avenue because of flooding and water contamination.

description: ROSAHN-Sonya. See ''Staff.''

He got together with friends, neighbors and other baseball enthusiasts, formed a committee and bombarded officials with letters.

description: Mother Teresa was buried yesterday in Calcutta, India, after a funeral largely closed to the poor she had devoted her life to helping.

title: Architecture of an Irish Peace
description: After years of fitful preparation, negotiations for peace are set to begin in earnest tomorrow in Northern Ireland. The Irish Republican Army has declared a new cease-fire, the British and Irish Governments seem committed to ending the violent conflict and the largest unionist party, though hesitating, seems likely to participate in the talks in some form. If so, all sides would be present. Whether the citizens of Northern Ireland get the permanent peace they dearly want and clearly deserve depends on whether Protestant and Catholic leaders alike are willing to settle for something less than their ultimate goals.

title: Corrections

title: As Piers Close, Gay Protesters See a Paradise Lost
description: For Ray Cartagena, the Hudson River piers are a refuge -- a place where he and his boyfriend come to meet friends, listen to music and be openly gay.

title: Barbara Glassman And Arthur Rubin
description: Barbara Ann Glassman and Arthur Mark Rubin were married last evening in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi James Diamond performed the ceremony in Prospect House at Princeton University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, DAVID
description: LEVITT-David. After a courageous stuggle for health, beloved husband for 60 years of Norma Uttal Levitt and loving father of Sally Steinberg, Nancy Hoffman and Andrew Levitt. The line points to the ubiquitous identity of the Berlitz language schools. This summer the company, founded in 1878 in Providence, R.I. by Maximilian D. Berlitz, a German immigrant, opened a museum at its new world headquarters in West Windsor.

title: James Bartlett, Sonja Weinkopf
description: Sonja Christine Weinkopf, a daughter of Nicole Anninger of Concord, Mass., and Gunther Weinkopf of Chatham, Mass., was married in Chatham yesterday to James Robert Theodore Bartlett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Bartlett of Wellesley, Mass. title: MUSIC ; Disparate Sounds From Other Centuries
description: BAROQUE music's phenomenal surge in popularity is easy to spot and fun to call a renaissance. The reason for it is harder to figure. Do predictable harmonies and repeated melodic sequences by lesser composers soothe commuting drivers? Do its jaunty rhythms, heard daily on what now passes for classical radio, help sluggards wake up?

The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School

description: Riding the Rails

title: Schools Preparing for Major Changes
description: FOR Long Island school districts, a new school year has begun with a mixture of optimism and concerns. Increased state aid to education comes as good news for some districts, while many are receiving less money than they did in 1989, when the state made drastic cutbacks in education aid. Some districts have been able to restore or add programs, upgrade technology and make building repairs. But a few on austerity budgets are unable to afford important projects.

title: On Language; Play's the Thing
description: Inventing palindromes -- words or phrases that read the same coming or going -- has been a worthwhile way to waste an afternoon since at least the third century b.c., when Sotades created his first palindromic sonnet. It takes patience, but the results are often surprisingly rewarding. While the Internet has taken the fun out of some kinds of wordplay -- I recently discovered an instant anagram program; what a killjoy for Jumble aficionados! -- it has yet to encroach upon the creative side of palindrome making. Sometimes the best palindromes just appear out of thin air: Logophiles everywhere were as elated about the victory of ANUTA CATUNA in the New York City Marathon as they were saddened by the death of Mr. Shakur (TUPAC'S CAPUT). Before sharpening your pencil, study ''I Love Me, Vol. I'' (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill), by Michael Donner, a scintillating new encyclopedia of palindromic phrases. Donner takes a surprisingly scholarly approach to his subject, but the results are anything but serious. In it are such compelling examples of the art as slob MYSTIC ATE TACIT SYMBOLS and AH! A MAYAN ON A YAMAHA!

title: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER -- The Bargains and the Blowouts; Istanbul: A day on the Bospurus, a night on the town
description: Istanbul is a city to be enjoyed both day and night, but because there is so much to see, it's often hard to know where to begin. One of the best ways is with a leisurely boat ride along the Bosporus toward the outskirts of the city and back, taking in the grand Ottoman palaces, lavish waterfront mansions, ancient fortresses and bustling villages that dot the European and Asian shores.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OZANICS, VICTORIA
description: OZANICS-Victoria, died September 9, 1997. She was born May 29, 1908 in Yugoslavia. She emigrated to New York City with her mother while in her teens. After graduating from Barnard College, she began work at the Harkness Pavillion of Columbia University Physicians and Surgeons as Assistant to Dr. George K. Smelser, Professor of Ophthalmology. Her work spanned 49 years as she taught many generations of second-year residents the anatomy of the eye. Her years as a research scientist led to the writing of many articles, as well as chapters in many widely-used textbooks. Beloved godmother of Emanuel, Thea, and Hayley Schiller. Beloved and respected by friends and colleagues at Columbia University, as well as her friends and neighbors in Inwood. Contributions in her memory to Columbia Presbyterian Hospital.

title: The Legacy of Thornton Wilder

title: Corrections

The author is his great-uncle's nearest living relative, but not by blood; the writer was adopted. (A message from a reader dated Aug. 29, pointing out the error, was delayed in routing at The Times.)

title: Word for Word/Local Police News; There Are Nuggets of Americana In Them Thar Ho-Hum Hills
description: THE ''Mother Lode'' region of central California, here in the grizzly foothills of the Sierra Nevada, has a legacy of lawlessness rooted in the prospecting frenzy that followed the Gold Rush of 1849. Back then, desperate miners swarmed to boom towns like Angel's Camp, Volcano Eruption and Sonora, which became instant legends not just for their occasional bonanzas of gold but for the crime and chaos that followed the mule trains into the hills.

title: Anne White, Timothy Girian

description: PASSIONS, and occasionally tempers, ran high at a special meeting of the Yonkers City Council here recently to discuss a proposed zoning change that could allow the construction of a concrete plant in full view of a residential community.

title: In America ; Punishing the Truth
description: Hessy Phelan was a tiny guy, a shade under 5 feet tall and something less than 100 pounds, but he liked to drink and his friends agree that when he was under the influence he could become obnoxious. He had a mouth on him and he tried to act bigger than he was. Most people understood what that was about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUEHLER, SEYMOUR J.

Dear uncle of Susan and Jon Kerz, and Beth and Jim Eisenstein. Service Sunday, 11:30 AM. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Sy fought a heroic battle. A special man of utmost integrity, he will be missed by his family and many friends. Contributions in his memory may be made to Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, 1440 York Ave, P4, NY NY 10021.

Is there a photograph of that building? I'm a regular visitor to the Eldorado Towers and was not aware there was an earlier one.''

title: September 7-13; Voters Get a Second Chance

Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and a fixture in city politics for 20 years, failed by barely 2,500 votes to get the 40 percent needed to challenge the city's popular Republican Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. The result: she now faces a Sept. 23 runoff against the Rev. Al Sharpton, who ran a strong second.

title: VIEWPOINT; Apples And Oranges At Your Alma Mater
description: IF you look at the financial performance of your alma mater today, you may have trouble figuring out what is going on. This is because new and absurd accounting rules have been imposed by a group with little experience in the area.

title: Hit the Road, June
description: I'LL BE HOME

description: Five months after voters here created a commission to overhaul the charter that governs the nation's second-largest city -- and elected 15 members to fill it -- the panel has barely begun work. Instead, it has been held hostage by political wrangling, by lack of money and by competition from a rival commission appointed by the City Council.

title: Pieter Cohen and Lauren Budding
description: Lauren Budding, the daughter of Pamela D. Adams and David W. Budding, both of Lexington, Mass., was married last evening in Marlboro, Vt., to Pieter A. Cohen, the son of Leila R. Kern, also of Lexington, and Perrin S. Cohen of Concord, Mass. Ann Rider, a justice of the peace, officiated at the house of the bride's mother and stepfather, Robert W. Adams.

title: September 7-13; When Death Isn't a Syndrome

description: ALL OVER

title: Avis vs. Hertz: Investors, Start Your Calculators
description: EVEN as an investment, Avis Rent-a-Car looks destined to be No. 2. The Hertz Corporation, its longtime rival, dominates the rental car business, with $3.8 billion in sales. And when the Ford Motor Company spun off part of Hertz last April at $24 a share, the stock ended its first day nearly $4 higher and has gone on to gain 24 percent more.

description: AFTER 25 years, this city is seeking a new superintendent of schools with the departure of Dr. William C. Prattella, who attended his last school board meeting on Sept. 4.

title: Ideas & Trends; Trade War on the Home Front

Sure, parking American cars in Osaka showrooms doesn't exactly concentrate the mind the way scrapping nukes aimed at Los Angeles once did. But whether the subject is throw-weights or tariff rates, the talks are really about national security and the uses of national power.

The hard part was actually getting the President to pick up the telephone. Mr. Ickes, the former deputy chief of staff, recalled that he had to leave the call sheets on Mr. Clinton's desk, where they often sat for weeks, untouched.

title: From John Harvard To Ramses II; Phnom Penh
description: Six hundred years ago, when Cambodia was ruled by magic and not by guns, Old Lady Penh pulled a tree trunk out of a rain-swollen river and found five miraculous statues of Buddha nestled inside it. She carried them to the top of a little hill not far from the river and built a shrine for them: Wat Phnom, or Temple of the Hill. The temple has been rebuilt over the centuries, but it remains one of the holiest places in Phnom Penh.

description: He stands erect, wearing the impassive gaze of his era: a king of kings, Ramses II, who ruled ancient Egypt for 67 years and whose massive, granite likeness was rendered more than 3,000 years ago.
