title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNK, BARBARA D., M.D.
description: MUNK-Barbara D., M.D., passed away Friday, September 12 in New York. Survived by her brothers, Dr. Peter Munk and Prof. Dr. Klaus Munk, her sister, Dr. Rosemarie Hoffmann, many loving family members in Germany, and friends here and abroad. Her life was dedicated to child psychiatry. She was Founder and Director of The Parent-Infant Therapeutic Program at Gouverneur Hospital, a Clinical Assistant Professor and Supervisor in Child Psychiatry at New York University. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, on Monday, September 15, from 6-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to Zero To Three, National Center for Infants, Toddlers and Families, c/o Central Fidelity Bank, P.O. Box 25494, Richmond, Virginia 23286-8214, would be greatly appreciated.

title: September 7-13; A Space Mission Provokes Nuclear Anxieties on Earth
description: A war of words is heating up over the launching next month of the $3.4 billion Cassini mission to Saturn, which is to have its explorations powered by batteries made of 72 pounds of plutonium, a deadly radioactive element never fired into space in such quantity.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A Washington political appointment, an ambitious schemer, formidable villains and a female executive propel a choice mix of films on television this week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''She learned to see the face of God in every suffering human being.''

title: The View From: New London ; After a Century, a Little Station For a Trolley Finally Finds Its Niche
description: THE tiny 1893 building was almost forgotten until its owners talked of getting rid of it. Preservationists rallied; they moved it to what seemed a good spot, fixed it up and tried to give it new life, but things didn't work out. It was moved again, to a parking lot smack dab in the middle of downtown New London.

title: In the Age of the Portobello Mushroom, Culinary Courses Keep Pace
description: WHAT'S cooking?

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1998 Honda Accord; Ex-Champ Returns to Center Court
description: THE high-stakes market for midsize sedans is not unlike an intensely competitive tennis tournament.

title: FAME'S PERMUTATIONS
description: You've probably seen the Miller Lite ads that feature a photo of a red-haired goof named Dick, supposedly the creative genius behind the campaign. It turns out that Dick is Jeff Barnes, 27, a Seattle bartender who was chosen after a nationwide ''talent'' search. Latest: Barnes is stepping out qua himself. He plays in a rock band, and grants interviews only after getting Miller's approval, all as part of Miller's plan to keep Dick going (as long as the public will have him). Why does this man bewitch us? ''He's an average Joe,'' says a Miller spokeswoman, ''who seems to have something on his mind.''

title: Laura Aswad, Joseph Belluck
description: Laura Lynn Aswad, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles N. Aswad of New York, was married last evening to Joseph Warren Belluck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Belluck of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Building, a turn-of-the-century warehouse in Long Island City, Queens.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 14, 1997
description: Weeks

title: PHOTOGRAPHER'S JOURNAL
WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CELEBRATING BOOKS

title: Restoring a Jewish Cemetery in Poland
description: IN a small town in central Poland near the Bug River, shoemakers pounded nails into soles, bakers kneaded dough with reddened hands, and yeshiva students strolled in long black coats.

title: Brokerage Deals Make I.P.O.'s Available, in Theory
description: DISCOUNT brokers, big and small, are getting into the business of initial public offerings. The discount arm of Fidelity Investments has linked up with Salomon Brothers in the sale of new stocks. Schwab has joined three Wall Street firms in the underwriting field, giving its customers access to offerings. Even E*Trade, a small Internet discounter, has announced a pact to distribute shares of stock offerings underwritten by Robertson, Stephens & Company.

title: Filling the Seats
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Seeing Pergamon Whole
description: DURING the years I lived in Berlin, I entertained scores or hundreds of visitors. For each of them, whether they were staying a day, a week or a month, I had a single piece of advice: Don't leave without seeing the Pergamon Altar.

title: Forbes Puts On Anti-Abortion Mantle
description: The surprise hit at the Christian Coalition's annual convention here today was not a politician known for his devotion to social issues but a wealthy businessman from the Northeast: Steve Forbes.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: BLAKE

title: Women and Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: The Enemy of Our Enemy
description: This summer bosnian serbs were telling a new joke, about a group of astronauts from the former Yugoslavia. Two Serbs, two Bosnian Muslims and two Croats land on Mars. The Croats say that the barren landscape so resembles their homeland that the planet must be Croat. The Muslims say that the craters are the twins of Bosnia's mountain valleys, so the planet must be Bosnian. One of the Serbs takes out a gun, shoots the other Serb and says, ''Since Serb blood has been spilled here, this is now Serb land.'' Recently a new version of the joke has made the rounds; it has Radovan Karadzic, the indicted wartime leader, pulling the trigger on his former comrade in arms, the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic.

title: Ideas & Trends; Testing Genes to Save a Life Without Costing You a Job
description: HUMAN genes hold a wealth of information that physicians hope will help them avert illnesses that may be passed on from one generation to the next. Yet the information, still a trickle but about to arrive in deluges, is so powerful that it will need to be handled with care.

title: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER -- The Bargains and the Blowouts; Frankfurt: The empress' art, then the winemaker's
description: Historians say that Empress Victoria, the daughter of Queen Victoria who married the German Emperor Frederick III in 1858, never felt truly at home in her adopted country. She was considered too outspoken, too intellectual and by some accounts simply too British.

title: The Stone Age
description: A CHILD'S NIGHT DREAM

title: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER -- The Bargains and the Blowouts; Vienna: A night at the opera, and the best coffee in town
description: A night at the Vienna Opera remains a grand occasion that has brought royalty, society and music lovers together for more than 100 years. For outrageous splendor, you could book a box, take six friends and peer down at the rest of the crowd ($132 a seat at 12.16 schillings to $1, seven chairs in a box; $164 a seat at a premiere). Or you can sit in the front orchestra seats and know that you are in the most expensive seats, with the best view and superb acoustics ($164; $189 at a premiere). Box-office sales begin a month ahead.

title: Milton Rubincam, Top Genealogist, Dies at 88
description: Milton Rubincam, a dogged and inspired researcher who spent the better part of his life swinging through family trees, sometimes finding plums, sometimes snapping off favorite branches, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUSON, KATHERINE ARTHUR
description: HUSON-Katherine Arthur. Playwright and teacher died peacefully after a short illness on Wednesday, September 3. She is much missed by her sons, Edward Arthur Huson and Christopher Gordon Huson and cousin, Phyllis Lavelle. Friends and relatives are invited to a memorial service in San Francisco on Saturday, 27 of September in the chapel at 355 Buena Vista East Avenue at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, MAX
description: SCHWARZ-Max. The Westside Institutional Synagogue sorrowfully mourns the passing of our esteemed member, Max Schwarz, beloved brother of our Past President Herb Schwarz, and beloved father of Joseph Schwarz and Marna Schwarz Carroll. May the comforter of Zion and Jerusalem comfort the grieving family. Moshe Morduchowitz, Rabbi Richard Wigler, President

title: Misdirected
description: Oops. With the stroke of a computer key, a sensitive memo (perhaps about your love life, your finances or your boss) has gone astray. Welcome to the wonderful world of computers, where really embarrassing things can happen in a big hurry. Have you ever sent a message to the wrong destination? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The Met's Great Rapier Wit at Play
description: FOR RUDOLF BING, WHO DIED early this month at 95, the Metropolitan Opera was life. He labored for it six days and nights a week and then collapsed in exhaustion on the seventh. Bing had little social life. He had a wife and an apartment in the Essex House, and he had the Met.

title: Getting Opal Caples to Work
description: Like Jason DeParle, I spent much of the summer studying Wisconsin Works (''Getting Opal Caples to Work,'' Aug. 24). How is it then, that I left Wisconsin seeing the glass half empty, while he saw it half full?

title: Two Neighborhoods, One Naples
description: ''QUESTA e Napoli,'' declares the waitress. With the city's trademark cynicism, more juice than rind, she says her trattoria hires only family because strangers entail taxes and paperwork. Blood is thicker, and cheaper. This is Naples.

title: Getting Opal Caples to Work
description: The welfare reformers preach the virtue of a work ethic, but their real purpose seems to be to demean those who are supposed to receive their message. Why else would Opal Caples, a welfare recipient, be forced to dignify a job cleaning toilets by writ-ing a three-page letter in order to get it back? How humiliating.

title: The Summer Sendoff at Club Atlantis
description: NOT much is regular about the regular weekend salsa dance sessions outside the Atlantis bar on the Coney Island Boardwalk at the end of Stillwell Avenue. A 4 feet 4 inch 50-year-old master of ceremonies barks into a microphone, urging a crowd of spectators, some in bathing suits, others in their Sunday best, to get on the makeshift dance floor, a small area of boardwalk cordoned off by brown twine tied to green trash cans. Dancers spiral and gyrate next to a spherical concession stand fashioned like a giant orange that forms one border of the dance area.

title: LAMBDA SQUARES
description: * International Gay Square Dance Month gets a hats-off in Denver next weekend at a three-day event held by the Rocky Mountain Rainbeaus. * The Rainbeaus are one of 58 clubs in the steadily growing International Association of Gay Square Dance Clubs. * Others include the Rocket City Rainbow Squares(Huntsville, Ala.), New York's Times Squares and the Ottawa-Hull (Canada) Date Squares, who recently produced a radio show called ''All My Lesbian and Gay Square Dancing Children.'' * Roughly 75 percent of gay square dancers are men. * The moves are the same, but free expression is encouraged. ''If some of the gals want to wear dresses, fine,'' says Karl Jaeckel, executive administrator of the I.A.G.S.D.C. ''If some of the guys want to wear dresses, fine.''

title: Penn State Proves Its Resiliency
description: This was no way to look out for No. 1. Asked whether Penn State deserved the top ranking after mauling its second straight overmatched opponent, Nittany Lions Coach Joe Paterno said: ''I haven't the slightest idea if we're the No. 1 team. But you can't say that about anybody right now, so you might as well make us No. 1.''

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE -- The Rampage of the Literati: Out, Out Damned Typos; At Least It Wasn't Babs Ruth, Right?
description: It was the kind of article that warmed the hearts of the city's grammarians, who decry the declining standards of New York's verbal landscape. On Aug. 24, a New York Post reporter, Gersh Kuntzman, took the Yankee organization to task for putting up placards full of typographical and punctuation errors as well as poor wording in the walkway leading to Monument Park at Yankee Stadium, which honors the team's legends whose numbers have been retired.

title: The Play of Light Among Monuments Of Ancient Egypt
description: FOUR millenniums of Egyptian architectural achievement have been documented in a book and inspired an exhibition in New Haven.

title: A Funny Lady Who's Now A Leading Lady
description: SO SHE DOESN'T GET TO KISS the leading man. So a man does.

title: A Master Plan for Copters
description: Irwin Suskind has lived in Brooklyn Heights since the 1960's, in an apartment overlooking lower Manhattan and the harbor. But only during the last few years has he really noticed the helicopters, swooping down from the sky like deafening birds of prey.

title: Roslyn Bank Offers Stock to Depositors And Value Rises
description: LAST fall 83,680 depositors at the Roslyn Savings Bank received a letter from the bank announcing its conversion from a mutual savings bank to a chartered stock savings bank.

title: Good Reasons for a Party
description: Celebrating women of the shutter, the City Opera at 53, an editor at 50 and a new shop in SoHo.

title: Remembering Ali, When He Floated And Stung at Will
description: A WOMAN NAMED NANCY, THE mother of two young boys, had asked me to get an autograph from Muhammad Ali for her sons. This was 1971, and I was off to Chicago to spend a day with the once and future heavyweight champ in training for a bout against Jimmy Ellis. I told her that I was sorry but that I couldn't ask someone I'm interviewing for an autograph because it wouldn't be professional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, JOHN RANDOLPH
description: HARRISON-John Randolph, of Hightstown, NJ, on Sept. 8, 1997, age 93. Father of Josephine H. Evarts of Mt. Kisco, NY, Randolph Harrison of Mill Neck, N.Y., and Robert C. Harrison of New York N.Y. Grandfather of eight, greatgrandfather of 16. Stepfather of Lawrence W. Fox, III, Diane F. Downs and Cary F. Fisher. Private service Hollywood Cemetery, Richmond, VA. Memorial contributions to St. Paul's School, Concord, N.H. 03301 appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLENNON, EILEEN M.
description: GLENNON-Eileen M. On Thursday, September 11, 1997. Eileen passed away in Florida. Beloved sister of Betty and beloved aunt of Posie and Billy. Family will receive friends on Sunday, 5-8 PM, and Monday, 4-6 PM and 7-9 PM, at the Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial St. Catherine of Siena R.C. Church, 411 E. 68th Street, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Israeli Market Seems Solid Despite Turmoil
description: THE terrorist bombing in Jerusalem on Sept. 4 prompted a flurry of diplomatic reaction in Israel and the United States, but the latest political unrest has had little effect on Israeli stocks and even less on portfolio managers, who remain optimistic about Israeli companies and their future.

title: No Longer A Fan of Tennis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Smoking and Glamour
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Vines
description: Port Bello

title: Deborah Kozart, F. H. Ludtke 3d
description: Deborah Eileen Kozart, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David M. Kozart of Philadelphia, was married at her parents' house last evening to Frederick Herman Ludtke 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ludtke Jr. of Daufuskie Island, S.C. Rabbi Julie Greenberg performed the ceremony.

title: POSTINGS: Making Nassau's Air and Space Museum Soar; A Grown-Up Cradle of Aviation by '99
description: For 20 years, curators at Nassau County's Cradle of Aviation Museum have been amassing and restoring a major collection of air and space vehicles.

title: Army Stops Lafayette On 545 Rushing Yards
description: Coming into today's game against Lafayette, Army had won its last 19 games against teams from the Division I-AA Patriot League. And it had beaten Lafayette 11 straight times since Lafayette's lone victory in the 104-year-old series, in 1940.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, KATHERINE V., RN
description: KELLY-Katherine V., RN, July 10, 1997. Graduated from St. Vincent's School of Nursing. Survived by niece Helen Booher and great nephew John Booher. Memorial mass at St. Lawrence O'Toole R.C. Church, Brewster, New York on September 15, 1997 at 11 A.M.

title: Getting Opal Caples to Work
description: Jason DeParle again raises the specter of the success or failure of welfare reform. While he reports dramatic declines in the welfare rolls, those declines are eclipsed by the fact that no one is tracking what happens to the families that leave the system.

title: Andrea Hirshon, Stephen Spaulding 4th
description: Andrea Lynn Hirshon, the daughter of Judith K. West of St. James, N.Y., and Kenneth S. Hirshon of Stamford, Conn., was married on Friday evening to Stephen Van Rensselaer Spaulding 4th, the son of Susan Barr Kingsbury of Munsonville, N.H., and Mr. Spaulding 3d of San Francisco. The Rev. Joyce L. Gioia, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: A Vintage Locomotive Will Propel Foliage Tours
description: America's last commercially built steam locomotive will return to the rails, traveling between Hoboken and Port Jervis, N.Y., on the first three weekends of next month.

title: When These Two Chat, an Era Is Speaking
description: JULIE HARRIS WAS SPEAKING WITH THE urgency of a heroine in a Victorian melodrama who recalls being snatched, at the very last minute, from the path of a speeding train.

title: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER -- The Bargains and the Blowouts; Rome: Do as the Romans do -- have a stylish party
description: It's fine to be romantic in Rome, but it can also be expensive. A deluxe double at a five-star hotel can cost upward of $500 a night and drinks at the best-known rooftop bars $15 a shot. But with the help of a stronger dollar -- now above 1,700 lire, the best rate since the early 1990's -- here are a few ways to celebrate your Roman holiday without going broke, and do it in style.

title: Andrew Weil, Shaman, M.D.
description: Dr. Weil doesn't puzzle me, but the article about him did. As a professional therapist who works with psychiatric patients and substance abusers, I have seen firsthand the power of reuniting mind, body and spirit to effectuate healing. I didn't understand the article's need to trivialize Dr. Weil. He was portrayed as a latter-day hippie who went to South America to ''fondle'' plants. The article ended by emphasizing that Dr. Weil believes we should all walk around in a ''stoned'' state of mind.

title: Maastricht's Worldly Ways
description: TWENTY years ago, I thought of Maastricht as a weekend getaway, a vestige of the Burgundian Empire tucked in the foot of the Netherlands between Belgium and Germany, a small, pleasure-loving city noted for brass bands, medieval churches and squares lined with bursting-at-the-seams cafes.

title: TOBACCO ACCORD, ONCE APPLAUDED, IS ALL BUT BURIED
description: Just three months ago, state attorneys general and tobacco industry executives announced a dramatic $368.5 billion legislative proposal that was to mark a turning point in the nation's decades-old conflict over smoking and health. But today, the proposed tobacco settlement is all but dead. And what, if anything, will rise in its place remains the subject of intense debate.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 10 with an article about hill stations in India misidentified the church shown. It was the Margaret Eddy Memorial Chapel at the Kodaikanal International School, not the Mount Zion Lutheran Church.

title: Fast Track on Treaties Leaves Labor in the Dust; Secret Talks in Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: A Kinder, Gentler Gallery
description: THE work of celebrity artists selling at Andre Emmerich or Leo Castelli can seem incomprehensibly expensive. But good art can be found for less than $1,000 -- sometimes less than $100 -- in many New York galleries. And it's not impossible to find dealers who are happy to give first-time buyers all the help they need, even if they walk in off the street wearing something other than a designer suit.

title: Substation at Park Entrance Called Substandard, Visually
description: To many residents of Central Park West's white-glove buildings, local historic preservationists and ordinary park enthusiasts, the electrical transformer that was installed at the 86th Street entrance to the park 18 months ago is a visual affront. Put in by the Central Park Conservancy to power the Great Lawn's irrigation system, the substation is 6 feet high, 10 feet long and 6 feet wide and is surrounded by a chain-link fence.

title: Israel's Uneasy State
description: As Madeleine Albright has bluntly acknowledged, her visit here last week was not a success. There are to be meetings between Israeli and Palestinian leaders in Washington, but you have to be a wild optimist to expect much from these in the present circumstances. The Secretary of State may well feel that her lengthy previous disinclination to imitate her predecessor's ceaseless jetting in and out of here was justified in the event.

title: Sports Stars As Good Sports: Lessons From the Field
description: STEVE YOUNG doesn't usually find himself in predicaments like this. But here he is, the San Francisco 49ers quarterback, the epitome of athletic grace, with arms flailing and knees angled out as he totters back and forth on a unicycle, showing off a childhood skill and adding new meaning to the term unflappable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUTTLE, LLOYD B.
description: TUTTLE-Lloyd B. 72. September 9, 1997. Music Department Chairman for 35 years, The Hill School, Pottstown, PA. Memorial Service, Hill Chapel, October 26, 3 PM.

title: Dr. Jerry Jacobs, 66, Juvenile Arthritis Expert
description: Jerry C. Jacobs, a pediatrician and leading authority on rheumatoid arthritis in children, died on Sept. 6 at his home in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. He was 66 and also had a home in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDBERG, MINDEL RUTH, M.D.
description: ERDBERG-Mindel Ruth, M.D. Born Sept. 20, 1916, died Sept. 11, 1997. Adored mother of Beverly (Stephen) Vosko, cherished grandmother of Jennifer and Michelle. Distinguished psychiatrist. Graduated medical school Lausanne U., Switzerland 1942. Res. Mt. Sinai Hospital 1944-45. Diplomate Am. Board Psychiatry and Neurology. Sr. Psychiatrist Creedmoor Psychiatric Center 1972-1983. Private practice Woodmere, NY 1983-1996. Attending Long Island Jewish, Franklin General Hospital, South Nassau Community Hospital, St. John's Episcopal Hospital, Peninsula Hospital. Contact family at 713-464-0055 after the 15th.

title: Ideas & Trends; Making Do Without A Devil's Advocate
description: OF all the departments within the Vatican bureaucracy, few have had as intriguing a name as the ''Devil's Advocate,'' the legal office whose duty it was to play the adversary whenever Rome considered a candidate for canonization.

title: After Movies, Unwanted Dalmatians
description: In the movie, the Dalmatians are cute and fun. But at home, they shed, tend to snap and sometimes bite, and often do not particularly like children, former owners complain.

title: Travel Pain, Stock Gain
description: Mutual funds that own big stakes in airline companies had good reason to cheer last week.

title: Tightly Strung
description: DOUBLE FAULT

title: Tom Morris
description: Morris, a former philosophy professor turned corporate consultant, is the author of If Aristotle Ran General Motors.

title: Connecticut Q&A: John Barracato; Fires, on Purpose and in Carelessness
description: FOR nearly 40 years, John Barracato has been preoccupied, almost obsessed, he says, with the cause of fires, whether it be arson fraud, arson for reasons of revenge, accidental or the work of a pathological fire setter.

title: Juicy American Fare in Large Portions
description: ITALIAN family-style dining has made its mark on Long Island. These restaurants, with their heaping platters meant to be shared by two or more, dot the island. The best of them are the La Violas in Cedarhurst and Syosset.

title: Beyond the Ivory Tower, a Sabbatical Is a Valued Perk
description: RICHARD F. ZIEGLER, a Manhattan lawyer, just came back from the Rockies. And Mike Phillips, the chief executive of an investment management firm near Seattle, just returned from Europe.

title: Anchoring History
description: THEY gathered dust in a photo stock library, but the photographs by Edward Levick chronicled a time when the Port of New York was the center of the nation's commercial life.

title: Jane Jacobs, Richard Lowe 3d
description: Jane Elizabeth Jacobs, a vice president at Mullin Consulting, executive benefits consultants in Los Angeles, and Justice Richard Bryant Lowe 3d of State Supreme Court in Manhattan were married yesterday in Solomon, Kan. Msgr. James Hake performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; My Dog and Rabbit: Save Them!
description: SATURDAY, 6 P.M. I head into the backyard to replenish our rabbit's food and water. I call to him, expecting him to hop to the front of the cage. No response. In fact, he's nowhere to be seen. I circle the hutch and discover that the back wall crumbled in last night's storm leaving one side of the cage completely open. Ariel is gone!

title: SOAPBOX; When New York's Finest Aren't
description: I LIVE in midtown Manhattan, in an East Side neighborhood that's noisy but generally safe enough for us to refer fondly to our local police precinct as ''Camp Beverly Hills.''

title: Rebecca Miller, James Ffrench
description: Rebecca Suzanne Miller, an associate editor at Fodor's Travel Publications in New York, was married yesterday to James Andrew St. Clair Ffrench, a vice president of Christie's, the New York auction house. The Rev. Charles D. Monts, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Adirondack Community Church in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Clare Williams, Peter Dougherty
description: Clare Yvette Williams and Peter Dyer Dougherty are to be married today in Manhattan. The Rev. Michael Conway is to perform the ceremony at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, CAROL
description: MOSKOWITZ-Carol. On September 10, 1997. Beloved wife of Herbert. Loving mother of Robert and Marlon. Visiting Saturday 7 to 9PM. Service Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to the American Cancer Society.

title: City Prepares For Memorial To Diana In the Park
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city was preparing to handle more than 12,000 people today at a memorial for Diana, Princess of Wales, in the North Meadow in Central Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIETHELM, MARGARET W.
description: DIETHELM-Margaret W., 90, of Delray Beach, FL., and formerly of Locust Valley, Long Island, NY, passed away Sunday, September 7, 1997. Mrs. Diethelm is the daughter of the late Arthur E. and Florence C. Whitney of New York. She is survived by a daughter, Margaret D. Foster of Honolulu, HI.; and a sister, Helen W. Brown of Huntington, Long Island, New York. Funeral services were held September 10, 1997 in Delray Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. For more information Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach,

title: Milken's Honorees, but Not His Proteges
description: IN the 1980's, when Michael R. Milken was earning hundreds of millions of dollars from his innovative use of high-yield securities known as junk bonds, a common question at cocktail parties was, ''What would you do if you had Mike Milken's money?''

title: From Closet to Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: Going to the Courts To Get School Test Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: Bilbao
description: For as long as large-scale tourism has existed, visitors to the Spanish Basque country searching for a city to explore have ignored Bilbao and headed for San Sebastian. There is an excellent reason for this. San Sebastian, with its striking ocean views, is a postcard. Bilbao, with its grimy apartment blocks, warehouses and disquietingly dark river full of unidentified floating objects, is not.

title: From Bald Eagles to Housing Starts
description: There were 12 bald eagle nests in New Jersey in 1995, up from only one in 1975, and 7,988,000 people last year, up 3.3 percent from 1990.

title: From Peace Process To Police Process
description: The Imam of the sterile, dust-covered west Bank town of Dura is a knife-thin 38-year-old ascetic known to his followers simply as Sheik Nayef. He is a graduate in Sharia (Islamic law) of the University of Jordan, and he is also a leader of Hamas, the Islamic fundamentalist movement. Dura, like Hebron, its neighbor to the west, is the sort of place that accords honor to Palestinian men who choose to end their lives -- and the lives of as many Jews as technically feasible -- by detonating nail-packed bombs strapped to their bodies.

title: Scold War; Yelling At the Little Red Menace
description: Testing fourth graders in reading and eighth graders in math, however important, doesn't sound like that incendiary an idea. But the rancorous debate over President Clinton's proposed national test, which was alternately depicted as part of a Federal takeover of education, a pathway toward a dumbed-down curriculum and a sure way to stigmatize and penalize ethnic minorities and the poor, was a vivid reminder of just how impossibly politicized the national educational debate has become.

title: MARKET WATCH ; Default: The Risk Bondholders Forgot
description: The biggest international financial news so far in 1997 has been the collapse of the Thai baht. Asian countries that had led the world in growth are in trouble, with implications for international competitiveness and for corporate profits around the world.

title: The High Cost Of Hope
description: In ''The High Cost of Hope,'' Michael Lewis makes several salient points regarding our misplaced hope in a C.E.O.'s ability to save his corporation (The Capitalist, Aug. 24). My favorite is how little impact on the price of stock a C.E.O. truly exerts. However, his example of an ''outsider'' -- George M.C. Fisher -- hired to save a business does not bear scrutiny well.

title: For These Volunteers, It's Always Christmas in April
description: THE last time t Irma Jones of Roosevelt had hot water running to her washing machine was Christmas. ''The pipes froze,'' she said, her breath labored as she breathed through an oxygen tube attached to her nose. ''I couldn't afford to fix it. So I washed in cold water.'' For nine months.

title: Albright Asks Arab States To Attend Summit Talks
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that he was hopeful the situation in the Middle East would improve enough for American-sponsored regional economic summit talks to go on as planned in Qatar in mid-November.

title: After 7 Years, a Residence
description: After seven years of delays and political squabbles, an ambitious new residence for homeless people with AIDS, replete with a roof garden and Ralph Lauren bedding, opened its doors last week, although with a volunteer staff, questions about the owner's finances and a lingering city contract dispute.

title: Play Ball!
description: Sometimes it seems as if every town in New Jersey is trying to woo a minor-league baseball team.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: A Cab Called Reliable

title: Phffft!
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Down by 6-0 in 9th With One Strike Left, Mets Pull Out a Victory
description: The Mets were dead and buried. They were done, plain and simple. They were ready for next year, beginning right now. But then came one of the more improbable bottom of the ninths in the team's 36 seasons.

title: Sports of The Times; Where Are The Wives' Pendants?
description: AS if tonight's return of Bill Parcells to the Foxboro home of the New England Patriots wasn't enough for the marquee, a subplot has developed. Call it the case of the wives' missing diamond pendants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, KATHARINE VAN NEST POST
description: GARDNER-Katharine van Nest Post. On September 2, age ninetyone. Survived by her children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren. Librarian. A woman of great intellect and boundless love. We will miss her. Donations to Doctors Without Borders, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, RONALD
description: ROSENFELD-Ronald. There will be a memorial service on Friday, September 19, at 3:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, at 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

title: Andrew Weil, Shaman, M.D.
description: In Larissa MacFarquhar's article, reference is made to Dr. Weil's ''East Coast Jewish accent.'' Such a reference is both irrelevant and inappropriate. What does his supposed Jewish accent (an accent that was undetectable to those of us who heard him recently on PBS) have to do with his competence or the validity of his claims? These remarks come across as a gratuitous ethnic slur, and, in the case of Dr. Weil, are untrue.

title: Getting Opal Caples to Work
description: My response to the welfare recipient featured in your article who says, ''I just don't always want to work'' is: ''Fine. If you don't work, you don't eat.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Football as Pulp Drama
description: Despite all the hoopla over tonight's nationally televised football game between the New York Jets and the New England Patriots, the Super Bowl is not yet at hand. But there are enough big egos and small subtexts here to make it a very interesting evening.

title: Judge Has His Own Take On Sentencing Formulas
description: It was one day last spring that Solomon Halberstam, the Grand Rabbi of the Bobov Hasidim, made an emotional appeal to a Federal judge in Manhattan on behalf of an Orthodox Jew about to be sentenced in an insurance fraud case.

title: Sports of The Times; No Dire Straits for King Football
description: OH, my goodness, Alexi Lalas is actually winning! That was my knee-jerk response -- exclamation mark and all -- upon realizing that the National Football League had hired a marketing executive named Sara Levinson away from MTV.

title: A Web Guide To Radio
description: To The Editor:

title: Children's Books
description: ANIMAL DADS

title: Susan Spratt, David Tendler
description: Dr. Susan Elizabeth Spratt and Dr. David Andrew Tendler, physicians at Beth Israel-Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, are to be married today. The Rev. John Spratt Bacot, a Presbyterian minister and a cousin of the bride, will perform the ceremony with Rabbi David M. Zielonka at Hightower, a historic house in Brattonsville, S.C.

title: Dora, Not Leonora
description: To the Editor:

title: Declarations of Independence
description: Required Reading

title: Sampling Is (a) Creative Or (b) Theft?
description: IT WAS EARLY 1991, AND TWO SONGS RULED THE radio airwaves: ''U Can't Touch This'' by M. C. Hammer and ''Ice Ice Baby'' by Vanilla Ice. The popularity of both songs was not necessarily due to the rapping skills of their performers. It was due to the fact that both melodies were sampled from familiar pop tunes, ''Superfreak'' by Rick James and ''Under Pressure'' by Queen and David Bowie, respectively. At the time, these derivative hits seemed to threaten the legitimacy of rap, which had always prided itself on its street credibility and a refusal to pander to popular taste. Consequently, the artists, justly or not, were soon mocked out of existence.

title: Miss Austen Regrets
description: JANE AUSTEN

title: Japan, Korea and 1597: A Year That Lives in Infamy
description: When they invaded Korea 400 years ago, Japanese samurai warriors brought back priceless porcelain, ingenious metal type for printing and noses and ears hacked off the corpses of tens of thousands of Koreans.

title: From John Harvard To Ramses II; Tokyo
description: Hachiko's statue presides over a plaza at Shibuya, one of the busiest subway stations in Tokyo, and is a popular meeting place for young people. A member of Japan's own Akita breed of dog, he sits, wisely and alertly scanning the crowd, looking for someone.

title: Cecil Lyon, Matthew Sanford
description: Cecil Gillet Lyon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Lyon of New York, was married last evening to Matthew Schuyler Sanford, the son of Wendy C. Sanford of Cambridge, Mass., and Alfred F. Sanford 3d of Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. James Burns, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: TELEVISION; Sexy Orphans With Great Demographics
description: CHRIS KEYSER REMEMBERS the meeting vividly. It was the fall of 1994, about four weeks into the first season of ''Party of Five,'' the Fox drama series that he and Amy Lippman, his writing partner, had created, following the emotional struggle of five orphaned siblings, ages 1 to 24, to stay together.

title: Correction: Patriot American's Hotel Properties
description: A map last Sunday with an article about two fast-growing hotel companies overstated the number of hotels managed by one of them, Patriot American Hospitality, and located some hotels incorrectly.

title: Fast Forward; Legal Eagles
description: Jessica dubroff died 17 months ago as a very young passenger in the left seat of a Cessna airplane. The pilot, in the right seat, took off in a driving rainstorm, in the thin air of an unfamiliar high-altitude airport, with the fuel-air mixture improperly set and the plane carrying almost a hundred pounds over its certified weight limit. Without ever reaching a safe airspeed, he made a climbing right turn in rough air, lost control of the plane and plunged into the ground. He, Jessica and Jessica's father, in the back seat, were all killed instantly.

title: Edward Feldman, Anastacia Leach
description: Anastacia Elizabeth Leach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Brian Leach of Boston, is to be married today in Shelburne, Vt., to Edward Bennett Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Mazur Feldman of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk is to perform the ceremony at Shelburne Farms.

title: Gender Studies 101
description: To the Editor:

title: Backtalk; Venus Ushers in a New Era, but of What, Exactly?
description: Martina Hingis is an adorable 16-year-old who last week won her third Grand Slam tennis event this season. She would have won four, but a horse stepped on her leg. Her attractive mother watched telegenically as Martina dominated the 17-year-old Venus Williams to win the final of the United States Open.

title: Coming of Age
description: A HISTORY OF YOUNG PEOPLE in the west Volume 1: Ancient and Medieval Rites of Passage. Volume 2: Stormy Evolution to Modern Times. Edited by Giovanni Levi and Jean-Claude Schmitt. Volume 1 translated by Camille Naish. Volume 2 translated by Carol Volk. Illustrated. Volume 1, 396 pp. Volume 2, 409 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $35 each.

title: Pennies Under the Bridge: 60-Year-Old Battle Winds Down
description: A 60-year-old battle is coming to an end. The $1.75 one-way toll on the Cross Bay Veterans Memorial Bridge, the only intraborough toll bridge in the city, is to be repealed in the next few weeks, the Mayor and the Governor's office said.

title: Half a Century of Celebrating Barnum
description: WHEN Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the Bridgeport Brass Company, gathered together a group of fellow Bridgeport business executives in 1948 to try to solve some of the city's problems, a cultural phenomenon was born. Now, nearly 50 years later and more than 800 volunteers strong, Mr. Stein kraus's idea has grown into what is known as The Barnum Festival, named after the circus promoter and former Bridgeport Mayor Phineas T. Barnum.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: I Who Have Never Known Men

title: From a Jingle to a New Recording
description: CAPTIVATED by the glamour of the Chicago nightclubs she passed as she walked to her piano lesson, Page Morton Black, then 10, said to herself, ''I want to do something at night.'' So when she went to Manhattan to follow her star, she began singing and playing the piano at a number of hotels including the Pierre, the Sherry-Netherland and the Vanderbilt into the wee hours.

title: Azerbaijan Has Reason To Swagger: Oil Deposits
description: When President Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan arrived in Washington in August he was given a welcome that might have seemed out of place for the leader of a small and remote former Soviet republic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAMPI, THOMAS S.
description: CAMPI-Thomas S., of LI and NYC. The children of Thomas wish to thank all family and friends for their kind expression of sympathy. Robert, Jeannine, Petey, Tom and Tim

title: SOAPBOX; The Other Rates Issue
description: MUCH front-page newspaper ink has been devoted of late to the important issue of New Jersey's high auto insurance rates, and the battle among the state's gubernatorial candidates to be credited with the best auto insurance reform policies. Yet buried in the business sections, an even bigger drain on the economic resources of New Jersey is exposed: the skyrocketing electricity bills stemming from decades of reliance on expensive and unreliable nuclear power. To date, neither the Republican nor the Democratic candidate has proposed a comprehensive plan to put a stop to uneconomic nuclear investment and chart a course toward a clean, safe, reliable and affordable energy future.

title: Army Plans to Require Women To Meet Higher Fitness Goals
description: The Army is expected to impose slightly tougher fitness standards for women, partly as a result of a new internal report that found a widespread complaint among male soldiers that women are held to less demanding standards for physical fitness, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Athens Dining, A to Z
description: While reading the elegant new Robert Fagles translation of Homer's ''Odyssey'' just before going to Greece, I was struck by the numerous feasts it recounts. When Odysseus' men are not being turned into swine by Circe or hurtling between Scylla and Charybdis, they quaff honeyed wine and stoke up on white cheeses (feta?), bread (pita?) and bits of sheep, goat or boar meat grilled on skewers (souvlaki?). Here and there they dip into appetizers, forerunners, perhaps, of the now traditional mezedes.

title: From the Ashcan School of Art? An Update for the 90's
description: RUSTY mufflers, irregular pantyhose and empty detergent bottles: these are items usually destined for the scrap heap or the trash can.

title: Where Babette Feasted
description: THE generalizations about Danish food, which is all most people outside Denmark seem to have heard, run to herring, dairy products, open-faced sandwiches and Danish pastry (called Viennese locally). The best-known meal served in Denmark in the last dozen years is the cinematic ''Babette's Feast,'' and indeed it is a commonplace that Danish cooking surrenders to French toward the top of the gastronomic scale. Thanks to my background in archeology, I knew that beer was the national drink: the existence and continuing excellence of the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, one of Europe's most important archeological museums, is owed to the philanthropy of the Carlsberg brewery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEERR, CLINTON JAY
description: SHEERR-Clinton Jay, 50, prominent New Hampshire architect, died Monday, September 8 at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center after a long and heroic struggle with cancer. Loving husband of Deirdre McCrystal Sheerr. Devoted son of Alvin and Vivian Sheerr. Beloved brother of Phyllis Duberstein and Patsy Cardillo. Dearly loved uncle, son-in-law and brother-in-law. The funeral was held on Friday September 12 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Concord, New Hampshire. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Clinton's memory may be made to the New Hampshire Charitable Foundation, 37 Pleasant Street, Concord, New Hampshire 03301.

title: INSIDE
description: Reed Goal: G.O.P. Coalition

title: Michelle Toll, W. A. O'Flanagan
description: Michelle Lynn Toll and William Anthony O'Flanagan, lawyers in New York, were married last evening at the White Elephant Hotel in Nantucket, Mass. Rabbi William Kuhn performed the ceremony.

title: No Mickey Mouse Union Protest at the Ice House
description: Some 50 union members began arriving in TriBeCa at 6:30 last Monday morning, a 20-foot inflated plastic rat by their side. They chanted and whistled, awakening neighborhood residents with the din. The reason? To make the point, said the protest organizer, Mike Hellstrom, that ''nonunion contractors are rats.''

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about twins referred incompletely to Dr. Nancy Segal, who is writing a book on the subject to be published by Dutton. Besides being a twin, she is a professor of psychology at California State University, Fullerton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, LOUIS
description: SCHWARTZ-Louis. On Sept 11, 1997, at his retirement home in Taos, NM. Former resident of Manhasset, NY. Former owner of Port Washington Window Cleaning Corp. Beloved father of M. Norman (Heather) of Clarksville, MD, S. Robert (Ann) of Valparaiso, IN, Kenneth J. of Tres Piedras, NM, and Yetta Belle Balisok of Chicago, IL. Cherished grandfather of Susan Alicia Blake, David Allen Blake, Michael Lawrence Schwartz, David Jacob (Debra) Schwartz, Steven Benjamin Schwartz, Marc Eric Schwartz, Kalman Avraham Balisok, Levi Yitzchok Balisok, Joseph Yaakov Balisok, Merrelle Dvorah Balisok, Esther Chana Balisok, Yocheved Perel Balisok, Scneur Zalman Balisok, Chaya Mushke Balisok, Nechama Dinah Balisok and Shmule Ezial Balisok. Dear great-grandfather of Jade Gabrielle Clayton. Brother of the late Nicholas. Services today, 10 AM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Advice to a Star
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'C' Still Not Sewn on a Jersey
description: Colin Campbell, the Rangers' coach, is getting tired of being asked when he will choose a captain to replace Mark Messier. Campbell said today that he did not expect anyone to wear the ''C'' on the front of his jersey when the Rangers open their nine-game exhibition season Sunday night in Montreal. He is not even sure anyone will wear the ''A'' that usually designates two or three alternate captains.

title: Accenting Grilled Vegetables With an Asian Flavor
description: LOCALLY grown eggplants, peppers and zucchini are still in abundant supply. Add tomatoes and you have ratatouille, that lusty Mediterranean French amalgam of summer's harvest.

title: On the Trail Of Rubens In Antwerp
description: DURING its heyday in the 16th century, Antwerp was one of the richest and largest cities in all Europe, nearly the equal of Paris or London. Its splendid fortified port assured its wealth, attracting artisans who built its magnificent Gothic cathedral and artists like Pieter Bruegel the Elder who amplified its reputation.

title: Why McEnroe?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Alyssa Walden, David Kelman
description: Alyssa Walden, the daughter of Barbara Walden of New York and James A. Walden of Fort Lee, N.J., is to be married today to David Roy Kelman, a son of Arthur J. Kelman of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Susan Kelman. Rabbi Jeff Roth is to perform the ceremony at the John Jay Homestead in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASINDORF, BLANCHE
description: KASINDORF-Blanche. Long time principal of P.S. 8. Beloved Aunt of Steven and Larry. Great-Aunt of Dana and Allison. Services held at Riverside Chapel, Coney Island Avenue and Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, NY. Sunday at 11:30AM.

title: Michele Verni, Bruce Sacerdote
description: Michele Verni, a daughter of Ralph Verni of Sudbury, Mass., and Janet Fund of New York, was married yesterday to Bruce Ian Sacerdote, a son of Carole Sacerdote of Walpole, Mass., and the late Albert Sacerdote. The Rev. David Phreaner, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the top of the mountain at Pats Peak Ski Area in Henniker, N.H.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 62 of The Times Magazine today, about the head of the Palestinian secret police, misstates the location of Dura, a town in the West Bank. It is west of Hebron, not east.

title: The Merits of Air-Powered Tools
description: MENTION power tools and most people think of electric drills, routers and circular saws. These tools have one thing in common: they are all powered by electricity. In addition to electricity, there is another power source for tools, air. The air pressure is generated by a compressor, which in turn is powered by an electric or a gasoline motor.

title: Trading Information
description: IMAGE AND LOGIC

title: Visiting the BBC On Its 75th Anniversary
description: In honor of its 75th anniversary, the BBC will open a new visitor center on Oct. 30 with exhibits, screenings and an interactive radio studio. Called the BBC Experience, the center will be situated in the Art Deco Broadcasting House, close to Oxford Circus, the headquarters since 1932 for BBC Ra dio's network of domestic stations.

title: Noodle Hiatus Leaves Pangs
description: When it opened eight years ago, Ollie's Noodle Shop and Grille on Broadway at 116th Street quickly became a favorite haunt for students and faculty members at Columbia University. At times, it even eclipsed other longtime neighborhood institutions like the funky Tom's restaurant and the West Gate, as the legendary West End bar and grill is now called -- even among those who could not stand the prickly attitude of some waiters.

title: From John Harvard To Ramses II; Cambridge, Mass.
description: If you, like almost every other visitor who passes through Harvard Yard, must have your picture taken with the bookish-yet-hunkish statue of John Harvard, at least know this: The caption of your photo should be, ''You can't trust a Harvard man.''

title: Sarah Bodman, Robert Greenhill Jr.
description: Sarah Hammond Bodman, a daughter of Samuel W. Bodman 3d of Boston and the late Elizabeth L. Bodman, was married yesterday to Robert Foster Greenhill Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Greenhill of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Peter G. Chase performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Newton Lower Falls, Mass.

title: At the Meadowlands Track, Horses Now Run in the Sun
description: Thoroughbreds at the Meadowlands Race Track began running in the daytime for the first time last week as the Sports and Exposition Authority moved the Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday race start to 12:45 P.M. from the traditional 7:30 P.M.

title: A Section of Cracow Restores Its Jewish Past
description: INTEREST in Jewish culture is growing in Poland, and this revival is nowhere clearer than in Kazimierz, the former Jewish quarter of Cracow. Many of the visitors here are foreigners who come to see Auschwitz, an hour's drive away, and then explore what is left and what is being resuscitated of a once-vibrant district.

title: As Townships Grow, Post Offices Seem Farther Away
description: A simple trip to the post office is not so simple for residents of some South Jersey townships that have experienced unusually rapid population growth, increases in automobile traffic and changes in township boundaries.

title: The Season Is for the Black-Eyed Susan
description: SOME plant hybridists are never willing to leave well enough alone. They often work with native plants to tuck in an earlier flowering component here or a brighter color there. The result is usually dazzling.

title: As East End Recovers From the Season, Locals Breathe Easier
description: BINKY MINETREE remembers the empty feeling as he waved good-bye to his best friend, Peter Elkoff, every Labor Day weekend. Peter, like so many youths who spend their summer on the East End, attended high school in New York City, and Binky was once again faced with the feeling of being left behind.

title: Beethoven Featured at 2 Openers
description: BACK-to-back season openers light up Purchase College next weekend, with Beethoven the link between the Westchester Symphony's concert next Saturday at 8 P.M. and the Viennese gala that ushers in Philharmonia Virtuosi's Mainstage Series next Sunday at 3 P.M.

title: Dirty Work
description: Eggs for young America By Katherine L. Hester. 176 pp. Hanover, N.H.: A Middlebury/Bread Loaf Book. University Press of New England. $19.95.

title: Heathcliff Redux
description: HERE ON EARTH

title: An Art-Filled Walkway Opens in Florence
description: Through the end of October, the Vasari Corridor in Florence, usually off limits to tourists, will be accessible as part of a tour that includes the Palazzo Vecchio, the Uffizi Gallery, the Boboli Gardens and the Pitti Palace. Hanging in the corridor, which crosses the Arno River atop the Ponte Vecchio, are some 700 paintings from the 16th through the 20th centuries.

title: Jets Go Through Extreme Measures to Prepare for Patriots
description: The Jets have installed a high-tech security system in their complex and many people in the organization now have their own access codes just to get in the building. It is safe to say that no member of the New England Patriots has the code.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 4/

title: A View and a Presentation in Pound Ridge
description: THE Garden Room, the gem of this inn, remains among the most beautiful dining spots in the county. In any season, the view beyond the glass wall is as pretty as a picture postcard. Right now, diners can enjoy the garden's brilliant blooms etched against dark green hedges, seemingly placed to balance the canvas, the mere corner of a weathered red barn.

title: Susan Norton, A. B. McCormick
description: Susan Catherine Norton, a daughter of Constance M. Norton of Avon, Conn., and Phillip E. Norton of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Borland McCormick, a son of Joan and George A. McCormick of Lancaster, Pa. The Rev. Susan M. Prichard, a Congregational minister, officiated at the First Church of Christ in West Hartford.

title: Changes for Pit-Stop Block That Wants to Be a Destination
description: With stately brownstone buildings and intricate architectural designs, the block on 72d Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues was a symbol of elegance 100 years ago. These days, the block is dotted with fast-food restaurants, a check-cashing store and colorful signs and awnings that advertise everything from shoes to girdles.

title: Domestic Solutions
description: THE WAY WE REALLY ARE

title: Two Opposable Thumbs Down
description: Research chimpanzees raised in captivity often watch television, for pretty much the same reason humans do: they're bored. We arranged for chimps at the New York University Medical Center Laboratory for Experimental Medicine and Surgery in Primates to screen tapes of three new fall sitcoms: NBC's ''Jenny,'' starring Jenny McCarthy; ABC's ''You Wish,'' which features a male genie trying to serve a reluctant divorced mom, and CBS's ''Gregory Hines Show,'' a heartwarming comedy about a widowed dad. Reactions were monitored to find out: Do chimps really pay attention to TV? Do they display actual preferences? And of course: How long will it take them to get tired of ''Jenny''? Here's a look.

title: For the Ultimate Outsider, the Moment Is Now
description: He is a minister without a congregation, a politician without a media consultant. He wants to raise New York City's commuter tax, but he owes tens of thousands of dollars in state and Federal taxes. He has long been an anti-establishment street demonstrator, yet he craves political legitimacy.

title: September 7-13; A New, Braver Version Of a South African's Death
description: In an inquest 20 years ago into Steve Biko's death, the South African officers who fatally beat the anti-apartheid leader strutted like men above the law and told a preposterous story: a wild Mr. Biko had attacked them for no reason.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLLTON, JOHN J.
description: CARROLLTON-John J. Of Manhahattan. On August 30, 1997. Sadly missed by Lois, brother William (Doreen) and their children William, Steve, John, James and Doreen Moog. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his memory to Cancer Care, 1180 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036.

title: 'Stop for Octroi'
description: To the Editor:

title: Cone Frets Over Hurt Shoulder
description: David Cone is still not ready to pitch because of tendinitis in his right shoulder and that is incredibly exasperating to him. Cone is unable to say that he will start again this season and that is incredibly frightening to the Yankees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITMAN, MARIAN COGGESHALL
description: PITMAN-Marian Coggeshall, July 12, 1905-August 25, 1997. Survived by husband, Lorraine Farquhar Pitman of Bloomfield, Conn.; daughter, Sandra Janie Pitman of El Cajon, CA; brother, Dr. Bayard Coggeshall and wife Mary Achilles of Basking Ridge, NJ. Amongst many volunteer activities she was Connecticut Co-Chairman for fund raising to build Lincoln Center. A private burial took place on August 28, 1997 in Simsbury, CT.

title: Soccer's U.S. Focus Is on the Young
description: JOE PROVEY sounded like a father recollecting the birth of a child as he pinned down the exact moment the idea for a children's soccer magazine was planted in his head.

title: Courtney Smith, Matthew Tuck
description: Courtney Ann Smith, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas Wilcox Smith of Worton, Md., was married yesterday to Matthew Marshall Tuck, a son of Linda Barnes Tuck and Edward Hallam Tuck, both of New York. The Rev. Brewster Beach performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Peace Corps Worker From Pound Ridge Tells of Muslim Life
description: WHEN Juliet Sorensen stepped outside her mud hut in southern Morocco to sit on her steps, it was not long before the village women would insist she come to dinner or spend the night. ''Since it is totally unheard of for Moroccan women to live alone, they felt sorry for me,'' Ms. Sorensen said. ''I had 10 mothers.''

title: Once Again, Airlines Are Making Beds
description: The next competitive battle in the international skies is going to be fought in the bedroom.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; Sibling Role Reversal In Romantic Plots
description: REMEMBER the last time you saw Abe and Miriam Goldman at the Forum Theater here? Their daughter, Sarah, a teacher, had hired Bob Schroeder, an actor, as her pretend-Jewish boyfriend. Sarah's beau stratagem was meant to mollify her parents after she had been dating a gentile, and to explain the play's title, ''Beau Jest.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAHM, HERBERT
description: RAHM-Herbert. The Brotherhood of Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the passing of our dear friend Herbert Rahm. Herb was a devoted member of the Brotherhood, Past Brotherhood President and Honorary Brotherhood President for life. He devoted himself to interfaith understanding as Chair of Jewish Chatauqua. His untiring efforts on behalf of Brotherhood and Chatauqua will serve as an inspiration to his friends and a commemoration of his memory.

title: Pomp Pushes the Poorest From Mother Teresa's Last Rites
description: Mother Teresa, who came to India as a teen-age religious novice almost seven decades ago and died here last week a national hero and international icon, was laid to rest today after a funeral largely closed to the poor she had devoted her life to helping.

title: The Times Is Adding Weekday Sections and Color
description: Tomorrow, The New York Times will introduce the broadest changes in its weekday form and format since the mid-1970's. The changes include later news reports, more complete sports results, new sections, and photographs, illustrations and advertisements in color.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MONUMENTAL ART

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, DR. STANLEY (STEVE) J.
description: BRODY-Dr. Stanley (Steve) J., on Sept. 11, 1997 in La Jolla, CA. He was 79. Dr. Brody was Prof. Emeritus of Rehabilitation Medicine in Psychiatry, Univ. of Pennsylvania and of the Wharton School of Business. He authored first texts on rehabilitation and the aged. Among his awards, Dr. Brody was recipient of the Key and Donald P. Kent Awards for Excellence in Gerontology. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Elaine, daughter Laurel Karpman of Phoenix, son Peter of San Diego and four granddaughters. Donations: The Stanley J. Brody Memorial Fund The Gerontological Society of America, 1275 K St NW Suite 350, Washington, DC 20005-4006.

title: Spain's Serene, Secret Ubeda
description: We have driven through miles and unchanging, unpopulated miles of olive groves; from the air, this part of Spain looks like a vast tufted chenille quilt (the tufts are olive trees). ''The lands are/sun drenched/wide slopes, distant hills/of olive trees embroidered!'' says the poet Antonio Machado.

title: Amory Armstrong, Peter Spizzirri
description: Amory Augustus Armstrong, a daughter of Whitney B. Armstrong and Thomas N. Armstrong 3d of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Eliot Spizzirri, a son of Lucy F. Greene of Greenwich, Conn., and Richard D. Spizzirri of Aspen, Colo. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: When Deli Was Just That
description: Thirty-two years is a long time for a storefront in New York, but on the changing streets of Chelsea, it's an eternity. At their grocery and delicatessen on Seventh Avenue near 22d Street, the Rosenbaum brothers, Sol and Mendel, are hanging on to a small slice of pre-gourmet takeout New York that was established by their father, Jack, in 1965. Jack Rosenbaum knew plenty about hanging on. A Polish Jew, he survived Auschwitz during World War II.

title: UP AND COMING: Gillian Wearing; Arriving in New York After Taking Off in London: Video Maker With a Taste for Secrets
description: THEY'RE KNOWN AS BRIGHT YOUNG Things. They trained at London's cutting-edge Goldsmith's College. They inhabit lofts in seedy, ergo trendy, East London. They show their work at Chisenhale, a converted propeller factory with immense empty spaces suitable for their Brit-pop installations. And their idea of art is famously to fill a room up with rice, dangle silver cutlery over the White Cliffs of Dover, embroider the names of their lovers onto fabric and -- in the best-known expression by their best-known member, Damien Hirst -- suspend dead beasts in formaldehyde.

title: Teen-agers and Marijuana; Scaring Them Straight Has Lost Its Edge
description: THE quarrel gets played out daily in thousands of families. Stay away from marijuana, the exasperated parent warns; it will mess up your future. The teen-ager retorts: But you tried it and it didn't hurt you.

title: Snappy Style and Something Scrumptious
description: RESTAURATEUR Richard Rosenthal's Maxes may not have cornered the market, but in the Hartford area they stand out as purveyors of very good, well-priced Italian fare served in smart but casual surroundings.

title: Lives; Pet Heaven
description: We buried Hampy the other day. We can't remember exactly which Hampy he is -- the third, fourth or fifth. He died naturally, in his sleep, as we like to say in our house, in which the death of hamsters is a fairly common occurrence. But who really knows?

title: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER -- The Bargains and the Blowouts; Madrid: Soar over the city in bespoke pearls
description: Spanish women never stopped wearing pearls, whatever the diktats of the fashion moment. One reason is that they are not shy about their jewelry and another is Spain's own important pearl industry. Majorica pearls, hand-made on the island of Majorca, rank among the finest of the simulated varieties. Because Majoricas are coated with organic materials, the uninitiated can find it hard to tell them from the real thing. And with pearls back in style, this is the moment to expand one's collection or pick up some fine gifts.

title: Setting Sail for Toledo And Milwaukee
description: Cruise passengers who are bored by island ports and balmy beaches may be intrigued by a sailing across the Great Lakes this month on the Columbus, which will dock at Chicago, Milwaukee and Toledo, in addition to Montreal and the Ontario ports of Sault Ste. Marie, Thunder Bay, Toronto and Port Colborne.

title: ONLY FOR THE VERY LONELY
description: ''There's no way this can compete with the real thing,'' says Matt McMullen, ''but it can fulfill a deep void in someone's life.'' McMullen, 28, is the creator of Real Doll, a next-generation, full-size adult love toy that is chillingly lifelike. Made from high-grade silicone rubber and engineered with the mobility of Malibu Skipper, Real Doll characters like Natasha (pictured), Nina and Stacy have been turning heads recently in advertisements on the World Wide Web. McMullen claims that his original intent was simply to create art -- a movable sculpture -- and share pictures of it on line, and that he went into business only after being flooded with E-mails asking if the dolls were''anatomically correct'' and for sale. They are and they are. Cost: $4,000 plus, depending on which ''options'' you choose. Next up: Real Doll guys, so no one will feel left out.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry
description: ALMOST NO MEMORY By Lydia Davis. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $21.

title: Amy Powers And Todd Harris
description: Amy Lynne Powers, a lyricist and songwriter, is to be married today to J. Todd Harris, a film producer. Rabbi Liza Stern is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 17 about differences in performance between variable annuities and their related mutual funds misstated the amount by which expenses reduce annuity returns. Expenses for the average variable annuity reduce its return by about two percentage points a year, not several. A variable-annuity portfolio associated with the Hartford Capital Appreciation fund, discussed in the article, has expenses of 1.89 percent, versus 1.45 percent for the fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SURBECK, L. HOMER
description: SURBECK-L. Homer. A retired litigation partner in Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP, died on September 5th, at his home in Atherton, California. He was 94. Mr. Surbeck was born October 8, 1902, in Jasper, Minnesota. He graduated first in his class from Yale Law School in 1927 and was selected to be Supreme Court Chief Justice William Howard Taft's law clerk. Two years later he became an associate of Hughes, Schurman & Dwight, where he researched law for future Supreme Court Chief Justice Charles Evan Hughes. Surbeck became a partner in the firm in 1934 and, in 1937, a founding partner in the firm that would become Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP. Mr. Surbeck established a reputation as a master of developing legal theories. Among his highprofile clients were Alcoa, Ford Motor Company and Merck & Company. ''Homer was always a lawyer's lawyer,'' commented Robert J. Sisk, Hughes Hubbard's Chairman. ''Whenever a partner needed a workable legal theory to sustain a client's position, he or she would usually turn to Homer. All of us who had the privilege of working with Homer will miss him greatly.'' Dedicated to motivating students to better their lives, Mr. Surbeck gave close to 1,000 scholarships to those seeking higher education in many schools. His ''Success on the Job'' address was read into the Congressional Record in 1957. He was also the author of ''The Success Formula That Really Works'' (1986), now in its seventh printing. In 1963 South Dakota School of Mines, Homer's alma mater, named its new student center the ''Surbeck Center.'' In recent years Mr. Surbeck wrote and lectured on the topic of how to apply religious principles to daily living and was active in Dr. Norman Vincent Peale's Foundation for Christian Living. He was a recipient of the Yale Medal and the Horatio Alger Award. Surbeck is survived by his wife, Margaret.

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing on Sept. 7 for ''Filumena: A Marriage Italian Style'' misstated the telephone number to call for tickets. Tickets for the play, which begins previews next month at Theater Four, can be purchased through the Blue Light Theater Company at (212) 265-8147.

title: Andrew Weil, Shaman, M.D.
description: One reason Dr. Weil is not respected by the general medical community is his truncated postgraduate medical education. Dr. Weil's formal medical training ended with internship. His lack of advanced training severely impairs his understanding of the state of the art in current medical practice and leads him to oversimplify complex clinical issues, particularly in psychosomatic medicine.

title: Backtalk; Accept It, America: There Is an 'I' in Tennis
description: Tennis, unlike baseball, basketball or football, is not a team sport. It is a family sport. Your immediate family is your primary supporting cast, not your teammates or the players in the locker room.

title: OUT THERE; Dancing Into the Realm of Fantasy
description: THE Fontainebleau Hilton is a monument to excess. Enormous chandeliers cascade like rhinestone waterfalls over a giant oval lobby glittering with neon and brass. Up the broad marble staircase, behind the double doors of the Grand Ballroom on this September evening, the scene is appropriately fantastic.

title: Trial by Air
description: FLIGHT OF THE GIN FIZZ

title: Books in Brief: Fiction and Poetry; Phrasemaker in the City
description: A mother's big hands are like ''careful shovels.'' A sprig of freesia is ''cake-smelling.'' A confused little girl feels her head ''is slivering on the inside.'' You're tempted to cull a glossary of phrases from DON'T ERASE ME (Houghton Mifflin, $20), Carolyn Ferrell's first collection of stories, but her book is much more than poetic plums. In fact, it's intimate in the way you used to hope a good book could be, until you were disappointed once too often by shock tactics masquerading as literature. Ferrell, formerly the director of a family literacy program in the South Bronx, deftly drops her readers into another world -- allowing us to eavesdrop on the inner life of the inner-city child. In ''Proper Library,'' for example, we meet Lorrie, short for Lawrence, a gay black teen-ager who has to ''keep on moving'' and ''trust my smart'' to get past the cruelty of others. ''Country of the Spread Out God'' offers great Jamaican patois (''I doan recinnize yu brash debbils,'' Auntie angrily tells the children she raised in America). It's also a he-said, she-said story of love unrequited and rechannelled. (''I want him to care enough to want to kill me,'' as the 16-year-old narrator puts it.) In ''Tiger-Frame Glasses,'' a girl named Glory weaves wish-it-were-so stories about her elementary school classmates, who are heart-twistingly mean to her in real life. (In Glory's fantasies, they ''was all big strong girl students'' who are ''Boy Smart'' and are ''always going round not hurting old people . . . but helping them.'') And then there's the title story, a diary working backward in time that traces one woman's road to becoming H.I.V. positive. As Glory observes elsewhere, ''Look for the genuine-ality of the thing.'' It's right here. Katharine Whittemore

title: New York Gangs Mimic California Original
description: The Bloods of Lenox Avenue were milling about, drinking beer and smoking on a quiet Harlem night. One of them, William, pulled up his sleeve to reveal a triangle of three dots that had been burned into his right shoulder with a cigarette. Then his friend Chelsea pulled up his shirt and bared his shoulder, with three similar scars.

Zuckerman, Chairman of the Departments of Orthopaedic Surgery of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute and NYU Medical Center. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Lee, sons Nathan, Howard and Joseph, grandchildren and to the entire family. William A. Perlmuth, Chairman of the Board Victor H. Frankel, M.D., President John N. Kastanis, FACHE, Chief Executive Officer

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on Aug. 24 about competing proposals, from the Volunteers of America and the Broadway Housing Development Fund Company, to buy a former single-room-occupancy hotel at 165th Street and Broadway in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the bids. They were not identical. The Volunteers of America made a bid of $2,600,000; Broadway Housing bid $2,550,000 but also agreed to cover the building's carrying costs until the closing. The Volunteers of America also agreed to an earlier closing date and had financing immediately available.

title: Andrew Weil, Shaman, M.D.
description: Larissa MacFarquhar misses the most important part when she states: ''Weil likes to think of his remedies as more humble and less invasive than conventional ones, since his involve ordinary things like plants and food rather than technology and prescription drugs. But his vision is, in its own way, rather grandiose, transforming medicine from something you make use of on rare occassions into something that comes to inform almost everything you do.'' If you would rather pop a few pills than change your life style into a healthy one, it may seem grandiose at first. But once you get used to it, it's almost as effortless as breathing, much less expensive and highly effective.

title: Food; The Way to Marcella's Heart ...
description: Victor Hazan is leaning over a mountain of blue-black mussels in an open-air market in Venice. Even as he sniffs, his gaze has moved on to tiny Adriatic shrimp and baby artichokes, basil and spring greens -- distraction being a way of life in Venice.

title: In Gangs, Youths Say They Find Quick Route to Respect
description: William and Chelsea and their friends liked to hang out together at a local pool hall on the corner of Lenox Avenue and 119th Street. Some days they would look for jobs, other days they would make a few dollars selling anything from T-shirts and socks to drugs. Most of the group -- there were about 30, and they had been friends for nearly a decade -- had given up their dreams of becoming basketball and baseball stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAFF, SONYA
description: STAFF-Sonya. Peacefully, on September 8, 1997. A remarkable woman. Widow of her beloved Otto; survived by her loving daughter, Eve S. Rosahn; daughter-inlaw, Marion D. Banzhaf; loving relatives, and countless friends. Social activist, feminist, with a passionate interest in Yiddish culture and imbued with a fierce love of life. Contributions may be made to The Sonya Staff Foundation, c/o Rosahn, 467 W. 22 St., Apt. F, New York, NY 10011. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: Who's on the spot to help readers of The New York Times when Justice Sandra Day O'Connor writes the word ''banausic'' into a Supreme Court opinion? Who took the trouble to identify the linguistic winner of the Presidential debate between/among George Bush, Bill Clinton and Ross Perot in 1992? Who has charted the abandonment of the once mighty ''jungle'' and its replacement by the ecologically correct ''rain forest''? Only William Safire, whose ninth collection of About Language columns from The New York Times Magazine now appears as WATCHING MY LANGUAGE: Adventures in the Word Trade (Random House, $27.50). As he has done before, Safire enriches his column material by incorporating in his book the second thoughts, arguments and corrections of lay readers as well as experts (the Lexicographic Irregulars, the Squad Squad, the Poetic Allusion Watch). Nobody's perfect, of course, and some readers are likely to reject the segment entitled ''Let's Kill All the Copy Editors,'' but so far, at least, Safire is not known to have sought to practice what he proposes.

title: Big Tobacco Has Eyed China for a Century
description: To the Editor:

description: TO break down barriers and to demystify appreciating and collecting art, the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan has formed a Collectors Club.

description: A NEW mall under construction just outside this city 35 miles northeast of downtown Atlanta has sparked a broad discussion about attempts to build a town center in an area of scattered subdivisions and small commercial strips.

The composer was Kurt Weill, not Cole Porter.

description: RESPONDING to the rising numbers of business travelers who need to be away from home for a week or longer, extended-stay hotel chains have targeted Westchester as ''under-roomed'' and have proposed the construction of three new hotels in the county. And several more may follow if appropriate sites can be found.

Montgomery and Robert L. Montgomery of New York. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

description: FASANO-Eugene. Remembering you on your second birthday in heaven. You are truly missed and in my heart always. N.G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISH, ELI
description: FISH-Eli. We note with sorrow the passing of a highly respected professsional. As Director of the Hospital's Pharmacy for more than thirty years, he presided over a department that evolved to serve the needs of North Shore as it grew in size and complexity. He was a good friend to many and will be truly missed. Our sincere condolences are extended to his family. John S.T. Gallagher President and CEO and the Physicians and Employees of North Shore University Hospital

title: The Prosecutor Game
description: The torrent of disclosures of political fund-raising abuses by the Democrats last year has no doubt had a numbing effect on many Americans. But if ordinary citizens find it hard to keep track of the shady characters, bank transfers and memos suggesting that Vice President Gore and others knew what they say they did not know, the Justice Department has no excuse. Recent weeks have brought fresh evidence that the department's investigators are either lethargic or over their heads. Even worse, Attorney General Janet Reno's failure to seek an independent counsel to oversee the probe no longer looks like a principled assertion of faith in Justice's career staff. It looks like a political blocking operation to protect President Clinton and Mr. Gore from the vigorous investigation that would be aimed at any other officeholder who had received so much suspicious money.
