description: LAWSUITS

title: From John Harvard To Ramses II; London
description: There are no grander monuments in London than its train stations with names that suggest alluring destinations as surely as the sound of a locomo-tive's whistle -- King's Cross, Victoria, Waterloo. Trouble is, the bold facades are often hidden behind the storefronts that have appeared weedlike at their foundations and curled up across their stone features.

title: Who's Minding The Agents?
description: FORTUNE tellers at state fairs are probably subject to more regulation than sellers of travel: agents, tour operators, bus companies, cruise companies, hotels and others. As Mike Spinelli, president of the American Society of Travel Agents, who heads Merrimac Travel in Lowell, Mass., puts it: ''A travel agent cannot give haircuts in Massachusetts, but a barber there can open a shop called Nails and Sails and sell travel.''

title: How Not To Look Like a Dope In an Art Gallery
description: THE door buzzes open and you step inside. Suddenly the noise of the street is replaced by total quiet. You can hear yourself breathe. In front of you is an empty room with whitewashed walls and shiny wood floors. There are pictures on the walls. They look weird. To your right, behind a counter, sits a devastatingly beautiful woman. She is wearing a chic ensemble and tapping idly at a computer. She does not raise her head. You are the only other person in the room. You stand with your back pressed against the door. A few seconds pass.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 24 about living in Irvington, N.Y., referred incorrectly to Madame C. J. Walker, whose mansion in the community was completed in 1918, the year before her death at 51. Madame Walker was the owner of a hair-care products company, but did not invent the first hair straightener for people of African descent. The article also misstated the given name she used in business. Originally named Sarah Breedlove, she used her husband's initials in business, in the custom of the time, not her given name.

title: Tar Heels Keep Rising With Defeat of Stanford
description: North Carolina has rarely dared to schedule difficult nonconference games during Mack Brown's tenure as head coach. But this season, Brown's 10th at Chapel Hill, the Tar Heels have a good offense, an outstanding defense and high aspirations.

title: After 50 Years of Struggle, Redemption; A Holocaust Museum Is Realized, and With It a Promise by Morgenthau
description: In the fractious five-decade history of New York's Holocaust museum, which opens to the public tomorrow, the year 1993 stands in its founders' memories as the humiliating low point. The museum commission created by Mayor Edward I. Koch was broke, with little to show for the millions of dollars raised but junked architectural plans and angry donors. The New York real estate market on which the museum had bet its future was in collapse.

title: Technologies That Enable The Disabled
description: WITH meetings, paperwork, phone conferences and a travel schedule that eats up three weeks a month, Urban Miyares doesn't get much reading done during the workday. So Mr. Miyares, a San Diego businessman who runs the Disabled Businesspersons Association, rises at 6 most mornings and spends an hour or so catching up on E-mail, reports and business magazines before leaving for the office. In the evening, he picks up where he left off, typically reading into the small hours.

title: 5 Are Arrested in Fatal Stabbing Of Boy, 14, on Subway Platform
description: Three adults and two youths were arrested and charged yesterday in connection with the fatal stabbing of a 14-year-old on a busy subway platform, the police said.

title: Police Wage Award Used Suffolk Scale, Rising Over 20%
description: ON a short list of the richest places in the United States, Nassau County and its exclusive villages virtually always rank near the top. Even in less expensive communities, the average household income is reported to approach $70,000 a year.

Chow of Palo Alto, Calif., is to be married today to Jason Marc Zajac, the son of Marcia and David Zajac of East Brunswick, N.J. Joseph N. Gruber, a commissioner of the Municipal and Superior Court of San Mateo County, Calif., is to officiate at the Byington Winery in Los Gatos, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDERSKY, MAX, M.D.
description: BENDERSKY - Max, M.D., F.A.C.C.P. Age 80 of Tamarac, Florida, formerly of Brightwaters, L.I. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Fryburg). Cherished father of Beatrice of Tamarac, FL., Dr. Ruby of Albuquerque, N.M., and Sarah of Portland, OR. Devoted grandfather of Kim and Ann, son of the late Tess & Sam Bendersky and brother of the late Jacob. Born in Amityville, L.I., graduated NYU in 1937 and received his medical degree from the University of Lausanne, Switzerland in 1942. He interned at Knickerbocker Hospital in New York City. He specialized in Pulmonary diseases serving residencies in Denver, CO., Syracuse, NY, and Patchoque, L.I. He entered in private practice in 1951 until his retirement in 1976 to Tamarac, Florida. He was a physician of intellect and integrity with great compassion for all people. He will be missed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: Susan Adler and James Curtis
description: Susan Lynn Adler, the daughter of Margaret Adler of Washington Township, N.J., and the late J. Jerome Adler, was married in Washington Township on Friday to James McGahren Curtis, the son of Marie Curtis of Montrose, N.Y., and James W. Curtis of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen Duffe performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church.

title: Not if, but When; Naming a Saint Isn't So Simple
description: DURING the early centuries of Christianity it was often enough to be saintly to be declared a saint, sometimes by popular acclaim. It was only later, starting in the 12th century, that the Roman Catholic Church moved to bring the bestowal of sainthood under control, instituting strict and lengthy procedures to determine who is, and who isn't, worthy to be venerated as a saint.

title: EUROPE: FALL AND WINTER -- The Bargains and the Blowouts; Paris: A sightseeing tour by city bus and a culinary tour de force
description: One of the few things in Paris that has become less expensive over the past few years, even before the dollar began surging toward 6 francs, is a bus ride. Long routes that used to require two tickets now cost just 8 francs (about $1.40, based on 5.74 francs to the dollar) if a single ticket is bought on the bus or 4.80 francs (about 85 cents) if a carnet of 10 is bought at a Metro station. This makes a ride on the scenic No. 63, from the Gare de Lyon in the east of the city to the Porte de la Muette on its western edge, the biggest bargain in town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELSEL, MILTON J., M.D.
description: HELSEL-Milton J., M.D. On September 12, 1997 in Miami, FL. Beloved husband for over fiftyeight years of Selma (Geshwind). Loving father of Eileen Swartz and Meryl (Robert) Meltzer. Adored grandfather of Reesa (Steven) Fischer, Jeffrey (Shayna) Swartz, Neal and Sara Meltzer. Cherished great grandfather of Adam & Brian Fischer and Jessica Swartz. Dear brother of Helen Epstein and the late Irving Helsel. Dr. Helsel practiced medicine in Lynn, MA. for over fifty years. He will be remembered by all who knew him for his great kindness, care and compassion. He was a wonderful man whose inate sense of caring, loyalty, fair play and intellectual curiosity added much to the lives of his family. He wished only the best for those he loved. He leaves us all with a legacy of love and devotion by which he will remain in our hearts and with us for all the days to come. Graveside services Sunday, September 14, at 1:45 PM New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Miami Jewish Home and Hospital at Douglas Gardens, 5200 NE 2nd Ave, Miami, FL 33137.

title: Dede Welles And Mark Gimbel

The Rev. Arlene Bodge, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in Chilmark, Mass., at Brookside Farm, a summer house owned by the bridegroom's mother and stepfather, Douglas Liebhafsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNER, JOSEPH
description: ARNER-Joseph on September 10, 1997 of Great Neck, NY. Beloved friend of Marta Bilek. Rabbi Balfour Brickner is to perform the ceremony at the house of Ed Rothfarb and Peter Trias, friends of the couple, in Wainscott, N.Y.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Hawaii With Julia: An Idyll
description: When we stepped off the plane into the sauna weather of a Honolulu evening in late December, my old friend Paul was waiting for us at the gate, carrying a brown paper bag, packed by his wife and full of gifts for my companion -- a lei, a hula skirt, a straw sun hat and a rainbow bikini. Everything, except for the bikini, which I nixed, was donned then and there, while our fellow passengers surged past us. Hatted, garlanded, hula skirt swirling, my companion strode off toward baggage claim. She looked like the tourist from hell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JOSEPH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKSTEIN, GERTRUDE S. ARIEL
description: LOOKSTEIN-Gertrude S. Ariel United Israel Institutes deeply mourns the passing of the beloved mother of Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, member of our Board of Governers, devoted friend and supporter. She was a true Woman of Valour, lover of Torah, Israel and Eretz Israel. Heartfelt condolences to Rabbi Haskel and Audrey Lookstein, Dr. Nathalie and Israel Friedman, and to the entire family. Rabbi Shear Yashuv Cohen, Chancellor and Chief Rabbi of Haifa Natalio S. Fridman, President Michael D. Jaspan, Treasurer Ariel American Friends of Midrasha

title: Paint It Black, Head to Toe
description: From midsummer to Labor Day, the rage for all black accelerated, and it now appears to be at gale force. The strategy, which adapts the look of deep-mourning clothes for everyday wear, is to appear invisible and to fade into the background. But as the style grows more prevalent, the opposite is occurring -- wearers now stand out because there are so many of them. The object is head-to-toe black, and the ultimate statement is stepping out of a black car with black windows dressed entirely in black. The look began as the uniform of fashion professionals and of punks in the club scene of the late 1970's in London, where rebellious young people seemed obsessed with gloom, doom and death. By the early 80's, it had taken on a spooky new-romantic style there, labeled ''goth,'' after neo-Gothic. In the last decade, it gradually lost its costume weirdness and became minimalist.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: IMAGINING CHARACTERS

description: IT'S the first day of Miss America's reign, and sometime between the morning-after news conference and the afternoon plunge in the ocean, she drops her crown.

description: FERRANDO-Miguel. 9/13/96. Dearest Miguel, you found it difficult to be simple and simple to be complicated. Gone one year. We miss you. Love always, Teresa, Mom and Family

title: Following Where a Renewed Heart Leads
description: A MOST UNFUNNY THING happened to Mariss Jansons on his way to the podium of the Pittsburgh Symphony. Mr. Jansons, a 54-year-old Latvian who begins his first season as the orchestra's music director on Friday evening at Heinz Hall, was named to the position in April 1995, to succeed Lorin Maazel. But a year later, while conducting the Oslo Philharmonic, of which he is also music director, in a concert performance of Puccini's ''Boheme,'' Mr. Jansons suffered a severe heart attack and collapsed into unconsciousness.

title: Jamie Holland And Edward Hull
description: Jamie Rebecca Holland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Holland of Washington, was married last evening to Edward Luckenbach Hull, the son of Kitty Skallerup of McLean, Va., and Kenneth D. Hull of Chevy Chase, Md. Judge Thomas F. Hogan of Federal District Court in the District of Columbia officiated at the Society of the Cincinnati, a club in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, LOUIS
description: EDELSTEIN-Louis. Uncle of Joann Thier, Amy Thier and Alex Martin. He is also survived by his devoted sister-in-law, Sonya Edelstein; the wife of his dear late brother, Samuel Edelstein. Mr. Edelstein was a well known philanthropist. Graveside services were held on September 11th in Philadelphia, PA. Roth-Goldsteins Chapel, Atlantic City.

description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Man Dies and Woman Is Hurt in Falls Down Elevator Shafts
description: A Senegalese man visiting a handbag store in midtown Manhattan was killed yesterday afternoon when he opened the door to the building's elevator and plunged four floors down the shaft, the police said.

title: Mill River Inn Voted Tops in Zagat Survey
description: AND the new champion is . . . the Mill River Inn. At least that is the opinion of the 2,118 people who participated in the Zagat 1998 survey of Long Island restaurants. More of them voted for the food at the Oyster Bay restaurant than the food at any other Island spot.

title: Three Lives, Three Directions
description: THREE back-to-school stories we will be revisiting this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Ice Hut, a business in Spring Lake Heights, omitted the name of a co-founder of the Ice Hut Corporation. He is Mark O'Neill, the brother of Paul O'Neill, who was mentioned in the article.

title: To See Ralph Reed, Take a Number; Republicans Line Up for the Man Who Would Be Kingmaker
description: In the eight years it took Ralph Reed to build the Christian Coalition into one of the most potent forces in Republican politics, he seemed to struggle to keep in check his passion for raw politicking. He injected references to ''God'' and ''Christians'' into his speeches and told everyone that the organization he ran was devoted to education, not politics.

title: Fordham Rallies From 21 Down To Improve to 2-0
description: If Fordham's triumph over Lafayette a week ago was a tremor in the Patriot League, then its 42-35 overtime victory over Lehigh yesterday was an earthquake.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Sunday with an article about two fast-growing hotel companies overstated the number of hotels managed by one of them, Patriot American Hospitality, and located some hotels incorrectly. A corrected map appears today on page 13.

title: Jesse Jackson Campaigns for Sharpton
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson yesterday denounced New York Democrats who said they would refuse to support the Rev. Al Sharpton should he win the runoff for the Democratic mayoral nomination. Mr. Sharpton's rival, Ruth W. Messinger, meanwhile, said she would support him if he defeated her on Sept. 23.

description: Julie Ellen Sternberg, a daughter of Donna W. Sternberg and Hans J. Sternberg of Baton Rouge, La., is to be married today to Paul Henry Schoeman, a son of Linda H. Schoeman and Michael E. Schoeman of New York. Rabbi Michael Strassfeld is to perform the ceremony in Bryant Park in New York.

description: EYER-James A. Age 64 years, on Friday, September 12, 1997. Husband of Patricia. He was reporter for NBC and ABC news in NYC retiring from NBC in 1988.

title: Guiliani Kills 2 Burning Issues With One Campaign Stop
description: There is perhaps no hotter topic in Forest Hills than a proposed super-shopping center and 24-screen multiplex movie theater planned for 25 industrial acres to the south of Metropolitan Avenue along Woodhaven Boulevard. Some residents see it as an architectural alligator that would clapperclaw the guts out of their neighborhood.

title: Upending Freud
description: To the Editor:

title: When Sanity Runs in the Family
description: ARNOLD AND CLIFFORD LAZARUS have looked into the minds of New Jerseyans and found enough to worry the most balanced of souls. In those heads, the father-and-son psychological duo say that they see a tangle of tension, depression, obsession, and most of all, at least here in this Ivy League town, a destructive need to compete.

title: Shaping a Marathon of Dance That Was Inspired by the Web
description: THE CHOREOGRAPHER and teacher Stephan Koplowitz has a passion for making large-scale pieces in unlikely places. Last year his ''Genesis Canyon,'' with 36 dancers, was seen at the Natural History Museum in London. In 1990, he assembled 90 performers and staged ''Union City'' in Union Station in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption and credit were omitted in The Times Book Review on Aug. 17 with a review of ''Space Is the Place,'' John F. Szwed's biography of the jazz musician Sun Ra. The picture, a still from the 1980 documentary film ''Sun Ra: A Joyful Noise,'' should have been credited to Robert Mugge/Rhapsody Films.

title: Bosnians Vote, But Animosity Is Unrelenting
description: Escorted by NATO troops in armored vehicles, buses lurched and rolled out of Sarajevo early this morning. They were taking Bosnian Muslims for a few emotional moments to villages in which they had lived before the war, where they cast ballots and were then hustled hastily away.

title: Yahoo!
description: B.J. BLAIRS'S face was all flushed. His cowboy hat was askew, as if somebody had taken a swipe at it. ''Sorry, I was out for a little while,'' he said, blinking, when someone asked him how he was doing.

title: Fast Track on Treaties Leaves Labor in the Dust; Subverting Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaker's Power Base Eroding?
description: Although the official recount will not be available for a few more days, last week's City Council primary on the Lower East Side proved that there is no such thing as conventional wisdom in what is perhaps the city's most fractured district. Most pundits assumed that Margarita Lopez, a social worker and liberal housing advocate, stood little chance of beating Judith Rapfogel, chief of staff for the Speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, the state's most powerful Democrat. Tuesday night Ms. Rapfogel appeared the winner, although her margin of victory was only 168 votes out of 12,420 ballots cast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, EVE A.
description: STONE-Eve A. Peacefully on September 10, 1997 at the age of 93. Devoted mother of Barbara Hess and the late Patricia Aks. Loving grandmother of John Newburger, Susan Karchmer, William Straus, Michael Untermeyer and Kathryn Atwood and four great-grandchildren. Services will be private.

title: Appearances; Shock Value
description: They're in their late teens or 20's. breakouts are behind them, wrinkles but a dim threat on the horizon. In the full flower of womanhood, they strike out beyond borders of taste in search of the perfect shade of lipstick that will make them look as if they have been imbibing toxic wastes. They are not punk rockers shambling out of the 70's but the shock troops of a beauty revolution that is changing what looks good to us.

title: Capra's Everyman
description: The director Frank Capra, with a script by Robert Riskin, again presents an honest and forthright fellow who believes in the innate goodness of people and has the courage to fight for his principles. In MEET JOHN DOE (1941), a brilliant fable of Depression-era America, an idealistic drifter (Gary Cooper) plays the role of a cynical firebrand for the sake of a newspaper stunt. When the guiding hand behind the stunt emerges as a fascist-minded tycoon (Edward Arnold), John Doe gives courages battle, vowing to leap from the Empire State Building in defiance. Can a beautiful, loving, journalist (Barbara Standwyck) dissuade him? One guess -- TUESDAY at 1:30 P.M. on AMC; TUES.-WED at 3 A.M on CHANNEL 55 Howard Thompson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSI, ALDO
description: ROSSI-Aldo. The Board of Directors of the Architectural League of New York mourn the death of Aldo Rossi, architect, theorist, artist, friend.

description: I wish to add a couple of comments to your very good article, ''Treating Childhood Obesity With Care''$(Aug. 3$).

title: Patents; Targeting cancerous tissue without poisoning the body.
description: MANY cancer treatments have harsh side effects, including nausea, hair loss and diminished immunity. This is because chemotherapy is toxic to healthy cells as well as cancerous ones. Indeed, what many consider the Holy Grail of cancer research is a method to target cancerous tissue without poisoning the rest.

description: To the Editor:

description: When Thomas F. McLarty 3d was pushed out as President Clinton's chief of staff more than three years ago, he lost his job and his high profile but not his access or his golden Rolodex.

Her involvement, commitment, and passion for the Center's students and its concerts spanned almost a half century. Her wisdom, enthusiasm, guidance and leadership will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathy is with her adored nieces, Mina Laskey and Rose-Barbara Neustadt and their families. Lydia Kontos, Exec. Director Leonard Goodman, Chairman Elaine Kaufman, President

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Everything you want to know is for sale. It's a question of how much risk you want to take and what your personal morals are.''

title: Evaluating Pupil Performance
description: President Clinton's proposal for a national test that would offer detailed comparisons among individual students, schools and states has run into heavy weather. The Senate has approved the idea and even strengthened it. But House Republicans argue that a new test is unnecessary and that a national test in any event would constitute a Government takeover of the schools. On the Democratic side, some black and Latino members warn that a national test would stigmatize minority children, who generally attend worse schools.

title: A Sad Death, a Bad Law
description: The sadness over Princess Diana's death continues, but some sense of proportion seems to be returning. The royal family of Britain is removing the flowers from Kensington Palace. Elton John has told the BBC it cannot continue to broadcast his performance at Diana's funeral at Westminster Abbey. The father of Dodi al-Fayed has stopped disputing the blood alcohol tests of Henri Paul, the inebriated employee whose mad driving caused the deaths. But it remains uncertain whether reason will prevail in the debate over how to cope with the trans-Atlantic community's most unpopular citizens, the paparazzi.

title: A Feisty Weld Criticizes Helms For His Stance on Mexico Post
description: William F. Weld today used his fight to become Ambassador to Mexico to articulate his vision of the Republican Party and to portray Jesse Helms, the conservative Senator who has denied him a hearing, as an undesirable representative of the party.

title: Israel Is to Release More Money Owed To the Palestinians
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said today that he would release another portion of the tax funds Israel has withheld from the Palestinian Authority, a step that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright had sought during her visit last week.

title: Keep Bosnia Whole
description: To the Editor:

title: Christian Coalition Reaffirms Its Strength
description: It appeared to be another joyous weekend of prayer and politics here at the Christian Coalition's annual convention. But between their familiar fulminations against abortion, homosexuals and President Clinton, many speakers left little doubt they fear that the group could lose some of its political punch.

title: People
description: * Nicholas Jeffery was named president of a new London office of Lehman Millet Inc., Boston. He had been managing partner at Ginn-Jeffery International P.L.C., London.

title: Market Place ; A Rare Sure Thing Goes Unnoticed
description: Two of the more popular bromides on Wall Street are ''there's no such thing as a sure thing'' and ''markets are efficient.''

title: Foreign Affairs; The Physics of Mideast Peace
description: The father of one of the Israeli commandos killed in Lebanon earlier this month said something after his son's funeral that pretty well summed up the mood in Israel. Loosely translated, he said: ''I just have this to say to the Prime Minister. If it's going to be war, then let's have war. If it's going to be peace, then let's make peace, but like this we can't go on.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: SUSAN GINGRICH, one of the half-sisters of NEWT GINGRICH, the Speaker of the House, is going to publish a magazine for the conservative woman. On Friday, she announced that she had quit her job as an administrator with the Pennsylvania Public Welfare Department to publish a national magazine called ''Today's Lady,'' according to Reuters.

title: In Nascar, Camping There Is Half the Fun
description: If any Winston Cup driver has earned the right to park his motorhome-away-from-home in victory lane this season, it is Jeff Gordon, who won the CMT 300 today at New Hampshire International Speedway.

title: 3 Are Charged in Killings
description: Two more suspects were arrested on Saturday and charged with murder in the shootings of a couple last week at a Newark boarding house, bringing the total number of suspects to three, The Associated Press reported.

title: Miss America Takes a Dip
description: Buoyed by a New Jersey crowd that claimed her as one of their own, Katherine Shindle, began her yearlong reign as Miss America 1998 yesterday with a dip in the Atlantic and a pledge to fight AIDS, the A.P. reported.

title: After 7 Turbulent Years at City University, Chancellor Leaves Today
description: W. Ann Reynolds leaves the City University of New York today after seven years as Chancellor, ending a tempestuous period during which her accomplishments were frequently overshadowed by her bitter wrangling with CUNY's teachers, administrators and trustees, as well as with the Mayor.

title: Restricting Youths at Mall
description: Two days after several hundred teen-agers ran screaming through the Freehold Raceway Mall, town officials said yesterday that they would consider an ordinance banning minors from the mall on weekend nights unless they were accompanied by adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORRES, ROBERTO
description: TORRES-Roberto. Of Queens, NY most of his life, died August 29, 1997 at Skyview Rehabilitation and Nursing Home in Wallingford, CT. He was the beloved husband of Nery Yero Torres and is survived by his children, Robert Torres, Jr., Hector Torres, Walter Torres, Edward Quintela, Elena Dorsey and Nancy Vazquez. He was formerly employed with Marriott Essex House in NYC until his recent retirement. Our beloved husband, father, grandfather and greatgrandfather dedicated his life to his family and friends. He remains in our hearts and minds forever.

title: Giovanni Di Chiro, Neuroradiologist, 70
description: Dr. Giovanni Di Chiro, chief of neuroimaging at the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, died on Aug. 27 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 70.

title: Trial Is to Begin for New York Police Officer and 2 Others in Bias Killing Case
description: In the year since Charles Campbell was shot and killed in an argument over a parking space, a small Italian delicatessen in the heart of Westchester County has become the site of weekly protests.

title: George W. Crockett Dies at 88; Was a Civil Rights Crusader
description: George W. Crockett Jr., a civil rights warrior who went over the top so often in the battle for racial justice that he earned a decade of bemused retirement in Congress, died on Sept. 7 at a hospice near his home in Washington. He was 88 and had represented a Detroit district in the House of Representatives from 1980 to 1991.

title: Washington Should Give Schools More Money, Not More Exams; Foolish Endeavor
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Where Have All the Women in Politics Gone?
description: It cannot have escaped everyone's notice that whenever a woman runs in a big election in New York, disasters occur.

title: Museum Tells a Tale of Resilience, Tuned to the Key of Life
description: At last, at long, long last, Battery Park City has acquired a soul. With today's opening of the Museum of Jewish Heritage -- A Living Memorial to the Holocaust, this 92-acre sliver of landfill at the southern tip of Manhattan finally joins New York City. The place moves beyond real estate development, beyond upscale shopping, beyond its well-intended but bleakly suburban, golf course conception of modern urban life.

title: A Voice and a Legend That Still Fascinate; Callas Is 'What Opera Should Be'
description: What is it about Maria Callas that continues to mesmerize us 20 years after her death?

title: Leo Burnett Plans Layoffs
description: The Leo Burnett U.S.A. division of the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago is as expected laying off employees because of recent account losses. The agency will dismiss 74 people, or 3.7 percent of its staff of 1,990.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW ; Have Concept, Will Travel: Palin Packs His Bags Again
description: Michael Palin, who traveled with the Monty Python troupe before becoming a tour guide for the BBC and PBS (''Around the World in 80 Days'' and ''Pole to Pole''), sets off tonight on the longest trip of his career. ''Full Circle,'' which took him 245 days of real time, will occupy 10 hours of television time as he covers 50,000 miles of the Pacific Rim.

title: Pas de 2.0
description: Jason Marchant, in his years as a student at the University of Michigan, often took a four-hour train ride from the Detroit area through lush farmlands to Toronto, his parents' home. He ''used the movement of the train and the rhythm of the landscape'' to invent moves for dancers on his Apple Powerbook, he said.

title: Dr. Roger Egeberg, 93, Nixon's Health Officer
description: Dr. Roger Olaf Egeberg, a blunt Democrat who criticized the Nixon Administration while he was its chief health officer, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, MAX M.
description: SIMON-Max M., on September 13 in Harrison, NY. Beloved husband for over 58 years of Rose. Loving father of David and Donna Simon and Lois and Robert Reich. Adored grandfather of Randi and Daniel Reich and Jared and Dana Simon. Dear brother of Philip and Percy Simon, and Bea Bloom.

title: Irish History, Remade
description: Anyone who has had an alcoholic in the family fall back into drinking after a period of recovery will understand very well the feeling of destitute despair that overwhelmed Ireland and England in February 1996. The Irish Republican Army set off bombs in London's Canary Wharf that ended the first cease-fire.

title: PATRIOTS 27, PARCELLS 24
description: The Patriots captured the game that captured the fancy of New England tonight, but the victory didn't come in an easy, or even timely, fashion. In a dramatic game that ricocheted into overtime, the Patriots defeated the Jets, 27-24, when Adam Vinatieri kicked a 34-yard field goal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUCHACEK, HELENA KOLDA
description: DUCHACEK-Helena Kolda. Age 68, photographer and video artist, died of cancer on Thursday, September 4, in Kent, CT. Born in the former Czechoslovakia, she was the widow of Ivo Duchacek, Professor of political science at CUNY. A memorial service will be held on September 20, 4 PM, First Congregational Church, Kent, CT.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, WILLIAM
description: SCHWARTZ - William. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Devoted father of Phyllis Goldstein, Linda Sigman, Barbara Krinsky. Loving and adored grandfather of Melissa, Allyson, Lance, Bradley, Alexis and Jessica. Service today, 10 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn (opposite Kings Plaza).

title: A Minor but Colorful Player in Chinese History
description: TWO-GUN COHEN

title: In the Park, a Usually Tough Crowd Bares Hearts for Diana
description: The card sticking out of Julio Belloso's shirt pocket expressed his feelings precisely. ''Clone Diana,'' it read.

title: Metro Matters; In School Law, Protection For Whom?
description: WHEN it happened last spring, the beating of a first-grade student at Public School 188 seemed like a classic narrative of cruelty at home and bumbling at school.

title: Disputed Call Preserves Remarkable Mets Victory
description: Todd Pratt was not quite sure what to say.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK
description: Will Elton John be the only media figure not to profit from the death of Diana, Princess of Wales? With ''Candle in the Wind 1997,'' the song he sang at the funeral seen around the world, he is about to have an international hit, and he's trying hard to do all the right things.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; A Time to Laugh, a Time To Weep: Don't Confuse
description: Laughter was not, it turned out, an appropriate response. ''This was supposed to be a sad section,'' said Karen Finley, the performance artist, addressing the soft but audible chuckles of a member of the opening night audience for her one-woman show ''The American Chestnut'' at Performance Space 122.

title: Unusual Sight: Wheatley Plays
description: Tyrone Wheatley, who had been used sparingly this season, was the featured running back for the Giants yesterday in the fourth quarter of their 24-23 loss to the Baltimore Ravens. Wheatley had 33 yards on 12 carries. He also caught 2 passes for 16 yards.

title: DANCE REVIEW ; Fresh Faces in Role Debuts
description: Dance Theater of Harlem is now in one of those magical times that occur when younger performers press through gaps left by departed veterans and take possession of the stage. There was a special electricity in the air on Saturday afternoon when the company presented new casts in its all-Balanchine program at Davis Hall at City College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORENSTEIN, GERALD
description: BORENSTEIN-Gerald on September 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Selma. Loving uncle, great-uncle and dear friend. Private service.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK ; Facing a Very Different Constituency
description: As a member of Congress, Susan Molinari had no trouble standing out from the pack. Delivering the keynote address at the Republican National Convention, she projected an image Bob Dole couldn't: perky, blond and female. But those qualities aren't so hard to find in television, and as the co-anchor of the new ''CBS News Saturday Morning,'' Ms. Molinari seems like a promising, slightly stiff wannabe with a Katie Couric haircut.

title: Warning to Broadcasters That Renege on Running HDTV
description: Leading members of Congress are threatening retribution against broadcasters who say they might not offer high-definition television on their new digital channels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARUCCI, SAMUEL A.
description: CARUCCI-Samuel A., Esq. On September 12, 1997, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Patricia, Caroline and Samuel. Loving grandfather of William and Michael. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York.

title: ELECTRONIC EYES: What the Computer Knows -- A special report.; On Line, High-Tech Sleuths Find Private Facts
description: On the night of Oct. 8, 1992, the towering pipes of the Texaco refinery in Wilmington, Calif., vented a sudden rise in pressure. Then the familiar hiss became a deafening screech, and a fiery explosion sent hundreds fleeing in panic from the poor Hispanic community that lies in the refinery's shadow.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Eddie O'Toole, Champion Runner, 76
description: Eddie O'Toole, the United States national champion in the 10,000-meter run from 1946 to 1948, died last Friday at South Nassau Hospital in Oceanside, N.Y. He was 76.

title: Repeat Performances At the Emmy Awards
description: The same shows that took most of the primetime Emmy honors last year stood out again in 1997, with ''Frasier,'' a series about a radio psychoanalyst, winning best comedy for the fourth straight year, tying a television record. The Emmy for the best drama went to ''Law and Order,'' which took the award for the first time but has been nominated for six years.

title: Convertible Debt, Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Washington Should Give Schools More Money, Not More Exams; Voluntary Testing?

description: REEVES-Minna. Vivid, sweet memories and deepest gratitude to my beloved unforgettable mother on her birthday.

title: Beijing Journal; Politics, Sex and Murder! A Banned Best-Seller!
description: In the midst of China's political season, the hottest book in the nation's capital is a juicy novel of political intrigue, sex and murder.

title: U.S., IN SHIFT, SAYS IT MAY SIGN TREATY TO BAN LAND MINES
description: In a major change in policy, the Clinton Administration told its allies this weekend that it could sign a treaty banning anti-personnel land mines under a compromise that would allow it an additional nine years before it begins to remove mines on the Korean peninsula, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Ins and Outs of French Law: Hotel Could Be Charged in Diana's Death
description: Consider the legal position of Mohamed al-Fayed. He is the owner of the Ritz Hotel; employer of Henri Paul, the driver in the crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, and father of Diana's escort on the fatal ride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, WALTER J.
description: GOLD-Walter J. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, died September 12, 1997, in Montgomery, AL. We will all miss your humor, wit, repartee and special twinkle in your eyes when delivering a sparkling one-liner. A NY businessman for many years, you daily read the New York Times regardless of where you hung your hat. There is an empty space in our hearts and at our tables. Graveside services Tuesday, Sept. 16, 10 AM, King Solomon, Clifton, NJ. For additional information, Gutterman's, 1-800-522-0588.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about The New York Observer included an incorrect figure from the Audit Bureau of Circulations for the circulation of The Village Voice. Including paid sales, it is 223,266 weekly, not 200,000.

title: INSIDE
description: Shifting Case Over Diana

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERDMAN, EDNA
description: ERDMAN-Edna. Helped to create the Henry Kaufmann Campgrounds forty-five years ago. From that moment on, Edna nurtured our growth with her honesty, judgment, love, and unfailing support. In doing so, she touched each of our lives and those of hundreds of thousands of day campers in the New York area. We were all honored to have known her and we will all miss her. We extend our condolences to her entire family. The Board and Staff Henry Kaufmann Campgrounds, Inc. Thomas J. Tisch, Chairman Walter H. Blum, Assoc Chairman Steven M. Levy, President Jeffrey A. Coopersmith, Exec Dir

title: N.F.L. Week 3; AT 3-0, Tampa Bay Tops the N.F.C.
description: BUCCANEERS 28

title: Devils Plan More Time For Dunham
description: With Martin Brodeur apparently headed for free agency after this season, the backup goaltender Mike Dunham is suddenly a very important player for the Devils.

title: Arrest Is Made In the Slaying Of an Officer
description: One man was arrested yesterday and another was being sought in the death of an off-duty police sergeant whose slaying under mysterious circumstances kept top city officials from attending his funeral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPPAS, WALLY
description: LAPPAS-Wally, 92, of Ft. Lee, NJ and Palm Beach, FL, passed away on September 13, 1997. Mrs. Lappas was born September 26, 1904, in Germany, daughter of the late Anton and Philomena Kammerbauer. She came to the USA in the late 1920's and amongst various interests and endeavors she was a model, confidante and advisor with her late husband's real estate business and to Archbishop Makarios III, President of the Island of Cyprus. Mrs. Lappas was an active member of the Evangelismos Greek Orthodox Church, Jersey City, NJ, and was active with the Cyprus Children's Fund and related Theodore and Wally Lappas Scholarship Fund. She was preceded in death by her late husband, Theodore Lappas, of 61 years on May 17, 1995. Survived by children Alexandra Lappas, Ft. Lee, NJ, Theodore Lappas, Jr., Clyde, NC, Corinne Kurica, Beach Haven, NJ, nine grandchildren, thirteen great-grandchildren, a great - great - grandchild, many nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held in North Palm Beach, FL. Donations may be made to the Theodore & Wally Scholarship Fund to be mailed to the Cyprus Children's Fund, 13 E. 40th St., NY, NY 10016.

title: Fast Pit Stop Boosts Gordon
description: Jeff Gordon won today by holding off Ernie Irvan, who was battling a viral illness and a starting position near the back of the field, on six restarts over the last 70 of the 300 laps of the CMT 300 at New Hampshire International Speedway.

title: Sports of The Times; No Excuses, Parcells Says, Hall Just Hit the Ball a Little Low
description: THE disappointment was in his face. Bill Parcells is 56 years old, but, after the Jets had lost last night in overtime to the Patriots, 27-24, his face resembled that of a coach who was 66 or maybe 76.

title: Two Ranger Newcomers Know the Role of Captain
description: With the dramatic departure of Mark Messier and the continuing debate over who should replace him as captain of the Rangers, it has been easy to overlook the history and projected value of two important newcomers.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Sports of The Times ; For Dave Brown, Learning How to Win While Losing
description: WHEN is a loss a loss? When is a loss a victory?

title: More at Play in Runoff Than Vote Outcome
description: In a city where blacks and whites, according to polls, hold essentially contrary views of the world, the runoff between the Rev. Al Sharpton and Ruth W. Messinger would appear to have all the makings of a racial-political conflagration. It is a contest between an often-caustic civil rights advocate and a white denizen of the Upper West Side, being played out against the backdrop of a horrific accusation of police abuse.

title: 'The Full Monty' is by far the biggest film success at Fox Searchlight Pictures.
description: MORE than a year ago, executives at Fox Searchlight Pictures, a division of 20th Century Fox, began watching the dailies -- scenes that were just filmed -- of ''The Full Monty.'' The low-budget British comedy-drama, costing about $3 million, is about a group of unemployed steel workers in Sheffield who decide to start a striptease act not only to earn money but to give them some self-esteem. The men are down on their luck and their physiques are far, far from ideal.

title: Mercedes Affected By Princess's Death
description: The Mercedes-Benz of North America unit of Daimler A.G. has joined the ranks of advertisers forced to alter television commercial schedules as a result of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: New in ad sales cyberspace, the Softbank Network will cover topics from sports to travel.
description: A LEADING Internet advertising sales agent will offer another way to buy sales pitches in cyberspace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, SALLY L.
description: CHASE-Sally L. On September 13, 1997. We love you, Sally, and we will miss you. Alison A.F. Chase Rebecca Chase Hughes Alison Chase Moore Abigail Chase Miller

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WORONER, ROSE
description: WORONER-Rose. Happy birthday, Mom, I miss you so. Love, Ilene

title: Washington Should Give Schools More Money, Not More Exams; Unwarranted Cynicism
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking In the Sites ; Statistics and Even Lore Of the Dismal Science
description: Should you wake up in the middle of the night wondering whether Americans or Norwegians have a bigger per-capita gross domestic product, there is no need to lose sleep. You can find the answer, quickly and free, on the World Wide Web.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW/NEW SEASON ; A Police-Show Hero Returns, as Brooding as Ever
description: Television viewers may have liked David Caruso on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue,'' but how attached does an audience get to someone who was around for only a year? All the hyperventilating about his leaving television for a movie career, followed by the splashy failure of that career and his return to television, was truly no more than hype.

title: News Analysis ; The Lure of Cable
description: USA Networks may be struggling to redefine its image to attract a younger audience, but the way that the cable programming service's joint owners, the Seagram Company and Viacom Inc., have been fighting over it, one might think it was the most precious commodity in the entertainment business.

title: POP REVIEW ; The Theme: Entrances, Entrances
description: For pop fans, there are few feelings like the beginning of a concert, when the musician whose performance they've been anticipating for months emerges onstage, the audience explodes and everyone flushes with the confidence that it is going to be a good show.

title: Being Critical When Beloved Figures Die
description: Trampling on the hallowed images of the famously departed is delicate business -- thankless as grave digging and just as inevitable.

title: Women Losing Ground to Men In Widening Income Difference
description: After nearly two decades in which the wage gap between men and women was steadily narrowing, it is now widening again, piquing confusion and concern among economists and women's groups alike.

title: Jury in CSX Case Sent Angry Message With a $3.4 Billion Stamp
description: For three hours on Monday, 12 angry black jurors argued over how much corporate America should pay for what they saw as sheer callousness.

title: Death Plot Reported Against a High-Ranking Russian Official
description: Russian officials said this evening that they had learned of a plot to assassinate Anatoly B. Chubais, the main architect of Russia's economic reforms and one of the country's most senior officials.

title: Today: Later News and More Sections
description: Starting today, The Times introduces its most sweeping improvements in more than 20 years:

title: Lott Predicts Vote to Decide Donation Rules
description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said today that the Senate was likely to vote this year on legislation to revamp campaign finance practices.

title: Internet Growth Continues
description: The Internet's dramatic growth is continuing, according to a new survey, which estimates that the number of host computers permanently connected to the network reached 26 million in September.

title: Roughriders Win
description: The Long Island Roughriders advanced to the A-League semifinals yesterday by defeating Montreal, 1-0, in a shootout in Game 3 of the playoffs. Montreal defeated the Roughriders, 2-0, in Game 2 of the series yesterday behind goals from Mauro Biello and Lyndon Hooper. Montreal's victory tied the series at 1-1 and forced a 30-minute mini-game. Neither team scored in the mini-game. The Roughriders won by scoring 3 goals in the best of 5 shootout.

title: New Step in Monorail Project
description: In a significant step in the $250 million project to connect Newark International Airport's monorail with the New Jersey Transit rail system, the Newark City Council is scheduled to vote tomorrow on an agreement giving the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey the right to condemn 12 acres of privately held land along the proposed route, officials said.

title: And the Emmy Winners Are . . .
description: Drama series:

title: Washington Should Give Schools More Money, Not More Exams; School Board Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUALEY, THOMAS
description: QUALEY - Thomas. Renowned floral designer. Owner of Kathleen Graham Flowers in New York with Cynthia; greatly respected in his field. Formerly of Bronx, NY. Died on September 12, 1997, in Boca Raton, FL. Cherished husband of the late Cynthia (nee Zimmerman), dear brother-in-law and adored uncle of many. We shall miss him greatly. The Auster Family and The Leicher Family

title: Abroad at Home; Whose Ox Is Gored
description: In late 1995 and early 1996 Vice President Gore made dozens of telephone calls from the White House to raise money from big political contributors. Those are the calls that have become the latest focus of the long-running Washington drama, the campaign funds scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEEMAN, ETA NEWMAN
description: ZEEMAN-Eta Newman, of New York and Jupiter, FL, died September 11, aged 85. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Zeeman, sister of the late Milton B. Newman and aunt of Barry Newman, she was for many years an executive secretary at Columbia Pictures in New York City. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. For information concerning memorials, please call 212-416-4902.

title: Edward Artinian, 61, Publisher's Founder
description: Edward Artinian, the founder and publisher of Chatham House Publishers, died on Sept. 9 at his home in Chatham, N.J. He was 61.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, MURRAY
description: SUSSMAN-Murray, of Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Miriam. Cherished father of Alan and Leonard. Devoted brother of Jessie Lynn. Adored grandfather of Emily, Julie and Andrew. He was a model of integrity and generosity for his family and all who met him in his long, productive, and caring life. Funeral services will be Wednesday, September 17, 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., NY, NY.

title: Late Rally by Colcon Wins the Noble Damsel
description: New York racing began the countdown to the Woodward next weekend with 11 fillies contesting the Noble Damsel Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, and Colcon supplied a splashy opening act by winning her first stakes with a late rush along the rail that completed a dazzling mile on grass in 1:324/5 .

title: Giuliani Attacks Sharpton As Unqualified to Be Mayor
description: Interjecting himself further into the Democratic mayoral runoff yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the Rev. Al Sharpton was unqualified to be mayor, challenged the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, to do the same and prepared to release another television advertisement trumpeting his support among Democrats.

title: A Mideast Peace Can't Be Built on Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: In the 1996 Reisinger Knockout Teams in Manhattan, the diagramed deal gave Alan Sontag of Manhattan a chance to demonstrate the playing skill that has brought him one world title and many national successes. He found himself in an optimistic four-spade contract after East had doubled the opening bid of one club.

title: Washington Should Give Schools More Money, Not More Exams; Nothing to Accomplish
description: To the Editor:

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL ; With Parcells Gone, the Next to Leave Foxboro Will Be the Pats
description: The exodus of Bill Parcells from the Patriots, from Massachusetts, did not keep Patriots fans from returning to Foxboro Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELOVICH, SOLOMON H.
description: ELOVICH-Solomon H. Beloved husband of Fanny. Devoted father of Larry and Eleanor. Adored father-in-law of Helen and Joel. Cherished grandfather of Lisa, Lauree, Lynn, Stacey and David. Loving great-grandfather of Austin and Ashley. Survived by sister Frances Greenstein. Funeral service Tuesday, September 16, 10 AM, at Temple Emanuel, 455 Neptune Blvd., Long Beach, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; The Giants' Defense Should Look Itself in the Mirror
description: THE easy scapegoat emerged from the shower and went right to his locker to dress. He did not stop to chat with his neighbors, Christian Peter and Howard Cross. He slipped on a pair of socks, black shoes, then a pair of faded blue jeans. Reporters hovered on the perimeter, like so many defensive backs in the prevent defense, but Brad Daluiso had another, more important, critic to face first.

title: Amid Big Numbers, Giants Are Undone By the Little Things
description: After 78 plays, almost 400 yards gained and after controlling the ball for nearly two-thirds of the game, victory today for the Giants came down to two of the most uncomplicated plays in their playbook.

title: Clinton Case Moves to Talk Of Settlement
description: Lawyers for President Clinton and Paula Corbin Jones, the woman who has filed a sexual harassment lawsuit against him, are set to confer this week in an effort to draft a statement that both sides could issue as part of a settlement.

title: Apple Picks TBWA To Handle Europe
description: The European unit of Apple Computer Inc. has selected TBWA International in Amsterdam to handle its creative account, with billings estimated at $20 million, after a review in which the agency had been left off the official list of participants.

title: Albright's Trip: No 'Big Steps'
description: As a measure of the deteriorating peace efforts in the Middle East, even the Davis Cup tennis team from Morocco -- one of the Arab countries warmest to Israel -- has refused to go to Israel to play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORMICK, THOMAS E.
description: McCORMICK-Thomas E., on September 13, 1997, of Port Washington, NY. Beloved husband of 60 years of Marian. Loving father of Brian and Mark. Also mourned by daughters-in-law Susan and Patricia. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Wednesday, 9:15 AM, St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington. Interment All Saints Cemetery. Contributions in his name may be made to St. Francis Heart Hospital, Roslyn, NY.

title: Redevelopment Effort Starts
description: Construction crews are expected to break ground this morning on a new drug addiction center in Trenton, the cornerstone of a $20 million redevelopment plan for the city's beleaguered Battle Monument district, officials said.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Washington Should Give Schools More Money, Not More Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW ; Mozart and Beethoven In a Resounding Space
description: Performing on a bright-toned piano in a highly reverberant space makes controlling dynamics terribly difficult: play a passage with what you think is a soft touch and the notes resound throughout the hall. This may have been the problem faced by Norbert Heller, a Czech pianist, on Friday night at Christ and St. Stephen's Church on West 69th Street in Manhattan.

title: Treasury's Financing Schedule Is Confined to Today's Auction
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: North Korea Famine May Be Killing 15% in Towns, Survey Says
description: An informal survey conducted for Korean-American organizations has found that about 15 percent of people in North Korea's towns and villages may be dying of starvation and famine-related diseases, an official of the international relief organization World Vision said yesterday.

title: Coach Moves Out of Dugout and Into Drama
description: The baseball coach told his players how Mozart endured after the emperor trashed ''Don Giovanni.'' How John Glenn trained for two decades for a few hours in space.

title: Congo Aid at Risk In Defiance of U.N. Over War Refugees
description: Four months after winning power through an armed rebellion, this country's new President, Laurent Kabila, is locked in a showdown with the United Nations. The outcome, diplomats say, could critically influence his Government's prospects for survival and will determine how it is seen by much of the world.

title: Favre Survives Another Week In Line of Fire
description: The season is young, but for quarterback Brett Favre it is already getting old. He is getting pounded so much that the Green Bay Packers, fresh off their 23-18 victory over the Miami Dolphins this afternoon, should be concerned for his health. Because Favre will not be able to take this kind of punishment all season.

title: Fuscas Wins Her First Grand Prix
description: Amanda Fuscas of Parker, Colo., won the first grand prix of her career when she rode Genesis to the only clear round in the jump off to win the $60,000 American Gold Cup. The 23-year-old equestrienne and Genesis, a 13-year-old gelding bred and previously campaigned in Germany, beat a field of 31 qualifiers to win the $18,000 winner's share of the purse.

title: Yachting's Best Defeated in Harbor
description: Terry Hutchinson, a 29-year-old sailor from Annapolis, Md., who was ranked No. 196 in the world, defeated three of the world's top competitors yesterday in the Cigna Knickerbocker Cup in New York Harbor.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 19 about girls in a play group in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with an article about the adoption of Chinese girls by parents in the New York area, referred incorrectly to the children. Not all were Chinese; one was Korean.

title: Lawyers Eclipse Agents in TV Deals
description: Tom Hansen vividly remembers the ''extraordinarily complicated'' renegotiation of the contracts for six cast members of the NBC hit series ''Friends.'' He and his partner, Craig Jacobson, represented two of the stars, and they found themselves at one point in a room crowded with agents and managers -- and other entertainment lawyers like themselves.

title: OPERA REVIEW ; Rossini as Sitcom, With Pratfalls and Semiautomatics
description: Already on the second evening of Paul Kellogg's first full season as general director of the New York City Opera came the second new production. Like the six still to come, this one, Christopher Alden's staging of Rossini's ''Italiana in Algeri,'' originated on another stage, in this case that of Mr. Kellogg's other love, the Glimmerglass Opera, in Cooperstown, N.Y., where the production was greeted this summer by a mixed reception.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, JOAN
description: HORN-Joan, on September 13, 1997. Loving sister of A. D. Horn. Cherished aunt of five. Graveside services Tuesday, 2 PM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: John Leddy, 83, Senior Official Faced McCarthy
description: John Marshall Leddy, a former senior official of the State and Treasury Departments whose Government career was interrupted by a confrontation with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in 1953, died on Aug. 31 at Fairfax Hospital in Fairfax, Va. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNER, STOCKMAN S.
description: BARNER-Stockman S. Actor, Editor of Greetings Magazine, President of 40+ Club, Board Member of National Association for Visually Handicapped. Died Thursday. Memorial service will be announced.

title: A Good Forecaster Is Hard to Find; Local Stations Seek Those Who Understand Storms and People
description: He does not love the bad weather, really, because of the hurt it can bring, but he does love the battle. Ask 65-year-old George Winterling about the hurricanes he has forecast and reported on as the senior television meteorologist in Jacksonville, Fla., and he almost sighs.

title: Another Waterway Is Closed in Maryland; Thousands of Fish Die in Most Recent Outbreak of Microbe Problem
description: Thousands of fish stricken with a microbial affliction thrashed weakly this morning on the surface of Chicamacomico River, leading the state to close yet another waterway to fishing and recreation and adding to the urgency of a festering new environmental problem for the Chesapeake Bay.

title: 'Quiet Dom' Is Seen as Heir to Gigante as Crime Family Boss
description: For decades, Dominick V. Cirillo has thrived on obscurity, shunning the trappings of wealth and influence. He lives in an attached house in the Bronx, drives himself around town in modest cars and has told neighbors that he turned to construction work after flopping as a professional boxer.

title: Washington Should Give Schools More Money, Not More Exams; Backfiring on Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Latin Voice in the World of Pop
description: Ostensibly it was a trade conference, but given the nature of the industry involved, it couldn't help turning into a huge party as well.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report last Monday, and another in New Jersey copies on Sept. 4, about contract negotiations involving lay teachers at eight Roman Catholic high schools in southern New Jersey, referred incorrectly to the Catholic body that operates the schools. It is the Diocese of Camden, not the Archdiocese.

title: Camacho Is Pounded But Not Totally Silenced
description: Oh, so that was why he wore a mouthpiece.

title: MUSIC REVIEW ; At Carnegie Hall, an All-Star Cast From India
description: Indian classical music, an improvising tradition with an age-old repertory, embraces extremes. It can serenely contemplate a single note suspended in time, and it can flaunt high speed and dramatic crescendos. It can linger over an unadorned melody, or it can abandon that melody for momentary inspirations. It is a spiritual tradition; it is also a pedagogical and dynastic tradition. All of those aspects were part of the Music Festival of India, which brought some of the most distinguished North Indian musicians and one South Indian master to Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALMAN, MINNIE
description: KALMAN-Minnie. On September 13, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Elliot and Myra. Cherished grandmother of Neil and Debbi, Merrill and Philip. Loving great-grandmother of Matthew, Aaron and Emily. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY (Parkside Building).

title: Oil Skimmer to Be Tested
description: In a demonstration of new methods for containing major oil spills, thousands of oranges will be dumped into Great Egg Inlet at Ocean City on Wednesday and then skimmed up by a revamped Coast Guard cutter.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 6 with the obituary of the tap dancer and choreographer Harriet Browne misidentified the dance group for which she was costumed, and misspelled the name of the group cited erroneously. She was shown in the Silver Belles. The other group was the Copa Setics, not Copasetics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, HARRY
description: JACOBS-Harry, of Englewood, NJ. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Robert Jacobs, Rochelle Zudkewich, and the late Mark. Dear father-in-law of Sally Jacobs and Arik Zudkewich. Loving grandfather of seven grandchildren. Services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ, on Monday, September 15, at 9:30 AM.

title: Fire-Related Civilian Deaths Reached a 37-Year Low in 1996
description: The number of fire-related deaths of civilians in New York City fell last year to the lowest point in 37 years, continuing a downward trend that began six years ago, the Fire Department announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTOCEK, SR. ANNA CARMITA
description: POTOCEK-Sr. Anna Carmita. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen, on September 13, 1997. Dearest sister of Sr. Jeanne de Lourdes, S.C., Rev. Msgr. Cyril J. Potocek, Mary and Ann. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY, on Monday, 1-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 11 AM at the convent. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY.

title: New Poll Says Users Give Parks Good Ratings
description: More than three-quarters of the people who regularly use New York City's parks say the parks are in either good or excellent condition, according to a poll by the Parks Council, an independent research and advocacy group.

title: When Birds of Man and Nature Meet; Falcons Keep Geese and Gulls From Colliding With Jets
description: As a Boeing 747 thundered to a landing at Kennedy International Airport, two silver Chevy Blazers raced down a road paralleling the runway, patrolling for intruders.

description: Wage Gap Widens Again Between Men and Women

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ARREST IN OFFICER'S DEATH -- One man was arrested and another was being sought in the death of an off-duty police sergeant who was slain in Queens under mysterious circumstances. B3.

title: When the Mighty Fall Quickly, a Long Season Takes on New Challenges
description: What happens when it is mid-September and your football team has already reached a crisis point?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUBER, FLORIAN
description: STUBER-Florian. A founding member of The Dickens Reading Group, for 26 years he graced us with his intelligence, erudition, humor, kindness, courteousness and unfailing generosity of spirit. He was a faithful friend and dear companion. His memory will be a blessing to us. Olivia Altschuler, Judith Baumrin, Joanna Cole, Nancy Dunbar, Barbara Fisher, JoAnn McGrath, Jane Melzer, Susan Rieger, and Susan Strane

title: Jet Nose-Dives At Air Show, Gutting Home And Injuring 6
description: An Air Force F-117A stealth fighter performing combat maneuvers in an air show northeast of Baltimore inexplicably broke apart in midair and crashed into a shorefront residential community.

title: Redskins Open Stadium With Overtime Victory
description: The Washington Redskins opened their big new stadium in the suburbs today by defeating the Arizona Cardinals, 19-13, on a touchdown pass in overtime to Michael Westbrook, who may have opened the door to the doghouse he put himself in during the preseason.

description: An Odd-Couple Concept,

description: To the Editor:

title: Headstones Overturned In S.I. Jewish Cemetery
description: About 90 headstones at a Jewish cemetery on Staten Island were found overturned yesterday and swastikas had been spray-painted on 5, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN LEGUIZAMO, the actor and writer, will perform 40 roles in ''Freak,'' which he describes as a ''semi-demi-quasi-pseudo autobiography,'' when it opens tomorrow at the Atlantic Theater in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

title: The style of on-line services may come to matter more than their substance.
description: THERE was an uncanny thrill, about 15 years ago, when at a lumbering speed of 300 baud, characters seeped across the computer display announcing that I was connected to Compuserve.

title: Gooden Shaky but Standing After Audition for October
description: Dwight Gooden survived tonight. He survived a near fiasco of a first inning when he could not locate the strike zone with a magnifying glass. He survived against the ornery Orioles, who do not enjoy being stifled. He survived to keep himself alive in the tepid competition with Kenny Rogers to be the Yankees' fourth starter in the post-season.

title: Met Hires A Russian As Backup For Levine
description: Breaking with tradition, the Metropolitan Opera has engaged Valery Gergiyev, director of the Marinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, as its first principal guest conductor, advancing a growing partnership with his Kirov Opera and Ballet.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The artist RED GROOMS is designing a carousel where people will ride people, not horses.

title: A Mideast Peace Can't Be Built on Punishment; Arafat's Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Couple Gives $30 Million To Penn State
description: In the latest example of multimillion-dollar fund-raising by a public university, Penn State has announced a $30 million donation to create an honors college within the university.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELSEL, MILTON
description: HELSEL-Milton. A very special, sweet, kind man has died. We will remember his softness and his caring for all people. He will be missed by all who knew him. Our thoughts are with his wife Selma, his children Meryl and Bob Meltzer, and Eileen Swartz, his grandchildren Neal Meltzer and Sara Meltzer and Reesa Swartz Fischer and Steven Fischer and Jeffrey Swartz and Shayna Swartz and his great grandchildren. Gale Ryan and Jordan Bruce and Marilyn, Jennifer and Justin

title: A Mideast Peace Can't Be Built on Punishment; Enclaves Aren't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Saatchi Canada Acquires an Agency
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Canada unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in Toronto has acquired Campaign Communications in Vancouver, British Columbia. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Hospital Says It Shut Unit After 4 Babies Died
description: Children's Hospital here reported today that it had temporarily closed its neonatal intensive care unit after four infants died of a bacterial infection.

title: War on the Media in Argentina
description: For the second time this year, an Argentine who spoke out about government abuses has become the victim of violent attack. Last week four men kidnapped Adolfo Scilingo, the only torturer from the ''dirty war'' of the 1970's whose conscience compelled him to tell the public about the murders and tortures he and his colleagues had committed. Mr. Scilingo's kidnappers released him after beating him and carving into his face the initials of three journalists who had reported his statements. The attack follows by nine months the murder of a photojournalist, Jose Luis Cabezas.

title: Study Supports Use of Stimulants For Children With Hyperactivity
description: A NEW study supports the value of stimulant drugs in treating children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, although scientists caution that the drugs may already be overused in this country.

title: Now, Giuliani's Best Friends Are Democrats
description: To any casual television viewer, there is no more invisible figure in New York City politics at the moment than a Republican who supports Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for re-election.

title: 'Flute' Makes the Most of the Comic and the Sober
description: Perhaps the most winning aspect of the New York City Opera's 1987 production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute,'' which had its first performances of the season on Saturday afternoon and evening, is the deftness with which it presents both the work's comic fairy tale qualities and its more sober glimpses into the human spirit.

title: Time Slows James Brown, But It Can't Trim His Soul
description: Soul, blues, gospel, rhythm-and-blues, jazz, funk: they're all connected, and there was a time in popular music when nobody felt compelled to specialize. The concert on Sunday afternoon at Central Park Summerstage, with James Brown and Chaka Khan, harked back to that era, before narrow radio formats and niche marketing.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Oil Spill Money to Help Birds
description: The United States Department of Environmental Protection has earmarked $40,000, from a fund established as part of a legal settlement following the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska, to protect migratory bird habitats on the Cape May peninsula, The Associated Press reported.

title: Market Place; A Russian bank turns about, a rare response to shareholders.
description: WHEN Uneximbank took control of Norilsk Nickel last month, it did not look like a banner day for shareholders' rights.

title: Mideast 'Kindness'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Prison in the Forest; The Itinerant Jailer Is an Adirondack Plan's Best Booster
description: In the Adirondacks, Richard Moeller is the prototypical migrant worker, though you might not realize it from his job description. He does not pick vegetables, trap beaver or sell encyclopedias. He is a prison guard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDELL, GERALDINE
description: MINDELL-Geraldine. On September 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving sister of Sarah and the late Martin David. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Services Thursday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St & Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to The Jefferson Market Garden, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, ARTHUR
description: MITCHELL-Arthur. 85, September 10, 1997, in New York City. Former author and professor of economics. Survivors include Bess Hecht Mitchell, his wife for 38 years, his nephew Robert Belenky and cousin Joseph Machlis.

title: As a Status Symbol, Big East Is Lagging
description: If the objective of the Big East Conference is to bring the competition to a point where everyone has a chance, then the current season is accomplishing just that.

title: Product Delay Sends Microsoft Shares Lower
description: Shares of the Microsoft Corporation fell more than 5 percent in heavy trading yesterday after the company confirmed that it would delay shipments of Windows 98, the new version of its dominant operating system software.

title: Weird Karma in the End Zone
description: This was eerie. It was like watching Moses descend, and watching water part. And then watching the Patriots drown.

title: WebTV Introduces a System Linking Live TV and Internet
description: WebTV Networks, designers of set-top boxes that bring Internet services to the television screen, introduced an upgraded version yesterday that melds live television programming with related pages on the World Wide Web.

title: Guards Find A Pipe Gun After Inmate Is Shot in Jail
description: An inmate shot himself in the leg with a homemade gun inside the Brooklyn House of Detention yesterday afternoon, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, FRANK
description: JOSEPH-Frank. On Sept. 12, 1997, patriarch of the family. Beloved husband of Klara, devoted father of John, adored father-in-law of Debbie, cherised zayde of Rebecca, Nina and Max, loving brother of Moshe, David, Ristu, and Jack. His unique wit, charm and warmth will be sorely missed by a loving, extended family, and many dear friends. Shiva will be observed at the home.

title: No Shortage of Criticism, But Little for Each Other
description: With no idea whether they will actually face each other in a runoff next week, Ruth W. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton nonetheless sat down for a courtly televised debate last night as if the contest was still on, displaying the occasional flash of disagreement but generally concurring with each other's criticism of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Jets Supply Effort, but Parcells Holds the Praise
description: A sleep-deprived Bill Parcells would not allow the Jets to believe that close is good enough today.

title: Whitman Shifts Focus From Car Insurance to Record on Other Issues
description: After six weeks of making automobile insurance the focal point of her re-election campaign, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is now seeking to move the campaign debate onto other issues and away from the one subject that some advisers believe makes her vulnerable to her Democratic challenger.

title: Aron Broches, 83, Official at World Bank
description: Aron Broches, who was general counsel of the World Bank for 20 years until he retired in 1979, died on Sept. 9 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington after a brief illness, his son, Paul, said yesterday. He was 83.

title: Will Hare, 81, a Founder of Actors Studio
description: Will Hare, a veteran character actor and a founding member of the Actors Studio, died on Aug. 31 at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 and lived in Weehawken, N.J.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japanese Economy Follows A Zigzag; Exporters Thrive as Other Sectors Sink
description: The giants of Japan Inc. may be full of vitality, but they increasingly resemble oases in a wasteland.

title: How Long Will Good Times Roll?
description: Steady growth for six and a half years. Low and steady inflation. Unemployment under 5 percent, the lowest level in decades. Productivity -- the amount of workers' output -- rising at the fastest clip in years. Stock markets soaring to dizzying heights.

title: Cloudy, Chance of Annihilation
description: I live in a canyon outside Los Angeles. The house launches itself out from a hillside and over a chasm below, away from the land and into the air. A few years ago, before I moved here, this canyon was razed by a terrible and spectacular fire; that was before the earthquake and after the riots. Every autumn holds the potential for such a disaster, when the hot Santa Ana winds blow and everyone from Malibu to the Palisades to the Hollywood Hills holds his or her breath waiting for the wrong match struck at the wrong moment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROTTA, PAULINE (NEE BORNSTEIN)
description: GROTTA-Pauline (nee Bornstein) of West Orange, N.J. Devoted wife of the late Louis William Grotta. Mother of Louis William Grotta, Jr. of New Vernon and Suzanne Nimaroff of Summit. Sister of Anne Sobel. Survived by four grandchildren and 4 great grandchildren. Funeral Wednesday, 10:30AM, September 17, 1997 from Temple B'Nai Jeshurun, Short Hills, N.J. Donations to the Grotta Foundation for Senior Care or a charity of your choice. For information contact Berheim Apter Goldsticker, (973-763-3505).

title: Violence Against Women Isn't a Numbers Game; No Feminist Trickery
description: To the Editor:

title: Interacting To the Beat Of a Street
description: Restless sleepers awoke to the tumultuous rhythms of urban life in ''El Puente/The Bridge,'' presented by Global Exchange/Danza Libre as an attraction of the Danspace Project of St. Mark's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POLIAK, SAUL AND JANICE
description: POLIAK-Saul and Janice. The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism will hold a tribute to the late Saul and Janice Poliak, champions of the First Amendment and benefactors of the Journalism School on Friday, September 19th, at 12 noon in the Joseph Pulitzer World Room of the Journalism School, 116th Street and Broadway, New York City.

title: Chief of Coke Still in Hospital
description: The Coca-Cola Company's chairman and chief executive, Roberto C. Goizueta, has begun a dual regimen of radiation and chemotherapy to treat a malignant lung tumor discovered last week.

title: Executive Changes
description: MATTEL INC., Los Angeles, the toy maker, named Bruce L. Stein chief operating officer. Mr. Stein, 42, will retain his position as president of Mattel Worldwide. His new duties include overseeing Mattel's Fisher-Price unit.

title: Sara Lee Announces a Big Revamping, and Stock Climbs
description: The Sara Lee Corporation announced a major revamping yesterday that would include the sale of several manufacturing assets and a $3 billion repurchase of the company's common stock, the largest such repurchase in the company's history.

title: Corrections
description: An entry on Sunday in the ''Playing in the Neighborhood'' column of the City section, about a musical comedy titled ''Barrio Babies,'' misstated the telephone number for ticket information. It is (212) 239-4324.

title: Even Scorecard Can't Help TNT Analysts
description: Who wouldn't want a television analyst to be provocative, smart and entertaining? Such skills would seem to be basic job requirements. If Fox's John Madden, ABC's Dan Dierdorf, NBC's Paul Maguire and Phil Simms or ESPN's Joe Theismann don't enhance a National Football League telecast they're not doing their jobs.

title: Kodak Warns Of Weak Sales; Stock Drops
