description: The Eastman Kodak Company warned yesterday that third-quarter sales and earnings could be below expectations, and its stock tumbled in late trading.

title: Ewing to Lead Players Union
description: Knicks center Patrick Ewing was elected president of the National Basketball Players Association yesterday, giving him one of the strongest voices in the union he once tried to decertify.

title: Citing Fraud in Home Care, Clinton Halts New Permits
description: President Clinton said today that he would bar new home health agencies from the Medicare program for at least six months while the Federal Government develops more stringent standards against fraud.

title: GRANCARE AND LIVING CENTERS RENEGOTIATE MERGER PLAN
description: Grancare Inc. and Living Centers of America Inc. changed the terms of their planned merger yesterday to have Living Centers stockholders exchange a smaller amount of shares and Grancare holders exchange all of their stock. Under the revised agreement, Living Centers shareholders will receive $40.50 a share in cash for about 90.5 percent of their shares and will keep the remainder of their stock in the recapitalized company. Previously, the shareholders were to exchange 93 percent. The merger, announced in May, will create the second-biggest United States nursing-home chain, with about $1.9 billion of revenue. The shares will now be converted at 0.2346 share of recapitalized Living Centers stock for each Grancare share, down from 0.2469.

title: Schools Chief Drops His Plan For Majors
description: The State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, backed away yesterday from a proposal that would have obliged all of the state's high school students to select a field of concentrated study similar to a college major.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELSEY, BILLIE (FAY CHARNEY)
description: GELSEY-Billie (Fay Charney), 97, Miami Beach, Florida. Widow of Samuel Z. Gelsey to whom she was married for 65 years, beloved mother of Helen Zirinsky and Daniel Gelsey, dearly loved grandmother of Nancy, John, William, Andrew, James and the late Jane, great-grandmother of Sara, Hanna, Samuel, Jacob and Shira. Services Wednesday in Miami Beach, Florida, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1250 Normandy.

title: Bonds Rise As Investors Await Reports
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday as investors waited for today's reports on consumer prices and industrial production and capacity utilization in August, which are expected to provide more proof that the economy is expanding at a noninflationary pace.

title: Wheat Falls on Export News As Weather Lifts Soybeans
description: Wheat prices fell yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, hurt in part by speculation that Egypt had bought wheat from outside the United States and by rain that drenched the Central Plains as farmers prepared to plant their next crop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINETTE, CHARLES. M.
description: FINETTE-Charles. M. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Steven and Deborah, Debra and Leonard, Barry and Sharon; beloved grandfather of Nicole, Zena, Zachary, Leah, Lucas, Elijah and Ezra; beloved brother of Florance and her husband Sam, and brother-in-law of Walter and Rose Klein. Memorial service will be held in Charlotte, VT.

title: Albright Says She Found 'Tattered' Mideast Situation
description: Evaluating her first official trip to the Middle East, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today, ''The crisis of confidence there is worse than I thought -- it's fairly tattered.''

title: Old Problem Is Pinpointed In the Crash Of Fighter
description: The crash of a $45 million stealth fighter near Baltimore on Sunday began with excessive flutter of a part that helps control the plane, Air Force officials said today.

title: Representative Plans Bill To Aid Deaf Immigrants
description: Representative Nydia M. Velazquez, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that she would introduce legislation to temporarily bar the deportation of the deaf Mexican immigrants who were found living in virtual servitude in Queens in July.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The English Heritage, a British Government group that celebrates notables who have been dead for at least 20 years, usually places its blue plaques at the homes of people like George Frederick Handel, who lived at 25 Brook Street, in the Mayfair section of London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPMAN, WILLIAM HAVEN
description: CHAPMAN-William Haven, of New Canaan, CT., died at home on August 27, 1997 after a long illness. Willy was 4 years old. His death was attributed to cardiac arrest. Willy was born on August 29, 1992, son of John William Haven Chapman and Jane Scanlan Chapman. Surviving, in addition to his parents are two brothers, Jack Chapman and Tom Chapman of Greenwich, CT., and New Canaan, CT.; a sister, Katie Chapman of New Canaan, and his maternal grandmother Joan Rouleau of South Salem, New York. A service was held at Lakeview Cemetery on August 29.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Libertarian Seeks Funds
description: The question of whether the Libertarian gubernatorial candidate, Murray Sabrin, will qualify for $280,000 in public matching funds remained unresolved yesterday after the State Election Law Enforcement Commission asked his campaign for more documentation.

title: Jews Oust Arab Tenants From House In Jerusalem
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today condemned the action of militant Jewish settlers who moved overnight into a house in an Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem, raising a new focus of tension along the volatile Arab-Israeli divide.

title: LORAL TO SELL BACK 22.5% INTEREST IN K & F INDUSTRIES
description: Loral Space and Communications Ltd. said yesterday that it would sell its 22.5 percent interest in K & F Industries back to the company for about $80 million. Closely held K & F also would buy Chase Capital Partners L.P.'s 2.2 percent interest for $7.7 million, a K & F spokesman, Kenneth Schwartz, said. K & F's chairman and chief executive, Bernard Schwartz, who holds the same positions at Loral, will increase his K & F ownership to 50 percent from 23.5 percent as part of the agreement. Lehman Brothers' Merchant Banking Group, which now owns 48.2 percent, will hold the other half after the transaction is completed. K & F makes aircraft wheels, brakes and anti-skid systems for airplanes as well as aircraft fuel tanks and other aviation equipment.

title: Theorists See Evolutionary Advantages In Menopause
description: THE Hadza people of northern Tanzania are a small group of hunter-gatherers who share a language, a culture and a distaste for gardening. Time and again, government and church agencies have sought to transmute them into full-time farmers, but the Hazda have always returned to the bush, where they subsist on wild goods like fruits, honey, tubers and game. The terrain is hard and hilly, and so is the life, but on one incomparable resource the foragers can always rely: a pack of old ladies with hearts like young horses.

title: Brave Quest of Africa Hunt: Bringing Back Extinct Quagga
description: ON the trail of the extinct quagga, one turns off the freeway just east of Cape Town airport and drives past a shantytown where roadside prostitutes sit by fires under the ragged gum trees. Then an abrupt left onto the ultramodern campus of the National Accelerator Center.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; No Smoking at County Jail
description: Following the lead of several other county jails around the state, officials at the Cumberland County Jail began enforcing a no-smoking policy yesterday, part of a plan to cut down on health problems related to second-hand smoke, the prison's warden, Stephen Kaftan, said.

title: Sinn Fein Joins Ulster Talks But Protestants Stay Away
description: For the first time since Ireland was divided in 1922 into the independent Irish Free State and the British province of Ulster, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, entered formal, broad-based peace negotiations today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBLE, ANNA (LOUGHLIN)
description: NOBLE-Anna (Loughlin), age 88, on Sunday, Sept. 14, 1997, at home. She was a Lease Custodian with Charles F. Noyes Co., New York, for over 50 years, retiring in 1974. Survivors include her brother, William Loughlin, a sister, Rita Walsh, and many nieces and nephews. Moore's Home for Funerals, 1591 Alps Rd., Wayne, NJ, 973-694-0072.

title: Ingersoll-Rand to Buy Westinghouse's Thermo King Unit
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company announced yesterday that it would buy the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's Thermo King division for $2.56 billion in cash.

title: Lahic Journal; From Splendid Isolation, Treasures for the World
description: The first clue to what makes this remote Caucasian village so extraordinary is the gentle tapping sound that spills from workshops along its roughly cobbled streets.

title: Tiniest Terror Plaguing Los Angeles
description: In the catalogue of natural disasters, California can always be counted on to hold its own, from earthquakes and mudslides to brush fires and floods. But in these hot, dry days of seemingly endless summer, the region is also dogged by a tinier terror, a black speck about the size of this ''t.''

title: Honoring Mother Teresa
description: To the Editor:

title: A Streetwise Solomon
description: Edward I. Koch, not famed for a judicial temperament while presiding over New York City, last week donned robes and assumed the bench of ''The People's Court,'' long operated from California by Joseph A. Wapner. This new, 60-minute version is definitely New York New York. It takes its zesty flavor not just from the homegrown Mr. Koch but from a feature called ''People's Corner,'' which gives pedestrians at Broadway and 33d Street an opportunity to vent on each day's cases; it's like being at a Rangers game.

title: Amgen to Pay $96 Million in Drug Dispute
description: Amgen Inc. said today that it would pay Ortho Pharmaceutical $96 million to settle a dispute between the companies over the anemia drug Epoetin alfa.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Armenian Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: A Good Reason to Floss
description: NOW there is another reason to floss your teeth every day and get regular dental checkups. Dental infections like gum diseases are associated with a doubling of the risk of having a stroke, a new study shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, GERTRUDE (GERRY)
description: YOUNG-Gertrude (Gerry). Devoted mother of Joseph and Marion, beloved mother-in-law of Richard Bernstein, adored grandmother of Mitchell and Cindy Bernstein, loving aunt. Services Wednesday at 11 A.M., (Boulevard Riverside Chapels), 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMORY, PAMELA JANE FENN
description: POMORY-Pamela Jane Fenn, of Virginia Beach, Virginia (formerly of Huntington and Shelter Island, New York), on September 13, 1997. Wife of Mark L. Pomory. Mother of Colin and Sean. Daughter of Dick and Mary Jane Roos Fenn. Sister of Susan and Jennifer. Aunt of Andrew and Dana. Reposing at The Shelter Island Funeral Home, 38 North Ferry Road, Shelter Island, tonight 7-9 P.M. only. Funeral Mass, on Wednesday, at 11 A.M., Our Lady of the Isle R.C. Church. Interment in Our Lady of the Isle R.C. Cemetery.

title: HEALTH WATCH; Red Wine in Virtual Tie
description: Health-conscious readers used to fine-tuning their life styles to the latest medical report may be surprised by a new study on the relative benefits of red wine, white wine, beer and liquor. The researchers' conclusion: Drink what you want.

title: Chess
description: The United States Invitational champion, Alex Yermolinsky, topped a 536-player field to win the 1997 United States Open title in Orlando, Fla., from Aug. 3 to 15. This was the second time in three years that the 39-year-old Euclid, Ohio, grandmaster has won the tournament. Yermolinsky scored 10 1/2-1 1/2 in the 11-round Swiss-system event and was awarded a $7,000 prize. In addition, he will be seeded into next year's Invitational.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, BRO. GREGORY, FSC
description: HUNT-Bro. Gregory, FSC. Age 71. Assistant to the President of Manhattan College for Alumni Affairs. Devoted son of the late Patrick and May Regan Hunt. Beloved brother of Marion Cahill and the late Thomas Hunt. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. The wake will be held in the Rotunda, Memorial Hall, at Manhattan College campus on Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM and Wednesday, 2-5 and 78 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at The Chapel of DeLaSalle and his Brothers Wednesday evening, 8 PM. Interment will take place on Thursday, September 18, from the Christian Brothers Center, 4415 Post Rd, Bronx, NY, leaving at 10 AM, for the Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Mideast 'Kindness'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasure of Biodiversity Discovered, and It's in Nation's Yard
description: FEW ecosystems in North America would seem to rival the Everglades of Florida for generating awe and, these days, dismay over their ecological state. Renowned for their biological diversity, but also for steep declines in many species because of the damage done by adjacent ditching, pollution and development, the drying Everglades have become a prime example of imperiled parcels of wild American nature.

title: Violence Against Women Isn't a Numbers Game; Fear of Retaliation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, S.
description: FELDMAN-S. Newton. Passed away Friday evening, Sept. 12 after a long illness, bravely suffered. Son of Sam Feldman and Blanche Passerman, late of Phila, Penn. Newton was a veteran of W.W. II, and retired as a Lt. Commander of the U.S. Naval Reserve. He was a devoted son, uncle, and mentor to many colleagues in the Securities industries and at the Bar. Newton was an active supporter of the New York City Police Dept., a respected member of the NYC Bar Association, and the Harvard Club, and many professional committees. He will be sorely missed by his entire family. Graveside services Wednesday, Sept. 17th, 1:30 P.M. at Arlington National Cemetery. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a date and time to be announced. The Feldman Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLER, RONALD R.
description: WALLER-Ronald R. All of us at Today Video are deeply saddened at the loss of our colleague and friend of 15 years. Ronald Waller, Chief Engineer & Vice President, passed away Friday morning. We are grateful for the privilege of having been associated with him. A trust fund for his children has been set up by Today Video. May God bless you, Ron, we love you. For any information concerning the trust fund or interment, contact us at 212-239-3999.

title: How to Hold, How to Fold: A Lost Art
description: THE very fact that you are reading this suggests you noticed that the newspaper came in six sections today instead of the old four.

title: Chess
description: The United States Invitational champion, Alex Yermolinsky, topped a 536-player field to win the 1997 United States Open title in Orlando, Fla., from Aug. 3 to 15. This was the second time in three years that the 39-year-old Euclid, Ohio, grandmaster has won the tournament. Yermolinsky scored 10 1/2-1 1/2 in the 11-round Swiss-system event and was awarded a $7,000 prize. In addition, he will be seeded into next year's Invitational.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of a wedding report on Sunday misspelled the surname of the woman married to Robert Davis Bernstein. She is Laure Lannes de Montebello, not de Montbello.

title: New Culprit in Deaths of Frogs
description: WHEN Dr. Karen Lips trekked deep into the Panamanian rain forest last Christmas to continue her field study of tree frogs, she found a horrifying scene: dead frogs were everywhere.

title: Muzzatti Makes Debut For Rangers in Victory
description: Jason Muzzatti says he is comfortable in his role with the Rangers. And since he will be backing up Mike Richter this season, understanding and embracing that role is a good thing.

title: O'Brien's Goal: Break Own Record
description: Dan O'Brien, the 1996 Olympic gold medalist in the decathlon, has some bad news for the competition: there is room for him to improve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, MURRAY
description: SUSSMAN-Murray. Congregation Rodeph Sholom records with sorrow the passing of our long time member, Murray Sussman. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife Miriam, their sons, Alan and Leonard, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Jack B. Levitt, President

title: Of America as a Splendid Junk Heap
description: UNDERWORLD

title: Colombian Utility Sold for $2.18 Billion
description: Two groups led by Endesa S.A. of Spain agreed today to pay $2.18 billion for Bogota's power company, in one of the largest sales ever of a Latin American utility.

title: Patients Who Require Antibiotics For Dental Work Can Cut Doses
description: MILLIONS of people with heart conditions who have been advised to take antibiotics before dental work can now reduce the dose by more than half, according to new recommendations issued by the American Heart Association. The revised guidelines also clarify which patients and procedures require medication, and offer more alternative drugs than in the past for people who are allergic to certain antibiotics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, ISAAC
description: GOLDIN-Isaac. Beloved husband of Pearl. Devoted father of Shmuel and Barbara, Rita and Yerachmiel Fuchs, Chana and Avrohom Garfinkel. Cherished grandfather of 21 grandchildren, he will be sorely and deeply missed. Services will be held today, 10:00 am, I.J. Morris, Inc, Hemptead, L.I.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: AGENCY ACCUSED -- The A.C.L.U. has accused immigration officials of illegally detaining a supporter of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman. B2.

title: Canada Tries Once Again to Make Unity Palatable to Quebec
description: After two years of observing an edgy armistice over the most divisive of issues in Canada, the English-speaking leaders of the country are moving aggressively to counter Quebec's campaign for an independent French-speaking nation.

title: Nassau Chief Wants to Cut Property Tax By 5 Percent
description: The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, today proposed an election-year budget that would cut county property taxes by about 5 percent, or between $17 and $26 for a typical homeowner.

title: Judge Denies ITT Move to Drop Hilton Suit
description: A Federal judge today denied the ITT Corporation's motion to dismiss a suit by the Hilton Hotels Corporation asserting that ITT management was failing to serve shareholders properly in breaking up the company through spinoffs and the sale of hotels.

title: I.B.M.'S TIVOLI SYSTEMS PLANS TO BUY UNISON SOFTWARE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its Tivoli Systems unit would acquire Unison Software Inc. for about $170 million. Unison, based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes software for managing computer networks. Under the agreement, each Unison share will be converted into the right to receive $15 in cash or I.B.M. common stock, at the shareholder's discretion. Unison shareholders may choose to receive up to about 50 percent of the total value of the transaction in cash. Tivoli Systems, which also makes networking software, was acquired by I.B.M. in early 1996. Unison's shares rose 50 cents, to $14.50. I.B.M.'s shares fell $1.50, to $96.25.

title: Queen Issues Feisty Denial Of Disputes Over Funeral
description: Stung by perceptions of insensitivity to the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, as well as the royal family's new drop in popularity polls, a spokesman for the Queen issued a statement today notable for its ferocity in denying reports of royal disagreements.

title: On My Mind; The Right Message
description: Sometime this fall, the new American movement to focus attention on the persecution around the world of Christians and other religious minorities will come up for its first and critical test -- a Congressional vote on legislation to do something, a modest something, to help the suffering.

title: National News Briefs; Arkansas Man Arrested In Series of Sex Assaults
description: Police officers today arrested an Arkansas man and charged him with three sexual assaults attributed to a serial rapist who had come to be known as the ''blue light rapist.''

title: By Design; The Velvet Accent
description: Fall calls for a touch or more of velvet in clothing and accessories, for both day and evening.

title: MARINER HEALTH TO BUY PRISM HEALTH FOR $84 MILLION
description: Mariner Health Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Prism Health Group Inc., a provider of rehabilitation services, for $84 million. Mariner Health, based in New London, Conn., provides health-care services at inpatient centers and nursing homes. It also manages hospital pharmacies. Prism Health, a privately held company based in Boston, provides rehabilitation services in hospitals, nursing homes and patients' homes in 23 states.

title: Arts in America; A Southerner Journeying From Blues to Bureaucracy
description: After William R. Ferris left a teaching position at Yale University 18 years ago to become founding director of the University of Mississippi's Center for the Study of Southern Culture, he wandered through dormitory hallways with his Gibson guitar, playing the blues for any student he thought he could serenade into joining his unconventional program.

title: A Choreographer's Sad But Funny Past
description: Neither laughter nor pain is ever quite undiluted for the character Paula Hunter plays in her solos. Ms. Hunter, a dancer and choreographer from Rhode Island, draws her material from her life as one of five hapless children of a well-meaning but passive mother and a comically lunatic father. But there is not an ounce of self-pity in her blunt yet delicately wrought monologues with movement.

title: A G.E. Apartment Venture
description: GE Capital Services said today that it had agreed to invest $470 million in a venture with the closely held JPI Realty to build and acquire apartments. GE Capital, a General Electric Company unit, and JPI intend to focus on luxury apartments and student housing across the country. JPI, based here, leases and manages more than 22,000 apartments. It has 7,600 additional apartments under development.

title: Other Nations Call New U.S. Terms for Mine Ban Unacceptable
description: Diplomats who have been drafting a treaty to ban land mines said here today that conditions Washington has set for signing the treaty were unacceptable.

title: Federal Express Doubles Earnings
description: The Federal Express Corporation said today that its earnings more than doubled in its fiscal first quarter, far exceeding analysts' expectations, largely because of increased business during the teamsters' strike against United Parcel Services of America Inc.

title: Concern Develops on Wall St. Over Wide Swings in Stocks
description: With the stock market swinging more wildly this year than it has in a long time, Billie Taylor is a bit more cautious about his investments.

title: To American Peacekeepers in Bosnia, Danger Is Just Beginning
description: By late afternoon today, when the last voters had departed in convoys of buses and a company of bone-tired American soldiers had begun the unenviable task of picking up scores of discarded plastic water bottles, it began to rain.

title: Metro Business; Suite for the Blind to Open
description: The Hotel Delmonico in Manhattan plans to open a new suite tomorrow for people who are blind or visually impaired.

title: Equity Office Properties to Absorb Beacon
description: Equity Office Properties Trust, which Sam Zell had already fashioned into the nation's largest publicly traded office real estate empire, today announced plans to acquire the Beacon Properties Corporation, its nearest competitor, in a merger valued at about $2.9 billion plus debt.

title: Seats Found After Crash of New Jersey-Based Plane
description: Searchers found airplane seats and papers in the South Atlantic today, two days after an Air Force transport plane based in New Jersey and a German aircraft apparently collided off the coast of the southern African nation of Namibia before plunging into waters about 4,000 feet deep.

title: Soccer; NOTEBOOK
description: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER

title: The Blame Slag Heap
description: In northern Idaho's Silver Valley, the abstractions of the Superfund program -- ''remediation,'' ''restoration,'' ''liability'' -- meet real life. For over a century, the region's silver mines provided bullets for our soldiers and fortunes for some of our richest corporations. The mines also created a toxic legacy: wastes and tailings, hundreds of billions of pounds of contaminated sediment, leaching into a watershed that is now home to more than half a million people.

title: Q&A
description: Digesting Calcium

title: Boeing Says Jet Output Is Off Pace
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that deliveries of a dozen aircraft scheduled for this month would be delayed until the fourth quarter because of production difficulties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELL, RICHARD, SR.
description: PELL-Richard, Sr. 9/13/97, in Ft. Myers, FL. Retired 1974 partner Pershing and Co. Survived by wife, Stasia, of 54 years, daughter, Jean, son, Richard, Jr., grandchildren, Laura and Richard III and sister, Fay of Westbury, New York.

title: Personal Health
description: PROFESSIONAL beliefs about the possibility of long-term weight loss by those who have a lot to lose have not changed much since 1958, when the renowned obesity specialist Dr. Albert J. Stunkard of the University of Pennsylvania said: ''Most obese persons will not stay in treatment. Of those who stay in treatment, most will not lose weight, and of those who do lose weight, most will regain it.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WESTFIELD AMERICA INC., Los Angeles, a real estate investment trust, will purchase the 50 percent of Meriden Square mall in Meriden, Conn., it did not already own from the closely held GGP/Homart Inc. for $54.5 million.

title: A Continental Divide of Stars
description: The National Hockey League's All-Star Game this season will accent the league's international flavor, with the North American All-Stars taking on the World All-Stars. The game will be played Sunday, Jan. 18, at General Motors Place in Vancouver, British Columbia, just three weeks before most of the same players compete in the Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan.

title: Violence Against Women Isn't a Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISHARA, ELIZABETH (NEE DOOGAN)
description: BISHARA-Elizabeth (nee Doogan). Died September 9, 1997 in Vero Beach, FL. Beloved widow of the late W.N. Bishara. Cherished sister of Mary D. McGuire and Edmund H. Doogan, and the late Francis J. Doogan. Devoted aunt of many nieces and nephews. Retired General Counsel of U.S. Life Insurance Corporation.

title: New Work Proposed For Shuttles: Salvage in Space
description: BILLIONS of dollars' worth of old communication, weather and spy satellites are circling Earth, dead or dormant and usually adrift. Typically, there is little or nothing wrong with them. They have just run out of fuel.

title: Many Pitchers Are Far From Post-Season Form
description: No home run record, no .400 hitter, no races, no playoff pitching.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Country CD's; Getting More Bang for the Twang
description: The twang is rock's primordial sound: the echo of an illicit rendezvous between the bent notes of the blues and the high lonesome holler of country music. But the twang is by no means obsolete. On the recent releases reviewed below, it shows up in familiar contexts and peculiar new ones, as ornery and resilient as ever.

title: Welfare's New Face?
description: To the Editor:

title: Downsizing Activism: Greenpeace Is Cutting Back
description: After 48 hours of daredevil dangling on ropes from a bridge in Seattle, trying to block outgoing trawlers in a recent protest against overfishing, Greenpeace staff members returned to solid ground, only to be told that the environmental group had just laid three of them off.

title: Fight Over Nomination Clearly Shows Rifts in G.O.P.
description: In their final showdown on Capitol Hill last week, Senator Jesse Helms accused William F. Weld, the former Governor of Massachusetts, of threatening to ''begin a war within the Republican Party.'' Today, Mr. Weld, the non-Ambassador, welcomed the battle, declaring, ''To the extent that people are looking at Jesse Helms as the face of the Republican Party, I think that carries a certain amount of freight with it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAXT, RUTH
description: BAXT-Ruth. Wife of Roland Baxt. Former Executive Director of FEGS for over 30 years. Ruth was an integral part of the FEGS family & together with Roland helped to create an organization committed to helping people in need, an organization which today serves over 50,000 people each year. Our heartfelt condolences to Roland and the entire Baxt family. Our thoughts are with you at this time. Joseph Stein, Jr. President and Chairman of the Board Alfred P. Miller Executive Vice President

title: AMERICA WEST SIGNS A $1.4 BILLION DEAL WITH AIRBUS
description: The America West Holdings Corporation's America West Airlines Inc. unit signed a contract with Airbus Industrie valued at $1.4 billion, before undisclosed price discounts, to buy 22 Airbus A319-100 aircraft and 12 Airbus A320-200 aircraft. In a statement Monday, America West said the firm portion of the order was structured as a commitment for 22 A319's and 24 A320's, 12 of which were subject to reconfirmation. The ordered aircraft will be delivered to America West in 1998, 1999 and 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RATNER, MORRIS
description: RATNER-Morris. We miss your loving presence and wise counsel more than we thought possible. We are taking good care of Mom and you would be proud of us. Linda, Lee, Marcy, Julie, Vic, Judy, Elizabeth, Deborah and most of all, Roz

title: Giants Lose Hilliard For Rest Of Season
description: On the day after a troublesome defeat to the Ravens, the Giants faced the dispiriting news that one of their best players would not return this season, another top player appeared unlikely to return this season and a promising player listed for expanded duty had been lost until next year as well.

title: Researchers Find a Concentrated Anticancer Substance in Broccoli Sprouts
description: Scientists have bred a novel form of broccoli that is tender, tangy and richer by far in powerful anticancer compounds than are the familiar broccoli heads slapped onto dinner plates and crudite platters. The new rendition of an old and often despised acquaintance are broccoli sprouts, three-day-old broccoli plants that look like alfalfa or bean sprouts but that have a slight zest to them, a kind of Proustian reminder of the bitter green vegetable from which they sprang.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, PHILIP HOMER
description: PETERS-Philip Homer, 81, died suddenly at his home on August 10, 1997. The former EVP of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co was committed to the greater Boston community and to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Memorial services will be held Sunday, September 21, 1997 at 2 PM at the Wellesley Hills Congregational Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the MIT Class of '37 Scholarship Fund in memory of Philip H. Peters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, STANLEY J.
description: BRODY-Stanley J. We mourn the loss of a pre-eminent leader in the fields of gerontology, rehabilitation and public health and a valuable advisor to The Lighthouse. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife, Elaine and his children and grandchildren. Barbara Silverstone Amy Horowitz Cynthia Stuen The Lighthouse, Inc.

title: Presenting the Governor's First Term in 30 Seconds
description: This is a 30-second television spot from the campaign of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Roadside Inspections to Start
description: Starting next month, the New Jersey State Police and the Department of Motor Vehicles will be conducting random roadside emissions inspections of diesel-powered trucks and buses traveling through the state.

title: Special Education Class Sizes Are Linked to a Drop in Scores
description: A decision by New York City and the state to increase the size of some special education classes has led to a decline in student achievement, according to a study by two New York University professors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBIN, EDWIN I., M.D.
description: CORBIN-Edwin I., M.D., beloved husband of Lenore, loving father of David and wife Bobbi, dedicated grandfather of Leah, Rachel and Jake, on September 13, 1997.

title: Grabbing TV Airwaves
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists Use Light To Create Particles
description: A TRAILBLAZING experiment at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center in California has confirmed a longstanding prediction by theorists that light beams colliding with each other can goad the empty vacuum into creating something out of nothing.

title: The Winners of the 1997 Emmy Awards
description: Drama series:

title: Yankees Bail Out Wells With Some Timely Hits
description: Their starting pitching may be crumbling. Their hitting is definitely not.

title: Private-Suite Concept Is Coming to Broadway
description: Skyboxes and luxury suites have all but saturated the sports world, providing cushy retreats for corporate executives and big-ticket fans in football stadiums and basketball arenas, at golf championships and tennis tournaments.

title: Excerpts From Weld Talk
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by William F. Weld, the former Massachusetts Governor who withdrew today as President Clinton's nominee to be Ambassador to Mexico and from his answers to reporters' questions. The transcript was made available by the Federal News Service.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REID, DONALD DAVID
description: REID-Donald David. In loving memory. We miss you. Charlotte, David and Donna

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTON, DR. HENNY T. (NEE SCHLESINGER)
description: MARTON-Dr. Henny T. (nee Schlesinger), of Fort Lee, N.J., on September 15th, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Oliver Marton. Devoted mother of Dorothy Walensky. Loving grandmother of Michelle. Services ''GuttermanMusicant,'' Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, 1:45 PM (1-800-522-0588).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUTON, AMY VIVIAN
description: LAUTON-Amy Vivian, Monday, September 15, 1997, of Springfield, NJ. Beloved daughter of Dr. Barry Lauton and the late Thea (Nee Odem) Lauton. Loving sister of Julie and Lisa Lauton. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ on Tuesday, September 16, 1997 at 1:00 PM. Interment in the Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: A Political Animal Trained Upon Victory
description: The undisguisable odor of decay envelops ''Atwater: Fixin' to Die'' long before its title character, the guitar-strumming, mischief-making, win-at-all-costs Republican campaign strategist Lee Atwater, learns that he has a terminal illness.

title: A Promise Is Kept: Mill Reopens
description: All in all, this was a very good day for Aaron Feuerstein, owner of Malden Mills and national poster mensch of the nascent American business vogue for having a heart, better known as corporate responsibility.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Two More Arrests in Arson
description: Two more suspects were arrested on Saturday in connection with a fire that gutted a house in Old Bridge over the Labor Day weekend after dozens of teen-agers had spent several days throwing parties in the house while the owner was on vacation, the police said yesterday.

title: Retirement Complexes Sold
description: Marriott International said today that it had agreed to sell seven Brighton Gardens retirement communities to Prime Care Two L.L.C., a private investment company, for about $95 million. Marriott, of Bethesda, Md., said it would continue to manage the properties. Two of the communities, in Winston-Salem and Raleigh, N.C., are in operation. The others are under construction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HASBROUCK BAILEY
description: MILLER-Hasbrouck Bailey, age 74, of New Vernon, N.J., died at home on September 14, 1997. He was comfortable and surrounded by his family. His keen sense of humor and wit, generous spirit and guiding light touched all who new him. He is survived by his loving wife, Jody & his adoring children, Kimberly, Stacey, Hasbrouck Jr. and Sloan. A man of great courage and honor, he will be deeply missed by family and friends. Service on Friday, September 19, 2:00 at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, New Jersey, Lees Hill Road and Glen Alpin.

title: Dollar Falls Against the Mark On Hint of German Rate Rise
description: The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday after the president of the Bundesbank hinted that it might soon raise interest rates.

title: Fund-Raising and Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Sappi in Deal to Create European Paper Giant
description: Sappi Ltd. agreed yesterday to pay almost $1.3 billion for nearly all of KNP Leykam of Austria, creating Europe's largest maker of fine-grade papers used in magazines and annual reports. Sappi, South Africa's biggest paper producer, which already operates in Britain, the United States and Germany, will pay Royal KNP BT N.V. of the Netherlands about 1.5 billion Dutch guilders ($750 million) for the unprofitable Austrian paper company. It will also assume $545 million in debt.

title: HOCKEY: The N.H.L.'s Olympic Gamble; Stars' Participation in Nagano Could Raise Sport's Profile
description: With some gruff bluster and a little bit of chutzpah, Gary Bettman waved his expired passport at people in uniforms as he talked and walked his way in and out of Switzerland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBACK, DR. CHARLES
description: TOBACK-Dr. Charles. On September 11, 1997, of pancreas cancer in New York City. A wonderful guy survived by a loving family who will miss him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLAN, SALLY (MRS. HARRY FRANCIS ROBY DOLAN, JR.)
description: DOLAN-Sally (Mrs. Harry Francis Roby Dolan, Jr.), 78 years old, formerly of Wilton, CT., died on Sunday, September 14, 1997, at her home in North Palm Beach, FL. Married for 51 years, she was predeceased by her husband. Mrs. Dolan is survived by four children: Ann Tauchert of Lexington, KY; Ellen Kirkpatrick of Exeter, NH; Heidi Baldwin of Lynchburg, VA; Peter Dolan of Princeton, NJ; twelve grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A graveside service will be held in Boston later this week. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in her memory to the Lost Tree Chapel, 11149 Turtle Beach Road, North Palm Beach, FL 33408, or to Brimmer and May School, 69 Middlesex Road, Chestnut Hill, MA 02167.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIREFMAN, GUSSIE
description: SIREFMAN-Gussie. September 14, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William; devoted mother of Gloria and Josef and daughter in-law Carol; loving sister of Joseph Kestenbaum and Martha (Max) Silverman; cherished grandmother of Emily (Daniel) Green, and greatgrandmother of Samuel William, and deal aunt. Services Tuesday 12:15 P.M. at ''The Riverside'' , 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 2 Teamsters Trade Barbs As Feud Gets More Heated
description: The controversy over improper campaign fund-raising in the teamsters union heated up yesterday as Ron Carey, the union's president, moved to disqualify James P. Hoffa, the man he defeated last December, while Mr. Hoffa asked for a special prosecutor to investigate links between the Carey campaign and the Democratic Party.

title: Making Their Mark In the Record Book
description: Is the recent irrepressible attack on world distance-running records by African athletes -- 7 set by men in 11 days last month -- a signal that more record-breaking is yet to come? Or were the performances so extraordinary that further advances will decelerate like a correction in the stock market?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGMAN, SAMUEL
description: BREGMAN - Samuel. Beloved father of Dr. Darlene Bregman Ehrenberg & Dr. Alvin Bregman. Loving grandfather of Shari and Tami Bregman and Jonathan and Erica Ehrenberg. Dear father-inlaw of Jeannette Bregman. Cherished husband of the late Pauline Bregman and husband of Anne Goldman Bregman. Services were held Monday, September 15, at the ''Forest Park Chapel'' of Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, JOAN H.
description: FRANK-Joan H. Of New York City. Died July 24, 1997. Memorial service on Friday, September 19, 1997, 3 PM, at Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, NYC.

title: Party Lines Don't Define Debate: Clinton's Foes on Trade Bill Are Democrats
description: The textile workers turned out in force, wearing white T-shirts emblazoned with the name of their union. Before them, on easels, colored charts tracked the United States trade imbalance with Mexico and the size of Mexican wages. And at center stage Representative David E. Bonior, the House minority floor leader, railed against the trade policies of his fellow Democrat, the President.

title: Observer; The Poor Get Poorer
description: Here's why Americans no longer have big families: college.

title: Latest Effort to Schedule New Auctions for Wireless Licenses Fails
description: The departing chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Reed E. Hundt, has failed in a last effort to schedule new auctions for wireless communications licenses that are held by companies in danger of defaulting on more than $10 billion in payments.

title: Patterns
description: Less Space at Chelsea Piers

title: Fine Those Who Deprive Workers of Sleep
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Denies Seeking I.R.S. Audit of Clinton Accuser
description: The White House denied today that it had any knowledge of an Internal Revenue Service audit of Paula Corbin Jones, who has accused President Clinton of making an improper sexual advance in a Little Rock hotel room six years ago.

title: Accounts
description: * Frierson & Mee, New York, was named as the first agency for two accounts with combined billings estimated at $3 million: Retail Media Systems, a media company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and New Frontiers, New York, a travel company that is a subsidiary of Nouvelles Frontieres, Paris.

title: Prudent on Central Park
description: To the Editor:

title: After Game 1 Homer Barrage, Mets Manage Only a Split
description: On the other side of Brian McRae, happy stragglers made their way into the Mets' clubhouse after winning the first game of a doubleheader here tonight in another extraordinary comeback after another wild finish.

title: At New Jersey Air Base, Day of Anxiety and Hope
description: On a day of waiting here, Air Force pilots stopped flying and a prayer vigil was held for the nine-man crew of a C-141 Starlifter transport jet missing off the coast of southwest Africa since Saturday afternoon.

title: Law Seen Aiding City in Battle Over Illegal Home Conversions
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has signed legislation giving New York City a weapon it had long sought in the battle against illegal conversions of homes into crowded, dangerous apartments, a growing problem in many poor neighborhoods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWCOMB, ROBERT S.
description: NEWCOMB-Robert S. Of Bethlehem, PA. Died Sept. 14 at age 77. Formerly of Chatham, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Doris, loving father of Nancy Newcomb Hargraves of NY and Robert of Charlottesville, VA. Memorial services at First Presbyterian Church, Bethlehem, PA, Thursday, Sept 18 at 11 AM. Contributions may be made to Lehigh University.

title: Dresdner Official Under Investigation
description: The supervisory board chairman of Dresdner Bank A.G. is under investigation for possible tax evasion, prosecutors said yesterday, amid a three-year investigation into whether bank employees illegally advised customers how to avoid taxes. The home of the executive, Wolfgang Roeller, was searched on Sept. 2 based on accusations made by an anonymous source, said Peter Lichtenstein, a spokesman for the Dusseldorf prosecutor's office.

title: Eagles Let Upset Slip Through Fingers
description: Field goal, field goal, field goal, field goal, field goal.

title: Ghost at China's Communist Banquet Recalls Tiananmen
description: The mere mention of June 4, the date of the massacre near Tiananmen Square in 1989, still has deep political resonance in this city. The event has a way of popping up when leaders least desire it.

title: Rats Need Hugging, Too
description: IT is a nervous life, being a rat. But a mother's love can ease the burden. Dr. Dong Liu and colleagues from McGill University in Montreal and Emory University in Atlanta have proved it.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Gambling Earnings Are Up
description: Casinos in Atlantic City earned $395.5 million on gambling in August, a 6 percent increase from a year ago, according to figures released yesterday by the Casino Control Commission. Results from 12 casinos reported to the commission showed earnings of $276.3 on slot machines, with an additional $119.3 million from table games. So far this year, the industry has earned $2.7 billion on gambling, a 3.5 percent increase.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARTH, PAMELA
description: BARTH-Pamela. 1946-1991. Always remembered. Phyllis and Harris

title: Absentee Vote May Give Nomination to Messinger
description: A new count of voting in last Tuesday's Democratic mayoral primary has discovered thousands of votes for Ruth W. Messinger that were missed that night, now putting her within a hair of the 40 percent she needs to avoid a runoff with the Rev. Al Sharpton, the Board of Elections reported yesterday. The final outcome rests with absentee and other paper ballots that will be counted today.

title: Fund-Raising and Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicare Overhaul Is Halted, Bogging Down in Complexity
description: The Clinton Administration has terminated the contract for a vast new Medicare computer system that had been promoted as a way to speed payment of claims, improve customer service and combat fraud in Medicare, the nation's largest health insurance program, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, JANIS WINFREY
description: BURKE-Janis Winfrey, 87, on September 11th, in West Palm Beach, FL., of heart failure. Loving aunt of Carey and Jane Winfrey and great aunt of Graham and Wells Winfrey. Prominent owner of thoroughbred horses, including Dedicate and Squared Away. Services private in Wills Point, Tx. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Metro Business; A New York Bank To Stay in the Bronx
description: Spurred by a package of city tax incentives, the New York National Bank has decided against moving out of New York and will instead move its corporate headquarters to another part of the South Bronx, where it will also open a new branch, the city announced yesterday.

title: Third Defense Line Found at Troy
description: IN their continuing explorations of ancient Troy, archeologists have uncovered evidence of a wooden palisade that served as an additional line of defense beyond the stone walls of the city in the late Bronze Age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MARY R.
description: KAPLAN-Mary R. Sutton Place Synagogue extends heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Honorary President, Warren Alpert and his family on the loss of his beloved sister. May the memory of this loving woman remain always as a blessing. Richard Thaler, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Weld Ends Fight Over Nomination By Withdrawing
description: William F. Weld pulled the plug today on his nomination as Ambassador to Mexico, saying he realized that pressing his case might jeopardize the Clinton Administration's relationship with Republicans on Capitol Hill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, MAX
description: SIMON - Max. The honorary Trustees of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison extend their heartfelt sympathy to the Simon family for so great a loss. Max was a founder, past president and honorary trustee. His commitment to our synagogue was exemplary. Irving N. Claremon Honorary Chairman of the Board

title: Bowness Pins Isle Hopes On Salo as No. 1 Goalie
description: Tommy Salo was the Islanders' No. 1 goalie when last season ended, and he will be the starting goalie when this season begins, Coach Rick Bowness said when training camp opened last week.

title: House Ready to Step In On Fund-Raising Cases
description: Congress's costly, politically polarized inquiry into 1996 campaign abuses is to open a second front Wednesday when a House panel of 45 members begins public hearings into the same big-money bonanzas already being finetooth-combed across Capitol Hill by the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISSO, JOSEPHINE
description: RISSO-Josephine, 94, September 14, at the Mary Manning Walsh Home. Beloved mother of Anne. Funeral Mass is on Wednesday, September 17th, at 10 AM, at St. Malachy's Church, 239 West 49th St. Burial at Pinelawn Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island. In place of flowers, donations may be made to Fr. Moore Foundation, Encore Community Services, 239 West 49th Street, NY, NY 10019.

title: Woman From Russia Held As a Sex Slave, the Police Say
description: A 28-year-old Russian woman who came to the United States two months ago met a man whom she knew from the old country and moved into his apartment in Brooklyn, where she was imprisoned and repeatedly raped and sodomized at knife point, the police and law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: State Office to Help Survivors Of Holocaust Recover Assets
description: Gov. George E. Pataki opened a state office yesterday dedicated to helping Holocaust survivors and their heirs recover assets held by Swiss banks and insurance companies. State officials called it the first governmental office of its kind in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHALOS, DAPHNE
description: MICHALOS-Daphne. Age 68. On September 15. Beloved mother of Renie Karidas, Dr. Peter Michalos, M.D., and George Michalos. Beloved wife of Argirios. Beloved sister of Penelope, Joanne and Lambrini. Grandmother of Dimos, Daphne, Irene, Arie and Peter. You were the best, loving and compassionate mother in the world. Your example will live in our hearts forever. For information on service, call Dahill Funeral Home: 718-336-2900.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: STERLING ELECTRONICS STOCK RISES 13% ON MERGER TALKS
description: Shares of the Sterling Electronics Corporation rose as much as 13 percent after the semiconductor distributor said it was in talks with an unidentified company over a possible ''strategic combination.'' Sterling shares rose $1.25, to $17.375, giving the company a market capitalization of about $125 million. Houston-based Sterling did not provide any details about the talks, which come two years after it rebuffed a takeover offer from Bell Industries Inc. for about $152 million in stock, or more than $21 a share. Since then, Sterling's stock performance has lagged behind competitors. Sterling is a major United States distributor of Japanese semiconductors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, SALLY
description: HELLER-Sally. Devoted mother of Scott, loving grandmother of Adam, Michael and Alexis. Services Wednesday 11 A.M. at Beth David Cemtery, Elmont, New York. For information: ''Wein & Wein'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Texas Law Professor Prompts A Furor Over Race Comments
description: The three top officials at the University of Texas issued an unusual statement today harshly condemning a law professor at the school for his ''abhorrent'' remarks and reaffirming that the university ''belongs to all the people of this state'' and should be ''fully representative of the marvelously rich diversity of the people of Texas.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I met lots of people who are experts in the way that Government in Washington works. And they said: 'We can't just have a hearing; first you have to go on bended knee and you have to kiss a lot of rings.' Well, my mother and father taught me that I'm no better than anybody else, but also that I'm no worse. So I said I wouldn't go on bended knee and I wouldn't kiss anything.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARAN, JACQUES F.
description: HARAN-Jacques F. On September 14, 1997. Beloved friend of William Franz Feldman and Janette Rigneault and family, Monsieur and Madame Kaspereit and Monsieur and Madame Regas. You will be mourned and missed and loved always. Visitation Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NY, today, 6-8PM. Mass Wednesday, September 17, 10AM, Church of Our Lady of Pompeii, Carmine and Bleecker Streets, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, LOUIS
description: EDELSTEIN-Louis. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of Louis Edelstein of Atlantic City, NJ. He was a legendary supporter of the American Technion Society, the Technion and Israel who modestly avoided any public recognition for his exemplary devotion. As a Technion Guardian, Mr. Edelstein demonstrated the highest level of commitment for the Technion. Passionate about the value of scientific and technological education and its centrality to Israel's future, he supported many projects at the Technion including the Louis Edelstein Center for the Investigation of Materials with Quasi-Periodic Structures, the Louis Edelstein Chair in Cancer Research and the Louis Edelstein Research Fund in the Faculty of Medicine. In recognition of his devoted support, he was awarded an Honorary Fellowship from the Technion. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sonia Edelstein and the entire Edelstein family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Irving A. Shepard, President Ben Z. Sosewitz, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Irwin L. Gross, Greater Delaware Valley Chapter President Stephen B. Klein, Greater Delaware Valley Chapter Chair Ivan Schonfeld, Eastern Seaboard Region Director

title: Sports of The Times; Past the Hype, It Looks Like The Jets' Past
description: NO medals for trying. That's what the great philosopher from northern New Jersey, Tunacrates, once wrote. No medals for hauling a defending Super Bowl participant into overtime, for losing with valor.

title: INSIDE
description: Rebuff to U.S. on Mines

title: Derailed Train Cuts Service At Penn Station
description: A New Jersey Transit train derailed yesterday as it passed over a switch on its way into Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, MURIEL H.
description: BURNS-Muriel H. Of East 8th Street, died on August 10 in Albury, England. A mainstay of the Village Green Recycling Team, she was also an avid bridge and tennis player. Muriel came to America in 1954 and for twenty-four years ran the HB Studio office. She is much mourned by her family and friends.

title: Today: Later News and More Sections
description: This week The Times introduces its most sweeping improvements in more than 20 years:

title: Ex-Snapple Chief Takes South Beach Posts
description: Michael B. Schott, who headed the Snapple juice and iced tea business during the last 10 months of its unprofitable ownership by the Quaker Oats Company, became president and chief operating officer of the South Beach Beverage Company of Norwalk, Conn., yesterday.

title: A Pocketful of Dreams, and Bytes
description: FORGET pocket protectors. You can tell modern nerds by the computers sticking out of their pockets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOOKSTEIN, GERTRUDE
description: LOOKSTEIN-Gertrude. American Friends of Yeshivot Bnei Akiva records with deep sorrow the passing of Gertrude Lookstein, a true Eishet Chayil who devoted her life to the Jewish People, the Torah and the Land of Israel. We extend deepest condolences to her son, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, a dedicated supporter of AFYBA and recipient of its Rabbinic Leadership Award, and a true religious Zionist leader. May the family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marvin S. Bienenfeld, Chairman Joel M. Schreiber, President Rabbi David V. Warshaw, Ex. Dir.

title: Adieu to William Weld
description: By the time the William Weld saga sputtered to an end yesterday, none of the protagonists could claim much glory. Senator Jesse Helms was the victor, but in burying Mr. Weld's nomination to be ambassador to Mexico without a hearing, Mr. Helms embarrassed the Senate. Trent Lott, the majority leader, weakly acquiesced. President Clinton went through the motions of supporting Mr. Weld, a Republican and the former Governor of Massachusetts, but clearly was not eager to do battle with Mr. Helms. Even Mr. Weld, though championing democracy as he withdrew yesterday, left the queasy feeling that his chief interest was to gain national exposure that might enhance a future campaign for the Senate or White House.

title: Gilmore in the Lead
description: Mike Gilmore of the Stanwich Club in Greenwich, Conn., shot a 4-under-par 66 yesterday and took the first round lead in the $70,000 Cadilac/Met P.G.A. Championship at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, N.Y.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''I will be the voice for those who are victims of injustice, cruelty and issues of human rights around the world,'' MARY ROBINSON, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, said yesterday in Geneva. Ms. Robinson, the former President of Ireland, spoke to reporters on her first day in office and said she would ''fulfill the intention of the reform package of the Secretary General, that human rights will be very central to the work of the United Nations,'' Reuters reported.

title: Breaking the Rules, Again
description: An art consultant wanted one so badly that she wore it out the next night to do the rounds in SoHo. A Chelsea architect's assistant has been trying to get one for weeks, to no avail. Marcy Klein, Calvin's daughter, bought two. Scoop, the hip store in Greenwich Village, sold out in a half-hour. Joyce Ma bought them for her Hong Kong store, and one ended up wrapped around a Chinese movie star.

title: His Cancer in Remission, Hamilton Is Back on Ice
description: For the past 15 years, Scott Hamilton said, he has felt more at home on the ice than at home. He was the 1984 men's Olympic figure skating champion, an effervescent entertainer on tour and in professional competitions. His trademark was a back flip performed on skates. But late last winter, Hamilton found it difficult to even stand up straight.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Norway Chief Steps Down As Votes Fall Short of Goal
description: Prime Minister Thorbjoern Jagland had posed an ultimatum to the voters of this oil-rich welfare state: if his Labor Party did not get 37 percent of the vote in Monday's national election, he would resign. With 95 percent of the votes counted early this morning, Mr. Jagland was 2 percentage points shy of his goal, and he announced that he and his government would step down.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Zell's Real Estate Empire In Deal for Boston Concern

title: Winnie Mandela Joins the Race for South Africa's No. 2 Spot
description: President Nelson Mandela's former wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, is facing new accusations about her role in the 1988 death of a 14-year-old activist and is about to be subpoenaed by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. But she is not letting any of that get in the way of her political aspirations.

title: The Met Is Delighted by New Russian Link
description: Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, formally announced the appointment of Valery Gergiyev as the company's principal guest conductor yesterday at a news conference.

title: Sheik Abdullah al-Tariki, 80, First Saudi Arabian Oil Minister
description: Sheik Abdullah al-TarikiSheik Abdullah al-Tariki, Saudi Arabia's first oil minister and a founder of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, died on Sept. 7 at the age of 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADONICK, LEON
description: MADONICK-Leon, of Tarrytown, NY. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Nora and Helene. Fond grandfather of Benjamin. Dear brother of Ruth Hennig and Carl Madonick. Service at 10 A.M., on Wednesday, at the EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford (Saw Mill Parkway, Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, New York.

title: In New York City Elections, the Precise Tallies Take Time
description: Precise election results are never available in New York City until at least a week after the voting takes place, as election officials verify and count thousands of paper ballots and double-check the tallies on nearly 7,000 voting machines.

title: Two Saudi Banks Merge
description: The United Saudi Commercial Bank and the Saudi Cairo Bank have merged to create United Saudi Bank, with Prince Walid bin Talal as its chairman, officials of the bank said today. The new bank has total equity of about 3.5 billion riyals ($933 million), consisting of 1 billion riyals in reserves and paid-up capital of 2.45 billion, which makes it the third-largest bank in Saudi Arabia in terms of paid-up capital, bank officials said. Total assets are 28 billion riyals, with total deposits of about 18 billion.

title: Networks Grumbling Over Emmys for Cable
description: Except for the actual winners, it seemed that Sunday night's edition of the Emmy Awards pleased almost no one in the television industry. It left executives of the broadcast networks complaining more loudly than ever yesterday about what they called unfair competition with cable networks, especially in every category in the made-for-television movie.

title: Like a Baby Streisand All Grown Up
description: Many performers who become famous when very young and go on to have show business careers as adults never lose the blushing self- conciousness of starry-eyed children drinking in the adulation of adoring parents and admiring neighbors. Julie Budd, who was discovered at the age of 12 in a Catskill Mountains talent show and became a protegee of Merv Griffin, still effuses the aura of a pre-adolescent fairy princess who has just stepped out of a pageant to wow the grown-ups singing grown-up songs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, ALLAN C.
description: ARNOLD-Allan C. Of NYC. Devoted father of Robin Shatzkin and Hillary Arnold; dear brother of Juliet Light and Phyllis Flatt; loving grandfather of Carly and Justin. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday, 12 noon. (1-800-522-0588).

title: Margo Rose Dies at 94; Helped Design 'Howdy Doody'
description: Margo Rose, a puppeteer who with her husband gave life to Howdy Doody, the redheaded, freckle-faced marionette baby boomers grew up with, died on Saturday at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London, Conn. She was 94 and lived in Waterford, Conn.

title: Dismissed Mail Carrier Is Shunning News Media
description: The mail carrier who was dismissed for walking too slowly on her route went into seclusion today in her apartment here after being besieged by television and newspaper reporters.

title: Metro Business; Canon USA Settles Claims
description: Canon USA of Lake Success, N.Y., said it would pay the Federal Government $6 million to settle claims that the company overcharged a Federal purchasing agency.

title: 2 Top Diet Drugs Are Recalled Amid Reports of Heart Defects
description: The makers of two popular diet drugs announced yesterday that they were withdrawing them from the market at the request of the Food and Drug Administration, which said new information indicates that the drugs may cause heart valve damage in as many as 30 percent of people who take them.

title: In Lawsuit, I.N.S. Is Accused Of Illegally Detaining Man
description: The American Civil Liberties Union accused the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday of illegally detaining an Egyptian man it is seeking to deport based on classified information that the agency still refuses to disclose.

title: Are Camera Saboteurs Just Fans, or Phillies?
description: The Philadelphia Phillies complained to the National League office earlier this season about cameras at Shea Stadium, concerned that the Mets were using them to steal signs.

title: Clairol and Sprint are just two of the big-time brands involved in account changes.
description: ACCOUNT changes are continuing to sweep Madison Avenue, this time affecting assignments with billings estimated at $135 million to $150 million. Among the blue-chip brands involved are Clairol, Baskin-Robbins and Sprint.

title: The Mayor's Money
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York did the right thing last week by assuming personal responsibility for his campaign's acceptance of $290,000 in illegal contributions, which the campaign has now promised to return. But that does not excuse the greedy approach to fund-raising that gave rise to the violations in the first place.

title: Device Opens the Theater to the Deaf
description: Theater history is to be made on Sept. 24 at the Music Box Theater when the dialogue of the play ''Barrymore'' will be displayed on a screen for playgoers with hearing loss. The captioning, synchronized manually with Christopher Plummer's Tony-winning performance, will scroll in red letters on a small digital screen in front of a side section of the orchestra, where 150 people can be seated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKELSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: FINKELSTEIN-Samuel. It's your birthday, Darling. You are lovingly remembered and sorely missed. Mim, Berne, Billy, Barbara and all the Kids

title: Mary Weinberger, 89, Worker for Disabled
description: Mary Weinberger, a lifelong advocate for the rights of people with muscular dystrophy, died on Sept. 8 at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. She was 89 and had lived in Long Beach, N.Y.

title: Satellite Gives Mir One More Close Call
description: Even as crew members struggled to fix their central computer, the Russian space station Mir came within 500 to 1,000 yards of colliding with a United States military satellite on Monday night.

title: Japan Says Trade Surplus Is Up Sharply
description: The Japanese merchandise trade surplus rose more sharply than expected in August, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: TV Notes; In the Ratings Game, 'Hollywood Squares'
description: Can ''The Hollywood Squares'' help CBS stations put some of their rival stations in ratings jeopardy?

title: Parcells Turns His Eyes to Special Teams
description: Successful pro football teams, like the New England Patriots, get consistent performances from their special teams. Inconsistent teams, like the Jets, get inconsistent play from special teams, as they demonstrated in Sunday night's 27-24 overtime loss to the Patriots.

title: Looking Death in the Eye, and Singing About It
description: Lucinda Williams has finished recording her third album of her own songs, she announced to a packed house at the Mercury Lounge on Monday night. The album, to be called ''Car Wheels on a Gravel Road,'' has taken five years, at least three producers and a small army of musicians. From the stage, Ms. Williams insisted, ''I'm no more neurotic than any other songwriter or artist.'' Later, she wondered aloud whether people told van Gogh he was taking too long to finish a painting.

title: The Pop Life
description: A heavy-metal musician recently mentioned a conversation with his record label two years ago in which they told him to take a vacation from music until the popularity of alternative rock blew over. Now, he said, his vacation was over because, as his label had predicted, alternative rock was over and it was all right to be a heavy-metal band again.

title: Harlem Troupe's Balancing Act
description: Dance Theater of Harlem, created nearly three decades ago to prove that black dancers could perform classical ballet, was always a company with a difference, a tight-knit family struggling together in a common mission. In January, that deeply ingrained sense of family was shattered by a strike that pitted the ''children'' against their ''father,'' Arthur Mitchell, founder and director of the troupe.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Plans for Marina to Be Shown
description: Plans for a new casino and hotel complex that is intended to spur development in the Atlantic City's marina district will be unveiled today, officials said.

title: Union Leader Who Made Threat Is Back on Job
description: A union leader at the Brookhaven National Laboratory who was charged last Thursday with threatening the life of a critic of the lab's work has returned to his job as a reactor technician.

title: Paul W. Brechler, College Athletic Official, 86
description: Paul W. Brechler, the youngest athletic director in Big Ten history and later the first commissioner of the Western Athletic Conference, died last Saturday at his home in Denver. He was 86 years old.

title: Coffee Prices Drop Sharply On Strong Inventory Report
description: Coffee prices tumbled yesterday after an industry report said stockpiles in the United States rose 11 percent last month, signaling unusually weak demand from roasters.

title: Bosnia Ruling On Vote Issue Brings Protest By Officials
description: Several senior officials working for the organization that administered elections here over the weekend have threatened to resign because the group failed to ''follow its own rules and regulations'' and annul votes cast in Pale for the ruling Serb Democratic Party.

title: Badly Wounded Officer Is Accused of Arranging His Own Shooting
description: A New York City police officer was charged yesterday with asking another man to shoot him and then falsely reporting that he had been shot by a stranger.

title: Dispiriting Dilemma For Dieters in U.S.
description: Monday's recall of two popular diet drugs has presented a dilemma that involves a choice between health risks and the hope of losing weight for Americans fighting obesity and those trying to respond to the dictates of a weight-obsessed culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLLER, ELI WILLIAM
description: MOLLER-Eli William. Born on August 25, 1905, Copenhagen, Denmark. Died Sept. 13, 1997. Service at the Brick Presbyterian Church on Park Avenue, Sept. 17 at 4 PM.

title: Three Shops Resign Accounts
description: Three agencies resigned accounts.

title: From Sky They Loved, Into the Sea; Missing Sons and Husbands Had Air Force in Their Blood
description: Since February, Larry Drager has kept track of his son's travels with the United States Air Force on a big map of the world taped to a wall in his home in Colorado Springs. The map has 19 colored pins in it, one for each of the countries Justin visited as a crew member of a C-141 cargo jet, the Air Force's workhorse in hauling troops, equipment and supplies.

title: Behind the Howl, A Poet's Gentleness
description: If any writer personifies an American postwar avant-garde, it is surely Allen Ginsberg. There was the power of his early poems (''I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness. . . .''); his place, along with Jack Kerouac and William S. Burroughs, as the prototypical Beat; his uncloseted homosexuality; his protests against the war in Vietnam; his experiments with LSD and his devotion to Buddhist teachings and practices. (William F. Buckley Jr. called him ''the hippie's hippie.'') And, in his later years, there was the almost patriarchal figure, in beard and beads, preaching a universal oneness of peace and love, inviting ridicule and earning respect.

title: About New York; Soul Ignites A Melting Pot At Roseland
description: IF staccato trumpet flourishes and manic, locomotive-steady guitar riffs weren't enough to lure the shyest dancers to the floor at Roseland, no wallflower could refuse a command from the Godfather of Soul. ''Everybody over heah! C'mon!'' boomed the raspy voice of James Brown. ''Everybody over theah! C'mon!''

title: DI INDUSTRIES TO BUY ASSETS OF JUSTISS OIL DRILLING UNIT
description: DI Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire most of the assets of a drilling unit owned by the Justiss Oil Company for $36 million. DI Industries, an oil and gas drilling company based in Houston, said the assets included a fleet of 12 drilling rigs and related equipment. DI had 1996 revenue of $81.7 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, BRO. GREGORY, FSC
description: HUNT-Bro. Gregory, FSC. Age 71. Assistant to the President of Manhattan College for Alumni Affairs. Devoted son of the late Patrick and May Regan Hunt. Beloved brother of Marion Cahill and the late Thomas Hunt. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. The wake will be held in the Rotunda, Memorial Hall, at Manhattan College campus on Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM and Wednesday, 2-5 and 78 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at The Chapel of DeLaSalle and his Brothers Wednesday evening, 8 PM. Interment will take place on Thursday, September 18, from the Christian Brothers Center, 4415 Post Rd, Bronx, NY, leaving at 10 AM, for the Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLEY, HELEN
description: BUCKLEY-Helen, of the Bronx, New York, on September 15, 1997. Survived by brother-in-law Patrick Cahill, aunt of Anne Walsh, Jeanne Ray, Noreen Cassidy, Thomas Cahill, Lawrence Cahill, Patricia Holland, Mary Reitz, Anne Principe, Teresa Lively and Elizabeth Walsh. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Wednesday, September 17, at 11:00 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, WILLIAM K.
description: WOLF-William K. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William K. Wolf, associated with The Times from 1946, until retiring in 1975.

title: Bomb Explodes Near Belfast, Rattling New Peace Talks
description: A bomb exploded in a small town near Belfast today, disrupting the Northern Ireland peace talks that got under way on Monday with the entry of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: THE PRICE OF BRUTALITY: A special report.; Police Complaints Settled, Rarely Resolved
description: On a muggy August morning, Sammy Velez, a transvestite with a crack habit, took advantage of the rush-hour commotion near Penn Station to snatch a purse. Tripping in his high-heeled boots, he couldn't make a clean getaway so he threw the purse back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBLE, ROSE
description: NOBLE-Rose, 80, of Coconut Creek, Florida passed away on September 16. She is survived by her loving children Steve (Laura), Brad (Lois), and Marion. Devoted brothers and sisters Lou Ross, Adelle Solomon, Joe Ross, Goldyne Lipson and Jesse Ross. Cherished grandchildren Jessica and James Wallace and Matthew and Michael Noble. Graveside services will be held Thursday, September 18th, at 3 P.M., at The Wellwood Cemetery in Pinelawn. For further information call Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, Tamarac, Florida (1-800-758-1151).

title: Sole Survivor Of Paris Crash Now Conscious
description: The badly injured sole survivor of the crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, on Aug. 31 has recovered consciousness and should be able to tell what he remembers of the accident, a doctor treating him said today.

title: Vote Correction Reverses Election Result
description: Judy Rapfogel, who had declared victory last week in a fiercely contested City Council primary on the Lower East Side, conceded defeat yesterday evening to her challenger, Margarita Lopez.

title: White House Guests Differ Over Solicitation of Money
description: A college professor who was Vice President Dan Quayle's national security adviser testified at the Senate campaign finance hearings today that he attended a coffee last year with President Clinton at the White House, where a Democratic Party official explicitly solicited campaign contributions.

title: A Great Tiptoe Forward: Free Enterprise in China
description: There is a joke widely circulating around town that may sum up how people interpret the doings at the Communist Party Congress under way here.

title: Metro Business; Bank Worker Is Accused
description: An employee of Citibank N.A., a subsidiary of Citicorp, was charged yesterday with defrauding the bank of more than $1.1 million through an unauthorized wire transfer.

title: Goldman Sees a Record Year As Quarterly Profit Rises 58%
description: The Goldman, Sachs Group L.L.P. said yesterday that its earnings before taxes rose 58 percent in the third fiscal quarter, as the firm heads toward its best year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOVERMAN, SAM
description: BOVERMAN-Sam, 86, Sept. 15. Devoted father of Jeffery. Fatherin-law of Christina and grandfather of Kale, Max and Michelle Boverman and Lisa Hantverk and Emily Solomon and great grandfather of four. Dear companion of Harriet Falk. Graveside service Thurs, 1 PM, Cedar Park Cemetery. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Wednesday 7-9PM and Thursday 10:30AM-12 noon. Gifts may be made in his memory to Rose Haven Nursing Home, 31 North St., Litchfield, CT 06759.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZION, MENACHEM
description: ZION-Menachem. The S/A/R Academy mourns the loss of the beloved brother of our founder, benefactor and trustee, Abraham Zion. May the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: Pair Hope to Help Farmers, Too : Putting a New Spin On Philippine Silk
description: MANILA  When Jean Goulbourn designed the barong shirts for the 18 leaders of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum who gathered in Manila late last year, she embroidered each front side with a column of intricate reproductions of Filipino windows from Spanish ancestral homes, churches and peasant bamboo huts.

title: Clinton Will Seek Tougher Proposals To Rein In Smoking
description: President Clinton will decisively reject a proposed tobacco deal negotiated by state officials and cigarette company lawyers and will outline his own tobacco policy in an Oval Office speech on Wednesday, White House officials said today.

title: Recasting Chinoiserie As Modern-Day Chic
description: HONG KONG  Whether it be Armani's wide-sleeved silk jackets or Givenchy's brocaded dragon-motif robes, China chic by Western designers perennially reaps applause. Ironically, few Asian labels are known for doing the same, but several Hong Kong-based companies are out to change that.

title: Government Plan Threatens Patients' Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Kohl Believes Something Will Turn Up: His Ratings
description: With a vote in Hamburg's city-state on Sept. 21, Germany embarks on a yearlong season of elections in which everything essentially turns on one political question: will Chancellor Helmut Kohl survive?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Voters Unmoved by Tax Cuts
