description: The state income tax cuts put in place by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman mean little to New Jersey voters seven weeks before Election Day, and they give her low marks on the issue they continue to cite as the state's biggest problem -- the cost of auto insurance.

title: Government Plan Threatens Patients' Privacy; Genetic Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: A Younger Generation Is Making Its Mark in West : New Wave Asian Designers
description: SINGAPORE  The search is on for the fashion designers of the new millennium. And this year's Fashion Connections Singapore, which opens on Wednesday, has something exceptional to celebrate: the arrival of Singapore-born Andrew Gn, 31, as the first Asian designer to be named to a French couture house.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the Communist Party congress in China misstated the date of the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in central Beijing. It was 1989, not 1988.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: John Madden's Road Game; Aboard the Bus, Heaping Helpings of Food and Football
description: John Madden was on the road. Like a pigskin Charles Kuralt, he pursues his personal nirvana from the confines of a large, earthbound vehicle.

title: 'Fast Track' Issue Deserves Fast Action
description: During more than two decades of divided government, Democrats and Republicans have often set aside their differences to take collective action on matters promoting our nation's interests beyond its borders. The next issue that calls for bipartisan leadership is the passage of legislation granting the President ''fast track'' authority -- a contract between the executive and legislative branches in which the President can negotiate trade deals knowing that the results will receive an up or down vote, without amendments, in return for a commitment that the Administration will consult Congress in the negotiations.

title: A Dazzling Schilling Settles For 3-Hitter
description: Before Curt Schilling took the mound for the Phillies tonight, some of the Mets debated over who might become his 300th strikeout of the year. By the third inning, they probably wondered who, if anybody, would muster a hit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CABOT, VIRGINIA WELLINGTON
description: CABOT-Virginia Wellington, of Weston, MA., September 15. Age 97. Wife of the late Thomas D. Cabot. Mother of Louis W. Cabot of Cambridge, Massachusetts; Thomas D. Cabot, Jr. of Greenwich, CT.; Robert M. Cabot of Seattle, WA.; Dr. Edmund B. Cabot of Belmont, MA., and Linda Black of Cambridge, MA. Also survived by 28 grandchildren and 26 great grandchildren. Services will be held on Saturday, September 20 at 1 o'clock P.M., at King's Chapel, 58 Tremont Street, Boston, MA. For information, call Waterman Funeral Home, 617-235-4110.

title: Bayerische Vereinsbank Expands Share Offer
description: Bayerische Vereinsbank A.G. said yesterday that it would sell 36 million new shares, raising an estimated 3 billion marks ($1.7 billion) for its planned merger with Bayerische Hypotheken-und Wechsel-Bank A.G. The banks also have the option of selling three million more shares. That means the offering could be larger than previously announced by as many as nine million shares. Vereinsbank's chief executive, Albrecht Schmidt, will, as expected, head the new bank. Hypo-Bank's chief executive, Eberhard Martini, will retire in late 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, NORMAN DUDLEY
description: JOHNSON-Norman Dudley. Died peacefully September 16, 1997 on Martha's Vineyard, Ma., in his 90th year. Survived by his wife Virginia Couper Johnson; father of Dudley Disosway Johnson, Cazenovia, NY, Kathleen Wu, Pontevedra, Florida, Norman Platt Johnson, Newport, R.I. Ridgely Couper Johnson, London, England, six grandchildren, two great grandchildren. Service St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, MA., 4 PM, Friday, Sept. 19th.

title: Burning With Romanticism
description: ''My Sex Life . . . Or How I Got Into an Argument'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 3, 1996. The film opens today at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, at Lincoln Center. It runs through Sept. 26.

title: House That Lou Built Reflects a New I.B.M.
description: Tomorrow is official moving day for one of the nation's most storied blue-chip companies. And though the old house and the new one are less than a mile apart, the vast differences between them speak to the radically altered look of today's corporate America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARE, WILL
description: HARE-Will. A dear friend, whose Dylan, with Rue McClanahan, production I was privileged to produce, was the finest Dylan ever portrayed on stage. God bless, Will. We'll miss you. Martin Richards

title: End of Chicago's Education School Stirs Debate
description: As the campus's shaded quadrangles fill with students for the start of the fall quarter -- hints of red dappling the ivy that climbs the neo-Gothic buildings, yellow self-move trucks rumbling along the streets -- there is a void at the University of Chicago this year: For the first time in more than a century there are no doctoral candidates entering the department of education.

title: Business Travel; American Express expects travel costs to continue rising next year, but at a less torrid pace.
description: EXECUTIVES experiencing sticker shock from constantly escalating travel costs can expect more of the same next year, though there are signs the increases are beginning to taper off.

title: Essay; The Millennial Campaign
description: The frenetic and unrepresentative way we select our Presidential candidates should be consigned to the ash can of political history. At present, activists of both parties in Iowa meet in the nation's first caucuses to select, unofficially, that state's convention delegates. Reporters swarm; candidates spend; pollsters and pundits study campaign entrails.

title: BRIGHTPOINT TO BUY DISTRIBUTOR OF WIRELESS EQUIPMENT
description: Brightpoint Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Legend International Ltd., a distributor of wireless communication equipment based in Hong Kong. Terms were not disclosed. For the year that ended on March 31, Legend had sales of $115 million. In 1996, Brightpoint had $589.7 million in sales. Brightpoint, which is based in Indianapolis and provides distribution services to the wireless communications industry, said it expected to close the acquisition on Sept. 30. Brightpoint also said it had reached an agreement with a unit of the Nokia Corporation, the Finnish telecommunications concern, to distribute Nokia equipment in Hong Kong and China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZION, MENAHEM
description: ZION-Menahem. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Abe Zion on the loss of his brother Menahem. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: $1 Million Push by Labor on President's Authority Over Trade
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. said it was spending $1 million this week alone to broadcast this 30-second commercial in 14 Congressional districts where members have indicated they will support President Clinton's drive for new authority to negotiate trade deals. At the end of each ad, viewers are urged to call their member of Congress to oppose the measure. The commercial began appearing yesterday.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Critic's Notebook; Lassoing a Cowboy Who's on a Posthumous Rampage
description: Garry Wills's ''John Wayne: The Politics of Celebrity'' reads as though it were written by a lover and a skeptic doing their best to ignore each other. The skeptic smartly analyzes Wayne's role as a hero of America's most self-righteous political myths and practices, from Manifest Destiny to cold war imperialism.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Tight Market Reveals 'Hidden Space'
description: As if by magic, some of Manhattan's invisible office space is starting to come into view.

title: To Westerners, Salmon Are Not Just Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about William F. Weld misattributed a quotation about the future of the Republican Party. It was Senator Gordon Smith of Oregon, not Senator Robert Smith of New Hampshire, who said: ''The Republican Party must be big enough for Jesse Helms and William Weld if we're serious about competing in national affairs. And I believe it is big enough for that.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDEL, HENRI
description: BENDEL-Henri. September 15, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Loving father of John and his wife Diana. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, September 20 at 1:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Small Group Sees Baseball Game Broadcast on High-Definition TV
description: Observing a time-honored tradition, a leading manufacturer of professional television equipment offered the first live broadcast of a major league baseball game in digital, high-definition television tonight, hoping to stir excitement about the new technology.

title: Recall of Drugs Leaves Many Dieters Hopeless
description: They know. They know that the drugs would not have been recalled lightly. But still, among the millions of American dieters who had seen Redux and the fen-phen combination as the weight-loss magic they crave, there were voices today expressing a loss of hope, and even sparks of defiance.

title: Swiss Economy Growing Faster Than Expected
description: Switzerland's economy expanded by a larger-than-expected 1.9 percent in the second quarter, in its biggest increase since the fourth quarter of 1994, confirming that a six-year slump is over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, ROBERT
description: LIEBERMAN-Robert. Died on September 15, 1997 at age 84. Cocreator for 31 years, under the name of Bob Lee, of ''Jumble, that scrambled word game,'' the widely syndicated newspaper puzzle feature. No immediate survivors. No funeral service.

title: Guerin and Rolston Missing
description: One week into the Devils' training camp, Brian Rolston and Bill Guerin are still missing. Both forwards are restricted Group 2 free agents who are refusing to report without a contract.

title: An Unsweetened Critique of 'New Age' Juice Beverages
description: Have you ever tried to make banana juice? Here's a hint: Squeezing a banana doesn't work. Neither does putting a banana in a blender, unless the resulting slush counts as juice.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CYPRESS FINANCIAL SERVICES INC., Cypress, Calif., a debt recovery company, acquired an accounts receivable portfolio valued at $109 million from an unidentified California financial institution. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Welfare Reform Hitch
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: On Monday night, SHANNON MILLER, the gymnast and Olympic gold medalist, TERESA WEATHERSPOON of the New York Liberty, the 1997 Women's National Basketball Association defensive player of the year, and NIESHA BUTLER, a senior at Riverdale Country School in the Bronx and the highest-scoring high school player -- man or woman -- in New York City basketball history, were among 600 people at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum to celebrate a new monthly magazine, Conde Nast Sports for Women.

title: Judith Merril, 74, Science Fiction Editor and Writer
description: Judith Merril, one of the first female writers and editors to influence the direction of modern science fiction, died on Friday in Toronto, where she lived. She was 74.

title: Child Abuse Suspicions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, RUTH S.
description: BLOCH-Ruth S. Died Saturday, September 13 in Lake Placid, NY. Beloved wife of the late Rene Bloch and devoted mother of Jeffrey Block. Graduate of Brooklyn College, proprietor of several stores in Lake Placid for many years. Services were Monday, September 15. Interment in the United Hebrew Community cemetery, Lake Placid.

title: Trouble Staying Awake? Try a Whiff of Pine
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOMEZ, JENNIE M. (GONZALEZ)
description: GOMEZ-Jennie M. (Gonzalez). In Stamford, CT., September 16, 1997. Jennie M. Gomez of Stamford, CT. formerly of New York. Mother of Lawrence J. of New York, sister of Ralph Gomez of Davie, Florida. Predeceased by sisters Angela and Rose Gomez. Mass of Christian burial to be held on Friday, September 19th, at 10 A.M., in St. Cecilia's Church, 1184 Newfield Avenue, Stamford, CT. Burial in St. Raymonds cemetery, Bronx, New York. Calling hours Thursday from 2-4 PM and 6-8 PM, at The Bouton and Reynolds Funeral Home, 545 Bedford Street, Stamford, Ct. Contributions to Bennett Cancer Center, C/O Stamford Hospital Health Foundation, 2015 West Main Street, Stamford, CT. 06902.

title: Restaurants; Rustic Regard for Fish Out of the Greek Isles
description: WE followed our waiter through the spare, high-ceilinged room to the front of Estiatorio Milos, where we were seduced by the fish. As he proudly pointed out the wonders of the day's catch, resplendent on its bed of ice, we suddenly grew very hungry. The wild black bass was gorgeous, the arctic char shimmered and an impressive striped bass stretched out at least three feet. We ordered with our eyes. The small, silvery sardines shone irresistibly, and tiny squid looked far too succulent to ignore. As for that regal loup de mer, it would surely be delicious.

title: Japanese Stocks Flat
description: Stocks ended virtually unchanged today. The Nikkei index of 225 leading issues closed up 8.7 points at 17,974.50. On Monday, the market was closed for a national holiday, Respect for the Aged Day.

title: W.N.B.A. Takes Top A.B.L. Star
description: The Women's National Basketball Association fired a big gun against the rival American Basketball League yesterday by stealing away the A.B.L.'s most valuable player, Nikki McCray. But officials of the two professional leagues, which began play in the last year, said that they did not anticipate open warfare for each other's best talent.

title: TV Notes; An On-Line 'Tool Kit' For Anxious Parents
description: With the new children's television season in full swing, many parents are curious to see what local television stations are offering to fulfill new Federal regulations that they carry three hours a week of educational shows for the under-16 set. Parents are also curious about enforcement: who will see to it that stations meet their new educational goals?

title: School Voucher Plan is Debated
description: With public schools in the District of Columbia opening three weeks late because so many needed roof repairs, Republican leaders of the House and Senate today urged that Congress pass a voucher system to allow children of low-income residents to attend a school of their choice.

title: William N. Oatis, 83, of A.P.; Jailed by Prague in Cold War
description: William N. Oatis, an Associated Press correspondent in Prague whose name entered cold war history when the Czechoslovak Communist Government forced him to confess falsely to espionage and held him prisoner from 1951 to 1953, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Army Neglects History Of Women as Warriors; Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Diet Pill Excesses
description: The withdrawal of two popular diet drugs from the market this week is a useful reminder that it is always risky to pop pills for long periods even if they have been approved as safe and effective by Federal regulators. In this case, the drugs had been approved by the Food and Drug Administration only for the most obese patients. Yet reckless doctors and diet clinics dispensed them to millions of pudgy Americans who demanded access to the latest weapon in the endless battle against overweight. Only later did it become clear that this supposedly miraculous magic bullet was capable of misfiring and doing more harm than good.

title: Kodak Shares Continue to Fall on Forecast
description: The stock of the Eastman Kodak Company continued to fall yesterday, a day after the company warned Wall Street about weak earnings for the third quarter and the year.

title: HONEYWELL TO SELL VALVE DIVISION TO PARKER HANNIFIN
description: Honeywell Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its solenoid valve business to the Parker Hannifin Corporation for $100 million in cash. The sale includes Skinner Valve of New Britain, Conn., and Lucifer S.A. of Geneva. The units make valves used in industrial and commercial applications. Honeywell, which is based in Minneapolis and makes thermostats and other controls, said it would use the proceeds to buy back shares and pursue acquisitions. Shares of Honeywell rose 81.25 cents, to $69.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, while Parker Hannifin, which is based in Cleveland, rose $1.125, to $44.3125.

title: Temptation; Butter-Yellow Blintzes As Tender as Crepes
description: NEW YORKERS raised on tough, glutinous, egg-roll-shape blintzes might never have imagined a blintz that could be as tender as a crepe, cradling a thin molten layer of sweet, tangy farmer cheese.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSO, PAUL
description: RUSSO-Paul, on September 15, 1997. Owner of Regina Footwear, Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of the late Julia (Colozzo). Devoted father of Rosemary Levin. Dear grandfather of David. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Wednesday and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Friday 9:45 A.M., St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, contributions will be appreciated to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOMBLE, CLEM
description: WOMBLE-Clem, March 3, 1920September 17, 1988. We think of you always, and miss you everyday. Memories of you remain forever in our hearts. Family and friends of Clem Womble

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bad Roads Have a High Cost
description: New Jersey drivers spend more than $207 million each year repairing damage to their cars caused by bad roads, -- more money than in all but four states, two public-interest groups said yesterday.

title: BE AEROSPACE SHARES DROP ON BRITISH AIRWAYS DECISION
description: The stock of BE Aerospace Inc. skidded 17 percent yesterday after British Airways P.L.C. said it would not buy the company's upscale in-flight video system. Despite reporting record earnings in the second quarter, shares of BE Aerospace dropped $6.50, to $34.25, in Nasdaq trading. British Airways told BE Aerospace, which is based in Wellington, Fla., that it would not consider buying its MDDS multimedia entertainment system, which allows passengers to choose audio and video selections individually, but would instead test the company's 12-channel video system through Dec. 15.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page yesterday about the designer Diane Von Furstenberg misstated the age of Faith Morford, a client. She is in her 50's, not her 60's.

title: High PCB Level Is Found in a Hudson Bald Eagle
description: The body of a young bald eagle killed along the upper Hudson River contained high concentrations of PCB's, toxic industrial chemicals that are the Hudson's last significant taint, New York State environmental scientists said yesterday.

title: A Toast, of Sorts, To Simmons Durham
description: Brown-Forman Beverages Worldwide in Louisville, Ky., said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Simmons Durham in St. Louis, awarding the agency domestic advertising responsibilities for four brands of distilled spirits. Billings have not been determined.

title: Bonds Rally As Inflation Stays in Check
description: The prices of bonds and stocks soared yesterday as investors seemed to rejoice at new economic data that showed inflation still in check despite signs of stronger economic growth.

title: Clinton Faces Off With Congress on Trade
description: President Clinton put his personal prestige on the line today, traveling to the Capitol to fight for new authority to negotiate trade deals in the face of muscular opposition from House leaders of his own party.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOWLER, ANDERSON
description: FOWLER-Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23rd, St. Luke's Church, Peapack, N.J. at 11 A.M.

title: Government Plan Threatens Patients' Privacy; Protected in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSS, DAVID
description: ROSS-David. You will live in our hearts forever. Harold and Mother

title: Poll Findings Hint at Trouble For Whitman Over Insurance
description: Most New Jersey voters say that neither they nor the state have benefited from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's income tax cuts, and now, seven weeks before Election Day, they give her low marks on the issue that they continue to cite as the state's biggest problem: the cost of auto insurance.

title: A Family as the Thanksgiving Turkey
description: A tight-lipped WASPy angst clings like a layer of frost to ''The Myth of Fingerprints,'' a hopelessly solemn exploration of the resentments eating at the soul of a picture-perfect New England family. By the end of the film, written and directed by Bart Freundlich, nary an ice crystal has melted.

title: Off the Menu
description: Stirrings at the Tea Room

title: Food Stuff; Marcella Hazan In Connecticut
description: Later this month, Marcella Hazan will spend an evening with a few hundred of her fans in Connecticut, showing slides of how she cooks and shops in Italy, answering questions and signing her new book, ''Marcella Cucina'' (HarperCollins, $35).

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: $25 and Under; Committed to Vegetarian Ideals, But Sneaking In a Little Beef
description: WHAT'S the difference between health food and healthy food? Flavor, to say the least.

title: Innovation to Double Chip Power May Cut Life Span of Computers
description: The world is no longer flat. Earth is no longer at the center of the solar system. And Moore's Law, a longstanding axiom of the computer age, is no longer true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIREFMAN, GUSSIE
description: SIREFMAN-Gussie. September 14, 1997. Beloved wife of the late William; devoted mother of Gloria and Josef and daughter-in-law Carol; loving sister of Joseph Kestenbaum and Martha (Max) Silverman; cherished grandmother of Emily (Daniel) Green, Susanna and Joshua; and great-grandmother of Samuel William, and dear aunt. Services were held Tuesday.

title: Government Plan Threatens Patients' Privacy; Privatizing Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Dismissal of City Caseworkers Is Ordered
description: A state judge has ordered New York City to dismiss 735 caseworkers hired by the Giuliani administration to bolster its revamped child welfare agency, saying the workers were hired in violation of the city's Civil Service laws.

title: F-16's Collide Off the Coast Of New Jersey; Fliers Survive
description: Two Air National Guard F-16 fighter jets collided in midair during night training exercises off Atlantic City last night, sending one jet plummeting into the ocean, but all three airmen survived, Air Force officials said.

title: WESTERN RESOURCES SELLS STAKE IN TYCO INTERNATIONAL
description: Western Resources Inc. has sold its remaining stake in Tyco International Ltd. for $572 million after Tyco beat out Western Resources in a takeover battle for ADT Ltd. Western Resources, a gas and electric utility, said it would record a gain on the sale in the third quarter. The sale was required by an agreement to end lawsuits stemming from Tyco's $5.9 billion acquisition of ADT. At the time, Western had 12.4 million Tyco shares, which it received as a result of Tyco's stock-swap acquisition of ADT. Western Resources, based in Topeka, Kan., bought a stake in ADT and began a hostile takeover bid for the company last December. Tyco stepped in and made a friendly offer for ADT that was accepted in March.

title: Burnett agency plans to reinvent itself, pledging to abandon the 'one size fits all' approach.
description: THE Leo Burnett Company is reorganizing its flagship American operations as part of continuing efforts to overcome account losses that have tarnished the venerable agency's reputation.

title: Mayor to Help Police Monitor He Had Fought
description: Facing criticism that his administration has not acted decisively to root out police brutality, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would provide more money and hire new investigators for the independent agency that investigates charges of police misconduct.

title: U.S. Seeks Compromise to Save Treaty Banning Land Mines
description: Facing overwhelming opposition from nearly a hundred countries, the Clinton Administration has embarked on a vigorous last-ditch effort to reach a compromise on a land mines treaty, with President Clinton himself making calls to world leaders seeking support for the United States position, diplomats here said today.

title: Suez Lyonnaise Bids For Rest of Degremont
description: Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. offered yesterday to pay 1.05 billion francs ($175 million) for the shares it does not own in Degremont S.A., a water-treatment company. Suez, France's second-biggest publicly traded utility, is offering Degremont shareholders 500 francs ($83.33) in cash a share, a 19.3 percent premium over Monday's closing price of 419.20 francs, to buy the 28.5 percent stake in the company it does not own. Trading in Degremont's shares were suspended yesterday in Paris.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Religious Freedom Bill Eyed
description: Three months after the United States Supreme Court struck down a Federal law limiting government interference with religious practices, legislators will join religious leaders in Trenton today to call for a state version of the law, officials said.

title: Sips; Supermarket Beer With Microbrew Character
description: I LIKE good beer, and I think the microbrewery movement is the best thing to happen to the beer industry since Prohibition was repealed. But I don't like spending $9 for a six-pack of microbrew any more than I like spending $9 for a movie ticket. Nor am I happy spending $4 for a six-pack of the mass-produced beers, which are about as satisfying as watching ''Star Wars'' on a nine-inch television screen. Yes, you save money, but you know what you're missing.

title: TV Notes; CNN Looks to Print For Inspiration
description: CNN, looking for ways to attract a more dependable -- and larger -- audience to the channel in prime time, is working on a plan to produce news-magazine programs based on the formats of print magazines published by Time Inc., including Sports Illustrated, People, Entertainment Weekly, Fortune, Money and Time magazine itself.

title: Wheatley Can't Run From Questions
description: In the final minute of the third quarter last Sunday, Tyrone Wheatley slipped out of the backfield and took a swing pass from Dave Brown. Ten yards from a first down, Wheatley headed upfield and the Giants Stadium crowd hardly mustered a yawn, perhaps jaded by seeing so little from him for the past two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, HELEN
description: WHITE-Helen, 83, of Queens, NY on September 13. Devoted Aunt of William, Carroll, Dayle, and Robert Zipse and Jan Zipse Wright; also survived by many grand nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian burial on Thursday, at 10 A.M., Holy Trinity Church, Westfield, New Jersey. Interment Mount Saint Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, Queens, New York.

title: Pettitte Shows Playoff Form as the Yankees Sweep
description: Locked in. That was what Andy Pettitte was at Yankee Stadium last night. And that is what makes Manager Joe Torre confident that his Yankees have at least one starter they can count on when the post-season arrives.

title: The Owners Are Stalled On Way to Realignment
description: The grand scheme for realignment of baseball's major leagues, which owners had at one time hoped to implement at meetings here this week, has stalled so badly that it may be moving in reverse.

title: GETTY COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY INTERNET IMAGE CONCERN
description: Getty Communications P.L.C. said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Photodisc Inc. for $160.8 million in stock and cash in a bid to create the world's largest provider of archived photographs. Getty will pay $30 million in cash and 9.6 million new shares, worth more than $130 million as of the end of last week. Getty Communications, which is based in London and is controlled by the Getty oil family, owns one of the largest collections of photographs and films in the world, which it provides to advertisers, publishers and broadcasters. Photodisc, based in Seattle, is the largest provider of images on the Internet. Getty's American depository receipts gained $1.75, to $15.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Curious Cook
description: CAN you overcook water? Tea connoisseurs claim that water boiled for more than a few seconds, or more than once, loses its air and produces tea that tastes flat.

title: Abraham Akaka, 80, Hawaii Clergyman, Dies
description: The Rev. Abraham K. Akaka, who as Hawaii's most widely known clergyman led the historic Kawaiahao Church in Honolulu for three decades, died on Sept. 10 in Honolulu. He was 80 years old.

title: Man in the News: Henry Hugh Shelton; General Who Sets Pace
description: If Gen. Henry H. Shelton sticks to his routine in his next job, as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, some of the people at the Pentagon may find themselves running a lot more.

title: Paris Bistro Is a Rare Pleasure
description: FOR the last 10 years I have done exactly the same thing every time I land in Paris. I clear customs. Then I call L'Ami Louis to see if I can get a table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOKES, ALEXANDER COXE
description: STOKES-Alexander Coxe, of Gulfstream, Florida, formerly of Philadelphia on September 15th, 1997. Beloved husband of Lynda Stokes. Loving father of Alexandra Thomas. Step-father of Michael, Scott, and Kim Tiernan and Martha Ely. Brother of William S. and Richard Stokes. Also survived by twelve grandchildren. Funeral service will be held at St. David's (Chapel) Episcopal Church, Valley Forge Road, Wayne, PA., on Thursday, September 18 at 11 AM. Interment St. David's Churchyard. Memorial donations may be made to New Bolton Center (Univ. of PA Veterinary School), 382 West Street Rd, Kennett Sq., PA 19348 or National Parkinson's Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Avenue, Miami, FL. 33136.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYTAN, YEHUDA
description: REYTAN-Yehuda. The Jewish Center mourns the tragic passing of the father of our devoted member Mrs. Meira Tugendhaft. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: A New Yorker Wins Over L.S.U.
description: He was a bad hire. He tells you so himself, leaning over a polished desk in this purple-and-yellow-accented office, which might be the most powerful seat in the state short of the Governor's office. It is where Louisiana State University's football coach directs the Tigers, where Gerry DiNardo, son of a New York police officer, was not supposed to end up.

title: Montana Family in Battle Over a Dinosaur Discovery
description: The discovery of a large meat-eating dinosaur embedded in a bluff in Montana has set off a legal confrontation between a family of cattle ranchers and a group of paleontologists who are backed by Federal and state officials.

title: Liberties; Dressing For Contempt
description: The last time I obsessed over the proper Look was when I began working at The New York Times.

title: Gramercy Movie House to Become Off Broadway Theater
description: A new 499-seat Off Broadway theater will open in the spring after a $2 million face lift as a result of an agreement between four producers and the landlord of a shuttered movie house near Gramercy Park.

title: By the Book; Five Pounds of Recipes
description: WITH 432 pages and a weight of about five pounds, ''The Essential Cookbook'' by Caroline Conran, Terence Conran and Simon Hopkinson (Stewart Tabori & Chang) is the kind of massive effort you would expect from the people who have opened 700-seat restaurants in London.

title: Turning the Tables on Those Who Spied on Him
description: THE FILE

title: Russia to Join Paris Club of Creditors
description: Russia will formally join the Paris Club of creditor nations on Wednesday, the French Finance Ministry said today.

title: Company Sues M.T.A., Saying It Was Denied Fair Chance to Vend Metrocards
description: A vending-machine company has sued the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, charging that it was denied a fair chance to compete for a contract worth about $20 million to supply nearly 500 machines that will dispense Metrocards to rail commuters.

title: From Italy, the Truth About Pasta; The Italians know that less is more: a call for a return to basics
description: Americans are strictly bush-leaguers when it comes to pasta, consuming about 26 pounds per capita each year. Italians, it almost goes without saying, are the world champions, averaging 60 pounds of pasta a year for every man, woman and child in the country. Which works out to five pounds a month. Or by my informal reckoning, at least one large plate of well-sauced and seasoned pasta six out of seven days a week.

title: At Yale, Daunting Initiation For Coach
description: He has lost his top three quarterbacks to injury within the last three weeks, so the freshman Mike McClellan will start the season opener against Brown on Saturday. And the team's No. 1 running back, Jabbar Craigwell, is out with a wrist fracture and unlikely to play this season.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: UPN Names TV Executive As President
description: In a long-awaited announcement, the United Paramount Network, one of two would-be fifth networks, yesterday named Dean Valentine, a longtime executive with the Walt Disney studio, as its new president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIGHT, WILLIAM T. III
description: KNIGHT-William T. III, of Saddle River, NJ, died September 16, 1997, at age 78, after a lengthy illness. Born in Savannah, GA., Mr. Knight graduated from the University of Georgia with a B.S. degree in Pharmacy. He served in the United States Navy during World War II and during the Korean conflict & retired as a Naval Commander. At the time of his retirement from American Cyanamid in 1981, Mr. Knight was the Departmental Manager with the Fine Chemicals Department and also Market Manager with the Organic Chemical Division with the Lederle Laboratories Division. A devoted citizen of Saddle River, Mr. Knight served as President of the Home and School Association and served the Borough as a councilman from 1976 to 1986. He was a member of the Guidance Council, Council Representative to the Zoning Board of Adjustment, Police Commissioner, Chairman of the Sanitation Committee, the Public Information and Personnel Committee and Ordinance and Legislature Committee Coordinator, and served as President of the Borough Council. He was a member of the Valley Hospital Foundation, St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Ho-Ho-Kus, The Society of the Cincinnati, The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, Proprietary Association, Drug, Chemical and Allied Trade Association where he served on the Board of Directors the last six years, the Philadelphia Drug Exchange and the Arcola Country Club. He is survived by his wife Frances (Peg) (nee Floyd); son Rex of Cortlandt Manor, NY; three grandchildren; brother Stuart Knight of Savannah, GA; sister Courtney Gaines of Savannah, GA. The family will receive their friends on Wednesday, September 17, at Vander Plaat Memorial Home, S113 Farview Avenue, Paramus, NJ from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be at 10:00 AM, Thursday, St. Bartholomew's Church, Sheridan Ave, Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ. Interment will be on Saturday in Bonaventure Cemetery, Savannah, GA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Dr. Elliott W. Strong, Chair, C/O Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021, The Valley Hospital, 223 N Van Dien Avenue, Ridgewood, New Jersey 07450 or the Van Dyk Manor Nursing & Convalescent Home, 304 S Van Dien Ave., Ridgewood, NJ 07450.

title: U.S. Federation Clears Slaney In Doping Case
description: After her reputation twisted in the wind for 15 months, Mary Slaney, America's greatest female distance runner, was cleared yesterday of any doping violation by the United States track and field federation.

title: A Pandora's Box of Drug Legislation
description: The recent debacle in which two diet drugs were taken off the market because they may cause heart valve damage shows clearly how the passage of legislation being debated in the Senate this week would make similar problems even more likely.

title: INSIDE
description: For Mir, Not Enough Space

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Governor Wins Endorsements
description: About 100 black religious leaders endorsed Governor Whitman for re-election yesterday, praising her efforts in building the state's economy and reducing crime. Shahid Watson, the chairman of the group, which calls itself Spiritual, Unified, Prophetic, Political, Economic Revival, said the leaders were impressed by Mrs. Whitman's ''character and family values.'' Mr. Watson, the chief executive of Amer-I-Can Academy of New Jersey, a program for inner-city teen-agers, has supported several Republican candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, BERYL LOUISE
description: PRATT-Beryl Louise. September 16th, 1997, at the Isabella Geriatric Center, NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to the College of St. Elizabeth, Morristown, New Jersey where a memorial mass will be celebrated later.

title: American Players Resist Davis Cup
description: It has taken a couple of years for Tom Gullikson, captain of the United States Davis Cup squad, to perfect his recruiting technique. He gets down on one knee and begs a fluctuating crop of recalcitrant stars to honor their country and observe tennis tradition by taking part in a century-old international competition that seems to be flourishing in every nation but the one that created it.

title: Bourbons In the Cognac League
description: Born in the backwoods traditions of the 18th century, bourbon has lost much of its kick in the last decades of the cosmopolitan 20th. To much of the country, it has seemed as up to date as a typewriter, as chic as a Studebaker.

title: A Necessary Evil, and a Devilish Cost
description: A car is nearly a necessity in New Jersey, a suburban state where the corner market may be miles away. And it has long been true that voters in the state have blamed their elected officials for the high cost of the auto insurance needed to keep those cars on the road.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILLETTE, NOETH B.
description: GILLETTE-Noeth B. 9/17/25-6/17/93. Happy Birthday to my dear father. Your wisdom still guides me. Your love still protects me. Your stories still make me smile. And I still miss you more than words can say.

title: SUPERCANAL OFFERS TO BUY CABLE TV CONCERN IN TEXAS
description: Supercanal Holding S.A. of Argentina said yesterday that it had offered to acquire Tescorp Inc., a cable television concern in Austin, Tex., for at least $59 million. Supercanal said it would pay $4.50 for each Tescorp common share and $144 for each share of series 1995 preferred stock. Tescorp's shares rose 81.25 cents, or 24 percent, to $4.1875, in Nasdaq trading. Tescorp develops cable systems and communications properties in Latin America. The company has 13.1 million common shares, valuing that portion of the deal at $59 million. The number of series 1995 preferred shares was not disclosed. Supercanal, based in Buenos Aires, provides television services in Argentina. It said that acquiring Tescorp would give it 130,000 new subscribers.

title: A Slump at the Plate, But Not in Attitude
description: Even in the worst days of his slump, when Bernard Gilkey's swing was awkward and incapable of generating anything more than slow rollers, John Olerud noticed that Gilkey never withdrew from his teammates, a natural act for players playing badly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, FLORA
description: ROSENBERG-Flora. In Fla. on September 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, loving mother of Robert C. and Joel Ed. Doting grandmother of Andrew, Michael, Scott and Benjamin and greatgrandmother of Chelsea Diane, Annie and William. Survived by sister Claire and a multitude of nieces and nephews. Private service.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, GLADYS
description: NEWMAN-Gladys. Although twenty years have passed since you left us, it seems like yesterday. You are in our hearts always. Our love always. Leslie, Alan, Jonathan, Justin, Keri, Arnold, Giulia and Rebecca

title: Senator Is Resilient During Inquiry
description: When Mary L. Landrieu first showed up for work at the Louisiana Statehouse after being elected to the Legislature right out of college, some male colleagues whistled at her, mocked her from the microphone and put a rubber snake in her desk. For a time, she regularly cried in public.

title: Senate Shelves Proposals to Restrict Indian Legal Protections
description: The Senate backed away today from attempts to strip American Indian tribes of their legal immunity against lawsuits and to force tribes to report their income in order to receive Government benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDELL, GERALDINE
description: MINDELL-Geraldine. On Sept. 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving sister of Sarah and the late Martin David. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Services Thursday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to The Jefferson Market Garden, 18 W. 9th St, C/O Allen Pilikian, NYC

title: VSI HOLDINGS IN DEAL FOR PROVIDER OF TECHNICAL SERVICES
description: VSI Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Visual Services Inc. for $77.7 million in stock. VSI Holdings will issue 14.3 million shares of its stock, valued at $77.7 million based on Monday's closing price. Visual Services provides training and educational services, telemarketing, data base management and Web site development services. VSI Holdings, based in Smyrna, Ga., operates a chain of 22 Dress Code stores, which sell women's apparel. It also operates a robotics technology business. VSI Holdings' shares rose 31.25 cents, to $5.75, on the American Stock Exchange, where the stock earlier reached a 10-year high of $6.

title: A Kicker Sues, Saying She Was Treated Unfairly
description: In 1993, Heather Sue Mercer left Yorktown Heights, N.Y., believing that her place-kicking skills, which had helped the high school win a state football championship, were good enough to secure a spot on the Duke University football team.

title: RENO TO REPLACE TOP INVESTIGATORS IN CAMPAIGN QUERY
description: Embarrassed by missteps and discord in the Justice Department's campaign finance investigation, Attorney General Janet Reno will replace the top Federal prosecutor and F.B.I. agent in charge of the inquiry with more experienced senior personnel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRAND, JOHN E.
description: FARRAND-John E. In Watch Hill, Rhode Island, September 15, 1997. Husband of Fanny Boudeville Farrand, residence 1 Ice Pond Road, Watch Hill. Former international businessman and consultant. Father of Christopher P. Farrand, Antoinette L. Farrand and Laura F. Cachera; and grandfather of Mathieu Farrand and Margaux Cachera. Memorial Service will be held on Friday at 11 AM, in the Calvary Episcopal Church, 27 Church Street, Stonington, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made: The Rhode Island Visiting Nurses Association, 14 Woodruff Avenue, Narragansett, R.I. 02882-3467.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1863, Col. Robert Gould Shaw, who was white, led the Massachusetts 54th Regiment, whose members were black, into the Civil War. In battle at Fort Wagner in Charleston, S.C., the colonel and 281 members of the regiment were killed and buried in a common grave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELMECZI, FREDERICK (FRITZ)
description: SELMECZI - Frederick (Fritz). Loving husband of Marussi. Loving brother inlaw of Nadia Jaglom. Loving uncle of Nellie Gardner and Regina Wachter. Funeral services at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, 17 September noon.

title: Fighting Religious Persecution
description: Conservatives in America have long been part of the human rights movement, but in the past they have largely focused on abuses committed by Communist governments. Today they are broadening their concerns. A small group of activists has succeeded in putting repression of Christians in other countries on the national agenda. This has brought attention to an important, neglected problem, and increased consideration of human rights in American foreign policy. But it has also produced demagoguery among politicians eager to gain points with the Christian right.

title: Elections in Hong Kong
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, MARJORIE
description: HYMAN-Marjorie, on September 16, 1997. Devoted wife of the late William A. Beloved aunt of Willa and Stuart Jurow. Loving great aunt of Steve and Peggy Jurow, Jessie Ortiz. Fond great grand aunt of Maggie Ortiz, Jonathan and Matthew Jurow, Danielle Savage and Andre Marshall. Services at Old Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY, Thursday at 2 PM.

title: Sports of The Times; Williams Runs, Hits And Thinks
description: BERNIE WILLIAMS knows the stereotype is out there: today's ballplayer doesn't know the game. The label goes with the price tag. Millionaires don't need to know the rules.

title: Adidas to Buy Salomon, a French Sports Company
description: Adidas A.G. said today that it planned to buy Salomon S.A., the French sports equipment maker, in a transaction that valued Salomon at as much as 8 billion francs, or $1.4 billion, and would create the world's second-largest sporting goods company.

title: TV Notes; One Kind of Kickoff Outdraws Another
description: The fall season officially begins in a week, but CBS wanted to get an early jump, offering a full night of new programs on Monday night.

title: Students Are Slashed In Brooklyn and Queens
description: Students from two high schools were slashed in separate incidents this week, but only one attack appeared gang-related, the police said.

title: A Creaky Vote System In the Computer Age
description: In an age when computers can do everything from collect bridge tolls to shepherd bank transactions involving billion-dollar deposits, New York City remains virtually the last major city that still clings to its old-fashioned mechanical voting machines. And that means that it still has to cope with the confusion the machines can create.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: U.S. to Wage a High-Tech War on Drugs at the Mexican Border
description: The Clinton Administration's drug policy chief, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, said today that the United States would soon deploy high-technology screening systems to detect narcotics being smuggled across the border from Mexico.

title: Torre Watches Fielder, Then Gives Him a Start
description: Joe Torre watched intently from behind the cage as Cecil Fielder banged homer after homer off the pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, during batting practice. As soon as Fielder was done, Torre told him that he would be in the lineup for yesterday's first game.

title: Police Dept. Begins a Monitoring Program for 225 Problem Officers
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir has started an intensive monitoring program for 225 police officers who have recurring problems dealing with the public.

title: Today: Later News and 'Dining In, Dining Out'
description: This week The Times introduces its most sweeping improvements in more than 20 years:

title: Maker Had Issued Warnings on Diet Drug
description: Redux, the diet drug that was withdrawn from sale Monday after 15 meteoric months, was a problem product virtually from the start. In that short time, the American Home Products Corporation, the big pharmaceuticals and health care company, repeatedly issued warnings of rare but dangerous side effects for Redux and sent 950,000 cautionary letters to doctors and pharmacists.

title: Cookbook Follies: Recipes That Fail
description: It's Chocolate Nemesis, an aptly named dessert that has been the downfall of dozens, maybe even hundreds, of cooks who have tried to make it according to the directions in the best-selling ''Rogers Gray Italian Country Cookbook,'' by Ruth Rogers and Rose Gray. This creation, which is described as a ''jelly,'' is one of the most requested desserts at the authors' River Cafe in London. Kate Dyson, who owns the Dining Room Shop in London, told me that her attempt ''looked like a floppy cow pie.'' So did mine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MILTON
description: FRIEDMAN-Milton, age ninetythree, real estate lawyer, scholar and author, September 16, at home, suddenly. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Guiterman Friedman, loving father of Alan, father-in-law of Carolyn and devoted grandfather of Wendy, Kathryn and Amy. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a future date.

title: Dollar Gains Against Mark As German Rate Isn't Raised
description: The dollar edged higher against the German mark yesterday after the Bundesbank left a crucial interest rate unchanged and an official at the central bank suggested that a weak mark would not automatically lead to a German rate increase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCKELL, ELIANE GRIGNARD
description: STOCKELL-Eliane Grignard. Of Glen Cove, Long Island, on 9/16/97. Age 73. Beloved wife of Mercer L., mother of Mercer L. Jr, (Debra), Albert G. (Dorothy), and Catherine S. Bannon (Edmond). Sister of Vivienne Pecau (William), Renee Eaton (William), and Emile Grignard (Patricia). Grandmother of Justin, Lillian, Evan, Edmond, and Ellen. Visiting at the funeral home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, Wednesday 7-9 and Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. Service Saint John's of Lattingtown, Friday at 11 A.M. Donations to: Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, New York 11590.

title: MetroStars Lose, but Keep Grip on Playoff Spot
description: The key moment of tonight's game between the MetroStars and Dallas was not the goal that gave Dallas a 1-0 victory at Giants Stadium. It was an injury to Tab Ramos of the MetroStars midway through the first half.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLFSON, SIR ISAAC
description: WOLFSON-Sir Isaac. On your 100th birthday today, the entire family, sisters Rose, Bebe, Dolly, brother-in-law Robert, nephews, nieces, grand & great grand nephews and nieces, offer your son Lord Leonard, Lady Estelle Wolfson, his daughters and grandchildren our gratitude for having our blood ties with such a magnificent brother as his father was. We celebrate his life today and forever.

title: A Player of Few Words Is Ready for No. 1 Speaking Role
description: When he began sounding off about things like unfair labor agreements and bad economics two summers ago, everyone associated with Patrick Ewing wondered what had happened to the often reserved and quiet man they thought they knew.

title: Test Kitchen; For the Finale, Here's the Ice Cream Maker
description: KITCHENWARE shops call September to December the buying season for ice cream machines. Sales of machines, at $40 to more than $1,000, are booming. Retailers say that sales surge now, not in the summer months, because the machines are terrific gifts and a boon to home entertaining.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the biographer Leon Edel on Sept. 8 misstated the given name of his second wife in some copies. Her name is Roberta Roberts, not Robert Roberts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the investigation into the murder of JonBenet Ramsey misstated arrangements made by The Rocky Mountain News to photograph John and Patsy Ramsey. The newspaper made no concessions to the couple in exchange for permission to photograph them.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Guilty Plea in Gambling Ring
description: A man who lost his job as a Passaic County detective in 1974 for protecting a gambling ring in Paterson run by organized crime pleaded guilty yesterday to running his own gambling operation in 1991 and 1992, officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chips With More Memory May Revolutionize Industry

title: Ao Dai Enjoys A Renaissance Among Women : In Vietnam, A Return to Femininity
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  Nguyen Hong is the image of patience waiting in a tailor shop here for her pink ao dai. Behind her the small production room at Thiet Lap hums with pedal Singer sewing machines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, EDWARD
description: SHAPIRO-Edward. On September 16th, 1997. Born in New York City on April 18th, 1911. Edward was President of Diane Button Co., Manhattan, which he founded over 65 years ago. Edward resided in Bronxville, New York and Boca Raton, FL. He is survived by his loving wife of 59 years, Irene and three children: Lester, Barry and Lori. Also surviving are daughtersin-law Samantha and Roz, son-inlaw Harold Gross, 9 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on September 17th, 10 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Fleet Financial In Deal to Buy Brokerage Firm For $1.6 Billion
description: Fleet Financial Group Inc. has agreed to buy Quick & Reilly Group Inc. for stock valued at slightly more than $1.6 billion in a move intended to help it build a nationwide franchise in consumer financial services.

title: Kestner Shoots a 65 For Share of Met Lead
description: Darrell Kestner, the 1994 and 1995 champion, shot a five-under-par 65 for a 36-hole total of 137 to move into a tie with Mike Gilmore, the first-day leader, in the $70,000 Izod/Cadillac Met P.G.A. Championship yesterday at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, N.J.

title: Man Charged With a Wave Of Muggings In a Subway
description: Prosecutors say a blank check led the police to charge a Manhattan man with a string of subway muggings of the elderly that began in early June and stretched through most of the summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWCOMB, ROBERT S
description: NEWCOMB-Robert S. Of Bethlehem, PA. Died Sept. 14 at age 77. Formerly of Chatham, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Doris, loving father of Nancy Newcomb Hargraves of NY and Robert of Charlottesville, VA. Memorial services at First Presbyterian Church, Bethlehem, PA, Thursday, Sept 18 at 11 AM. Contributions may be made to Lehigh University.

title: No Way to Run a Primary
description: New York City residents will have to wait until at least this afternoon for word on whether there will be a runoff election next Tuesday for the Democratic mayoral primary between Ruth Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton. The confusion and shifting signals have thrown Ms. Messinger's campaign into turmoil. Mr. Sharpton's supporters, who had every reason to believe he had qualified for a runoff, are naturally angry and suspicious at word that Ms. Messinger might already have won the nomination outright.

title: Hartford Says Utility Hid Nuclear Contamination
description: A nuclear power plant that was permanently closed last year for safety reasons has been widely contaminated by two fuel leaks and other problems that the power company, Northeast Utilities, tried to cover up, state officials charged today.

title: Study Criticizes Textbooks On Marriage as Pessimistic
description: College students are being taught a pessimistic and sometimes inaccurate view of marriage, with great emphasis on issues like divorce and domestic violence, and little attention to the benefits of marriage, particularly for child-rearing, according to a new study of undergraduate textbooks on marriage and family.

title: Let the Wine And the Wit Flow Again
description: When the Camberley Hotel chain bought New York City's famed Algonquin in March, it not only acquired a hotel that is a historical and architectural landmark. It also bought a literary legend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYATT, MORRIS BURRELL (CHUCKIE)
description: WYATT-Morris Burrell (Chuckie), on September 12, 1997. Beloved father of Sara Jordan Wyatt of New York. Dear son of Alice M. Jones Wyatt. Fond brother of Francine L. Wyatt-Sykes, Lawrence, Allen Darrell Kevin and Keith Lamont Wyatt. Also survived by mother-in-law, 3 sistersin-law, two brothers-in-law, a host of cousins, uncles, aunts, and other relatives and friends. Funeral services, 12 Noon, Thursday, at St. James AME Church, 588 MLK Blvd., Newark, NJ. where friends may call on Wednesday 6-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Family Focus Adoption Service 54-40 Little Neck Pkwy Suite #

title: McGwire Stays With Cards For 3 Years, $28.5 Million
description: Putting his signature where his mouth was, Mark McGwire embraced the city that had embraced him and accepted less than the going rate yesterday to play for the St. Louis Cardinals for the next three years. A few hours later, he hit his 52d homer of the season to tie Ken Griffey Jr. for the major league lead, but the Cards lost to the Dodgers, 7-6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERRY, FRANCES NEWTON
description: TERRY-Frances Newton. Of Stonybrook, L.I., NY on September 15, 1997, in her 78th year. Beloved wife of the late Francis ''Deac'' Terry. Loving mother of Rev. Dr. Robert N. Terry and Anne Dee. Dear mother-in-law of Suzanne and Jon. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Robert II, Christina, Kristen, Tara and Terri. Retired Chairman of the Math Dept. at Earl L. Vandermeulen High School, Port Jefferson where she taught for 38 years. Past President of the Lake Ronkonkoma Historical Society. Active member and descendant of the Founder of the United Methodist Church, Lake Ronkonkoma. An accomplished organist, she was Phi Beta Kappa at Swarthmore College and received her Master's degree from Columbia University. A world traveller and had a love for opera, music and all people. Reposing at Moloney's Lake Funeral Home, 132 Ronkonkoma Ave., Lake Ronkonkoma, where religious services will be held 8 P.M., Wednesday. Funeral Service 11 AM, Thursday at United Methodist Church, Lake Ronkonkoma. Interment following at Lake Ronkonkoma Cemetery, Lake Ronkonkoma. Visiting on Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to United Methodist Church, 792 Hawkins Avenue, Lake Grove, New York 11755.

title: Immunity Demand Snags Burton Panel's Debut
description: On the eve of its first public hearings, the House committee investigating fund-raising abuses in President Clinton's re-election campaign put off questioning its opening witnesses today after they demanded immunity from prosecution.

title: Market Place; Petrofina of Belgium tiptoes into Big Board trading.
description: PETROFINA S.A., the Belgium-based oil and petrochemical company, made its debut on the New York Stock Exchange earlier this month, at a time when the few analysts who have followed the company are beginning to warm up to its stock.

title: Tuscany: New York's Newest Neighborhood
description: IT takes a village to market Tuscany. On Monday evening, the population of Tuscan Square, a collection of shops and restaurants in Rockefeller Center in Manhattan, swelled to more than 800 for a party to inaugurate the restaurateur Pino Luongo's homage to the romantic Italian province. The $4.5 million, 12,000-square-foot complex is scheduled to open on Saturday.

title: Same Time, Next Year: Islanders' Green Is Not in Camp
description: For the second straight off season, Travis Green and the Islanders were unable to reach an agreement on the center's worth.

title: $150 Million to Sell Issues
description: In the last election, $150 million a third of the advertising spending -- went for ''issue ads'' sponsored by independent groups not connected to a party or a candidate, a research group reported today.

title: Johannesburg Journal; Finding Polished Jobs for Diamonds in the Rough
description: On a recent morning Wendell Littler, 21, was staring through a magnifying glass judging his polishing work on a tiny diamond, just six-hundredths of a carat -- worth barely more than $30.

title: Sailing on a Rising Tide of Juice; The Almost Accidental Success of Nantucket Nectars
description: While many of their fellow Brown University graduates headed for Wall Street eight years ago, Tom First and Tom Scott retreated to Nantucket to loll on Mr. Scott's 22-foot Boston Whaler and work odd jobs like tending bar, shucking scallops and even shampooing dogs to pay their rent.

title: In Thailand, Once Asia's Tiger, Anger Boils
description: As usual in Thailand, it seemed as if everyone was smiling: the demonstrators with their red paper flags, the police officers with strips of cloth protecting their noses from pollution, the sidewalk vendors selling grilled pork and squid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, SELMA
description: STERN-Selma, on September 16, 1997. Beloved wife of Herman for 51 years. Adored mother of Robert Stern and Beverly Kingsley. Cherished grandmother of Elizabeth and Michael Kingsley. Dear sister of Gloria Riser and dear sister-in-law of Harold and Frances Stern. Services are today, 1 P.M., at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. Contributions to the National Diabetic Association would be appreciated.

title: Metro Business; Astoria Deal Advances
description: The Astoria Financial Corporation said Federal and New York State regulators approved its $293 million purchase of Greater New York Savings Bank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, IKE
description: GOLDIN-Ike. Young Israel of West Hempstead mourns the death of its beloved member, Ike Goldin, husband of Pearl. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yehuda Kelemer Mark Nathanson, President

title: Clerks Count Slowly While a City Hovers Impatiently
description: The fate of New York's Democratic mayoral contenders rested yesterday in the hands of dozens of city workers, like Keith J. Lilly, 32, of Harlem. But by 1 P.M., barely halfway into his shift counting the crucial absentee ballots at the Board of Elections' Manhattan office, all Mr. Lilly wanted to do was hold his head.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: METROPOLITAN DIARY -- Ballroom dancing along the Hudson; brouhaha on an uptown bus; soccer on East 70th Street, and the Address Book Mystery. B3.

title: Wine Talk; Bordeaux Again Leads a High-Price Parade
description: THE official date set for picking white grapes in Bordeaux this year was a remarkably early Aug. 25; mid-September is more the norm for all grapes. But the crop was so precocious that picking in the Graves region, a major source for white Bordeaux wine, began on Aug. 18. The early harvest reflects the magnificence of this year's growing season, which means the grapes and the wine should be superb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUDERT, FERDINAND
description: COUDERT-Ferdinand, Lyme, CT., September 15, 1997. Husband of the late Helen Carey Coudert. Retired international lawyer for Coudert Brothers, Attorneys in New York City. Private Funeral Services will be held at the convience of the family. For information Swan Funeral Homes, 1224 Boston Post Rd, Old Saybrook, CT.

title: Let's Make a Doctor, Or Let's Make a Deal?
description: Before conducting a recent seminar on medical ethics for interns and residents in orthopedic surgery, I reviewed the questions residents are typically asked on this subject in the Orthopedic In-Training Examination, the annual test they are given to assess their progress. These multiple-choice tests also prepare them for the exam they will take at the end of their residency to become board-certified orthopedists.

title: Withering Report Criticizes Officials Over a Rape in School
description: In a withering report, the top investigator for the New York City schools said yesterday that administrators at a Queens high school could have prevented a gang rape from occurring in an abandoned classroom last April if they had heeded a teacher's warning that students were using the room for clandestine sexual activity.

title: The Chef
description: RESTAURANT cooking doesn't normally leave much time for introspection. But this newspaper assignment is just the thing to force me to stop and notice the swirling influences -- the hunches, bits of memory, recent experiences, serendipity -- that culminate in a new dish.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If they sell them in Canada, I'll drive up there and come back with a carload of them. There are people who can't live without those drugs. For me, fen-phen is an alternative to dying.''

title: Army Neglects History Of Women as Warriors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, ANDERSON
description: FOWLER-Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23, at 11 A.M., at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone, New Jersey.

title: Mayoral Runoff Still in Limbo As Election Board Counts On
description: Seven days after the Democratic mayoral primary, the Board of Elections yesterday still could not say who won, forcing Ruth W. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton to step through the motions of a campaign suddenly in electoral limbo. The candidates visited subway stops, kissed babies and confronted confusion at every turn about whether their runoff would ever make it to the ballot box.

title: Government Plan Threatens Patients' Privacy; Presidential Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Minimalist; Every Day, a Red Pepper Day
description: THE Minimalist's quest -- to create exciting dishes with the smallest number of ingredients and the least fuss -- can take many paths. One is to search out and identify the sort of simple embellishments that unfailingly turns the ordinary find at the supermarket into something transcendent.

title: Government Plan Threatens Patients' Privacy; Social Security on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Ziff-Davis Discusses Acquiring New Site
description: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company is negotiating to move its headquarters to 63 Madison Avenue, in what would be one of the largest office deals of the year and a further sign of strength in the Midtown South real estate market.

title: Calendar
description: Harvest Lunch

title: More Money in Transit Bill
description: Under pressure from Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a Senate committee agreed yesterday to add an extra $20 million a year for New Jersey to a pending transportation bill.

title: New York Arts Council Wins 15 Percent Increase
description: While the National Endowment for the Arts is struggling to survive, its state counterpart, the New York State Council on the Arts, has quietly won an increase of nearly 15 percent in its budget from Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature.

title: U.S. FILTER OFFERS $30 A SHARE FOR MEMTEC
description: The U.S. Filter Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy Memtec Ltd. of Australia for $30 a share, or $330 million, in either United States or Australian dollars. U.S. Filter said the offer would begin in early October. The offer was announced after Memtec's American depository receipts closed at $24.625, up 62.5 cents a share. Memtec, based in Sydney, develops and produces membrane and other filtration and separation products. U.S. Filter, of Palm Desert, Calif., sells industrial and municipal water treatment systems. Its shares rose 75 cents, to $41.75.

title: In America; Time Bomb in Blue
description: Laura Gentile warned a city lawyer in 1991 that Richard Molloy, a young police officer who was both hot-tempered and weird, would end up killing someone.

title: For the Clintons, Stanford Parents' Day Won't Come Soon Enough
description: The first time Bill Clinton tried to steel her for the peculiar life ahead of them, his little girl cried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUSCO, GUIDO
description: FUSCO-Guido, of Boca Raton, FL, Sept. 17. Beloved husband of Irma, devoted father of Mary and Laurie, grandfather of Joshua and Marlana, cherished brother of Adrienne and Mario, uncle of Lisa, stepfather of Neil and Michael Harris. Shiva Friday 2-4 P.M.

title: Into the Spotlight With a Disability
description: The mystery at the core of ''Miracle Mile,'' Clark Middleton's graceful, affecting monologue about his lifelong struggle with a physically debilitating illness, is: Why does someone with a disfiguring condition subject himself to the trials of public display?

title: Exploring the Roles Of Liberty and Power In Love and Politics
description: S.O.A.P. Dance Theater Frankfurt, an experimental troupe that has caused a stir in Europe, tries too hard, but most of its two-hour production at the Joyce Theater is worth the try.

title: Renee Fleming Is the Philharmonic's Guest for First Concert of the Season
description: The New York Philharmonic opened its 156th season last night at Avery Fisher Hall with a gala concert that also celebrated the 70th birthday of its music director, Kurt Masur, who conducted. Joining Mr. Masur for part of the program was an artist who usually makes any concert special, the American soprano Renee Fleming.

title: Sports of The Times; How Many Flunked Geography?
description: WITH the big league baseball owners meeting in Atlanta to discuss radical realignment, this is a historic occasion. If only because the words ''baseball owners'' and ''radical'' have never been known to be used in the same sentence before, much less in the same meeting room.

title: Tokyo Cracks Down on Yamaichi Securities
description: Japanese authorities today arrested five current and former employees of the Yama ichi Securities Company and banned the firm from underwriting Government bonds as they investigated accusations that the brokerage house made illegal payoffs to a corporate racketeer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEISSLER, ROSALIE
description: SEISSLER-Rosalie, on September 16, 1997. Beloved wife of Sheldon. Devoted mother of Peter Seissler and Amy (Steven) Keith. Adored grandmother of Ross and Dylan. Loving sister of Frieda Low and Annette Raddock. Funeral service today, 2 PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Plainclothes Officer Is Shot in Brooklyn
description: A plainclothes police officer was shot in the right thigh last night in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn and was listed in stable condition at Kings County Hospital Center early today, the police said.

title: Amex Specialists to Cover Options Losses
description: Specialists at the American Stock Exchange will pay for losses incurred when options trading was halted Tuesday, exchange officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTONE, EMILIA
description: MATTONE-Emilia, 51, Locust, New Jersey, died on September 16, 1997, at Mt. Sinai Hospital, New York, New York. Born on June 28, 1946. Beloved wife of Vincent J. Mattone, Sr., loving mother of Mrs. Michele Corvisiero, Alan and Vincent Mattone, Jr. Devoted daughter of Anthony and Helen Mascolo, adoring sister of Mrs. Linda Rizzuto and Anthony Mascolo. As a loving partner and trusted friend of her adoring husband, Emilia was the depth and soul of their union. The warmth of her shining spirit will dwell within his heart for eternity. He will forever feel the touch of her hand in his. As a compassionate mother, Emilia taught her children how to love themselves and how to share that love. Her grace and goodness will be honored through their love for one another. Emilia graced our lives as a devoted, loving, and caring wife, mother, daughter, sister, and friend. Her warm smile, gentle heart, and quiet elegance will be missed by every life she touched. Our loss can only be comforted by knowing that God and all in heaven now share in what we miss. In pursuit of furthering her education, Emilia became a member of the International Honor Society-Phi Alpha Theta as well as a member of the Honor Society at Monmouth University, Lamda Sigma Tau. John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, New Jersey, will be handling arrangements, Thursday, September 18, 79PM, Friday, September 19, 2-4 and 7-9PM. A funeral mass will be held Saturday, September 20, at 11:00 AM, Holy Cross Church, Rumson, New Jersey, where she was a communicant. Celebrant Archbishop Renato R. Martino, Performance Observer of the Holy See to the United Nations. Con Celebrant Fr. Joseph Hughes, Holy Cross RC Church, Rumson, NJ and Fr. James Leone, Archdiocese of Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to her favorite charity, Path to Peace Foundation, 25 East 39th Street, New York, New York 10016. EM Forever in Our Hearts

title: Some prominent executives are on the move at several agencies around the country.
description: PROMINENT executives are on the move at several agencies.

title: Giants' Owner Creates Bump for Realignment
description: The myriad plans for realignment of the major leagues that have been proposed have a common denominator: all eight western teams are included in the National League.

title: From Mannerly Ballet to Ethnic Processional
description: The program presented by Dance Theater of Harlem on Tuesday night at Davis Hall at City College was the perfect example of the extraordinary range of ballet the company is presenting during its packed two-week season, which ends on Sunday. A George Balanchine signature piece opened the program, followed by a stylized modern dance trio, an emotion-drenched modern ballet and an exotic foray into ethnic dance and ceremony that brought the cheering audience to its feet. Even more notable was the way the dancers gave full and distinctive value to each style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, NORMAN DUDLEY
description: JOHNSON-Norman Dudley. Died peacefully September 16, 1997 on Martha's Vineyard, Ma., in his 90th year. Survived by his wife Virginia Couper Johnson; father of Dudley Disosway Johnson, Cazenovia, NY, Kathleen Wu, Pontevedra, Florida, Norman Platt Johnson, Newport, R.I. Ridgely Couper Johnson, London, England, six grandchildren, two great grandchildren. Service St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, MA., 4 PM, Friday, Sept. 19th.

title: All-Girls School May Violate Rights of Boys, Officials Say
description: The experimental all-girls public academy that opened in East Harlem last fall appears to violate civil rights laws by discriminating against boys, but a compromise could keep it open, Federal education officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMSON, MARTHA EMERY
description: ADAMSON-Martha Emery, of Rumson, N.J., Sept. 15, 1997, at her late residence. Memorial services will be held Friday, Sept. 19, 1997, at 11 A.M., at St. George's By The River Episcopal Church, Rumson, New Jersey. Contributions to Planned Parenthood or SPCA of Monmouth County in her name would be greatly appreciated.

title: Breaking Ground; So Beautiful This Ghastly Flower
description: STRUGGLING the other evening to stake a particularly menacing Scotch thistle without incurring too great a loss of blood, I suddenly realized that Morticia Addams has become an important influence in my garden. I haven't quite reached the point where I snip the blooms off my roses in order to showcase their thorns, but the philosophy behind such a practice -- that there is something to be said for the thorn as well as the rose and that there are times when flowers only get in the way -- no longer seems so perverse.

title: Speaking Out on Race Helps Advance Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEW, ROBERT PRESTON
description: CHEW-Robert Preston, formerly of Greenwich, Conn., died of cancer at his home in Charlottesville, VA., September 15, 1997. Bob Chew graduated from Princeton University in 1942, served as Field Artillery Captain in the Philippines where he earned the Silver Star for ''action behind the Japanese lines.'' He then spent 38 years in the chemical industry, retiring in 1984 from Essex Chemical Co. Bob Chew is survived by his wife Elena and by his sons John, Robert and Thomson.

title: Close to Home; If the Doorbell's Ringing, This Must Be Home
description: ALL her life my momma had lived in other people's houses. Sometimes through cheap rent, sometimes through charity, she had lived beholden. The closest thing we had ever had to a home of our own was a small trailer we lived in for only a few months, when I was a boy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL BALSO, ANTHONY MICHAEL
description: DEL BALSO-Anthony Michael, of Aiken, SC on September 16 after a brief illness. Husband of the late Suzanne Wilding Del Balso, father of Dina Rosser of Atlanta, GA., and Michael Del Balso of New York City, stepfather of Wendy Berol Gifford of McLean, VA and J. Robin Berol Bliss of Bedford Hills, New York, grandfather of eleven and great-grandfather of 3. Funeral services will be private. Memorials may be made to Aiken County Public Library, 314 Chesterfield St., SW, Aiken, SC 29801.

title: Asset Sales and Cost Cuts Double Pechiney Profits
description: Pechiney S.A., France's biggest aluminum producer, said yesterday that first-half profits more than doubled on one-time gains and cost-cutting. The company earned 1.03 billion French francs ($172 million), up from 426 million francs a year earlier. Earnings included gains from asset sales of 560 million francs.

title: Senate Republicans Criticize Clinton's Effort on Trade Accords
description: The Clinton Administration's stance on international trade encountered intense opposition from important Senate Republicans today, only a day after it was denounced by House Democratic leaders.

title: Newspaper Reading 101
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Eye
description: SWEET, their fans call the sound that comes from the vacuum-tube stereo equipment of the 1960's: sweet, natural and warm. When solid-state equipment -- built first around transistors, then around chips -- began to flood the market in the 1970's, it left devotees of the traditional stereos stranded high and dry. Tube buffs, or retrophiles, condemned the solid-state sound as harsh, hard, cold, grainy, glazed and steely. Over the intervening years, this rump group has grown more fervent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, ISAAC
description: GOLDIN-Isaac. American Friends of Yeshivot Bnei Akiva records with deep sorrow the passing of Isaac Goldin, beloved father of Rabbi Shmuel Goldin, a dedicated supporter of AFYBA and recipient of its 1997 Rabbinic Leadership Award. May the family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marvin S. Bienenfeld, Chairman Joel M. Schreiber, President Rabbi David V. Warshaw, Ex. Dir.
