title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; 10 People Arrested In Police Drug Sweep
description: Police and narcotics investigators closed 5 businesses, arrested 10 people and seized 2 handguns, $25,000 in cash and a kilo of cocaine in an anti-drug sweep in Washington Heights yesterday.

title: Proposed Deal With Democrats Draws Focus of Investigators in Teamsters Election
description: On a scorching summer day in 1996, a top consultant to Ron Carey, the teamsters president, dined with the Democratic Party's finance director at the Palm Restaurant in Washington and made an intriguing proposal. He said the teamsters would give $1 million to the Democrats if wealthy Democratic donors would in turn make big contributions to Mr. Carey's re-election campaign.

title: Excerpt From Pat Robertson's Remarks
description: Following is an excerpt from Pat Robertson's remarks to Christian Coalition members on Saturday in Atlanta, referring to Don Hodel, the coalition's president, Vice President Al Gore and Representative Richard A. Gephardt.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Woman Indicted in Killing Of Newborn Son at Prom
description: The New Jersey teen-ager accused of killing her newborn son in a bathroom stall at her senior prom in June has been indicted on a murder charge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, MAX
description: BRENNER-Max. Age 94 in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Beloved husband of Ilse Brenner. Loving father of Joan Toder of Scarsdale, New York. Also survived by his twin brother Hans Brenner of Fort Lauderdale. Services to be held at Schwartz Funeral Home, 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Thursday, September 18th, at 10:00 AM. Contributions may be made to the Arthritis Research Center, 300 S.Duncan, Suite 240, Clearwater, Florida 33755 in memory of Max Brenner.

title: Still Helping the Police, But in Another Country
description: When information on the new television season began to filter out a few months ago, one of the more troubling bits of news was that ABC planned to present an Americanized version of ''Cracker,'' the searing British crime series seen regularly in the United States over the last several years on A&E.

title: A Key Ulster Protestant Agrees to Join Talks With Sinn Fein
description: The leader of the largest Protestant political party in Northern Ireland agreed today to take part in formal, broad-based peace talks that include Sinn Fein, the political wing of the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army.

title: I.M.F. Says Currency Troubles Will Curtail Growth in Asia
description: The International Monetary Fund has cut its growth forecast for Southeast Asia, delivering a bleak assessment of the damage caused by months of turmoil in the region's currency markets.

title: Former White House Aide Tells Of Pressure Over a Party Donor
description: A former White House national security adviser told Senate investigators today that officials of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Department of Energy and the Democratic Party lobbied heavily to make sure that a big-money campaign contributor and controversial oil promoter obtained an audience with President Clinton despite warnings that he had a ''shady and untrustworthy reputation.''

title: Commissioner Considers Changes In Police Officers' Midnight Shift
description: In a bid to break a pattern of misconduct on the midnight shift, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that he was considering proposals to transfer officers and rotate their working hours more frequently instead of holding them to steady tours of duty.

title: Priest With Many Questions But Not a Single Easy Answer
description: ''Can anyone tell me why we have an atheist on staff?'' a callow parish priest asks during a staff meeting.

title: Meadowlands Makes a Move to Compete With Belmont
description: Hal Handel, who runs racing in New Jersey, said he had no malice in mind but merely saw ''a window of opportunity'' in the schedule when he decided to confront the people who run racing in New York.

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK ; Green Sounds Warning About Landfill Closing
description: As Staten Island residents rejoice over plans to shut down the Fresh Kills landfill, the Public Advocate, Mark Green, sounded a note of caution yesterday and urged the city to conduct a full public review of the environmental hazards connected to the closure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, AARON
description: HALPERN-Aaron. On September 16, 1997. Age 77. Of Clifton, N.J., and Delray Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Dorothy (Leibowitz), loving father of Doretta. Adored brother, uncle, great uncle, great great uncle, cousin and friend. Educator and Principal of Clifton H.S. for 25 years, 1963-1988. Services on Friday, September 19 at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 66 Howe Avenue, Passaic, NJ, 10AM. Donations may be made to the Aaron Halpern Scholarship Fund, PO Box 416, Little Falls, N.J. 07424.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts to revive literary discussions at the Algonquin Hotel misspelled the name of a participant in one such discussion, the publicity director at Scribner's. She is Patricia Eisemann, not Pat Eiseman.

title: Accounts
description: * New York Restaurant Group to Mad Dogs and Englishmen, New York, to handle its account, which had been handled by Hampel/Stefanides, New York, until that agency resigned in June. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $1.5 million. The company manages or owns restaurants like Smith & Wollensky and Maloney & Porcelli.

title: M.I.T. Loses Money In Diet Drug Recall
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology lost a revenue source that paid more than $1 million in annual royalties when dexfenfluramine, a popular diet drug, was withdrawn from sale last week.

title: Stunned by War, the Arts of Sarajevo Are Reawakening
description: It was logical that Bosnia's first postwar movie should be about the war that savaged this country for four years. Yet barely 18 months after an uneasy peace was imposed by NATO, it seemed almost too soon to ask people here to relive the war as fiction. One moment, they were watching the bombardment of Sarajevo on a huge screen; the next, they were stepping back into a city still largely in ruins.

title: For Some, Diet Pills Are Worth the Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family Foray Into New and Old
description: The musicians were all smiles when Ravi Shankar performed at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. The two drummers, Bikram Ghosh on the North Indian tabla and Vedakrishnan Venkatesan on the South Indian mrdangam, each grinned at the other's skill as they tossed accelerating solos back and forth. Mr. Shankar beamed as he traded phrases on sitar with his 16-year-old daughter, Anoushka. And she, in turn, listened intently to her father's playing, responding to his most daring forays with a shy, winning smile. Mr. Shankar, who is 77 years old, is passing on Indian classical music in the traditional way, through aural instruction and via his family line (although he also has other students). His daughter has been studying with him for six years, and performing with him for the last three.

title: For Some, Diet Pills Are Worth the Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss to Give First Payouts To Survivors Of Holocaust
description: Nine months after Switzerland committed itself to creating a fund to help Holocaust survivors, the first money -- up to $1,000 each for 12,000 survivors in Eastern Europe -- is about to be paid out, Swiss and Jewish officials said today.

title: Mortality Rates for Infants
description: New Jersey's mortality rate for black infants during the first year of life is gradually dropping, but it is still nearly three times as high as the rate for white infants, a state panel reported yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Residential Resales
description: Big Deal

title: Campaign Finance Hearing Excerpts
description: Following are excerpts from testimony today by Sheila Heslin, a former staff member of the National Security Council, and questions by Harry Damelin, a staff lawyer for the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, at a hearing on campaign finances, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Starts of Housing Decline As Inflation Stays in Check

title: Jones Takes a Pounding To Cap a Day of Blows
description: There is symmetry in the terrifying way the Mets were eliminated from the National League East race today.

title: Calendar: Crafts Show And a Skyscraper Tour
description: Walking Wall Street

title: The Face Behind the Bagel ; Afghan Newcomers Use Coffee Carts to Succeed As Vendors of New York's Rush-Hour Breakfast
description: On his way to work as a supervisor at a downtown deli in the mid-1980's, Fahim Saleh, an Afghan refugee with an easy smile, would buy coffee from a chatty Greek vendor in a pushcart at Lexington Avenue and 43d Street. Mr. Saleh had fled Afghanistan in 1980 and, while he liked his job at the deli, he wanted something to call his own. Like a business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, BERYL LOUISE
description: PRATT-Beryl Louise. September 16th, 1997, at the Isabella Geriatric Center, NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to the College of St. Elizabeth, Morristown, New Jersey where a memorial mass will be celebrated later.

title: 5 Awards for Reporting on Latin America
description: Five journalists have won the 1997 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for distinguished reporting on Latin America. The journalists, two from the United States, two from Colombia and one from Argentina, will each receive $1,000 and a gold medal at a ceremony at Columbia University on Oct. 16.

title: LAND MINE TREATY TAKES FINAL FORM OVER U.S. DISSENT
description: Sweeping aside the objections of the United States, about 100 countries agreed here today to submit for formal ratification a treaty outlawing anti-personnel land mines, the first international agreement to ban a widely used weapon system since the end of World War I.

title: Cigarette Makers Criticize Clinton Policy
description: The nation's cigarette makers reacted bitterly to President Clinton's new tobacco policy, saying it demands concessions that go far beyond a costly and ground-breaking plan they reluctantly agreed to in June.

title: Islanders See the Future in Goal, and He Looks Promising
description: When the Islanders made 18-year-old Roberto Luongo the highest pick for a goalie in National Hockey League draft history last June, the team said it was looking to the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CABOT, VIRGINIA WELLINGTON
description: CABOT-Virginia Wellington, of Weston, MA., September 15. Age 97. Wife of the late Thomas D. Cabot. Mother of Louis W. Cabot of Cambridge, Massachusetts; Thomas D. Cabot, Jr. of Greenwich, CT.; Robert M. Cabot of Seattle, WA.; Dr. Edmund B. Cabot of Belmont, MA., and Linda Black of Cambridge, MA. Also survived by 28 grandchildren and 26 great grandchildren. Services will be held on Saturday, September 20 at 1 o'clock P.M., at King's Chapel, 58 Tremont Street, Boston, MA. For information, call Waterman Funeral Home, 617-235-4110.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Foreign Affairs; www.mideast.com.war?
description: I spent last week following Secretary of State Madeleine Albright on her Middle East tour. Here is what was being talked about outside the corridors of diplomacy.

title: U.S. AIDS Research Abroad Sets Off Outcry Over Ethics
description: For the past two years, the United States has been conducting experiments on pregnant women infected with H.I.V. in Africa, Thailand and the Dominican Republic, in which some women are given drugs that can prevent transmission of the deadly AIDS virus to their babies and some receive only dummy pills.

title: Slumping Ripken May Need Some Rest
description: Davey Johnson, manager of the Baltimore Orioles, once joked that only Cal Ripken or a supreme being could end Ripken's record consecutive-game streak, which reached 2,467 games last night. If Ripken is to end the streak voluntarily, he has more sound reasons now than at any time since he last missed a game for the Orioles, in May 1982.

title: In the Pure Voices of Boys, A Chorus's Self-Renewal
description: To the eye and indeed the ear, the Choir of King's College, Cambridge, an assemblage of 30 young men and boys, appears anything but a mighty institution. Yet the group, founded 555 years ago by King Henry VI, embodies the truth that institutions remain great precisely because they renew themselves constantly.

title: Roster Reshuffled At Perrier Group
description: Perrier Group, a unit of Nestle S.A. in Greenwich, Conn., has reshuffled its agency roster, eliminating one shop, Lord Group in New York, and adding another, Citron Haligman Bedecarre in San Francisco. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Metro Business; Tour Operators Sue Bus Service on Name
description: New York Apple Tours was sued yesterday by two Pennsylvania-based companies that said the bus-tour operator's name violates their rights to trademarks using the word ''apple.''

title: COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS
description: When David (Deacon) Jones played pro football a generation ago, he became a Hall of Fame defensive end for the Los Angeles Rams' Fearsome Foursome. Now he has formed the Deacon Jones Foundation to provide four-year college scholarships for inner-city youngsters, then requiring the recipients to remain active with the foundation as mentors.

title: Georgia-Pacific to Split Up Interests in Timber and Paper
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that it would put its 5.8 million acres of timber into a new operating group and spin it off to shareholders to allow separate valuation of its timber and paper businesses.

title: Mendoza Challenges For a Post-Season Start
description: While the Yankees know that scooting into post-season play is a virtual certainty, they also know that their post-season starting rotation is a virtual uncertainty. Even Ramiro Mendoza knows how sluggish the skirmish for the fourth starter spot has been between Kenny Rogers and Dwight Gooden, so he decided to try and sneak into the race.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RECEPTAGEN LTD., Burnaby, British Columbia, a pharmaceutical company, plans to merge with Scitech Genetics Ltd., a privately held Singapore biotechnology company, for stock worth $21.6 million.

title: Mining the Politics of the Cha-Cha
description: Euphoria comes in different forms, and at Hostos Community College, where Orchesta Aragon played on Saturday night, it showed up in a political form. The group, legendary and from Cuba, played cha-chas with violins and flute and several singers; it was light, precise music that recalled the 1940's and 1950's. Three local politicians -- Representative Jose E. Serrano, Councilman Jose Rivera and State Senator Efrain Gonzalez Jr. -- came out and delivered incendiary speeches, and gave the group official government proclamations. Mr. Serrano said that he wanted to make sure that the Cubans understood that ''not everything the American Congress does is meant to hurt the Cuban people.'' The place, filled with a middle-aged Puerto Rican audience, went wild.

title: Rebels' Journey Leaves Mexico Confused About Their Role
description: In the fourth year since the Zapatista rebels began a quixotic uprising from southern jungles, their movement has become the equivalent for the Government of a bad elbow, causing no actual trauma but making the nation feel that it is not really well.

title: Ex-Letter Carrier Laments That She Stressed Service, Not Speed
description: She was once an obscure mail carrier, her workaday existence nothing to write home about. Now, Martha Cherry is a media star, having been dismissed by the Postal Service for taking short steps, or what it called ''baby steps,'' on her appointed rounds.

title: Events: Artwork For Sale
description: Interpreting a Landmark

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, ANDERSON
description: FOWLER-Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23, at 11 A.M., at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone, New Jersey.

title: Fire Leaves 54 Homeless
description: A suspicious fast-moving fire destroyed two multifamily dwellings yesterday and damaged four others, leaving 54 people homeless, officials said.

title: Adecco to Acquire Massachusetts Company
description: Adecco S.A. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire TAD Resources International, a closely held temporary-staffing company, for $387.5 million. Adecco is one of the world's biggest employment-services companies. It was created last year from the merger of Adia S.A. of Switzerland and Ecco S.A. of France.

title: In Early Returns, Ravens Surprise
description: Baltimore's owner, Art Modell, was on the telephone asking for a little respect for his 2-1 Ravens. His team didn't get much before the season. Many thought the Ravens -- without running back Bam Morris (lost to a drug suspension) and their top draft pick, linebacker Peter Boulware (who reported late because of a contract dispute) -- would disappear south of the .500 border.

title: Conflict Over Settlers Deepens for Netanyahu
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's efforts to defuse a mounting crisis over Jewish settlements were thwarted today when an American Jewish millionaire refused to reduce the number of Jewish settlers occupying a house he owns in East Jerusalem.

title: Yes to Aged Windows
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Years After 'Black Wednesday, 'Mood of Acceptance Takes Hold : Britain and Euro:Not 'If' but 'When'
description: LONDON  It was a day no one in Britain will forget. Fighting massive speculation in the financial markets, the government jacked up interest rates by 50 percent in a desperate bid to defend the pound, only to let the nation's currency crash hours later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARE, WILL
description: HARE-Will. A dear friend, whose Dylan, with Rue McClanahan, a production I was privileged to produce, was the finest Dylan ever portrayed on stage. God bless, Will. We'll miss you. Martin Richards

title: Pilot of F-16 Overcame Wing Damage To Reach Base
description: With one wing of his plane severely damaged in a midair collision off the Atlantic City coast, the pilot of an F-16 fighter jet managed to fly 30 miles back to his base in Pomona, N.J., on Tuesday night, alerting the base by radio that the pilot and a flight instructor from the other jet had parachuted into the ocean.

title: Giuliani Reports on City, Acknowledging Few Flaws
description: For the last four years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's release of the twice-yearly Mayor's Management Report has occasioned an election-year-like atmosphere of cheerful statistics and self-congratulation, but yesterday -- in a real election year -- the Mayor took a step further in using the report to burnish his administration's reputation.

title: CASINO COMPANIES AGREE TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $304 MILLION
description: Two Las Vegas casino companies have agreed to be acquired by the R & E Gaming Corporation, a company owned by Allen E. Paulson, a casino and race horse investor. The companies said late on Tuesday that R & E would buy the Elsinore Corporation for about $54 million, including the assumption of debt, and the Riviera Holdings Corporation for about $250 million plus assumed debt. Elsinore owns the Four Queens Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, and Riviera operates the property. Elsinore's shareholders will receive $3.16 a share, and Riviera shareholders will receive $15 a share. Shares of Riviera jumped $1.50, to $14.50, on the American Stock Exchange. Elsinore's shares fell 75 cents, to $2.50, on the Nasdaq market.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANCELLIERE, M.A. (CANCY)
description: CANCELLIERE-M.A. (Cancy). Of blessed memory. Leah

title: Theater in Review
description: Death as a Mechanism For Coaxing Out Truth

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HICKEY, WILLIAM
description: HICKEY-William. Family, Friends & Colleagues will gather to remember and celebrate his life. The Majestic Theatre 247 W 44 St. Friday, September 19th at 2 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHUMER, RICHARD
description: SCHUMER-Richard. Always in our hearts. Doris, Jeff, Roshann, George, Jeanne, Leona, Howell

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, NORA AGNES (NEE MISKELL)
description: REILLY-Nora Agnes (nee Miskell). Native of Glenamaddy, County Galway, Ireland, on September 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John M. Reilly; loving mother of John J., Richard W., James P., and the late William M.; dear grandmother of 13 and greatgrandmother of 12. Family will receive friends Friday, 3-9 P.M., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Mass of Christian Burial, at St. Ignatius Loyola, R.C. Church, Park Avenue at 84 Street, Saturday, 10 A.M.

title: Library Lauds Chairwoman As It Seeks $500 Million
description: The New York Public Library gave a rousing sendoff to its chairwoman yesterday as it formally announced a $500 million capital campaign that it says is the largest fund-raising effort ever undertaken by an American cultural institution.

title: San Pablo de Cantesiaya Journal; Across Jungle Iron Curtain, Cousins Yearn to Meet
description: When Fernando Payaguaje decided to flee the Peruvian jungle with his family 56 years ago, escaping a rubber dealer who had made virtual slaves of his people, he could not have imagined that the distant fire he was hearing would permanently divide him from his tribe.

title: New York to Allow Bigger Fines on Lawyers' Nuisance Tactics
description: Putting some muscle into their campaign to require good conduct by lawyers, New York State's top judges said today that they would remove the ceiling on fines a judge can impose on a lawyer for using nuisance motions and delaying tactics in trying a case.

title: UNC SELLS EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE UNITS TO CARLYLE
description: The Carlyle Group said yesterday that it had acquired the military aircraft and vehicle maintenance divisions of UNC Inc. for an undisclosed sum. Carlyle said it would rename the operations, which have annual revenue of about $290 million and 4,000 employees, Lear Siegler Services Inc. The new company's headquarters will remain in Annapolis. Carlyle, based in Washington, is a closely held investment group headed by Frank Carlucci, the former United States Defense Secretary. UNC, an aircraft maintenance company also based in Annapolis, said the sale was part of its plans to be acquired by the General Electric Company's Greenwich Air Services unit.

title: One-Pennant Wonders
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHAR, RUTH K.
description: BEHAR-Ruth K., formerly of New York City and resident of Pompano Beach, Florida for the last 22 years died on September 16, 1997, at age 80. The cause of death was Alzheimers. A graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College and the recipient of a Master's Degree in speech from Barnard College, Ruth was the loving wife and best friend for 58 years of Joseph Behar, caring mother of Kenneth Behar of Lexington, Massachusetts and Joan Behar of Vashon Island, Washington, and devoted grandmother of Katherine and Jonathan Behar.

title: MELLON SAID TO SEEK FOUNDERS ASSET MANAGEMENT
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation is rumored to be the leading contender to buy the Founders Asset Management Company, a Denver-based mutual fund company, for as much as $300 million. Mellon would increase its equity mutual funds business by acquiring Founders, which oversees $6.5 billion in assets. The Pittsburgh-based Mellon already owns the Dreyfus Corporation, a fund manager with $90 billion in assets that is best known for its fixed-income funds. Neither a Mellon spokesman nor a Founders spokesman would comment. Founders is a closely held firm controlled by its chairman, Bjorn Borgen.

title: Speaking Out on Race Helps Advance Equality; Admissions Are Flawed
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking Out on Race Helps Advance Equality; A Sign of Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: American Topics : A Surprise Controversy:'Stork' Parking Spaces
description: More and more shopping malls, supermarkets and other businesses are offering special parking spots in prime locations to pregnant women and mothers of infants. But the practice, much appreciated by most of the women, has drawn some surprisingly tart criticism.

title: WARNACO IN STOCK DEAL FOR DESIGNER HOLDINGS
description: Warnaco Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Designer Holdings Ltd., a maker of Calvin Klein jeans, for $11 a share, or $353.7 million, in stock. The purchase would give Warnaco, which is based in New York, a larger share and greater control of Calvin Klein's clothing and accessories business. Warnaco already makes Calvin Klein underwear and accessories. Designer Holdings' stock price rose 62.5 cents a share, to $10, and Warnaco rose 81.25 cents, to $34.75. Calvin Klein brand goods generated $472.9 million, or about 98 percent, of Designer Holdings' 1996 sales, a company spokesman said. The 40-year license, which expires in 2034, cannot be revoked if Designer Holdings is acquired.

title: A Tape Reveals Pat Robertson, the Politician
description: In remarks delivered privately to supporters last weekend, Pat Robertson, chairman of the Christian Coalition, dispensed with his traditional prayerful invocations and plunged into a blunt political speech in which he spoke admiringly of the Tammany Hall political machine and declared his desire to select ''the next President of the United States.''

title: Rethink the Cottages
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Skelton, Knockabout Comic and Clown Prince of the Airwaves, Is Dead at 84
description: Red Skelton, a master of mime and clowning whose gentle humor captivated generations of Americans, died yesterday at a hospital in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 84.

title: BPI to Purchase Clio Awards
description: BPI Communications in New York, which publishes trade magazines like Adweek, Mediaweek and Billboard, said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the Clio Awards Inc. from James M. Smyth. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Fall Asters

title: A Monument, or an Oilfield?
description: Apart from one or two lamentable lapses, the Clinton Administration has been a more responsible steward of the American landscape than its Republican predecessors. It has resisted Congressional efforts to enrich local and commercial interests at the expense of America's national resources, and has embarked on ambitious efforts, as in the Everglades, to correct misguided policies of the past. Yet each day brings another test, and in some instances the Administration can be found wanting.

title: McDonald's Has No Plan for New Burger
description: The McDonald's Corporation said today that it had no plans to sell nationwide a quarter-pound hamburger that it was testing in a limited number of restaurants across the United States.

title: Another Autumn Rerun: B.C. Starts Over Again
description: Starting over has been a recurring theme at Boston College lately. The football team has started over a couple of times already this season, after a loss to lowly Temple followed by an unexpected victory over West Virginia last Saturday. Coming up is a Big East contest at Rutgers on Saturday.

title: Who Has Sovereignty Over Mother Earth?
description: Hastiin Alexander Etcitty was already old and full of the wisdom for which his Taadii clan is noted when he befriended me in 1961. If he were alive today for me to ask him about the attempts to weaken Indian sovereignty that are now worrying his Navajo tribe, I'm sure he'd offered his standard two-step solution. For Etcitty, step one was always the same. ''First,'' he'd say, ''make all the lawyers go away.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MILTON
description: FRIEDMAN-Milton, age ninetythree, real estate lawyer, scholar and author, September 16, at home, suddenly. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Guiterman Friedman, loving father of Alan, father-in-law of Carolyn and devoted grandfather of Wendy, Kathryn and Amy. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a future date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYATT, MORRIS
description: WYATT-Morris. Family Focus Adoption Services mourns the passing of our friend and Board member, Morris (Chuck) Wyatt. Chuck was a quiet and thoughtful man who lived a life of great courage. He was an example to all of us and we will miss him. Our sympathy goes to Sara and the entire Wyatt and Zirinsky families. Kathleen Wallace, Board Pres. Maris H. Blechner, Exec. Dir.

title: Chrysler Building Lures 20 Bidders With Romance and Profit Potential
description: An unprecedented number of investors, real estate moguls and foreign companies have joined the bidding for the Chrysler Building, the landmark Art Deco skyscraper on Lexington Avenue at 42d Street that serves as a monument to the industrial age.

title: Gingrich Tries to Rein In Ally On Big Spending for Highways
description: Hoping to avoid an internecine floor fight with one of his most powerful and loyal lieutenants, Speaker Newt Gingrich spent today trying to persuade the chairman of the House Transportation Committee to rein in his plan for steeply increased highway spending.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you tried to do this study in the U.S., you would have to do it through a throng of demonstrators and a sea of reporters.''

title: Bonds Rise Somewhat on Congenial Data
description: The prices of Treasury securities were mostly higher yesterday, buoyed by weak housing-start figures for August and a friendly Federal Reserve report on business conditions.

title: Speaking Out on Race Helps Advance Equality; Texas Professor Is Unfit
description: To the Editor:

title: CREATIVE COMPUTERS OFFERS $43 MILLION FOR ELEK-TEK
description: Creative Computers Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $43 million to acquire Elek-Tek Inc., a computer-products and services marketer. Elek-Tek filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code yesterday, and Creative Computers signed the deal in connection with Elek-Tek's bankruptcy filing. Creative Computers said that if the acquisition, which requires court approval, was completed, it might close some Elek-Tek retail stores. Elek-Tek, based in Skokie, Ill., sells microcomputer products and services. Creative Computers, based in Torrance, Calif., is a direct marketer of personal computer equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, SOL
description: FRIED-Sol. On September 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Bernice. Loving father of Bonnie, Roger & Lori. Dear grandfather of Justin and his wife Rondi. Service Friday, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No surprise: DONATELLA VERSACE, the sister of the late fashion designer Gianni Versace, will become the chief designer at Versace, the company announced yesterday.

title: Ballesteros Gets His Ryder Cup Team, at a Cost
description: The controversy involving Seve Ballesteros, Miguel Angel Martin and the European team has only increased the intrigue surrounding next week's Ryder Cup.

title: Fleet Taking Another Fork In Road to Bank Expansion
description: As big banks try to figure out strategies for succeeding in stock trading and investment banking, Fleet Financial Group Inc., the large regional banking company based in Boston, is taking an approach different from most of its peers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORAN, RITA K.
description: ORAN-Rita K. Of Brooklyn, New York, on September 17th, 1997. Loving mother of Bruce and Sue, Scott and Sandi. Cherished grandmother of Matthew, Stephanie, Steven, Jillian and Jordan. Funeral service 10AM Thursday, I.J. Morris Inc., 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn. Burial Mount Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Eerie Embroidery From the Windsor Dustbin
description: THE ROYALS

title: With or Without U.S., Latin Trade Group Is Marching Forward
description: After years of backstage rivalry between Brazil and the United States over which country's vision will shape the rules of trade in this part of the hemisphere, a high-level economic conference here has emerged as a coming-out party for Mercosur, a Brazilian-led South American trade group.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Search for Words to Express The Horrors of the Holocaust

title: Speaking Out on Race Helps Advance Equality; Educational Inequity
description: To the Editor:

title: Million Wetland Acres Lost in 1985-1995
description: More than one million acres of American wetlands vanished from 1985 to 1995, a period when the Government imposed tough new protections for the threatened ecosystems and set a national goal of ending wetland losses, the Clinton Administration estimated today.

title: Metro Business; Developers Sue Over Lilco
description: A Long Island developers' group has filed suit to block a Nov. 4 referendum in Suffolk County asking voters if they support Gov. George E. Pataki's plan for a partial takeover of Long Island Lighting.

title: Design Notebook; The Shape of Things to Come Is Here
description: THINGS have not looked good for the future business for some time now, ever since the Walt Disney Company dismantled the Monsanto ''House of the Future'' in Disneyland three decades ago. More recently, Disney started the company town of Celebration in Florida, a comfy enclave brimming with sweet blandishments of the architectural past -- clapboard, gingerbread and picket fences. The future, so optimistically anticipated at Disneyland and in other fantasies before and after the war, never really roared into America's cities and suburbs, perhaps because visionaries and builders lacked the technical capacity to travel to the wilder shores of their imaginations.

title: Starts of Housing Dropped by 4.8% in August
description: Housing construction unexpectedly dropped in August as builders started projects at the slowest pace this year, though the broad economy shows few signs of losing its steady-growth, low-inflation rhythm.

title: Federal Agency Is Proposing Regulation for Mortgage Brokers
description: The mortgage broker initially told Erick and Barbara Barbosa that their interest rate on a 30-year loan for the $78,000 house they were buying in North Miami Beach would be 8.75 percent. At closing, he told them it had jumped to 9.5 percent because interest rates were rising.

title: Field for Interim CUNY Chief Is Narrowed to Four
description: A committee of trustees of the City University of New York has narrowed its search for an interim chancellor to four candidates and will interview them tomorrow, according to several people familiar with the search process.

title: Roundabout Finds a 2d Act In the Old Selwyn Theater
description: Under threat of eviction from its Times Square home in the spring of 1999, the Roundabout Theater Company has signed a memorandum of understanding to move into the historic but dilapidated Selwyn Theater in the heart of the New 42d Street redevelopment project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, LEON
description: SCHWARTZ-Leon. On September 16. Beloved husband of Juliette. Services 2:30 PM, 9/18, Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Bosnia Crash Kills 12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTENHEIMER, LILLY, M.D.
description: OTTENHEIMER-Lilly, M.D. On September 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Dearest friend of Edith and Mel Smilow, Anne and Frank Weill, Lisa Loose and Eva Hauptman. Respected and loved by her many colleagues, patients and friends. Service is on Friday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: SPIEKER TO BUY A GOLDMAN, SACHS PROPERTY PORTFOLIO
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company agreed yesterday to sell a portfolio of 44 properties to the real estate investment trust Spieker Properties Inc. for $725 million. Most of the properties, which were part of Goldman's Whitehall Street real estate fund, are office and industrial buildings, totaling about 6.3 million square feet. Shares of Spieker, based in Menlo Park, Calif., rose 93.75 cents, to $40.125. The purchase, which increases Spieker's holdings by about 23 percent to more than 34 million square feet, comes in a robust market for office properties. Spieker will keep 32 properties and sell the remaining 12.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: A Big-Game Quarterback?; Tennessee's Manning Has a Lot to Prove Against Florida on Saturday
description: Peyton Manning could have placed all these questions in his very own rearview mirror. He could have been on a quiet practice field off Hempstead Turnpike on Long Island this week, or any spot in the National Football League more comfortable than here, where Tennessee is coping with a four-game losing streak against Florida that will be ended or extended on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBLE, ROSE
description: NOBLE-Rose. Congregation Ohab Zedek of Belle Harbor, New York, mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed member, Marion Noble. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Mendy Bauman, Stanley Liker, Presidium

title: Market Place; At Seagram, Waiting for the Glitz to Pay Off
description: Two years ago, the Bronfman family bet heavily that its fair-haired scion, Edgar Bronfman Jr., was making the right decision in converting Seagram's passive investment in a chemical company into control of a glamorous Hollywood studio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYTAN, YEHUDA
description: REYTAN-Yehuda. We are deeply saddened by the tragic passing of the father of our friend, Meira Tugendhaft. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. The Simantov Family

title: EQUITY OFFICE BUYS 2 CHICAGO TOWERS FOR $462 MILLION
description: Equity Office Properties Trust, headed by the financier Sam Zell, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire twin 40-story towers at 10 and 30 South Wacker Drive in Chicago for $462 million, giving it two million square feet of office space flanking the north and south ends of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The real estate investment trust declined to disclose the property's seller. The announcement comes just two days after Equity Office agreed to buy the Beacon Properties Corporation for $3.8 billion in stock. The acquisitions are part of Mr. Zell's strategy to dominate each real estate category in which he operates -- offices, apartments and mobile homes.

title: People
description: * Kate Hartnick was named to the new post of business development director at Nicholson New York. She had been corporate sales director at Jupiter Communications, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, MARY CATHERINE (NEE RYAN)
description: QUINN-Mary Catherine (nee Ryan), 93, of Seaside Park, N.J., formerly of Westfield, NJ and San Diego, CA., died on Monday. Predeceased by her husband Frank and her son Lawrence. Loving mother of Michael, John, Kathleen McHale, Elizabeth McKenna, Ellen Quinn and Constance Hourihan. Grandmother of twenty-one grandchildren and twenty-one great grandchildren. Family and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral at 5PM, Friday, St. Catharine's RC Church, Seaside Park, NJ, where a mass of Christian burial will be offered. Visiting will be at St. Catharine's RC Church on Friday from 3-5 PM. Burial will be on Saturday at St. Mary's Cemetery, Clark, N.J.

title: Strong Dollar Taking a Toll On U.S. Stocks
description: Fears that a strengthening dollar could undermine the growth in earnings of American companies in the third quarter have sent the stocks of some large multinational corporations reeling in recent weeks.

title: Clinton Says Ban on Mines Would Put U.S. Troops at Risk
description: Despite a drumbeat of pressure at home and abroad, President Clinton said today that the United States could not support an international ban on land mines that are designed to kill or maim people because doing so would put American soldiers at risk.

title: Vermeil Relying On Vast Experience
description: Dick Vermeil, who will be 61 years old next month, is having trouble making curfew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, IRA
description: SPIEGEL-Ira. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Men's Club and Couples Club, mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member Dr. Alan Spiegel and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, Pres.

title: Arts Abroad; Transforming Mayan Mysteries Into Fancy Footwork
description: Amalia Hernandez, who is turning 80 this week, has spent her life culling popular dances from remote regions of Mexico and turning them into foot-stamping show numbers. But now in search of steps for her Christmas pageant, she has become more ambitious.

title: Angel First Baseman Hurt
description: First baseman Darin Erstad of the Anaheim Angels is day-to-day with an inflamed right shoulder, the team said today.

title: Devils Could Make Deal Using Crop of Forwards
description: The Devils have amassed such a huge collection of talented forwards in recent drafts that the general manager, Lou Lamoriello, has the option of putting together a package of players to trade for an established defenseman or two as replacements for the loss of Shawn Chambers and Dave Ellett to free agency.

title: S.E.C. Accuses 6 of Defrauding A Swiss Bank and Lehman Bros.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused six people yesterday of masterminding a scheme involving the ''leasing'' of shares in small companies. The commission said they managed to defraud a Swiss bank, Bank Leu, of $3 million, and to defraud Lehman Brothers of $6.5 million.

title: Immigration Agency Is Changing Its Process for Fingerprinting
description: Under pressure from Congress to fix its troubled citizenship program, the Immigration and Naturalization Service is changing how it fingerprints applicants, but many immigrants' advocates say that rushing the new system into place may wor sen the backlog of 1.4 million people waiting up to two years to become citizens.

title: Order for 12 Boeing Jets
description: The Boeing Company said today that it had received an order for 12 airliners from the Easyjet Airline Company valued at $492 million before discounts. Boeing said the order was its first from Easyjet, a London-based economy airline. Delivery of the 737-300 planes will begin in the second half of next year and last through 1999. Neither company would disclose the terms of the transaction. Large buyers usually receive discounts.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A NEW SEASON

title: Man Is Shot to Death In Work Site Dispute
description: A member of a group seeking work at a construction site in Queens was killed yesterday morning, apparently in a dispute over jobs, officials said.

title: Messinger Appears Victor in New Count
description: By a margin of just 658 votes, Ruth W. Messinger appears to have broken the 40 percent barrier needed to avoid a runoff with the Rev. Al Sharpton for the Democratic mayoral nomination, the Board of Elections announced early this morning.

title: Janet Reno's Faulty Fix
description: In shaking up the Justice Department's hapless investigation of campaign finance scandals, Attorney General Janet Reno mistakes efficiency for integrity. While new, more experienced leadership and a larger staff of investigators may energize the inquiry, they cannot restore the public confidence that has been lost. At this point everyone's interest, including Bill Clinton's and Al Gore's, would be best served by an impartial investigation by an independent counsel. Only such an inquiry would be free of suspicion that the Justice Department either protected the White House or treated it unfairly to make up for the investigative lapses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDELSTEIN, SIDNEY
description: EDELSTEIN-Sidney. 3 years since the love of my life left. Remembered and loved always. Mildred

title: BRIDGE
description: There is probably only one place in the world where thousands of bridge enthusiasts may be glued to their television sets to watch a match in progress. It happened two weeks ago when the Marlboro China Cup was played in Chengdu, China.

title: For First Time, U.S. to Halt Air Training for All Armed Services
description: Alarmed by a spate of dramatic and often fatal airplane crashes in the last four days, the Defense Department for the first time ever has ordered each of the armed services to suspend training flights for 24 hours to give aviators and ground crews additional safety lectures.

title: Stock Buyback Begun At British Gas Company
description: BG P.L.C., Britain's biggest natural gas distributor, began a stock buyback worth $:1.3 billion ($2.1 billion) yesterday. The company, formed in February when Britain broke up the British Gas monopoly, also said it would take a $:4.9 billion charge to reflect 21 percent lower pipeline tariffs that regulators have demanded. And it will pay a dividend of 8 pence a share this year, down from 14.5 pence last year. Shares of BG fell 7 pence, to 261.5 ($4.22). Analysts said investors were disappointed that the dividend had been cut so much.

title: Jets' Priority: Pass Rush To Stop Raiders' George
description: Yes, they insist, they have recovered. So instead of worrying about the one that got away up in New England last Sunday, the Jets concerned themselves today with halting the Oakland Raiders' offense, the most explosive one in the National Football League.

title: Must Have That Interview Chair? It's for Sale
description: TELEVISION viewers are a loyal breed. They watch ''Geraldo''; they want the chair. The one the guests sit in.

title: The Sun Doesn't Set on Michigan Building Boom
description: No one knows better than Rodger Jabara about the golf boom in Northern Michigan. This affable 50-year-old has been working at Shanty Creek Resort in Bellaire since 1967, the last 20 years as director of golf. ''When I was growing up nearby, we had all of two nine-hole courses to play,'' he recalled, ''and one of them was 35 miles away.''

title: Songs for the Love of Hal Prince
description: ''Send In the Clowns'' is one of those songs that every high-toned pop diva sooner or later feels obliged to tackle. In Barbara Cook's new cabaret act, ''Hail Prince,'' a tribute to Hal Prince that opened the fall season at the Cafe Carlyle on Tuesday, the eternal ingenue from Georgia puts her wistfully compassionate stamp on the Stephen Sondheim warhorse.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As told in ''Please Kill Me: The Uncensored Oral History of Punk'' (Grove Press, 1996), the punk years were a long exercise in self-destructive debauchery, with some good songs thrown in. By comparison, a scaled-down tour to promote the Viking Penguin paperback publication of ''Please Kill Me'' has been a fairly grown-up affair, with a few good songs thrown in, said GILLIAN McCAIN, who wrote the book with LEGS McNEIL.

title: Turf; Where a Celebrity's Name Isn't Worth a Dime
description: IN the mirrored entryway illuminated only by distant tall towers twinkling through the drawing-room windows, velvety-black shadows darted from side to side as real estate agents searched for a light switch. It was a scene that revealed Marlene Dietrich's empty apartment at its most glamorous. As every star knows, when one grows older, the lights must get dimmer.

title: Economic Scene; The latest move by China toward capitalism: Is it real?
description: KARL MARX envisioned the withering away of the state as the final stage of the socialist revolution. But it is unlikely he had in mind today's China, where President Jiang Zemin just broadened the definition of ''public ownership'' to include publicly held private companies and announced that the vast majority of state-owned enterprises would soon be left to the fate of the free market.

title: Time Warner-TCI Deal
description: Time Warner Inc. exercised its option on Tuesday to purchase Southern Satellite Systems Inc. from Liberty Media Group for $213.3 million in cash or stock and assumption of debt. The transaction is expected to close on Dec. 31. Liberty, which is a unit of Tele-Communications Inc., said that it distributed the Time Warner superstation WTBS through Southern Satellite Systems. Time Warner received the option to acquire Southern Satellite on June 24.

title: Swedish Bank to Pay Penalties in U.S.
description: Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken, a big Swedish bank, said yesterday that it had signed a consent order to pay $5 million in penalties, divided equally between the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the New York State Banking Department.

title: Bond Ratings May Slip
description: Moody's Investors Service, which on Monday sharply downgraded $17.5 million in bonds issued to build the Warren County Landfill, may soon have bad news for other counties.

title: School Voucher Study Finds Satisfaction
description: In the first independent evaluation of Cleveland's groundbreaking school voucher program, a Harvard University study has found that the program was very popular with parents and raised the scores of those students tested at the end of the first year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Reality Vs. Artifice
description: To the Editor:

title: Double Standard on Religious Persecution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kestner Wins 3d Title
description: Darrell Kestner of the Deepdale Golf Club in Manhasset shot a two-under-par 68 for a 54-hole total of 205 yesterday that earned him another Met PGA Championship title.

title: Weld Rules Out Bid For Office in 3 Years
description: Two days after dropping his attempt to become Ambassador to Mexico, William F. Weld said today that he had no plans to run for President or the Senate three years from now.

title: Our Towns ; An Artist Moves Off the Street Into the Spotlight
description: SUCCESS is moving in on Don DeNarie. One day, he's hanging around the Woodstock Village Green with his street buddies, shaking spare change from the tourists. The next, he's sleeping in a real apartment, painting full time like a regular Michelangelo.

title: Copter Crash In Bosnia Kills Envoy And 11 Aides
description: A United Nations helicopter carrying officials trying to help Bosnia carry out elections crashed today in central Bosnia, killing all 12 passengers, United Nations officials said. Those reported dead included a senior German diplomat and five Americans.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; A Stylish Handelian Weight Loss
description: Bach's idiom, it is often argued, works well in any medium, on any scale. Few would suggest the same of Handel, yet has anyone's music had to weather more drastic changes in performance style since the time it was created than Handel's?

title: Can We Talk? Television Hosts Turn to the Comfy Couch
description: TELEVISION talk shows are on the couch these days -- literally. Producers seem to have decided that the way to get guests to talk earnestly is by making the sets homey, be it with sculptural sofas or gigantic armchairs; even a futon.

title: Lucent Introduces Strategy To Aid Data Networking
description: Aiming to profit more directly from the wired world's ravenous appetite for digital information, Lucent Technologies Inc. announced its long-awaited data networking strategy yesterday, sending its shares up modestly.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the British royal family's response to criticism of its role in the aftermath of the death of the Princess of Wales misstated Queen Elizabeth's age. She is 71, not 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MAX G.
description: COHEN-Max G., of Long Beach, NY, on September 16, 1997, age 89. Beloved husband of the late Joan Cohen. Loving father of Steven Cohen, Jayne Cohen and Howard Spiegler, and Sami Schindelheim (Joseph). Cherished grandfather of Robert Cohen, Alexandra Cohen-Spiegler, and Jake, Arielle, Ricky, Daniel and Jonah Schindelheim. Dear brother, uncle and great-uncle. Funeral services Thursday, September 18, 9:30 AM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. Memorial contributions in his name may be made to any children's charity.

title: Cottages No Eyesore
description: To the Editor:

title: Brother (or Sister), Can You Spare a Dime for a Boom-Era Economist?
description: The better the economy, the worse things seem to get for economists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOVERMAN, SAM
description: BOVERMAN-Sam, 86, Sept. 15. Devoted father of Jeffery. Fatherin-law of Christina and grandfather of Kale, Max and Michelle Boverman and Lisa Hantverk and Emily Solomon and great grandfather of four. Survived by the mother of his children and grandchildren Muriel Boverman. Dear companion of Harriet Falk. Graveside service Thurs, 1 PM, Cedar Park Cemetery. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Thursday 10:30AM-12 noon. Gifts may be made in his memory to Rose Haven Nursing Home, 31 North St., Litchfield, CT 06759.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ARTHUR THOMAS
description: ROTH-Arthur Thomas, ninetyone, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, September 17, at his home of sixty years in Rockville Centre, New York. He will long be remembered in American banking circles for the extraordinary innovations he successfully brought to commercial banking as CEO of the Franklin National Bank before retiring in 1968, and more locally for his dynamic role in spearheading the phenomenal economic growth of Long Island following W.W. II for which the press dubbed him ''Mr. Long Island''. His family however will remember him as a loving husband, father and grandfather whose generosity, warmth, strength, and will to do the right thing is deeply impressed on them all. His many acts of community and church leadership and his widespread philanthropy speak for themselves. He leaves his wife of 67 years, Genevieve, and his daughter Mrs. Carol Madigan of Oldwick, New Jersey, and son, Donald Arthur Roth of E. Setauket, N.Y., their spouses John P. Madigan, Jr. and Mrs. Patricia Roth, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. He will be interred at the Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York, on Saturday, September 20, following a 9 AM Mass of the Resurrection at St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre. Visitation will be at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, on Thursday and Friday between 2 and 4 PM and 7 and 9 PM.

title: Hollywood and Esquire in Privacy Dispute
description: Following an article in Esquire magazine that dealt with the sexuality of the actor Kevin Spacey, an executive at the William Morris talent agency announced yesterday that he would discourage his colleagues from cooperating with Esquire in the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, ESTHER
description: HANDLER-Esther. Of West Palm Beach, FL. At 101 years. Wife of the late Harry. Mother of the late Judith Pine and Dr. Archie Handler. Survived by 7 grandchildren and 14 great grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, TIMOTHY, PH.D.
description: JOYCE-Timothy, Ph.D. The officers and employees of Roper Starch Worldwide mourn the passing of our Vice-Chairman, Dr. Timothy Joyce on Saturday, September 13. He was a true pioneer in the media/market research field and we will long remember his unparalleled wit, keen intelligence and loyal devotion to his friends and colleagues throughout the world. The research industry and we, in particular, will miss him dearly. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Helen, his son Nicholas, and daughter Rachel Frosh.

title: Tentative Teachers' Pact
description: Striking lay teachers at eight Roman Catholic high schools in southern New Jersey reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a three-year contract with the Diocese of Camden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBMAN, LILLIAN
description: TAUBMAN-Lillian. Beloved mother of Carolyn, Bernie and Elliott. Beloved grandmother and great grandmother to Richard Osnat, Robin, Kevin, Marc, Lisa, Victor and Scott, Brett Geffen and M.J. You will be missed. Funeral services Thursday 2 PM, Parkside.

title: Theater in Review
description: Living by the Clock: The Moments of Life

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, EDWARD
description: ALBERT-Edward. The officers and members of the Glee Club of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick note with sorrow the untimely death of our colleague and friend. John L. MacLean, Past President

title: Later News, and 'House & Home'
description: This week The Times introduces its most sweeping improvements in more than 20 years:

title: Philatelic Progress: Self-Sticker Stamps
description: Probably, nobody warned you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDEL, HENRI
description: BENDEL-Henri. September 15, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Loving father of John and his wife Diana. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, September 20 at 1:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Under Pressure, 2 Broadcasters Decide They Will Now Run HDTV
description: Under hostile questioning from Congress today, Preston Padden, president of the ABC television network, reversed his previous position and promised to begin broadcasting high-definition television programming starting next year.

title: Cone Says He's Ready, but Torre Will Wait and See
description: David Cone halted his simulated game workout after 11 minutes yesterday and his manager, Joe Torre, his pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, and his team physician, Dr. Stuart Hershon, convened around the mound in the bullpen at Yankee Stadium. Looking extremely concerned, the men spoke for five minutes before Cone tossed the second inning of his session. This time he stopped after only three minutes.

title: Mariners Hold On to Johnson
description: The Mariners exercised the option on pitcher Randy Johnson's contract, ensuring that the hard-throwing left-hander will anchor the team's starting rotation for at least one more season.

title: Metro Matters; Adding 2 + 2 Apparently Isn't So Easy
description: OFFICIALS of the New York City Board of Elections like to keep out of the public eye, preferring, by and large, to perform their important tasks in anonymity. And with good reason. It's been about a half a century since anyone who has taken the time to notice them has had a kind word to say.

title: Sports of The Times ; The Boss (Again) Puts Up His Dukes
description: SOME fans might be shocked that the principal owner of the prestigious New York Yankees, of all people, actually had a confrontation that nearly led to physical blows -- and with one of his own players yet! -- instead of discussing the problem calmly and rationally.

title: Double Standard on Religious Persecution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitaker Still Wants a Rematch
description: Pernell Whitaker won't beg Oscar De La Hoya for a rematch, but he craves one. He says he feels cheated by the decision that led to his losing the World Boxing Council welterweight title on April 12, and he insists De La Hoya is ducking him.

title: Dutch Drug Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: With a Nod and a Wink
description: WHEN Marcel Duchamp put a bicycle seat on the wall and called it art, the world of decorating changed forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZ, SARA
description: SPITZ-Sara. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Sara Spitz. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Personal Shopper
description: YOU don't have to be a magician to conjure up a roomful of chairs. Not when the chairs stack like acrobats.

title: Court Decides Internet Issue
description: In a closely watched case on jurisdictional issues in cyberspace, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has ruled that an out-of-state business that establishes a World Wide Web site outside New York State cannot be forced to defend an action in New York on the basis of its presence on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETTAS, ATHENA
description: PETTAS-Athena. Nick Glavas, Athena Glavas Pettas, Bob Glavas, Eugenia Glavas Liris. For we...are as water spilt on the ground.

title: Charges of Nuclear Cover-Up Alarm Plant's Neighbors
description: Earlier this summer, Dan Necle did not think twice about eating the catfish and bass he caught in the Connecticut River across from the nuclear power plant here.

title: In Distorting History, Movie Defames Dewey
description: To the Editor:

title: Angry Sharpton Backers Present Sinister Theories
description: As the news sank in that their candidate apparently would not get a chance at a runoff against Ruth W. Messinger for the Democratic mayoral nomination, supporters of the Rev. Al Sharpton said last night that they were dazed and disheartened by the turn of events.

title: America, Absent on Land Mines
description: About 100 countries agreed yesterday on a treaty that will prohibit them from producing, using or stockpiling anti-personnel land mines and require them to remove mines they have already sown. Regrettably, the Clinton Administration, after having failed to persuade other countries to agree to several loopholes sought by the Pentagon, withheld American support. That eliminates pressure on other holdout countries, like Russia, China and India, to join the land mine ban.

title: Woman Is Raped in Phone Booth
description: A man armed with a razor blade raped a woman in a Park Avenue telephone booth early yesterday as several pedestrians passed by, the police said. Less than an hour earlier, the same man apparently raped another woman in the same area, officials said.

title: Clinging to Its Past, Europe Is Warily Awaiting the Euro
description: Franz Schmid is old enough to have suffered his share of European upheaval, and now, as the century wanes, he is convinced that the Continent is on the brink of another disaster, one that will wipe out all he has slowly built from the ruins of Hitler's war.

title: U S Airways and Its Pilots Still Snagged in Cost Talks
description: Less than two weeks before it must tell Airbus Industries whether it will buy 400 new airplanes worth $14 billion, U S Airways and its pilots are still far away from reaching a cost-cutting agreement that the company says is a precondition for the airline's future growth.

title: Arrest in Toddler's Death
description: A Hackensack man was charged yesterday with murdering his girlfriend's 19-month-old son by dropping the child on his head, officials said.

title: New Build-to-Order Desktops at CompUSA
description: The computer retailer CompUSA Inc. introduced its new line of build-to-order desktop computers today in a challenge to the Dell Computer Corporation and Gateway 2000 Inc.

title: Rossignol Shares Jump On Adidas-Salomon Deal
description: Shares of Skis Rossignol S.A. rose yesterday on speculation the company, a French maker of winter-sports goods, might be a takeover target after the acquisition of its rival, Salomon S.A., by Adidas A.G. Rossignol shares rose 5 francs, to 134.50 ($22.46). They have climbed 18.6 percent this week. Salomon shares closed at a record high of 516 on their first trading day after Adidas said it had agreed to buy the sporting goods maker.

title: A Martian Mystery Is Solved: Planet Has a Magnetic Field
description: In its first major discovery, the American spacecraft that went into an orbit of Mars last Thursday has solved one of the planet's longstanding mysteries: Mars does have a magnetic field. Its magnetism may be weak, compared with that of most planets, but is considerably stronger than scientists had suspected.

title: An Old School Inflation Fighter; Fed Official Resists Notion of a New Era in Economics
description: Inflation is almost nonexistent despite steady growth and an unemployment rate hovering near a quarter-century low. Companies are chalking up ever-higher profits. Millions of investors are basking in the glow of the longest, strongest bull market on record. Even curmudgeons like Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, are increasingly optimistic that the economy is undergoing a transformation that should yield more good times ahead.

title: In Plea Bargain, Two Admit Guilt in Mob Figure's '89 Killing
description: In February 1989, Everett Hatcher, a Federal agent posing as a cocaine trafficker, was shot to death in a desolate area of Staten Island where he was supposed to meet a Mafia-connected drug dealer to talk business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFTLER, HAROLD
description: HEFTLER-Harold. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Harold Heftler, and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife, Rebecca, and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Dr. Philip Adler, President

title: Kotite: Affable and Available
description: Rich Kotite was affable and relaxed actually, acting much as he did during his Jets' tenure -- as the master of ceremonies at a March of Dimes dinner Tuesday night in Staten Island, where he has lived for many years.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Is Retiring Fred
description: Fred, the diligent Dunkin' Donuts baker who has dutifully driven himself with the mantra ''Time to make the doughnuts,'' is hanging up his advertising apron after 15 years.

description: FOWLER-Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23rd, St. Luke's Church, Peapack, N.J. at 11 A.M.

Dear brother of Ernest, May, George and Robert. Loving grandfather of Eric and Adam Rosenzweig. Reposing at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 39th Ave. at 215 St., Bayside, Thurs. 7-9, and Fri. 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass, Sacred Heart Church, Bayside, Sat. 9:45AM. Donations to Home Care Resources Hospice, 615 Hope Rd., Bldg. 3, Eatontown, NJ 07724.

description: DEUTSCH-Ira A. On Sept. 16, 1997, beloved husband of Susan, dear son of Frieda, loving father of Jesse and Elena and father-in-law of Alison, adoring grandfather of Hannah. Service today 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, TIBOR
description: SCHIFF-Tibor. Suddenly in Vancouver, Saturday, September 13, 1997. Dearly beloved husband of Marilyn (Regenstreif-Teitelbaum). Adored stepfather of Fern (George Wachter), Gina (Harry Zelnick), and Paul Teitelbaum. Cherished grandfather of Jackie, Brahm, Jennifer and Sharon. Dear son-in-law of Sara Regenstreif. He will be sadly missed by his cousins and friends, and all who knew him. Funeral service is from Paperman & Sons, 3888 Jean Talon West, Montreal, Quebec, on Thursday, September 18 at 12:15 P.M. Burial at Memorial Park Cemetery, de la Savane. Shiva private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the ''Tibor Schiff Memorial Fund'' care of The Jewish General Hospital Foundation at 514-340-8251.

Albright at 212416-5438 or 203-222-9291.

title: Welsh Vote on Whether to Take Hold of Some Reins Themselves
description: The people of Wales appeared more divided than expected today on whether to accept an offer from London to set up their first elected assembly in nearly 600 years. Early this morning the vote was too close to call.

title: With Eye Toward Playoffs, Cone Returns Tomorrow
description: David Cone desperately wants to pitch again, believes he is ready after a monthlong bout with tendinitis in his right shoulder and will get the opportunity earlier than expected, against the Toronto Blue Jays tomorrow. It could be the most pivotal game of the regular season for the Yankees, and it will definitely be the most scrutinized.

description: Thomas Nozkowski

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SEYMOUR WILLIAM
description: SCHWARTZ-Seymour William. Dentist of Hewlett, New York, died on September 18, 1997 after a long illness. Devoted husband of Vera and father of Jeanne. Survived by loving sister Ann Schwartz Penn Fremont. Funeral service will be private.

title: Bumping Around Cyberspace: The Evolution, Virtual or Otherwise, of Bots
description: BOTS

title: Latest Loss Has Mets Just About Finished
description: Todd Hundley won't have his elbow surgery until the Mets are eliminated, but he can certainly schedule an appointment. John Franco has a strained muscle in his back, and there doesn't seem much point in him returning. The coup de grace on the Mets' season is imminent, and the last vestige of drama is whether Rey Ordonez will get another hit this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALAGHBAND, ZADEH, MOUSSA
description: ALAGHBAND - ZADEH - Moussa. On September 18, 1997 at the age of ninety. Beloved husband of Touria, loving father of Helen, Parviz, Fardon, Jamshid, Fourogh, and David. Adoring grandfather of 14 grandchildren, and two greatgrandchildren. Services on Friday 9:30 AM, Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, between 2nd and 3rd Avenues.

title: Memorial to Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ARTHUR THOMAS
description: ROTH-Arthur Thomas, ninetyone, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, September 17, at his home of sixty years in Rockville Centre, New York. He will long be remembered in American banking circles for the extraordinary innovations he successfully brought to commercial banking as CEO of the Franklin National Bank before retiring in 1968, and more locally for his dynamic role in spearheading the phenomenal economic growth of Long Island following W.W. II for which the press dubbed him ''Mr. Long Island''. His family however will remember him as a loving husband, father and grandfather whose generosity, warmth, strength, and will to do the right thing is deeply impressed on them all. His many acts of community and church leadership and his widespread philanthropy speak for themselves. He leaves his wife of 67 years, Genevieve, and his daughter Mrs. Carol Madigan of Oldwick, New Jersey, and son, Donald Arthur Roth of E. Setauket, N.Y., their spouses John P. Madigan, Jr. and Mrs. Patricia Roth, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. He will be interred at the Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York, on Saturday, September 20, following a 9 AM Mass of the Resurrection at St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre. Visitation will be at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, on Thursday and Friday between 2 and 4 PM and 7 and 9 PM.

title: Home Video
description: Sampling Films Of the East Bloc

title: 'Megan's Law' Is Delayed
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday extended for 90 days an order blocking the state from notifying communities of the whereabouts of paroled sex offenders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONARD, WILLIAM C., ''BILL''
description: CONARD-William C., ''Bill''. 41, of Manhattan on September 13, 1997. Beloved partner of Arthur Fama of Manhattan and Ulster Park, NY, loving son of Thelma Conard of London, OH and adored brother of Patricia, Susan, Linda and Diana all of Ohio. Services and burial were held in Ohio on Wednesday Sept. 17, 1997. Bill will be deeply missed by his many firends and family. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to GMHC, AMFAR & Holy Cross Episcopal Church, 30 Pinegrove Ave, Kingston, NY 12401. Memorial services are planned at a later date for Manhattan and Kingston.

title: No to Adirondack Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Says AIDS Cases Fell In '96, Ending 16-Year Rise
description: The number AIDS cases diagnosed in the United States dropped last year for the first time in the 16-year history of the epidemic, a trend that Federal officials attributed to aggressive new therapies that keep infected patients healthier, as well as the possibility that fewer people are becoming infected in the first place.

title: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE INCUMBENT ; Mayor Removes the Gloves And Laces Into Messinger
description: Unleashing a formal assault on his newly named Democratic opponent, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began the general election campaign yesterday by ridiculing Ruth W. Messinger for opposing his plan to regulate sex businesses in New York City, and vowing to highlight differences between them every day until the Nov. 4 election.

title: Owners Take No Action On a Realignment Vote
description: The magic number is 7.

title: His Specialty: Collecting Addresses
description: Roger E. Tamraz came from a family that was successful in real estate and the export-import business in Egypt. And from the time he was young, he knew how to make a lot of friends -- and a lot of money.

title: Accessing Outernet: Medieval Software
description: ''Medieval Best Seller: The Book of Hours'' is the kind of in-house exhibition that the Pierpont Morgan Library could put together with one hand tied behind its back.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stocks ended higher in trading here today, in an advance led by shares of the Toyota Motor Corporation and other auto makers. The Nikkei index of 225 leading issues closed up 246.82 points, or 1.40 percent, at 17,930.09. On Wednesday, the Nikkei fell 291.23 points, or 1.62 percent.

title: Messinger Aims for Giuliani, and Sharpton Heads for Court
description: Its contenders finally in place, the New York City mayoral race burst into a full-throated competition yesterday as the Board of Elections declared Ruth W. Messinger the Democratic nominee and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began what he promised would be an unceasing series of attacks on her.

title: TED TURNER PLANS A $1 BILLION GIFT FOR U.N. AGENCIES
description: Ted Turner, the billionaire founder of Cable News Network, who has made a career out of defying expectations and shocking the public, announced last night that he is making a gift of $1 billion to benefit the United Nations, one of the largest single donations ever.

title: Tel Aviv Journal; 'Out of Lebanon!': Mothers' Cry Rouses Israelis
description: There is a new bumper sticker on the streets here these days, and it carries a blunt message: ''Let's Get Out of Lebanon.''

title: Fitness, Not Medicine, Increases Life Expectancy; Income Affects Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, DR. TIMOTHY
description: JOYCE-Dr. Timothy. Founder and former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Mediamark Research Inc. died on Saturday, September 13. Dr. Joyce was internationally prominent in media and market research for nearly four decades. He developed Target Group Index, a survey system for measuring consumer behavior of media audiences which is still widely in use today. Dr. Joyce is survived by his wife, Helen, a son, Nicholas, a daughter, Rachel Frosh, and a grandson, Alexander Frosh. Memorial Services are being held at the McGraw-Hill Auditorium, 1221 Avenue of the Americas, 2nd Floor, New York, at 4:00 P.M., on September 25th. Memorial contributions may be made to the United Network for Organ Sharing, 1110 Boulders Parkway, Richmond, VA. 23225. The officers and employees of Mediamark will truly miss Timothy and extend their deepest condolences to the members of his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, LILLIAN L.
description: AUERBACH-Lillian L., on Wednesday, September 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late David E., devoted mother of Cheryl Feldman & Enid (Dennis) Lehr, loving grandmother of Shawn and Lauren Bryant and Amy and greatgrandmother of Samantha, David Connor, Jami and Andrew David. Service will be held on Friday, September 19, at 12:15PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Cedar Park, Paramus, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, SHIRLEY
description: LANE-Shirley. On September 17, 1997. A great Jazz aficionado and friend to the artists. Former store manager of Georg Jensen, Shirley spent forty years in the home furnishings industry, most recently as the showroom manager for designer John F. Saladino. She is survived by her son Steven of Manhattan. Donations in her memory to DIFFA or The arts organization of your choice.

title: Houston Makes U.S. Team
description: Knicks shooting guard Allan Houston has been chosen to represent the United States at the world championships next July in Athens. Houston and nine other players were selected by U.S.A. Basketball's senior men's selection committee during a meeting yesterday in Orlando, Fla., where the National Basketball Association is holding its annual meetings.

title: Imagination? Poetry? Oh, Horrors!
description: The time: 1840's. The place: Coketown, Dickens's version of a dark, Satanic mill town, whose red bricks are black with soot from the foundry's smokestacks and whose river runs purple from its industrial dyes. It is a town shaped on the anvil of hard facts, and at Gradgrind's school the pupils are admonished to shun the temptations of imagination: ''You are never to fancy! Facts alone are wanted in life. Fact, fact, fact!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMPION, GEORGE
description: CHAMPION-George, of Greenwich, CT, retired Chairman of the Board of Chase Manhattan Bank, on September 16, 1997. Husband of Eleanor Champion. Father of George Champion Jr and Emily Jean Knobloch. Brother of Mrs. S.C. Andrews. Grandfather of seven. Great grandfather of three. Funeral services at the Second Congregational Church of Greenwich today September 19, 1997 at 11:00 AM. Interment at Spring Grove Cemetery in Darien, CT.

title: Hal Riney Names Creative Executive
description: Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco named John Doyle, a longtime art director, as one of its two top creative executives yesterday.
