description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. Concerts that are highly recommended have a *.

title: Daniel Meenan, TV and Radio News Reporter, 75
description: Daniel Meenan, a television and radio news reporter whose gravel-voiced delivery was known to nearly every cabby in New York City for three decades, died at New York University Medical Center on Monday. He was 75 and had spent most of his time on Shelter Island since his retirement in 1988.

title: Street and Web Art Flow in Bryant Park
description: Bryant Park was overtaken by byte-art on Wednesday afternoon in a free, seven-hour outdoor festival that combined dance, theater, music, poetry and improvisation, generated in part by online contributions to the World Wide Web. Work on ''Webbed Feats,'' created by Stephan Koplowitz, incorporated words and choreography contributed to Mr. Koplowitz's Web page for specific park locations.

title: Campaign Finance Board's Makeup
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board is an independent municipal agency that was set up in 1988 to administer the city's voluntary campaign finance system, which gives candidates public funds if they accept limits on fund-raising and spending.

title: INSIDE
description: New AIDS Cases in U.S. Drop for the First Time

title: Weekend Warrior; Gently Down the Stream? Nope!
description: It was a perfect plan: reservations for four canoes and a kayak, nine people signed up, and an early forecast of cloudless skies. Two of us would pick up the rented minivan at 6:30 A.M. and meet the others at Starbucks at 87th Street and Broadway. We'd be gently drifting through painterly vistas by 9:30.

title: Guess Who Complained Runoff Is Racist Tactic?
description: WILL someone please explain why the Rev. Al Sharpton is upset that, barring court intervention, he and Ruth W. Messinger will not have a runoff after all? He is getting only what he asked for.

title: Free Transfers in Bus Ridership Rise
description: When transit officials announced the free bus-to-subway transfers that started in July, they predicted that the transfers would cost the system millions in lost revenue.

description: REILLY-Nora Agnes (nee Miskell). Native of Glenamaddy, County Galway, Ireland, on September 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John M. Reilly; loving mother of John J., Richard W., James P., and the late William M.; dear grandmother of 13 and greatgrandmother of 12. Family will receive friends Friday, 3-9 P.M., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Mass of Christian Burial, at St. Ignatius Loyola, R.C. Church, Park Avenue at 84 Street, Saturday, 10 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about Sarabeth's assigning its account to Dweck & Campbell misstated the account's previous status. Dweck & Campbell is not the first agency for Sarabeth's; the account had been handled for 15 years by Dick Mendelsohn Inc.

title: A Street-Fighting Man No More
description: Larry Mosley's amateur boxing career got off to an inauspicious beginning on the streets of Watts, and he tells the story with as much glee as he exhibits delivering left hooks to the body.

title: Once Again, Old Rivals Are Down to Precious Days
description: Don't realign this.

description: GILBERT-Charles A. Remembering Charlie. D.

title: 'Wow': Cash Infusion For Internet 'Kids'; Computer Chat Room Began as Idea For 2 Students in Their Cornell Days
description: When Stephan Paternot and Todd Krizelman decided to start an Internet business called Web Genesis during their junior year at Cornell in 1994, it wasn't exactly something that had been years in the making, with business forecasts and marketing strategies. Try spur of the moment.

title: Low Dividends Are a Gamble for Wall Street; 'Ordinary' People Invest
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stealth Boondoggle
description: In Washington, a bad idea is like Dracula. No matter how many stakes you drive through its heart, sooner or later it rises from the dead.

title: INTEL AND COMPAQ PLAN JOINT NETWORKING PRODUCTS
description: The Intel Corporation and the Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that they were forming an alliance to develop products aimed at reducing bottlenecks in computer networks. The first products from the alliance could be available later this year. The venture between Intel, the world's largest chip maker, and Compaq, the world's largest maker of personal computers, is intended to bolster sales of personal computers by speeding the flow of information over networks, analysts said. Each company will contribute some money for joint marketing, and the two will share technology and pool their engineering efforts. Intel shares fell 53.125 cents yesterday, to $95.125. Compaq shares fell 56.25 cents, to $73.1875.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Cars May Visit Internet While on the Interstate
description: WHEN a car's ''check engine'' light flashes on, what does it mean? Only the on-board computer knows, and generally it won't tell until the driver goes to a service department and a technician connects a desktop computer to the car's computer, through a port under the hood or beneath the dashboard.

title: A Festive Start for the Philharmonic's Season
description: The New York Philharmonic opened its 156th season Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall with a gala concert that also celebrated the 70th birthday of its music director, Kurt Masur, who conducted. Joining Mr. Masur for part of the program was an artist who usually makes any concert special, the American soprano Renee Fleming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZIS, ROSALIND Z.
description: MINTZIS-Rosalind Z. On Sep. 18, 1997. Beloved mother of Matty Levine and Ethel Schneider, loving grandmother of Jackie and Mark, Jordan and Holly, Michelle and Mike and two great grandchildren.

title: Picasso as Engraver
description: Elements of an intimate print show mix somewhat distractingly with those of a retrospective in ''Picasso the Engraver: Selections From the Musee Picasso, Paris,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The exhibition features prints from 72 engravings, created through the 1940's, including SEATED WOMAN WITH A HAT (1939). The Met has added some of its own Picasso paintings, drawings and prints. Along with differences between the show's catalogue and wall labels, these additions indicate some trans-Atlantic curatorial disagreement. And rooms big enough to accommodate the anticipated crowds may hamper close, careful concentration. But whatever vicissitudes the show has suffered, Picasso, as usual, survives.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''Don't let me look,'' the woman in black says. Shielding her eyes, she grabs her husband's hand as she moves past the pastry and candy counter to the bistro in the back. She sinks into her seat, wearing the look of a person who has just averted great danger. ''I love Francois Payard's pastry,'' she moans. ''It would just ruin my diet.''

title: On Long Island, Critics Upset About the High Cost of Police
description: For years Long Island's police officers have been among the nation's best compensated, with high salaries, short work schedules and generous fringe benefits.

title: Clowning Inventively With Stuff Of Beauty
description: Years ago, apropos of his good friend Robert Rauschenberg, John Cage famously said, ''Beauty is now underfoot wherever we take the trouble to look.'' His ''now'' implied not that the world itself had changed, of course, but that the way we viewed it had. The other important word was beauty, which at the time seemed a less vexed concept than it does today: Cage meant that we had come to see, through Rauschenberg's work, not just that anything, including junk on the street, could be the stuff of art (this, after all, wasn't new), but that it could be the stuff of an art aspiring to be beautiful -- that there was a poetics in urban glut, which Rauschenberg revealed and celebrated.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Widened to $10.3 Billion
description: Driven in part by a mounting deficit with Japan, the nation's trade gap widened sharply in July, to $10.34 billion, the biggest since January, from $8.29 billion in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Rubin to Press Central Banks to Disclose Financial Data
description: In the Clinton Administration's first major response to the Southeast Asian currency crisis, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said today that the United States would press governments and central banks around the world to disclose more financial data that most nations routinely keep secret.

title: No Escapes at Boys' School
description: For the first time in its 130-year history, the New Jersey Training School for Boys reported no escapes in more than a year, officials said yesterday.

title: Deutsche Telekom Net Below Expectations
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said yesterday that its net income rose less than expected in the first half of the year, to 1.8 billion marks ($1 billion), as the cost of expanding its digital phone network offset higher sales from mobile phone service. Shares in the company dropped as much as 5 percent even though its net income before minority interests rose ninefold from 200 million marks a year earlier, when Telekom paid 1.75 billion marks in costs related to its initial public offering.

title: Sharpton's Lawyers Say Voting Irregularities May Have Affected the Outcome
description: In asking a Federal judge to order a runoff election for the Democratic mayoral nomination, lawyers for the Rev. Al Sharpton argued yesterday that the primary voting last Tuesday and the weeklong ballot count that followed were riddled with errors and irregularities.

title: 2 Senators Trim Campaign-Finance Sails
description: Giving up on efforts to limit campaign spending voluntarily, the authors of the main campaign-finance legislation in Congress have pared down a compromise that would keep a ban on contributions that national political parties use for generic purposes.

title: Council to Fight Rent Increase Won by Landlords in Court
description: Setting the stage for a long court battle over the city's rent-control system, the City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to throw out a new method for calculating rents that would mean steeper annual increases for thousands of tenants, many of them elderly.

title: A Gene Link To a Disease Of the Eyes Is Identified
description: Scientists have found the first genetic link to age-related macular degeneration, an incurable eye disease that strikes 25 percent of Americans over the age of 65 and is the major cause of vision loss in the elderly.

title: Stock Rally Fades a Lot By Day's End
description: The stock market rallied again yesterday, ignited by additional indications that the economy is growing at a moderate but sustainable pace.

title: Film in Review
description: 'The Birth of Love'

title: Art in Review
description: Amy Adler

title: Brooks Brothers moves beyond the gray flannel suit.
description: FOR decades, customers called Brooks Brothers ''B-squared,'' and not only because both words begin with ''b.'' Brooks Brothers had been an unhip haberdashery for so long that even in the 1950 musical ''Guys and Dolls,'' Sky Masterson dismissed the ideal man of his love interest as ''a Scarsdale Galahad, a breakfast-eating, Brooks Brothers type.''

title: Helms Offers Deal to Back Bigger NATO
description: Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, gave his tentative support today for the expansion of NATO, saying he would help lead the fight for ratification of the plan if the Clinton Administration addresses a series of ''serious concerns.''

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. Highly recommended shows have a *.

title: Taliban Forces Seize Afghan Rival's Stronghold on Uzbek Border
description: Afghanistan's radical Taliban movement seized a military stronghold today on the border with Uzbekistan, raising the danger that the Afghan civil war will widen, Western analysts said.

title: The Dark Underbelly of a Sunny Town
description: Curtis Hanson's resplendently wicked ''L.A. Confidential'' is a tough, gorgeous, vastly entertaining throwback to the Hollywood that did things right. As such, it enthusiastically breaks most rules of studio filmmaking today. Brilliantly adapted from James Ellroy's near-unfilmable cult novel, it casts anything-but-A-list stars (yet) in a story with three leading men, no two of whom can be construed as buddies. It embroils them in a cliche-free, vigorously surprising tale that qualifies as true mystery rather than arbitrary thriller and that revels in its endless complications. Take a popcorn break and you'll be sorry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, PEARL
description: MARCUS-Pearl. September 17, 1997. Beloved wife of Henry for 57 years. Devoted mother of Sherry (Robert) Hatcher. Loving grandmother of Jessamyn and Juliet. Honored teacher of English, Highland School; columnist for Jewish Post and Opinion; teacher of Yiddish in adult education; former Director, Workman's Circle Shule in Northern Westchester. Services September 19, 12:30 PM, Temple Israel of Northern Westchester. Contributions to American Heart Association.

title: Devil Holdouts
description: Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire said yesterday that the absence of Bill Guerin and Brian Rolston from training camp had reached the critical point for the two restricted free agent forwards.

title: Attack on Cairo Tourist Bus Kills 9 Germans and Driver
description: At least two men attacked a tour bus with automatic weapons and gasoline bombs in Cairo today, killing 10 people, 9 of them German tourists, and igniting a fierce firefight in Tahrir Square.

description: SPIEGEL-Ira. The colleagues and friends of Dr. Alan Spiegel in the Departments of Medicine and Cardiology at the New York University Medical Center express heartfelt condolences to Dr. Spiegel and his family upon the death of his father, Ira.

title: The Cries of Welfare States Under the Knife
description: At the end of a dim corridor full of yellowing files spilling their forgotten contents onto dusty shelves sits Dr. Mario Maddaloni, the Italian state's inquisitor in this depressed southern town.

title: Republicans In House Vow To Kill Raise
description: Republican sophomores in the House threatened another uprising against their leaders today, vowing to block a raise for members of Congress and throwing their support behind the transportation committee chairman in his row with Speaker Newt Gingrich over highway spending.

title: China's President Ousts Rival From High Party Positions
description: President Jiang Zemin ousted a major rival on Thursday, and the Communist Party leadership selected a new Central Committee at the close of a weeklong party congress. The gathering embraced an ambitious plan for economic reform and secured Mr. Jiang's place as the leader who will guide China in the post-Deng era.

title: United Cuts Travel Agency Commissions
description: United Airlines has cut travel agency commissions to 8 percent from 10 percent for all tickets sold in the United States, saying yesterday it did so to save $80 million to $100 million annually so that it could ''survive and succeed'' in the global marketplace.

title: Possibility of Police Perjury Is the Focus of a New Inquiry
description: The Bronx District Attorney's office will reopen its inquiry into whether police officers committed perjury during the trial of an officer charged with killing a man with an illegal choke hold, a spokesman for the District Attorney said yesterday.

description: 'Drawings and Paintings'

title: Art in Review
description: 'Six Feet Under'

title: Bonds Slip As Traders Take Profits
description: The four-day rally in Treasury securities ended yesterday as investors took profits.

title: Ancient Indian Site Challenges Ideas on Early American Life
description: Earthen mounds at an ancient American Indian site in Louisiana have been found to be the earliest known remnants of human construction in the New World. The discovery challenges traditional ideas about early American cultures and suggests that pre-agriculture, pre-ceramic hunting societies were more socially complex than previously thought.

title: Kiner's Homer Feats Came Outside the Spotlight
description: Ralph Kiner never thought he was chasing Babe Ruth's mark of 60 home runs in a season when he hit 51 in 1947 and 54 in 1949. Hardly anyone wrote about a pursuit or reminded him of it, and newspapers did not project his output every day.

title: F.C.C. Accord Said to Be Near On Debts of Wireless Companies
description: Under escalating pressure from lawmakers on Capitol Hill, the Federal Communications Commission is close to resolving a standoff over how to refinance the debts of a group of troubled companies that are seeking to offer a new type of cellular service, F.C.C. officials involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMER, BABETTE (NEE JACOBSON)
description: SOMMER-Babette (nee Jacobson). Of Leonia, N.J. On September 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Dear sister of Charles Jacobson. Services ''GuttermanMusicant'', corner Passaic and Park Streets, Hackensack, New Jersey, Sunday at 10:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTENHEIMER, LILLY, MD.
description: OTTENHEIMER-Lilly, MD. We mourn the death of our colleague, teacher and friend. An outstanding psychoanalytic physician, she personified the highest ideals of medicine and psychoanalysis. Members of the Faculty The Psychoanalytic Institute, New York Medical College

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMOCK, FRED
description: DIMOCK-Fred. September 15. Beloved Broadway Dresser for over two decades and dear friend and companion of 43 years of John Check. Died peacefully at home after a brief illness. Services on Saturday, September 20, 1 P.M., at Royal Palm Home, 801 Tyrone Blvd., St. Petersberg, Florida.

title: People
description: Deborah Millman, senior vice president at Sterling Group, New York, was named to the new position of president of its Sterling Design division.

title: Classical Music and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: GOLDSTEIN-Joseph, died September 17, 1997. A loving father of Alan, Carol and Murray. Loving brother of David, Sonia and Amy. Funeral services are on Sunday, September 21, 11 A.M., at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: Metro Business; Drug Prices Compared
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs released a survey yesterday that found large differences in the prices of some children's health products at local pharmacies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSNER, JOSEPH
description: ROSNER-Joseph. Family and friends will gather in his memory at the Vivian Horan Gallery, 35 East 67th St., 2nd Floor, at 6 PM, Tuesday, September 23.

title: At Whirlpool, 4,700 Workers To Lose Jobs
description: The Whirlpool Corporation announced today that it would dismiss 4,700 employees -- just more than 10 percent of its work force -- and take a $350 million charge against earnings as part of a plan to improve profits.

title: Two of the Big Six In Accounting Plan To Form New No. 1
description: Coopers & Lybrand and Price Waterhouse, two of the world's largest accounting and consulting firms, said yesterday that they planned to merge their practices worldwide.

title: Baryshnikov and French Innovator Win Bessie Awards
description: A Russian ballet star who has encouraged modern dance and an experimental French ballet choreographer were among the dance world figures honored on Wednesday night when Dance Theater Workshop presented its 13th annual New York Dance and Performance Awards at the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts. The awards, familiarly known as the Bessies, are named for Bessie Schonberg, a respected teacher of dance composition who died this year.

title: Life at Hyper-Speed
description: The computer chip manufacturer Intel surprised and delighted the computer industry this week with the announcement that its engineers had invented a way to speed up the design cycle of their chips. From now on, the amount of memory each chip can hold will double every nine months, instead of every 18 months. That means computer processing speeds will increase at an even faster rate than before.

title: New York Times Company Promotes Three Executives
description: Laura J. Corwin, corporate secretary of The New York Times Company, has been promoted to the additional position of vice president.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Accounting Firm Merger To Create an Industry Giant

title: Jets Draw The Line On Their Problems
description: Neil O'Donnell's eyes don't burn with anger often, but they have on recent Sundays. The Jets' quarterback mistakenly thought he had lost that losing feeling.

title: Flu Outbreak on Ship; Shots Are Advised
description: A cruise ship carrying scores of passengers and crew members stricken with the flu is scheduled to dock in New York City tomorrow, and health officials yesterday advised New Yorkers in high-risk groups to consider getting flu shots.

title: Sinking the Neighbors, Even Dead Ones
description: Thank someone -- the gods of comedy, some producer on the ball, an eagle-eyed real-estate agent -- for moving ''Forbidden Broadway Strikes Back!'' to a cabaret on Broadway and West 51st Street. If any show was ever ordained for residency just up the street from Times Square, it is this delightfully wicked knife-twister of a revue forever on the lookout for a pompous production in need of a puncture and a Broadway ego requiring a trim.

title: Puerto Rico Newspaper War Puts Editors at Odds
description: Last April, Puerto Rico's largest daily newspaper assessed the first 100 days of Gov. Pedro J. Rossello's second term by highlighting a corruption scandal and the slow pace of legislation to promote his program. The next day, 16 government agencies canceled advertisements worth about $4.5 million a year to the newspaper.

title: I.M.F. Chief Vouches for Thai Reforms
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that Thailand was meeting conditions for a $17.2 billion rescue package, disputing reports that the fund might deny the aid if officials stalled on revamping the nation's finances.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Thai Slump at Ground Level; Loans Scarce, Imports Prohibitive; a Region Shudders
description: In his glass-sheathed board room overlooking a velvety green golf course here, Vanus Taepaisitphongse seems becalmed in the eye of the storm. In reality, he is hanging on to a life raft by his fingertips.

title: Fassel Says Emotion Is Quite Becoming
description: It isn't hard to remember the moment Sunday when Giants linebacker Corey Widmer seemed to lose his mind. He was the guy waving his arms and yelling at the Baltimore Ravens' bench.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KATZ, MO
description: KATZ-Mo. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23 at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street at 6 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, MURRAY LEONARD AND DOROTHY JOAN (KALLENBACH)
description: JACOBS-Murray Leonard and Dorothy Joan (Kallenbach). Of Ossining, NY. Unexpectedly on September 15, 1997. Ages 80 and 77. Dearest, devoted parents and kindest friends. Survived by Raphaela Judy Willington and Karen Erica Arbetter, their devoted daughters. Father-in-law and mother-in-law of Jeffrey Arbetter. Second parents to Javier Fernandez-Schoeners. Grandparents of Jason, Joshua and Emily Arbetter. Contributions may be made in their memory to the National TaySachs and Allied Diseases Association, 2001 Beacon Street, Brookline, Mass. 02146 and the Guiding Eyes for the Blind, Inc. 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, New York 10598.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Sept. 8, reprinted in the Diary column of the Money and Business section on Sunday, showing the amount of leisure time spent on line, carried incomplete labels. The figures applied only to households that subscribe to on-line services or Internet service providers. The figures also represent the aggregate time spent by all members of the household, and were based on survey results, not direct measurements.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 4
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Helen Jepson, 92, a Soprano At the Met in the 30's and 40's
description: Helen Jepson, a soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera and with other American companies in the 1930's and 40's, died on Tuesday at the Blake Memorial Hospital in Bradenton, Fla. She was 92 and lived in Bradenton.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MONROE, SYLVIA (FOXTOW)
description: MONROE-Sylvia (Foxtow). Syl is not gone, she is just away. Since 1992 her captivating smile is watching over all of us. Harold Monroe and Barbara, Eric, and Scott Mogelof

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Getting Beyond the Democratic Primary
description: Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger is now the official Democratic mayoral nominee. Ms. Messinger has been gearing her career toward that prize for nearly a decade, but she certainly never expected to win it by such a narrow margin amid so much confusion.

title: Spare Times
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Eating Out; Places With Gardens
description: In the heat of the summer, dining outdoors can be more sweaty than pleasant. But now, when the air is conditioned naturally by the changing seasons, the al fresco meal can be truly appreciated. These restaurants don't just offer outdoor seating, they offer gardens, where the clamor of the city loses out to an unexpected tranquillity. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: On My Mind; The Sharpton Albatross
description: Faced with a critical political dilemma, Ruth Messinger reviewed her principles, made a firm, important decision, and told New Yorkers what not one of them thought she believed: Al Sharpton would make a better mayor than Rudolph Giuliani.

title: New Ethics Rules Are Approved, Including a Ban on Outsiders' Complaints
description: Republicans in the House pushed through a change in ethics rules today that would bar outside groups from lodging an ethics complaint against a House member, but failed to pass a provision that would have made it possible to kill an ethics complaint by delay.

title: After Pact With Netanyahu, Settlers Leave East Jerusalem House
description: Right-wing Jews occupying a house in East Jerusalem reached an agreement with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today under which the families later left the building and were replaced by 10 Jewish religious students acting as guards and maintenance men.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think next time I'll give $600,000.''

title: Travelers-Bankers Trust Rumor Sends Street Into Tizzy
description: Wall Street went on a wild and sometimes comic ride yesterday as investors flirted with the prospect that the Travelers Group, the giant financial company headed by Sanford I. Weill, might be preparing to buy the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The last time the American soprano BARBARA HENDRICKS visited Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, in 1993, she was there primarily to sing at a New Year's Eve concert. Today, she is returning on a more solemn mission.

title: Beauty, in a Variety of Guises
description: What if McDonald's sponsored a medical conference and invited cardiologists from around the world to talk about the importance of a healthy diet? What would you think?

title: Family Fare
description: 'Cat in the Hat Comes Back'

title: Music for America Online
description: America Online Inc. said today that it had entered into a three-year partnership with N2K Inc., a retailer of recorded music. The deal makes N2K's Music Boulevard the exclusive music retailer within America Online's Musicspace and music areas. America Online, an Internet on-line service, said it would receive a minimum of $18 million over the span of the agreement, with $12 million to be paid by Dec. 1. America Online said it planned to make a small investment in N2K's planned initial public offering of stock.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Accounting Firm Merger To Create an Industry Giant

title: Antiques; The Interest In Furniture From China
description: The buzz was palpable Monday evening in Manhattan at Christie's auction preview of the Robert P. Piccus collection of fine classical Chinese furniture. Among those examining the folding stools and high yokeback armchairs were the dealers Grace Wu Bruce and Charlotte Horstmann from Hong Kong and Nicholas Grindley from London, along with collectors like George Weiss of Hartford, Dr. Marvin and Pat Gordon of San Francisco and Robert Blumenfield of Los Angeles.

title: Japan Retailer In Bankruptcy
description: The Yaohan Japan Corporation, a Japanese retailer that has expanded aggressively in America and Asia, filed for bankruptcy court protection today.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. Shows that are highly recommended have a *. Shows that had discounted tickets available yesterday at the TKTS booth for last night's performance have a +.

title: Arranging Light to Make The Most of Minimalism
description: Dan Flavin's love of light earned him a place in the history of Minimal Art. It was an affection befitting a lapsed Roman Catholic who would later recall being mesmerized by the candles of high mass, and it found its ultimate expression in the fluorescent tubes that Flavin started using in 1963.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Abroad at Home ; 'Humans, Not Animals'
description: Elba Digna Wood is a Honduran woman who lives in Nicaragua with her husband, a former commandante of the contras. In 1994 she visited her sister in Houston. She was pregnant and planned to go home in September for the birth. But the baby was born prematurely in August, and she stayed until the doctor said she could go home, in December.

title: Stealing a Glimpse Over the Shoulder Of Picasso at Work
description: It's hard to know what has befallen ''Picasso the Engraver: Selections from the Musee Picasso, Paris,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Taken as a whole, it's certainly an odd-looking show.

title: Poor N.J. Drivers Save Under Insurance Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Real Estate; Construction of Rentals Is Surging
description: Capitalizing on the steady demand for new rentals in Manhattan, developers will start leasing 227 apartments next month in a building rising at 33d Street and First Avenue, once the site of a gas station.

title: A Split on Ethics Rules
description: After a debate that showed the continuation of a bitter division between the parties, House Republicans pushed through changes in the rules on ethics.

title: Art in Review
description: 'The Sleeping Beauty'

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS BOOSTS OFFER FOR LIBERTY MEDIA
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, increased its offer yesterday for shares of its separately traded unit Liberty Media Group. Tele-Communications, based in Englewood, Colo., said it had increased the purchase price to $30 a share from $27 and was offering to buy 15 million shares, up from 10 million. It also extended the tender offer to Oct. 2; it was to expire on Wednesday. The offer is part of a plan by Tele-Communications to buy back as many as 55.5 million common shares of Liberty Media, the programming unit of Tele-Communications. Liberty Media series A shares rose 68.75 cents yesterday, to $29.0625. Liberty's series B shares were at $29.50, up $2.75.

title: Master Creator of Ghosts Is Honored by C.I.A.
description: When cold war spies wanted to disappear, they went to see Tony Mendez, the master mask-maker, the Central Intelligence Agency's chief of disguise. Mr. Mendez has now doffed his own mask of anonymity. Today, at a secret ceremony at the C.I.A.'s headquarters in Langley, Va., on the agency's 50th anniversary, he was named one of 50 all-time stars of the spy trade.

title: Yankees Let Guarantee of Playoff Spot Slip Away
description: The vanishing Angels had already botched another game by the time the Yankees were in the fifth inning last night, so the Yankees knew they were one victory away from clinching the wild-card spot in the American League. All they had to do was stifle the Tigers and they would be assured of playing baseball in October.

title: Broadway's Permanent Players
description: From center aisle of the Richard Rodgers Theater comes this seismic show-biz shocker:

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. Films and series that are highly recommended have a *. Running times and ratings of films are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: When Criticism Becomes Judge-Bashing
description: To the Editor:

title: Sauers's 64 Earns Lead
description: Gene Sauers beat the heat and regained his putting stroke to take the first-round lead yesterday at the La Cantera Texas Open in San Antonio.

title: MARRIOTT AND SODEXHO CONFIRM ALLIANCE TALKS
description: Confirming a report in The Financial Times, the British newspaper, Marriott International Inc. and Sodexho Alliance S.A. said yesterday that they were in talks to combine their food service and facilities-management operations in North America. Marriott's unit supplies and prepares foods or manages cafeterias for about 3,400 businesses, health care companies and schools. Sodexho is a French catering company. Shares in Marriott rose $1.5625, to $70.625. Sodexho got 18 percent of its sales from North America in the year that ended on Aug. 31, 1996, and three-quarters of its sales came from outside of France.

title: A Male Poppins From Another Planet (but Will It Fly?)
description: A lot of people are going to misunderstand ''Meego,'' the new series about a nanny from outer space. They'll see Bronson Pinchot as Meego doing the housework ''Bewitched''-style (but while disco dancing to ''She Works Hard for the Money'') or answering ''How come you speak English?'' with ''Well, it's not like I'm from Mars,'' and they'll judge the show by adult standards.

title: LCI INTERNATIONAL TO ACQUIRE RIVAL TELEPHONE COMPANY
description: LCI International Inc., the nation's sixth-largest long-distance phone company, agreed yesterday to acquire a smaller rival, the USLD Communications Corporation, for about $332 million in stock. LCI said the deal would allow it to enter the Southwest and Northwest markets and increase its business in the West and Southeast. USLD, based in San Antonio, had $180.3 million in revenues for the year that ended Sept. 30, 1996. LCI, based in McLean, Va., had $1.1 billion in revenues in 1996. Under the agreement, LCI is to swap $20 worth of its stock for each of USLD's 16.6 million shares outstanding. USLD's shares rose $1.125, to $19.25. LCI gained 6.25 cents, to $24.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUER, HENNY
description: BAUER-Henny. On September 17, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Frederick, loving mother of the late Walter and Ilse, cherished grandmother of Fred Bauer, Alan Feibelman, David Bauer and Robert Feibelman, great-grandmother of Heather, Melissa, Joshua, Eric, and Nicole. Services 10:30 A.M., Sunday, Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: Offer to Green
description: Travis Green, an integral part of the Islanders' scoring attack, is still unsigned and out of camp, but both sides were optimistic yesterday that an agreement could be reached soon.

title: Weekend Excursion; Where the Dutch Left Their Mark
description: There are places in New York State, not far from the Hudson River, where the houses look less like the product of human workmanship than of some particularly tidy natural event. Their carefully jumbled fieldstones suggest nothing so much as an ancient itch in the earth -- a believable image, given the writhing landscape -- that seems to have stood for a moment and shaken itself free of soil, leaving behind handsome piles of rocks in which people only later came to take shelter.

title: MEMTEC SAYS IT WILL OPPOSE TAKEOVER BID BY U.S. FILTER
description: Memtec Ltd., an Australian maker of water filters, said yesterday that it had rejected a $330 million takeover bid by the U.S. Filter Corporation and said it would vigorously oppose the offer. Memtec called the $30-a-share offer, announced late on Wednesday, ''opportunistic and woefully inadequate.'' American depository receipts of Memtec surged $9.50, or 38 percent, to $34.125, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of U.S. Filter fell 93.75 cents, to $40.8125.

title: Detective Is Recovering After Shooting Leg
description: A police detective was recovering from surgery yesterday, after he shot himself in the leg on Wednesday night in Brooklyn while arresting a construction worker who is suspected of murder, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, CARL C.
description: MANDELBAUM-Carl C., MD. Pompano Beach, Florida. Age 90. Passed away 9/17/97. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Graveside services today 11:00am. Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Georges Guetary, 82, Suave French Singer, Dies
description: Georges Guetary, the French singing star best known to American audiences as Gene Kelly's rival for the affections of Leslie Caron in the Oscar-winning 1951 film ''An American in Paris,'' died on Saturday in a clinic in Mougins on the French Riviera. Mr. Guetary, who lived in Cannes, was 82.

title: ACE AGREES TO BUY XEROX INSURANCE UNIT FOR $333 MILLION
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell one of its Talegen Holdings Inc. insurance units for $333 million cash to Ace Ltd. The sale is part of a strategy by Xerox to leave the financial services business and concentrate on document processing. Earlier this month, it agreed to sell another of Talegen's units for $612 million. The unit that Ace is acquiring, Westchester Specialty Group Inc., is an Atlanta-based property and casualty insurer. It has about 210 employees and had annual written premiums of $125 million last year. Ace is a Bermuda-based insurer.

title: If Royalty Can Change, So Can Rolls
description: BEFORE the end of the century, Rolls-Royce plans to begin selling cars that are new from the ground up -- the first major design change since 1980.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, WARREN (BUD)
description: REYNOLDS - Warren (Bud). Larchmont resident, died at home on September 17 at age 81. Retired sales representative of 35 years for the Manhattan and Hathaway Shirt Companies of Manhattan. He was born December 11, 1915 to Blanche Hollis and Thomas F. Reynolds, Sr. former Westchester County Sheriff in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Attended Fordham and Georgetown Universities. Parishioner and Usher of Sts. John and Paul, Larchmont, NY. Member Larchmont Shore Club. World War II Miitary Police with US Army. Member Board of Directors Bellato Engineering Company, Stockton CA. Survived by wife Lola Godsell Reynolds, son Jay Reynolds (Lieutenant, Town of Mamaroneck Fire Department), daughter Lola Reynolds Bellato, five grandchildren, Erin, Kimberly, Michael, Grace and Gina, two brothers, Thomas F., Jr. of Larchmont and Robert of Westport CT. Predeceased by two brothers, Hollis and Edwin, and two sisters Cecilia Hanifin and Helen Glassford. Visitation at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont today 2-4 and 79 Mass of Christian Burial 10AM, Saturday at Sts. John and Paul, Larchmont NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla NY.

title: Oilman Says He Paid for Access By Giving Democrats $300,000
description: Roger E. Tamraz, an international businessman with an unsavory reputation who gave $300,000 to Democrats for last year's election campaigns, testified today that he had donated the money expressly to pry open the doors of power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MILTON
description: FRIEDMAN-Milton, age ninetythree, real estate lawyer, scholar and author, September 16, at home, suddenly. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Guiterman Friedman, loving father of Alan, father-in-law of Carolyn and devoted grandfather of Wendy, Kathryn and Amy. Interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at a future date.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Sept. 11 with an article about generic drug manufacturers misstated the location of one such company, Schein Pharmaceutical Inc. It is Florham Park, N.J., not Florida.

title: Lots of Money but Few Horses in Stakes
description: No matter how hard Sonny Hine tries, he can't quite explain why his colt Skip Away rocketed through that workout last week, flying six furlongs in 1 minute 83/5 seconds, just four-fifths of a second off the Belmont Park record for a race of that distance. Nor could he quite tell whether Skip Away, the favorite in tomorrow's $500,000 Woodward Stakes, had left his race on the training track.

title: 2 Executions In Chechnya Anger Russia
description: A Chechen firing squad publicly executed two men today, defying Russian demands that capital punishment be brought to a halt.

title: From the Valley of Death to Israel
description: Extremely powerful archival scenes punctuate the Holocaust documentary ''The Long Way Home,'' giving an intimate dimension to the film's historical drama. Frankly Zionist in its sympathies, Mark Jonathan Harris's stirring and accomplished film spans the period from the liberation of Nazi concentration camp survivors in 1945 to the founding of Israel as a Jewish homeland three years later, emphasizing the profound connection between these events. Along the way, Mr. Harris creates an intense empathy for the refugees' experience and for aspects of their ordeal that are often ignored.

title: FILM REVIEW ; Opposites Attract, Even if Repellent
description: When a filmmaker feels compelled to pump up a story through caricature and expressionistic visual tricks, it's usually a sign of distrust in the inherent drama of the material. In ''Going All the Way,'' a flashy movie adaptation of Dan Wakefield's popular 1970 novel about growing up in the heartland in the repressed 1950's, Mark Pellington, a director from the world of music video, has inflated a realistic memoir into a garish, hyperkinetic social satire.

title: Man Is Rescued After a Fall
description: Firefighters rescued a homeless man yesterday after he plunged 180 feet off a rocky cliff overlooking the Hudson River, the police said.

title: Taliban Forces Seize Afghan Rival's Stronghold on Uzbek Border
description: ALMATY, Kazakstan, Sept. 18

title: Oil Is Spilled in the Bay
description: A narrow slick eight miles long spread over the Delaware Bay yesterday after a Nigerian tanker leaked light-grade crude oil during an offshore transfer operation, officials said.

title: Rival Ousted in China
description: Securing his place as the nation's leader in the post-Deng era, President Jiang Zemin ousted a major rival at a party congress: Qiao Shi, No. 3 in the hierarchy, was excluded from the Politburo.

title: Giuliani Campaign Is Fined $220,000 Over Contributions
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board fined Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election campaign $220,000 yesterday for accepting more than $300,000 in illegal contributions, most of which were given by developers and others doing business with the city government.

title: Rage Cited in Killing of Man By Officer Over Parking Spot
description: It was rage and retribution that led to the death of a black man in a dispute over a suburban parking space, lawyers for both sides said today in opening statements in the trial of an off-duty white police officer charged with murder.

title: Bold Fat Cat Tells How West Wing Was Won
description: ''If they kick me from the door, I come through the window,'' Roger E. Tamraz, campaign contributor and oil promoter extraordinaire, explained to a panel of Senators alternately mesmerized and appalled at his resilience in finally attaining the ear of President Clinton last year, despite national security warnings that he was ''shady.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, SOL
description: FRIED-Sol. On September 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Bernice. Loving father of Bonnie, Roger & Lori. Dear grandfather of Justin and his wife Rondi. Service Friday, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Business; Palladium to Fall For N.Y.U. Housing
description: Amid an aggressive campaign to expand student housing near its Greenwich Village campus, New York University officials said yesterday that the university had acquired a building dear to the hearts of the young and the restless -- at least those who fit the description when Ronald Reagan was President -- the Palladium theater and nightclub at 126 East 14th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, ANDERSON
description: FOWLER-Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23, at 11 A.M., at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone, New Jersey.

title: Store Owner Is Indicted
description: A customer was browsing in the A.C.L. Hardware Store on Springfield Avenue last year, when he noticed a familiar-looking hand truck offered for sale. It had come from the customer's employer, the Newark Housing Authority.

title: Market Place; When Thomas Hanley starts spreading bank merger rumors, many serious investors listen.
description: Why would Bankers Trust New York's stock jump 7.5 percent after a rumor started circulating yesterday morning that it would be acquired by Travelers Group, despite a Federal banking law that prevents insurance companies from buying banks?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORTO, ANDREA
description: TORTO-Andrea. The leadership of Greater Metropolitan Health Systems (GMHS) and the entire Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) family acknowledge with sadness the passing of Andrea Torto, beloved father of our dear friend and colleague, Malvina Torto. To Malvina, her mother and the entire Torto family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, GMHS and BIMC Robert G. Newman, M.D., President, GMHS Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President, BIMC

title: Ripken's Streak Isn't Unbearable Burden Yet
description: The Yankees were in position to clinch their third playoff berth in three seasons last night, while the Dodgers and the Giants, the Yankees' onetime dance-card partners in the Big Apple, were waging yet another chapter in a storied rivalry that has lost little in its transfer to the West Coast.

title: From an Affair With Books to a Book Fair
description: It was Tim Costello who told me to get out of his bar and walk a few blocks to where I'd see two lions, and to go in there and get myself a library card. I did what he told me because he was ferocious and I was a timid newcomer to New York in the early 1950's. I climbed the steps between the lions and wandered around the great halls, up one marble staircase and down another, afraid to ask anyone anything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHAN, JOSHUA HARRISON
description: KAHAN-Joshua Harrison. On September 17, 1997, of Voorhees, NJ. ''Our Joshy Bear.'' Born November 5, 1994, his smile is indelible in all of our hearts. He is truly a treasured gift to all of us. Joshy wanted to be a fireman. When one thinks of Joshy we think of his infectious, magical smile, his ability to light up a room. Joshy, you are so brave. You are our hero. We will always be with you. Joshy is survived by his parents, Jeffrey and Michele (nee Taub) Kahan, his sister, Allison Kahan, his brother, Brian Kahan. He is the grandson of Sunny and Jay Kahan, Myrna and Joseph Douglas and Lloyd and Linda Taub. Services Friday, 11 AM, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., 2001 Berlin Rd, Cherry Hill, NJ. The family will return to the late residence and respectfully requests in lieu of flowers contributions in his memory be made to Joshua Kahan Memorial Fund for Pediatric AML Leukemia, c/o The American Cancer Society, 1626 Locust Street, Phila, PA. 19103.

title: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE BOARD ; Election Officials Say They Were Right to Be Deliberate
description: As the Board of Elections certified the results of the Democratic mayoral primary -- five days before a scheduled runoff -- election officials yesterday defended the board's actions, saying that time and care had been necessary to comply with state election laws and to conduct a fair and accurate count of the ballots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, BERNARD
description: LONDON-Bernard. Devoted father of Bud, Leslie and Joanne. Dear brother of Toby Lublin and the late Archie London. Cherished grandfather of Dylan, Daniel, Kristen, Matthew, Ethan, Jenna, Ari, Brian and Emily. Services are today 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. Shows that are highly recommended have a *.

title: Philip Morris U.S.A. Gets New Chief for Tough Times
description: The newly designated United States tobacco chief of the Philip Morris Companies, Michael E. Szymanczyk, is an expert on retail sales and distribution. That is exactly the focus that the company will need, experts say, to sell cigarettes in an uncertain future when tobacco companies may be bound by harsh advertising restrictions and Federal regulations.

title: China Turns Another Corner
description: The centerpiece of this week's Chinese Communist Party Congress was President Jiang Zemin's call for the sale, merger or closing of the vast majority of China's state-owned enterprises. His declaration exceeded expectations and signals the boldest economic transformation attempted by Beijing since the early 1980's.

title: Aluminum Industry Deal
description: Imco Recycling Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Alchem Aluminum Inc. of Coldwater, Mich., for $49.3 million in newly issued stock and assumed debt. Other terms were not disclosed. Imco, based here, is an aluminum recycler. Alchem supplies aluminum alloy to the automotive industry.

title: Low Dividends Are a Gamble for Wall Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Transfusion Therapy Averts Strokes in Sickle-Cell Young
description: A major international study has found that regular blood transfusions prevent the vast majority of strokes in children with sickle cell disease, doctors said today.

title: Tougher Penalties for Employers Who Cheat on Pay
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today that imposes tougher penalties on employers who hire migrants and other low-skilled laborers but refuse to pay them all or part of their wages.

title: Fitness, Not Medicine, Increases Life Expectancy
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies; A Studio Drama In a Real Court
description: Courtroom dramas are a Hollywood staple. And what could be better than a drama pitting two powerful moguls against one another, two men who worked side by side for years to build an empire but now loathe each other. The drama -- better than most movies -- is a real-life one, pitting Jeffrey Katzenberg against Michael Eisner. And to the amazement of virtually everyone in town -- including the two antagonists -- the issue is set to go before a Los Angeles Superior Court judge and jury on Nov. 18.

title: Sports of The Times; Howie Vogts Is the Bear Of Suburbia
description: BEAR BRYANT had his tower, where a venerable football coach could survey his legions at the University of Alabama. This being a modest high school program, Howie Vogts drives right up to the edge of the practice field.

title: Art in Review
description: Roberto Juarez

title: Old Flamenco, New Age: A Chamber of Guitars
description: The Friends and Enemies of New Music generally offer concerts of contemporary chamber music, but having already devoted evenings to solo piano and solo violin works, the organization opened its season on Wednesday evening, at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, with what it called a Guitarathon. It was a sensible idea: there may be more first-rate guitarists per capita in New York City than anywhere else in the United States, and since the cream of the repertory is modern, most guitarists are experienced and devoted new-music players.

title: Yo! What a Fabulous Window Treatment!
description: Everything that ''In and Out'' has to say about masculine behavior is encapsulated in a single dance scene with Kevin Kline, a scene in which Mr. Kline is pure bliss. There he is, dressed like Paul Bunyan and almost alone, except for a surreally meddlesome instructional tape that is trying to teach him what real men -- Paul Bunyan men -- do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, NORMAN DUDLEY
description: JOHNSON-Norman Dudley. Died peacefully September 16, 1997 on Martha's Vineyard, Ma., in his 90th year. Survived by his wife Virginia Couper Johnson; father of Dudley Disosway Johnson, Cazenovia, NY, Kathleen Wu, Pontevedra, Florida, Norman Platt Johnson, Newport, R.I. Ridgely Couper Johnson, London, England, six grandchildren, two great grandchildren. Service St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Edgartown, MA., 4 PM, Friday, Sept. 19th.

title: NASA Aides and House Panel Debate Safety of Mir Station
description: As NASA officials testified that it was safe to send more Americans to live on the troubled Mir space station, members of the House Science Committee said today that further stays aboard the Russian craft posed unacceptable risks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, MAUREEN DOWNEY
description: HARTMAN-Maureen Downey. 9/17/97 of Harrison, New York. Beloved wife of David Hartman. Loving mother of Sean, Brian, Bridget and Conor. Dear sister of Patrick Downey. The family will receive friends Sunday 5-8 P.M., at the Wm. H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye. It is at this time friends and relatives will have an opportunity to reflect and share our special feelings about Maureen. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of the Resurrection, Monday, 10 A.M. Interment private in Peoria, IL. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Stehlin Foundation for Cancer Research, 1315 Calhoun, Suite 1818, Houston, TX 77002.

title: Martin Collapses at the Davis Cup Draw
description: The teams from the United States and Australia did not mind being typecast as the Democrats and the Republicans of their sport at today's Davis Cup draw ceremony on Capitol Hill. When it comes to Davis Cup, they are, after all, the Hatfields and McCoys of this international tennis competition.

title: The Open Door for Mr. Tamraz
description: In the hall of fame for rogues operating in the corrupt American political system, Roger Tamraz will have no trouble standing out. But the larcenous charm with which he admitted paying $300,000 to meet President Clinton should not obscure the import of his testimony before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee yesterday. He was affirming that in the shadowy reaches of the international business world, it was believed, accurately, that during 1996 dubious entrepreneurs could buy White House audiences, particularly if they did not quibble about the cost of the ticket. Mr. Tamraz said he would have been happy to give the Democrats $600,000 if that is what it took to see Mr. Clinton.

title: Metro Business; Homestead Inn Is Sold
description: The Homestead Inn in Greenwich, Conn., a mainstay of stylish Fairfield County dining and weddings, has been bought by a group including Thomas Henkelmann, the chef at La Panetiere in Rye, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOWLER, ANDERSON
description: FOWLER-Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23rd, St. Luke's Church, Peapack, N.J. at 11 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDEL, HENRI
description: BENDEL-Henri. September 15, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Loving father of John and his wife Diana. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, September 20 at 1:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: KNICKS
description: John Starks's surgically repaired finger is still swollen but it doesn't hurt anymore. What still hurts Starks and his Knick teammates is how they were eliminated from the playoffs without getting the chance to dethrone Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington honored its founding chairman, ROGER L. STEVENS, on Wednesday with a life-size bust.

title: Art in Review
description: Richmond Burton

title: New Video Releases
description: The English Patient

title: Public Advocate Issue Raised
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey said yesterday that the elimination of the State Public Advocate's Office three years ago had contributed to the rising cost of automobile insurance. He vowed to work to restore the office if he is elected governor.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: PRISON CARE

title: 3 TEAMSTER AIDES MAKE GUILTY PLEAS AND HINT AT PLOT
description: Three top campaign aides to Ron Carey, the teamsters president, pleaded guilty yesterday to funneling illegal contributions to his re-election drive as part of a broad scheme that they said involved officials of the Democratic Party and the President's re-election campaign and included improper cash payments by leaders of other major labor unions.

title: Where Life Is Sideshow, Street Art Passes Limit
description: Artists love to pull on the chain of convention, and the young blond graffiti artist who calls himself Xpress is no different.

title: A Poignant Role Takes a New Turn
description: Who is this poised, charmingly sardonic hostess, presiding over a party made up of her own dark memories? Surely it isn't Li'l Bit, the damaged refugee of a sexually abused childhood and the narrator of Paula Vogel's superb comic drama, ''How I Learned to Drive.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, AARON
description: HALPERN-Aaron. On September 16, 1997. Age 77. Of Clifton, N.J., and Delray Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Dorothy (Leibowitz), loving father of Doretta. Adored brother, uncle, great uncle, great great uncle, cousin and friend. Educator and Principal of Clifton H.S. for 25 years, 1963-1988. Services on Friday, September 19 at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 66 Howe Avenue, Passaic, NJ, 10AM. Donations may be made to the Aaron Halpern Scholarship Fund, PO Box 416, Little Falls, N.J. 07424.

title: Rhone-Poulenc To Take a Charge
description: The French chemical and pharmaceutical company Rhone-Poulenc S.A. said yesterday that it would take a charge of 9.5 billion francs, or $1.6 billion, this year related to its revamping. The Paris-based company said in June that it would combine its chemicals, fibers and polymers activities into an independent company that will be operational on Jan. 1 and sold to the public. The new company will be called Rhodia.

title: Later News, and a 2-Part 'Weekend'
description: This week The Times introduces its most sweeping improvements in more than 20 years:

title: Metro Business; Expo Moves to New York
description: Amid an intense rivalry for business with convention halls in Boston, executives of the Jacob K. Javits Center said yesterday that they had booked the Macworld Expo, a large computer industry trade show, for July 1998. Macworld Expo had been held in Boston each year since 1984.

title: Persecuted Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALZA CORP., Palo Alto, Calif., a developer of pharmaceuticals products, agreed to buy the United States and Canadian rights to several drugs for urinary-tract conditions from Ivax Corp. for $75 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, LAURA
description: ROBBINS-Laura, 93, died peacefully on September 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving & loved mother of Michael and Benedict and daughters-in-law Lois and Ann Barbara; grandmother of Jeanie, Louis, Matthew, Elizabeth, Juli, Jil, Polly, and the late Daniel, great-grandmother of six. Sister of Sara Selis, Ben Neufeld, and the late Phillip Neufeld. Services for the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRILL, EMILY LOU
description: MORRILL-Emily Lou. Age 13. Died on Thursday, September 18. Daughter of Aaron Morrill and Fran Eicholz Morrill and sister of Samuel. She is also survived by maternal grandparents, David and Helene Eicholz and paternal grandparents, Richard and Carole Morrill. Services will be held Friday, 9/19 at 1:00 at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue, 131 Remsen St., Brooklyn. Contributions can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or Chai Lifeline.

title: Make Room for Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FROMKIN, REBECCA
description: FROMKIN-Rebecca. Sept. 19, 1961. In loving memory of the dear mother of Minette Cirker. Stanley

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Sir Rudolf Bing on Sept. 3 referred incorrectly to the departure of Maria Callas from the Metropolitan Opera after her dismissal by Sir Rudolf in 1958. It was not permanent; she returned to the Met in ''Tosca'' in 1965, seven years before his retirement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETT, RICHARD D. (DICK)
description: BRETT-Richard D. (Dick). A man made out of words was silenced on September 17th after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Survived by loving life partner Gary Jacobson, beloved brother Ronald and his family, cherished cousins, and many dear friends. Memorial to be held at his former residence on October 17, his 64th birthday. Donations to Cancercare or Cabrini Hospice.

title: King Lear (Just Call Him Larry) In Iowa
description: Shakespeare doesn't play in Peoria, at least not in the screen adaptation of ''A Thousand Acres'' by Jane Smiley. Or even in Iowa, which is no closer to home for ''King Lear.'' That was the underlying inspiration for Ms. Smiley's literary experiment. (A sign of these not-so-literary times: the front cover of the mass-market paperback edition trumpets ''the New York Times best seller,'' ''more than one million copies sold'' and, of course, ''soon to be a major motion picture.'' Only on its back cover is ''A Thousand Acres'' identified as ''winner of the Pulitzer Prize.'')

title: 4-Year-Old Boy Is Killed in the Bronx When a Radiator Falls Over
description: A 4-year-old boy who was playing in the ground floor hallway of a Bronx apartment building was killed yesterday when a radiator that apparently had not been properly attached to the floor toppled and fell on him.

title: Deal to Bring Rikers Inmates Managed Care
description: In a deal that for the first time brings managed care into New York City's prisons, the Health and Hospitals Corporation has signed a $350 million, three-year contract with St. Barnabas Hospital to provide medical services for the 133,000 inmates who pass each year through the Rikers Island jail complex.

title: Not Just the Same Old Illicit Sex
description: When a good-looking young lodger named Harold Guppy (Rupert Graves) is invited to move into the fussy little household of Marjorie Beasley (Julie Walters), he is made more than welcome. Living her idea of a dainty existence in a provincial British town (the year is 1954), the 50-ish Marjorie still has some unladylike impulses.

title: Headed to Midtown: Traffic-Stopping Cars
description: This 1936 Delahaye with coachwork by Figoni et Falaschi, once owned by the actress Dolores Del Rio, will be among 50 rare automobiles taking up residence in Rockefeller Center next week for the second Louis Vuitton Classic, an exposition of cars that epitomize, its sponsors say, the marriage of style and technology. Nine European cars will arrive in New York on Tuesday aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2; all will be on display Sept. 26-28. On the final day, they will parade down Fifth Avenue before an awards ceremony at 3 P.M.

title: A Police Mistake, an Injured Man, But No Charges Against Officers
description: Early on the morning of his 40th birthday last summer, Harold Dusenbury, a black electrician, ambled down Eighth Street in the Village on his way to work at a Kmart construction site. He wore a T-shirt and dungarees and carried a toolbox.

title: Federal Doctors' Report Appears to Say Gigante May Be Mentally Ill
description: In a report that his lawyer said seemed schizophrenic, Vincent Gigante, recently convicted of crimes as a Mafia boss, was said by Government mental-health experts to be possibly suffering from dementia, but also to have shown them signs of faking symptoms of mental illness.

title: Tv Weekend; Call Him the Fugitive Alien Angel
description: The hero of the new sci-fi series ''The Visitor'' has spent 50 years in another world picking up household hints and spiritual insight from extraterrestrials. Those survival tips come in handy after he crash-lands back in Utah. He turns a greenhouse plant luminous yellow and uses it to heal his serious chest wound. And he will need all his enhanced mental and physical agility -- mind melding with dogs, and playing dead so well himself that even doctors are convinced -- to evade the Government agents pursuing him.

title: Film in Review
description: 'Aaron's Magic Village'

title: Film in Review
description: 'The Toilers and the Wayfarers'

title: Tax-Exempt Group Linked To Democratic Fund-Raisers
description: A tax-exempt group that promoted voter turnout in the 1996 elections received contributions from donors in close coordination with Democratic fund-raisers, Federal and Senate investigators said today.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES TO BUY STERLING FOR $162 MILLION
description: Marshall Industries said yesterday that it would pay about $162 million to acquire the Sterling Electronics Corporation of Houston. Both companies are distributors of electronic components. Marshall, based in El Monte, Calif., said it would pay $21 a share for Sterling, which has about 7.2 million shares outstanding and options for 1.1 million shares. Marshall will also assume about $55 million of Sterling debt. According to Marshall, the combined company will have more than 2,200 employees, 74 sales outlets and serve more than 40,000 customers in the United States and Canada. Shares of Sterling rose $2.25, to $20.3125. Shares of Marshall Industries fell 18.75 cents, to $38.6875.

title: Man Gets 23 Years to Life For Killing Officer-Wife
description: After spitting at his victim's police colleagues, a Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to 23 years to life for fatally shooting his estranged wife, a New York City police officer.

title: Timothy Joyce, 63, a Pioneer in Market Research
description: Timothy Joyce, a pioneer in the field of magazine readership research, died on Sept. 13 in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: Outlook for Iowa Crop Lowers Corn Prices
description: Corn prices slumped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as an early harvest in Iowa suggested that the crop was larger than expected.

title: World News Briefs; Official Who Took Bribes May Quit Japan Cabinet
description: A politician who was once convicted in a bribery scandal but was appointed to the Cabinet last week suggested today that he would resign, defusing a political crisis for Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPECIAL DEVICES INC., Newhall, Calif., a maker of airbag initiators, said it was not involved in merger or acquisition talks.

title: A Medieval Festival
description: Knights, jugglers and jesters will be among the revelers at the Medieval Festival tomorrow from noon to 6 P.M. at Fort Tryon Park, West 191st Street and Fort Washington Avenue in Washington Heights. The annual event, sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation and the Washington Heights and Inwood Development Corporation, is free; visitors are encouraged to attend in period costume. The rain date is Sept. 28. Information: (212) 795-1600.

title: Without Excess Enthusiasm, Welsh Back Local Parliament
description: The people of Wales have voted by a surprisingly narrow margin to accept an offer from London to set up their first elected assembly in 500 years.

title: Hopes Are All but Gone As the Marlins Go Deep
description: The pitch from Dave Mlicki looked like a nice enough slider. It just happened to dip into Moises Alou's bat, and as the ball soared over the left-field fence, it squeezed the life out of the Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, JAY NICHOLAS
description: LONG-Jay Nicholas. Passed away on September 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Maria, cherished father of Angelique and her fiance, Hampton Peterson, and of Christopher and his wife Christianna and adoring grandfather of Nicholas and Alexander Long. Loving uncle, brother-in-law, and devoted friend and mentor to many, and esteemed attorney for almost 50 years. Funeral services to be held at Greek Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St, NYC, on September 22, 1997 at 11am. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to St. Michaels Home for the Aged, 3 Lehman Terrace, Yonkers, NY 10705-3699.

title: Governors Pledge to Join Fight Against Microbe Killing Fish
description: The governors of states in the Chesapeake Bay region, backed up by Federal environmental and public health agencies, declared an allied front today in a broadening war against a toxic microbe that has been blamed for killing fish and is suspected of causing alarming mental impairment in people exposed to infested waters.

title: Tea and Sympathy
description: To the Editor:

title: Gertrude Lookstein, Jewish Advocate, 90
description: Gertrude S. Lookstein, who with her husband, Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein, was a leader in the New York Orthodox community and active in a number of organizations, died on Sept. 9 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. She was 90.

title: A Cultural Divide on AIDS Research
description: An editorial in The New England Journal of Medicine this week was critical of AIDS research in Africa that studied the transmission of H.I.V. from pregnant women to their babies. In this research primarily financed by the United States, some of the infected women were given drugs in an effort to prevent that transmission, while others were given placebos. The journal's editorial likened the research to the infamous Tuskegee experiments, in which black men were denied proven treatment for syphilis.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a dispute over a dinosaur discovery in Montana misstated the resolution of criminal charges against a South Dakota fossil dealer, Peter L. Larson, who was involved in a separate dispute over a tyrannosaur fossil. He was convicted of failure to declare to the United States Customs Service money he had received in Japan and taken to Peru, but he was acquitted of money laundering. He served 18 months -- not one year -- of a two-year sentence.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Ted Turner's announcement that he was donating $1 billion to benefit United Nations agencies referred incorrectly in some copies to the professional sports team Mr. Turner owns. It is the Atlanta Braves baseball team, not the Atlanta Falcons football team.

title: The U.N., Cambodia And Patience
description: With the convening of the 52d United Nations General Assembly this week, the members must decide whether the United Nations will continue to honor its commitment to building a new Cambodia or whether it will unceremoniously abandon it. More narrowly cast, the Assembly has to determine who should be recognized to represent Cambodia at the United Nations: the government led by Hun Sen, the Second Prime Minister, who has been in control since a bloody coup in July, or the government led by the First Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who has been in exile since then.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SEX SHOP IS CLOSED

title: Long Drive Off Short Ferry Puts Commuter in the Bay
description: A woman drove off the Staten Island Ferry a moment too soon yesterday, knocking an off-duty deckhand overboard as her car plunged into the choppy waters of Upper New York Bay with the 270-foot-long boat less than 50 feet from the dock.

title: Myra T. Weiss, 80; Radical Who Ran Quixotic Campaigns
description: Myra Tanner Weiss, an unlikely Trotskyist whose radical vision of an egalitarian, collectivist society led her to organize migrant farm workers, rail against racism, make two quixotic mayoral races in Los Angeles and run for Vice President of the United States three times on the Socialist Workers Party ticket, died last Saturday at a nursing home in Indio, Calif. She was 80.

title: Furor Builds Over Sweatshop Exhibition
description: Another dispute has broken out in Washington over a museum exhibition that touches on a controversial subject, this time over whether a show on sweatshops can be presented in an objective manner.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday with a sports picture of the television commentator John Madden in the bus he uses to travel cross country misidentified the Green Bay Packers' opponent tomorrow. It is the Minnesota Vikings, not the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Judge Denies Sharpton Bid For Runoff
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected the Rev. Al Sharpton's bid for a runoff in the Democratic mayoral primary, but the judge unleashed a harsh attack on the city's Board of Elections for what he called its ineptitude in handling the Sept. 9 primary.

title: The Republican Court-Splitting Plan
description: Altering the Federal judicial system is not something to be undertaken lightly, or in a transparent effort to change the outcome of decisions. But just before Congress recessed in August, Senate Republicans approved an appropriations bill containing a rider that would split the Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in two. They did so without holding public hearings to review the merits of a proposal with profound implications for the independence and integrity of the judiciary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERABONA, MARIO, M.D.
description: CERABONA-Mario, M.D., passed away peacefully at Westchester Medical Center on September 19, 1997. Dr. Cerabona came to the U.S. from Naples, Italy in 1960 and practiced internal medicine for over 20 years serving Queens and Brooklyn. He is survived by his loving wife Caroline (Garofano) and 2 devoted sons Franco and Tom who have followed in their father's profession. He will always be cherished by his two daughterin-laws Susan and Roe and his grandchildren Matthew and Chloe. Reposing at Glendale WalshLabella & Son Funeral Home, 7017 Cooper Avenue, Glendale, N.Y. Mass of Christian burial Sacred Heart Church, 9:30 A.M., Monday. Entombment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting 2-5PM and 7-9 PM Sunday.

title: How a Group of Outsiders Moved Nations to Ban Land Mines
description: On the Sunday after Thanksgiving six years ago, a small group of political activists gathered in the faded Washington, D.C., offices of the Vietnam Veterans of America, troubled by the human devastation wrought by land mines.

title: Clinton Wins Round on B-2 Bomber's Fate
description: President Clinton, who has repeatedly argued that no more B-2 bombers should be built, won a victory on Capitol Hill today as House and Senate negotiators agreed to let him decide.

title: Suffolk Chief Proposes Property Tax Rise in $1.7 Billion Budget
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, proposed a $1.71 billion budget for 1998 today that would raise taxes for most residents because of higher police costs.

title: Gooden's Strong Pitching Not Enough
description: Joe Torre could not have asked for much more. Dwight Gooden, on the other hand, could have used a little run support.

title: Pay the Fine, Graciously
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani should be repentant rather than argumentative in the face of the $220,000 fine levied against his re-election campaign for accepting illegal contributions. Instead, his aides are savaging the Campaign Finance Board, which assessed the fine, claiming the board refused to seat the Mayor's new appointee. The Giuliani campaign says it is trying to decide whether to go to court to challenge the board's actions.

title: Elias Is Likely to Make the Devils
description: Patrik Elias, the Devils' young left wing who made a strong impression during the playoffs last spring, is a virtual lock to earn a spot on the opening day roster.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: World News Briefs; Koreans' Talks Stumble Over U.S. Troop Presence
description: The Administration's effort to negotiate a formal end to the Korean War collapsed today after North Korea insisted on linking the talks to a withdrawal of American troops in South Korea and more food aid, officials said.

title: Strollers in the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Indians Don't Dismiss Idea of Sovereignty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILLAR, SELMA
description: PILLAR-Selma. On September 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted mother of Dr. Robert, Richard and Dr. Charles. Loving mother-in-law of Marilyn, Marjorie & Ursula. Dear sister of Esther Laitman. Cherished grandmother af Amie, Ronald, Russell, Meredith, Matthew, Joanna, Laura and Ari. Adored great grandmother of Lauren, Jared and Carli. Services Sunday 2:00 PM, at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: All-Girls School Is in East Harlem's Best Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, LAURA
description: ROBBINS-Laura, 93, died peacefully on September 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving & loved mother of Michael and Benedict and daughters-in-law Lois and Ann Barbara; grandmother of Jeanie, Louis, Matthew, Elizabeth, Juli, Jil, Polly, and the late Daniel, great-grandmother of six. Sister of Sara Selis, Ben Neufeld, and the late Phillip Neufeld. Services for the family. Donations may be made to the Green Chimneys School, Brewster, NY 10509.

title: N.F.L.: WEEK 4
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Campaign Finance Inquiry Shifts Focus From Misdeeds to System
description: The chairman of the Senate committee investigating campaign-finance abuses abruptly changed course today, announcing that the panel would move its focus away from illegal activities to how political races are paid for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORST, RUTH
