description: FORST-Ruth. Beloved wife of Jerry, devoted mother of Barbara and Jeffrey Peters, Jeffrey Korman, Jimmy and Helene Korman, Stephen & Ellie and Robert Forst. Loving daughter of Harriet Littwin. Dear sister of Steven Littwin and the late Cookie Grossman. Adored grandmother of Charlee, Freddy and Sammy Peters; Blake & Miles Korman; Adam and Tyler Forst. Funeral service Sunday, 10:30AM, Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street, (between Lexington & Third Avenue), NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the ''Ruth Forst Memorial Scholarship Fund'' of Park East Synagogue.

title: Rough Riders Lose
description: For 89 minutes of yesterday's 90-minute game at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, N.Y., the Long Island Rough Riders and the Carolina Dynamo battled to a scoreless tie. Then Carolina broke through, Long Island's desperation defensive move failed and Carolina won, 1-0.

title: Hofstra Offense Getting the Job Done
description: In the eight seasons Joe Gardi has been its coach, Hofstra has always moved the ball, mostly by air. With Rob Spence back as the offensive coordinator of a run-and-shoot attack this season, the Flying Dutchmen (2-0) have piled up the yards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERCURIO, ANTOINETTE
description: MERCURIO-Antoinette. Devoted wife of the late Fortunato. Loving mother of John and Joseph Mercurio. Dear sister of Frank and Louis Pizzarello. Reposing at LeahyMcDonald Funeral Home, Atlantic Aveune at 111 Street, Richmond Hill. Mass on Monday 10:30 A.M., St. Benedict Joseph Labre Church. Visiting 2-4:30, 7-9 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, NORMAN DUDLEY
description: JOHNSON-Norman Dudley. The Allen-Stevenson School records with great sadness the death of Norman Dudley Johnson, an alumnus from the Class of 1922, father of Ridgely Couper Johnson '73 and Norman Platt Johnson '70, and former trustee of the School. Ronald S. Rolfe '60 President of the Board David R. Trower, Headmaster

title: B-1 Crashes In Montana: Another Blow For Pentagon
description: The Pentagon said tonight that yet another warplane had crashed, an Air Force B-1B bomber on a training mission that went down in the southeastern corner of Montana, killing all four crew members.

title: Translator-Free Investing
description: Any day now, the Securities and Exchange Commission will announce new rules intended to simplify language in prospectuses, those dense documents that millions of Americans routinely drop in the recycling bin because they can't understand them. Since a prospectus is the document that is supposed to tell would-be investors what they're investing in and what the potential risks are, this is good news.

title: Bridge
description: The 12th annual charity game for the Israel Cancer Research Fund was played on Wednesday night at Le Parker Meridien Hotel, 118 West 57th Street, Manhattan, and set two records. One was for the money raised, more than $40,000. And Selma Schlechter won the event for the third time, a remarkable achievement. Partnering Edith Sacks, she scored 64 percent, with Irma Schulman and Lee Greenstein second with 61.3 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Sept. 9 about the discovery of a gene that affects social behavior in mice omitted the name of the journal that published the study. It was Cell.

title: Big Board Reports a Drop In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Short interest is the number of open short sales that have not yet been bought back by the seller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, PHILLIP DAVID MARCUS
description: BROWN-Phillip David Marcus, on September 16, 1997. Born in San Francisco on December 23, 1959. An accomplished singer and actor based in New York. Beloved son of Geraldine Smith. Loving brother of Michael, Terrence and Eric. Loving brother-in-law to Charlotta Brown & devoted uncle to Micala Brown. Also survived by three aunts, two uncles, eleven cousins and long-time friends Regis Schultis and Deborah Long. Funeral services will be held at the Church of the Epiphany, 22nd Street and 2nd Avenue, Saturday, September 20, 1997, at 10:00AM. A memorial service is being planned.

title: Mexico Post Should Go to Hispanic American; Send a Career Diplomat
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Football
description: P.S.A.L.

title: Sports of The Times; Gators Begin Seeking Higher Gear
description: FLORIDA plays Tennessee today in the renewal of a bitter rivalry. But you don't feel the pull of the rivalry until you leave New York. There are too many layers of pro teams -- those Jets, those Giants. The Yankees, Mets, Knicks, Nets, Rangers, Islanders and Devils.

title: Businessman Gets Probation for Perjury
description: William D. Fugazy, a prominent New York businessman, has been sentenced to two years of probation for committing perjury during a bankruptcy proceeding.

title: Queens Prosecutor Seeks Death Penalty in 2d Case
description: The Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, announced yesterday that he would seek the death penalty for a Queens man charged with killing an off-duty New York City police officer and a businessman during a failed robbery last December.

title: Barbara Munk, Child Psychiatrist, Dies at 72
description: Dr. Barbara D. Munk, an expert in the psychiatry of adolescence who worked with mentally ill mothers and their vulnerable infant children, died on Sept. 12 at New York Hospital after a seven-year battle with cancer. She was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mexico Post Should Go to Hispanic American; Weld and Clean Needles
description: To the Editor:

title: Aim for Touch Gold Goes Beyond Pegasus
description: David Hofmans was reunited with his colt Touch Gold yesterday at the Meadowlands, where they will take a long stride tonight toward one and possibly two championships, and said: ''I'd like to win the Breeders' Cup Classic with him.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLERGET, REILAND, LINDA (LYN)
description: CLERGET - REILAND - Linda (Lyn), on September 19th, 1997. Beloved wife of Timothy. Dear daughter of Maxime and Muriel Clerget. Loving sister of Gerald Clerget and of Patty Agnello. Family will receive friends at Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway, at 232nd Street, Bronx, Sunday 2-4PM & 7-9PM, with religious services being held 3PM Sunday. Interment in Clarion, Iowa. Contributions to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY will be appreciated.

title: Planting a Garden Beyond 'The Rose'
description: When Amanda McBroom made her New York cabaret debut 14 years ago at the now defunct Freddy's Supper Club, the Los Angeles-based singer and songwriter was known primarily for having composed the title song for the movie ''The Rose.'' Since then, Ms. McBroom has returned regularly to Manhattan nightclubs, warming them with a gregarious West Coast style of cabaret that is by turns homey, theatrical, jazzy, soul-searching, sexy and comic.

title: College President to Resign
description: Two weeks after faculty members demanded his resignation, ''for undermining collegiality,'' the president of the College of New Jersey announced Thursday that he would step down on Jan. 1, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, ROBERT A.
description: McGUIRE-Robert A., September 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Gertrude and the late Eileen. Devoted father of Maureen Lloyd and her husband Richard, Terry McGuire and his wife Kate and Robert G McGuire and his wife Isabelle. Loving grandfather of Eileen, Margaret, Karin and Jeanine Lloyd and Jessica McGuire. Dear brother of Bernadette Flynn and her husband James, and John McGuire and his wife Eleanor, also Kay McGuire, wife of the late William. Friends may call at the Williams Funeral Home Inc, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx, on Sunday & Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday, St John's Church at 9:45 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to a favorite charity are requested.

title: Russia and De Beers In Accord on Diamonds
description: Russia's diamond-marketing agency, RAO Almazi Rossii-Sakha, has reached a two-year accord with De Beers/Centenary A.G. for $1.1 billion of uncut stones, resolving a yearlong dispute that roiled the diamond market. An accord on the sale of Russian gems would let the Central Selling Organization of De Beers re-establish its virtual monopoly on the wholesale trade and provide a lift to Russia's diamond industry.

title: Scalpers on Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COURT, DANIEL JUAN
description: COURT-Daniel Juan, of Yorktown Hgts., on Sept 18, 1997. Loving son of Daniel and Carol Court. Beloved brother of Erick. Stepbrother of Lucas, Jessi and Makenzie Smith. Stepson of Terri Court. Grandson of Juan and Mercedes Del Valle and Rod and Ann Court. Reposing Sat. and Sun. 2-4 and 7-9 PM Clark Funeral Home, Inc., Yorktown Heights, NY. Mass Monday 10 AM, New St. Patrick's Church, Yorktown. Interment Amawalk Cemetery, Yorktown. In lieu of flowers donations to the Daniel Court Scholarship Fund, C/O Yorktown High School, 2727 Crompond Rd., Yorktown Heights, N.Y. 10598.

title: Top Enlisted Soldier Faces Probable Trial in Sex Case
description: After reviewing the sexual misconduct case against the Army's highest-ranking enlisted soldier, a military hearing officer has recommended that Gene C. McKinney, Sergeant Major of the Army, be court-martialed on 22 charges of indecent assault, adultery and obstruction of justice, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BIFFER, SYLVIA
description: BIFFER-Sylvia. We are forever bound. No words can express the depth of my love and gratitude. Everything has become possible. Karen

title: Delay Expected In Nickel Project
description: Inco Ltd. said today that it would probably delay starting production at its giant Voisey's Bay nickel property for at least a year, until late 2000.

title: Restore the Ferry's Fare
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEMPNER, IVAN
description: KEMPNER-Ivan. 18 ELUL 5752. Loved, missed, remembered by his wife Arline and daughters Robbi, Juli and Lani.

title: All-Girls School Is in East Harlem's Best Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Art That Tweaks British Propriety
description: Visitors entering the new exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts are immediately confronted by perhaps Britain's most familiar artistic image of recent years: an enormous dead tiger shark floating in a glass-and-steel tank, staring blankly and eerily at nothing.

title: Energy Beyond The Goals Of Art
description: A telling comment by Nietzsche appears on the first page of the program for Complexions -- A Concept in Dance, which performed on Thursday night at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. ''We should consider each day lost on which we have not danced once,'' the quotation reads. And that was very much the spirit of the evening's five pieces, choreographed by Dwight Rhoden, a co-founder of the company with Desmond Richardson.

title: U.S. Boxers Find Tourney Is a Learning Experience
description: Gabriel Elizondo of San Antonio sat in a corner of an empty dressing room at the Commonwealth Convention Center this afternoon, crestfallen.

title: Man Held in One Assault And Linked to Others
description: A man believed to have sexually assaulted a number of women in Bensonhurst was arrested yesterday morning after one of his victims spotted him on the street, the police said.

title: A Clear-Eyed Romantic Bravely Faces the Truth
description: Since Hank Williams established the dominant model for problem-racked confession in country music 50 years ago, truth has been a muse and a deity for performers. Facing up to it and avoiding it become palpable issues.

title: INTERRA STOCK SOARS AMID TAKEOVER SPECULATION
description: The stock of Interra Financial Inc. rose 10 percent amid speculation the securities firm could be a takeover target. Interra, the parent of the brokers Dain Bosworth Inc. and Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc., rose $5.0625, to $54.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. ''They are a takeover candidate,'' said Steven Eisman, an analyst who covers securities firms for Oppenheimer & Company. The speculation came amid a rash of mergers in the securities industry this year. Neal St. Anthony, director of investor communications at the Minneapolis-based Interra, declined to comment.

title: Florida Bank Acquisition
description: The Bankunited Financial Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Consumer Savings Bancorp Inc., parent company of Consumers Savings Bank, for about $11 million in cash and stock. Bankunited said it expected the acquisition to strengthen its presence in Dade and Broward counties in Florida. Bankunited is a savings and loan holding company based here.

title: Manila Journal; People Power 2: A Sleeping Giant Is Awakened
description: Corazon C. Aquino, former President of the Philippines and champion of the ''people power'' uprising 11 years ago, sat in her car the other day and honked her horn.

title: Wears No Army Boots, But Does Call, 'Action!'
description: Action directors are usually macho men who bark orders on a movie set, intimidate actors and the crew, and are about as subtle as a Sherman tank.

title: Witness Says Clinton Aide Asked Him to Shred a Fax
description: An unemployed businessman from Florida testified today that a few days before last year's Presidential election, he was asked by Harold M. Ickes, then the top political officer in the White House, to donate $1.5 million to help President Clinton and then, a few hours later, to shred a fax that described the request.

title: Alaska's Oil Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Welsh Back Home Rule, but It's Close
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Tony Blair vowed Friday to press ahead with plans to give Wales its first assembly in nearly 600 years, but a razor-thin margin in the Welsh referendum cast serious doubt on the government's program of decentralizing political power across Britain.

title: First Store Is Padlocked Under Sex-Shop Law
description: City officials have padlocked their first store under an ordinance intended to restrict sex-related businesses, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: What Makes Ted Turner Give? Others' Examples.
description: A soaring stock market, the end of the cold war and the examples set by such disparate figures as Mother Teresa, Jacques Cousteau and Diana, the Princess of Wales, inspired Ted Turner to pledge as much as $1 billion over 10 years, but possibly less, to support United Nations programs.

title: PAYLESS SHOESOURCE TO BUY BACK $150 MILLION IN SHARES
description: Payless Shoesource Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back $150 million worth of stock, in its second big repurchase plan in a year. The company, a shoe retailer with 4,411 stores, has about 37.5 million shares outstanding. Shares of the company, which is based in Topeka, Kan., rose $1.3125 yesterday, to $63.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Earlier this month, the company completed another $150 million buyback program, purchasing 2.8 million shares at an average price of $53.50. The company said it would make sure that it can proceed with the buyback plan without violating tax laws that apply to companies that have been spun off in tax-free distributions.

title: Mexico Post Should Go to Hispanic American
description: To the Editor:

title: August Jobless Rate Fell To Its Lowest in 7 Years
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate fell to 5.2 percent in August, the lowest jobless rate in seven years, the state's Department of Labor said yesterday. The rate in July was 5.4 percent.

title: Westinghouse To Acquire 98 Radio Stations
description: In a deal that may complete both a corporate makeover and the consolidation of the radio industry, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the American Radio Systems Corporation for $1.6 billion in cash.

title: Irvine Apartment Deal
description: The Irvine Company said today that it planned to buy up to one million shares of the common stock of Irvine Apartment Communities Inc., an affiliate in which it already has a 58 percent stake. The purchase would be valued at more than $30 million, based on recent stock prices. Irvine, based here, is a privately held company engaged in developing the Irvine Ranch in Orange County, Calif.

title: Jailer and Jailed, Alone Together
description: An adage urges storytellers to write about what they know. Raymond Chandler followed this advice and wrote about the underside of Los Angeles. Martin Scorsese used the New York City of his childhood to make movies about gangsters. Now, Joe Brewster has made a movie about a place he knows well: the Brooklyn House of Detention.

title: Survivor Remembers Nothing
description: The sole survivor of the high-speed car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, three weeks ago told a French investigating judge today that he remembered nothing about the accident, an official familiar with the investigation said.

title: Beliefs
description: For years, religious leaders have lamented the absence of any major television series that took religious life and spiritual struggles seriously. The popular blend of therapeutic wisdom and supernatural gimmickry of ''Touched by an Angel'' and its knock-offs was not what they had in mind.

title: Trains Crash In London; 6 Are Killed, 170 Injured
description: A crowded passenger train collided with a freight train here today, killing 6 people, injuring 170 and raising renewed questions over the privatization of Britain's railways, which some experts contend has led to a serious deterioration in safety and service standards.

title: Home Depot Pays $87.5 Million For Not Promoting More Women
description: Home Depot, the home improvement discount chain accused of parking women behind cash registers instead of putting them on the sales floor and promoting them, agreed yesterday to pay an $87.5 million settlement and reform its assignment and promotion practices.

title: The Music Of Monk, Bent, Split And Floating
description: Jazz can be a wonderful mess of competing systems, and when the tenor saxophonist Teddy Edwards stepped up to play ''Straight, No Chaser,'' at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, one of those systems took over.

title: Wells Has Yet to Secure Spot in Playoff Rotation
description: Manager Joe Torre hopes that David Cone has a good start today, so that he can pencil in Cone and Andy Pettitte as the Yankees' starters for Games 1 and 2 of the playoffs, respectively.

title: China's Communists Announce New Top Lineup
description: China's top leadership announced a new hierarchy today, revealing a freshly tuned balance of power that favors President Jiang Zemin.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think, as probably many of you will know from the experience of family loss perhaps in your own lives, it is inevitably very difficult to cope with grief at any time. But perhaps you might realize it is even harder when the whole world is watching at the same time.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, JACK
description: ROSEMAN-Jack. Israel and Fenie Feit Family Circle mourn the loss of the father of our member Surella Feit.

title: Strip Clubs Under Siege as Salesman's Haven
description: In recent years, women have fought their way into male enclaves like private clubs and golf courses where business is discussed. But most still steer clear of another male bastion of business wheeling and dealing: the bars and restaurants where topless dancers gyrate across stages, swing around poles and cozy up to customers.

title: Jobless Rate at 7-Year Low
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate fell in August to 5.2 percent, the lowest jobless rate in seven years, the state's Department of Labor said yesterday. The rate in July was 5.4 percent.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on Thursday with a sports picture of Peyton Manning, the Tennessee quarterback, misstated the final score in a game against Florida last year. Florida won, 35-29, not, 62-37.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHAPIRA, ARTHUR
description: SCHAPIRA-Arthur. 1907-1996. One year has passed. I hope your soul is at peace. Ruth

title: Liberties; In Praise Of Girl Scouts
description: She had the look rare in Washington -- of someone who had never wanted to be on television.

title: Slime, Blood and Pluck
description: Along with plastic pumpkins and piles of candy corn, the advent of autumn has coughed up another harbinger of Halloween in the form of ''Wishmaster,'' which is equally hollow and loaded with empty cinematic calories.

title: Report on Foster Care Finds Lapses and Raises Questions
description: New York City caseworkers responsible for monitoring foster children often failed to evaluate the safety of the children's homes and arrange for medical exams in a timely fashion, and in many cases could not provide documentation of required monthly visits, according to a report released yesterday by the city's child welfare agency.

title: Mexican Drug Dealer Tried to Buy Way Out, General Says
description: Six months before his apparent death in July, the billionaire Mexican drug trafficker Amado Carrillo Fuentes sent his top lieutenant to negotiate with the Mexican Army for protection from prosecution, the country's disgraced former anti-drug chief, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, testified on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIS, ROSALIND B.
description: ELLIS-Rosalind B. On September 18, 1997 of White Plains, NY. Wife of Sanford Ellis. Mother of Kerry and Russ Ellis. Reposing Saturday (today) 6 PM-8 PM at Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave., Hawthorne, N.Y., where services will be held on Sunday at 12 noon. Interment Kensico Cemetery.

title: Sampras and Chang Master the Australians
description: The yellow jackets menaced, the horns honked, the sirens wailed, and some out-of-towners way up in the crammed bleachers kept waving Australian flags. But Pete Sampras and Michael Chang, the two hired guns who signed on with the United States Davis Cup team for this weekend's semifinal against Australia, were impervious to distractions today.

title: All-Girls School Is in East Harlem's Best Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: No Credit Where Credit Was Due
description: A few weeks ago, while I was on a shopping spree at Saks Fifth Avenue, the clerk told me I could get a 10 percent discount by opening a Saks charge account, so I filled out an application.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: The Moor, Condensed, Taut and Timeless
description: Actions spoke eloquently on Thursday night when Dance Theater of Harlem told good stories well at Aaron Davis Hall.

title: Geraldine Mindell, Garden Founder, 84
description: Geraldine Mindell, who led the campaign to create the Jefferson Market Garden, an oasis of more than 200 varieties of flowers, shrubs and trees in the heart of Greenwich Village, died on Monday. She was 84.

title: Adobe Systems Reports 79% Rise in Profits
description: Adobe Systems Inc. reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings yesterday on strong sales for its desktop publishing software for both the Windows and Macintosh operating systems.

title: Croatians Are Accused of Subverting the Peace Accords
description: The Croatian Government is being accused of subverting the Dayton peace accords, financing and essentially ruling the Croatian region of Bosnia, amassing millions of dollars in illicit profits, and helping to hide indicted war criminals, according to a confidential report.

title: Four Sections Today
description: This week The Times introduces its most sweeping improvements in more than 20 years. They include a four-part format on Saturdays:

title: Shipping Concern Alters Bid for Swedish Rival
description: Frontline Ltd., a shipping company in Oslo, said yesterday that it had changed its offer for ICB Shipping A.B. of Sweden to an all-cash bid in place of a previous stock-and-cash bid. ICB, though, said it still thought the offer undervalued the company and urged shareholders not to sell their shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ARTHUR
description: ROTH-Arthur. The trustees and officers of Long Island University mourn the death of our former Vice Chairman of the Board, Chairman of the Finance Committee and benefactor, whose memory is being honored by the establishment of a new Arthur Roth Scholarship Fund. David J. Steinberg, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALIBA, ESSIE
description: BALIBA-Essie. 9/18/97. Your adoring children Roberta and Jeff Friedman, Jackie Sheinberg and Jay Morganstern; devoted grandchildren Wendi, Gary, Elaine; Evan, Abby, Kenneth, and their father George Sheinberg, will miss the warmth of your generous spirit and loving presence. You will ever remain in the hearts of your sisters and brother-in-law, Ida Wexler, Miriam and Irving Logue. Your memory will be cherished by your nieces and nephews, and all their children. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY, at 11:30 AM, Sunday. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery.

title: N.B.A. Contract in Need Of Change, Stern Says
description: The labor peace that Commissioner David Stern worked so diligently to keep in the National Basketball Association two years ago may be threatened again as early as next spring.

title: SUIZA FOODS TO ACQUIRE COUNTRY FRESH FOR $135 MILLION
description: The Suiza Foods Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Country Fresh Inc., a dairy and juice maker, for stock worth about $97 million, based on Thursday's closing price, and the assumption of about $38 million in debt and preferred stock. The acquisition is Suiza's seventh purchase of a dairy business in the last year. Suiza will give closely held Country Fresh about 2.1 million of its shares. The stock closed yesterday at $50, up $3.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Country Fresh, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., operates eight processing and five distribution plants. Suiza, based in Dallas, has steadily added dairy businesses in the last year, besides buying a water-bottling company and 16 plastic bottle factories.

title: WELLSFORD TO ACQUIRE VALUE PROPERTY FOR $180 MILLION
description: Wellsford Real Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Value Property Trust for $180 million in cash and stock. Under the agreement, Wellsford, a real-estate investment company, will pay about $130 million in cash and will issue 3.35 million of its common shares. Each shareholder will receive $11.58 in cash and 0.2984 of a Wellsford common share for each share of Value Property, which is based in New Brunswick, N.J. Wellsford's shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $15.375, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Slaying Victim Backed Away From Fight, Witness Says
description: A man who prosecutors say was killed by an off-duty police officer in a fight over a parking space had a baseball bat in his hand but had backed away from his antagonists when he was shot, a witness testified today.

title: John C. Liebeskind, 62, Pioneer in Researching the Effects of Pain
description: John C. Liebeskind, a leading researcher in the study of pain and its relation to health, died on Sept. 8 in Los Angeles. He was 62 and lived here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, H. HANFORD, JR.
description: SMITH-H. Hanford, Jr., died suddenly on Sept. 16, 1997 at his home on Nantucket, MA. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane Cowles Smith, his devoted mother, Elizabeth E. Smith, his daughter, Lisa S. Cashin, his sons, H. Brooks Smith and H. Hanford Smith, III, and 5 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 20 at 10 A.M. at Brant Point Lighthouse, Nantucket. A reception in his memory will be held on Thursday, October 2, 1997 at noon at the River Club, 447 East 52nd Street, New York City, to which his friends are invited. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Addison Gallery of American Art, Phillips Academy, Andover, MA. 01810.

title: Teacher Skills Plan Revised
description: The Whitman administration proposed yesterday that teachers be required to update their skills every five years by receiving 100 hours of training. But unlike an earlier version of the plan, the revised proposal specifies that teachers who do not meet the requirement would not have their licenses suspended.

title: Public Funds Are Approved For Libertarian
description: A college professor running for governor of New Jersey on the Libertarian ticket was ruled eligible yesterday to receive matching campaign funds, the first time that a third-party candidate has qualified for state money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, MOLLY
description: SANDLER-Molly. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin; loving mother of Adele and Will; and affectionate grandmother and great-grandmother to several new generations; a beautiful spirit who sang throughout her life. We will miss you dearly.

title: Chelsea and 1,649 Other Freshmen Arrive at Stanford
description: Lucas Ryan was still getting used to his new dorm room and new friends at Stanford University here today when the President of the United States materialized in the hallway.

title: Battle of What May Be the West's Last Big Dam
description: Two years ago, the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund objected to a $700 million water diversion project planned for the Animas River here and proposed a $264 million alternative.

title: World News Briefs; Allies of Peru's President Take Over a TV Station
description: In a crackdown on press freedom in Peru, investors with close ties to President Alberto K. Fujimori today seized control of a Lima television station that had exposed Government wrongdoing.

title: At a Public School, Parents Rally With Money to Keep a Teacher
description: At first it seemed like an ordinary note from a New York City public school, innocently tucked in the fourth graders' backpacks when they arrived home Thursday afternoon.

title: Merger Plan By Audit Firms Puts Ex-Clients In a Quandary
description: As clients of two of the nation's largest accounting firms absorbed the news of a pending merger, perhaps nowhere is the consternation greater than at those companies that have recently switched from one firm to the other. Having chosen firmly between Coopers & Lybrand or Price Waterhouse, taking into account how much they charge, the personalities of the partners and their contrasting approach to looking over the books, these companies now find that decision undone.

title: A Stolen Monet For a Mere $5,000
description: A Manhattan pawnshop owner who tried to sell a stolen Monet painting for $5,000 was arrested on Tuesday, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Fans Not Going Crazy Over Cup Semifinal
description: In South America, they sing, bang drums and have been known to toss a few rocks. Here in North America, in our sophisticated capital, we are annoying our Davis Cup opponents with a few honking cars and prerecorded music by John Philip Sousa.

title: For Poles, Arms Deal Hid Political Mine Field
description: Two months after Poland was invited to join NATO, the Government is in an embarrassing storm over its plan to buy $700 million in weapons from Israel although an offer from Boeing would be more militarily compatible and pleasing to its new Western allies.

title: About New York; Ex-Addicts Blazing Trails For Scouts
description: IT'S a point of fact, not pride, when John Vislocki admits he pretty much did it all before arriving at the Phoenix House residence in Long Island City. He started getting high when he was 8, and he spent the next 24 years using and selling drugs. ''After a while, when my friends saw me coming down the street they all ran away,'' he said. ''That's how crazy I was.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Home Depot in Deal To Settle Sex Bias Suit

title: Wily Coaching Veteran Poses Test for the Giants
description: Bud Carson has been trying to bewilder and confuse offenses and quarterbacks in the National Football League for more than 25 years. The wily Carson, the defensive coordinator of the St. Louis Rams, will have concocted another sly plan for the Giants and Dave Brown Sunday when the teams meet in St. Louis.

title: PICTURETEL TO RESTATE RESULTS OF 3 QUARTERS
description: The Picturetel Corporation said yesterday that it would restate results from three quarters to lower its reported profit and revenue, after deciding to cancel or defer some revenue from leases of its video conferencing systems. The restatement adds to the company's financial woes. It reported a second-quarter loss and lower revenue because of unexpectedly soft demand and lower prices for video conferencing systems, and analysts expect it only to break even for the current quarter. Picturetel, which makes high-priced systems mainly for corporate customers, said the restatements would be for the third and fourth quarters of 1996 and the first quarter of 1997. Picturetel shares fell $1.3125, to $11.50, in trading of 1.2 million.

title: In New Deportation Process, No Time, or Room, for Error
description: An Albanian asylum seeker, whose lawyers believe she was gang-raped this spring in retaliation for her husband's refusal to fight for the Government, fled to the United States in May. Detained in Elizabeth, N.J., she failed to convince immigration officials that she had a good chance to win asylum and was deported in July under a new law designed to weed out groundless asylum claims.

title: Hotel to House the Elderly
description: Resolving a legal battle over the vacant Essex and Sussex Hotel, the Spring Lake Council approved a settlement Thursday that would allow developers to convert the grand 1914 structure into a luxury residence for the elderly.

title: RUSSIANS PASS BILL SHARPLY FAVORING ORTHODOX CHURCH
description: Defying Western objections that it was restricting religious freedom, Russia's Parliament today passed a bill that protects the Russian Orthodox Church from competition from other Christian denominations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN BEELEN, SYBIL GRACE (NEE ALEXANDER)
description: van BEELEN-Sybil Grace (nee Alexander). Died peacefully on August 29, 1997 after a short illness in Delray Beach, Florida. Born in London, England on September 5, 1903. She was widowed from Pieter van Beelen on June 4, 1990. Funeral services took place in Florida at Scobee-Ireland-Potter Funeral Home, Delray Beach, Florida. A memorial service is scheduled for Sunday, September 28, 1997 at 2 P.M. in St. George's Church, 209 East 16th Street, NYC, New York 10003. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. George's Church will be appreciated.

title: Eugene Lehner, 91, Violinist and Violist
description: Eugene Lehner, a violinist in the Boston Symphony Orchestra for 43 years and the violist in the Kolisch Quartet in the 1920's and 30's, died on Sept. 13 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 91.

title: 3 Executives Leave A.M.A. Over Sunbeam Endorsement
description: Three top managers of the American Medical Association left the organization yesterday, five weeks after they approved an ill-fated endorsement deal with the Sunbeam Corporation that raised a storm of protest over commercialism and conflicts of interest.

title: Steinbrenner Skeptical of Plan to Align Western Teams
description: The Super West that is coming in baseball's realignment does not have a fan in the owner of a super East team.

title: Kansas City Southern Plans To Split Off Financial Unit
description: Forsaking its railroad roots for a brighter future peddling mutual funds, Kansas City Southern Industries said yesterday that it would sell or spin off its storied railroad franchise to focus on its faster-growing financial services business.

title: Toughening the Tobacco Deal
description: President Clinton drew the right lines this week when he laid down the minimum conditions that any comprehensive deal with the tobacco industry must meet. Our only quibble would be that he may not have gone far enough.

title: Brazil's Football Family Feud
description: Brazil's World Cup fortunes once again seem to rest with its soccer legend, Pele. Now minister of sports, Pele has just given the Brazilian Congress a bill that would professionalize Brazilian soccer and fight corruption. But his countryman Joao Havelange, the head of FIFA, the international body that governs soccer, says that some of the changes run afoul of FIFA rules. Mr. Havelange threatens to bar Brazil, the defending champion, from next year's World Cup if the bill passes.

title: UNION CARBIDE SHARES FALL ON PROFIT WARNING
description: The stock of the Union Carbide Corporation dropped yesterday after the company, a chemical and plastics maker, said its third-quarter profits would be below Wall Street's expectations. Union Carbide, based in Danbury, Conn., cited the impact of higher raw materials prices and the impact of a strong dollar. A strong dollar makes money earned overseas worth less when translated back into dollars. Analysts surveyed by First Call Corporation had estimated profits of $1.34 a share in the quarter. Union Carbide did not specify a figure but said earnings would be above the $1.08 a share reported in the year-earlier period. Shares of Union Carbide fell $5, or 9 percent, to $48.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Finance Board Accepts Giuliani's Choice for Seat
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board yielded to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday and allowed his appointee to join the board, but a dispute still swirled around whether the Mayor had sought to push through the choice to discourage the panel from fining his re-election campaign.

title: FIGURE SKATING: An Olympic Dream Ages Gracefully; 30 Years After Winning Gold, Skating Team Wants to Return
description: It has been said that Oleg and Lyudmila Protopopov, the Olympic pairs champions in 1964 and 1968, performed with a brilliance that was not quite figure skating and not quite ballet, but more in the realm of poetry.

title: INSIDE
description: Teacher Is a Pet Project

title: As Pressure Builds, Gore Hires Lawyers To Help Him
description: With momentum building at the Justice Department for the appointment of a new independent counsel to investigate his campaign fund-raising practices, Vice President Al Gore has hired two former Watergate prosecutors in hopes of heading off the appointment -- or failing that -- to defend him.

title: Demonizing the I.R.S.; Is an Overhaul Needed, Or Just Less Posturing
description: For more than a decade, Ernest Kugler Jr. was locked in a struggle with the Internal Revenue Service over taxes the agency said he owed from his heating and cooling business.

title: Child Welfare Warnings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, MAUREEN DOWNEY
description: HARTMAN-Maureen Downey. 9/17/97 of Harrison, New York. Beloved wife of David Hartman. Loving mother of Sean, Brian, Bridget and Conor. Dear sister of Patrick Downey. The family will receive friends Sunday 5-8 P.M., at the Wm. H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye. It is at this time friends and relatives will have an opportunity to reflect and share our special feelings about Maureen. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of the Resurrection, Monday, 10 A.M. Interment private in Peoria, IL. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Stehlin Foundation for Cancer Research, 1315 Calhoun, Suite 1818, Houston, TX 77002.

title: Nelson Gross, Prominent State Republican, Is Missing
description: Nelson G. Gross, one of New Jersey's most prominent and powerful Republicans before a campaign fund-raising scandal toppled him a generation ago, has been missing since Wednesday morning, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Home Depot in Deal To Settle Sex Bias Suit

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACCARINO, JOE
description: YACCARINO-Joe. 2/5/19-9/20/96. You are the music in my life: opera, blues, jazz, ballads. Mulli and I miss you. Nancy

title: Stocks End Week Up, but the Day Down
description: Investors, soothed by new evidence that the economy is strong but not yet inflationary, sent stock and bond prices soaring this week to their largest gains in months.

title: Safe Driving Advocate Killed
description: A car struck and killed a man yesterday who had become a prominent advocate for tougher laws against drunken driving after his wife was killed in a car accident two years ago, the police said.

title: Vols Look To Get Past Stumbling Block
description: They do not make language extravagant enough for what will happen this weekend in the Swamp.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 10 about Richie Ashburn, the Hall of Fame center fielder, omitted his survivors. They were his mother, Genevieve Warner Ashburn; his wife, Herberta; three daughters, Jean Ashburn, Sue Ann Morrison and Karen Hall; two sons, Richard and John; a brother, Robert; a sister, Bette Cram, and nine grandchildren.

title: The Ballot Stops Here; The Chief of Elections Stands Up to a City's Disdain
description: This has not been a stellar week for Daniel DeFrancesco, the executive director of the Board of Elections, the city agency that is having an unhappy collision with the 1990's.

title: Jets Seek Some Advantage At Home Against Raiders
description: It happens every year to the Jets at least it has for most of this decade. There is a home game, and people wonder: just why can't they win in their own backyard?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, PETER W.
description: WHITE-Peter W. Of Bethesda, MD. On September 17, 1997 of cancer at age 45. Cherished husband of Carol Brotman White. Devoted father of Alexander and Jeremy. Beloved son of F. Warren White and brother of Amy Morgan and Thomas White of Greenwich, CT. Memorial services Wednesday, September 24th, 11AM, First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich and a later one in Bethesda.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WALKING MAIN STREET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTER, MARY F. (NEE PEARSON)
description: PORTER-Mary F. (nee Pearson), on Friday, September 19, 1997, in Arlington, Virginia. Wife of the late Clifford L. Porter; mother of Lynn Schnepper (Howard), Lee Porter and Mary Porter; grandmother of Jane Lustig (William), John Bodman (Anne), Ann Bodman, and Carrie Bodman (Jason Lind); great-grandmother to Kylie Lustig and Maizy Lind; gracious friend to Howard's children. A memorial service will be held in Port Washington, N.Y., at Saint Stephen's Episcopal Church, on Saturday, October 25, 1997. Donations in her memory may be made to the Hospice of Northern Virginia, 6400 Arlington Boulevard, Suite 1000, Falls Church, VA. 22042.

title: Pittsburgh at Progress Crossroads
description: This is no ordinary mining machine and no ordinary building where scientists are tinkering with it.

title: Parental Involvement Makes Better Students; 'Sentimental' Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: The Last Print of Summer
description: Army camouflage is proving the main ingredient with trend setters in the East Village and SoHo. Cargo pants and long skirts made from the familiar olive green, black and sand pattern are mixed with skimpy tops for late summer days. A camouflage print denim jacket worn with a fringe wrap shawl-skirt, left, shows originality. His camouflage trousers and her camouflage T-shirt with slip skirt, top far left, are a good match. And a camouflage skirt with leopard print sweater and apple-green backpack, below left, are an inspired combination.

title: Ms. Moxon, Mr. Kirshenbaum
description: Rosamond Adelaide Moxon, a daughter of Elizabeth Chiang Moxon of Tainan, Taiwan, and John S. Moxon of Oley, Pa., was married last evening to Michael Sobel Kirshenbaum, the son of Myrna Baxter of New York and the late Jordan Kirshenbaum. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at Le Cirque 2000 in New York.

title: On Wide Screen, Everybody's Back in the Action
description: WHEN ROBERT ZEMECKIS'S ''Back to the Future Part II'' was being turned from a rectangle to a square during its transfer to videotape, an odd thing happened to Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox) -- actually to two Marty McFlys. Encountering an incarnation of himself in a restaurant, one McFly avoids the other by ducking behind the counter, with each of them ending up at the extreme right and left edges of the shot, respectively.

title: Jane von Mehren, Kenneth Diamond
description: Jane von Mehren, a publishing executive, was married yesterday to Kenneth Seth Diamond, a graphic designer. Arthur T. von Mehren, an uncle of the bride and a civil marriage celebrant, officiated at the Chilmark, Mass., house of the bride's father, Robert B. von Mehren, and stepmother, Susan Heller Anderson, of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, MOLLIE
description: FISHMAN-Mollie, 98 years on September 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abe. Devoted mother of Bob and Claire and mother-inlaw of Sylvia. Loving grandmother of Ellen and Miriam and Cheryl and Michael. Also survived by six loving great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEYER, MURRAY P.
description: MEYER-Murray P. Sept. 21, 1986. Lovingly remembered today and always. Lucille Ruby, Phyllis, Laurence

title: The Travels and Travails of Michael Palin
description: MICHAEL PALIN is the only 54-year-old joining the freshman run at the University of Otago, in Dunedin, New Zealand. Too late, he learns that this is no ordinary jog. Soon he and the freshmen are waist-deep in water, and upperclassmen are pelting them with eggs and flour. Luckily, Mr. Palin says, he knows how to handle such situations. ''Having had the benefits of an English public school education,'' he explains, ''I understand pain and pointless exercise.''

title: Bavarian Cuisine Transformed
description: GERMANY'S days as a Wirt schaftswunder, or economic miracle, may be over, but the interest in good, increasingly bold cooking that prosperity encouraged lives on. Foreign travel and small restaurants run by Italians, Turks, Spaniards, Yugoslavs and Greeks have banished bland from most German tables.

title: Modern Mann
description: SIX EARLY STORIES By Thomas Mann. Edited by Burton Pike. Translated by Peter Constantine. 128 pp. Los Angeles: Sun and Moon Press. $22.95.

title: Ms. Fitzgibbons And Mr. Smith
description: Caroline Mitchell Fitzgibbons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Fitzgibbons of New London, N.H., was married last evening to Thomas Sidney Smith Jr., a son of Carolyn S. Smith and Thomas S. Smith, both of Denver. The Rev. George S. Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: At Cummins Engine, a Purr Instead of a Rattle
description: SINCE the late 1970's, the Cummins Engine Company has usually had the dubious distinction of being more intriguing to students of business than to investors. Its struggle to hang on to leadership of the diesel-engine industry led to a classic price war with Japanese rivals in the 1980's. Then Cummins was caught napping by the Detroit Diesel Corporation, the lethargic subsidiary of General Motors that became an aggressive competitor once it was sold to Roger Penske, the former race-car driver.

title: Word for Word/The National Smokers Alliance; Got a Light? How About The Flame of Freedom?
description: WITH the people's blood up over smoking, tobacco advocates seem to comment in public only when they really have to -- like last week when the industry balked at President Clinton's tougher new terms for a liability settlement. Maybe tobacco executives figure that after all those damaging Congressional hearings, it doesn't help to speak up if you leave many people with the impression that your nose just might begin to grow very long.

title: Getting Opal Caples to Work
description: I was disappointed that Jason DeParle failed to mention what to me is the quintessential problem with the philosophy behind the new welfare reforms: That is, the refusal among many politicians and policy makers to recognize that motherhood is work, critical work, and that women who are the mothers of young children need to be able to choose to do that work if and when they please (''Getting Opal Caples to Work,'' Aug. 24).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOIS, HARRY JOSEPH
description: LOIS-Harry Joseph. 9/5/58-9/21/78. Our love for him deepens; our sadness remains unbearable. Rosemary, Luke & George Lois

title: Out on a Limb
description: Wearing a suit should be a kind of adventure, not a dull, workaday experience. To help dramatize that point, our fashion escapade is set in the mysterious Lava Beds National Monument in Northern California.

title: The Lobbyist; Is Richard Lipsky Battling for the Little Guy? Or Is He Just Gumming Up the Works
description: THE hallelujahs from City Hall and the State Capitol were almost audible. After years of bitter contention over whether to build a new Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem, Mayor Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki were scheduled to break ground at the 125th Street site in late August.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTENHEIMER, DR. LILLY
description: OTTENHEIMER-Dr. Lilly. In loving memory of a most extraordinary, courageous and supremely civilized lady. She was a brilliant psychoanalyst who practiced with great artistry and affection, a model to her many patients and a mentor to generations of students. We shall miss her very much. June and Wally Davison

title: Yes, Virginia, a Thousand Times Yes
description: IT was exactly 100 years ago today when The New York Sun responded to the plaintive inquiry of Virginia O'Hanlon, an 8-year-old whose ''little friends'' had told her the unthinkable when she returned to school that fall. ''Please tell me the truth,'' Virginia wrote at the urging of her father, a New York City police surgeon and deputy coroner. ''Is there a Santa Claus?''

title: Jets' Blueprint for Success Is to Give a Little and Take a Lot
description: Are the Jets emerging from one of the worst 40-game stretches in the history of pro football?

title: Up in the Old Hotel
description: The Mirror

title: Right Bus at the Right Time but It's Covered in Vinyl and Free
description: ROY ALEXANDER of Eastchester received a surprise on a recent afternoon as he waited for the Route 40 bus to take him to Westchester Community College in Valhalla, where he is studying food service management. The bus arrived at the White Plains Transportation Center at the right place and time, but it looked different.

title: Marissa Lubin, Robert Trimarchi
description: Marissa Dawn Lubin, the daugher of Sharon and Alan Lubin of Clifton Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Vincent Trimarchi, a son of Barbara and Charles Trimarchi of Colonie, N.Y. The Rev. James Hayes, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Ari Alpern at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Here's Food for Thought ; Cutting Waste Can Be a Waste
description: YOU'VE probably always suspected that Vice President Al Gore was a charter member of the Clean Plate Club -- that when his mom warned that every lima bean ending up in the garbage was a lima bean less for the starving children of Africa or Appalachia, little Al took it to heart. Now there's proof.

title: Some Second Thoughts On Options
description: WHAT could possibly be wrong with stock options?

title: The World; Disunited Kingdom
description: GOADED by the modernizing passion of Prime Minister Tony Blair, Britain has embarked on a program of constitutional reform -- of basic change in the structure of the country and its government -- that has no parallel in this century. The question is this: Will it create a more nimble, more efficient system, closer to the people, or will it create more layers of bureaucracy and lead to a Disunited Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland?

title: September 14-20; Weld Says Good Riddance To Helms and the Capital
description: William F. Weld, the former Governor of Massachusetts, dropped his bid for the Ambassadorship to Mexico and left Washington, dripping with scorn for the capital and for Senator Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee who blocked his nomination.

title: THEATER; 'Author! Author! May We Make a Suggestion?'
description: WHEN IT COMES TO THEATER, everyone's a play doctor. What member of the paying audience does not feel perfectly justified in firing off unsolicited advice to the hapless playwright, and anyone else involved in a production? Herewith, some fanciful notes and letters proffering unasked-for help.

title: Movie Magic
description: AMONG the highlights of her childhood, Helen Vaspoli remembers riding the elevator to the 13th floor of the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotel for lectures, musicals and movies in the Viking Theater.

title: The Morgan Spirit
description: To the Editor: My father, Harry Carter, was the proud owner of a 1966 British racing green Morgan Plus 4. He was also president emeritus of the 3/4 Morgan Group Ltd. He edited The Morganeer. He knew (and made up) Morgan lore like a genuine fanatic.

title: ON THE MAP ; A First-Aid Station That Faces an Emergency of Its Own
description: On a side street off Spring Lake's commercial avenue stands an unimposing red-brick, Tudor-style building, the headquarters of the town's First Aid Squad. Most histories of the town include a picture of the structure, whose occupants have aided victims of the Morro Castle shipwreck in 1934 and the Hindenburg disaster in 1937. These days, they make close to 400 emergency calls a year.

title: Corinne Cantrall and James Patten
description: Corinne Christine Cantrall, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cantrall of Santa Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to James Hughes Patten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Patten of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas M. Richard performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church on Nantucket, Mass.

title: CHATTER ; School Dress Codes
description: Asked their opinions on dress codes for public schools, many correspondents took that to mean uniforms, as one of them comments.

title: Siege of 163d Street: Police Take Over Drug-Ridden Block to Save It
description: Crossed arms and uneasy glances met Police Officer Miguel Adorno as he began his pitch. Women interrupted him and old men shook their heads. But such suspicion did not deter him as he urged residents of the drug-worn block to take a stand against the dealers and violence that for years have been its standard.

title: How the Biggest Investors Are Forcing the Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Arnold and Brett Sylver
description: ''YOU got to do what you got to do'' is Nancy Arnold's motto.

description: To The Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILLAR, SELMA
description: PILLAR-Selma. On September 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted mother of Dr. Robert, Richard and Dr. Charles. Loving mother-in-law of Marilyn, Marjorie & Ursula. Dear sister of Esther Laitman. Cherished grandmother af Amie, Ronald, Russell, Meredith, Matthew, Joanna, Laura and Ari. Adored great grandmother of Lauren, Jared and Carli. Services Sunday 2:00 PM, at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Listen to 'Them!'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Connoisseur's Tour de France
description: It's not too late to sign up for an unusual, if somewhat costly, trip to France, with the Friends of Vieilles Maisons Francaises, a group that restores historical houses. Participants in the tour, which begins on Oct. 15, will spend four nights in Paris at either the Crillon or the George V and dine in courtly style in the Orangerie at Versailles after the public has left the grounds on a meal prepared by Michel Troisgros. Other highlights include a reception at the Elysee Palace, the residence of Jacques Chirac, the President of France, and visits to the Gobelins tapestry factory, the Flag Restoration Atelier of the Invalides, the Sevres Museum and workshops of the newly completed Viaduc des Arts near the Bastille. Outside Paris, participants will have lunch in the Champagne region, followed by a guided tour of Reims Cathedral and dinner at the 16th-century Chateau de Conde.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 21, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Evanne Salomon, E. J. Gargiulo Jr.
description: Evanne Barnes Salomon, a daughter of Christie Calder Salomon of Greenwich, Conn., and Richard E. Salomon of New York, was married yesterday in Newport, R.I., to Edward Joseph Gargiulo Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gargiulo Sr. of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Neely P. Towe, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Charles F. Gilley, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Newport Congregational Church.

title: A New Figure Steps Up to Westfield's Podium
description: WHEN word went out that the 14-year-old Westfield Symphony Orchestra was seeking a new music director, the board of trustees was astonished to receive 100 resumes. As the list was narrowed, the choice became harder; in the end, the job went to the English-born David Wroe, who makes his first public appearance in the post at Saturday's concert.

title: 'Terrific' Amenity
description: To the Editor: On a recent trip to the Lombardy Lakes of Northern Italy, large amounts of acqua minerale (frizzante) made rest stops imperative.

title: Commissioner Faults Union Square Coverage
description: To the Editor:

description: The Starlite Drive-in

title: Maria Manganaris-Decavalles And David A. Powar
description: Maria Daphne Manganaris-Decavalles, a daughter of Kalliope and Dr. Andonis Manganaris-Decavalles of Madison, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Alan Powar, the son of Susan and Lee Powar of Moreland Hills, Ohio. Judge George Kopita Sr. of the Dover (N.J.) Municipal Court performed the ceremony at the Mansion at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: Hitler's Legacy
description: THE BEAST REAWAKENS

title: Number of Cars Is Growing Faster Than Human Population
description: They are bigger, stronger and faster than the last generation. They come to this country from all over the world, they live longer and healthier lives, and they fill the cities, suburbs and countryside, quicker than anyone had imagined.

title: Since the Crossing, It's Amazing How Fitz Has Changed
description: GERRY (FITZ) FITZGERALD, the central character of the gritty British crime series ''Cracker,'' is a brilliant criminal psychologist who smokes and drinks too much, can be callous to family and co-workers and, as embodied by the actor Robbie Coltrane, could stand to shed a few pounds. Fitz is also one of the most popular characters on British television.

title: Superfund Cleanup Plan Irks Sag Harbor
description: IT is 14 years since a plume of toxic chemicals was found in wells near a manufacturing plant south of Sag Harbor, and it is 10 years since the site was placed on the the Superfund list for a cleanup.

title: Slowing the Pace at a Scarsdale Trattoria
description: TRAFFIC commands the course of Central Avenue, hastening shoppers from store to store. But one strip in Scarsdale slows the pace, encouraging an alternative shopping mode. Those on foot will encounter Rustico, a lively and charming trattoria, filled with animated patrons blithely ignoring the din as they dine alfresco, or, almost so, through the open front.

title: Cruise Passengers Return With the Flu
description: The cruise ship Westerdam, with 1,500 people aboard, docked in New York City yesterday, unloading about 100 wheezing, coughing and feverish passengers and crew members as Federal health officials looked on.

title: Don't Make Gore the Fall Guy
description: I have publicly supported those who have called for Attorney General Janet Reno to appoint an independent counsel to investigate the campaign donations intended for the 1996 Presidential campaigns.

title: Miss Sacerdote, Mr. Brockelman
description: Alisa Ann Sacerdote, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Sacerdote of New York, was married yesterday to Curtis Francis Brockelman Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brockelman of Waccabuc, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas M. Richard performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church on Nantucket, Mass.

title: Heating Up the Ovens for the Country Fair
description: ANNA MARIE CWIKLA, 32, moves about her mother's kitchen in Lebanon with a familiarity that reveals she has grown up in this room with its dark pine cabinets and well-worn carpeting. She is baking a tropical chiffon cake in the hope of capturing yet another blue ribbon at the Lebanon Country Fair.

title: Airline Tickets As Presents
description: AN airline ticket makes a welcome gift and a cost-free one at that if financed by frequent flier miles. A journalists' organization often asks its members to provide travel to an annual seminar in the Far West for younger members for whom a $500 air ticket constitutes a hopeless barrier.

title: Elizabeth Silverberg, Kenneth Dinitz
description: Elizabeth Ann Silverberg and Kenneth Samuel Dinitz were married in a two-part ceremony yesterday at the Lewis Farm on Block Island, R.I. The Rev. Betsy Spaulding, a Unitarian Universalist minister, presided in the afternoon; Cantor Richard Weisbroat performed a traditional Jewish ceremony that evening.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 5/

title: September 14-20; Empty Nest in the White House
description: Bill and Hillary Clinton aren't scheduled to move out of the White House for three more years, but Chelsea left last week. Her things packed into Air Force One, she flew to California to begin college at Stanford University.

title: INQUIRY HEATS UP AS RENO EXAMINES PRESIDENT'S CALLS
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has opened a formal inquiry into whether President Clinton illegally solicited campaign contributions in telephone calls from the White House last year, the Justice Department said today.

title: Canucks' Messier Is Moving On as He Settles In
description: Beneath the famous forehead of Mark Messier are those flashing dark eyes, fixed in their familiar glaring stare. His mouth is obscured by the top edge of a newspaper, but there is no doubt about the identity of the recent arrival.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Super Foodstores Growing in Size and Diversity
description: THE $5 million Waldbaum's supermarket scheduled to open here this weekend is, at 64,400 square feet, a bit more than twice the size of the store it replaces.

title: Messinger Begins Race Against Giuliani
description: Finally unburdened of Democratic challengers, Ruth W. Messinger set out yesterday on her six-week quest to unseat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, revisiting one of her favorite campaign stops, the Greenmarket in Union Square, where she hunted for votes amid the stalls of multicolored legumes.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Jamaica Estates, Queens; An Enclave That Treasures Its Trees
description: THE first thing that strikes a visitor to the enclave in eastern Queens that is Jamaica Estates is its hilly streets lined by huge oak, maple, elm and chestnut trees.

title: Accusations Flying Over the Generations
description: IT is better than an hour of Oprah Winfrey, Sally Jessy Raphael or all those other overpaid purveyors of the tell-all genre, with their spotlights on the dysfunctional.

title: Lives; Tales of a Lingerie Saleswoman
description: I sold underwear for a living -- women's lingerie. I did so for more than 10 years, in shops on Madison, Fifth and Lexington. It was not what I had envisioned doing. Still, lingerie has always appealed to me. At 14 I spent my first paycheck on a flimsy lilac concoction with big, puffy sleeves, made of transparent polyester. Pretty awful. Needless to say, my taste has improved. Now my dresser is stuffed with lace bras (full cup and demi-), G-strings, garter belts, stockings -- all the lingerie that a woman could ever hope to own, or that a man could dream of removing.

title: Father, Sure. But Dancer? In His Dreams.
description: For seven years, Gregory Hines has been on a hunt for the perfect job.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; James Joyce Meets the Brothers Grimm
description: The ''I'' of AN IRISH EYE (Viking, $22.95) is a 13-year-old orphan named Dervla O'Shannon, whose vaguely incredulous narrative voice is John Hawkes's sharpest success in this, his 16th novel. Readers, too, will be left somewhat incredulous that Hawkes is able to sustain the unique tilt of Dervla's speech for over 150 pages without veering into preciousness -- or, for that matter, taking a breath. Dervla's story rushes out in a headlong stream that, even accounting for her impetuous age, occasionally feels like James Joyce doing the brothers Grimm. The result is an engaging blend of genres and literary traditions -- from fairy tale to farce to the epistolary novel -- that ultimately becomes a kind of post-modern picaresque. Dervla's adventures begin when her delegation from St. Martha's Home for Foundling Girls troops over to the neighboring St. Clement's Home for Old Soldiers. There she meets the proud Corporal Stack, aging horseman and World War I veteran, and begins an improbable romance. Stack is somehow able to spring them both from captivity, but after ominously promising that ''I'll not lay a hand on you until you reach 16 years of age,'' he is promptly trampled when they are overtaken by a fox hunt. He disappears into convalescence at a decrepit manor house, where the mistress in charge (who is 16) dotes on him and enslaves Dervla. Yet her voice loses none of its resolve, deftly ushering readers through Hawkes's bizarre world -- and proving, in the process, that his ear is as good as his eye. Liam Callanan

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BLOOMSBURY PIE

title: Getting Opal Caples to Work
description: True, every capable person should work, but the problems lie in the system's inability to place underskilled workers in an increasingly high-tech economy.

title: Habitats/240 East 82d Street; A Home of Her Own
description: ADRIANNE SAMUEL said she had been through it all: roommates who suddenly brought in their girlfriends, roommates who suddenly decided to learn to play the saxophone, landlords who suddenly decided they wanted their apartment back. She has lived in walkups and nonwalkups. She has moved back with her father. She has moved to San Francisco. She has moved to New Jersey and back to Manhattan. But she has never had a place of her own -- until now.

title: September 14-20; A Treaty Bans Land Mines
description: The United States may be the world's only superpower, but last week it was defeated in Oslo by a coalition of nonprofit groups that pressured more than 100 countries into approving a treaty banning the use of anti-personnel land mines.

title: Thank God You Have a Roof Overhead
description: ''JUST be thankful we have a roof over our heads,'' my mother used to say whenever I complained about some childish deprivation. This made no sense to me at the time. Having a roof was nothing to be thankful for, it was part of the natural order of things. Without a roof over our heads, we would be wide open to rain, bird droppings and falling meteorites.

title: Romper Rooms
description: For William Diamond and Anthony Baratta, more is more. The partners in the New York firm of Diamond Baratta Design are known for interiors that combine relentlessly cheerful colors and multitudes of patterns. Most of the time, their work tends toward the traditional, for clients who have big houses and budgets to match -- and who aren't interested in anything edgy. We do so many 12,000-square-foot houses, and they're so serious, says Diamond.

title: Nicola Belzer, Bradley Korn
description: Nicola Alys Belzer, the daughter of Sheila Stein of Forest Hills, Queens, and Sheldon A. Belzer of Manhattan, was married on Friday to Bradley Allen Korn, a son of Ruth and Seymour Korn of Valley Cottage, N.Y. Rabbi Eli Greenblatt performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: September 14-20; And I Say It's Still Broccoli
description: In broccoli, it seems, as in Hollywood, fashion, football and . . . everything else, youth has its advantages. Researchers at Johns Hopkins University have found that three-day-old broccoli sprouts are 30 to 50 times richer in powerful anti-cancer compounds than mature broccoli heads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALAKOFF, NORMAN
description: MALAKOFF-Norman, 67, of Kingston, NY, an associate with the International Group, died September 19, 1997. Husband of Alberta, father of Jeffrey and Ilene, son of Murray and Sylvia Malakoff. Donations to the American Cancer Society, 159 Green St., Kingston, NY 12401. For information, contact Simpson-Gaus Funeral Home, Kingston, NY.

title: Fuel's Paradise
description: The Fusion Quest

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: ON-LINE PLANNING

title: The Stealth Chancellor
description: Those in charge of the New York schools keep searching for methods and programs to make the educational system work better for children. However, I think there has to be a change in the mind-set of all involved in order to achieve reform.

title: Bill Clinton's Garbage Man
description: On Jan. 20 of this year, Harold Ickes left his job at the White House and returned to private life. He had been fired on short notice from his job as President Clinton's deputy chief of staff and was not fully prepared for the ordeal of departure. Just getting out of the White House takes four or five hours, even for a man who dismisses red tape with obscenities as often and as gustily as Harold Ickes does. You must pay off your debts at the White House mess, return your cell phone, fill out forms, submit to security debriefings. But for Ickes the departure was especially arduous; he left with more baggage than most.

title: A Whitman Man's Views On the Politics of Women
description: When you're paid to represent one of the most powerful women in Republican politics, taking gratuitous and critical shots at female conservatives might seem unwise.

title: Philippine President Promises Not to Run
description: Bowing to public pressure, President Fidel V. Ramos promised today that he would not run for re-election next year. But organizers of a major rally Sunday said they would proceed anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAVLIK, MARGARET
description: PAVLIK-Margaret. On September 11, 1997 of North Brunswick, New Jersey. Beloved wife of Andrew J. Pavlik. Devoted mother of John A. Pavlik. Loving mother-in-law of Claribel. She is much missed.

title: '100 Years' and Counting A Fledgling Named Cent'anni
description: IF I were going back to Cent'anni, I would begin my evening at the comfortable U-shaped bar. How many bars, after all, offer privacy, comfort and French doors that open onto the street during Indian summer? I might then order the perfectly drinkable house merlot or, if I were more ambitious, Antinori's Peppoli Chianti, a full-bodied, flavorful red reasonably priced at $35.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERCURIO, ANTOINETTE
description: MERCURIO-Antoinette. Devoted wife of the late Fortunato. Loving mother of John and Joseph Mercurio. Dear sister of Frank and Louis Pizzarello. Reposing at LeahyMcDonald Funeral Home, Atlantic Aveune at 111 Street, Richmond Hill. Mass on Monday 10:30 A.M., St. Benedict Joseph Labre Church. Visiting 2-4:30, 7-9 P.M.

title: Dvorak, Back Home at Last
description: Until recently, Richard Bliss has always sat in the western portion of Stuyvesant Square Park. But last Sunday he took a seat in the northeast corner to enjoy an emotional state that matched his name.

title: Philadelphia Story
description: Man on the Flying Trapeze

title: Food; By Ginger!
description: Fresh ginger is a mother lode of exotica, as fundamental to the Asian kitchen as onion is to European cuisine. Often called ginger root, ginger is actually a rhizome, a tuberlike stem that grows underground in the shape of a gnarled hand. In some cultures a recipe might call for a finger from a hand of ginger. A stunning commandment when you stop to think about it.

title: Revisionist History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEGGIE, ROSE (NEE TENKE)
description: HEGGIE-Rose (nee Tenke), 91. Died peacefully September 20 at Britthaven of Chapel Hill, NC, where she had resided since 1994. The widow of John S. Heggie and mother of the late Dr. John F. Heggie. She is survived by her two loving daughters, Marilyn DeLalio of Fearrington Village, NC, formerly of Laurel Hollow, NY, and Anne Warnes of Durham, NC, formerly of Manhasset, NY. Other survivors include two sisters, Margaret Lisberg of Glen Head and Elizabeth Wilken of Bayville, and a brother, John Tenke of Bayville, ten grandchildren, six great-grandchildren and one great-great grandchild. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Tuesday, September 23, 9:30 AM, at St. Dominic's Chapel, Oyster Bay, NY, with interment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale. Visiting hours Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Francis P. Devine Funeral Home, Oyster Bay, NY. Donations to the National Endowment for the Arts, Washington, DC.

title: Katharine Allen, Paul Sisson
description: Katharine Mulford Allen, a daughter of Ann P. Roberts of New York and James H. Allen of Tiburon, Calif., was married yesterday to Paul Charles Sisson, a son of Jean A. Sisson of London and the late John H. Sisson. The Rev. Dr. John T. Ames performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: 'Neglected Stories'
description: To the Editor:

title: Nitric Oxide Therapy Used to Save Babies
description: AT 2 A.M., the neonatal fellow at Schneider Children's Hospital of Long Island Jewish Medical Center received a phone call that a newborn baby at a nearby hospital was in respiratory distress. He phoned the attending physician on call and they agreed to accept the case. Within 30 minutes, the nursing and respiratory therapy staff left Schneider Children's Hospital to pick up the baby, Rayne Rivers.

title: The Characters Have New Clothes
description: It's not as if every writer has the compulsion to drop names throughout prose with the fervor of Judith Krantz. But the designer-addled 1990's have forced today's would-be Fitzgeralds to be students of fashion. At the very least, an Armani reference placed properly can do a lot of quick character development work. Budd Schulberg, for example, might not have taken pages to evoke his Hollywood honcho in ''What Makes Sammy Run?'' But the result might not have been as eloquent.

title: The Ape Who Mistook Himself for a Man
description: Great Apes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENNON, REV. JOSEPH L.
description: LENNON-Rev. Joseph L. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the retired Air Force chaplain on September 19. Reposing at Boyd-Caratozzolo Funeral Home, 1785 Deer Park Avenue, Deer Park, Long Island, Sunday, September 21, from 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass in SS. Cyril and Methodius Church, 125 Half Hollow Road, Deer Park, Monday, September 22 at 10:15 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: A 'Mad Max' World Of Sleek Armor
description: FROM spike-heeled boots to shiny silver belts, this is a metal moment. Not since the futuristic 1960's has such a steely glint run through fashion. Although the metallic look may have started at the outer rim of style, it is now at its hub.

title: Amid the Cheers After AIDS Ride, Costs Are Faulted
description: More than 3,000 hot, extremely tired people pulled into Chelsea last Sunday after the three-day, 250-mile Boston to New York AIDS Ride. But amid the cheers and tears of those who turned out for the closing rally on Eighth Avenue were voices of criticism.

title: Correction
description: The View column on Sept. 7, from Yonkers, about hawk watching at Lenoir Preserve, misstated the date of Hawk Day. It is next Saturday at 10 A.M., not Oct. 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, THOMAS GIBSON
description: SHEA-Thomas Gibson. Of Greenwich, CT. Died on September 19, 1997 while undergoing treatment for leukemia at 59. Much loved husband of Mary Anne, father of Cara, Sally, Thomas Jr. and Cynthia, and brother of Sara Tyce and Terrence. Memorial service, Tuesday, September 23, 10 AM, St. Michael's Church, North Street, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Yale-New Haven Cancer Center or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAASE, DUBOSC, ARNOLD
description: HAASE-DUBOSC-Arnold. The family of Arnold Haase-Dubosc, former President of American Radio Company, Inc., and distinguished member of the French-American community in New York, died peacfully at home on September 14, 1997 at the age of 92. Services were private. Donations can be made to the Simon Wiesenthal Center, 9760 West Pico Blvd, Los Angeles, California 90035.

title: 'A Father's Day Diary' as Confession
description: IT is better than an hour of Oprah Winfrey, Sally Jessy Raphael or all those other overpaid purveyors of the tell-all genre, with their spotlights on the dysfunctional.

title: Runaway Girl
description: ON a moonless night two weeks ago, as the first of the autumn winds sliced through Tompkins Square Park, a group of shivering runaways clutched themselves and dreamed of nothing more than a warm sleeping bag and a half-smoked butt.

title: POSTINGS: $56 Million Building Is 'User Friendly'; For Queens, A Civil Civil Court
description: Many courthouses are forbidding places, but New York City's $56 million Queens Civil Court building, nearing completion at Sutphin Boulevard and 89th Avenue in Jamaica, just south of the State Supreme Court building, was designed by Perkins Eastman Architects of Manhattan to be ''user friendly.''

title: Sports of The Times; Say That Again, Just Exactly Which Farce Are We Discussing?
description: DON'T tell the baseball owners this, because I don't like to clutter up their minds, but their rush to realignment makes no sense.

description: COOPERBERG-Irving You know I'm trying... Your Lou

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, IVAN
description: GERSON-Ivan. Dear Ivan, you've been joined by two new angels in heaven this year. As their light shined for others, your light will always shine and guide us. Your loving wife and daughter, Liana and Tara

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Tempo Picks Up on Warehouse-Distribution Projects
description: WORK began Sept. 10 on transforming a patch of farmland not far from Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike into a 2 million-square-foot industrial park. Its first building will be constructed on speculation over the next nine months.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALBRIGHT, ARCHIE E.
description: ALBRIGHT-Archie E. A memorial service will be held for Archie E. Albright, Monday, September 22, 1997, at 4 P.M. at the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 East 50th Street (at Park Avenue), New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Archie Albright Scholarship Fund, 1 Big Canyon Drive, Newport Beach, CA 92660. For additional information please call John S. Albright at 212416-5438 or 203-222-9291.

title: Whitbread Crew Ready to Set Sail
description: A tinge of pain in a back tooth sent Paul Cayard scurrying to the dentist one morning late last week. It would not have ordinarily been a concern. But Cayard told the dentist to check all his fillings. By the time he was done, the bill was $1,000.

description: INTERNATIONAL 3-18
