title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLENNON, EILEEN M.
description: GLENNON-Eileen M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eileen M. Glennon, associated with The Times from 1968, until retiring in 1991.

title: The Right Angles
description: This season's distinctly minimalist urban sportswear styles share an esthetic with modernist architecture: they both possess clean, spare lines and emphasize high-quality materials. Here the two forms are brought together, with streamlined clothes photographed in a Golden Beach, Fla., house designed by the modernist architect Carlos Zapata.

title: Julie Nadler, Peter Abramson
description: Julie Brin Nadler, the daughter of Hannah B. Nadler of New York and Dr. Paul S. Nadler of Summit, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Peter Abramson, a son of the late Francesca and Samuel Abramson, who lived in Cape Town. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs is to perform the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Harvard Shows Reason For Optimism With Rout
description: Harvard was ready for the start of the Ivy League season and Columbia was not. The Crimson, anticipating a winning season for the first time in 10 years, took advantage of four turnovers to score 38 points in the first half of today's game and went on to win, 45-7.

title: County Board Rejects Term Limits
description: WHEN Andrew A. Albanese, a County Legislator from Eastchester, retires this year after 26 years and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke leaves office after 14 years, they will not necessarily be the last of the Westchester officials with longevity.

title: Parental Involvement Makes Better Students; Old Medicine in N.Y.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, STANLEY H.
description: ALEXANDER-Stanley H. September 19, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Grace. Devoted father of Mickey, Toni and Heather. Cherished grandfather of Ian, Jeffrey and Jamie. A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 22, at 11:00 AM from Temple Israel, Westport, CT.

title: Misalliance
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter Bias
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fresh Meadows Is for Sale, and Interest Is Brisk
description: TO old-timers at the sprawling Fresh Meadows development in eastern Queens, the glory days were the period of New York Life's ownership in the 50's and 60's.

title: Jerilyn Ross, Ronald Cohen
description: Jerilyn Ross, a psychotherapist, and Ronald J. Cohen, a real estate developer, were married last evening at their home in Potomac, Md. Rabbi Bruce Lustig officiated.

title: Crunch Time for Campaign Reform
description: For months, the drive to clean up the American campaign finance system has seemed frozen. Especially insulting has been the cynical argument from politicians who trade access for donations that Americans do not care about reform. But the two leading reformers on Capitol Hill, Senators John McCain of Arizona and Russell Feingold of Wisconsin, believe the cynics are wrong, and they seem to be having some success with a strategy of forcing the Republican leadership to allow a vote on a slimmed-down version of their campaign-finance bill. It would focus on banning the most serious abuses, particularly huge open-ended campaign contributions by rich individuals, corporations and labor unions.

title: How to Run Wires Through Walls
description: POSSIBLY the hardest part of installing a new outlet or switch is running the new wires through the walls. This job is often frustrating because you cannot look into the wall to guide the wires. Frequently obstructions within the cavity, like fire stops, will block your attempts to run a wire from one location to another.

title: Subaru Impreza 2.5RS; From Granola to a Jolt of Espresso
description: SUBARU is on a roll. Long known for nerdy but reliable all-wheel-drive wagons built for New England winters and Rocky Mountain highways, the car division of Fuji Heavy Industries stole the heart of exurbia with the tricked-up Legacy Outback. And this summer it managed another miraculous makeover, creating the cute, cute, cute Forester mini-sport utility from the chassis and engine of the solid if nondescript Impreza compact car.

title: Maybe Joe Sharkey Should Get Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sidewalk, the Final Frontier
description: IT is nightfall and an alien being, singing loudly in an unintelligible language and throbbing to an imaginary Walkman, stuffs another neon container into his bulging plastic sack. A phosphorescent ooze drips steadily behind our hero, who spots the evil uniformed agent lurking nearby. He wonders: were they sent to abduct him in their shiny blue metal transport pods simply for plying his futuristic wares?

title: Life in the Bus Lane: Sharing Seats, Lives and Stories
description: I Am a Garbage Man For New Jersey Transit

title: Gators Give Manning No Place to Go But Home
description: Peyton Manning had chosen to be here today at the temporary expense of his bank account and his peace of mind. He had heard the threat that the Florida Gators would seek to knock him out of a game with national championship implications. What Manning discovered this afternoon, in the heat of Florida Field, was a far more efficient way for the Gators to say their goodbyes. In the biggest game of Manning's final college season, they ran him out of town.

title: Chess Expertise or Rich Man's Vanity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Voting System Is Now Facing Big Questions
description: Born in a long-gone era of reform, New York State's system that lets political parties control the election apparatus has always reliably served and fed the politically connected, despite periodic investigations and criticism.

title: New York
description: There's an agreeable feeling of deja vu in New York's crisp autumn air, a sense that certain characteristics from the 1980's have resurfaced. True, shoulder pads are less pronounced and no one is predicting a rapid reprise of ''greed is good.'' But a sense of prosperity has returned, or so it seems.

title: Mike Tyson Misses Tribute to Ali and Possible Reconciliation With Holyfield
description: Evander Holyfield and Mike Tyson still have not spoken to each other since their July 18 heavyweight championship fight in Las Vegas, Nev., when Tyson bit Holyfield's ears and was disqualified in the third round.

title: Mary Acker, Thomas Lesser
description: Dr. Mary Helene Acker, an associate professor of economics, and Dr. Thomas Allen Lesser, a management consultant, were married yesterday at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle, N.Y. Msgr. John Mescall performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on page 35 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Schanzer-Speach Duo includes an outdated reference to its concert at the Knitting Factory. After the section went to press, the concert, originally scheduled for tomorrow night, was postponed to Oct. 3.

title: In a Fight for Its Life, Amtrak Courts Riders
description: SINCE it was created by Congress in 1970, Amtrak has come close to being permanently derailed any number of times. Last month a dispute between Congress and the Clinton Administration over Amtrak employees' severance pay led Congress to withhold the $2.3 billion in capital funds that it had voted for the railroad, and soon after that crisis passed the subsidy narrowly escaped a Presidential line-item veto.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Picturing the Third World
description: In his search for an authentic state of being, Pierre Verger spent most of his life traveling in the Southern Hemisphere, mainly on a northeastern Brazil-West Africa trajectory. Born in Paris, Verger (who died last year at the age of 93) is relatively unknown today because his publications have been limited for the most part to illustrations for books on art or anthropology. Transcending the photographer's role as professional voyeur, he became both an expert and an initiate in cults and religions of West Africa and the New World. PIERRE VERGER: The Go-Between, Photographs 1932-1962 (D.A.P., $65), a collaboration of Jean Loup Pivin and Pascal Martin Saint Leon with Verger, presents, for the first time, Verger's photos as a body of work, with images from West Africa, the Caribbean, South America and Asia. His photographs are neither the dusty field notes of an academic anthropologist nor the cool tableaux other photographers have used to picture the third world. Verger used his camera like an amorous hand -- exploring broad mouths and muscled torsos, fingering textiles and brushing the surfaces of bamboo walls and peeling stucco. Despite the obvious deterioration of some of the negatives, the images have retained their freshness. Rosemary Ranck

title: Hearing on Low Participation In Cancer Treatment Trials
description: New Jersey had the seventh highest mortality rate for all forms of cancer in 1996, and consistently ranks in the top 10, according to the American Cancer Society. And yet only 1 to 3 percent of cancer patients in New Jersey are estimated to participate in clinical studies of potential treatments, while the national average is 3 to 6 percent, said Ann Marie Hill, Executive Director of the State Commission on Cancer Research. Women, along with minorities and the elderly, have especially low participation rates, she said.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Aug. 30, about Columbia County, N.Y., referred incorrectly to Martin Van Buren's political career. He ran for re-election as President in 1840 and 1848, but not in 1844.

title: Vermont's Subtly Shaded Towns
description: CALVIN COOLIDGE was not exactly famous for his eloquence. But in a moment of rational exuberance, Silent Cal strung together 23 words about his beloved home state: ''I love Vermont,'' he said, ''because of her hills and valleys, her scenery and invigorating climate, but most of all because of her indomitable people.''

title: Editorial Notebook; Chelsea Clinton Goes to College
description: The area around Wilbur Hall looked like an armed camp on Friday morning as Stanford University prepared for the arrival of Chelsea Clinton. The last time I saw so many policemen on campus was a frightening night in 1969 when heavily armed units were summoned to end the violent takeover of an administration building by student protesters. As policemen in riot gear moved into Encina Hall that night, the university lost its innocence. The sunny, sandstone campus was no longer a magical world of learning and jasmine-scented breezes, but a battleground in the American civil conflict over the Vietnam War.

title: Schindler Street, N.J.
description: ABRAHAM ZUCKERMAN and Murray Pantirer built their first housing development, in South Plainfield, in 1953. The houses were four-room bungalows that sold for $12,000. Their most recent subdivision, in Livingston, features luxury homes around $400,000.

title: Neighbors Press City to Lock Drug Dealers' Playground
description: In the late afternoons and early evenings, the playground on 142d Street east of Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard is a place where children play on the slides and young adults hang out.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today:

title: Couple Plead Guilty To Smuggling Immigrants
description: Two deaf undocumented immigrants pleaded guilty Friday to a single charge of conspiring to smuggle other deaf Mexicans into the United States to peddle trinkets in the streets of Sanford, N.C.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; For Rent: The Castle, $17,000 a Month, 28 or 35 Rms
description: OVER the last 18 months, eight prime houses in Greenwich have been rented for $15,000 to $25,000 a month in leases running for a year or more.

title: Recital Strings Solo, In Duo and Quartet
description: SEASON openings are with us in ever increasing abundance. The first recitals in two series begin this afternoon, both at 4 P.M.: the violin-cello duo of Michael Roth and Laura Bontrager usher in music at St. Stephen's Church in Ridgefield, while the guitarist Pepe Romero gives a solo program for Friends of Music of Fairfield County at St. John's Episcopal in Stamford.

title: Glitches Aside, Bridgeway Is Rewarding the Brave
description: FIRST, the bad news: The Bridgeway Ultra-Small Company fund, which has gained a stunning 27 percent since the end of June, better than any diversified American mutual fund tracked by Morningstar Inc., and 53 percent since the beginning of the year, is closed to new investors.

title: Gore Avoids Disputed Trade Issue in Speech to Labor Leaders
description: In the Clinton Administration's first appearance before an important labor group since it unveiled its hotly opposed fast-track trade plan earlier this week, Vice President Al Gore avoided the issue entirely today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHABERT, MARTHA G.
description: SCHABERT-Martha G. On September 16, 1997. Memorial service Saturday, September 27th, 3:30PM, Saint James Episcopal Church, Route 25A, Saint James, L.I. Donations may be made to the Nature Conservancy, 250 Lawrence Hill Rd, Cold Spring Harbor NY 11724.

title: Nan Becker, Shane Lennon
description: Nan Jackson Becker, a banker, and Shane Patrick Lennon, a marketing executive, were married yesterday in Windham Center, Conn. The Rev. Julia Gatta performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOCK, MEL
description: HAMMOCK-Mel, 49, interior designer, died of cancer, August 29 at his home in NYC. Born and raised in Atlanta, GA., Mel was the son of Charles E. and Betty Hammock. Survived by his mother, brothers Alan & Andy Hammock, sister and brother-in-law Nancy and Harry Stewart, nieces Kim Arant and Lori Stewart. A memorial service was held August 31 at All Saints Episcopal Church. In celebration of his life and talent friends and clients will be honoring him on Thurs., Sept. 25 at the D&D Building from 5-7 PM. A scholarship is being established in his name at Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club.

title: The View From: Tarrytown ; At a Festival, Adventure Takes the Form of Books
description: THE atmosphere was a combination of college campus and early fall festival. Intellectual-looking people of all ages, many in denim and brown leather sandals and chunky silver jewelry, strolled the grounds of Sunnyside here, clutching books and talking about heady subjects. Admiring historic buildings, gathering at tiny tables and sipping iced coffee and eating tabbouleh and vegetable burgers provided by Jan and Volker Country Cooking, they seemed like students on a holiday. In a gift shop, they admired souvenirs imprinted with words and likenesses of Washington Irving, who once lived here, alongside black and orange Halloween toy spiders and pumpkins.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the remodeling of the Ollie's restaurant at Broadway and 116th Street misidentified the stretch of Broadway on which Columbia University owns nearly half the retail space. It is West 109th to 116th Street, not 106th to 109th.

title: Nebraska Survives Huskies' Rally and Phenom
description: Quarterbacks are like a box of chocolates you never know what you're going to get.

title: At Yale, an Adventure in Learning to Look
description: AS director of the Yale University Art Gallery, Susan Vogel is concerned with presenting art. She has also been a scholar of African art for more than 30 years, and with the exhibition, ''Baule: African Art/ Western Eyes'' she has ingeniously combined two interests in an exhibition that becomes an adventure.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: RESENTMENT

title: A Task Force for Recouping Stolen Property
description: WHEN burglars broke into his garage and storage shed earlier this year and made off with thousands of dollars' worth of rare specialty tools, 79-year-old Louis Ashen of Fairfield figured the items were gone forever.

title: Street Politics
description: Civic Wars

title: Riverdale Routs Horace Mann After Ceremony for Coach
description: Preps

title: PROTO ORSON
description: ''Bright Lucifer,'' a lost play written by Orson Welles in his youth, gets a world premiere next weekend in Madison, Wis. ''Lost'' may be a stretch -- scholars have known about the drama for years, but ignored it. Welles planned to produce the play but abandoned that idea when Hollywood beckoned after his 1938 radio broadcast of ''The War of the Worlds.'' Set in northern Wisconsin, the play features a newspaperman and an actor debating big questions, a la: ''Thicker and quicker flows the force and tide of evil . . . wickedness whelms over good.'' It's hardly great art, but Jay Rath -- the play's producer and a local writer and part-time butcher -- figures true fans will give it some slack. ''Welles was working on this when he was 23, 11 years younger than I am now,'' he says. ''When you think about it, it's a bit frightening.''

title: For the Poles, Brimming Baskets and a Vote Too
description: The new abundance in Poland is evident everywhere in the supermarket parking lot here.

title: Sour Notes
description: Who Killed Classical Music? Maestros, Managers, and Corporate Politics. By Norman Lebrecht. Illustrated. 455 pp. Secaucus, N.J.: Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group. $24.95.

title: The View From: New Haven ; Books in Sound for All Those With Reading Problems
description: WITH precision, 79-year-old Osea Noss threads the reel-to-reel tape recorder at the Connecticut unit of Recording for the Blind and Dyslexic in New Haven, and then switches on the intercom to the recording booth. ''O.K., David. We're recording tape one, track one,'' she says.

title: Ellen Kaye and Andrew Besch
description: Ellen Kaye and Andrew Francis Besch, cable television executives, are to be married this afternoon in Napa, Calif. Rabbi Jerry Winston will perform the ceremony at Villa de Arboles, a private house.

title: The Stealth Chancellor
description: Three cheers for Rudy Crew for ''not doing business as usual'' and to the New York City Board of Education for having the political will to hire a tough outsider who is getting the job done (The Stealth Chancellor,'' by Sara Mosle, Aug. 31)!

title: Joni Ives and Jeffrey Waldhuter
description: Joni Soderstrom Ives and Jeffrey Sidney Waldhuter are to be married today in North Salem, N.Y. Rabbi Ari Fridkis is to perform the ceremony at the Hammond Museum.

title: Will Was Here
description: Oxford, Miss., wasn't always happy with its most famous native son, William Faulkner. His Nobel Prize-winning fiction, which remade Oxford and its countryside into the darkly twisted Yoknapatawpha County, was as popular locally, an old pal once said, as ''a dead skunk in a sleeping bag.''

title: Whatever Happened to Basics?
description: To the Editor:

title: Managed Care Through Doctors' Eyes
description: FOR many doctors like Dr. Philip Heinegg, the advent of managed care has been a mixed blessing. As a family practitioner, he has become the newly respected gatekeeper to an increasingly complex maze of insurance companies and medical providers -- the first stop for most patients before they see a specialist. But at times Dr. Heinegg feels as if he is being inundated with forms, procedures and a seemingly infinite number of requirements that interfere with the business of healing.

title: Wrong Address
description: Oops. With the stroke of a computer key, a sensitive memo (perhaps about your love life, your finances or your boss) has gone astray. Welcome to the wonderful world of computers, where really embarrassing things can happen in a big hurry. Have you ever sent a message to the wrong destination? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINSKY, ALICE
description: KAMINSKY-Alice. On September 19, 1997, one day after her 92nd birthday. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Loving mother of Drs. Ruth and Nathaniel Karush, Dr. David Kaminsky and Dr. Rochelle Schreibman. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie, Melissa, Jennifer, Daniel, Deborah, Adam, Alison, Matthew and Sarah. Graveside service today, September 21, 12 noon at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, New Jersey. Contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Bagpipes Lead Off First of Noonday Concerts
description: THANKS to the ''Noonday Getaway'' concerts that brighten September-to-May Wednesdays at Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains, brown-bagging it and listening to music at 12:35 P.M. has replaced the power lunch for many office workers. This week, the skirl of bagpipes heralds the 10th anniversary series, as Jonathan Henken, a member of the Mount Kisco Highland Regimental Band, plays a selection of Scottish airs, love songs, dances and military marches in the front entrance garden (weather permitting). Beginning Oct. 1, the half-hour concerts continue the international focus indoors, when Dorothy Happel and Dorothy Beach play Czech music for violin and piano by Smetana, Dvorak, Fibich and Suk. For more details of these and later events, call the music office at 949-0384.

title: Giants' Faltering No. 1 Picks: Tough Luck
description: As the 1990's dawned, it seemed as if divine providence had sided with the Giants. The first team of the decade started the season with 10 successive victories. The Giants went to San Francisco for the conference championship and, as underdogs, beat the 49ers to secure a Super Bowl berth. Then, in Super Bowl XXV, the 1990-91 Giants beat the Buffalo Bills by a point, waiting until the fading, wide-right path of a field-goal attempt secured their championship.

title: Prime Seats at Democracy Still Only $5
description: MY wife does not like it when I get jury duty. She thinks I express my opinions too freely for a guy who will be technically in the custody of a court, in a building that has jail cells in the basement for troublemakers.

title: September 14-20; An AIDS Placebo
description: The current buzzword for unethical medical experiments is Tuskegee, after the infamous Government study in which poor black men with syphilis were left untreated. Last week it was applied to experiments financed by the United States in which thousands of pregnant women infected with H.I.V. in Africa, Thailand and the Dominican Republic are being given dummy pills instead of medicine.

title: Nicole Lefton, Eric Mullen
description: Nicole Robin Lefton and Eric Bernard Mullen were married yesterday at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass. Suzanne Eismann, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: The Qumran Library
description: THE COMPLETE DEAD SEA SCROLLS IN ENGLISH By Geza Vermes. 648 pp. New York: Allen Lane/The Penguin Press. $39.95.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 31 about the New York Jets receiver Keyshawn Johnson quoted incorrectly from his book, ''Just Give Me the Damn Ball!'' He called the Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet a ''mascot''; it was Ron Erhardt, a Jets coach, whom he called ''an old fool.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACCARINO, JOE
description: YACCARINO-Joe. 2/5/19-9/20/96. You were the music in my life: opera, blues, jazz, ballads. Mulli and I miss you. Nancy

title: Like Its Neighborhood, a Spiffy 'Fort Apache' Is Reborn
description: Seen from the elevated subway platform on Westchester Avenue, the old precinct house at 1086 Simpson Street seems to rise above the surrounding tidy two-story row houses like a grand hotel. The limestone facade has been sandblasted, painted a fawn brown and crowned with a green terra-cotta roof that glistens in the sunshine. Inside, the changes are even more impressive. Floors are marble tile, doors are oak with brass handles and the walls of the main floor have been sanded smooth as a mirror and painted cream.

title: OUTDOORS; Concern Grows That a Whirling Disease Upsurge Is Near
description: The whirling disease threat to American trout has been raised to a possible ''biological Chernobyl,'' leading Alberta, a huge province of Canada, to shut its border to live trout from the United States, effective Oct. 1, to protect its own streams.

title: Contrarian Investing Pays Off For Loews
description: When it comes to excessive mood swings, few people could possibly be as affected individually as millions of them are collectively, at least when it comes to investing. An industry can be loved by all at high prices, then hated after prices plunge.

title: First Woman Trooper Wins Harassment Decision
description: New Jersey's first female state trooper, who sued the State Police for sexual harassment and discrimination in 1990, deserves a pension normally reserved for officers who have suffered traumatic accidents in the line of duty, a judge has ruled.

title: In the Glare of the Spotlight, Muscular Rivals Glint and Shine
description: ONE was an electrical engineer, another was a high school student. There was a registered nurse, a dietician and a grandmother: Morjorie Newlin, 77, of Mt. Airy, Pa. She said she became interested in body building six years ago.

title: Kurt Hetzel and Page Neelly
description: Carolyn Page Neelly, the daughter of Linda Page Posey of Nashville and Michael Leigh Neelly of Fairport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kurt Charles Hetzel, a son of Judy Hetzel of Southampton, N.Y., and C. Charles Hetzel 3d of New York. The Rev. Dick Neelly, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Southampton.

title: Well, the New Office Is Very Nice but . . . Cough, Cough
description: After 11 years in a renovated but desolate warehouse on Fulton Landing in Brooklyn, several hundred State Labor Department employees were for the most part delighted when they moved to new offices at 345 Hudson Street in February. Their new neighborhood, SoHo, has restaurants, drugstores, newsstands and other amenities like public transportation nearby. And the new building, between Charlton and King Streets, is well kept and the offices bright, if a bit cramped.

title: Horse Sense
description: THE NATURE OF HORSES

title: North African Touches, a Winning Menu
description: IT'S never easy to follow in Daddy's footsteps. But in the three years since it opened, Mediterranean Grill in Wilton has honed its craft and now demonstrates that it, like its parent, Meson Galicia in Norwalk, can play in the big leagues.

title: For People Who Dance The Same Language
description: DRINKS flowed, strobe lights flashed, and the thump of techno shook the Westend Lounge on the fringe of Chelsea. Outside, an anxious throng of impeccably primped and perfumed clubgoers waited behind the velvet ropes. Inside, clutches of pinkie-thin, well-dressed women chattered over cosmopolitans or bottles of Evian. Occasionally, they would throw coy glances at the men in tight-fitting T-shirts who hovered in the shadows enveloped by plumes of cigarette smoke.

title: Where to Eat Like a Vermonter
description: VERMONT'S gentle beauty reveals itself modestly as you thread your way by car over the rolling hills and streams, past white churches, village greens and town gazebos. Unlike the magnificence of a Pacific seascape, or the reverence inspired by the Rockies, this landscape offers tranquillity.

title: VIEWPOINT; How to Boss the Boss, in Five Easy Steps
description: WE now call the boss a ''coach,'' ''team leader'' or ''facilitator.'' But the concept of ''boss'' hasn't changed much since early in the century, when titans of industry kept tabs on their employees' personal lives.

title: Kathryn Misrock, Adam Goldstein
description: Kathryn Susan Misrock, a daughter of Barbara and S. Leslie Misrock of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Stuart Goldstein, the son of Carole Goldstein and Dr. Harold Goldstein of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: THEATER REVIEW ; Around the Table, Life Keeps Changing
description: TO the questions ''Where is style?'' and ''Whatever happened to class?'' some chosen people do not need to provide an answer; they are the answer. And for them, a dining room table is an essential thing of the present.

title: Formal Gold Is Class of Field in Woodward
description: The stars came out at Belmont Park yesterday, and none shone brighter than Formal Gold, the 4-year-old colt who outran Skip Away and Will's Way and won the $500,000 Woodward Stakes by 5 1/2 lengths.

title: Suspect Is Charged In 3 Sexual Attacks
description: A 24-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with three recent sexual attacks, including the rape of a woman who was making a call at a pay phone Wednesday on Park Avenue.

title: Civil Rights Anniversary Points to Unfinished Tasks
description: Perhaps no building in America is as haunted by the legacy of racial hatred as the brown-brick fortress known as Little Rock Central High School.

title: Chasing Maris
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: After Tough Week Off the Field, Rutgers Gets Stung on It
description: After enduring a week of severe criticism of the program and with the team wallowing in an 0-3 mire, Rutgers took the field against Boston College before a small crowd today. And it was clearly apathy, not traffic, that was causing the late arrivals.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBEL, FRANCES (NEE MANDEL)
description: LOBEL-Frances (nee Mandel). September 19, 1997. Born 7-17-20, NYC. Preceded in death by husband Norman. Survived by sons Michael Lobel, Dallas, TX; Edward Lobel, Marlboro, MA; and Steven Lobel, Baltimore, MD; eight grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Graveside services 2:45 PM, Sunday at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: At Home in an Irish Cottage or a City Flat
description: THE Earls of Enniskillen don't live at Florence Court anymore. They no longer enjoy the view from the 18th-century mansion to the wilds and hills of County Fermanagh in Northern Ireland. Nor do they sit in the salons, all plasterwork and good paintings, waiting for a servant to bring a morsel from the cavernous kitchen below. The last Earl left in 1973; these days the National Trust, which owns Florence Court, locks it up as soon as the last tour leaves. But visitors staying at Rose Cottage, a house in the midst of the Florence Court gardens, can still fall asleep in the hush of the old estate.

title: Dallas Owner May Walk Sideline, to Coach
description: The Dallas owner, Jerry Jones, was on the practice field late last week, speaking to his players about their blocking schemes and talking with his defense. The 2-1 Cowboys have been lethargic in their last two games, and in an attempt to raise their level of play they have resumed the two-a-day practices that are employed in training camp.

title: In America; Someone Else's Fault
description: Even as a judge was refusing on Friday afternoon to order a runoff in the Democratic mayoral primary, the Board of Elections was doing its best to shirk all responsibility for one of the biggest election debacles in New York City history.

title: Market Indicators: Multiple Bids, Unbound Binders, Frayed Tempers
description: IF the perils of Carol Joyner's quest through the rugged terrain of the residential real estate market -- pocked as it is by the pitfalls of multiple bidding and unrequited contracts -- were scripted for a silent movie, it would be a cliffhanger.

title: A Realm of Woods and Water
description: BACKED up against the Canadian border on a lofty plateau between the Green and White Mountains, the northeastern corner of Vermont is one of the last remnants of an earlier, undeveloped New England. As I discovered some 30 years ago when I first came here as a young teacher, it's a remote territory of deep woods, sequestered hill farms, steep maple-sugar groves, glacial lakes and icy rivers, many of which drain north into Quebec. Like the Michigan Upper Peninsula, the region has a name, conferred nearly 50 years ago by George Aiken, a Vermont Governor and Senator. It was such a beautiful part of the state, Aiken said after a fishing trip to one of the area's numerous wilderness trout ponds, that it ought to have a special name. ''Let's call it the Northeast Kingdom,'' he said.

title: Ann Grozier, Stewart Dixon
description: Ann Wilson Grozier, an interior designer in New York, and Stewart Strawn Dixon, a lawyer in Chicago, were married on Monday at the Colony Club in New York. The Rev. Carol N. Seaman, a Presbyterian pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, ANDERSON
description: FOWLER-Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23, at 11 A.M., at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone, New Jersey.

title: The Last Detail
description: The right suit or sport coat is always important, but it's the details that define a man of style. These days, a man can find the perfect particulars in shoes, watches or eyeglasses to reveal his sense of self, whether he is a lawyer, horse breeder or both. The notable accessories this fall are substantial-looking shoes with heavily grained or suede finishes, richly colored silk Jacquard, wool or cashmere ties, streamlined leather belts with brushed-metal buckles, high-tech chronograph watches (some with crocodile-leather straps) and industrial-like sterling silver cuff links. Put them all together, and they spell style.

title: Another Try for Bond Fund Ratings
description: IS your bond mutual fund risky? Is it loaded with the type of securities that could plunge in value if interest rates soared?

title: Greenburgh District And Balanced News
description: I reviewed the June 22 article $(''Schools Scramble for Funds''$) and was upset by the mischaracterization of me and our school district. Indeed, I was not available to return the reporter's call on this particular story due to the preponderance of press requests I had immediately following our budget defeat. However, Ned Price, Assistant Superintendent for Business, called on my behalf and spoke with the reporter.

title: Skillful Ploy On Tobacco
description: Every negotiation requires a ceiling and a floor between which the parties can hope to hang a compromise. Those dimensions in the national debate over the tobacco policy became clear this week.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Who Protects Us From H.M.O.'s?
description: THREE years ago we lost our infant son after an agonizing battle with an inexplicable array of birth defects. Our health maintenance organization at the time behaved abominably.

title: Parental Involvement Makes Better Students; Scholarship Was Fine
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Reading the Tea Leaves' Via Stock Analysis Software
description: MAYNARD E. BURSTEIN'S computer terminal is splashed full of fancy stock charts. He is plotting ''moving averages'' and ''volatility measures'' to help him ferret out buy and sell signals.

title: POSTINGS: A.I.A. Awards Symposium; A Peek at the Peak of Design
description: The American Institute of Architects' New York Chapter is inviting the public to attend two events on Thursday: its Design Awards Symposium announcing the best-designed projects that were built recently, that are being built, or that perhaps may never get built, and a tour of a nearly completed project, the Queens Civil Court building (see article at left). Both begin at 6 P.M.

title: Long Island Q&A;: George Bouklas; Can Psychotherapy Benefit the Elderly?
description: GEORGE BOUKLAS'S first career was spent working as a teacher and principal on Long Island, in New York City and in Dutchess County, for children with special needs. He has spent the last 20 years with the elderly, first as a troubleshooter in nursing homes and currently as a psychological consultant for patients in their 60's in several Long Island nursing homes.

title: Public Sculpture the Public Likes. Really.
description: IN 1995, WHEN THE SCULPTOR Tom Otterness was asked to create an artwork for a plaza outside the Sacramento Federal Courthouse, he had an inspiration: a four-foot-tall chess set that reflected the drama of the proceedings unfolding inside. In his first proposal, he envisioned one side as the financial establishment -- rooks as banks, bishops as lawyers, king and queen as rich entrepreneurs. The other would be an army of working-class pawns bearing shovels, mallets and serving trays.

title: Gunpowder and Beheadings
description: A MONARCHY TRANSFORMED

title: The World; To Deplore Capitalism Isn't Always To Fight It
description: FOR Karl Marx, the right approach to private property was simple: abolish it. But from Beijing to Paris, two cities where Communists are in government, the question of how to deal with property has become a complicated one, exposing the strangely divergent hues of Communism today.

title: The Price Of Turnover
description: Low turnover in a mutual fund's portfolio can mean lower taxes for investors, especially under the new tax law. But there can be another advantage in funds that trade infrequently: higher returns.

title: The Nation; On Senate Stage, a Star at Last
description: WITH brazen candor, a natty multimillionaire named Roger E. Tamraz has suddenly thrown open a window for the American public onto the dense, shadowy, treasure-trove workings of campaign fund-raising, the empowerment engine of modern American politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORISI, MIGLIORINI THERESA
description: MORISI-Migliorini Theresa, on September 19, 1997. Mrs. Theresa Morisi Migliorini of Pine Plains, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Tues., 9/23, 11 AM at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church, Pine Plains. Interment Evergreen Cemetery. Friends may call 2 to 4 & 7 to 9 PM Sunday 9/21 and Monday 9/22 at the Peck & Peck Funeral Home, Main St., Pine Plains. (518) 398-7777 Memorial contributions are requested to the Pine Plains Rescue Squad PO Box 100 Pine Plains, NY 12567.

title: Gift to Stevens Tech Endows Business Technology School
description: A former executive of a prominent medical supply company has donated $6.63 million to Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken for the nation's first graduate business school dedicated to management technology.

title: Corrections
description: An article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about plans to construct housing on part of a commercial development site in Fair Lawn misstated the projected cost. It is up to $25 million, not $125 million.

title: Popular Science
description: RICHARD FEYNMAN

title: Elizabeth Burns And Milan Kirby
description: Elizabeth Margaret Burns, the daughter of Richard Barker Burns of Westfield, N.J., and the late Dorothy Garretson Burns, was married yesterday to Milan Stanton Kirby, a son of Shelby Baran Kirby of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Allan Price Kirby Jr. of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Zachary Fleetwood, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J.

title: Essay; Thompson Takes a Breather
description: Why, just as the investigation into Clinton campaign corruption was hitting pay dirt, did Fred Thompson suddenly strike a deal with Democrats to shift the hearings into a softer, gentler discussion of legislative changes?

title: Ted Turner's Gift
description: Mayhem, poverty and pestilence overseas, relentlessly chronicled on his Cable News Network, have been good to Ted Turner, so it is nice of him to return the favor. On Thursday he announced what is probably the single largest charitable donation in history, up to $1 billion in Time Warner stock. This stunning amount should shame his fellow Americans, moguls or not, into giving more.

title: Jennifer Goldman, Jonathan Fox
description: Jennifer Lynn Goldman, the daughter of Carol L. Rosetti of Weston, Conn., and Arnold J. Goldman of Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Jonathan Wayne Fox, a son of Irene M. Fox of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Dr. Irving R. Fox. Rabbi Jon Haddon performed the ceremony at the Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton, Conn.

title: Starting Over
description: They got married, made a home in New Jersey and didn't live happily every after.

title: Brice Shipley and Noelle Leon
description: Noelle Elisabeth Leon, a daughter of Bonnie J. Leon of Gardiner, Me., and the Rev. Robert R. Leon of Chebeague Island, Me., was married yesterday to N. Brice Shipley, the son of Catherine M. Phillippe of Alexandria, Va., and the stepson of the Rev. Dr. William R. Phillippe. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Car of Missing New Jersey Developer Is Found
description: The silver BMW that Nelson G. Gross, the former New Jersey Republican chairman, was seen driving when he disappeared on Wednesday was found yesterday in New York City, a spokeswoman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Hands and Wrists Are Thrust Into the Hiring Process
description: RICHARD AYERS still struggles to understand.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAYNOR, CHARLOTTE
description: GAYNOR-Charlotte. September 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Alvin; adored mother of Steven; cherished sister of Bob (Shirley) Levinsohn. Services on Sunday, at 11 AM, graveside at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York

title: The Driver of Diana: Friends Are Puzzled
description: As Henri Paul was buried in France, his family and friends were still puzzled by official reports that he had been drinking heavily and had taken antidepressant drugs just before the car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, three weeks ago.

title: Seeing Through Eyes Born Poor and Born Black
description: GORDON PARKS AT THE AGE of 84 has already had more experience, more lives, and a lot more professions and honors than Methuselah had in 969 years. The youngest of 15 children of a dirt farmer in Kansas, Mr. Parks never finished high school but has been given 30 honorary doctorates for his various achievements: fashion photographer and noted photojournalist who worked for Life magazine for more than two decades; film director; writer of technical manuals, novels, memoirs, poetry and screenplays; composer of symphonic music, film scores and a ballet, pianist and painter.

title: Women Leaving Medicine for Home
description: WHEN Dr. Ruth Martin graduated from the George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences in 1981, she was proud to be one of 49 women in a class of 148. In 1970 there had been only 13 women in the school's freshman class of 127. In the 1960's there had been only three or four women in each class.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Acura Integra Type R; A New-Age Muscle Car With a Racing Pedigree
description: ACURA has always had two distinct personalities. Its big sedans, like the TL and RL Series, are practical, reliable and just a tad uninspiring. But the Integras -- especially the coupes -- are stylish runabouts that make up for their modest creature comforts with zippy performance.

title: Setting Standards for Testing
description: WHO Dorothy S. Strickland, 63, a professor of reading at Rutgers University's Graduate School of Education. She is also chairwoman of a committee formed by President Clinton to develop a standardized national test to measure the reading skills of fourth-graders.

title: Relief Replaces Anxiety Over Sports
description: FOR many Westchester student athletes, educators and parents, this summer will be remembered as one of the most intriguing ones ever. Their anxiety came as a result of the rejections of proposed spending plans in several school districts including Greenburgh, Harrison, Mount Vernon and Peekskill.

title: Designer Houses for the Poor
description: Mason's Bend is not the kind of place you expect to find architecture. Less a town than a wide place in the red-dirt road, the Bend consists of a dozen or so houses tucked into a curve of the Black Warrior River in western Alabama. Four extended families, a community of about 80 people -- many descended from a black sharecropper who bought this land in the 1920's -- live here in structures ranging from tidy bungalows to tumbledown shacks to an abandoned school bus. By most standards, everyone living here is poor: many of the residents get some sort of public assistance; most of their houses have no indoor plumbing.

title: Backtalk; Ali's Wares and Our Cares Go on the Auction Block
description: Somewhere along the way I picked up a Muhammad Ali doll; think of a G.I. Joe with little red boxing gloves and a white robe. One day in the 1980's, when the former champion seemed blue, I gave it to him. He was sitting with his feet in a pan of water, dipping in live electrical wires to try to wake up his numb muscles. He smiled and played with the 10-inch figure for a while, crooning at it, teaching it to box. As he began to lose interest, his best friend, the photographer Howard Bingham, snatched it away and gave it back to me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, LAURA
description: ROBBINS-Laura, 93, died peacefully on September 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving & loved mother of Michael and Benedict and daughters-in-law Lois and Ann Barbara; grandmother of Jeanie, Louis, Matthew, Elizabeth, Juli, Jil, Polly, and the late Daniel, great-grandmother of six. Sister of Sara Selis, Ben Neufeld, and the late Phillip Neufeld. Services for the family. Donations may be made to the Green Chimneys School, Brewster, NY 10509.

title: Position On Abortion Spurs Dispute
description: THE head of an influential Westchester abortion-rights group says that Ted Dunn, the Republican candidate for county executive, threatened her after her group made it clear that they would not endorse him because of uncertainties about his position on abortion.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Pieces of Time The Life of James Stewart. By Gary Fishgall. Lisa Drew/Scribner, $27.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, ANTONIA V. (TONI)
description: SOBEL-Antonia V. (Toni). Of Miami, Florida. Formerly of Scarsdale, New York. Passed away September 19, 1997. Beloved wife of Frank. Loving mother of Ralph, Marc, Nancy, Rick, John, Alice, Debbie, Stacey and Liz. Dear sister of Delia and Lina. Cherished grandmother of Chris, Kevin, David, Michael and Steven. Family suggests contributions to: Catholic Hospice, 14100 Palmetto Frontage Road, Suite 370, Miami, Florida 33016. Chapel services today (Sunday) September 21, 1997 at 4 PM at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 5900 SW 77th Avenue, Kendall, Florida. 305-274-0641

title: A Favorite Son Finds Comfort From Home
description: On the eve of Florida's big game with Tennessee, Dwayne Dixon, Florida's receivers coach, was very much in the here and now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, MOLLY
description: SANDLER-Molly. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin; loving mother of Adele and Will; and affectionate grandmother and great-grandmother to several new generations; a beautiful spirit who sang throughout her life. We will miss you dearly.

title: Why Religious Rights?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The answer to a reader's question in the Streetscapes column on Aug. 31 about the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, on Amsterdam Avenue between 136th and 138th Streets in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to its remnants. While only some retaining walls are left of the main building, a separate gymnasium structure has been incorporated into P.S. 192.

title: In Post-Soviet Era, the Old Style Works
description: At the sprawling Pasaj market in downtown Baku, there is little subtlety in people's praise for President Heydar Aliyev.

title: Burials at Sea Gaining in Popularity
description: WHEN boat captains go out to sea, they usually pray for fish and a journey that does not end in a watery grave. But a handful on Long Island are helping people look to the sea in death.

title: Olson Rewarded
description: Coach Lute Olson, who brought a national basketball championship to Arizona, is about to get a contract extension and a pay raise to last until his expected retirement. Olson will get a total of about $530,000 a year and his contract be extended by two years, to 2002, The Arizona Republic reported yesterday. Olson will be 67 by then and is expected to retire.

title: Return of the Cranes
description: Of all the cris de coeurs you'll hear this season, none is likely to be as impassioned, or as weird, as the mating call of Frasier Crane. In the season premiere of ''Frasier'' (Tuesday at 9 P.M. on NBC), he comes out of his long romantic slump and becomes entangled with his dream woman (Sela Ward), a model who is also a Ph.D. candidate in zoology. But when her busy schedule and an almost-ex boyfriend make her presence scarse, Frasier's family believes he has invented an imaginary friend.

title: Art and Crafts Amid Fall Foliage
description: The third annual Paradise City Arts Festival will take place during what is usually peak fall foliage season, on Columbus Day weekend at the Tri-County Fairgrounds in Northampton, Mass., the town that the Swedish Nightingale, Jenny Lind, liked so much that she called it paradise.

title: Blind Fate
description: Oedipus on the Road By Henry Bauchau. Translated by Anne-Marie Glasheen. 240 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $24.95.

title: Julie Chwatsky, Steven Hatfield
description: Julie Ellen Chwatsky and Steven Douglas Hatfield were married yesterday at the Mackall House, a historic house in Amagansett, N.Y. Rabbi Phyllis Shapiro officiated. The Rev. Janet Hatfield Legro, a minister of the United Church of Christ, who is the bridegroom's sister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Against Tolerance
description: Drawing Life

title: Jennifer Rothschild, Paul Robinson
description: Jennifer Eve Rothschild and Paul Lawrence Robinson, lawyers in Washington, are to be married today at the Headquarters Plaza Hotel in Morristown, N.J. Rabbi Louis Frishman is to perform the ceremony.

title: Elk Ranchers See More Profits, and Critics
description: Welch Brogan climbed out of a battered vehicle in the middle of a mountain pasture, cupped his hands around his mouth and yelled. ''Come babe. Come babe. Come baby.'' A few minutes later, 40 or so curious, sloe-eyed elk, some with massive antlers, drifted over a rise toward him and began eating apples from his hand.

title: Trouble Spots On the Road
description: A look at trouble spots you can expect to encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of the State Department of Transportation.

title: Here's One Way You Can Beat the Bursar
description: WHEN Timothy Radle entered Ohio State University in 1994, his parents were not concerned about college tuition or how much it might climb while he was there.

title: Mosquito Puts Crimp in Florida's Night Life
description: On one side of the football field, 26 people rooted for the De Laura Junior High School Scotties. On the other side, 150 fans cheered for the home team, the Edgewood Junior High Indians -- and 65 of them were playing in the school band.

title: Two Candidates Face Off
description: THE two major candidates for Westchester County Executive, Ted Dunn, the Mayor of Rye and a Republican, and Andrew J. Spano, the former County Clerk and a Democrat, have a number of joint forums and debates scheduled as well as separate public appearances.

title: Debra Meyers And Roy Szuper
description: Debra Mary Meyers, a daughter of Carol McMahon of Oceanside, N.Y., and the late Peter F. Meyers, was married yesterday in Montauk, N.Y., to Roy Sebastian Szuper, the son of Barbra Bouilloux of Geneva and Roman Szuper of Astoria, Queens. The Rev. Dr. John M. Best, a Protestant minister, performed the ceremony at the Montauk Community Church.

title: A Foursome for the Ryder Cup: Passion, Anxiety, Patriotism and Glory
description: It is the most pressure-packed event a golfer will face. It happens only once every two years. And it usually leaves both the winners and the losers in tears.

title: Virus Kills 13 in Chile, Alarming Other Countries in the Region
description: An outbreak of hantavirus, which causes pneumonia and high fever, has killed 13 people and hospitalized dozens more in Chile in recent months and health officials fear the virus is spreading to other countries in the region.

title: 'X-Files' Looks For the Room To Stretch Out
description: STEAM BILLOWED AROUND the familiar, expressionless visage of F.B.I. Special Agent Fox Mulder as he clawed his way out of a crevice in the ice of Antarctica, then rescued his partner, the wet, injured Agent Dana Scully, the threat of aliens, Government conspirators and spaceships looming somewhere out of sight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBLIN, CHRISTINA CARLYLE
description: DUBLIN-Christina Carlyle, on Sunday, September 14, 1997. Christina Carlyle Dublin of Washington, D.C., beloved wife of Dr. Thomas D. Dublin, mother of Sarah C.D. and Eberhard Slenczka of Nuremberg, Germany and Barbara D. Van Cleve of McLean, Virginia, sister of Agnes Hadden of Needham, Massachusetts, Barbara Reed of Seattle, Washington and Margaret Angell of Haverhill, Massachusetts; beloved godmother and grandmother. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 26th, 1997, at 2:00 P.M., in the Bethlehem Chapel of The Washington National Cathedral (Massachusetts and Wisconsin Avenues, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20016-5098). Interment is private. In lieu of flowers the family would welcome memorial donations to The Reginald S. Lourie Center for infants and young children in Rockville, Maryland; Simmons College, Boston, Massachusetts; or The Washington National Cathedral.

title: September 14-20; Going First Class on Broadway
description: The impresarios of ancient Greece gave Dionysus a front-row throne at theater performances; in Shakespeare's Globe, the aristocracy enjoyed the view from boxes above the stage. Now the plutocracy of modern New York is to have a special way to take in a Broadway show.

title: Word & Image; No Pix, No Di
description: At her death, the english-speaking media and much of the English-reading public obviously went berserk. We pretended that a sad accident was a universal catastrophe, that the deportment of Britain's monarchy bears on the fate of humanity and that civilization's great challenge now is to rewrite the laws of privacy, to make the world safe for celebrity.

title: Clinton Threatens Veto in Fight to Preserve Education Proposals
description: Setting himself on a collision course with the Republican Congress, President Clinton vowed today to veto a mammoth spending bill if it contains amendments blocking his national school standards and testing plan or channeling money away from his other cherished Federal education programs.

That was the year Mr. Erickson, a county planner in New Jersey, became executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Regional Planning Agency, which became the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments in 1991.

Only a token takeout counter remains at this stunning spot on Jericho Turnpike in Huntington. The large display case has been replaced by a fully stocked bar.

title: On Language; Coinages of the Realm
description: A 1996 Newsweek headline called him ''Dead White Male of the Year,'' and The Washington Post has named him ''Greatest Genius of the Millennium.'' But modern audiences all too often think of William Shakespeare's language in terms of forsooth (an Old English adverb meaning ''truly'') or bodkin (a Middle English noun for ''dagger or sharp weapon'' first used by Geoffrey Chaucer in ''The Canterbury Tales'').

description: Ellen Louise Reddy and Paul Michael Donofrio, financial executives, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. John Bucki performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: The Morgan Spirit
description: To the Editor: You might be interested to know there is a Morgan car club, the 3/4 Group Ltd., with over 200 members in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. We are having our annual autumn meet Oct. 3 to 5 at the Shawnee Inn, Shawnee, Pa. We are expecting 50 to 60 Morgans of all ages, styles and condition to compete in skill and condition events, as well as a gala auction and plenty of food.

title: Shocked!
description: I was delighted to read Jack Rosenthal's On Language column Shocked!'' (Aug. 24). He gives several persuasive explanations for the tendency to fall into cliche. Another that could be explored is a desire to give a cultural or historical dimension to mainly ordinary material. Using shocked, shocked'' is an attempt to move the reader beyond the mundane and into a world inhabited by Bogart and Ingrid Bergman.

title: BOOKEND; Tambimuttu in New York
description: Does the name ring a bell? Certainly in London, faintly in New York. Thurairajah Tambimuttu. Everyone called him Tambi. A Ceylonese poet, brown-skinned, longhaired. A bohemian, verbose and skinny. Very British sounding, too. ''Actually. . . . '' ''In point of fact. . . .''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, JANICE LEE
description: GOLDSMITH-Janice Lee, 67, formerly of Manhattan and San Francisco, died September 19, at her home in Boca Raton, FL. Loving daughter of Arthur and Esther Goldstein. Former wife of Morton. Devoted mother to Ann and Jonathan. Loved by all in her family including daughter-in-law Ginny, granddaughters Robin, Rebecca and Sarah, grandson Matthew, nieces Karen and Rachel, nephew Evan and his wife Barbara, her brother Marc and sister-in-law Joyce. She will be truly missed. A woman of great strength and open heart. Contributions in her memory may be made to the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition, Boca Raton, FL, 561-888-OVARIAN.

title: In Forbes Strategy, Religious Right Now a Friend
description: Thunderous applause greets him when he tells conservative audiences, ''Life begins at conception.'' In speeches and television commercials around the country, he speaks out against everything from late-term abortions and Federal financing of the arts to teen-age pregnancy and needle exchanges for drug addicts. And at last week's Christian Coalition convention, one of the meeting's organizers marveled that he was ''the belle of the ball.''

title: Girl Scout Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Katharine Fleet, Douglas Miscoll
