description: Nicole Ann Russo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Russo of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Michael Steinthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. John Steinthal Jr. of Rye Brook, N.Y. Msgr. William J. Bradley performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.

title: In a World of Secrets
description: THE FAR EUPHRATES

title: The Jerusalem Artichoke Is Doubly Misnamed
description: A vegetable garden is no place for a xenophobic North American. Those tomatoes came from South America, the eggplant from Asia, the okra from Africa, the arugula from Europe. That's why it is unfortunate that one of the few native North American vegetables sounds as if it came from somewhere else.

title: Greene Takes 100 In Indonesia
description: The world champion Maurice Greene fell 0.32 of a second short of his personal best in winning the 100 meters at the Bob Hasan Invitational yesterday in Jakarta.

title: Perils of Subletting Your Co-op
description: GIL NEARY, president of DG Neary Real Estate in Manhattan, was nervous when he took a sales listing on a two-bedroom co-op in Chelsea. Though the apartment was sure to sell in Manhattan's hot co-op market, it was occupied by a subtenant of the shareholder who owned it.

title: Grooming Gear Hits the Road
description: When the American astronaut Michael Foale had to relocate from the damaged module of the beleaguered Mir space station in June, he left behind his personal belongings. Reporting back to the Johnson Space Center in Houston, he relayed technical data and then announced: ''I would really like a shaver. I would really like a toothbrush.''

title: Stepping Out of His Father's Long Shadow
description: ON AN AUGUST EVENING FIVE years ago, John Pizzarelli looked up from his seven-string guitar and thought he had stumbled into a time warp: watching intently as he picked out chestnuts like ''Isn't It Romantic?'' and ''Penthouse Suite,'' were Richard Nixon and his wife, Pat, their daughters, Tricia and Julie, and Bebe Rebozo, once the nation's First Friend.

title: Getting the Boot, Illegally, in Parking Lots
description: All summer, one Bronx motorist after another returned to their cars from shopping sputtering with outrage. Their stories, recounted last week in a City Council hearing on booting in private parking lots, were the same: the driver parked in a store's lot, crossed the street for an errand, and came back to find the car immobilized by a large bright-yellow lock attached to a wheel. In minutes a man -- imposing and tattooed, according to drivers' descriptions -- appeared, demanding $100 to remove the boot. If no payment was made, the car was held hostage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, MARVIN S.
description: GREENBERG-Marvin S., on 9/16. Beloved husband of the late Hazel, loving son of the late Gertrude and Irving, brother of Robert. Memorial contributions may be made to The Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 West 106th St, NYC 10025.

title: Role Model
description: Michael J. Fox has the time of his life as a deliriously self-confident Hollywood icon in John Badham's comedy THE HARD WAY (1991). As Nick Lang, the discontented but hugely popular star of adventure movies, he longs to play a tough, gritty New York cop in a new picture; and he's off to New York City to find out firsthand how a typical detective walks, talks, thinks and breathes. James Woods plays his reluctant guru, John Moss, and Annabella Sciorra plays the woman in Moss's life with humor and intelligence. The sensibility is pure Hollywood; and though this is not a perfect comedy, it is a very entertaining one. -- SATURDAY at 6 P.M. on USA.

title: A Small Utility Fights A Ban in Patchogue
description: IN the year since Patchogue enacted a ban on outdoor public phones, all illegal outdoor pay phones have been removed except one, at a service station.

title: The Morgan Spirit
description: To the Editor: ''British Eccentricity on Four Wheels'' (Aug. 10) evokes memories of the sporty Morgans of the 1930's. But four wheels? Real enthusiasts saw the introduction of the fourth wheel as a sign of decadence. The three-wheeler (two front and one rear) was noisier, probably faster and certainly less weatherproof than its much younger sibling.

title: Maureen Weiss, Brian Driscoll
description: Maureen Cara Weiss, a daughter of Elizabeth and David Weiss of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian John Driscoll, a son of Frances Driscoll of San Leandro, Calif., and the late William Driscoll. The Rev. R. John Nelson officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Just Get Along
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Translating A 'Universal Language'
description: IN HIS CHARACTERISTICALLY BRILLIANT, wide-ranging and humane new book, ''Le Ton Beau de Marot'' (''A Poetical Head's Tone,'' perhaps), Douglas Hofstadter has much to say about music. The central subject on which he writes -- or rather, on, around, under and over which he writes -- is translation, which he likens to musical performance, then unlikens again.

title: School Construction Gets State Aid Boost
description: ALBANY'S more generous approach to school aid in the 1997-98 budget, representing a $750 million increase for a total expenditure of $11 billion, has brought relief to many school district leaders who in recent years have grown accustomed to less.

title: Nancy Greenspan and Lynn Wilson
description: Nancy Caroline Greenspan, a daughter of Joan Greenspan and Dr. Waldo Greenspan of River Edge, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Lynn Deyo Wilson, the son of the late Dr. Marjorie P. Wilson and Lynn M. Wilson, who lived in Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Fredric S. Dworkin performed the ceremony at the Edgewood Country Club in River Vale, N.J.

title: The Nation; Medicine Remains as Much Art as Science
description: AMERICANS have become used to the idea that medical treatments should be carefully tested to assure that they work and are safe. So there was surprise the last two weeks as two widely accepted practices were upended by researchers after they had affected the lives of millions of people.

title: Living an Adventure to the End
description: THREE WEEKS AGO, JUST days before he died, Sir Georg Solti was in a typically effusive state. With his 85th birthday approaching in October, he was facing a daunting schedule of concerts and commemorations.

title: Brown Thrashes Yale in an Inauspicious Debut for the Eli's New Coach
description: When Carm Cozza made his debut as the Yale football coach on Sept. 25, 1965, in the Yale Bowl, he endured the ignominy of losing to Connecticut, which had never beaten the Eli.

title: DIARY
description: TOBACCO

title: N.Y.P.D.: BY LAND, SEA AND AIR
description: The New York Police Department, founded in July 1845 with about 800 to 900 officers, created most special patrol units before the 1930's in an effort to get around the city in every way that criminals could. Today, in a department of 38,000 officers, the units use everything from horses to speedboats to helicopters. Here is a look at the evolution of three units.

title: Christine Gephardt And Marc Leibole
description: Christine Leigh Gephardt, a daughter of Representative Richard A. Gephardt and Mrs. Gephardt of St. Louis and Washington, was married yesterday to Marc Alan Leibole, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ted Leibole of Midland, Mich. The Rev. Dr. John Anderson, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Missouri Botanical Garden in St. Louis.

title: Fund for Preserving Land Sought
description: IN an effort to preserve open spaces against the onslaught of rapid development, the town of Greenburgh is preparing to place on the Nov. 4 ballot a referendum to finance a capital reserve fund for acquiring and protecting the municipality's remaining undeveloped land.

title: The Capitalist; The Case Against Tipping
description: No lawful behavior in the marketplace is as disturbing to me as the growing appeals for gratuities. Every gentle consumer of cappuccinos will know what I'm getting at: Just as you hand your money over to the man behind the counter, you notice a plastic beggar's cup beside the cash register. ''We Appreciate Your Tips,'' it reads in blue ink scrawled across the side with calculated indifference. The young man or woman behind the counter has performed no especially noteworthy service. He or she has merely handed you a $2 muffin and perhaps a ruinous cup of coffee and then rung them up on the register. Yet the plastic cup waits impatiently for an expression of your gratitude. A dollar bill or two juts suggestively over the rim -- no doubt placed there by the person behind the counter. Who would tip someone a dollar or more for pouring them a cup of coffee? But you can never be sure. The greenbacks might have been placed there by people who are more generous than yourself. People whose hearts are not made of flint.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Mao Game

title: Bouqui Kya-Hill And Guido Moller
description: Bouqui Ann Kya-Hill, the daughter of Sally and Robert Kya-Hill of New York, was married yesterday to Guido Wolfgang Moller, the son of Jutta and Wolfgang Moller of Lunen, Germany. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, a Reformed Church of America minister, officiated at the New York Marriott East Side Hotel.

title: Sir Alec's Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORST, RUTH
description: FORST-Ruth. Beloved wife of Jerry, devoted mother of Barbara and Jeffrey Peters, Jeffrey Korman, Jimmy and Helene Korman, Stephen & Ellie and Robert Forst. Loving daughter of Harriet Littwin. Dear sister of Steven Littwin and the late Cookie Grossman. Adored grandmother of Charlee, Freddy and Sammy Peters; Blake & Miles Korman; Adam and Tyler Forst. Funeral service Sunday, 10:30AM, Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street, (between Lexington & Third Avenue), NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the ''Ruth Forst Memorial Scholarship Fund'' of Park East Synagogue.

title: Garcia Wins Stage
description: Jose Vicente Garcia Acosta of Spain won the Tour of Spain's mountainous 14th stage yesterday as Switzerland's Alex Zulle widened his overall lead in the cycling race. Garcia Acosta finished the 99-mile ride from the northern city of Oviedo through winding mountainous roads to Naranco Peak in 4 hours 7 minutes 10 seconds. Italy's Mariano Piccoli finished 1 minute, 18 seconds behind Garcia Acosta. Zulle widened his lead to 1 minute 13 seconds over his countryman Laurent Dufaux, who finished more than 11 minutes behind Garcia Acosta yesterday.

title: The Heat Is Outside the Kitchen
description: I did not know that David Bouley rode motocycles with Lyle Lovett or that he dated Bernadette Peters (The Heat Is Outside the Kitchen,'' by David Blum, Aug. 17). What I do know is that when I would deliver vegetables grown on my family's organic farm, he was always there, stirring and tasting and arranging and tossing, just as you described. He'd stop to help me carry in the bags of tomatoes, coolers of lettuce and bunches of herbs and ask me about my family, the farm, the crops -- did I want any coffee? He made me feel that what my brother was growing and what I was delivering was extraordinary. He deserves every success.

title: Behrens Upsets Touch Gold at the Meadowlands
description: Behrens, a late-developing colt who did not make his first stakes start until July, pulled off a stunning upset in tonight's $1 million Buick Pegasus Handicap at the Meadowlands, pulling away to a 5 3/4-length victory over Anet while the odds-on favorite, Touch Gold, finished fourth and last.

title: Stolen Luggage
description: To the Editor: At the end of June, leaving Istanbul for New York, my husband and I encountered a new travel hazard: theft from the airport X-ray machine. Procedures at the airport made the theft relatively easy, despite the four security personnel looking on. No security people were on the side of the machine; all luggage, including heavy bags that were to be checked, had to pass through. The staff appeared interested only in the X-ray screen.

title: Special Education Is Not A Scandal
description: Before congress intervened, public schooling for disabled children ranged from dismal to truly barbaric. As recently as the 1970's, they could be found strapped into their chairs and screaming, in conditions reminiscent of the Dark Ages. The picture changed with the Education for All Handicapped Children Act of 1975 -- since renamed the Individuals With Disabilities Education Act -- which ordered the states to provide disabled children with ''a free, appropriate public education.'' The effort to comply has been hellishly expensive, and disabled students still fail or drop out more often than they succeed.

title: Cone Returns to the Mound, Yankees to the Playoffs
description: It wasn't so much that David Cone allowed six hits at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon. Or that he was charged with three runs, two of them earned. Or even that he pitched five innings, leaving with the Yankees trailing the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-1, in a game they would rally to win, 4-3, on a bases-loaded walk in the bottom of the 11th inning and thereby clinch the wild-card berth in the American League.

title: INSIDE
description: Campaign Trail Conversion

title: Q and A
description: Viewing the Turin Shroud

title: Mets Beat The Heat, As Well As Marlins
description: By the fifth inning today against the Florida Marlins, Mets' third baseman Edgardo Alfonzo was so dizzy he had to retreat to the locker room and douse himself in water.

title: Holocaust Memorials Multiplying on Island
description: ACROSS Long Island the last generation to live in the presence of Holocaust survivors is making a determined effort to preserve the words of those who remain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, PHYLLIS
description: MEYER-Phyllis. My dear sister and best pal. Loving aunt of Rebecca Valuch and Russell Dash. Great-aunt of David and Rachel. I'll miss you so very much. Services 1:30 PM, Sunday, September 21, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. Ethel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, SOL
description: FRIED-Sol. Living is what he loved-Loving is what he got-No complaining for him-He traveled the optimistic highway of lifeTaking us along with him. It was a great trip for those-Who really knew him!

title: Nina Jaffe, Jason Vianese
description: Nina Beth Jaffe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Jaffe of Cheshire, Conn., is to be married today to Joseph Jason Vianese, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Vianese of Syracuse. Rabbi Dennis S. Ross is to perform the ceremony at Blantyre, an inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: Adding Sweat and Muscle To a Familiar Formula
description: YOU can usually tell that you are in the offices of a women's magazine as soon as you walk off the elevator. Racks of clothing crowd the corridors, waiting to be photographed for a fashion spread. The smell of baking from test kitchens clashes with the scent of perfumes to be featured in the beauty pages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATKIN, BERTHA
description: SLATKIN-Bertha. Beloved wife of the late Max. Loving mother of Edgar, David, Claire and the late Sondra. Caring grandmother and great - grandmother. Graveside services on Monday, 10:30AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: A Nice Kettle of Fish
description: COD

title: Shortage of Rooms In San Francisco
description: Travelers to San Francisco this fall are finding that hotel rooms are more expensive than last year and harder to come by.

title: Research Balloons That End Up in Ocean May Endanger Whales
description: The plastic balloons that physicists use to gather information about weather, climate, ozone depletion and cosmic rays may pose a serious threat to endangered species of whales, an aquatic ecologist at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory has warned.

title: An Irish Hotelier's Bad Luck
description: ''Those dancing days are gone,'' lamented John Baxter, an old Irish import who arrived on the banks of the Hudson in 1952 with a head stuffed with Yeats and songs of whisky and women.

title: Equity Funds Gallop Past a Big Benchmark
description: FOR the first time in many quarters, well over three-fourths of all domestic stock funds are beating the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

title: The Country Lanes Where Broadway Summered
description: THE STORY GOES LIKE THIS: In 1940, Oscar Hammerstein 2d hadn't had a hit in more than nine years. It looked grim. He and his wife, Dorothy, were taking a drive in the country when, in the middle of Bucks County, Pa., they spotted a rainbow. It was an omen, they decided, so they followed it along the winding roads and came upon a farm that was for sale. They bought the place and moved in, and the next year Hammerstein won an Academy Award for his song ''The Last Time I Saw Paris'' in the film ''Lady Be Good.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMOSE, CELIA
description: SAMOSE-Celia. In loving memory of your birthday, September 19th. Grandchildren

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Clinton, Mo., Journal; 5 Generations of Meeting Deadlines
description: In Henry County and in Clinton, its hub, anyone who is born, marries, dies, enters or leaves the hospital, has a birthday party, graduates, needs help or wins an award gets mentioned in The Clinton Daily Democrat.

title: Arriving From Afar to Get Inside America
description: THE YEAR IS 1973, AND AMERICA IS A country where all bets are suddenly off. President Nixon tiptoes through the shards of Vietnam, Watergate and a nation's shattered trust. Men and women eye each other warily, uncertain about the new rules wrought by feminism and a sexual revolution. And in a house in the woodlands of New Canaan, Conn., the members of the Hood family gather for Thanksgiving and brace themselves against a chill that has little to do with the gusts of late November.

title: Pipe Dreams; A Perilous New Contest for the Next Oil Prize
description: IN donating $300,000 to Democratic Party organizations during the 1996 campaign, an ambitious businessman named Roger E. Tamraz sought access to President Clinton and other senior officials so he could ask them to support his project for a new oil pipeline from the Caspian Sea.

title: Money Goes Fast-Forward In Celebration of Its Past
description: MONEY magazine has seen the future, and it's Hollywood. The one in Florida, not California.

title: ART REVIEW ; Novel Ways of Painting the Familiar
description: PAINTERS still use familiar, straightforward imagery, but after modernism and the ascendancy of abstraction, they use it in a subtly different way; their choice of subject matter reflects an implicit statement about what painting is. On those grounds, the exhibitions of paintings and works on paper by Jill Kerwick and Betsey Regan at the Thompson Park Galleries here might be seen as a sort of polite debate that goes something like this: is a painting more like a place, something you can look at with the objective gaze of an eye scanning a landscape? Or is it something that looks back at you, the way an animal can suddenly catch your eye in a manner that unexpectedly suggests human consciousness?

title: September 14-20; Thanks a Billion, Ted
description: Ted Turner, the brash founder of Cable News Network, described the decision as ''spur of the moment,'' like ''deciding you're going to buy a new car.'' Some car. He had just decided to give the United Nations a billion dollars.

title: New Jersey Schools Planning to Sue State
description: At least 25 school districts in New Jersey are planning to sue the state by October, saying they have raised property taxes as high as homeowners can bear but still cannot cover the cost of the state's new academic standards, which are supposed to guarantee a quality education.

title: True Romance; Goethe Is Outed And Germany Yawns
description: WAS Goethe gay? And if he was, does it change the reader's understanding of his greatness? The answer to both questions, according to Karl Hugo Pruys, is a resounding yes.

title: Cone Puts Yankees' Minds at Ease
description: Cito Gaston didn't intend the double meaning. He merely meant to deliver the highest of compliments.

title: Parental Involvement Makes Better Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; There's a Place For Every Pet, Sort Of
description: SATURDAY is the biggest adoption day of the week at the Elmsford Animal Shelter. It's a crazy scene you'd find at any shelter, only more so. The shelter, a big white building on five acres, is bigger than most. It has about 500 cats and 600 dogs, and there are times when they all seem to be making noise at once.

title: Scotland Yarns
description: Nothing is quite what it used to be. Scotland is now better known for cutting-edge films than kilts, and tweeds have gone trendy with a new, offbeat personality. Where better than Glasgow, with everything from gritty shipyards to Charles Rennie Mackintosh's School of Art, to document the innovative styling, vibrant colors and unexpected combinations seen here? You'll find a mix of patterns, like a plaid sport jacket with mini-check trousers, and a mix of colors, like a gold cable sweater with a purple corduroy shirt. Even orange and lime have their places in this new country look. What's more, cardigans come with zippers, suede coats are knee-length, hooded sweaters are an option, and sport coats often have belted backs and bellows-style front pockets. Scottish lairds would be amazed.

title: Christina Wiedenhaefer, W. S. Meyer
description: Christina Marie Wiedenhaefer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Wiedenhaefer of Oyster Bay, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Willets Symington Meyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Meyer of Cove Neck, N.Y. The Rev. Malcolm J. Burns performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ROSALYN (NEE AVEDON)
description: SIEGEL-Rosalyn (nee Avedon). Of Freeport, on September 14. Beloved sister of Richard and the late Maxine and Doris. So rare, the dear wife of Edwin.

title: Parental Involvement Makes Better Students; Teaching the Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on July 27 about tax credits for investments in low-income housing misstated the name and location of a company that sells such credits to corporate markets. It is the Arcand Company of Portland, Ore., not Arkand & Company of Seattle. The Portland company telephoned on Sept. 10 about the errors.

title: When an Unofficial Military Presence Is Welcome
description: WHEN A HOLLYWOOD movie maker turns to the military for technical advice and for access to bases and equipment, the military gets to look at a script and play critic.

title: New Plumage
description: THE BIRDCAGE (1996), Mike Nichols's film excursion onto delicate ground, lands squarely on target. It's not only tasteful but tasty -- a droll sophisticated caper from a Broadway hit adding, finally, wit to ''La Cage aux Follies.''

title: The Colorado, From River To Lake
description: ON the west side of Hoover Dam, two 30-foot bronze figures sit with upraised wings and forbidding expressions, like fierce angels welcoming me to the state of Nevada. Behind them, as far as the eye can see, lies Lake Mead. Here at the bottom of the Colorado River canyon, even on a day of brilliant winter sun and high-desert warmth, the walls give off a feeling of remote disapproval. The magnificent accomplishments of men, the great feats of engineering that elevate us to the level of angels, mean little or nothing in geologic time. Dam building is one of nature's oldest occupations, and every landslide, every plug of lava that stopped the river in its tracks for hundreds, even thousands of years, eventually gave way to the forces of erosion until the river once again ran free.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: DINOSAURS OF THE FLAMING CLIFFS

title: How to Run Electrical Wires Through Walls
description: POSSIBLY the hardest part of installing a new outlet or switch is running the new wires through the walls. This job is often frustrating because you cannot look into the wall to guide the wires. Frequently, obstructions within the cavity, like fire stops, will block your attempts to run a wire from one location to another.

title: Atomic Guinea Pigs
description: Your photo essay Atomic Guinea Pigs (by Michael D'Antonio, photographs by Dan Winters, Aug. 31) was disturbing. Equally disturbing is that such disclosures are invariably declassified and made public decades after the fact.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FOWLER, ANDERSON
description: FOWLER-Anderson. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 23rd, St. Luke's Church, Peapack, N.J. at 11 A.M.

title: Jennifer Gordon and Adam Gross
description: Jennifer Brett Gordon, a daughter of Elaine Taylor-Gordon of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Mort Gordon of New York, was married last evening to Adam Michael Gross, a son of Barbara S. Abramo of Stratford, Conn., and Fred Gross of Louisville, Ky. Rabbi Dennis N. Math officiated at Bridgewaters in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEICHER, SUSAN T.
description: SCHLEICHER-Susan T. She died peacefully at home on September 9, 1997, at 94. A very special human being. Former Broadway actress (stage name Suzanne Powers), successful business executive. Wife of the late Rowell A. Schleicher, supportive mother and grandmother. In spirit, she will always be with us.

title: Nocturne In Black And Lace
description: THE invitation looked like a vampire's valentine: a black matte card veiled in a shroud of lace. Who could refuse? Virtually everyone who attended the Visionaire party on Tuesday religiously followed the seductively simple dress code: ''black/lace.'' Variations on the theme ranged from barely there to beyond Barbarella.

title: Susan Carroll, James Dineen
description: Susan Jean Carroll and James Joseph Dineen were married yesterday by the Rev. George Easter at the Episcopal Church of St. John in the Wilderness in Paul Smiths, N.Y.

title: Uncle Charlie's Closes and With It, Perhaps, an Era
description: It was 1987, and Rick Whitaker had just arrived in New York from Ohio. He was told that if he visited just one gay bar in the city, it should be Uncle Charlie's Downtown, on Greenwich Avenue.

title: 3 Accused of Beating Black Man in Suspected Bias Crime
description: A black man who had stopped to use a pay phone in Brooklyn early yesterday morning was attacked by three white teen-agers while a friend stood by helplessly, the police said.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: VARIETY spices the movie menu on television this week: a bleak melodrama reflecting the spirit of the American Depression; a western with no holds barred; a frightening classic of black comedy, and a transposition from the Broadway stage.

title: Earning Way Is Not Racism
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Q&A; Helping Asian Women Find Their Voices
description: WHO Dr. Margaret Varma, director and founder of the Leadership Institute for Women of Asia and the Pacific Islands, an organization based at Rutgers University that works to improve the leadership skills of Asian women and students.

title: In a Report on Welfare, Trends but No Final Verdict
description: Much of the public has long believed that welfare mothers bear more children simply to receive larger government checks. Four years ago New Jersey became the first state to adopt a policy to stop that practice, if indeed it was occurring.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Main Road White

title: Bettina Ranis, Eric Altschuler
description: Bettina Suzanne Ranis, the daughter of Rachel and Gustav Ranis of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married today to Dr. Eric Lewin Altschuler, the son of Sheila Brody of New York. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik is to perform the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Yeltsin Foe Tries to Harness the Military's Discontent
description: Decked out in his green general's uniform, Lev Rokhlin told his nascent political movement today that he had one overriding goal: the resignation of President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Some Tips for Protecting a Home
description: ''BURGLARY is the crime with the most frequency here,'' said the Fairfield Police Chief Joseph Sambrook, so when the regional task force was formed, his town ''jumped right in'' and he feels it has already been ''a major deterrent to burglars.''

title: Andrew Weil, Shaman, M.D.
description: Even Dr. Weil's homilies are wrong (Andrew Weil, Shaman, M.D.,'' by Larissa MacFarquhar, Aug. 24): ''the body can heal itself....we have all seen scabs form on a cut -- but we tend to forget it, and so we turn to drugs and surgery.'' But as any dermatologist knows, once the bleeding has stopped, a scab impedes the granulation and re-epithelialization required for healing. Faster healing and less scarring can be achieved by gently removing the scab by soaking, then keeping the area moist with an antibacterial ointment and an artificial semi-occlusive dressing.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Lights in the Sky

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMPION, GEORGE
description: CHAMPION-George. The Board of Governors of The Sky Club deeply mourns the passing of our former Governor. We wish to extend our condolences to the entire family. John J. Sullivan, President

title: Ann Asch and Joseph Forristal
description: Ann Margaret Asch, the manager of licensing and product development at the Giorgio Armani Corporation in New York, was married on Friday to Joseph Forristal, a scriptwriter and producer, in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York, from which the bride graduated.

title: Arthur T. Roth, 91; Built Long Island Bank
description: Arthur T. Roth, a driving force in the consumer banking business and in the development of Long Island, died Wednesday at his home in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 91.

title: Moscow Cathedral
description: To the Editor: I was amazed to see your photograph of the Cathedral of Christ the Saviour being resurrected on the banks of the Moscow River (''At 850, Moscow Takes a Bow,'' Aug. 17). I have long been interested in this church.

title: Middle Eastern Cuisine for the Adventurous
description: THE new Aladdin restaurant is a stylish surprise in a storefront at the far end of the Syosset Plaza at 629 Jericho Turnpike, Syosset (921-7777). It is ideal for diners who seek adventurous eating. The food, billed as fine Middle Eastern cuisine, is a vibrant melange of the dishes of Greece, Morocco and Turkey, among others, prepared by Iranian chefs, sometimes with an unexpectedly sweet spin.

title: With Election Day Nearing, Think Spring
description: IT'S that time of year again: Bulbs. Even though the garden is glorious with many late-blooming flowers, this truly is the time to think about spring.

title: Andrew Weil, Shaman, M.D.
description: Would it be indelicate to suggest that at least some of Andrew Weil's inspiriting messages sound like schlock Walt Whitman? In your article, Weil utters such nuggets as My heart fills with loving kindness -- I love myself.'' And here is Whitman in section 24 of Song of Myself'': ''I dote on myself, there is that lot of me and all so luscious/Each moment and whatever happens thrills me with joy. ...''

title: Furniture Scarlett Might Have Used To Deck Out Tara
description: A HALF CENTURY AGO, Joseph Downs, the legendary curator of the American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, told scholars and collectors attending the first Williamsburg Antiques Forum in Virginia that as far as American furniture was concerned, little of artistic merit was made south of Baltimore.

title: Cannes, Venice . . . the South Bronx
description: WHO says television lacks redeeming social values? As Paul Lipson, associate director of the Point, a social service agency in Hunts Point, watched ''The Simpsons,'' an idea struck. The Simpsons' mythical hometown, Springfield, started its own film festival, and Mr. Lipson thought the South Bronx could use the same thing, said Majora Carter, a coordinator of the festival. The first South Bronx Film Festival opens Thursday at the Point, with two dozen films competing for honors in four categories: documentary, narrative, experimental and films about the Bronx.

title: Julie Harman, Keith Levenson
description: Julie Ann Harman, a television director, and Keith Lewis Levenson, a conductor and musical supervisor, are to be married this afternoon in Wilton, Conn. Rabbi Jon R. Haddon is to officiate at the home of Martin Charnin and Jade Hobson Charnin, friends of the couple.

title: What Is Mainstream Politics And What Is Fringe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kelly Jackson, David Schnabel
description: Kelly Leanne Jackson and David Henry Schnabel, associates at the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, were married yesterday at the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Dr. William Crouch, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: SOAPBOX; Portrait in Blue
description: MY father recently retired from police work after 30 years on the job. He left rather uneventfully, working a regular day, cleaning out his locker, and turning in his gun and badge at the end of his shift.

title: Old-Fashioned Vitamin C Is the Hot New Beautifier
description: VITAMIN C is not just for breakfast anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, NORMAN DUDLEY
description: JOHNSON-Norman Dudley. The Allen-Stevenson School records with great sadness the death of Norman Dudley Johnson, an alumnus from the Class of 1922, father of Ridgely Couper Johnson '73 and Norman Platt Johnson '70, and former trustee of the School. Ronald S. Rolfe '60 President of the Board David R. Trower, Headmaster

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVITT, STACY
description: LEVITT-Stacy. 9 years ago we parted in the Dentist's office. We'll always miss you, Sweetie. Love, Mommy and Michael

title: Advertising Agency Finds Niche in Irvington
description: ''IT was like changing hubcaps on a moving car,'' said Gregory Hoffman, speaking about the momentum generated by the Yellowstone Group, an advertising agency, shortly after it opened its doors for business.

title: Charles Colson's Christian Prison
description: Texas can put 'em away -- from 1992 to 1995 the state spent $1.5 billion to nearly triple prison capacity -- but, like everywhere else, it has trouble keeping them from coming back. Of 139,000 prisoners now doing time in Texas, officials predict that almost half will return someday. Can anything stop the recidivism? At Jester II, a small, decrepit prison west of Houston, 36 convicts are taking part in a new program called Inner Change, financed and run by Charles Colson's Prison Fellowship Ministries, a private contractor that arranged this cooperative experiment with the state. Though it will take years to find out if the nation's ''first Christian prison'' does any good, boosters tout it as revolutionary. Here's a look.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HATAB, LILA
description: HATAB-Lila. 9/21/79. We miss you very much and love you more. George, Larry, Helen, Anne, Paul and John

title: Tomorrow's Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Cinematically Deprived
description: It is the most ''underscreened'' area in town, to use an industry expression: Battery Park City, at Manhattan's southern tip, two miles or more from any meaningful concentration of movie theaters. And though theaters have long been planned, nothing has come to fruition, with previous projects falling victim to adverse economic conditions and financing problems.

title: Greta Austin, Clark Lombardi
description: Greta Austin, a daughter of Shirley and George Austin of Madison, Wis., and Clark Benner Lombardi, the son of Rosemarie and Bonnell Lombardi of Washington, Conn., were married yesterday in Dodgeville, Wis. Pastor Ronald Seymour, a brother-in-law of the bride, performed the ceremony with Pastor Duane Hanson at Bethel Horizons, the summer camp of the Madison Bethel Lutheran Church.

title: Oliver Stone Doesn't Want to Start an Argument
description: Labor Day weekend couldn't have begun better for Oliver Stone. On the day of its premiere at the Telluride Film Festival in the Colorado mountains, ''U-Turn,'' his 13th film as a director, was reviewed glowingly by both Variety and The Hollywood Reporter. In Variety, Todd McCarthy wrote, ''Few, if any, directors with as many films under his belt as Stone has, are displaying this kind of stylistic urgency and restlessness, without the slightest speck of Hollywood complacency in evidence.''

title: If You're Thinking of Traveling to China, Try This Route
description: On an August day in 1271, if the story is to be believed, a four-masted ship sailed into the crowded harbor of Zaitun in southeast China, carrying a gray-bearded Italian Jewish trader named Jacob.

title: Horse Farming: A Way to Save Open Land?
description: WITH the 22d annual Hampton Classic horse show drawing over 70,000 people this year, and rows of fencing along green pastures becoming a more common sight, the East End is seeing a boom in horse farming. For some, equine sports symbolize the leisure time of the rich, for others a time-honored tradition. Yet beyond this may lie a solution to over-development: horse farming as a preserver of open space.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THEATER AND ART

title: Atomic Guinea Pigs
description: In all five cases you present, everyone is still alive, except for one person who died in 1991 at the age of 80. These people have developed various ailments, like cancer and degenerative diseases of the spine.

title: Whatever Happened to John?
description: IMAGINE a classroom of 40 squirming grade-schoolers. There's possibly a spitball thrower among them, and maybe a teacher's pet. But there is almost surely a Michael and an Ashley. For the last three decades, those names have led the national popularity list for baby boys and girls, according to onomasticians, the people who study such things.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON LINE -- THE FIVE POINTS SITE: http://R2.gsa.gov/fivept/fphome.htm; New York's Lengendary Slum
description: When construction began in the early 1990's for the new United States Court House in lower Manhattan, workers unearthed hundreds of thousands of artifacts from Five Points, the most notorious neighborhood of 19th-century Manhattan. Charles Dickens in 1842 described Five Points as such a center of debauchery that he wondered why residents walked ''upright in lieu of going on all-fours.''

title: QUICK BITE/Sea Bright; A Muffin Baker Who Learned His Lessons Well
description: Tired of stale muffins being delivered late to his diner in Sea Bright, Stephen A. Garelli, who opened Steve's Breakfast & Lunch almost 21 years ago, taught himself to bake.

title: Uneasy Partners
description: THE CLASH

title: Kelly Smith, C. P. O'Hara
description: Kelly Susan Smith and Christopher Peter O'Hara were married yesterday at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. The Rev. Matthew Leavy, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony with Canon John Morrow, an Episcopal priest. Reverend Leavy is the abbott of St. Anselm's Monastery and the president of St. Anselm's College in Manchester, N.H.

title: Q. & A.
description: A Lease With a Minor

title: Rubin Warns of Asia Trade Backlash
description: With economic troubles in Southeast Asia and Japan and China's exports booming, Administration officials meeting with finance ministers from around the world said today that they feared the United States was headed toward a revival of huge trade deficits with Asia that could provoke a backlash in Congress.

title: Life in the Bus Lane: The Inside Story
description: GULP a cup of coffee. Grab the briefcase. Catch the bus.

title: Style; A Dashing Figure
description: One day not too long ago, I got on my rusty old bicycle and pedaled down to Century 21, the designer discount field of dreams in Lower Manhattan. I was in search of something gray, which I had heard was the new black, although something brown, the other new black, might also suffice. It had been a while since I'd been on a shopping tear. But after two years of hearing about flat-front trousers and how black is over, the pressure had become too much, and I was feeling tremors of acquisitiveness.

title: Ms. McLoughlin And Mr. Connolly
description: Sheila Ann McLoughlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Stephen McLoughlin of Garden City, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Francis Connolly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis Connolly, also of Garden City. The Rev. John McLoughlin, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church.

title: 'Jewish' Songs By Anti-Semites
description: UNDER A PAINFULLY hokey title, ''Tradition!! Jewish Songs From Russia'' (one exclamation point is not enough?), Koch International has issued a perfectly fascinating collection and done everything possible to hide the fact. The content of this CD (DICD 920259) is admirable; the packaging is an absolute disgrace.

title: SOAPBOX; Brutality Isn't Part of New Tactics
description: THE case of Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who prosecutors say was brutalized on Aug. 9 in the basement of the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn, has many New Yorkers complaining that Mayor Guiliani's assertive anticrime strategies cause police brutality. But Mr. Guiliani is about as much to blame for what happened to Mr. Louima as Jodie Foster was in John Hinckley's shooting of President Reagan.

title: For the First Time in Memory, Boston Has No Mayoral Contest
description: Ah, says many a Bostonian, what I would not give in these political dog days for the rhetorical pirouettes of an Al Sharpton, or even for the wonkish erudition of a Ruth W. Messinger or the belligerence of a Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YARETT, JEROME W., D.D.S.
description: YARETT-Jerome W., D.D.S. Devoted and loving husband of Eva. Wonderful father of Deborah and Jordan. Beloved grandfather of Joshua, Gabriel, Ian and Roger. Father-in-law of Richard and Susan. Services Sunday, 2 PM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: Magical Number Is Due Up in Seattle: 3,000,000
description: This Wednesday night baseball will experience what could be considered the most remarkable development of the season, maybe of many seasons. This Wednesday night the Seattle Mariners will hit the three million mark in attendance. The Seattle Mariners.

title: A Sports Proposal Passes
description: ALTHOUGH residents of Greenburgh Central School District 7 approved a $203,000 proposition to finance sports and extracurricular activities in a special vote on Sept. 10, voters rejected two other proposals to spend an additional $709,460 to support a computer program and buy equipment and furniture and two buses and build a new playground at the Highview Elementary School.

title: Sports of The Times; For the Giants' Brian Williams, the Future Is Just 50-50
description: BRIAN WILLIAMS doesn't appear to be different from any of his Giants teammates. He sits in the offensive-line meetings. He lifts weights. He runs. He's been on the sideline at games. He prowls the locker room, a big man with a big smile.

title: Drama Backstage at the Levitt Pavilion in Westport
description: FORMALITY filled the air at the outdoor pavilion in Westport. Classical music was the night's free entertainment, and those who walked onto the grassy, riverfront concert area seemed pretty serious. Pavilion workers darted about to make sure everything -- from the sound system to the bug zappers to the buffet table -- was just right.

title: A New Season, New Voices
description: IF it isn't one new era, it's another. Over the next two seasons, a transition at the top in two of the state's major theaters is bound to create a buzz.

title: Stacey Siegel, Michael Bloom
description: Stacey Ruth Siegel, the daughter of Gloria and Alan M. Siegel of New York, was married last evening to Michael Alan Bloom, the son of Phyllis Beck Bloom of Morristown, N.J., and Ivan Bloom of Chicago. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Top Mob Figure Is Losing U.S. Backing for Leniency
description: In the late 1980's and early 90's, Anthony S. Casso was one of the top Mafia figures in New York. Known by the nickname Gaspipe, he was portrayed by the authorities as a vicious, hot-blooded killer in $2,000 suits.

title: Lemon Helps Bring Out The Essence of Foods
description: WHATEVER did cooks do without lemons? I thought about this the other day as I prepared a platter of grilled eggplant, peppers and zucchini for guests.

title: The Heat Is Outside the Kitchen
description: Alan Richman, GQ's restaurant critic, couldn't be more off the mark when he says: The Austrians lost wars because of their food. After an Austrian lunch, you couldn't remount.'' Extensive scientific research has shown that countries with great cuisine hardly ever win wars -- not because the food is heavy'' but because their people would rather eat than fight.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Jail Contract Renewed

title: Corrections
description: A headline about the Turkish region of Cappadocia on Aug. 31 referred incorrectly to the creators of early chapels and religious paintings there. The works were made by Christians several centuries before Turkic tribes arrived in the region; thus they are not by Turkish Christians.

title: Stanley Garfinkel, 67, Documentary Producer
description: Stanley N. Garfinkel, a historian and documentary film producer, died on Monday at University Hospital in Cleveland. He was 67 and lived in Cleveland.

title: Returning to Its Roots, and Prospering
description: LORD ABBETT is not a company known for its management of growth stocks. But it has a standout now in the Lord Abbett Developing Growth fund.

title: Streetscapes/National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South; The Literary 1884 Facade of Samuel J. Tilden's House
description: WHEN the restoration scaffolding goes up on the National Arts Club at 15 Gramercy Park South in November, the building will be obscured for two years. So there is still time, in advance of its restoration, to consider the curious Gothic-style facade put up in 1884 by Samuel J. Tilden, eight years after he narrowly missed being elected President of the United States.

title: A New Gentleness From a Pop Diva
description: MARIAH CAREY SINGS softly and carries a big torch on her new album, ''Butterfly.'' Yes, she can still hit whistling high notes and let loose gospelly curlicues; now and then, she does. But for most of ''Butterfly'' (Columbia), Carey has decided to turn her voice into an airy whisper, as if she would rather charm listeners than overpower them.

title: The Stealth Chancellor
description: Everyone postulates about what's wrong with the schools, but no one seems to respect the insights of the teachers, except when it comes time to blame a troubled system. If Crew is looking for talent, as he says, it's not because the talent isn't out there, it's that it goes where it is appreciated.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: The Swashbucklers Of the South; Dungy Has the Bucs Doing Everything Right
description: Five games. Five losses. Tony Dungy's initiation last season as the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' head coach was turning heads, all of them the wrong way.

title: Behind Turmoil For Teamsters, Rush for Cash
description: Late last September, Michael Ansara, a Harvard radical turned telemarketing millionaire, was visiting the Washington townhouse of his friend Martin Davis, a brash, 36-year-old fund-raiser for liberal causes, when Mr. Davis made a surprise plea concerning the teamsters' union.

title: Family Style
description: Here I was, ready to argue that I am predisposed to the classic look -- darkish suits, button-down shirts, khaki pants. That I inherited whatever it is that drives me to dress this way from my father's end of the gene pool.

title: Courtney Cooney, Topher Solmssen
description: Courtney Carroll Cooney, the archivist at the Gagosian Gallery in New York, was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., to Christopher Todd Solmssen, a research analyst at Sun America Asset Management in New York. The Most Rev. Edmond Lee Browning, the primate and presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, U.S.A., performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in West Tisbury, Mass. The Rev. James Martin, a minister of the United Church of Christ, took part in the service.

title: To Those Who Knew Diana's Driver, His Actions Are an Unsettling Puzzle
description: Henri Paul, the man who died behind the wheel in the crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, and her escort three weeks ago, was buried this morning, leaving his family and friends still perplexed by official findings that he drank heavily and took antidepressant drugs before the accident.

title: Racial Tension in Dallas School System Intensifies Over Lawsuit
description: The racial turmoil that has roiled this city's school system in recent years intensified again this week as the new superintendent of schools offered to resign after a lawsuit accused her of sexual harassment and about 300 high school students walked out of classes in her support.

title: Jewel With a Past Reigns in New Gallery
description: The fabled Hope Diamond, once thought to bring bad luck to anyone who owned it, is to be the star attraction of a new hall that the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History was scheduled to open yesterday.

title: 3 Retrospectives on East End's Center Stage
description: Peter Blanc

title: States to Give More Children Health Coverage
description: In the largest expansion of government-paid health insurance since the formation of Medicaid 32 years ago, states say they will soon be providing free or low-cost health care to at least half the nation's 10 million uninsured children.

title: The Stuff Of Legends
description: Toasting the New York Philharmonic, women in fashion, the publication Visionaire, the Conservatory Garden in Central Park and Kitty Carlisle Hart.

title: Edith Pepper And Tad Goltra
description: Edith Morton Pepper, a daughter of Anne E. McLucas of Washington and Charles W. Pepper of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Edward Seipp Goltra, a son of Catherine P. Mack of The Plains, Va., and Peter S. Goltra of Middleburg, Va. The Rev. John Mack, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Claremont, a hotel in Southwest Harbor, Me.

title: Manning's Nightmare Continues
description: At 8:30 last night the Manning family emerged from the visitors' locker room at Florida Field into a balmy evening. Olivia Manning came first, with one of her sons. Her husband, Archie Manning, the Ole Miss legend and former National Football League star, walked with their son Peyton, the Tennessee quarterback and Heisman Trophy candidate.

title: Culinary Escapes In Busy Midtown
description: BOBBY VAN'S STEAKHOUSE * $(rating: one star$)

title: Sanchez Vicario And Seles Advance
description: Arantxa Sanchez Vicario staved off seven match points and defeated Yayuk Basuki of Indonesia in the semifinals of the Toyota Princess Cup in Tokyo yesterday to advance to the title match against Monica Seles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCALL, MARSH, M.D.
description: McCALL-Marsh, M.D. Cardiologist, Medical Director of Beekman Downtown Hospital, NYC 1945-1965, Medical Consultant for the City of New York Fire Department 1975-1997, Colonel US Army Medical Corp 1942-1945. Died on September 19, 1997. Born in Tazewell, VA, December 16, 1903. Husband of the late Josephine Suddards. Father of Dixianne Penney and Marsh McCall, Jr. Father-inlaw of Thomas Penney, III and Susan McCall. Also survived by one granddaughter and four grandsons. Reposing at the family home, 25 Truesdale Lake Drive, South Salem, Sunday 3-5 PM. Funeral service at the South Salem Presbyterian Church Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to The Elsasser Fund ''Fireman's Widows and Orphans'', 204 W. 23rd St, NY NY 10010.

title: Mr. MacCracken and Ms. Whitehead
description: Kimberly Dale Whitehead, a daughter of Dorothy and Stephen Whitehead of Birmingham, Ala., was married on Friday to Mark Mitchell MacCracken, a son of Martha M. Howard of New London, N.H., and Calvin D. MacCracken of Englewood, N.J. Colleen Farry, a marriage celebrant for Queensland, Australia, officiated at the Hayman Island resort in Queensland.

title: Five Reporters Assaulted in Mexico in Efforts to Intimidate Them
description: With violent crime and revelations of police corruption in Mexico's capital surging, five news reporters covering the police have suffered attacks in the last month that were intended to intimidate them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWELL, ALLEYNE CARLETON JR.
description: HOWELL-Alleyne Carleton Jr. Of Fairfield, CT., President and Founder of the Howell Corp. died Sept. 16, 1997 in Bridgeport, CT. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, Sept. 25 at 11:30 AM in the Spear Funeral Home, 39 South Benson Road, Fairfield, CT.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; The Clipping of a Perk
description: THE company barber shop closed the other day, leaving 200 men and women in sheer frustration. A cherished benefit has been clipped, and now we must bear the hairy consequences.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Triumph of Meanness

title: Police Investigating Claim of Brutality
description: A man arrested in Washington Heights Thursday on drug possession charges claims he was beaten by the police, a Police Department spokeswoman said last night.

title: Just What's Under the Redding Green?
description: THE Old Green at Redding Center, the Old Town House on one end and the Congregational Church and its parsonage on the other, seem to hark back to the quietude of an earlier age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLENS, DR. BENJAMIN C.
description: MULLENS-Dr. Benjamin C. September 14 at age 85 in Palo Alto, California. Former longtime resident of Binghamton, New York. Past President of the Podiatry Society of the State of New York. Past President of the American Podiatry Association. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father of Judy Cohen, Steven Mullens and Dr. David Mullens. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Sarah, Jed, Scott, Jessica and Jonah. Devoted brother of Roy Sall, Arnold Mullens and Phyllis Siskin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISENSON, ARNOLD, M.D.
description: NISENSON-Arnold, M.D. On September 19, 1997. Devoted husband, father, grandfather and dedicated Podiatrist. May Mozart play in heaven for him. Shiva at home.

title: Crime
description: What can the 35-year-old Jesse Stone do that the ageless and presumably immutable Spenser can't? That's the question that keeps nagging as you read NIGHT PASSAGE (Putnam, $21.95), Robert B. Parker's strong first entry in a projected series about an alcoholic homicide detective struggling to rebuild his ruined life.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Model-Minority Myth Is Unfair to Blacks; Don't Forget Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about mistakes in a series of placards at Yankee Stadium honoring past players referred incorrectly to Rick Cerrone, a spokesman who commented on behalf of the Yankees. He is not a former catcher with the team. The former Yankee catcher is Rick Cerone, now a television announcer for the team.

title: Women's Place
description: THE HUNGER MOON

title: Where the Wild Things Meet; Tiny Thumbs Up for New Central Park Children's Zoo
description: They crawled through giant logs. They jumped from stump to stump and watched African goats doing the same thing. They saw a guinea fowl lay an egg. They swarmed over a simulated spider web like giggling insects. They felt tongues tickle their little fingers as they fed goats, sheep and a Vietnamese potbellied pig.

title: Anger and Confusion Mark Mood at Brookhaven Lab
description: FROM senior scientists and maintenance workers, feelings of confusion and anger are mounting among the 3,100 employees of the Brookhaven National Laboratory as the lab goes through the most uncertain and troubled period in its 50 years.

title: September 14-20; No Second Chance, After All
description: It appeared that the Rev. Al Sharpton had achieved a remarkable upset: coming in second in New York's Democratic mayoral primary but winning enough votes to force a runoff with the first-place finisher, Ruth W. Messinger.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Every single state I have talked to has begun the planning process of expanding children's health care.''

title: A Bet on Electric Bikes, Or at Least on Lee Iacocca
description: IT is a tiny company that has toiled for 14 years on the technological frontier of electric vehicles, but it has yet to turn a profit.

title: Users of Pay Phones Confront New Rules
description: A MESSAGE appeared on the beeper that Monte M. Rosenzweig kept on his belt. It was from a customer, asking him to call immediately.

title: One Hand Out and One Held Back
description: The turmoil of the on-again, off-again Democratic runoff has left the party's newly designated candidate for mayor, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, in a political quandary that would challenge even the most seasoned and wily campaigner.

title: Ornaments Of the Ages As Homage To Identity
description: BODY adornment, one of the world's oldest art forms, is the subject of an exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through Nov. 9. ''The Splendor of Adornment'' examines the universal passion for ornamentation from 3500 B.C. to the present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, ROBERT H.
description: BERKOWITZ-Robert H. The Board of Governors and members of Bocaire Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Thursday, September 18, 1997. He will be missed. Services will be held Sunday, September 21, 10AM at Apter Funeral Parlor in Maplewood, NJ. Barry Berger, President

description: To the Editor:
