description: Fostering Human Rights

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMGARTNER, FRANCES
description: BAUMGARTNER-Frances. On September 20, 1997 after a long illness. She was a dedicated volunteer for over 30 years at The Lighthouse for the Blind, New York City and also was employed by Rubin Donnoley Corp. of New York City. Beloved sister of Edith O. Katz of Sarasota, Florida and Lillian Kiesler of New York City. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, 1PM at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue (9th and 10th Streets). Contributions in her memory may be made to: The Lighthouse for the Blind or Cabrini Hospice of New York City.

title: Apathetic And Bitter, Serbs Select New Leader
description: Serbia's voters on Sunday will get to choose among three main candidates for the presidency in a contest that has often seemed more like a bad soap opera than an instrument of political change.

title: Commercial Property/Philadelphia; Penn Planning to Build Hotel and a Commercial Hub
description: NEARLY 30 years after its last major construction project added dormitories, the student bookstore and a new research center, the University of Pennsylvania is in the midst of two major building and renovation projects that will again reshape its campus.

title: Freshmen Get Lesson In Woes of Housing
description: Like many breathless freshmen about to discover a college away from home, Aanjes Larkin, an 18-year-old from Woods Hole, Mass., was excited about starting at Marymount Manhattan College on the Upper East Side. Then, earlier this month, she arrived at her dormitory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMOCK, FRED
description: DIMOCK-Fred. September 15. Beloved Broadway Dresser for over two decades and dear friend and companion of 43 years of John Check. Died peacefully at home after a brief illness.

title: State's Last Independent Phone Company Is Merged With SNET
description: PEOPLE served by the Woodbury Telephone Company, which until July was the state's only independent local service provider, are concerned about the recent acquisition of the company by Southern New England Telephone. Their concern, says Woodbury Telephone's former president, Donald Porter, is unfounded. ''We have merged with a subsidiary of SNET, SNET Telco, but we are still the local service provider,'' he said.

title: Scott Ehrlich, Alexandra Muse
description: Alexandra Vickrey Muse, a project coordinator and consultant at Pamela Auchincloss, Arts Management in New York, was married yesterday to Scott Hamilton Ehrlich, who directs research and Internet services for the news division of Fox Broadcasting in New York. Judge Charles H. Loughran, of the 10th Judicial District of Pennsylvania Court in Greensburg, officiated at the Frick Art and Historical Society in Pittsburgh.

title: A New Kind of Classic
description: What's revered as classic by one generation, be it a movie star or a popular song, might be considered irrelevant by the next. Baby boomers, for instance, now consider Mick Jagger a classic, while Bing Crosby is seen as a nostalgic icon of their parents' time. Though they both defined the best musical expression of their eras, few people now remember Crosby's prime, the 1930's, even from old movies on ''The Late Show.'' Thus, the definition of classic is constantly changing, and this evolution most assuredly includes men's style.

title: Votes In Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALIBA, ESSIE
description: BALIBA-Essie. 9/18/97. Your adoring children Roberta and Jeff Friedman, Jackie Sheinberg and Jay Morganstern; devoted grandchildren Wendi, Gary, Elaine; Evan, Abby, Kenneth, and their father George Sheinberg, will miss the warmth of your generous spirit and loving presence. You will ever remain in the hearts of your sisters and brother-in-law, Ida Wexler, Miriam and Irving Logue. Your memory will be cherished by your nieces and nephews, and all their children. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY, at 11:30 AM, Sunday. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER EAST SIDE

title: History Screams
description: Promised Lands

title: Arafat Says the U.S. Should Do More for Peace in the Mideast
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, said today that the United States should do more to rescue the quest for a broader Middle East peace, and he called on the Clinton Administration to support the creation of a Palestinian state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLANSKY, MORRIS AARON, M.D.
description: SKLANSKY-Morris Aaron, M.D., of Evanston, IL, beloved husband of Alice Sklansky for 51 years, devoted father of Laura, Paul and Andrew Sklansky and his wife, Susan Sklansky, grandfather of Maxwell Sklansky, fond uncle and friends of many. Associated with the Chicago Institute for Psychoanalysis for 40 years. Author of various books and articles including ''The Drop-Outs'' and ''The High School Adolescent.'' Professor at Northwestern University, the University of Chicago and the University of Illinois, consultant in adolescence for The Scholarship and Guidance Association. After graduating from Drew University in Madison, NJ, Dr. Sklansky attended medical school at the University of Louisville, Kentucky and continued his training at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago and the Chicago Institute for Psychoanalysis. Dr. Sklansky was Director of the Institute's Child and Adolescent Program. He participated in the development of new training facilities for psycholanalysts in other states. He was a committed and dedicated psychoanalyst who was greatly respected and esteemed by his colleagues, and was much sought after for advice and counseling. He is well-known for his teaching in the field of adolescence. A memorial service for friends and family will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, friends are asked to make donations to the Chicago Institute for Psychoanalysis, The Scholarship and Guidance Association or the American Cancer Society. For more information: Wm. H. Scott Funeral Home (847) 251-8200.

title: DIANA'S DIRT
description: * Glenn Johanson is looking for Princess Diana dirt, and he's not ashamed -- he's the curator of the Museum of Dirt in Boston, the only dirt, dust and grit museum in the country. * Among the specimens: John Waters's mulch and dirt from the Grassy Knoll and Nicole Brown Simpson's home. * The exhibits, which supposedly represent a neglected-but-essential aspect of human existence, are sent in by fans or obtained through direct solicitation. * Vanna White and David Hasselhoff have coughed up samples; Prince Charles has refused. * Johanson, 38, says the sample from the tunnel where Princess Diana was killed will be collected by a friend in Paris. * He admits that the prospect has caused ''a bit of a stir'' at the museum. ''People say it seems disrespectful,'' he says, ''but I think it could be a moving tribute.''

title: Model-Minority Myth Is Unfair to Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Women With World of Finances
description: TO Marilyn Crockett and Diane Terman Felenstein shopping for stocks is not much different from shopping for clothes and groceries. They liken bond ratings to pantyhose sizes and the buying of stocks in downturns to buying tuna fish on sale.

title: Westchester Q&A: Daniel A. Biederman ; The Greening of Downtown Districts
description: IF midtown Manhattan is a bit safer and a lot cleaner, there are those who think Daniel A. Biederman of Chappaqua deserves some of the credit. Mr. Biederman is president of the Grand Central Partnership and the 34th Street Partnership and executive director of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation. Together they make up the largest complex of private downtown management districts in the United States.

title: Parental Involvement Makes Better Students; Bold Change at Chicago
description: To the Editor:

title: Woodies Keep Australia's Hope Alive
description: Pete Sampras and anybody. It was the Davis Cup doubles combination the Australians feared most, even if the anybody happened to be Todd Martin, who fainted on the steps of the Capitol Thursday during the draw ceremony. The Australians knew that Sampras, the world's No. 1 tennis soloist, wanted to close out this three-of-five-match Davis Cup semifinal in a timely, teamly manner no matter who was on his side of the court.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SLIPPAGE

title: Brodeur Sharp In First Exhibition
description: Goalie Martin Brodeur made his first appearance of the preseason for the Devils last night and looked extremely sharp, playing the entire game and turning aside all 29 shots he faced in a 2-0 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers (1-2-1) at Continental Arena in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Heart-Surgery Theater
description: The classroom field trip is usually a pretty tame experience -- a visit to the local bread factory, say, or the power plant -- but at Inova Fairfax Hospital in northern Virginia, students get to see something quite a bit more captivating: heart surgery. The idea is that showing teen-agers what can happen when you smoke, eat too much or play Nintendo all day instead of exercising will somehow shock them into adopting healthier habits. Whether that lofty goal is achieved is open to debate, but the gore certainly holds their attention.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUOTOLO, ANDREW KEOTH, JR.
description: RUOTOLO-Andrew Keoth, Jr. November 5, 1952-Sept. 21, 1995. ''Now you will not swell the rout Of lads that wore their honours out, Runner whom reknown outran And the name died before the man.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERMAN, NATHAN
description: LEDERMAN - Nathan. Beloved father of Stephanie, adored grandfather of Evin Ruth, Glenn and Jeffrey. Loving brother of Lillian Schreier. Services today at 12 noon at ''Parkside'' Chapels, 66th Avenue and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Building a Stairway Between Columbia and Harlem
description: With a cliff that plunges nearly 135 feet from Morningside Heights to the Harlem plain, Morningside Park has always separated the major institutions of the Heights from the black residents of Harlem. The emotional distance between the two communities widened in the 1960's, when Columbia University, despite vocal opposition from the Harlem community and its own students and faculty, decided to build a gymnasium in the park.

title: Lemon Helps Bring Out Essence of Dishes
description: WHATEVER did cooks do without lemons? I thought about this the other day as I prepared a platter of grilled eggplant, peppers and zucchini for guests.

title: Doctors Disagree On LaFontaine
description: Doctors who have examined Pat LaFontaine disagree on whether the Buffalo Sabres captain should resume his career after sustaining a serious concussion.

title: A Jailed Chicago Gang Leader Is Charged as a Drug Criminal
description: It was to be an imprisoned gang leader's grand return to the streets. After serving a quarter-century behind bars, Gustavo Colon, one of the chieftains of the notorious Latin Kings, was to have walked out of a downstate prison on Friday.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Aug. 24 with an article about New Jersey butterflies misidentified an example seen in a Somerset yard. It was a tiger swallowtail, not a monarch. Captions and credits were also reversed under two other pictures. The butterfly seen with outstretched wings was a northern metalmark, photographed by Rick Cech. The butterfly seen perched on a plant was an American lady, photographed by Patricia Taylor Sutton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, CECILE N.
description: LANE-Cecile N. Of Hollywood, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Melvin V. Lane; loving and loved mother of Bill and the late Steve Lane; adored mother-in-law to Ronnie and Audrey; cherished grandmother of Jon, Hillary, Lauren and Whitney and dear and loving friend to all who knew her. She will be sorely missed and forever remembered.

title: Where to Connect
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIWANT, ANN
description: LEIWANT-Ann. Of Verona, NJ, on September 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Alan, Bruce, Peter and Amy Jayson. Dear sister of Sarah Levine and Ceil Zuts. Also survived by eight grandchidlren. Graveside services were held at the Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ, on Friday, September 19, 1997. A memorial service and memorial fund will be announced by the family in the near future. For information call Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, NJ.

title: Atomic Guinea Pigs
description: This was not a single, isolated incident, but involved numerous people over a period of 30 years. Where were the whistle-blowers? Why, even now, are there no criminal in-vestigations, Congressional hearings or any sanctions against the (still living) perpetrators of such evil experiments? To simply offer monetary compensation to the victims and their families is an insult, without holding individuals accountable for their roles in these crimes.

title: Chess Devotees Retake a Corner Of Tompkins Sq.
description: The southwest corner of Tompkins Square Park, at Avenue A and East Seventh Street, has long been the domain of some of the park's most destitute characters. Many have regularly used the area's granite chess tables as a place for a midday beer, a recuperative snooze or a parking spot for their overloaded shopping carts.

title: A Show Heralds Romanticism
description: AN 18th-century farmhouse, plain as the Republican cloth coat of myth and fable, Philipsburg Manor here, makes Lyndhurst, the neo-Gothic mansion down the road, seem overdressed. Yet, the whitewashed stone pile beside a mill pond has postcard charm and, when ducks are moseying about the weedy water, the scene needs only a few wading cows to make it a pastoral worthy of the Hudson River School.

title: Gioia Bonmartini, Andrew Brophy
description: Gioia Giacinta Bonmartini, the daughter of Charlotte and Francesco Bonmartini of Wilmington, Del., and Rome, was married yesterday to Andrew Townsend Brophy, the son of Jeannette and Raymond C. Brophy of Washington. Msgr. Peter Vaghi performed the ceremony at St. Joseph on the Brandywine Church in Greenville, Del.

title: G.M. Geography: Farewell, Geo
description: GOODBYE, Geo. Hello, Chevy. As the 1998 car models arrive in showrooms this fall, a familiar name is missing. The General Motors Corporation is dropping the Geo nameplate from its Metro and Prizm cars and Tracker sport utility. Those vehicles will now wear the bow-tie insignia of Chevrolet.

title: He's Back. He's Sorry. He's Hoping For the Best.
description: IN 1994, DAVID CARUSO BEGAN HIS disastrous, highly publicized dispute with the producers of the hit crime series ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' Since then, he has not complained to the press -- or to anyone else -- of being ''demonized'' by his enemies. Mr. Caruso has not sued anyone connected with the ABC show, nor has he retreated from public life for treatment of any drug, alcohol or emotional problems.

title: Over a Bagel, a Primary Post-Mortem
description: WE were in line for the movie ''Cop Land,'' which some people thought was a documentary, when a kid in a white shirt and tie waved a sign, ''Meet Ruth Messinger.'' Behind him was a woman who vaguely resembled Ruth Messinger. But her eyes were lifeless black dots, as blank as Orphan Annie's in the old comic strip, so it couldn't be Ruth Messinger. That's why I didn't feel snubbed when she looked at my face, shook my hand and moved on. Other people on line last month thought it was the real Ruth Messinger and treated her like a dotty old aunt.

title: The Nation; How Political Theater Lost Its Audience
description: GREENPEACE is pruning itself back. Act Up has quieted down. People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals gets more attention lately with blushing bottom-baring by models than scarlet paint-splashing by protesters.

title: Tale of Making Mob Movie Promoted Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROUGHS, MALCOLM S. ''BUZZ.''
description: BURROUGHS-Malcolm S. ''Buzz.'' At home on Chipmunk Farm, Topsfield, MA, on September 16, at age 98. Husband of the recently deceased Lucille ''Pat.'' Son of the late Fred E. and Jennie E. (Short). Senior V.P., Dexter Folder, V.P. Miehle-Goss-Dexter (Rockwell International). Accepted at MIT at age 15, he entered at 17, and was Captain of Freshman crew, a DKE, and graduated in 1920. He served in the US Navy in WWI and WWII and oversaw the Newport Torpedo Station. He was discharged as a Commander in 1945 and was a member of the American Legion and VFW. Buzz was an eager and accomplished golfer, curler, sailor, navigator and collector of early Americana. He was a member (now or formerly) of the Winchester (MA) CC, Winged Foot and St. Andrews (NY), the Bay State and U.S. Seniors Golf Associations, The Seignioury (Canada) Club, the University Club (NYC), The Corinthians. An active supporter of the Peabody-Essex and Bath Museums, he was an authority on 19th Century maritime art. Past Commander, Westchester Power Squadron and the teacher of generations of navigators from Westchester (NY) and Beverly (MA). Past Dean of The Print Society; the National Association of Watch and Clock Collectors; Officer, Grand National Curling Club; member, Wyoming Lodge AF&AM (Melrose, MA); recent recipient, Boston Post Cane Award from the town of Topsfield. He is survived by five nephews: Roger Wingate of Tuftonboro, NH; Scott Davis, Tustin, CA; Walter ''Buck'' Davis, Bedford, NY; Sumner ''Skip'' Davis, Roswell, GA; and Kirk Davis of Savannah. Memorial service at the Congregational Church at Topsfield, Monday, September 22, at 2 PM. Memorial gifts to ABL Nurses, 123 Brimble Avenue, Beverly, MA 01915, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACKERMAN, SEYMOUR K.
description: ACKERMAN-Seymour K. Unveiling Sept. 21, 1997, 73rd birthday. Miss and love you. Children, Grandchildren and Always, Esta

title: Dorothy Adler, Edward Braniff 3d
description: Mary Dorothy Adler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Franz A. Adler of Bozman, Md., was married yesterday to Edward Braniff 3d, a son of Carol and Edward Braniff of Holmdel, N.J. The Rev. John R. O'Connell officiated at St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Star Restaurateur's Failed Recipe
description: He was one of TriBeCa's restaurant pioneers, beginning in 1985 with Montrachet, a low-key, three-star French establishment that's still going strong. Since then, with such famous partners as Robert De Niro, his Myriad Restaurant Group has been on a tear, opening well-reviewed places like TriBeCa Grill and Nobu, both on Franklin Street, which have instantly garnered public favor and celebrity status. He has even expanded his empire beyond downtown, opening restaurants in San Francisco and London and, this summer, on Nantucket, and seeing his reputation grow with his business. (Some writers have called him the best restaurateur in America.)

title: In the Absence of Language
description: ALL AROUND ATLANTIS

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Misconceiver

title: New Push by Urban Police: Getting Out of the Station House
description: Shortly after 4 P.M. one day this week, Officer Emilio Ramos, a motor scooter patrolman here, sat down at a small table and began typing up an account he had taken from a man who claimed that his girlfriend was harassing him.

title: Up-and-Coming Asian Candidate Has a Week of Downs
description: Pauline Chu, the woman who many thought could some day become the first Asian-American to win a major elective office in the city, is trying to cobble together her political career after a week of setbacks.

title: Paget Reed, Christopher Bahr
description: Paget Gage Reed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Creighton Reed of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Gordon Bahr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Bahr of Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. Alden Besse, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in West Tisbury, Mass.

title: As Election Day Nears, Think Spring
description: IT'S that time of year again: bulbs. Even though the garden is glorious with many late-blooming flowers, this truly is the time to think about spring.

title: The Ubiquitous 'Idiot Guides' Are Not Being Written by Idiots
description: ''EAT the heads first -- they shouldn't suffer,'' Laurie Rozakis said, placing a plate of low-fat animal crackers next to the freshly baked chocolate chip cookies. Just then the mailman approached the front stoop of her Farmingdale home and, the day being hot, she met him at the door with a glass of iced tea.

title: Ideas & Trends; In Classical Music, Selling Hard and Selling Out
description: THE fall equinox is just around the temporal bend, but in classical musical life that usually signals the beginning of spring. Each year around this time, as gala opening nights approach and the season's concerts begin, there are numerous signs of rebirth, not just in the halls themselves or in the mounting new releases in the record stores, but in the proliferation of full-color brochures and full-page advertisements.

title: Six Miles of Rail May Become a Bike Path
description: Officials in Morris and Passaic counties want to reactivate a six-mile stretch of the old Erie-Lackawanna Rail Road -- for bikes. The Mercer County Department of Transportation will ask the North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority for Federal funds to study putting an eight-foot-wide asphalt path on the railroad right-of-way from the Mountain View Station in Wayne to a spot just south of the Paterson-Hamburg Pike in Riverdale, said Jerry Rohsler, the department's assistant director. The Pequannock and Wayne Township Councils have passed resolutions supporting the bike path, and Scott Rumana, a Passaic County Freeholder who is also a Transportation Planning Authority board member, said the community's and his own support is strong. ''I've heard it for years, on and off, 'Why don't we have that? We need a safe place for our kids to ride,' '' Mr. Rumana said. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: Stolen Luggage
description: To the Editor: On Saturday, April 26, my assistant and I checked in at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza in Madrid. Our room was not ready, and we were told to wait in the lobby and assured that we could safely leave our luggage near the reception desk, since a security guard was watching. We sat nearby, but the lobby was crowded and in less than 10 minutes, a piece of luggage had been stolen.

title: September 14-20; Safety Lessons, on the Ground
description: It was a first for the military: the Defense Department ordered the Air Force, Navy, Army and Marine Corps to suspend all training flights for a 24-hour period to sit down aviators and ground crews for safety lectures. In only four days, five crashes had occurred.

description: Weeks

description: Melissa Brand Shelby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Shelby of Glenshaw, Pa., was married yesterday to Todd Matthew Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Weiss of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. James Churchill, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Emmanuel Baum at the Duquesne Club in Pittsburgh.

description: FOOTBALL

title: On the Office PC, Bosses Opt For All Work, and No Play
description: Just how personal is the personal computer?

title: The Giants Set A New Low In Inept Loss To the Rams
description: The only thing worse than the Giants' inept output in their 13-3 loss to the St. Louis Rams today was the hard, inevitable conclusion such a numbing defeat will leave on the doorstep of the franchise and its fans. The Giants now have a 1-3 record, and next week the New Orleans Saints arrive at Giants Stadium with an identical record. It is not too early, or too cruel, to suggest that the Giants are in the running for the top pick of next spring's National Football League draft.

title: Chronicle
description: Dozens of people will set out on a tour of New York on Saturday and Sunday, but they will not be stopping at places like the Empire State Building or the Statue of Liberty. Rather, they will be visiting sites considered central to the sexual revolution of the 20th century.

title: A New On-Line Publisher Promotes Nonfiction on a Pay-Per-Read Basis
description: Jon Franklin has had it with the New York publishing industry. The journalist, who has twice won a Pulitzer Prize, has written four acclaimed medical science books. But they are all out of print.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHTER, JOYCE FORTUNE
description: LACHTER-Joyce Fortune. On September 20, 1997. Services to be held at the Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, NJ, on September 23, 11 AM.

title: Film Fest Has a Theme This Year, It's Family
description: When the New York Film Festival made its first appearance, John F. Kennedy was in the White House, Ed Sullivan was on television, and Rabbit Angstrom had been running for only a couple of years.

title: Manila Rally Opposes Moves By Ramos to Seek a New Term
description: The crowds were smaller and the threat was smaller, but once again today an outpouring of ''people power'' sought to force a Philippine President to back down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANIGAN, JANET M.
description: LANIGAN-Janet M. On Friday, September 19, 1997. Of New York, NY, formerly of Maplewood, NJ. Beloved daughter of Eugene D. and Rita Burke Lanigan of Maplewood. Loving sister of Daniel R. Lanigan and Joan Strauss. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Sorrows Church, 217 Prospect St, South Orange, on Wednesday, September 24, at 10:30 AM. Visitation will be held at The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave, Maplewood, on Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Nurses Education Fund, 555 W. 57th St, NY, NY 10019, would be appreciated.

title: U.S. Business and Euro
description: To the Editor:

title: Enduring the Perils of the Single Life
description: You don't meet a lovable bunch of single urban neurotics like these every day. Leo (Jeremy Scott Johnson) has turned into a stalker because, after sleeping with Miriam (Julianne Zinkewicz) once, he's obsessed. (''If I were a multiple amputee, would you still love me?'' he asks.) Miriam, who has had a few too many double espressos, looks normal but confesses that she's looking for a man whose calves match Prince Charming's in her favorite storybook illustration. Heather (Cynthia King) arrives at a party with a ham in a Bloomingdale's bag and is henceforth known as the Ham Lady. Bo (David Palmieri), who has been celibate for eight and a half months, asks any woman he dates to call him Shaft. Eddie (P. J. Sosko) just wants his friends to smell his new stereo.

title: Still Running With the Cows; For Now, the Founder of Gateway Sticks to His Roots
description: Drop out of college, start a company, work endless hours and, against all odds, your fledgling personal-computer marketer becomes a success. You watch with pride and some awe as the company, started in a tiny office on the family cattle farm in Iowa, grows astronomically in size and value, into the millions of dollars, and then billions.

title: Premier of Malaysia Spars With Currency Dealer
description: It was high noon in Hong Kong this weekend.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Asian Crisis Likely to Slow Economic Liberalization

title: Heroics by Sampras Lead the U.S. Over Australia and Into the Davis Cup Final
description: Courtesy of yet another flawless Davis Cup singles performance from that caped crusader, Pete Sampras, the United States captured its semifinal bout against Australia, 4-1, today at Rock Creek Park's sold-out Fitzgerald Tennis Center and advanced to the championship round against Sweden, another perennial power in this international team competition.

title: Patents; A data base that knows exactly when to call, and a new incentive for buckling up in the car.
description: THE phone rings just as you are putting down your mail inside the front door. It is someone from the bank, informing you that as a valued customer, you are eligible for a brand new account service. Do you talk to that person or hang up? Is there any good time for a telephone marketing pitch? Would you be more open to a salesman, a survey-taker or even a bill collector if they knew that you prefer to be called at the office during your morning coffee break, or at home in the late afternoon but only on weekends?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARASH, LANCE M.
description: BARASH-Lance M., 58, of Trumbull, CT. Beloved husband of Karen, loving father of Melanie Barash Levitt, and father-in-law of Daren Levitt of Jackson, NH. Adored brother of Barbara Simmons of Toronto, Canada, and wonderful son of Esther Barash of Canisteo, NY. Services Tuesday, September 23, 11 AM, at Albany Hebrew Tailors Assoc. Cemetery, Western Ave, Albany, NY. Memorial contributions to the American Cancer Society or to the Brain Tumor Society of Boston, MA.

title: I.B.M. to Make Smaller and Faster Chips
description: I.B.M. plans to announce today that it has solved a fundamental problem holding back the development of faster semiconductor chips and will begin manufacturing chips early next year that are smaller and up to 40 percent more powerful than the most advanced chips currently being produced commercially.

title: Radioactivity May Bring Fine
description: A hospital in New Brunswick could be fined by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission for not reporting a mistake in which a small radioactive pellet was taken from the hospital in November 1995, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported yesterday.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: INSIDE
description: Arab States Defy U.N.

title: In the Balance, the Future of a Lake; Arizona Town Battles Environmentalists Over Drainage Plan
description: To Sierra Club directors, their proposal to drain Lake Powell, the nation's second-largest artificial lake, is breathtaking in its boldness.

title: Reunion Recalls a Limitless Age
description: The young men of Stuyvesant High School's classes of 1947 and '48 came of age in an era of dizzying change. Born in the Depression, they were freshmen in the middle of World War II and graduated into a world that offered once unthinkable opportunities.

title: Diet Pills Show Folly of Animal Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNRO, LYDIA (NEE SHARANEVYCH).
description: MUNRO-Lydia (nee Sharanevych). At Beth Israel Hospital on Thursday, September 18, 1997. Beloved wife and friend of Robin. Daughter of Gregory and sister of Oleh. Private cremation took place on Saturday, September 20. Donations to The Animal Medical Center, 510 E 62nd St, NYC 10021.

title: Jimmy Witherspoon, Singer Of Blues and Jazz, Dies at 74
description: Jimmy Witherspoon, one of the great postwar blues singers and a figure who naturally bridged the worlds of blues and jazz, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 74.

title: Critic's Notebook; Computer Games Capture Filmmakers' Imaginations
description: Watching Michael Douglas land unceremoniously in a Dumpster after desperately fleeing down a dark alley in the new hit movie ''The Game'' made me wish I were holding a mouse. The urge was not inspired by the scavenging rodents Mr. Douglas's character must have come in contact with but by the nature of his adventures: it seemed as if he were less a film character than a hero of an interactive computer game. As Mr. Douglas dodged bullets and betrayals, I kept wanting to help with a point and click.

title: Sports of The Times; Gullikson Relies on His Ace and Friend
description: WHO says the big man out of the bullpen can only pitch an inning? Tom Gullikson went to his trusted closer here this weekend in the Davis Cup semifinals, and we may reasonably assume the United States would not have survived them had he not.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Make a Play!' So Brown Made Two of Them
description: WHEN the New England Patriots released Corwin Brown on Aug. 24, he was a free agent. He could have signed with any other National Football League team; the Miami Dolphins got in touch with him. But when he knew Bill Parcells wanted him, Brown joined the Jets the next day.

title: Low-End PC's Take Growing Share of Home Market
description: When the price of a personal computer fell below $1,000 earlier this year, consumers began flocking to stores in search of the ultimate deal. For the first time, they are discovering that $999 can buy the latest technology -- or something close to it -- rather than a closed-out model the manufacturer had long ago replaced with something bigger, faster and better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMUNTZ, LAWRENCE ALLEN
description: GOLDMUNTZ-Lawrence Allen. On Friday, September 19, 1997, of Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Barbara Goldmuntz. Devoted father of Ellen Goldmuntz of Washington, DC, Jane (Randall) Grady of St. Louis, MO, and Elisabeth Goldmuntz (Frederic G. Barr) of Philadelphia, PA. Loving brother of Janet Liebowitz of New York, Doris Vogel of Bridgeport, CT. Adoring grandfather of Justin and Peter Metz, Jacob and Caleb Grady, and Julia Goldmuntz Barr. Funeral service on Tuesday, September 23, 1997, 10 AM, at Adas Israel Congregation, Washington, DC. Interment at Vineyard Haven, MA. In lieu of flowers expressions of sympathy in his memory may be made to the Lawrence A. Goldmuntz Memorial Fund at Jewish Communal Fund of NY, 130 E. 59th, NY, NY 10022. Additional information call Danzansky-Goldberg Chapels, Inc. 301-340-1400.

title: Foreign Affairs; If I Forget Thee, O Jerusalem
description: The deal concocted to allow 10 Israeli settlers to remain in a building in the Ras al-Amud Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem is a moral and political fraud (embraced by the Clinton Administration) perpetrated by people whose goal is to drive Palestinians out of the city. This is sad. The issue today is not whether Jerusalem will remain the unified capital of Israel, but whether it will be the habitable capital of Israel. Anyone who has visited Jerusalem lately knows Israel's hold over the city is unchallenged, and I'm glad it is. Jerusalem was never a more open city to all religions than under Israeli rule after 1967. But that is changing.

title: Gore in Russia, Hoping to Be Cast in a Different Light
description: If Vice President Al Gore thought he would get away from questions about campaign finance once he had landed in Russia, he soon found out otherwise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIMOWITZ, NUCY
description: HAIMOWITZ-Nucy. On September 20, 1997. Devoted wife for 47 years to Irving. Loving mother of Benjamin Haimowitz and Vivian Belen. Dear grandmother of Michael, Erica and Sara. Services 12:30 PM, Monday, September 22, Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett.

title: Gilmour Making It a Point to Prove Himself
description: Doug Gilmour's pride was deeply hurt at his arbitration hearing against the Devils last month. There they were, the lawyers representing the Devils, telling the arbitrator, Richard Bloch, that Gilmour's offensive production had fallen and that he was no longer the player he once was.

title: Overfishing of Eels Is Feared
description: As a taste for eel cuisine catches on, young live eels have been fetching up to $300 a pound. But the growing popularity of the delicacy has brought with it the increasing danger of overfishing, State Assemblyman John C. Gibson, a Republican of Sea Isle City, said Friday.

title: When the Thin Blue Line Becomes Unstrung
description: Steven Bochco's ''Brooklyn South'' plays like an elaborate game of good cop-bad cop. If his ''Hill Street Blues'' redefined the police genre for the 80's -- fast and gritty, more about character than cops and robbers -- this new series picks up the Bochco style at its best and races with it into the late 90's. Filled with realism, violence, heroism and, above all, an astute sense of wary public attitudes toward the police, ''Brooklyn South'' lives up to its advance hype as the most explosive drama of the season.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article yesterday about Henri Paul, who was driving for Diana, Princess of Wales, when her car crashed, omitted the first two lines in some copies. The passage should have read: ''Lawyers for the Fayed family were so surprised by the results of the first two tests that they insisted on a third, which also revealed traces of drugs used for treating depression.''

title: 'You Can't Take It With You,' Featuring Hippies
description: CALIFORNIA'S OVER

title: Top Health Vacancies
description: Six months into his second term, President Clinton has yet to fill socres of offices. This list of vacancies at the Department of Health and Human Services is one of a series of occasional tallies of unfilled posts throughout the Administration, including Cabinet departments and the judiciary.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: 8-Foot Barrier Closes Part of Thai Border : Malaysia Slams the Door On a Troubled Neighbor
description: PEDANG BESAR, Thailand  Bicha Ponboon, a sprightly man in his early 20s, lives on Wall Street, an address that has more in common with downtown Manhattan than just a name. Mr. Bicha's neighborhood is full of dealers and traders whose main business centers on commodities and a thriving service industry.

title: Software as Traffic Manager
description: Check Point Software Technologies, a leader in the market for Internet security products, plans to introduce a software program today that helps companies manage the flood of Internet traffic into their corporate networks.

title: The Other Life of Karen Finley; 'I Try to Fix Things,' Says a Startling Performance Artist
description: Just off the main street of this small Hudson River town is a large, rambling house, a converted barn built in 1886. In the garden, a gray-haired woman is puttering and pruning. Inside the house is a catacomb of rooms filled with old and antique furniture. It is a jumble of work and play, the play area belonging to a 4-year-old named Violet, who attends school nearby. The homey environment and the three generations of occupants -- grandmother, mother and daughter -- are like an image of Victoriana thrust suddenly into the modern age.

title: Opposition Is Set Back In Germany
description: In a bellwether local election at the start of a year of balloting leading to national polls, Germany's opposition Social Democrats suffered an embarrassing setback in Hamburg today.

title: From Sunny Folk From Mexico, Nonstop Zest
description: Ballet Folklorico de Mexico brought good cheer to Radio City Music Hall on Friday night. Because the troupe of 65 dancers and musicians is big and its home in Mexico City is the grandly scaled Palace of Fine Arts, it looked very much at ease on Radio City's large stage. Even more important, its zest was apparent throughout the vast auditorium.

title: Watchdog Group Is Under Scrutiny for Role in Teamster Race
description: In its three decades as a liberal grass-roots organization, Citizen Action has rallied against the influence of money in politics. ''Real reform must stop the flow of special-interest money into campaigns,'' the group has said in its literature, in calling for changes in campaign-finance laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ANN DURKIN
description: WALSH-Ann Durkin, 9/20/97, an avid arts enthusiast. Beloved wife of Michael T. Loving mother of Ann, Michael and Rosemarie; grandmother of Adam, Jane, Sarah, Michael. Dear sister of Catherine Flood, Margaret Starrs, Thomas and Bernard Durkin and the late Eileen V. Flood and John P. Durkin. Visitation Harmon Funeral Home, Staten Island, today, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass 10 AM, Tuesday, St. Clare's, Great Kills, Staten Island.

title: A Showcase For Works By Fledgling Directors
description: Four years ago, the director Kevin Smith was just another hungry young filmmaker vying for attention at the Independent Feature Film Market, the giant downtown screening frenzy and talent hunt for the next Kevin Smiths of the independent film world. Under his arm was a movie called ''Clerks.'' Though it got a 10 A.M. Sunday screening attended by exactly 11 people, 10 of them members of his own film crew, it did alert the one scout in the audience, whose solitary word of mouth started ''Clerks'' on its way to the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art and the Sundance International Film Festival.

title: Ditka Finally Wins
description: When Mike Ditka dropped his nice-guy pose and ripped his players, the New Orleans Saints responded with their first victory.

title: London Journal; How to Review 'The Royals' Without Viewing It
description: A lot of Britons are talking about Kitty Kelley's new book ''The Royals,'' which claims to blow the lid off decades of adultery, alcoholism, drug addiction, caddishness and other disgracefully un-regal behavior in the upper reaches of the British royal family.

title: Rules on Emissions Protested
description: About 150 people many of them driving vintage cars -- gathered at the New Jersey State House yesterday afternoon to protest new emissions standards, effective next year, that they fear will force some drivers off the road, The Associated Press reported.

title: Mother of Slain Jogger Adjusts to Solitude
description: When Lidia Pinto Machado walks through the streets, her gaze sometimes settles on other aging mothers, strolling with their grown daughters. She remembers the way her daughter would take her arm on similar outings, and tease her whenever she talked about remarrying.

title: Era of Futility At the Meadowlands Comes to an Improbable End For Jets
description: After 13 straight losses at home, after exactly 700 days of unimaginable futility in the Meadowlands, it figured that the Jets would have to do something totally out of the ordinary to finally win a game in front of their own fans.

title: Diet Pills Show Folly of Animal Tests; Beware Side Effects
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Focus For Ketchum Unit
description: The Ketchum Public Relations Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group in New York has formed a worldwide practice specializing in public relations for technology companies, after acquiring two agencies in that field. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Asia's Economic Tigers Growl At World Monetary Conference
description: After a decade of persuading nations to open their financial markets, American officials at a tense conclave here have run into a wall of resistance as angry Asian leaders charge that foreign investors and Wall Street-style trading exacerbated Southeast Asia's financial crisis.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Monday about Southern hurricanes misstated the deadliest such storm of the century. It was the Galveston, Tex., hurricane of 1900, which killed 6,000 people, not a 1928 Florida storm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, JANET
description: STONE-Janet. Central Synagogoue Sisterhood notes with sorrow the death of our longtime friend and Board Member. We extend sincere condolences to her family. The Sisterhood Board

title: Small Daily Tries to Teach College Paper a Lesson
description: This town may be as placid a place as there is in a state where good manners and neighborliness seem as much a part of the landscape as corn and soybeans. Yet a legal campaign by the owners of the local daily newspaper to curtail competition for advertising and readers from the campus paper could set off repercussions at dozens of public colleges whose student papers have come to act more and more like the commercial variety.

title: For Fielder, a Moment of Celebration
description: New York is not an easy place to play. Deliver, and you are adored. Struggle, and out come the Bronx cheers.

title: Policeman Makes Sure History Stays Put
description: A warning to time travelers from Claire Hemmings: ''You mention television to someone in 1850 -- all of a sudden, World War I is broadcast live on CNN.''

title: Even in Victory, Vermeil Is Wearing a Frown
description: After scoring the only touchdown of the game on a 4-yard run late in the fourth quarter today, Rams fullback Craig Heyward stopped for a moment in the end zone to contemplate his next move. Then he heaved the ball into the second level of seats at the Trans World Dome.

title: Reed Forces Marlins to Delay Their Party
description: A season-high 44,176 fans poured into Pro Player Stadium today, most of them looking for the Florida Marlins to finally clinch the wild-card playoff spot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, JOSEPH J.
description: GLICKMAN-Joseph J. Beloved husband of the late Edna. Dear and devoted father of Bette and Maxwell Krieger, Phyllis and Joel Weisman. Cherished grandfather of Robert and Melissa Krieger, Steven and Cathy Krieger, Charles and Joanne Weisman, Randi and Marc Fisher, Suellen and Howard Singer. Adoring great-grandfather of eleven. Also survived by Louis J. Glickman and Ruth Gleen. Graveside services.

title: An Electronic Sheriff to Battle Book Rustling
description: Faced with the vast, open range of the Internet and its inherent risks for rustling, the United States publishing trade association will today announce a global campaign to organize the equivalent of an electronic roundup, a newly developed digital system to brand electronic books and journals that could otherwise wander away unfettered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, SELMA
description: OPPENHEIM-Selma. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Selma. On behalf of all Fairview members we express our deepest condolences to her family. Andrew J. Frankel, President Stephen A. Leber, Secretary

title: Taking In the Sites; On-Line Help With Entrance Exams
description: High school juniors and some seniors start getting a little nervous at about this time. Upperclassmen at universities and colleges may be a little on edge. In a couple of weeks, the standardized test-taking season begins yet again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGER, SOFIE M.
description: EGER-Sofie M. On September 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Fred. Adored mother of Tom (Robin) Eger. Cherished grandmother of Brooke and Blake. Services 9:45 AM, Tuesday, ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel,'' 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Richmond Children's Center, 919 North Broadway, Yonkers, NY 10701.

title: John S. Whale, 100, Theologian And Congregational Historian
description: The Rev. Dr. John Seldon Whale, a Congregational historian and theologian who taught, lectured and preached in New York, New Jersey and elsewhere in the United States and his native Britain, died last Wednesday after moving to a nursing home in Edinburgh. He was 100 and had lived in southwestern England, not far from his birthplace in Cornwall.

title: A Dominican Immigrant Says Police Beat Him at Drug Raid
description: The Police Department and the Manhattan District Attorney's office are investigating the charges of an immigrant from the Dominican Republic who says that he was beaten by police officers on Thursday night during a drug bust in Washington Heights, the police said.

title: Country Songs That Reflect a Personal Whim
description: Merle Haggard doesn't give the kind of performance that one has come to expect from touring country singers. For one thing, he takes nearly excessive pride in his musicians, some of whom have stuck with him for more than 30 years. For another thing, his instrumentation is anti-economic and predicated on personal whim rather than convention: three guitars, a fiddle, an accordion, a tenor saxophone, a backup singer. Onstage together at Tramps on Saturday night, they looked like a salty bunch, traveling pirates with their own form of communication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUSS, FLORENCE
description: DRUSS-Florence. Beloved wife of Sol. Devoted mother of Nancy and Bracha (Vicki). Beloved grandmother of Andy, Robby, Gavriel, Sara, Rochel, Dina, Shira and Binyamin. Survived by her sister Syd Denis. Please make donations in her memory to the Bernard and Edith Samers Scholarship Fund, American Committee for Weitzman Institute of Science, 51 Madison Ave, NY, NY. Services today, 10 AM, at ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Ave, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, WILLIAM BECKWITH
description: HART-William Beckwith Ormond Beach, FL. Died September 19, 1997. Survived by wife Sara Faison; sons Will (NY), Kirke (Middlebury, VT); four grandchildren.

title: Search for Developer Leads to Manhattan
description: Hoping for leads in the search for the former head of the New Jersey Republican Party, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation handed out fliers yesterday in Washington Heights, where the missing man's car was found on Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the meeting of finance ministers in Hong Kong misspelled the given name of the President of China. He is Jiang Zemin, not Jiang Zimen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIN, ETHELINE D.
description: DUBIN-Etheline D., on September 18, 1997. Social worker; community activist in Crown Heights; beloved wife of Dr. Marshall F. Dubin Ph.D.; devoted mother of Dr. Jonathan Dubin M.D. and Jason Dubin. Memorial to be held on September 26, 1997 at 1PM, at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, 53 Prospect Park West (between 1st and 2nd Sts). All who knew her are welcome to attend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, JANET IASON
description: STONE-Janet Iason. September 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late J. Jacques Stone. Her vibrant intellect, remarkable spirit and devotion to those she loved will always be remembered by her children Carol and Alan Pomerantz, and Toni and Freeman Shore, her grandchildren Michael Romano and Julie and Peter Strauss, and her brother Jerry Iason. Services will be held at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street, 12 noon, Monday, September 22. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Stone Family Fund, 22 E. 40th St, NY NY 10016.

title: As Messier Starts Over, Rangers See a Void
description: As the song said, believe half of what you see, some or none of what you hear. That certainly applies to Mark Messier and the grapevine he maintains with his former team, the Rangers.

title: Virginia's Race for Governor Turns on Education and a Tax
description: As the governor's race in Virginia heats up through the final weeks of the campaign, the messages get louder if not clearer: Both candidates to succeed George F. Allen, a popular Republican, are selling comprehensive programs to improve education, their highest priority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVAK, DANIEL
description: NOVAK-Daniel. Age 58. Husband, father, brother, teacher, friend, lawyer, fisherman. Memorial service 11 AM, September 22, Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. Shiva at home Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday.

title: Abroad at Home ; Vigilance and Fairness
description: A stringent new immigration law became fully effective six months ago. Some of its fundamental features -- elimination of judicial review in many cases, restrictions on asylum, retroactive application -- are being tested in the courts. But it is possible to make a few preliminary observations on how the Immigration and Naturalization Service is carrying out the new law.

title: Clinton Got List Of Rich Donors For Phone Calls
description: Justice Department investigators have obtained documents showing that President Clinton was urged to make as many as 40 fund-raising phone calls to wealthy contributors from the White House, nearly three times as many requests for solicitations than was previously known, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALLON, BARBARA L. (NEE HOILE)
description: FALLON-Barbara L. (nee Hoile). Of Clifton, NJ, on September 20, 1997. Beloved mother of Linda F. Zielinski. Sister of Mrs. Elizabeth H. List. Grandmother of Kristina and Suzanne Zielinski. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 73 South Fullerton Avenue, Montclair, NJ, on Friday, October 10, at 10 AM. Donations may be made in her memory to Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, NJ or a charity of your choice. For more information call Arthur K. Brown, Inc., Bloomfield.

title: Corrections
description: An art review on Friday about ''Picasso the Engraver: Selections From the Musee Picasso, Paris,'' an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, omitted the show's sponsor. It is Goya Foods Inc.

title: Diana Photo Restarts Debate Over Lack of Restrictions on Internet Postings
description: The publication on the Internet last week of a photograph purporting to show Diana, Princess of Wales, as she lay dying in the back of a crashed Mercedes -- and its publication on the front page of a French newspaper -- has set off a new controversy over the ease with which inaccurate information can be disseminated over the global computer network.

title: Tougher, Better I.N.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Shoplink Inc., Westwood, Mass., to Orsatti & Partners, Boston, and Brandscape, New York, as the first agencies to handle advertising for the shopping-by-computer service. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Brown Shakes Off His Head Injury
description: Concussions to quarterbacks in the National Football League have been a hot topic this season, especially with another head injury sustained by the San Francisco 49ers' Steve Young. So Giants quarterback Dave Brown, who was briefly sidelined in yesterday's game with what was termed a mild concussion, was asked whether he was concerned about his health.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALBRIGHT, ARCHIE E.
description: ALBRIGHT-Archie E. A memorial service will be held for Archie E. Albright, Monday, September 22, 1997, at 4 P.M. at the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 East 50th Street (at Park Avenue), New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Archie Albright Scholarship Fund, 1 Big Canyon Drive, Newport Beach, CA 92660. For additional information please call John S. Albright at 212416-5438 or 203-222-9291.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOSEPH, HAROLD N.
description: JOSEPH-Harold N. 1923-1987. Ever in our thoughts, always in our hearts. Terry, Wendy, and Sandy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILLERSDORF, HERBERT K.
description: PILLERSDORF-Herbert K. The family of Herbert K. Pillersdorf, distinguished attorney and former small claims court arbitrator, mourns his peaceful passing on September 20, 1997, the day of his 78th birthday. He is survived by his wife Adele, his children Mr. and Mrs. Gary Pillersdorf, Dr. and Mrs. Alan Pillersdorf, his adored grandchildren Stephanie, Andrew, Lance, Alexander, Geoffrey, Tara, and his brother Arthur. Services Monday, 2 PM at ''The BoulevardRiverside Chapels,'' Ocean Pkwy at Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

title: Search Goes On for Developer
description: Hoping for leads in the search for a New Jersey man who has been missing since Wednesday, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation handed out fliers yesterday in upper Manhattan, where the man's car was found on Saturday.

title: RULES ON WELFARE FOR NEW YORK MISS GOALS FOR CHANGE
description: The dismantling of the Federal welfare system nearly a year ago has led many states to become laboratories of change, creating innovative programs to manage and shrink their welfare rolls and drastically altering the lives of millions of poor families in the process.

title: Land Mine Ban Ignores Benefits; Rare Fortune in U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Wednesday about a Federal review that found that silicone breast implants do not cause breast cancer referred imprecisely to the source of the conclusion that there was only ''borderline'' evidence linking them to any other disease. It was said in an interview by a co-author of the report; the published report was limited to breast cancer.

title: Ted Turner's Really Big Pledge Problem
description: Ted Turner wants to have his cake and eat it, too. The ebullient billionaire, who pledged on Thursday to give United Nations agencies as much as $1 billion over 10 years, said on Friday that he wanted to find a way to dispense the gifts without selling his Time Warner stock. His 58 million Time Warner shares -- representing about 10 percent of Time Warner's outstanding shares -- are the source of his $3.2 billion fortune.

title: Favorites Add New World 10-K Title to List of Triumphs
description: The fact of a 10-kilometer world championship for wheelchair racing was new, but the winners were familiar.

title: National Marketers Award 4 Accounts
description: Four national marketers have named agencies to handle accounts after reviews.

title: Deutsch Withdraws From Mazda Review
description: Deutsch Inc. of New York and Santa Monica, Calif., has withdrawn from the review for the Mazda Motor of America account, with billings estimated at $250 million. The account had been handled by the Santa Ana, Calif., office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of True North Communications, until that agency resigned in July because of a conflict.

title: Janet Reno's Baby Steps
description: The need for an independent counsel to look into White House fund-raising during the 1996 campaign has long been obvious. By ordering preliminary reviews of the legality of phone solicitations made from Federal offices by Vice President Al Gore and possibly by President Clinton, Attorney General Janet Reno is finally lurching in the direction of doing her duty. But Ms. Reno is still moving with the inexcusable lassitude and lack of precise legal focus that have been typical of her tenure at the Department of Justice.

title: Land Mine Ban Ignores Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Faces 2d Trial on Murder Charge
description: Harry Aleman walked away with an acquittal in a murder case linked to organized crime 20 years ago. But on Monday, Mr. Aleman, now 58, will be tried a second time for the killing of a teamsters' union shop steward.

title: Computer Services Companies Plan Merger
description: Affiliated Computer Services Inc. said today that it would buy Computer Data Systems Inc. for stock valued at about $325 million. The company will also assume $48 million in debt.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the decision by the New York City Board of Elections against holding a runoff in the Democratic primary for mayor misidentified the restaurant where one candidate, Ruth W. Messinger spoke. It was the Water Club, not the River Club.

title: Samuel Lurie, Dance and Music Publicity Agent, 88
description: Samuel Lurie, a veteran dance and music publicity agent, died on Sept. 11 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 88 and lived in West Hollywood.

title: 2 Women Try For Referee Job
description: Rod Thorn, the National Basketball Association's vice president of operations, confirmed that Dee Kantner and Violet Palmer could begin working as the league's first female referees this season.

title: Aide to Clinton Sees Flexibility On Tobacco
description: President Clinton will accept some form of legal immunity for the tobacco industry in exchange for a strong program to reduce the number of teen-age smokers, Bruce Reed, the head of the President's task force on tobacco, said today.

title: Laura Margolis, 93; Helped Rescue Jews
description: Laura Margolis, who helped rescue thousands of Jews fleeing persecution during World War II, died on Sept. 9 at the home of a nephew, James A. Margolis, in Brookline, Mass. She was 93 and lived in Brookline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MICHAEL J., JR.
description: SMITH-Michael J., Jr. On 9/20/97, of Pelham Manor. Beloved husband of Josephine Killilea Smith. Devoted father of Claire Mary Smith. Brother of Margaret Gansert, Thomas Smith, Catherine Valente, Ann Marie Gremler, Mary Sullivan and Eileen Burdick. Loving brother-in-law, uncle and friend to many. Reposing Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY. Mass Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor, NY, on Tuesday at 11 AM. Visiting hours on Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Donations may be made in his memory to Sister Una McCormick Catholic Home Bureau, 1011 First Avenue, NYC 10022.

title: Make the Police Liable For Abuse Settlements
description: To the Editor:

title: Neumann Back in Form
description: WELCH'S CHAMPIONSHIP

title: Clinton Has Little to Say on New Inquiry by Justice Dept.
description: Early yesterday morning, as Air Force One flew back to Washington from San Francisco, President Clinton wandered back to the reporters' cabin in blue jeans and a chatty mood. He reminisced about Orval E. Faubus, the former Governor of Arkansas, and spoke enthusiastically about the dormitory of his daughter, Chelsea, at Stanford University.

title: Church to Voice Sorrow for 'Silence' During War Deportations : Catholic Apology to Jews of France
description: PARIS  The Roman Catholic Church in France will issue an unprecedented statement this month apologizing for its "silence" during the persecution and deportation of Jews in World War II, a church official said Sunday.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Are Arraigned In an Attack
description: Three white teen-agers from Brooklyn were ordered held in $100,000 bail yesterday after they were arraigned on charges of beating a black man with a baseball bat and a steering-wheel lock early Saturday morning in what the authorities described as an apparent bias crime, officials said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: N.B.A. Rules Aim to Open Up Offenses
description: It may have been the familiar sight of one or two stars excluding their teammates from the offense. Or all those bodies crashing to the floor underneath the basket. Certainly, the glut of sub-100-point games did not help.

title: Mayor's Panel On Corruption Faces Scrutiny
description: Although Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has made aggressive crime fighting a hallmark of his administration, critics say he has given little clout to one obscure law enforcement body that he established himself: the Commission to Combat Police Corruption.

title: Make the Police Liable For Abuse Settlements; Samaritans With Badges
description: To the Editor:

title: Meadowlands Arena Upgrade
description: In the first step toward a planned multimillion-dollar upgrade, the commissioners of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority voted last week to approve a $110,000 engineering contract for design improvements at the Continental Arena at the Meadowlands.

title: Metro Matters; The Vote The Mayor Couldn't Get
description: FOR the first hour or so, things seemed to be going well for Rudolph W. Giuliani, or at least as well as they could be expected to go for a mayor accused of accepting more than $340,000 in illegal campaign contributions.

title: Henri Bendel, 89, Head of Store And Founder of Belgian Shoes
description: Henri Bendel, the founder of Belgian Shoes and a former president of the fabled Manhattan specialty store founded by his uncle in 1909, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Claiming a Right Not to Know; Town Smarts as a Paper Bites the Hand That Feeds It
description: This has been the quintessential company town for more than 100 years. So there was a collective gasp here earlier this month when the daily newspaper, The Leader, reported that one of the main businesses of Corning's famous glass company, Corning Inc., was in a ''state of emergency.''

title: No Berra In My Book
description: I grew up in Baltimore at a time when the tallest building was 29 stories high. In New York, a nondescript apartment complex was taller. We suffered from an inferiority complex.

title: Walter A. Spiro, 74, Chairman Of Ad Agency in Philadelphia
description: Walter A. Spiro, the chairman of Earle Palmer Brown/Philadelphia, an advertising agency, died on Tuesday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 74.

title: People
description: * Steve Rosen was named to the new position of president for public relations at RBT/Strum, Cherry Hill, N.J. He had been executive vice president and public relations director at Elkman Advertising and Public Relations, Philadelphia.

title: A new TV season, and executives fret about more than the latest cop show.
description: FOR the network executives who program the prime-time schedules, the new television season that starts tonight is D-Day of sorts: A long-planned invasion whose coming is marked by feelings of giddy excitement and abject fear.

title: Primary Races Expose Cracks in Once-Unified Bronx Democratic Machine
description: On the night of the Democratic primary, the headquarters of the Bronx Democratic Party was brimming with people celebrating the resounding victory of Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, who triumphed over a well-financed city councilman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, H. HANFORD, JR.
description: SMITH-H. Hanford, Jr. died suddenly on Sept. 16, 1997 at his home on Nantucket, MA. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane Cowles Smith, his devoted mother, Elizabeth E. Smith, his daughter, Lisa S. Cashin, his sons, H. Brooks Smith and H. Hanford Smith, III, and five grandchildren. A memorial service was held on Saturday, September 20 at 10 A.M., at Brant Point Lighthouse, Nantucket. A reception in his memory will be held on Thursday, October 2, 1997 at noon at the River Club, 447 East 52nd Street, New York City, to which his friends are invited. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Addison Gallery of American Art, Phillips Academy, Andover, MA. 01810.

title: Clinton, in New York, Shows Support for Messinger
description: President Clinton reached out to support the mayoral campaign of Ruth W. Messinger, the Democrat challenging Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, meeting briefly with her yesterday evening and posing for pictures after he arrived in New York City for a short visit to address the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Stamford Would Like to Turn A Successful Mall Inside Out
description: When the Stamford Town Center opened here 15 years ago, it was seen as a marvel of urban renewal, the marble and concrete happy ending to a hard-fought battle against the decay and flight that had destroyed so many downtowns in cities across the country.

title: Fine Legal Distinctions Are at Heart of Debate
description: President Clinton raised $950,000 for the Democratic Party on Saturday by appearing at a lunch, a reception and a dinner in California. It was all well publicized, perfectly legal and in keeping with the long tradition of Presidents who considered fund-raising to be an integral part of their political duties.

title: Stock Issues Expected This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Tampa Bay Covering Unfamiliar Ground
description: It looked like a simple screen pass. Trent Dilfer dropped back. The Miami rush came. The ball went toward the left flat to Warrick Dunn. Simple. But the play proved to be much more.

title: Arab Countries Vote to Defy U.N. Sanctions Against Libya
description: Arab countries voted today to defy United Nations sanctions by permitting airplanes carrying Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to land on their territory and to permit other flights for religious and humanitarian purposes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, ABRAHAM
description: BROOKS-Abraham. On Septemter 21, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Clara. Adored father of Sheldon (Leila) and Sandra (Edward) Ginsburg. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Services Monday, 12 noon, ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel,'' 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: A Bittersweet Victory For Influent at Belmont
description: For an encore to a memorable day of upsets in racing, Belmont Park staged Act II of its Super Stakes Weekend yesterday, and the big winners were the 2-year-old filly Beautiful Pleasure, the 2-year-old colt Grand Slam and the 6-year-old warrior Influent. But the dramatic impact of the day was provided by Influent, who ran one of his best races four days after his owner, Richard Kumble, died in surgery.

title: Chronicle
description: The last time a woman was in the spotlight at a Friars Club roast was in 1993 when WHOOPI GOLDBERG was the target of the barb fest and TED DANSON, then her companion, appeared in blackface and made comments some people considered racially insensitive.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORST, RUTH
description: FORST-Ruth. We will always remember our shining star. Your love and beauty will light up the heavens and will be with us forever. Barbara, Jeff, Jimmy, Helene Jeffrey, Stephen, Elie, Bobbie Charlie, Adam, Freddie, Tyler Sammi, Blake and Myles.

title: A sweeping reorganization at McCann-Erickson seeks to highlight marketing services.
description: McCANN-ERICKSON WORLDWIDE in New York, the world's second-largest agency, is undertaking its most comprehensive reorganization in almost four decades.

title: Corrections
description: A brief sports report by The Associated Press last Monday about the Jamaican soccer team referred incorrectly to its effort to qualify for the World Cup. Jamaica would not become the first Caribbean country to do so; Haiti qualified in 1974.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, RUTH BEAL.
description: NORTON-Ruth Beal. Of the Green Village section of Harding Township, NJ, on Sunday, September 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Donald Chase Norton. Loving mother of Phyllis Norton-Towers and Frank H. Norton. Loving motherin-law of Michael J. Towers and Anne Norton. Also survived by two grandchildren, Raymond Norton and Wendy Messina and one great-granddaughter, Stephanie Messina. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Harding Township Library. For information, contact Madison Memorial Home, 159 Main Street, Madison, NJ 07940.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CRACKS IN THE MACHINE -- The legendary Bronx Democratic organization is showing some cracks with the primary loss of an incumbent councilman to an insurgent. B3.

title: Land Mine Ban Ignores Benefits; Who's Defending Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Offerings Tentatively Set for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and on Wednesday.

title: Chiefs Taunt and Then Toy With Trash-Talking Panthers
description: Kansas City Coach Marty Schottenheimer is the kind of man who is so convincing that he can walk into a room full of people who are afraid to fly, and by the end of the day have them sky-diving. So when the Chiefs' defensive players showed how fired up they were today against the Carolina Panthers, it looked as if Schottenheimer had given another of his rousing speeches. But the man perhaps most responsible for the Chiefs' being so emotional was someone who was not even playing.

title: Rural Opposition to Hog Farms Grows
description: In the latest skirmish between rural counties in the South and West and corporate hog farms, voters in Seward County, Kan., have voted by more than 2 to 1 to keep out new manifestations of big pork.

title: 50 West Bank Palestinians Detained in Israeli Dragnet
description: Hundreds of Israeli soldiers mounted a powerful dragnet through West Bank villages around Nablus early today, detaining about 50 Palestinian men.

title: Very Long Day For Jets' Smith
description: Jets cornerback Otis Smith had one of the worst days of his career before the first half was over: he was beaten for three Raiders touchdown passes. Typically, Smith did not offer an excuse. Then again, winning makes it easier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, SELMA
description: HAAS-Selma. September 20, 1997. Adored mother of Steven and Peter. Beloved sister of Jerry Kassel. Loving aunt of Louis and Terry Kassel. Service Tuesday, 10:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Editorial Observer; When Grieving 'Victims' Can Sway the Courts
description: The death of a loved one is painful enough when it comes as no surprise and through natural causes. But a savage act of murder leaves a wound on the survivor's soul. The closer the loved ones, the easier it is to envision their final moments and hear their cries for help. Learning to shut out these thoughts is a long and mysterious process. The murder of my younger brother has been a central theme in my writing and day-to-day life for the better part of 15 years. The image of Blake begging for his life as he was shot to death will be with me always.

title: North Korean Leader Set to Take Over Top Posts
description: The long-time ''Dear Leader'' of North Korea, Kim Jong Il, has taken the first public step to assuming formal control over the country.

title: Making Sure War Crimes Aren't Forgotten
description: On a gentle hillside a few miles from here one afternoon this month, David J. Scheffer, the Clinton Administration's Ambassador at Large for War Crimes Issues, stepped slowly through a field of wooden crosses marking the spot where Hutu extremists slaughtered thousands of Tutsi in 1994.

title: Let Women Play Ball
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The most challenging test for the rule of law in our generation is the genocide of 1994 that consumed Rwanda.''

title: Tamraz's Tales
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Violinist Plays Concerto for a Virtuoso
description: Although the New York Philharmonic opened its season with a gala concert on Wednesday, its regular subscription series began on Thursday. Kurt Masur was again on the podium, and the major work from the gala, Brahms's First Symphony, was repeated. The new offering was Beethoven's Violin Concerto with the 23-year-old Siberian-born violinist Maxim Vengerov as soloist.

title: Shoney's Warns of Possible Debt Default
description: Shoney's Inc. said it would be in default on credit agreements soon and was in talks with lenders to refinance its debts.

title: Rabies Vaccinations Urged
description: State health officials are urging people to vaccinate their pets against rabies in light of a sharp increase this year in the number of cases of the disease in animals.

title: Raider Kicks Turn to Misses and Misery
description: Al Davis was standing with his arms folded in the middle of the Oakland Raiders' locker room today, looking as imposing as a prison guard, if a prison guard wore a white satin Raiders jacket and sported a silver chain dangling from his glasses. Adam Treu, the rookie long snapper, who had found himself the starting point of a series of disasters, had to get past Davis to get to the shower and meekly whispered, ''Sorry, Mr. Davis,'' as he moved by him. Davis never blinked, either not hearing the low, apologetic murmur or choosing to make Treu's hard day harder.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks were trading somewhat higher here today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 140.51 points, or about three-fourths of a percent, at 18,198.72.

title: BRIDGE
description: England has long had a virtual monopoly on the production of bridge books in which excellent bridge hands are spiced with wit and humor. S. J. Simon began the tradition half a century ago, and was succeeded by Victor Mollo. Now we are fortunate to have David Bird. His latest effort, in collaboration with Simon Cocheme, is ''Bridge With a Feminine Touch,'' available from the Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, for $15.95 including mailing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: The Up-and-Coming Get Comeuppance
description: They don't tell you about the dues.

title: Poland's Revamped Solidarity Coalition Leads Ex-Communists
description: In a surprisingly strong showing in parliamentary elections today, Poland's right-of-center Solidarity coalition appeared to have defeated the former Communists who have governed the country through four years of economic growth, according to exit polls and preliminary results.

title: Diet Pills Show Folly of Animal Tests; Treatment for Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: Down by 26 Points, Miracle Bills Rally
description: Colts 35

title: George Champion, 93, Head Of Chase Manhattan in 1960's
description: George Champion, a former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 93.

title: After all the Hoopla, Balloons and Electronics For Schubert? Why Not?
description: The solemnity surrounding celebrations of the Schubert bicentenary this year has been enough to make even the most ardent Schubertian (and probably Schubert himself) yearn for a little irreverence. So the ''Alternative Schubertiade'' presented on Friday evening at American Opera Projects in SoHo, by Composers Recordings and the Downtown Arts Festival, seemed in principle the ideal departure.

title: Lawmakers gear up to try to control the surging on-line gambling industry.
description: UNDAUNTED by their recent setbacks in trying to ban sex-related material on the Internet, lawmakers are now turning their attention to the on-line gambling industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDOM, LYNN SUZANNE
description: EDOM-Lynn Suzanne. On September 20, 1997, of East Rockaway and The Wyndham, Garden City. Beloved mother of Chris and Mark and mother-in-law of Jennifer. Dear grandmother of Jonathan. Cherished daughter of the late John and Evelyn Hores. Loving friend of Frances Pertusi, Kathleen, Albert and Alison Razzetti and Lee Ann and Glenn Henneberger. Graduate of Concordia College. Vice-President of Sales, Carnegie Fabrics, Rockville Centre. Vice-President, Board of Trustees, Capitol House Condominium, East Rockaway. Former President of the Park Avenue School P.T.A., North Merrick. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious service at the Sacred Heart Church, North Merrick, Wednesday, 9:45 AM. Ms Edom's ashes will be scattered at Jones Beach on Sunday afternon, September 28, 1997. Donations to the Children's Library-East Rockaway Public Library or The Rockefeller Institute Cancer Research, c/o Dr. Daniel Miller appreciated.

title: Stanley Grover, 71, Actor on Broadway
description: Stanley Grover, a longtime supporting player on Broadway and in numerous touring musicals who also acted in films and on television, died on Aug. 24 at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles, where he lived. He was 71.

title: A Soprano Who Makes Violetta a Specialty
description: For all its popularity, the role of the courtesan Violetta in Verdi's ''Traviata'' is difficult to bring off. During the party scene of Act I, Violetta must make a show of her free-spirited approach to life through brilliant coloratura singing. But in the later acts, as she is broken down by her love for Alfredo, the sacrifice she makes for his father and her fatal illness, Violetta must become a full-voiced lyric soprano with great dramatic range.

title: Why the Fish Are Dying
