description: Maryland's decision to close a third waterway on the state's Eastern Shore to fishing and recreation is an urgent summons to Congress to close one of the gaping holes in the Clean Water Act, an otherwise successful statute that does not address the threat to the nation's streams and lakes from agricultural runoff.

title: Egyptian Press on Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Vast Worker Database to Track Deadbeat Parents
description: Enforcement of child support obligations enters a new era on Oct. 1, when the Federal Government will start operating a computerized directory showing every person newly hired by every employer in the country so Federal and state investigators can track down parents who owe money to their children.

title: Cone Is Upbeat The Day After
description: A day after looking sharp in his five-inning comeback performance from shoulder tendinitis, David Cone said he felt fine. The Yankees hope Cone will feel the same way after he throws today during his off-day workout.

title: Isles Hand Palffy a Challenge: 60 Goals
description: Zigmund Palffy's goal should be to score 60 of them this season, according to Islanders General Manager Mike Milbury.

title: The Conservative as Techno-Libertarian
description: George Gilder has a warning for would-be entrepreneurs involved with new technologies: Watch out for emperors and morons.

title: Markets Gulp After Mahathir Remarks
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia's stock market tumbled hand-in-hand with its currency Monday in the first day of trading after Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad said currency trading "should be made illegal."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORST, RUTH
description: FORST-Ruth. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to our beloved member Steven Littwin on the loss of his beloved sister Ruth. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Party Unity Not the Goal For Sharpton
description: CONSIDER the case of Judy Rapfogel, who thought she had won a City Council primary on the Lower East Side last week, only to be done in by an errant zero.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGER, EDWARD M.
description: LANGER-Edward M. On September 20, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Natalie (Nee Neslin). Dear brother of Lillian Greenspan and Jerome Langer. Adored uncle of Rhoda Greenspan and Carol Greenspan. Graveside services will be conducted on Wednesday, September 24, 1997 at 10 AM at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, N.Y.

title: Woman Sentenced to 22 Years in Death of Adopted Son
description: Four years ago, Renee and David Polreis adopted a baby boy, Isaac. The affluent couple had such a good experience that they wanted their son to have a brother. In August 1995, after giving up on another domestic adoption because of what seemed like endless red tape, they flew to Russia and adopted a blond, blue-eyed boy they named David.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I believed then and I believe now what we did was legal. But I am absolutely positive that we intended to be firmly within the letter of the law when we were out there campaigning and raising funds.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, SYLVIA FINK
description: KLEINMAN-Sylvia Fink. Of Norwood, NJ. Died on September 19, 1997, at age 85. Loving mother of Larry Fink and Elizabeth Fink. Loving grandmother of Molly Fink, and Jennifer and Sara Sgobbo. Beloved sister of Norman and Norma Caplan. Beloved comrade of all those who struggle for social justice. Representative to the United Nations for the Grey Panthers. Died on the eve of trip to Grey Panther convention in San Francisco. Memorial services Riverside Memorial Chapels, 180 West 76th St, Tuesday, September 23, at 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to Grey Panthers, 2025 Pennysylvania Ave NW, Suite 821, Washington, DC 20006.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLIMANOPULOS, ANNA P.
description: CALLIMANOPULOS-Anna P. A longtime resident of Greenwich, CT, died on September 22, in Athens, Greece. She was the adoring wife of the late Pericles G. Callimanopulos and is survived by her devoted children, Katy Mazarakis of Athens, Mary Fey of New York, Gregory Callimanopulos of Athens and Domna Stanton of New York. She is also survived by eight grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. Burial is on Friday, September 26, in Athens, Greece.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVON, NICOLETTA SIRIGNANO
description: AVON-Nicoletta Sirignano, of Pleasantville, N.Y., September 22, 1997. Age 77. Mother of Daniel Avon and Jacqueline Goin. Grandmother of Kieran, Dineen, Colin, Terrence and Daniel. Services by Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, New York.

title: WHITMAN TO REVAMP AND TAKE $120 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Whitman Corporation said yesterday that it would take about $120 million in charges against second-half earnings to restructure its Hussman, Midas International and Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers units. Whitman, the world's largest independent Pepsico Inc. bottler, said the charges would total $130 million before taxes in the third quarter and $30 million in the fourth quarter. The charges are expected to help Whitman reduce debt and improve profitability as it prepares to spin off Hussman and Midas later this year. Shares of the company, based in Rolling Meadows, Ill., rose 87.5 cents, to $25.75.

title: Clinton, at U.N., Says He'll Press Senate on Test Ban Pact
description: Almost a year after signing it, President Clinton announced here today that he was asking the Senate to approve the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, which he called ''the longest-sought, hardest-fought prize in the history of arms control.''

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Battle Over a Park Goes On
description: Plans to build a minor-league baseball stadium in a popular waterfront park were scrapped last week, but community groups that fought the proposal are pressing on with efforts to have the park named a state historic landmark.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER KRYSA, a violinist and a founder of the Lake Winnipesaukee Music Festival in Wolfeboro, N.H., will not only be dedicating the final two concerts of the Fall Foliage Festival to Sir Georg Solti, who died on Sept. 5, but will also be wearing the maestro's tailcoat and trousers.

title: Blighted Branches
description: Earlier this year, when lawmakers on Capitol Hill debated whether to include fund-raising abuses by members of Congress in their investigation of campaign finances, many members bristled. ''The President is the alleged violator, not the Congress,'' exclaimed Senator Larry E. Craig, an Idaho Republican.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RUTH LIPPE
description: MILLER-Ruth Lippe, died peacfully on Saturday morning, September 20, at the Fishkill Health Center in Beacon, NY. Beloved wife of the late Matthew W. Miller, devoted Mother of Barbara Miller Hoxworth and Joan Mack. Cherished grandmother of Timothy Mack. Dear Sister of Jerome S. Lippe. Mother-in-Law of Duncan Hoxworth and Stuart Rothkopf and dearest friend of Ralphine Gross. The Family wishes to express their love and gratitude to all the staff at Fishkill Health Center who gave such wonderful and loving care. A memorial service will take place on Sunday, September 28, at 10:00 AM at the Robert H. Auchmoody Funeral Home, Inc., 126 Main St., Fishkill, NY (914) 896-6166.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: One-parent, two-parent and multi-generational sitcoms about families are crowding onto television. Here are reviews of several with premieres today and tomorrow.

title: PIONEER IN $235 MILLION DEAL WITH IMPERIAL CHEMICAL
description: The Pioneer Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the North American forest-products business of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of Britain for $235 million. I.C.I.'s forest-products unit had annual sales of about $200 million, Pioneer said. It makes chlorine, caustic soda and industrial chemical products for the pulp and paper sector and other industrial customers. Pioneer, a Houston-based company with annual sales of about $270 million, said the deal would more than double its annual sales. Imperial Chemical Industries is based in London. The forest unit's 465 workers are expected to join Pioneer after the deal closes, by the end of the year.

title: Skandia to Sell Its Reinsurance Unit
description: Hannover Re, the world's fifth-largest reinsurer, said yesterday that it would buy the main part of Skandia Insurance A.B.'s international reinsurance business for 245 million German marks, or about $138 million. Hannover Re said that the Skandia International Insurance Company would add 650 million marks to its 1997 premium income, which is expected to rise about 13 percent to 7.2 billion marks.

title: Keep the Academic Bar High
description: There's wide agreement that American students can achieve more than they do now and that they should be held to higher standards. For states that are trying to develop academic standards for their public schools, the big questions are what to include in these guidelines and how tough to make them. As California, for one, is finding out, serious mistakes can be made in setting such standards -- mistakes that threaten our children's potential for achievement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMMAN, AYMAN
description: SAMMAN-Ayman. With deep sorrow we the mourn passing of our friend Ayman in Miami Beach, FL on Sunday, September 14, 1997. We all feel privileged to have known him. He will live forever in our hearts. Our sincere sympathy to his mother, Berlant, and all his family. Funeral arrangements were scheduled for Sunday, September 21st, in Damascus, Syria. A special memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Menopause Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathy Keeton Guccione, 58, President of Magazine Company
description: Kathy Keeton Guccione, who helped found Penthouse magazine in the United States with her husband, Bob Guccione, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York. She was 58 years old and lived in New York.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Handicapped Bias Is Charged
description: The Newark Teachers Union filed a follow-up complaint with the Federal Department of Education yesterday, accusing the Newark school district of continuing to violate Federal laws barring discrimination against handicapped students.

title: Informix Says It Is Restating Results Again
description: The Informix Corporation said today that a continuing audit had shown that it must restate 1996 and 1995 financial results to a greater degree than previously reported. The company's shares plummeted on the disclosure.

title: How Fen-Phen, A Diet 'Miracle,' Rose and Fell
description: IN 1995, desperate for extra money, Dr. Israel Levavi, a Los Angeles internist, went to work for a brief period at a weight loss clinic that was run by a chiropractor and overseen by an infectious disease specialist. He was paid $50 an hour to race through what he called ''very, very cursory exams'' of six new patients an hour. The patients paid the clinic $100 for an exam and paid an additional $27 for blood tests. The clinic's weight loss education program, Dr. Levavi added, ''consisted of a video loop in the waiting room.'' It was, he said, ''very upbeat, showing 350 pounds melting into 135.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a surge in the shares of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation after comments by an analyst, Thomas Hanley of UBS Securities, misidentified the forum in which he spoke. The comments, in which Mr. Hanley said the company was a takeover candidate, were made to UBS clients and its sales force and were reported by the CNBC cable network; Mr. Hanley himself did not appear on CNBC.

title: The Jets' Favorite Quarter Is, Surprisingly, the Fourth
description: It is only four games, but it is also a fourth of a season, and it appears the 2-2 Jets have learned something very important about themselves: They can survive in the fourth quarter. Indeed, they can win in the fourth quarter. For the Jets have discovered they can make big plays when it counts.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, EVELYN A.
description: FRANK-Evelyn A. On September 22, 1997. Loved and missed by her children, grandchildren and dear friends.

title: The Hot Zone: Technology Issues Continue to Rise
description: When Wall Street strategists were asked last December to select their favorite sector for the coming year, the choice was just about unanimous: technology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELARDIN, CORDULA
description: GELARDIN-Cordula. September 22, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Hugo Gelardin, dear mother of Christine Gelardin and Nicole Berlin. Services Thursday, 10 AM St Ignatius Loyola. Visiting Tues. 2-5 and 7-9 and Wed. 7-9 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz CD's; The Life and Breath of Saxophones
description: Benny Golson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEETON, GUCCIONE, KATHY
description: KEETON - GUCCIONE - Kathy, your courage in sickness and your strength throughout your life will always inspire us. We will miss you everday. With love and condolences to both the Guccione, Keeton families. Nancy Kestenbaum-Moses Beverly Wardale-Vine

title: Clinton Backs Fund-Raising, Saying Actions Were 'Legal'
description: President Clinton said today that he was confident that neither he nor his campaign broke ''the letter of the law'' in fund-raising during the 1996 campaign. But the chairman of the Senate committee investigating the question said everything he had found pointed toward the need for an independent counsel.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Congresswoman Declares for Connecticut Governor
description: Barbara Bailey Kennelly, scion of one of Connecticut's most powerful political families, announced today she would leave Congress after 18 years to try to unseat Gov. John G. Rowland.

title: By Design; Lips Turn Red for Fall
description: After seasons of brown, purple, pink and nude lips, red lips are back. Intense red, to contrast with smoky eyes and to complement the rich colors and fabrics of fall clothes. Shades range from a classic pure red to reds with a hint of blue or wine.

title: The Ingredients of Peace
description: This is a bewildering moment for the cause of peace. In Northern Ireland, all-party talks are starting for the first time. But the current state of the Middle East peace process, now breathing only with the diplomatic equivalent of a heart-lung machine, shows how hard negotiations can be. Other than surrender, talk may be the only way the world knows to end a war. But some conflicts seem more susceptible to negotiation than others -- and some can be pushed in that direction.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about a proposed combination of Coopers & Lybrand and Price Waterhouse misspelled the surname of an accounting professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania who commented. He is Peter Knutson, not Knudsen.

title: ING Unit Is Audited On Trading Backlog
description: ING Groep N.V. said yesterday that the New York office of its ING Barings investment banking unit is being audited by United States authorities for amassing a backlog of unsettled stock trades caused by a surge in emerging-market trading.

title: White House Fund-Raising Clearly Violated Law; Where Policy Is Sacred
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, MARIA (MITZY)
description: ROSNER-Maria (Mitzy) On Sept 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Charles. She is survived by Mr. & Mrs. Ernest Silber, Mrs. John Rosner, Mr. Leslie Rosner, Mr & Mrs. Bernard Rosner, Rachel Rosner and Adam Rosner. Services Wednesday, 12:15pm at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, MAURICE M.
description: McDERMOTT-Maurice M. of Oceanside, N.Y. on September 21, 1997. Former Assistant US Attorney, SDNY and former Assistant Chief of the Criminal Division. Beloved husband of Claire P. (Nee Postiglione). Loving and devoted father of Glen (Gail) and Christopher. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y., today and tomorrow 2-4, 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Thursday 10 am. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, N.Y. Donations to N.Y. Hospital Lung Cancer Research, Rm. Starr 341, CUMC Hematology/Oncology, 520 East 70th St., NYC 10021, in Mr. McDermott's name would be appreciated.

title: Sounds of South India, From Loud Rhythms To Meditative Violins
description: The World Music Institute's concert of South Indian music on Sunday night at Symphony Space was divided between the outdoors and the indoors. The first half had two nagaswaram players and a drummer. (The nagaswaram, a double-reed instrument that buzzes and howls, is meant to be heard outside.) The second half featured violinists playing introspective, intimate music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, MARK JEFFERSON (JEFF)
description: GILBERT-Mark Jefferson (Jeff). Age 28. Died suddenly Saturday in an auto/pedestrian accident in New York, NY. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, in Abilene, TX, Elliott-Hamil Funeral Home, 542 Hickory Street. Jeff was currently employed by Sullivan & Cromwell of New York, NY, and prior to that, by Plenum Publishing, Inc. and HBO, Inc., both of New York, NY. Memorials may be sent to Compassion International, 3955 Cragwood Dr, Colorado Springs, CO 80918. Condolences may be sent to the family at 808 Westwood Drive, Abilene, TX 79603. Jeff had many friends and associates whose thoughts and prayers are greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEEVER, FRANCIS SARGENT, M.D.
description: CHEEVER-Francis Sargent, M.D., formerly of Wellesley, Mass., and Pittsburgh, Pa., died in Westwood, Mass., at age 88 on September 19, 1997. He was Vice Chancellor, Schools of the Health Professions, at the University of Pittsburgh, 1967-74; Dean of the School of Medicine, 1958-69; and Professor of Microbiology and Epidemiology, Graduate School of Public Health, 1950-74. After retiring to Wellesley in 1974, he was Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Massachusetts General Hospital, 1978-82, and Director of Admissions and Visiting Professor of Microbiology at Harvard Medical School, 197477. He is survived by his wife, Jane Garfield Cheever; four children, F. Sargent Cheever Jr. of Chisinau, Moldova, Julia Cheever Altshuler of San Francisco, George M. Cheever of Pittsburgh, and Henry J.S. Cheever of Riverside, Conn.; three stepchildren; seven grandchildren; and five stepgrandchildren. His first wife, the former Julia Whitney Martin of New York, died in 1988. A funeral will be held at Saint Andrew's Episcopal Church, Wellesley, on Saturday, Sept. 27, at 1 p.m. For information, call Waterman Funeral Home, 617-235-4110. Donations may be made to the Dr. Francis Sargent Cheever Distinguished Professorship Endowment or the F. Sargent Cheever Historical Library Fund Endowment, University of Pittsburgh, 500 Craig Hall, Pittsburgh PA 15260

title: Mrs. Clinton Campaigns for McGreevey at New Jersey Rally
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton stopped by a rally for the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, James E. McGreevey, here today, praising Mr. McGreevey's education proposals and urging the overwhelmingly female audience to help him win the support of women in New Jersey.

title: Kovalev Is Pivotal Man in Rangers' Plans
description: Rangers come and go. They get traded away or they just fade away. And Aleksei Kovalev stays, saying hello to teammates when they arrive and goodbye to them when they depart. The subject of trade speculation throughout his young career, Kovalev is now one of the senior Rangers in terms of service with the team.

title: White House Fund-Raising Clearly Violated Law; Who Will Investigate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Navajo Leaders Embrace Faith -- and Lawyers; Wounded Knee Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: Exercise Headaches
description: EXERCISE can leave people with all sorts of aches and pains, but when the pain is in your head, you had better take it seriously, says Dr. Richard Lipton, a neurologist and co-director of the Headache Unit at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: Beating in Brooklyn Shatters Fragile Neighborhood Truce
description: The arrests of three white teen-agers in the beating of a black man in Brooklyn over the weekend rekindled memories of a time when the brownstones of the largely white Carroll Gardens were considered off-limits to blacks from a housing project across the street, some residents said yesterday.

title: NOTEBOOK
description: Metrostars

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SAM J.
description: MILLER-Sam J. On September 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Esther Miller. Loving father of Frances Goldstern and husband Arnold, and Berton Miller and wife Jan. Loving grandfather of David and wife Marcia Goldstein, Daniel and Jason Goldstein, Alison and Amanda Miller and great granddaughter Dana Rae Goldstein. For information call, Weinstein West End, 1-800-452-9597.

title: Earthbound Elegance From Korea
description: The In-Young Sohn Dance Company presented traditional Korean dances and music when it performed on Saturday night at Symphony Space. Most of its offerings were gentle, elegant and stately.

title: Another Possible Climate Culprit: the Sun
description: THE blame for the global temperature rise in the last century is often laid on civilization and its genius for generating clouds of greenhouse gases that trap sunlight in the atmosphere. But another possible culprit is fast emerging.

title: Pakistan Asks India to Open No-War Talks
description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan invited India today to open negotiations on a ''non-aggression pact'' between the two South Asian neighbors who have fought each other in three wars since independence 50 years ago.

title: Fine Reflects How Donors Curry Favor
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election campaign was fined $220,000 last week for accepting excessive contributions, left unscathed were those who gave the money -- the construction conglomerates and Broadway barons, superstar developers and hotel tycoons. While it is illegal for candidates to accept contributions that exceed the limit, it is perfectly legal for people to make them, even if the sums are vastly more than the law allows.

title: Slow Night in the Lab
description: Nightingales beware. People who prefer the wee small hours of the morning, a couple of deals before dawn, may think that at night they are just as sharp at filling an inside straight or making change at the convenience store as during the day. But researchers at the Western Psychiatric Institute and Clinic in Pittsburgh say no.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOAZ, RICHARD S.
description: BOAZ-Richard S. On Sept 21, 1997. Beloved father of Leslie Boaz and Melinda Boaz Kopp. Cherished father-in-law of Martin Kopp. Devoted grandfather of Jesse, Corey and Kelsey Kopp. Loving son of the late Peggy and Alfred Boaz. Adored brother of the late Melvin Boaz. Funeral service today, 10:30 AM, Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Arthritis Foundation, 122 E 42, NYC 10168

title: Senate Panel Is Told of Penny-Stock Abuses
description: The booming stock market has brought a fresh wave of securities fraud, much of it concentrated in so-called penny and microcap issues, which are subject to minimal disclosure and other scrutiny, Federal and state regulators told a Senate panel today.

title: With More Space to Spare, Grand Central Draws Shops
description: A year before the renovation of Grand Central Terminal is to be completed, eliminating the detours, movable bagel counters and hard-to-find newsstands that have confounded commuters, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it had leased almost half the station's expanded retail space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLARD, NANCY OLNEY
description: WILLARD-Nancy Olney, longtime resident of Katonah, died at her home in Somers, N.Y. on Saturday, September 20, 1997. She was 88. Mrs. Willard, the beloved wife of the late Charles H. Willard, was born April 13, 1909 in Dedham, MA, to Richard and Ann Olney. She was married Oct. 20, 1934 in Dedham and moved to Bedford Hills, NY, where she lived for 10 yrs during the War. She lived briefly in Washington, D.C., with her husband, where she volunteered nursing at a children's hospital until the War was over. Then she returned to N.Y., where they lived in Katonah, NY, for the following 30 yrs. When Mr. Willard retired from the law firm of Davis, Polk, they moved to Guilford, CT. for 10 yrs. In 1981 they returned to New York, where they lived in Heritage Hills. She was an active member of the St. Lukes Church, where she served on the Altar Guild and also helped with the Young Christian Education Program. She also helped with the Program for the Homeless. In her spare time, she enjoyed gardening and bridge. She is survived by her children, Albert H. Willard of West Paris, Maine, and Richard O. Willard of Spruce Head Island, Maine; four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren; and one sister, Catherine Russell of Chatham, Mass. The funeral will be held on Friday, Sept. 26 at 11:30 a.m. at St Lukes Church in Katonah, N.Y. It is requested that any donations be made to Hospice of Northern Westchester, 43 Kensico Drive, Mt. Kisco, N.Y. 10549.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: AT THE MET -- Placido Domingo and, in the title role, Denyce Graves performed in ''Carmen'' last night before an audience at the Metropolitan Opera that included President and Mrs. Clinton. B6.

title: Personal Health
description: IT happens all too often: An unexpected moment of passion that ends in unprotected sex, a condom that slips or breaks, a few missed doses of the pill, an unprepared teen-ager who goes too far, a rape. And the consequences can be unintended pregnancies for women and girls who happen to be at or near the middle of their menstrual cycles.

title: School-Bus Inspectors Find Extensive Problems
description: Surprise inspections of school buses around the state that began in June have found hundreds of safety problems, Attorney General Peter Verniero said yesterday.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: One-parent, two-parent and multi-generational sitcoms about families are crowding onto television. Here are reviews of several with premieres today and tomorrow.

title: Gore Urges Moscow to Veto Limits on Minor Religions in Russia
description: Vice President Al Gore pressed the Yeltsin Government today to reject a new bill to protect the Russian Orthodox Church against competition from other Christian faiths.

title: Growth Hormone Use in Children Found Ineffective in Large Study
description: A LARGE study has cast strong doubt on the increasingly common practice of giving growth hormone injections to short children to help them reach an average height. It concludes that years of treatment do not achieve this goal even for the one group of children who are thought to benefit: those who are deficient in human growth hormone, a pituitary gland chemical that stimulates growth.

title: Sportscaster Pleads Not Guilty As Sexual Assault Trial Opens
description: Marv Albert, the NBC sportscaster, pleaded not guilty today to charges of forcible sodomy and assault involving a 42-year-old Virginia woman in a hotel room here last February. Then he listened solemnly as his trial began with a prosecutor telling a state jury in graphic detail why the charges were filed.

title: Faulty Radar Delays Flights In the Northeast
description: A computer failure in the air traffic control center that governs planes at high altitudes over New England and most of New York State caused widespread minor delays in commercial traffic yesterday afternoon, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, JANET
description: STONE-Janet. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Janet Stone. Janet was a gracious and elegant woman who loved beauty. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Man Kills Wife and Himself
description: A Burlington County man strangled his wife while their two young daughters were home, delivered the children to a relative and later committed suicide by shooting himself in the head, the A.P. reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, SELMA
description: OPPENHEIM - Selma. Beloved wife of Henry. Devoted mother of Steven and Richard. Loving grandmother of Laura, Donald, Michael, Allyson and Daniel. Services today, 1:30 pm, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Broad St, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, JACK
description: ROSEMAN-Jack. The National Offices of EMUNAH of America mourn the passing of the beloved husband of our honorary National President, Betty Roseman. Jack Roseman was a staunch and generous friend of EMUNAH who earned the respect of everyone who knew him. We express our heartfelt condolences to Betty, children Surella and Joseph Feit, Rena and Michael Reinhard, Chani and Simon Lichtiger and grandchildren. Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld, Nat'l Pres.

title: Court Orders Hearing on Vote Fraud Charges by Sharpton
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered an immediate hearing into the Rev. Al Sharpton's allegation that he was unfairly denied a runoff bid because the vote count following the Democratic mayoral primary on Sept. 9 was riddled with fraud and other irregularities.

title: Grand Met and Foster's Selling British Pubs
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. agreed yesterday to sell about 4,300 pubs to an investment vehicle set up by Nomura Securities for $:475 million in cash, or about $765 million, and the assumption of $:775 million of debt. The companies being sold -- the Inntrepreneur Pub Company and Spring Inns Ltd. -- own 2,903 and 1,406 British public houses respectively.

title: Argentina and the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTORS OF CHECKERS AND RALLY'S PLAN STOCK SWAP
description: The largest investors of Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that they would swap a 25 percent stake in Checkers for 42 percent of Rally's Hamburgers Inc. In June, Checkers canceled a plan to buy Rally's for $178.5 million in stock and debt because some accounting methods used in the transaction were not approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The stock swap would allow the fast-food restaurant chains to cut costs by combining legal, accounting and finance departments, a Rally's spokesman said. Rally's has 473 double drive-through hamburger restaurants and Checkers operates 480 restaurants. The shares of Checkers rose 15.625 cents, to $1.53125, and Rally's was unchanged at $3.4375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSER, LOUISE KLAUBER
description: MOSER-Louise Klauber. With love and sadness we record her peaceful death at home in Larchmont, NY on September 20, 1997. She is survived by sons David and Ronald and grandsons Gregg and Adam. The family welcome those who knew her to her home from 3pm to 5pm on September 23, 1997 to share an appreciation of her life. In lieu of flowers, donations to United Hospital Hospice, 406 Boston Post Road, Portchester, NY 10573.

title: One Killed and One Hurt By Home Invaders
description: Two men pushed their way into a home in Canarsie, Brooklyn, last night, shooting one man to death and critically wounding another, the police said.

title: Hamburg Results Stir Rivalries in German Left
description: FRANKFURT  - The rivalry within Germany's political left over who will challenge Chancellor Helmut Kohl next year stepped up on Monday following the Social Democratic Party's worst postwar showing in Hamburg's local elections over the weekend.

title: Finding Points to Suicide Mechanism in Damaged Cells
description: CRACKING a longstanding mystery about human cells' defense against tumors, scientists at Johns Hopkins University have discovered the probable means by which most cells, when genetically damaged, will kill themselves rather than grow into a tumor that threatens the whole organism.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSLOW, DAVID
description: KOSLOW-David. Passed away peacefully on September 20, 1997. David is survived by ''Sammye,'' his loving wife of 54 years; his devoted children Ron, Bob (Tracy), Ken, Judy (Stefan) Zweig. He is the adored ''Poppa'' of Jenna. He will also be missed by his sister, sister-in-law, his many nieces and nephews, and fond friends around the world. Services will be Tuesday, September 23, 1997 at 2:00 p.m. in the Hillside Memorial Park, Los Angeles, CA.

title: ELECTRO RENT TO ACQUIRE GE CAPITAL TECHNOLOGY UNIT
description: The Electro Rent Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the computer and test and measurement equipment rental businesses of GE Capital Technology Management Services for $320 million. GE Capital Technology is a division of GE Capital Services, the financial services unit of the General Electric Company. Electro Rent said the deal should close by Oct. 31. For the year ended May 31, Electro Rent earned $24.1 million, or $1.94 a share, on revenue of $150.5 million. Electro Rent, of Van Nuys, Calif., is involved in the short-term renting and leasing of personal computers, work stations and general-purpose electronic test equipment. Electro Rent's shares closed at $33.25, up $5.25, or 18 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRIMOFF, ESTHER SHAINER
description: PRIMOFF-Esther Shainer. Died September 14, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Bertram; mother of Walter Primoff and Marilyn Kohn. Loving grandmother of Douglas Kohn. She will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, ABRAHAM
description: BROOKS-Abraham. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood, mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member Sandra Ginsburg and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, Pres.

title: The Book on Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Representative Aims Higher

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUCCIONE, KATHRYN KEETON
description: GUCCIONE - Kathryn Keeton You so bravely explored new frontiers. We admire your strength, courage, vision and dedication to so many worthy causes. Our deepest condolences to our friend, Bob Guccione, on the loss of his partner in life. Stephanie and Jay Newman

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN ANNUITY GROUP INC., Cincinnati, which markets individual and group annuities, agreed to purchase General Accident Life Assurance Co. of Puerto Rico, a subsidiary of General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corp. P.L.C., Perth, Scotland, for $50 million.

title: Chess
description: The 1997 United States Invitational Championship and a $10,000 prize is now in the possession of Joel Benjamin, a Manhattan grandmaster. He won the final match by 3 1/2-2 1/2 against Larry Christiansen of Seattle on Sept. 12 in Chandler, Ariz. Christiansen was awarded $7,000.

title: Metro Business; Second Bid Received To Run Nuclear Lab
description: The United States Department of Energy announced yesterday that it had received a second bid to manage its Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, even though the lab's idle main nuclear reactor may never be restarted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVERMAN, WILLIAM PETER
description: OVERMAN - William Peter. Adored and beloved husband of Jane Leavy Overman. Adored and loving father of Jennifer, David and Jonathan Blinken. Pop Pop to Alegra, Emma and Benjamin. Beloved brother to Nancy Sher and friend to so many. The family will receive friends Tuesday September 23 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., 7-9 PM, with service Wednesday, September 24, 9:45 AM. Burial will be in East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in his memory to either Dr. David Pfister Head and Neck Service Fund, in care of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NYC 10021, or SCAN NY, 207-215 East 27th St, NYC 10016

title: Shoney's Places Account in Review
description: Shoney's Restaurants has placed its account in review. The account, with billings estimated at $26 million, has been handled by Bernstein-Rein Advertising in Kansas City, Mo., since May 1995.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Calls for Overhaul of Campaign System 'Awash With Dirty Money'
description: One of the biggest players in the freewheeling world of campaign finance, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., called today for overhauling the nation's system of paying for political fund-raising, asserting that it gave a far larger voice to corporations and the rich than to Americans of more modest means.

title: New Economic Chief Sees Slow March to Open China Markets
description: China's newly elevated economic chief, Zhu Rongji, said today that he planned to move cautiously in opening the nation's markets and exposing its sclerotic state-owned enterprises to foreign competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMUNTZ, LAWRENCE
description: GOLDMUNTZ-Lawrence. The officers, members and staff of the American Jewish Committee are deeply saddened by the death of Lawrence Goldmuntz, noted scientist and public policy consultant, who served AJC in numerous distinguished capacities for many years, including as president of our Washington, DC Chapter and a member of our Board of Governors. His support for causes related to US and Israeli security, as well as his abiding devotion to the Jewish community, will be sorely missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Barbara, his daughters, and the rest of his grieving family. Robert S. Rifkind, President David A. Harris, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINIKER, CECELIA (FRIED)
description: WINIKER-Cecelia (Fried). On September 22, 1997. R.N. Beloved wife of Norman for 46 years. Loving mother of Linda, Kenneth, Janice. Dear mother-in-law of Charles Truboff and Anthony Tuozzo. Cherished grandmother (Bubbe) of Zachary, Benjamin, Jordana Truboff and Dylan and Joey Tuozzo. Shiva will be observed at 19 E. Rogues Path, Huntington Station, NY. Contributions can be made to the charity of your choice.

title: ON HORSE RACING ; Cup Left Half-Empty After a Day of Upsets
description: This is what you call a day to remember in horse racing, or maybe a day to forget:

title: Sun Microsystems Rejects Suggestions It Give Up Java
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. lashed out at the Microsoft Corporation yesterday, saying that it would not give up its ownership of the Java computer language, as Microsoft and other companies have recently suggested, in order to have it officially certified as an international standard.

title: Crew Rejects Parents' Money To Pay One Teacher's Salary
description: Hours after a group of parents at a New York City public school raised nearly $46,000 to prevent a fourth-grade teacher from being laid off, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew blocked the move yesterday and ordered a moratorium on similar efforts throughout the system, saying such fund-raising drives were unfair to other schools with large classes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: B. F. Goodrich to Buy Rohr For $789 Million in Stock

title: William L. Rowe, Police Official, Dies at 82
description: William L. Rowe, a nationally syndicated newspaper columnist who became New York City's first black deputy police commissioner, died on Thursday at Glen Island Care Center in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 82.

title: In Murk, Rainbow of Cichlid Fish Colors Is Disappearing
description: IN recent years, hundreds of the fast-evolving fish species known as cichlids that swim in Africa's Great Lakes have been going extinct under the stresses of pollution and introduced predators. Now researchers report that even more of these colorful little fish are being driven out of existence by an entirely unexpected problem: a curious glitch in their love lives.

title: A Serious Wells Turns Down the Music and Quiets the Jays
description: David Wells usually plays air guitar and sings backup vocals while he blares heavy metal music in the clubhouse before he pitches. The starting pitcher gets to pick the pre-game tunes for the Yankees, and Wells usually opts for something like Metallica. He wants the music to be loud and hard.

title: CONSECO IN DEAL FOR AN INSURER, WASHINGTON NATIONAL
description: Conseco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Washington National Corporation, an insurer, for $33.25 a share, or $410 million. Conseco, based in Carmel, Ind., is a $31 billion financial-services holding company. Washington National, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., is a provider of life insurance, annuities and specialty health insurance with assets of $2.8 billion. The acquisition and the pending acquisition of the Colonial Penn Life Insurance Company are expected to give Conseco assets of $34 billion and annual premiums and revenue of $8 billion. Washington National's stock edged up 6.25 cents a share, to $32.4375, and Conseco rose 56.25 cents a share, to $47.625.

title: Herzliya Journal; Spring Forward, Fall Back Into a Religious Debate
description: As the sun dipped toward the horizon late this afternoon, Yaniv and Efrat Peri hurried down to the beach to get in a quick walk before darkness fell on this seaside town north of Tel Aviv.

title: Executive Changes
description: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO., New York, named John Reid its chief technological officer, succeeding the late Craig Tate. Mr. Reid had been vice president of the South Pacific region, which included the Colgate businesses in Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Papua, New Guinea.

title: Thai Noodle Business
description: To the Editor:

title: France Telecom Issue Is Prepared
description: The French Finance Ministry said yesterday that it would sell about 37 billion French francs, or about $6.2 billion, worth of shares in France Telecom S.A. to institutional and individual investors at a price at the high end of analyst expectations.

title: Directory Venture Is Set
description: The Atlantic Information Services Group of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and R. R. Donnelley & Sons said today that they would form a joint venture to publish shopping directories outside the United States. The new venture, called the Global Directory Services Company, will include operations in Poland, Gibraltar and the Czech and Slovak republics. Starting next year, Global Directory Services will publish Yellow Pages shopping directories in Greece, starting in Athens.

title: 37 YEARS LATER, A SECOND CHANCE FOR THALIDOMIDE
description: Thalidomide, the drug whose use in the 1960's produced thousands of babies with flipperlike arms and other gross deformities, is on the verge of receiving approval from the Food and Drug Administration, nearly four decades after the agency's legendary decision to reject it for use in the United States.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; School Bus Safety Problems
description: Surprise inspections of school buses around the state that began in June have found hundreds of safety problems, Peter G. Verniero, the Attorney General, said yesterday.

title: Some Changes At WPP Group
description: There were developments yesterday involving the public relations and media services operations of WPP Group in London.

title: Another Late Kick, Another Blunder
description: What is this thing with football and field goals and Monday nights? Such drama.

title: ECONOMIC PULSE: New Jersey; Diversity Propels New Jersey In Region Stung by a Recession
description: Five years after the end of the deep, punishing recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, New Jersey's economy stands on the brink, finally, of full recovery.

title: Seagram Deal With Viacom On Cable Unit
description: After weeks of complex negotiations, the Seagram Corporation has agreed to pay Viacom Inc. $1.7 billion for the 50 percent of the cable programming service, USA Network, that it does not already own.

title: Lloyd's Playoff Position Is Still Not Nailed Down
description: When Joe Torre was asked an innocent question about Graeme Lloyd's status on the post-season roster, the manager suddenly revealed that the reliever has been hampered by a left elbow injury and had to test his arm yesterday.

title: Eddie Sawyer, 87, Manager Of the Phillies' Whiz Kids
description: Eddie Sawyer, who never played in the major leagues but managed the Philadelphia Phillies' 1950 Whiz Kids team to the franchise's first National League pennant in 35 years, died yesterday in Phoenixville, Pa., after a brief illness. Sawyer, who lived in Valley Forge, Pa., was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, CATHERINE MARSHALL
description: FISHER-Catherine Marshall. Died suddenly September 21, 1997 while on vacation in London. She was born August 30, 1921 in New York City and spent her life in Greenwich, CT. She graduated from Rosemary Hall and Vassar College, Class of 1943. She was a past President of the Board of Trustees of Rosemary Hall, a past President of the Round Hill Guild and a member of the District 10 Delegation to the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting. She was a lifelong member of the Round Hill Community Church. At the time of her death, she was a member of the Board of Directors of the Boys and Girls Club in Greenwich and an active member of the Teagle Scholarship Fund Committee. She is survived by her husband of fiftyfour years, Everett Fisher, her daughters Catherine Fisher Field of Dresden, ME and Emily T. Fisher of Old Lyme, CT, her sons-inlaw Elliot Field and Evan S. Griswold, and four beloved grandchildren, Jesse and Molly Field, and Oliver and Andrew Griswold. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 27th, 2PM at the Round Hill Community Church. Memorial contributions may be made to the Round Hill Community Church or the Grenwich Boys and Girls Club for the Teagle Scholarship Fund.

title: Delta Earnings to Be Below Expectations
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. warned yesterday its earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30 would be below analysts' expectations and down from a year ago on lower revenue.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Ellen J. Langer; A Scholar of the Absent Mind
description: ELLEN J. LANGER'S specialty may seem a little odd for a psychologist: she studies mindlessness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINMAN, GEORGE L.
description: HINMAN-George L., of Pennsylvania Avenue, Town of Binghamton, died Sunday morning, September 21, 1997, at his home. He was born in Binghamton, N.Y., on September 25, 1905, the son of Harvey DeForest Hinman and Phebe Brown Hinman. He was predeceased by his wife, Barbara Davidge Hinman and his daughter Constance H. Getz. He is survived by three children, Mrs. George A. Vaughn III, (Martha), Princeton, NJ, Mrs. Harlan Cummings, (Virginia), Quechee, Vermont, Mr. Harvey D. Hinman, II, Atherton, California; also by twelve grandchildren, Peter L., Robert H., and George H. Getz, Barbara D. Vaughn, Susan p. O'Brien, Phebe H. Outerbridge, Winthrop A., George H. and Sanger T. Robinson, George L. Hinman, Sarah P. Whittle, Marguerite B. Hinman; seven great-grandchildren. The body was removed to the J.A. McCormack Sons Funeral Home, 141 Main Street, Binghamton, New York. There will be a private interment at Floral Park Cemetery, Johnson City. A memorial Service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church, 42 Chenango Street, Binghamton, New York at 11 a.m. Thursday September 25, 1997. In Lieu of Flowers, Expressions of Sympathy may be made to Lourdes Hospital Foundation Hospice, 169 Riverside Drive, Binghamton, New York 13905 or the Tri-Cities Opera, 315 Clinton Street, Binghamton, New York 13905.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about legislative proposals to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service referred incorrectly to a plan for an oversight board. It would comprise appointees from government, education and business, not exclusively business.

title: Arts in America; The Unsung Hero of Nonprofit Theater Is Still Selling
description: For the opening night of the 43d Lyric Opera season here on Saturday, Danny Newman wore his new tuxedo, the one he bought in 1974. He chose it, he said, over his other one, the 1946 model -- ''a very good winter suit'' -- because the weather has been warm. He sounded disappointed, like a man with a long memory and a nostalgic bent.

title: Do Modest Improvements in Windows 98 Make It Worth Waiting for?
description: LAST week the Microsoft Corporation announced that Windows 98, the successor to its Windows 95 operating system, would be delayed. The new target date is the second quarter of 1998, which in the computer world tends to mean ''one minute before the first of July, assuming we don't blow it.'' The news depressed the company's stock price despite the fact that a vast majority of new personal computers will continue to be supplied with some version of Windows.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Texaco in Rich but Troubled Kazak Field
description: Texaco Inc. has reason to crow about its latest deal. In one stroke, its reserve base swelled nearly 20 percent and it became a major participant in one of the world's most coveted energy-producing regions.

title: Patterns
description: Bottega Veneta's Venture

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARIA N. (NEE NEKOS)
description: DAVIS-Maria N. (Nee Nekos) of Summit, NJ, and South Hampton, L.I., on September 21, 1997. Wife of George A. Davis, mother of Stephen of New York City, Carol Fiske of Hartford, Conn., and Leslie Dahl of Greenwich, Conn., sister of Peter Nekos of Pleasantville, NY, and three grandchildren. A Memorial service will be held on Thursday, Spetember 25, 1997 at 2 p.m. from Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name may be made to the Fresh Air Fund, New York City, or The Summit Speech School, Summit, NJ. William R. Dangler Funeral Home, Summit, NJ.

title: New York Police Issues Echo In Houston's Race for Mayor
description: Lee P. Brown has never been known as the most loquacious of men. When he was Atlanta's Commissioner of Public Safety nearly 20 years ago, he spoke so tersely at public briefings that he acquired the nickname ''No Rap Brown,'' a contrast to H. Rap Brown, the fiery former Black Panther leader.

title: 2 Sought in Disappearance of Businessman
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is searching for two Manhattan men who were with Nelson G. Gross, New Jersey's former Republican Party chairman who disappeared on Wednesday, New York City law enforcement officials said today.

title: Brazil's Soccer Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELLY, FELIX ALOYSIUS III
description: CONNELLY-Felix Aloysius III, age 88, of Manhattan, NY, on September 22, 1997. Husband of Aline (Clapp) Connelly and the late Kathleen (Fay) Connelly. Father of Patricia M. Wilson. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday 10 AM at St. Joseph's Church, Croton Falls, NY. Burial will be Private. Calling Hrs Tuesday 7-9 at the Beecher Funeral Home, 1 Putnam Terrace, Brewster, NY. Contributions in his Memory may be made to the St. John's Queens Hospital, Attn: Emergency Room Division, 9002 Queens Boulevard, Elmhurst, New York 11373.

title: Deal for Miami Building
description: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company said today that it had agreed to buy an office tower in Miami for about $132 million from the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Crescent, a real estate investment trust headed by Richard Rainwater, said the office tower, named Miami Center, is 78 percent occupied. Crescent also said today that it had sold $400 million of senior unsecured notes. Proceeds from the sale will be used for acquisitions and to repay debt. Crescent, based in Fort Worth, had 1996 revenues of $208.8 million.

title: A New 'Lolita' Stalls in Europe; Hollywood Snubs Remake of the Tale of an Adolescent Siren
description: Americans read ''Lolita,'' the book, in the 1950's, and saw ''Lolita,'' the movie, in the 1960's. Now, decades after it first became a test of both artistic license and freedom, ''Lolita,'' the film remake, is about to open across Europe but not in the United States, where major distributors have so far shunned Vladimir Nabokov's disturbing story of an older man's passion for a prepubescent girl.

title: Refugees From Congo Give Vivid Accounts of Killings
description: Like many of the 4,600 Hutu refugees in the United Nations camp in this remote riverside village, Odette Mporayonzi remembers in all its terrifying detail the army attack that killed her husband and hundreds of her compatriots and finally drove the survivors out of the country formerly known as Zaire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAINA, NICHOLAS JOHN
description: TRAINA-Nicholas John Steel-in San Francisco, September 20, 1997, after a longtime struggle with a lifetime illness and valiant fight to the end, of an accidental overdose. Son of Danielle Steel Traina and John A Traina, Jr., of San Francisco. Nicholas was 19 years old (1 May 1978). He graduated from Town School and the Woodside International School and for the past 2-1/2 years was the lead singer, lyricist and manager of the rock band, Link 80, which had gained considerable acclaim nationally and internationally, mostly among teenagers. His C.D.'s and videos were being distributed internationally. A month ago he started a new band of his own, ''Knowledge''. Nick Traina was the bright star of his family and will be greatly missed by all. He is survived by his parents and his eight siblings: Samantha, Victoria, Vanessa, Maxx, Zara, Trevor and Todd Traina and Beatrix Seidenberg. Friends are invited for Visitation, Tuesday, September 23rd from 5-8 pm at HALSTED N. GRAY-CAREW & ENGLISH, 1123 Sutter St., San Francisco, and to attend the Funeral Service on Wednesday, September 24th at 3:30 pm at Grace Cathedral Episcopal Church, 1100 California St., San Francisco, CA. Interment private. Flowers or charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCK, LEONARD PLAUT
description: STOCK-Leonard Plaut. Of Pompano Beach, Florida on September 22nd. Beloved husband of Ruth (Gunzburger). Loving father of Ellen, John and his wife Janet. Devoted grandfather of Alissa and Debbie. Visiting hours at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street on Wednesday, September 24th 5:30PM to 7:30PM. Graveside service Thursday September 25th 11AM at Union Fields Cemetery, Cypress Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Right Time, Right Place in Tampa Bay
description: Two defensive starters were in jured and out tackle Warren Sapp and linebacker Rufus Porter. So before Sunday night's kickoff against the Miami Dolphins, Tampa Bay Coach Tony Dungy, who has built his team on defense, told his offense that it had to win the game. Make plays. Convert third downs. Keep the ball away from Dolphins quarterback Dan Marino.

title: Patriotic Marionette
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Rises as South Swelters; North's Chill Lifts Heating Oil
description: Natural gas prices surged yesterday after unseasonably hot weather in the southern United States bolstered demand.

title: Albany Legislature Votes to Reinstate Law on Ticket Scalping for One Year
description: Nearly four months after the expiration of the state law banning ticket scalping, the Legislature today completed passage of a bill that would reinstate the law for a year.

title: Trial Opens in Fatal Shootings At Bronx Shoe Store in 1995
description: The trial of a man charged with killing five people and maiming three others in a Bronx shoe store began yesterday with the prosecution portraying him as a deadly accurate shooter and the defense countering that his actions were the result of mental illness.

title: Timothy W. Stanley, 69, Expert On Defense Policy and Strategies
description: Timothy Wadsworth Stanley, an authority on defense policy who served in the 1960's as assistant to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara for NATO force planning and then as a defense adviser, with the rank of minister, in the United States mission to NATO, died on Sunday at his home in Washington, D.C. He was 69.

title: Q&A
description: I Hear the Train a' Comin'

title: Correction: Leading Accounting Firms
description: A chart in Business Day Friday ranking the Big Six accounting firms on several measures, included some incorrect figures for Ernst & Young and thus ranked the firms incorrectly in several categories. Here are corrected versions of the affected portions.

title: Celebrating Coltrane And a Shrine to Jazz
description: There are musical shrines that are big and lofty and well-heeled, and then there is the Village Vanguard, which is small and in a basement and which affects a down-at-heels look. The Carnegie Hall of jazz, the Vanguard, in Greenwich Village, is jazz's heart and soul. And this week it is part of a celebration that pays tribute to the saxophonist John Coltrane, who died in 1967, and whose towering reputation is in part based on the recordings he made there.

title: Push for Volunteerism Brings No Outpouring
description: Lorraine Bodden did not show up for work yesterday at KPMG Peat Marwick, the giant accounting firm. Instead, she danced with patients at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home's ''autumn ball'' in Manhattan, one of 20,000 KPMG employees in 130 offices across the country who got the day off with pay to volunteer at schools, hospitals, nursing homes, parks and youth centers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Personal Health
description: IT happens all too often: An unexpected moment of passion that ends in unprotected sex, a condom that slips or breaks, a few missed doses of the pill, an unprepared teen-ager who goes too far, a rape. And the consequences can be unintended pregnancies for women and girls who happen to be at or near the middle of their menstrual cycles.

title: For the Giants, It's Time to Retool, Not to Panic
description: Forgive Jim Fassel for dreaming. He had a design for his first four games as the Giants' coach, and it included three victories.

title: Giuliani and Rival Dig Into Past and Stir Up Campaign
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger delved into the past yesterday, searching for information that they could use to derail each other's mayoral candidacy. The Mayor accused Ms. Messinger of holding a party in 1979 for an inmate convicted of killing an Attica Prison guard. Ms. Messinger responded by saying that Mr. Giuliani tried to dodge the draft in 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: GOLDSTEIN-Joseph. On Sept 18. Age 93. Accomplished artist, Cooper Union grad and good friend of the late Byron Browne. Modest man of many talents and a font of knowledge. Father of Alan, Carol, grandfather of Gerald. Brother of Frances, Dave and Manny. The world will be a lesser and meaner place without you old friend.

title: Man in the News: Marian Krzaklewski; Architect of Solidarity's Victory
description: When President Clinton visited here in July to celebrate Poland's invitation to join NATO, a move backed and orchestrated by the Administration, Marian Krzaklewski, the Solidarity leader, was invited along with other opposition leaders to meet him.

title: Sports of The Times; In Westfield, Fans Hope For a Miracle
description: ON the corner of Central Avenue and East Broad, in the heart of the last place that still believes in a quarterback named Dave Brown, Officer Gregory Hobson ushered a young mother across the street, then wished upon an offensive line that could do likewise for a hometown kid desperate for traffic control.

title: A Buffo Rossinian Book in a Chinese Wrapper
description: A cunning maidservant outwits a foolish and venal official. A young woman of high rank tries to avoid disclosing her romantic feelings. Her father finds it more politic to order her suitor's death than to investigate his fitness. The same cunning maidservant outwits another foolish and venal official. As a result, the young woman of high rank gets her man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINHORN, HERBERT ARTHUR
description: EINHORN-Herbert Arthur. On September 19, 1997. Devoted father of Eric and Kirsten Einhorn and Diane and Bill Colish. Loving grandfather of Katrina, Peter, Daniel and Stefanie. A memorial service will be held October 19 at 2 PM at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Rye, NY. Specifics can be obtained from Ballard Durand Funeral Home at 914-949-0566. Contributions in his memory may be made to Ohio University Scholarship Fund.

title: A Troupe's Far-Flung Family Gathers in Tribute
description: Dance Theater of Harlem saluted Virginia Johnson, its prima ballerina and a dancer with the company since its founding in 1969, in a loving tribute on Sunday afternoon at Davis Hall at City College. It was clear that the company was indeed a family, as its director, Arthur Mitchell, stressed, when the stage filled with early dancers, staff members and choreographers, many of whom had flown in for the occasion.

title: Ballesteros Is Brimming With Pride In His Team
description: Spain is his homeland, golf is his passion, and winning the Ryder Cup has become his mission.

title: House May Seek Court Ruling on Census Sampling
description: Shifting its stance on an issue of importance both constitutionally and politically, the House Republican leadership may ask the courts for a quick decision on the Census Bureau's plans to use statistical sampling in 2000, a House Republican aide said tonight.

title: Pitt's Passer Is Quick To Share Fans' Praise
description: When the fans charged onto the field at Pitt Stadium after the Panthers' unexpected victory over Miami on Thursday night, the players were surprised and gratified, said quarterback Pete Gonzalez, the hero of the game.

title: Mussels' Mighty Muscles
description: SPACE-AGE materials are tough and strong, but sometimes one cannot beat nature, in particular mussels. Clumps of these marine shellfish can be found stuck on rocks, oil rigs, bridge pilings, docks, just about anything in the water. And anyone who has tried to detach them from their homes, whether for the end purpose of crab bait or moules mariniere, knows how tough they are.

title: Shaken by Collapse of Bubble Economy, The Mindset of Investors Begins to Change : Japanese Come to Terms With Idea of Credit Risk
description: TOKYO  In the past few years, Japan has seen some of its trusted corporations listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange go bust and some smaller financial institutions declared insolvent, prompting a fundamental shift in attitude among investors and the public alike toward the concept of credit risk.

title: Rangers May Get LaFontaine
description: The Rangers may solve their vacancy at the center position by obtaining Pat LaFontaine from the Buffalo Sabres. LaFontaine, trying to come back from a concussion that sidelined him for most of last season, is being offered in trade by Darcy Regier, the new general manager of the Sabres.

title: Bulls Add Burrell
description: The Chicago Bulls acquired guard/forward Scott Burrell from the Golden State Warriors for forward Dickey Simpkins yesterday.

title: The Varying Accents of Romanticism
description: Jorge Federico Osorio, a Mexican pianist who lives in London and is known to New York City listeners mainly through recordings, offered a demanding debut recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Osorio has been performing outside New York for the last two decades, and his credentials are impressive: Wilhelm Kempff and Nadia Reisenberg are listed among his teachers, and he won several international competitions as far back as the early 1970's. He directs a chamber music festival in Mexico, and his recordings range from the Beethoven concertos to works by his countryman Manuel Ponce.

title: Is Global Warming Tied to Solar Storms?
description: For centuries, scientists have known that the Sun has seasons, storms and rhythms of activity, with its sunspots and flares appearing in cycles roughly 11 years long. But only in the last decade or so have researchers begun to tie solar variations to climate shifts on Earth.

title: Genovese Crime Figures Given Federal Sentences
description: A man described by the authorities as the onetime acting boss of the Genovese crime family was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in prison for his involvement in extortion conspiracies in the garbage-hauling and construction businesses.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Economy Nears Full Recovery
description: Five years after the end of the deep, punishing recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, New Jersey's economy stands on the brink of a full recovery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHICK, ROBERT D.
description: SCHICK-Robert D. On September 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruth (Shultz). Loving father of Nathaniel and Joseph. Cherished brother of Elliot. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd (76th Rd), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column of the Long Island Weekly on Sunday about the Long Island Apple Festival in East Setauket misstated the date. It is this Sunday, not Saturday.

title: Patronage in the Counting House
description: In the wake of the mayoral primary debacle, a great many people in New York City are now aware of some dispiriting facts about the Board of Elections. It is clear that the board did not do everything in its power to make sure the unofficial count was accurate on Election Night. Because of the confusion, the public noticed for the first time that it takes the board itself more than a week to count the votes, and heard many stories about election disasters in years past.

title: For Spring Bridge Lines, Fashion Comes First
description: They call it bridge. It's a word retailers coined to describe clothes priced to bridge the gap between expensive and moderate. It came to mean mainly career clothes for a woman who could afford to spend $800 to $1,000 for a three-piece outfit -- prices that just a decade ago bought a designer suit.

title: As the stigma fades, Madison Ave. steps up its fight against AIDS.
description: ANY advertising mainstays are becoming involved again -- or for the first time -- in efforts to fight AIDS.

title: You Want Boring? Try That Game in '83
description: There is a difference between boring good and boring bad. The Giants once cornered the market on the former. The Jets patented the latter.

title: New Strain of Highly Contagious Tuberculosis Is Identified
description: A HIGHLY contagious, rapidly growing strain of the bacteria that cause tuberculosis has mysteriously emerged in the foothills of the Smoky Mountains, in a rural area along the Tennessee-Kentucky border.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAHAN, JOSHUA
description: KAHAN-Joshua. On September 17, 1997, 2 year old Joshua Kahan lost his courageous battle against leukemia. A fund has been established to help find a cure for Acute Myelocytic Leukemia (AML). If you wish to help, Jeff and Michele request that you contribute to the battle against childhood cancers. Please send checks payable to THE JOSHUA KAHAN FOUNDATION, Inc., 46 Downing Lane, Voorhees, NJ 08043

title: White House Fund-Raising Clearly Violated Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Giants Woo Lower-Income Market : Tuning In To Small Investors
description: PARIS  If it is a banker's fate to follow his customers, there is one class of client that no bank in the world canafford to ignore any longer:the small investor.

title: Playoff Tickets On Sale Today
description: Tickets for Games 1 and 2 of the American League first-round playoff series at Yankee Stadium next Tuesday and Oct. 2 will go on sale at 5 P.M. today by telephone through Ticketmaster at (212) 307-1212 and at the advance-ticket windows at the Stadium.

title: Sham Ethics
description: Despite public concern about ethical lapses in Washington, House Republicans have pushed through new rules designed to make it even harder to hold lawmakers accountable for serious misconduct. They took as their basic text a flawed set of rules proposed by a bipartisan task force formed in February to recommend changes in the workings of the House ethics committee, following that committee's sluggish investigation of Speaker Newt Gingrich. But instead of improving the task force report the House moved, by a largely partisan vote of 258 to 154, to make ethics enforcement even weaker.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TIGER WOODS had a bit of advice for President Clinton, and it had nothing to do with golf.

title: Bobby Jones and the Mets Foil the Marlins' Celebration for One More Day
description: The Champagne was on ice. The banners were ready. But tonight, for the third straight time, the Mets left the Florida Marlins frustrated while preserving their own improbable playoff hopes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MILDRED (BARRY)
description: FRIEDMAN-Mildred (Barry). The Division of Vascular Surgery, SUNY-HSC Brooklyn notes with sorrow the loss of Barry, a longtime patient of the Division and wife of Eli Friedman, MD, Distinguished Professor of Medicine and Chief, Division of Renal Medicine at the Medical Center on September 21. We extend our sincerest condolences to Eli and their daughters Amy, Sarah and Becky, their husbands and children. Thomas F. Panetta, M.D., Jon D. Kirwin, M.D. Willem Wisselink, M.D. George Varughese, M.D. William Rodino, M.D.

title: Children of the Reform; Benefits at Risk, Young Mothers Turn Back to School
description: Jesenia Valdivieso, 15, arrived at Eastern District High School in Brooklyn one morning early this month, her 14-month-old child in her arms, her mother at her side. Out of school for a year and lacking any high school credits, the girl from the Southside section of Williamsburg briefly listed her motivations: I want to register for classes; I want to be a journalist; I don't want to lose my welfare benefits.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: One-parent, two-parent and multi-generational sitcoms about families are crowding onto television. Here are reviews of several with premieres today and tomorrow.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Backing for a Casino License
description: New Jersey casino investigators announced yesterday that an 11-year-old bribery allegation against Sol Kerzner, the chairman of Sun International Hotels Ltd., should not be held against the company, The Associated Press reported.

title: Goodrich Plans to Buy Rohr In $789 Million Stock Deal
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Rohr Inc., a maker of aircraft engine parts, in a stock swap valued at $789 million.

title: BIG FLOWER PRESS TO PAY $260 MILLION FOR 3 COMPANIES
description: Big Flower Press Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it would pay a total of about $260 million in stock and the assumption of debt to acquire three companies. Last week, Big Flower, an advertising and marketing company, acquired Olwen Direct Mail Ltd., a British direct mail company. On Sunday, Big Flower said it had agreed to buy two more companies: the Riverside County Publishing Company, a California-based provider of advertising inserts with annual revenues of about $130 million, and Columbine JDS Systems Inc., a provider of computer-based management systems with 1996 revenues of $60 million. Big Flower, based in New York, said yesterday that it expected to incur costs of about $55 million from its purchase of Columbine.

title: On My Mind; Getting To Know Him
description: Jiang Zemin is a very important man and gets more important all the time. Next month he will visit President Clinton in Washington. So we really ought to do a little boning up on the man.

title: Snarled Traffic, the Secret Service, and a Presidential Night at the Opera
description: Vernon James, one of the 3,800 other ticket-holders for the season-opening performance of ''Carmen'' at the Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center last night, was hardly impressed by the presence of President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKMAN, FLORENCE
description: BLACKMAN-Florence. Beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother. Graveside services at Wellwood Cemetery 2pm Tues.

title: Tobacco Profits May Soar Under Deal, Government Study Shows
description: Tobacco industry profits could soar under terms of a legal settlement proposed in June by 40 state attorneys general and cigarette makers, according to a new analysis of the agreement by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: McDonald's Brazil Plans
description: The McDonald's Corporation said today that it planned to invest more than $500 million over the next four years to expand Brazilian operations. McDonald's, based in Oak Brook, Ill., said it projects its Brazilian operations will have sales of $800 million this year, making it one of the company's top 10 markets. McDonald's has 270 restaurants and 130 satellite sites in Brazil. The company plans to double the number of restaurants by 2001.

title: 'Carmen' Opens Met Opera Season
description: Given his legislative agenda, it was a surprise to find President Clinton visiting a cigarette factory last night. But there he was at the Metropolitan Opera, warding off theatrical second-hand smoke from the likes of Carmen, Don Jose, Morales and Zuniga in the safe, distant air of his first-tier box.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, JACK
description: GOTTLIEB-Jack. On September 22nd at age 83 of Kings Point, LI, after a lengthy illness. Loving husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. We will all miss his detailed recaps of his winning hands and biggest exactas. From the starting gate to the finish line, he was always the favorite! Services will be today at 12:30, Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations may be made to the Yeshiva Scholarship Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, THOMAS G.
description: SHEA-Thomas G. The Board and staff of Ballet Hispanico note with profound sorrow the death of our longtime friend and board member emeritus. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife and family. Jody Gottfried Arnhold, Chairman Thomas W. Ostrander, President Dhuanne Tansill, Chairman Emeritus

title: Navajo Leaders Embrace Faith -- and Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: When Rabbi ARTHUR SCHNEIER receives Austria's Grand Decoration of Honor in Gold With Star at the Austrian Consulate in New York tomorrow, he will have come full circle with the land of his birth.

title: Eat Fat, Get Fat
description: Not only do calories count when it comes to gaining or losing body fat, but the source of those calories counts as well. The human body was designed to use carbohydrates for ready energy and to store dietary fat as body fat for the future, when calories may be in short supply. So it should come as no surprise to learn that children who eat a high-fat diet have more body fat than children who eat a high-carbohydrate diet, even if their total energy intake and expenditures are the same.

title: Hundley Will Focus On Elbow
description: As soon as the Mets are eliminated from the playoff race, catcher Todd Hundley will head to Birmingham, Ala., to be examined by Dr. James Andrews for his right-elbow woes, a team official said today.

title: Should the Yanks Play for Position or Prepare for the Post-Season?
description: Major League Baseball is fortunate that it has managers and players whose ethics and honesty are above reproach. Otherwise, imagine the suspicion that could run rampant through Jacobs Field in Cleveland the next three nights.

title: The Land of Cowboys and Indians
description: LEGENDS OF THE AMERICAN DESERT

title: Drug Money (in Literal Sense) Is a New Legal Twist
description: ROUGHLY three-quarters of the $1 bills circulating in the Chicago suburbs, Miami and Houston are tainted with cocaine, the Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois has determined. But despite assertions by many defense lawyers that their clients were accidentally contaminated by cocaine-tainted money, cocaine in the bills does not normally rub off on skin, an Argonne chemist said.

title: BASEBALL: Formidable, And Forgetful; Whether at Bat, in the Field or on the Street, Cleveland's Ramirez Is on a Path of His Own
description: In one game earlier this season Manny Ramirez was thrown out trying to steal first base. The youthful Cleveland right fielder, by way of Washington Heights and George Washington High School in upper Manhattan, had stolen second base, then looked around and trotted back to first. The pitcher, blinking to make sure he was seeing correctly, tossed the ball to the second baseman, who tagged Ramirez out.

title: Fassel Sticking by Daluiso
description: Jim Fassel was resolutely trying to avoid pinning blame for the Giants' troubles on any one player today, and he extended that courtesy to Brad Daluiso, assuring the place-kicker that his job was not in jeopardy. But Fassel also pointed out that while the job is Daluiso's, the job needs to get done.

title: Bond Prices Mixed Ahead Of Auctions
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, in trading that was slightly above average for a Monday.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Friday about ''In and Out,'' starring Kevin Kline and Joan Cusack, misstated Debbie Reynolds's role. She plays the mother of the high school teacher portrayed by Kevin Kline, not the mother of his fiancee.

title: A Nazi's Trail Leads to a Gold Cache in Brazil
description: Albert Blume died 14 years ago, an outcast and a mystery to his relatives, buried in a poor man's grave. As odd as his life was his legacy -- a $4 million fortune in luxury watches, rings, gold bars and gold teeth for which an aging aunt has been battling in court since his death.

title: Observer; Ravaged by Piety
description: Washington's forces of piety want us to feel disgusted with Albert Gore. He used the office phone, it is said, to solicit campaign funds. That's against the law.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Friday about ''Webbed Feats,'' performed in Bryant Park in Manhattan on Wednesday, misidentified the producers. They were the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation and Stephan Koplowitz & Company, not Dancing in the Streets.

title: Broadway Tries Analysis And Gets Shock Therapy
description: Despite some signs of life, the New York theater industry is still in decline and beset by rising costs and lagging audiences, an unusually detailed industry-sponsored study has concluded.

title: Metrocard Transfers Are Only a First Step
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBERMAN, TILLA
description: LEIBERMAN-Tilla. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to our member Nathan Zucker on loss of his beloved sister Tilla. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Memorandum Suggests That Clinton Made $50,000 Call From the White House
description: A 1994 memorandum indicates that President Clinton made a fund-raising call to a wealthy California businessman from the White House that resulted in a $50,000 campaign contribution just two weeks later.
