title: 5 on Bankruptcy Panel Cleared in Conference-Call Case
description: Five members of the National Bankruptcy Review Commission who took part in a telephone conference call that was once thought to have possibly violated Federal rules have been cleared of any wrongdoing by the group's general counsel.

title: WALTER INDUSTRIES TO BUY APPLIED INDUSTRIAL MATERIALS
description: Walter Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Applied Industrial Materials Corporation for about $400 million. Walter Industries, a home-building concern, said both companies had approved the acquisition, which was expected to close in the current quarter, ending on Nov. 30. Applied Industrial, based in Stamford, Conn., provides products and services to the petroleum, steel, foundry and aluminum industries. The company has annual revenue of about $450 million. Walter Industries, based in Tampa, Fla., had revenue of $1.5 billion for the year that ended on May 31. Walter's shares rose 56.25 cents each yesterday, to $20.625.

title: Market Place: Quality Service, With Wings; Midwest Express Profits By Pampering Passengers
description: Susan Dietman of Plano, Tex., has been flying Midwest Express between Dallas and Milwaukee almost every weekend for four years. Asked why she was so loyal, she ticked off some familiar reasons: adequate leg room, good food, nonstop flights and attentive service. Then she added a new one:

title: Columbia's Ties to Doctors To Be Severed
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation will end its partnerships between doctors and hospitals at a cost of $200 million to $300 million over one or two years, the company's chairman and chief executive, Thomas Frist, said today.

title: College Admissions Test Isn't Culturally Biased
description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T Offers Buyouts to 3,000 Employees
description: The AT&T Corporation has offered 3,000 nonmanagement employees voluntary severance packages in the company's latest attempt to cut its payroll.

title: Metro Business; Time Warner Settlement
description: Time Warner Cable has agreed to pay at least $1.5 million to settle a class-action lawsuit accusing the company of stealing electricity from thousands of Manhattan buildings that were connected to the company's cable television service.

title: REXEL AGREES TO BUY 2 ELECTRICAL PARTS DISTRIBUTORS
description: Rexel Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire two closely held electrical parts distributors for about $40 million. Rexel, also an electrical supplies distributor, said it agreed to buy Pacific Electrical Supply Inc. and Taylor Electric Supply Inc. The company also said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Utility Products Division to closely held Cummins Holdings Inc. for about $30 million. Utility Products had 1996 sales of about $107 million. All three transactions are expected to close in the next six weeks. Rexel, which is based in Coral Gables, Fla., had 1996 sales of $1.16 billion.

title: Fie! Enough Mud Slung At Bob and the C.I.A.!
description: Let's hear it for Bob. For weeks, now, the Senate hearings on campaign finance abuses have flirted with the cat's-paw workings of the Central Intelligence Agency and the role of an agency worker who somehow got caught up in the application of political muscle at the White House in behalf of the relentless oil pipeline promoter Roger E. Tamraz.

title: Kennedy Filibuster Is Final Hurdle for Measure to Speed the Review of Medicines
description: After months of negotiations, much compromise and a fresh round of parliamentary arm-twisting, a bill to speed Government review for many medical devices and drugs is expected to come to a vote on the Senate floor this week.

title: De Klerk's Party Ends Suit Against South Africa's Truth Panel
description: Apparently satisfied by apologies from the two leaders of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission for their criticism of former President F. W. de Klerk, the National Party today dropped its lawsuit against the commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, JULIUS (BIG JULIE)
description: WEINTRAUB-Julius (Big Julie). On September 21, 1997. Devoted father of Rebecca and son-in-law Joseph Matura, Captain Marc Weintraub, Paul, Lois and the late Russ. Loving brother of Yetta, Marilyn and the late Charles. Cherished grandfather of Logan Rose (Queenie), Sharisse, Wes and Elena. Services Wednesday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARLES, RICHARD LINCOLN
description: CHARLES-Richard Lincoln. The Actors' Fund of America mourns the loss of its beloved Trustee, Richard Lincoln Charles. Chair of The Fund's Nursing Home and Assisted Living Facility Committee, he was also admired for his leadership of The Lambs Club and Foundation, where he served as Shepherd. He led by example and will be remembered with love, respect and admiration. Tom Dillon, President Joseph P. Benincasa, Executive Director

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Turns Energy Against Pacts On Free Trade
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s convention turned into a protest rally today against President Clinton's plans to negotiate new free-trade treaties as labor leaders gave repeated standing ovations to Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, who is Congress's chief opponent of the trade proposal.

title: CALENDAR
description: Licensed to Cook

title: Wine Talk; In the Ratings Game, 1995 Graduates With Honors
description: THE 1995 ratings in the latest wine vintage chart of The New York Times recall those little pocket charts one used to find in French restaurants: the wines were all French, and the ratings began with ''excellent'' and went up from there.

title: INSIDE
description: Ties, and Knots, With Japan

title: AIDS Studies Violate Helsinki Rights Accord; Women at Greatest Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefs; Renewing the Old Hotel
description: The Hotel Iroquois, a budget hotel in midtown Manhattan that is best known as the former home of James Dean, is getting a facelift, hotel officials announced yesterday.

title: Chancellor Agrees to Let Teacher Return in Dispute
description: Under pressure from a state judge, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew agreed yesterday to allow a teacher whose job was in jeopardy to return to a Greenwich Village classroom temporarily, giving at least a brief victory to parents who had raised tens of thousands of dollars in recent days to pay the teacher's salary.

title: End for Team's Dream And Hundley's Season
description: Todd Hundley's season ended the night that the Mets were eliminated from post-season contention.

title: The Return of Thalidomide
description: The Food and Drug Administration's impending approval of thalidomide for use by leprosy patients raises fears that this infamous drug will create a new generation of babies born without limbs or eyes as a result of their mothers having taken thalidomide during pregnancy. The decision to approve the drug is a difficult one, since making it available to even a limited group carries with it the danger that some patient who is taking thalidomide will become pregnant and bear a child with severe birth defects.

title: Bits and Bytes
description: Going on the Hunt With a Chowhound

title: With Timber Scarce, Old Logs Deep in a Lake Become a Sunken Treasure
description: Russet sunlight skips across Lake Superior, the last waltz of a fading summer, as a scuba diver 30 feet below the surface swims toward a pile of ancient oak logs. They are sunken remnants of the virgin forest, felled in a boom-time fury, then lost and forgotten for a century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, BETTY
description: SCHULMAN-Betty, of North Miami Beach, FL., on September 22, 1997. Beloved wife of Richard. Adored mother of Donald, Kenneth and Debbie. Loving mother in-law of Ellen, Sharon and Andy. Devoted grandmother of Rachel, Matthew, Lindsay, Jason, Gregory and Jessica. Funeral services at Gutterman's Funeral Parlor, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, today at 11 A.M.

title: Washington Journal; Stores Invite Police To Stop By
description: Surafel Worku's 7-Eleven has not been robbed in the last year.

title: Twist in Case of Missing Restaurateur
description: Law enforcement officials investigating the disappearance of Nelson G. Gross, a New Jersey developer and restaurateur, said tonight that they had found inconsistencies in an account of the day he vanished that was provided by his son, Neil, and that the son had failed a lie detector test over the weekend.

title: AIDS Studies Violate Helsinki Rights Accord; Similar to Tuskegee
description: To the Editor:

title: Residents Can Opt For Hospice Treatment
description: Connecticut is planning to offer residents the chance to state the type of treatment they would want if they became terminally ill.

title: Endgame: It's All Work Now for Deep Blue, Chess Champ
description: Deep Blue, the chess-playing I.B.M. computer that emerged as the world's first artificially intelligent media celebrity earlier this year in defeating Garry Kasparov, the world champion, has landed a day job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELS, ARTHUR N. (ARTY)
description: WELS-Arthur N. (Arty). Beloved husband of the late Midge. Devoted father of Lorin and Susan, Robert and Linda. Cherished and loving grandfather of Steven, David, Sandy and Jonathan. Funeral services today 1 P.M. at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Campus Journal; Final Volume of Study Documents a Central Role for Black Colleges
description: The number of black students taking the Scholastic Assessment Test increased by nearly a third from 1980 to 1996, according to the third and final reference book in a series of three devoted to African-Americans and their educational experiences. And, in a development that suggests the importance of historically black colleges and universities, most black students asked that their test scores be sent to those institutions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMETI, VINCENT
description: SIMETI-Vincent. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Monte). Father of Frances Sinon and Lucille King. Father-in-law of Martin and James. Survived by twelve grandchildren, 14 great-grandchildren, seventeen sisters, brothers and inlaws, 4th Degree Member Knights of Columbus. Retired from New York Daily News and The New York Times. Reposing at the James Romanelli-Stephen Funeral Home, 89-01 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park, NY until Friday 9:30AM. Mass of the Resurrection at St. Brendan's R.C. Church, Bronx, New York, at 10:30 A.M., on Friday, September 26, 1997. Entombment at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx, New York. Chapel hours 2-5 PM, 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPANELLI, MARY
description: CAMPANELLI-Mary. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Mary Campanelli, associated with The Times from 1918, until retiring in 1971.

title: Cheap Food Is Costly
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebels Gear Up for Colorado Primary
description: In the two years since he left the Democratic Party, Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell has embodied the very image that Republican leaders want to project for their party: contemporary, ethnically diverse and blue collar. Last year, party leaders showcased their ponytailed convert, as he donned leathers, mounted his Harley and kicked off the Republican National Convention with a roaring motorcycle rally.

title: Student Wins Suit Accusing A Professor Of Plagiarism
description: Ruling that a professor at the University of Ottawa had plagiarized an M.B.A. student's paper, an Ontario court has ordered the university and the professor to pay the former student $7,500 in damages and to reimburse legal costs.

title: City Opera Sets Strike Deadline
description: The American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents the singers, chorus, dancers, directors and stage managers of the New York City Opera, has announced that it will go on strike if an agreement has not been reached with the company by midnight Monday.

title: Temptation; A Potato Chip That Flirts With Perfection
description: SALTY? Yes. Greasy? Just a touch. What's a good potato chip without these devilish attributes? But there has to be more to surpass mere acceptable snackability. The ultimate chip must also taste cleanly of potato and be parchment thin and exquisitely crisp. Voila -- Eli's Potato Chips from the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street.

title: Scientists Ease Up On Fear Of Eggs
description: WHEN it comes to eggs, few medical experts are neutral. Either they want to see the entire population, young, old, women, children, those with low cholesterol levels and those with high cholesterol levels, assiduously restricting egg consumption. Or they dismiss the anti-egg movement as so much dogmatism by heart disease fanatics.

title: DANA WILL DISMISS 1,100 EMPLOYEES
description: The Dana Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss 1,100 workers, or about 41 percent of the work force, at its vehicle frame factories in Pennsylvania by June 1998 to cut costs and that it would take a $22 million charge for severance expenses. The auto parts maker, which is based in Toledo, Ohio, said the charge would be offset by a gain of $70 million from the sale of a transmission division to a Mexican affiliate. The cutbacks at the plants at Reading, Pa., which make vehicle frames, reflect pressure on automotive suppliers to cut costs. Dana employs 2,700 at the Reading plants. It will dismiss 325 employees by year's end, in addition to 275 cuts it announced in January but had not made yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, MAURICE M.
description: McDERMOTT-Maurice M. The members of the Seymour Association extend our deepest sympathy to Claire, Chris and Glen McDermott. For seven years, Mac served ably and skillfully as an Assistant U.S. Attorney. He was a trusted and wise Assistant Chief of the Criminal Divison. We miss him and honor his memory. Seymour Association

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Metro Business Briefs; HMV Records Plans Store in Harlem USA
description: HMV Records has signed a 10-year lease to open a music store at Harlem USA, an entertainment and retail complex being developed at 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Manhattan, city and state officials announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RYLE, JOSEPH D.
description: RYLE-Joseph D. Memorial Service on Friday, September 26, at 10:30 A.M., in Lady Chapel, St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Double Surprise In a Maverick Piano Contest; Out-and-Out Grant to a Star
description: Say this for the piano news out of Kalamazoo, Mich.: It is never dull. When the Irving S. Gilmore International Keyboard Festival named the recipient of the 1998 Gilmore Artist Award yesterday, it overthrew most of the assumptions piano mavens had carefully puzzled out on the basis of the two quirky prior awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, JANET IASON
description: STONE-Janet Iason. September 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late J. Jacques Stone. Her vibrant intellect, remarkable spirit and devotion to those she loved will always be remembered by her children Carol and Alan Pomerantz, and Toni and Freeman Shore, her grandchildren Michael Romano and Julie and Peter Strauss, and her brother Jerry Iason. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Stone Family Fund, 22 E. 40th St, NY, NY 10016.

title: For Haitians, Leadership Split Is a Generation Gap
description: Before last month's march to City Hall to protest the alleged police beating of Abner Louima, Tatiana Wah made a small but significant request.

title: Columbia/HCA Unit Gets Offers
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation is receiving offers for its Value Health Inc. units well within expectations, the company's chairman and chief executive, Thomas F. Frist Jr., said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, IRA M.
description: HECHT-Ira M. Life partner for 16 years to James Esposito. Son of David Hecht and the late Donna Belonte-Hecht. Brother of Victor Hecht. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services are on Wednesday, 1:30 P.M. precisely, Goldsteins' Rosenberg's RaphaelSacks, 6410 North Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19126. Interment in Lawnview Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Gay Mens Health Crisis Center of New York City.

title: F.C.C. Is Urged to Keep Close Eye on Cable Rates
description: Cable television rates are once again spiraling upward. But rather than accuse the cable companies of price gouging, two consumer groups blamed the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, saying that it failed to keep a rein on the newly aggressive cable industry.

title: Kiwi Announces New Routes
description: Kiwi International Air Lines announced a series of new routes yesterday, the first expansion of service since the troubled air carrier was saved from bankruptcy in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINE, ARNOLD J.
description: SCHEINE-Arnold J. On behalf of the Board of Directors and Officers of LCS Industries, Inc., we note with deep sorrow and great sadness the passing of our founder, Chairman and President, and the loss of a friend. Arnie Scheine was an individual of great strength and foresight, who built our company, inspired us and endeared himself to everyone. He will be immensely missed. To his wife, Helene; his sons, Jeff, Greg and Steven, their wives, his grandchildren and relatives, go our profound condolences. William Rella, President

title: Topics of The Times; Croatia Bullies A Critic
description: On the Croatian Government's list of its most bothersome citizens, Ivan Zvonimir Cicak ranks very high. Mr. Cicak, president of Croatia's Helsinki Committee for Human Rights, is the country's leading human rights advocate. Because Croatia's authoritarian President, Franjo Tudjman, has corrupted or intimidated much of his political opposition, Mr. Cicak's courage in criticizing government abuses is particularly important. So it is disturbing that prosecutors are now investigating Mr. Cicak on charges that he made false statements.

title: Hicks, Muse to Seek Investments in Food
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. said today that it had committed $500 million to $700 million of equity capital to companies that produce food and other branded consumer products in North America and Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURINGAN, JEAN, M.D.
description: TURINGAN-Jean, M.D. It is with profound sorrow and a deep sense of regret that we, the Board of Trustees, the Medical Staff and the entire Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center family mourn the passing of Dr. Jean Turingan, Deputy Director for Quality Assurance and Residency Training and an attending physician in our Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Dr. Turingan was also Clinical Assistant Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. She was a compassionate, caring and dedicated physician at Bronx Lebanon for more than twenty years. Her sudden passing is certainly a great loss to us. We extend our sincere condolences to her family. Miguel Martinez, Chairman, Board of Trustees Miguel A. Fuentes, Jr., President and Chief Exec Officer Milton Gumbs, MD, Vice President, Medical Affairs/Medical Director

title: What's in a Name? Testing a Bar for 'Greatness'
description: WHAT makes a bar great?

title: Diplomacy, Gore-Style, Is a Study In 'Process'
description: After days of closed talks about the obstacles facing American oil companies in Russia, Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin announced a decision: They agreed to work on the problems over the next two months.

title: Campus Journal; Marlboro College Seeking More Welcoming Campus
description: Since 1946, when Marlboro College was founded by World War II veterans on the G.I. Bill, important decisions about changes at the school or how to spend its money have always been made at campuswide meetings. In the past, students and faculty have voted on things like designating smoking areas and deciding not to change the clocks to daylight savings time. But few issues have been as important as the one that will soon come up for vote: how to redesign the campus to give it a sense of place.

title: Lewis's Injury Causes More Scrambling
description: Battered by three successive defeats and bruised by the news that Thomas Lewis, a starting wide receiver, will be out two to three weeks because of a sprained left big toe, the Giants have restructured the contracts of two players to create salary cap room should they decide to acquire a replacement for Lewis or additional help on the offensive line.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDLEY, SOL J.
description: EDLEY-Sol J. Sept 24, 1990. Dear Sol, forever on our minds and in our hearts. We love you and miss you very much. Your children, grandchildren, son-in-law Joe and always your Pearl.

title: From Chairman of House Inquiry, No Apologies for Aggressive Style
description: Representative Dan Burton is a take-no-prisoners politician of the right, unbowed by his critics and proud of his combativeness.

title: Texas Deal by Merry Land
description: The Merry Land and Investment Company said today that it had acquired three apartment communities in the Dallas-Fort Worth area for $68.5 million. The company, a real estate investment trust based here in Augusta, said that it had financed the purchase by using its $200 million syndicated revolving credit facility. Merry Land said that the apartment communities -- Riverhill, Wimberly and Hidden Lakes -- had a total of 1,018 units and that 91 percent of the units were currently occupied.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Business Travel; American and Delta join United in cutting travel agent commissions. Should consumers care?
description: COMMISSIONS to travel agents were lowered yesterday by American Airlines and Delta Air Lines, following the lead of United Airlines, which cut them last Friday. Because the Big Three carriers command about 60 percent of domestic market share, there appears little chance that the commission cuts will be reversed, at least voluntarily.

title: Remarks Send Dollar Lower Against Yen
description: The dollar plunged against the yen today after remarks by a key Japanese Finance Ministry official that the Group of Seven accord over the weekend would send a strong message to markets.

title: A Star Is Licensed; With 'Arthur,' Public TV Stretches Commercial Limits
description: Move over, Barney and Big Bird. Arthur has arrived.

title: The Pop Life; Buildup Begins For Star Wars
description: At a party celebrating Janet Jackson's new album in the penthouse of the Chrysler Building this month, the narrow doorways were so dense with people trying to come and go that hardly anyone could move. At one point, trapped in a 20-by-20-foot corridor, were Puffy Combs, Billy Corgan, Marilyn Manson, Naomi Campbell and several members of the Wu-Tang Clan, all pressed cheek to cheek and exasperated. Meanwhile, in a room off to the side guarded by bowler-topped bodyguards, Ms. Jackson, standing next to Lisa-Marie Presley, was inviting in celebrities one by one to have her photograph taken with them. ''I feel so used,'' said one musician upon leaving the room. ''I think the whole purpose of this party is so Janet Jackson can have her picture taken with us.''

title: Gooden Nominates Wells to Be Third Post-Season Starter
description: Dwight Gooden is supposedly alive in his quest to be the third starter for the Yankees in the American League division series. Joe Torre said today that he has not decided whether David Wells or Gooden will start Game 3, so Gooden still has a chance. Or does he? Gooden does not believe it.

title: Restaurants; Cleverly Combining Flavors Borrowed From All Across Asia
description: THE people at the corner table are having a wonderful time. As they laugh and slap each other's palms, the sound of their revelry ricochets around the room. The cacophony grows; the din is incredible. Suddenly someone says, ''Shh,'' loudly, as if this were a theater. Another table picks it up, then another and another, a chorus of reproof. The noise subsides abruptly, and Match Uptown grows eerily and wonderfully silent. The people at the corner table look abashed; folding their hands in their laps, they begin to whisper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSON, MORRIS
description: LIPSON-Morris. Beloved and devoted husband of Dorothy. Cherished father of Michael, Pauline Tamari and Roberta Lipson-Plafker. Loving grandfather of Ari, Rachel, Raphael, Jeremy, Jennie, Dorothy, Judy-Ann, Jonathan, Daniel and Benjamin. An ardent supporter of the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, JARC, Israel Bonds and ADL. Services today at 10:30 A.M.,. at GuttermanWarheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, Florida 1-800-992-9262.

title: $25 and Under; In Greenwich Village, A Trattoria Gives It a Try
description: GRANO is an instantly likable yet maddening trattoria that opened about two months ago on a Greenwich Village corner, where the restaurants seem to come and go every year or so.

title: Smith Barney Agrees to Settle Bond Charges for $2 Million
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that Smith Barney Inc., the securities brokerage firm and investment bank, had agreed to pay $2 million to settle charges that it failed to supervise a former employee in the underwriting of a municipal bond issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEETON, KATHY
description: KEETON-Kathy. Elegant friendyou gave it your all. I'll miss your brilliant light and just you. Heartfelt sympathy to the family. Elaine Taylor-Gordon

title: TV Notes; Fox Quits Time Slot
description: The Fox network has thrown in the towel at 9 o'clock on weekday mornings, canceling ''The Vicki Lawrence Show'' after five weeks and telling its affiliated stations they must fill that hour with their own programs, starting on Oct. 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCK, LEONARD PLAUT
description: STOCK-Leonard Plaut. Of Pompano Beach, Florida on September 22nd. Beloved husband of Ruth (Gunzburger). Loving father of Ellen, John and his wife Janet. Devoted grandfather of Alissa and Debbie. Visiting hours at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street on Wednesday, September 24th 5:30PM to 7:30PM. Graveside service Thursday September 25th 11AM at Union Fields Cemetery, Cypress Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANIGAN, JANET
description: LANIGAN-Janet. The Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing Alumni Association expresses deep sympathy to the family, friends, colleagues and patients of our beloved and dedicated past President.

title: CRACKEN HARKEY IS BUYING EL CHICO RESTAURANTS
description: El Chico Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired for about $65 million by Cracken Harkey & Company, an investment concern, and the restaurateurs E. Gene Street and Clyde E. Culp 3d. The company said Cracken Harkey, Mr. Street and Mr. Culp would pay El Chico's shareholders $12.75 a share. El Chico, a Dallas-based Mexican restaurant owner, had 1996 revenues of $104.4 million. Shares of El Chico closed at $11.50, up $1 each.

title: McGreevey Takes On Whitman's Good-Times Theme
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey unveiled his first television advertisement today with what his strategists say will be his message over the next six weeks: the state's economy might be getting stronger, but New Jersey voters still pay some of the highest auto insurance rates and property taxes in the nation.

title: Critic's Notebook; Attuning Classical Music to the Eye as Well as the Ear
description: Classical musicians and the impresarios who sponsor their concerts have been thinking a lot lately about how performances look, and about what can be done to drag classical concerts toward the 21st century. Music, they argue, may be the principal attraction and main event of the concert experience, but why not engage the eye as well as the ear? Why maintain a tradition of unadorned stages, formal dress and unvaried white lighting at a time when the young audiences that musicians hope to attract regard that presentation style as uninvitingly dull, and assume that the music is as well?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, MARK JEFFERSON (JEFF)
description: GILBERT-Mark Jefferson (Jeff). Age 28. Died suddenly Saturday in an auto/pedestrian accident in New York, NY. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, in Abilene, TX, Elliott-Hamil Funeral Home, 542 Hickory Street. Jeff was currently employed by Sullivan & Cromwell of New York, NY, and prior to that, by Plenum Publishing, Inc. and HBO, Inc., both of New York, NY. Memorials may be sent to Compassion International, 3955 Cragwood Dr, Colorado Springs, CO 80918. Condolences may be sent to the family at 808 Westwood Drive, Abilene, TX 79603. Jeff had many friends and associates whose thoughts and prayers are greatly appreciated.

title: SECURITY AIDE SEES PRESENCE IN BOSNIA BEYOND DEADLINE
description: President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said today that the United States and its European allies must be prepared for an extended stay in Bosnia beyond the scheduled withdrawal of NATO forces next June.

title: Guinness Profit Climbed 4% in First Half
description: Guinness P.L.C. said yesterday that its first-half profit rose 4 percent on higher sales of liquor and beer even though the strength of the British pound sliced $:12 million pounds ($19.2 million) from earnings. In its last interim earnings report before it is scheduled to merge with Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., Guinness said its half-year profit rose to $:255 million ($410 million), from $:245 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the American Home Products Corporation's problems with two diet drugs misidentified the one that the company warned last winter was approved only for short-term use. It was Pondimin. Redux was approved for longer-term use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAINA, NICHOLAS JOHN
description: TRAINA-Nicholas John Steel-in San Francisco, September 20, 1997, after a longtime struggle with a lifetime illness and valiant fight to the end, of an accidental overdose. Son of Danielle Steel Traina and John A Traina, Jr., of San Francisco. Nicholas was 19 years old (1 May 1978). He graduated from Town School and the Woodside International School and for the past 2-1/2 years was the lead singer, lyricist and manager of the rock band, Link 80, which had gained considerable acclaim nationally and internationally, mostly among teenagers. His C.D.'s and videos were being distributed internationally. A month ago he started a new band of his own, ''Knowledge''. Nick Traina was the bright star of his family and will be greatly missed by all. He is survived by his parents and his eight siblings: Samantha, Victoria, Vanessa, Maxx, Zara, Trevor and Todd Traina and Beatrix Seidenberg. Friends are invited for Visitation, Tuesday, September 23rd from 5-8 pm at HALSTED N. GRAY-CAREW & ENGLISH, 1123 Sutter St., San Francisco, and to attend the Funeral Service on Wednesday, September 24th at 3:30 pm at Grace Cathedral Episcopal Church, 1100 California St., San Francisco, CA. Interment private. Flowers or charity of your choice.

title: Already One of the Best, Richter Gets Better Still
description: Ten hockey seasons ago, when goalie Mike Richter first played in the Saddledome, he was a 21-year-old member of the United States Olympic team, wearing the red, white and blue colors he would later wear as a professional with the Rangers.

title: Anger Flares as Focus Shifts to Campaign Remedies
description: The Senate's campaign finance inquiry changed course today, turning from an investigation of political fund-raising abuses to an examination of potential remedies, but the partisan rancor that has characterized the hearings since they began in July did not abate.

title: Fables or Not, Marco Polo's Legacy Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, NAOMI
description: NEWMAN-Naomi. On September 23, 1997 in Kingston, NY after a long battle with leukemia. She is survived by her devoted daughter Darya Panesoff and will be deeply missed by her many friends. Services will be held September 25 at 2 P.M., at The Woodstock Jewish Congregation.

title: Israel Identifies Four Suicide Bombers as West Bank Palestinians
description: The Israeli Government said today that four of the five suicide bombers who struck in Jerusalem this summer were Palestinians from the West Bank. The identity of the fifth was not announced, but he was also believed to be a West Bank Palestinian.

title: ROUNDUP
description: Grand slam cup

title: How Honesty Can Lead Police Astray
description: There are parts of the world where the subject of police corruption allows no margin for merriment. But leave it to the French to understand that in an imperfect world, police corruption is simply a subdivision of fallible humanity and that the devil you know is sometimes preferable to the devil you don't.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 17 about Judith Merril, a science fiction writer and anthologist, misspelled the given name of her former husband. He is Frederik Pohl, not Frederick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, JULES L.
description: GREEN-Jules L., 84, of New York City, died on September 15, 1997. Beloved husband of late Nancy W. (Stern) Green for 33 years. Mr Green began his career as a film booker in his native Pittsburgh. Later, he arrived in Los Angeles where he worked as Bob Hope's agent before becoming Steve Allen's personal manager and developing NBC's first Tonight Show for which he also served as Executive Producer. In the late 50's he brought Mr. Allen to prime time, serving as Executive Producer of the Steve Allen Show, the only show to rival Ed Sullivan for supremacy on Sunday night. In the later years, Mr. Green developed independent theatrical properties as well as working for N.W. Ayer Advertising as Executive Producer of the Emmy Award winning Bell System Family Theater where he introduced Vladimir Horowitz and Jascha Heifetz on their own television specials. He is survived by a son, Steven Green and two stepchildren, Tony Stern and Susan Cookson, nine grandchildren: Todd and Jason Green; Joshua, Eric, Hilary and Jeremy Stern; Sasha Wilson and Aram Cookson. Two nieces: Herchelle Miller Siegel and Roslyn Miller Seltzer as well as many grand and great grandnieces and nephews. I will always love and miss you. With you a chapter has unfortunately closed in my life. Stephen Miller Siegel

title: Sports of The Times; Barry Bonds: Too Little, Too Late?
description: BARRY BONDS, the player who pales in the wake of his own greatness, knows what will come of the wonderful week in which he just reasserted his presence.

title: Serpico Steps Out of the Shadows to Testify
description: A quarter of a century has passed, a full lifetime for some in the rougher precincts of the city, and still Frank Serpico is treated by New York police officers like an excommunicate knocking at the church door. Not that he would want it any other way, he says.

title: About New York; Raffle Plan For Yankees Thrown Out
description: PLAYOFF tickets went on sale at Yankee Stadium yesterday, and fans braved the presumed horrors of the South Bronx (or the Major Deegan Expressway) for the chance to snag some ducats. It was all about luck, since everybody received randomly numbered bracelets that determined who got a chance to spend some money.

title: Musical Tribute to Diana Sells Briskly in U.S. Debut
description: It took all kinds, and they took all the copies they could grab. British tourists on holiday, compulsive buyers adding to their collections, men sheepishly buying for their wives and men weepily getting copies for themselves. The Elton John song memorializing Diana, Princess of Wales, went on sale nationwide yesterday and moved briskly, with some stores in New York selling out within hours.

title: Messinger Says Giuliani Ad Falsifies Position She Took
description: Ruth W. Messinger called on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday to withdraw a television advertisement that accuses her of opposing restrictions on sex businesses in New York neighborhoods, charging that Mr. Giuliani had distorted her position and falsely quoted her as saying that such businesses gave ''New York character.''

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS TO CLOSE POULTRY EXPORT UNIT
description: The International Multifoods Corporation said yesterday that it would close its poultry-exporting business because the unit's costs far exceeded its contribution to earnings. The specialty-food company said the unit had operating profit in its 1997 fiscal year of $5.7 million, or 14 percent of the company's total. International Multifoods said shedding the business, which exported poultry to a distributor in Russia, would reduce earnings. The company also said it was in talks with potential buyers for its Canadian frozen baked-goods business, which the Minneapolis-based company expects to sell by February. Shares of International Multifoods rose $1.375 yesterday, to $28.4375.

title: On U.S. Team, Woods Is Just One of the Guys
description: He is the leading money-winner on the PGA Tour, the youngest player in the Ryder Cup, and a focal point of any event he enters.

title: 20th Century Fox Is Added to Gravano Suit
description: New York State officials, who are suing the mob informer Salvatore Gravano to prevent him from profiting from a book about his Mafia days, added Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation to the lawsuit yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, THOMAS G.
description: SHEA-Thomas G. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Thomas G. Shea, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Victor D. Ziminsky, Jr., President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Questionable Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Ripken's Will Is Still Iron, but Not His Body
description: Cal Ripken hits a pop-up, tosses his bat aside in disgust and moves stiffly toward first base. His back hurts. His batting average is plummeting. When he is playing the infield, ground balls that Orioles fans have seen him reach every day for more than 15 years are rolling past his outstretched glove.

title: Stretching Limits, and Ears and Noses
description: Like a spicy condiment, the irreverent, uninhibited animation of Bill Plympton is probably best sampled in small doses. But in ''Mondo Plympton,'' the prize-winning filmmaker has assembled an 80-minute walk through his wild side, mixing bits of autobiography with bracing servings of his sometimes surreal cartoons.

title: N.Y.U. Center And Mt. Sinai Resume Talks
description: Officials at Mount Sinai Medical Center and New York University Medical Center, who abandoned a much anticipated merger early this year, are back at the negotiating table, and senior staff members at both hospitals said they were told to expect an imminent announcement about a partnership between the two institutions.

title: Lawsuit Charges Racial Bias
description: It started as a routine shopping trip to Bloomingdale's at Riverside Square in Hackensack. But the outing in February turned into an ordeal when Lloyd Morrison, a financial analyst from Teaneck, N.J., and his 6-year-old son, Lloyd Jr., were strip-searched to determine if they had shoplifted a boy's suit, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Witness Says He Warned Man Who Was Slain Over Parking
description: The manager of a pizza store testified today that he warned a customer who was shot moments later that the owner of a nearby delicatessen was often angered by drivers who parked in front of his deli but did not shop there.

title: A Seedy World You Want to Flee
description: Hollywood has so successfully conditioned us to expect grandly choreographed flourishes whenever guns are drawn that the limp, haphazard shots fired in Jeremy Horton's terminally glum, no-budget film ''100 Proof'' will disappoint anyone hoping for the visceral charge of a full-scale shootout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, MICHAEL
description: KIMMEL-Michael. On Sept 22, 1997, at home. Beloved husband of Karen, nee Krause, adored son of Sylvia, and loving brother of Bruce and Robert. The celebration of his life is to be held on Thursday, Sept. 25th, at 11 A.M. at his home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHS, SADIE
description: WACHS-Sadie. Beloved wife of the late Julius; loving mother of Linda and Albert Cassuto, Martin and Annette Wachs, Robert and the late Michael. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother; sister of Minnie Sherman and Nathan Schwartz.

title: For Panthers, a Cure For Racial Strife: Win
description: The year was 1989, and a group of Buffalo Bills players were in a bar having a few beers. One of the starting offensive players approached a woman and began to talk to her. The player, who was white, was apparently rebuffed by the woman, who was black. He became angry and used a racially disparaging remark in reference to the woman.

title: House Seeks Leverage for Favored Items
description: Adding another complication to President Clinton's drive to win authority to negotiate new trade accords, the House majority leader suggested today that Republicans would link the trade proposal to action on two of their initiatives that the Administration has threatened to veto.

title: Democrats' Chances Rated
description: The Democrats have a good chance of gaining control of the State Senate for the first time since 1991, State Senator John A. Lynch, the minority leader, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, JACK
description: ROSEMAN-Jack. Young Israel of Flatbush mourns the loss of its member. Devoted husband of Betty, father of Surella Feit, Rena Reinhard and Chani Lichtiger. Rabbi Kenneth Auman Sheldon David, President

title: What Victims Seek
description: To the Editor:

title: A Philosophical Eye on Big Prizes
description: After trying to revive play writing with prize money, the Alexander S. Onassis Foundation may select dance, music, sculpture or philosophy as the next discipline to benefit from its largess.

title: Risking China's Wrath, U.S. and Japan Bolster Military Ties
description: The United States and Japan agreed yesterday to strengthen their military relationship despite warnings from China that the stronger alliance was a provocation that would threaten peace and stability throughout Asia.

title: An industry women's group passes judgment with the Good, the Bad and the Ugly Awards.
description: THE vexing issue of how to portray women in advertising has been debated by everyone from politicians to semioticians. Now joining in -- with awards meant to punish as well as reward -- are women in advertising themselves.

title: Liberties; The Devil in Prime Time
description: My mother watched the premiere of ''Nothing Sacred,'' a critically blessed new drama on ABC about a hip, glib, cute young priest struggling with temptations of the flesh.

title: BELLSOUTH TO BUY BACK UP TO $1 BILLION IN STOCK
description: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $1 billion in stock by the end of 1998. BellSouth's repurchase will involve about 21.2 million shares, or 2 percent, of its 992 million shares outstanding. The stock is the second most widely held in the United States, behind that of the AT&T Corporation. BellSouth shares rose 3.125 cents, to $47.5625, after touching a record $49 earlier.

title: Disappointing Auction Trims Bond Prices
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped moderately yesterday, after a disappointing Government auction of new two-year notes.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of The Arts on Sept. 17 about the Booker Prize, awarded annually in Britain to an author, misstated the nationality of one finalist. Jim Crace is British, not American. Only citizens of the Commonwealth are eligible for the prize.

title: BASEBALL: Mets' Drama Ends and Yanks' Rehearsals Continue; In a Preview, Indians Take Center Stage
description: If Cleveland's epic comeback from a seven-run deficit to a 10-9 triumph over the Yankees tonight was a dress rehearsal for the division series, the Indians cannot wait for the real show to begin.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Fine Imposed on Trader for Daiwa
description: A Federal Appeals court in Manhattan has upheld a judge's decision to impose a $2 million fine on Toshihide Iguchi, the convicted Daiwa Bank bond trader, in a sentence that was made contingent on Mr. Iguchi's potential for future earnings based on the notoriety of his crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ANNABELL E.
description: LEVY-Annabell E. On September 22, 1997. Formerly of Rockville Centre, beloved wife of Gerald, loving mother of Valerie, Patti, Nanette, and mother-in-law of Andrew. Service Wednesday, 11:15 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Viscount Tonypandy, 88, Ex-Speaker of Commons, Dies
description: George Thomas, a former Speaker of the House of Commons whose cry of ''Order, Order!'' in his distinctive lilting Welsh accent became a British catch phrase, died on Monday in Cardiff, the Welsh capital. Created Viscount Tonypandy when he joined the House of Lords in 1983, he was 88.

title: What Victims Seek
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PAUMARD, BRICE
description: PAUMARD-Brice. Five years have flown by. I miss you desperately every day. Spencer

title: The Chef
description: WITH the ever growing popularity of risotto in New York restaurants, many chefs -- myself included -- have put on their thinking-toques to come up with new flavor combinations and twists on the old classics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUCCIONE, KATHY KEETON
description: GUCCIONE-Kathy Keeton. How better to remember you, dearest friend, than with your own beautiful words: ''Surrounded by light/ Enfolded by love/Protected by the power of an angel who watches wherever you are./All is well with your world/Sleep in peace.'' Jackie, Arthur, Allan and Eddy

title: Attempted Murder Charge Is Added in a Beating Case
description: A charge of attempted murder was added yesterday to earlier assault charges against three white teen-agers accused of what the authorities called the racial beating of a black man in Brooklyn on Saturday morning.

title: What Victims Seek
description: To the Editor:

title: Restoring a Fragile Link to New Years' Past
description: HANA LUSTIGOVA GREENFIELD will never forget the Rosh ha-Shanah of 1945. After three years in concentration camps, she had been liberated that June from Bergen-Belsen.

title: Return of a White Marble Palace; Buildings Agency to Occupy Old Home of Stewart's and The Sun
description: Proving that anything kept around long enough will come back in fashion, the 151-year-old ''marble palace'' near City Hall that once housed the A. T. Stewart & Company dry goods emporium is about to make a comeback.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOSBERG, HOWARD
description: SLOSBERG - Howard. Beloved husband of Gloria; loving father of Mark and Lisa, Ronald and Kathy, Craig and Chris, Eric and Sarah; loving grandfather of seven; devoted brother of Alyce and Frank Juliano and Jay William and Florence Seligman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PONSFORD, ERICA (NEE NEWMARK)
description: PONSFORD-Erica (nee Newmark). On September 13, 1997 in London. Witty, loving, lifetime friend. I will miss you profoundly. My deepest sorrow and love to your beautiful son Luke. Heather Rosario-Sievert

title: Chelsea at Stanford
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Climbs Against Mark On German Economic Data
description: The dollar rose against the mark yesterday after reports of falling prices in Germany's two biggest states eased speculation that the Bundesbank, the country's central bank, might soon raise interest rates.

title: EATON TO SELL APPLIANCE CONTROL BUSINESS
description: The Eaton Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its appliance controls business to Siebe P.L.C., a British electronics company, for $310 million. Eaton said the subsidiary, with 1996 sales of $440 million, makes electronic and mechanical parts for household appliance manufacturers. The business has 4,800 employees in 17 operations worldwide. Eaton said the sale would not affect its automotive controls business, which serves the vehicle-parts market. Eaton, based in Cleveland, had sales of $7 billion in 1996. Its shares fell 9.375 cents yesterday, to $93.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Siebe had sales of $4.8 billion in its most recent fiscal year.

title: Wall St. Giant Reports Net Soared 51%
description: Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter net income rose 51 percent, led by record profits in its securities and asset management businesses.

title: Giants Hope To Get Offense and Defense Clicking Together
description: Not since opening day have the Giants been able to put together a complete game. One week the offense performs well while the defense flounders. The next week brings the opposite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLTMAN, EVELYN O.
description: COLTMAN-Evelyn O. Of Brooklyn and Greenwood Lake, NY. Beloved wife of the late Louis R. Coltman. Devoted mother of Barnet and Ellen Coltman, Henrietta and Stephen Feldman. Adored grandmother of Eve and Jeffrey Greenstein, Brett and Robert Coltman, Randi and Steven Newman, Allison Feldman, and Gary Auerbach. Cherished great-grandmother of Ryan Lewis and Michael Ross Greenstein. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:00 noon, today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOTTEL, BERTHA
description: MOTTEL-Bertha. Seven years. We still talk, laugh and think about you. Love, Geri.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, JULIUS
description: WEINTRAUB-Julius. The Town Club announces with profound sorrow the death of our esteemed member. Irving Friedman, Chairman of the Board Larry Korman, President

title: ATKINSON MULLING POSSIBLE SALE OR MERGER
description: The Guy F. Atkinson Company of California said yesterday that it had hired the New York investment bank Salomon Brothers Inc. to advise it on strategic and financial alternatives, including the possible sale, merger or recapitalization of the company. Atkinson, based in San Bruno, Calif., said it was engaged in discussions with potential merger partners. It gave no further details. In August, Atkinson, which provides construction services, filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11. Since then, Atkinson has said that the bankruptcy court authorized the use of about $11.8 million of cash collateral, and its surety companies provided a $60 million revolving line of credit. Both arrangements will remain in effect through Oct. 31.

title: TV Notes; Spike Lee on Hold
description: A year ago, when Jamie Tarses had just taken over as president of ABC's entertainment division, she announced she had signed a deal for a new comedy, to be written, produced and directed by Spike Lee, with a six-episode commitment for this fall.

title: Market Place; Salomon Soars On Speculation Of a Takeover By Travelers
description: On an otherwise quiet day for financial stocks, Salomon Inc.'s shares surged 6.6 percent yesterday on seven times their average daily volume in recent months.

title: Health Care Behind Bars
description: To the Editor:

title: Disaster Relief for County
description: Atlantic County, where residents are still trying to recover from last month's severe flooding, was declared eligible for Federal disaster relief yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, IRWIN
description: ROSS-Irwin. On September 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Marian, devoted father of Amy Siegel and Aileen Lerner and sons-in-law Fred Siegel and Harvey Lerner. Cherished grandfather of Zachary, Margot, Jeremy and Jordan. Memorial service Thursday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Louima, on Critical List, Has Blood Clot
description: Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who the police say was the victim of an attack inside the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn, remains in critical but stable condition at Brooklyn Hospital Center. On Friday, Mr. Louima developed a blood clot in his left leg, requiring him to stay in the hospital for about two more weeks, said his doctor, Jean Claude Compas.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: AD UNDER FIRE -- Ruth Messinger called on Mayor Giuliani to withdraw a television advertisement that she says is a distortion. B2.

title: LIGHT TRUCKS, HEAVY RISK: A special report.; A Deadly Highway Mismatch Ignored
description: Albert and Marianne Hassan were driving their Chrysler Concorde through Merrick, N.Y., last spring to pick up their 3-week-old son when a Chevrolet Suburban slammed into their car at an intersection. The Suburban's high front end pushed in the driver's side door, hitting Mr. Hassan in the chest. He died quickly of internal bleeding.

title: Speaker and Panel Chief Avert Battle on Highway Spending
description: Backing away from a showdown over spending in a highway bill, Speaker Newt Gingrich and the chairman of the House transportation committee agreed to a truce today that would give them until next year to resolve their differences.

title: Flight Of the Bumblers
description: Nov. 1 The Mir space station collided with a hot-air balloon over the Alps, the Russian space agency announced today.

title: Gehrig's Streak Ended When Gehrig Said So
description: As Lou Gehrig's consecutive game streak rolled along in the Roaring Twenties and into the Depression Thirties, only minor attention was paid to it, nothing like the commotion surrounding the successful challenge by Cal Ripken Jr. in recent years. There was relatively little news media heat in those days, and television had not come on the scene.

title: Norwest to Split Stock
description: The Norwest Corporation, a financial services company, declared a 2-for-1 stock split yesterday. The split, which doubles the number of shares and halves each share's value, is payable Oct. 10 to shareholders of record Oct. 2. There are currently about 375 million Norwest shares outstanding. Shares of Norwest, based in Minneapolis, closed yesterday at $62.6875, up 43.75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Shell to Buy Tejas Gas for $1.45 Billion
description: The Shell Oil Company agreed today to buy the Tejas Gas Corporation, a major natural gas marketer and pipeline operator, for $1.45 billion in cash. The deal allows Shell, like several other energy companies, to better position itself in the nation's rapidly deregulating natural gas and electricity markets, where all customers are coming up for grabs.

title: Islamic Rule Weighs Heavily for Afghans
description: Nearly a year after the Taliban Islamic movement cemented its position as the dominant power in this country by seizing Kabul, the Afghan capital is a place of deepening frustration and fear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRABER, SIDNEY
description: GRABER-Sidney. On September 22, 1997, beloved husband of the late Anna, adored father of Stuart Graber, cherished brother of Vera Skigen. Graveside service on Thursday at 2:30 P.M., at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: TRANSACTION
description: BASEBALL

title: College, a Survivor, Digs for Wisdom, Limestone and Tenants
description: From its tall bluff with a sweeping view of the Missouri River, the Gothic-style administration building of Park College seems to announce itself as a bastion of classical liberal education, one of the aspiring Harvards that Protestant dreamers scattered around the Midwest in the 19th century.

title: Kentucky's No. 1 Challenge
description: Fresh from throwing seven touchdown passes last weekend against archrival Indiana, Tim Couch, the University of Kentucky's sophomore quarterback, said yesterday that he was not intimidated by the prospect of facing the No. 1 team in the country on Saturday.

title: Sparring on Sex Shop Rules
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the campaign of Rudolph W. Giuliani begin broadcasting yesterday.

title: Usinor Sees Partner In Cockerill of Belgium
description: Usinor Sacilor S.A., France's biggest steelmaker, said yesterday that it was interested in a partnership with Cockerill Sambre S.A., Belgium's biggest steelmaker. Usinor also reported a 4 percent decline in first-half profit, to 801 million francs, or $133 million, from 833 million francs in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: A Three-Cornered Pork Barrel
description: The Community Enhancement Facilities Program is a monument to the fecklessness of New York's elected officials. It will cost $450 million, raised through the sort of backdoor borrowing that made the state infamous during the tenure of Gov. Mario Cuomo. There are no restrictions on how the money is to be spent. The same three politicians who make all the other decisions in Albany -- Gov. George Pataki, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno -- will decide the allocation behind closed doors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARIA N. (NEE NEKOS)
description: DAVIS-Maria N. (Nee Nekos) of Summit, NJ, and Southampton, L.I., on September 21, 1997. Wife of George A. Davis, mother of Stephen of New York City, Carol Fiske of Hartford, Conn., and Leslie Dahl of Greenwich, Conn., sister of Peter Nekos of Pleasantville, NY, and three grandchildren. A Memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 25, 1997 at 2 p.m. from Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name may be made to the Fresh Air Fund, New York City, or The Summit Speech School, Summit, NJ. William R. Dangler Funeral Home, Summit, NJ.

title: For PEN's New President, Latin America Is Not on the Margins
description: Most mornings you can find Homero Aridjis, the Mexican poet, writing at a computer terminal in his home here, where Rufino Tamayo paintings stare down from the walls at a comfortably bohemian clutter of Mayan masks and stacks of Castilian novels. He devotes his afternoons to environmental causes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: BASEBALL: Mets' Drama Ends and Yanks' Rehearsals Continue; On Shea's Scoreboard, News Is All Bad
description: Most people laughed before the season when Joe McIlvaine, the Mets' general manager at the time, suggested that 91 victories was not out of the question.

title: Scientists Press Campaign For Computer Data Security
description: A Clinton Administration-backed proposal that would impose strict new controls on the domestic use of data-scrambling equipment has drawn fresh opposition from some of the nation's leading scientific, educational and engineering organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, JACK
description: GOTTLIEB-Jack. The partners and staff of Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield mourn the loss of our friend and client of many years. Jack will be especially missed by his dear friends, Bunny and Bert Podell, who shared a lifetime of joy and sorrow with Jack and Edythe. We extend heartfelt condolences to Edythe, Mark, David, Stuart and Jack's large and loving family. Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield LLP

title: N.F.L. Kickers Are on Target
description: Watching ''Monday Night Football'' or the last two Jets games, one would think that field-goal accuracy has disappeared in the National Football League.

title: Off the Menu
description: Tony May's Latest

title: After the Fall: Humpty Dumpty Regains His Throne
description: ANYONE who has weathered a fall from grace can appreciate an egg.

title: Saving a Master's Murals At a Manhattan Church
description: Morning mass is long over, and the church on East 29th Street in Manhattan is dark, save for a few lights at the back. There, Constance S. Silver and Henry Pospieszalski stand on scaffolds, restoring a badly damaged mural of St. Cecilia, inch by inch. To the left is a Madonna that, since June, has also been on the receiving end of their solvents, scalpels and paintbrushes, and beyond is King David. All three murals, their paint once cracked and curled, are starting to look as they did about 125 years ago, when Constantino Brumidi painted them and the rest of the interior of Our Lady of the Scapular and St. Stephen Church.

title: She's Wild, He's Square: It's Made in Heaven
description: When Dharma Finkelstein, a free spirit whose parents are permanently stuck in the 60's, meets Greg Montgomery, an assistant United States Attorney from an upper-crust San Francisco family, their eyes lock, they realize they are soul mates, they fly to Reno for blueberry pie and get married that very night.

title: TV Notes; A Winning Mood
description: How confident is Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that he'll win re-election? He has already signed up to be host of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' after the election.

title: Kmart in Link To Pizza Chain
description: The Kmart Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement with Little Caesar Enterprises to have the pizza chain supply all its in-store restaurants, allowing the retailer to cut costs.

title: Fair or Not, Rules Are Bent To Bankroll Public Schools
description: At a public elementary school in Park Slope, Brooklyn, the parents raise more than $100,000 a year to pay the salaries of two art teachers and a science teacher, whom they refer to as ''consultants'' because they are hired outside Board of Education channels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONS, ANNA
description: RONS-Anna. Beloved wife of the late Robert S. Devoted mother of Sondra Welkis, Charles Rons and the late Lenore Kornblau. Dear sister of Charlotte and Rose Kenton. Loving grandmother of Ryan and Scott. Services Thursday, 10AM, ''Plaza Memorial'', 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Fresh Dose of Terror In Algerian Conflict
description: At least 85 people were killed and 67 wounded in another unexplained attack on the outskirts of Algiers that spread panic through the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMINERIO, ANTHONY J.
description: SIMINERIO-Anthony J. Of Medford, NY. On September 22, 1997. Formerly of Lynbrook, NY. Beloved husband of Frances J. Devoted father and father-in-law of Martin M. and Joan Sommers, Andrew C. and Linda, Paul R. and Joyce Siminerio. Cherished grandfather of seven. Funeral Thursday 10 AM, from the McManus-Lorey Funeral Home, 2084 Horseblock Road, Medford, NY. Funeral Mass 10:45 AM, at St. Sylvester R.C. Church, Medford, NY. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association, 245 West Houston Street, Room 205, NY, NY 10014 and St. Charles Hospice, PO Box 245, Port Jefferson Station, NY 11776 would be appreciated. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM.

title: Low-Fat Holiday Fare That Keeps Kosher
description: THAT none of the recipes in ''The Low-Fat Jewish Cookbook'' by Faye Levy (Clarkson N. Potter, $24.95) have a fat content exceeding 30 percent is commendable. More commendable are the recipes themselves; the ones I tried were easy to prepare and produced satisfying results. This kosher cookbook includes a concise yet thorough chapter on dietary laws. Each recipe is labeled dairy, meat or pareve.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOKOLOFF, MIRIAM
description: SOKOLOFF-Miriam. Five years ago you left us. We have never stopped loving you and miss your love and wisdom tremendously. Albert, Barbara, Judy, Peter, Alan, Pete, grandchildren and great grandchildren

title: SENATE LEADERS AGREE TO DEBATE CAMPAIGN MONEY
description: President Clinton threatened today to keep the Senate in session until it agreed to schedule debate on a campaign-finance reform bill, and hours later Senate leaders agreed to take up the legislation before the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEISLER, FRANK
description: GEISLER-Frank. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Men's Club and Couples Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted members, Harvey and Edward, and extend heartfelt condolences to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Quarterbacks Pick on Otis Smith, and Jets Are Worried
description: In all their joy over their improbable 23-22 victory over the Oakland Raiders, the Jets have one huge concern -- right cornerback. Otis Smith, who holds the job, is erratic covering wide receivers, and the Raiders stung him for their three touchdowns in the first half on Sunday.

title: The Minimalist; Tangy Ways With Sea Scallops, Nature's Original Fast Food
description: THE Minimalist is always looking for quick flavor boosts without expending unnecessary energy. A logical candidate for this treatment is the sea scallop, which is one of the most perfect of nature's convenience foods because almost nothing cooks faster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVERMAN, WILLIAM PETER
description: OVERMAN - William Peter. Adored and beloved husband of Jane Leavy Overman. Adored and loving father of Jennifer Overman, David and Jonathan Blinken. Pop Pop to Allegra, Emma and Benjamin. Beloved brother to Nancy Sher and friend to so many. Funeral services to be held Wednesday, September 24, 9:45 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue. Burial will be in East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in his memory to either Dr. David Pfister Head and Neck Service Fund, in care of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NYC 10021, or SCAN NY, 207-215 East 27th St, New York City 10016.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Stuff column of the Dining section last Wednesday about a recall of Model 864 Moulinex juicers produced before July 1995, which had a defective lid and filter, misstated the amount of the reimbursement. It totals $45; shipping and handling are not refunded separately.

title: AIDS Studies Violate Helsinki Rights Accord
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Sputters, but Small Stocks March On
description: Stock market indexes finished mixed yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average flirted with 8,000 for the second consecutive session early in the day but quickly retreated.

title: Two Big Drug Wholesalers Set a Merger
description: Leapfrogging back to its perch as the nation's biggest drug wholesaler, the McKesson Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Amerisource Health Corporation for $1.72 billion in McKesson stock.

title: TV Notes; Early Returns For the Season
description: News flashes from the first night of the new television season:

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1973, LYNN SHERR, the ABC News correspondent, went on safari in Kenya and promptly fell in love with giraffes.

title: A Call for Small Government
description: Murray Sabrin, the Libertarian Party's gubernatorial candidate, called yesterday for an end to mandatory auto insurance, state aid to education, the personal income tax, affirmative action and environmental laws that interfere with property rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, SELMA
description: OPPENHEIM-Selma. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a dear friend who, with her beloved husband, Henry, was a Fellow of our Sy Syms School of Business. Dedicated to the advancement of higher education and the welfare of the Jewish people, they established SSSB's Selma and Henry Oppenheim Scholarship Fund-ensuring the perpetuation of their honored name for future generations. We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, Steven and Richard, grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Doctors vs. Demons: A Tragic Misunderstanding
description: THE SPIRIT CATCHES YOU AND YOU FALL DOWN

title: A Lighter, Sleeker Form of Metal
description: Every non-heavy metal band that appropriates metal's texture and volume must alter it: it's incumbent on them to shake off metal's brutish, dull-witted associations of the past for a discerning young audience. Nirvana had Beethovenian pathos, Soundgarden had slow and careful song hooks the size of continents.

title: Mariners Win West, Griffey Still at 55
description: Mariners 4, Angels 3

title: Chicago Art Institute Gets 400 Asian Works
description: The Art Institute of Chicago said yesterday that it had received a major gift of some 400 works from one of America's largest private collections of Indian, Himalayan and Southeast Asian art.

title: Eating Well; Folic Acid: Pop a Pill, Or Eat The Food?
description: WILL folic acid turn out to be the latest miracle nutrient, following in a long line of other miracles that never quite lived up to their advance billing? Beta carotene and vitamin C come immediately to mind. Or will folic acid prove to have staying power after the initial rush to buy it?

title: Essay; 'Letter of the Law'
description: ''We intended to be firmly within the letter of the law,'' lawyer-President Clinton artfully explained this week.

title: Matt Christopher, 80, Writer Of Sports Novels for Children
description: Matt Christopher, whose more than 120 sports novels for children and young adults entranced two generations of American youth and sold six million copies worldwide, died Saturday at the Carolinas Medical Center in Charlotte, N.C. He was 80 years old.

title: National Origins: Washington-Idaho Border; America's Golden Land Of Lentils
description: At harvest time in this stretch of lush and endless hills, the world is golden. In field after rolling farm field for 200 miles, the earth is a patchwork of copper and amber and desert brown, brilliant hues against an open sky.

title: Herbert Blyden, 61, Speaker For Inmates in Attica Revolt
description: Herbert X. Blyden, the jail-hardened, prison-educated civil rights activist who gave eloquent voice to 1,200 beleaguered inmates as their chief negotiator during the 1971 Attica prison uprising, died on Sunday at a hospice in Buffalo. He was 61.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It will be one naming ceremony after another this week for PRESTON ROBERT TISCH and his wife, JOAN TISCH.

title: White House and Congress Reach Deal to Restore 2 Tax Breaks
description: Under a deal negotiated with the White House, the House Ways and Means Committee today approved a bill to modify and restore two tax breaks that were the targets of President Clinton's first use of the line item veto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENAHAN, BERNARD T.
description: LENAHAN-Bernard T., Freeport, on September 22, 1997. Retired New York City School System 1982, Lecturer at Hunter College 19 yrs. Veteran of W.W. II, Lt., 8th Air Force. Beloved husband of Marie (Dorothy). Loving father of Mary Ellen Lenahan-Clarke, Bernard, Jr., John J., Henry, and Eileen Lenahan - Vancraeynest. Dear grandfather of four. Fond brother of Rita Ellen Lenahan. Reposing at Hungerford & Clark Inc. Funeral Home, 110 Pine Street (cor. So. Ocean Ave), Freeport. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 PM, Wed 2-4, 7-9 PM.

title: U.N. Reacts To Clinton: 'Show Me The Money'
description: President Clinton's motorcade had not left United Nations territory on Monday before the recriminations against the world's biggest deadbeat began.

title: Trains Run Only by Motormen To Expand to 3 More Lines
description: After a year of running subway trains on its shuttle lines without a conductor, the Transit Authority is planning to do the same on three of its main lines beginning in 1998 or 1999.

title: Officer's Trial Is Set to Begin
description: Testimony is scheduled to begin today in the trial of an East Orange police officer who is accused of threatening to kill a fellow officer after that officer filed a police brutality complaint against him.

title: S.E.C. Official Announces Departure Date
description: Steven M. H. Wallman, a Securities and Exchange commissioner, said today that he would resign next Tuesday to pursue opportunities in finance and technology and work part time at the Brookings Institution.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption and a map in Business Day on Sept. 15 with an article about a jury verdict involving a rail tank car fire in New Orleans misstated the cause. The car itself did not explode; it leaked a chemical, which ignited.

title: McGreevey Says State Ranks First in All the Wrong Things
description: This is a 30-second television advertisement from the campaign of James E. McGreevey, the State Senator and Mayor of Woodbridge Township, who is the Democratic gubernatorial nominee challenging Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in November.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Shell Oil Agrees to Buy Tejas Gas for $1.45 Billion

title: The Real Class Divide
description: Last year, my husband and I chose to take our two children out of private school and place them at Public School 41 in New York City. We wanted them to have the broad educational and social experiences that public education can provide. And we thought that public school teachers were as well trained as private school teachers and that curriculum standards endorsed by the Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, were vigorous. We believed that the other problems schools faced could be solved with the active involvement of parents.

title: News Corp. Unit Will Fuse HarperCollins to TV Guide
description: The News Corporation took steps yesterday to revamp its publishing house HarperCollins along with its weekly magazine TV Guide, combining those properties into a new hybrid called the News America Publishing Group. The new unit will be headed by Anthea Disney, the president of HarperCollins.

title: Metro Business Briefs; Steady Jobless Rates
description: New York City's unemployment rate remained unchanged in August at 9.5 percent, hovering at nearly twice the national jobless rate of 4.9 percent, the New York State Department of Labor said yesterday. The state's unemployment rate, at 6.4 percent, seasonally adjusted, was also unchanged from July.

title: Russian Religion Law Denies Catholic Past
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Any player should sit down when there's another player who could handle the position better. I'm looking at it from an offensive, defensive and leadership standpoint, and I don't see another player other than Cal who could do better.''

title: Food Stuff; The Leaves Fall, the Fruit Ripens and a Cook's Fancy Turns to Baking
description: Apples, on the Tree Or at the Market

title: Topics of The Times; Mrs. Aquino Sends a Message
description: Eleven years ago Corazon Aquino mobilized huge rallies to help drive Ferdinand Marcos, then the Philippine President, from office. Lately she has used the same tactic to persuade her presidential successor, Fidel Ramos, to drop the idea of changing the Constitution to permit himself a second term. Mr. Ramos is no dictator. But the one-term limit is an important democratic safeguard for a country that has so recently suffered from self-perpetuating tyranny.

title: REGIONS FINANCIAL TO BUY 2 SOUTH CAROLINA BANKS
description: The Regions Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $223.5 million in stock to buy two South Carolina banks: Palfed Inc. and First United Bancorp. Regions, Alabama's second-largest bank in terms of assets, said it would acquire Palfed, based in Aiken, S.C., for $27.375 a share, or a total of $144.5 million, based on Monday's close. It also announced a separate agreement to buy First United Bancorp of Anderson, S.C., for $20.24 a share, or a total of $79 million. The purchases would give Regions Financial about $1.09 billion in assets and $913.2 million in deposits in South Carolina. Shares of Regions fell $2.4375 each, to $36.6875; First United Bancorp rose $1.25, to $18, and Palfed rose $2.8125, to $24.3125, all in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, WALTER D.
description: MARX-Walter D., 9/22/97. Beloved husband of Prude Marx, loving father of Daniel, Ralph and Evelyn. Grandfather of Laura, Steven and Gabriel. Services Wednesday, September 24, 9:30 A.M., at Schwartz Bros, Forest Hills.

title: Seoul Journal; Ex-Enemy of the State Sees His Chance to Lead It
description: It was on the grounds of the sprawling presidential mansion here that Government officials hatched successive plans for eliminating their enemy, first by killing him in a car accident, then by drowning him in the ocean, and finally by having him executed by hanging.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEW ENGLAND INVESTMENT COS., Boston, agreed to acquire Daniel Breen & Co., of Houston, a money management firm with about $2.4 billion in assets, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: U.S. SURGICAL ACQUIRES PROGRESSIVE ANGIOPLASTY
description: The U.S. Surgical Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Progressive Angioplasty Systems Inc. for $78 million in stock. U.S. Surgical, a surgical products company, said it might pay an additional $72 million in stock upon the completion of certain sales and other conditions. In February, U.S. Surgical acquired an option to buy Progressive, of Menlo Park, Calif., a maker of angioplasty balloons and stents, subject to a six-month evaluation period. Stents are tiny metal scaffoldings deployed inside a blood vessel after an angioplasty procedure to prevent a reclosing of the vessel. The stock of U.S. Surgical, based in Norwalk, Conn., fell $1.25, to $32, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, JEANNE WEBSTER
description: BLANK-Jeanne Webster, 77, died Sept. 22 in Albany, NY, formerly of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Greenwich, CT. Wife of Robert H. Blank of Albany, NY, mother of Laurel B. Andrew of Guilderland, NY and Paul W. Blank (Annette Yuki Makino) of Arcata, CA., and the late Catherine Jane Blank. Grandmother of Paul A. Inglis and Maya Jeanne Makino. This past June her book ''The Death of an Adult Child'' was published by Baywood Press. Contributions may be made to Compassionate Friends, 83 Brookline Ave., Albany, NY 12203. For additional information you may contact the Ginsburg Memorial Chapel, Inc., Albany, NY.

title: Nurse Tells of Retaliation For Efforts in Louima Case
description: The Coney Island Hospital nurse who first tried to alert the authorities that a Haitian immigrant had apparently been tortured in a Brooklyn police station said yesterday that she had been physically attacked in the hospital by another nurse, apparently in retaliation.

title: Teamster Chief Contends Aides Betrayed Him
description: In his first public defense since three of his top campaign aides pleaded guilty last week to improper fund-raising for his campaign, Ron Carey, the president of the teamsters union, today asserted that he was a victim of the case and not a participant.

title: 85 Slain in New Attack Near Algiers, Setting Off Panic
description: At least 85 people were killed early today and 67 wounded in another brutal, unexplained attack on the outskirts of Algiers that spread panic through the capital.

title: Whitman Offers a Health Plan For Poor and Uninsured Children
description: Following in the steps of New York, Connecticut and other states, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed today that New Jersey provide low-cost health care to more than 100,000 uninsured children from low-income families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLBACH, HENRY J.
