description: STOLBACH-Henry J., on September 22nd. Loving husband of Margaret Stolbach. Beloved father of Leo & Jeanne Stolbach, Newton Center, MA., Rene and Joan Stolbach, Reston, Virginia. Devoted grandfather of Deborah, Bradley and Leah Stolbach. Graveside services will be held at the Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, Wednesday at 11 A.M. Family will be receiving at Mr. Stolbach's residence on Wednesday from 3 PM. Family request donations be made to the NYU Geriatric Center, C/O Martin Finkelstein, M.D., N.Y.U. Medical Center, 560 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10016 or to the local chapter of the Alzheimers Association in Mr. Stolbach's memory.

title: At First Meeting, Ulster Unionist Leader Blasts Sinn Fein
description: For the first time since Ireland was divided 75 years ago, Protestant political leaders sat down today across a negotiating table from Sinn Fein, the political wing of the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army. But the Protestants immediately attacked their adversaries as ''an evil mafia.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about an information technology conference organized by the author George Gilder referred incompletely to Charles H. Keating Jr., the former savings and loan executive, who attended. While he was convicted on charges stemming from the collapse of a savings and loan association, both Federal and state convictions were overturned last year.

title: AIDS Studies Violate Helsinki Rights Accord; What Is the Harm?
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes; In-Joke on 'Seinfeld'
description: So what's new on ''Seinfeld'' this season? How about the best in-joke allegory of the new season.

title: LVMH Says Profits Rose 10% in First Half
description: LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton said yesterday that its profit for the first six months of 1997 rose 10 percent, to 1.70 billion francs, or $282.4 million. In the first half of 1996, the company earned 1.54 billion francs. The company, a French wine, liquor and luxury goods concern, reported that sales has surged 62 percent to 21.59 billion francs, or $3.59 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, ISIDOR
description: TAUB-Isidor. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of the beloved father of its devoted faculty member and gifted educator, Rachel Taub Weinstein, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Money for Charter Schools
description: The State Department of Education was awarded a $1.3 million Federal grant yesterday to help defray the costs of opening charter schools, officials said.

title: Metro Business; Bank Merger Unblocked
description: The Astoria Financial Corporation said its $293 million purchase of Greater New York Savings Bank would proceed now that a judge has refused to block the transaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, HERBERT A.
description: RAISLER-Herbert A. Of Purchase, NY and Boca Raton, Fl. A very special person suddenly left us on September 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Norma. Loving father of Margery Fisher and Richard and Kenneth Raisler and his wife, Sara. Devoted brother of Shirley Medalie. Beloved grandfather of Lauren and Jason Fisher and Caroline, Kate and David Raisler and step-grandfather of Henry and Larry Raisler. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Kol Ami at the Jewish Community Center at 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY on Friday, September 26, 1997 at 10:30AM. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either the Herbert A. Raisler Master of Engineering Fellowship, Cornell University College of Engineering, Office of the Dean, 242 Carpenter Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853-2201 or The Hebrew Technical Institute, 230 Park Avenue, #

title: Chief of W. R. Lazard Resigns Amid Rift
description: The chief executive and co-chairwoman of W. R. Lazard & Company, Marianne Spraggins, resigned yesterday amid a rift over how to revamp the securities firm.

title: Liberty Bowl
description: The Liberty Bowl game gained a sponsor and a new name yesterday. For the next three years, the game in Memphis will be known as the A.X.A./Equitable Liberty Bowl

title: Dress for Success: Public School Uniforms
description: From tiny southern towns to the nation's largest cities, public school uniforms have become so common this year that in many areas, they are no longer the exception, but the rule.

title: BEAUTY FROM ALL ANGLES
description: For a new and graceful bar stool, Melissa Brown and Havely Graves (both proteges of Dakota Jackson) bent thin maple plywood into a springy clamshell. The sculptural highchair is lightweight and looks beautiful from the back (''which is where bar stools are usually seen,'' Mr. Graves said). It is $400 from Brown Graves, (212) 965-0284.

title: Events; Three Exhibitions
description: Aspects of Design

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Worms Holders Urged to Reject Artemis Bid
description: Worms & Cie.'s board urged shareholders today to reject a $4.8 billion bid by Artemis S.A., the family holding company of the French businessman Francois Pinault.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Metro Business column on Friday about the sale of the Homestead Inn in Greenwich, Conn., misstated the connection of one buyer, Thomas Henkelmann, to La Panetiere, a restaurant in Rye, N.Y. He is a former chef, not the current one.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: New Rules on Asylum Give Victims Little Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: SOCCER

title: SO FRENCH, IT MUST BE FROM CALIFORNIA
description: Barbara Barry, the Los Angeles furniture designer, is known for a Southern California neo-traditional style. Much of her collection has a spare elegance, with fluted carving; her upholstery is often in creamy parchment colors or in leather with oversize nailheads. She credits 1930's French designers like Jules Leleu and Jean-Michel Frank for her inspiration.

title: Darting Around Like Dolphins at Play
description: Stephen Petronio set dancers splashing through a sea of movement when his company opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night.

title: Yeltsin Moves to Insure Greater Free-Market Competition
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that Russia's economic development was being jeopardized by powerful business interests and vowed the Government would play a stronger role to insure free competition.

title: Up With Eiderdown
description: To the Editor:

title: Serpico Redux
description: Frank Serpico achieved national acclaim -- and was nearly killed in the line of duty -- when he revealed corruption within the New York City Police Department a quarter-century ago. Appearing at Tuesday's City Council hearings on a new anti-corruption bill, Mr. Serpico urged the city to create an agency to monitor police misconduct and ''an atmosphere where the crooked cop fears the honest cop, and not the other way around.'' Mr. Serpico's testimony was especially powerful because it echoed sentiments he expressed so dramatically before the Knapp commission hearings in 1972 -- as well as testimony by others at the Mollen commission hearings in 1994.

title: Performance Art In Curtain Form
description: MARY BRIGHT, a New York curtain designer, has never done the expected with a curtain in her life. Where one expects silk, she unfurls burlap. Where one looks for symmetry, she conjures jubilantly mismatched panels in pink and blue, one long, one short. And where one expects something minimally conformist like fabric, Ms. Bright unveils a curtain of chain mail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAINA, NICHOLAS JOHN STEEL
description: TRAINA-Nicholas John Steel, in San Francisco, September 20, 1997, after a longtime struggle with a lifetime illness and valiant fight to the end, of an accidental overdose. Son of Danielle Steel Traina and John A Traina, Jr., of San Francisco. Nicholas was 19 years old (1 May 1978). He graduated from Town School and the Woodside International School and for the past 2-1/2 years was the lead singer, lyricist and manager of the rock band, Link 80, which had gained considerable acclaim nationally and internationally, mostly among teenagers. His C.D.'s and videos were being distributed internationally. A month ago he started a new band of his own, ''Knowledge''. Nick Traina was the bright star of his family and will be greatly missed by all. He is survived by his parents and his eight siblings: Samantha, Victoria, Vanessa, Maxx, Zara, Trevor and Todd Traina and Beatrix Seidenberg. Friends are invited for Visitation, Tuesday, September 23rd from 5-8 PM, at Halsted N. GrayCarew & English, 1123 Sutter St., San Francisco, and to attend the Funeral Service on Wednesday, September 24th at 3:30 P.M., at Grace Cathedral Episcopal Church, 1100 California St., San Francisco, CA. Interment private. Flowers or charity of your choice.

title: Switch to 3-4 Defense Has Douglas in Tears
description: Bill Parcells remembers that Hugh Douglas was crying. But Douglas said, no, ''I was a little misty-eyed.''

title: A Visit to Brimfield
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVEMBER, LILLIAN REISS
description: NOVEMBER-Lillian Reiss. Of Boynton Beach, FL. Died Sept. 23, 1997. Wife of the late Sidney November and William Reiss. Loving mother to Jill, Barry, David, Michele, Rita, Russell, Bernie and Leslie. Most devoted grandmother to Lisa, Jonathan, Bruce, Bill, Seana, William, Ben, Aaron, Stacey and Matthew. Memorial services Friday, 10 AM, Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, New York, Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. If desired, sympathy may be expressed by a memorial contribution to Hospice of West Palm Beach, Florida or Hospice of Cincinnati.

title: OBJECTS THAT HOLD MEANINGS OF THEIR OWN
description: There's a new design retailer downtown. Totem, a 1,800-square-foot gallery at 71 Franklin Street (Broadway), in TriBeCa, opened earlier this month with an evocative collection that consists primarily of furniture, lighting and accessories -- like Quasimodo, a pricey, sturdy set of wall-mounted hooks (right, $110).

title: Rivera and Boggs Hope Trainer Has the Potions
description: Mariano Rivera cruised in and out of the trainer's room today to receive heat treatment and a massage on a valuable right arm that has become a curious question mark lately. The Yankees will rest Rivera until at least Friday because it is taking him too long to get himself loose. It has become a delicate subject, no matter how the closer and Manager Joe Torre tried to minimize the fatigue factor.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Swiss Struggle
description: There is a struggle going on in Switzerland today. It is a struggle between fury and shock. It is important that shock wins. It's not clear that it will.

title: Don't Blame Computers for Frenetic Pace of Life; Intel's Looking Glass
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL INC., Willoughby, Ohio, named Glenn Lindemann, president of its Scott Aviation unit, to be Figgie's new president and chief executive, filling a vacancy created by the resignation of its former chief executive in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSON, MARILYN (NEE WEISENSEEL)
description: PEARSON-Marilyn (nee Weisenseel), 69 years. Formerly of Stamford, CT. On September 22, 1997 in San Luis Obispo, CA. Beloved of Henry Gillis. Adored mother of Mark and Suzanne. Loving sister of Richard Weisenseel. Former wife of Kenneth Pearson. Fervid supporter of the Economic Opportunity Commission charities. Visiting at John J. Fox & Sons, Inc, 201st St and Grand Concourse, Bronx, Friday 6PM-9PM. Services Saturday 10:30 AM at the Funeral Home. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. She will be deeply missed and always remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBART, JAMES J.
description: WEISBART-James J. Beloved husband of Bayla; devoted father of Cindy and Cathy; grandfather of Olivia; adored brother of Jane Nusbaum of Scarsdale, N.Y. Interment Concord, NH, September 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSON, MORRIS
description: LIPSON-Morris. A special person, a special friend, you will be missed. Our hearts go out to Dottie and her family. Gloria and Richard

title: Carbide's Chief Bets Some Pay On Performance
description: Shareholders distressed by escalating executive pay -- even in the face of mediocre corporate performances -- got what looked like a ray of hope yesterday: William H. Joyce, the chief executive of the Union Carbide Corporation, said he would give back his base salary in the year 2000 if the company failed to earn $4 a share that year, which is expected to be a tough one for the giant chemical company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLBACH, HENRY J.
description: STOLBACH-Henry J. on Sept. 22. Loving husband of Margaret Stolbach. Beloved father of Leo and Jeanne Stolbach-Newton Center, MA. Rene and Joan Stolbach-Reston, VA. Devoted grandfather of Deborah, Bradley and Leah Stolbach. Services were held at the Westchester Hills Cemetery. Family request donations be made to the N.Y.U. Geriatric Center, c/o Martin Finkelstein M.D., N.Y.U. Medical Center, 560 First Ave, N.Y., N.Y. 10016 or to the local chapter of the Alzheimers Association in Mr. Stolbach's memory.

title: Drug Program Helps Forgotten Victims
description: When Pedro Marrero, a 73-year-old laborer, took two frisky young grandsons to live in his modest apartment on Manhattan's Lower East Side, he coped as best he could. The boys' father was in prison for drug dealing, and their mother had drifted off to the streets to chase drugs.

title: ABC Says Documents on Kennedy Were Faked
description: ABC has decided to revise a planned documentary about former President John F. Kennedy, saying documents the report was relying on to prove that the President made a deal with Marilyn Monroe to guarantee her silence about their rumored sexual affair were fakes.

title: Drug's Failure Hurts Sanofi Shares
description: The shares of Sanofi S.A. plunged yesterday, a day after it said its drug Skelid had proved ineffective in trials for treating osteoporosis in post-menopausal women. Sanofi's shares fell 83 French francs ($13.78), or 13 percent, to 552 francs ($91.63). Investors had harbored high hopes for Skelid. The investment firm HSBC James Capel had forecast that the drug would generate annual sales of 2.5 billion francs ($41.5 million) within five years of its introduction.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHRISTOPHER A. DARDEN, the O. J. Simpson prosecutor, was married last month to MARCIA CARTER, an entertainment executive, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Darden's publicity agent, Claudia de Llano.

title: A Deal Maker's Dream Deal
description: Sanford I. Weill can hardly contain himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMMAN, AYMAN
description: SAMMAN-Ayman. With deep sorrow we mourn the passing of our friend Ayman in Miami Beach, FL on Sunday, September 14, 1997. We all feel privileged to have known him. He will live forever in our hearts. Our sincere sympathy to his mother, Berlant, and all his family. Funeral arrangements were scheduled for Sunday, September 21st, in Damascus, Syria. A special memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Witness to Killing Tells Of Deli Owner's Comment
description: The father of a police officer who is accused of murdering a man in a fight over a parking space advised a witness to the killing to ''just get out of here, you didn't see anything,'' the witness testified yesterday.

title: Picture Postcard World
description: Picture postcards were introduced in 1889, and it took only a few years for it to reach the Jewish market.

title: Longest-Serving Council Member to Depart, Setting Off Battle
description: For nearly three decades, the northeastern section of the Bronx has been represented in the City Council by Michael DeMarco, who became such a political force that he was the candidate of not only the Democrats, but the Conservatives and Republicans as well.

title: Crew Pledges to Rule on Teacher Today
description: After meeting with parents from a public school who are fighting for the right to spend their own money to pay a teacher's salary and reduce class size, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he was willing to consider compromises proposed by the parents, and asked for a day to decide, the parents said.

title: Airport Fight Holds Up $23 Billion
description: The Giuliani administration has a new weapon in its battle with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey over control of the city's airports. City officials said they are holding up $23 billion in Federal money for transportation projects in order to block the Port Authority's plan to build a train connection from the Jamaica rail and subway stations to Kennedy International Airport.

title: Of the Romantic School
description: The American pianist Abbey Simon is one of the last direct links to the old Romantic tradition. In 1930, at the age of 8, he became a pupil of the Polish-born virtuoso Josef Hofmann, who had studied devotedly with the great Russian pianist Anton Rubinstein. Today, the playing of 75-year-old Mr. Simon still abounds in the qualities that marked the Romantic heritage: luxurious tone, evenness of touch, spacious sense of timing and ruminative lyricism. Clearly his approach to the piano continues to command attention, for his anniversary recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday night was nearly sold out.

title: Tug of Home Is Stronger Than the Pull of the Office
description: Brenda Barnes, who announced yesterday that she was stepping down as chief executive of Pepsico's $7.7 billion North American beverage business for family reasons, said, ''Every time you would miss a child's birthday, or a school concert or a parent-teacher discussion, you'd feel the tug.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWITZLER, WILLIAM F.
description: SWITZLER-William F., 88. Of South Kent, CT., formerly of Montclair, N.J. Died peacefully on September 21. Survived by his wife of 50 years, Beulah Burgess Switzler, two children, C. Brant Switzler of Stockton, N.J. and Jayne S. Warman of Bronxville, N.Y., their spouses Angele and Ray, and seven grandchildren. Arrangements private. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Washington-Warren VNA, 131 New Milford Tpke, New Preston, CT. 06777.

title: 3 Big Health Plans Join in Call for National Standards
description: Three big health maintenance organizations joined two consumer groups today in calling for more regulation of managed health care, saying all health plans should be subject to ''legally enforceable national standards.''

title: Arts Abroad; Bonn Reclaims Beethoven, Local Boy Who Did Well
description: Prophets are supposed to be shunned in their own lands, the proverb says, so consider the tale of Ludwig van Beethoven and his birthplace in Bonn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, PAULINE KORETSKY
description: GLASS-Pauline Koretsky. On September 23, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Stanley. Mother of Leonard, David and Gail. Sister of Yetta Goldman and Sonny Koret. Grandmother of Adam, Alexander, Rebecca, Noah and Rachel. Services will be held today September 25 at 1:30PM, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

title: In California, a Candidate Makes an Early Entry Into the Governor's Race
description: With deep pockets and years of experience in the often cut-throat world of corporate takeovers, the wealthy businessman Alfred A. Checchi has officially declared himself a candidate to become the next Governor of California.

title: Say No to the Egg
description: To the Editor:

title: Romanian Cement Deal
description: Lafarge S.A., the world's second-largest producer of cement and concrete, said today that it had agreed to buy 51 percent of Romcim, Romania's largest cement producer, for $200 million. The purchase is subject to some conditions imposed by the Romanian Government's asset sale program, the company said, though it did not give details. Romcim controls 40 percent of Romania's market for cement and has 8,000 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDERMOTT, MAURICE M.
description: MCDERMOTT-Maurice M. We mourn the untimely loss of our dear friend and longtime colleague Mac. We will miss his sage counsel and unflagging good humor. Our heartfelt sympathy to Claire and the family. Andrew M. Lawler, P.C.

title: The New TV Season in Review
description: Producer of 'Brooklyn South'

title: Chancellor Media Forms Radio Network
description: The Chancellor Media Corporation said today that it was forming a national radio network and had hired the president of the ABC Radio Networks, David Kantor, to run the business.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Taming Driveway Fungus

title: Adventures in the Care and Feeding of a Fortune
description: MY VAST FORTUNE

title: People
description: * Liz Dolan, vice president and marketing director at Nike Inc., Beaverton, Ore., is leaving to form her own sports and marketing company, working on projects for Nike and others. Ms. Dolan was scheduled to return next week from a three-month sabbatical; many of her duties had been assumed by other Nike executives.

title: INSIDE
description: Calls for Health Regulation

title: House Panel Immunizes 3 Witnesses
description: In a fleeting moment of unanimous agreement, the House committee investigating campaign finance abuses voted today to grant immunity to its first three witnesses. Then it quickly moved into a slogging series of partisan skirmishes.

title: AN ARCHITECTURE LESSON IN THREE DIMENSIONS
description: Pop go the buildings in a new novelty book of astonishing complexity. ''The Architecture Pack,'' conceived by Ron van der Meer and written by Deyan Sudjic (Alfred A. Knopf, $50), is an 11-inch-square, hardcover book-in-a-box that opens to reveal a barrage of three-dimensional buildings, including the Sydney Opera House (above).

title: Still Going Their Own Way, Now, Then and Forever
description: For about five minutes before Fleetwood Mac came on stage at the Nassau Coliseum on Tuesday night, the audience listened to a recording of crickets played over the speakers. The association with the outdoors must have provoked a massive sense memory, because one remembers nearly every track from the band's 1977 album ''Rumours'' heard at barbecues and swimming pools and beaches, coming out of carry-along AM radios with bulging plastic designs, back before everyone had a sleek home stereo. More Fleetwood Mac albums have been sold than the combined populations of New York, California, Florida and Texas; the band's music, for a time, was an atmospheric component everywhere, like cricket noises.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GELLIN, SAMUEL
description: GELLIN-Samuel. Gone seven years. Remembered you every day. Inez and all those who love you

title: Born to Drive; New Jersey's Runaway Romance With Cars
description: Off Exit 16W, there is a Burger King on frenzied Route 17 in Rutherford that proclaims the arrival of a 24-hour drive-through, the quintessential New Jersey convenience. In this state, no matter what the hour, people don't like to step out of their cars if they don't have to.

title: ON SCREEN, TRANSPARENT STRUCTURES OF DESIRE AND DESPAIR
description: The dangerous splendor of glass architecture serves as compelling metaphor in two new films.

title: NETANYAHU ADDING HOUSING FOR JEWS IN THE WEST BANK
description: Despite an American call for a ''time out'' on new Israeli housing in the West Bank, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu promised today to build 300 new homes for settlers and vowed that the Jewish presence in the West Bank would grow.

title: House Also Plans a Debate On a Campaign Finance Bill
description: A day after Senate leaders agreed to debate campaign-finance legislation this fall, the House majority leader said today that the House would also consider a similar bill this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, STEPHEN J.
description: HALPERN-Stephen J., 60. Of Lincroft, New Jersey, died suddenly September 20, 1997. Doctor of Law, he was a member of the New York and New Jersey Bar, Cornell Law School Association, Phi Alpha Delta Law Fraternity and Horace Mann Alumni Association. Adored & loving husband of Edith. Devoted father of Nicole of Chicago and Lincroft and Jeff. Beloved brother of Enid Ofshlag of New Jersey and Boca Raton, Florida and Willa Rose Abramson, Miami, Florida. Cherished and loved by his many friends, he will be sorely missed. Memorials to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center of New York.

title: Stocks Drop on Continued Earnings Concerns
description: Stocks fell yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average failed for the fourth time in five sessions to sustain a run above 8,000.

title: COLLEGE: A Test of Eligibility; Athletes Stunned by N.C.A.A. Rules That Put Them on Sideline
description: Winny Brodt, a top high school hockey player from Minnesota and an honors student, was headed to college a year ago on a full athletic scholarship. Then, in a bewildering reversal, she found herself back in high school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPSHAW, GEORGE S.
description: KOPSHAW-George S. On Sept. 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Helen. Graduate of St. John's Univ. and Polytech University, Commander USNR, retired Ad Manager, Hearst Corp. Visiting Thursday 1-6 PM from McLaughlin and Sons, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10:15 AM, St. Patrick's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, ANGELA V.
description: LYNCH-Angela V., 83, formerly of Long Island, died September 22nd, at Mediplex of Southbury, CT., widow of Eugene F. Lynch, beloved mother of Eugene, Michael, Maureen, Angela and Mary Elizabeth.

title: Asset Growth of Mutual Funds Doesn't Reduce Fees, a Study Says
description: The mutual fund industry, whose assets have doubled in the last four years and quadrupled in the last seven, does not enjoy the economies of scale that would allow fund companies to lower the fees charged to investors as assets grow, a new study concludes.

title: THE ART OF THE BLOOM
description: ''You don't need time, you need vision,'' is the wise advice of ''Garden Design'' (HarperCollins, $50). The vision is there -- along with plans -- from the stylish magazine of the same name.

title: Thalidomide, at What Price?
description: Thalidomide, a pharmaceutical that has not been made or legally sold in the United States, is about to be approved for leprosy patients by the Food and Drug Administration -- despite the fact that in the 1960's the drug was responsible for thousands of malformations in newborns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, CHARLES
description: MILLER-Charles. Loving husband of Ruth; adored father and grandfather. Services Thursday, 9:30 AM, Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills (at 76th Road), New York.

title: George Hinman, 91, Is Dead; Longtime Rockefeller Adviser
description: George L. Hinman, a longtime political adviser to Nelson A. Rockefeller who was also a Republican national committeeman for two decades, died on Sunday at his home in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURTON, JOHN R.
description: BURTON-John R. A graduate of M.I.T. and Harvard Business School and a Colonel with Shaef during W.W. II, passed away one year ago today leaving his widow, two sons, John and George of Bow, N.H. and Agoura Hills, CA, respectively, and his brother Clark, Moneta, VA. He is missed.

title: David B. Kelly, 79; Led New Jersey State Police
description: David B. Kelly, who modernized the New Jersey State Police during his tenure as its Superintendent from 1965 to 1974, but who later retired after being criticized by his own men as a harsh disciplinarian, died Sunday in the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J. He was 79.

title: GENERAL SIGNAL TO SPIN OFF NETWORKING UNIT NEXT YEAR
description: The General Signal Corporation said yesterday that it would spin off its GS Networks unit to shareholders in the middle of 1998. The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said it would also look at selling three other businesses that have combined annual sales of more than $150 million. General Signal, which makes electrical parts, instruments and components for various industries, said it would have 11 operating units after a spinoff of GS Networks and the sale of the 3 other units. In addition, General Signal's board increased the company's share repurchase program to $300 million, from $150 million. The company said it expected to buy back stock through the end of 1998. General Signal's shares gained $1.25 each yesterday, to close at $43.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUSS, SYLVIA
description: DRUSS-Sylvia. Congregation Kol Ami Jewish Community Center of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and convey sincere condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark Hershey, President

title: Upshaw Deal
description: Gene Upshaw, the National Football League Players Association's executive director, signed a seven-year, $11.2 million contract extension, making him the richest union leader in team sports.

title: Success Hides Mets' Lingering Problems
description: The greatest questions facing Bobby Valentine at the outset of spring training were never answered this season. With only three games remaining, the manager of the Mets still doesn't know what to make of Jason Isringhausen, Paul Wilson and Bill Pulsipher, the young pitchers recovering from injury.

title: London and Dublin Reject Demand to Bar Sinn Fein From Talks
description: The British and Irish Governments today rejected a demand by the largest Protestant political party in Northern Ireland that Sinn Fein, the political arm of the I.R.A., be expelled from the peace talks on the future of Northern Ireland.

title: PUBLIC EYE
description: LAUNDRY CARE LABELS: CAN YOU BREAK THE CODE?

title: College Tuitions Climb 5 Percent, Survey Finds
description: The cost of a college education rose by 5 percent this year, which administrators described as proof that they were bringing costs down from the spiral upward in the 1980's. But critics noted that the rate was still twice that of inflation and three times that of the growth of the average family income.

title: Mixing Sex With Satin And Sugar
description: There is a reason every show nestled between ''Seinfeld'' and ''E.R.'' becomes a hit. During that half-hour, an evil wizard takes control of your television, sending out bad-taste waves and making you think your arms are too heavy to lift the remote. Before you know it you've watched ''Fired Up.'' You have a better explanation?

title: Backlog Slows City Payments For Adoptees
description: Overwhelmed by the deluge of paperwork required to process the adoptions of a record number of foster children, the city's child welfare agency has left about 200 newly adopted children without monthly stipends or medical insurance, city officials said yesterday.

title: Many Factors Prompt Rise In Bond Prices
description: Treasury prices turned sharply higher yesterday, as market participants weathered the Treasury's auction of new five-year notes and reacted to a number of other factors including a report that the Government was likely to curtail its borrowing needs in the coming fiscal year.

title: Don't Blame Computers for Frenetic Pace of Life; Is Faster Better?
description: To the Editor:

title: The New TV Season in Review
description: In the Diner They Come and Go, Bringing to Mind Another Show

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; World's Fair of Gardens Grow at the City's Doorstep
description: TWELVE plain sheds, along with plots striped with corn, beans, collards, okra and even peanuts and tobacco, emerge from morning fog along Surf Avenue in Coney Island. It is harvest time, and these are Southern family farm gardens, though water comes from the hydrant and morning glories bloom on chain-link, not split-rail fences.

title: Rarely Seen Burmese Leader Appears in Public in Indonesia
description: Emerging in public from a long and enigmatic absence, Myanmar's legendary strongman, U Ne Win, is in Indonesia for a personal visit at the invitation of President Suharto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACKOW, LEON L., M.D.
description: RACKOW-Leon L., M.D., Died September 16, 1997 in Pompano Beach, Florida. Survived by his loving wife Doris, children Eric, Kenneth and Sari, grandchild Lauren and sister Norma Perlman. He was Director of FDR Hospital in Montrose, New York and Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at Cornell Medical School. A memorial fund has been established in his name at St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 West 11th Street, New York, New York 10011, C/O Dr. Eric Rackow.

title: In America; Remaining Blind to Brutality
description: Frank Serpico always seems lost. And on Tuesday, testifying at a City Council hearing, he seemed confused as well. He took his seat behind the microphone and slipped on a pair of reading glasses. He identified himself as Citizen Serpico. And before long he was talking about the ''meddling, hounding pursuit'' by the F.B.I. that forced him to flee naked in the snow from his residence in Switzerland, accompanied only by his beloved sheepdog.

title: Painful Choices For Immigrants In U.S. Illegally
description: Sometime this evening, before she boards a plane for Germany, Angelica Struba will pull her son, Anthony, close to her, give him a tight hug and extract a promise that he will be good while she is gone. She will not tell him that, although she holds a return ticket to the United States, she fears that they will be apart for a long, long time.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: FOR THE FAMILIES

title: Fidelity Sales Link Won't Be Severed
description: Fidelity Investments and Salomon Brothers said the takeover of Salomon Inc. by the Travelers Group would not affect Fidelity's contract to offer shares in public stock offerings led by Salomon to customers of Fidelity's discount brokerage operation.

title: For the Playoff Bound, Tying Up Loose Ends
description: For those who think that the mop-up games being played by playoff-bound teams are meaningless, consider the following:

title: New Rules on Asylum Give Victims Little Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: By Large Margin, Senate Votes to Streamline F.D.A.
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly passed a bill that would enable the Food and Drug Administration to speed the availability of drugs and medical devices while giving manufacturers greater authority in reviewing and promoting their products.

title: Youths Accused of Killing New Jersey Millionaire
description: The weeklong hunt for Nelson G. Gross, a New Jersey millionaire and once-prominent Republican official, ended yesterday along the banks of the Hudson River in upper Manhattan, where investigators say three youths tossed his body after repeatedly stabbing him in the fatal conclusion to a $20,000 robbery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACNEIL, JANE MOORE
description: MACNEIL-Jane Moore, on September 24, at 79, at her home in Manhattan. Daughter of the late Stewart Charles Moore and Edna Hart Moore of Aliquippa, Penn. A superb golfer, she won numerous awards and championships in her amateur career, including Pennsylvania and Ohio championships from 1936-1945. After relocating to New York City in 1955 with her three children, she established herself as the office manager for several prominent physicians, including the late Dr. Arthur Davids. Years of dedication and hard work allowed her to raise three children on her own in Manhattan, a feat of which she was certainly proud. Married in 1968 to Robert Paul MacNeil, noted industrial engineer and cousin of the current chief of the MacNeil of Barra clan. Survived by three children: Susan Greenbaum of New York City, a doctoral student at Union Theological Seminary & faculty member at Hunter College, Nancy Gordon of Wheaton, Illinois, senior labor attorney for United Airlines, and Stewart Moore Johnson, also of New York City, investment technology expert and head of Investment Information Systems for The Guardian, a major insurance firm. Also survived by a stepdaughter, Eleanor MacNeil Dozier of New York City, & grandchildren Joshua Greenbaum, Sarah Hart Greenbaum, Lawrence Johnson, Scott Gordon, Jennifer McBride and Whitney Gordon. Special thanks to her close friend Gerry Bird for his care and dedication in the last years of her life. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street), on Sunday, September 28, at 3:30 P.M. Memorial donations may be made to the Autism Society of America, in honor of her grandson Lawrence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALIN, JOSEPH V.
description: VALIN-Joseph V. Beloved father of Paul Valin. Visitation Saturday, September 27, 1997, 12 Noon-1 PM. Religious services 1 PM, CassidyFlynn Funeral Home Inc., Mount Kisco, New York (1-800-244-6634).

title: Remembering de Kooning as 'the Guy to Beat'
description: Some 400 friends, acquaintances and admirers of Willem de Kooning gathered yesterday in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art to remember the Abstract Expressionist painter.

title: STARWOOD LODGING BUYS CROWNE PLAZA IN NEW ORLEANS
description: Starwood Lodging Trust said yesterday that it had acquired the Crowne Plaza Hotel in New Orleans for $58.8 million from a joint venture run by affiliates of Holiday Inns Inc., which is a unit of Bass P.L.C., and Joseph C. Canizaro Interests. At the same time, Starwood sold three Best Western hotels -- in El Paso; Las Cruces, N.M., and Savannah, Ga. -- to Columbus Hotel Properties L.L.C., a Canizaro affiliate, for $12 million. Starwood, based in Phoenix, recently agreed to buy Westin Hotels and Resorts to create the world's third-largest hotel company. Starwood will own more than 200 hotels when this acquisition is completed. The Crowne Plaza, in downtown New Orleans, has 439 rooms, a full-service restaurant and meeting space.

title: WARNACO'S PACT TO BUY DESIGNER HOLDINGS IS EXTENDED
description: Warnaco Group Inc. said yesterday that its agreement to acquire Designer Holdings Ltd. had been extended to midnight on Friday, until the proper documents are filed. ''It's only paperwork; it has nothing to do with the deal,'' said Warnaco's chairman and chief executive, Linda Wachner. Both companies are based in New York. Warnaco, which makes Calvin Klein clothing and accessories, agreed last week to buy Designer Holdings for $11 a share, or $353.7 million, in stock. Designer Holdings shares slipped 6.25 cents, to $9.6875, yesterday. Under the terms of the agreement, Designer Holdings and its majority shareholder, New Rio L.L.C., agreed not to solicit other proposals or enter into acquisition talks with another party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAFFARD, FREDERIC CHAUNCEY
description: PAFFARD-Frederic Chauncey. Longtime resident of Sewickley, PA, Stonington, CT., and Mountain Lake, FL., died at his family home on September 23. Born on May 7, 1915 in Brooklyn, NY, son of the late Dr. Frederic C. Paffard and Helen Adams Paffard of Stonington. Survived by his wife of 58 years, Edith Wynne Rizer and four daughters: Wynne Delmhorst of Riverside, CT.; Jane Nichols of Boston, MA.; Heidi Simmons of Stonington, CT, and Helen Wertheimer of Everett, WA and 9 grandchildren. He was predeceased by 2 sisters, Elizabeth Anderson of Noank, CT and Jane Hamill of Stonington, CT. A memorial service will be held at 11:30AM at Calvary Episcopal Church on Church Street in Stonington. Interment will be private. Memorial contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to the Stonington Free Library, PO Box 188, Stonington, CT 06378 and Hospice of Southeastern CT, PO Box 902, Uncasville, CT 06382.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, HILDA S.
description: JACOBS-Hilda S. Formerly of Teaneck, NJ, died Sept. 24, 1997, in Vernon, VT. Wife of the late Isidor Jacobs. Beloved mother of Martin Jacobs, Alice Twombly, Evelyn McLean and Verandah Porche. Sister of Sadye Wexelblatt. Grandmother of Jonathan and David Twombly, Daniel and Michael Jacobs, Oona Adams, Emily Coutant and Ian McLean. Funeral services Gutterman Musicant, 402 Park Ave., Hackensack NJ, Sept. 26, 1997, 11:30 AM. Donations to National Council of Jewish Women, or Hadassah, appreciated.

title: Teamsters Scandal Dampens Celebration of Labor's Revival
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s convention here has largely been a celebration of labor's revival since John J. Sweeney took the federation's helm two years ago, but the party has been marred by an unwelcome distraction: the teamsters scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARLES, RICHARD
description: CHARLES-Richard. We mourn the loss of our beloved fellow member and esteemed trustee of the Actors' Fund and Shepherd of the Lambs, he was a great leader and a great guy. Our love to Joyce and Randy. The Players

title: Still No Exit Strategy on Bosnia
description: Having already stretched America's troop commitment in Bosnia from 12 to 30 months, the Clinton Administration has begun an effort to prepare public opinion for the possibility of an even longer stay. That is the way to read Samuel Berger's speech at Georgetown University on Tuesday, when he linked the duration of American involvement to a notably ambitious set of policy goals. Mr. Berger, the President's national security adviser, is too hasty. Instead of managing the public relations of a longer stay, he should be using that time to try to produce a workable exit strategy by the June deadline.

title: Economic Scene; Tobacco might thrive with a $1.50-a-pack rise for cigarettes.
description: IS the tobacco industry playing Brer Rabbit to President Clinton's Brer Fox? The President's assertion that if necessary, the price of cigarettes should rise by $1.50 a pack to deter teen-age smoking evoked bitter denunciations from Big Tobacco. ''The industry should be not held solely accountable for social behavior that neither it, nor the Government, can control,'' read the cigarette manufacturers' collective response.

title: Spain Says It Will Sell Another 35% of Endesa
description: The Spanish Government will begin selling up to 35 percent of Endesa S.A., the nation's largest power company, on Monday, the company said yesterday. The stake's value, at yesterday's share price, is 1.13 trillion pesetas ($7.48 billion), and it represents Spain's biggest sale of state assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: FINKELSTEIN-Sylvia. Devoted wife of Philip. Loving mother of Joan and Martin Cohen. Cherished grandmother of Amy and Lauren Cohen. Loving aunt of Myra and Janet Cohen and Paul Schulman.

title: Merger Roils A Changing Wall Street
description: Even after a record-breaking year of mergers and acquisitions in the securities industry, the Travelers Group announcement yesterday that it would acquire Salomon Inc. for $9 billion rattled Wall Street and reverberated into the offices of the largest banks in the country.

title: 'Clean Money' Politics Keeps Fat Cats at Bay
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Clinton's Blow for Reform
description: The Senate's Republican leaders needed the gutsy shot in the ribs that President Clinton gave them on Tuesday, when he threatened to call a special session if Congress adjourned without acting on campaign finance reform. Democrats and the stalling Republicans speedily reached an agreement permitting a vote on the McCain-Feingold reform legislation as early as next month. Only last summer, getting a vote in the Senate on the first overhaul of campaign laws in a generation seemed like a nearly hopeless goal. Advocates of reform need to be vigilant, however. The enemies of change are preparing myriad maneuvers to weaken the bill, cloaking their tricks in the mantle of free speech and reform.

title: Industry, Not Sun, Is Culprit in Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: When Art Is Underfoot
description: FOR those who love their polished wood floors but also want a patch of warmth under their feet now and then -- or just something to sweep the dust under -- a small rug with punch can be an attractive idea. The rugs are available everywhere from mass-market catalogues to SoHo galleries. (Check your socks before going to the rug show at the A/D Gallery: a sign at the door asks visitors to shed their shoes. The show runs through Oct. 31.)

title: South African Casino Owner in Atlantic City Pitch
description: Sol Kerzner, a South African casino magnate with a reputation for lavish resorts and unsavory political dealings, made his appeal today to the New Jersey agency that will decide whether he can extend his empire into this city.

title: A Healthy Sykora Hopes To Stay a Devil All Season
description: When Petr Sykora was held scoreless in the Devils' first preseason game this month, you might think that there was little for him to smile about. A player battling for a roster spot cannot afford to waste chances, and Sykora could have put his head down and pouted. But he woke up the next morning feeling healthy, and that was enough to make him laugh out loud.

title: Lawmaker Takes Highway to Power
description: Representative Bud Shuster says he has witnessed some ''pretty heady stuff'' in his 24 years in Congress, like flying into jungles with Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader, and crossing the Khyber Pass with the mujahedeen guerrillas.

title: CHRONICLE
description: People have not exactly been heaping praise on KITTY KELLEY, the author of ''The Royals,'' the tell-all-and-then-some book about the British monarchy that reached bookstores last week, less than three weeks after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAZDAG, ILONA
description: GAZDAG-Ilona. On Sept. 22, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Devoted mother of Carmen and mother-in-law of Rik. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87 Street, NYC Thursday and Friday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass 10 A.M., Saturday, at St. Stephen of Hungary RC Church, 412 East 82 Street. Burial at St. Raymond Cemetery.

title: Park Gets Landmark Status
description: A waterfront park that became a battlefield of sorts is now a landmark. The State Review Board for Historic Sites voted yesterday to confer historic landmark status on Riverbank Park, which was proposed as the site for a minor-league baseball stadium until pressure from community groups caused local officials to back off. They announced earlier this month that they had come up with an alternative site.

title: Residential Resales
description: Big Deal

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Choral Works With a Spiky Edge
description: Boston has long been a mecca of the early-music movement. But it is also a hotbed of contemporary music, and it's not just the city's numerous contemporary chamber ensembles that spark the activity. Two choral-instrumental groups founded to perform the works of Bach have commissioned and championed a great deal of new music, as a pair of splendid recent recordings amply illustrate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, MANUEL
description: MAXWELL-Manuel, on September 23, 1997. Mercifully. Beloved husband of Rhoda for 53 years. Loving father of Douglas F. Dear brother-in-law of Sandy and Fern Granowitz. Devoted uncle of many nieces and nephews, great nieces and nephews and great great nieces and nephews. Service Sunday 10 AM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made in his memory to either Parker Jewish Geriatric Institute or the NYU School of Law.

title: Seagram Sets Big Buyback Of Its Shares
description: The Seagram Corporation said yesterday that its board had given permission for the company to purchase up to 10 percent of Seagram's 228.5 million publicly traded shares.

title: Messinger Assails Plan On Hospitals
description: Signaling a new line of attack in her challenge to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Ruth W. Messinger last night assailed the Mayor's efforts to sell the city's public hospitals to private health care companies, saying it would jeopardize the care of poor and immigrant New Yorkers who rely on the system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIGENBAUM, MILDRED (ROTH)
description: FEIGENBAUM-Mildred (Roth), on September 24th, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving cousin of Loretta and Martin Corwin. Services Thursday, 10 AM, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills (76th Road), NY.

title: The New 'God Forbid' Room
description: THE bedroom closet with a difference the one with the bullet-resistant window and the green exit button concealed behind the silk kimonos -- can be found at the top of a gentle cascade of steps, past the African fertility figure and across from the pair of dueling indoor and outdoor Jacuzzis.

title: Once a Star, Hampton Will Have to Make Do With Bit Parts
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel and his staff have been waiting since July for Rodney Hampton to show the ability that has made him the team's career leading rusher. All signs now indicate that Fassel and the Giants have stopped waiting.

title: TRAVELERS TO BUY SALOMON, MAKING A WALL ST. GIANT
description: Travelers Group, the sprawling ensemble of financial companies gathered under the company's trademark umbrella, announced yesterday that it would acquire the Wall Street powerhouse that owns Salomon Brothers for more than $9 billion in stock.

title: CATERING TO CLASSIC TASTES AND DESIGN BIBLIOPHILES
description: For Cristina Modern, her new gallery in SoHo, Cristina Kane has assembled a mix of what she called ''modernist classics that also function well,'' many of them reproductions of finds from the 1940's and 50's. An elegant, eight-foot-long beechwood wall unit has hidden drawers as well as shelves (below, $5,200). Other pieces are based on 40's furniture by Vladimir Kagan, and Ms. Kane has new upholstery by the New York decorator Larry Laslo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERBILT, HELEN C.
description: VANDERBILT-Helen C. It is with the deepest sadness that Housing & Services, Inc. (HSI) bids farewell to one of its founding Board members, Helen C. Vanderbilt. Helen will be remembered always in the hearts and minds of the thousands she touched for helping the least able in our society to help themselves, for her indomitable strength and for her courage. She believed in the power of the human spirit-her inspirational example will be a beacon for us for many years. The Board and Staff of Housing & Services, Inc.

title: 2 Killed by Spanish Police in Basque Region
description: The police killed two Basque rebels in a shootout in the northern city of Bilbao today and later arrested 12 other members of a Basque commando unit, the Interior Minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, said in a nationally televised news conference.

title: Millionaire Is Found Slain
description: The weeklong search for Nelson Gross, a New Jersey millionaire and once-prominent Republican official, ended yesterday along the upper Manhattan banks of the Hudson River, where investigators found the body of the former state Republican chairman.

title: Orioles Clinch, but Yankees Keep Eyes on Gooden
description: The lingering mystery about the Yankees' third starter for the division series against the Indians has become a soap opera, with Dwight Gooden saying that David Wells deserves the job while also claiming that Manager Joe Torre has already decided who will get it. The manager has disagreed vehemently with his talkative pitcher and insisted ''we're not even close'' to choosing a starter.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; World's Fair of Gardens Grow at the City's Doorstep
description: TWELVE plain sheds, along with plots striped with corn, beans, collards, okra and even peanuts and tobacco, emerge from morning fog along Surf Avenue in Coney Island. It is harvest time, and these are Southern family farm gardens, though water comes from the hydrant and morning glories bloom on chain-link, not split-rail fences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, IRWIN
description: ROSS-Irwin. On September 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Marian, devoted father of Amy Siegel and Aileen Lerner and sons-in-law Fred Siegel and Harvey Lerner. Cherished grandfather of Zachary, Margot, Jeremy and Jordan. Memorial service Thursday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Crew Says No to Compromise on All-Girls Middle School
description: In his strongest statement yet in support of an experimental all-girls public middle school in East Harlem, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he had ruled out admitting boys to the school or creating a separate boys' school to satisfy the civil rights concerns of Federal education officials.

title: Bridge
description: Every tournament player knew the Man in the Bow Tie. He was Maurie Braunstein, who died last Saturday at his home in Schenectady, N.Y., at 83, and he was one of the world's great tournament directors. When he retired recently after 43 years of service at regional, national and world championships, his friends gathered for a party. Everyone wore a bow tie, and that included the women and the dogs.

title: Using Fancy Footwork, Buffett Makes a Go of It
description: Salomon Brothers is not Warren E. Buffett's best deal, if it is measured against his own standards.

title: A Very Golden Oldie Stays Big by Staying Small
description: As the Rolling Stones started their new world tour here at Soldier Field on Tuesday night, everything was golden: the curtains, the inflatable women, the frame for the video screen, even the speakers clustered overhead. It's a none too subtle reminder that the Stones are likely to rake in huge profits as the tour circles the world through next year, reactivating the rock-and-roll cash machine that grossed $124 million when the band last toured three years ago.

title: After a Decade's Retirement, 'Manon' Returns to the Met
description: When Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's production of ''Manon'' had its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in 1987, it was roundly excoriated as an affront to Massenet and to the operatic values that ''Manon'' embodies. Some of the sets, conceived mostly in Ponnelle's signature black, white and gray tones, were at odds with the vibrant passions of this tragic story, let alone Massenet's rich, stylistically wide-ranging score.

title: Nurse's Murder Throws Britain and Saudi Arabia Into Crisis
description: The sentencing of one British nurse to eight years in prison and 500 lashes, and the possibility that another British nurse accused of murder in Saudi Arabia may be beheaded, have set off the most serious diplomatic crisis between Saudi Arabia and Britain in years.

title: 3 Go Into N.Y. Hall
description: Three players from different eras will be inducted into the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame today at the New York Athletic Club: Harry Boykoff, Kevin Loughery and World B. Free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MECKLER, BARNEY
description: MECKLER-Barney, 84, of Fort Lee, died Tuesday. Beloved uncle to Jerry Meckler, Myron Galef and Beatrice Hess. Loving cousin of Hannah Mallin, Anita Kornreich and Charles Kornreich. Graveside services today 1:30 PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus. For more information Louis Suburban Chapels, Fair Lawn.

title: F.T.C. in New Investigation Of Intel's Business Practices
description: The Intel Corporation said late today that it had been notified that the Federal Trade Commission has begun an investigation of the company's business practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, JULIAN
description: STEINER-Julian on September 23, 1997, former dentist and attorney. Son of the late Oscar and Gertrude Steiner. Brother of the late Cyrus Steiner. Services private.

title: A Call to Enforce Wiper Law
description: Because drivers are routinely ignoring a statute requiring them to switch on headlights when they use windshield wipers, the New Jersey Division of Highway Traffic Safety is calling for stepped-up enforcement of the two-year-old law, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYNARD, SAMUEL M.
description: KAYNARD-Samuel M. Beloved husband of Ann Kaynard. Loving father of Meryl and Alan Kaynard, Gerry Wall and Joyce Kaynard. Adoring grandfather of Rebecca, Emma and Natalie. Patriarch of our extended family. Teacher and mentor of many. He will live in our hearts forever. Funeral service to be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City, Thursday September 25 at 12:30 P.M.

title: Witnesses in Sharpton Bid Say Disparities Put Vote in Doubt
description: Witnesses called by lawyers for the Rev. Al Sharpton testified yesterday on what they called voting irregularities in the recent Democratic primary. And Mr. Sharpton's lawyers said the problems were pervasive enough to cast the outcome of the mayoral primary in doubt.

title: Home Health Attendant Is Guilty of Murder
description: A home health care attendant charged with killing two elderly women in Bensonhurst in May 1996 was convicted of first-degree murder yesterday afternoon in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Tourniquet TV
description: Tonight, as millions of Americans tune in to a live broadcast of NBC's popular medical drama ''E.R.,'' a few poor souls will find themselves in actual emergency rooms. Does this drama seem more realistic?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, HARVEY
description: SILVERSTEIN-Harvey. On September 24, 1997. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Ira, Mitchell and Susan. Loving fatherin-law of Marilyn, Andrea and Rodrigo. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Jaime, Gayle, Robert, Zoe and Kiara. Services on Friday, 1 P.M., at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLANSKY, MOLLIE
description: POLANSKY-Mollie. She was a woman of such strength of character that even the powerful were humble in her presence. Her selflessness was unparalleled. Her kindness knew no bounds. Her commitment was such that she could move mountains. Her loss is incalculable to so many. I thank her for having been my friend. Judy Piesco

title: Sharpton Visits Man Who Claims Police Beat Him
description: Seizing again on the issue of police brutality, the Rev. Al Sharpton went to Metropolitan Hospital Center yesterday to visit a Washington Heights man who claims that he was beaten by police officers during a drug raid last week.

title: Metro Business; More New York Shipping
description: Saab Cars USA has decided to stop shipping its cars through Rhode Island and instead use New York as the port through which it delivers cars to the Northeast.

title: U.S. Picks a Key Target in Mexico in Its War on Drug Trafficking
description: With a barrage of tough talk and the offer of a huge reward, United States officials pledged today to hunt down a 33-year-old Mexican whom they described as the most ruthless drug trafficker in Mexico.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOSS, VIRGINIA JOHNSTON
description: GOSS-Virginia Johnston, at Sanibel, FL., on September 23, 1997. Formerly of Waterbury, CT., she was the wife of the late Richard Wayne Goss. She is survived by two sons, Richard W. and Porter J., 2 daughters, Wayne G. Douglas & Garril G. Page, 13 grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren, all of whom will miss her keenly. Funeral arrangements will be private. Contributions may be made in her memory to St. Margaret-McTernan School, 565 Chase Parkway, Waterbury, Conn. 06708 or Hope Hospice, 9470 HealthPark Circle, Fort Myers, Florida 33908.

title: With Sales Slow in Asia, Gucci Shares Take a Big Hit
description: In the slick new advertising campaign for the fall line of Gucci apparel, there is nary an Asian face among the models seen frolicking in various stages of undress. But it is that customer, and her powerful spending ability, that helped send the Gucci Group's stock flying last year. And her pullback is what led to its tremendous fall yesterday.

title: Gigante Verdict Upheld; Next Issue Is Sentencing
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld the murder-conspiracy and racketeering conviction of Vincent Gigante, rejecting renewed defense arguments that the man who prosecutors called the boss of the nation's most powerful Mafia family had been mentally incompetent to stand trial.

title: Don't Blame Computers for Frenetic Pace of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, SELMA
description: OPPENHEIM-Selma. The Board and executive staff of the Educational Alliance mourn the passing of the beloved mother of our Vice President, Steven D. Oppenheim. May her memory bring comfort to Steven and all her loved ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYE, ROBERT H.
description: MAYE-Robert H. On September 24, 1997. Assistant Controller of General Host. Beloved husband of Joan. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 Street, Friday at 11 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROMBERG, SUZANNE
description: BROMBERG-Suzanne. It is with deep sadness the League for the Hard of Hearing and advocates for better communication (abc) mourn the loss of a leader and friend. Her advocacy efforts touched the lives of thousands of people who are deaf and hard of hearing. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her husband, Bill and her family. Keith D. Muller, Exec Dir. League for the Hard of Hearing Ruth R. Green, Coordinator, abc.

title: Bacteria at Highway Office
description: High levels of the bacteria that cause Legionnaire's disease have been found in bathrooms at the headquarters of the New Jersey Highway Authority, officials said yesterday. No employees have reported contracting the disease, said Dennis Ingoglia, a spokesman for the highway authority.

title: 3 Executives Leave Lally McFarland
description: Three top executives have unexpectedly left Lally McFarland & Pantello/Euro RSCG, a leading medical agency in New York, to form a shop specializing in health care advertising under the aegis of the McCann-Erickson World Group.

title: Industry, Not Sun, Is Culprit in Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Sampras a Big Winner
description: Grand Slam Cup

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: F.T.C. Is Investigating Intel's Business Practices

title: 525 Made in America continues to seek name recognition by using dogs to model its clothes.
description: A MANHATTAN-BASED knitwear company, 525 Made in America, is going to the dogs and is proud of it.

title: House Approves 2.3% Raise For Lawmakers and Judges
description: Bucking a trend against rewarding themselves, the House of Representatives today voted for a 2.3 percent cost-of-living increase for members of Congress and Federal judges.

title: Many Reported Unready To Face Year 2000 Bug
description: A new study shows that a large proportion of businesses and government agencies around the world are not properly preparing for the effect that the year 2000 will have on their computer systems, increasing the possibility of potentially serious disruptions as the end of the century approaches.

title: Open Short Sales Rose Slightly In Nasdaq Market Last Month
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 1 percent in the most recent month, according to figures released yesterday.

title: A Swell, Swanky Emporium Turns Literary
description: IT rises in Art Deco splendor from the breadth of Wilshire Boulevard, its 241-foot tan terra cotta and copper tower as Californian as a redwood. For three generations of Angelenos, Bullocks Wilshire was much more than the most elegant emporium in town; it was an old friend, the place where well-bred brides bought their wedding gowns and movie stars their jodhpurs.

title: Clinton Urges Labor Unions Not to Punish Free-Trade Democrats in Congress
description: Aggressively defending his trade strategy before a skeptical labor audience, President Clinton urged the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today not to punish Congressional Democrats who vote to give him more freedom to negotiate trade deals.

title: Trizec Hahn to Sell Stake in Clark USA
description: The Trizec Hahn Corporation will spin off its 46 percent stake in the oil refiner Clark USA Inc. to focus on expanding its real estate portfolio.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''While we do get some complaints, lots of people shrug their shoulders, thinking it may not do any good, but it won't do much harm, either.''

title: Back Remedies Are on A Roll
description: YOU might be married or single, in love or divorced. But if you're approaching middle age, already there or beyond it, your back is probably your significant other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRWIN, A. MICHAEL
description: IRWIN-A. Michael. On September 23, 1997 at the age of 79 of Lymphoma. Beloved husband, father, brother, grandfather and friend. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 76th St, 12:15 PM, Thursday, September 25, 1997. Family and friends will be received Sept 25Sept. 30 at 315 W. 70 St, #

title: Sul Hagar Journal; King Cotton Exacts a Tragic Toll From the Young
description: Here in the heart of this Delta, too, cotton is king, and in the early autumn it rules absolutely -- especially over children, to whom it usually falls to harvest the fluffy puffballs for the sake of Egypt's economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHON, HERBERT
description: GERSHON-Herbert, died 9/24/97. Basketball Legend. Esteemed member of Lone Star Boat Club. Funeral at Beth-David Cemetery, Hollywood, FL., 2:00 PM, Sunday. Lone Star Boat Club Jonathan Kurtin, President

title: Forest Service Bans New Leases For Oil and Gas in Rockies Area
description: The Forest Service on Tuesday banned new oil and gas leasing along the Rocky Mountain Front in Montana because the agency feared the possibility of environmental damage to one of the country's most scenic, wildlife-rich areas.

title: What Will $5 Million Buy and Who Will Buy It?
description: HERE'S some news you might not be eager to hear: The rich are not only getting richer, but they're getting younger and their taste in real estate is improving.

title: Martin Makes His Ryder Cup Peace
description: Miguel Angel Martin, who was angry about being quickly replaced on Europe's Ryder Cup team after wrist surgery, held a news conference today and declared that the dispute was over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, GOLDIE
description: RATNER-Goldie. Beloved wife of Meyer. Devoted mother of Sheldon and Kenneth. Loving motherin-law of Joan. Adored grandmother of Richard, Tracy and Brett. Dear aunt. Services today 11:30 am at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', 2576 Flatbush Ave., opposite Kings Plaza cor Ave V.

title: Petersen Reduces Offering
description: The Petersen Companies, the publisher of Hod Rod, Teen, Motor Trend, and Guns & Ammo magazines, has reduced the amount of its initial public offering to $100 million. In its original registration filed on Aug. 7, the company estimated the offering could raise as much as $172.5 million. The Los Angeles-based company said in an amended filing last week that it planned to sell 6.25 million shares at $15 to $17 each. At $16 each, Petersen could raise $92 million after expenses.

title: SOURCE MEDIA IN $35 MILLION DEAL FOR BRITE VOICE ASSETS
description: Source Media Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire certain electronic publishing assets of Brite Voice Systems Inc., a maker of voice-processing systems for interactive telecommunications, for $35 million. Source Media, based in Dallas, is an interactive programmer, providing weather, sports and other information by telephone. Brite Voice, based in Wichita, Kan., said Source Media had agreed to distribute Brite Voice-manufactured equipment for the electronic newspaper and directory market. Brite Voice's shares rose 43.75 cents, to $10.75, and Source Media's fell 31.25 cents, to $10.0625.

title: Despite Ranger Talks, LaFontaine Still a Sabre
description: Pat LaFontaine is still a Buffalo Sabre, at least until Sunday morning's waiver draft.

title: F.D.A. Approves 1st Neurex Drug
description: The Neurex Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Menlo Park, Calif., said today that it had received final marketing approval from the Food and Drug Administration for Corlopam, a drug for the treatment of acute high blood pressure.

title: School Worker Accused Of Internet Pornography
description: A Bronx elementary school custodian was arrested yesterday on charges of storing child pornography on the principal's computer and using it to send some of the pictures over the Internet.

title: Metro Matters; Uncrowding City Schools Is Elusive Goal
description: SEPTEMBER is a month of many hopeful rituals: meeting new teachers, choosing new clothes, sharpening new pencils. And as students jam into portable classrooms, it has also become the month for offering new solutions for New York City's increasingly overcrowded school system.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Passaic Officer Pleads Guilty
description: Police Officer Salvatore Mastropole had already counted a Nissan 300ZX among his 22 cars, prosecutors said, but when a rare twin turbo model caught his eye, he bought that one, too, for $27,700.

title: Abe Gibron, 72, N.F.L. Coach, Wit and a Lover of Good Food
description: Abe Gibron, who left his mark on professional football as a player, coach, wisecracker and gourmand, died on Tuesday at home in Belleair, Fla. He turned 72 the day before and had been confined to home since strokes in December and February.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 3 about financial pressures on hospitals that serve poor patients referred imprecisely to Dr. Manuel de la Rosa, who spoke of the problems facing the Texas Tech University School of Medicine. He is dean of the El Paso campus; Dr. Joel Kupersmith heads the overall school of medicine.

title: SmithKline Names Jordan, McGrath
description: SmithKline Beecham Consumer Health Care North America said yesterday that it had consolidated its domestic gastrointestinal business at Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor in New York, by naming that agency to handle advertising for Tagamet HB200, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million. That assignment had been handled for three years by Ogilvy & Mather New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, DANIEL S.
description: COHEN-Daniel S. Died on September 23, 1997 in Atlantis, Florida. Beloved husband of Helen Housten Cohen, loving father of Nancy Buirski, Marjorie and Judith and adored grandfather of Erica and Teddy Rosen. Funeral service on Thursday, September 25, at 12 Noon, at Riverside Gordon, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONS, ANNA
description: RONS-Anna. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Anna Rons, beloved mother of our dedicated members Lenore, of blessed memory, and Allan Kornblau. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Sports of The Times; Cal Ripken Isn't Talking, But Hamlet Is
description: AS the days dwindled to a precious few in other Septembers, the biggest baseball question (except in 1994) was: Which team will win the World Series?

title: Corrections
description: The Technology column in Business Day on Monday, about efforts to regulate on-line gambling, misstated the background of Kay Cole James, chairwoman of a Clinton Administration panel studying the impact of gambling. While she has close ties to the Christian Coalition, she is not a dues-paying member.

title: From Political Heights to a Quiet Life in the Suburbs
description: A generation ago, Nelson G. Gross reigned as a bold power broker and crafty political strategist in New Jersey's Republican Party. He helped steer the 1968 Presidential nomination to Richard M. Nixon and a year later managed William T. Cahill's successful campaign for governor.

title: VALUJET SHARES RISE AFTER NAME IS CHANGED TO AIRTRAN
description: Shares of Valujet Inc. jumped yesterday after the low-fare carrier changed its name to Airtran Airlines in an effort to shake its image as a disaster-struck airline and return to profitability. The stock rose $1.59375, to $6.46875. Valujet, based in Atlanta, is still reeling from the crash of one of its planes in the Florida Everglades last year. It will drop its name as part of an agreement to buy the Airways Corporation of Orlando, Fla., parent of Airtran Airways. The combination of the two airlines will create Airtran Holdings Inc., a low-fare air carrier with about 40 jets. It will probably be based in Orlando.

title: Southeast Asia Chokes on Indonesia's Forest Fires
description: On the bad days, a milky twilight settles over the city at noon, tall buildings become ghostly shadows and people hurry along the streets with surgical masks covering their mouths and noses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEERHUSEN, PAMELA
description: VEERHUSEN-Pamela, 75, a long term executive with Planned Parenthood died September 19, in Chicago. Mrs. Veerhusen moved in 1971 from the Minneapolis affiliate to the national office of Planned Parenthood in New York. There she served in various capacities including Director of Affiliate Services and Educational Director. She is survived by three children: Peter Veerhusen, Katrina Veerhusen, Nancy Veerhusen and four grandchildren. Memorial services will be held in Michigan next summer. Contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc., 810 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10019. Attn: In memory of Pam Veerhusen.

title: Valderrama: Silent Player in the Cup
description: Some shots will require caution. Others will require courage. But this year's setting for the Ryder Cup will also be guaranteed to test the skill, patience and creativity of every player, which should make the competition even more unpredictable than usual.

title: COMPAQ LOWERS PRICES FOR DESKTOP PC'S AS MUCH AS 15%
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had reduced prices by up to 15 percent on most of its business desktop personal computers in the United States, including its Deskpro 2000 and Deskpro 4000 Pentium models. Compaq, based in Houston, said its new manufacturing process, in which it builds products as orders are received, had resulted in lower material costs. The company's stock fell $2.0625, to $74.875.

title: Market Place; A humdrum little spinoff that could just be a Cinderella stock.
description: SOLUTIA INC., the $3 billion chemical company that the Monsanto Company spun off on Sept. 1, went into the world with a lot more than the proverbial three strikes against it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNETT, MURRAY
description: BURNETT-Murray. Playwright, 12/28/10 to 9/23/97. Beloved husband of Adrienne and loving father of Lori. You will forever be a part of us and all those affected by ''Casablanca''.

title: Algeria's Main Rebel Faction Takes Risk and Calls Truce
description: The military wing of the main Islamic opposition group in Algeria instructed its followers today to lay down their arms for the first time since the country plunged into civil war six years ago.

title: New Life for Ex-Jets
description: They are three of the most famous former Jets still making an impact, and each said today that he was better off where he was -- with the Bengals.

title: Vampires on the Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPAIGN FINANCE: THE LAW ; An Old Fund-Raising Law Is Revisited in New Context
description: Waving a flier from Republican leaders that levied ''voluntary contributions'' from civil servants who owed their jobs to the party, an Ohio Democrat demanded in 1882 that his fellow Senators put an end to the practice.

title: Epidemic of Jitters: 'E.R.' Goes Live
description: More than 40 years ago, during television's golden age, live dramas written by authors like Horton Foote, Paddy Chayefsky and Rod Serling were broadcast weekly on shows like ''Playhouse 90,'' ''Studio One'' and ''Goodyear TV Playhouse.''

title: Industry, Not Sun, Is Culprit in Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: When Paul Brown Smashed the Color Barrier
description: In a year when the nation celebrates Jackie Robinson's historic breakthrough in major league baseball, one of the lesser-known stories of integration is the role that professional football played in paving the way for African-American players in the modern era of professional athletics.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WOLVERINE WORLD WIDE INC., Rockford, Mich., will close two more women's shoe factories in Arkansas by the end of the year and will convert a New York plant into a warehouse, cutting 540 jobs, as it moves more of its shoemaking to other countries.

title: Help From the Home Doctor
description: A SHORTAGE of stonemasons has been reported in northern Virginia, as greater numbers of the landed gentry compete with their neighbors to build stone walls. Meanwhile, in Greenwich Village, Pottery Barn is selling double-handfuls of pebbles for $19 that people display in water-filled dishes.

title: More Than Enduring, Faulkner Prevails; At Centenary, the Herd Honors a Maverick
description: From Oxford, Miss., to Pirate's Alley in New Orleans to Rennes, France, to Tbilisi, Georgia, scholars and other Faulknerians are gathering today to commemorate the centenary of William Faulkner's birth. Faulkner himself would have been amazed to think he had such a worldwide following.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORF, FLORENCE WAXBERG
description: DORF-Florence Waxberg, 73, of Lake Worth, FL., on September 23, 1997 in Waterbury, CT. Beloved wife of Edwin. Loving mother of Michael, Linda and Andrea. Grandmother of four. Services September 25 at 1 PM, at the Munson-Lovetere Funeral Home, 235 N. Main Street, Southbury, CT.

title: Man Who Built Gatorade Is Hired To Run Pepsico's Biggest Drink Unit
description: Pepsico Inc. yesterday named Philip A. Marineau, the former Quaker Oats executive who was praised for the success of Gatorade but held responsible for the decline of Snapple, to replace Brenda Barnes, who is resigning as president and chief executive of Pepsi-Cola North America, the company's largest beverage division.

title: 'Clean Money' Politics Keeps Fat Cats at Bay
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; World's Fair of Gardens Grow at the City's Doorstep
description: TWELVE plain sheds, along with plots striped with corn, beans, collards, okra and even peanuts and tobacco, emerge from morning fog along Surf Avenue in Coney Island. It is harvest time, and these are Southern family farm gardens, though water comes from the hydrant and morning glories bloom on chain-link, not split-rail fences.

title: Metro Business; Fitzpatrick Planning 2d Irish-Theme Hotel
description: The Fitzpatrick Group, an Irish hotel company, has acquired a 10-story office building near Grand Central Terminal and plans to convert it into the company's second Irish-themed hotel in Manhattan.

title: Design Notebook; At Armory Show, Shocks in the Rearview Mirror
