description: RUFUS FOSHEE, a ceramics dealer from Camden, Me., was talking about his display of 18th-century mocha ware -- all butterscotch bands, ice-blue stripes and polychrome polka dots -- but his words could easily be the leitmotif of the Fall Antiques Show: ''What always impresses me is its infinite variety.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, RITA V.
description: RYAN-Rita V., on September 24, 1997. Formerly of White Plains, New York. Wife of the late Edwin W. Loving mother of Mark and Barbara. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th St., Garden City, Friday 7-9 P.M. Funeral mass Saturday 11 A.M. at the St. Francis Chapel at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y.

title: The New TV Season in Review
description: A Fish Out of Water In a Pacific Setting

title: Calendar; A Dialogue And Tours
description: TriBeCa Tour

title: NORTHWEST ORDERS 50 JETS AND OPTIONS 100 FROM AIRBUS
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation said yesterday that it had formally ordered 50 jetliners from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, and took options for 100 more as it simplifies its fleet by buying planes from one manufacturer to keep maintenance and training costs low. Northwest, which is Airbus's largest customer, signed a preliminary agreement in June to buy the 50 A319 jets, valued at $2 billion. The planes will be delivered between 1999 and 2003. If the options for the 100 additional narrow-body planes become firm orders, they will be valued at $4 billion. Northwest's shares rose $1.25, to $42.875.

title: Community Boards Inviting Feedback on Internet
description: It has become a frustrating refrain for Denise Woodin, district manager of Community Board 8 on Manhattan's Upper East Side: mail out fliers on upcoming meetings to some of the district's 211,000 constituents. Expect a dozen people to show up -- on a good day.

title: MCDERMOTT GETS $35.7 MILLION FROM SALE OF UNIFAB
description: McDermott International, the energy services concern, said its McDermott Inc. unit had received $35.7 million from the sale of its stake in Unifab International Inc. Unifab, based in New Iberia, La., makes decks for offshore drilling rigs. McDermott, based in New Orleans, said it received about $28.7 million from the sale of its 1.7 million Unifab common shares and $7 million from the sale of contractual rights and real estate to Unifab. As a result, it said its second-quarter earnings would increase by about $32 million. In the second quarter of 1996, McDermott posted a loss of $12.4 million, or 27 cents a share, on revenue of $806.9 million. Its shares slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $33.375.

title: Mexican Snubs Visiting Head Of Rights Unit
description: The Mexican Government snubbed the head of Amnesty International, who was visiting to explore reports of growing human rights abuses, officials of the organization complained today. It was the latest of several incidents that have put Mexico at odds with international rights monitoring groups.

title: F.B.I. Files on Lennon Reveal Little Beyond Some Weird Details
description: After a 14-year legal battle by a California history professor, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has released a new cache of material from a 300-page dossier on the late rock star John Lennon, and has agreed to pay $204,000 to cover legal fees incurred in his efforts to open the file.

title: Doubts Rising On Election In California, Gingrich Says
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich suggested today that evidence of voter fraud was mounting in the election of Representative Loretta Sanchez, the Democrat who defeated Robert K. Dornan, an incumbent Republican, in California last year. The accusation outraged Democrats and prompted them to rally anew around Ms. Sanchez.

title: Fuel Standards a Factor in Truck-Related Deaths; Bigger Can Be Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Isles' Rookie Defender Stands Out in a Crowd
description: Zdeno Chara has been the big surprise during the Islanders' training camp, and it is not just because the rookie defenseman is still around.

title: Studying the Causes of His Wounds and America's
description: DRAWING LIFE

title: TV Weekend; It's More Sass Than Help From the World Beyond
description: If you're ABC and you need to shore up your Friday night lineup of shows for young people, where do you turn? To the otherwordly, naturally. These days, witches and angels are tried and true. There's no point in being too imaginative.

title: A Cabinet Member Foresaw Jets' Kicker as a Winner
description: Donna E. Shalala, who knows something about kickers, remembers helping to recruit John Hall when she was the chancellor of the University of Wisconsin.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOURTAKIS, EMMANUEL
description: KOURTAKIS - Emmanuel, in Brooklyn, NY, on September 22, at 79. Cherished husband of Joanna. Devoted father of Evanthia and Kostantinos, and their spouses, Emmanuel and Maria. Adored grandfather of Christina and John. His devotion to his children and sacrifices to ensure their education are deeply appreciated. He was born in Springfield, Mass., but emigrated to Crete, Greece as an infant. After World War II, he returned to start his career in the fur trade. His integrity, good nature and kind heart were known to all. Funeral services will be held on Sunday in his beloved Greece, in the village Astrika, Crete. He will be deeply missed and will live in our hearts forever.

title: Canada Peeved and Puzzled By Big Neighbor to the South
description: It's always something, though rarely has it ever threatened the peace along the world's longest undefended border or amounted to much more than Canada and the United States getting on each other's nerves.

title: Columbia/HCA's Use of Special Medicare Units Under Scrutiny
description: Documents and testimony obtained by Federal prosecutors investigating the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation indicate that some of its hospitals may have used rehabilitation units specifically created for Medicare patients as part of a financial scheme to increase reimbursement illegally.

title: Crude Oil Prices Rise as Iraq Considers Shutting a Pipeline
description: Crude oil prices climbed yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange on fears that Iraq might shut a major export pipeline because of a dispute with the United Nations over the import of spare parts for the pipeline.

title: Steinbrenner Expects Watson Back for '98
description: As general manager of the Yankees, Bob Watson has been badgered and berated and scrutinized and criticized by George Steinbrenner for two years in a job that the team's manager, Joe Torre, has often called the most difficult in baseball. But Steinbrenner is apparently so satisfied with Watson's performance that he has decided to exercise the first option year on his contract and bring him back for the 1998 season.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Television section on Sunday about ''The Gregory Hines Show'' misidentified Mr. Hines's father. He is Maurice Hines Sr., not Earl Hines.

title: F.E.C. Budget Is No Match For Its Task, Panel Is Told
description: An exasperated executive of the Federal Election Commission told a Senate committee today that while campaign fund-raising complaints had skyrocketed his agency was operating in an underfinanced ''triage'' mode, with two-thirds of its cases incomplete and only two investigators able to travel into the field.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth last weekend for last Friday and Saturday nights' performances.

title: Police Report Breaking Up Rings Selling Drugs in Two Boroughs
description: In the largest seizure of heroin and cocaine in the Bronx in eight years, more than $45 million worth of the drugs was confiscated and 16 people were arrested in connection with a drug operation run out of a Bronx delicatessen, the authorities announced yesterday.

title: Carl Icahn's Latest Project: Film Distribution Company
description: Sensing that consolidation in the film industry has created new opportunities for independent distributors, the financier Carl C. Icahn plans to start a film distribution company in New York.

title: When bad things happen to good clients.
description: STYLISH advertisements in October issues of Elle, Harper's Bazaar, Vanity Fair and Vogue magazines present an elegant woman, cool and poised, showing off a large purse slung over her shoulder. As it turns out, the beautiful model isn't the only one holding the bag.

title: Bartoli Puts On a Display Of Coloratura Fireworks
description: A New York musical season comprises many small seasons, and one of them began at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, when the Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli sang in a concert to benefit brain-tumor research at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Ms. Bartoli's current visit is to include another benefit concert, in Katonah, N.Y., for the Caramoor Endowment Fund, on Oct. 4; the leading role in a new production of Rossini's ''Cenerentola'' at the Metropolitan Opera, beginning on Oct. 16, and a Carnegie concert with James Levine and the Met Orchestra on Nov. 9.

title: American Express Reassigns Accounts
description: The American Express Company in New York has reassigned domestic direct marketing accounts with billings estimated at $50 million that an agency resigned because of a conflict. The shifts, announced yesterday, came after Wunderman Cato Johnson in New York resigned because its parent, Young & Rubicam Inc., was awarded the consolidated worldwide account of an American Express competitor, the Citibank consumer banking unit of Citicorp.

title: NORTHROP GRUMMAN SETS SALE OF CARGO VEHICLE UNIT
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Grumman Allied Industries unit to the unit's management as the company sheds some businesses before being acquired by the Lockheed Martin Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Grumman Allied supplies walk-in delivery vehicles and cargo vans used by food and commodity delivery companies. Grumman Allied, based in Sturgis, Mich., has annual sales of about $130 million. The company employs about 1,000 people at plants in 3 states. Northrop Grumman's shares fell $1.125, to $124.8125.

title: Helmsley Turns Over Control of Company
description: Leona Helmsley has turned over control of Helmsley-Spear Inc., one of the city's largest real estate management companies, to her late husband Harry Helmsley's two closest business associates, ending a bitter three-year feud that had hampered her ability to sell off a $5 billion real estate empire.

title: Finding Yarns in Video Imagery
description: In the wave of German artists that washed over Manhattan in the 1980's, Rosemarie Trockel, whose fifth solo exhibition in New York is at the Barbara Gladstone Gallery in Chelsea, was exceptional for being neither Neo-Expressionist nor male. The works for which she became known here seemed to celebrate this fact: they were Minimalist paintings made on knitting machines that insinuated notions of domesticity, everyday life and women's work into the sacred realm of high art.

title: Cone Is Back, Firing Blanks: 5 No-Hit Innings
description: David Cone had a problem. He needed one more solid start to prove his right shoulder was sound, and he was prepared to oppose the Indians in the first game of the American League division series on Tuesday. But Cone did not want to show too much of his snazzy repertory tonight to the same batters he would stare at in five days. What should he do?

title: A 41-Story Tower Is to Rise Over the West Side Y.M.C.A.
description: The Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York said yesterday that it would proceed with a fiercely opposed and long-stalled plan for a 41-story condominium over its branch on West 63d Street, creating one of the tallest residential buildings to overlook Central Park.

title: World Court Leaves Fight Over Danube Unresolved
description: In an inconclusive ruling on one of Central Europe's most vexing environmental disputes, the International Court of Justice in The Hague said today that Slovakia and Hungary had both broken a treaty regarding the diversion of the Danube River for a hydroelectric dam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIN, THELMA BRESENOFF
description: SCHEIN-Thelma Bresenoff. With love and sadness we record her peaceful death at the Hospice of Beth Israel Hospital, NYC, on Sept. 22, age 79. She was retired from the NYC school system, where she'd been a librarian-teacher for many years. Her daughter Louise Schwartzman pre-deceased her by two days. She is survived by husband Abraham Schein, daughter Deborah Epstein, sons-in-law Joel Schwartzman and Mark Epstein and grandchildren Stephen Schwartzman and Leah and Ari Epstein. A memorial service will be held Sun., Sept 28, 2PM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd at 66th Ave, Forest Hills. Shiva will be observed at the Schein residence in LIC from Sept 28-30.

title: French Grocery Chain Raises Hostile Bid
description: Promodes S.A. raised its hostile offer yesterday for Casino Guichard-Perrachon S.A. by 10.5 percent, hoping to undo a friendly bid by Rallye S.A. in its drive to become France's No. 1 supermarket operator. Promodes said it would offer 375 francs for each Casino share, or a total of 22 billion francs ($3.6 billion), up from 340 francs, or 19.1 billion francs. The formerly all-cash bid now includes an optional one-for-seven share swap with certificates guaranteeing a minimum Promodes stock price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKULA, PETER F
description: PAKULA-Peter F. Age 58. Beloved husband of Marlies and adored brother of Judy. Memorial services Frank E. Campbell, 81 St and Madison Ave, Sun, Sept 28, 1:30PM. Contributions in his memory to Columbia Univ., Dept of Neurology, ''Patient Care'', Dr. D. Sciarra, Neurological Institute, Rm 214, 710 W. 168 St, NY NY 10032.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about Senator George H. Pendleton, who in the 1880's pressed for a law restricting the solicitation of campaign contributions by Federal employees, omitted the credit. It was from the United States Senate Historical Office.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about sculptures for an exhibit at the Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center in Connecticut misstated where the photo was taken. It was at the sculpture studio, Studio EIS in Brooklyn, not at the museum.

title: James J. Houlahan, 90, Ex-Chief Of the William Esty Ad Agency
description: James J. Houlahan, a former advertising executive at the William Esty Company, died on Sept. 18 at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 90 and had lived in Ocean Ridge, Fla. and Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: Contest Winners in Recital
description: Since 1979, the Juilliard School has held an annual competition named for the pianist Gina Bachauer, who died three years earlier. The winners get scholarship money and public performances, and on Wednesday the school presented Emi Kagawa and Adam Neiman, pianists who won this year, in a recital in Paul Hall. The concert was broadcast live on WQXR (96.3 FM), the classical music radio station owned by The New York Times, as the season opener of the weekly McGraw-Hill Companies' Young Artists Showcase series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, IRA M.
description: HECHT-Ira M. Life partner for 16 years to James Esposito. Son of David Hecht and the late Donna Belmonte-Hecht. Brother of Victor Hecht. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services are on Wednesday, 1:30 P.M. precisely, Goldsteins' Rosenberg's RaphaelSacks, 6410 North Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19126. Interment in Lawnview Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Gay Mens Health Crisis Center of New York City.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; Street Art: Vintage Gems Shine in a New York Setting
description: ASK a New Yorker to imagine an unbelievable collection of cars, and she might envision a dozen freshly washed cabs, with immaculate interiors and attentive drivers, waiting patiently with medallion numbers invitingly lighted. This weekend, an even more impressive sight will beckon on the streets of Rockefeller Center as the Louis Vuitton Classic presents a multimillion-dollar assemblage of exotic cars, not one of them for hire.

title: Reforming the Tax Collector
description: Irate taxpayers and disgruntled current and former agents of the Internal Revenue Service provided horrifying testimony in the Senate this week depicting a callous, incompetent and abusive agency. A woman testified to a 17-year battle with the I.R.S. during which the agency mistook her husband for another taxpayer. A Delaware man testified that he had paid the I.R.S. $50,000 that he did not owe out of fear of financial ruin if he fought its false accusations. Other taxpayers told of I.R.S. agents who wrongly seized bank accounts, fabricated evidence, ignored exonerating evidence and refused to acknowledge payments.

title: Art in Review
description: Gregory Crewdson

title: El Nino's Wrath: Floods and Tickets
description: It is still early in the ''weather event of the century,'' as some scientists have taken to calling El Nino, which is brewing in the Pacific, threatening a tantrum of odd and calamitous weather late in the year.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Admit Killing New Jersey Businessman, Police Say
description: Three Manhattan teen-agers seized in the murder of Nelson G. Gross acknowledged in videotaped confessions that they abducted him in a robbery plot and promised to release him once they had their money, investigators said yesterday. The decision to kill him was made when it occurred to them that he might identify one conspirator who had worked in his New Jersey restaurant this summer, the investigators added.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Northwest Visions'

title: Court Backs Drug Tests For Transit Police
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that New Jersey Transit could continue to perform random drug tests on its armed police officers.

title: Courts Back H.M.O.'s Over Doctor Honesty; Not Tall, but Healthy
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTAINER SHIP FLEET CONSOLIDATION IS SET
description: The General Electric Company and Sea Containers Ltd. said yesterday that they would combine their container ship operations to cut costs and increase profits. The joint venture, to be called GE Seaco Services Ltd., will operate one of the world's biggest fleets of marine-freight containers, with 1.2 million metal containers and depots around the world. Sea Containers' class A shares rose $1.375, to $27.375, while its class B shares rose $1.5625, to $27.4325. Shares of G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., fell $1.75, to $66.875. Under the agreement, GE Capital will receive 70 percent of any profit from existing operations and Sea Containers, which has its headquarters in Hamilton, Bermuda, will get 30 percent. The two companies will split profits from additions to the fleet.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Villanova

title: Fuel Standards a Factor in Truck-Related Deaths; A Road of Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CABRERA, MARTIN
description: CABRERA-Martin, on September 24, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Lourdes (nee Rodriguez). Loving father of Gerard and Carmela (Mitchell). Beloved grandfather of Martin, Gerard, Andrew and Maximilian. Reposing at the Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street, NYC on Saturday and Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, on Monday at 10 AM, Our Lady of the ScapularSt. Stephens Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: A Baroness's Choices, With a Surprise or Two
description: The ritzy little show (14 paintings, 4 sculptures) titled ''The Spirit of Place: Selections From the Carmen Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection'' at the Frick Collection feels like an A-list cocktail party, celebrity-intensive with a few less familiar faces mixed in.

title: From Boredom to Broken Dreams, Nothing but Trouble in an Academic Family
description: ''The Lay of the Land'' looks like the dud of the week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have to decide, all you young people have to decide, will we stand as a shining example or a stunning rebuke to the world of tomorrow? For the alternative to integration is not isolation or a new separate but equal, it is disintegration.''

title: No-Shows Are Forecast For the Giants Already
description: The weather forecast for Sunday afternoon calls for considerable sunshine. A pleasant day may only accentuate more unsettling conditions for the Giants at Giants Stadium.

title: 2 Agencies to Share Diesel Jeans Account
description: A review for the Diesel jeans worldwide account, which began with Diesel prepared to change agencies, has ended with the account being divided between the incumbent, Paradiset DDB in Stockholm, and a finalist in the review, Lowe Howard-Spink in London. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: At the Movies; For a Fast Plot: 2 Men, Add Bear
description: Art Linson's conversation with David Mamet last year resembled, well, a terse bit of Mamet dialogue. It showed, to some degree, how Hollywood movies are made.

title: Market Place; Signs of Life, and Wall St. Applause, for the Giant of Detroit
description: The General Motors Corporation, a sleeping giant on Wall Street, has reawakened.

title: Suburbanites Pure as Driven Slush
description: When the roads freeze in New Canaan, Conn., during the climactic night in ''The Ice Storm,'' the elegant and deeply disquieting drama that opens the 35th New York Film Festival this evening, everything starts to slide.

title: Blind Turk Is Going to Jail To Find Freedom, He Says
description: A blind lawyer has sat in his apartment for the last few days, waiting for the police to take him to jail so he can begin serving a 23-year sentence after making a speech deemed favorable to separatism.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Runway Project on Schedule
description: Despite an ongoing attempt by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York to block the project, a $92 million runway extension at Newark International Airport is on schedule, the Port Authority said yesterday.

title: Election Agency Woes
description: An executive of the Federal Election Commission told a Senate committee that while the complaints of campaign finance abuses last year have multiplied, his agency has yet to receive emergency financing from Congress to review the questions.

title: Salomon May Lose on Real Estate, Again
description: Salomon Brothers, the venerable investment bank where traders make tens of millions of dollars buying and selling bonds, has never had much luck with its real estate deals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAISLER, HERBERT A.
description: RAISLER-Herbert A. Of Purchase, NY and Boca Raton, Fl. A very special person suddenly left us on September 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Norma. Loving father of Margery Fisher and Richard and Kenneth Raisler and his wife, Sara. Devoted brother of Shirley Medalie. Beloved grandfather of Lauren and Jason Fisher and Caroline, Kate and David Raisler and step-grandfather of Henry and Larry Raisler. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Kol Ami at the Jewish Community Center at 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY on Friday, September 26, 1997 at 10:30AM. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either the Herbert A. Raisler Master of Engineering Fellowship, Cornell University College of Engineering, Office of the Dean, 242 Carpenter Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853-2201 or The Hebrew Technical Institute, 230 Park Avenue, #

title: On Stage and Off
description: Getting Ready For, Yes, Spring

title: Where Men Are Manly and So Are Bears
description: Charles Morse (Anthony Hopkins) is a brilliant billionaire with a nice airplane, a beautiful trophy wife (Elle Macpherson) and a spectacular Alaskan hunting lodge rented as the setting for his latest birthday celebration. According to ''The Edge,'' a barbed, great-looking adventure film written cannily by David Mamet and directed with verve and fury by Lee Tamahori (''Once Were Warriors''), all this is very, very bad. It's soft. It's empty. It's complacent. In terms of manly accomplishment, it can't compare with the thrill of battling a hungry bear.

title: Tale of the Cat Heads Fast Field in Vosburgh
description: A dozen of the best sprinters in the country, led by the 3-year-old stars Tale of the Cat and Kelly Kip, were entered yesterday in tomorrow's seven-furlong Vosburgh, the premier sprint of New York's racing year and the gateway to the Breeders' Cup Sprint six weeks later.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Financial Option for Condo Boards
description: Condominium boards in New York are examining a financial option that, while long available to co-op buildings, had rarely been used by condos until a change in the law made in the recent session of the State Legislature -- the ability to borrow money to finance large repairs and improvements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLINTOCK, JOHN THOMAS
description: MCCLINTOCK-John Thomas. Of New York City. Sept 25, 1997 in Salisbury, CT. Born on April 3, 1909 in Huntington, W. VA., Yale ('31), Harvard Business School ('33). Longtime partner of Wood Walker & Co. Member Downtown Association and University Club. Elder and Trustee of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church and a Director of the Isaac M. Tuttle Fund. Beloved husband and father, he will be deeply missed by his wife of 55 years, Mary B. Mitchell, their three daughters, Mary Dusenbury and her husband Jerry of Attica, KS, Elizabeth McClintock of New York City and Millerton, NY, and Lucy Calhoun and her husband Clay of Covington, GA, 2 grandchildren, Kenneth Dusenbury and his wife Wendy of Harper, KS, & Katie Calhoun of Covington, GA, 3 great-grandchildren, Joseph, Jordan and Jacob Dusenbury, other relatives and numerous friends. The funeral will be at 2:00PM on Sunday, September 28, at St. John's Church in Salisbury, CT.

title: The Mayor's Campaign Overkill
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's re-election campaign kicked into a higher gear this week, then swiftly started skidding downhill. Mr. Giuliani unveiled his first negative television ad, which turned out to be inaccurate. Facts also emerged about his recent appointee to New York City's Campaign Finance Board that made the Mayor's choice seem more and more unsuitable.

title: Congress Passes Spending Bill That Could Keep G.I.'s in Bosnia
description: The House and Senate both passed a $247.5 billion spending bill today that would open an avenue for President Clinton to extend the stay of American troops in Bosnia.

title: David Kriskovich, 56; Devised SWAT Teams for the F.B.I.
description: David J. Kriskovich, who went from serving as a Green Beret in Vietnam to an F.B.I. career where he helped develop the concept of the special weapons team, died on Sept. 17 in a helicopter crash in Bosnia, where he had gone to help that country re-establish its police force.

title: Shirley Clarke Is Dead at 77; Maker of Oscar-Winning Film
description: Shirley Clarke, an Academy Award-winning filmmaker, a champion of independent filmmaking and a missionary for video as a force in communications, died on Tuesday at the Palliative Care Center of Beth Israel Deaconness Medical Center in Boston. She was 77 and lived in Carlisle, Mass.

title: When Equity Is Shorthand For 'Forget It'
description: HAVE you ever found yourself in the following situation?

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''You sold any sea urchins?'' asks the man in the suit, walking behind the counter at the newly reopened Oyster Bar.

title: Metro Business; New Charges Filed At 47th Street Photo
description: The saga of 47th Street Photo continued yesterday, when its former owner and president, Irving Goldstein, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan on new charges of fraud in connection with a bankruptcy filing by the company in 1992.

title: Gingrich Asserts Campaign Bill, Alive in Senate, Is Dead in House
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich today ruled out any chance that the House would pass the major bipartisan proposal for overhauling campaign finance that has been advanced in the Senate.

title: Spare Times; FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: But No State of Emergency Yet : Fire Haze a Disaster, Indonesia Declares
description: KUCHING, Malaysia  As this smokebound city endured another day of choking fumes Thursday, neighboring Indonesia declared a national disaster and called on "all levels of society" to mobilize against the forest fires that have left several countries in the region under a thick, gray haze.

title: Signatures From Yorubaland
description: We tend to think of African sculpture as more or less anonymous, the creations of a tribe rather than a person. But that doesn't fit the work of the Yoruba, the Nigerian culture that is one of the most prolific -- if not the most accomplished -- art-producing groups on the continent. Olowe, Adigbologe, Areogun, Bamgbose, Osamuko and Bamgboye may not exactly be household names to us, but they are masters, some of whom -- Olowe, for instance -- are celebrated outside of Africa.

title: Fried Chicken With Soul Sees a Family Through
description: Exhale a sigh at the simple pleasures of ''Soul Food.'' This new menu movie has a soapy plot, appealing stars, family values, down-home atmosphere and a conviction that there's rarely a problem fried chicken can't cure. There sure are worse ways of looking at the world than that.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: 4th Arrest in Bias Attack
description: A fourth suspect was arrested Wednesday night in what the authorities have termed a racially motivated assault on a black man by a group of whites in Brooklyn last Saturday morning.

title: Emphysema Finding May Lead to Treatment
description: For decades researchers have speculated that it is the body's own chemicals, mustered to defend against irritants, that bring on the inflammation and lung-cell destruction of emphysema, a disease that eventually develops in many people who smoke.

title: Pork-Barrel Spending Totals $600 Million, Report Says
description: The State Legislature set a record for pork-barrel spending this year, doling out more than $600 million on projects favored by individual lawmakers, according to a report released today by an anti-tax group.

title: Will the Real Fiend Please Curl a Lip?
description: If you believe that Elvis still lives or that a millennial invasion of flying saucers is imminent, you might buy the bogus premise behind Christian Duguay's spy thriller, ''The Assignment.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, HILDA S.
description: JACOBS-Hilda S. Formerly of Teaneck, NJ, died Sept. 24, 1997, in Vernon, VT. Wife of the late Isidor Jacobs. Beloved mother of Martin Jacobs, Alice Twombly, Evelyn McLean and Verandah Porche. Sister of Sadye Wexelblatt. Grandmother of Jonathan and David Twombly, Daniel and Michael Jacobs, Oona Adams, Emily Coutant and Ian McLean. Funeral services Gutterman Musicant, 402 Park Ave., Hackensack NJ, Sept. 26, 1997, 11:30 AM. Donations to National Council of Jewish Women, or Hadassah, appreciated.

title: Vote on Transit Plan Is Postponed Again
description: The vote on a $23 billion plan for Federal transportation aid that New York City has threatened to veto was postponed yesterday, for the second time in two weeks.

title: Too Big To Fail
description: The recent consolidation of firms on Wall Street accelerated on Wednesday when the Travelers Group announced its intention to pay $9 billion for Salomon Brothers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, PHILIP
description: GOLDFARB-Philip, peacefully at home after a very long illness. Beloved husband for sixty years of Helen; devoted father of Peter; loving uncle, great-uncle; dear brother of Sidney. Owner of the Goldfarb Novelty Company; longtime member of the Friars and Lone Star Clubs. Service Monday, 12:00 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHON, HERBERT
description: GERSHON-Herbert. Members of Master Truckmen of America mourns the passing of their former Executive Director and esteemed colleague and extend their deepest sympathies to his family. Funeral at Beth-David Cemetery. Graveside #

title: Shoichi Yokoi, 82, Is Dead; Japan Soldier Hid 27 Years
description: Shoichi Yokoi, a Japanese soldier who hid in the jungles of Guam for 27 years rather than surrender to American forces at the end of World War II, died on Monday of a heart attack. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENENHOLZ, MARSHALL FREED
description: DENENHOLZ - Marshall Freed. (1908-1997). Celebrate his life on Sunday, October 5 at 3 P.M., in Manhattan. Call 516-537-1961.

title: Deborah Voigt as a Down-to-Earth Ariadne
description: The title role in Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' has been so central to the soprano Deborah Voigt that she jokingly refers to her international career as Ariadne Inc.

title: New Video Releases
description: Liar Liar

title: Bank Client Makes Off With $32,000 in Cash
description: An unarmed man walked into a branch of Citibank in Flushing, Queens, yesterday and snatched $32,000 in cash that had been left on a teller's counter, the police said.

title: Stock Seesaw Tips Down As Dow Posts Loss of 58.70
description: It has been this way for more than six weeks now, a seesaw battle between those investors who are more bullish and those who are less so.

title: U.S. Doctor on Shuttle to Join 2 Russians
description: The space shuttle Atlantis took off tonight for a rendezvous with the Mir space station after the NASA Administrator decided that Dr. David A. Wolf could replace another American astronaut for an extended stay aboard the Russian craft.

title: Prodigy Splitting Itself Into 3 Business Units
description: Prodigy Inc. is splitting itself into three units to focus separately on its on-line service, the international market and software development and licensing.

title: Racing Taking Healy On a Lifelong Journey
description: The first time Shane Healy was asked to run a mile, the convincing reward was $50 and a promise of free groceries, more than enough for the displaced Irish native trying to fulfill his version of the American dream.

title: Wal-Mart to Pay Staff For Illegal Restrictions
description: Wal-Mart Stores has agreed to pay 933 employees in Connecticut $325,000 in back wages for not allowing them to leave the store during breaks, a violation of state law, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal announced yesterday.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Climb a Hefty 2.7%
description: Record demand for electronic products during August led the third consecutive monthly increase in orders for durable goods, suggesting that the economy continued to expand at a healthy pace.

title: Courts Back H.M.O.'s Over Doctor Honesty; Drugs Won't Stop AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Should Retain Role In Illness Inquiry, Cohen Says
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen took issue today with a White House panel's recommendation in a draft report that the Pentagon should be stripped of its supervision of Government investigations into the illnesses reported by thousands of ailing veterans of the Persian Gulf war.

title: David Brinkley Retiring From Broadcasting
description: David Brinkley's 54-year career as a broadcast journalist, which he has been winding down for a year, will come to a close on Sunday morning, Mr. Brinkley and ABC News announced yesterday.

title: Inside Art
description: 2 Quit Sotheby's For a Venture

title: Family Fare
description: A Victorian 'Peter and Wolf'

title: UNILEVER TO COMBINE THREE UNITED STATES UNITS
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products maker, said yesterday that it would merge the United States operations of Chesebrough-Pond's, Helene Curtis and Lever Brothers into a single company worth about $3.7 billion. The company, whose products range from Magnum ice cream to Calvin Klein perfume, said the sheer size of the new unit would make it more competitive and bring faster growth. The merged unit will operate under the name Unilever Home and Personal Care USA. The three United States consumer products businesses accounted for nearly half of Unilever's United States 1996 sales, which exceeded $8 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBART, JAMES J.
description: WEISBART-James J. Beloved husband of Bayla; devoted father of Cindy and Cathy; grandfather of Olivia; adored brother of Jane Nusbaum of Scarsdale, N.Y. Interment Concord, NH, September 25.

title: Gags That Push the Speed Limit
description: What does it take to get up in front of people and simply be?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIM, SELMA
description: OPPENHEIM-Selma. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation note with sorrow the passing of Selma Oppenheim. Her son, Steven, is an outstanding member of our Board of Directors and a leader in our Business and Finance Division. He served as vice president of the Educational Alliance, a UJA-Federation beneficiary agency. The entire Jewish community is indebted to the family's dedication and support, and express condolences to Steven, Mrs. Oppenheim's daughter-inlaw, Lucille, and her grandchildren, Laura, Michael and Daniel. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: F.C.C. Offers New Options On Wireless
description: Over the sharp objections of its chairman, the Federal Communications Commission approved a plan yesterday to help bidders who say they cannot pay for billions of dollars of wireless-communications licenses.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks were lower this morning. At the midday recess in trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 101.8 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,240.16. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 78.12 points.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 5
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, MANUEL
description: MAXWELL-Manuel. The Board of Trustees of Parker Jewish Institute for Healthcare and Rehabilitation is deeply saddened by the loss of one of its esteemed founders and Past Chairman, Manuel Maxwell. We will remain forever grateful for his visionary leadership and extraordinary devotion to the Institute. He carried forward the work begun by his father-inlaw, Jacob Granowitz, and now so ably continued by his son and our fellow Trustee, Douglas Maxwell. His name will forever be a part of our history just as his deeds will inspire us to perpetuate the mission that was such an integral part of his life. We are indeed diminished in every way by his passing. Our most sincere condolences to Douglas and his mother, Rhoda. David Taub, Chairman David Glaser, President

title: Images Capturing A National Identity
description: In February 1941, Henry Luce wrote an essay for Life magazine titled ''The American Century,'' in which he proclaimed this country the world's most powerful nation as well as its intellectual, scientific and artistic capital. He called on his readers to invent ''our century.'' A current photography exhibition in SoHo, ''The American Century: Photographs and Visions -- Part 1: 1900-1935'' at the James Danziger Gallery, ''gratefully borrows Henry Luce's spirited phrase,'' to quote the show's catalogue. If this exhibition doesn't quite prove that our still photographs could lord it over other countries' as our other means of mechanical production had dominated a world war, these 69 images nonetheless eloquently suggest that the nation was a worthy contender in the photography stakes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESTAINO, R. RAY
description: RESTAINO-R. Ray, of Cliffside Park, NJ, on September 24, 1997. Funeral Saturday 8 AM from Hunt Stellato Funeral Home, 1601 Palisade Ave, Fort Lee, New Jersey. Funeral Mass 9 AM at Church of the Madonna, Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, NY. Friends will be received Friday 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM. Donations to American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer St., Hackensack, NJ in the name of R. Ray Restaino.

title: A Wonderful Summer For Rich and Infamous
description: The stories appeared week by week, most of them wire dispatches, not much bigger than dots on the professional sports landscape. There were lines to be drawn, though, connections to be made. When they were, it spelled out N.B.A., only N stood for naughty, B for battery, A for arrest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, GOLDIE
description: RATNER-Goldie. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation mourn the passing of Goldie Ratner, beloved mother of Shelly Ratner, who has been a dedicated leader and generous supporter of UJA-Federation as Co-Chair of our Apparel Division and as the former Captain of our Vanguard Solicitors Club. To Mrs. Ratner's beloved husband, Milton, and her sons, Shelly and Kenny, we extend our sincerest sympathies. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: FARE DEAL -- The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to expand free transfers to its Long Island Bus system, which would reduce the cost of travel into New York City to as little as $1.50. B3.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYNARD, SAMUEL M.
description: KAYNARD-Samuel M. We mourn the passing of our friend, colleague, teacher and recipient of the Committee's Lifetime Achievement Award. As Director of NLRB Region 29, Regional Attorney of NLRB Region 2 and law Professor, Sam helped shape the law with intelligence, fairness, compassion and a profound understanding of the concerns of labor and management alike. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Anne, and his family. Labor and Employment Committee Association of the Bar of the City of New York

title: Sports of The Times; Nice Gesture Substitutes For Justice
description: THE gold medal is somewhere back in South Korea, the property of Park Si Hun. Roy Jones Jr. has not seen the medal nor the boxer since that horrible September day in 1988 when an Olympic referee ushered the two boxers to the center of the ring for the judges' decision.

title: U.S. Envoy to Nigeria Is Given a Stormy Farewell
description: When Walter Carrington, a lifelong African specialist, became the American Ambassador to Nigeria four years ago, soon after the military leadership annulled the most democratic elections that country had ever held, he knew that his assignment would not be easy.

title: Livio Beccaccio, 58, Trainer Of Future Leaders of Police
description: Livio A. Beccaccio, an F.B.I. official who supervised the training of thousands of local police officers who later rose to leadership in their departments nationwide, was among 12 people killed in the crash of a United Nations helicopter in Bosnia on Sept. 17.

title: Mets' Draft Plan Mixes Health, Wealth and Stealth
description: Some of the lists are delivered by hand, others by overnight express, some through the United States Postal Service, all of them landing on the desk of Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager. Every few weeks, he has asked 14 members of the organization to provide him with lists naming 15 players the club should protect in the Nov. 18 expansion draft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGLIO, PIRO, ROSE
description: VOGLIO-PIRO-Rose. A charming, beautiful, special person. Cherished mother of Rose, Lillian and Diane. Beloved mother-in-law of Ronald, Salvatore and Paul. Adored grandmother (nana) of David, Michele, Mark, Melissa and Salvatore. Dear sister of John. Loving aunt of many nieces, nephews, and dear good friend to many. She lived life with energy and zest. She loved good times with her family and friends. She enjoyed travel, good food, her novels and her shopping trips. She carried her devastating illness with infinite courage, strength and dignity. She will be remembered for her loving ways and caring spirit. Though she will physically no longer be with us, her love, warmth, humor, kindness, generosity of spirit will live inside all she touched. She was the light of our lives, who enriched us all by her very being and gave us the true meaning of family and love which will keep us strong and together. For information, please call the Horne-Dannecker Funeral Home, 212-242-5250.

title: Altar Beckons Eastern Banks; As Giants Emerge, Pairing Off Becomes More Likely
description: Where are the giant East Coast banks?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, REV. RAYMOND J.
description: DAVID-Rev. Raymond J. On September 25, 1997. Pastor-Emeritus of Our Lady of Good Counsel R.C. Church, Inwood, L.I. Survived by his sister Cecile B. David, his nephew Joseph David III and several grandnieces and nephews. He was predeceased by brothers John and Joseph Jr. and sister Katherine David. Will repose Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 PM at Meserole Funeral Home, Inwood. Mass of Transferral Monday 8 PM at Our Lady of Good Counsel Church. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 11 AM. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, North Lawrence.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Close One in Rolex
description: Vicki Sodaro, a 41-year-old sailmaker from Tiburon, Calif., had a tenuous grip on the lead yesterday in the Rolex International women's keelboat championship off Newport, R.I.

title: Fighting Has Already Begun for Both Lewis and Golota
description: The connections for Lennox Lewis, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, and Andrew Golota sounded two familiar themes in some verbal sparring yesterday in preparation for their title fight on Oct. 4 in Atlantic City.

title: Art in Review
description: Lezley Saar

title: In Intel Inquiry, U.S. Regulators Send a Message
description: With its investigation of the Intel Corporation, the Federal Trade Commission is signaling that the Government will continue to closely police the leading high-technology companies that play an increasing role in the economy, antitrust experts and industry analysts said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROMBERG, SUZANNE W.
description: BROMBERG-Suzanne W., of Rockville Centre, New York. The officers, Board, and members of Self Help for Hard of Hearing People/South Nassau Chapter mourn the loss of Sue Bromberg on Saturday, September 20. Sue served as President for three terms, and chaired both our Advocacy and Legislation Committees from 1984 until the time of her death. She was a tireless fighter for access for hard of hearing people under the Americans with Disabilities Act. She established the Assistive Devices Consultation Center at the Oceanside Library. She was the consummate role model for hard of hearing people and the mainstay of our Chapter. A memorial service will be held at the Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre on Saturday, September 27, from 3:005:00 PM. Sue is survived by her husband, William L. Bromberg, of Rockville Centre, a daughter, Elissa, of Manhattan, a son, Jonathan; daughter-in-law, Jan; and two grandchildren, Jennifer and Jeffrey, all of Redmond, Washington. She also left behind a legacy of service to hundreds of hard of hearing people. Donations may be made to SHHH/South Nassau Chapter, PO Box 533, Oceanside, New York 11572-0533.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JUDITH S. KAYE, Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, received the Corning Award for Excellence given by the Business Council of New York State, a trade organization that represents 5,000 businesses. The first jurist to be so honored, Judge Kaye responded with remarks that were anything but stuffy on Wednesday at the Sagamore Resort in Bolton Landing.

title: Verkhny Lars Journal; Vodka Bottleneck Contains a Volatile Political Mix
description: Eldar Porolashvili has been stranded here on the border between Georgia and Russia since mid-July, sleeping in a truck with 10 tons of raw alcohol for making vodka.

title: Irishwomen Find Niche (And It's Not In Kitchen)
description: Ireland, where women have traditionally been relegated to second-rate status, finds itself in the middle of a presidential campaign in which all four candidates are women.

title: Clinton Awards Medals In Arts and Humanties
description: The White House announced this year's winners of the National Medal of Arts and the National Humanities Medal yesterday. The honorees are chosen by the President, and the medals are given to those who have made significant contributions in their fields.

title: What's Playing at the Film Festival
description: The 35th New York Film Festival opens tonight with screenings of ''The Ice Storm,'' directed by Ang Lee, and closes on Oct. 12 with ''Live Flesh,'' directed by Pedro Almodovar. The festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, includes 26 programs representing 18 countries. All films are shown at Alice Tully Hall, with the exception of the late show tonight and ''Live Flesh'' on Oct. 12, which will be at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KANTOR, SHEPARD M.D.
description: KANTOR-Shepard M.D. A memorial service will be held Sunday, September 28; at 3 P.M., Ansche Chesed Synagogue at 100 Street and Westend Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSON, MARILYN (NEE WEISENSEEL)
description: PEARSON-Marilyn (nee Weisenseel), 69 years. Formerly of Stamford, CT. On September 22, 1997 in San Luis Obispo, CA. Beloved of Henry Gillis. Adored mother of Mark and Suzanne. Loving sister of Richard Weisenseel. Former wife of Kenneth Pearson. Fervid supporter of the Economic Opportunity Commission charities. Visiting at John J. Fox & Sons, Inc, 201st St and Grand Concourse, Bronx, Friday 6PM-9PM. Services Saturday 10:30 AM at the Funeral Home. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. She will be deeply missed and always remembered.

description: U.S.G.A. Seniors

title: Toast of the Hudson Valley Vineyards
description: When Prohibition more or less dried up the nation in 1920, the Brotherhood Winery in Washingtonville, N.Y., then as now America's oldest continuously operated winery, focused on medicinal and sacramental wines. ''You would not believe the number of customers who said they were doctors and priests,'' said Cesar Baeza, the president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWELL, ALLEYNE CARLETON JR.
description: HOWELL-Alleyne Carleton Jr., age 85, of Fairfield, husband of Jean Field Howell, died Tuesday, September 16, 1997, in Bridgeport Hospital of heart failure. Mr. Howell lived on Greenfield Hill in Fairfield. He founded and until recently managed the Howell Corporation, Stratford, which designs and manufactures electric systems for application in the United States and abroad. He attended Saint Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, and graduated from Yale University in 1934. He also received a degree from the University of Virginia Law School. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II achieving the rank of Captain. In addition to his wife he is survived by a son, Alleyne C. Howell III of Vershire, Vermont; a step daughter, Beverly Borger of Jacksonville, Florida; a brother, John Howell of Greenwich; and two grandchildren.

title: Classical Music and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLEY, EDWARD J. JR.
description: FOLEY-Edward J. Jr., of New Vernon, on September 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan Poole Foley. Father of John C. and Edward J. III of Morristown, Matthew Wicks Foley of Haddonfield. Grandfather of five and great grandfather of one. A memorial service for family and friends will be held Monday, Sept. 29, 11 AM, at the First Presbyterian Church Lee's Hill Road, New Vernon. On Tuesday, September 30th at 4 P.M. a memorial service will be held for employees, customers and business associates at Our Lady of Mount Virgin Church, Harris Ave. Middlesex, N.J. The Foley family requests that contributions be sent to the Bancroft School, Attn: Bev Mertz, Hopkins Lane, P.O. Box 20 Haddonfield, N.J. 08033-0018 or the Visiting Nurse Assn of Somerset Hills, P.O. Box 478, Gladstone, New Jersey 07934. For further information contact Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home, 908-766-0250.

title: West Bank Settlers See New Fuss Over Old Plan
description: The Jewish settlers in this town of red-roofed houses sprawling across the hills south of Bethlehem say they cannot understand the dismay that the State Department has expressed at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's pledge on Wednesday to add 300 new homes here.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: Grand Slam Cup

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROSS, DAVID T.
description: KROSS-David T., 90, of Boca Raton, on September 24th, 1997. Formerly of Nyack, NY. For information, Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, 800-992-9262.

description: To the Editor:

title: Long Island Commuters, M.T.A. Has a Deal for You
description: They sound like the kind of deals Crazy Eddie would offer if he were a suburban travel agent: Babylon, Long Island, to Riverdale in the Bronx, a distance of about 50 miles, for the low, low price of $1.50. Oyster Bay to Staten Island for the same fare. But sometime next year, such fares could become routine. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has begun the process of expanding the free bus-to-subway transfer program it started in July to its Long Island Bus system.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: I.R.S. Official Apologizes For Agency Mistreatment

title: LaFontaine Aside, Rangers' Big Worry May Be Leetch
description: The buzz around Madison Square Garden these days concerns Pat LaFontaine, the Buffalo Sabres' former All-Star center. But the buzz there last night concerned Brian Leetch, the Rangers' All-Star defenseman, whose right wrist is sore again, one week before the regular season opens.

title: Metro Business; Newspaper Price War
description: To the mutual insults and one-upmanship practiced on each other by two scrappy newspapers, add another weapon, a price war on Sundays. The Daily News, its Sunday circulation injured by competition from the new, and less expensive, Sunday issue of The New York Post, announced yesterday in the paper that it would cut its price, from $1.50 to $1, starting Sunday. The Post, which has lost money for Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation since the company reacquired the paper four years ago, responded by announcing that its Sunday price would fall, from 50 cents to 25 cents, on Oct. 5.

title: From the Global Village, New Composers' Voices
description: Joel Sachs casts his net widely in forming the New Juilliard Ensemble's programs, as he is rather bound to do. For one thing, student performers and student listeners (though sadly there were not many of the latter in evidence at the ensemble's first concert of the season on Tuesday evening) deserve to be exposed to the full variety of contemporary music worldwide. For another, if Mr. Sachs and his players do not bring us, say, ''Crossing II'' by the Azerbaijani composer Franghiz Ali-Zadeh, who will?

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Running times and ratings of films are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: Planet Hollywood Hotel Deal Is Completed
description: The Vornado Realty Trust and a developer from Singapore said yesterday that they had completed their $159 million purchase of the 1,700-room Hotel Pennsylvania in a partnership with Planet Hollywood International. The partners added that they planned to spend an additional $40 million to turn the 20-story building, on Seventh Avenue opposite Madison Square Garden, into a sports-theme Official All-Star Hotel.

title: Woods Up Early, And Montgomerie Stands in the Way
description: If Colin Montgomerie really wanted to face Tiger Woods, he got his wish.

title: MetroStars Are Eliminated And Star Player Is Ejected
description: The MetroStars sported a league-high six players with World Cup experience, but they could not fashion a winning record. They endured the humiliation of being told they could no longer play on grass -- theirs. Because of injury and World Cup qualifying duty, they had to reshuffle their lineup 30 times in 31 games. And tonight at Giants Stadium, their season of indignities peaked when they failed to reach the playoffs in Major League Soccer.

title: Pataki Signs Bill Criminalizing Improper Use of 'Special K' Drug
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today criminalizing the improper possession and sale of ketamine, an animal tranquilizer that has become popular on the club scene under the street name of ''Special K.''

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUBER, FLORIAN
description: STUBER-Florian. The English and Speech Department of The Fashion Institute of Technology mourn the loss of Professor Florian Stuber, a superb teacher, a distinguished scholar, and a beloved colleague. His outstanding contributions to the Department and the College will be long remembered.

title: Fuel Standards a Factor in Truck-Related Deaths; Fending Off Wild Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Video
description: 5 Men and a Suit, Finally on Film

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Dispute in Italy Is Conjuring Up Its Terrorist Past
description: On May 17, 1972, Luigi Calabresi, the police commissioner of Milan, was shot dead on his way to work. His slaying was a harbinger of the political violence that was to grip Italy for the next several years as terrorists on the right and the left waged a vicious war against one another and claimed hundreds of innocent victims.

title: Art in Review
description: Gillian Wearing

title: VIAD ACQUIRING GAME FINANCIAL IN $50 MILLION STOCK SWAP
description: The Viad Corporation has agreed to acquire the Game Financial Corporation, a provider of cash services to casinos, for about $50 million in stock. Phoenix-based Viad, a diversified company, said it would issue common stock valued at $10.75 for each share of Game Financial. Viad said Game Financial, of Plymouth, Minn., would become part of its Travelers Express unit, which processes payments for financial institutions and money order issuers. Game Financial's shares slipped 50 cents yesterday, to $10.125. Viad's shares rose 18.75 cents, to $19.3125.

title: SASSABY DEAL OPENS MASS MARKET TO ESTEE LAUDER
description: The Estee Lauder Companies agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Sassaby Inc. in a move aimed at expanding its line of cosmetics aimed at preteen and teen-age girls. Terms were not disclosed. Sassaby owns the cosmetics brand Jane, which tries to appeal to 12- to 19-year-olds in the United States. Jane includes face, lip, eye and nail products. The acquisition will move Estee Lauder into the mass market, Peter Schaeffer, an analyst at SBC Warburg Dillon Read Inc., said. Jane products, all of which cost $2.99, are sold in major drugstore and discount chains. Sassaby, based in Hunt Valley, Md., has annual retail sales of $30 million to $50 million. New York-based Estee Lauder is one of the world's leading makers of skin care products, makeup and fragrances.

title: Art in Review
description: James Angus

title: Inflation Fear Drops Prices Of Treasuries
description: Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday to a nearly two-month low as reports on durable goods orders, jobless claims and home sales rekindled investor fears that the economy might be growing too fast.

title: Public Advocate Rivals Accuse Each Other of Opportunism
description: The candidates for the office of Public Advocate met last night in a contentious debate largely highlighted by dueling charges of political opportunism.

title: My New York; Tales of New York For Young Listeners
description: On a recent weekend afternoon, four little girls hunkered down on scratchy museum carpeting and listened hard to a story about a famous 6-year-old named Eloise who lived at the Plaza hotel.

title: Seafood
description: It's easy to forget that New York City was once a busy seaport, with all the boisterous excitement that came with sailors returning from the far corners of the world or preparing to voyage out. Fish houses and chowder shacks were natural outgrowths of the bustling waterfront, while raffish lobster palaces appealed to a sophisticated Broadway crowd. Nowadays, that waterfront is barely a memory, and New York's best seafood restaurants are temples of culinary creativity. Still, these seafood restaurants are all reminders of the city's watery ties. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Transit Drug Tests Upheld
description: In one of the first two opinions by the recently appointed Chief Justice, Deborah T. Poritz, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that New Jersey Transit can continue to perform random drug tests on its armed police officers.

title: Albert Lost His Case, His Job and His Dream
description: As a boy daydreaming in his Brooklyn bedroom, Marv Albert always planned on becoming a sportscaster. And he grew into one of the greatest basketball announcers ever with the Knicks and then with NBC.

title: Britain May Join Euro by 2000, Paper Says
description: The British Government is considering joining Europe's planned single currency as early as 2000, a year after the currency, the euro, is scheduled to start, The Financial Times of London reported early today.

title: She's a Lonely Widow, He Appreciates Antiques
description: There's a feverish ''Body Heat'' quality to ''Elmore Leonard's Gold Coast,'' but this story has a different color scheme. In Mr. Leonard's Miami Beach, the sunlight is always just a little too bright. Everyone, from the criminally rich to the struggling drug dealer next door, has huge windows or sliding glass doors with views of blue-green ocean and lots of sky. And the stars are two of television's best and brightest redheads: David Caruso and Marg Helgenberger, he at his most quietly intense, she looking rich-lady glamorous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROSE, SHARON
description: AMBROSE-Sharon. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club mourn the loss of their esteemed Member, Friar Sharon Ambrose on September 23, 1997. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Private services were held. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALIN, JOSEPH V.
description: VALIN-Joseph V. Beloved father of Paul Valin. Visitation Saturday, September 27, 1997, 12 Noon-1 PM. Religious services 1 PM, CassidyFlynn Funeral Home Inc., Mount Kisco, New York (1-800-244-6634).

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; 7 Accused of Rigging Bids
description: The owners of seven school bus companies in Monmouth and Ocean Counties were charged yesterday with rigging bids for public transportation contracts totaling more than $2 million, state and Monmouth County officials said.

title: Art in Review
description: Lucky DeBellevue

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 11 about Joanne Winship, who was active in many charity benefits in New York City, misstated the year of her marriage to Alexis Thompson. It was 1953, not 1956. The error was pointed out in a letter to The Times last week.

title: Striving to Erase Grace And Turn Up the Heat
description: The saxophonist Sam Rivers turned in a wonderfully unbalanced set on Wednesday night at Sweet Basil, where he will be performing through Sunday. At 74, Mr. Rivers has become intent on destroying the ritual distance of seriousness that most jazz performances maintain, and he went at it by shouting during the music, telling jokes between songs and jumping around.

title: In 'New' Britain, Politicians Take Stock at Party Conferences
description: Autumn in Britain sends politicians flocking to seaside resorts as surely as leaves fall, but the round of annual party conferences this year is taking place in a landscape dramatically altered from past seasons by electoral upheaval.

title: Courts Back H.M.O.'s Over Doctor Honesty
description: To the Editor:

title: Messinger Visits a School, but the Press Is Excluded
description: It had seemed set: Ruth W. Messinger, the Democratic candidate for mayor, would be the guest teacher at a social studies class in Queens. She would walk 26 students through a discussion of government, newspapers and civic duty, with a group of reporters on hand to record a fairly routine campaign event.

title: Babbitt Assails G.E. Over Delay In Ridding Hudson of Chemicals
description: The Secretary of the Interior, Bruce Babbitt, speaking from a hilltop overlooking the Hudson River, assailed the General Electric Company today as a corporate giant bent on delaying the restoration of the Hudson River and weakening a Federal program for cleaning toxic sites.

title: Fuel Standards a Factor in Truck-Related Deaths; Separate Parking
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Nicholas Krushenik

title: APPLAUSE, A NOVELTY MAKER, SOLD TO MANAGEMENT GROUP
description: Applause Enterprises, a privately held maker of gifts and collectibles, has been acquired by a company formed by Applause's management and the Frontenac Company, a Chicago investment firm. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Applause, which has annual sales of about $175 million, specializes in marketing plush toys, collectibles and novelty items through gift shops, toy and stationery stores and similar outlets. The company, which is based in Woodland Hills, Calif., near Los Angeles, was sold investment concerns including Shamrock Capital Advisers, Apollo Advisers and the Loews Corporation.

title: The Cold War Is Back, Nuclear Bombs and All
description: The camera crosses over a bombed-out courtyard at a Sarajevo apartment house. It moves into the book-lined home of an erudite piano teacher who is gently giving a lesson to a young girl. In the language of ''The Peacemaker,'' which is filled with catchy and ironic juxtapositions like this one, this scene can mean only one thing. The gentlemanly teacher is planning to blow up New York.

title: Marv Albert Pleads Guilty And Is Dismissed by NBC
description: Marv Albert, whose staccato play-by-plays helped make him one of television's most distinctive and ubiquitous sportscasters, ended a trial filled with embarrassing testimony about his sex life by pleading guilty today to a misdemeanor count of assault and battery.

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Antiques
description: Auction House Tests New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, NELSON
description: GROSS-Nelson. Of Saddle River, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Noel. Cherished son of Albert and the late Rose. Devoted father of Dinah Mills and Neil. Dear brother of Paul and Michael. Loving grandfather of Eliza and Jacob. Services private. For information ''Gutterman - Musicant,'' 1 - 800 522-0588. Period of mourning at residence, on Friday, 4-7 P.M., Saturday and Sunday, 12-4 PM.

title: In Little Rock, Clinton Warns Of Racial Split
description: Speaking from the steps of Little Rock Central High School, the same steps climbed 40 years ago by nine pathbreaking black students and their paratrooper protectors, President Clinton warned Americans today of the dangers of racial separation and pleaded with them not to give up on the idea of integration.

title: Chancellor to Keep Teacher in Her Job In Parents' Victory
description: In a victory for parents who raised $46,000 to keep a teacher at a public school in Greenwich Village, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that the teacher could stay, but he ordered the local school district to pay her salary, not the parents.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED REPURCHASING 16.4 MILLION SHARES
description: The seed giant Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. opened a tender offer yesterday to buy back about 20 percent of its common stock, amounting to about 16.4 million shares. Des Moines-based Pioneer made the offer by means of a Dutch auction, in which a company sets a price range within which a stockholder can specify a minimum price to sell his shares. The lowest price at which the company can buy all the stock it seeks becomes the purchase price. Pioneer set a range of $88 to $104 a share, and said the offer would run through Oct. 23. The move follows Pioneer's sale last month of a 20 percent stake to DuPont for $1.7 billion. Pioneer had said it would use proceeds to buy back stock. Pioneer's stock fell $1.1875, to $91.875.

title: Fuel Standards a Factor in Truck-Related Deaths; Bad Birthday Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: Fuel Standards a Factor in Truck-Related Deaths; Raise the Gas Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Bohemia: It's East of SoHo And Still Unspoiled
description: At certain hours, say about 11:30 on a Friday night, it seems more guitars are being carried along Ludlow Street, between Houston and Stanton Streets, than on any other block in New York City. On that block of the Lower East Side, some musicians are finishing up sets at the Mercury Lounge, the Luna Lounge or Arlene Grocery; others are knocking off rehearsal and climbing up from the basement of Ludlow Studios. Still others appear to be just lugging their instruments up and down the block, perhaps hoping to hook up a serendipitous gig.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Warning for Health Insurers
description: The chairwoman of the Assembly Policy and Regulatory Oversight Committee warned insurers yesterday that if they do not cover new cancer treatments given as part of clinical research projects, they will be forced to.

title: DIRECTOR OF I.R.S. ISSUES AN APOLOGY FOR AGENT ABUSES
description: The acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service issued an extraordinary public apology today to four individual taxpayers -- and, by extension, to all American taxpayers -- for severe mistreatment at the hands of agency officials. The tax official, Michael P. Dolan, also promised immediate changes to eliminate incentives for misconduct and make the I.R.S. more responsive to public complaints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYE, ROBERT H.
description: MAYE-Robert H. On September 24, 1997. Assistant Controller of General Host. Beloved husband of Joan. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62 Street, Friday at 11 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVEMBER, LILLIAN REISS
description: NOVEMBER-Lillian Reiss. In addition to being a loving mother and devoted grandmother she was a loving sister to Ida and Louis Bobrow of Jamaica Estates, New York and Lake Worth, Florida, and Bess and Herman Glaster of Delray Beach, Florida.

title: Our Unfair Share
description: Last week, a fellow parent of a fourth grader at Public School 41 phoned to ask me to bring $360 to school to help pay the $46,000 needed to save a teacher's job. I said no. Even after the caller explained that the teacher's 24 students would be absorbed into the remaining fourth grade classes, I refused not because I couldn't afford to pay, but because I didn't believe it was the right thing to do.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DORIS KEARNS GOODWIN, the Presidential historian, does not often get flustered in the presence of powerful figures; she is, after all, the biographer of the Roosevelts and Kennedys, as well as Lyndon B. Johnson. But meeting Rachel Robinson this Sunday will inspire more than a bit of awe.

title: Excerpts From President's Comments on School Desegregation
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech today commemorating the 40th anniversary of the desegregation of Central High School, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service:

title: Principal Took Tests Home, Says Report On Tampering
description: The principal of an award-winning elementary school, who was forced to resign in a test-tampering scandal, acknowledged to investigators that he took standardized tests home overnight, newly released documents show.

title: Kodak to Cut 200 Senior and Middle Management Jobs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, looking for ways to arrest the downward spiral of its profits, said yesterday that it would cut more than 200 senior and middle management positions, or about 20 percent of its worldwide management work force. It also said it would trim at least 10 percent of its general and administrative staff.

title: Art in Review
description: Project Painting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUSS, SYLVIA SCHOFLER
description: DRUSS-Sylvia Schofler, 101 years, September 24, 1997 in Riverdale, NY. Beloved wife of the late Louis A. Devoted mother of Viola Rosenheck and the late Adelle Wolff. Dear mother in law of Alfred R. Wolff, and the late Dr. Kenneth Rosenheck. Adored grandmother of six grandchildren and sixteen great grandchildren. She was an active volunteer in several organizations in White Plains, NY throughout her lifetime with special interests in the Red Cross, Education and Nursing Homes. Services will be private. For those who wish, contributions may be made to the White Plains Beautification Foundation, Inc., PO Box 1614, White Plains, NY 10602 or to your favorite charity.

title: Umpires Named for Division Playoffs and League Series
description: The American and National Leagues have named the umpiring crews for the divisional playoffs and League Championship Series.

title: Military Aid in Bad Hands
description: American foreign policy has long been stained by the use of Washington's military aid abroad against innocent civilians. American weapons have supplied death squads. Aid designed to fight drugs has instead often gone to fight guerrillas whose activities concern foreign militaries more. Human rights groups even charge that American-supplied helicopters have been used to strafe villages.

title: On My Mind; Solution for Bosnia
description: The United States has no exit strategy from Bosnia -- a failure almost as shocking as its entrance strategy.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Bad Cuticle In Close-Ups Of Romance Tells It All
description: Despite the downtown marquee value of its cast and the presence of Martin Scorsese as its executive producer, Matthew Harrison's ''Kicked in the Head'' is as amateurish as it is woebegone. In a charmless urban comedy with almost nothing on its mind, every scene looks like an outtake. The camera embarks on a personal mission to embarrass the actors. The overused image of the Hindenburg, as a metaphor for the hapless hero's love life, is all too appropriate here.

title: Sonics' Kemp Gets Wish And Is Traded, to Cavs
description: Shawn Kemp's desire to be traded from an organization he did not trust anymore was fulfilled last night when the Seattle SuperSonics sent him to the Cleveland Cavaliers in a three-team deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEJW, EDWARD
description: TEJW-Edward. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia, devoted father of Dorothy Ann and Donald Kirsch, loving grandfather of Mark Adam, Rebecca Hoffman, and Jonathan Bradford. Adoring and adored great-grandfather of Joshua, Saul, Zachary Wolf, Yosef and Aryeh. Funeral service Friday 12 noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: My New York; Where Your Destiny Is in Your Hands and the Pot's the Limit
description: New Yorkers can play poker in Atlantic City, if they don't mind giving a share of their winnings to Donald Trump or Steve Wynn. They can play in Connecticut, if they want to make a personal contribution to redressing the injuries done by somebody else's forebears to American Indians in the Northeast. They can play in joints around Manhattan that require a membership fee and charge rent for occupying a chair.

title: Albright Insists Netanyahu Undercuts Talks
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today pointedly rebuked Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for promising to build 300 new homes for Israeli settlers in the West Bank, saying the decision undercut already faltering efforts to revive talks with the Palestinians.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Rebukes Netanyahu

title: Art in Review
description: Terence Main

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEHOE, MARTIN J.
description: KEHOE-Martin J. Of Rosedale, on Sept. 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Matilda (nee Heine). Dear brother of Grace Freibaum of Long Branch, NJ and the late Jeremiah, William, Harry, Josephine, Evelyn and Mary. Also survived by numerous, loving nieces and nephews. Born in Manhattan, served in WWII, 18th General Medical Army Corp & worked for Bankers Trust. In lieu of flowers, donations to the L.I. Epilepsy Foundation and St. Francis Hospital, Pediatric Unit. Visiting Saturday & Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Rosedale F.H., 245-01 Francis Lewis Blvd, corner Sunrise Hwy, Rosedale. Mass Monday, St. Clare's R.C. Church, 10:15 AM.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Liquor Curbed on Boardwalk
description: The Avalon Borough Council has passed two ordinances intended to help maintain the beach resort's family oriented atmosphere by forbidding any business on the boardwalk to have a liquor license.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; New Rule on Horseshoe Crabs
description: The State Marine Fisheries Council voted 5 to 3 yesterday to let commercial fishermen return to trawling for horseshoe crabs starting Sunday, despite objections from some environmentalists who say the diminishing numbers of horseshoe crabs are endangering several species of birds that feed on the crab eggs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LESLIE FAY CO., New York, said Dickstein Partners had agreed to raise its stake in the women's clothing maker to 40 percent and named two of its officers to its board.

title: A Michigan Coach Keeps Rising to the Challenge
description: He moved into an office in Schembechler Hall late last winter. Terry Malone grew up 40 minutes from here. He had returned to the campus in the summers as a young football coach, sharing information and learning the business. Now he was part of the University of Michigan staff, an offensive line coach, a high-profile position with problems nearly as large as the expectations.

title: Alomar's Season on the Edge; Despite Efforts to Avoid It, Controversy Dogs the All-Star
