description: Early this season, an umpire made what appeared to be a bad call on a pitch that struck out Roberto Alomar, and his Baltimore teammates in the dugout and in the bullpen held their breath, waiting to see what would happen next.

title: Leap Partnership To Handle Michelob
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that it had named the Leap Partnership in Chicago to handle its Michelob beer brands, which had been handled by the Glennon Company in St. Louis. Billings have not been determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRON, HELEN
description: CITRON-Helen, on September 25, 1997. Beloved wife of Dan. Devoted mother of Andy and Amy Dubow. Loving grandmother of Rachel, Jared, Risa, and Erica. Services Friday, 12 Noon, at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Dial Makes Acquisition
description: The Dial Corporation said today that it had acquired Nuevo Federal, an Argentine maker of household products, for $35 million. Dial, the soap and consumer products maker, said Nuevo Federal had annual revenue of $60 million. Under the deal, the company will open a manufacturing plant in Buenos Aires by the end of 1998. Dial said the acquisition was part of its plan to grow internationally. The company, which is based in Phoenix, had 1996 revenue of $1.41 billion.

title: Executive Files For Bankruptcy
description: Mark Whitacre, the former Archer Daniels Midland Company executive and F.B.I. informant, has filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Inventing Shapes To Tease The Mind And Eye
description: In Rome a few years ago, Richard Serra saw the oval volumes of Borromini's Church of San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane and wondered, what would it be like to make a sculpture in the form of a torqued ellipse? Imagine a wide belt of steel standing on its edge to form an oval enclosure but twisting so that its top and bottom are not aligned. Now imagine a belt the size of a trailer.

title: Abroad at Home; Kafka In America
description: The prisoner has been in solitary confinement for 17 months. There is no charge that he has ever committed a crime. He is held as a danger to the security of the state -- on the basis of evidence that he is not allowed to see and cannot answer.

title: Stealth Bomber Is Latest in String of Failures
description: To the Editor:

title: Yawney Joins Hawks
description: The Chicago Blackhawks signed the free-agent defenseman Trent Yawney yesterday, returning him to the city where he began his National Hockey League career.

title: 2 Advertisers End Sponsorship of an ABC Show
description: A week after ABC began ''Nothing Sacred,'' a television series about a somewhat hip and self-doubting Roman Catholic priest, the show has lost sponsors following a campaign led by a Catholic group.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Stanley Grover, an actor, misstated his performance history. He did not create the title role in the 1956 Broadway musical ''Candide''; the part was played by Robert Rounseville.

title: Listening for the Message And Sometimes Finding It
description: At the beginning of the recent movie ''She's So Lovely,'' there's a continuous shot from the air of an industrial American town. You see bridges, factories, chimneys, a river, some streets. But there are no landmarks. You want to put into context what you're looking at, but you don't know where you are.

title: Art in Review
description: Alison Saar

title: Metro Business; New First Ave. Apartments
description: A parking lot and two small apartment buildings on the southwestern corner of 82d Street and First Avenue in Manhattan have been sold to a real estate company that plans a 22-story luxury apartment building for the site. The terms of the deal, which was announced yesterday, were not disclosed. But Aby Rosen, a partner with the new owner, RFR Holdings L.L.C., said the building would be a $70 million to $80 million project tentatively called the Wellington Tower.

title: Courts Back H.M.O.'s Over Doctor Honesty; In Search of Diet Magic
description: To the Editor:

title: Off Drugs, Off Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: A Passion for Polo, Stable to Chukker
description: In years past, during the month of August, my friends and I would watch the polo matches in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where the world's highest-ranked players galloped down the fields, swinging mallets after a little wooden ball, while cotton-clad spectators sipped Champagne.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 10 about Hans J. Eysenck, the psychologist, included an incorrect reference to his work on extroversion and introversion. He carried out extensive research on the topics, but he did not coin the terms.

title: PBS Buys BBC Show For Tiniest Children
description: A new BBC show whose target audience is children not yet able to speak, and whose main characters have television screens in their tummies and speak only babbling baby talk, has just been sold to the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Citicorp and First Union Buy Into Integrion
description: Citicorp and the First Union Corporation agreed yesterday to buy stakes in Integrion Financial Network, an electronic banking and payment venture owned by I.B.M. and 16 North American banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RAE
description: SCHWARTZ-Rae, on September 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Lester and Mara; and Martin and Dorothy. Loving sister of Jenifer Roth and the late Bertha Wechsler. Caring grandmother of Richard and Joyce; Ralph and Victoria; Lisa, and Theodore, and greatgrandmother of Carly, Keith and Spud. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with an article about the emerging entertainment scene around Ludlow Street in Lower Manhattan misidentified the act at the Arlene Grocery rock club. It was Debbie Schwartz, not the Schramms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZER, DAVID JOHN
description: SELTZER-David John. Age 71. Died in Tucson, AZ, September 24, 1997. Formerly of Cliffside Park, NJ. Survived by his wife of fifty years Faye, sons Cliff A. (Elaine) and Brad M. (Tina) Seltzer and six grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at 9 AM on Sunday, September 28, 1997 at East Lawn Palms Chapel, Tucson, Arizona. A private family committal will be held on the ''Mountains High''.

title: Clinton Presses for Change In Campaign Financing
description: Hours before appearing as the big draw at a $600,000 fund-raising dinner here for the Democratic Party, President Clinton today castigated politicians for not being sincere about curbing the influence of money in politics and asserted, ''We desperately need to reform the way we finance our campaigns.''

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS AGREE TO PUT OFF DEADLINE ON ARMS
description: The United States signed a package of arms control agreements today with Russia that pushed back by five years one of the major treaties of the cold war, but that could clear the way for further cuts in nuclear weapons.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: New Jersey

title: Schools Aren't Alone in Getting Private Money; Corporate Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: Flawed F.D.A. Reforms
description: The Senate-passed bill to reform the Food and Drug Administration is an improvement over previous Congressional attempts to overhaul the agency, but it still weakens the F.D.A.'s ability to protect consumers.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW ; Amid Anguish and Beauty, A Son and a Dying Mother
description: To perhaps the deepest and most complex of human relationships, the Russian filmmaker Aleksandr Sokurov brings the eye of a masterly painter and the sensitivity of a poet.

title: T. Emmet Clarie, 84, Judge At Long Trial of Nationalists
description: T. Emmet Clarie, the Federal judge who presided over the most complex criminal case in Connecticut history -- the six-year-long legal proceedings against Puerto Rican nationalists charged with stealing $7 million in 1983 -- died on Wednesday at Day Kimball hospital in Putnam, Conn. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYNARD, SAM
description: KAYNARD-Sam. To Anne and family, fond remembrances of a great guy. I speak for Alan, too. Renee Gallay

title: Moscow Circus Struggles in Orlando
description: As part of the Moscow Circus, Svetlana Nugzarov and her family performed daring acrobatics on galloping stallions to packed houses all over the world, including in this city. But upon their return to Orlando this year, the Nugzarovs received standing ovations from as few as 50 people.

title: Kellstrom Aircraft Deal
description: Kellstrom Industries said today that it had agreed to buy commercial aircraft and jet engines from the Aerocar Aviation Corporation for $20.3 million in cash. The aircraft and engines are under operating leases. Other details were not provided. Kellstrom, based in Sunrise, leases and sells aircraft, jet engines and parts. Aerocar Aviation, based in Miami, is an independent engine leasing company.

title: Injuries to Two Key Guards Have Knicks Concerned
description: Allan Houston, in Harlem yesterday to shoot a public-service announcement, arrived on the set with just one star demand: he needed his hand therapist in his trailer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTY, RAYMOND A.
description: CHRISTY-Raymond A., on September 25, 1997, of Mineola. Beloved husband of the late Marie. Loving father of Marie Gabrielle Christy and Michael Christy, M.D. A loving father who will be greatly missed. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, Monday 10 A.M. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Mental Health Association or Dr. James Cavanagh, appreciated.

title: A Fatal Quake Shatters Fresco In Assisi Shrine
description: Two earthquakes hit central Italy with a one-two punch today, killing at least 10 people and sending parts of the vaulted inner roof of the Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi crashing to the ground, damaging the 13th-century frescoes on its walls and ceiling.

title: Unhurried, Reno Ponders the Proper Course in a Political Storm
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's aides have become accustomed to her laborious style of decision-making. After numbing hours of meetings, she retreats to her fifth-floor Justice Department inner sanctum -- a cozy corner office with a soft couch and easy chairs, a cheery stone fireplace (where Bobby Kennedy once grilled hamburgers) and bullet-resistant windows installed during a scare over Colombian hit men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, TYLER DAVID
description: NORTON-Tyler David. Beloved son of Amy Norton (nee Littlefield) and Michael Norton of Upper Montclair, N.J. Taken all too soon in his eleventh day of life. He will be dearly missed by parents, grandparents, family and friends. We love you ''wiggle worm''.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: A Company Man Succeeds as Astros' Manager
description: He has been with the company 33 years, back to when it was the Houston Colt .45s and he was a pitching phenom called up on his 18th birthday. Larry Dierker made his pitching debut memorable. He struck out Willie Mays in his first major league inning.

title: Max Berking, 80, Executive And Democratic Leader, Dies
description: Max Berking, an advertising executive who became an influential figure in Westchester County Democratic politics, died on Wednesday at the home of his daughter, Charlotte Berking Zanecchia, in Alford, Mass. He was 80 and had lived in Northport, Fla., since his retirement in 1982.

title: Poll Finds Broad Support For Interleague Schedule
description: Americans who are interested in baseball favor interleague play and the designated hitter, but are divided over realignment and whether Bud Selig should remain the acting commissioner, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, LEONARD W., D.M.D.
description: HARRIS-Leonard W., D.M.D. Of North Hills, New York, September 26th, 1997. Beloved husband of Miriam and the late Jacqueline, brother of Mildred and Helen. Graduate of Dartmouth College, 1937, and Tufts School of Dentistry, 1941. Served as Captain in the U.S. Army Dental Corps overseas during World War II. Former member of Dental Staff, at Long Island Jewish Hospital. Services 2 PM, on Sunday, September 28, RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, (516487-9600). All donations to the Women's League of Israel.

title: Vallone Softens Measure On Religious Persecution
description: Under pressure from some of the city's most powerful business leaders, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, is planning to scale back a measure that would bar the city from doing business with companies that operate in 15 countries where he said he believed that Christians are being persecuted.

title: Early Fugard on One Note: Sorrow
description: The paths that cross in ''Hello and Goodbye,'' Athol Fugard's bleak 1965 domestic drama, could not be more twisted. Johnnie Smit is a reclusive manchild weakened to the point of neurological collapse by an emotionally barren family; his older sister, Hester, is a hardened refugee from the household who has turned to prostitution for sustenance.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CASUAL TRADING -- The New York Stock Exchange, where dress codes have been in force since the late 18th century, marked its first dress-down Friday. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VIG, LOUIS
description: VIG-Louis. My precious husband, and Ivan, my adored son. On your birthdays, thank you for the unforgettable 56 beautiful years together. Your heartbroken Sophie and family.

title: It's No Small Feat as Braves' Belliard Hits a Rare Homer
description: Rafael Belliard hit his first major-league home run on May 5, 1987, and he did not hit another for more than 10 years. But last night, after 1,869 at-bats without a homer, Atlanta's tiny backup infielder struck again, at Shea Stadium.

title: Liberties; J.F.K., ABC and Me
description: Peter Jennings and Seymour Hersh have ears full of cider.

title: 2 Paramedics Face Inquiry Over Surgery In Emergency
description: New Jersey health officials are investigating the actions of two paramedics who performed an emergency Caesarean section on Thursday to deliver the baby of a woman in North Bergen who was in cardiac arrest and could not be revived.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a plan by the Federal Communications Commission to help bidders of wireless communications licenses misstated the position of the commission chairman, Reed E. Hundt. He voted for the overall plan; he dissented on only one of its four parts.

title: Saudi Sentences for 2 Britons May Be Eased
description: A senior Saudi official said today that he expected the controversy over the sentencing of two British nurses charged with the murder of an Australian colleague in Dhahran in December to be resolved without execution or flogging.

title: ROUNDUP
description: B.C. Open

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AND MANAGEMENT CO., Denver, a real estate investment trust, said it and some limited partners had acquired an apartment complex in Miami Beach for $63 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Long Denial Keeps Rose From Hall
description: WHILE he begins the painful process of living the rest of his life, Marv Albert might take a look at the enduring case of Peter Edward Rose, an object lesson in denial.

title: In the Human Anthill, Room for Individuality And a Sense of Dignity
description: For most people the will to live, even in hard times, is more than a determination to survive. It is an unquestioning, ebullient zest for being sensate in the world. This humanistic perception was the rock-bottom insight of the great Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami's last two films, ''And Life Goes On'' and ''Through the Olive Trees,'' which were shown in the New York Film Festival in 1992 and '94. Both films portrayed Iranian farmers rolling with the punches of nature and almost cheerfully rebuilding their lives after a devastating earthquake.

title: Slaying Witness Aids Defense
description: A witness testifying today in the murder trial of an off-duty police officer placed the bat-wielding victim only five and a half feet from the officer's father when the officer shot him, far closer than earlier witnesses had said.

title: ITT SAYS VNU SOUGHT TO BUY DIRECTORIES UNIT
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that VNU N.V., a Dutch publisher, offered in April to buy its telephone directory business for as much as $2.2 billion in cash but that the two companies had failed to agree on the terms. The tax structure sought by VNU was impossible to accomplish, an ITT spokesman said. The Hilton Hotels Corporation, however, which is waging a hostile campaign to acquire ITT, contends that ITT did not want to sell the directories business because it was key to its plans to keep Hilton at bay by separating into three companies, according to a document Hilton filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. ITT and Hilton will go before a judge on Monday, who will rule on whether ITT can spin off its hotel and casino operations into one company and its technical schools into another, leaving the telephone directory business as a third company.

title: Asfordby Journal; Laborite Power Is Little Help To Dwindling British Miners
description: The three men in blue public-works coveralls weeding the shoulder of the road just up from the clattering conveyor belts of the Asfordby coal mine were asked where the plant entrance was.

title: Nazi Gold Scandal Spreads to Brazil
description: To the Editor:

title: Possible Aid for Mud Study
description: Researchers who are studying ways to decontaminate mud dredged from clogged channels in the Port of New York and New Jersey could receive $3 million in Federal aid under a bill approved yesterday by a House and Senate conference committee. The measure now goes to the full House and the full Senate.

title: YACHT RACING: A Slow Start; To an Around-the-World Race
description: We are crossing the treacherous Bay of Biscay near the coast of Spain and my watch on deck is next. Boats have been known to break apart in the Bay of Biscay because of the storms that frequent the region. But the winds have been so light and variable that the most treacherous thing about the voyage to date may have been my lunch, an unidentifiable freeze-dried something that resembled couscous with vegetables.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, NELSON GERARD
description: GROSS-Nelson Gerard, on Wednesday, September 17, 1997, after succumbing to an unprovoked vicious attack by three thugs who inflicted multiple stab wounds to his chest and back. He is the beloved husband of Noel; the loving father of Neil and Dinah; the devoted brother of Michael and Paul and the adoring son of Albert. A private funeral service was celebrated on Friday, September 26. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to The Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation, Inc., or The Harness Retirement and Youth Foundation where endowment funds will be established in the memory of Nelson Gross. For information, Gutterman-Musicant 1-800-522-0588.

title: A Proper Funeral For Baby Angelica; The Staff of a Long Island Courthouse Adopts and Buries an Abandoned Newborn
description: Regular business at the Nassau County District Courthouse came to a halt today for the funeral. Led by police motorcycles, a procession of buses and cars followed the hearse, wending the short route from the courthouse to Greenfield Cemetery.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: IMMUNEX SHARES SOAR ON NEWS OF DEAL TO SELL NEW DRUG
description: Shares of the Immunex Corporation rose 10.7 percent yesterday after the American Home Products Corporation agreed to pay the biotechnology company as much as $100 million for the right to sell its rheumatoid arthritis drug, Enbrel. Immunex shares rose $6.375, to $66.125. Shares of American Home rose $1.5625, to $70.9375. Enbrel is in the final stages of clinical testing and has shown positive preliminary study results. Immunex said it expected to seek approval from the Food and Drug Administration next year.

title: Strutting Their Own Stuff; Department Stores Pushing In-House Clothing Labels
description: On the second floor of Macy's in Herald Square, within sight of a rack of Calvin Klein jeans and around the corner from the Polo Ralph Lauren shop, is a collection of like-minded clothing for women. There are smart starched shirts, colorful knit sweaters and three-button wool jackets -- the armor of women who earn their living in an office.

title: Carey Aware of Fraud Scheme, Some Aides Reportedly Tell U.S.
description: Aides to Ron Carey, president of the teamsters' union, have told Government prosecutors and a Federal election overseer that he had general knowledge of a fraudulent scheme in which union money was donated to several liberal groups that, in exchange, had their donors contribute to his re-election campaign last year, officials involved in the investigation say.

title: Anti-Dumping Duties Against Japanese
description: The International Trade Commission voted 3 to 0 today to back the imposition of punitive anti-dumping duties against the Vector supercomputers produced by the NEC Corporation and other Japanese manufacturers.

title: On the Murky Trail of Stolen Art
description: It was late morning and the No Name Restaurant on Fish Pier was deserted.

title: Coke Expands in Russia
description: The Coca-Cola Company said on Thursday that it planned to invest $116.5 million to open four plants in Russia. The plants bring the Atlanta-based company's investment in Russia to $600 million. The new plants will be in Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East; Krasnoyarsk, in central Siberia; Nizhny Novgorod, in central Russia, and Rostov-on-Don, in southern Russia. The Vladivostok plant is fully owned by Coca-Cola, while the other three are joint ventures with local companies.

title: Skittish About Growth in Sleepy Hollow
description: General Motors has proposed transforming the hulking automobile factory that was the clanging heart of North Tarrytown into a luxurious development that could be the humming new center of Sleepy Hollow.

title: DURAMED TO MAKE PRESCRIPTION DRUG FOR PARKE-DAVIS
description: Duramed Pharmaceuticals Inc. entered a long-term agreement yesterday to make a name-brand pharmaceutical for the Parke-Davis unit of the Warner-Lambert Company. Financial terms were not disclosed. Duramed said that the Food and Drug Administration had not approved the prescription product but that Warner-Lambert would file for approval in 1998. As part of the agreement, Warner-Lambert guaranteed a refinancing loan for Duramed's manufacturing plant in Cincinnati. Duramed will use part of the loan to pay off an existing loan from Johnson & Johnson. Separately, Duramed said it extended a marketing and distribution agreement with Johnson & Johnson's Ortho-McNeil unit for some products. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Hong Kong Developer Raises Jardine Stake
description: The billionaire property developer Li Ka-shing raised his stake in Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd. to 4 percent. The 69-year-old executive made the investment though his main companies, Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd. and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SAMUEL
description: STEINBERG - Samuel. Devoted husband of Rose, father of Frances, and grandfather of Helen, Heather and Sally.

title: Irking U.S., Yeltsin Signs Law Protecting Orthodox Church
description: Spurning appeals from the United States, President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a new law today that protects the Russian Orthodox Church from competition with other Christian faiths.

title: Laws in Plain English
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ALEXANDER. MD.
description: WOLF-Alexander. MD. On September 25, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Tony Prince and the late Florence Interrante. Loving brother of Dr. Harriet Strachstein and the late Dr. Abner Wolf. Dear uncle and good friend. He was the originator in psychiatric analysis in groups and the Diegophrenic concept, Dean Emeritus of the Contemporary Center for Advanced Psychiatric Analytic Studies, long-term faculty member of post-grad center for mental health, author of six books and over 100 articles on psychiatric analysis in groups, Diegophrenal, and submersive personalities. Dr. Wolf was world famous. Service Sunday, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam

title: NBC Also Questioned Book on Kennedy
description: After agreeing to pay more than $2 million for the rights to make a film based on a book on John F. Kennedy, NBC abruptly ended production on the project last spring because of ''serious questions'' about the authenticity of documents on which part of the book was based, an NBC executive said yesterday.

title: Religion Journal; A Times Square Religious Landmark
description: Over the last few years, the neighborhood around Times Square has undergone a much-heralded revival. Grittiness has given way to glitter, as pornographic theaters have moved out and tourist-friendly shops and restaurants have arrived.

title: Federal-Mogul Offers to Buy T & N for $2 Billion in Cash
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, an ailing maker of auto parts now showing signs of recovery, said today that it had offered to pay about $2 billion in cash to buy the British auto supplier T & N P.L.C.

title: A Way to Break the Impasse on Global Warming
description: If global warming were a Communist plot, there would be a treaty to combat the peril by now. Instead, only two months before representatives from industrial and developing nations are scheduled to meet in Kyoto, Japan, to agree on steps to counter the threat of climate change, it is becoming ever more clear that five years of negotiations have produced little that is meaningful.

title: Savard Scores Again as Rangers Top Devils
description: While trade rumors still circulate, the rookie center Marc Savard emphatically stated his own case one more time tonight. In the Rangers' final preseason game, he scored a late goal to beat the Devils, 1-0, at Continental Arena. The goal was his team-high sixth of the preseason.

title: Vigilant Police Panel
description: To the Editor;

title: Test Ban Treaty Should Remain Absolute
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Prepare to Start Without Cone
description: David Cone had ice wrapped around his right shoulder, a vacant look on his flushed face and concern accenting his voice tonight as he discussed whether he will be sound enough to start Game 1 of the division series against the Cleveland Indians on Tuesday.

title: Schools Aren't Alone in Getting Private Money; Fund-Raising Helps
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ELLEN
description: LAZAR-Ellen. It is with profound sorrow that we announce the untimely passing of our beloved Ellen. Devoted wife of Laurence. Cherished mother of Jason and Jodie. Dear sister of Susan, Michael, and Robert. Loving daughter of Sylvia Heidenberg and wonderful friend to many. Her life was filled with the joy of living. Her courageous death will be an inspiration to all those who knew her. Ellen will live in our hearts forever. Service is on Sunday, September 28, 1997, at 11:15 A.M., at The ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: One to a Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Manages A Small Gain For the Week
description: A revised Government estimate of second-quarter gross domestic product that showed economic growth was slower than expected fueled a rise in stocks yesterday, pushing broad market indexes higher.

title: How to Be a Hit? A Whodunit Has the Solution
description: The biggest attraction in the history of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a place usually associated with symphony, ballet and opera, is a freewheeling, audience-participation comedy about a murder in a beauty parlor. ''Shear Madness,'' which celebrated its 10th anniversary this week, has been seen here by nearly 1.5 million people. It is Washington's longest-running play. In Boston, ''Shear Madness'' has been running almost 18 years, and it has just had its 15th anniversary in Chicago.

title: WARNACO TO BUY COMPANY THAT MAKES CALVIN KLEIN JEANS
description: The Warnaco Group reached an agreement on Thursday to buy Designer Holdings Inc., a maker of Calvin Klein jeans, for $353.7 million in stock, the companies said. The terms are unchanged from the initial agreement, which was announced last week. Designer Holdings shareholders will receive 0.324 of a share of Warnaco for each Designer Holdings share, valuing Designer Holdings shares at nearly $11 each, based on the average closing price for Warnaco stock over the last eight trading days, the companies said. Designer Holdings shares closed at $9.875 yesterday, up 18.75 cents. Warnaco shares fell $1.5625, to $31.875. The acquisition gives Warnaco, which already makes Calvin Klein underwear and accessories, more control over the Calvin Klein clothing business.

title: Ryder Cup Opponents Play It Close
description: When darkness fell tonight, neither the American team nor the European team could claim a clear advantage at the Ryder Cup.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the House & Home section on Thursday with an article about community gardens in New York City misidentified the man at the garden at 115th Street and Madison Avenue. He was Omar Valentine, who founded it, not Albert Rivera, an artist who works there.

title: F. W. Zuckerman, Former Treasurer Of 3 Corporations
description: Frederick W. Zuckerman, a former treasurer of the Chrysler Corporation, RJR Nabisco and the International Business Machines Corporation, died on Sept. 19 at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan at age 63.

title: Australian Bank Buys Stake in E.D.S. Unit
description: Commonwealth Bank of Australia, one of Australia's four biggest commercial banks, said yesterday that it paid about $240 million (Australian), or $174 million (United States), for a 35 percent stake in the information technology services company EDS Australia. The transaction is part of an agreement under which the Electronic Data Services Corporation of Plano, Tex., is taking over all of Commonwealth Bank's information technology functions.

title: ATLANTA CONCERN BUYS TENNESSEE RESTAURANT OPERATOR
description: Port Royal Holdings Inc. acquired the Krystal Company for $109 million, Krystal said yesterday. Under the deal, Port Royal, which is privately held, will pay $14.50 for each of Krystal's 7.5 million shares outstanding and assume $37 million in debt. Port Royal, which is based in Atlanta, will merge Krystal, a restaurant operator in Chattanooga, Tenn., into one of its units and make it a private company. Krystal owns and operates 249 restaurants in eight Southern states.

title: Sharpton Is Rebuffed In Quest for a Runoff
description: A state judge has rejected the Rev. Al Sharpton's bid for a runoff in the Democratic mayoral primary, saying there was no evidence of ''false votes or any excessive miscounting'' in the Sept. 9 vote and no basis to question the result.

title: Schools Aren't Alone in Getting Private Money; Give the System a Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L.: WEEK 5
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: Police Say Teen-Ager Died For His Sneakers and Beeper
description: They were children growing up on the edges of Crown Heights and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, spending their days trying to dress cool and act tough.

title: 24 Top Mafia Figures Get Life Sentences in Sicily
description: A court in Sicily convicted and sentenced Salvatore Riina, the chieftain of the Sicilian Mafia, and 23 top lieutenants to life sentences today for their role in the killing of Giovanni Falcone, the prosecutor whose work and dramatic death in 1992 made him the hero and martyr of Italy's war against organized crime.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Saturday about the entertaining of business clients at strip clubs referred incompletely to an employee of Capitol Design Inc., who said he had done such entertaining. The entertaining occurred before he joined Capitol Design; the company says it prohibits such practices.

title: Mid-Atlantic Seafood Industry Is Suffering
description: While scientists say a toxic microbe that has killed millions of fish in Middle Atlantic waters this year poses no threat to fish-eaters, state officials in Maryland and Virginia say the outbreak is severely hurting their seafood industry.

title: 'Soft Dollar' Case Charges Filed
description: A general partner at the First New York Securities Company was indicted on tax charges on Thursday in a case stemming from a Government investigation of the ''soft dollar'' practices of brokerage firms.

title: Businessman Recalled as Victim of Greed
description: Nine days after he was abducted and slain in a $20,000 robbery, Nelson G. Gross was remembered at a private funeral in New Jersey yesterday as an astute political strategist, a community-spirited business and family man and a tragic victim of senseless cruelty and the greed of strangers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUBAS, JONATHAN
description: YUBAS-Jonathan. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Jonathan Yubas. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife Susan, his children Jessica, Marissa and Natalie. Leon Fassler, President Monty Davis, Secretary

title: Rose Asks Baseball To Let Him Back
description: In the eight years and one month since he was banished from baseball for life, Pete Rose has often talked about wanting to get back in. Yesterday he made his first formal attempt at a comeback. With the odds overwhelmingly against him, the game's career hit leader applied for reinstatement in a letter to Bud Selig, the acting commissioner.

title: Data Show Economy Grew at 3.3% Pace in Spring
description: The economy grew at a 3.3 percent annual pace during the spring, new data showed today, somewhat slower than was previously thought but still faster than what most analysts consider the economy's speed limit, above which inflation would revive.

title: Schools Aren't Alone in Getting Private Money; A $46,000 Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Shifts Ways It Sells Computers
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it planned to simplify how it sells computers to dealers to put its products in more stores.

title: SBC to Sell Stakes In 2 Cable Systems
description: Prime Cable said yesterday that it would acquire, with the backing of the Carlyle Group, two cable television stakes from SBC Communications for $887 million.

title: Union Fighting for Officer Who Refused Gay Group's Medal
description: A police officer who was suspended after refusing to accept a medal for valor from a gay officers' organization has touched off a storm of protests, pitting union leaders who say he was unfairly punished against gay officers who are calling for further punitive measures.

title: A Fuddy-Duddy Who Discovers Youth
description: John Hurt is simply wonderful -- acerbic, funny and heartbreaking -- in the role of a fusty English writer who, to his astonishment, is seduced by the beauty of the new. Some of that beauty belongs to the American teen-age heartthrob on whom the writer develops an insane crush. Some of it also belongs to the modern-day wonders like film, television and pizza of which he has been unaware. ''Does the 20th century play any part in your life?'' an interviewer asks him early in the story.

title: Investor Put Pennsylvania School Assets at Risk, Officials Say
description: School districts across Pennsylvania face the loss of more than $70 million that they invested with a financial adviser who secretly ran up big trading losses, Federal regulators said yesterday.

title: DAI-ICHI KANGYO TO SELL 20% OF STOCK OF U.S. SUBSIDIARY
description: Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd., Japan's fifth-largest bank in terms of assets, plans to sell 20 percent of the stock of its United States financial subsidiary, CIT Group Inc., after obtaining permission to list the stock on the New York Stock Exchange, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Dai-Ichi Kangyo owns 80 percent of CIT, which is based in Livingston, N.J., and provides financing to corporate customers. The Chase Manhattan Corporation owns the remaining 20 percent. CIT has $20 billion in total assets and shareholder equity of $2.2 billion.

title: Tennis; ROUNDUP
description: Grand Slam Cup

title: Torn by Debt and Questions, Party Meets to Chart Course
description: Against the backdrop of mounting questions about fund-raising, the Democratic National Committee opened a two-day meeting here deep in debt and searching for ways to get its message out -- but at a much lower cost than before.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY TO ACQUIRE TALLEY INDUSTRIES
description: The Carpenter Technology Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Talley Industries, which develops air-bag technology and makes aerospace products, for $185 million in cash plus assumed debt. Carpenter, based in Reading, Pa., makes specialty metals. Under the agreement, Carpenter will pay $12 for each of Talley's common shares; $11.70 for each of Talley's series A preferred shares, and $16 for each of Talley's series B preferred shares. A minority group of holders representing about 9 percent of Talley's shares called Carpenter's bid ''unsatisfactory'' and said Talley should allow other companies to bid on its divisions individually. Shares of Talley rose $1.125, to $12.5625, while Carpenter Technology rose $1.25, to $47.5625.

title: The Saints' Ditka Shows He Hasn't Lost His Fire
description: Mike Ditka knows his image.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRNE, EILEEN (NEE REILLY)
description: BYRNE-Eileen (nee Reilly). On September 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Thomas. Devoted mother of Thomas, Jr. & Gerard. Loving grandmother of Megan & Gavin. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, at 10:30 AM, St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point, L.I. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Mets, Playing It Safe, Won't Rely on Hundley
description: There is always the chance that catcher Todd Hundley will quickly recover from the major elbow surgery he had yesterday. There is a chance the Mets' slugger could be swinging a bat in spring training and be back in the lineup sometime in April. But the Mets cannot count on this.

title: Ernest J. Parham, 93, Witness in a Rights Case
description: Ernest J. Parham, whose riveting account of one of the century's most appalling racial atrocities prompted the Florida Legislature to provide the survivors a measure of compensation more than 70 years after the fact, died last Saturday at a hospital near his home in Orlando. He was 93.

title: Worms Shares Surge After Bid Is Cleared
description: Shares of Worms & Compagnie surged yesterday on their first day of trading after French stock regulators cleared the French businessman Francois Pinault's hostile $4.8 billion takeover bid for it. Mr. Pinault is making the bid through his family holding company, Artemis. Worms shares immediately rose above the 410 francs ($69.33) that Mr. Pinault offered a week ago in his bid. During the day, the shares rose as much as 8.9 percent, to 431, before retreating to 427.9 ($72.36) at the close of trading, up 8 percent.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'll always wear a suit and a tie to work. This is an institution that's been around for a long time and we have an image to uphold, a certain demeanor. I don't think you want to see someone trading millions of shares in dungarees and a ripped shirt.''

title: 'E.R.' Live: Get the Taping Crew Back, Stat!
description: At least the dead man didn't breathe, and there were no ''Three Stooges'' collisions as the docs raced into the trauma room. Maybe there should have been. The live ''E.R.'' on Thursday was something the show has never been before and isn't likely to be again: terminally dull.

title: Data Showing Slower Growth Helps Treasury Bonds to Rally
description: Treasury bonds rallied yesterday as the Federal Reserve entered the market as a buyer and a revised figure for gross domestic product in the second quarter showed the economy growing at a slower pace than previously reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROSE, SHARON
description: AMBROSE-Sharon. The force behind the successful Music Resources Division of EMI Music Publishing. Raised in Worcester, MA., Ms. Ambrose attended the University of Connecticut and received a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Theater in 1968. Her early positions in New York City were with International Famous Artists and the Talent Group. She started the Ambrose/Nanni Agency, which eventually became The Ambrose Company. In 1989, she joined EMI Music with the challenge to build a new service-oriented department to assist music users in finding the right songs. In 1996, Ms. Ambrose was made Vice President of that department. Her warmth, her knowledge of music, her genuineness and her deep commitment to the music and writers she represented brought affection and respect from her colleagues. Ms. Ambrose was also a Friar and was involved with various charities. She is survived by her father William J. Ambrose, her sister Janice Ambrose and brother William P. Ambrose, DVM. A memorial service will be held October 6th, 10:30AM at the New York Center for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, NYC. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society, 800-227-2345 and the Animal Rescue Fund, 718-205-8607.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHLMAN, ERNEST
description: MEHLMAN-Ernest. The family of Ernest Mehlman, his beloved wife Rae, his children Diane Schiff, Rabbi Daniel Mehlman, Evelyn Liker, and Chani Dear announces that the funeral will take place on Sunday, September 28, at 11 A.M., at Shomeri Adath Chapels, 3803 14th Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. Shiva will be observed at 223 Beach 140 Street, Belle Harbor, NY until Wednesday, October 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNOFF, EDITHE L. (NEE ZINN)
description: KRASNOFF-Edithe L. (nee Zinn), Sept. 24, 1997, in Buffalo, NY. Wife of the late William. Daughter of the late Samuel and Mary Zinn. Oldest sister of the late Alex, Rose and Sadie; aunt of Judith Cane, Joel Zinn, Gene Grabiner, Howard and Mara Verman. Sister-in-law of Michael J. Verman, Harold Grabiner, Sylvia Zinn, Frances Krasnoff, & Faye Patch. Family and friends will meet at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd at 76th Rd, Forest Hills NY, Sunday, September 28 at 1:30PM. Graveside services will follow at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. No prior visitations. For information, Delaware Park Memorial Chapel, Inc., Buffalo, NY, 800-784-1990

title: German Court Sentences Serb To Life for Genocide in Bosnia
description: A German court convicted a Bosnian Serb of genocide and other charges today in the killing of Muslims during the war in Bosnia, and sentenced him to life in prison.

title: Whitman Makes Issue of a Critic's Marital Dispute
description: For the last year, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has repeatedly called for a clean campaign driven by issues, like the economy and taxes, and not by personal attacks. But when the Democrats renewed questions this week about a state-paid settlement of a sexual harassment case against a prominent Republican, it was the Governor who got personal.

title: Market Reform Irreversible, Chinese Leader Tells U.S.
description: In his first meeting with a senior American official since consolidating his power as China's leader, President Jiang Zemin told Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin today that he was irreversibly committed to the wide-ranging economic reforms already under way here.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Blow Against Mafia

title: Overhaul of Public Housing Is Voted to Aid Working Poor
description: The Senate voted today to revamp public housing across the nation by making room for a greater number of the working poor and retooling rent policies that some say favor the unemployed.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW ; Unconventional Route To Playing a Good Guy
description: After a career spent playing psycho killers and lesser criminals, Eric Roberts moves with remarkable ease into a good-guy role as John Olansky, the head of the F.B.I.'s major cases unit in Los Angeles. Though the gimmick of ''C-16'' is that he leads a group of unconventional agents, (''This is not your father's F.B.I.'' is ABC's tag line), this is a well-paced but familiar variation on the crime series.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Arthur Rutledge, 90, Leader Of Labor Unions in Hawaii
description: Arthur A. Rutledge, who arrived in Hawaii as a young stowaway from Seattle in 1934 and stayed to become one of Hawaii's most powerful union leaders ever, died on Monday at Kaiser Medical Center in Honolulu. He was 90 and lived in Honolulu.

title: Assemblyman Fights Indictment, Citing Grand Jury Site
description: From the reaction of a skeptical Federal judge, it appeared yesterday that lawyers for Assemblyman Dov Hikind might be tilting at windmills -- or, to be more precise, at office buildings -- in an effort to throw out an indictment charging him with receiving illegal payoffs.

title: Parcells Strives for More From the Special Teams
description: Because he believes the Jets' special teams are on the verge of breaking out, of becoming a successful unit earlier than he had hoped, Coach Bill Parcells is once again going to deactivate the flashy rookie punt returner Dedric Ward and replace him with the almost-forgotten Alex Van Dyke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGAZINER, WALLACE ROBERT (BOB)
description: MAGAZINER - Wallace Robert (Bob). Died peacefully on September 24th. in his home after a long illness. Loving brother of Elliot, loving uncle of Leni Johnston and Phyllis Shea and good friend whose many devoted friends helped him through these two difficult years.

title: Asia's Forest Disaster
description: The thick smoke spreading throughout Southeast Asia apparently claimed 234 more lives yesterday, when an Indonesian airliner lost its way in the haze and crashed. The smoke, coming from forest fires on the Indonesian island of Sumatra and the Indonesian part of Borneo, now blankets Singapore, Brunei and parts of Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand.

title: Schools Aren't Alone in Getting Private Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Adrift Between Dream and Fairy Tale
description: There comes a point late in Wojciech Has's teasingly labyrinthine three-hour film, ''The Saragossa Manuscript,'' when so many phantasmagoric stories have sprouted out of one another in such rapid succession that the mind begins to reel. Questions of who did what to whom and which adventures were charades invented by characters who revel in deceit, and which were not, begin to blur into a surreal comic vision of a world in which reality and fantasy are indistinguishable. Or at least they become so in the mind of the film's genially swashbuckling protagonist.

title: Marubeni Plans Venture With Generale des Eaux
description: The Marubeni Corporation, a Japanese trading company, said yesterday that it would invest 100 billion yen ($827 million) along with Generale des Eaux of France, a municipal services and construction group, for a venture to promote social infrastructure development in Asia.

title: Judge Rejects Runoff for Sharpton, Saying Votes Are Valid
description: A state judge yesterday rejected the Rev. Al Sharpton's bid for a runoff in the Democratic mayoral primary, saying there was no evidence of ''false votes or any excessive miscounting'' in the Sept. 9 vote and no basis to question the result.

title: Constitution Is Stealth Issue of 1997, Attracting Strong Feelings
description: New York politics is creating some of the strangest bedfellows these days: the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Sierra Club with the Conservative Party and Change New York, the antitax group; Mario M. Cuomo with the Business Council of New York State and B. Thomas Golisano, the Perot supporter who ran against Mr. Cuomo three years ago.

title: Bridge
description: Almost all bridge players are consistently ethical and moral at the card table. The exceptions are in two groups: the ones who have not learned enough to know better, and a much smaller group who know better but are determined to win at all costs.

title: Fairness and Single-Sex Schools
description: Since its opening a year ago, the Young Women's Leadership School, an experimental all-girls public middle school in East Harlem, has been at the center of a thorny controversy. Offended by the exclusion of boys, the New York Civil Liberties Union and other civil rights advocates filed a complaint with the Federal Department of Education, charging that the school violates the Title IX prohibition against sex discrimination.

title: Fielder Says Steinbrenner Spoiled His Year
description: Cecil Fielder was talking tonight about how important laughter was for his mental state after he returned to the Yankees to pursue a post-season roster spot 10 days ago. But he frowned in expressing bitterness toward George Steinbrenner for not signing him to a three-year, $21 million contract extension before the season.

title: 3 Skulls Found Under Home
description: Construction workers renovating a home in Ridgewood discovered three skulls -- but no other human remains -- beneath the floorboards yesterday, prosecutors said.

title: British Stocks Surge At Hint of Euro Shift
description: Stocks in London surged following a newspaper report that Britain is considering joining Europe's single currency, the euro, shortly after its planned introduction in 1999.

title: Struggling Notre Dame Confronts Limitations
description: Desmond Howard's Heisman Trophy-winning catch for Michigan. Raghib Ismail's pair of kickoffreturn touchdowns for Notre Dame. Remy Hamilton's decisive field goal, and Reggie Ho's, and Harry Oliver's, with the pennants in South Bend suddenly and mysteriously falling limp. The series between Notre Dame and Michigan, the two leading programs in the history of college football based on victories and winning percentage, has created instant heroes and produced gripping moments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIG, RICHARD LEWIS
description: SWIG-Richard Lewis, in San Francisco on Sept. 25, 1997 at age 72. Beloved husband for 47 years of Roselyne Swig; loving father of Rick Swig, Susan (and Richard) Watkins, Marjorie Swig and Carol (and George) Sedlack; ''Poppy'' to 12 adoring grandchildren. Dear brother of the late Melvin Swig and Dorothy Betty Dinner; brother-in-law of Richard (and Joan) Dinner, Tobey (and Allen) Moss and Miriam Handel. Dear nephew, uncle, cousin and friend to many. Contributions to The Coast Guard Foundation, Stonington, CT.; Hospitality Management Program, McLaren School of Business, University of San Francisco; American Society for Technion, S.F.; The Peddie School, Hightstown, NJ; Jewish Museum San Francisco; Institute for Health and Healing, c/o California Pacific Medical Center, S.F. or the charity or your choice.

title: Schools Aren't Alone in Getting Private Money; Myth of Smaller Classes
description: To the Editor:

title: Folic Acid as Fortifier
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Debates Campaign Bill, But Two Sides Remain Divided
description: Less than a year after the most expensive election in the nation's history, the Senate opened debate today on rewriting the country's campaign-finance laws, arguing about whether there was too much or too little money in the system now and about what kind of changes could be made without violating the First Amendment.

title: 3 Human Skulls Found In House Being Rebuilt
description: Construction workers renovating a house discovered three skulls but no other human remains -- beneath the floorboards yesterday, Bergen County prosecutors said.

title: Lawyers for Malcolm Shabazz Say He Thrives in Treatment
description: Twelve-year-old Malcolm Shabazz has grown two inches, learned to play the drums and been elected secretary of his class in his first month of confinement at the Hillcrest Center, a threadbare, turn-of-the-century mansion here that is home to about 60 boys and girls with severe behavioral disorders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONROY, OSSIE RAY
description: CONROY-Ossie Ray, of Manhattan, formerly of East Setauket, L.I., on September 25th in her 81st year. Devoted wife of the late Vincent P., beloved mother of Vincent, Harry, Helen Del Guercio, Frances Conroy and mother-inlaw of Nicholas Del Guercio and Jan Munro. Dear grandmother of Nicholas, Cecil, Evan and Collin, great grandmother of Freja. Friends are invited to visit the Del Guercio Home, 208 W. Broadway, Port Jefferson on Sunday between 3 & 8 PM. Parking on Beach St. or by the harbor. Religious service at the Caroline Church in Setauket Monday 11 A.M., Canon Wancura officiating. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Ossie R. Conroy Home Care Scholarship Fund, benefiting the the educational needs of deserving home care workers would be appreciated. Please send checks to P.O. Box 1577, Stonybrook, New York 11790. For further information contact Casimir Funeral Home 516-473-5555.

title: Federal Money for Lab
description: The Plasma Physics Laboratory at Princeton University was forced to shut down its Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor earlier this year and lay off 35 workers because of declining congressional support. But the lab will get enough Federal financing during the coming year to avoid further cuts, officials at the lab said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, PHILIP
description: GOLDFARB-Philip, peacefully at home after a very long illness. Beloved husband for sixty years of Helen; devoted father of Peter; loving uncle, great-uncle; dear brother of Sidney. Owner of the Goldfarb Novelty Company; longtime member of the Friars and Lone Star Clubs. Service Monday, 12:00 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 12th University Is Certified
description: Kean College became the state's 12th university yesterday, after the Commission on Higher Education voted unanimously to approve the change in status.

title: School Issues Pose Conflicting Demands for Messinger and Husband
description: Ruth W. Messinger, the Democratic mayoral candidate, was watching the news the other night when a parent from Greenwich Village called her apartment with an urgent request. Chancellor Rudy F. Crew was opposing an effort by parents to raise private money to pay the salary of a teacher who was about to lose her position at Public School 41, and the parents wanted Ms. Messinger by their side the next morning for a demonstration against the Chancellor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAF, RUSSELL C.
description: LEAF-Russell C., 61, of Princeton, N.J., on September 25, 1997. Husband of Diane Alington. Father of Daniel M., Jonathan I. and Sarah R. Brother of Diana Clewett. Funeral services Monday, 11:00 AM at The Jewish Center, Nassau Street, Princeton. Burial in Princeton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Parkinson Disease Foundation, 650 West 168 St, NY, NY 10032.

title: Excerpts From Senators' Remarks on Fund-Raising
description: Following are excerpts from the texts of speeches on campaign finance change delivered in the Senate today by Senators Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, Trent Lott, John McCain and Fred Thompson, all Republicans.

title: Deal to Cut Incinerator Fees
description: Union County officials say they have struck a deal that would cut fees at the county incinerator by 40 percent while still allowing the bondholders to be paid off.

title: A Heart Lost Over a Loincloth
description: Diane is a trim 40-year-old book editor with a successful career and a happy family. One day while she is visiting her most intransigent author, his roommate lopes across the apartment in a loincloth and gives Diane a warmly inquisitive look. And that's it. That's all it takes. Diane's respectable life is over.

title: A Hard-Boiled Detective Who Has a Tender Side
description: Takeshi Kitano is a Renaissance star in Japan: comic actor, serious director, painter, film editor, tough guy. Apparently in all these realms he relies on contrast and shock value, whether in a startling juxtaposition of images or in sweeping pronouncements. ''I really hate young people,'' he told an interviewer not long ago. ''I think they're fools.''

title: Attacking Money, But Raising It, Too
description: Hours before appearing as the big draw at a $600,000 Houston fund-raising dinner here for the Democratic Party, President Clinton castigated politicians for not being sincere about curbing the influence of money. ''You hide and watch,'' he told a college audience. ''There will be a lot of efforts to make it look like we're going to do something and nothing will happen unless we all work hard and demand that something happen.''

title: Burst Main Empties Hotel
description: More than 700 people were evacuated from the Claridge Hotel and Casino for eight hours yesterday after a high-pressure hot-water main burst on the hotel's 11th floor, the authorities said.

title: About New York; Youthful Foes Go Toe to Toe With Nike
description: ADRIANE CAMPO could wear a different Nike sneaker for each day of the week. She doesn't belong to any sports teams, she just likes to look good. ''Mine glow,'' she said, showing off a pair of Air Max shoes she received a few weeks ago. ''These aren't even the latest ones. This is old.'' Perhaps a trip to Nike Town is in order for a fashion fix?

title: Schools Aren't Alone in Getting Private Money; Pair Rich and Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIGGINS, DR. DONAL KEVIN
description: HIGGINS-Dr. Donal Kevin. Say not in grief that he is no more, but that he was. Maureen

title: Travelers Plans Further Growth To Fill Gaps Internationally
description: Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Travelers Group Inc., has a healthy appetite. One would think that this week's bite -- an agreement to swallow Salomon Inc. for more than $9 billion -- would be enough for anyone.

title: Indonesia Jet Crash Kills All 234 Aboard; Haze Was a Possible Cause
description: An Indonesian Airbus A-300 that left Jakarta carrying 234 people crashed today as it approached an airport on the neighboring island of Sumatra, part of a vast region where thick smoke from forest fires has cut visibility.

title: Report Says British Warm To Euro Plan
description: A leading British stock index recorded its biggest one-day gain today and other markets reacted sharply after a report that the British Government was considering joining the European single-currency union shortly after its planned introduction in 1999.

title: Op-Art; After Managed Care
It's Not How Much You Give, It's How You Give It
description: Ted Turner's $1 billion gift to the United Nations astonished everyone, and many Americans no doubt cheered Mr. Turner when he challenged other wealthy business leaders to make big philanthropic gifts of their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHFIELD, SYLVIA Z.
description: HIRSHFIELD-Sylvia Z. On September 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Morton Hirshfield. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOKELL, SYLVIA
description: YOKELL-Sylvia, of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved mother of David Yokell & Rosemary Mandelbaum. Dear grandmother of Timmy, Jamie and Adam. Great grandmother of Louis, Lily, Samantha and Elizabeth. Funeral service Monday, 11:00 AM at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: More In-Your-Face Art? Let the Debate Be Rehashed!
description: Yes, it's shocking, disturbing, even infuriating, but is it art? A new exhibition across the Atlantic has re-ignited the infamous fight over the line between art and its commoner cousin, sensationalism. But haven't we heard it all before?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 16 about the process of counting votes in New York City misstated the amount paid daily to poll monitors. It is $130, not $135.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINMEL, SIDNEY
description: FEINMEL-Sidney. Age 77 of Searingtown, New York, suddenly on September 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Edith. Devoted brother of Michal and Daniel. Fond uncle and great uncle of many nieces and nephews. Services were private.

title: On Borneo, Anger at Lack Of Haze Help
description: KUCHING, Malaysia  The island of Borneo, with its millions of acres of rain forest, has long been touted in promotional brochures and tourist guidebooks as the lungs of the earth.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: COLLEGE

title: Casual Friday on Wall Street
description: Just when young people are being suited with school uniforms, Wall Street suits are, it seems, thinking of dropping their suits.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: British Parts Supplier Gets $2 Billion Federal-Mogul Bid

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPSHAW, GEORGE S.
description: KOPSHAW-George S. On Sept. 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Helen. Graduate of St. John's Univ. and Polytech University, Commander U.S.N.R., Naval Aviator. Retired Advertising Mgr, Hearst Corp. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Up to No Good
description: WHERE TROUBLE SLEEPS By Clyde Edgerton. 260 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $18.95.

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: I was deeply moved by Herbert Muschamp's article on Frank Gehry's new Guggenheim Museum (''The Miracle in Bilbao,'' Sept. 7). I have been a Gehry fan for years but have never read anything about him that so beautifully expresses the man and the imaginative quality of his work.

title: Backtalk; Pinstriped Transgression May Finally Be Forgiven
description: At last. For the first time in baseball history, my Indians are facing the dreaded Yankees in the post-season. Maybe if I come clean and admit my transgression nearly 50 years ago, the baseball gods will finally lift their hex on my hometown team. You see, I once wore a Yankee uniform, but I can explain. . . .

title: Hilary Smith, Andrew Landis
description: Hilary Jill Smith, a daughter of Ellen and Martin Jay Smith of New York, was married last evening to Andrew James Landis, a son of Elayne and Leonard R. Landis of New York. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Victims Should Have Their Day in Court, Too; Shedding Tears, Loudly
description: To the Editor:

title: To Everything, a Trash Can
description: Theresa Hansen examined the piles of blue and green garbage containers at the recycling display at the Pergament Home Center in Long Island City, Queens. Then, with a look of utter annoyance, she latched on to a 20-gallon green one.

title: The Showdown in Washington Square Park
description: It's 7:30 A.M. in Washington Square Park and Ruth Cassell is standing in a claque of other middle-aged women, conferring, as they have every day of late, about the changes under way in their beloved public green.

title: These Are Some of My Favorites
description: Representative Michael P. Forbes

title: Technology Makes Us Comfortable; Life as We'll Know It
description: The technology that keeps our homes and offices running smoothly will look very different in the future -- that is, when it's visible at all.

title: The View From: Greenburgh; Volunteers Put the Fright in Halloween but No Real Horror
description: SCARY but safe seems to be the motto of modern Halloween. The ghouls are there, gory and gruesome, but they are costume ghouls. The monsters are only masks. The real demons -- people who would want to do irreparable harm -- are kept at bay as much as possible.

title: Ready for Takeoff
description: In Claudia Dreifus's article ''Ready for Takeoff'' (Aug. 17), Philip M. Condit, C.E.O. of Boeing, was asked, ''Do you have personal feelings about human rights violations in China?'' He answered: ''Oh, yeah, absolutely. And I'm going to put it in context: they are the same ones that I have about human rights violations in the United States.'' He continues by saying he was in China at the time when the Rodney King beating was on television, and China wanted to know what that was about.

title: Technology Makes Us Cooler; 64 Megs Can Set You Free
description: More than 25 years have passed since a guy in my freshman English class asked me if I wanted to help blow up a computer center. He approached me after class one fall afternoon and gave me a soul shake for something I'd said about a Vonnegut novel we'd all been discussing -- something about alienation, or maybe it was dehumanization. As we cut across the campus together, a couple of late-to-the-action student-radical types in our jeans and work boots and ratty Shetlands, he got into a long rap about Marshall McLuhan's growing technological pessimism, how McLuhan was saying that ''the electric situation of instant information'' was erasing people's individuality, leaving them empty and scared. Television was McLuhan's chief culprit, but my classmate was looking ahead and seeing nothing but the computer.

title: Cadets Stumble to a Defeat As Running Game Is Slowed
description: It was not supposed to be this way for Army.

title: Westchester Q&A: Gini Reticker; Film Maker Explores Schools and Politics
description: AS Gini Reticker's child approached school age, she became fascinated with the issues surrounding the Christian Coalition's involvement with some school boards and the increasing influence of fiscal conservatives on budget decisions.

title: Keeping the Shop Talk Out of the Pillow Talk
description: FRIENDS at home, foes at work. This conundrum clearly fascinated the screenwriters who cooked up the idea of having Tracy and Hepburn battle it out as rival lawyers in ''Adam's Rib.'' But thousands of professionals also confront it in real life, particularly as more women move forward in their careers.

title: Our Towns; For Seamen, A Long Haul Between Jobs
description: WEEKS tick by while the seamen wait at the union hall for work. Friday afternoon marked Nathan Rosenthal's 14th week of waiting for a shipboard job. He tried to sound cheery about it. ''One reason we got into this,'' he cracked, ''is for the time off.''

title: Lennon Edwards, Monique Carkum
description: Monique Christine Carkum, an associate at Debevoise & Plimpton, the Manhattan law firm, was married yesterday to Lennon Constantine Edwards, a staff lawyer at Miracle Makers, a social-services agency in Brooklyn. The Rev. Ross Johnson Jr. performed the ceremony at the Tulane Memorial Baptist Church in New Orleans.

title: Byers Provides Burst of Fun in Dash From the Past
description: Isaac Viciosa, a 28-year-old Spaniard, was so confident that he tolerated a slow pace and won the men's elite division of the Fifth Avenue Mile yesterday for the third consecutive year. Paula Radcliffe, a 23-year-old Briton, was so unsure of her speed that she ran hard from the start and won the women's elite race for the second straight year.

title: For Maywood Synagogue, a New Path for the Jewish New Year
description: Since 1928, Temple Beth Israel has been the only synagogue in Maywood. But in recent years, the congregation had dwindled to the extent that they often could not get a minyan, a gathering of at least 10 Jewish men, to read from the Torah. Faced with the prospect of closing the doors of the Conservative synagogue -- housed, since 1931, in a building that originally was a church -- the members decided they would rather adapt than die. In February, they voted 36 to 1 to affiliate with the Reconstructionist movement of Judaism, and unanimously approved the choice of a woman as their new spiritual leader. (They also now count women in the minyan.)

title: Paris
description: In September, the cooling breezes of autumn sweep gently into Paris, blowing the fallen chestnuts and sycamore leaves along streets filled once again with traffic as the city comes out of its summer torpor.

title: Shoplifting: The Life Style; When Having Enough Is Not Enough. Why People With Money Raid the Aisles
description: JOSEPH ROSEN is a devoted Kmart shopper. He loves the acres of merchandise, the endless variety, the convenience. Kmart's Astor Place emporium is just a few short blocks from his lower Fifth Avenue co-op, making it a quick bicycle ride away when he gets the urge to shop.

title: A Bright Light in a City Shadowed by Trouble; Washington School Emphasizes Respect
description: The metal detector was delivered to Thomas Jefferson Junior High School last week, but when District of Columbia schools finally opened on Monday after a three-week delay for roof repairs, it was still standing in a corner, ignored and unused.

title: In Rescuing a Relative, a Helping or a Heavy Hand?
description: ''Rescuing a Relative Who Won't Accept Help'' (Aug. 10), by Roy Furchgott, described the author's efforts over the last year to restore the financial affairs of his 95-year-old great-uncle, Joseph Nathan Rosolio of Thomasville, Ga. The article drew various responses from readers.

title: N.C.A.A. Labyrinth
description: To the Editor:

title: Checking In, On Japan's Ice
description: The National Hockey League has never played a season like this one.

title: Barbershop Quartet, Times 10
description: It's a sultry Tuesday night in Manhattan Beach and the guys are getting together for a good time. Dressed in jeans and T-shirts, they might be mistaken for a bunch of off-duty construction workers. But what they build is the finest four-part harmony this side of the Gowanus Canal.

title: Phillip Brown, Actor and Singer, 37
description: Phillip David Marcus Brown, an actor and singer, died on Sept. 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 37.

title: In This Corner, Trees With National and State Championships
description: IN the arboreal world, the best of a species does not necessarily stand out in the forest.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Tommy Edison; On the Air About Traffic, and Blind
description: TOMMY EDISON has never seen a traffic jam. He can't; he's been blind since birth. But every day Mr. Edison, the on-air traffic reporter for Star 99.9 FM in Bridgeport, tells motorists how to avoid them.

title: I Found the Best Trail for Me and My Horse
description: ROY ROGERS had the right idea about Happy Trails -- the hard part was finding some in the area.

title: Katharine Alfond, Joseph Donahue
description: Katharine Brooke Alfond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Alfond of Weston, Mass., was married in New York last evening to Joseph Patrick Donahue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Donahue of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Walter J. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel at the Pierre.

title: Q and A
description: New Orleans

title: Technology Makes Us Daring; Wizards, Wonders And Wonks
description: They are among the brightest stars in today's high-tech firmament, but each has a different vision of the future, and they can't all be right. Some are betting that the Internet is going to make the PC obsolete; others are convinced that the desktop box is still where the action is. They have one thing in common, however: a rarefied and well-earned optimism in the face of everyone else's doubts. ''The first reaction to a new idea is usually, 'That's crazy,' '' says Alan Huang, a computer scientist. ''The next is, 'That's impossible,' then, 'That's impractical.' Followed by, 'It's not that significant.' The last is, 'I had that idea before.' '' Technological innovation is a team effort, so we've included a theorist, two investors, a programmer, an industrial designer and plenty of entrepreneurs -- all players in a process that routinely converts impossible ideas into marketable realities. What they dream, the rest of us will live.

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: Muschamp's exuberance and eloquence in writing about Gehry's great accomplishment in Bilbao deserve a corresponding expression of appreciation.

title: Guns on the Run
description: ''SOME guys like to bowl on Tuesday nights,'' says Donald Passantino, lining up the sights of his .22-caliber pistol as if it were a 9-iron. ''We shoot guns. It's a real family thing to do and the kids enjoy it.''

title: Sonya Lawrence, Wesley Merritt
description: Sonya Leigh Lawrence, the daughter of Cheryle and Charles B. Lawrence of Stratham, N.H., was married yesterday in Portsmouth, N.H., to Dr. Wesley Arthur Merritt, a son of Betty Anne and Charles W. Merritt Jr. of Mountain Lakes, N.J. The Rev. Anthony E. Acheson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the North Church of Portsmouth.

title: Parents Support Florida School District's Offer of Drug Testing
description: Sandy Ojeda remembers vividly the first football game she attended with her 14-year-old daughter at the girl's new school earlier this month, not because of the football but because of the drug raid. Vials came out of pockets as the police searched a group of teen-agers under the bleachers. One youngster cracked his head open as he resisted arrest.

title: September 21-27; U.S. Troops in Bosnia May Stay Longer
description: American G.I.'s keeping the uneasy peace in Bosnia can stop counting the days until their scheduled June departure: chances are they'll be staying awhile. Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, last week made the case for a longer engagement in Bosnia in a speech intended to reassure nervous NATO allies and counter Republicans who want to cut off funds for any future military presence.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: GRACE NOTES

title: HOCKEY -- Wearing Hockey's Badge of Leadership; Captain's 'C' Carries Much Influence, on the Ice and Off
description: No other team sport recognizes its highest-ranking player quite the way a hockey team honors its captain. He wears the ''C'' on his jersey the way a police officer wears a badge or a military officer wears stripes.

title: Forget the Traffic, Long Island Is Home, and Close to My Heart
description: TALK about an overview. Long Island never looks better than from the air. For one thing, you do not have to deal with the dreaded Long Island Expressway, at least not yet.

title: Food; The Cook's Night In
description: Buy this (stove/refrigerator/microwave oven), and cooking will be a breeze! Such is the longstanding covenant between technology and the consumer. And for a while, it was true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIG, RICHARD
description: SWIG-Richard. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound regret at the loss of Richard Swig of San Francisco. Chairman of the board of the Northern California chapter of the ATS for the past decade, Mr. Swig was fervent in his support of Israel and education and research at the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology. He served on the Technion International Board of Governors and the ATS Board of Regents. Together with his wife, Roselyne, he established the Roselyne and Richard Swig Sports Hall and supported the Baltimore Aerospace Laboratories, the Trauma Helicopter Development Project and other programs at the Technion. In recognition of his commitment, Mr. Swig was awarded an Honorary Fellowship from the Technion in 1995. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Roselyne Swig and to the entire Swig family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Irving A. Shepard, President Ben Z. Sosewitz, Chariman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Sidney Konigsberg, Northern California Chapter President Jack Kadesh, Northwest Region Director

title: In Race to Fill Molinari's Seat, A National Test
description: For almost two decades, the Congressional seat that encompasses Staten Island and southwest Brooklyn has been held by a member of the Molinari family, which lorded over the sole bastion of Republicanism in heavily Democratic New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGAN, JAMES R.
description: COGAN-James R., aged 69, died on September 26, 1997. Survived by his wife, Arrial, his children, Sarah E., George W. and Julia Finney, and seven grandchildren. Memorial service on Wednesday, October 1 at 4 PM at The Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and 10th Street. For those who wish, contributions to Ascension Music, 12 West 11th Street, New York, NY 10011.

title: A Dance-World Veteran With Youthful Troops
description: IN THE SUMMER OF 1996, AFTER eight years as a freelance choreographer for major American and European modern dance and ballet companies, the irrepressible Twyla Tharp decided to re-establish her own troupe. She auditioned countrywide, selected highly motivated young dancers, rapidly created a new repertory and started on a worldwide tour. The 11-member ensemble arrives on Tuesday at the City Center for its two-week engagement featuring four premieres.

title: How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying On a Suit
description: IT'S time to assess.

title: Vonnegut Stew
description: TIMEQUAKE

title: Moving Toward a Cleaner Sound
description: IF Long Island Sound isn't clean, Connecticut and New York could lose between $5 billion and $6 billion a year in business generated by boating, swimming and scuba diving as well as things like gasoline and food, according to a study of the sound.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SPEAKING OF SEX

title: Speaking Her Mind About Art, and Giving It
description: THE THREE WOMEN WHO founded the Museum of Modern Art in 1929 -- Lillie P. Bliss, Mary Quinn Sullivan and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller -- may have been esthetic revolutionaries, but their personal style was in keeping with the conservative values of Old Guard, upper-class benefaction. Thus when ''On the Edge: Contemporary Art From the Werner and Elaine Dannheisser Collection'' opens at the Modern on Tuesday, the offbeat manner of Mrs. Dannheisser, one of the museum's newest trustees, will be as much a departure for the institution as the 85 adventurous works she is giving it.

title: France Says Lower Deficits And New Jobs Are Possible
description: France's Socialist Government now says it can manage to do what seemed impossible when it was elected four months ago: create jobs while reducing the state deficit to the level required for France to join a common European currency in 1999.

title: New Captain Behind Aggressive Policing in 33d Precinct
description: When Capt. Garry F. McCarthy came to the 33d Precinct three months ago, it was hardly an ideal post for an ambitious police captain. Relations between residents and the police, never cozy, had deteriorated to downright hostility after a local black youth, Kevin Cedeno, was shot in the back and killed by a white officer in April. The situation worsened when the officer, Anthony Pellegrini, was elected Officer of the Month, and a grand jury refused to indict him.

title: After Deluge, Europeans Pull Away In Ryder Cup
description: If the rain in Spain had forced the postponement of today's Ryder Cup play, the United States team would have been far better off.

title: Victims Should Have Their Day in Court, Too; Coming to Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
