description: A rendering with the Postings column on Sept. 14, showing three penthouses to be built atop 1150 Fifth Avenue, carried an erroneous credit. It was by Platt Byard Dovell Architects.

title: Emily Steiner, Peter DeCherney
description: Emily Rebecca Steiner, the daughter of Marilyn and Dr. Robert Steiner of Wynnewood, Pa., is to be married today to Peter Saver DeCherney, a son of DeeDee and Dr. Alan DeCherney of Los Angeles. Rabbi Ivan Caine is to perform the ceremony at the Society Hill Synagogue in Philadelphia.

title: Calling Attention To the Schindler Sculptor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Take My Comedy Club, Please
description: ''I WAS only 18 when I played Pips,'' recalls Rosie O'Donnell. ''It was a tough club to perform at. It's where I learned to handle hecklers.''

title: Anne Klavans, Scott Casher
description: Anne Charlotte Klavans, the daughter of B. Christina and Alan J. Klavans of Rye Brook, N.Y., is to be married today to Scott Harvey Casher, the son of Carol E. Weir of Chatham, N.Y., and Harvey Casher of New York. Rabbi Donna B. Berman is to officiate at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Eleanor Dickson and John Gargiulo
description: Eleanor Ann Dickson, the daughter of Eleanor F. Byram of Naples, Fla., and the late John Van Every Dickson, was married yesterday to John Francis Gargiulo, a son of Audrey R. Gargiulo of Goshen, N.Y., and the late Joseph A. Gargiulo. The Rev. Percy A. Brathwaite, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Players, a club in New York.

title: $16.5 Million Surplus for The County
description: WESTCHESTER ended 1996 with a budget surplus of $16.5 million, county officials have reported. Under law, the money will go into the general fund for use in 1998. The 1996 county budget provided for $948.8 million in spending. The surplus was about $6 million higher than at the end of 1995.

title: Ann Chara, David Bailey
description: Ann Chara, a daughter of Margaret and Vincent Chara of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to David Carter Bailey, the son of Luella M. Bailey of Portland, Me., and the late Warren C. Bailey. The Rev. Michael L. Bradley, who is the bridegroom's brother-in-law, performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I.

title: Research Supports Parents on Class Size, to a Point
description: The conventional wisdom, if you ask a teacher, is that students would always do better if there were fewer of them in the classroom, whether it is a class of 31 pared to 25, or a class of 25 winnowed to 21.

title: Falling Off The Edge
description: Wade Greene laments the ''loss'' of the beach in front of his Codfish Park cottage on the eastern shore of Nantucket. But the sea giveth what the sea taketh away. If he will check out the southern shore in front of the Cisco Beach parking area, he will find that a prodigious beach buildup has taken place there since July 1995, when I watched the waves eat at the base of the dunes -- just as they are eating the Siasconset beach now. What goes around comes around. Even so, he'd best move his cottage to somewhere else for the time being.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAN, YUPU, DR.
description: PAN-Yupu, Dr. On September 24, 1997. Survived by beloved sons, Daoyang and Daojun, dear sisters, Yuchun and Zhaomei, grandchildren, Lihong, Ying, Wei and two great grandchildren. Retired from the United Nations in 1976 after twenty-seven years of service. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends for her warmth, strength and loving spirit. Funeral services will be private.

title: Who's Afraid of Arnold Bennett?
description: I have an experiment for you to try. The next time you're at a literary gathering, ask 10 people whether they've ever read Arnold Bennett. Now, by ''literary gathering'' I do not mean your run-of-the-mill publisher's cocktail party, your average book award ceremony. For the experiment to work, you have to choose a group consisting of people who actually read -- anti-Derridean English professors, say, or poets over the age of 40, or freelance writers who pack Trollope novels in their vacation luggage.

title: SOAPBOX; The Family Cap and Other Myths
description: In the past 25 years, welfare benefit levels rose dramatically, consuming an ever-larger portion of the Federal budget. Birth rates among welfare recipients soared. Five years ago, New Jersey enacted a ''family cap,'' path-breaking welfare reform legislation that denied benefits to children born to mothers on welfare; the cap has been extremely effective in countering these alarming trends by removing the incentive for welfare recipients to have additional children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERCLOUD, COCHISE OCHOA
description: SILVERCLOUD-Cochise Ochoa. On September 15th. As a Makeup Artist/Hair Stylist in fashion photography and commercials he lived in L.A., New York and Paris. We mourn the loss of one who could always surround us with laughter. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Madrone Hospice, Box 1193, Yreka, CA. 96097.

title: Harry Raftopoulos, Amelia Prounis
description: Amelia Estelle Prounis, a vice president in the private client group at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, was married last evening to Dr. Harry Raftopoulos, a hematologist and oncologist at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, also in New York. Archbishop Iakovos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Information Was Lacking In a Vote on Gardens
description: To the Editor:

title: At Janus, Two Funds Lure the Most Cash
description: WHEN Kansas City Southern Industries announced this month that it would separate its fast-growing mutual fund business from its century-old railroad, Wall Street cheered. And it gave an extra hurrah to the Janus Funds, the Kansas City Southern subsidiary whose rapid expansion caused its parent to predict that third-quarter earnings would exceed Wall Street's expectations by 35 percent.

title: At Season's End, Winterizing Is a Prudent Rule
description: It was a boat that had operated well all summer. The 38-foot auxiliary sailboat came with a small inboard engine for docking or clearing narrow channels. The owner, a sailor from City Island, decided that he would winterize the boat himself, a procedure that could save him hundreds of dollars.

title: Parents Choose Public Schools Over Private, but Exact a Price
description: Before June Penick-Leroy moved back to New York from Paris last summer, she visited the city twice to go apartment hunting and -- more important -- to find a school for her two young sons.

title: New Buyers Renew Levittown, Now 50
description: ONCE upon a Saturday in Levittown, Cathy and Nick Galatro were running out to pick up items for their new ranch house, Jeanne and John Katsigiorgis were playing with the parakeet in their new Cape, Scott Pensante was patting his month-old baby inside his new living room and Ed and Jackie Gutierrez were unpacking boxes in their new home on Periwinkle Road.

title: Spy Versus Spy
description: BATTLEGROUND BERLIN

title: September 21-27; The I.R.S. Says It's Sorry
description: Before last week, working for the Internal Revenue Service meant never having to say you're sorry. But on Thursday, Michael P. Dolan, the acting I.R.S. commissioner, humbled himself and the agency before the Senate Finance Committee and apologized for I.R.S. mistreatment of taxpayers.

title: VIEWS; Taking Sides, Once Again, to Relive a Battle on Blood-Stained Ground
description: IT was the bloodiest day in American history. One-hundred thirty-five years ago, 23,000 troops under the command of Robert E. Lee and George B. McClellen were killed, wounded, captured or listed as missing in action in 12 hours of fighting outside Sharpsburg, Md.

title: How Less May Be More
description: Lower costs for investors. Fewer fund groups. And more money invested. That's what today's fund group leaders envision for the mutual fund industry at the close of the century.

title: ITT May Shrink, but Chief's Pay Stays the Same
description: HONEY, I shrunk the company -- again!

title: Edward Emmet and Jody Wolfson
description: Jody Mary Wolfson, a daughter of Jill Herman of New York and Milton Jay Wolfson of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday evening to Edward Watson Emmet, the son of Linda Louise and Edouard Charles Emmet of Paris. Cantor Bernard Fitch performed the ceremony at the Knickerbocker Club in New York.

title: Victims Should Have Their Day in Court, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation.; Hawaii Bucks the Trend on Welfare Reform
description: AS stricter welfare rules sweep across the country, one state after another is celebrating its shrinking rolls. In Wyoming, the number of welfare recipients has declined 68 percent from four years ago. In Oregon, 48 percent. In New York, 12 percent.

title: Sports of The Times; How Long Is Too Long to Direct a Football Team?
description: GEORGE YOUNG was agitated, not angry. The debate had reached a point where he felt logic had broken down. It had broken down with the suggestion that he should step down as vice president and general manager of the Giants.

title: In Rescuing a Relative, a Helping or a Heavy Hand?
description: ''Rescuing a Relative Who Won't Accept Help'' (Aug. 10), by Roy Furchgott, described the author's efforts over the last year to restore the financial affairs of his 95-year-old great-uncle, Joseph Nathan Rosolio of Thomasville, Ga. The article drew various responses from readers.

description: EXCHANGING IDEAS

title: Altruism For Fun and Profit
description: My sister and I rode in this past spring's California AIDS Ride, which was also a Pallotta Teamworks event (''Altruism for Fun and Profit,'' by Jeff Wise, Sept. 7).

title: Ailing, Goldwater Fades Out of the Game
description: From his hilltop home in this affluent suburb of Phoenix, Barry M. Goldwater can scan the city and sprawling desert landscape with ease and comfort through a telescope.

title: A Stand-Up Egg
description: To the Editor:

title: Attaining Winning Footsteps in the Sand
description: UNLESS you're a professional traffic engineer, there's a good chance your decision to live on Long Island has something to do with the water. For me, it was the chance to live on a beach so close to New York City with good waves, and it is the beach that I always mull over first when I have a chance to move away.

title: Victims Should Have Their Day in Court, Too; Emotions as Law?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mystery Divides Family in Wyoming
description: The disappearance of a former University of Wyoming track star here is a mystery that has divided a family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, GEORGE
description: FRANK-George, 94, master wood finisher with works in the Louvre and Metropolitan Museum, died September 2 in his native Budapest, Hungary. He lived in Paris, where he established his atelier, moved to New York and founded the George Frank Cabinet Corporation. On retiring to Florida, he became Consulting Editor for Fine Woodworking magazine and published Adventures in Woodfinishing and Wood Finishing with George Frank, both classics in the field. He was married to the late Catherine Hevesi and is survived by Eva Frank of Sarasota, FL, Liliane Akyali of New York City and Christine Frank Green of San Antonio, TX, five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Memorial services will be held in New York City, October 12th at the First Hungarian Reformed Church. Donations may be sent to the Dakota County Technical College, Rosemount, MN 55068.

title: Places That Rate Some Kind of Mention
description: OCCASIONALLY, we explore or revisit restaurants and food shops that have attributes readers might like knowing about like attractive settings or bargain prices, but for other reasons, these places do not warrant a full review. Here we offer in short the results of our recent excursions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIGOGOSIAN, VAHAKN
description: NIGOGOSIAN-Vahakn. The Board and membership of the Violin Society of America bid a fond farewell to Vahakn Nigogosian. One of America's most important restorers of fine stringed instruments, he was a founding member of the Violin Society, joining the Board of Directors in 1973 and serving it for 24 years. In 1986 he created the Violin Restoration Workshop at Oberlin College, a program he directed for ten years. He will be deeply missed and fondly remembered by his many friends, colleagues, clients and students. Philip J. Kass, President Violin Society of America

title: Editorial Notebook; Candidates in Search of a Story Line
description: New York City is a more conservative place than it used to be. But you still would not expect to see a mayoral campaign being waged over whether somebody practiced radical chic in 1979. Nevertheless, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani seems to feel there is real political meat in the tactic. ''Ruth Messinger Throws a Party for a Murderer,'' read his campaign press release, claiming that 18 years ago Ms. Messinger hosted a welcome home party for John B. Hill, an inmate who had been convicted of killing a guard during the Attica prison riots and then had his sentence commuted.

title: BENEFITS
description: Fete de Famille XII

title: Greek Jews Still Gather On Broome
description: On Broome Street, just west of Allen Street, most of the signs have Chinese lettering. But there is a modest wooden door inscribed with Hebrew letters; behind it sits Kehila Kedosha Janina, the last Greek Jewish synagogue in the city, its members and Jewish historians say.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: WHEN ZAYDEH DANCED ON ELDRIDGE STREET. By Elsa Okon Rael. Illustrated by Marjorie Priceman. Simon & Schuster. $16. (Ages 6 to 8) This Jewish holiday story is set on the Lower East Side of Manhattan in the 1930's and tells of the year Zeesie was sent to stay with her grandparents and accompanied her grandfather to the great synagogue on Eldridge Street.

title: Mortgage Brokers And Lenders
description: To the Editor:

title: A Safe Portfolio Of Bankable Art
description: IT'S the exhibition you always wished were in the bank when you had to wait in a long line. But the exhibition, titled ''The Bank: Inside the Counting House'' -- a collection of interactive installations, performance art and video -- is set in a site that is a bank no longer, a former Chase Manhattan branch at Canal and Mott Streets on loan from the bank.

title: Backtalk; First, Doughnuts
description: The hardest part about composing any collection of thoughts or ideas is finding a starting point. I could probably start with the day I was drafted, but you're probably not interested in hearing the story of how I sank a 10-foot basketball shot seconds before my cell phone rang and a voice on the other end said:

title: A Shift to Classical
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ALEXANDER. MD.
description: WOLF-Alexander. MD. On September 25, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Tony Prince and the late Florence Interrante. Loving brother of Dr. Harriet Strachstein and the late Dr. Abner Wolf. Dear uncle and good friend. He was the originator in psychiatric analysis in groups and the Diegophrenic concept, Dean Emeritus of the Contemporary Center for Advanced Psychiatric Analytic Studies, long-term faculty member of post-grad center for mental health, author of six books and over 100 articles on psychiatric analysis in groups, Diegophrenal, and submersive personalities. Dr. Wolf was world famous. Service Sunday, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam

title: OFF-SEASON: With Kurt Vonnegut; No Manual for Life as a Living Classic
description: PUMPKINS are on the vine, tables are available at Bobby Van's, and Kurt Vonnegut, 74, the novelist who has lived long enough to see himself enter the canon, is soaking up the September glory of the off-season Hamptons. ''Who wouldn't?'' he says, his arm sweeping toward the glistening waves and nearly deserted sands of Sagg Main Beach. ''This is Winslow Homer.''

title: Talks About Race Get an Early Start
description: The event here today was billed as a national conversation on race, the kind that many people, including President Clinton, have urged the nation to undertake. It warranted the presence of several members of the advisory board for President Clinton's Initiative Race and Reconciliation, the first time they have taken part in discussions with the public on racial matters.

title: Hope for Congo's Revolution Dissolves Over Old Tensions
description: When Frank Kumbu rises each morning and surveys the world from the concrete slab that serves as his modest stoop, the scenery of children playing in muddy streets, smoke-belching traffic, and a noisy parade of soldiers, beggars and petty traders remains much as it has been, he reckons, for the last 20 years.

title: Construction Site as Shelter
description: The skies are big and open. The spaces are grand. It's TriBeCa, land of the million-dollar loft conversion. And of the homeless people sleeping on the construction sites.

title: Fill 'er Up, Up to 14,000 Gallons a Day
description: WHAT do a grilled hot dog machine, a nacho cheese chips machine, a friendly serve person and 10 gas-pump dispensers add up to?

title: Fine China
description: I GREW up eating Chinese food, usually on Sunday with my grandparents and often in Chinatown in Manhattan. The food was novel, flavorful, ridiculously cheap and available on a take-out basis for people who didn't enjoy the wildness of Chinatown as much as my family did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORKMAN, DAVID
description: WORKMAN-David. We mourn the death of David, our President and devoted Board member. David more than anyone understood the role for basic cancer research. His wisdom and leadership helped the Foundation through its infancy. He formulated and guided our efforts for economic independence by creating our endowment program. We have lost a close and valued friend whose wise counsel, humility, tireless devotion, humanitarian spirit, compassion and commitment we will always cherish and remember. Our condolences are extended to his family and the many who loved this extraordinary man. Alan P. Safir, Chairman Board of Directors The Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation

title: Some Days The Bear Gets You
description: ''ALL MY LIFE, I WANTED TO DO SOMETHING that was unequivocal,'' the stoical billionaire, lost somewhere in the Alaskan wilderness without food, water or even, God help him, a cell phone, declares in ''The Edge,'' a new action-adventure film with a screenplay by no less a heavyweight than David Mamet.

title: Steppin' on West Broadway
description: In recent years, trendy fashion boutiques, retail store outlets and chic restaurants have crowded into SoHo, and nowhere has this trend been more pronounced than on West Broadway between Canal and Houston Streets. Their arrival has raised the question: has the street lost the edge that made it so attractive to artists and galleries in the 60's, 70's and early 80's?

title: Terri Constant and Thomas Varner
description: Terri Ann Constant, a painter, and Thomas Lindsay Varner, a jazz musician, were married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard. The Rev. Alden Besse, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Vineyard Haven, Mass.

title: In Rescuing a Relative, a Helping or a Heavy Hand?
description: ''Rescuing a Relative Who Won't Accept Help'' (Aug. 10), by Roy Furchgott, described the author's efforts over the last year to restore the financial affairs of his 95-year-old great-uncle, Joseph Nathan Rosolio of Thomasville, Ga. The article drew various responses from readers.

title: Islanders Sign Green
description: Center Travis Green's bitter holdout ended yesterday when he and the Islanders agreed to a three-year contract worth $4.65 million, about what he was seeking.

title: A Common Scene On the Bus I Take
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeremy Howard, Cloud Schoales
description: Cloud Narcissa Schoales, the daughter of Cecile B. Schoales of Old Lyme, Conn., and the late Dudley Vanderlip Schoales, was married yesterday to Jeremy Conrad Howard, a son of Nadine Howard and the Rev. Geoffrey Horace Howard of Sudbury, Mass. The bridegroom's father, a Swedenborgian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme. The Rev. David Good, a Congregational minister, took part in the service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, DR. LEONARD
description: HARRIS-Dr. Leonard. The members of Shelter Rock Tennis club record with great sorrow the passing of our member Leonard Harris. He was a friend to all and will be sorely missed. Our sincere condolences to Miriam and the family. Peter Agins, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, IVAN H.
description: BERNSTEIN-Ivan H., Major USAF. It's been twenty years but part of us is still missing. You're remembered with love. Karl, Karen and your family

title: Ideas & Trends; Struggling to Scare A Contented World
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON has long been seen as an instinctive politician, one with a talent for sensing a public yearning and turning it to political advantage. So why, when Americans are blithely pumping record amounts of gasoline into their Blazers, Jeeps, and not-so-mini-vans, is he preparing to campaign to cut the nation's use of fuel?

title: Party and Antiques Show To Honor Hartford's Past
description: THE curtain is going up on one of the older and more fashionable antiques shows in the country. The 31st annual Antiquarian and Landmarks Society Antiques Show (formerly the Connecticut Antiques Show) opens with a preview party on Oct. 17 from 5 to 9 P.M. at the Connecticut State Armory in Hartford (corner of Capitol and Broad Streets), and to the general public on Oct. 18 from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. and on Oct. 19 from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Jill Neptune and Ned Bicks
description: Jill Marie Neptune, the daughter of Carolyn and Harold D. Neptune of Prairie Village, Kan., was married yesterday to Edward Thomas Bicks, a son of Marian and David P. Bicks of New York. The Rev. Robert K. Buckwalter, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Seven Hills Country Inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: Port Washington Library: A Diverse Mecca of Culture
description: IN a packed room at the Port Washington Public Library in April, Leonard Marnell, owner of the Port Washington Fish Market, stood up and spoke of his grandfather, Charlie.

title: Wheeling Along Where Trains Once Ran
description: THE Osage Indians called it the land of the Middle Waters, the great swath of rolling hills, bluffs and fertile valleys shaped by the Missouri River, extending west from modern-day St. Louis to today's Kansas City and beyond.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Game

title: Greek Comedy
description: THE FALLING BOY By David Long. 287 pp. New York: Scribner. $22.

title: Climbing That Mountain Behind the House
description: Some people long to climb Mount Everest. I'm haunted by the mountain behind the house.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: My Lucky Face

title: In Brooklyn, 2 Worlds on an Edge; At the Scene of a Bias Beating, a Line Divides Red Hook and Carroll Gardens
description: Carroll Park, a placid haven of benches and ball courts in the heart of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, reflects the neighborhood's blend of Italian-American families and yuppie strivers. Old men play boccie there while newer arrivals hold wine-tastings to raise money to keep the park spruced up.

title: It's 10 P.M.: Here's Where the Kids Are
description: THERE are more than seven million New Yorkers. Some 650,000 of them are teen-agers. That's 650,000 running the punishing marathon from age 13 to 19 in a superheated urban environment. Teen-agers may grow up faster in New York than anywhere else in the country. They may be more jaded, and more likely to see their street fashion and their language translated into the popular culture.

title: No Cheers for Bing
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Westchester; Role for Elderly Nears on Former Iona Campus
description: THE former Iona College campus on North Broadway, which for the last year has been used by this city's public schools, has moved a step closer to also becoming the site of a 250-unit residence for the elderly at the southern end of the campus.

title: Gore Urges Passage of Bill to Change Campaign Fund-Raising
description: Addressing a gathering of several hundred Democratic Party officials, the two main aspirants to lead the party out of the campaign finance morass said today that Republicans were blocking legislative steps to limit the corrosive influence of money in politics.

title: Combining Adjacent Apartments
description: WHEN suburban homeowners need more living space, their options are relatively clear -- buy a bigger house and move or add to the existing house and stay. But co-op shareholders and condominium owners in similar circumstances face a more limited array of alternatives. They can buy a bigger apartment and move, or . . . what?

title: String of Pearls for Wildlife and Friends
description: IN the farthest northern reaches of the Connecticut River watershed, on swampy land in northeastern Vermont owned by a big timber company, an inconspicuous butterfly called the bog elfin sometimes sips the nectar of rhodora, an uncommon azalea. In this black spruce bog -- a waterlogged, flat open mat of decaying plants -- bog laurel, pitcher plants and lady-slipper flourish and moose leave 10-inch footprints as they browse.

title: Kings of the Wild Frontier
description: A LIFE WILD AND PERILOUS Mountain Men and the Paths to the Pacific. By Robert M. Utley. Illustrated. 392 pp. New York: A John Macrae Book/Henry Holt & Company. $27.50.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: FOUNDING MOTHERS & FATHERS: Gendered Power and the Forming of American Society

title: Jonathan Shapiro and Hank Ryan
description: Harriet Ann Phillippi Ryan, a television reporter, and Jonathan Shapiro, a lawyer, were married last evening in Boston. Rabbi Joel Sisenwine performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel.

title: Energy Costs' Impact On Office Is Alarming
description: To the Editor:

title: Democracy Without Borders
description: No one had ever asked anyone in Hungary whether the country wished to join the Warsaw Pact, the military union of the Eastern bloc. Yet on May 14, 1955, Hungary became a founding member of the pact, membership immediately becoming one of the most incontrovertible requirements of the Communist dictatorship.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about state plans for saving for college tuition misstated a rule governing the new Federal education I.R.A.'s. Provided the money is used for college expenses, earnings on these accounts will not be subject to Federal taxes when withdrawn.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Peacemaker

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A silent-screen heroine, a pair of short-story classics and a vivid melodrama about California produce truckers provide the pick of this week's movie crop.

title: Victims Should Have Their Day in Court, Too; Mere Case Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Taliban Grew With U.S. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Kirstie Alley's Comedy Mines the Humor in a Messy Divorce
description: A SUCCESSFUL woman in the throes of a messy public divorce from a philandering husband hardly seems the humorous stuff that sitcoms are made on.

title: Reuniting Nancy, Sluggo and the Gang
description: FOR the hordes of people who grew up on daily or weekly doses of ''Nancy'' in the comics pages of their local newspapers, the 1982 death of the comic's creator, Ernie Bushmiller, was cause for concern. Would Nancy, Sluggo and the rest of the gang also fade away?

title: Memories of Spain
description: To the Editor: I read your article ''The Game Is Golf, the Accent Is Catalan'' (Aug. 10), with a profound sense of loss for Catalonia, and pity for those who go there inspired only by golf.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Mondo Plympton

title: Islamic Front in Algeria Again Calls for Truce and Peace Talks
description: Pursuing its apparent attempt to end six years of fighting in Algeria, the Islamic Salvation Front today urged all opposition groups to adhere to a truce and called for a national peace conference involving ''all forces in society without exclusion.''

title: Ellis Island
description: To the Editor: It interested me to read your article ''History in Peril'' (Travel Advisory, Aug. 10). In 1930, right out of college, I was accepted by the New York Red Cross as a Gray Lady and told to report to the Marine Hospital on Ellis Island. Thus began several years of weekly visits to that facility, dispensing items of comfort to merchant marine seamen: tobacco, shaving cream, cards, etc. I am now 89, and still volunteer in my retirement home nursing facility. I hope to learn what becomes of Ellis Island's Marine Hospital.

title: Scheduling Breast Cancer in Prime Time
description: TELEVISION NEWSWOMEN have been indispensable in transforming breast cancer from a source of private shame into a very public, very political crusade.

title: Long Beach Ties Top-Seeded Uniondale
description: Long Island

title: Outbreak Of Fever Brings Chills
description: No one wants to rain on Wall Street's parade. Particularly not when the parade is being led by the Travelers Group's Sanford I. Weill, one of the most widely admired executives in the securities business.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE; Slovenian Church Endures
description: On the way to the Slovenian Church of St. Cyril, you have to pass half a dozen body-piercing and tattoo stores, the Religious Sex boutique and the Trash clothing store.

title: Father of Sputnik
description: Korolev

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Beth Mart, David Sherman
description: Beth Mart, the daughter of Hilda and Michael Mart of Palm Beach, Fla., is to be married today to David Sherman, a son of Justice Burton S. Sherman and Mrs. Sherman of New York. The bridegroom's father, who retired from State Supreme Court in Manhattan, is to perform the ceremony at the Manhattan Penthouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, JESSIE
description: STRAUSS-Jessie, on September 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Carl. Loving mother of Marian and Norman Adams and Florence and Peter Strauss. Dear sister of Florence and Bernard Strauss and the late Selma Rosenthal. Cherished grandmother of Diane, David and Dara Adams and Mark Strauss. Adoring great-grandmother of Cameron Adams. RaRa-forever in our hearts. Service Sunday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Clinton Seeks Action on Court Nominees
description: President Clinton today warned of a ''vacancy crisis in our courts'' and accused Republicans in Congress of clogging the courts by not acting swiftly on his judicial nominations.

title: Falling Off The Edge
description: It's difficult to stir up sympathy for the people of Nantucket who build in harm's way on the ocean front and then ask the Federal Government to bail them out (Falling Off the Edge,'' by Wade Greene, Sept. 7). This is especially true when one learns from the article that, on the island, the average house sale in 1997 was $684,000, and 23 houses sold for more than $1 million.

title: Car Theft
description: To the Editor: About ''Carcassone, City of Stone'' (Aug. 24). Our Toulouse hotel desk clerk warned us of car theft. The four of us had two cars, which we parked west of the walls. My brother-in-law, Kern, did not want to go. He remained in his car, feigning sleep. While our wives headed off, I quietly returned to the plaza where we were parked and videotaped five young men breaking into my car. After taking a few quick slides, Kern ran them off. I sent all the evidence with a letter in French to the local authorities -- nothing! I love France, but now I am very careful in the south.

title: Murder Case Draws Ties to Bias And the Police
description: THE dispute erupted late on a fall afternoon almost a year ago in a tiny shopping center -- one of those suburban strip malls with a delicatessen and an assortment of other small service shops.

title: Chicago, in Reversal, Is Now Importing Priests
description: The stockyards and grain elevators of Chicago's past shared the title of champion producer with another exporter, the Roman Catholic Church, which sent Chicago sons to be priests around the world. Now the Chicago church finds itself, painfully, in the position of borrower from abroad.

title: Graduating With Honor After Rebuilding Their Lives
description: Frank Grande says he was an alcoholic even before he graduated from high school in Miami Beach in the 1950's. After numerous arrests for drunkenness and a discharge from the Army, he tried every available option to fight his addiction, failing each time. In 1964, when he was 27, his family gave up on him and bought him a one-way plane ticket to New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKSTAT, CHARLES
description: ECKSTAT-Charles, 89, on Sept. 22. A language teacher in the NYC school system for 30 years, active in the labor movement, a loyal union member. Survived by his beloved wife of 61 years, Jenny Eckstat, his daughter Elsa Meyers, his son-in-law Ronald R. Meyers. By his grandchildren Daniel Meyers and Lisa Reznik Meyers, Seth Meyers and Eloise Flood Meyers, and his great-granddaughter Miranda Colette Meyers. Also survived by his sisters Mae Anderman, Lillian White and Beatrice Bienstock.

title: Mr. Rubin's Long March to China
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin spent the last 10 days in Asia. In Hong Kong, he wrestled with the problems of Southeast Asia's currency crisis, first at meetings of the finance ministers of the world's leading industrial nations, and then at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Next he traveled to China's interior to assess its confusing, often contradictory brew of economic changes. David E. Sanger, formerly the Tokyo bureau chief of The Times and now Washington economic correspondent, joined the tour. Following is his day-by-day account:

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: The new museum is stunningly beautiful, and I loved Muschamp's emotional reaction to it. However, I cannot understand how he could write an analysis of the building without recognizing it as evolving -- at least in part -- from Frank Lloyd Wright's original Guggenheim in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Residential Sales column on Sept. 14 misstated the area of an apartment at 2000 Broadway in Manhattan and the length of time it was on the market. The area was 1,600 square feet, not 1,500. The duration was a year and nine months, not just four weeks.

title: Elise Runsdorf, Brian A. Napack
description: Elise Runsdorf, the daughter of Lucette and Lee Runsdorf of New York, was married yesterday at her parents' house in Mount Marion, N.Y., to Brian Alexander Napack, a son of Rosalind and Robert Napack of Old Brookville, N.Y. The Rev. Bonnie Cohen, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Mayor Gives Staten Island A New School
description: Ruth W. Messinger yesterday ventured deep into the Republican stronghold of Staten Island, where her criticism of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the city's failure to erect a public school brought an immediate response from his aides: the school would be built after all.

title: Panama Leader Accused of Cronyism Over Appointees to Run the Canal
description: As a presidential candidate in 1994, Ernesto Perez Balladares was burdened by voters' misgivings about his party's unsavory ties to the deposed dictatorship of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. To allay those fears, he promised that, if elected, he would treat the Panama Canal not as the spoils of victory, but as the jewel of the national patrimony.

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: The negative introduction to the city of Bilbao (bleak, rusty, bomb scares) leaves me to wonder why it was chosen for this ''miracle.'' Can it be that no one else wanted this monstrosity?

title: Committed Civil Servant (or 'That Man') Makes His Park
description: K. C. Sahl is standing atop the Washington Square Arch, surveying his turf and speaking philosophically.

title: How to Prepare for Moving Day
description: STATISTICS show that the average American moves about 12 times during his lifetime. Some of these are simple, but other moves are more involved because they require relocating a family and the entire contents of a house. These can be so stressful that it may take weeks or even months to recover.

title: Era Ending For Chile As Pinochet Plans Exit
description: Twenty-four years after Gen. Augusto Pinochet led a bloody coup that began Chile's transformation from a backwater banana republic to the economic star of Latin America, the 82-year-old military commander is finally preparing to retire.

title: Soaking Up The Surroundings
description: Openings for an antiques show and the opera, and benefits for American Craft Museum and Robin Hood Foundation.

title: Laurinda Lowenstein, E. M. Douglas
description: Laurinda Vinson Lowenstein and Edward Malcolm Douglas were married yesterday in Seal Harbor, Me. The Rev. Malcolm A. Hughes performed the ceremony at St. Jude's Episcopal Church.

title: It's 10 P.M.: Here's Where the Kids Are
description: THERE are more than seven million New Yorkers. Some 650,000 of them are teen-agers. That's 650,000 running the punishing marathon from age 13 to 19 in a superheated urban environment. Teen-agers may grow up faster in New York than anywhere else in the country. They may be more jaded, and more likely to see their street fashion and their language translated into the popular culture.

title: For the Economy: Better Times, But Not the Good Old Days
description: New Jersey's economy has arrived at an uncertain, anxiety-producing place in the late 1990's: It's called prosperity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COURY, WILLIAM A.
description: COURY-William A. Died June 29, 1997. Predeceased by his wife Frances Fagley Coury and son Donald W. Survived by his son David F. His vision, stories and good work will be missed. Memorial service October 4 at St. Mark's in Mt. Kisco. Donations to Wellesley College in lieu of flowers.

title: Punitive Damages; Crime Keeps On Falling, but Prisons Keep On Filling
description: IT has become a comforting story: for five straight years, crime has been falling, led by a drop in murder.

title: Boy Mozart Still Speaks To Youth
description: ANDREW THOMAS, THE DIRECTOR OF THE pre-college division of the Juilliard School, was telling me recently about the very young composers he teaches there. He has, he said, a number of children who are composing by the age of 10, and they all write like Mozart.

title: Slowly, U.S. Is Returning Some Envoys To the Sudan
description: Revising its strategy of treating the Sudan as a complete pariah state, the Clinton Administration decided this week to put a handful of diplomats back in Khartoum to press the North African nation to stop harboring Palestinian, Lebanese, Egyptian and Algerian terrorists.

title: Food for the Hungry
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECKLER, VERA CHIZINSKY
description: STECKLER-Vera Chizinsky. Seventy-one, on September 2. She is survived by her sister Ruth and daughters Claudia, Laura and son Paul. Send donations to the Vera Steckler Scholarship Fund: DANCECLEVELAND, 1148 Euclid Ave, #

title: Sailing on Alaska's Highway of Water
description: ''FOR the one Yosemite of California, Alaska has hundreds,'' said the geographer Henry Gannett. But it's difficult to see them, because Alaska has relatively few paved roads. In 1963, the state addressed the problem by starting the Marine Highway System, with eight ships, almost all named for Alaskan glaciers, currently plying the longest ferry route in the world. They carry walk-on passengers, pets in cages, kayaks, cars and RV's and cover more than 1,000 nautical miles in the Panhandle region alone, through the Inside Passage from Skagway, at the head of the Lynn Canal, to Bellingham, Wash., on Puget Sound.

title: Technology Makes Us Better; A Special Issue
description: The Net. Terabytes. Flash memory. The virtual office. The list expands endlessly. Technology is changing the world. But what is it doing to us? Propelling us into a new age of affluence or dragging us into a robber-baron era of widening income disparities? Liberating us from stultifying bureaucracies or creating unprecedented opportunities for ''hidden persuaders''? Wiring us for success or driving us to distraction? On balance, does technology make us better? We asked writers of many perspectives; their answers appear in the following pages. Most would probably agree: Orwell may have been right about 1948, but he was wrong about 1984. As James Gleick shows in his revealing article on movies and TV, technology makes us faster. It also makes us richer, and at times a little crazy. All told, it makes us better.

title: Columbia Wins One But Loses Top Back
description: Columbia won a key game yesterday at Baker Field but lost a key player. The team's best running back, Jason Bivens, tore ligaments in his left knee on the third play of the game and did not play again. His availability for the rest of the season is in doubt.

title: Rat Problem: Rats or No Rats?
description: It's spelled R-O-C-H-D-A-L-E. You can pronounce it Rawtch or Rock or Rosh. Just don't say Roach-dale.

title: If Only You Knew Them in High School
description: LONG ISLAND is known for its quality schools and the numerous notables who attended them. Everybody has school memories, some of going to school with people who became famous. But what are the famous peoples' memories?

title: At Nassau Coliseum, Designer Skyboxes
description: IN the 1980's they called the private rooms at stadiums that have many amenities and a prime view of the playing field galaxy or luxury boxes. By the '90's, they were called skyboxes. In approaching the end of the century, they are becoming better known as executive suites.

title: Guided Tour to Uncover Crestwood's History
description: WHEN she was a little girl, Marguerite Oumann would stand on the porch of her house here and watch the Flying Jennys go by overhead. ''This was the 1920's, and that was a type of plane,'' she recalled recently. ''In those days, pilots flew by sight -- or, as we said, by the seat of their pants. They used our red roof as a landmark to navigate by.''

title: A Bookseller Becomes a Legend
description: Canio Pavone, the founder of one of Sag Harbor's true institutions, Canio's Books, was reminiscing about how he came to learn Japanese, having already mastered his grandfather'ss native Italian at home, and French and Spanish in college, when the pounding on his store's door began.

title: A Tin Pan Alley Where Nobody Is Really Nice
description: FRED STEVENS and Edna Baker start schmoozing in a parlor car, on the way to New York City; he from Schenectady, she from Hudson. Fred tells Edna that he just quit General Electric to become a songwriter (''Not the music part, just the words. Lyrics they're called''). Edna works for a dentist.

title: Elway's Broncos Visit Reeves's Falcons: May the Angriest Win
description: Can't they all just get along? No way. Not this group. This week, Atlanta Falcons Coach Dan Reeves, who is 0-4, faces his old team the Denver Broncos, who are 4-0.

title: Lynda Kommel, David Browne
description: Lynda Kommel and David A. Browne were married last evening at Club Getaway in Kent, Conn., by Rabbi Edward Schlaeger.

title: Lives; Technology Makes Me Mad
description: First there was breast-feeding. Then there was formula. Now there's patent No. 5,571,084, a microprocessor-controlled breast-pump vest with a programming chip that vacuums out milk for your baby without human contact. Why? So you can answer more E-mail?

title: For Clammers, a Chance to Thrive, Not Just Survive
description: As a boy, growing up in the North Wildwood community of Angelsea, Bob Kelleher used to pull surf clams out of the shallow water with his feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODMAN, HARRIET
description: BRODMAN-Harriet. On September 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Charles F. Funeral services were held Friday at Long Island National Cemetery under the direction of Rabbi Steven Ziskind. For information, contact McCourt & Trudden Funeral Home, Inc., Farmingdale.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Location Isn't Everything
description: Sleeping With The Mayor

title: New Boot Camp Gives Inmates Alternative
description: JESSE MANWARING, 18, of Ossining, has been held here in the County Jail for assault. But instead of serving his time the conventional way, Mr. Manwaring volunteered this summer to become one of the first inmates to take part in a military-style boot camp for male offenders between 16 and 21.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: Looking Beyond Atlanta; Turner's Charity Blind Spot
description: TED TURNER's charity often hasn't begun at home. For all of his philanthropy, crowned by his $1 billion pledge to the United Nations last weekend, relatively little of his largess has landed in Atlanta, where he lives and where his companies and sports teams are based.

title: Lost World
description: THE SHADOW CATCHER By Andrzej Szczypiorski. Translated by Bill Johnston. 161 pp. New York: Grove Press. $21.

title: Insomniacs For Kerouac
description: JOYCE JOHNSON remembers the day Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road'' was published: ''I wired Jack $30 so he could come to New York for its publication. No one knew him when he went to bed the night before that first incredible review came out, but when he woke up in the morning, he was famous.''

title: What We Don't Know
description: Why Aren't Black Holes Black? The Unanswered Questions at the Frontiers of Science. By Robert M. Hazen with Maxine Singer. Foreword by Stephen Jay Gould. 309 pp. New York: Anchor Books/Doubleday. Paper, $12.95.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BALLING THE JACK

title: Up & Coming: Jessica Hecht; Working All the Time Is Her Idea of Fun
description: THE DIRECTOR RON LAGOMARSINO is on a mission: ''To make actress Jessica Hecht known to the world at large.''

title: South Pause
description: Need a quick getaway?

title: Coco Hatch, John Harris
description: Katherine Ross Hatch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Ross Hatch of Hartford, was married yesterday to John Alexander Harris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Elton Harris of Lake Forest, Ill. The Rev. Joseph L. Pace performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, Conn.

title: Dogged Leader for the Justice Department's Campaign-Finance Inquiry
description: As a Federal prosecutor, Charles G. La Bella hurriedly labors to repair the Justice Department's embarrassing performance in the White House fund-raising inquiry, and lawyers who have battled him in the courtroom eye his arrival here with the sort of wary respect extended to itinerant sheriffs in the Old West.

title: Greek Islands To Call Home
description: MAYBE it was when we were sitting in Lilis's Taverna, relishing a spicy local sausage called louza and looking down a long, steepish hill to the port and the sea, that we came to what felt very much like a decision. Or maybe it hit us at Delphini's, which is on a pretty bay on the other side of the island and serves remarkably delicate stuffed aubergines.

title: A Smoke-Free Zone On the High Seas
description: The Paradise envisioned by believers may or may not be smoke free, but the cruise ship Paradise will be. The ship, a $300 million, 2,040-passenger vessel still under construction, has already been designated smoke free more than a year before her first scheduled sailing.

title: LEADERS OF G.O.P. SEEK TO OVERHAUL FEDERAL TAX CODE
description: On the third anniversary of their Contract with America, Republican leaders in Congress have begun a concerted drive to move beyond their signature issue of tax cuts and shift the national debate to a radical revision of the tax code.

title: The Return of the Schlemiel
description: THE COMPLETE STORIES

title: MORE DEALS: Let Them Drink Sake
description: Detroit once owned the road in America. That was before Honda, Toyota, Subaru and Nissan claimed it. Now, Nomura, the Japanese investment bank, is buying the pub chains Inntrepreneur and Spring Inns for $1.9 billion, becoming Britain's largest independent pub company . . . Seagram agreed to pay Viacom $1.7 billion for the 50 percent of the cable programming service, USA Network, that it does not already own, settling a nearly two-year-old feud . . . B. F. Goodrich agreed to acquire Rohr Inc., a maker of aircraft engine parts, in a stock swap valued at $789 million. A week earlier a different deal for Rohr fell through. Goodrich will also assume Rohr debt, bringing the deal's total value to $1.3 billion . . . McKesson, leapfrogging past Cardinal Health to reclaim its perch as the nation's biggest drug wholesaler, agreed to acquire Amerisource Health for $1.72 billion in stock. McKesson will also assume $532 million in debt . . . Shell Oil agreed to buy Tejas Gas, a major natural-gas marketer and pipeline operator, for $1.45 billion in cash. The deal will give Shell a better position in the nation's rapidly deregulating markets for natural gas and electricity.

title: Group Therapy
description: NOT ONLY FOR MYSELF Identity, Politics, and the Law. By Martha Minow. 245 pp. New York: The New Press. $25.

title: School Newspaper in Illinois Revives a Debate Over Censorship
description: For the second time ever, censorship of a high school newspaper in a Chicago suburb has led to calls for legislation protecting the rights of student journalists.

title: Sheila Blutstein, Gerald Green
description: Sheila Blutstein, the daughter of Molly Blutstein of Brooklyn and the late Ira Blutstein, is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Gerald Norman Green, a son of Pauline Green of Rockaway Beach, Queens, and the late George I. Green. Rabbi Alan Lavin is to perform the ceremony at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn.

title: Contenders for County Executive Trade Charges of Patronage
description: AFTER weeks of making charges against each other through news releases and paid advertisements, the two main contenders for Westchester County executive are now getting the chance for a direct confrontation -- and are pulling no punches when they do so.

title: 2 Shot, 1 Fatally, in Robbery of Armored Car on Long Island
description: The driver of an armored van was shot to death and his partner was wounded Friday night by masked robbers who approached them outside a bank in Riverhead, N.Y., the police said.

title: As Tale of the Cat Gets Stalled, the Victor in the Vosburgh Is a Surprise
description: After running second in his previous five races, the Canadian sprinter Victor Cooley ran second to no one yesterday in the biggest race of his career, winning the Vosburgh at Belmont Park over an all-star field, including racing's latest glamour horse, Tale of the Cat.

title: In America; Out of the Sanctuary
description: The alarm that couldn't be ignored came on the evening of May 14, 1992. A funeral was being held at the Morning Star Baptist Church in the tough and poverty-stricken Mattapan neighborhood. The deceased, a 20-year-old man, had been shot in the head while dancing at a party.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, some Long Island copies of the Real Estate section today omit the Letters column and the continuation of an article about combining apartments. Corrected copies of the page are available from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. Provide a postal return address.

title: Gustave Freeman, 88, Scientist Who Studied Effects of Pollution
description: Gustave Freeman, a pathologist who used animals to show how chronic exposure to low levels of air pollutants can harm the lungs, died on Sept. 16 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 88.

title: Classical Briefs
description: BARBER: VIOLIN CONCERTO, PIANO CONCERTO, 'SOUVENIRS' SUITE

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: Muschamp tipped his hand about Frank Gehry when he described the Bilbao Guggenheim as ''the reincarnation of Marilyn Monroe.'' Those of us east of the San Andreas fault know that Monroe -- even her name was a stage prop -- was an empty, unhappy and ultimately self-destructive person inside, where it matters.

title: David Butner and Moira Ariev
description: Moira Ann Ariev, the daughter of Deborah and Theodore Ariev of Chevy Chase, Md., is to be married this evening to David Scott Butner, the son of Eleanor and Lawrence Butner of New York. Rabbi Irving Koslowe is to perform the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Mortgage Mileage
description: To the Editor: We were disappointed that the story on frequent flier mileage in conjunction with mortgages and buying or selling a home (''Frequent Flier Miles for Real Estate Deals,'' Aug. 31) failed to mention American Airlines.

title: Definition Grows for 'Mansion'
description: THE talk of Roxbury and Bridgewater these days often centers on William Rondina, a somewhat enigmatic businessman from New York City with plans to build one of the biggest mansions in the state in Roxbury.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS

title: Brooke Wilson, David Sheldon
description: Brooke Kirlin Wilson, a painter and muralist, was married yesterday to David Joseph Sheldon, an assistant United States attorney in New Haven. The Rev. Louis Bourgeois performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Paul in Hamilton, Mass.

title: A Series of Recitals Remains at Norfolk
description: THE Norfolk Chamber Music Festival is holding an Indian Summer Series, with chamber ensembles returning to perform at Battell Recital Hall. The Elm City Ensemble, winner of four major chamber music competitions this year, opens the series at 8 P.M. on Saturday, playing the Brahms Clarinet Trio, Bartok's ''Contrasts'' and Samarov's ''Kretchnian Rhapsody.''

title: It's 10 P.M.: Here's Where the Kids Are
description: THERE are more than seven million New Yorkers. Some 650,000 of them are teen-agers. That's 650,000 running the punishing marathon from age 13 to 19 in a superheated urban environment. Teen-agers may grow up faster in New York than anywhere else in the country. They may be more jaded, and more likely to see their street fashion and their language translated into the popular culture.

title: Noses Lead to Briermere Pies at the Farm
description: TRUE connoisseurs of the fruit pie -- the all-American culinary creation -- don't hesitate to call the pies from Briermere Farms in Riverhead the best in the world.

title: One Company's Four Seasons in Three Spaces
description: GIVE a good director a couple of chairs, a plank of wood and a light bulb, or some such manifestation of the elementary and the minimal -- and theater will happen. Be it in a five-flight walk-up, in an unfinished basement or, of course, in a barn, the show will go on.

title: Of Power Brokers and Race Cards; Educational Establishment Ignores Ethnic Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: It's 10 P.M.: Here's Where the Kids Are
description: THERE are more than seven million New Yorkers. Some 650,000 of them are teen-agers. That's 650,000 running the punishing marathon from age 13 to 19 in a superheated urban environment. Teen-agers may grow up faster in New York than anywhere else in the country. They may be more jaded, and more likely to see their street fashion and their language translated into the popular culture.

title: The Vision Thing
description: The Fire Within

title: Always a Chase, and Special Effects Galore
description: A LOT was accomplished in the first episode of ''F/X: The Series,'' just beginning its second season on WWOR (Saturdays at midnight). A holdover from last season, Detective Leo McCarthy (Kevin Dobson), was sent to special-effects heaven in a thunderous explosion while pursuing gunrunners.

title: The Nation; Sports Networks Ready to Rumble
description: ALL politics is local, Tip O'Neill used to say. But what would that diehard Red Sox fan have said of sports?

title: September 21-27; Algerian Rebels Call for a Truce
description: Battered by Government forces and worn down by six years of war, Islamic rebels in Algeria last week for the first time called for a truce.

title: For Libraries, a Time of Rebirth
description: DON'T bother to shush. This ample room, luminous in morning light that streams through a glass curtain wall, will soon be the multicultural center of the Queens Borough Public Library's Flushing branch. But for now, it is a construction site. And no librarian is going to stop the whine of a 14-inch saw buzzing through metal studs.

title: A Wiser Voice Blowin' In the Autumn Wind
description: BOB DYLAN CAN BARELY sit still. He pulls at his curly hair, fidgets with his black T-shirt, constantly shifts position on a comfortable couch. Sitting in his publicist's oceanside hotel suite for a rare interview, the songwriter who transformed rock is in a jovial mood. He's wearing two-tone patent-leather shoes, there's a twinkle in his blue eyes, and he smiles easily and often.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WITH CHATWIN

title: What the Donors Want
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Schumacher And Mr. Block
description: Jennifer Leigh Schumacher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Schumacher of Rye, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael David Block, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Block of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Alex Goldman performed the ceremony at the Carlyle in New York.

title: September 21-27; Marv Albert Pleads Guilty
description: For Marv Albert, the NBC sportscaster charged with assaulting and sodomizing a Virginia woman last February, two days of humiliating and graphic testimony about his sexual behavior and the possibility of a third was enough for him to give up.

title: At Reunion, Clinton Helps In Starting School Fund
description: Bill Clinton, Hot Springs High class of 1964, returned today to the building where he honed his skills on the tenor saxophone, delivered his first political speech to a large audience (the graduation benediction), played a (small) part in ''Arsenic and Old Lace'' and lost the election for senior class secretary.

title: Goal Line to Bottom Line: Degrees in Sports Management
description: AMARA E. WOODCOCK is an avowed sports fanatic. So it did not take her long to enroll in the bachelor's degree program in sports management at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J.

title: Sound Shore Is Staying on Course and Growing Without Pains
description: ACCORDING to conventional wisdom, too-rapid growth is a sign that a mutual fund's peak performance time has passed. But sometimes conventional wisdom is wrong. A case in point is the Sound Shore fund.

title: Calling All Artists About Liberty State Park
description: The canvas measures only 3 by 3 1/2 inches, but there's potential for the artwork to be seen by millions of people.

title: Desiree Schweitzer, Peter Rashish
description: Desiree Schweitzer, a counselor for public diplomacy at the Austrian Embassy, is to be married today to Peter S. Rashish, the executive vice president of the European Institute in Washington. Rabbi Robert Saks is to officiate at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Danbury's Gift to Medicine
description: TWENTY FIVE years ago, hundreds of youngsters in Danbury participated in the first mass immunization in the United States against meningitis.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Food Stamp Sting

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOCHHAUSER, MARSHALL
description: HOCHHAUSER-Marshall. To the love of our lives. 15 years and you remain a part of all our lives each day. We think of you-speak of you and pass your legacy of love to all your newest treasures. Joyce, David, Scott and Beth

title: FILM; The Iranian Who Won The World's Attention
description: WHEN THE 1997 CANNES FILM FESTIVAL awarded the Palme d'Or, its highest honor, to Abbas Kiarostami's ''Taste of Cherry'' on its closing evening in May, the audience's acclamation had an extra edge of electricity. Two days before, the film's public debut had prompted standing ovations for the director before and after the screening. On awards night, as the applause returned, it indicated a signal event: the first time the Palme, Europe's equivalent of the Academy Award for best picture, had been bestowed on a film from Iran.

title: Mo Willems and Cheryl Camp
description: Cheryl Lynn Camp, a production manager for television commercials, and Mo Willems, a writer for ''Sesame Street,'' both in New York, were married last evening. The Rev. Orlanda R. Brugnola, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church of Brooklyn.

description: THERE are more than seven million New Yorkers. Some 650,000 of them are teen-agers. That's 650,000 running the punishing marathon from age 13 to 19 in a superheated urban environment. Teen-agers may grow up faster in New York than anywhere else in the country. They may be more jaded, and more likely to see their street fashion and their language translated into the popular culture.

title: Sports of The Times; Keep the Ryder Cup Free Of Any Prize Money, Please
description: IN the Ryder Cup at Valderrama, the golfers are familiar, but their faces and their emotions are different.

title: Jobs Seminar Seeks to Aid the Over-50
description: SEPTEMBER signals the return to school and work. And for men and women seeking employment or people who want to start their own businesses, help is available.

title: A Lighthouse And a Cleanup On the Sound
description: AS a man with homes on Central Park West in Manhattan, in Palm Beach and in Atlantic Beach, N.Y., as well as a chateau in France, Eryk Spektor is not lacking in places to stay. But when he came across a small notice in The Wall Street Journal in 1984 about an auction for a lighthouse he was intrigued.

title: Swiss Weigh Fate of Clinics Offering Legal Heroin
description: Several years ago, Thomas sold himself on Zurich's streets, burgled houses and sold drugs at the city's notorious needle park to finance his heroin habit.

title: DIARY
description: WALL STREET

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: To my unpracticed eye, Gehry's architectural product of the museum in Bilbao doesn't look so much a post-modern edifice as it does a major meltdown of a nuclear power plant. Perhaps that is Gehry's message.

title: Catherine Skeen, Michael Brannigan
description: Catherine Skeen, the daughter of Charles Skeen of New York and the late Irene Reilly Skeen, was married on Friday to Michael Brannigan, the son of Mrs. and Mrs. Patrick Brannigan of Belfast, Northern Ireland. The Rev. John A. Farry, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York.

title: Afghan Taliban Grew With U.S. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Mass-Produced Masterworks From the Ancients
description: BY THE FOURTH CENTURY, when St. Ambrose offered St. Augustine the advice ''When in Rome, live as the Romans do,'' Rome had long been more than a city. It was a vast empire that extended over three continents. The entire enterprise was financed by Rome, with raw materials and finished products flowing between Alexandria and Olbia on the Black Sea, Carthage and Cologne, Gaul and Britain. Provincial centers became in effect little Romes, retaining an autonomy of taste and style that enriched daily life throughout the empire.

title: Mayan Women Find Their Place Is on the Stage
description: HALF A DOZEN BLOCKS FROM the central square of San Cristobal de las Casas, a colonial town of 70,000 nestled in the mountains of Chiapas in southern Mexico, two local Mayan women are engaged in their own social and artistic revolution.

title: Murrell Aims to Hold On To Gains vs. Ex-Coach
description: Bruce Coslet still does not understand Adrian Murrell. Coslet, the Bengals' coach who has a wise guy's kind of humor, considered the Jets facing his run-poor defense Sunday.

title: No Home on Earth
description: THE MAD DOG Stories. By Heinrich Boll. Translated by Breon Mitchell. 164 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

description: First Trans-Atlantic Flight

description: Aaron's Magic Village

description: CLIMBING THE MOUNTAIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, MARSHA CLAIRE
description: HOPKINS-Marsha Claire, nee Kaplansky, Sept. 26, 1997. Beloved wife of Major Ian Hopkins, A.G.C. (E.T.S.). Beloved mother of Bethan Claire and Ceri Ann. Services will be held October 2 at Michael's Church, Warefield, Berkshire, England. Donations in lieu of flowers to Thames Valley Hospice, Windsor SL43RW England.

title: The Nation; On Campaign Finance, No Looking Inward
description: IN a single week, the focus on campaign finance has shifted from highly-charged Senate hearings that laid bare legally and ethically questionable practices to a more measured debate -- in committee and on the Senate floor -- about how to fix the laws governing the financing of political campaigns.

title: Calling All Tourists In Multicultural Markets
description: There's $32 billion a year out there in the nation's multicultural tourism market and Commerce Commissioner Gualberto Medina wants to be sure that New Jersey gets its share.

title: Mary Jo Wrenn and Raj Tahil
description: Mary Jo Wrenn, a daughter of Mary and Patrick Wrenn of Hilton Head, S.C., was married yesterday to Raj Vikram Tahil, the son of Sheila Tahil of Willowdale, Ontario, and the late Gurmukh L. Tahil. Msgr. James Mahoney performed the ceremony at Corpus Christi Church in Chatham, N.J.

title: Destination: Disaster
description: Oops. With the stroke of a computer key, a sensitive memo (perhaps about your love life, your finances or your boss) has gone astray. Welcome to the wonderful world of computers, where really embarrassing things can happen in a big hurry. Have you ever sent a message to the wrong place? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Cone Says He's Ready; Wells Seems a Lock
description: The most significant 10-minute pitching session in this long Yankee season lasted only seven minutes today. The workout ended with David Cone telling Joe Torre that he felt better than he had since tendinitis was diagnosed in his right shoulder last month. The Yankees think Cone is being honest, instead of heroic, in his quest to start Game 1 of the division series against the Cleveland Indians on Tuesday night.

title: Dividing and Trimming for a Bountiful Season
description: NATURE is winding down again. Some of the tree leaves are turning. Dogwood berries are getting red. Petunias and snapdragons are forming their fat seed pods.

title: The Sun Also Sets
description: WARRIORS OF THE RISING SUN A History of the Japanese Military. By Robert B. Edgerton. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

title: East Hampton Library at 100
description: THE East Hampton Library has had a big year. A three- day celebration in August marked its 100th anniversary and the completion of a much needed expansion and renovation. ''It was the most successful capital campaign in the history of East Hampton,'' said Sheila Rogers, development director of the library. ''Over $3.5 million wase donated, all by the private sector, most of it in two years.''

title: The Tar Heels' Defense Inspires Big Turnabout
description: Undefeated North Carolina has developed the uncomfortable habit of spotting opponents early leads, then rallying to victory.

title: It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World; You're Not Bad, You're Sick. It's in the Book.
description: EXPERTS warn that road rage is at epidemic levels on America's highways. In a recent study, the American Automobile Association found a 51 percent increase since 1990 in incidents of motorists behaving in an overtly hostile manner.

title: There's Something Old and Something New as Trades Museum Reopens
description: WHAT -- A glass and steel conservatory.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WITTNER, HENRY W.
description: WITTNER-Henry W., September 28, 1974. Henry, I always miss you. Love, Miri

title: Karen Higgins, Ronald Carter
description: Karen Ann Higgins, a daughter of Virginia and John Higgins of Centerport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ronald Cecil Carter, the son of Kathleen and Dennis Carter of Hauppauge, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Robert Whitfield performed the ceremony at the Centerport United Methodist Church. Msgr. Joseph Colligan took part in the service.

title: The View From: New Haven; When the Actors Are Russian and American
description: THE director, Gennady Trostianetsky, stood just below stage level and looked up at a troupe of 20 actors in training. He pounded his fist and whirled his arms. Then he stopped abruptly, and 20 sets of eyes shifted to Ana Efremova, who sat in the front row of the Yale University theater.

title: Correction
description: The What's Doing column on Sept. 14, about Bilbao, Spain, misstated the position held by Igone Orbe Iturbe-Ormaetxe. She is a proprietor of the hotel Iturrienea Ostatua, not the sole proprietor.

title: Technology Makes Us Crazy; Dazed and Bemused
description: Is Anybody There? The first time I made contact with someone on a Web site was with a guy who said his interests were music and sand. And I said, ''Sand?'' I have a kind of special interest in sand. When I was on my first and only LSD trip, I went to the beach and I spent 12 hours lying there looking at grains of sand. I had decided to make a collection of the sand, and the idea was to choose six of the most perfect and representative grains -- a project that took all day and well into the night. I still have this collection in a small box lined with velvet. And I took some pictures of it with an electron microscope and sent them to this guy at his Web site.

title: Technology Makes Us Acquisitive; The Great Technological Future Behind Us
description: A few months back, I had a scary close call. I'd been shopping for a new desktop computer and had settled on the latest and best PC -- a system built around a 200-megahertz Pentium chip with MMX technology -- when I got so busy with work I didn't have a spare few hours to buy and install the thing. Thank God. By the time my schedule cleared, days later, the Pentium II chip had hit the market, rendering the mere Pentium of the week before an also-ran, a relic, a hopelessly inferior system. Which I'm sure would have horribly distressed my 3-year-old daughter, Molly Jane, who is the primary user of the desktop computer in our house, when she sat down for a CD-ROM session with ''Dr. Seuss's ABC.''

title: Nation's First Supermarket Attempts to Stay Competitive
description: THE sushi counter in my local King Kullen supermarket was doing a brisk business over Labor Day weekend. As a couple of Japanese chefs fashioned spicy inside-out tuna rolls for one customer, Bill Strain, who lives in Vancouver, Canada, and was visiting friends, was waiting his turn to buy several California rolls.

title: Midlife Support
description: Declining to Decline Cultural Combat and the Politics of the Midlife. By Margaret Morganroth Gullette. 276 pp. Charlottesville: University Press of Virginia. $29.95.

title: East 78th to 89th: The Comfort Zone
description: CAFFE GRAZIE +

title: For God, for Country -- and for Golf?
description: SO this priest and this rabbi are playing golf when the rabbi loses his ball. Round and round in a golf cart he goes, looking for it. The priest says, ''I'll help you look.'' He jumps into his golf cart and joins the search. So do the other two in the foursome, a Jew and a Roman Catholic who won the rabbi and the priest in an auction.

title: For Writers, Plenty of Inspiration
description: SURE, Walt Whitman sang a song of himself. But he also sang a song of Long Island -- of trying to find dinner on a weekend in the Hamptons without a reservation, of being mesmerized by the swells at Montauk. (He was, of course, describing the thundering Atlantic Ocean, not his beachgoing companions. No punster, Whitman.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYNARD, SAMUEL M.
description: KAYNARD-Samuel M., J.D., L.L.M. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Samuel M. Kaynard, Professor of Law at the Hofstra University School of Law. Professor Kaynard taught at the School of Law for eleven years. He received his B.A. from College of the City of New York, his J.D. from New York University School of Law, and his L.L.M. from Georgetown University. A nationally recognized expert and frequent speaker in the field of labor law and labor relations, Professor Kaynard was a revered and respected teacher. He is survived by his wife Ann, his son Alan and daughter-in-law, Joyce; his daughter Meryl and son-in-law Gerry Wall; and three granddaughters. In tribute to the memory of Professor Kaynard, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half-staff. James M. Shuart, President Helene Fortunoff, Chairperson Board of Trustees Hofstra University

title: In Wheelchair Games, the Emphasis Is on the Slice and Spin
description: ''I AM happy he won,'' said Alan Rosenberg, talking about his opponent, Tom Stearley, in the tennis championships of the '97 Burke Wheelchair Games held at the Burke Rehabilitation Hospital here. ''I didn't mind losing. He looked like he could use a win.''

title: Miss Piggy in Albuquerque
description: LEGENDS OF THE AMERICAN DESERT

title: I Scream. You Scream. Will Wall St. Scream?
description: FOR ice cream lovers in the Northeast, Friendly's restaurants have long been synonymous with tasty treats, from the company's signature shakes to its sundaes studded with bits of candy bars.

title: The Burrell Bottles
description: To the Editor: When I visited Glasgow a few years ago, I did so without a guidebook and was mystified by Glaswegians' saying that I must see ''the bottle collection.'' I couldn't imagine how bottles could be so interesting, but everyone ooohed and aaahed about had I seen the bottle collection yet, and oh, I really must see the bottle collection. So I did.

title: Children's Books
description: KISSING THE WITCH

title: Word for Word/Gay Stand-Up Humor; So This Homosexual Comic Goes Into a Nightclub . . .
description: YOU think Ellen DeGeneres had it rough, hiding her homosexuality in the closet all those years until after she hit the big time in television? What about comics long out of the closet who have struggled in relative obscurity in large part because they are openly gay? Some have a higher profile on the tube lately, but TV hotshots aren't exactly stampeding to gay comics with offers of sitcoms, fame and fortune.

title: The Nation; Weighing Hope Against Horror
description: NOW that thalidomide, the drug that was banned worldwide in the 1960's after it produced 10,000 babies with missing and stunted limbs, is headed for approval by the Food and Drug Administration, Randy Warren has a question: Are the benefits of the world's most notorious sedative worth the risk that just one more baby will be born like him?

title: Suit Says Minority Tenants Were Steered From Suburbs
description: When Maria Malave of Hartford learned she had to leave the Charter Oak Terrace housing project, which was being demolished, she wanted to move to a nearby suburb. But Mrs. Malave ended up in an apartment back in Hartford, where, she says, the ceiling leaked and roaches were so prevalent that she twice had to remove one from her son's ear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, HAL MARTIN
description: JACOBS-Hal Martin. On September 25, 1997. Interior designer, former Hollywood producer and active fund raiser for various charitable causes. Brother to Bernice and her husband Herbert Jones, uncle, great-uncle and friend of many. Services Monday, 12 noon, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Classical Briefs
description: HANDEL, SCARLATTI: KEYBOARD WORKS

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON LINE ; Travels With Sheila: A Down and Under View of New York
description: Like other expatriate Australians, Kate Juliff thinks of herself as part of an extend ed family of Australians who are either abroad or about to go abroad. Australians love to travel, but their nation is distant from every other country on earth, said Ms. Juliff, who settled in Manhattan in 1993. Indonesia, the nearest nation, is five hours away by air from Melbourne, where Ms. Juliff was born; New York is 30 hours away ''door to door,'' she said.

title: Technology Makes Us Better; Our Oldest Computer, Upgraded
description: When the Sojourner's tiny wheels rolled over the Martian surface on July 5, it was in some ways a bigger leap for mankind than Neil Armstrong's first step on the Moon. You may not have realized that if you were watching network television, which gave the Mars landing relatively short shrift. But that was the beauty of this extraterrestrial event: you didn't need a television to follow it.

title: It's Not the Economy, It's the Monthly Bills
description: The national economy must be doing better if voters in New Jersey, and Virginia, the only states with gubernatorial elections this year, are preoccupied with the cost of running a car.

title: How 'Sweat Equity' Pays Off in California Housing
description: BUILDING a home is something personal to Jamie Ellison, a single mother of two who, with her father's help, is constructing a 1,252-square-foot house in this hilly central California agricultural city.

title: CLASSIC MUSIC; Before the Renaissance, A Renaissance Woman
description: A GERMAN MAGAZINE recently ran an article about the surprising popularity of music that was once considered elite. A focus was the 1994 Angel recording ''Vision,'' a platinum juggernaut offering chant by the 12th-century German nun Hildegard of Bingen, arranged for synthesizer and vocalist. ''What Is Hildegard Doing at the Disco?,'' the article's subtitle asked.

title: Rescuers Search Indonesian Air Crash Site
description: Working in a thick haze from nearby forest fires, rescuers on the island of Sumatra today dug through the debris of an airliner that crashed on Friday in Indonesia's worst air disaster.

title: It's Robinson's Day, but His Team Suffers a Blowout Loss
description: In a pre-game ceremony at Giants Stadium, Grambling Coach Eddie Robinson called being elected to the College Football Hall of Fame today ''one of the greatest moments of my life.''

title: Back to School, And to Fund Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: So What Will He Do After November?
