description: TOM WILSON does not get out much these days. While his boss, Governor Whitman, crisscrosses the state in search of votes, he remains holed up in an office suite here, running meetings, taking calls and keeping tabs on the opposition.

title: Technology Makes Us Faster; Addicted to Speed
description: Cameras roll, the platform shakes and Sharon Stone -- her famous face all but obscured inside a black diving helmet -- widens her eyes in a simulacrum of fear. Her director, Barry Levinson, is speaking to her in real time through a hidden earpiece: ''Fireball is coming up, coming up . . . coming straight toward you . . . wham! In your face!'' She grimaces appropriately as a beam of yellow light flares from somewhere beneath her right foot. One shot completed.

title: The Dalmatian Coast Beckons Once More
description: EVERYONE in Split comes out to walk at dusk, and the broad esplanade along the Adriatic fills up with groups of teen-agers, courting couples, young families equipped with tricycles, and well-dressed grandparents. This is the korso, the local version of the Italian passeggiata, the ritualized stroll by evening past the palm trees and through the warm seaside night along the harbor, or into the old town, through the gates of Diocletian's Palace and on into the medieval town squares, where ice cream is sold, where outdoor cafes are tucked in among the medieval buildings.

title: Sharon Haimov, Simon Mendelson
description: Sharon Haimov, a daughter of Esther and Dr. Moshe Haimov of New York, was married last evening to Simon Mendelson, the son of Lola and Dr. Jack Mendelson of Montreal. Rabbi Allan M. Langner performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Montreal.

title: JACKIE ROBINSON: 50 YEARS -- A Baseball Celebration; After Jackie Robinson's No. 42 Was Retired, So Was the Celebration
description: I was led to believe that this was to be a seasonlong celebration of Jackie Robinson, the summer of No. 42, full of glorious festivities and ceremonies to honor the modern era's first black player.

title: Trend Toward Managed Care Is Unpopular, Surveys Find
description: The anger that Americans felt about the soaring health care costs of the 1980's has turned emphatically against the organizations that are most responsible for halting the rising costs, new surveys of public attitudes are showing.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Mother's Little Helper
description: Justine Levy's first novel, THE RENDEZVOUS (Scribner, $22), is a story of obsessive love, longing and loss. While there is nothing special about the shape of the obsession, there is something special about its object: the lover is a child; the object of her obsession is her mother. The unnamed daughter, 18 years old, waits for her consistently inconsistent (and also nameless) mother for almost an entire day while sitting in a Paris cafe. As she waits, aware of the futility of her patience, she remembers. Her recollections are almost exclusively of her once-beautiful mother, a former model who had been on the cover of Vogue. Beguiling, seductive and dangerous, the mother promises and disappoints. Yet the daughter longs and hopes, even though her memories cover a range of neglect and abuse. She remembers her mother abandoning her, going to jail, using her to fetch drugs. The daughter reports these and other activities calmly: ''It's crazy how a little girl ends up finding the most scandalous situations normal.'' Despite her cry, ''I grow to hate you from loving you so much,'' the child remains faithful. Waiting and dreaming are her only ways of approaching her mother. She will never relinquish them, and the reader understands why. This slender book by the daughter of the noted philosopher Bernard-Henri Levy, deftly translated by Lydia Davis, provides a devastating description of the fierce and firm grip of a young woman's love, a reminder that while it is painful to hope and be disappointed, it is more painful still to give up hoping. Barbara Fisher

title: Jessica Fredericks, Andrew Freiser
description: Jessica Lee Fredericks and Andrew Todd Freiser, art dealers in New York, are to be married today. Rabbi Peter J. Rubenstein is to perform the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

title: Among Those Who Can, a Switch to Teaching
description: DAVE MOSS had just received a promotion and a 19 percent increase in salary when he quit his banking career at age 35. Instead, Mr. Moss, who had been working as a commercial loan officer, began pursuing a 15-year dream: becoming a teacher.

title: Drive-In Days
description: The Flamingo Rising

title: A Quandary For Fidelity
description: Few companies have the problem that faced Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant based in Boston, when it learned last week that two of the Big Six accounting firms were talking about merging. Fidelity uses two auditors to look over the books of its empire, and the two firms that Fidelity now employs, Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand, are the ones that plan to couple.

title: Streetscapes/The Garibaldi-Meucci Museum in Staten Island; 4-Room Tribute to the Hero of Italian Independence
description: AT the tiny Garibaldi-Meucci Museum, at Chestnut and Tompkins Avenues in the Rosebank section of Staten Island, the trustees have steadily upgraded the frame cottage where Giuseppe Garibaldi, the hero of Italian independence, briefly stayed with Antonio Meucci, the inventor of the ''teletrofono.'' But there's only so much you can do with four rooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, MAY G.
description: WINSTON-May G. Beloved wife of Joseph, devoted mother of Allan B. and David A. Loving grandmother of Joshua and Julia. Services today at 1 PM, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY.

title: September 21-27; A $9 Billion Wall Street Merger
description: Travelers Group, the financial behemoth that sells everything from insurance to mutual funds, surprised Wall Street last week by acquiring Salomon Inc. for more than $9 billion in stock.

title: The Talk of the Town
description: SPEAKING slowly and ever-so optimistically, Don Williams, the self-styled ''conservative with compassion,'' has been the highest-rated morning talk radio host in Atlantic City since he started his show on WOND-AM in 1985. A transplant from Pennsylvania whose brothers are in the Atlantic City police and fire departments, Mr. Williams soothes, teases but mostly agrees with an audience, that, according to the latest Arbitron ratings, accounts for some 6,300 listeners from Toms River to Cape May.

title: In Black and White
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There's more public oversight and control over the food I feed my cat than the tests they give my kids.''

title: Deidre O'Byrne And Paul Staller
description: Deidre Gerarda O'Byrne, a daughter of Margaret O'Byrne of West Long Branch, N.J., and the late John P. O'Byrne, was married on Friday to Paul George Staller, the son of Dorothy and George Staller of Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. Charles J. O'Byrne, a Roman Catholic priest who is the bride's brother, performed the ceremony at the Church of Notre Dame in New York.

title: I Was a Teen-Age Suspect
description: According to your report on Oregon's Yamhill County Juvenile Detention Center, kids ages 12 to 17 who are suspected of having criminal tendencies can be incarcerated without due process for four days (Sunday: ''I Was a Teen-Age Suspect,'' Sept. 7).

title: Philip Fidler, Jody Collens
description: Jody P. Collens, a lawyer, is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Philip Edward Fidler, a surgical resident. Rabbi Bernhard Rosenberg is to perform the ceremony at Lyndhurst Castle in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: Herbert Muschamp's glowing paean to Gehry's museum was severely diminished by the lack of input of anyone from Bilbao. What has been the reaction there so far? Muschamp never tells us, preferring instead to devote much space to somehow seeing Gehry's building as an example of an American architecture of optimism (whatever that means).

title: Limiting Children's TV Viewing
description: How would you limit television viewing among your children?

title: Altruism For Fun and Profit
description: The AIDS Rides not only raise money, they also educate the public and empower the riders. Given their complex nature and their inherent expenses, a return of 60 percent on the dollar is extraordinary.

title: Duel Between Griffey and McGwire Makes Season Memorable
description: So, Roger Maris's home run record stands for a 36th season, three seasons longer than Babe Ruth held the record. But the chase by Mark McGwire and Ken Griffey Jr. captivated anyone who followed baseball and helped make the season a memorable one.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Pedestrian Plastic

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSINGER, ALEX
description: MESSINGER-Alex. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Alex Messinger. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Deana, and his entire family. Leon Fassler, President Monty Davis, Secretary

title: Guiding Eyes for the Blind Is Sponsoring a Walkathon
description: IT costs $25,000 for each guide-dog team that graduates from Guiding Eyes for the Blind in Yorktown Heights. Yet the organization breeds, trains and provides guide dogs free of charge to blind men and women who come from all over the United States to spend 26 days at Guiding Eyes for the Blind working with their new canine companions. The dogs, labrador retrievers, are selectively bred for careers as guides. About 140 a year are paired with blind owners.

title: The World; Poland Achieves Politics as Usual
description: THE change of government in Poland from the remodeled former Communists to the heirs of the fiercely anti-Communist Solidarity movement was surprise enough in last week's elections. But will this mean much difference in the direction of increasingly prosperous, westward-looking Poland? Probably not.

title: Acting Across the Class Divide
description: NO, RUPERT GRAVES IS not Rupert Everett, and he did not appear in ''My Best Friend's Wedding'' (please don't ask). But although the chameleonlike Mr. Graves, who made his screen debut 12 years ago playing Helena Bonham Carter's younger brother in ''A Room With a View,'' seems currently to be the Other Rupert of British films, he doesn't really mind. For one thing, he has been an enormous hit here recently in a revival of the David Rabe play ''Hurlyburly.'' (''It is worth crawling over broken glass to get to this production,'' concluded the radio arts program ''Kaleidoscope.'')

title: Some Belt-Tightening Revitalizes Oshkosh
description: THE name Oshkosh B'Gosh conjures up images of toddlers dressed like farmhands, clambering around the swing set in overalls. Behind that look is a 102-year-old, family-run Wisconsin company that rode the affluence of the 1980's to become the biggest and best-known brand in children's clothing.

title: Denise Strait And Paul Hsi
description: Denise Lynne Strait, a daughter of Shirley and A. Marvin Strait of Colorado Springs, was married there last evening to Paul Peter Hsi, a son of Peter Hsi of Honolulu and the late Priscilla Hsi. The Rev. Mark T. Hsi, the bridegroom's brother, performed the Protestant ceremony at the Broadmoor Hotel.

title: The Trouble With Telling Tales On the Teacher
description: In and Out

title: Fire Island: The Valuable Protective Barrier
description: THIS summer was a great success for everyone who filled their shoes with sand on Fire Island, whether a beachcomber, environmentalist, real-estate agent or ferry boat operator.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Laura Jacobs, Robert Girvin 5th
description: Laura Felice Jacobs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Jacobs of Roslyn, N.Y., was married last evening to Robert M. Girvin 5th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Girvin 4th of Breckenridge, Colo. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at Harrison House, a conference center in Glen Cove, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTY, RAYMOND A.
description: CHRISTY-Raymond A., on September 25, 1997, of Mineola. Beloved husband of the late Marie. Loving father of Marie Gabrielle Christy and Michael Christy, M.D. A loving father who will be greatly missed. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, Monday 10 A.M. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Mental Health Association or Dr. James Cavanagh, appreciated.

title: This Suffolk Station Moves Cars Quickly
description: CATHERINE TOKAR was on her way to Chuck E. Cheese to enjoy a fast food lunch with her two young sons when she noticed the long line of cars along Jericho Turnpike in Commack.

title: Helena Willner, Robert Vahradian
description: Helena Michelle Willner, a daughter of Sophia Zimmer of Manhattan and Robert G. Willner of Austerlitz, N.Y., was married last evening to Robert Karnig Vahradian, the son of Diane and Mardooni Vahradian of Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Peter M. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman took part in the service.

title: A Few Fine Trips for the Two-Wheel Set
description: FOR bikers the lure of Long Island is unsurpassed. Nowhere are the rewards greater and more varied than in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The land mass between Montauk Point and New York City offers diverse views of seascapes and cityscapes, country lanes, boardwalks, vast beaches, rolling hills, flatlands and historic reminders of days gone by. For novices who ride 5 or 10 miles with plenty of stops to serious bikers who grind out 100 or more miles a day, the possibilities are exhilarating: the Montauk Lighthouse, the Jones Beach boardwalk, the spectacular beaches of the Hamptons and Montauk, a ferry ride to Shelter Island and the wineries of the North Fork and.

title: Tina Roman, Bruce Freeman
description: Dr. Tina Marie Roman and Dr. Bruce Goodkind Freeman, pediatricians, are to be married this afternoon at the Inn at Mystic in Mystic, Conn. The Rev. Alan C. Mermann, a minister of the United Church of Christ and the chaplain of the Yale University School of Medicine, will perform the ceremony.

title: The Fugitive Kind
description: Robert Siodmak's CRY OF THE CITY (1948) gradually builds in tension and seems to fulfill it's title, as a wounded criminal on the run draws various reactions from compassion to revulsion and fear. The film starts familiarly as two pals go separate ways; a cop and acriminal. Then suddenly the movie changes into an interesting and revealing gallery of characters. Richard Conte plays the desperate and dangerous fugitive; Victor Mature (above) is the pursuing police officer. The odyssey has effective comeos by Hope Emerson, Shelley Winters, Berry Kroeger and others. It's moody and thoughful -- Friday at 2:45 P.M. on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: Rights Redux
description: A NEW BIRTH

title: Mets' Reed Completes Rise From Pariah to Staff Ace
description: The fear remains in the hollow of Rick Reed's insides, when he is pitching, when he is sitting at home mulling his station in life. He is sure that if he does not pitch well and the Mets need to make a change, he will be the first to go, because of his six-week history as a replacement player in 1995. The fear, he admits, will be with him the rest of his career.

title: Essay; Iran Girds For War
description: In the 80's, Israel's Mossad warned of nuclear weaponry being developed secretly by Saddam Hussein. The C.I.A. disagreed; ''not for 10 years'' was its complacent judgment, which warped Bush Administration policy. Now everyone admits that Mossad had it right.

title: Technology Makes Us Optimistic; They Want To Live
description: Obviously I'm an optimist to some degree,'' says Larry Wood, a hard-bodied 50-year-old who lives with his wife, Candy, and their two dogs in the mountains above Los Angeles, ''but I really believe we could be the first generation that lives forever. Either that, or we'll be the last generation to die.''

title: Pergamon
description: To the Editor: Since you introduced your readers to the city of Pergamon (''Seeing Pergamon Whole,'' Sept. 14), you should go further: The 200,000 ''volumes'' removed by Mark Antony were probably scrolls. But it was in the second century of the common era that rectangular books sewed together on one edge were invented in Pergamon. Our word ''parchment'' comes from ''Pergamon.''

title: VIEWPOINT; China Needs Market Reform
description: CHINA'S 20-year journey toward economic reform has reached a crossroad.

title: At Hofstra, Stadium Suites With Luxuries
description: THE lustrous reds of a rosewood found in only three areas of the world frame the plush deep-blue seats, and brass and granite countertops line the sliding glass windows of Suite 4, Hofstra University's most prestigious skybox. It is one of six suites on the third floor of the one-year-old state-of-the-art sports complex that overlooks the 15,000-seat stadium where the Flying Dutchmen football and lacrosse teams play.

title: The Oyster Bar Is Itself Again, Less a Few Tiles
description: Autumn has returned, and with it a long progression of months ending with the letter ''r.'' And the 84-year-old Oyster Bar in the basement of Grand Central Terminal is also back, little more than two months after a fire destroyed its kitchen, melted its counters and sent thousands of distinctive glazed tiles tumbling from its vaulted ceilings to the sooty floor below.

title: Campaign Reform Picks Up Speed
description: From opposite ends of the Capitol, Trent Lott and Newt Gingrich have been assuring each other that campaign finance reform would never pass this year. That the two Republican leaders of Congress felt it necessary to say so was the surest sign that the opposite was true. In fact it suddenly became obvious last week that legislation banning open-ended donations to parties by rich individuals, corporations and labor unions already commands majority support in both the Senate and the House. Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Lott, knowing they cannot defeat the reform legislation on the floor, must now focus on watering it down or bottling it up.

title: Secondhand Souvenirs
description: IN the spring of this year I crisscrossed the United States, stopping not at national parks or historic monuments, but at thrift shops. I traipsed a trail to the outermost bargain bins with a Rand McNally and the local Yellow Pages as my guides.

title: Check Your E-Mail Between Flights
description: Cyberflyer, an Internet access booth, has made its debut at Norfolk International Airport in Virginia.

title: Mrs. Schwarzman And Mr. Katz
description: Ellen Philips Schwarzman and Howard Carl Katz were married on Thursday at Le Cirque 2000 in New York. The bride's stepfather, Rabbi Kalman L. Levitan, who is a retired Air Force chaplain, performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, BETTY (NEE ROSENBERG)
description: LEVINE-Betty (nee Rosenberg). Beloved aunt of Joseph Karban, Gail Able, the late Gary Karban and the late Mark Rosenberg. Beloved sister of the late Edith Karban, the late Milton Rosenberg, the late Herbert Rosenberg and the late Joseph Rosenberg. Graveside service 11 AM, Monday, at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Madison Square; Commercial, but With Residential Appeal
description: ''WITHOUT the park we wouldn't be living here,'' said Melissa Schoen, who with her husband, J. Christopher, lives in a two-bedroom, two-balcony condominium at 25th Street and Madison Avenue overlooking Madison Square Park. The couple -- she is 29, he, 31 -- bought the apartment for $240,000 shortly after their marriage in 1993.

title: Intimidating Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: SPOTLIGHT; Trouble in Florida
description: From the 1990 novel comes ELMORE LEONARD'S GOLD COAST, directed by Peter Weller, with wiseguy dialogue, poolside machinations and a tropical soundtrack. The widow of a Miami Beach mobster (Marg Helgenberger) must choose between abiding by terms of her late husband's $15 million bequest -- she is forbidden from finding a new man, ever -- and taking up with an appealing ex-criminal with a boy scout personality (David Caruso). When a cocky, cowboy-outfitted thug (Jeff Kober), hired to oversee his charge's chastity decides to ''go independent'' and extort the money for himself, melodrama ensues. -- SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on SHO. Matthew Phenix

title: Technology Makes Us No Different; My Father's Machines
description: I am someone who feels an uncommon closeness with machines. I don't really care much about them one way or another, and don't know how the majority of the ones that I use each day work. Still, I feel I know them intrinsically. I'm always acutely aware of a machine's presence in a room and often feel a vague empathy for it, especially when it's working. One might say that I feel existentially close to machines. I identify with their position in life, their distinct ability to function without any real sense of purpose.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Renaissance Moon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPEER, MARGARET BAILEY
description: SPEER-Margaret Bailey. On September 21, 1997. Head of the Shipley School, Bryn Mawr, PA., 1944-1965. Dean of Yenching College for Women, Beijing, China, 1934-1941. Service, Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, October 4th, 11:00 A.M. Donations in lieu of flowers: The Shipley School Speer Fund or Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church Foundation.

title: It's 10 P.M.: Here's Where the Kids Are
description: THERE are more than seven million New Yorkers. Some 650,000 of them are teen-agers. That's 650,000 running the punishing marathon from age 13 to 19 in a superheated urban environment. Teen-agers may grow up faster in New York than anywhere else in the country. They may be more jaded, and more likely to see their street fashion and their language translated into the popular culture.

title: Princeton Edges Fordham on Late Kick
description: Kicker Alex Sierk had been a sure thing, the only sure thing, all afternoon. The only problem for Princeton was finding a way to hold onto the ball and give him a chance to win today's game.

title: Giant of Exam Business Keeps Quiet on Cheating
description: Richard Weston was skeptical.

title: Uptown Developers Ignored a Piece of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ELLEN
description: LAZAR-Ellen. It is with profound sorrow that we announce the untimely passing of our beloved Ellen. Devoted wife of Laurence. Cherished mother of Jason and Jodie. Dear sister of Susan, Michael, and Robert. Loving daughter of Sylvia Heidenberg and wonderful friend to many. Her life was filled with the joy of living. Her courageous death will be an inspiration to all those who knew her. Ellen will live in our hearts forever. Service is on Sunday, September 28, 1997, at 11:15 A.M., at The ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Where the Need for Mr. Chipses, and Ms. Chipses, Is the Greatest
description: EDUCATORS strongly advise potential career switchers to do their homework before entering a teacher certification program.

title: Seton Melvin, Edward Weld
description: Seton Jeffrey Melvin and Edward Kingman Weld were married yesterday in Delaplane, Va. The Rev. Charles Upchurch Harris, the bride's maternal grandfather, performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: Good Fences Make . . . Trouble
description: For weeks, Jeannette LoSciuto had harangued the city about a fence that Sea Gate, the private community that abuts her street, erected in August to bar the public from a strip of beach behind the colony.

title: September 21-27; U.N. Gets a Clinton Promise
description: President Clinton said it again last week: the United States really will pay its debt to the United Nations of more than $1 billion one of these days (when Congress gets around to appropriating the money, with many strings attached). The other 184 members of the organization, many of whom are owed millions of dollars for peacekeeping services that cannot be reimbursed because of Washington's delinquency, are getting tired of waiting for a check that never comes.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: RESORT

title: Jut-Jawed Hero
description: A legendary comic-strip is gloriously reinvented as a live-action Hollywood feature via Hollywood. DICK TRACY, Chester Gould's square-jawed detective, comes to the screen in a 1990 project directed by and starring Warren Beatty. It's great fun, with lots of surprises and stunning colors. Little has escaped director's eye, like those toy river boats inching across the urban horizon. Glenne Headly brings Tess Trueheart to life and Madonna is charming in a cameo role. A galaxy of stars including Al Pacino, Dustin Hoffman and Paul Sorvino add to the enjoyment. -- FRIDAY at 8:05 P.M. on TBS. Howard Thompson

title: A Memorable Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: Victims Should Have Their Day in Court, Too; Hard-Luck Stories
description: To the Editor:

title: Cambodian Leaders in Exile Seek International Monitoring of New Elections
description: Bolstered by recent decisions of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the United Nations to rebuff the Government of Hun Sen, Cambodian political leaders in exile began a campaign this week for international supervision of an election scheduled for next spring.

title: Calling All Fans For a Football Rivalry
description: As if the battles over Ellis Island and clothing sales taxes weren't enough, New Jersey has yet another war to wage with New York. This time, it's over which state has better high school football players, a question that will be decided at an all-star game at Rutgers Stadium in Piscataway on July 9, 1998.

title: No Decision on Risk Ratings
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers did not come to an agreement last week on the question of allowing risk ratings in advertisements for bond funds, but it will continue to seek a compromise before the end of the year.

title: Beyond Redemption?
description: MAYBE they're deluding you.

title: Victor Szebehely, 76, Pioneer In Field of Orbital Mechanics
description: Victor Szebehely, a theorist of celestial mechanics whose work in the 1950's provided the tools still used to chart the orbits of spacecraft, died on Sept. 13 at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 76.

title: Light of the Island Inspires Its Artists
description: EVER since the Long Island Rail Road opened the region to travelers in the mid-19th century, artists have been celebrating the luminosity that envelops our coastline. The particular combination of geographic and climatic factors accounting for it is hard to define, however, nor is there a consistent pattern to the Island's weather that might explain what an early critic called the ''tang'' in the light that is so attractive to artists.

title: For Wine Lists, Check These Restaurants
description: CHOOSING a wine on a restaurant list can be as risky as choosing a mate. It can be even costlier, if the wine, especially an old Bordeaux, doesn't work out. It's cheaper to pay alimony than to spring for a '29 or a '45 that's a bust -- and for real wine lovers it's less painful.

title: Salter's Debut
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Ulster Enemies Face Each Other for First Time in Talks
description: After 75 years of sporadic sectarian violence between Northern Ireland's Protestant majority and its Roman Catholic minority, political leaders from both sides will face each other for the first time on Monday in formal negotiations over disputes that have divided the British province into mutually suspicious, often hostile communities.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercury Grand Marquis; Rear Drive but Refusing to Retire: A Case of Modern Maturity
description: MY first thought as I slid behind the wheel of a tan Mercury Grand Marquis: ''Detroit sure doesn't make cars like this anymore.'' But it does. The front bench seat, split into two sections, is as long and supple as a sofa. One's legs stretch out in a space that is deep and wide, and the top of the dashboard, which swoops from pillar to pillar, has the look of a surfboard. Up front is a powerful V8 and in the back, the traditional gearing for rear-wheel drive.

title: Technology Makes Us Closer; The Intimate Reach of Remote Control
description: There's an argument to be made that the defining characteristic of human life is not language or tool use but the development of remote control. Not in the narrow sense, of course. Only a true misanthrope would argue that channel surfing is what distinguishes us from other animals. Besides, there's no solid experimental evidence that other animals would stick to watching one show at a time if we let them hold the remote.

title: Where to Turn for Tips on Pet Care: Catalogues, of Course
description: WHAT -- A&F Quarterly, the latest in the magalogue trend.

title: Altruism For Fun and Profit
description: I rode in the infamous 1996 Philadelphia to Washington AIDS Ride. While my friends and family gave more than $3,200 to the event (more than twice the minimum of $1,400 that was required for me to participate), $1,536 went to overhead, including money for Pallotta's personal fee, a year-round, full-time staff in both cities and parties and grandstands for the overhyped ''closing ceremonies.''

title: INSIDE
description: Remaking Public Schools

title: Remnants of an Era When Great Cellists Roamed the Earth
description: INSTRUMENTS NEED THEIR superstars. The power of an outsize personality can prove an enormous draw. Think of the violin without Heifetz or the piano without Horowitz. The cello, too, has had its great exponents. But unlike other instruments, it has been woefully short of truly outstanding advocates of late.

title: September 21-27; Nothing Light About Those Trucks
description: Drive a car down any American road these days and it's hard not to feel intimidated by the growing number of huge sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans. That sense of fear may be justified. According to a New York Times analysis of Federal crash statistics, these so-called light trucks kill more car drivers and passengers than other cars do -- even though there are still twice as many cars around as light trucks.

title: Altruism For Fun and Profit
description: I live in Chicago and rode in the 1996 Twin Cities-Chicago ride. Pallotta's California organization had salaried staff here who spent most of that year setting up offices, coordinating volunteers, arranging the route, food, trucks, financing and so on.

title: The Island's Heavy Hitter Restaurants Take Center Stage
description: NAMING the best restaurant on Long Island is a challenge I rarely take. A one-word answer often elicits responses like, ''Oh, I'm tired of Italian,'' ''Anything but French'' or ''Not a steakhouse. We never eat red meat.''

title: Roping Them In, With Pomp and Deep-Fried Alligator
description: THE Dunn cabernet is flowing, the antelope is to die for, Willie Nelson is about to take the stage and, all in all, the 1,900 attendees of the 27th Montgomery Securities annual investment conference here are in a darn good mood.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Delicatessen Worker Is Robbed and Killed by Gunman in Manhattan Garage
description: A delicatessen worker was shot and killed in Manhattan early yesterday by a masked gunman who followed him from the deli to a nearby parking garage and stole his large duffel bag, the police said. The bag contained no money, only some papers and personal belongings, the officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHLMAN, ERNEST
description: MEHLMAN-Ernest. The Lido Beach Synagogue family mourns the passing of the father of our distinguished Rabbi, Daniel Mehlman. May he and the family be comforted in their time of bereavement with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Herman Berger, President

title: Culture Zone; Never-Ending Saga
description: Here is a glimpse of the electronic future, at least as some cyber-prophets see it: the 500-year-old Gutenberg revolution has come to an end, and the novel -- that outmoded vestige of the bourgeoise industrial world -- is a casualty of its own irrelevance. Indeed, the book itself is on the verge of extinction, and with it the colonial, patriarchal, hierarchical and authoritarian values its critics say it embodies. For that matter, distinctions are no longer made between writers and readers; there are only ''co-learners,'' in the words of the experimental novelist Robert Coover, ''fellow travelers in the mapping and remapping of textual (and visual, kinetic and aural) components. . . .''

title: The Music Channels Retool, Singing Different Tunes
description: FROM THE BEGINNING, MTV and VH1 were conceived and perceived as opposite ends of the attitude scale: the former, a sweaty, thrill-seeking, beach-party brat making the transition from high school to college; the latter, an upwardly mobile, Banana Republic-wearing young adult with aspirations to family and stability.

title: Britain Salutes American Airmen
description: The American Air Museum, a tribute to the 500,000 United States airmen who served in Britain during World War II and a memorial to the 30,000 who died, opened last month at the Imperial War Museum at Duxford Airfield, 50 miles east of London. Duxford, which is still an active airfield, was home to the 78th Fighter Group of the Eighth Air Force during World War II.

title: William Miley, 99, a Paratroop Pioneer, Dies
description: William M. Miley, the acrobatic officer who transformed ground troops into the Army's first parachute combat unit in 1940, then led the famous jump across the Rhine that helped sound the Geronimo death knell for Nazi Germany in 1945, died on Wednesday at his home in Starkville, Miss. He was 99.

title: How Can 18 Little Round Holes Be So Difficult to Conquer?
description: OFTEN called one of the most frustrating games ever invented, golf can take years for a player to learn to send the ball in the right direction. Throw in a few trees, some water and some sand, and things can get real interesting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, HARRY W., JR.
description: SCHMIDT-Harry W., Jr. On September 23, 1997. He is survived by his sister-in-law Jeannine, nieces and nephews Kendall, Mary, Copeland and Rebecca. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Marisa Garcia and Paul Tascarella
description: Maria Luisa Garcia, a daughter of Belen and Anastacio S. Garcia of Manila, was married yesterday to Paul James Tascarella, a son of Carmel A. Tascarella of Holliswood, Queens, and the late Dr. James W. Tascarella. The Rev. Thomas Joyce performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Commercial Property/Electricity and Gas; Energy Deregulation: Lower Costs, More Confusion
description: JUST as the deregulation of telephone service brought down the price of long-distance calls at the cost of a bewildering range of carriers and choices, deregulation of energy offers the potential for similar savings and confusion for the owners and managers of office buildings.

title: Honey-Glazed Quail Leads Holiday Menu
description: WHEN apples replace peaches on the produce stand you know summer has segued into fall. Among the earliest fall holidays is Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, which begins Wednesday at sunset. One of the food traditions for this celebration is eating apples with honey as a harbinger for a sweet year. Though it is easy enough simply to dip apple slices in honey, here are some other ideas for adding honey and apples to the menu.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Paris With Palm Trees: Hawaii's French Festival
description: French fashion, food and art will be celebrated in Hawaii next month. From Saturday to Oct. 12, the French Festival will present special events, exhibitions and performances at over 20 Honolulu locations.

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: With the Guggenheim in Bilbao, Spain, Frank Gehry has transcended the future and taken us into eternity.

title: Altruism For Fun and Profit
description: I find fault in the insinuation that riders run the risk of personal debt if they do not meet the fund-raising minimum. Individuals who cannot meet the minimum may drop out of the ride and avoid any out-of-pocket payments.

title: Ideas & Trends; Dissociative Fugue and Other Ailments
description: FEELING a tad testy when some idiot roars into your rear-view mirror to tailgate an inch from your bumper? You might not get much sympathy from your shrink, because road rage isn't yet listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, LILLIAN
description: ROBBINS-Lillian. On September 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Adored mother of Sheri and the late Ronald. Loving grandmother of Seth and Chad. Devoted sister of Ruth Bergman and Leonard Adell. Loved mother-in-law of Bonnie Robbins. Dear sister-in-law of Bernice Adell. Caring aunt and sweet, warm friend to all. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Altruism For Fun and Profit
description: The people making real money off the AIDS Rides are the dozen or so companies that sell or rent the products and services that are necessary for the comfort and safety of the participants. The real reason the expenses are as high as they are is the difficulty the rides' organizers have in signing up corporate sponsors to help defray the costs, as well as their inability to get donations of expensive necessities like food and temporary kitchen and shower facilities, not any untoward profiteering on the part of the organizers.

title: Who Runs This Game? Baseball Squabbles Into the Playoffs
description: Buoyed by its most successful season since 1993, Major League Baseball will launch its playoff prelude to the World Series on Tuesday on a potentially threatening note. Its umpires may be poised to throw out any player, utilityman or star, if he so much as looks quizzically at one of them.

title: It's 10 P.M.: Here's Where the Kids Are
description: THERE are more than seven million New Yorkers. Some 650,000 of them are teen-agers. That's 650,000 running the punishing marathon from age 13 to 19 in a superheated urban environment. Teen-agers may grow up faster in New York than anywhere else in the country. They may be more jaded, and more likely to see their street fashion and their language translated into the popular culture.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TOYS THAT BIND

title: Q. & A.
description: Habendum Clause? Yes In Deed

title: Going Up? Maybe, Maybe Not
description: ''I tell you, it's very nice, it's really pretty,'' Mildred Fogel said of her building's new elevator. ''If it would only work, it would be all right.''

title: Sports of All Sorts on Roads Out of Westport
description: OVER breakfast in a Westport diner recently, Jim Nantz was discussing his career in general and his peripatetic life style in particular. When asked how many days this year he had spent on the road, he put down his cup of coffee and smiled.

title: Body Politics
description: The Strange Death

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Cleaning Up Environment Along With the Pants

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, SHIRLEY
description: CLARKE-Shirley. Film Forum notes with deep sadness the loss of a wonderful filmmaker and delighful iconoclast. Karen Cooper Bruce Goldstein

title: Technology Makes Us Richer; The Paper-Bag Revolution
description: Envision, if you can, a technology that sharply improves the efficiency with which goods can be delivered to the consumer; that, in the view of one prominent economist, is the ''most effective innovation during the preceding decade in speeding up American retail sales''; that within only a few years of its introduction becomes a pervasive feature of American life.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Monstrum

title: Irish Are Granted Three Wishes, but Still Lose
description: They call the scenario ''sudden change.'' The defense creates a turnover. The offense takes the field.

title: Products, From 10-Cent Filters to M.R.I. Scanners, in Demand
description: WHILE the Island may not be the manufacturing mecca of the Eighties, the region has not lost its touch for making products that are innovative and significant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARIS, DR. LEON
description: PARIS-Dr. Leon. Age 88, died suddenly on September 23, 1997, in Florida. Predeceased by loving wife Jerry. Beloved father of Lenny (Alvin) Katz, Philip (Sally), Michael, and Judy. Brother of Sarah. Devoted Poppop to grandchildren and great-grandchidren. He will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTERWEIS, HARRY L.
description: OSTERWEIS-Harry L. 88. Died in NYC September 25, 1997. He was the husband of May Louise Bodenheimer Osterweis. He was the son of the late Rose and Gustav Osterweis. Born February 5, 1909 in New Haven, CT. He graduated Yale College in 1931 and later Yale Law School. He served in the Army Air Force during WW II leaving as Lieutenant Colonel and also served in the Army Intelligence Division. He practiced international patent law working for the international firm of Schwartzkoff Industries. He was a member of the Yale Club of NY. Funeral service will be private and interment in Mishkan Israel Cemetery, New Haven CT.

title: Guides for Making the College Try
description: FOR college hopefuls at high schools across the country, this is the season of high anxiety. In a few days, the heart of the testing season will begin, with many 11th graders confronting the P.S.A.T. Soon afterward, many seniors will grapple with the S.A.T. Then there's the scariest test of all -- the existential one that involves Making a Decision.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Huge Hills Project Gaining Momentum in Bernards
description: IN construction that began in 1994 and picked up momentum in the last year, 1,158 town houses and detached homes have been or are being built in the Bernards Township portion of the 1,800-acre Hills development atop the Watchung Hills, which spills into neighboring Bedminster.

title: Shrub Oak Library Is Host to Fair
description: NEXT Saturday the aromas of different foods and the beat of the music may well make fairgoers think they are in the middle of a New York City street fair, not at the John C. Hart Memorial Library in Shrub Oak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, HOWARD
description: GOLDBERG-Howard. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend to many, died on September 26, 1997. Served in the armed forces from 1943 to 1946 and was a founding member of Temple Emanuel New Hyde Park. He will be forever missed by all.

title: Israel Is Turning 50: Let Celebrations Begin
description: Next year marks Israel's 50th anniversary, but the yearlong celebration will begin early -- on Oct. 6 with a concert by the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra at Frederic Mann Auditorium in Tel Aviv. It will be followed the next night by a performance of ''The Marriage of Figaro'' that will open the 50th-jubilee season of the New Israeli Opera in Tel Aviv.

title: Airline Clubs
description: To the Editor: I received a wonderful birthday gift from my sister many years ago: a life membership to the Admirals Club of American Airlines. It has been a pleasure and more than a life saver.

title: Leslie Goodwin, John Stonestreet
description: Leslie Todd Goodwin, a daughter of Beverley Benjamin Goodwin of New York and Todd Goodwin of Southampton, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Paul Stonestreet, the son of Mrs. Craig Bennett Stonestreet of West Newton, Mass., and the late Mr. Stonestreet. The Rev. Warren E. Haynes performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton.

title: A Chance for Algerian Peace
description: For the first time in years, there is a small but significant opening for peace in Algeria. If successfully exploited, it could eventually bring an end to the horrific violence that has been tearing that country apart since 1992 and has so far cost 60,000 lives. But this precious opportunity will likely be lost unless France, which provides Algeria's military-backed Government with diplomatic support in Europe and $1 billion a year in subsidized loans, uses its leverage to insist on a serious Government effort to negotiate a compromise peace.

title: Correction
description: A brief report last Sunday about plans to put a bicycle path along a rail line in Wayne, Pequannock and Riverdale misidentified the county planning to seek Federal funds for the project. It was Morris, not Mercer.

title: New Designer to Take a Seat at Ford's Drawing Board
description: ONE of Detroit's most influential auto designers of recent times is retiring, and the Ford Motor Company will hand over his responsibilities to a young designer whom many consider one of the world's most promising up-and-comers.

title: A Plaintive Note Heard in a Heartbeat
description: DR. ELIZABETH BEAUTYMAN put her stethoscope to my chest earlier this month and decided that the murmurs of my heart sounded louder than they had two years ago, when she said they sounded louder than they had three years before that. This time, however, she sent me up the med chain for an echocardiogram. She suspected that a valve had begun to lose its snap; if it was the mitral, it would have to be watched, and I might need antibiotics before dental work. I wasn't thrilled, but I was glad she knew my heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, PHILIP
description: GOLDFARB-Philip, peacefully at home after a very long illness. Beloved husband for sixty years of Helen; devoted father of Peter; loving uncle, great-uncle; dear brother of Sidney. Owner of the Goldfarb Novelty Company; longtime member of the Friars and Lone Star Clubs. Service Monday, 12:00 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRCHNER, MERIAN
description: KIRCHNER-Merian. On September 25, 1997. We cherish the memory of a gentle and courageous lady who enriched the lives of all who knew her, including her late and beloved husband, Engelbert, his family, her nieces and nephew, and her extended family of friends. That family grew to embrace readers of the ''Betsy-Tacy'' books written by Merian's mother, Maud Hart Lovelace, which originated as bedtime stories for her daughter. A gifted writer herself, Merian of the lively mind, tender heart and indomitable spirit will be missed but not forgotten.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; Where to Stoke Up With a Little Heat as Days Get Cooler
description: On a recent cool autumn evening, the breeze in Montclair was hardly tropical, and there was not a palm tree to be seen on Bloomfield Avenue. But inside the storefront with the cheery purple and yellow neon sign, Rocky's kitchen was serving up pure Jamaica.

title: It's 10 P.M.: Here's Where the Kids Are
description: THERE are more than seven million New Yorkers. Some 650,000 of them are teen-agers. That's 650,000 running the punishing marathon from age 13 to 19 in a superheated urban environment. Teen-agers may grow up faster in New York than anywhere else in the country. They may be more jaded, and more likely to see their street fashion and their language translated into the popular culture.

title: Have Paws, Will Travel
description: ALISON L. SMITH of Houston has recently added a ''sweet, playful dog'' to her household, so she and her husband are interested in a new form of travel -- one that takes them to places where dogs are welcome and their pet can ''freely run, explore, play and swim.''

title: Follow Your Nose
description: SMELL The Secret Seducer. By Piet Vroon with Anton van Amerongen and Hans de Vries. Translated by Paul Vincent. 226 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23.

title: The Good Loser
description: The Senator lost an election but not his sense of self. Thomas Mallon's article ''The Good Loser'' (Sept. 7) portrayed Bob Dole as a gentleman's politician and showed that men who accept defeat well should not be thought of as ''good losers'' but rather as great men.

title: Beyond Beauty, Art That Takes Action
description: ''BAULE: AFRICAN ART/Western Eyes,'' an exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery, is many things at once, all of them stimulating. It is a gathering of astonishingly beautiful objects; a radical rethinking of traditional museum presentations of art; and, perhaps most important, a suggested model for a new kind of art history in which the very act of seeing art is redefined.

title: September 21-27; It's the Year of The Aardvark
description: Drawing from the lessons of Barney and Big Bird, an aardvark has emerged as the latest public-television hit -- both on the tube and in the toy stores.

title: Legislators to Vote on How to Pay for Courthouse Changes
description: HOPING to avoid millions of dollars in sanctions, the County Board of Legislators is poised to act Oct. 6 to finance the design phase of a plan to rehabilitate the County Courthouse and build an eight-floor adjacent annex in White Plains.

title: With the Giants Feeling Overwhelmed, Fassel Backpedals on Offense
description: It's as if Giants Coach Jim Fassel taught his kid to ride a bicycle one day, then entered him in the Tour de France a week later. Today, he is putting the training wheels back on. Son, let's start over.

title: Amy Schermerhorn,Todd Bertsch
description: Amy Merrill Schermerhorn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Schermerhorn of Tulsa, Okla., was married there yesterday to Todd Colin Bertsch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. William Bertsch Jr. of Oyster Bay, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. James Miller performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Saving the Ghosts of the State's Industrial Past
description: THE DARK ZONE. It may sound like the title of a spooky movie but it is really nothing that scary. The Dark Zone is simply a nickname given to the dimly lighted storage area at the Museum of Connecticut History, in the State Library building in Hartford.

title: On Language; Over and Outreach
description: When he was first asked about his presence at a 1996 fund-raiser in a California Buddhist temple, Vice President Al Gore claimed he had no idea it was a fund-raiser, which has now become a politically dirty word. He thought the purpose of the gathering was ''community outreach.''

title: Skirting the Skateboarders
description: Ever since the birth of skateboarding in the 1960's, the activity has been dominated by wiry adolescent boys whose rebel-without-a-car regalia generally included baggy Bermuda shorts and T-shirts sporting pithy slogans like ''Asphalt rules.'' Recent additions to the fashion statement include boxers worn on the head and pierced extremities.

title: Unnatural Selection
description: THE PONY FISH'S GLOW

title: At the Whitney, Feisty Women From an Earlier Era
description: THE Whitney Museum's branch in Stamford is fairly bursting with black and white drawings and prints; the works make up an exhibition called ''Between the Wars: Women Artists of the Whitney Studio Club and Museum.'' The era the show spans gives a good clue to its contents: essentially realism, often with deft social commentary.

title: Learning the Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Stone, Christian Hartigan
description: Elizabeth Marie Stone, a daughter of Justice Parker J. Stone and Mrs. Stone of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Christian Michael Hartigan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice H. Hartigan 2d of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen Hornat performed the ceremony at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Syracuse.

title: Miss Asplundh And Mr. Gardner
description: Meredith Paige Asplundh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher B. Asplundh of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., was married last evening to Timothy Rittenhouse Gardner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Gardner of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Kurt H. Asplundh, a Swedenborgian minister and the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Bryn Athyn (Pa.) Cathedral.

title: The Miracle In Bilbao
description: Your story offers no reason why the new Guggenheim, with its fantastical constructs, belongs in Spain. How about this? Spain was the home of Antonio Gaudi (1852-1926), one of very few architects who, like Gehry, make you happy to be alive.

title: Strokes (As Few as Possible) of Inspiration
description: TO be only a spectator in the Main Gallery of the Morris Museum these days is to deprive yourself. The nine clusters of sculpture there are exempt from the almost universal prohibition against touching art: they're meant to receive a lot of hard knocks, soft taps and occasional swear words.

title: Shelter Island: Paradise Lost
description: THE noise rolls up from the mouth of the creek in short, angry bursts, perhaps a stinkpot motor trying to turn over, maybe a large dog cornered by a tick-mad deer. I know I should be annoyed, but I can't dredge up any negative energy, even when I figure out that the noise is the amplified waste product of a musical group let out of its garage to stimulate drinking at an open-air bar at the local marina.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Older Association of Yemenis Yielding to Younger League
description: After nearly two decades of serving the Yemenis in New York, known among Arab immigrants for their tightly knit community, the National Association of Yemeni Immigrants is unraveling.

title: Torre Shows Saving Grace Of Serenity
description: The pictures of Joe Torre sitting impassively in the Yankee dugout rarely change. His baseball cap is tugged down tight over his sleepy face, his arms are folded, his body is slumped slightly on the bench and he is chewing on a peach pit. He looks more like a grandfather watching a Little League game than the manager of the most storied franchise in baseball history.

title: Notable 'Firsts'; First Mass-Housing Suburb
description: Troops returning home to the New York metropolitan area after World War II marched into a housing crisis. Apartments were scarce and houses, when they could be found, were too expensive for many veterans. Then, with astounding speed, William J. Levitt turned potato fields on the Hempstead Plains into Levittown, the first mass-housing suburb in the country. Levittown set the pace for phenomenal postwar population growth on Long Island in the 1950's and 1960's as new suburban communities transformed the region.

title: In the Region/Long Island; The Darling of the 50's and 60's Makes a Comeback
description: THE Meadows at Hauppauge, where sales began last weekend, is one of several new subdivisions in which developers are reviving a design that had fallen out of favor -- the high ranch.

title: To Whitman's Opponent: Make a Name for Yourself
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstart American Persimmons Add to Fall Colors
description: The American persimmon tree ''has received more criticism, both adverse and favorable, than almost any known species,'' W. F. Fletcher wrote for an Agriculture Department Farmers' Bulletin in 1915.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 28, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Energy Dept. Is Weighing the Fate of Old Radioactive Capsules
description: Above a pool that is the most radioactive spot in America, where a human being would get a lethal dose in less than half a second, two technicians with a remote-controlled video camera peered at racks of submerged stainless steel capsules, looking for the ones that were ready for their annual ''clunk test.''

title: Power Lunches, In My Apartment
description: I'M a young woman who runs a small, but thriving, writing business. But I've often had this question vis-a-vis business lunches: Just how unusual and personalized can I be with them and not lose every client I've ever had? How creative can I become while still looking professional and bolstering the bottom line?

title: A Literary Pilgrimage
description: LAST year I set out on an eight-day trip along the southeastern coast of Norway in the footsteps of the 18th-century British author Mary Wollstonecraft. Wollstonecraft had made this journey two centuries earlier and movingly described it in her last finished book, ''Letters Written During a Short Residence in Sweden, Norway and Denmark.''

title: A Trove of Ethnic Delicacies
description: INTERESTED in a trip around the world that will cost almost nothing? You can visit this country without ever leaving Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUBECK, JOHN
description: SCHUBECK-John. Veteran broadcast newsman. Los Angeles, September 26, 1997. John Schubeck a veteran of local television news died of multi-systems failure at the Columbia West Hills Medical Center early Friday morning. John's career spanned 35 years making him one of the most distinguished newscasters in the country. He began broadcasting in Detroit, MI, on radio station WJR, frequently teaming up with J.P. McCarthy. Eventually his knowledgeable yet warm style drew large audiences as he anchored local news on network stations in NY and Los Angeles. He was a recipient of many broadcast journalst awards including several Emmies and the Gold Mike. John Schubeck was a graduate of the University of Michigan and Loyola Law School. During his college years in Ann Arbor, he was heard on WUOM and as a half-time voice of the Wolverine football games. As an Evans Scholar, he became the top ranked amateur golfer in the country, eventually participating in many pro am and celebrity golf tournaments. He is survived by his wife Meghan, his mother Anne, his sister Barbara and five children: Tina, Gretchen, Elliott, Jonathon and Avery.

title: Technology Makes Us Escapist; The Cult Of the Mind
description: They came from cyberspace, sporting ''My Favorite Martian'' haircuts and ''Star Trek''-inspired arm patches that read ''Heaven's Gate Away Team.'' The saucer-worshiping ''cybergeeks'' in the Heaven's Gate cult were ''never truly of this earth'' in the words of Andrea Peyser, a columnist with The New York Post.

title: Correction
description: A report on Sept. 14 about the wedding of Barbara Ann Glassman and Arthur Mark Rubin misstated the university from which Mr. Rubin graduated. It is Yale, not Princeton.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Marine Studies Give Southampton a Boost
description: IN intercollegiate sports students at Southampton College are called the Colonials. In academic competition, they are more like the Starfish.

title: One Man's Dream, Blissful Jones Beach Is Like No Other Place
description: AS the blue-gray waves roll in, curl and break, thousands of delighted bathers frolic in the frothy white surf. The beach of sugar-fine sand is the backdrop to the giant mosaic of brightly colored swimsuits, towels, umbrellas and chairs and human skin ranging across every racial hue and gradation of tan.

title: Giants in Candy Waging Battle Over a Tiny Toy
description: For the past several weeks a little-noticed war involving chocolate balls has been raging across the capital's specialized battlefields of regulatory agencies, Congress and consumer organizations.

title: Family Duos in City Island Series
description: IF this is Sunday, it must be time for another noon concert at Le Refuge Inn on City Island. For more than five years, the series has not missed a week, the repertory centered on music from the Baroque and Classical eras, but especially since last January, when ''Sundays on the Island'' inherited a grand piano, often moving further down the chronological line. Today, for instance, the violinist Ariel Shamal, the cellist Iris Regev and the pianist Ilan Rechtman complement Beethoven's ''Archduke'' Trio with some of Mr. Rechtman's ''Jazzicals,'' amusing pop takes on classical favorites.

title: 'The Judas Economy'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACNEIL, JANE MOORE
description: MacNEIL-Jane Moore, on September 24, at 79, at her home in Manhattan. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street), on Sunday, September 28, at 3:30 PM.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 28, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, ELSIE
description: SHAPIRO-Elsie. September 27, 1992 Missed by many Remembered with love

title: Special Today: What Technology Is Doing to Us
description: Technology is changing the worlds of politics, business, and entertainment. A special issue of The Magazine asks, what is it doing to us?

title: The Good Loser
description: I'm certainly in favor of remembering the brave and valiant women and men who served in World War II. But we need to be realistic. The juxtaposition of welfare reform resulting in draconian cuts and Bob Dole's promise to raise $100 million for another statue is disturbing. That this has the backing of the President and Congress, even as they are busy taking food out of the mouths of the hungry, I find offensive. Health care, enough to eat, a decent place to live and education are more important than another statue to World War II.

title: Not So Tough
description: There is a less-aggressive black leather jacket being worn this fall, replacing the tough, zipper-decorated biker gear. The new jackets merge the masculine/feminine polarities that dominate contemporary fashion. Here, the lure is not so much the novelty associated with women's clothing as the functional stability of men's clothes. The color is all-black, with an occasional brown, and interest is achieved through mixing textures: shiny or matte-finished leather jackets with knitted or woven clothing. The wearers become shadows, without ornamental distractions.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on Sept. 14 about cellular telephone antennas referred incorrectly to Peter Hudiberg, a member of the Cellular Phone Task Force. He is not a founder of the group. It was founded by Arthur Firstenberg and Pelda Levey.

title: Scholar Takes On His Toughest Study of Race
description: For John Hope Franklin, the problem was maddening: the orchids he was trying to grow 37 years ago in the window box of his Brooklyn apartment either died or failed to bloom. His solution was typical of his approach to a lifelong study of race relations in America: he read everything he could on the subject.

title: Ready to Rev Up the Zamboni
description: The N.H.L. regular season starts Wednesday. Here is a scouting report with teams listed in projected order of finish.

title: Now for Some of the Bad Things
description: THE assignment was to write an essay about the worst of Long Island, to temper the accolades about to be recorded in a special section dedicated to the Island's best. At first I refused, offended by the suggestion that Long Island is anything but a suburban Eden, a fish-shaped isle of serenity.

title: POSTINGS: $7.6 Million Residence in East New York; Rental Housing For the Elderly
description: A $7.6 million, six-story residence with one-bedroom rental units for low-income elderly couples or individuals is going up at 568 Rockaway Parkway, between Linden Boulevard and Church Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Parks to Study Snowmobiles' Effect on Bison
description: To settle a lawsuit brought by environmental and animal rights groups, officials at Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks have agreed to study whether snowmobiles in the parks encourage bison to migrate into Montana and Wyoming.

title: Farther Along
description: NEARER, MY GOD

title: Fake Flowers, Real Critters and, Oh, Yes, a Mountain
description: THE FLOWERS ARE FAKE; THE dirt is real. So are the dogs and the sheep. The hippo is only a clever contrivance. But when the big wall falls, that's no illusion.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Dear Mom and Dad: I Love Paris
description: ''My unbiased opinion is that my material is the best and that reviews will deal with my work in great detail.'' So the Hungarian-born, Paris-based photographer Brassai (1899-1984) wrote to his parents on Dec. 4, 1931. It had been barely a month since the best art-publishing house in Paris had agreed to publish ''Paris de Nuit,'' his collection of photographs of the city by night, and it would be another year until the book, which established his reputation as (in Henry Miller's words) ''the eye of Paris,'' would be published. But Brassai, at 32, was exultant with characteristic self-confidence. It was this indomitable faith in his abilities and his unconquerable optimism that carried him through the period covered in Brassai: Letters to my Parents (University of Chicago, $29.95), a delightful volume (published in Hungarian in 1980 and translated by Peter Laki and Barna Kantor) that collects the letters Brassai sent from his arrival in Berlin to study art at the age of 21 to when he fled Paris during the German invasion in 1940. The book provides a fascinating insight into how a bright individual slowly found his calling (he took his first photograph in March 1930). Although rich in anecdotes about endless struggles with money, food and lodging and in descriptions of the ''enormous and radiant magnetism'' of Paris and of the chic Parisian circles to which Brassai was invited, ''Letters to My Parents'' hardly mentions the artists and intellectuals -- from Picasso and Andre Breton to Man Ray and Jacques Prevert -- he befriended during those years. This omission makes perfect sense: what mattered most to his parents, Brassai knew, was that he could support himself and find himself as an artist. ''Oh, I await and fear the moment in which I will find my own voice, but also the place that will multiply it,'' Brassai wrote in December 1924, 10 months after arriving in the French capital. He came to the right place. Christine Schwartz Hartley

title: In Rescuing a Relative, a Helping or a Heavy Hand?
description: ''Rescuing a Relative Who Won't Accept Help'' (Aug. 10), by Roy Furchgott, described the author's efforts over the last year to restore the financial affairs of his 95-year-old great-uncle, Joseph Nathan Rosolio of Thomasville, Ga. The article drew various responses from readers.

title: Lisa Higgins, Oliver Dow
description: Elizabeth Shorey Higgins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Prentiss C. Higgins of Wellesley, Mass., was married yesterday to Oliver Parker Dow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Burton Dow of Buffalo. The Rev. Eugene V. N. Goetchius, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: A Cafe of Many Cuisines in Stonington
description: WATER Street Cafe in Stonington has only been open since June, replacing Harbor View, a longtime occupant of the premises. The change is 180 degrees, both in looks and in food -- and for the better. Instead of a classic French menu that had become ossified in the current era of lighter, more imaginative fare, the cafe offers a small menu of fresh, intriguing dishes that draw on various cuisines. It serves such dishes in immaculate all-white surroundings, punctuated by vibrantly colorful modern paintings and nautical-blue seat and booth cushioning.

title: Fliers by Moving Companies Signal a Double Offense
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/A Late 19th-Century Gatehouse in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; When She Finally Saw It, It Was Love at First Sight
description: BACK when it was built, in the time of bustles and beaver-top hats, the gatehouse for the Flower Estate was nestled alongside the hill leading up to the fine brick mansion. Both overlooked the spring-fed pool that provided water for the horses in the family stables.

title: It's Hevesi, Financed and Visible, Against a Field That Isn't

title: Elizabeth Hickey And Kevin Blaney
description: Elizabeth Ward Hickey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hickey of Essex Fells, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin Joseph Blaney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Blaney of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Frank J. McNulty performed the ceremony at St. Peter the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Amagansett, N.Y.

title: A Cleaner That Is Kind to the Environment
description: HOW do businesses get started? In Diane Weiser's case, it was ''the night of the living dead Laundromat'' that lead her to a new industry.

title: Down the Aisle, With Checkbook
description: I'VE done Mary Kay, I've done Tupperware, now I'm in lingerie,'' said Bette DeVincenzo. Let me add quickly that Ms. DeVincenzo was actually in proper business attire as she handed me a business card that identified her as a sales representative for a company called Undercover Wear. The card had a baby blue feather attached to it.

title: POSTINGS: Daffy's to the Meadowlands; A Warehouse Stays In Fashion
description: A 215,000-square-foot warehouse off the New Jersey Turnpike in the Meadowlands in North Bergen, built in 1955 as a fashion distribution center by Sears, Roebuck but empty for nearly a decade, is soon to reopen, still in the fashion business but with a new role. It is being refurbished as corporate headquarters, distribution center and retail store for Daffy's, the off-price clothing retailer.

title: Mia Reynolds, John Chimples
description: EVERYTHING about Mia Reynolds and John Chimples's wedding seemed to have been scooped up from the sea, beginning with the invitations. They were printed on yellowed pieces of paper, burnt around the edges like a pirate's treasure map, and rolled up inside clear plastic bottles with sand, tiny shells and bits of dune grass. The labels had pictures of a full moon at the beach, with the addresses typed over the surf.

title: Europe Offering Free Calls, But First, a Word From . . .
description: Filippo Simonelli lifts the receiver of his phone, punches some buttons and a voice barks into his ear: ''Fresh pizza? Ristorante Buon Amico. Via dei Campi, 24.'' No, he did not call a pizza parlor. He is part of a curious experiment in which some Europeans are being offered free calls if they will also listen to commercials.

title: Of Power Brokers and Race Cards; Educational Establishment Ignores Ethnic Realities
description: To the Editor:

Cullinan of Sands Point, N.Y., and the late George W. Ellinger. The Rev. Lidabell Pollard performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in New Cannan.

title: A New Space for Fleetwood Stage
description: GIVE a good director a couple of chairs, a plank of wood and a light bulb, or some such manifestation of the elementary and the minimal (the polite word for meager) -- and theater will happen. Whether it is in a five-flight walk-up, in an unfinished basement or, of course, in a barn, the show will go on.

title: Airline Clubs
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's ''Airline Clubs: Worth the Cost?'' (Practical Traveler, Aug. 24) concludes that the clubs are expensive if not a business expense, and too crowded.

description: A body burned beyond recognition was found outside the Bronx Terminal Market in the South Bronx yesterday morning, the police said. Officer Leslie Cardona, a police spokeswoman, said the body was burned so badly that the victim's sex, age and race could not be determined.

title: Of High Morals and Short Memories
description: So Marv Albert has been deemed unfit to be a network sportscaster. Why? It cannot be that his professional talents have deserted him, that his bark is suddenly less potent than his bite, or maybe the other way round. Nothing so practical. It must be a moral matter.

title: Chronicle
description: Good thing that HERMAN DANIEL FARRELL 3d's father was not an accountant or a salesman. He would surely have lacked provocative material on which to base the play he has written, ''Bedfellows.''

Bennett of Utah sat quietly steaming as representatives from Common Cause and others who call themselves reformers insisted to the Senate committee examining campaign finance practices that the country desperately needed tighter restrictions on political contributions.

title: Testing Time in the Everglades
description: Surely the most ambitious environmental pledge to emerge from the Clinton White House is its promise to restore the Everglades and Florida Bay to good health. It has made heartening progress in a very short time, extracting large sums from a budget-conscious Congress to get the project under way. Now, however, President Clinton faces a serious test of his commitment to the enterprise. He must decide whether to allow plans for a major commercial airport south of Miami and adjacent to the Everglades to move forward or to halt the project pending a complete review of its environmental consequences.

But the pain in Cone's right shoulder is not totally throttling him, so he will pitch Game 1 of the division playoffs Tuesday against the Cleveland Indians.

The slaying, and its classification, led to several civil rights demonstrations that drew hundreds of protesters to the quiet village of Dobbs Ferry in Westchester County.

Brady, who was wounded in a 1981 assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan, and who inspired a Federal law mandating a waiting period for handgun purchases, will travel here today to endorse Ilan Plawker, a Democratic candidate for the State Senate in the 39th District and a fellow gun-control advocate.

title: System Is Swamped for Immigrants in Quest of Citizenship
description: In the midst of a vast movement of immigrants to citizenship that dwarfs those of earlier eras in its magnitude and diversity, the creaky, understaffed machinery of naturalization ground virtually to a halt last week in Brooklyn and Queens, national centers of immigration.

title: Innovation Kvaener Leads Whitbread
description: The yacht Innovation Kvaener maintained its lead yesterday over nine other boats in the Whitbread Round the World Race for the Volvo Trophy.

title: From Hard-Fought to Vicious: Restraint Is First Casualty in Mayoral Race
description: In recent weeks, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has portrayed Ruth W. Messinger, his struggling Democratic opponent, as a promoter of dirty-book stores. He has called her a defender of the killer of an Attica prison guard. (The evidence for both charges is questionable.) Yesterday, he all but said that the city's loss of the Brooklyn Dodgers, the Giants and the Jets was Ms. Messinger's fault, suggesting she was an enemy of professional sports.

title: I Raised Money From My Office. So?
description: I get an odd sort of flashback when I hear about the uproar over the Vice President's fund-raising phone calls. I can see him reaching for the phone, dialing the number, making his pitch. I can see it all because I've done it myself, under roughly similar circumstances.

title: Mets Wrap Up Their Season With a Victory and Tears
description: Emotion ambushed the Mets once their season ended yesterday at Shea Stadium. Somebody started the hugs after reliever Greg McMichael sealed the team's 88th victory with a strikeout, and pretty soon everybody was hugging everybody, players started bawling and the eyes of Manager Bobby Valentine spilled with tears.

title: Foreign Affairs; Excuse Me, Mohamad
description: Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, used the latest World Bank meeting in Hong Kong to denounce the evils of globalization, after Malaysia's stocks and currency were ravaged by global traders. Mr. Mahathir blasted ''morons'' like George Soros, who speculate in currencies, and he criticized the ''great powers,'' accusing them of forcing Asians to open their domestic markets to global traders and then manipulating their currencies to destroy them as competitors. U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin listened diplomatically to this outburst. But here's what I suspect Mr. Rubin would have liked to have said to Mr. Mahathir:

title: The Talk in the Town Where Whitman Announced: Less Than Solid Support
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced her bid for re-election in the spring, she chose this small, middle-class town with a Republican mayor whose voters supported her over Jim Florio four years ago.

description: The Financial Times, the salmon-colored newspaper that is a business staple in Europe, is expanding in the United States in the expectation that its international focus will match America's growing interest in overseas markets.

title: Making His Point, Brown Lifts The Giants
description: When Giants quarterback Dave Brown threw his second touchdown pass in the Giants' 14-9 victory over the New Orleans Saints today, he turned to the Saints' bench and pointed his right index finger directly at their coach, Mike Ditka.

description: Cary Lu, a scientist, author and film maker known for his ability to explain science and technology to children and adults, died of cancer on Wednesday, according to his wife. He lived in Kirkland, Wash., and was 51 years old.

description: As dawn broke this morning, Hong Kong's unelected lawmakers approved plans for next year's legislative election, sharply curtailing the number of people eligible to vote in the first election under Chinese rule.

Christine Todd Whitman's office said she has committed $7.5 million in state aid for development of a 200-room hotel and conference center next to the War Memorial.

description: WORKMAN-David Thorpe. On September 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Sue. Devoted father of Betsy Lee and Cindy. Loving brother of Peter. Cherished son of Bernard. This generous, respected man will be profoundly missed by all who knew and loved him. Sevices Monday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation, 1 Gustav Levy Place, NYC 10011.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about the filmmaker Shirley Clarke referred imprecisely to a documentary she directed. The film, ''Robert Frost: A Lover's Quarrel With the World,'' won an Academy Award in 1963 not for her but for its producer, Robert Hughes.

title: 2 Are Hurt in Rutgers Brawl
description: A Rutgers University student and a university police officer were stabbed early yesterday in a brawl after a party at a student center, the Associated Press reported.

title: High-Technology Job Fair Is Now an Industry in Itself
description: Allied Signal Aerospace has a chronic need for embedded software developers, people who write the programs that are already installed when someone buys a computer. That is why Christopher A. Lewis, a senior staffing consultant, was at a Tech Expo job fair recently, schmoozing and collecting resumes.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Held in Death of Grocer
description: Three teen-agers were charged yesterday with killing a grocer early Saturday during a bungled robbery in the Kips Bay section of Manhattan, the police said. As residents mourned the loss of their grocer, a popular local figure, they said they were stunned to learn that the suspects arrested by the police were all youths from the neighborhood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, MANUEL (MANNY)
