description: MAXWELL - Manuel (Manny). The entire NYU Law School community mourns the passing of one of its great citizens. Always there to guide and to help, Manny was a model lawyer and a wonderful friend. We will remember him with love always. Martin Lipton, Chair of Trustees John Sexton, Dean

title: Behind Murrell, 3-2 Jets Break New Ground
description: If you didn't know this team was the Jets, if you didn't know its history, you would think this was a club accustomed to winning, and winning convincingly.

title: Magazine Publishers Circling Wagons Against Advertisers
description: By some measures it was an executive's dream. True, Fortune magazine's cover story about I.B.M.'s chairman and chief executive, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., described Mr. Gerstner as arrogant, brusque and obsessed with status. But it also hailed him for doing the job at I.B.M. ''better than anyone expected'' and repositioning the company ''against all odds'' -- attributes by which most top executives would presumably wish to be judged.

title: An Atonal Couple, Muddling Through
description: The biggest work Schoenberg produced after he had opened the door into atonality was a light opera: ''From One Day to the Next'' might be the best translation of its title, ''Von Heute auf Morgen.'' It is rarely performed in the theater, so the new film version -- ''From Today Until Tomorrow'' and being shown tonight at 6:15 at the New York Film Festival -- affords a rare opportunity to savor Schoenberg at his weirdest and to consider what he might have been up to.

title: Mount Airy Journal; Reality Plays a Bit Part on Mayberry Days
description: Don't tell the thousands of people visiting here this weekend that Mayberry never really existed. Don't tell them that Andy Griffith was careful to never equate Mayberry with his hometown of Mount Airy.

title: Speaking for China's Silent Voices
description: As the White House prepares to roll out the red carpet for Chinese President Jiang Zemin next month, China's most prominent dissident, Wei Jingsheng, is dying in prison. Mr. Wei has been there since 1994, the year President Clinton decided not to link most-favored-nation trading status with human rights conditions in China.

title: Jury to Be Picked in 2d Oklahoma Bomb Trial
description: With comparatively little fanfare, jury selection will begin on Monday in the trial of Terry L. Nichols, the second man charged with murder and conspiracy in the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: New Apple Ad Lifts Off From Disney's Land
description: Apple Computer Inc. has not officially adopted the Walt Disney ditty ''It's a Small World'' as a corporate song. But it might as well after the cozy events surrounding the introduction last night of a highly anticipated advertising campaign.

title: Patents; Some new products and approaches for making lice insecta non grata on children's heads.
description: HEAD lice are the unspoken scourge of the school-age set. The tiny critters indiscriminately infest families of all socio-economic backgrounds and would just as soon take up residence in clean hair as in dirty hair. Worst of all, as many parents can testify, they are a resilient species and can keep reappearing despite repeated washings with lice shampoos.

title: Possible Misuse Is No Cause to Ban Thalidomide
description: To the Editor:

title: Independent Films Draw a Financier: Icahn Sees Prospects in Distribution
description: Here is the no-risk formula for an independent film distribution company: Find a small gem like ''Sling Blade'' or ''Breaking the Waves'' at a festival. Pick it up cheaply. Release it in movie theaters. Keep the overhead low. Then make a bundle by selling the company to a major Hollywood studio.

title: Why just watch 'E.R.' when you can talk about it at the same time.
description: The time: 10 P.M. E.D.T. Thursday.

title: Wells to Start Game 3, But He Still Isn't Happy
description: David Wells has not been officially told, but he will start Game 3 of the division series against the Cleveland Indians on Saturday because Manager Joe Torre has already answered one of the delicate questions hovering above the Yankees. But that does not mean Wells will be elated. He is not happy. Not even close.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Hearings Set on Bears
description: With the number of black bears and people -- in New Jersey continuing to grow, state environmental officials are holding a series of hearings this week on how to keep the two populations from colliding.

title: Free Spirits Flock to Park to Hear Ginsberg Poetry
description: The message on the answering machine giving directions to yesterday's memorial reading of Allen Ginsberg's poem ''Howl'' could not have been more fitting: from the East 72d Street entrance to Central Park, ''follow the flower children'' to Frisbee Hill.

title: Mason Rankin, 56, Is Dead; Founded AIDS Group in Utah
description: Mason Rankin, a Salt Lake City businessman who had such an abundance of compassion for people with AIDS that he kept scores of volunteer knitters furiously clicking away to supply afghans, sweaters, scarves and hats to people in Utah's H.I.V. community, died on Sept. 21 at a hospital in Salt Lake City. He was 56.

title: MIDEAST LEADERS TAKING FIRST STEP TO REVIVING TALKS
description: Israeli and Palestinian leaders said today that they expected their meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in New York on Monday would lead to the revival of long-stalled committee talks on such issues as the release of Palestinian prisoners and an airport in Gaza.

title: How to Make a Poor School Change; A Well-Financed Exodus of Students Is Countered by a Flurry of Fixing
description: Last winter, a philanthropist from Manhattan named Virginia Gilder decided that she wanted to dramatize what she considered the collapse of inner-city public education. So she went shopping for a school in need of fixing.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about prospects for banking companies in the Northeast misstated the age of Charles K. Gifford, chief executive of the BankBoston Corporation. He is 53, not 64.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The dream of peace, on some days recently, seems to be turning into a nightmare.''

title: M.T.A. Seeks Greater Power To Reject Subway and Bus Ads
description: Graffiti on subway cars is under control, and more cleaners are being hired to pick up litter on the trains. Now the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is looking to clean up public discourse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENMAN, GRACE
description: ROSENMAN - Grace. Grandma Grace, your strength and power amaze me. Your wisdom and compassion inspire me. Part of who I am today is because of your love and eternal support. You have taught me so many things that I will cherish and carry with me in every step of my journey through life. Most importantly, you have taught me to always strive for the best and experience the most wonderful things that life has to offer. I am so grateful to have been a part of your life and to have shared with you a very special bond, a bond that I possess with no other, that will keep you alive in my heart forever. Your loving granddaughter, Hilary Grace

title: At F.C.C. Confirmation Hearings, Emphasis Will Be on Competition
description: When William E. Kennard, President Clinton's nominee for the chairman's post of the Federal Communications Commission, sits down at his Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday, the biggest implicit question may not be his fitness for the job but whom he will listen to in Washington once he gets it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ELLEN
description: LAZAR-Ellen. We will miss you and you will be in our hearts forever. Bonnie, Danielle and Lara Englebardt

title: Analyzing Saints Is Simple for Ditka: 'We Didn't Do a Good Job'
description: What would Mike Ditka, the television analyst, have said about Mike Ditka, the football coach, today? Hard to say, but it is doubtful that he would have been this easy on himself and this hard on the news media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, RUTH (ROSE)
description: LERNER-Ruth (Rose), of Ruth Ladies Sportswear. Beloved wife of Saul. Devoted mother of Lili, Joseph, and son-in-law Kenneth. Adored grandmother of Elana and Leah. Services Monday, 10 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn, near Ave V. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Beth El, 314 N. Main St, Monroe, NY 10950 or to the American Cancer Society, Orange County Chapter, 450 Main St, Middletown, NY 10940.

title: Role Reversal: Now, Xerox Is Making Printers and Hewlett-Packard Is Making Copiers
description: First, there was Xerox the Copier Company. Then, there was Xerox the Document Company.

title: Abroad at Home; Why The Gloom?
description: The performance of American soldiers in Bosnia should be a reason for national pride. U.S. leadership made possible an international force, including units from NATO countries and Russia, that has kept the peace there for nearly two years. Not one American life has been lost in combat.

title: With Hits by the Number, Harlan Howard Enters Hall of Fame
description: After all these years, Harlan Howard is still a love junkie. He can't get enough. Parental love, filial love, but most of all the intense, chaotic, all-consuming, insanely happy-making kind that draws men and women together and can go bad, really bad, at any moment -- he needs it all.

title: Numbers Tell It All: 1997 Was Impressive
description: In a season marked by both the beauty of pitching well done and the brawn of pitches well hit, the most tantalizing achievement of the 1997 baseball season resulted from a home-run effort that landed just short of immortality.

title: Joel Hilton Fisher, 79, Lawyer Who Helped Find Nazi Loot
description: Joel Hilton Fisher, a Washington lawyer who helped recover gold, silver and artwork looted by the Nazis in World War II, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Baltimore. He was 79.

title: TAINTED IMPORTS -- A special report.; Imports Swamp U.S. Food-Safety Efforts
description: Since the 1980's, food imports to the United States have doubled. But Federal inspections of those imports by the Food and Drug Administration have dropped to less than half what they were five years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCWILLIAMS, LOUIS J.
description: McWILLIAMS-Louis J., 62, of Freehold Township, NJ, on September 26, 1997. Member of N.Y. Stock Exchange. Survived by his wife, Agnes, six children and eight grandchildren. For further information contact Higgins Memorial Home, Freehold, NJ, 732-462-0895.

title: Possible Misuse Is No Cause to Ban Thalidomide; Women at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: As it moves toward its centennial year, Pepsi gets the blues -- but it doesn't mind.
description: PEPSI is going blue.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: YOUTHS ARRESTED -- The officers investigating the death of a grocer in the Kips Bay section of Manhattan have arrested three teen-agers from the neighborhood. B3.

title: Fast Start by Jaguars Doesn't Faze Redskins
description: There were 12 minutes 8 seconds left before halftime, and the Jacksonville Jaguars had scored all of the game's points. Jacksonville had reached the Washington Redskins' 12-, 24- and 7-yard lines. And each time, Jacksonville had managed only field goals. Though ahead, 9-0, the Jaguars could sense they were in trouble.

title: Jaws, Claws and Cash; Show Biz Jungle of Wildlife
description: The leading natural history filmmakers from around the world came down from the trees and out of the deserts, rain forests and oceans to commune at this year's Jackson Hole Wildlife Film Festival, which was appropriately set in this watering hole amid the rugged Grand Tetons. The annual festival attracted more than 800 participants, including behind-the-camera legends of nature films like Wolfgang Bayer (''Yellowstone in Winter''), Alan Root (''Castles of Clay''), Dereck Joubert (''Lions and Hyenas'') and Hugh Miles (''Kingdom of the Ice Bear'').

title: Mayday! Mayday! We're Leaking Visuals!; A Shakeout of the Special Effects Houses
description: In Hollywood, the place where art and technology intersect with commerce, no one looks twice when a spacecraft flashes across the horizon or a ship is gored by an iceberg. In the contorted reality here, what threatens life is a dearth of spectacular events.

title: Berlin in Talks To Buy Agency
description: Andy Berlin, chairman and chief executive of Fallon McElligott Berlin in New York, is negotiating to buy the majority interest in the agency held by his partner, the Minneapolis shop Fallon McElligott.

title: NBC Keeps Door Open For Albert
description: Although he fired Marv Albert last Thursday after the sportscaster pleaded guilty to misdemeanor assault and battery charge, Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, said he would consider rehiring Albert in the future.

title: Meld of Forms, Informed by the Sea
description: Abdel R. Salaam, the founder and director of the Forces of Nature dance theater company, describes his work as a ''living book of choreography.'' Two dances on his company's 15th-anniversary program, presented by 651 an Arts Center at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night, were the vivid work of a first-rate teller of tales.

title: Flaws in Immigration Laws
description: The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is a morass of technical complexity that has yet to be fully explicated by either the law's drafters or the immigration officers who are supposed to carry it out. But it is already apparent that at least two elements need immediate correction.

title: Critic's Notebook; Juliet of the Five O'Clock Shadow, and Other Wonders
description: But, soft! What light through yonder window breaks?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, LOUIS ''BUCKY.''
description: HARRIS-Louis ''Bucky.'' Of Verona, on Sunday, September 28, 1997. Beloved husband of Lillian. Devoted father of Brian and Richard. Also survived by four grandchildren. Funeral from the BernheimApter - Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Home, 1600 Springfield Ave, Maplewood, NJ, Monday, September 29, at 2 PM. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIG, RICHARD L.
description: SWIG-Richard L. The members of the Weiler and Arnow families are saddened by the death of our associate and partner of many years. We extend our sincere sympathy and condolences to his wife, Roselyne, his children, and all of the members of the Swig and Dinner families. The Weiler and Arnow Families

title: Hundley Plans Not to Rush His Return From Surgery
description: Todd Hundley hugged teammates awkwardly yesterday at Shea Stadium after the Mets' final game of the season, any full embraces blocked by the bulky brace covering his surgically repaired right elbow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASPAN, DR. JEANNE RAFSKY
description: JASPAN-Dr. Jeanne Rafsky. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Sisterhood, Men's Club and Couples Club mourn the passing of our senior member, the granddaughter of the late Harry Fischel, the beloved wife of our former Trustee, Norman Jaspan, and the dear mother of our Trustee, Michael Jaspan, and our devoted member, Ronald Jaspan. We extend heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Funeral service Monday, 12 noon, Kehilath Jeshurun, 125 E. 85th St. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRAGER, DAVID A.
description: PRAGER-David A. A memorial service will be held at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, Tuesday, September 30th, 6PM.

title: Thousands Celebrate Completion of Talmud Study
description: To say that all the people in a sold-out Madison Square Garden were on their feet, rocking back and forth, and that the arena was utterly silent would seem contradictory.

title: Renewed Is Top Surprise At Lawrence Realization
description: Rarely has the Lawrence Realization, which was run yesterday for the 105th time, been dominated by so many long shots: Renewed, the winner in a photo finish at 39-1, with Devonwood second at 14-1 and Belgravia third at 5-1.

title: Lions Upend Packers
description: They win when they should lose and lose when they are expected to win. It is hard to get a handle on the Detroit Lions.

title: Murdoch Partner Is Said to Want Half of Dodgers
description: Rupert Murdoch's plan to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers for his Fox sports and television ventures may encounter a hurdle. John C. Malone, the chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc. and a partner of Mr. Murdoch in one of his sports ventures, reportedly plans to claim a right to buy half of the team if the sale goes through.

title: Offerings Of Equity Scheduled This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Possible Misuse Is No Cause to Ban Thalidomide; Denying People a Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Off to the Country With Their Insecurities
description: Terminal ambivalence -- a disease at least as old as ''Hamlet'' and now, one gathers, epidemic among young bourgeois Americans -- has found its perfect poster child. Her name is Val Nyquist, and she is one of five surprisingly engaging (if also overly familiar) characters in ''Plunge,'' Christopher Kyle's slender contribution to the ambivalent genre of the rueful comedy of manners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZNER, IDA
description: WEITZNER-Ida. Age 92. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Devoted mother of Gloria and Martin, and mother-in-law of Leonard. Treasured grandmother of Tina, Donna, Michael, Peter and Beverly; and great-grandmother of Joshua, Nicole, Chelsea, Jake and Lindsey. Service private.

title: This Week
description: NEWS

title: Chronicle
description: The author KEN KESEY, who was a member of the Merry Pranksters during the 1960's, was recovering in a hospital yesterday after a mild stroke he suffered last week.

title: Defying U.S., French Firm To Explore for Gas in Iran
description: In a direct challenge to the United States, a major French oil company teaming up with Russia's largest gas company and one of the largest oil companies in Malaysia has signed a $2 billion contract to explore for gas in Iran, according to Iranian and French reports today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROONEY, ISOBELL WOZNIAK
description: ROONEY-Isobell Wozniak. On Saturday, September 27, 1997, Darien, CT. Aunt of Mary Hill, Jean Tharp, Sister Stephanie O.S.U., and Dr. John M. Wilson, Jr.; six grandnieces and nephews and eight great-grandnieces and nephews. Funeral service at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, Darien, CT, Tuesday, September 30, at 11 AM. Family will receive friends at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Road, Darien, CT, at 10 AM, on Tuesday. Memorials to your favorite charity. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEENSTOCK, EDWARD
description: BEENSTOCK-Edward. Age 91. September 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Gladys. Adoring father of Barbara and J. Robert Mann, Jr., and Edward, Jr., and Vivian Beenstock. Loving grandfather of John and Lisa Mann, Anthony and Sally Mann, Margaret and Ted Berenblum, Jeffrey and Sharyn Beenstock and Steven Beenstock. Cherished great-grandfather of Joshua, Alexandra, Samantha, Arielle, Rachel, Isabelle and Julie. Special uncle of Ellin Rosenzweig. Services will be private. Donations in his memory may be made to Gladys Lampert '28 and Edward Beenstock Fund, Smith College Office of Development, 33 Elm Street, Northampton, MA 01063.

title: Showing Why Bach Is Indestructible
description: There was nothing in the program note for the concert on Saturday night at the 92d Street Y by the Greenleaf Chamber Players to explain the program's provocative title: ''The Indestructible Bach.'' But by the end of this engrossing evening, what these superb performers had been up to seemed clear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROLL, JANET SMYTH
description: CROLL-Janet Smyth. Beloved by all. The daughter of Joseph D. Croll and Helen Schroeder Breed, sister of Selina Croll and Helen Chinitz, died suddenly on September 24, in Coulterville, CA. A memorial service will be held in NY at a date to be announced.

title: Recreation at Lake Powell Hurts Thirsty West
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Monday about a dispute between The Daily Tribune of Ames, Iowa, and The Iowa State Daily misstated the location of Penn State University. It is in State College, Pa., not College Station.

title: Sports of The Times; Kings for a Day, and Maybe Even Longer
description: IN the happy moment following an impressive victory yesterday afternoon, the Jets' locker room was a melange of exuberance and restraint. The players were trying to control the fire but stoke the flame of their early-season success. The Jets are 3-2. This is the first time in nine seasons that the Jets have won more times than they have lost after five games.

title: Seven, Moving Inexorably, Are Not What They Seem
description: Formal values and a sometimes surprising emotional distance were at the heart of four dances in ''Meditations and Mandalas in Movement,'' presented by Dancycle Project on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo.

title: Jules L. Green, Television Producer, 84
description: Jules L. Green, a television producer, died on Sept. 15 at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Expecting Excellence Is Too Much for Irish
description: Before the buses returned to campus on Saturday night, the Notre Dame players already occupied an extremely uncomfortable place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSSES, FREDERICK
description: POSSES-Frederick. On September 22, 1997, in Kansas City, MO. Former resident of New York City and Amityville, LI. Son of the late Max and Minnie Posses; former husband of the late Catherine Moynahan Posses. Survived by his daughter Mary Posses of Kansas City, and by nieces, nephews and cousins. Born Brooklyn, NY, 1911. Educated at James Madison High School, the University of Alabama, and Brooklyn Law School. Served in U.S. Army during WW II. Practiced law in New York, Amityville, and London. Author of several books published in England.

title: Editorial Observer; Poland's Belated Thanks to a Patriot Spy
description: The cold war ended for Ryszard Kuklinski last week. Mr. Kuklinski was a colonel in the Polish Army who rose to become deputy chief of operations, responsible for drawing up Poland's strategic defense plans, working with top commanders of the Warsaw Pact and writing speeches for then-Defense Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski. Colonel Kuklinski was a hard-working and trusted soldier who performed his many duties well. Where he truly excelled, however, was as a spy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUMAN, SAMSON
description: BUMAN-Samson. October 25, 1943-September 25, 1997. Funeral Monday, 1 PM. For information, contact Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, Woodhaven Boulevard, 718-441-3300. Condolences to the family. United Telugu Christian Fellowship

title: U.S. Reshaping Cancer Strategy As Incidence in Children Rises
description: The rate of cancer among American children has been rising for decades. Although the reasons remain unclear, many experts suspect the increase may be partly the result of growing exposure to new chemicals in the environment.

title: People
description: * Susan Pechman was named to head a new New York office of Cone Communications, Boston, as general manager, and also becomes executive vice president of Cone Interactive. She had been senior vice president for marketing at iVillage, New York, owned by the Prodigy Inc. unit of International Wireless Inc.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Good Nature Stands Out In a Pursuit Of Ideas
description: The saxophonist Chris Potter went into Birdland on Wednesday night to celebrate the release of his new album, ''Unspoken'' Concord Jazz), and played a completely affable set. Modern jazz isn't particularly disposed to affability, and Mr. Potter's general sources -- the Blue Note sound of the middle 1960's, the Miles Davis group of the same time -- are even less disposed to lightness.

title: National News Briefs; Collision With Hayride Kills 2 and Injures 17
description: A pickup truck slammed into the back of a farm wagon hauling a church group on a hayride, killing 2 women and injuring 17 people.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz and World Music CD's; An International Swing Into Fall
description: Fall doesn't excite just pop record companies; international labels working in all sorts of music are pushing their big names to release albums -- now.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Republic Selling Security Unit To Ameritech for $610 Million
description: The Ameritech Corporation said today that it would buy the security business of Republic Industries for $610 million, giving Ameritech more residential customers and a wider reach for its fast-growing theft-protection unit.

title: White House Opens Attack On I.R.S. Oversight Proposal
description: The Clinton Administration today harshly criticized a Congressional proposal to revamp oversight of the Internal Revenue Service, saying the plan would create new problems as the agency responds to disclosures that its agents harassed taxpayers.

title: Vahakn Nigogosian, 87, Builder of Violins
description: Vahakn Nigogosian, a builder and restorer of stringed instruments who operated the Stradivarius Studios on West 57th Street for many years, died on Sept. 20 at his home in Bayside, Queens. He was 87.

title: A Lilliputian Pocket Secretary
description: JUST when you think computing devices cannot get any smaller, along comes one that proves you wrong. A stack of five credit cards is an almost perfect match for the size and heft of the Rex PC Companion, marketed by Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc. under the Rolodex brand.

title: U.S. Convenes Experts on Drugs To Grapple With Heroin Use
description: The Government brought together more than 500 drug experts from around the country today to discuss the scope of the nation's heroin problem and how to deal with it.

title: Dr. Karl F. Koopman, 77, An Authority on Bats, Is Dead
description: Dr. Karl F. Koopman, an expert on bats and a former curator at the American Museum of Natural History, died on Sept. 22 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the museum announced on Friday. He was 77.

title: For U.S., '99 Ryder Can't Come Too Soon
description: As the Europeans celebrated in an adjacent room on Sunday evening, Brad Faxon started to feel the depth of his sadness. The Ryder Cup will remain in Europe at least another two years. And the Americans could do nothing about it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MYRON L. (MIKE)
description: GREENE-Myron L. (Mike), 79, died suddenly on September 28th, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley, devoted father of James and Robert, father-in-law to Marinita and Debra, loving grandfather of Anthony, Max, Lindsay, Benjamin and Hannah, adoring sisters Gloria Kaye, Arleen Gevanthor, loving sisters-in-law Hinda and Anita, many nieces & nephews. Private graveside service Wednesday, October 1st at 11:30 AM at the Westchester Hills Cemetery, 400 Saw Mill Rd., Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. He will be deeply missed.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Fumes Sicken Students
description: At least 40 students from the Thorne Middle School were taken to the hospital yesterday morning after fumes from bleach being used to clean a teachers' lounge permeated the school and apparently sickened several students.

title: Potential Jurors Queried in Bomb Trial
description: Jury selection began today in Federal District Court here in the trial of Terry L. Nichols, charged with 11 counts of conspiracy and murder in the Oklahoma City bombing, the worst terrorist crime on American soil.

title: Luxury Hotel Planned for 55 Wall Street
description: The Cipriani restaurant family, the owner of Harry's Bar in Venice and two restaurants in Manhattan, is planning to open a luxury hotel and banquet hall beneath the marble rotunda and Ionic columns of the landmark building at 55 Wall Street in the heart of Manhattan's financial district.

title: Plan for Airborne Laser Weapon Is Attacked
description: THE plan is to build an $11 billion fleet of Boeing 747's equipped with powerful lasers. Flying above the clouds, the jets would zap enemy missiles shooting upward from launching pads a few hundreds miles away, in places like Iraq or North Korea. The lasers are supposed to do what no weapon can do now: destroy missiles before they can deploy their warheads, letting the debris fall back onto enemy territory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, AGNES B.
description: FARRELL-Agnes B., September 28, 1997. Native of Kilmore, Co. Longford, Ireland. Loving wife of the late James. Devoted mother of John and James Farrell, Joyce Gormally, William Farrell and Ann Westfield. Always remembered as a wonderful mother-in-law. Cherished grandmother of twelve and great-grandmother of 9. Reposing on Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M., at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In memory of Agnes, donations to Frances Schervier Elderly Fund, Franciscan Sisters of the Poor, 2975 Independence Avenue, Bronx, New York 10463, would be greatly appreciated.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's another son for MARIA SHRIVER and ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER. Ms. Shriver gave birth on Saturday afternoon to a nine-and-a-half-pound boy in Los Angeles, Mr. Schwarzenegger's publicity agent, Catherine Olim, said yesterday. A name has yet to be announced.

title: After 2-Year Hiatus, Soap Opera on AIDS Returns to the Subways
description: Remember Julio and Marisol? Eight years ago, they walked into the lives of millions of New York's subway riders, bringing with them a tale of passion and betrayal in the age of AIDS.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Gets Perrier Account
description: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide has been named to handle the creative portion of the worldwide Perrier sparkling water account, which had been handled for almost five years by agencies owned by Publicis S.A. in Paris. Billings were estimated at $40 million to $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, NETTIE
description: GARDNER-Nettie, of Brooklyn, NY, September 28, 1997. Devoted wife for 63 years of Dr. Hyman Gardner; beloved mother of Michael, Marjorie (Joel), and David (Debra), and grandmother of seven. Founding president of Shalom Group of Hadassah and president of Brooklyn Central Chapter of Hadassah. She was an active member of the East Midwood Jewish Center, participated in many charitable organizations, and was an accomplished artist. Her devotion to Jewish learning was exemplified by becoming a Bat Mitzvah at the age of 74. Services Tuesday, September 30, at 12 Noon, at Garlick Funeral Home, 1700 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. The family requests memorial donations be made to Hadassah.

title: House-Senate Negotiators Agree to Cost-of-Living Increase for Members of Congress
description: Brushing aside a legislative roadblock that had been erected in the Senate, a House-Senate conference committee tonight cleared the way for members of Congress to receive the first increase in their paychecks in five years.

title: Little Talk on Sexual Diseases
description: ALTHOUGH more than 12 million new cases of sexually transmitted diseases are diagnosed each year, three million of them among teen-agers alone, a recent survey of women from 18 to 44 years old found that most did not discuss such diseases in their first visits with a new gynecologist or obstetrician.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPELAND, ARNOLD I.
description: COPELAND-Arnold I. On September 28th, 1997. Beloved husband for 58 years of Muriel. Devoted father of Arthur Copeland of Stamford, Ct., Jackie Beecher of Puerto Rico & Jill Simbari of Cortlandt Manor, NY. Cherished grandfather of 11. Also survived by his sister Mildred Kirsch of New Jersey. He and his wife practiced Optometry in Port Chester for 55 years, the last 30 with their son. Service Wednesday, October 1st at 9:30AM at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: At Officer's Trial, Man Tells Of Being Slapped and Choked
description: A Bronx man who says he was slapped and choked during an arrest in 1993 by Francis X. Livoti, a police officer who was dismissed from the force last year in the wake of a similar case, described the incident in court yesterday on the first day of testimony at Mr. Livoti's trial on assault charges.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARASUK, MILTON
description: TARASUK-Milton. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member, Linda Glaser and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: U.N. Monitor Investigates American Use of the Death Penalty
description: For the first time, a United Nations monitor is visiting the United States to report on the use of the death penalty and deaths in prison or in police custody.

title: Pain of '97 May Be a Key for the Knicks in '98
description: Perhaps the Knicks have avoided the healing powers of time and have kept their wounds ripped open like an envelope.

title: Now It Can Be Told: 1992 Tell-All Book's Source Was Diana
description: The principal source disclosing details of the Princess of Wales's unhappy marriage to Prince Charles and her troubled relations with the royal family for the 1992 book ''Diana, Her True Story,'' was Diana herself, the author, Andrew Morton, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARSONS, LOUISE BIGELOW
description: PARSONS-Louise Bigelow, 90, of Crescent Surf, died on Saturday in Kennebunk. Member of the Junior League of New York City, the Colony Club in New York and the Colonial Dames of America. Widow of William Parsons. Mother to William Parsons Jr, the Rev. Dr. Llewellyn Parsons Smith and the Rev. Dr. Louise Parsons Pietsch, and 9 grandchildren also survive. Funeral is on Monday at South Congregational Church, Kennebunkport, ME. Interment in Hope Cemetery, Kennebunk. Memorials to the ASPCA, 424 East 92 Street, New York, New York 10128.

title: Penguin and Booksellers Settle an Accounting Feud
description: After months of negotiations, Penguin Books USA and a trade association for thousands of independent bookstores have struck a deal to settle a feud arising from a multimillion-dollar accounting scandal that involved unauthorized discounts to large retailers.

title: Clash of Cultures Tears Texas City
description: Everyone here agrees that Rosa Gonzales and Ester Hernandez were hired at the Allied Insurance Agency because they spoke Spanish. But the question that has set off a remarkably passionate debate here in the Texas Panhandle is this: Should they have been dismissed for the same reason?

title: Life's Lessons, From the Lab and the Lion's Den
description: Errol Morris's delightfully exotic documentary ''Fast, Cheap and Out of Control'' explores the curious thoughts of four visionaries: a topiary gardener, a lion tamer, a robot scientist and an expert in the social behavior of naked mole rats. All are interesting, but certainly the most fascinating figure here is the man behind the camera. The director of ''The Thin Blue Line'' and ''A Brief History of Time'' remains a one-of-a-kind filmmaker capable of melding science, philosophy, poetry and sheer whimsy into an elaborate meditation on mankind's mysteries. He's as good a teacher as he is a filmmaker, which is saying a lot.

title: Samuel Kaynard, 78, Labor Expert Involved In Cabbies' Dispute
description: Samuel Kaynard, a former official with the National Labor Relations Board in Brooklyn and a law professor who helped train many of New York's labor lawyers, died last Tuesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 78 and lived in Roslyn Estates, N.Y.

title: Review/Fashion; In London, a Newfound Maturity
description: There's a syndrome that affects the subjects of fawning profiles and analytical press reports: they tend to get sick of themselves.

title: Though Back In the Hunt, The Yankees Feel Ignored
description: The discussion began among a few Yankees on the charter flight from Detroit to Newark on Sunday night and filtered into the bustling and cramped clubhouse yesterday. The defending World Series champions had just completed a remarkable season with 96 victories and were a day away from the division series against the Indians. Still, some players felt like the Rodney Dangerfield Nine.

title: Indians Adjust the Mix and Have More Fun
description: Taking the temperature of the Cleveland Indians has never been a complicated thing.

title: China, Pre-Marco Polo? Publisher Puts Off Book
description: Citing doubts raised about its authenticity, the publisher Little, Brown and Company announced yesterday that it was postponing publication of a book purporting to show that a 13th-century Italian-Jewish merchant visited China four years before Marco Polo.

title: Treasuries Mostly Flat; Trading Thin
description: Treasury securities ended little changed yesterday in thin volume, as investors and traders awaited news from the Federal Reserve meeting today on monetary policy. Most expected no change.

title: CUNY to Develop A New Writing Test
description: Four months after insisting that all community college students pass a writing examination to graduate, the City University trustees said yesterday that such diagnostic tests should not be an ''exit requirement'' and voted to develop a separate test.

title: Q&A
description: The Fertile Turtle

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALM, MARIE C.
description: PALM-Marie C. On September 29, 1997, at home in Bedminster, NJ, Marie, age 49, died after a long struggle against cancer. A resident of Summit, N.J., she is survived by her loving husband Greg and daughters Jennifer and Katherine, of NYC and Summit, respectively, as well as her parents Steve and Mary Hambalek of Vestal, N.Y., her siblings Michael (and his wife Patricia) of Seoul, Korea and Fort Meade, MD, Lisa of Albany, N.Y., Steve (and his wife Kiomi) of Tokyo, Japan and Anne Hambalek Lahr of Vestal, her grandmother Lena Every of Chatham, NJ, and her many nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles and cousins. Her sister Catherine died shortly after birth. After graduating from Bryn Mawr College in 1970 with a degree in medieval history, she was a course assistant in the finance department at the Harvard Business School. Marie devoted her life to her family and friends, particularly her daughters of whom she was justifiably proud. All who knew her were enriched by her judgement, intelligence, kindness and patience. For the past decade, Marie was very active in show jumping, along with her daughter Kate, as president of Golden Song farm, and as an officer of the New Jersey Horse Show Association and the New Jersey Professional Horse Show Association. Since graduation from Bryn Mawr, she also has been lovingly devoted to its affairs. Services: Our Lady of Sorrows Church, Vestal (10 AM), October 2. A memorial service will be held at a later date in New Jersey. Donations, in lieu of flowers, may be sent to Bryn Mawr College or the cancer-related charity of your choice.

title: THE WARMING WORLD: Coping With Climate Change; If Climate Changes, Who Is Vulnerable? Panels Offer Some Local Projections
description: IF mainstream scientists are right in their forecast that the earth will warm up substantially in the decades ahead, what will happen to a place like, say, New England? Will its brilliant fall foliage fade? Its sugar maples migrate to Canada? Its ski slopes turn to slush? Its tourists vanish?

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Editorial Notebook; Man and Beast in Botswana
description: While international alarms have sounded over the slaughter of elephants and rhinos by poachers and the killing of male lions by trophy hunters, wildlife in Botswana is facing a more subtle threat. An expanding cattle industry and hundreds of miles of new veterinary cordon fences are robbing some of the last free-roaming animals in southern Africa of the range and habitat they need to survive.

title: John F. McMahon Jr., Leader of Volunteers, 87
description: John F. McMahon Jr., president of Volunteers of America from 1958 until retiring in 1979, died on Tuesday in Louisville, Ky. He was 87.

title: Foiling S.A.T. Cheaters; Tighter Security Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Messinger Twits Giuliani on Timing of School Rewards
description: In a letter to parent-teacher associations, Ruth W. Messinger asserted yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may bestow election-year rewards on public schools that she visits and suggested that parents take advantage of her mayoral candidacy by inviting her to tour their schools.

title: Homage at Last for Blues Makers ; Through a Fan's Crusade, Unmarked Graves Get Memorials
description: Memphis Minnie was renowned among the early blues musicians whose howling, rhythmic calls, piercing harmonica riffs and wailing slide guitar licks rose out of the gritty Mississippi Delta cotton fields in the 1920's and 30's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, DORIS
description: BERMAN-Doris. On September 28, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis; devoted mother of Faith Lieberman & Philip Rosner; loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services are today, at 2 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to The American Cancer Society.

title: Golota Makes Donation to Poles
description: Five days before he is scheduled to challenge Lennox Lewis for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship on Saturday in Las Vegas, Nev., Andrew Golota, twice disqualified from bouts for punching Riddick Bowe below the belt, provided a shot in the arm to his native country yesterday. Golota donated $100,000 to the victims of the floods in Poland after briefly working out in a ring before hundreds of onlookers in Times Square.

title: Sports of The Times; In the Bronx, The Season Of Survivors
description: JOE Torre assigned David Cone yesterday to open the playoffs for the Yankees against the Cleveland Indians tonight, and assigned Graeme Lloyd to the bullpen for possible relief when Cone's amazingly resilient but recently aching right shoulder simply refuses to throw another pitch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, ARNOLD
description: BAUM-Arnold. Educator, financial adviser, MBA Wharton School. Survived by wife Elaine and son Eric. Services were held Sept 28.

title: Chile's Democratic Past
description: To the Editor:

title: New Evidence Is Said to Link Mad Cow Disease to Humans
description: Scientists in Scotland say they have found the first ''compelling evidence'' that mad cow disease -- a mysterious brain ailment that has killed thousands of cattle in Britain -- has been transmitted to people who apparently contracted the disease somehow after eating beef or being exposed to cattle.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Sex Charge for Postal Worker
description: A letter carrier was arrested yesterday and accused of sexually assaulting a 12-year-old girl inside his Postal Service van while making mail deliveries in Englewood in late August, prosecutors said.

title: Special City School On S.I. Investigated Over Admissions
description: The Special Commissioner of Investigation for the New York City school system, Edward F. Stancik, is examining whether an experimental public school on Staten Island rigged its random admissions policy to favor the children of politically connected parents.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER IN DEAL FOR COMMERCIAL PRINTER
description: Wallace Computer Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the commercial printer Graphic Industries for $18.50 a share, or about $260 million. The price was below the closing stock price on Friday of Graphic Industries, and the shares fell $1.5625 yesterday, to $18.4375. Graphic Industries of Atlanta specializes in short-run and medium-run color-printing projects for corporate marketing and other customers. Wallace, of Lisle, Ill., has specialized in providing business forms. For their latest fiscal year Graphic had revenue of $437.1 million and Wallace had revenue of $906.3 million.

title: Union Strategy Results in Coup At US Airways
description: In the biggest union organizing election in private business in a decade, nearly 10,000 reservations takers, gate agents and ticket sellers at U S Airways have voted to join the Communications Workers of America, Federal labor officials announced yesterday.

title: Searchers Find a Body; Seek Match to Missing Boy
description: Search teams looking for an 11-year-old boy who vanished Saturday afternoon in Jackson Township, N.J., found a boy's body late last night, but were unable to confirm early today that it was that of the missing youth, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBACH, GAMLIEL
description: WEISBACH-Gamliel. We mourn our co-founder. Gam was a brilliant, compassionate and unselfish person. His imagination, generosity and creativity earned the respect of everyone. He was a credit to the accounting profession and he will be sorely missed by us. Weisbach & Greenfield, PC George Greenfield, President

title: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COCA-COLA COMPANY, Atlanta, said that third-quarter case sales of its beverages would rise 9 percent to 10 percent worldwide, led by stronger-than-expected growth in Europe and Latin America.

title: Seven Challengers Aim for Yankees' Crown
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: March of Glaciers Challenged as Engine Of Bird Evolution
description: FOR decades biologists have relied on a well-accepted theory to explain the appearance of a host North American animal species. As the ice ages were beginning to wind down, so the theory goes, the last rounds of glaciers came creeping into North America, their frozen fingers splitting apart species, creating geographically isolated populations that evolved into many of the species seen today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture in some copies on Sept. 23, showing President Clinton waving from a box at the Metropolitan Opera, carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was G. Paul Burnett of The New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORN, IDA H.
description: CORN-Ida H. September 28 1997, age 87. Beloved great-grandmother. Family, friends and ex-students will miss you. Donations to SloanKettering Memorial Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, STELLA JOLLES
description: REICHMAN-Stella Jolles. Died September 9 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Henry Reichman. Loving mother of the late Thomas and Steven, grandmother of Jamie. Memorial service Wednesday, October 1, Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 Street at 2PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAVIN, ALLEN
description: RAVIN-Allen. The Ford Dealers Alliance would like to express our deepest sympathy to the family of Allen Ravin. Allen had been legal counsel to the Alliance since its inception in 1969 and had worked relentlessly with dealers toward ending factory injustices beginning in 1967. His dedication to the cause was genuine, his fairness, unparalleled. He was a true advocate of dealer rights with a no-nonsense approach to the law. He did not ''suffer fools gladly.'' He was a true friend in battle, like Don Quixote, we fought the windmills. Win or lose, he never lost passion in the challenge. Allen, you were a true and loyal friend. We will miss you and we are proud to have known you. Goodbye, old friend. Ed Mullane, Ford Dealers Alliance

title: Growing Up and Happy to Do So
description: To the 30-year-old folk singer Dar Williams, every aspect of maturing is poignant, and stories about gained wisdom flow through her songs in delirious, wordy rushes of truth. Some are dredged-up memories presented quite plainly, drawing power not from poetic mystery but from Ms. Williams's pressing drive to be honest. In ''The Babysitter's Here,'' she recalls her intense admiration for a teen-age baby sitter when she was a child; it describes a momentous evening in which she saw the baby sitter performing in a high school play, in the role of a unicorn.

title: McCaughey Ross Plans to Switch to Democrats
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, whose short and turbulent career in New York politics was placed in jeopardy when Gov. George E. Pataki barred her from running for re-election with him next year, said yesterday she would bolt the Republican Party and become a Democrat.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press in Business Day on Sept. 16 about the sale by Neste, a Finnish state-owned oil and gas company, of a 50 percent stake in Borealis, which makes a key ingredient in plastics, misstated the location of one buyer, OMV. It is an oil and gas company in Austria, not Australia.

title: IRON MOUNTAIN IN DEAL FOR ARCUS GROUP
description: Iron Mountain Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Arcus Group Inc. for about $160 million, the latest in a series of acquisitions made to beef up its services for backing up and storing computer data. Iron Mountain. a Boston-based records-storage company, said it would pay $103 million in cash and about $57 million in stock and options for the closely held Arcus. The agreement brings to 19 the number of purchases Iron Mountain has initiated this year, a spokeswoman said. Iron Mountain's stock rose 25 cents, to $35.50. Arcus, based in Pleasanton, Calif., had sales of $88 million last year. Iron Mountain's 1996 revenue was $138.7 million.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC AND FRONTIER CANCEL ACQUISITION PLANS
description: Western Pacific Airlines Inc. and Frontier Airlines Inc., two low-fare carriers based in Colorado, said yesterday that they had canceled plans for Western Pacific to acquire Frontier in a stock swap, citing ''cultural differences.'' The deal had been valued at $33.6 million when announced on June 30, one day after Western Pacific moved the bulk of its operations to Frontier's home base at Denver International Airport from Colorado Springs. Western Pacific and Frontier said they would also end a code-sharing arrangement on Nov. 16; such arrangements allow passengers to book flights to cities served by the other airline.

title: Rangers Finally Make Deal for LaFontaine
description: Pat LaFontaine officially joined the Rangers last night and could play when they open the regular season against the Islanders on Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIG, RICHARD
description: SWIG-Richard. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation mourn the passing of Richard Swig of San Francisco, a champion of the Jewish community and fervent supporter of Israel, who will be greatly missed. Mr. Swig emulated the extraordinary generosity and humanitarian concerns of his family, who have been cherished friends of the federation system in New York and San Francisco for four generations. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Swig family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Doubts Shelve Book On Marco Polo Era
description: Little, Brown & Company announced that it was postponing publication of a book purporting to be a 13th-century Italian-Jewish merchant's account of visiting China four years before Marco Polo.

title: Legacy of Fear Lingers for Italians in Quakes
description: For three nights now, the residents of this tiny hillside hamlet have lain awake in their cars and pup tents, huddled together against the autumn chill, waiting to hear the earth beneath them move again.

title: Testing Giant Exceeds Roots, Drawing Business Rivals' Ire
description: The Educational Testing Service has the trappings of an affluent small college or an adjunct campus of nearby Princeton University in New Jersey. Its lush 360-acre property is dotted with low, tasteful brick buildings, tennis courts, a swimming pool, a private hotel and an impressive home where its president lives rent free. Employees are often referred to as faculty and one in five holds an advanced degree.

title: N.F.L. NOTEBOOK
description: SEATTLE

title: Spine Researchers Seek Recipe for Regeneration
description: THE ancient Egyptian doctors taught their students that if a patient with a neck injury also had a loss of feeling and movement in the arms and legs, it was due to ''breaking of the spinal cord.'' In such a case, the advice was bleak: ''This is a condition that cannot be treated.''

title: Small-Stock Funds Handily Beat Their Big Index Brothers
description: In the last few years, the surest way for an investor to get the best returns in the stock market was to buy shares of the biggest blue-chip companies or the index mutual funds that track them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORKMAN, DAVID
description: WORKMAN-David. Long time in our lives, forever in our hearts. Profound sympathy to all family. Judy and Mickey Chasanoff

title: Mr. Clinton Speaks Up for Judges
description: President Clinton has finally rallied to defend the Federal judiciary and his own record of moderate judicial nominations against a Republican campaign of fear and delay in filling dozens of court vacancies.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; 2d Bias Claim Against Store
description: A second black man alleged this week that he was abused by security personnel working at a branch of the Bloomingdale's chain, the Associated Press reported.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I made this decision after years of soul-searching. I found that I had to choose again and again between doing what I knew was right, instead of what Republican politicians expect me to do.''

title: Limiting Speech in Subways
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board, in the name of protecting New York transit riders from sexually suggestive ads, is scheduled to vote today on overly broad changes to the agency's advertising standards that could bar all sorts of legally permissible ads on buses and subway trains, including those that target the M.T.A. itself. The proposed guidelines are vague, far too sweeping and patently self-serving from a government agency that hates to be criticized.

title: With Rice Sidelined, Niners Diversify
description: The excitement in San Francisco's meeting with Carolina tonight was supposed to be the return of Kevin Greene, who led the league in sacks last year as a Panther but is now a 49er. Only that story line turned out to be about as intriguing as a sock sale on the Home Shopping Network.

title: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders; An Angry Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Gumbel to Interview McKinney on Charges
description: When Bryant Gumbel left NBC's ''Today'' show after 15 years to join CBS as the anchor of a news magazine program, he was at pains to describe exactly how he could bring something new to a highly familiar format.

title: Helping or Confusing, TV Labels Are Widening
description: Starting tomorrow, most television networks will add the labels D, L, S and V -- for suggestive dialogue, coarse language, sex and violence -- to the existing labels of TV-G, TV-PG, TV-14 and TV-MA.

title: Defects Lead to Voiding Of 24 Protesters' Cases
description: A judicial hearing officer yesterday dismissed the cases of 24 people arrested on charges of disorderly conduct stemming from a march last month to protest the reported brutalization of an immigrant in a Brooklyn police station house.

title: Threat Is Seen to Campaign-Finance Bill
description: Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, proposed amending the main bipartisan campaign-finance legislation in Congress today with a provision that Democrats immediately denounced as a ploy to kill the bill.

title: Two-Edged Sanctions Sword
description: The issue of how to use economic sanctions as a weapon of foreign policy has bedeviled and divided the Clinton Administration during the last five years. But the case facing the White House now -- whether to punish companies with Government links in France, Russia and Malaysia for their $2 billion investment in Iran -- is filled with particularly agonizing choices for the White House.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There must be something about the encouraging words of LARRY GATLIN that put his old school's football team on the road to victory.

title: Ditka Blasts 'Very Average' Brown
description: New Orleans Saints Coach Mike Ditka fired back at Giants quarterback Dave Brown today for criticism Brown leveled at him Sunday, calling Brown ''a terrible football player last year.''

title: Clinique is introducing scent in bid for share of premium market.
description: IS Happy a dopey idea for a fragrance or are critics just being grumpy?

title: Campaign Finance Fix Would Cost a Pittance
description: To the Editor:

title: Sister Wendy, Cloistered
description: Had you been unfamiliar with her name, occupation and eccentric manner of interpreting masterpieces through incidental details, the sight and sound of her would have been surreal: a buck-toothed nun in a billowing black habit chattering about the length of Jesus' loincloth in one wooden sculpture and the comfy plumpness of the mattress below St. Anne in another.

title: TENNIS
description: SWISS INDOORS

title: His Own Way, Yet Like Glenn Gould
description: Sergei Schepkin is completing his graduate studies at the New England Conservatory in Boston, in addition to teaching there and at the University of Iowa. But he has also established himself in recent years as a formidable Bach pianist through performances at Weill Recital Hall and recordings of the ''Goldberg'' Variations and the Partitas.

title: Netivot Journal; In Spirit of Atonement, an Apology to Sephardim
description: Squatting in his dark suit next to a group of boys beating bongos outside a cafe here, Ehud Barak took a drum and began laying down his own beat.

title: Worker Dies as Scaffold Collapses in Repair Job
description: A piece of scaffolding crumpled and collapsed beneath the Queensboro Bridge yesterday, killing an ironworker and leaving three others dangling 135 feet above the East River until they were rescued by firefighters and police officers using mountain-climbing gear.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A soprano's best friend? In the case of RENEE FLEMING, it's not Pasha, the Russian wolfhound who was to have appeared on stage during this season's Metropolitan Opera production of Massenet's ''Manon.''

title: Bankers Trust to Buy Stake in Nippon
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation has bought an option that allows its buy as much as $124 million of shares of Nippon Credit Bank Ltd. of Japan in three years, the companies said early today in Tokyo. The two companies also said that they would buy between $8 million to $16.5 million in each other's shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, KALB, MARILYN I.
description: HERMAN-KALB-Marilyn I. Ever the director and creator, wife of Carlton C., mother of Alissa S. Herman Levine and her husband Bob. Sister of Renee Hoffmann Lenoble and Shirley Kalb Klepel. Caring aunt and good friend. Services were held Monday, September 29, 1997, at the ''Dix Hills Chapel'' of I.J. Morris Inc. Donations to St. Charles Hospice, Port Jefferson, New York and Hadassah Mid Island Chapter.

title: By Design; And Now, Ethnic Arms
description: Ethnic influences on fashion are many and varied, in clothing and accessories. From Africa comes the latest trend: thin bangle bracelets worn in multiples, the more the better.

title: Roy Lichtenstein, Pop Master, Dies at 73
description: Roy Lichtenstein, the quintessential master of Pop painting and a major figure in American art since he began scavenging comics like ''Winnie Winkle,'' ''G.I. Combat'' and ''Secret Hearts'' (''I don't care! I'd rather sink -- than call Brad for help!''), died yesterday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Australia Prices Stake In Telecommunications
description: The Australian Government's asking price for one-third of its telecommunications company, the Telstra Corporation, will be between $12 billion and $14.2 billion (Australian), or $8.6 billion and $10.2 billion (United States), the Government said yesterday. The shares will be sold to institutions and individuals at prices between $2.80 and $3.30 (Australian) each. At least 70 percent of the 4.29 billion shares sold will go to Australian investors, with the application process to start soon.

title: Brazilian Fire and Smoke
description: The accent was on tumultuous passion, chic and murk in ''BraSil With S,'' a program of dance by three Brazilian choreographers that was presented on Sunday night at St. Mark's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, KATIE CASSIDY
description: HIGGINS-Katie Cassidy. Age 19. Dear Katie, I shall always cherish our time together and will love and miss you forever. Love, Penn Egbert

title: Sawyer Riley Wins 3 Creative Awards
description: Sawyer Riley Compton in Atlanta took top honors, winning three awards, at the Creative Excellence in Business Advertising competition sponsored by the American Business Press in New York.

title: SAUDI PRINCE BUYS STAKE IN DONNA KARAN INTERNATIONAL
description: Prince Walid bin Talal, the Saudi billionaire, has purchased a 7 percent stake in Donna Karan International Inc. for about $20 million, his office said yesterday. The shares were bought in the open market at an average price of $13.70. Donna Karan's shares closed at $16.125, up $1.50. The prince's Kingdom Holding Company bought a 10 percent stake in Saks Fifth Avenue in 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUBAS, JONATHAN
description: YUBAS-Jonathan. A good man. A good doctor. A good friend. Our love and admiration to his children Jessica, Marissa, Natalie, and especially to his wife Susan. Rebecca Mercer-White Tommy, Larry & Deborah White Sarah and Matthew Barnett

title: Executive Changes
description: ADOBE SYSTEMS INC., San Jose, Calif., named John E. Warnock and Charles M. Geschke to jointly hold the newly created title of chairman. Mr. Warnock has been Adobe's chairman and chief executive, while Mr. Geschke is the company's president. Also, David B. Pratt resigned as chief operating officer and executive vice president, effective Nov. 30. The company said it was eliminating the chief operating officer post.

title: Attica's Blood Is Obscured In Sound Bites
description: IT comes as no shock that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been harsh in attacking Ruth W. Messinger instead of using his big lead in the polls to take the high road back to City Hall. It is his nature to treat opponents, or even well-meaning critics, as enemies.

title: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders; Letting Off Steam
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: The Personal Health column last Tuesday discussed ways in which women could prevent pregnancy immediately after intercourse if they had not used birth control or if their birth control had failed.

title: Public School In Hartford Preserves Accreditation
description: Hartford Public High School, the nation's second-oldest public school, was spared today from becoming the first in Connecticut to be found so far below standards that its degrees would not be honored by colleges, the military and the National Honor Society.

title: Metro Business; Comptroller Reviews Tax Breaks and Jobs
description: In a mixed job review for the city's Economic Development Corporation, Alan G. Hevesi, the New York City Comptroller, said yesterday that most of the large companies that have received tax breaks in exchange for keeping jobs in the city have honored their commitments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, DANIEL G.
description: ROSS-Daniel G. On September 29, 1997. Beloved husband of Grace Jarcho Ross. Loving father of Ann & Michael Loeb, James & Laura Ross, Lynn & Edward Rosenfeld. Adored grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of 6. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday 7-9 PM with service Wednesday 9:45 AM. Please omit flowers.

title: Market Place; U.S. Healthcare a Harder Fit Than Aetna Thought
description: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's largest health insurers, is struggling to digest U.S. Healthcare, the health maintenance organization that it acquired more than a year ago for $8.8 billion.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Flood Project to Start
description: A quarter century after six people were killed by flash flooding of the Green Brook and its tributaries, officials announced yesterday that construction of a $284 million flood control project will finally begin next fall. A Congressional conference committee approved a water resources spending bill last week that includes $3 million for site acquisition, Federal and state permits, and replacement of wetlands. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Metro Business; New Plaza Hotel Owner
description: Great Eagle Holdings Ltd., a commercial property and hotel company in Hong Kong, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of understanding with Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia to pay about $40 million for half his interest in several hotels, including the Plaza Hotel in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, PEGGY
description: ROSENTHAL-Peggy. On September 28, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Herbert M. Rosenthal. Devoted and loving mother to son Alan. Cherished sister of John and Joanne Meyer. Loving aunt to her niece and nephews and many friends of the Young Adult Institute. Memorial services are on Wednesday, 1 P.M., at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Arts in America; In Nashville, It's Not the Same Old Song Anymore
description: Late Wednesday night, as the tourists, music business executives and the biggest stars in country music celebrated the Country Music Association awards here in renowned venues like Opryland, the Wildhorse Saloon and the Sunset Grill, Ernest Van Trease nursed a beer at Third and Lindsley's, a roomy honky-tonk on the outskirts of downtown.

title: Israel Aid as Leverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, FLORENCE
description: ROTHMAN-Florence, of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Devoted mother of William, Russell & Douglas. Motherin-law of Janet, Nina and Jackie. Dear sister of Emily Sattell and Aaron Ruvinsky. Loving grandmother of David, Jennifer, Rachel, Martin, Michael, Dana, Allison, Jason, Paul and Madalyn. Services ''Gutterman Musicant,'' Hackensack, NJ, Tuesday 10:00 AM. Contributions may be made to Northern NJ Alzheimers Foundation.

title: William M. Berger, 70, Commodities Trader
description: William M. Berger, a former vice chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange who had more than four decades of experience in commodities trading, died on Sept. 20 at St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester, Minn., while undergoing heart surgery.

title: Braves Hope Relief Is in Store
description: Once again, the Atlanta Braves will be entering the post-season with a suspect bullpen. On Monday, Braves Manager Bobby Cox named three rookie relievers to join Alan Embree, the lone left-handed reliever; the veteran submariner Brad Clontz, and the enigmatic closer Mark Wohlers in the bullpen for the division series against the Houston Astros.

title: Conviction for Child Abuse Overturned 10 Years Later
description: An appellate court has overturned the conviction of a Methodist minister who spent 10 years in prison after being found guilty of sexually abusing children at a Bronx day-care center, and prosecutors said yesterday that they would not try him again.

title: Despite Benching, Fielder Is Serene
description: The questions kept coming, and Cecil Fielder kept deflecting them. He refused to concede that he was perturbed about being benched for Game 1 of the division series, and he refused to criticize Manager Joe Torre for choosing Tim Raines as the designated hitter.

title: France Scoffs At U.S. Protest Over Iran Deal
description: Lionel Jospin, the French Prime Minister, said today that he rejoiced in a $2 billion contract signed between a leading French oil company and Iran to explore natural gas fields and rejected what he called American attempts to impose its laws on the world.

title: Campaign Finance Fix Would Cost a Pittance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, FLORA
description: ROTHENBERG-Flora. On September 28, 1997. Former Executive Director of New York Section of National Council of Jewish Women. Beloved sister of Henry E. Rothenberg. Loving aunt of Jon Rothenberg, Jane Seides, James Rothenberg and Judy Rothenberg Forman. Adored great aunt of David, Theodore, Sarah, Catherine, Erin, Laura, Daniel, Nadya and Vera.

title: Israel and Palestinians to Meet Next Week in New Talks
description: After meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Israel and the Palestinians agreed yesterday to resume committee talks that broke down more than six months ago, a modest step that Administration officials said left difficult issues of security and Jewish settlements unresolved.

title: A Test of Honor
description: Are trustworthiness and the spirit of sharing still alive in our cities? Last June, as an Eagle Scout candidate with Troop 87 in Syracuse, I began a project that suggested some answers to that question.

title: NEW REPORTS SAY MINORITIES BENEFIT IN FISCAL RECOVERY
description: Brightening economic fortunes are increasingly extending to racial and ethnic minorities and reaching farther down the economic ladder as the nation's recovery moves briskly through its sixth year, several reports released today indicate.

title: Senator Faces Friendly Fire On Changing Campaigns
description: Heading for another day in the debating chamber, Senator John McCain recalled his earlier career as a fighter pilot when he had his trusty ''IFF,'' a cockpit defensive device that he dearly wishes had a counterpart in politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOFFER, STUART
description: SOFFER-Stuart, 55. On 9/26/97. He was the Supervisor of Music for the Bedford School District in Westchester. He is survived by his mother, Marion, adored sister, Janet, and brother, Marvin. Services were held Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYNARD, SAM
description: KAYNARD-Sam. The partners, associates and staff of Proskauer Rose LLP, where Sam Kaynard was an irreplaceable member of the Labor and Employment Law Department from 1986 to 1994, extend their deepest sympathies to the family of their former colleague, who will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGAN, ROBERT
description: EGAN-Robert. Secretary treasurer of Enterprise Assoc., Steam Fitters Local 638, Saturday, September 27, 1997. Viewing on Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 PM and 7-10 PM at Dalton's Funeral Home, Hicksville Chapel, 47 Jerusalem Avenue, Hicksville, New York. Mass on Thursday, 10:30AM, at St. Ignatius Church, Interment, Pinelawn Memorial Park. Officers and members of Local 638 extend to the family of our deceased brother our deepest sympathy. John J. Torpey, President

title: Judge Says ITT Holders Must Vote on Split
description: In a decision that buoyed the Hilton Hotel Corporation's hostile $11.5 billion bid for the ITT Corporation, a Federal judge in Las Vegas, Nev., ruled yesterday that ITT directors could not split the company into three businesses without shareholder approval. The judge gave the company until Nov. 14 to hold a shareholders meeting.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Lab Manager Is Indicted
description: The manager of a Manalapan testing laboratory was indicted yesterday for allegedly billing Medicaid for $5 million worth of tests that were unnecessary or never performed, the State Attorney General's office said.

title: Albert G. Hart, 88, Monetary Policy Specialist
description: Albert Gailord Hart, a former professor of economics at Columbia University known for his research in monetary policy and economic development, died Sept. 19at his home in Sherman, Conn., at the age of 88.

title: Foiling S.A.T. Cheaters
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE METRO
description: DEATH ON BRIDGE -- One worker was killed when a piece of scaffolding crumpled and collapsed beneath the Queensboro Bridge, leaving other workers dangling 135 feet above the East River. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROACH, PETE
description: ROACH-Pete. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Pete Roach, associated with The Times from 1946, until retiring in 1983.

title: SOCCER: NOTEBOOK
description: M.L.S. PLAYOFFS

title: For 3 Inspired Yanks, Chance to Make Good
description: If there is one thing players hate -- one thing? -- it is being reminded of past failures. Especially when those failures were in the post-season and the players are in the post-season again.

title: As Nurses Take On Primary Care, Physicians Are Sounding Alarms
description: Four women opened a primary health care practice near Bloomingdale's in midtown Manhattan yesterday. But this group was different: The women are nurses, doing what doctors with a general or family practice ordinarily do.

title: Natural Gas Prices Fall 7.6% On Warm Forecast for U.S.
description: Natural gas futures fell sharply yesterday on a forecast of warm weather for the coming week.

title: Metals USA Makes Deals for 4 Companies
description: Metals USA Inc. has bought four metal-processing and distribution companies with combined annual revenue of about $250 million, increasing its sales and geographic reach. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders; Removing the Stigma
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, ISABEL
description: FITZGERALD - Isabel, 93, of Greenwich, Conn., on September 28, 1997. Wife of the late Clifford Fitzgerald. Beloved mother of Shirley Gately, Joan Schaffer, and Clifford Fitzgerald Jr. Memorial service to be held at the First Church of Round Hill, 464 Round Hill Road, on October 5, at 2 PM.

title: Digital X-Ray Systems to Replace Old Films With Electronic Images
description: THE alphabet soup of imaging technology that arrived in medicine over the last two decades (including PET scans, CAT scans, and M.R.I.'s) has, until now, left standing the venerable old X-ray film, which is still used for 70 percent of all medical images.

title: Islanders Are 0 for Preseason
description: Their regular season begins on Friday, and the Islanders could not appear less ready for their encounter with the Rangers. In six exhibitions, the Islanders (0-6) were thoroughly outplayed and scored only nine goals, by far the fewest in the National Hockey League. Tonight, in the final game of the preseason, the Islanders wasted an otherwise decent performance, losing by 4-3 to the Devils in overtime at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Iraq and Iran Tempt World Energy Industry
description: On any evening in the last three years, a visitor to Baghdad, Iraq's capital, could spot senior officials of the French oil company, Total S.A., in the lounge of the plush Al-Rasheed Hotel where they have permanent suites.

title: Hall of Fame Hails Coaches From Old School and New
description: Before Pete Carril ever fashioned the mad-scientist look from his seat on the Princeton bench, he watched Don Haskins pace the sideline nervously. ''I saw the game in a tavern,'' he said of Texas Western's monumental victory over Kentucky in the 1966 National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game. ''Nobody had any idea how big that would become then.''

title: Man Arrested in Slashing After Police Show Sketch
description: A 25-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with slashing a woman during an apparent robbery attempt in Woodlawn Cemetery two weeks ago, the police said. The man was apprehended after another woman recognized a police sketch of him and told the police that it resembled a man who had tried to rape her, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JASPAN, DR. JEANNE RASKY
description: JASPAN-Dr. Jeanne Rasky. ARIEL Institutes deeply mourns the passing of the beloved mother of Michael D. Jaspan, our devoted treasurer, longstanding member of our board of governors and a piilar of strength to our efforts in the United States and in Israel, and our board member, Ronald Jaspan. We extend our heartfelt condolences to them and to her husband Norman. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. ARIEL American Friends of Midrasha Rabbi Shear Yashuv Cohen, Chancellor Natalio S. Fridman, President Lawrence A. Kobrin, Board Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARRABEE, ELEANOR DOERMANN
description: LARRABEE-Eleanor Doermann. Architect and college trustee, died September 27 at Saint Vincent's Hospital in New York. She was 74 years old. She died of head injuries after being struck by a car on September 13th. Mrs. Larrabee began architecture practice in 1955 at the Office of Charles H. Warner, Jr., and in 1963 became Associate in the successor firm of WBTL Architects. She specialized in the design of college buildings, particularly libraries. She served as a Trustee of Barnard College from 1976 to 1986. Mrs. Larrabee is the widow of Eric Larrabee, former executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts (1970-77), who died in 1990. Eleanor Larrabee was born in New York City on October 7, 1922, and was a lifelong resident of New York City. She graduated from Radcliffe College in 1943, and received a Master of Architecture degree from Columbia University in 1949. She is survived by two brothers and three nieces. A family graveside service will be held later. Memorial donations may be sent to Barnard College.

title: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders; No Legal Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: On Sex, Death and the Self: An Old Man's Sour Grapes
description: TOWARD THE END OF TIME

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Blue Cross Goes to Court
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey will begin a legal challenge today of a Superior Court decision that designated the nonprofit health care company as a charity in March.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Old Men and Baby Boys

title: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders; Compulsive Disorder
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERBILT, HELEN C.
description: VANDERBILT-Helen C. The South Forty Corporation mourns the passing of Helen C. Vanderbilt, a founding member, director and former chairperson who, along with her late husband, William, was a tireless advocate for the disadvantaged and the guiding spirit of an organization that has helped thousands of ex-offenders lead productive lives.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ruling Helps Hilton In Its Bid for ITT

title: Welfare Catch-22
