description: When Congress was rewriting the welfare law, it expected two-parent families to have an easier time finding work than single-parent households. After all, one parent could work while the other watched the children.

title: M.T.A. to Add Bus Service to Meet Demand
description: To cope with a 17 percent surge in weekday bus passengers in the last three months, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to announce a plan today to spend $15 million that the State Legislature approved for better bus and subway service.

title: Rival Buying Burger Kings
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. is planning to sell eight Burger King outlets in France to the McDonald's Corporation, Tracy Grannum, a Grand Met spokeswoman, said today. Terms of the sale, including the price, have not been determined, she said. Earlier this year, Grand Met said that Burger King would quit operating in France. The company does not yet have a buyer for the remaining seven Burger King outlets in France, Ms. Grannum said.

title: A Key to Redskins Receivers' Success
description: They had talked countless times, but this time would be different. Michael Westbrook, a Redskins receiver, had just repeatedly punched a teammate, running back Stephen Davis, in training camp. What was the Redskins' receivers coach, Terry Robiskie, possibly going to say to reach Westbrook now?

title: Chess; Problems for the Polymath Who Plays in Many Styles
description: In this era, there is no dominant playing style. The figure who epitomizes conservative positional play is Anatoly Karpov. He contrasts with Judit Polgar, who is out and out devoted to adventurous, often risky, tactical play. They represent extremes. But most of the top grandmasters, particularly Garry Kasparov, Vladimir Kramnik and Viswanathan Anand, make it their business to win in every conceivable way. Whatever their early inclinations were, they have trained themselves to be opportunists.

title: New York Goes On Line to Aid Fight Against Child Pornography
description: Announcing a major effort to rid cyberspace of child pornography, the New York State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, announced yesterday that his office had identified more than 1,500 people around the world suspected of trafficking in illegal pornography over the Internet.

title: Pound Is Steadier as Britain Denies Change of Euro Plans
description: The pound steadied a bit yesterday from a sharp selloff on Friday after several British ministers over the weekend denied that there had been a change in the Government's policy on European monetary union.

title: Senators' Remarks on Campaign Finance Proposals
description: Following are excerpts from prepared texts of speeches in the Senate today on campaign finance proposals by Senators John McCain of Arizona, Susan Collins of Maine and John W. Warner of Virginia, all Republicans:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINER, SYLVIA
description: FINER-Sylvia. Passed away in Israel on 9/27/97. The devoted daughter of the late Jacob and Frances Arond, beloved wife of the late Rabbi Morris H. Finer, mother and mother-in-law of David and Miriam Finer, Bennett and Paula Finer, and Sharon and Yoel Ben Avraham, adoring grandmother of 11, proud great-grandmother of 4, caring sister of Lionel Arond and Rhoda Hoschander. A woman of strength, dynamism, sweetness and commitment to Israel. She will be missed by all her family and many friends.

title: A Man Can Run Away From Love and Home, But Not From Himself
description: Separation is the theme that overarches the sensitive, keenly observed and beautifully acted Argentine-Spanish film ''Martin (Hache).''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZFELD, KAREN
description: HERZFELD - Karen. Beloved mother Janine Schulz of Berlin and Seda Lasnik of Seattle. Grandmother of four and great grandmother of two. Wife of the late Walter Herzfeld. Visitation today is at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue 5:30 to 8:00 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Murray Burnett, co-author of the play that inspired the film ''Casablanca,'' misspelled the surname of the composer of the song ''As Time Goes By.'' He is Herman Hupfeld, not Hupfield.

title: Parcells Must Learn When to Walk Away
description: It may be time to tone down those daring Jets, the team that goes for it on fourth down more than anyone in the National Football League, tries fake punts and field goals and has surprised the pro football world with a 3-2 record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, DAVID
description: MARCUS-David. Died on September 28th, 1997. Beloved father of Adam David and Uncle of Carol Landsman. Services today at 10AM, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York. Graduated from the University of Kentucky and Cornell Law School and practiced law with distinction for forty-seven years. Formerly Law Secretary to Irving Lehman, Chief Judge of the State of New York and Assistant Attorney General of New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Cornell Law School or U.J.A. in his memory.

title: On My Mind; The Rotten Apples
description: Not long ago, New Yorkers used to say that the big problem with the police was just that there were some rotten apples in the barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, ROY
description: LICHTENSTEIN - Roy. Agnes Gund, founder of Studio in a School, its Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of their dear friend and Board Member, Roy Lichtenstein. Roy's generous support of Studio's programs in New York City Public Schools and his interest and caring in bringing the arts to children will be sadly missed. We extend our sympathy and condolences to his wife, Dorothy, and their families. Agnes Gund, Founder Thomas Cahill, Executive Director The Studio in a School Association

title: Herbert Einhorn, 84, Corporate Mergers Expert
description: Herbert A. Einhorn, a retired New York lawyer who specialized in corporate mergers, takeovers and proxy fights, died Sept. 19 at his home in Amherst, Mass. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGAN, JAMES R.
description: COGAN-James R., aged 69, died on September 26, 1997. Survived by his wife, Arrial, his children, Sarah E., George W. and Julia Finney, and seven grandchildren. Memorial service on Wednesday, October 1 at 4 PM at The Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and 10th Street. For those who wish, contributions to Ascension Music, 12 West 11th Street, New York, NY 10011.

title: Walter Trampler, 82, Violist With Lincoln Center Ensemble
description: Walter Trampler, a violist who was a founding member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and who performed and recorded frequently with other chamber ensembles, died on Saturday at his home in Port Joli, Nova Scotia. He was 82 and lived in Port Joli and Manhattan.

title: BANKBOSTON IS BUYING DEUTSCHE BANK ARGENTINA
description: The BankBoston Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Deutsche Bank Argentina S.A. for about $250 million. BankBoston said the deal excluded Deutsche Bank Argentina's pension funds, insurance and investment banking businesses. BankBoston said it expected to consolidate some Deutsche Bank Argentina branches with BankBoston offices. Deutsche Bank Argentina, a unit of Deutsche Bank A.G. of Germany, has assets of $2.6 billion. BankBoston has assets of $66.1 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ELLEN
description: LAZAR-Ellen. A valiant woman of great courage and beauty. Our heartfelt condolences to Larry, Jason and Jodie. Joel, Ronny, Sam and Evan Siegal

title: US Airways Order Hinging On Pilot Talks
description: With the hours ticking away, US Airways and its pilots negotiated feverishly yesterday in hope of reaching a new contract in time for the airline to meet a deadline tonight to confirm an order for as many as 400 jets from Airbus Industrie.

title: Tales of Instant Genius And the Life After Life
description: In the middle of one night in the year 2005, Gabriel, an uneducated, unsophisticated death-row prisoner, wakes up and starts madly painting van Gogh's ''Starry Night'' on his cell wall. In ''Seeing Through Walls,'' the first and best installment of ''Foto-Novelas,'' Gabriel (John Verea) becomes a genius and a Renaissance man overnight through ''augmented cognition,'' an implant in his brain. But there is one unforeseen complication.

title: Psychiatric Guide Stirs Up Debate on Disorders; Everyday Complaints
description: To the Editor:

title: The Deal Wasn't Made in Heaven; How a Planet Hollywood Transaction Lost Its Luster
description: Perched on ornate Louis XVI-style chairs, the Malaysian princess and the one-time national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan spent hours talking business at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Cashless Society Put to Test in Ontario Town
description: Jay L. Strom and his wife, Margaret, have been selling sweet corn from a stand behind their century-old farmhouse near here for 20 years. But this season, for the first time, some local residents making their way along the country roads of southwestern Ontario near Toronto paid for their corn in a brand new way. Instead of prying small bills and Canada's bulky $1 and $2 coins out of their pockets, they handed over electronic cash cards.

title: Liberty Will Not Intrude on Dodger Sale
description: The Liberty Media Corporation said yesterday that it would not interfere with the purchase of the Los Angeles Dodgers by its cable sports partner, the News Corporation's Fox Broadcasting group, by asserting a right to half ownership in the team.

title: Night of Symbolic and Mystical Themes, but Passion, Too
description: Flesh triumphed over spirit in the Distinguished Faculty Dance Concert on Saturday night at the Frederick Loewe Theater of New York University. There were symbolical and mystical themes on this program by choreographers teaching in the department of music and performing arts professions and the program in dance education of the university's School of Education. But the most compelling piece was ''Captured,'' a depiction of hotblooded passion choreographed by Nancy Turano and Niles Ford.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, S. HIRSCH
description: JACOBSON-S. Hirsch. We mourn the passing on Shabbat, September 27, of our beloved former principal and master teacher. He led our school with vision and commitment and helped to create an outstanding Conservative Jewish Day School. We extend our deepest sympathy to his devoted wife Marion, to his beloved daughters, Shira, Atara, Roni and Adina, to his sister Sylvia Antelman and his brother Shai. Burial and Shiva are taking place in Israel. May his memory be for a blessing. Solomon Schechter Day School of Essex and Union Neil B. Goldstein, President Dr. Elaine R.S. Cohen, Head

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMO, ROBERTO
description: SIMO-Roberto. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Roberto Simo, associated with The Times from 1957, until retiring in 1976.

title: INSIDE
description: Defecting to the Democrats

title: Letting Viewers Select the Works and Their Order
description: Trajal Harrell allowed his audience to exercise free will in the program of three short dances he called ''The Midday Modular Concert'' on Saturday afternoon. Every quarter-hour between noon and 2 P.M., one of the works was presented. Spectators could come and go as they pleased and see the pieces in any order.

title: Metro Business; Makeover for Utility
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company said yesterday that it would revamp its corporate structure and turn itself into a holding company called KeySpan Energy Corporation.

title: Milton R. Friedman, Real Estate Lawyer, 93
description: Milton R. Friedman, a real estate lawyer and scholar who wrote several standard works on property law, died on Sept. 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: CONDOMS IN SCHOOL SAID NOT TO AFFECT TEEN-AGE SEX RATE
description: A new study says that making condoms easily accessible to public high school students through AIDS education programs does not increase rates of sexual activity, but it does increase condom use.

title: Offering a Glimpse of a 2d Term, Giuliani Vows a War on Drugs
description: In the first glimmer of a new policy he intends to pursue if re-elected, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today promised a widespread effort to reduce drug use in New York City, outlining a three-part program that would focus on law enforcement, anti-drug education and increased treatment programs.

title: Patterns
description: A Soft Look Prevails

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKS, EVERETT
description: HICKS-Everett, age 74, of Port Washington, L.I., on September 28, 1997. Beloved father of Mark Hicks of Naples, Fla., Jeffrey Hicks of No. Brookfield, Mass., and Lindsay Reeves of Chapel Hill, N.C. Devoted grandfather of seven grandchildren. Also survived by sisters, Grace Johns and Helen Coulter and a brother, Harry Hicks. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, October 1st at 3 P.M. at the Community Reformed Church, Manhasset, NY. Interment is private. Memorial Contributions may be made in his name to: The Reformed Church in America, P.O. Box 19381, Newark, N.J. 07195-1938.

title: Observer; Big Mob in Charge Here
description: It was practically empty here in 1930, at least by today's standards. I was one of only 123,202,624 people that year. No, that didn't make me a contender, Charlie, but I was still somebody. One of only 123,202,624!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STYLES, JAMES G.
description: STYLES-James G., Chappaqua, N.Y., September 28, 1997. Son of Patricia Styles. Husband of Ann M. (nee Lacoseglio). Father of twin sons, Gordon and Connor. Brother of Michael and Roger Styles and Kathleen Nehus. Resting Beecher Funeral home, Pleasantville, where family will receive friends Wednesday 7-9 and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Burial of the Dead: Rite II, Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Saturday 11 A.M. Interment will follow in Churchyard. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Teatown Lake Reservation or the Church of St. Mary The Virgin in his name would be appreciated.

title: Democrats Get Look at Rivals To Governor
description: With all the brave talk of spring training, when every team is a contender, Democratic hopefuls for governor paraded before the New York State Democratic Committee today, in their first major chance to impress the party machinery, more than a year before the election.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Movie Clock on Friday misidentified the actors shown in a scene from ''On Approval'' (1943), which was screened on Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art. They were Roland Culver and Googie Withers, not Clive Brook and Beatrice Lillie.

title: Fight Heats Up As High Court Considers Fate Of Ellis Island
description: With the longstanding dispute between New York and New Jersey over control of Ellis Island burning hotter than ever, the Supreme Court announced today that it would hear arguments in January and decide the case itself.

title: Personal Health
description: MY friend Helen was certain that osteoporosis was one problem she would not have to worry about. She had been taking estrogen since menopause and calcium supplements for years. She quit smoking decades ago and remained unusually physically active throughout her adult life. Now in her 70's, she regularly walked for exercise, cycled to her tennis games and ice-skated daily all winter. Then one day last winter in the middle of a skating lesson, Helen found herself lying on the ice with a broken hip and arm. She had not tripped or slipped, suggesting that the fall may have resulted from her hip breaking rather than the other way around.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Statistics Indicate Prosperity
description: In another sign of renewed prosperity, the median income of New Jersey households during the past two years averaged $46,345, second only to Alaska among the 50 states and the District of Columbia, according to figures released yesterday by the United States Census Bureau.

title: William Craig, Historian, 68
description: William Craig, a historian who wrote two best-selling books about World War II, died on Sept. 22 at Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, Conn. He was 68.

title: New York May Drop Pension Manager
description: New York City has dealt a blow to W. R. Lazard & Company, a small bond firm already suffering inner turmoil. A spokesman for Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said it had frozen funds managed by Lazard for city employees and was ''seriously considering recommending the pension fund withdraw their money.''

title: The Place for the Aspiring Dot Com; Internet Industry's Most Popular Address Is Manhattan
description: The stereotyped symbol of New York City's Internet industry is an ultracool, twenty-something cyberhead with a tattoo and a skateboard, plotting the overthrow of Microsoft from a fifth-floor walk-up on East 10th Street.

title: A Planet Eases Into View: The Occultation of Saturn
description: IN the wee hours of Sept. 18, a young astronomer at the Whipple Observatory on Mount Hopkins near Tucson, Ariz., took a break from measuring the distance to the M31 galaxy. He shifted the telescope to catch sight of a passing phenomenon right here in the solar system: a lunar occultation of Saturn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROUTMAN, RONALD R.
description: TROUTMAN-Ronald R. Senior Technology Staff Member at IBM Watson Research Center, Yorktown, NY, on September 23, 1997. Leader and author in fields of CMOS Technology and Flat Panel Displays. Known for book on CMOS and more than fifty articles, held fifteen patents. Survived by wife, Gail (Ridgefield, CT.), sons, Kelby and Ramsay, mother, Dorothy, and sister, Joyce.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUBY, DR. ROBERT
description: TUBY-Dr. Robert. Daddy-Eight years have passed. Our hearts ache for you. We are lonesome and lost without you. All our love is with you forever! Joan, Evelyn and Family

title: U.S. Alerted Photo Film Makers, Not Public, About Bomb Fallout
description: Through most of the 1950's, while the Government reassured the public that there was no health threat from atmospheric nuclear tests, the Atomic Energy Commission regularly warned the Eastman Kodak Company and other film manufacturers about fallout that could damage their products, according to a review of Government literature by a private watchdog group here.

title: Huizenga's Millions Demand Even More
description: Jim Leyland elected not to have his Florida Marlins take batting practice today, the day before their first playoff experience.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KERN, JOSEPH F.
description: KERN-Joseph F. September 30, 1988. Remembered with love and thanksgiving. Mary and the Children

title: Rutgers Will Try To Stop Zereoue
description: For Rutgers, this is Z week, the handful of days it will have to set a defense for Amos Zereoue of West Virginia, the leading running back in the Big East. To his teammates, he is just plain Z.
